title: BUDGET PASSAGE IN ALBANY IS DELAYED BY DISPUTE OVER SCHOOL AID
description: Passage of the state's $41.4 billion budget was stalled today by a dispute between Assembly Democrats and Senate Republicans on the complex formulas for allocating aid to local school districts.

title: TESCO AMERICAN INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
FEDERAL JUDGE SENTENCED TO 5 YEARS FOR PERJURY
description: Federal District Judge Walter L. Nixon Jr. was sentenced to five years in prison for perjury today.

title: SUPER RITE FOODS reports earnings for 13wks to March 1
description: The Food-A-Rama group acquired Dec. 31, 1984, is included for the entire 52-week period ended March 1, 1986, compared with only two months in the prior fiscal year.

title: ORION CAPITAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After realized investment gains of $2,442,000 for the quarter and $13,557,000 for the year. c-Net income and after realized investment gains of $948,000 for the quarter and $5,098,000 for the year.

title: BANK OF NEW ENGLAND IS FINED $1.24 MILLION
description: The Bank of New England, the second-largest financial institution in the region, was fined $1.24 million today for criminal violation of Federal currency reporting laws - the stiffest fine to date for such an offense.

title: INTERAND CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
HENRY VIII PALACE DAMAGED IN BLAZE
description: A fire today destroyed part of Hampton Court, Henry VIII's palace by the Thames and one of Britain's most famous historic buildings.

title: AZZEDINE CURVES CAST SPELL
description: Azzedine Alaia showed his collection for three days this week at the end of the ready-to-wear presentations here, in a bleak converted garage in the Marais district. Enthusiastic fans hailed it as the wave of the future. He is said to glorify a woman's body with intricate seams that deliberately focus on rounding the back of the hips.

title: VATICAN LIFTING 'SILENCE' ORDER ON BRAZIL FRIAR
description: The Vatican has suspended an order of ''penitential silence'' imposed 11 months ago on a Brazilian theologian.

title: LYNCH OF METS HAS ANOTHER BAD OUTING
description: The rumors have not escaped Ed Lynch. He has read the papers and heard the speculative talk, but he still does not understand how the Mets could not find a place for him on their pitching staff this season.

title: NEVER NERVOUS PERVIS
description: And a child shall lead them - a 6-foot-9-inch freshman with braces on his teeth who will be 19 years old on Thursday.

title: JOHN CIARDI, A POET, ESSAYIST AND DANTE TRANSLATOR, DIES
description: John Anthony Ciardi, the poet and professor who was internationally acclaimed for his translation of Dante's ''Inferno,'' died Sunday at the John F. Kennedy Medical Center in Edison, N.J., after suffering a heart attack. Mr. Ciardi, who made his home in Metuchen, N.J., was 69 years old.

title: CUOMO URGES FRIEDMAN TO QUIT DEMOCRATIC POST
description: Governor Cuomo yesterday called for Stanley M. Friedman to step down as Bronx Democratic leader in the face of his indictment on bribery conspiracy, coercion and fraud charges.

title: N.B.A.'S SUIT DISMISSED
description: A Federal judge today dismissed a $25 million lawsuit filed by the National Basketball Association contesting the transfer of the Clippers in 1984 from San Diego to Los Angeles.

title: FAR NORTH HAS MILITIA OF ESKIMOS
description: If an enemy ever sweeps down to invade North America, it will have to contend with the Ikkidluak brothers and their bolt-action rifles.

title: READING THE MAIL
description: Every now and then, evidence surfaces to suggest that ordinary individuals writing sincere letters can have an effect on public policy.

title: TEXAS INTERNATIONAL CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After an extraordinary gain of $1,315,000 from the early retirement of debt for the quarter and year. c-After an extraordinary gain of $425,000 from the early retirement of debt.

title: HERRINGTON CAUTIONS OPEC ON OIL'S SLIDE
description: Energy Secretary John S. Herrington said today that Saudi Arabia and other members of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries must consider the international ''political ramifications'' of falling oil prices that have hurt domestic producers.

title: BLACKS IN SOUTH AFRICA NOW SEEK LOCAL POWER
description: After 19 months of violence that has claimed around 1,400 lives, some of South Africa's black activists say they are seeking to complement their campaign against white rule with alternatives to official control at the local level.

title: STAGE: 'ROSE COTTAGES' BY BILL BOZZONE
description: WHILE the logic is too baroque to explain here, Bill Bozzone, the author of ''Rose Cottages,'' has figured out exactly how and why those who lie about the date of Donald Duck's birthday can end up in jail. This playwright has other odd concerns on the brain as well in his new comedy at the Ensemble Studio Theater. He tells us why an expectant mother should never enter the hospital until she's told her husband the exact location of her kitchen's bottle of A-1 sauce, and why a McDonald's restaurant can be a safe place to dispose of a homicide victim. We're also firmly cautioned against marrying anyone we meet in a roller rink, especially if that marriage is scheduled for only two weeks after the initial contact.

title: INSURANCE CRISIS THREATENS L.I. SURFERS
description: For more than a generation, the familiar cry ''Surf's up!'' has sent thousands of enthusiastic surfers charging down Long Island's sandy beaches.

title: Nortek Makes Offer
description: Nortek Inc., the Providence, R.I., textile manufacturer, said today that it has offered to purchase all of the outstanding shares of the Universal-Rundle Corporation for $27 a share in cash, or an estimated total of $42.7 million.

title: DOC OPTICS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss

title: A.T.&T. Issue To Yield 8.75%
description: The American Telephone and Telegraph Company yesterday offered $300 million of 8 5/8 percent debentures due in 2026 at a price of 98.615 to yield 8 3/4 percent. The underwriters are led by Salomon Brothers Inc.

title: FOR FALL, EUROPE OFFERS A NEW SPIRIT OF REALISM
description: Behind the hoopla and the theatrics of the European fall ready-to-wear openings, it was possible to discern the beginnings of an important change in fashion. Designers in Milan, London and Paris are paying attention to the women destined to wear their clothes rather than using the presentations as vehicles to show how clever they are and how radical their designs can be.

title: Consultant Guided Icahn's T.W.A. Bid
description: Two summers ago, when Carl C. Icahn was looking to acquire an airline, he sought advice on how to penetrate what he considered an ''esoteric industry.''

title: G.M. Seen Reducing Output
description: The General Motors Corporation, plagued by stockpiles of unsold cars, has ordered another major round of production cuts by its North American assembly plants to reduce inventories, a trade paper said.

title: WHITE-COLLAR AND CORPORATE CRIMES REQUIRE CREATIVE SENTENCING
description: To the Editor:

title: TAINTED WINE IN ITALY HOSPITALIZES 5 PEOPLE
description: At least five people were hospitalized over the weekend after drinking wine containing excessive amounts of methyl alcohol, hospital officials said today.

title: STRONGER MINDS
description: The recent transaction in which the Generals in effect took over the Houston Gamblers wasn't technically a merger - the Generals didn't assume all of the Gamblers' massive debts - but rather a bizarre sort of trade, which led to another bizarre kind of circumstance.

title: REPORTS SAY DAUGHTER OF STALIN SEEKS RETURN
description: Svetlana Alliluyeva, Stalin's daughter, has met with United States Embassy officials in Moscow and, according to Soviet sources, may be trying to leave the Soviet Union once again with her daughter.

title: OPEN U.S. AID TO REBEL GROUPS IS URGED
description: The chairman of the House intelligence committee called today for an end to covert United States support for insurgents in Afghanistan and Angola.

title: WHY KEEP TESTING
description: Would the United States, the Soviet Union and the whole world be better off today if the two superpowers had agreed to stop nuclear testing 20 years or more ago, an agreement both pledged themselves to seek in the Limited Test Ban and Nuclear Nonproliferation treaties?

title: 'BLUE LEAVES' MOVING UP TO BEAUMONT
description: The revival of John Guare's 1971 play ''The House of Blue Leaves'' has turned the darkest corner of Lincoln Center into one of the brightest theatrical attractions in New York. The critical and popular success has been such that ''Blue Leaves'' will move from the 299-seat Mitzi E. Newhouse upstairs to the 1,000-seat Vivian Beaumont Theater, reopening April 29 - just in time to become eligible for Broadway's most prestigious awards, the Tonys.

title: Key Rates
description: n.a.-Not available due to observance of Good Friday* Municipal Bond Index, The Bond Buyer Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: PLANS TO BUILD 2 WASTE PLANTS UPSET MANY IN POOR SECTION OF N. CAROLINA
description: Big T's Bait and Tackle Shop is lined with soda cans, boxes of candy bars, crackers and beef jerky, artificial flies and worms, fishing rods, and a sign reading ''Stop the Nuclear Incinerator.''

title: Q&A
description: Q.

title: U.P.I. WORKERS REPORT ACCORD ON CONTRACT
description: Union workers of United Press International said today that they had reached an agreement with the proposed new management extending their contract a year, until April 1987, and guaranteeing the jobs of all staff members until then.

title: REAGAN THREATENS CURB ON GOODS FROM EUROPE
description: Intensifying trade tensions with Western Europe, President Reagan threatened today to raise barriers against as much as $1 billion of imports from the European Economic Community to retaliate for European measures that the White House says have hurt American farm exports.

title: Pulitzer Sued By 7 Relatives
description: Seven members of the Pulitzer family sued the management of the Pulitzer Publishing Company yesterday in Federal District Court in St. Louis, accusing it of fraud and violation of securities laws. A trial is scheduled for May 12.

title: FINAL CONTACT WITH THE PLANE
description: Following is a transcript of the last communication today between flight controllers in Mexico City and Mexicana Flight 940, as provided by the Ministry of Communications and Transportation: (9:01 A.M., central standard time.) Mexicana 940 to Mexico City Control Center: Mexicana 940, Mexico Center, buenos dias.

title: Lotus Cuts Price Of Jazz Software
description: The Lotus Development Corporation, trying to revive sales of its faltering Jazz program for Apple Computer Inc.'s Macintosh, said it would lower the software's list price to $395, from $595.

title: U.N. COUNCIL CONTINUES DEBATE ON LIBYAN CLASH
description: The Security Council continued debate today on the fighting last week between Libya and the United States, but adjourned without voting.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: GREAT AND DESPERATE CURES. The Rise and Decline of Psychosurgery and Other Radical Treatments for Mental Illness. By Elliot S. Valenstein. Illustrated. 338 pages. Basic Books. $19.95. IN November 1935 a surgeon in

title: THE MADNESS OF MEHMET ALI AGCA
description: ''The trial of the century'' has ended as it began nearly a year ago, with Mehmet Ali Agca shouting that he is Jesus Christ. That claim is too much for any court, and the state of mind it suggests made it finally impossible to corroborate Mr. Agca's other assertions. Was he hired by Bulgaria to shoot the Pope in 1981 and paid $1.2 million for it? Three Bulgarians and three Turks have now had to be acquitted for lack of proof that such a conspiracy existed. The equivocal Italian legal formula is comparable to the ''not proven'' allowed in Scottish law.

title: THE CAMERAS ARE COMING
description: New York, that great center of communications, is out of step when it comes to giving the public televised views of justice at work. Forty-three states have experimented with cameras in courtrooms, but New York's Senate has balked three times at bills passed by the Assembly.

title: CORRECTION
description: The Broadway column in Weekend on March 21 gave an incorrect age for Sol Frieder, who is appearing in the American Jewish Theater production of ''A Rosen by Any Other Name.'' He is 66.

title: CANADIAN SENATOR ENDS 22-DAY HUNGER STRIKE
description: Canadian Senator, Jacques Hebert, ended a hunger strike today that he began 22 days ago to protest the cancellation of a Government-funded youth program he helped found a decade ago.

title: NUREYEV AND BARYSHNIKOV TO JOIN IN A BENEFIT AT MET
description: Rudolf Nureyev, director of the Paris Opera Ballet, and Mikhail Baryshnikov, artistic director of American Ballet Theater, will both dance, along with their companies, at a special performance on July 8 at the Metropolitan Opera House.

title: FEBRUARY NEW-HOME SALES FELL
description: Sales of new homes fell an unexpected 3.8 percent in February despite the lowest mortgage interest rates of the decade. But sales are picking up, housing industry officials said, with the beginning of the spring home-buying season.

title: WASHINGTON HEIGHTS: COCAINE TRADE THRIVES
description: As night falls on Washington Heights these days, traffic chokes to a halt on many residential streets. Hundreds of cars, some with out-of-state license plates and driven by well-dressed suburbanites, stop at street corners or double-park for a few minutes. The drivers have come to buy cocaine.

title: OPEN SEASON STARTING ON PARKING SCOFFLAWS
description: ''We've got a hit,'' Alberto Rosario shouted, putting down his radio receiver and revving his tow truck down the quiet streets of the Upper East Side.

title: FOR JERSEY TENANTS, HARD LESSONS IN REAL ESTATE
description: On the New Jersey bank of the Hudson River, in West New York, where the views of Manhattan's skyline are spectacular, there is now big money to be made in real estate if landlords can just get rid of their low-income tenants.

title: THERE'S LITTLE SIGN OF FARM-BELT REVOLT THAT DEMOCRATS HOPE FOR
description: The crisis that has gripped the Farm Belt for months does not yet appear to have generated the sort of political revolt against the Reagan Administration that would help the Democrats win control of the Senate this year, according to politicians in the region.

title: SAD END CAN'T DIM LUSTER OF DAWKINS
description: The look in his eyes said that Johnny Dawkins was puzzled. Certainly, he had a right to be. He had scored 13 of the first 25 Duke points in the championship game of the national collegiate basketball tournament. He had contributed to a defensive effort that had disrupted the Louisville guards and helped create 24 tunovers.

title: ROBOT DEFENSE SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
PARTS OF CHALLENGER CABIN RETRIEVED AS WEATHER EASES
description: Navy salvage divers today hauled up more silt-covered wreckage from the space shuttle Challenger's crew cabin and planned to return to port Tuesday night to unload debris and take on fresh supplies.

title: ON THE SEVENTH DAY, HUNGER
description: DORIS S. is 86, arthritic, almost blind and poor. When she became physically and financially unable to shop and cook for herself, the City of New York began its delivery of five hot meals a week. Then Citymeals-on-Wheels added the sixth meal. Now who is to provide the seventh?

title: CONNORS ACCEPTS BAN
description: Jimmy Connors paid a $20,000 fine and began a 10-week suspension yesterday, it was announced by the Men's International Professional Tennis Council. The 33-year-old Connors will not be able to play in a sanctioned tournament until Queens Club at London, a grass-court event that begins June 9 and is a warmup tournament for Wimbledon.

title: Chess; Hastings International Won By Petursson, as Expected
description: The form chart was followed at this year's 61st Hastings International Tournament when Margeir Petursson of Iceland took first prize. Petursson was the highest rated player in the event on the International Chess Federation's computer and his 9 1/2-3 1/2 score constituted his final norm for achieving grandmaster rank.

title: MARCOS WEALTH: LONG FIGHT EXPECTED
description: The Philippine Government has now identified many Marcos family assets, but it still lacks crucial documentation on the biggest holdings and faces a long and arduous legal battle as it turns to efforts to actually recover the wealth, according to United States and Philippine officials.

title: U.S.-Turkey Talks
description: Clarence Brown, Deputy Secretary of Commerce, began talks today with Turkish officials on bilateral trade. Turkish sources said that Mr. Brown had been told of Ankara's displeasure over the recent imposition of import quotas on Turkish textile and steel exports to the United States.

title: Advertising; Stern Walters/Earle Fills Its Top Position
description: Today William Quigley Jr. becomes chairman and chief executive of Stern Walters/Earle Ludgin in Chicago, an agency he joined two years ago from Needham, Harper & Steers in that city.

title: STARRETT HOUSING CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After an extraordinary charge of $3.2 million related to costs and continuing interest to complete arbitration claims submitted to the Iran-U.S. claims tribunal, for the quarter and year. c-Net income d-After tax credits of $646,000 for the quarter and $2,447,000 for the year.

title: TRENDY MOSCOW MALL DRAWS SHOPPERS AS WINTER DEPARTS
description: With the arrival of warmer weather and the reappearance of sidewalks buried for months under ice, Muscovites have shed their fur hats and abandoned the shelter of their apartments.

title: LOUISVILLE OVERTAKES DUKE FOR N.C.A.A. TITLE
description: For nearly 33 minutes in tonight's National Collegiate Athletic Association championship game, Duke's smothering defense ground Louisville's running game almost to a standstill. But with about seven minutes left, the Cardinals, led by Pervis Ellison, their 6-foot-9-inch freshman center, switched gears and surged past Duke to a 72-69 victory.

title: NIKE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
description: b-Net loss

title: NEW SOFTWARE FOR MAKING NOTE SCRIBBLING EASIER
description: THE two most popular concepts in software today seem to be memory-resident programs and outliners. Certainly their attractiveness is understandable enough, considering that they can make personal computing a little easier for us all.

title: TRYING TO CLOSE THE DOOR ON 'OPEN DIPLOMACY'
description: As Secretary of State George P. Shultz flew home Sunday from Europe, he complained to reporters about the tendency of Washington and Moscow these days to negotiate with each other ''through press statements of one kind or another.''

title: HALLEY'S COMET
description: Halley's Comet will rise over the New York City area at 2:34 A.M. today and set at 8:43 A.M. Tomorrow it will rise at 2:28 A.M. and set at 8:15 A.M.

title: 'SCHOOLBREAK SPECIAL' EXPLORES CRISIS OF FAITH
description: SKIPPING across the delicate surfaces of religion, ''God, the Universe, and Hot Fudge Sundaes'' focuses on a crisis of faith. The ''CBS Schoolbreak Special,'' scheduled for 4 o'clock this afternoon, is trying to take young viewers through an emotionally charged thicket that includes nothing less than the issue of creationists versus evolutionists. As usual with television, the treatment carefully tries to look even-handed, finding something nice to say about everybody but the obvious frauds.

title: CONABLE TELLS ALL
description: Now that Barber B. Conable Jr. is safely out of politics and headed for the presidency of the World Bank, he is telling how one of his House campaigns was financed, in part, by 150 of the biggest corporate executives in the country without the reporters who pore over campaign financial reports ever recognizing the fact.

title: OF PUZZLES, BILLBOARDS AND TAXES
description: THIS week in history has been glorious for inventions. In 1858 Hyman Lipman of Philadelphia invented the eraser-tipped pencil. In 1889 Charles Martin Hall invented aluminum. And in 1976, two Steves, Jobs and Wozniak, invented Apple Computer Inc. In this spirit of daring innovation, several entrepreneurs have recently passed along news of their computer-related inventions. Rubic's Cube Cubed

title: MR. ASPIN SLAYS THE MONSTER
description: For years a monster has been gnawing away at America's military strength. But the grosser the monster grew, the harder it was to slay. Just when everyone despaired of ever bringing it under control, the monster has stepped into a wonderfully adroit trap prepared by Representative Les Aspin.

title: TEACHERS' AUTONOMY AT ISSUE
description: WHEN Margaret J. Lathlaen was asked to join the national Teacher in Space program 18 months ago, she almost said no because she did not want to take the time away from a job that she found challenging and rewarding, teaching gifted and talented students in an elementary school in Friendswood, Tex. But now, she says, she is not sure she wants her job back because the State Legislature has taken all the fun out of it.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article in The Home Section on March 20 about a house in Miami Beach restored by Dr. Annella Brown misstated the year of the Chicago World's Fair. It was 1933.

title: SAGE-ALLEN & CO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 1
MORE PRIVACE FOR PSYCHIATRIC RECORDS
description: To the Editor:

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''The fire is a great tragedy. This building is one of the jewels of our heritage.''

title: PIZZA INN INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 29
description: b-Net income

title: TUESDAY SPORTS
description: Baseball Mets vs. Los Angeles Dodgers, at Vero Beach, Fla., 1:30 P.M. Yankees vs. Kansas City Royals, at Fort Myers, Fla., 1:30 P.M. Basketball Knicks vs.

title: AMID CELEBRATION, FRUSTRATION FOR HALL
description: With the ball tucked safely in hand, and victory certain, all Jeff Hall wanted to do was celebrate.

title: LEADING ECONOMIST TAUGHT AT COLUMBIA
description: James Waterhouse Angell, a leading economist at Columbia University and a financial negotiator for the Government during and after World War II, died Saturday in Hyannis, Mass., after suffering a stroke. He was 87 years old and lived on Martha's Vineyard, Mass.

title: TRIBUNE/SWAB-FOX COMPANIES reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a $1.7 million writedown of oil and gas properties. The prior year net includes the operations of Swab-Fox Cos. after Oct. 1, 1984.

title: RUTH FRANC VON PHUL
description: Ruth Franc Von Phul, a crossword-puzzle composer and champion, died last Wednesday at Lenox Hill Hospital.

title: MARCOS TELLS FOLLOWERS TO KEEP FAITH
description: Ferdinand E. Marcos, in a letter and tape-recorded message addressed to the people of the Philippines, again denied accusations of corruption today and urged his followers to ''remain united so that we will see each other again.''

title: Peter Heggie Is Dead at 66; Long an Authors Guild Aide
description: Peter Heggie, who served as executive secretary of the Authors Guild for the last 30 years, died of a heart attack yesterday at his sister's home in Brewster, N.Y. He was 66 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Osceola Again Sweetens Offer
description: The Alamito Company received a second sweetened offer from Osceola Energy Inc., of $165 a share in cash, or $376 million, and postponed until Friday its special shareholders meeting to vote on its buyout agreement with the Ventana Electric Company.

title: CITY AND STATE WILL SEEK REMOVAL OF LAZAR FROM TIMES SQ. PROJECT
description: The Cuomo and Koch administrations will seek to remove a developer from the $2 billion plan to rebuild Times Square because of his indictment last week in the City Parking Violations Bureau scandal, officials said yesterday.

title: MORE ROCKETS HIT TOKYO PARLEY SITE
description: Several homemade rockets were fired today at the historic palace where leaders of the major industralized democracies are to hold their annual economic meeting in May, the police said.

title: EQUIPMENT COMPANY OF AMERICA reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes tax benefits of $66,000 for the quarter and $294,000 for the year. c-Includes tax benefits of $83,000 for the quarter and $267,000 for the year.

title: THE LINKS BETWEEN LaROUCHE AND NEW YORK CORRUPTION
description: With a third of a century of political work behind me, I am presumably one of the senior Democrats in New York. It ought then to be expected that I should have something to say about two events that just now have our local and our national party reeling.

title: LONG AN OFFICIAL AT A.F.L.-C.I.O.
description: Leo Perlis, for 25 years director of community services for the A.F.L.-C.I.O., died of a stroke Sunday at the Miami Heart Institute in Miami Beach. He was 74 years old and lived in Bay Harbor Islands, Fla.

title: Cost of Defending Troopers
description: The state has paid nearly $500,000 to defend two troopers convicted in the beating death of a drunken driver and two officers acquitted in the case, a spokesman for the Attorney General said today. The state will not to pay for appeals, unless the troopers win reversals, the spokesman said. The lawyers who represented the officers charged in the death of the driver, Joseph P. Topolosky, submitted almost $750,000 in bills, but some costs were disallowed.

title: VOLUME SHRINKS
description: The stock market ended narrowly lower yesterday in subdued post-holiday trading.

title: AN EMPTY SPACE IN THE SPACE PROGRAM
description: There is a yawning gap between the two Presidentially appointed commissions scrutinizing the United States' civil space program.

title: How to Obtain a Film On Alzheimer's Disease
description: This column has been deluged with inquiries about how to obtain the film on Alzheimer's disease ''There Were Times, Dear,'' with Shirley Jones and Len Cariou.

title: Colgate Tuition Increased
description: For the first time, tuition at Colgate University will top $10,000 next year, according to school officials. Vice President Raymond Krehel said the the tuition would rise $875 to $10,575. In addition, related costs of room, board and activities will increase, bringing the total student cost to $14,450, a rise of 8.8 percent, for the 1986-87 school year.

title: Picture That
description: You can never tell what will sell in Washington. For several years a street vendor has been working the sidewalk alongside the Treasury Building, renting a lifesize cardboard figure of President Reagan to passing tourists, who take photographs of one another standing next to it.

title: LUSKIN'S INC reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
Surgery for Raccoon
description: Morty, a raccoon that underwent cataract surgery, has been released in woods on a 500-acre farm to begin life in the wild.

title: ISRAELI TROOPS KILL PALESTINIAN AND WOUND 3 DURING PROTESTS
description: Israeli troops killed a Palestinian youth and wounded three others today while quelling several Palestinian nationalist demonstrations in the West Bank and Gaza Strip, an army spokesman said.

title: BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: Water Bond Issue From California
description: The East Bay Municipal Utility District of California tentatively offered $149.3 million of water revenue refunding bonds yesterday.

title: HARTMAX CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
description: b-Includes a charge, estimated at $3,000,000, for restructuring expenses and related costs.

title: Advertising; Cinzano Line Moves
description: The advertising for the Cinzano line, which since last September has been marketed by the Paddington Corporation, is going to be done by Berenter Greenhouse & Webster. The former agency was McNamara, Clapp & Klein. The line is made up of both vermouth and Asti-Cinzano.

title: A MOTHER'S BATTLE TO OUTLAW HAZING
description: AT least 39 American college students have died in the past seven years as a result of brutal or thoughtless hazing by fraternities. Many more have been seriously injured. And experts say that the statistics may understate the problem because many such deaths are reported as accidents, and injuries are often covered up.

title: TEACHER HELD ON SEX CHARGE
description: A 39-year-old public-school teacher was arrested yesterday and charged with sexually abusing four girls, 8 to 11 years old, in his third-grade classroom in the Bronx on several days last month.

title: MOUNTAIN TRAPPER ESCAPES IDAHO PRISON
description: A trapper who was captured and convicted in 1982 after killing two game officers is a fugitive again.

title: Veterans' Benefits Are Being Cut
description: The Veterans Administration said today that monthly checks in some veterans' education programs would be reduced as much as 13 percent beginning Tuesday as a result of cuts required under the new deficit-reducing law.

title: MORRISON INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 1
description: b-After a $255,000 loss from discontinued operations.

title: U.S. HOUSING DEPT. ORDERS EVICTIONS OF ILLEGAL ALIENS
description: The Department of Housing and Urban Development today directed local housing authorities to end all Federal housing assistance for illegal aliens and to evict them if they cannot pay unsubsidized rents.

title: SECOND PERSON IN GOTTI'S CASE IS NOW MISSING
description: A racketeering case co-defendant of John Gotti, the reputed head of the Gambino crime family, has disappeared, Federal authorities said yesterday. He was the second figure connected with the case to vanish.

title: AUDITORS QUESTION USE OF CITY U. STUDENT FEES
description: Student activity fees paid by the 180,000 students in the City University of New York system have been used for a variety of ''questionable and undocumented'' purposes by leaders of student government and other campus organizations for at least five years, student leaders and city officials say.

title: HALL, FRANK B & CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $946,000 for the quarter and $8,146,000 for the year and losses on disposal of discontinued operations of $85,000,000 for the quarter and $192,000,000 for the year. c-After income of $272,000 for the quarter and a loss of $1,158,000 for the year, both from discontinued operations and losses on the disposal of discontinued operations of $16,000,000 for the quarter and $32,000,000 for the year. The year also includes an extraordinary gain of $11,000,000.

title: GOODBYE DUPONT CIRCLE
description: The Dupont Circle Building has long been the capital's main haven for liberal nonprofit groups, a central office for organizing environmental demonstrations and anti-war rallies, planning civil rights legislation and lobbying consumer issues.

title: M.A.C. Bond Offering Sets Refunding Record
description: The Municipal Assistance Corporation is offering $884 million of new bonds in the largest tax-exempt financing ever arranged for the refunding of outstanding bonds.

title: Dusky Sparrow: Just One Left
description: Orange Band, a Dusky seaside sparrow, has become the last known member of his species, and he probably will not live much beyond this year, wildlife experts say.

title: JUSTICE DEPT. OPPOSES NORTHWEST-REPUBLIC DEAL
description: The Justice Department said today that it continued to oppose the proposed merger of Northwest Orient Airlines and Republic Airlines, asserting that the transaction would stifle competition.

title: OXFORD FIRST CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $66,000 for the quarter and $226,000 for the year. c-After losses from discontinued operations of $249,000 for the quarter and $405,000 for the year. Share earnings reflect an 8 percent stock dividend paid July 16, 1985.

title: ROBB TAKES CHARGE
description: Former Gov. Charles S. Robb of Virginia officially succeeded Representative Richard A. Gephardt of Missouri only yesterday as chairman of the Democratic Leadership Council, a group led by men and viewed as largely consisting of white conservatives who are primarily oriented to regional concerns of the South and West.

title: JUSTICES ACCEPT MINE PERMIT CASE
description: The Supreme Court agreed today to decide whether state environmental regulators may impose permit requirements on private companies mining on Federal forest land.

title: PITT PLAYER FINED
description: The University of Pittsburgh running back Craig Heyward was found guilty yesterday of harassing a 12-year-old newspaper delivery boy and was fined $348.50 by a Pittsburgh city magistrate.

title: ARTIFICIAL MOUTH BUILT
description: THE human mouth is a far more complicated organ than most people realize.

title: NARRAGANSETT CAPITAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After an extraordinary charge of $2,732,000 for the quarter and year and capital gains of $3,713,000 for the quarter and $5,405,000 for the year. c-After capital gains of $863,000 for the quarter and $1,521,000 for the year.

title: NOT WELL-ARMED
description: Jay Bilas, Duke's 6-foot-8-inch center, on his questionable future in basketball: ''I'd give my right arm to play in the N.B.A., but I don't think there's any call for one-armed players.''

title: VERNITRON CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 28
description: b-Net income and the full year results reflect the reversal of $915,000, or 14 cents a share, of deferred taxes on the undistributed earnings of the company's DISC provided in prior years.

title: Stake in Quotron
description: The FMR Corporation, a Boston-based financial services concern, and a group of its affiliates said they had raised their stake in Quotron Systems to 9.3 percent, from 7.9 percent.

title: Market Place; Theft-Detection Stock Outlook
description: THE battle for market share among companies producing theft-detection devices appears to be heating up again as new technologies proliferate.

title: TRIAL IS TOLD DRUG SUSPECT RECEIVED MILLIONS IN CASH
description: A deposition saying that a major heroin suspect received millions of dollars in cash was presented yesterday in the ''pizza connection'' trial.

title: TULSA VOTE ALMOST A FREE-FOR-ALL: 47 ON TODAY'S BALLOT FOR 6 OFFICES
description: Thanks to a local entrepreneur, T-shirts with ''I Ran for Mayor of Tulsa'' imprinted on them are appearing all over town.

title: G.E. Is Marketing $500 Million Notes
description: The General Electric Company is offering $500 million of 7 1/8 percent notes at 99.80 to yield 7.20 percent to maturity in three years through underwriters led by Salomon Brothers.

title: Fracas Over Park Tours
description: A sting operation was mounted over the weekend, not in a darkened alley or smoke-filled room, but in the sunlight of Central Park.

title: TOO MUCH FOR TURKEY
description: To the Editor:

title: ABOUT PHILADELPHIA: WATERFRONT DEVELOPMENT STARTS TO CATCH UP
description: For a couple of decades or so, Philadelphia has wanted to turn the place where William Penn first stepped ashore in 1682 into a waterfront development whose charm and atmosphere would draw and delight hometowner and out-of-towner alike.

title: BELZBERG'S BID IGNORED BY ASHLAND
description: Ashland Oil Inc. yesterday let pass a deadline for responding to the Belzberg family's offer to negotiate a purchase, indicating to the investment community that the company would not cooperate with the Belzbergs' offer to acquire the company.

title: HECK'S INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
U.S.-SOVIET COUPLES HOPE FOR REUNIONS
description: To the Editor:

title: SUPREME COURT HEARS CASE ON HOMOSEXUAL RIGHTS
description: Arguing that ''Big Brother'' should not have power to regulate ''sexual intimacies in the privacy of the home,'' a Harvard Law School professor urged the Supreme Court today to rule that the Constitution protects private homosexual and heterosexual acts between consenting adults.

title: TEKTRONIX INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 2
description: b-Includes a tax credit of $4,859,000 because of overaccrual of tax expense in the first two quarters of the year. The results for the latest year have been restated to reflect the acquisition in March 1985 of Cae Systems Inc.

title: REAGAN SAID TO SEEK LEGISLATION ALTERING LIABILITY INSURANCE RULES
description: President Reagan will seek legislation to make significant changes in liability insurance coverage, including possibly imposing limits on jury awards and attorney's fees, White House officials said today.

title: FLIGHT'S PASSENGERS AND CREW
description: Mexicana Airlines made public this list of passengers and crew members aboard Flight 940, which crashed today. Many first names were cut off by the airline's computer after a few letters.

title: PETROMINERALS CORP reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
'BIG FLOYD' JOINS THE FORCE
description: Sometime next month, agents from the Federal Bureau of Investigation working on a major labor racketeering investigation somewhere in the United States will begin receiving helpful tips from a highly trained operative known as ''Big Floyd.''

title: Advertising; People
description: * Penelope A. Queen, Jean-Claude Kaufmann and Clifford L. Freeman have been elected executive vice presidents at Dancer Fitzgerald Sample.

title: Eastern Loans
description: Eastern Airlines said it had completed an agreement with its lenders on new loan covenant levels that extend through May and put the airline in compliance with various tests required by its lenders, removing it from technical default. The airline underwent a series of tough negotations with two of its unions to get major concessions needed to satisfy the lenders that Eastern can meet its loan payments.

title: SAN FRANCISCO FACES GIANT ISSUE
description: Late last Friday, the office of the San Francisco city attorney issued an opinion that seemed to bring the players for the town's baseball team under the protective umbrella of a new right-to-privacy ordinance. Like hundreds of other major league players, a total of 20 Giants had, at management's insistence, signed individual 1986 contracts including a provision that gave the front office the right to test them at random for drug use. The new law forbids employers' demanding such tests without probable cause for suspicion of use, and the city attorney's finding was that the Giants were covered, both at home and during road trips.

title: INJURY SIDELINES COX
description: Danny Cox, the right-handed pitcher who won 18 games for the Cardinals last year, suffered a bone chip in his right ankle on a fishing trip in St. Petersburg, Fla., Sunday and could be sidelined for two months. ''I jumped off a sea wall while I was going fishing and I didn't land right,'' Cox said.

title: OPERA: MILLO AND VERRETT IN THE MET'S 'DON CARLO'
description: IT is not often that a Metropolitan Opera cast falls apart at a late hour with enormously satisfying results, but that happened with the season's first performance last night of ''Don Carlo.'' Aprile Millo, who sounds more and more like the young Verdi soprano we have been waiting for, stepped in as Elizabeth of Valois and gave the performance the firm cornerstone of vocal respectability that evenings at the Met have so frequently lacked of late. Mara Zampieri, who was to have made her debut in the role, was summarily dropped from the cast - kidney ailment being the official reason - at the dress rehearsal. Luckily, Miss Millo, scheduled to sing Elizabeth in the opera's last four performances, will now appear in all eight.

title: MOSCOW OFFERS TO HELP SOLVE PROBLEMS OF SOUTHERN AFRICA
description: Mikhail S. Gorbachev offered the Soviet Union's services today in helping to find political solutions to the conflicts of southern Africa.

title: Advertising; JanklowBender Gets Campus Sportswear
description: JanklowBender is welcoming the soft goods advertising account that it has been so anxious to land to round out a client list that already has a shoe account, some watches and a licensing program.

title: FLAKEY JAKE'S INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Results include special charges of $7.8 million in the latest quarter and $10.4 million in the latest year.

title: DID OCEAN WATERS ARRIVE IN RAIN OF ICY COMETS?
description: Scientists from the University of Iowa have proposed a startling new theory of how water accumulates on the earth and other planets.

title: Bridge; Jerseyans in Dominant Role At Spring National Tourney
description: Players from New Jersey were dominant at the end of the recent Spring Nationals in Portland, Ore.

title: THE U.N. TODAY: APRIL 1, 1986
description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY Human Rights Committee - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: City Planning to Offer Classes for 4-Year-Olds
description: New York City will begin offering preschool classes to some 4-year-olds next September, but on a much more limited scale than a city commission has recommended, Mayor Koch said yesterday.

title: Man Dies in Fall As Cable Breaks
description: A construction worker was killed yesterday at an apartment building in Co-op City in the Bronx when a cable holding a scaffold broke and he fell five stories to the street, the police said.

title: BOARD PREDICTS MEDICARE BANKRUPTCY
description: The Federal trust fund for the portion of Medicare that pays for hospitalization is in more trouble than was believed, and Congress should take ''early remedial measures'' to prevent bankruptcy in the mid-1990's, the fund's trustees said today.

title: Business and the Law; Pacifying Step In Robins Case
description: TRIAL lawyers are supposed to be contentious - but when they are working on the same side, that can be a problem. Bitter fights among lawyers representing the plaintiffs have plagued most of the mass tort class actions in recent years, from the Agent Orange case to the litigation following the Hyatt Regency skywalk collapse in Kansas City, Mo.

title: 'GENERATIONS OF VIOLENCE,' THE CYCLE OF CHILD ABUSE
description: ''GENERATIONS OF VIOLENCE'' explores, usually sensitively, what may be our greatest domestic problem: Violence, passed down from one generation to the next, spawns more violence. A child who is abused is more likely to abuse others as an adult. The cycle, self-perpetuating, spreads. The one-hour program will be seen on Channel 13 at 11 o'clock tonight.

title: KENNINGTON LTD reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-Net income

title: DRUG TESTS AND SEARCHES VIOLATE WORKER RIGHTS
description: To the Editor:

title: POLICE BREAK UP PROTEST AT WEST GERMAN A-PLANT
description: Policemen used water cannons and tear gas today against protesters at the planned site of a nuclear reprocessing plant.

title: POWER PLANT SHOWS PROMISE IN CLEANER BURNING OF COAL
description: The first full-scale commercial test of a new nonpolluting technology for generating electricity from high-sulfur coal is running so smoothly here, according to its sponsors, that they see it as the leading long-term solution to the acid rain problem.

title: FALWELL MINISTRY TO DROP ITS TOLL-FREE LINE
description: The Rev. Jerry Falwell said his ministry will drop its toll-free telephone line because it has received thousands of harassing calls.

title: SURGERY FOR TONEY
description: Andrew Toney, the guard for the 76ers, who has missed most of the season with foot problems, underwent surgery for an inflamed testicle yesterday and will miss at least the remainder of the regular season. Dr. Richard Kendall, a urologist at Temple University Hospital, said the surgery was done to loosen a twist in Toney's spermatic cord. The 76ers said that Toney's availability for the playoffs starting April 18 would be determined later.

title: Better Audit Result At Financial Corp.
description: The Financial Corporation of America said today that its auditors had given the company an unqualified opinion, in another sign that the nation's largest savings and loan company is making progress in returning to fiscal health.

title: Prices Drop For Farmers
description: The prices farmers get for raw products dropped eight-tenths of 1 percent in March, falling to 9.7 percent below the level of a year ago, the Agriculture Department said today.

title: Prices for Crude Oil Fall Below $11 a Barrel
description: Prices for crude oil plummeted below the $11-a-barrel level yesterday on the New York Mercantile Exchange, and those of petroleum products also sank sharply.

title: PENGUINS SIGN COLLEGIAN
description: The Pittsburgh Penguins, in their stretch run with the Rangers for the last playoff spot in the Patrick Division, signed Dwight Mathiasen, a free agent right wing from the University of Denver, to a multiyear contract.

title: U.S. AID PROGRAM ADDS $10 MILLION FOR HAITI
description: The United States has added $10 million to its food aid for Haiti to help meet emergency needs, it was announced today.

title: CENTURI INC reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-After net from discontinued operations of $401,797. c-Net loss after loss from discontinued operations of $2,233,155 and a charge of $1,399,044 from the retirement of convertible debt.

title: IMPERSONATIONS YANKEE DOODLE BOY
description: Foreigners are not the only people who first know America through its movies. So do millions of Americans, not simply because the camera took us around the country but because it introduced us to so many of our fellow citizens.

title: THE SHRINKING DEDUCTIBILITY VALUE OF CHILDREN
description: To the Editor:

title: THE CRAFTING OF A CATALOGUE
description: Four-year-old Steven James was tired. He was wearing two sweaters and woolen pants and standing under a hot photographer's light on a day that showed all the signs of spring. Steven was a little cranky, too. He was playing back-to-school when his thoughts were more aptly turned to summer vacation.

title: IMPERSONATIONS BAD ACTOR
description: Add Melvin Lowe to the roster of strongmen who have fallen from power in this season of democratic rebirth. Under pressure from a state Supreme Court, Mr. Lowe has resigned as chairman of the Student Senate at the City University of New York.

title: BUJONES AND BALLET THEATER: ANATOMY OF A SCHISM
description: When Fernando Bujones sweeps onto the stage at the New York State Theater tonight as a guest artist in the opening-night gala of the Joffrey Ballet's spring season, his appearance will dramatize his break with the American Ballet Theater, the company that made him a star.

title: HOUSTON EYES DAVIS
description: The University of Houston has asked Tom Davis of Stanford to succeed Guy Lewis, who has retired, as head basketball coach, but Davis was at the University of Iowa yesterday, being interviewed for the coaching position there. The Iowa coach, George Raveling, left the Hawkeyes last week to become the coach at Southern California. ''We still feel reasonably optimistic,'' Don Sanders, a member of Houston's search committee, said about Davis.

title: RANGERS ROUT DEVILS, 9-0, LEAD PENGUINS BY 3 POINTS
description: The goaltending was sharp, as usual; the offense struck in mighty thrusts, bowling over the rivals from across the river; and with all that working for them on the first night of their big week, all went smoothly for the Rangers.

title: 166 FEARED DEAD IN THE FIERY CRASH OF A MEXICAN JET OTHERS REACH LOS ANGELES
description: A Mexican airliner with 166 people aboard crashed in a remote mountainous region of central Mexico today, There were no immediate reports of survivors in the crash, which airline officials said could turn out to be one of Mexico's worst air disasters.

title: SFM CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income and after losses from discontinued operations of $2,000 for the quarter and $6,000 for the year.

title: NOTES ON FASHION
description: THE big guns of Europe are back in their holsters. But before the fashion world turns its sights on New York City, grant the little pistols of Paris and London - the renegade designers who keep fashion's royalty productively nervous on their thrones - a moment in the sun.

title: CUOMO PLAN WOULD LET 3 COUNTIES QUIT M.T.A.
description: Three counties north of New York City would be allowed to withdraw from the jurisdiction of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority under legislation submitted today by Governor Cuomo.

title: HARRY RITZ, 78, LAST BROTHER OF SLAPSTICK COMEDY TEAM
description: Harry Ritz, the youngest and last surviving member of the Ritz Brothers comedy team, died of pneumonia Saturday at his home here. He was 78 years old.

title: REDRAWING THE FINANCIAL MAP
description: Hardly a day passes now without one of the Wall Street giants opening a new office abroad, raiding top talent to beef up overseas operations or acquiring a foreign securities company.

title: NEW INDICTMENT IS EXPECTED AGAINST EX-HOSPITALS CHIEF
description: John J. McLaughlin, the former New York City hospitals chief, is expected to be indicted shortly on charges involving his city position, lawyers familiar with the investigation said last night.

title: NICARAGUAN DEPORTING STAYED
description: The Immigration and Naturalization Service today delayed the deportation of a Nicaraguan immigrant who said he would be drafted by the Sandinista Government to fight rebels backed by the Reagan Administration.

title: FORMER AIDE TO REAGAN IN TALKS WITH OFFICIAL
description: Michael K. Deaver, who left his job as deputy White House chief of staff to become a lobbyist and consultant, met recently with the budget director, James C. Miller 3d, and the two talked about the B-1 bomber, whose maker is a Deaver client, an budget office spokesman said tonight.

title: CITING CHARGES, CITY VOIDS COMPUTER PACT
description: New York City canceled two computer contracts yesterday with a company whose top officials have business ties to Stanley M. Friedman, the Bronx Democratic leader and are co-defendants with him on bribery charges.

title: INSPECTIONS OF CRUISE SHIPS BY U.S. TO END THIS MONTH
description: The Federal Government will stop its regular inspections of sanitary conditions on cruise ships April 30 in favor of a self-inspection system, the Centers for Disease Control has announced.

title: GALAPAGOS ANIMALS STILL THREATENED
description: Assaults of predators on rare native species and the spreading effects of human settlement may cause more damage to the animals and plants of the Galapagos Islands than the widely publicized fires that ravaged more than 100,000 acres on two of the islands a year ago.

title: STAFF CUTBACK IS BEGUN AT ABC NEWS
description: ABC News, anticipating corporate orders to reduce costs, began a major staff cutback yesterday, laying off producers, writers and other employees. The cutbacks, which will eliminate about 75 jobs, would affect every program produced by ABC News, network executives said.

title: McRock
description: Through a glass-brick wall, undulating blue neon tubes can be glimpsed on the ceiling. There are gray carpets on the dining platforms, turquoise and salmon tiles elsewhere and ladder-back chairs that are not bolted down.

title: Advertising; Wyse-Celanese Link
description: Wyse Advertising's New York office on July 1 will become agency for Celanese Fibers, which had been serviced by Doyle Dane Bernbach since 1973. Wyse has been doing projects for Celanese for the last year. Billings are probably around $2 million.

title: TWO VIEWS OF MARRIAGE EXPLORED: HIS AND HERS
description: EVERY marriage, researchers are discovering, is actually two marriages: his and hers. The differences suffuse even the happiest of relationships between husbands and wives.

title: AS DRAFT NEARS, KNICKS MAKE WISH LIST
description: With the Knicks headed for a second straight draft lottery, their fans are again looking to the college ranks for help. During games at the Garden, longtime courtside ticket-holders are debating whether Bernard King will be back, if Bill Cartwright will play again, and, if not, which player would best suit their needs. Unlike last season, when all the teams hoped for Patrick Ewing, this year they are focusing on what position needs help.

title: SORG PRINTING CO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
description: b-Net loss c-Includes a gain of $240,000, or 15 cents a share, from the effect of an accounting change.

title: Advertising
description: WITH marvelous appropriateness Bradley, Dimmock & Hungerford has changed its name to Bradley & Faecher.

title: RITE AID CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 1
description: b-After income from discontinued operations of $2,433,000, or 5 cents a share, for the quarter and $1,040,000, or 2 cents a share, for the year. c-After a loss of $5,377,000 from discontinued operations. Sales for the year-ago quarter and year have been restated to exclude sales from discontinued operations of Circus World toy stores and Heaven stores.

title: HMG PROPERTY INVESTORS reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After gains on the sale of real estate of about $3,959,000 for the quarter and $5,328,626 for the year. c-Net loss and after gains on the sale of real estate of $246,692 for the quarter and $242,120 for the year.

title: SOUTH KOREA POLICE CHIEF CRITICIZES THE OPPOSITION
description: In a statement that could signal a tougher stance toward demonstrators, the national police chief today criticized opposition party leaders for failing to restrain students who clashed with policemen Sunday in Kwangju.

title: Chairman Has Retired At Tiger International
description: Tiger International Inc., the financially troubled air freight and trucking company, said yesterday that Wayne M. Hoffman, a co-founder, has retired as chairman, effective immediately.

title: Chairman of Stater Bids for Its Stock
description: Stater Brothers, which operates 94 supermarkets in southern California, said it had received an offer of $20 a share from the company's chairman, Bernard R. Garrett. The offer has a total value of about $83.5 million and at least half would be in cash, the company said.

title: 3D STRONGER QUAKE NORTHERN CALIFORNIA
description: A strong earthquake, the third in northern California in three days, made skyscrapers sway, bottles crash from shelves and shook people their slumber early this morning.

title: 49 HURT IN CLASHES IN AN ULSTER TOWN
description: A Protestant protest rally that began in this rural town early today to the sound of flutes ended late this afternoon in gunfire. The police said 49 people were injured, including 13 officers.

title: 44 ARE KILLED IN CRASH OF MOZAMBIQUE PLANE
description: A Mozambican Air Force plane crashed and burst into flames on takeoff, killing 44 people, Mozambique's official press agency reported today. The dead included a founder of the rebel movement that successfully fought Portuguese colonial rule.

title: IN BATTLE OF WITS, SUBMARINES EVADE ADVANCED EFFORTS AT DETECTION
description: DRAWING from many advanced technologies, the Navy is bringing powerful new detection systems to bear on lurking Soviet submarines. But as the oceans grow noisier and Soviet submarines grow quieter, the quest is becoming harder and the hunters may actually be losing ground.

title: BONDS SURGE AS OIL PRICES FALL AGAIN
description: The bond market's rally continued at full speed yesterday as falling prices in oil futures markets helped raise prices of long-term Treasury issues by more than two points.

title: Carson Pirie Rejects Bid
description: Carson Pirie Scott & Company, Chicago's second-largest department store chain, after Marshall Field's, said it had rejected an offer valued at about $350 million from Baytree Investors Inc.

title: Trade Gap for Soviet
description: The Soviet Union ran a trade deficit of $8.3 million with Western countries last year after a surplus of $2.3 billion in 1984, Tass, the official press agency, said today. The Soviet Union's trade performance improved during the last quarter of the year, however, following a deficit of $1.46 billion for the first nine months. Total trade with non-Communist industrial countries fell to $51.9 billion, from $56.2 billion in 1984, the press agency said.

title: NUCLEAR-FUEL STRIKE OF SETTLED
description: Union workers at the only plant producing nuclear fuel for Navy submarines ended a bitter 10 1/2-month strike by overwhelmingly approving a new three-year contract that contains a no-strike clause, officials say.

title: WICHITA INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $94,000 for the quarter and $124,000 for the year. c-Net loss d-After losses from discontinued operations of $9,000 for the quarter and $48,000 for the year.

title: MUNICIPAL TURMOIL AS D.C. VOTE NEARS
description: By some measures, these may not seem the best of times for Marion S. Barry Jr., the Mayor of the District of Columbia.

title: HERSHEY OIL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Reflects a $13,400,000 writedown of oil and gas properties. c-Net income.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Chevron Corp., San Francisco, confirmed reports that it is seeking buyers for interests in exploration licenses held by its subsidiary, Gulf Oil Ireland Ltd.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: CELEBRITY READERS In what a bookstore says is an effort to ''pair important new books with celebrity readers in an effort to introduce these books dramatically to the reading public,'' Chartwell Booksellers is beginning today a six-part series called ''First Readings: A Fanfare for New Fiction.'' Today's new book is ''In Country,'' Bobbie Ann Mason's first novel, which was published last September. Miss Mason, a product of small-town Kentucky, has established herself as a writer of short stories, some of which appeared in The Atlantic and The New Yorker.

title: J.R.'S MESSAGE? AS VARIED AS KIBBUTZ AND BAZAAR
description: Israeli Arabs refused to watch it in mixed company, while kibbutzniks loved it, saying it reminded them of life in their own collective family.

title: AIRLINES DEFY BRITISH FARE BAN
description: At least three major United States carriers - Pan American World Airways, Trans World Airlines and Northwest Orient Airlines - have continued to offer discounts on flights to England even though the British Civil Aviation Authority ordered the discounts stopped last Thursday.

title: Queens Man Held As Bogus Officer
description: A man accused of posing as a police officer and convincing a Queens merchant he was collecting money for the family of a slain detective was indicted yesterday for impersonation, grand larceny and possession of stolen property.

title: Careers; A Growing Executive Wage Gap
description: WITH salaries and bonuses of top executives now exceeding $1 million more often, several questions may bother stockholders. Are top officers overpaid? What about the growing gap between high-salaried executives and middle managers? Why during a corporate takeover should top executives be awarded ''golden parachutes'' -large sums of money - while middle managers who lose their jobs receive only several weeks' salary?

title: DOCUMENTS DETAIL ISRAELI MISSILE DEAL WITH THE SHAH
description: Before the fall of the Shah in 1979, Israel was involved in a multibillion-dollar project to modify advanced, surface-to-surface missiles for sale to Iran, according to documents said to have been left in Teheran by Israeli diplomats.

title: MAHAFFEY PONDERS HIS VICTORY
description: The 13th annual Tournament Players Championship was a disaster for Larry Mize, the 27-year-old Georgian who let a four-shot lead evaporate during the final eight holes. But John Mahaffey, who won with a par 4 on the final hole, thinks Mize will learn from it.

title: FOLKS RESTAURANTS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a loss on the disposal of property and equipment of $873,857 for the quarter and year. The latest year is also after a writeoff of pre- opening costs of $548,308. c-After a writeoff of pre-opening costs of $98,476 for the quarter and year.

title: CORRECTION
description: Because of an editing error, a Washington dispatch yesterday on the reinstatement of a suit against the manufacturer of the drug Benedictin misidentified the court involved. It was the Court of Appeals of the District of Columbia, a local court, not the United States Court of Appeals.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: TUESDAY, APRIL 1, 1986
description: International

title: ARTRA GROUP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $3,476,000 for the quarter and $3,885,000 for the year. c-Net income after net from discontinued operations of $2,580,000 for the quarter and $2,998,000 for the year. The periods also included an extraordinary gain of $523,000 for the quarter and year. The 1984 results have been restated to reflect discontinued operations in 1985. The company said its latest results include its interest in R.N. Koch Inc., which was acquired in February 1985.

title: AILING HENDERSON TROUBLED BY ANKLE
description: Fifty-four weeks ago today, Rickey Henderson slid into third base in a game against Boston and sprained his left ankle. Henderson did not sprain his left ankle today because he did not play in the Yankees' game against Baltimore in Miami because of a swollen left ankle.

title: Newest Fans of the Subway
description: ''We'll never see you again if you go down to the subway.''

title: LIQUOR UNIT SALE IS SET BE WALKER
description: In a move to thwart a hostile takeover bid by the Reichmann family of Canada, Hiram Walker Resources Ltd., the big Canadian oil and liquor producer, said yesterday that it had agreed to sell its distilled spirits business to a ''major international corporation'' for $1.86 billion.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: TUESDAY, APRIL 1, 1986
description: Companies

title: Stake in Fruehauf
description: A group led by the New York investor Asher Edelman said it holds 6.1 percent of the Fruehauf Corporation. Mr. Edelman has offered to buy the remaining Fruehauf common shares for $41 a share, or a total of more than $812 million. In a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, Mr. Edelman said that if the company did not accept his offer by the end of business Tuesday, he ''intends to seek control of the company through a proxy contest.''

title: CALLON PETROLEUM CO reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-Net income The latest results of operations include a $29.4 million writedown in the company's oil and gas properties.

title: ALASKA VOLCANO ERUPTS WITH STRONGER FORCE
description: The Augustine Volcano exploded today with its biggest eruption in 10 years, spewing ash and debris in a plume eight miles high and turning day into night in the fishing village of Homer.

title: THE PRESIDENT'S RESONANCE, FOR SALE
description: At first glance the latest grumbling about Michael Deaver, lobbyist, sounds like nasty nitpicking. Sure, he was one of President Reagan's chief aides until last May, and yes, he recently went to see the head of the President's Office of Management and Budget to push the B-1 bomber, made by a client. But so what?

title: SCHOOL ON L.I.'S RTE. 110 IS NOW AN OFFICE BUILDING
description: No other part of Long Island has seen a more concentrated explosion of commercial growth than Route 110, a major north-south throughfare just inside Suffolk County near the Nassau County border.

title: AFTER AN EPIDEMIC, DAIRIES REASSESSED
description: When Sally Harris takes milk from her refrigerator, her mind sometimes wanders back to a night a year ago when her 5-year-old son, Adam, lay stricken with salmonella poisoning. ''We honestly thought he was dying, he was so lifeless,'' she said.

title: DOW PLUNGES 28.50 IN HEAVY SELLING
description: Stock prices plunged yesterday, with prices hurt by sell programs that began after Prime Computer projected a 25 percent drop in first-quarter earnings.

title: FACTORIES' ORDERS FALL
description: Orders to factories, after increasing for three consecutive months, dropped 1.4 percent in February, the Commerce Department reported today. It was the largest decline in a year and a half.

title: DANCE: DAMELIA MUJICA
description: DAMELIA MUJICA is an unusual performer, with her dark sibylline eyes, her impaling glance and her way of creating an atmosphere of quietly charged stillness on the stage. Her arms move down and her hands riffle almost abstractedly in ''Green Storm,'' a new solo choreographed and performed in silence by Miss Mujica on Saturday nights at Dance Theater Workshop's Bessie Schonberg Theater. There is a failed handstand, a slow roll and crawl through the seats and mysterious eye-blinking in the solo. The gestures and moves do not carry a great deal of weight in themselves. Instead, they suggest a world of tasks and emotional states beyond the small space on the stage where a small woman dances with a soft-edged largeness that is striking.

title: INVESTIGATION LINKS TUROFF TO MISSING TAXI MEDALLIONS
description: The former head of the agency that regulates city taxis, Jay L. Turoff, has been linked to the disappearance of medallions and records concerning the illegal licensing of taxis, state and city officials said yesterday.

title: BUILDING OUTLAYS UP
description: Construction spending rose for the third consecutive month in February, with the strongest gains concentrated in the home-building business.

title: FOOD NOTES
description: James Beard Foundation A coast-to-coast gastronomic fund-raising event is scheduled for May 5, which would have been the 83d birthday of James Beard. His death last year ended an era in American gastronomic history. The object of the effort, which will involve restaurants serving special dinners at $100 a person and cooking schools conducting lessons at $50 a person, is to raise enough money for the James Beard Foundation to take its first steps.

title: USING WINE GRAPES FOR JUICE
description: NEW YORK wine-grape growers, hurt by a worldwide surplus, cheap imports and a national decline in wine drinking, are staking part of their future on plain juice from grapes like the aurora, Delaware, Catawba and baco noir varieties that had been used almost exclusively for wine.

title: A SIMPLE IMPROVEMENT FOR PARKING VIOLATIONS
description: To the Editor:

title: City Seizes 10 Vehicles Owing $8,750 in Fines
description: In the first day of a citywide crackdown, city tow trucks yesterday seized 10 cars belonging to scofflaws who owed a total of $8,750 in parking fines, officials said.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: I THE SUPREME. By Augusto Roa Bastos. Translated by Helen Lane. 438 pages. Alfred A. Knopf. $18.95.

title: 'BLACK BOXES' RECOVERED IN MEXICAN PLANE CRASH FATAL TO 166
description: Rescue teams today recovered the cockpit voice recorder and flight data recorder from a Mexicana Airlines plane that crashed in central Mexico on Monday, killing all 166 people aboard.

title: AFTER INDICTMENT, CITY SEEKS TO CANCEL LAZAR PROJECTS IN TIMES SQUARE AND BROOKLYN
description: New York City will seek to cancel two of more than a dozen contracts, proposals or projects involving a developer indicted last week in the Parking Violations Bureau scandal, Mayor Koch said yesterday.

title: RESTORE HAGIA SOPHIA FOR THE BIMILLENNIUM
description: To the Editor:

title: EXECUTIVES
description: * Applied Materials Inc., Santa Clara, Calif., a semiconductor wafer fabrication concern, announced that Robert F. Graham would return to his post as senior vice president after a one-year leave.

title: WHICH TAX-EXEMPTS TO EXEMPT
description: Bob Packwood, the Senate Finance Committee chairman, recently achieved a remarkable distinction. He advanced a proposal that received not one vote of support, not from his fellow committee members, not even from himself.

title: PLAYERS OFFSIDE?
description: When leaders of the Indiana University Student Foundation told the school's football coach, Bill Mallory, that they wanted to use Memorial Stadium for a fund-raising rock concert April 26, he agreed to accommodate them by using another field for the final days of spring practice so Memorial could be prepared for John Cougar Mellencamp.

title: Wells Fargo Move To Pay Midland
description: Wells Fargo & Company said it had filed a registration statement with the Securities and Exchange Commission for the sale of 1.15 million new shares of common stock.

title: S.I. Man Held in Theft Of Heavy Equipment
description: A 22-year-old Staten Island man was arrested yesterday and charged with possession of five stolen dump trucks, a bulldozer, a tractor and other parts of equipment that police said were taken from construction sites in New York City and on Long Island.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''We will impose the full penalties of the law on those who blatantly or repeatedly violate safeguards necessary to protect American workers.'' - Labor Secretary Bill Brock on proposed fine against the Union Carbide Corporation. [ A1:3. ]

title: Books: Industrial Coup
description: THE JAPANESE AUTOMOBILE INDUSTRY: Technology and Management at Nissan and Toyota. By Michael A. Cusumano. 493 pages. Council on East Asian Studies, Harvard University Press. $25.

title: Key Rates
description: * Municipal Bond Index, The Bond Buyer Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: WITNESS SAYS SPYING SUSPECT REMOVED DATA
description: A former Navy radio operator testified today that she saw Jerry A. Whitworth, who is accused of spying for the Soviet Union, take messages from an office in a naval communications center and put them in his briefcase.

title: COLLINS & AIKMAN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
ENOUGH TIMIDITY TOWARD SEOUL
description: The people of South Korea are seeking a political miracle to accompany the economic miracle achieved during the past 25 years. Buoyed by the example of the Philippines, the democratic opposition has begun a campaign to collect 10 million signatures in favor of direct presidential elections. If dissident leaders could count on minimal rights of free speech and assembly, they could potentially gain power through the ballot box and effect a peaceful transfer from dictatorship to democracy.

title: OIL MARKET SAGS, THEN REBOUNDS
description: Oil prices swung wildly yesterday, plunging below $10 a barrel in the world oil market before rebounding on word that the United States would press Saudi Arabia to help stabilize the market.

title: 20,000 CHEER CHAMPIONS
description: Almost 20,000 people packed Freedom Hall tonight to welcome Louisville's national championship basketball team.

title: STAGE: FLYING KARAMAZOV BROTHERS
description: THE Flying Karamazov Brothers can juggle anything -tenpins, meat cleavers, bons mots and bad puns - and any two hours in their company is bound to be life-threatening as well as laugh-inducing. As they say, ''There is only one edge of a sickle one can catch -more than once.'' At that point, the front row of the audience cringes. Theatergoers may also cringe at some of the word-bending wisecracks, but it would be difficult not to be disarmed by this team of hirsute, mock-Russian zanies, related only in their all-out assault on collective sobriety.

title: Republican Leads the Crowd Running for Mayor of Tulsa
description: The Republican candidate for Mayor held a strong lead tonight over the leading independent candidate, a Democrat and 16 other rivals, With more than 78 percent of the 188 precincts counted, Dick Crawford, a business executive, was leading with 35,263 votes, or 48 percent.

title: Mexico Puts Growth at 3%
description: President Miguel de la Madrid said that despite the nation's economic troubles, the economy grew at a moderate rate of 3 percent last year. The Government had earlier projected a pace of 3.9 percent.

title: A FOND FAREWELL TO CAGNEY AT HIS NEIGHBORHOOD CHURCH
description: James Francis Cagney Jr., Hollywood's ''tough guy'' and one of America's favorite showmen, was eulogized at a church in his childhood neighborhood yesterday, receiving an unusual public apology by John Cardinal O'Connor on behalf of the church and a final ovation by hundreds gathered to pay their respects.

title: GETTY PETROLEUM CORP reports earnings for Year to Jan 31
description: b-Net loss The share earnings do not reflect a 4-to-3 stock split which is payable April 22. Adjusted for the split, the latest year share earnings would be $1.20.

title: FIGHTS SET FOR FORUM
description: A series of 10 boxing matches at Felt Forum, beginning with Juan LaPorte against Vinnie Costello tomorrow night, has been arranged by the new matchmaker at Madison Square Garden. Bob Goodman, who became the Garden's boxing director in January, said at a news conference yesterday that the bouts would be held on alternate Thursdays.

title: WHY PUMP UP OPEC?
description: Look who's offering aid and comfort to OPEC. John Herrington, the United States Secretary of Energy, warns Saudi Arabia that its failure to shore up oil prices will have ''political implications.'' And Vice President Bush will visit Saudi Arabia to ask it to cut production.

title: U.S. CURBS LOW-FAT CLAIMS
description: The use of low-fat claims on meat and poultry products will be limited under a policy adopted Monday by the Agriculture Department.

title: THE SPENDTHRIFT TURNS MISER AT ABC
description: Shortly after Capital Cities Communications assumed control of ABC last January, Thomas Murphy, chairman of the new company, was asked whether Roone Arledge, the free-spending president of ABC's news and sports divisions, had a future at a company publicly committed to cost control. ''Roone Arledge,'' Mr. Murphy responded, ''is one of the assets we bought when we bought ABC.''

title: METS PUT GORMAN ON WAIVERS
description: The Mets began the difficult phase of their roster cuts today when they asked for waivers on one veteran player - the pitcher Tom Gorman, who had won 10 games over the last two seasons -and traded another player from their minor-league team at Tidewater. And there were strong indications that the club may not be through making deals.

title: CBS TO SHOW GAMES IN 1987
description: CBS formally announced today that it would televise 26 hours of next year's Pan American Games here in August.

title: SOVIET STILL OPEN TO MEETING U.S.
description: Mikhail S. Gorbachev's call for a special meeting in Europe with President Reagan on nuclear arms testing does not preclude a regular meeting in Washington this year, a senior Soviet official said today.

title: SUDAN BEGINS LONG-AWAITED ELECTION
description: This vast and impoverished country today began its first multiparty elections since 1968.

title: ENTER THE APRIL FOOL
description: On the first of April, I always try to catch up with my old buddy, the April Fool, and have a little talk with him about the foolishness of the human race.

title: REAGAN IS SAID TO ACCEPT PLAN FOR JOINT CHIEFS
description: President Reagan has approved sweeping changes for the Pentagon, including strengthening the role of the Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff and creating a post to oversee the development and production of weapons, White House officials said today.

title: Helping the Disabled
description: TO THE LIVING SECTION:

title: ON TERRORISM AND TOURISM: AMERICANS ALTER TRAVEL PLANS
description: Two American tourists from Dayton, Ohio, had just gotten out of the Paris metro and were strolling up the Avenue des Champs Elysees on the evening of March 20 when a bomb, later linked to an Arab prisoner group, exploded in a shopping gallery. It killed two passers-by and injured 28 others.

title: 3 GAMES ADDRESS ABUSE OF CHILDREN
description: THREE toy companies have introduced board games that, according to their creators and manufacturers, examine child abuse and abduction from a child's point of view and try to help children avoid them.

title: MILDRED SHAGALL
description: Mildred Shagall, a manager of concert artists in the 1960's and 70's, died of lung cancer March 28 at New York University Hospital. Miss Shagall lived in Manhattan in the winter and on the island of Capri in the summer.

title: Bloomingdale's Sets Bar Codes
description: Bloomingdale's plans to become the first retailer of its type to shift its pricing system to make use of Universal Product Codes, those black-and-white bars that have become a standard sight on cans and boxes on supermarket shelves.

title: YANKEES ON SEAVER TRAIL
description: The belief was growing among Yankee personnel today that Tom Seaver would become a Yankee before opening day next Tuesday. No one knew anything for sure because George Steinbrenner was talking to the Chicago White Sox himself, but the Yankees' interest in adding Seaver to their pitching staff has grown and club personnel think a trade can be worked out.

title: THE TIMING OF THE BLOOM
description: Cherry blossoms are big business in Washington, as thousands of tourists come from around the world to witness the annual flowering of the city's trees.

title: STEROID USE GOES ON TRIAL
description: On three nights last June, Michael David Williams, a 26-year-old Navy aircraft mechanic and a devout body builder, broke into a total of six Maryland homes, from which he stole cash and jewelry, and set fire to three of them. Williams, who had a solid service record, gave a full confession upon his arrest, but when he went to trial last month his attorney offered a novel defense: that his frenzied use of anabolic steroids had raised his level of aggression to the point where he'd been unable to appreciate that his actions were criminal (Scouting, March 19).

title: ASHLAND TO BUY OUT BELZBERGS
description: Ashland Oil Inc. said yesterday that it had agreed to pay the Belzberg family of Canada $51 a share for its 9.2 percent stake in Ashland, ending a brief skirmish for control of the nation's largest independent oil refiner.

title: DEFENSIVE MOVE TURNS TIDE
description: While Monday night's national championship game may have lacked the drama of Villanova's upset of Georgetown last year, Louisville's victory over Duke was a classic exhibition of two high-powered, evenly matched teams playing with sustained intensity.

title: WEDNESDAY SPORTS
description: Baseball Mets vs. Minnesota Twins, at St. Petersburg, Fla., 7:35 P.M. (Radio - WHN 1050, 7:30 P.M.) Yankees vs. Chicago White Sox, at Fort Lauderdale, Fla., 1:05 P.M. (Television - Channel 11, 1 P.M. Radio - WABC 770, 1 P.M.) Basketball Knicks vs. 76ers, at Philadelphia, 7:30 P.M. Final chance this season for the Knicks to win a game against the 76ers.

title: Alamito Rejects Bid by Ventana
description: In a major setback for the Ventana Electric Company, the Alamito Company ended its merger agreement with Ventana because it has found an offer from Osceola Energy Inc. more favorable to shareholders.

title: DELAY SET IN BIDS FOR WALKER
description: Hiram Walker Resources Ltd., the big Canadian oil and liquor producer, won a two-week breather yesterday in its battle to fight off an unwanted takeover bid by the Reichmann family of Canada.

title: Benefit Revue at Players
description: Len Cariou, Paul Sorvino and the comedy duo Penn and Teller will appear in the benefit revue ''Beginnings'' on April 7 at 7 P.M. at the Players, 16 Gramercy Park South.

title: A CONTINENTAL DIVIDE
