description: Charles W. Freeman Jr., a top State Department expert on Asia, is about to switch continents.

title: Officer Upheld in Shooting
description: The dismissal of a manslaughter indictment against a New York City police officer who shot and killed a 66-year-old Bronx woman during an eviction attempt was affirmed yesterday by the Appellate Division of State Supreme Court. The officer, Stephen Sullivan, fired two shotgun blasts at the woman, Eleanor Bumpurs, on Oct. 29, 1984. Officers said she had slashed at them with a knife when they came to evict her from her apartment in a housing project at 1551 University Avenue.

title: DOME MINES LTD reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-Includes a $4,929,000 extraordinary gain reflecting Dome Mines' share of Dome Petroleum Ltd.'s recovery of income tax. c-Net loss

title: CHINA'S ACROBATS DAZZLE RINGLING CIRCUS CROWDS
description: It was 4:51 P.M. on a spring afternoon in 4684, the Year of the Tiger, and the 15 members of the Shanghai Acrobatic Troupe were struggling mightily to maintain their balance. They weren't performing, but simply trying to keep their seats on a wildly lurching B train that was hurtling them downtown for their first visit to Chinatown.

title: UNION CARBIDE FACES FINE OF $1.4 MILLION ON SAFETY VIOLATIONS
description: WASHINGTON, April 1 -

title: U.S. AWAITS SERIOUS SOVIET ARMS RESPONSES
description: To the Editor:

title: PROJECT DAEDALUS
description: Not content with its flight next month of a re-created flying prehistoric reptile, the Smithsonian Institution's Air and Space Museum plans to get involved in the development of a human-powered aircraft that is to be flown from the island of Crete to Greece, a distance of 60 miles.

title: TOP DANCER OF HIS GENERATION
description: Erik Bruhn, the leading danseur noble of his generation and one of the finest ballet dancers of the 20th century, died yesterday in Toronto's General Hospital. He was 57 years old, and had been diagnosed as having lung cancer two weeks ago.

title: DUKE WON, TOO
description: During timeouts in the Final Four, a bad odor from nearby Austin drifted through this showcase of college sports. Loans and free legal counsel for as many as 33 University of Texas football players arrested for driving while intoxicated or cited for traffic violations had reportedly been supplied through an assistant athletic director who once had been the Longhorns' recruiting coordinator.

title: 60-MINUTE GOURMET
description: I AM often asked to describe the nature of the wine I use in cooking. I usually answer with a simple guideline: The wine should be compatible with the food being served, much like the wine you will be drinking with the meal. The general rule about like-with-like is as good a guide when cooking as it is when dining. A hearty dish would call for a full-bodied wine, while a light, herbaceous dish would call for a dry, crisp wine and a sweet dish would work well with a sweet wine.

title: Computerland Promotes Executive to President
description: The Computerland Corporation said yesterday that Kenneth R. Waters, the company's executive vice president, had been named president and chief operating officer. Until yesterday, Edward E. Faber, 53, the company's chairman and chief executive officer, also held the title of president.

title: SCREEN: 'LAS MADRES' OF ARGENTINA
description: ''LAS MADRES'' draws power from the pain and the determination of the mothers of the Plaza de Mayo, that remarkable group of women who drove the enormity of political repression in Argentina into the world's consciousness in the 1970's. Every Thursday they would appear at the big plaza in Buenos Aires, near the Presidential Palace, wearing white kerchiefs imprinted with the names of missing sons or daughters. ''They took them alive!'' the mothers cried, their numbers growing until they became a moral force that the military juntas could not destroy. ''We want them back!''

title: A ROUX BROTHERS RESTAURANT GOES WEST
description: ALBERT ROUX, one of the world's leading French chefs, spent the last month in this small jewel-like city celebrating the formal albeit tardy opening of his first American gastronomic venture - Michael's Waterside Inn, begun two years ago by his first American protege, Michael Hutchings.

title: JAPAN EXPRESS: SPEEDING BULLET ISN'T FAST ENOUGH
description: For two decades Japanese have taken pride in their famous ''bullet train,'' which gets them from Tokyo to Nagoya, 210 miles away, in less time than the IRT sometimes takes to cover the length of Manhattan.

title: IMPEACHMENT OF JUDGES: A 'CUMBERSOME TOOL'   Special to The New York Times
description: Federal District Judge Harry E. Claiborne of Las Vegas was convicted two years ago of failing to report nearly $100,000 in income on his tax returns. This week the chief Federal judge for Mississippi's Southern District, Walter L. Nixon Jr., was sentenced to five years in prison for lying to a grand jury.

title: U.S. RETURNS EX-POLICE CHIEF TO MEXICO FOR TRIAL
description: After a long fight against extradition from the United States, a former Mexico City police chief was handed over to Mexican officials tonight to face charges of extortion and illegal arms possession, United States Embassy officials said.

title: DANCE: PAUL TAYLOR OFFERS A PREMIERE
description: IT isn't your everyday choreographer who will unabashedly turn to self-parody but Paul Taylor plunges straight into such waters in his zany and newest work, ''Ab Ovo Usque ad Mala.''

title: ISLANDERS FALL TO FLYERS
description: The Islanders did not make an impressive entrance against the Flyers tonight at the Spectrum, and their slow start cost them the game.

title: SIGNS OF PROGRESS SNIFF
description: Those glad they've lived long enough to witness the birth of the toothpaste pump and spray-on hair coloring have a new reason to hope for continued health. Someday they may be able to hail the first contraceptive activated by a deep breath.

title: FLYERS AN OBSTACLE FOR RANGER HOPES
description: Maybe the Rangers are shuddering behind closed doors, but publicly they are showing a brave face. The specter of the Philadelphia Flyers, they say, does not intimidate them.

title: PUNJAB STATE GETS TOUGH NEW GOVERNOR
description: Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi today named a man known for being tough on crime as the new Governor for Punjab State, where more than 100 people have been killed in the last month in religious strife.

title: PENGUINS FAIL, TRAIL BY 3
description: Larry Murphy, a defenseman, scored one goal and had two assists tonight to lead the Washington Capitals to a 5-3 victory over the Pittsburgh Penguins.

title: SOUTH AFRICA BLACK, 19, GUILTY OF SHOPPING CENTER BOMBING
description: A 19-year-old black man was convicted today of carrying out a bombing in December that killed five whites at a shopping center.

title: Peugeot Picks HCM for U.S.
description: Peugeot of America, the marketing arm of the French auto manufacturer, has selected the HCM agency for its $15 million United States advertising.

title: STATE PANEL SEES RISE IN SALE OF TAINTED GASOLINE
description: Sales of contaminated and mislabeled gasoline have become increasingly common in New York State, according to a gubernatorial commission. The panel urged the creation of a state testing and enforcement unit to end such abuses.

title: FOR STOCKMAN, THE PEN MAY PROVE LESS MIGHTY
description: When David A. Stockman left his job as director of the Office of Management and Budget last summer, Harper & Row offered him $2.4 million to write a book about his experiences in the Reagan Administration. It is one of the largest sums a publisher has ever paid for a single book.

title: OPERA: MILLO AND VERRETT IN THE MET'S 'DON CARLO'
description: IT is not often that a Metropolitan Opera cast falls apart at a late hour with enormously satisfying results, but that happened with the season's first performance Monday night of ''Don Carlo.'' Aprile Millo, who sounds more and more like the young Verdi soprano we have been waiting for, stepped in as Elizabeth of Valois and gave the performance the firm cornerstone of vocal respectability that evenings at the Met have so frequently lacked of late. Mara Zampieri, who was to have made her debut in the role, was summarily dropped from the cast - kidney ailment being the official reason - at the dress rehearsal. Luckily, Miss Millo, scheduled to sing Elizabeth in the opera's last four performances, will now appear in all eight.

title: ELSINORE CORP reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-Includes a $10,455,000 provision for operating losses and Chapter 11 administrative costs for the Atlantis Casino Hotel. c-Net income and includes a gain of $7.5 million on the early extinguishment of debt.

title: PRISON RAMPAGE REPORTED
description: Convicts at Kirkland Correctional Institution went on a rampage tonight after overpowering a guard and opening cell doors, corrections officials said. The officials said that the inmates set fire to several buildings that burned out of control for more than four hours before firefighters could get in, but that no serious injuries were reported.

title: HILLENBRAND INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to March 1
Cook for Retired Executive Dies in an Apparent Suicide
description: A 23-year-old woman, employed as a cook in the home of Charles B. Wrightsman, the retired oil executive, at 820 Fifth Avenue was killed in a plunge from the roof of the 12-story apartment building early yesterday morning, the police reported.

title: 61 ARRESTED AT BERKLEY IN PROTEST OF APARTHEID
description: The police arrested 61 anti-apartheid protesters at the University of California today and removed a symbolic shantytown built in front of the chancellor's office.

title: EXODUS OF INDIANS FROM NICARAGUA FEARED AS FIGHTING IS REPORTED
description: International relief officials based here say they fear that large numbers of Miskito Indian refugees may be preparing to cross the border into Honduras because of renewed fighting inside Nicaragua.

title: MILITARY FINDS HIGHER AIDS ANITBODY RATE IN OLDER RECRUITS
description: In screening military recruits for an antibody associated with the disease AIDS, the Pentagon has found that older recruits are more likely to be affected and that a tiny percentage of women are testing positive.

title: BIG BEAR INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 1
description: b-After a gain of $605,000 on the sale of land for the quarter and 6 months.

title: A KEY MANES HAD THE NIGHT HE DIED IS FOR SAFE-DEPOSIT BOX, BUT WHERE?
description: Donald R. Manes was carrying the key to a safe-deposit box in his pocket the night he killed himself, but investigators have not yet been able to find the box that the key will open, law-enforcement officials said yesterday.

title: ACCORD REACHED IN PHILIPPINE STRIKE
description: Leaders of a wage strike at the American naval base near here reached a tentative agreement Tuesday with United States officials, but some of the picketers blocking the main entrance to the base still refused today to accept the settlement.

title: SOUTH KOREA PUTS LIMITS ON PROTEST
description: Authorities announced new restrictions on anti-Government rallies today after a huge rally in Kwangju on Sunday.

title: SMALL I.B.M. MODEL IS EXPECTED TODAY
description: The International Business Machines Corporation is expected today to announce its first lap-top computer, the only sector of the personal computer business in which it has no offerings, according to industry sources.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: WEDNESDAY, APRIL 2, 1986
description: International

title: KNICKS OUT OF PLAYOFFS
description: The Knicks' playoff hopes, which zoomed last May when they won the draft lottery and the right to pick Patrick Ewing, ended in despair last night when they were mathematically eliminated from contention. And it was their bitter rivals, the Nets, who made it official with a second-half surge that enabled them to score a 111-93 victory at Madison Square Garden.

title: JAPANESE STEP UP SECURITY FOR SUMMIT MEETING IN MAY
description: The police stepped up patrols and manned roadblocks today in a dramatic increase in security after a rash of rocket attacks by radicals who have vowed to disrupt the May economic conference of industrialized nations.

title: A REGAN ENGAGEMENT
description: Later in the week, next Wednesday, a big turnout of Administratio officials is expected at another dinner, this one honoring the White House chief of staff, Donald T. Regan, who will be given the distinguished service medal of the Center for the Study of the Presidency.

title: CONGRESS SAID TO DELAY CITIES' SEWAGE MONEY
description: Because of Congressional inaction, many cities are running out of money to build plants to treat waste water, which they are required to do by law, says a group that represents officals who run programs to clean up polluted water.

title: Avon Shifts Accounts To Ayer
description: N. W. AYER, the nation's oldest ad agency, celebrated its 117th anniversary yesterday with a nice increase in billings, thanks to a consolidation move by its client Avon.

title: HEALTH FAIRS MOVE INTO MAINSTREAM
description: A LINE was forming at the ion shower Friday on the first day of the New York Whole Life Expo. It wound between an exhibit for Kirlian photography, where an expert offered to photograph the aura that surrounds every human being, and an exhibit for ozonetics, where a saleswoman sold machines that produce ''energized oxygen,'' also known as ozone.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: WEDNESDAY, APRIL 2, 1986
description: International Vice President Bush plans to tell the Saudis, when he visits the Middle East this week, that action to stabilize oil prices is needed. America's national security is affected, he said, by the oil price slump. Voicing a similar theme, Energy Secretary Herrington spoke of ''depression'' in American oilfields. The price collapse is generally attributed to the Saudi decision to vastly expand output. While the decline helps the overall economy, a long drop would severely harm the U.S. energy industry, analysts contend. [ Page A1. ] Prices fell below $10 a barrel, the lowest since the mid-1970's, before rebounding on word of Mr. Bush's message for Saudi Arabia. [ D1. ] The Administration said it would curtail the duty-free access of developing countries to the U.S. market. Particularly affected are economically advanced developing countries, such as Taiwan, South Korea and Hong Kong. The domestic industry has put pressure on the Administration to act. [ D2. ] Markets Stock prices plunged, pulled down by sell programs that began after Prime Computer projected a 25 percent drop in first-quarter earnings. The Dow Jones industrial average fell 28.50 points, to 1,790.11. Transportation issues were hit especially hard. The market was beset by arbitrage selling, which set off some sell programs and retail profit taking. Volume grew to 167.4 million shares. [ D1. ] Lower interest rates gave the Dow Jones industrial average its best quarterly gain in percentage terms in more than a decade. [ D1. ] Treasury bonds were mixed in erratic trading.

title: IN DAIRY STATE, A WAY OF LIFE ENDS FOR MANY
description: Warm spring breezes, creaking timbers and restless cows formed a soothing ensemble before dawn today as John Carr milked and fed his 24 Holsteins.

title: CAUGHT SHORT
description: Mychal Thompson explains why he and the rest of the Trail Blazers miss Portland's injured center, Sam Bowie: ''He's our Manute. Without him, we're minute.''

title: BOLIVIA DISMISSES TEACHERS IN STRIKE OVER A PAY DISPUTE
description: The Government said today that it had dismissed at least 38,000 striking schoolteachers who refused to accept a minimum monthly wage equivalent to $25.

title: A CASEY ENGAGEMENT
description: William J. Casey, the Director of Central Intelligence, does not make very many speeches, so the American Israel Public Affairs Committee was pleased when it landed him as its main speaker for the beginning of its three-day annual conference Sunday at the Washington Hilton Hotel.

title: PART OF SPACE SHUTTLE'S BOOSTER JOINT FOUND IN SEA
description: Space agency engineers said today that a piece of the Challenger wreckage found two weeks ago included part of the joint of the right solid-fuel booster rocket, the main suspect in the accident investigation.

title: CHAPLIN: PLAY HIM AGAIN
description: Charlie Chaplin, once viewed with& such distrust by the Government that the Federal Bureau of Investigation compiled a huge dossier on his political and romantic interests, has become a Government favorite.

title: CORNING GLASS WORKS reports earnings for Qtr to March 23
description: b-After tax credits of $4 million. c-After tax credits of $1.6 million, or 4 cents a share, and a gain of $20.1 million, or 47 cents a share, from the cumulative effect on prior years of change in accounting method.

title: Erratic Trading in Treasuries
description: After six consecutive days of sharply rising prices, Treasury bond prices were mixed yesterday in extremely erratic trading.

title: C.I.A. CHANGES WAY THAT IT MEASURES SOVIET ATOM TESTS
description: The Central Intelligence Agency has changed its procedures for estimating the yield of large Soviet nuclear tests because it has decided its previous estimates were too high, Reagan Administration officials said today.

title: HASKINS TO MINNESOTA
description: He coached the last six seasons at his alma mater, Western Kentucky, but now Clem Haskins will be trying to rebuild the strife-ridden basketball program at the University of Minnesota. Haskins was named last night to replace Jim Dutcher, who resigned in January after three members of the Gopher team were charged with sexual assault after a game in Madison, Wis.

title: ISRAELI'S JOKE: NOT SO FUNNY
description: An Israeli Army intelligence analyst, playing an April Fools' joke, disseminated a false report to top Israeli Government offices today that Nabih Berri, the Lebanese Shiite leader, had been seriously wounded in an assassination attempt, an army spokesman said.

title: PRESERVING THE JEWISH COOKING OF GREECE
description: When Nicholas Stavroulakis took charge of the Jewish Museum of Greece in 1977 - revitalizing it in the process - elderly women began bringing him traditional embroideries for display and he became interested enough to learn embroidery. One thing led to another, and when he asked the women, who were from Salonika, Rhodes, Ioannina and Istanbul, for traditional recipes, he began to learn cooking. The result is ''Cookbook of the Jews of Greece,'' which is being published this month by Cadmus Press in the United States.

title: U.S.O.C. REACHES ACCORD ON DRUGS
description: The United States Olympic Committee announced today that all 38 national governing bodies of amateur sports would participate in the committee's drug-abuse and drug-testing program.

title: COWBOYS SEEK COLLIER
description: While allowing Gary Hogeboom, their second-string quarterback, to shop around for a possible trade, the Dallas Cowboys have requested and been granted permission to talk to Reggie Collier, quarterback of the United States Football League's Orlando Renegades.

title: BRIBE INDICTMENT CHARGES EX-CHIEF OF CITY HOSPITALS
description: A former president of the New York City Health and Hospitals Corporation was indicted yesterday on charges of accepting a $150,000 bribe in return for giving a city contract to a medical consulting company.

title: CRIME PANEL ISSUES ITS FINAL REPORT
description: The President's Commission on Organized Crime ended its business today with a final report charging that organized crime was a pervasive threat and could reap more than $100 billion in the United States this year.

title: FEDERAL TAX AMNESTY WOULD REDUCE THE DEFICIT
description: To the Editor:

title: FROM DREAM ACADEMY, BEATLES-STYLE ART ROCK
description: NICK LAIRD-CLOWES, the 28-year-old guitarist, singer and leader of the English pop trio the Dream Academy, wears his hair below his shoulders and dresses in black velvet suits with Nehru collars. While this late-60's John Lennon look may be overly self-conscious, musically the Dream Academy belongs to a new breed of English pop act that is seriously concerned with extending the romantic art-rock exemplifed by the Beatles' late 60's studio albums.

title: Market Place; Specialty Shop: Allure Grows
description: IN an uncertain 1986 retail environment, specialty stores stand out as a shining beacon. If last year's performance is any barometer -and most analysts think it is - the retailers concentrating on a narrow merchandise category, whether apparel, toys, shoes or widgets, should outstrip general merchandisers in growth of sales, profits and stock values.

title: SIGNS OF PROGRESS CALL ME A FATHER
description: ''Call me a cab.'' ''You're a cab.'' The joke is stale, says a friend who just returned from Denver, but the process of calling a cab grows steadily more refined.

title: GOLDYS AWARDED FOR YIDDISH THEATER
description: The second annual Goldy Awards ceremonies were held Monday night and it seemed, just as it does with Oscars, Tonys and Obies, that half of the people in the field were making the presentations to the other half. Since the world of theater touching on Jewish themes, in English and Yiddish, is much smaller than the others, it was probably closer to the truth in the Goldys' case.

title: WORRY ABOUT AIR CONTROL REPAIRS
description: Shortages of technicians to repair and maintain equipment for controlling air traffic are so acute that preserving the quality of air operations ''will soon be impossible,'' Federal Aviation Administration documents say.

title: BUSH TO SEEK SAUDIS' ASSISTANCE IN STABILIZING PLUNGING OIL PRICES
description: Vice President Bush, outlining a four-nation trip to the Middle East that starts Thursday, said he would tell Saudi Arabia that the protection of American security interests requires action to stabilize the falling price of oil.

title: TV Review; A MOVIE ON ROLE OF ANCHORS
description: NO question about it, television journalism is one tough game. The price an anchorman pays to keep his integrity in a middle-market city - San Diego, say - can be something awful. On the other hand, the pay isn't bad, and it sure beats heavy lifting. ''News at Eleven,'' a two-hour movie on CBS at 9 o'clock tonight, gives us the picture. What's nice is that it does it in a reasonably intelligent and even mildly provocative way.

title: PAINTINGS WERE SAVED IN HAMPTON COURT FIRE
description: Volunteers saved a priceless Renaissance art collection from the fire at Hampton Court Palace and all seven major paintings that were damaged can be restored, officials said today.

title: MEASURING SOVIET TESTS: U.S. METHODS QUESTIONED
description: Administration experts as well as those outside the Government have long questioned Administration estimates of the yield of Soviet underground nuclear tests.

title: U.S. CURTAILING IMPORTS ON ITS DUTY-FREE LIST
description: The Reagan Administration said today that it would curtail the duty-free access that developing countries have to the United States market. Particularly affected are Taiwan, South Korea and Hong Kong.

title: METROPOLITAN DIARY
description: THE scene is the Oceana Theater near Brighton Beach in Brooklyn, where a line of moviegoers is waiting to see ''Hannah and Her Sisters.'' Among them: Leah Hymowitz and two women behind her, who are carrying on a conversation. ''I had hot cereal for breakfast,'' said one. ''What kind?'' her companion asked. ''The instant or the one minute?''

title: 21 BOMBS JOLT SANTIAGO; 20 ARE HURT IN PROTESTS
description: Twenty-one bombs exploded in Santiago during a night of clashes between policemen and left-wing demonstrators, the police said today.

title: CENTURI INC reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-After net from discontinued operations of $401,797. c-Net loss after a loss from discontinued operations of $2,233,155 and a charge of $1,399,044 from the retirement of convertible debt. Corrected from yesterday's editions.

title: ISRAELI PREMIER CALLS U.S. ACTIONS AGAINST LIBYANS 'A GREAT MOVE'
description: Prime Minister Shimon Peres of Israel said today that the United States military action against Libya was ''a great move'' that was ''really necessary for the free world.''

title: Economic Scene; Stabilizing Currencies
description: A MONTH from now, the leaders of the major industrial democracies - the United States, Japan, West Germany, France, Britain, Canada and Italy - will meet in Tokyo to discuss their common economic problems.

title: ALBANY BUDGET REMAINS STALLED OVER SCHOOL AID
description: A dispute over education aid continued to hold up passage of the state's $41 billion budget early this morning after Senate and Assembly negotiators sharply disagreed about which house was responsible for the increasingly political squabble.

title: 5TH DEFENDANT IS GIVEN 16 YEARS IN CASINO CASE
description: The last of five reputed leaders of organized crime to be convicted of skimming $2 million from Las Vegas casinos was sentenced today. He got 16 years in prison.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: DRAMATIC LUNCH The third annual New Dramatists Lunchtime One-Act Play Festival will begin today at noon and take place every Wednesday through May 7. The playwrights, who have all been professionally produced, are in the New Dramatists, whose 48 members are selected from an annual application pool of 300 to 400 people. Each week a one-act play will be read.

title: NEW PINIELLA PLAN: PLATOON 5th STARTER
description: On the day that all three candidates for the fifth spot in the Yankees' starting pitching rotation were supposed to pitch, Doug Drabek and Dennis Rasmussen each pitched five shutout innings today and Tommy John lay in the trainer's room receiving treatment for a knot in his back.

title: IDEAS FOR SPRING ON LAND AND AFLOAT
description: 1.Bather's Companion For the person who needs to have a telephone absolutely everywhere, there is Webcor's Float Fone. This water-resistant telephone is designed to go into the shower or even the swimming pool. The handset is sheathed in a yellow rubber glove that keeps water out. The price is $149.50 at Hammacher Schlemmer, 147 East 57th Street. #2.

title: Getty Oil Chairman Retires From Post
description: Texaco Inc. said yesterday that Robert C. McCay, a senior vice president and chairman of its Getty Oil Company subsidiary, had decided to retire, effective immediately.

title: Zinfandel's Origins
description: TO THE LIVING SECTION:

title: 5 Dismissed At the S.B.A.
description: Charles Heatherly, acting director of the Small Business Administration, dismissed directors of five of the agency's 10 regional offices shortly after taking office today, an S.B.A. spokesman said.

title: Up to Date With Sleight of Hand
description: April Fool's Day is symbolic for magicians. They gathered yesterday at Rockefeller Center to watch Jeff McBride perform at the skating rink, admire an exhibition of magic memorabilia at the American Festival Cafe, and play tricks.

title: DISK JOCKEY ON NIGHT SHIFT SHOT IN A ROBBERY ATTEMPT
description: A college student who had just started work as a disk jockey at a small radio station in this rural quarter of the state was shot on the job early this morning by a man who tried to rob him, the police said.

title: WHITE HOUSE TO PRESS CONGRESS OVER BUDGET
description: White House officials have decided on a Congressional strategy of no compromise on tax increases or on stepped-up military spending, Reagan Administration officials said today.

title: KAISER STEEL CORP reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-After income from discontinued operations of $3,591,000 and a gain from the cumulative effect of prior years accounting changes of $3,741,000. c-Net income after income from discontinued operations of $70,437,000.

title: American Motors
description: The American Motors Corporation plans to link up with a small Japanese manufacturer to produce a small four-wheel-drive vehicle under the Jeep name in A.M.C.'s Venezuala factory, company sources said. The car's designer is reportedly the Daihatsu Motor Company, the smallest of Japan's nine major auto makers. The sources, who spoke on the condition they not be named, said the vehicle would have a four-cylinder engine made by A.M.C. in Kenosha, Wis.

title: EX-HAITI POLICE CHIEF BEING HELD BY BRAZIL
description: The former police chief of Port-au-Prince, Col. Albert Pierre, who sought asylum here after the ouster of the Duvalier Government, was arrested today and will be held pending a response to Haiti's request for extradition.

title: Bridge: 2 Top Players From Florida Will Try for the World Title
description: Two Florida experts, Bill Root and Richard Pavlicek, share a number of distinctions: they are both successful bridge teachers, are joint authors of a major book, ''Modern Bridge Conventions,'' and have won four major national titles in the past five years, including the recent Vanderbilt Knockout Teams in Portland, Ore.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article in Metropolitan Report last Thursday about bookings at the new Jacob K. Javits Convention Center misidentified the law school that has scheduled a commencement there for June 8. It is the New York Law School, not New York University Law School.

title: TROUT AND JOY CAUGHT AS ONE
description: There may have been a more auspicious start for the New York State trout season during the past two decades, but I doubt it.

title: U.N. IS ASKED TO OPEN THE FILE ON WALDHEIM
description: Amid mounting evidence that Kurt Waldheim concealed his wartime past, Jewish organizations and New York legislators and officials have called on the United Nations to make public a secret file on the former Secretary General.

title: FRANCE, CITING INCREASED DANGER, REMOVES BEIRUT TRUCE OBSERVERS
description: The new French Government, in its first major foreign policy decision, announced today that it was withdrawing France's 45-member observer force from Lebanon.

title: PERSONAL HEALTH
description: JUDGING by the spate of new products and advertisements, dental plaque has become the latest scourge of health-conscious Americans. Plaque-fighting toothpastes, mouth rinses and high-tech toothbrushes are among the newly promoted products aimed at helping people keep their own teeth for their entire lives. But it may be decades before the value of these products can be measured and then, only if the proper long-term studies are carried out.

title: URANIUM TRACES FOUND NEAR OKLAHOMA SITE
description: Measurable levels of uranium and fluorine have been found southeast of a uranium-processing plant that was closed after a fatal accident earlier this year, but the contamination may not be a health hazard, according to a Federal report released today.

title: AQUINO DROPS MILITARY OFFICERS
description: President Corazon C. Aquino retired 20 generals and 19 colonels today. They had been allowed to stay past retirement age by President Ferdinand E. Marcos.

title: STOCKS' RATE-PROPELLED SURGE
description: The sharp decline in interest rates sent the nation's stock markets soaring in the first quarter, producing the biggest percentage gain for the Dow Jones industrial average in more than a decade.

title: People
description: * Philip R. May has been promoted to executive vice president at Cramer-Krasselt/Direct, Chicago.

title: EASING THE STORAGE OF LEFTOVERS AND WINE
description: CERTAIN simple kitchen items are hard to improve upon, such as storage jars for leftovers. However, vacuum-lock canisters offer a combination of advantages that make them worth mentioning.

title: HBM/Creamer Gets Allied Aftermarket Unit
description: HBM/Creamer announced yesterday that its Boston office had been assigned the Allied Aftermarket division of Allied Automotive and will do advertising for the Fram filter products, Bendix brakes and Autolite spark plugs.

title: BULGARIA CONGRESS EXPECTED TO BACK KEY PARTY CHANGES
description: After a shuffle in the Bulgarian leadership, the Communist Party will open a congress Monday, in which these changes are expected to be endorsed.

title: SURROGATE AIDE TO BE REMOVED OVER AN INQUIRY
description: The Queens Surrogate said yesterday that he would remove a subordinate who is emerging as a key subject in an investigation into whether kickbacks were paid out of legal fees in estate cases.

title: COMINGS AND GOINGS
description: John (Hot Rod) Williams, the Tulane basketball star who has been in legal and athletic limbo since his mistrial last August on sports-bribery charges, has a new trial date, May 27. Orleans Parish Judge Patrick Quinlan set a pretrial hearing for April 18.

title: WHO BUYS IT? THE AFFLUENT AND THE AWARE
description: A NEW JERSEY dairy specializes in unhomogenized milk - the kind with the cream on top - and sells it for $1.75 a half-gallon at the Union Square Greenmarket, Nest eggs from uncaged hens fed roasted whole grains retail for $1.98 to $2.40 a dozen at several D'Agostino's and elsewhere.

title: JURY ASSAILS NEWARK POLICE ON COURT-OVERTIME ABUSES
description: A state grand jury said today that, between 1981 and 1984, Newark police officers routinely collected thousands of dollars in unwarranted overtime pay by appearing as witnesses in court cases not ready for trial.

title: JAVITS CENTER SPECIAL: 3 MEAT LOAVES
description: The $486 million Jacob K. Javits Convention Center opens tomorrow, and Charlie Hristidis, owner of the River Diner aross the street, has seized the moment, adding not one but two meat loaf items to the menu.

title: PROBLEMS OF ADOPTED CHILDREN NEED RECOGNITION
description: To the Editor:

title: Latest in Desserts
description: TO THE LIVING SECTION:

title: JERRY PARIS, TV DIRECTOR, 60
description: Jerry Paris, an actor and director in films and television, died yesterday at Cedars-Sinai Medical Center in Los Angeles of complications caused by an inoperable brain tumor. He was 60 years old and lived in Pacific Palisades, Calif.

title: LESS WASN'T AS GOOD FOR THE BIG GAME
description: Like two weary fighters, they moved slowly and unsteadily toward the conclusion of the marathon National Collegiate Athletic Association basketball tournament. It was a long season and they wanted to go out winners, but one couldn't help feeling they mostly wanted it all to end.

title: Placating the Mayor
description: Last year, Mayor Koch walked into the all-male Union Club to address a group of artists known as the Dutch Treat Club. He told them that holding meetings in a place that discriminated against women was ''outrageous.''

title: LABELING WINE TO WARN OF ADDED SULFITE
description: AFTER a long struggle, the American wine industry appears ready to accept and promulgate a sulfite warning on wine labels. ''We have decided that even if only one person in the country is in danger of a severe reaction to sulfites in wine, their presence should be noted on the label,'' said Richard Peterson, the president and wine maker at the Monterey Vineyard in Gonzales, Calif., a subsidiary of Joseph E. Seagram & Sons.

title: Edelman Rebuffed
description: The Fruehauf Corporation, the Detroit-based manufacturer of truck trailers and auto parts, said its board had rejected a takeover proposal by Asher Edelman, the New York investor. Mr. Edelman had offered last week to buy Fruehauf for $41 a share, or a total of $860 million. On the New York Stock Exchange, the company's shares closed yesterday at $37.25, down $1.625.

title: Q&A
description: Q. On a recent visit to Portugal we dined on a fine dish called a cataplana. Can you tell me precisely how this is made? A. The word cataplana is the name of both a cooking utensil that is used and of the dish that is cooked inside it. The utensil is generally made of copper, round in shape and hinged on one side, like a clam.

title: Officer in Traffic Case Is Accused of Assault
description: A New York City police officer has been charged with assaulting a 57-year-old woman after he stopped her car for traffic violations in Brooklyn last year, authorities said yesterday.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Bethlehem Steel Corp., Bethlehem, Pa., has joined with Armco Inc., Inland Steel Co. and Weirton Steel in a long-range agreement to develop a direct sheet-casting process that eliminates major steps in steel-making.

title: Loews Raises Its CBS Stake
description: The Loews Corporation has increased its holdings in CBS Inc. to 16.7 percent, from 12.3 percent. It bought the stake from Fisher Brothers, a New York City real estate concern that had long been rumored to own nearly 5 percent of CBS.

title: JOHN CIARDI, POET, ESSAYIST AND TRANSLATOR, 69
description: John Ciardi, the poet and professor who was internationally acclaimed for his translation of Dante's ''Inferno,'' died Sunday at the John F. Kennedy Medical Center in Edison, N.J., after suffering a heart attack. Mr. Ciardi, who made his home in Metuchen, N.J., was 69 years old.

title: THE U.N. TODAY: April 2, 1986; GENERAL ASSEMBLY
description: Human Rights Committee - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: NEW COACH AT HOUSTON
description: Pat Foster, who had withdrawn his name from consideration for the head basketball coaching job at the University of Houston, said last night he had changed his mind and accepted the job. Foster, who is 46 years old, compiled a 134-49 record in six years as coach at Lamar.

title: TEACHING ENGLISH TO THE POOR
description: While equal opportunity is a major goal of education, the debate over bilingual education still divides educators, minority groups and politicians - and often anyone who has children. Can poor children perform as well as our own? Individually, we might answer yes. But as a society we often send less encouraging signals to the poor. When it comes to learning foreign languages, the rich still have it better.

title: SIDNEY HUBSCHMAN
description: Sidney Hubschman, a co-founder of the Two Guys discount store chain, died of cancer Sunday at Naples (Fla.) Community Hospital. He was 69 years old and lived in Naples.

title: ROME COURT CLEARS WAY FOR BULGARIAN TO LEAVE
description: An appeals court here cleared the way today for a Bulgarian acquitted last week in the papal shooting to leave Rome.

title: CONTRACT REVIEW LAW UPHELD
description: A Federal appeals court has upheld an order to Reagan Administration officials to comply with a law authorizing a General Accounting Office review of disputed contracts.

title: Tokyo String Quartet
description: The Tokyo String Quartet, which celebrated its 15th anniversary this season, will appear with the oboist Heinz Holliger on April 15 and 16 at 8 P.M. at the 92d Street Y, at Lexington Avenue. Mr. Holliger will join the quartet for Boccherini's Quintet in D and two works by Mozart- the Quartet in F and the Adagio in C; also on the program are Haydn's Quartet in D and Schumann's Quartet in A minor. Tickets range from $12.50 to $17.50. Information: 831-8603.

title: SWIPE AT SPORTS
description: It has become a commonplace among many college administrators that a successful athletic program is essential for academics. Without a headline football or basketball team, so the thinking goes, students would gravitate to other schools.

title: AFTER YEARS OF PROBLEMS, ALL AGREE CENTER IS SAFE
description: There are times in life when, to prove a point, a certain kind of man feels the calling to stand alongside an upright 10-foot-long steel tube of questioned structural integrity and to smile at a camera as 245,000 pounds of pressure are applied to one of the tube's ends.

title: Causes for Jubilation At Reborn Vanity Fair
description: Tina Brown has a couple of reasons for jubilation: George Evans, who was recently born, and Vanity Fair. which appears to be reborn, for the second time. She is mother of the former and editor in chief of the latter.

title: NADER ASSAILS BID TO LIMIT LIABILITY
description: The consumer activist Ralph Nader asserted today that limits on jury awards to victims of defective products would victimize people twice, first when they were injured and second when they could not get adequate compensation.

title: FORD IS SET TO REVISE EXECUTIVE BONUS PLAN
description: The Ford Motor Company reported today that its chief executive was paid $1.69 million in salary, bonus and stock options last year, but it also said the company was planning a new compensation plan that would emphasize accumulation of stock rather than short-term cash bonuses.

title: Authors
description: The election for governor of New York could become a matter of trading book reviews, along with the predictable political palaver.

title: DERIVATION OF YARMULKE
description: To the Editor:

title: NEW YORK LEGISLATURE SET UP SEABURY PANEL
description: To the Editor:

title: TESTIMONY ENDED IN TRIAL ON ALIENS
description: The Federal Government began closing arguments today in the trial of 11 church workers who provided sanctuary to illegal aliens by asserting the case should be viewed as routine smuggling and nothing more.

title: GAIN A YEAR ON LIFE, AT AGE 4
description: Suddenly, a shining governmental initiative has broken through New York's cloud of scandal, an initiative so promising it could become a model for cities everywhere: Send 4-year-olds to school.

title: THE 'FLY-IN' SUPERSEDES THE DRIVE-IN
description: OUTSIDE McGehee's Catfish Restaurant hangs a quartet of hummingbird feeders, but on busy evenings the birds are often interrupted by the approach of another planeload of customers cruising onto McGehee's grassy landing strip.

title: HOW COMPANIES GET CONTRACTS WITHOUT BIDDING
description: The $1 million consulting contract that figured in yesterday's bribery indictment of John J. McLaughlin, the city's former hospitals chief, was among nearly $4 million in contracts Nu-Med Inc., a California-based medical management firm, received without competitive bidding from 1981 to 1983.

title: Accounts
description: * Times Mirror National Marketing to Warren Pfaff Inc.

title: SIGNS OF PROGRESS EARLYSPRING SUMMER
description: ''Midwinter spring is its own season,'' wrote T.S. Eliot, and the same might be said of our current meteorological hybrid, earlyspring summer.

title: JUSTICES EXTEND RESTRAINTS ON POLICE INTERROGATION
description: The Supreme Court ruled today the police may not interrogate a defendant who asks at his arraignment that a lawyer be appointed to represent him, unless the lawyer is present or the defendant talks spontaneously.

title: NATIONAL DATA CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
A 'MARSHALL PLAN' IN MIDEAST URGED
description: The United States and Israel have begun discussion of a multibillion-dollar ''Marshall Plan'' for the Middle East to foster a better climate for peace in the region, a senior State Department official said today.

title: POLICE QUELL UPRISING AT SOUTH CAROLINA PRISON
description: Rioting inmates who set fire to four buildings at the Kirkland Correctional Institution Tuesday night took some guards hostage but quickly released them when the police stormed the prison, the authorities said today.

title: MED-CHEM PRODUCTS reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
description: b-Includes tax credits of $110,000 for the quarter and $186,000 for the 6 months.

title:
NEW YORK DAY BY DAY;
TIMES SQ. NEWS SIGN
description: The big news on Times Square yesterday was the big sign that for years had delivered big news. In other words, the zipper, which off and on has screamed headlines in lights since 1928, is back on, flashing the good and the bad from the walls of 1 Times Square Plaza.

title: O'KELLY ISLEY
description: O'Kelly Isley, a rhythm-and-blues singer and one of the siblings who as the Isley Brothers sold more than 12 million records with such hits as ''Twist and Shout'' and ''Love the One You're With,'' died of a heart attack Monday at Englewood (N.J.) Hospital.

title: IF THE EXTERIOR IS DINGY OR DULL
description: WHEN the exterior trim and siding of a house start to look dingy or dull, most homeowners think it's time for a paint job. Yet often, repainting may not be necessary or advisable.

title: AMERICAN RECREATION CENERS reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 26
Reichmanns Fight Hiram Unit Sale
description: Olympia & York Developments Ltd., owned by the Reichmann family of Canada, said it would ask the Ontario Supreme Court to prevent Hiram Walker Resources Ltd. from selling its liquor business to Allied-Lyons P.L.C. Fighting off a takeover bid by the Reichmanns, Hiram Walker said on Monday that it had agreed to sell its liquor operations to Allied-Lyons for nearly $1.9 million.

title: TUTU URGES MORE SANCTIONS AGAINST SOUTH AFRICA
description: Bishop Desmond M. Tutu called for punitive economic sanctions against South Africa today in a statement that seemed designed to illuminate black despair and to challenge Western governments to put pressure on Pretoria to liberalize its racial policies.

title: Celtics' Streak 28-0 at Home
description: The frontcourt of Robert Parish, Larry Bird and Kevin McHale combined for 83 points as the Boston Celtics set a league single-season record with their 28th consecutive home victory by beating the Detroit Pistons, 122-106, tonight.

title: U.S.F.L. Aiming for 'Galaxy'
description: Just what does the United States Football League hope to achieve if it wins its antitrust lawsuit against the National Football League in a trial scheduled to begin here late this month in Federal District Court?

title: POSITIVE APPROACH HELPS PULZ
description: Penny Pulz said that when she came from three shots back on the final nine to win the Circle K Tucson Open 10 days ago, ''It was proof that sobriety works and that this is the way to go.''

title: U.S. LISTS IMPORTS FOR RETALIATION
description: Americans may soon pay more for white wine from France, Italy and West Germany, Perrier from France, pork and canned hams from Denmark and the Netherlands, Scotch whisky and cookies from Britain, and olives from Spain and Portugal as a result a trade war that is about to break out with the European Common Market.

title: MANILA OFFICIAL CITES PROGRESS ON RETRIEVING ASSETS
description: The chairman of a commission seeking to recover the assets of former President Ferdinand E. Marcos returned today from the United States and reported that there had been rapid progress on several fronts.

title: COGNITRONICS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes a $222,000 charge for the writeoff of certain deferred expenses and increases in the provisions for uncollectable receivables and excess inventories. c-Net income d-Includes a charge of $1,653,000 related to an acquisition and a tax credit of $311,000.

title: HADSON PETROLEUM CORP reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-Includes a gain on the sale of Hadson's oil and gas properties in the United Kingdom of about $16.5 million, a writedown of its domestic oil and gas properties of about $12.5 million and a tax credit of $1,141,000.

title: DISPLAY COMPONENTS reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After tax credits of $4,105 for the quarter and $59,445 for the year. c-Net income

title: TERRORISM BOYCOTT URGED IN PILOTS' GROUP
description: A leader of the International Airline Pilots Association said yesterday that a move was under way to organize a worldwide pilots' boycott against governments found responsible for terrorist acts such as the bombing today of a Trans World Airlines jet.

title: Japan Postal Investments
description: The Posts and Telecommunications Ministry will allow the postal insurance system to increase the pace of its investment in foreign currency assets, ministry sources said today. But the ministry left the limit on investment in foreign assets unchanged at 10 percent of total outstanding reserves, the sources said.

title: HERS
description: IN the brown leatherette booth in the diner Kathy Burke sips her tea and lets her eyes roam round and round the narrow room, over the man in the corner booth, over the one at the counter with his hand jammed in his pocket, over the group moving to a table in the back. It comes with the territory. Kathy Burke is a police detective. She has a gun and a badge and, near her left shoulder, a rosy little raised dimple. It is what is left of the hole where a bullet went in one night in January; on her back is a corresponding spot where the bullet came out. In between were a lung and some ribs. She says she didn't feel a thing until later. Her partner died.

title: INDEPENDENCE HOLDING CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes a non-recurring ''fresh- start'' tax benefit of $4.6 million for the quarter and year.

title: GEMCO NATIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $3,453,000 for the quarter and $5,553,000 for the year. c-Net income and after net from discontinued operations of $522,000 for the quarter and a loss of $125,000 from discontinued operations for the year. Sales represent net sales from continuing operations.

title: MONOFORT OF COLORADO INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 1
Coffey Breaks Orr Mark
description: Paul Coffey's record-breaking offensive showing sparked the Edmonton Oilers to an 8-4 victory over the Vancouver Canucks tonight. Coffey scored his 46th and 47th goals to break the National Hockey League record for goals in a season by a defenseman.

title: DELTAUS CORP reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $6,693,000 for the latest year and $3,201,000 for the earlier period. The 1984 figures were restated.

title: THE U.N. TODAY: April 3, 1986
description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY Human Rights Committee - 10:30 A.M and 3 P.M.

title: Soviet Emigre Arrested In February Shootout
description: A 27-year-old Brooklyn man was arrested last night and charged with the slaying of a Russian immigrant in a dispute at a wholesale gasoline distributorship in the Sheepshead Bay section two months ago, the police reported.

title: Aching to Be Best
description: Jeff Ruland of the Washington Bullets suggests that there's a method to his maddeningly frequent aches and pains: ''I'm trying to be like Bill Walton - be injured a long time and end up in Boston.''

title: HONDURAN TELLS OF U.S. PRESSURE
description: A senior Honduran official has asserted that the Government never felt its security was threatened by a Nicaraguan border raid last week and sought to resist pressure from the Reagan Administration to treat the episode as a major crisis.

title: OPENING SKIRMISH TO O'NEILL IN BATTLE WITH MOFFETT
description: About 400 Democrats crowded into the cafeteria of the Academy School here Tuesday night for a first skirmish in the battle to determine whether Gov. William A. O'Neill or former United States Representative Toby Moffett will be the party's nominee for governor this fall.

title: SUNSTATES CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes extraordinary charges of $1,579,000 for the latest quarter and $681,000 for the year-earlier quarter. c-Includes a loss of $5,503,244 from a discontinued division. d-Net income and includes an extraordinary tax credit of $2,387,000.

title: POLAROID BETS ON NEW CAMERA
description: With all the fanfare of a circus opening, the Polaroid Corporation introduced a new camera today that it hopes will recast its image and its prospects. Hurt in recent years by a shrinking market for instant cameras and film, Polaroid is betting that consumers will spend up to $225 for an instant camera that takes sharper and more vivid photos than its predecessors.

title: BARRIER SCIENCE & TECHOLOGY reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss

title: LENNAR CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
description: b-Includes a gain of $1,835,000, or 20 cents a share, from land sales.

title: LATE RALLY LIFTS BOND PRICES
description: Prices of Treasury notes and bonds rose as much as 1 1/4 points yesterday, but only after prices moved erratically as bond traders continued to slavishly follow developments in the oil markets.

title: CINTAS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
PUBCO CORPORATION, DEBTOR-IN POSSESSION reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-Includes an extraordinary gain of $198,000 for the latest year and $1,545,714 for the prior year.

title: HOW NEW YORKERS DEFEATED LAROUCHE
description: The startling victory in the Illinois Democratic primary of candidates associated with Lyndon LaRouche's neo-Nazi organization has generated the question, ''How could it have happened?'' It would be a mistake to consider the victory a freak event that cannot be repeated. In fact, LaRouche adherents have won large vote totals in numerous races around the country since 1982.

title: Phillips and Polygram Deal
description: Phillips International and Polygram International, two pioneers of the compact disk industry, said yesterday that they had formed a new company that would develop software for a new generation of compact disk systems. The new systems, called

title: Bridge: A Top Partnership Reveals Its Methods in a New Book
description: Most top-ranked partnerships devote hours of work to polishing their bidding methods. Many wind up with pages of notes, amounting to a small book, and some players would give a lot to have access to it.

title: OHIO MILK FOUND UNTAINTED
description: Preliminary tests by the United States Food and Drug Administration have found nothing wrong with milk distributed by the Lawson Milk Company, a company spokesman said.

description: Share earnings reflect a 2-for-1 stock split distributed March 12.

title: AUTHOR OF ECONOMICS BOOKS
description: Nathan H. Mager, the author of more than two dozen books on economics, business management and history, died at Mount Sinai Hospital Monday of complications arising from heart surgery. He was 73 years old and lived in Teaneck, N.J.

title: HAITIAN PRELATE IS UNDER ATTACK
description: A group of Haitian priests and nuns are pressing for the resignation of the Archbishop of Port-au-Prince because of what they say was his collaboration with the Duvalier Government.

title: NETWORK SECURITY CORP reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
U.S.-CZECH EXCHANGE ACCORD REACHED
description: The United States and Czechoslovakia have agreed on the first cultural and scientific exchanges between the two nations, Administration officials said today.

title: NEW ORLEANS TO SETTLE LAWSUIT ON POLICE ABUSE
description: The City of New Orleans has agreed to pay more than $2.8 million in out-of-court settlements of lawsuits filed by 13 people who accused the police of mistreating them in an investigation of a police officer's slaying in 1980.

title: CSX CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
YOUTHFUL BROOM BRIGADE
description: Dressed in bubble-gum pink sweatshirts and armed with brooms, 10 homeless children stood in front of the Holland Hotel yesterday, the beginning of a Department of Sanitation nine-week cleanup contest in Manhattan.

title: Pan Am to Buy Ransome Airlines
description: The Pan Am Corporation announced plans to buy Ransome Airlines, a major commuter airline based in Philadelphia.

title: N.C.A.A. ADOPTS 3-POINT GOAL
description: The National Collegiate Athletic Association adopted the 3-point field goal in men's basketball today and decided to use instant replays to check scoring and timing errors.

title: AN I.B.M. STEP IN KEY MARKET
description: The International Business Machines Corporation introduced its long-awaited lap-top computer yesterday, a 12-pound battery-operated model built for traveling executives, writers and sales representatives.

title: ASHLAND TO REPURCHASE 27% OF STOCK
description: Ashland Oil Inc., the nation's largest independent oil refiner, said yesterday that its board had authorized the company to repurchase 7.5 million, or 27 percent, of its 28 million shares.

title: Kellogg's Final Crowds
description: Hordes of people are pouring through the Kellogg Company's cereal plant this week. Its 80 years of public tours will end April 11. Monday's 7,000 visitors set a record, a Kellogg spokesman said today.

title: EDWARDS, AG & SONS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
BROOKLYNITE HELD AS FAKE DOCTOR
description: A Brooklyn man was indicted yesterday for posing as a doctor and illegally treating dozens of patients for infertility problems since November at an office in Borough Park.

title: MERCHANT AND IVORY'S COUNTRY RETREAT
description: THEIR large 1805 brick manor house has not yet suggested a film to James Ivory, Ruth Prawer Jhabvala and Ismail Merchant - the director, writer and producer of the widely acclaimed movie ''A Room With a View'' and many other films.

title: 11 DEAD IN NEW MEXICO IN MILITARY PLANE CRASH
description: An Air Force HC-130 search-and-rescue airplane carrying 11 crew members crashed in a ball of flames today in a desolate area of west-central New Mexico, and the authorities said all aboard were killed.

title: THOUSANDS OF FIRES STRIKE PARCHED STATES IN THE EAST
description: For months, the land's dryness has been the talk of neighborhoods around the South, and now a budding spring has brought fire instead of rain.

title: ENDING AN ERA, WALLACE ANNOUNCES HE WILL RETIRE
description: Gov. George Corley Wallace of Alabama, whose leadership bridged three turbulent decades of Southern history from the years of segregation to the new era of biracial politics, said today that he was retiring from public life.

title: 31-YEAR POLICE VETERAN IS AN APPARENT SUICIDE
description: A New York City police sergeant who for four years was the principal investigator into the disappearance of Etan Patz and who served on the force 31 years was found dead in his kitchen in Brooklyn on Monday, apparently a suicide, the police said yesterday.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''After much prayerful consideration, I feel that I must say I have climbed my last political mountain.'' - George Corley Wallace. [ A1:3. ]

title: SPAIN 10 YEARS AFTER FRANCO
description: SPAIN has been in the news only intermittently in the last 10 years: an election, say, or an attempted coup, or a decision to reaffirm ties to the Western alliance. Spain ought to be heard from more. Its transition from dictatorship to democracy, ably examined on an ''Inside Story'' documentary last night on Channel 13, is an account of political success.

description: THE numbers of a digital speedometer appear to float in the air about halfway down the length of the hood on a specially equipped Ford Thunderbird. The image is small enough not to interfere with the view of the road, and permits the driver to check the auto's speed without having to look down at the instrument panel.

title: LOBBYING A NATIVE CAUSE
description: Suzan Shown Harjo, who says her great-grandfather led the Cheyenne at the Battle of Little Big Horn, sat surrounded by American Indian artifacts in her office in a Capitol Hill townhouse and recited a litany of ills that beset her people.

title: Making Carpeting Fit in a New Home
description: WHEN moving, whether to take expensive wall-to-wall carpeting from one location to another often becomes a major decision. Room sizes vary and many times the new spaces will be larger or smaller, with different layouts. Obviously, one solution is to have the wall-to-wall carpeting made into a smaller rug. But often, the carpeting can be reworked wall to wall in the new location.

title: PERES URGES U.N. TO RELEASE ITS FILE ON WALDHEIM
description: Prime Minister Shimon Peres of Israel said yesterday that he did not understand why the United Nations was holding secret documents on the World War II activities of its former Secretary General, Kurt Waldheim, adding that Israel might ask the world organization to release the file.

title: Rock Hudson Items Fetch Good Prices
description: Rock Hudson's memorabilia, which were auctioned yesterday at the William Doyle Galleries, brought prices that were as much as two to ten times what the auction house expected.

title: Wang Products
description: Wang Laboratories Inc. said it had introduced the VS5 and VS6 32-bit minicomputers for use in small businesses and corporate offices. It said that the VS5, priced at $12,000, supports up to eight users and the VS6, priced at $19,950, supports up to 16 users.

title: WAR RECALLED IN ARGENTINA
description: Argentines marked the fourth anniversary of the invasion of the Falkland Islands today with church masses and somber commemorative ceremonies throughout the country.

title: Generalists In Direct Marketing
description: IT was no great surprise yesterday that Al Ries and Jack Trout, the leadership of the Trout & Ries agency, put on their marketing-as-war show with all of its quotes from the venerable military strategist Carl von Clausewitz, since they have become one of the more popular road shows in advertising.

title: MEROLA CHECKS SCHOOLS FOR POLITICAL MEDDLING
description: The Bronx District Attorney said yesterday that he was investigating allegations that community school boards in his borough had allowed ''political considerations'' to play a part in the hiring and promotion of teachers and school administrators.

title: RANGERS MISS CHANCE TO CLINCH
description: It seemed that this would be the night the Rangers would finally fulfill their quest for a playoff spot and bring down their mighty nemesis, in one grand performance. They were close. They were clicking. Their fans were stomping, eager for celebration.

title: RECITAL: ALAN FEINBERG
description: ALAN FEINBERG gave a splendid piano recital at the 92d Street Y Tuesday. Interest centered on works less than 10 years old, by Charles Wuorinen, Gyorgy Ligeti, George Edwards and Milton Babbitt, and while that is odd in the round of ordinary concert life, Mr. Feinberg never made it seem so for a moment. He played with verve and at times with something like glee; the audience (small but not dismally so) seemed to hear it all in like spirit.

title: FIRST CENTRAL FINANCIAL reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
SHADOWBOXING ON NICARAGUA
description: President Reagan has told us angrily that he is the last one in the world who wants to send United States troops to Central America. For reasons he would not like, I incline to believe him - though I still strongly oppose his plan to give $100 million in military and other aid to the contras, and I still think it's quite possible we'll see United States troops in Central America.

title: A New Top Post Filled By Hughes Aircraft
description: The Hughes Aircraft Company yesterday named Albert D. Wheelon to the newly created position of executive vice president for operations, with responsibility for the aerospace company's six major divisions.

BRITONS ASSAIL NEW TAX AFFECTING U.S. INVESTORS
description: A new British tax on the shares of British companies as traded in the United States is pitting banks, brokers and corporations against the generally pro-business Thatcher Government.

title: CBS ASSAILS NBC NEWS OVER A PAYOLA REPORT
description: In an unusually harsh criticism of another network, Thomas H. Wyman, chairman of CBS, labeled as a ''second-class example of broadcast journalism'' a recent NBC News investigative report suggesting a connection between the head of CBS Records and allegations of payola in the music business.

title: 'MIRACLE OF THE HEART,' A BOYS TOWN TALE
description: IN the late 1930's, a moving performance by Spencer Tracy as the Rev. Edward Flanagan brought the Irish priest's ''Boys Town'' to worldwide attention. Now, in ''Miracle of the Heart,'' a syndicated television movie that can be seen tonight at 9 on WOR/Channel 9, the Boys Town community, caring for abused and troubled youths, is getting an updated film treatment. This one, featuring Art Carney as a lovable priest, is equally eager to endorse Father Flanagan's guiding rule: ''There are no bad boys. There is only bad environment, bad training, bad example and bad thinking.'' The message remains appealing.

title: JAVITS HALL IS POISED TO EXHIBIT
description: After two years of delay, the Jacob K. Javits Convention Center of New York yesterday assumed the appearance of a building about to open: hundreds of construction workers painted walls and installed sprinkler systems while art dealers and furriers scrambled to set up exhibition booths before the building's scheduled 9:30 A.M. debut today.

title: Fund, C.D. Yields Off
description: Yields for certificates of deposit, bank money market accounts and money market mutual funds on the whole slipped lower for the week ended yesterday.

title: Beijing Jeep's Cash Squeeze
description: A joint car-making venture is owed millions of dollars by Chinese state enterprises and is crippled by a shortage of foreign exchange, automotive sources said today.

description: Heinz Nixdorf, widely regarded as West Germany's most successful postwar entrepreneur, died of heart failure on March 17 while attending the Hannover trade fair. He was 60 years old.

title: BRITISH TREASURE HOUSES' HEROES
description: ALTHOUGH much ado has been made of the aristocratic patrons whose country house furnishings are on view until April 13 in Washington at the National Gallery of Art in ''Treasure Houses of Britain,'' the real heroes responsible for the survival of the contents of these homes are the time-honored British housekeepers and their staffs.

title: DYNATEC INTERNATIONAL reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
GOING OUT GUIDE
description: BALLADE FOR CARNEGIE HALL The Grieg Ballade in G minor is a favorite piece of Jorge Bolet, the Cuban-born pianist and head of the piano department at Philadelphia's Curtis Institute of Music. But he has not performed it publicly, saying that he could not find an appropriate format for it. ''It's too long for an encore,'' he said, ''and it just doesn't work in the context of a typical recital.'' Ballades are romantic or narrative works created specifically for instruments, usually the piano. The word is the French equivalent of ballad, but ballad usually implies something vocal.

title: UNION LOANS: MOB'S HOLD ON CASINOS
description: About 10 years ago three mob bosses, Frank Balistrieri of Milwaukee, James Licavoli of Cleveland and Nick Civella of Kansas City, quarreled over the division of money they were illegally reaping from the Stardust Hotel and Casino in Las Vegas.

description: The Administration's decision to seek oil price stability from Saudi Arabia has sharply refocused national attention on the benefits and liabilities of falling oil prices and underscored the high political stakes involved.

title: FRANCE, IN SHIFT, MAY BACK AN ANTITERROR PACT
description: President Francois Mitterrand, apparently in a policy reversal, has indicated that he is no longer opposed to an American proposal for a new initiative on terrorism at the meeting of the seven leading industrial democracies in Tokyo next month, according to officials preparing for the talks.

title: BALLET: JOFFREY COMPANY IN AN ANNIVERSARY GALA
description: THE Joffrey Ballet gave itself a birthday party on Tuesday night. The gala performance at the New York State Theater simultaneously opened the company's spring season and celebrated its 30th anniversary. Perhaps, back in 1956 when Robert Joffrey sent a little group of dancers on a tour of one-night stands, only the visionary Mr. Joffrey envisioned that his company would one day be playing some of the greatest theaters in the world. Thanks to diligence and fortitude, his dreams have come true.

title: CONGRESS UNITS SEEK TO HALT DELIVERY OF ANGOLAN MISSILES
description: Senior members of the House and Senate intelligence committees are trying to prevent the Reagan Administration from delivering portable antiaircraft missiles to rebel forces in Angola, according to congressional and Administration sources.

title: TAKE IT TO COURT
description: When two neighbors quarrel over the correct location of a fence on their boundary line, they usually do not step across into the disputed area with guns in hand, each daring the other to shoot. What they normally do is take the matter to a court, where it is resolved after the hearing of historical evidence on the conflicting boundary claims.

title: CONCERT: MENUHIN CONDUCTS
description: A LITTLE more than 60 years ago, on Jan. 7, 1926, Yehudi Menuhin made his first professional appearance in New York, his birthplace, setting in motion a career that earned him a secure place in the history of the violin. Then, he was the miraculous young virtuoso in short pants, the envy of the fiddling profession. Now, it somehow seems seems strange to say, the former wunderkind is on the brink of 70 (his birthday is tomorrow) and he bears the title of Sir Yehudi, knight of the British Empire. He was granted British citizenship last year and the right to use the title, which actually was awarded to him two decades ago. Sir Yehudi is also a Swiss citizen, thanks to his services in founding the Gstaad Festival.

description: b-After writedowns of $1.6 million on oil and gas properties.

title: RASMUSSEN IS NAMED STARTER

title: BUDDHIST SCRIPTURES FOUND IN STATUE
description: Curators of the New Orleans Museum of Art, examining a newly donated piece of Buddhist sculpture, have found inside the statue what they believe to be rare Chinese manuscripts dating to the 12th century.

Herrmann, 37 years old, came to the Academy with Evans in 1980 and has played an integral part in the team's success in recent years, according to J. O. Coppedge, the athletic director, who pointed to Herrmann's skill in recruiting and teaching defense.

title: 'BABY BOOM BLUES' ON 13

The team did not win in 14 Big Eight games, the worst record in conference history.

title: WHEN IDEOLOGY IS KING
description: America's political genius has been pragmatism. We are not burdened as a people by the ideological formulas imprinted on the memory of, say, the French or the Irish. Our great political leaders - a Lincoln or a Franklin Roosevelt -have adapted to critical circumstances without regard to ideology.

title: MUSIC: ROSTROPOVICH CONDUCTS SHOSTAKOVICH
description: STANDING between Dmitri Shostakovich and his deserved reputation as one of the great composers of all time have been two related impediments. First, there was his involvement in the cultural politics of Stalinist Russia, which led Soviet critics to condemn his introspective work and Western critics to suspect Soviet populism at any sign of extroversion. Second, his adherence to mostly traditional harmonies, instruments and forms attracted scorn from Western avant-gardists.

title: Q&A
description: Q.In very cold weather, dampness collects on our outer walls near the ceiling. The roof has no leaks, the vents are open in the attic and all the gutters are clear. The upstairs rooms are closed and not heated in winter, but we leave the bathroom door open. The thermostat is set for 68 degrees downstairs during the day and 60 at night, and we have steam heat. Can you suggest a solution? A.You probably need more ventilation upstairs, and at least a little heat in cold weather. The inside of the outside walls gets so cold that moisture in the air condenses and forms droplets. Keeping the rooms and walls a little warmer will help prevent this. Circulating more air, perhaps by opening windows slightly every couple of days, when the outside air is dry, will also help. Q.The white aluminum siding on my house was apparently installed about 28 years ago, before I moved in. This siding is becoming increasingly discolored, especially on the north side, and less so just under the roof overhang on the three other sides. I have tried vigorous scrubbing and washing with a chlorine bleach, to little avail. A cleaning service said it didn't expect much improvement from a professional washing. If I paint the siding, I would have to repaint every few years. Do you have any other suggestions? A.I'm afraid not. Because cleaning doesn't help, the paint must have oxidized or changed color (yellowed), perhaps from fumes in the air or aging.

title: APPLIED POWER INC reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
STAGE: 'PERFECT PARTY,' NEW GURNEY COMEDY
description: IN comedies such as ''The Dining Room'' and ''The Middle Ages,'' the playwright A. R. Gurney Jr. has claimed John Cheever's territory for the stage. With rueful humor, if not exactly regret, Mr. Gurney writes about the decline and fall of the hapless white Anglo-Saxon Protestant in the second half of our century. But while there's much more to Cheever's fiction than artful social reportage, Mr. Gurney's plays have been a shade cautious. His writing, highly polished and enjoyable, has often seemed as polite as his characters are - at least until they knock back their requisite double martinis. Mr. Gurney his given us the telling details of reality without always finding a larger truth of his own.

description: Two offerings of collateralized mortgage obligations totaling $640 million were offered yesterday with yields that were as much as 1 5/8 percentage points above Treasury bonds.

title: CUOMO DECLINES TO ENTER DISPUTE OVER SCHOOL AID IN STATE BUDGET
description: Governor Cuomo said today that it would not be ''fruitful'' for him to intervene in the dispute over school aid that is stalling passage of the state budget because the squabble is a Republican problem.

title: MEDIATION RESUMED IN RAIL STRIKE
description: Federal mediators sought today to end a railroad workers' strike in the Northeast that could harden Congressional resistance to President Reagan's proposed sale of the Government's 85 percent interest in Conrail to the Norfolk Southern Corporation.

title: FUNDSNET INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Revenue results represent service revenue figures.

title: A LIBERAL BILL
description: The other day, after Americans for Democratic Action issued ratings of members of Congress on the basis of how they had voted on various issues, particularly liberal issues favored by the A.D.A., the organization got a request for a copy of its report from one of the least liberal of places, the White House political office.

title: CONVENIENT FOOD MART INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Including an extraordinary gain of $917,000. The full year of 1984 revenue included $1.3 million generated from Chicago operations that were sold in the 1984 third quarter. Share earnings have been adjusted for a 5-for-4 stock split on Sept. 2, 1985.

title: WILSHIRE OIL CO OF TEXAS reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Share earnings reflect a 3 percent stock dividend paid in February.

title: New Spot for Uni-ball Reports No 'Goopers'
description: Grant Marketing Communications, the Philadelphia ad agency, has done a 30-second spot for Faber-Castell's Uni-ball, a writing instrument that uses a water-based ink rather than the oil-based ink usually found in regular ballpoint pens.

title: 3 ORDINARY APARTMENTS IN BRIGHT NEW GUISES
description: THREE of the more usual layouts in New York apartments are the unwieldy railroad-car plan, the boxy two-bedroom apartment that does not take advantage of a dramatic view and the one-bedroom apartment with two similarly shaped rooms. Three case histories illustrate imaginative solutions to these problem layouts without major structural changes.

title: PATIENT TECHNOLOGY reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-Includes a loss from discontinued operations of $5,152,000. c-Net income and includes a loss from discontinued operations of $127,000 and an extraordinary gain of $60,000.

title: No Headline
description: After a night in port unloading more pieces of the Challenger's crew cabin, the Navy's prime salvage ship returned to sea this morning amid indications that it had virtually completed the task of recovering that wreckage.

title: KINDER-CARE LEARNING CENERS INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 14
description: b-After net from discontinued operations of $1,091,681 for the quarter and $853,198 for the 6 months.

title: WINSTON MILLS INC reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-After loss from discontinued operations of $1,581,000 and a loss on the disposal of discontinued operations of $1,608,000. c-Net income after net from discontinued operations of $378,000, a gain on the sale of a liscense of $1,010,000, and a tax loss carryforward benefit of $1,602,000.

title: MEXICAN POLICE CHIEF IS EXTRADITED FROM U.S.
description: Arturo Durazo Moreno, a former Mexico City police chief, was in jail today after being extradited from the United States.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: THE BOOK OF ABRAHAM. By Marek Halter. 722 pages. Henry Holt. $19.95.

title: Comings and Goings
description: Mike Fitzgerald, the former Met catcher who was traded to Montreal as part of the Gary Carter deal in 1984, has been optioned to the Expos' Indianapolis farm club in the Class AAA American Association. Fitzgerald, 25, has not caught since March 12 after injuring his shoulder while working with weights. . . . Governor Cuomo has nominated Richard F. Corbisiero, executive director of the State Racing and Wagering Board since 1979, to succeed John Van Lindt as the board's chairman.

title: REPORTER'S LETTERS TO JURORS DELAY NAVY RADIOMAN'S TRIAL
description: Jurors in the spy trial of a former Navy radioman notified the judge today that they had received letters from a newspaper reporter asking for post-trial interviews because they were involved in ''a historic trial.''

title: U.S. FLEET THAT STRUCK LIBYA STARTS TO SCATTER
description: The American naval fleet that attacked Libya across the Gulf of Sidra last week began dispersing today, with one aircraft carrier headed home to Florida and the two others to Spain and Italy to give their crews liberty, Defense Department officials said.

title: UNITED PARK CITY MINES reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Figures reflect extraordinary tax benefits of $221,502 for the latest quarter, $111,170 for the year-ago quarter, $497,629 for the latest year and an extraordinary tax credit of $405,440 for the previous year.

title: NASA'S FUTURE IN SPACE
description: Humans should return to the moon by 2017 and start colonizing Mars by 2027. So the National Commission on Space will recommend to the White House this month. But before assessing this lofty goal, the Administration and Congress must resolve a more pressing issue: What is America's new policy on space, now that the old one is in ruins?

title: CLABIR CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-After a gain of $214,000 on the retirement of debt for the quarter and year. c-Net income and after a loss of $1,128,000 on the retirement of debt for the quarter and year. The latest periods include a pre-tax gain of $929,000 on the sale of common stock of associated and subsidiary companies. The year-earlier quarter and year results include pre-tax gains of $27,693,000 and $36,788,000, respectively, on the sale of stock.

title: KOCH SIGNS HOMOSEXUAL RIGHTS BILL
description: With hundreds of protesters waving banners and shouting slogans outside City Hall, Mayor Koch yesterday signed into law the homosexual rights bill.

title: MAYNARD OIL CO reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-After a tax credit of $1,503,050. c-Net loss after a gain of $280,843 from the termination of a pension plan. The latest year net includes a pre- tax gain of $10.8 million on the sale of a 52 percent stake in Maynard Energy Inc.

title: OF NIJINSKA, PLURALISM AND GAPS IN REVIEWS
