description: ONE of this spring's best dance attractions is not on any stage. It's ''La Nijinska: A Dancer's Legacy,'' the exhibition at the Cooper-Hewitt Museum. Through photographs, costumes and stage designs, it documents the choreographic career of Bronislava Nijinska, from her years with Diaghilev's Ballets Russes de Monte Carlo early in this century to the Royal Ballet's triumphant revivals of her works in the 60's.

title: DO-IT-YOURSELFERS NEED PESTICIDE GUIDANCE
description: To the Editor:

title: MCO HOLDINGS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After income from discontinued operations of $19,500,000, or $2.64 a share, for the quarter and $20,590,000 for the year. c-After income from discontinued operations of $1,227,000, or 17 cents a share, for the quarter and $5,465,000 for the year. The latest fourth quarter and year income from discontinued operations include a gain of $19,420,000 resulting from the sale of the company's gas processing and transmission business, completed in November.

title: COURT BARS 'YUPPIE TAX'
description: A Chicago tax that added 2 percent to health club membership fees has been declared unconstitutional.

title: L.I. POLICE SEE KILLING AS RANDOM AMBUSH
description: Detectives theorized today that someone with a high-powered rifle shot the car tire of a Freeport, L.I., motorist, and then shot the motorist to death after he changed the tire.

title: DIGITAL COMMUNICATIONS ASSOCIATION reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
STAGE: 'SO LONG ON LONELY STREET'
description: IN Sandra Deer's ''So Long on Lonely Street,'' the new play at the Jack Lawrence Theater, an eccentric Southern family gathers at its faded homestead, Honeysuckle Hill, for the funeral of its spinster Aunt Pearl and the reading of her will. A lot is at stake. To some members of the extended Vaughnum family - especially Raymond, a New York soap-opera heartthrob who is described as ''the prodigal son returned'' - the old estate may be ''a heritage'' worth preserving. To others - especially King, the good ole boy who is described as ''greedy'' and ''conniving'' - the manor is prime real estate that might be cleared for a shopping mall. Still another putative heir - Ruth, a rebellious poet who is described as not having ''much use for her heritage'' - doesn't even care what happens to Honeysuckle Hill. Do you?

title: TO-FITNESS INC reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-Net income.

title: ALEC COLLETT, THE MOST FORGOTTEN HOSTAGE OF ALL
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S. SUES COHN FOR $7 MILLION IN TAXES AND FEES
description: Roy M. Cohn, one of the most influential and controversial lawyers in the country, was sued yesterday by the Federal Government for $7 million in income taxes, interest and penalties.

title: U.S. HAS A BIG LEAD IN HANDGUN HOMICIDE
description: To the Editor:

title: CENERGY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes an after-tax writedown of $63.1 million of oil and gas properties and non-recurring charges of $2.7 million for the quarter and 9 months. c-Net income

title: UNIVERSITY GRAPHICS INC reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
JERSEY, IN A MEASLES CRISIS, STEPS UP IMMUNIZATIONS
description: Facing the country's worst measles epidemic since 1983, New Jersey yesterday declared a measles emergency in seven northern counties and directed local health officials to step up efforts to ensure that young children are immunized.

title: Rep. Gallo Seeking 2d Term
description: Representative Dean A. Gallo, a Republican whose district includes parts of Morris, Essex, Warren and Sussex Counties, announced today that he would seek a second term in Congress. Mr. Gallo, a 50 years old, of Parsippany, said he wanted to return to Congress to complete ''a lot of unfinished business,'' including work on balancing the budget, reauthorizing funds to clean up toxic waste and solving highway and mass-transit problems.

title: A MACY BOUTIQUE WITH ELAN
description: It's not exactly the kind of thing that one could miss - Esprit's 6,000-square-foot space on the fourth floor of Macy's Herald Square. And it happens to be one of the liveliest departures for department store boutiques in years.

title: ATE ENTERPRISES INC reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-After a loss from discontinued operations of $241,000 and an extraordinary gain of $877,000. c-After a loss from discontinued operations of $440,000.

title: MAN BITES DOG
description: A man admitted in court today that he bit his dog in the ear after it made a mess in his house. The man, Stuart Smale, 19 years old, of Bristol, said in magistrate's court here that he became angry after his dog, Jade, misbehaved. Mr. Smale said he bit the animal's left ear and threw it out of the house. The court barred Mr. Smale from keeping a dog for the next year and ordered him to pay $33 in veterinary costs.

title: FILM: 'MIX-UP,' 2 ENGLISH BABIES ARE SWITCHED
description: ONE day in November 1936, in a Nottingham (England) nursing home, two respectable, middle-class, expectant mothers, Margaret Wheeler and Blanche Rylatt, as yet unknown to each other, were each delivered of a daughter. Twenty years later, it was generally agreed by all of the interested parties, including the daughters who'd been raised as Valerie Wheeler and Peggy Rylatt, that a terrible muddle had been made. Each mum had been sent home with the other's baby.

title: QADDAFI IS NOT RULED OUT AS THE CULPRIT, U.S. ASSERTS
description: President Reagan today condemned the bombing aboard a Trans World Airlines jet as a ''barbaric action of wanton international terrorism'' and said no group or individual had been ruled out as the attacker.

title: STATE SURVEY OF GEORGIA U. CITES PREFERENTIAL GRADING FOR ATHLETES
description: The Board of Regents of the University System of Georgia today released a special report that showed a pattern of academic abuse in the admission and advancement of student-athletes at the University of Georgia for the last four years.

title: FRIDAY SPORTS
description: Baseball Mets vs. Philadelphia Phillies, at St. Petersburg, Fla. (Television - Channel 9, 7:30 P.M.) Basketball Knicks vs. Celtics, at Boston, 8 P.M. The Celtics have lost only once this season at home, to Portland on Dec. 6, and the Knicks have only beaten Boston once this season, in double overtime on Christmas Day.

title: CITY PROGRAM BRINGING 5 DOCTORS TO POOR AREAS
description: Five young physicians will open medical practices this summer in poor neighborhoods of Brooklyn and Queens under a new city program that offers subsidies to ''physician homesteaders.''

title: STRIKERS BACK AT WORK AT BASES IN PHILIPPINES
description: Picketers holding out against a settlement of a 12-day strike at United States bases in the Philippines agreed Wednesday to return to work, saying, ''We have reached the limitations of our power.''

title: ALABAMA PONDERS LIFE AFTER WALLACE
description: In the corridors of the state's office buildings and along the wide avenues of this gentle Southern capital, there seemed to be a mixture of sadness and relief today, the morning after Gov. George C. Wallace bade a tearful goodbye to Alabama politics.

title: LATIN MISSILES
description: Excerpt from a March 27 floor speech by Senator Dave Durenberger, Republican of Minnesota, in which he warned that if President Reagan provides the Nicaragua rebel organization F.D.N. with advanced new types of air defense missiles, Nicaragua might respond by supplying the missiles to rebels it supports in neighboring El Salvador:

title: Market Place; Anti-Takeover Leeway Urged
description: ALONG with hundreds of other companies that are adopting ''shark repellants'' to protect themselves from a hostile takeover, Dow Jones & Company, which owns The Wall Street Journal, Barron's magazine and other publications, will ask its stockholders to give directors substantially more leeway in deciding how to respond to a takeover bid.

title: DERBY CONTENDERS TO CLASH ON 4 FRONTS
description: This weekend's busy schedule of key Kentucky Derby preps reads like the quarterfinal pairings, complete with rankings, for a tournament:

title: A MUSICAL REDUX: THE SEARCH FOR THE REAL 'NANETTE'
description: FOR many theatergoers, the 1971 Broadway revival of ''No, No, Nanette'' is synonymous with the nostalgia craze it created. That 70's fad saw vintage shows from the teens and 20's campily remounted with contemporary orchestrations, revised librettos and sometimes even new music. But not until this week could musical-comedy buffs hear the real ''No, No, Nanette'' in its complete form with its original orchestrations and book.

title: 2 NEW DESIGNS PUTTING SLIVER BAN TO THE TEST
description: Two Manhattan real-estate developers have discovered a way to poke through a law that was designed to stop builders from putting up towers of 30 or 40 stories in prime residential neighborhoods on slivers of land as narrow as 20 feet.

title: RESTAURANTS
description: BUKHARA is not your typical Indian restaurant. For one, this six-week-old midtown establishment, modeled after the original in New Delhi, is the most handsome and comfortable of its type to come along in years. Moreover, the food, described as ''frontier cuisine'' from the northwest, is a bright and brassy change of pace from more familiar Indian fare around town. Every entree is grilled over charcoal or roasted in the ancient clay oven, the tandoor; diners wear big checkered bibs and eat with their hands. While Bukhara may not be everyone's cup of Darjeeling, I found it over all to be a diverting experience with some spirited food.

title: WASHINGTON SCIENTIFIC CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 9
POPULAR BANCSHARES CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
BLALOCK, AT 40, LOOKS AHEAD
description: Jane Blalock turned 40 years old last Sept. 19 and loved every moment of it. She made it an occasion for the biggest celebration of her life - even bigger than any celebrating done after any of the 29 victories she has achieved in 18 years on the Ladies Professional Golf Association tour.

title: INTERMOUNTAIN POWER IN $325 MILLION OFFERING
description: The Intermountain Power Agency, the most active issuer of tax-exempt bonds in 1985, is offering $325 million of revenue bonds to refund bonds sold in 1981, 1983 and 1985, when interest rates were higher.

title: STEEL UNION VOTE KEY TO MANY PACTS
description: Negotiations between the United Steelworkers of America and major steelmakers will be strongly affected by the results of a vote by LTV Steel Company workers to be tablated starting Friday.

title: TERRORIST SUSPECT MAY HAVE PLANTED BOMB BELOW SEAT
description: An international investigation of a midair explosion aboard a Trans World Airlines jet turned today to the possibility that a known Arab terrorist had planted a bomb aboard the plane.

title: Barzun on Liszt
description: A lecture by Jacques Barzun, entitled ''Liszt's Adventures of the Mind and Heart,'' followed by a concert by the pianist Jorge Bolet, will open a yearlong Liszt centennial at Columbia University tomorrow. The event, which will take place at McMillin Theater (Broadway and 116th Street), is free. Information: 280-3671 or 280-5423.

title: TAKE IT TO THE LIMIT
description: Michael Jordan's playing time has been limited to 14 minutes a half by the Bulls since the star player insisted on resuming play after missing most of the season because of a broken left foot. Last night, Jordan had scored 15 points in the fourth quarter to bring Chicago back from a 96-86 deficit against the Indiana Pacers.

title: SOCIAL SECURITY'S ROLE
description: To the Editor:

title: TAPES MADE PUBLIC IN DONOVAN CASE
description: Secretly recorded tapes that prosecutors contend will provide vital evidence in the larceny and fraud trial of former Labor Secretary Raymond J. Donovan and nine other men were made public yesterday by the Bronx District Attorney's office.

title: FEDERAL CO reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
Yiddish Poetry Reading
description: Five Yiddish poets - Yonia Fain, Bella Gottesman, Jeremiah Hersheles, Elinor Robinson and Moyshe Steingart - will read from their works on Sunday at 2 P.M. at the YIVO Institute for Jewish Studies, 1048 Fifth Avenue, at 86th Street.

title: AUCTIONS
description: A LONG-LOST Charles Willson Peale portrait of David Rittenhouse, the 18th-century Pennsylvania astronomer, clockmaker and statesman, was sold last Saturday at Robert C. Eldred gallery, in East Dennis, Mass., for $451,000 - an auction record for the artist and for any artwork sold in New England. Stanley Sax, a Birmingham, Mich., industrialist and collector of American art, purchased the painting.

title: Crude and Heating Oil Register Slight Gains
description: Prices of crude oil, heating oil and leaded gasoline rose a bit yesterday while unleaded gasoline ended lower.

title: PROGRESSIVE SAVINGS & LOAN ASSN reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss The latest results reflect a $1 million decrease in loan loss reserves and a tax benefit of $523,000. The prior year's results reflect a $5.7 million increase in loan loss reserves and a tax benefit of $269,000.

title: POWER CONVERSION INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
CHINESE AIDES TO STUDY SOVIET NUCLEAR PLANTS
description: Deputy Prime Minister Li Peng said at a news conference today that Chinese officials had discussed nuclear power cooperation at a meeting with Soviet officials in Peking last month and that a Chinese delegation would go to the Soviet Union soon to study nuclear power stations.

title: AT THE MOVIES
description: FOR the Loews State Theater on Broadway between 45th and 46th Streets, time is running out.

title: IN RE QUILLS
description: From Congressional tie-clips to chauffeur-driven limousines, status symbols abound in the capital.

title: INTERNATIONAL MOBILE MAHINES CORP reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
GARBAGE CRISIS: LANDFILLS ARE NEARLY OUT OF SPACE
description: With many landfills in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut nearing capacity or already closed for environmental reasons, more and more communities are facing a garbage crisis, state and municipal officials say.

title: Busing From Brooklyn
description: Downtown Brooklynites who say they want bus service to lower Manhattan have been given four more weeks to prove how earnest they are - by riding the bus.

title: SAXON OIL CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income and after extraordinary gains of $64,994,142, or $7.38 a share, for the quarter and $65,159,179, or $15.33 a share, for the year.

title: ONCE MORE THE AIR TERROR
description: Four more Americans are dead from a fresh assault on civil aviation by faceless killers in the Mediterranean. They were sucked from a Trans World airliner when a bomb exploded in the cabin minutes before it landed in Athens. Soon after, an anonymous caller in Beirut claimed revenge, by the ''Arab Revolutionary Cells,'' for America's military actions against Libya. Do the bombers take extra glee in the murder of a child, mother and grandmother? Is that proof of revolutionary virtue?

title: ESQUIRE PARTNERS ARE SPLITTING UP
description: After nearly 20 years as partners in building a publishing empire that includes Esquire magazine, Chris Whittle and Phillip Moffitt - two Tennessee boys who made it good in New York but still vote in Knoxville - announced yesterday that they would divide their holdings and go their separate ways.

title: Cavalcade Offers To Acquire Tesoro
description: The Cavalcade Asset Corporation, a closely held concern with interests in oil, said yesterday that it was offering to acquire the Tesoro Petroleum Corporation for cash and securities estimated by analysts to be worth $20 to $25 a share, or between about $263 million and about $329 million.

title: BANK REGULATORS SEEK NEW POWERS
description: The three Federal agencies that regulate commercial banks will ask Congress next week for broad powers to let troubled banks be bought by sound banks in other states.

title: CARE PLUS INC reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss

title: LAROUCHE SAVORS FAME THAT MAY RUIN HIM
description: Since his emergence from obscurity two weeks ago, Lyndon H. LaRouche Jr. has used his newfound prominence to promote his extremist theories, clearly relishing the national attention that Democratic leaders hope will destroy his chances of mainstream support.

title: WALL TO WALL SOUND & VIDEO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
LEAP-FROG EXPRESSES FOR IND SUBWAY LINES
description: To the Editor:

title: Advertising; Southwestern Aims At the Yellow Pages
description: High above the southeast corner of Seventh Avenue and 43d Street on a 53-foot-by-96-foot billboard where Sergio Valente long held sway, workmen are putting the finishing touches on the latest tweek of New York Telephone by the guys from Southwestern Bell.

title: AFGHANISTAN AND PAKISTAN AGREE TO RESUME TALKS
description: Afghanistan and Pakistan have agreed to begin their first formal discussion of the sensitive subjects of withdrawal of Soviet troops from Afghanistan and noninterference in Afghanistan's internal affairs, a high-ranking United Nations official announced today.

title: CAR RENTERS ARE LOSING MILEAGE DEALS
description: Drivers who rent cars on weekends in New York City are encountering new limits on free mileage, the elimination of corporate discounts and gasoline for $1.75 a gallon.

title: MUSIC: LINDA FENNIMORE, A JAZZ AND POP VIOLINIST
description: LINDA FENNIMORE, a violinist who is moving from classical training into a jazz and pop repertory, is doing it with a flair of elegance. Accompanied by the pianist Don Coates, Miss Fennimore wears a tailored white dress and a wide-brimmed, round hat tipped seductively over one eye as she plays on Tuesday evenings at Charmant, a restaurant on Columbus Avenue between 90th and 91st Streets.

title: 6 HELD IN TAINTING OF WINE IN ITALY
description: The Italian police arrested six people today in connection with the illegal adding of methyl alcohol to wine.

title: GLOBAL NATURAL RESOURCES PROPERTIES LC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss The company recorded an extraordinary credit of $2.3 million, or 10 cents a share, for 1985 resulting from a tax credit.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article in Sports Pages yesterday about Jens-Peter Berndt, an East German swimmer who is seeking American Citizenship, incorrectly listed the party affiliation of Senator Jeramiah Denton of Alabama. He is a Republican.

title: AMERICAN HOIST & DERRICK CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 15
THE U.S. DENIES PUTTING PRESSURE ON HONDURANS
description: The Reagan Administration today denied assertions by a senior Honduran official that the United States had deliberately exaggerated the seriousness of Nicaragua's recent border raid, and had pressed Honduras to ask for $20 million in emergency aid.

title: SHL SYSTEMHOUSE reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
description: b-Includes a $5,733,000 gain on the sale of subsidiaries.

title: Mellon Backed On Thrift Unit
description: Legislation was signed today to allow the Mellon Bank Corporation of Pittsburgh to buy a bankrupt Maryland thrift institution and begin commercial banking operations in Maryland.

title: SCHEDULE OF SCREENINGS FOR FILM SERIES AT MODERN MUSEUM
description: New Directors/New Films opens tonight at the Museum of Modern Art's Roy and Niuta Titus Theaters, 11 West 53d Street. All films will be shown at the museum. Single tickets are $4.50; there is a series ticket of $75. Information: 708-9500 or 877-1800, extension 489. Additional screenings may be scheduled later for those that are sold out.

title: EMINENT TENOR WAS 75
description: Sir Peter Pears, a British tenor celebrated for his profound and original interpretations, died of a heart attack yesterday in Aldeburgh, England. He was 75 years old and lived in Aldeburgh.

title: U.S. PLANS TO CONDUCT NUCLEAR TEST SOON
description: The United States plans to carry out an underground nuclear test soon, perhaps as early as April 8, Administration officials said today.

title: CALLED TO ACCOUNT
description: Melvin Lowe, who resigned as chairman of the City University of New York's Student Senate amid charges that he misused Senate funds, has surfaced to deny the charges and accuse his detractors of ''character assassination.''

title: AT CENTER, HOPES FOR APPROACH TO LABOR DISPUTES
description: Earlier this week, union jurisdictional disputes erupted over cleaning and security contracts at the Jacob K. Javits Convention Center, disputes that under ordinary circumstances could have threatened to delay the center's opening yesterday. But the center opened on time as the grievances were heard by the center's special labor arbitrator.

title: FILM: 'TOXIC AVENGER'
description: TROMAVILLE, N.J., a town whose corrupt public officials sit around stuffing themselves with junk food and collecting graft, proudly bills itself as ''The Toxic Waste Capital of the World.'' Even the beautiful people at the local health spa are moral monsters whose favorite sport is running down children in fast cars. In between pumping iron and making assignations in the sauna, these demented health nuts also delight in tormenting poor Melvin (Mark Torgl), the gym's mop boy, who is almost a dead ringer for Mad magazine's Alfred E. Neuman.

title: PROVOCATIVE PAINTINGS BY GREGOIRE MULLER
description: THE new work of Gregoire Muller should be seen. His gift is impressive. So is his curiosity and nerve, and his ambition to make paintings that will not back down from anything and that will engage us in the fullest possible way. His exhibition at the Gruenebaum Gallery is one of the most challenging this season.

title: OFFICERS FEARED BY QADDAFI REPORTEDLY CLOSE RANKS WITH HIM AGAINST U.S.
description: When Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi, Libya's leader, prepares to fly inside his own country, two planes await him on the tarmac, according to witnesses. Only the Colonel knows which plane he will use, they say. The other then takes off as a decoy.

title: Dominion Textile
description: Dominion Textile Inc. of Montreal said that its American subsidiary, Dominion Textile America Inc., had withdrawn its sweetened offer to buy Avondale Mills for $26 a share, or $108 million. The company said it had decided to withdraw after analyzing a later bid of $28.20 a share, of $112.9 million, made by AM Acquisition Inc., a group of investors led by Walton Monroe Mills Inc. and the First Boston Corporation.

title: CHRISTOPHER CARRIUOLO
description: Christopher W. Carriuolo, former executive vice president of Heublein Inc., died of a heart attack Monday in a hospital in Sri Lanka. He was 65 years old and lived in Farmington, Conn.

title: ACTON CORP reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
WEEKENDER GUIDE
description: Friday THE FITTEST OF THE FLORA The first flowers of spring are appealing wherever they bloom. But there's something especially heartwarming about an urban blossom. The small, delicate creature defies the odds, emerging pink or blue or white amid patches of gritty soil and in window boxes cornered in perpetual shade. This weekend these hardy flowers will receive due recognition in ''April Showers, City Flowers.'' On display will be hundreds of flowers and plants that thrive in urban settings, such as geraniums, African violets, daffodils, lilies of the valley, tulips and azaleas. Numerous horticultural groups will exhibit their collaborations with nature, including the Pit Society, which specializes in urban vegetables, the Begonia Society and the Cacti and Succulent Society. The show will also feature educational displays for gardeners on overcoming the constraints of window sills, flower boxes, tree beds, courtyards and indoor lighting. A few types of flowers will be on sale. The show, sponsored by Village Visiting Neighbors, is open today from 1 to 9 P.M. and tomorrow from 11:30 A.M. to 8 P.M. at Public School 41 on Avenue of the Americas at 11th Street. Proceeds will benefit services for the elderly. Admission is $3 ($1.50 for the elderly today from 1 to 5 P.M.). Information: 929-5869.

title: PHILADELPHIA INQUIRY IS BEGUN ON ROW HOUSE BUILDING LAG
description: District Attorney Ronald D. Castille has begun an investigation into the city's rebuilding of 61 row houses destroyed in the May 13 police confrontation with the radical group Move.

title: GUITAR TWIN BILL
description: Once upon a time, the world of the classical guitar seemed the personal kingdom of Andres Segovia. He was to the guitar what Jascha Heifetz was to the violin, with one major difference - Mr. Segovia had no close competitors.

title: SOUND WAREHOUSE reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
SERVOTRONICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a tax credit of $537,000. c-After a tax credit of $437,000 and a non-recurring extraordinary charge of $243,000.

title: Seagram Inquiry
description: The Seagram Company expressed an interest in acquiring Hiram Walker Resources Ltd.'s spirits and wine operations for a price ''substantially'' above that of any other potential purchaser the day before Walker announced another deal, court documents show. Walker agreed to sell its liquor business to Allied-Lyons P.L.C. for $2.6 billion (Canadian), the equivalent of about $1.86 billion, in a plan that was announced Tuesday. The Seagram interest was disclosed in court documents filed here by Olympia & York Developments Ltd., which is seeking an injunction to block the Walker sale.

title: ELDER-BEERMAN STORES CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 2
description: b-After an extraordinary credit of $1,998,000, or 56 cents a share, from a revision to the employee pension plans for the quarter and year. The share earnings reflect a 15 percent stock dividend distributed in January.

title: FILM: 'EYES OF FIRE,' A MORALITY TALE
description: IN a frontier forest, human souls are drawn into trees and bark-covered faces emerge like bas-reliefs from the tree trunks; the sky sends down charred bones along with rainwater; a red-haired witch swallows a luminous yellow toad. ''Eyes of Fire,'' which opens today at the RKO Warner Twin and other theaters, is an imagistic morality tale written, produced and directed by Avery Crounse, a still photographer. Set in 1750, it follows a small group of settlers who wander into a haunted valley ''where the devil-witch lives.''

title: WALKER TELECOMMUNICAIONS reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income

title: U.S. TO GIVE HAITI MORE MILITARY AID
description: A high-ranking American official said today that the United States intended to increase military and economic assistance to Haiti and to help it recover some of the vast riches stolen from the country by the Duvalier Government.

title: Advertising; Chiquita's Fruit Pops Campaign
description: ALTHOUGH the two 30-second commericals created by Ammirati & Puris for the Chiquita Fruit and Juice Pops and the Chiquita Fruit and Cream Pops feature a lot of kids, they were only invited to the party to illustrate the junk food that kids put away in a contrast to the simple goodness offered by Chiquita.

title: Night of Nations
description: The site is Manhattan, but the food, music and dance will be European at the Night of Nations tomorrow at International House, Riverside Drive and 124th Street.

title: OLLA INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-Includes loss from discontinued operations of $77,066 and a los on disposal of discontinued handbag operations of $611,000. c-Net income and includes loss from discontinued operations of $148,861.

title: AN OPEN CITY COUNCIL
description: To the Editor:

title: Roaches at City Hall
description: Yet another hidden problem came to light at City Hall yesterday.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: FRIDAY, APRIL 4, 1986
description: International A known Arab terrorist may have placed a bomb aboard the Trans World Airlines jet that exploded over Greece Wednesday, killing four Americans and wounding nine, according to a team of international investigators in Athens. Earlier, Italy's Foreign Minister said the terrorist had been aboard the airliner on an earlier flight. [ Page A1, Column 6. ]

title: STINGER MISSLES' USEFULNESS FOR CONTRAS IS QUESTIONED
description: Diplomats and military officers said this week that they doubted whether the acquisition of advanced antiaircraft weapons by the Nicaraguan rebels would be sufficient to turn the tide of battle in their favor.

title: ART: EXTENSIVE SHOW OF ALECHINSKY PAINTINGS
description: THOUGH the object in 1977 of a mammoth exhibition at the Carnegie Institute in Pittsburgh, and slated for a retrospective at the Guggenheim Museum in February of next year, the 59-year-old Belgian painter Pierre Alechinsky is curiously untouched by the promotional machine. Represented in New York by the Lefebre Gallery for more than a quarter of a century, he has a way of vanishing into that privileged burrow and calling attention to himself as little as possible.

title: Dining Out Guide: Midtown (West Side)
description: Following is a summary of reviews of restaurants that have appeared in The New York Times. Stars are followed by the date of original publication. Prices are current, and only weekend hours are given. AMERICAN FESTIVAL CAFE, #20 West 50th

title: JAPAN PANEL URGES SHIFT ON TRADE
description: Japan must reshape its economy to make it less dependent on exports and more amenable to greater domestic spending, especially on imports, according to an advisory council to Prime Minister Yasuhiro Nakasone.

title: Harry Gross Is Suicide; Bookmaker in '51 Case
description: Harry Gross, a bookmaker convicted in 1951 of running a multimillion-dollar gambling operation with New York City policemen, has committed suicide, the police said today. He was 71 years old.

title: NETS SLIPPING IN PLAYOFF DRIVE
description: Both the Nets and the Washington Bullets came into Byrne Meadowlands Arena tonight needing a victory. The Nets needed it to solidify the sixth playoff spot and the Bullets needed it to slice the Nets' lead over them to a half-game.

title: AMERICANS CANCELING SOME MEDITERRANEAN TOURS
description: Tour operations and travel representatives yesterday reported a scattering of canceled Mediterranean bookings but no abrupt response to Wednesday's suspected terrorist bombing of a Trans World Airlines jet over Greece.

title: SCREEN: 'THE WAY IT IS'
description: ERIC MITCHELL, the director and writer of ''The Way It Is,'' must intend for it to become a midnight-movie classic. What other excuse can there be for so vacant an enterprise?

title: Bancroft Prizes Given For 2 Books on History
description: The 1986 Bancroft Prizes in American history, given by the trustees of Columbia University for books of exceptional merit and distinction in American history and diplomacy, have been awarded to Kenneth T. Jackson for ''Crabgrass Frontier: The Suburbanization of the United States'' (Oxford University Press) and Jacqueline Jones, author of ''Labor of Love, Labor of Sorrow: Black Women, Work and the Family from Slavery to the Present'' (Basic Books). Both winners received a prize of $4,000.

title: GREECE SENSES A THREAT
description: The bombing incident Wednesday is likely to deal a serious blow to the already troubled Greek tourism industry, Greece's largest source of foreign currency earnings, Greek officials and Western diplomats said today.

title: Mired in Queens
description: Graffiti so thick that they keep a subway train from running?

title: 87 HELD IN CAMPUS PROTEST AGAINST SOUTH AFRICA POLICY
description: Protests on the University of California campus against the school's investments in concerns that do business with South Africa led to the arrest of 87 students early today.

title: INTERGROUP CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes extraordinary tax credits of $208,000, or 18 cents a share, for the quarter and $330,000, or 28 cents a share, for the 6 months.

title: DEREGULATION'S FAULT?
description: To the Editor:

title: VERDI HAS A NEW VOICE IN OPERA'S APRILE MILLO
description: Opera lovers will have more opportunities than expected to see and hear Aprile Millo, the young soprano who won rave reviews as Elizabeth in ''Don Carlo'' the other night at the Met. Miss Millo was originally scheduled to sing four performances of the Verdi opera, but she has picked up four more since Mara Zampieri bowed out for health reasons.

title: SALEM CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income

title: Mortgage Rates Fall
description: Interest levels on fixed-rate home mortgages fell sharply between early February and early March, the Federal Home Loan Bank Board said yesterday. Rates on adjustable mortgages also declined, but less sharply.

title: SUPER VALU STORES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 22
description: b-Includes net from discontinued operations of $73,000 for the quarter and $23,950,000 for the year.

title: MARLO THOMAS AS FORMER MENTAL-HOSPITAL PATIENT
description: ''NOBODY'S CHILD,'' the television movie on CBS Sunday evening at 9, gives Marlo Thomas the type of true-story role that not only allows but also demands a bravura performance. Miss Thomas delivers impressively. She portrays Marie Balter, an extraordinary woman who, after spending 20 years in a Massachusetts mental institution, went to college and, in the mid-1970's, earned an M.A. from Harvard University and founded the Balter Institute, a center for psychiatric treatment and counseling.

title: ESPRIT SYSTEMS reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
description: b-Net loss

title: BANKER'S NOTE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 1
description: b-Net loss

title: BRONX DEMOCRATS BACK FRIEDMAN'S DECISION TO REMAIN AS LEADER DESPITE CHARGES
description: Bronx Democratic district leaders and public officials last night overwhelmingly endorsed Stanley M. Friedman's decision to remain as Bronx Democratic leader as he faces state bribery charges.

title: DOUGHTIE'S FOODS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 28
BUSINESS DIGEST: FRIDAY, APRIL 4, 1986
description: The Economy

title: F.C.C. IN PLAN TO BRING MORE LISTENERS TO AM
description: In the start of an effort to bring listeners back to AM radio, the Federal Communications Commission staff today recommended a comprehensive relaxation of regulations governing AM stations.

title: Ex-Treasury Aide Joins Nomura Securities
description: Nomura Securities International Inc., the giant Japanese securities house, appeared to bolster its case for designation as a primary dealer of government securities yesterday when it announced that John J. Niehenke, former deputy assistant secretary of the Treasury for Federal finance, had been named senior vice president in its United States Goverment securities department.

title: KLEINERT'S INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 1
description: b-After tax credits of $137,000 for the latest quarter and $180,000 for the year-earlier period.

title: WHAT'S THE BEEF?
description: Consumers' ignorance about fast food is hazardous to their health. Yet the Federal Government resists efforts to require the purveyors of burgers, fries and shakes to disclose their ingredients. It's therefore up to the states to mandate disclosure. New York's Consumer Protection Director, Richard Kessel, responds with a sensible proposal.

title: NEVEX GOLD COMPANY INC reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-The company reported no sales since it began its gold recovery operations in March 1985. The latest year loss was primarily the result of a writedown of certain assets related to its Haywood-Santiago property in Nevada.

title: OPTELECOM INC reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss

title: ALEC COLLETT, THE MOST FORGOTTEN HOSTAGE OF ALL
description: To the Editor:

title: SISK, GARDENHIRE SENT DOWN BY METS
description: The Mets did not trade Ed Lynch or anybody else today. Instead, they made the final cuts in the team by sending three players to the minor leagues: Doug Sisk, once their premier right-handed relief pitcher; Ron Gardenhire, the backup shortstop, and Ed Hearn, the rookie catcher.

title: Chilton at CBGB
description: The songwriter Alex Chilton will perform tonight at CBGB, 315 Bowery, at Bleecker Street, on a quadruple bill that begins at approximately 10 o'clock. Tickets are $8; for exact set times, the number is 982-4052.

title: MORE TRANSPLANTS/MORE CONTROL LEGACIES FOR LIFE
description: New York State's ''required request'' law, in effect since Jan. 1, is already making more organs and tissue available for transplants. The Eye-Bank For Sight Restoration, for example, reports that donations of corneas are up 47 percent this year.

title: Continental Illinois Will Settle Suit
description: The Continental Illinois Corporation said that it had agreed to settle a class action alleging violation of securities laws.

title: PLAINS RESOURCES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The company said share earnings were reduced by preferred dividend requirements of $231,084 in the latest quarter and $451,087 in the latest year. There were no similar requirements in the year-ago periods.

title: Southwestern Bell
description: The Southwestern Bell Telephone Company is offering $450 million of 8 5/8 percent debentures due 2020 at a price of 96.76, to yield 8.93 percent through underwriters led by Salomon Brothers Inc. The 34-year debentures are noncallable for the first five years and are rated Aa-2 by Moody's and AA- by S.&P. They yield about 1 1/2 percentage points more than 30-year Treasury bonds.

title: WORLD'S A STAGE FOR '49 CLASS
description: For Harvard Business School's class of 1949 - dubbed ''the class the dollars fell on'' in Fortune magazine's 25th-reunion profile -media attention is old hat.

title: PLYMOUTH RUBBER CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 1
CAPITALS WIN, 4-2
description: Lou Franceschetti's goal at 1 minute 12 seconds of the third period led Washington to a 4-2 victory over the Hartford Whalers tonight and moved the Capitals into a first-place tie with the Flyers in the Patrick Division with two games left. The Whalers failed to clinch a playoff spot, but remained in fourth place in the Adams Division, 2 points ahead of Buffalo. Each team has two games left.

title: Otis Clay to Perform
description: The soul singer Otis Clay and his Chicago-based band will perform this weekend at Tramps, 125 East 15th Street (777-5077). Sets begin at 9:30 P.M. and midnight, tonight and tomorrow; there is a $10 cover and a two-drink minimum.

title: Economic Scene; Oil and Dollar: Twin Concerns
description: FALLING oil prices and the falling dollar are worrying United States policy makers.

title: MANSION IN WESTCHESTER NOW A PROJECT'S CLUBHOUSE
description: The mansion, with its stately graystone facade, has presided over the wooded estate since the 1920's. But in the last 40 years, as it stood vacant, caretakers painted some of its grand interior spaces combined shades of purple and green.

title: U.S. QUIETLY APPROVED THE SALE OF GENETICALLY ALTERED VACCINE
description: The Department of Agriculture acknowledged today that it had granted a Nebraska company the world's first license to market a living, genetically altered virus, and scientists in and out of the Government questioned whether it had followed guidelines intended to safeguard the public.

title: FREESTYLE MARK BY BIONDI
description: Matt Biondi, a University of California junior from Moraga, Calif., broke the American record for the 50-yard freestyle tonight as the National Collegiate Athletic Association's 63d annual men's swimming championships began. Coming off the only turn, Biondi opened a slight lead over Tom Jager of U.C.L.A. and beat him by 10 inches in 19.22 seconds.

title: STEINBRENNER CALLS YANKS CONTENDERS, BUT NOT WINNERS
description: Expressing concern over his team's lack of hitting, George Steinbrenner said today he could not pick the Yankees to win their division championship. He then went into a meeting with Manager Lou Piniella and the coaches and warned them about the necessity of getting off to a fast start.

title: EX-CHANCELLOR VOICES CRITICISM OF WALDHEIM
description: Bruno Kreisky, the former Chancellor of Austria, today criticized Kurt Waldheim, the former United Nations Secretary General who is running for President, for decades of silence on his wartime activities and said Austria needs a head of state who is above reproach.

title: GUERRERO HURT
description: Less than a week after he was released by the Yankees, two days after he became 47 years old and just before he would have become a free agent, Phil Niekro, the oldest player in the majors, was back in business yesterday, agreeing to a one-year contract with the Cleveland Indians.

title: CAM-OR INC reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
MESTEK INC reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-The company's first full year of operations was 1985 after it emerged from Chapter 11 reorganization.

title: FOREST CITY ENTERPRISES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-Includes gains from the sale of properties of $645,000 for the quarter and $1,775,000 for the year. c-Includes a loss of $95,000 for the quarter and a gain from the sale of properties of $1,009,000 for the year.

title: IMASCO SET TO ACQUIRE TRUSTCO
description: Imasco Ltd., Canada's biggest cigarette producer, said yesterday that by April 15 it expected to take over the Canada Trustco Mortgage Company, one of the largest financial institutions in Canada. The complex deal would involve nearly $1.9 billion - all or almost all in cash.

title: Tacoma Publisher
description: The Tribune Publishing Company, publisher of The Tacoma News Tribune, has been sold to McClatchy Newspapers and Viacom International Inc. McClatchy, owner of newspapers and other media properties in California, Nevada, Washington and Alaska, would acquire The News Tribune. Viacom, a New York-based cable television company, is buying the company's cable assets.

title: British Woolworth Rejects Takeover
description: Woolworth Holdings P.L.C. of Britain, a retailer that formerly was part of F. W. Woolworth & Company of the United States, rejected a takeover bid from another British retailer, Dixons Group P.L.C.

title: AYATOLLAH KAZEM SHARIAT-MADARI OF IRAN, 87
description: Kazem Shariat-Madari, an Iranian Islamic leader who helped overthrow Shah Mohammed Riza Pahlevi but was later put under house arrest on accusations of complicity in plotting against the Khomeini Government, died of liver cancer yesterday in a hospital in Teheran. He was 87 years old and had been hospitalized for more than a month after suffering from kidney cancer for two years.

title: HALLEY'S COMET
description: Halley's Comet will rise over the New York City area at 2:15 A.M. today and set at 7:10 A.M. Tomorrow it will rise at 2:07 A.M. and set at 6:33 A.M.

title: THE WRONG SIDE OF THE TRACKS
description: Two sets of train tracks run parallel to the southern border of Hialeah Park, and together they symbolize how the changing demographics of the Miami area have threatened the prosperity of Hialeah, arguably the country's most beautiful race track and once the home of all important winter racing.

title: DCNY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The share earnings reflect the 2-for- 1 stock split effective May 20, 1985.

title: Accord on Marijuana For Cancer Is Reached
description: The Government reached agreement today with a group concerned with drug laws to allow marketing of a synthetic marijuana pill for patients undergoing chemotherapy for cancer.

title: FOOD LION INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 22
PLAYING PEORIA
description: The House of Representatives' version of the proposed tax revision is so voluminous that it is not surprising that little bits and pieces are still being discovered by those willing to take the time to try to read between the lines.

title: Frank Foster Band
description: The saxophonist Frank Foster will lead a 12-piece band today at 9:30 and 11 P.M. at the Terrace Room of Newark Symphony Hall, 1020 Broad Street in Newark, N.J. (201-643-4550). Admission is $10, including a free drink.

title: PRESIDENTIAL LIFE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Including a realized investment loss of $2,245,279 for the quarter and a realized investment gain of $160,721 for the year. c-Including realized investment gains of $3,049 for the quarter and $819,711 for the year. Share earnings reflect 2-for-1 stock split paid Jan. 10. Latest year net reflects a provision for deferred income taxes of $984,000.

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL BALTIMORE (AL) - Released Wayne Gross, third baseman.

title: THE U.N. TODAY:April 4, 1986; GENERAL ASSEMBLY
description: Human Rights Committee - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: WHITE HOUSE FINDS NO PRESSURE TO LAUNCH
description: The White House said today that several of President Reagan's aides were in telephone contact with the space agency before the launching of the shuttle Challenger but that there was no evidence the communications entailed pressure on the launching schedule.

title: GEORGE G. KIRSTEIN, EX-PUBLISHER
description: George G. Kirstein, the publisher and principal owner of The Nation magazine from 1955 to 1965 and a former health insurance executive, died of a heart attack yesterday at his home in Mamaroneck, N.Y. He was 76 years old.

title: ACCORD ON CHEMICAL WEAPONS
description: Negotiators at the Geneva conference on disarmament have reached a preliminary agreement on commercial chemicals that would be included in a proposed treaty banning the production, storage and use of chemical weapons, United States officials said today.

title: RANGERS CLOSE IN ON PLAYOFFS
description: Early in the season, John Vanbiesbrouck would sit in his locker stall after games, still sweaty, his shoulders slumped, the weight of the earth - or at least, the weight of his team - clearly on him. He would speak about how his teammates needed him and about how he had let them down.

title: MATHILDE BECKMANN
description: Mathilde Beckmann, the widow of the painter Max Beckmann, died of pneumonia Sunday at a hospital in Jacksonville, Fla. She was 82 years old.

title: PROSECUTORS ACT TO JOIN FORCES IN TAXI INQUIRY
description: The United States Attorney in Brooklyn and the Queens District Attorney announced yesterday that their offices would join forces in the investigation of the New York City Taxi and Limousine Commission.

title: EXPERTS SAY CAIRO AIRPORT'S SECURITY IS MEDIOCRE
description: Airport security in Cairo, where a suspect in Wednesday's midair bombing may have boarded a Trans World Airlines jet, is regarded as mediocre by security experts, Government and airline officials said yesterday.

title: U.S. CRIME PANEL: DISCORD TO THE END
description: The President's Commission on Organized Crime, born amid controversy three years ago, completed its work this week with several members of the panel locked in dispute.

title: Diner's Journal
description: LA BOHEME, a congenial new French bistro at 24 Minetta Lane in Greenwich Village, is a good, moderately priced option for dinner in this animated neighborhood. It is a comfortable spot that melds country French and high tech - barn-board wainscotting, pink banquettes, bare test-tube-shape lights dangling overhead and an open kitchen.

title: NEWPARK RESOURCES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes losses from discontinued operations of $1,700,000 for the quarter and $3,200,000 for the year. c-Includes losses from discontinued operations of $4,100,000 for the quarter and $6,700,000 for the year.

title: NEW VATICAN EFFORT ON THEOLOGY SEEN
description: Pope John Paul II has opened a new phase in his campaign against some forms of liberation theology, seeking to tie Christianity's commitment to the poor - the core of the theology's teachings - to a traditional approach to Catholic doctrine.

title: PIANO: BOLET IN PROGRAM OF BALLADES
description: IT has always been a special pleasure to hear Jorge Bolet play the piano. The tall, ambassadorial-looking virtuoso's technique is so brilliant and his control over it so complete that one could always attend his recitals in full confidence of being thrilled by a genuine master of the art of pianism. There was a time, however, when Mr. Bolet's strength and keyboard command tended to take over from his musicality. He could leave his awed listeners with the feeling that they had heard an exciting pianist, but not primarily an exciting musician.

title: 5 LATIN PIANISTS TAKING SALSA'S BEAT UPTOWN
description: ''THE last mambo!'' Eddie Palmieri instructs the musicians set up at Tom Cat Studios in Chelsea. ''Ba-DA-duh-AH!'' He sits at the piano and rolls off a powerful left-hand vamp; then, as trumpets and trombones punch out a theme, he leaps up to conduct, semaphoring with both arms and, when the rhythm kicks in, hopping back and forth, both feet off the ground. By the time he waves the final note to a cutoff, everyone in the studio is dancing along.

title: IS PAROLE STILL A WORKABLE CONCEPT?
description: The institution of parole is under siege. Judicial fixed sentencing would abolish it, and recent court rulings have held that parole boards may be liable for damages when parolees are charged with new crimes. Is parole still a workable concept?

title: KLEER-VU INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss

title: BRIEFS
description: * American Information Technologies Corp., Chicago, said it had signed a five-year equipment and services contract with American Telephone and Telegraph Co. valued at more than $140 million.

title: EQUITY FUNDS UP SHARPLY IN QUARTER
description: The first-quarter performance of equity mutual funds reached the double-digit level for the second consecutive quarter as sales and assets of mutual funds continued to soar at record levels.

title: JUDGE DELAYS FINE TO LET NEWSPAPER FILE APPEAL
description: A judge today stayed a $100,000 fine and a suspended prison term he gave The Providence Journal's top editor while the newspaper appealed his contempt finding.

title: Head of NBC Replies To Criticism by CBS
description: Grant Tinker, the chairman of NBC, yesterday defended an NBC News report that suggested a connection between the head of CBS Records, Waltern Yetnikoff, and allegations of payola in the music business.

title: SELL PROGRAMS ARE CITED AS DOW DECLINES 28.86
description: The stock market fell broadly yesterday, with the Dow Jones industrial average dragged down 28.86 points by several large sell programs.

title: BGS SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
STANDARD-BRED PACERS & TROTTERS INC reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
PLAYING BOSTON
description: Word has trickled out of the Justice Department that William F. Weld, the United States Attorney in Boston, is the leading candidate to succeed D. Lowell Jensen as Deputy Attorney General.

title: SEND 'EM A MESSAGE? HE SURE DID.
description: Has Ronald Reagan pushed American politics to the right? Such realignment may have occurred, but if so it is not, with all respect, Mr. Reagan's doing. A generation has come of political age believing that the rightward swing of the 1980's represents a cyclical reaction against the liberal 1960's. To understand the superficiality of that view, please contemplate the career of George Wallace.

title: 8 Louisiana Bonds Are Downgraded
description: The Standard & Poor's Corporation yesterday downgraded ratings for eight series of bonds issued by the state of Louisiana and also lowered the credit rating for two Texas banks because of the sharp decline in oil prices.

title: TOTAL SYSTEM SERVICES reports earnings for Qtr to March 1
description: Share earnings reflect a 2-for-1 stock split payable May 1.

title: GRUDGE MATCH
description: It's been five years and almost 100 fights since Mark Breland, then an undefeated 17-year-old amateur with a couple of dozen bouts under his belt, took on 22-year-old Darryl Anthony, a 100-bout veteran, in the Amateur Athletic Union's boxing championships. A lot has happened to Breland since then, including his Olympic welterweight gold medal in 1984, but, now an undefeated professional, he can still give a virtual jab-by-jab account of what happened in that 1981 fight.

title: Wells Fargo To Shed Assets
description: Wells Fargo & Company said yesterday that, as expected, it would shed $5.9 billion in assets as part of its acquisition of the Crocker National Corporation.

title: G.O.P. SEES 3 SENATE RACES AS CRUCIAL
description: Republicans are counting heavily on holding Senate seats in three Southern states in contests that could be among the most hard-fought and significant of the 1986 campaign year.

title: THEATER: 'DAUGHTERS,' BY JOHN MORGAN EVANS
description: FIVE women in four generations of an Italian-American family in Brooklyn are the quarrelsome characters in John Morgan Evans's ''Daughters,'' opening last night at the Westside Arts Theater. Watching the play, one cannot suppress the feeling that it is a two-hour pilot for television and that the theater is succumbing to sitcom-itis. As long as it holds to that genre, ''Daughters'' provides a modicum of amusement, but, repeatedly, it has delusions of being something more -a colorful family play on the order of ''Crimes of the Heart.'' In that dramatic league, it is about as serious as soap opera.

title: SPAIN STANDS FIRM ON BAR TO MARCOS
description: Spain's Foreign Minister said today that his Government would not grant asylum to Ferdinand E. Marcos despite requests from Washington to do so.

title: REPRISAL
description: When Bobby Shull, a right-hander for West Lincoln High School in Lincolnton, N.C., pitched a no-hitter against archrival East Lincoln a while back, James Grant got the victory.

title: SALANT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes an income tax benefit of $376,000. c-Includes a provision of $6,600,000 related to the closure and loss on disposal of certain manufacturing facilities and withdrwal from certain product lines.

title: CENTURY BUSINESS CREDIT reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss

title: AMPAD CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 1
MAX & ERMA'S RESTAURANTS reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 16
description: b-Net income

title: REAGAN'S BILLY CARTER
description: The growing Reagan access-peddling mess was presaged in this space four years ago, in a suggestion that Michael Deaver, public relations man to the President, might be ''advertising for clients'' in his complaints about the hardship of living on a White House salary.

title: SWENSEN'S INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a charge of $3,475,000 as a provision for doubtful long-term notes receivable.

title: Advertising; US Sprint Goes to J.W.T.
description: J. Walter Thompson's San Francisco office has won the business of US Sprint Communications with an advertising budget of more than $70 million.

title: ARMED MAN KILLS 2 AND TAKES HOSTAGE
description: A heavily armed man who was apparently months behind in his rent shot and killed his landlord and a police officer today, then took an elderly neighbor hostage and barricaded himself in an apartment, the authorities said.

title: THE EVENING HOURS
description: The sight of a bubble-gum pink 1959 Cadillac convertible, 18 feet long, was irresistible, so William S. Paley jumped behind the wheel and took three friends for an imaginary spin. He posed for ''prom pictures'' in the car and then signed autograph books.

title: At Home in Harlem
description: The Dance Theater of Harlem had never had a season in Harlem. Now, as it ends a two-week sold-out run at the Aaron Davis Center, at Convent Avenue and 134 Street, the company has proved that Harlem can be as welcoming as Lincoln Center.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''After much prayerful consideration, I feel that I must say I have climbed my last political mountain.'' - George Corley Wallace. [ A1:3. ]

title: POP AND JAZZ GUIDE
description: Karen Akers, the Ballroom, 253 West 28th Street (244-3005). The statuesque singer with a haunting reedy alto full of strange, subtle resonances has returned to the Ballroom, where she sold out a two-week engagement last fall, for a monthlong visit. Miss Akers, whose compressed emotionality suggests a ladylike Edith Piaf with folk-pop and Broadway crosscurrents, has added to her program some material from the London hit show ''Les Miserables,'' as well as a rendition of ''Somewhere,'' sung in French. High points include ''I Know Him So Well'' from ''Chess,'' and ''You Can Have the TV'' by the talented Craig Carnelia. Led by the keyboardist-arranger Mark Hummel, Miss Akers's backup includes Jay Leonhart on bass and Andry Drelles on woodwinds. Class cabaret of the highest order. Shows tonight and tomorrow are at 9 and 11. There is a $15 music charge ($25 for ringside seating) and a two-drink minimum.

title: Money Fund Assets Up
description: Assets of the nation's 360 money market mutual funds increased by $681 million, to $217.16 billion, for the week ended Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute said yesterday. Assets of the 85 institutional funds rose $60.5 million, to $57.71 billion, and assets of the 188 general purpose funds were up $350.5 million, to $59.85 billion. The 81 broker-dealer funds increased $270 million, to $99.60 billion.

title: GERRY FAUST STARTS OVER WITH AKRON
description: A painting of the football stadium, Gerry Faust said with his usual ebullience, will eventually hang on the wall behind his desk. It will add a familiar splash of blue and gold to the office, colors Faust has worn throughout his coaching career. The colors represent a rare unbroken thread in an occupation woven in uncertainty, one in which all positions are considered temporary. The colors are a nice touch, but not necessary to make Faust feel at home at the University of Akron.

title: COMP-U-CARD INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for Year to Jan 31
description: b-After a tax credit of $3,589,000, or 34 cents a share, and includes a $2,348,000 pre-tax charge for non- recurring acquisition costs. c-After a loss from discontinued operations of $1,659,000 and a tax credit of $1,809,000, or 18 cents a share. The prior year results were restated to reflect the acquisition of Financial Institutional Services Inc., effective Dec. 9, 1985, which was accounted for using the pooling-of-interest method.

title: DESPITE ASSURANCES, THE SKIES ARE NOT GETTING SAFER
description: To the Editor:

title: PUBLISHERS EQUIPMENT INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income Previous quarter and year nets include a $45,000 pre-tax charge from tax adjustment.

title: CHICAGO JUDGE ORDERS RECOUNT IN PIVOTAL WAR
description: Election officials must recount write-in ballots in a pivotal ward race in which an ally of Mayor Harold Washington holds a narrow lead, a judge ordered today.

title: BALLET: 'FORCE FIELD, BY LAURA DEAN, IN PREMIERE BY THE JOFFREY
description: ROBERT JOFFREY was the first artistic director to invite the experimental modern-dance choreographers who emerged from the 1960's and the 1970's to work with a major ballet company.

title: STRIKER PETROLEUM CORP reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
I.R.S. in Shape For Final Rush
description: The Internal Revenue Service expects to receive more than 45 million personal tax returns during the next 12 days.

title: FINANCIAL SCANDAL LINGERING IN OHIO
description: When Gov. Richard F. Celeste ordered Ohio's 70 privately insured savings institutions shut for 11 days in March 1985, Debi Rickert had $8,000 on deposit at the troubled Home State Savings Bank of Cincinnati.

title: SCREEN: 'DONA HERLINDA'
description: ''DONA HERLINDA AND HER SON'' is a deftly told anecdote about a mother in Guadalajara who creates a menage a cinq that satisfies the needs of all parties -homosexual, heterosexual and maternal. The Mexican film, directed and written by Jaime Humberto Hermosillo, will be shown as part of the New Directors/New Films festival at the Museum of Modern Art tonight at 8:30 and tomorrow at 1 P.M. It will open at the Waverly Theater on Sunday.

title: NATIONAL LAMPOON INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income.

title: Bond Prices Slip in 'Thin' Day
description: Investment activity in the Treasury bond market subsided yesterday, discouraged by yields of less than 7 1/2 percent in some cases, and befuddled by wide intraday price fluctuations.

title: BRIDESMAIDS REVISITED: GOWNS OF YORE
description: There were pale pinks and funny greens and bright apricots, and a variety of fabrics and styles they wouldn't be caught dead in - usually. The overall effect was a downright fashion disaster.

title: ART: WORK OF A FUTURIST, GIACOMO BALLA, IN SHOW
description: IT was no Peaceable Kingdom that the Futurists strove -shrieked - for, but their movement was Utopian nonetheless. For instance, Luigi Russolo, who spent his life alternating between painting and music, foresaw machines and motors ''consciously attuned, so that every factory'' would become ''an intoxicating orchestra of noises.''

title: TIERCO GROUP INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: BLOOD TEST. By Jonathan Kellerman. 257 pages. Atheneum. $14.95. UNBALANCED ACCOUNTS. By Kate

title: Shafranov Quartet
description: The pianist Vladimir Shafranov and a quartet with Jon Faddis on trumpet, Mel Lewis on drums and Ray Drummond on bass will perform tonight through Sunday at the West End Cafe, 2911 Broadway, at 114th Street (666-8750). Sets begin at 9 and 10:30 P.M., and midnight and 1:15; there is no fourth set on Sunday. There is a $6 cover and a $7.50 minimum.

title: APPEAL ON 'CASABLANCA' FAILS
description: Two playwrights who sold a play to Warner Brothers Pictures Inc. that was used to make the film ''Casablanca'' gave up rights to future use of the material, New York State's highest court ruled today.

title: BAKER FAVORS INCREASE IN LINKAGE OF POLICIES
description: Treasury Secretary James A. Baker 3d said late Wednesday that he would like more of the sort of multinational actions that drove interest rates and the dollar down and a strengthening of the institutions involved.

title: Eastern Hiring
description: Eastern Airlines said that it planned to hire about 700 flight attendants as part of its plan to increase flights by 6 percent in 1986. The carrier also said that it had recently recalled 861 attendants who had been furloughed since February. Eastern is in negotiations with the Texas Air Corporation, which has offered about $600 million for the airline.

title: KEY POINTS FROM HEARING ON EXPLOSION OF THE SPACE SHUTTLE
description: Following are excerpts from a transcript of hearings on the explosion of the space shuttle Challenger, held in Washington yesterday by a Presidential investigative panel, as recorded by The New York Times through the facilities of ABC Radio News:

title: THE PANEL'S GOALS
description: In the first hint of changes they will recommend for the space shuttle program, members of the Presidential commission investigating the Challenger accident said they would urge the creation of a watchdog group with the power to postpone flights for safety reasons.

title: A New Sky Show
description: ''Starborn: Earth's Odyssey Through Time and Space,'' a new sky show about the planet, can be seen at the Hayden Planetarium of the American Museum of Natural History, Central Park West and 81st Street.

title: CHERRY BOWL REDUCTION
description: Maryland and Syracuse each will be paid $700,000 less than they were promised for playing last Dec. 21 in the Cherry Bowl in Pontiac, Mich., according to members of the bowl's board of directors. Each school, which accepted invitations with the assurance of a $1.2 million payment, will instead receive $499,312 apiece.

title: WEINBERGER ARRIVES IN JAPAN FROM SEOUL
description: Defense Secretary Caspar W. Weinberger arrived in Japan tonight after attending security talks in South Korea, where he warned of an increased threat to that country as it prepares to hold the 1988 Olympics.

title: NASA OFFICIAL SAYS SHUTTLE PROGRAM HAD MAJOR FLAWS
description: A top space agency official testified today that there were major flaws in the management of the space shuttle program in the months leading up to the explosion of the Challenger.

title: Refinancing Loans Surge
description: Homeowners' refinancing mortgage loans accounted for more than a third of all mortgage lending in the nation for the last three months, the president of the Mortgage Bankers Association of America said today.

title: BRENNER INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
FILM: 'DESERT HEARTS,' ABOUT WOMEN IN LOVE
description: THE time of ''Desert Hearts'' is 1959. Vivian Bell (Helen Shaver), a professor of English literature at Columbia University, arrives in Reno to divorce her husband, who's also a professor (and who remains safely offscreen throughout the film). Vivian is 35 years old, a handsome, initially icy, well-groomed woman who wants to find herself.

title: JAVITS CENTER BUSTLES ON OPENING DAY
description: After years of accusations, staff shake-ups, cost overruns and construction delays, the Jacob K. Javits Convention Center of New York opened almost nonchalantly yesterday when a group of furriers organized a five-minute ribbon-cutting ceremony and then hustled off to the business of selling tens of millions of dollars worth of jackets and coats to the trade.

title: TENTATIVE PACT REACHED ON STATE AID TO SCHOOLS
description: Negotiators for the Assembly and Senate have reached a tentative agreement on how to distribute $510 million of new education aid. The compromise is expected to permit passage of the state budget on Friday.

title: DeCARLI NAMED COACH
description: St. Bonaventure has hired Ron DeCarli, a former assistant basketball coach, as its new head coach, replacing Jim O'Brien, who left last week to take the head coaching job at Boston College.

title: A FALSE DILEMMA
description: Mario Cuomo is reported to be impaled on the horns of a political dilemma:

title: STATE OWNS A PRIME FISHING SPOT BUT CAN'T USE IT
description: Ever since it bought the land more than four years ago, New York State has wanted to make a park out of 2,865 acres of canyons and forest along the Neversink River in the southern Catskills. The site would be a trout fisherman's paradise, officials believe.

title: TALKS IN SOUTH AFRICA ON INTERRACIAL ASSEMBLY
description: Talks on setting up an interracial legis-ature for one of South Africa's four provinces opened in Durban today, but major anti-apartheid groups refused to take part.

title: JAILED EX-CITY AIDE IS SAID TO WEIGH AIDING INQUIRY
description: A former New York City leasing director who pleaded guilty in 1984 in one of the largest extortion cases ever made against a public official by the Government is considering an agreement to tell Federal prosecutors about the politicians and real-estate executives he has protected through his silence, according to lawyers close to the case.

title: PITTSBURGH & WEST VIRGINIA RR reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
10 WAYS REAGAN CAN OPPOSE TYRANNY
description: President Reagan's proclamation last month that the United States opposes ''tyranny in whatever form, whether of the left or the right'' inspired hope but also some questions about the President's commitment and staying power.

title: Don Adams in Sitcom About a Supermarket
description: Don Adams - best remembered as Maxwell Smart, the superdolt sleuth of ''Get Smart'' - shows up once again as the star of ''Check It Out!,'' a half-hour sitcom about supermarketing that starts on Channel 5 at 7 P.M. tomorrow.

title: 5 ARE SENTENCED FOR MAJOR ROLES IN NEW ENGLAND ORGANIZED CRIME
description: Gennaro J. Angiulo, described by Federal prosecutors as the No. 2 man in the group that controls organized crime in New England, was sentenced to 45 years in prison today, concluding a trial that began last June in Federal District Court here.

title: DIPLOMAT ELECTRONICS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-Includes equity in loss of affiliate of $245,000 for the quarter and $495,000 for the 9 months.

title: A FRANKING FIGHT
description: One of Congress's most cherished political assets, the right to send mail free to constituents, the franking privilege, seems close to becoming a political albatross and may be significantly curtailed.

title: PLAYING CARACAS
description: No sooner had the word spread a week or so ago that Speaker Thomas P. O'Neill Jr. would lead a group of fellow House members on a four-nation tour of Central America than dark mutterings of boondoggling began to arise. But they were just as quickly shot down even before the trip ended.

title: BROADWAY
description: SOME say it's a chestnut and some say it's one of the funniest plays they ever saw; it has been a staple of stock and school productions for more than a generation. But nobody has seen ''Arsenic and Old Lace'' on Broadway since the 1940's, where it ran for years after opening in 1941. The 1944 film starred Josephine Hull, Cary Grant and Peter Lorre. Now Elliot Martin is bringing in a major revival of the murderous farce with those two dear, dotty old aunties who drop poison in their gentlemen callers' elderberry wine. There are 13 corpses.

title: CONSOLATION
description: If the sentimental among 11,024 trackside witnesses could have willed a horse into the winner's circle at Aqueduct the other day, then a colt named Jimmy Cagney would have hauled down first prize.

title: DAIRY MART CONVENIENCE STORES reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-Net income The latest year figures include results of the Lawson Co., acquired in July.

title: NEVADA RESOURCES reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss Nevada Resources, a precious metals company, said it had no active mines in 1985 or 1984 and thus reported no revenue for those periods. Net income for the latest quarter was derived in part from a gain on the sale of marketable securities of $51,000.

title: COMPANIES PROFIT FROM PENSION RULE
description: A surge of corporate enthusiasm is emerging over the intricacies of a new pension fund accounting rule that could allow companies to report billions of dollars more in earnings than they otherwise might this year.

title: NORCAP FINANCIAL reports earnings for Year to Nov 30
PACIFIC INTERNATIONAL SERVICES reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-Net income

title: Occidental Plan
description: The Federal Trade Commission said that it would ask a Federal District Court to bar the Occidental Petroleum Corporation's proposed $70 million acquisition of some Tenneco Inc. plastics production facilities. The commission said it had reason to believe the proposed acquisition could substantially reduce competition in the production of three polyvinyl chloride resins, used in making many plastic goods.

title: IN OLD DEHLI: A HOSPITAL FOR FIGHTING NIGHTINGALES
description: Flocks of pigeons circle above the teeming streets of Old Delhi, going nowhere in particular, or so it seems. Longtime residents look to the skies and know better.

title: Airline Entrepreneur Provides Pan Am Link
description: Since he was 16 years old, J. Dawson Ransome has flown an array of planes, from small commuter jets to World War II cargo carriers.

title: Q-MED INC reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
FMI FINANCIAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes losses from discontinued operations of $647,000 for the quarter and $1,293,000 for the year. c-Includes losses from discontined operations of $231,000 for the quarter and $225,000 for the year.

title: FILES SAY CITY U. OFFICIALS WARNED EX-STUDENT LEADER ON EXPENSES
description: City University officials warned the chairman of the Student Senate at least three times about unsubstantiated and ''questionable'' expense claims, according to university records.

title: SILVER'S CHOREOGRAPHY IS FILLED WITH SURPRISES
description: Sally Silvers creates dances that critics have described, sometimes a little helplessly, as original, unconventional and even wacky. Her choreography is at once intricately ordered and colored by wittily anarchic impulse. And so it is unsurprising, perhaps, that the influences have been various on Miss Silvers, whose ''Every All Which Is Not Us'' will be performed tonight through Sunday at the Washington Square Church.

title: PERU TOURIST TRAIN DERAILS
description: Eleven people were injured, none seriously, when a train carrying 120 tourists derailed near here this morning. Most of the injured suffered cuts and bruises when the three-car express train from Cuzco to Machu Picchu slammed into a hillside as it rounded a curve.

title: WHO WANTS PHILLY?
description: All right, let's get this straight. The Nets want Philadelphia because Moses Malone has a fractured eye socket, but that's basketball. In hockey, it's the other way around. Nobody wants Philadelphia because their Moses Malone, fellow named Tim Kerr, is scoring goals in clusters again, reaching his personal high of 56 against the Rangers on Wednesday night.

title: NEW DIRECTORS PRESENT FILMS FROM INTIMATE TO THE EXOTIC
description: ITS alumni include Steven Spielberg and Hector Babenco, two directors whose films received Academy Award nominations this year.

title: Key Rates
description: * Municipal Bond Index, The Bond Buyer Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: 2 PANELS ASK ATOM TEST HALT
description: Two panels of American and Western European experts said today that a Soviet-American test ban treaty would go a long way toward curbing the spread of nuclear weapons.

title: Lunch Visit by Nixon Thrills a Burger King
description: Richard M. Nixon surprised employees and patrons of an Ocean County fast-food restaurant Wednesday when he stopped in for lunch. The former President signed autographs and posed for photographers before leaving.

title: FOR SOME, DRUG TESTS UNENFORCEABLE
description: Approximately 450 baseball players have contracts that include drug-testing clauses, but most of the clauses are unenforceable, the players' union chief quoted an owner's representative as saying in New York today at a hearing into the Players Association's grievance over the clauses.

title: HEARINGS ON CRIME: A $100 BILLION BUSINESS, PANEL SAYS
description: The President's Commission on Organized Crime was established by executive order on July 28, 1983, with Judge Irving R. Kaufman of the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit as chairman.

title: ON THE RADIO, TRANQUILLITY IS TOPS
description: In the broadcast industry, the 50-station Washington radio market is considered relatively bland, with neither the economic potential nor the programming freneticism of such larger markets as New York, Chicago and Los Angeles. But none of the disk jockeys or news people or management team over at WHUR-FM see things that way.

title: President Resigns At Castle & Cooke
description: Robert D. Cook resigned yesterday as president of Castle & Cooke Inc., the diversified company controlled by David H. Murdock, the financier.

title: QUESTION OF TRADITION
description: ''The B.A.A. is running the race -there is no question about it,'' says the Boston Athletic Association president, Francis Swift, about the haggling going on between his organization and The Athletics Congress regarding changes in some traditions for the 1988 Boston Marathon. T.A.C., which governs track and field in the United States, not only wants the race to serve as the United States Olympic trial for the Seoul Olympics, but also wants race officials to insure that an American finishes first in the event. It adopted that requirement at its convention last December.

title: 10-DAY AUTO SALES FALL 21.5%
description: Sales of American-made cars slumped 21.5 percent in late March and 15.5 percent for the full month, as the modest interest-rate incentives of the Big Three evidently failed to entice buyers.

title: Bridge: Stacking the Deck Can Be Useful Method in Teaching
description: On serious bridge occasions it is important that the deals should be totally random. A little flexibility is acceptable, however, if the game is for novices who are seeking to improve their understanding of the game.

title: LaPORTE WINS DECISION
description: Juan LaPorte, a former World Boxing Council featherweight champion now fighting as a junior lightweight, scored a majority 10-round decision over Vinnie Costello last night at the Felt Forum.

title: U.N. WILL GIVE WALDHEIM FILE TO ISRAEL
description: The United Nations said today that it would make available to Israel a secret file on former Secretary General Kurt Waldheim.

title: TSR INC reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
CACOPHONOUS SOUTH AFRICA
description: Notes from ''off the record'' visits in South Africa:

title: LAZAR OUSTED FROM ROLE IN TIMES SQUARE PROJECT
description: The state and city removed Michael J. Lazar yesterday as a developer in the $2 billion plan to rebuild Times Square, citing his indictment last week on racketeering charges stemming from the scandal at the city's Parking Violations Bureau.

title: SARAH CUNNINGHAM
description: Sarah Cunningham, an actress of stage and screen and co-founder of the Ensemble Studio Theater in New York and Los Angeles, died of an asthmatic attack March 24 while attending the Academy Awards Dinner in Los Angeles. She was 67 years old and had been a resident of Los Angeles for several years.

title: WITNESS IN SUIT SAYS MRS. JOHNSON STRUCK HER HUSBAND'S FACE
description: A witness in the suit challenging the will of J. Seward Johnson testified yesterday that he had seen Mr. Johnson's wife, Barbara, slap her husband across the face and call him a ''stupid American'' and a ''stupid old man.''

title: MAYORAL CANDIDATE IN CARMEL QUITS IN FAVOR OF EASTWOOD
description: One candidate for Mayor has withdrawn and endorsed the actor Clint Eastwood, one of the three people still running in the election Tuesday.

title:
Patents;
Expanding Stations In Space
description: THE National Aeronautics and Space Administration received two patents this week on the launching of space stations in folded condition and their expansion aloft.

title: TV: 'THE TED KNIGHT SHOW,' ABOUT A SMALL-TOWN PAPER
description: ''The Ted Knight Show,'' which premieres tonight at 7:30 on Channel 5, is about a small-town newspaper that gives journalism, television-style, a bad name, and makes a strong case for repealing the First Amendment. It's a tossup which rings more hollow -the newspaper characters or the canned laughter.

title: LEADERS IN PUSH AGAINST SOUTH AFRICA HOPE FOR BROADER CAMPUS ACIVISM
description: College students observed a National Divestment Protest Day today, aimed at getting trustees to discontinue investments in South Africa, and their leaders are hoping the movement will be a springboard to involvement in other issues.

title: I.R.E. FINANCIAL reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The share earnings reflect a 1-for-3 reverse stock split effective March 5. Corrected from Thursday's editions.

title: U.S. HEALTH RESOURCES reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
ANSWERS TO QUIZ
description: 1. The Supreme Court bestows the quills and pewter inkwells on lawyers who argue cases before it. 2.
