In the trial of three Bulgarians and three Turks charged with conspiring to assassinate Pope John Paul II, an Italian court acquitted the defendants for lack of proof. 3. Gov. George C. Wallace of Alabama announced that he would retire from public life after finishing his term in January. 4. A fire destroyed part of Hampton Court, Henry VIII's palace. 5. Mario M. Cuomo says he will decide whether to run for re-election as Governor or concentrate instead on seeking the Presidency. 6. Sulfites. 7. Bombs. 8. The President's Commission on Organized Crime. 9. The National Collegiate Athletic Association approved 3 points, instead of 2, for shots made 19 feet 9 inches or farther away from the basket. 10. The Harvard Business School's Class of 1949, its first full postwar class. 11. The glass-walled Jacob K. Javits Convention Center opened in Manhattan. 12. Jaime Cardinal Sin of the Philippines was referring to the flight of Ferdinand E. Marcos and the political ascension of Corazon E. Aquino. 13. Luciano Pavarotti and Joan Sutherland. 14. High. 15. Nebraska. 16. The era of deregulation ended with the completion of a five-year program of removing controls on interest rates. 17. Should. 18. The Louisville Cardinals won the N.C.A.A. men's basketball championship with a 32-7 season record. The Lady Longhorns of the University of Texas took the women's title with a perfect 34-0 season. 19.

title: KNICKS NO MATCH FOR CELTICS
description: The plight of the Knicks was obvious tonight as soon as the players lined up for the opening tap. Chris McNealy, a recent arrival from the Continental Basketball Association, was matched against Kevin McHale, an all-star at power forward. Ken Bannister, a seventh-round draft choice, had to guard the center Robert Parish, another all-star.

title: SECURITY AT MIDDLE EAST AIRPORTS IS FOUND TIGHTER, BUT STILL SPOTTY
description: Airport security in many Middle Eastern cities has been an on-and-off affair, according to travelers.

title: THE CASINOS RAISE THE ANTE
description: When New Jersey eased into bed with the gambling industry nine years ago, it tried to keep one foot on the floor by limiting the hours of casino operation. Now the Legislature is urged to give up that pretense to modesty and let the gamblers roll round the clock. A state that was unmoved by arguments against casinos in the first place seems unlikely to be persuaded that 18 or 20 hours a day is better than 24. Still, New Jerseyans ought to reflect on the choice; it is not inconsequential.

title: JAVITS CENTER: EARLY CHEERS
description: Jay R. Thalheim watched the crowds stream into the American International Fur Fair, the first trade show at the Jacob K. Javits Convention Center. He acknowledged the controversy that has surrounded the building, which was two years behind schedule when it opened this week. He agreed that the 1.8-million-square-foot smoked-glass structure was imposing.

title: Stalled North Sea Talks Cause Crude Oil Gains
description: The possibility of a strike in the Norwegian North Sea oilfields pushed up crude oil prices yesterday. They closed above $12 a barrel for the first time since last week.

title: Back to Baltimore
description: The 1971 Super Bowl trophy and the jerseys worn in their careers by Johnny Unitas, No. 19; Gino Marchetti, 89, and Raymond Berry, 82, have been returned to Baltimore along with other items of memorabilia from the city's former N.F.L. team, now the Indianapolis Colts. Mayor William Schaefer opened the carton containing the Super Bowl trophy in a City Hall ceremony that came about following an out-of-court settlement made last month between the city and Robert Irsay.

title: Tenor-Turned-Painter
description: You know Luciano Pavarotti, the tenor. But an exhibition of Luciano Pavarotti, the painter, is on display at ICF Inc., at 305 East 63d Street, through May 23.

title: Ozark Deal Is Questioned
description: The Justice Department said today that it feared the proposed takeover of Ozark Airlines by Trans World Airlines might reduce competition and lead to higher fares.

title: JOAO BETELHO'S 'PORTUGUESE FAREWELL'
description: ''A Portuguese Farewell'' (''Um Adeus Portugues'') is a handsome, formal, hermetically sealed movie whose point may well elude any American who doesn't have at least a little knowledge of recent Portuguese history.

title: 2 DIE IN BOMB BLAST AT WEST BERLIN DISCO
description: A bomb exploded in a discotheque frequented by American servicemen early today, killing at least 2 people and wounding 150, the police said.

title: AQUINO AIDE HAD MARCOS TIE
description: Finance Minister Jaime V. Ongpin, a key adviser to President Corazon C. Aquino, has disclosed that the company he headed for 12 years was secretly controlled by a relative of Ferdinand E. Marcos.

title: FILM: 'P.O.W. THE ESCAPE'
description: There are a couple of curious twists in ''P.O.W The Escape,'' an action film in which a group of American prisoners shoot their way out of Vietnam just before the war ends. Early on, a North Vietnamese officer shows a sunny family photograph to the P.O.W.'s leader, the tough, terse Col. Jim Cooper (David Carradine). ''I have relatives in Miami,'' the Vietnamese soldier says proudly, and suggests that Cooper help him and his stolen gold get to America. There is also a bad good guy, one of the Americans not only selfish enough to desert his buddies and steal a rucksack full of gold, but stupid enough to think he can escape on his own.

title: CITY'S NEW RIGHTS LAW STIRS REFERENDUM DRIVE
description: Republican and Conservative Party leaders opposed to New York City's new homosexual-rights law have joined in a drive to place a referendum on the issue on the city's fall ballot.

title: QUEENS CONCERN FACES A REVIEW OVER CITY PACTS
description: The Koch administration ordered its agencies yesterday not to grant new contracts to Arc Plumbing and Heating Corporation of Queens without special approval, pending a city review of criminal charges against its officers.

title: Young Parents in the City
description: A sobering note was sounded by Dr. Donna E. Shalala, president of Hunter College, when she spoke recently to a luncheon of the League of Women Voters Education Fund.

title: HOSTAGE IS HELD 2D DAY IN A STANDOFF
description: A man accused in the slaying of his landlord and a police officer before taking a woman hostage continued his standoff with the police today, telling negotiators that he had made breakfast for his captive and drawn up his will.

title: CABARET: 'LIVING COLOR' REVUE
description: The characters who parade through ''Living Color,'' a cabaret revue that bills itself as ''A Twisted Mnemonic Entertainment,'' represent a bizarre assortment of emotional cripples obsessed with childhood toys and shopworn media images. ''I don't like myself, so I took a positive seminar -now I'm positive I don't like myself,'' announces a character in the middle of a song called ''Life Is Funny.''

title: GOODBYE DOCUMENTS
description: In Washington information is power. But with the mandatory spending reductions required by the new Federal budget-balancing law, it is in increasingly short supply.

title: Northwestern's Choice
description: Bill Foster, who has had teams win 20 basketball games in a season at four colleges in his coaching career, has accepted a truly formidable task. The former Rutgers, Utah, Duke and South Carolina coach has been named head coach at Northwestern University, replacing Rich Falk. Falk was dismissed after his team posted an 8-20 record and went 2-16 in the Big Ten, where the Wildcats finished last for the second straight season.

title: THE LONELY DEATH OF A MAN WHO MADE A SCANDAL
description: It was an era of bookmakers and wire rooms, of horse players with bankrolls and thugs in pin-striped suits and flashy convertibles. It was 1950, and an immense scandal - a cancer of police graft - was about to break in New York City.

title: RECITAL: ELLY AMELING, SINGER
description: Elly Ameling's song recital at Carnegie Hall Wednesday night evoked the world of Goethe. Beethoven, Loewe, Schubert, Wolf, Brahms, Mozart and Mendelssohn were the composers, and their songs were to texts by the German poet or by Marianne von Willemer, who shared an important part of his life.

title: CITY'S DATA SHOW LITTLE CHANGE IN TOTAL FELONIES REPORTED IN '85
description: After falling steadily since 1981, the number of reported felonies in New York City was basically unchanged last year, according to Police Department statistics released yesterday.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: * AM Acquisition Inc. said it owns 2,028,100 Avondale Mills common shares, representing about 50.6 percent of the shares outstanding.

title: FEAR OF TERRORISM: U.S. FAMILIES ABROAD
description: It was just 7:30 on a bright Roman morning, and a 40-year-old American woman was faced with what to her seemed like a life-and-death decision.

title: Judge in Civil Court May Face Suspension
description: A Civil Court judge in Brooklyn who has been charged in an arson case is facing possible suspension from the bench.

title: Brazil Debt Talks Set
description: Debt-burdened Brazil will begin talks this month on refinancing $2.3 billion owed to creditor countries in the Paris Club, a central bank spokesman said Thursday. But the talks seem likely to be complicated by Brazil's refusal to reach an accord with the International Monetary Fund on an economic program.

title: CHRYSLER PAID IACOCCA $1.6 MILLION LAST YEAR
description: Lee A. Iacocca, who worked at an annual pay rate of only $1 a year for several months in the early 1980's while the Chrysler Corporation was near bankruptcy, received $1.6 million in salary and bonuses last year, realized $15.5 million from stock options over the last five years and this fall is due to collect 225,000 shares of common stock outright, worth nearly $10 million.

title: OFFER FOR WALKER IS RAISED
description: The Reichmann family of Canada raised its takeover bid for Hiram Walker Resources Ltd. yesterday to $2.1 billion in cash for the 74 percent of the big liquor producer that it does not yet own or control.

title:
PATENTS;
A Mechanical Fish; Carrier for Games
description: Inventions for home entertainment were patented this week by two members of the Inventors Workshop International Education Association, which has its headquarters in Tarzana, Calif. Howard Gomez of Costa Mesa, Calif., received patent 4,578,888 for a mechanical fish that can be displayed in a breeze, such as near an open window, and moves its mouth and fins entertainingly.

title: Tesoro, Cavalcade
description: The Tesoro Petroleum Corporation said it would reply to a takeover offer by Cavalcade Partners after its board, management, legal and investment advisers had had a chance to examine the bid. Cavalcade is offering a package of cash and securities valued by analysts at $20 to $25 a share,

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: SAVACOU The Savacou was a big-beaked mythological war bird of the Caribs, Indians who inhabited parts of Latin America and the West Indies. The name has come to be associated with a variety of things Caribbean, the latest of which is an art gallery somewhat on the Lower East Side. The Savacou Gallery, at 240 East 13th Street (473-6904), was established last fall to promote as well as market third-world art, with a special focus on Caribbean work.

title: Article 241486 -- No Title
description: Atlantic Coast Conference teams received an estimated total of $3 million for their appearances in the National Collegiate Athletic Association men's basketball tournament, according to league officials.

title: HELLO POPULARITY
description: The current wave of budget-cutting is painful to many in Washington, but not to Stanley E. Collender.

title: Alamito Agrees To Osceola Offer
description: The Alamito Company, the electricity wholesaler that has been the focus of an intense takeover battle, said today that it had agreed to a sweetened takeover offer from Osceola Energy Inc. of about $376 million cash.

title: BUDGET EFFORTS GO ON INTO THE NIGHT
description: The State Legislature moved early this morning toward completing passage of the state's $41.5 billion budget, having resolved the final obstacle - a last-minute dispute between two Queens legislators over how a Queens medical school should be run.

title: U.S. Debt Tops $2 Trillion
description: The national debt, which has doubled in the last five years, passed the $2 trillion milestone this week for the first time in history, the Government said today.

title: FINISH SOUTH KOREA'S MIRACLE
description: South Korea is astir in ways not seen since the brief ''democratic spring'' of 1980. That ended when Gen. Chun Doo Hwan, now the nation's President, crushed a student-led insurrection in Kwangju, with heavy loss of life. So when the current drive for direct elections came to Kwangju last Sunday, emotion ran high. The event was the largest legal political demonstration of the Chun era. Its mostly peaceful course demonstrated the growing maturity of both the opposition and Government. Nevertheless, the regime has seized on some minor clashes between militant students and police to threaten new restrictions. A fresh test comes today with a rally in the city of Taegu.

title: Nora Scott Weds William I. Kaplan
description: Nora Cresson Scott, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. David Scott of New Hope, Pa., and William I. Kaplan, the son of Helen Kaplan of South Fallsburg, N.Y., and the late Moe Kaplan, were married yesterday at the Church Center for the United Nations.

title: F.A.O. SCHWARZ RELOCATING
description: F. A. O. Schwarz, the world-renowned toy store, will move this year or early in 1987 from the location at 745 Fifth Avenue that it has called home for 50 years, the agent for the owners of the building said last night.

title: MAY ENERGY PARTNERS reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income Share earnings reflect funds provided from operations per unit.

title: Reno Lights Endangered
description: Financial problems may force this city to turn off its arch over Virginia Street that for 50 years has proclaimed it ''The Biggest Little City in the World.'' Julie Betz, Acting City Manager, says budget constraints mean either turning off the lights or laying off another employee. The sign's annual cost is $12,000.

title: SATURDAY NEWS QUIZ
description: Questions are based on news reports in The Times this week. Answers appear on page 50. 1. To some lawyers, a quill like this is the ultimate status symbol. Explain. 2. The verdict was neither ''guilty'' nor ''not guilty.'' What was the trial and what was the verdict? 3. ''After much prayerful consideration, I feel I must say that I have climbed my last political mountain.'' Who said this and what were the circumstances? 4. ''One of the jewels of our heritage,'' said an official about one of Britain's leading tourist attractions. What building is it, with what monarch is it associated, and why was it in the news? 5. To run or not to run is the question facing a politician who says he will make a decision by the middle of next month. Who is he and what is at issue? 6. After a long struggle, the American wine industry appears ready to accept a warning on wine labels against (alcoholism/drug-related interactions/nitrates/sulfites). 7. The X-ray machines and the metal detectors at airports that screen luggage and passengers are virtually useless in detecting (knives/firearms/bombs/all three types of weapons). 8. According to 9 of the 18 members of a Presidential commission that recently issued a final report, their experience was a ''saga of missed opportunities.'' What commission was it? 9. There will be a premium for scoring in college basketball next year. Why? 10. It is called ''the class the dollars fell on'' because of the large number of corporate chairmen and other business notables among its alumni.

title: More Than Mania
description: The possibility of injury at Wrestlemania II, scheduled for Chicago on Monday, is causing a problem for Bill Fralic of the Atlanta Falcons, but not for William (Refrigerator) Perry of the Chicago Bears. The Falcons' president, Rankin Smith Jr., has asked Fralic, an offensive lineman who had an oustanding rookie season, to sign a document that could void a portion of his contract should he suffer a career-ending injury in the free-for-all wrestling exhibition.

title: FIDATA CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a charge of $264,000 related to the reversal of a tax credit for the quarter and an extraordinary tax benefit of $579,000, or 13 cents a share, for the year. c-Net loss and includes pre-tax charges of $2,329,000 for the quarter and $16,329,000 for the year with both related to litigation settlement and other costs related to loan losses. Both year-ago periods also include a pre- tax loss of $5,876,000 on the disposition of a product line. The latest quarter and year nets also include a pre-tax loss of $3,150,000 on the disposition of a product line and a pre-tax gain of $4,656,000 on the disposition of an affiliate. The latest periods' nets include pre-tax losses of $1,000 for the quarter and $112,000 for the year, both on the sale of securities. The 1984 year also includes a pre-tax loss of $58,000 on the sale of securities.

title: MORALES AND BIONDI SWIM TO 2D TITLES
description: Pablo Morales of Stanford and Matt Biondi of California won their second titles in two nights tonight in the National Collegiate Athletic Association's 63d annual swimming championships.

title: FOCUS OF T.W.A. BOMB INQUIRY: WHO SAT IN SEAT 10F AND WHY?
description: An international inquiry into the explosion Wednesday aboard a Trans World Airlines jet just before it landed in Athens now seems to center on two questions: Who is the woman who sat in seat 10F on an earlier leg of the plane's journey, and did she plant the bomb that later exploded under the seat?

title: NEW YORK JOBLESS RATE STABLE
description: Unemployment levels remained relatively stable last month in New York City and New York State, the Federal Bureau of Labor Statistics reported yesterday. In New Jersey, joblessness declined by more than one percentage point, but officials said it was too soon to interpret that drop as a sign of overall improvement.

title: VIDEO LIBRARY INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income

title: A JAMAICAN FILM
description: ''The Harder They Come,'' a Jamaican film starring the singer Jimmy Cliff, will be shown tomorrow at 3 P.M. at the Brooklyn Museum, 200 Eastern Parkway.

title: Fruehauf Fight
description: The Fruehauf Corporation agreed to give the New York investor Asher B. Edelman a list of its shareholders and, in full-page advertisements, urged them to reject Mr. Edelman's bid to win control of the truck-trailer manufacturer.

title: DR. CHARLES LAWRENCE
description: Dr. Charles R. Lawrence, former chairman of the department of sociology at Brooklyn College, died Thursday at his home in Pomona, N.Y. He was 71 years old.

title: HARRY L. FUCHS
description: Harry L. Fuchs, an assistant conductor with the New York City Opera since 1971, died of cancer yesterday at Mount Sinai Hospital. He was 58 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: 240 Million Americans
description: The population of the United States reached 240,123,000 on Nov. 1, according to Population Today, a publication of the private Population Reference Bureau. At the current rate the population should pass 250 million by 1990, the organization said. It based its figures on updated Census Bureau estimates not yet made public.

title: ONEOK INC reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
Write-Off Set On Tin Losses
description: The American Express Company says it plans to take a write-off to cover multimillion-dollar tin trading losses when it reports first-quarter earnings this month.

title: I.B.M. Head's Pay Cut in 1985
description: John R. Opel, the chairman of the International Business Machines Corporation, took a $186,404 pay cut last year because of a decline in profits, according to a proxy statement released by I.B.M. yesterday.

title: WRITING THE BOOK ON THE MOB
description: The President's Commission on Organized Crime has ended a three-year investigation with a mixed assessment of its own work. The chairman, Federal Judge Irving Kaufman, believes the commission has illuminated dark places and pointed a path for combating mob influences. But 9 of 18 commissioners deplore a ''missed opportunity'' for a lasting contribution to the fight against the mobsters. Both views seem warranted.

title: Bell Atlantic Unit
description: The Bell Atlantic Corporation said its real estate subsidiary, Bell Atlantic Properties, had signed a letter of agreement with the Pitcairn Company to purchase for $135 million to $150 million the assets of its real estate subsidiary, Pitcairn Properties Inc. The transaction is subject to final legal and financial review by Bell Atlantic, the company said. Pitcairn Properties' portfolio of commercial real estate includes an interest in 41 office buildings, 39 in the Philadelphia area, and 2 in Raleigh, N.C., and about 200 acres of undeveloped land.

title: FLOWERS INDUS reports earnings for Qtr to March 8
SATURDAY SPORTS
description: Baseball Mets vs. Pittsburgh Pirates, at Bradenton, Fla, 1:30 P.M. (Radio - WHN 1050, 1:30 P.M.) Yankees vs. Toronto Blue Jays, at Fort Lauderdale, Fla., 1:30 P.M. This exhibition game was the first of two originally scheduled for Denver, but the trip was canceled because of snow in Colorado, and the series will be played in Florida today and tomorrow. (Radio - WABC 770, 1:30 P.M.) Atlanta Braves vs. Cincinnati Reds, at Tampa, Fla. (Television - WTBS, 1:05 P.M.) Basketball Nets vs. Knicks, at Byrne Meadowlands Arena, 7:35 P.M. The Knicks are out of the playoffs and the Nets are in, jockeying for position. (Television -SportsChannel, 8 P.M. Radio - WNBC 930, 7:30 P.M.) Boxing Mike Weaver vs. James (Bonecrusher) Smith, 10 rounds, heavyweights, at Latham, N.Y. Weaver, the former World Boxing Association champion from Pomona, Calif., is 28-11-1 and ranked No. 3 by the World Boxing Council and No. 10 by the W.B.A. Smith, from Magnolia, N.C., is 15-5 with 12 knockouts and is ranked No. 8 by the W.B.C. (Television - Channel 2, 4 P.M.) Amateurs: United States Championships, at Beaumont, Tex. (Television - Channel 7, 4:30 P.M.) Hockey Islanders vs. Devils, at Nassau Coliseum, 5:05 P.M. First of a home-and-home season-ending series. (Television - SportsChannel, 5 P.M. Radio - WMCA 570, WOR 710, 5 P.M.) Rangers vs. Washington Capitals, at Landover, Md., 7:35 P.M. The outcome could determine fourth place for the Rangers and first place for Washington.

title: ENTRE COMPUTER CENTERS reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
Thinner Winner
description: The fellow aboard Flantasia in the sixth-race post parade at Aqueduct yesterday looked familiar, and for good reason. It was George Martens, who rode Summing to victory in the 1981 Belmont Stakes but later fell victim to a weight problem. After a three-year hiatus, he's back down to 115 pounds (from a high of 137), and in his return yesterday he piloted Flantasia, a first-time starter, to third place.

title: CNW-Douglas
description: The CNW Corporation said it had agreed to pay $52.4 million in cash to acquire Douglas Dynamics Inc., a Milwaukee-based manufacturer of snowplows.

title: TOTAL ASSETS PROTECTION reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss after a reversal of a tax loss carryforward of $82,469. c-Net income including a tax credit of $79,331. Revenue results represent contract revenue.

title: SENATOR ATTACKS SECRECY BREACHES
description: The chairman of the Senate Select Committee on Intelligence said today that officials in the executive branch were largely to blame for unauthorized disclosures of secret information affecting national security.

title: THE DANCE: A KUDELKA PREMIERE
description: ''The Heart of the Matter,'' by the Canadian choreographer James Kudelka, is bound to be one of the season's most important ballets and it is the Joffrey Ballet that has given Mr. Kudelka his first showcase within a major American company.

title: TERROR'S VICTIMS: 3 GENERAIONS OF A FAMILY...
description: In a well-kept house on Lafayette Avenue, with family photographs on the walls and daffodils blooming in the front yard, friends and relatives of three American victims of terrorism gathered today in shared sorrow.

title: CAROLINA FREIGHT reports earnings for Qtr to March 22
PROSTITUTION CHARGES DROPPED IN BROWN CASE
description: Prostitution charges were dropped today against two Brown University seniors arrested in an alleged sex-for-hire ring, but they still could be indicted by a grand jury.

title: SOUTHERN HOSPITALITY reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
description: b-Net income

title: DOW LOSS FOR WEEK AT RECORD
description: The fear that the bargain in oil prices may soon come to an end unsettled Wall Street yesterday, sending stock prices sharply lower and producing the biggest weekly loss ever in the Dow Jones industrial average.

title: SUMMIT OILFIELD reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-Includes a loss from discontinued operations of $575,000 and writedowns of $2,656,443 of goodwill and other intagible assets. c-Includes a loss from discontinued operations of $4,447,981.

title: REAGAN SEEKS CAP IN LIABILITY OF U.S. FOR DAMAGE CASES
description: The Reagan Administration has drafted a legislative proposal that would sharply limit the damages people could collect from the Government for injury or death caused by the negligence or misconduct of a Federal employee.

title: AMERICAN INVESTMENT reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes extraordinary credits of $2,837,000 resulting from income tax obligations eliminated by tax loss carryforwards of a subsidiary contributed to the company by its parent. c-Includes a charge of $4,000,000 relating to traditional life insurance products principally sold prior to 1980. The 1985 net income also includes realized net gains of approximately $2,775,000 from the sale of certain investments, compared to net gains of $4,791,000 in 1984.

title: STATE SAYS CITY TAXI AGENCY MIGHT HAVE TO BE ABOLISHED
description: The agency that regulates the city's taxi industry is so riddled with corruption and mismanagement that it might have to be abolished, the head of the State Commission of Investigation said yesterday.

title: WOMEN IN PROFESSIONS: THE BAD NEWS
description: To the Editor:

title: CALIFORNIA'S HIGH COURT TO DECIDE ON BOOK SUIT
description: The California Supreme Court has agreed to decide whether William Peter Blatty may sue The New York Times Company because his novel ''Legion'' did not appear on the paper's best-seller list.

title: MR. HARDROCK, SIR
description: Hardrock Johnson died. He was 90 years old.

title: INTERCONTINENTAL LIFE reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After realized losses from investments of $873,000. c-Net income d-After realized losses of $131,000 for the quarter and $86,000 for the year. e-After realized losses of $804,000.

title: JOBLESS RATE DECLINES SLIGHTLY, TO 7.1%
description: The nation's jobless rate eased one-tenth of a percentage point in March, despite rising unemployment in the oil and gas industry, the Labor Department reported today.

title: YANKS COOL TO CRITICISM
description: George Steinbrenner burst into the press trailer at Fort Lauderdale Stadium shortly after noon today and blurted out the word that everyone in New York seems to be waiting for.

title: Redus Can't Wait To Touch Base
description: Gary Redus of the Philadelphia Phillies will be the first man to bat in the National League this season when he steps in against Mario Soto on Monday afternoon at Cincinnati. And if Redus manages to reach first base, he'll find himself standing next to the Reds' player-manager and bona fide legend, Pete Rose, whom he publicly criticized last September.

title: SOVIET SAYS IT'S READY TO FIX DATE FOR TALKS ON NEXT SUMMIT PARLEY
description: The Soviet Union, after months of delay, told the United States today that it was ready to discuss the date for talks expected to center on the next Soviet-American summit meeting, Administration officials said.

title: LORI CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes a loss from discontinued operations of $77,000 and an extraordinary charge of $285,000 from a reversal of a tax credit. c-Includes income from discontinued operations of $77,000. d-After a loss from discontinued operations of $60,000 and a tax credit of $2,757,000. e-Net loss after a loss from discontinued operations of $311,000 and a gain of $801,000 from the restructuring of debt. The company said after restatement for discontinued operations there were no sales in the year-ago fourth quarter or the prior year.

title: DANGEROUS WINE SEIZED IN EUROPE
description: The Danish and Swiss authorities today reported seizing thousands of gallons of Italian wine adulterated with methyl alcohol, a poison.

title: FROM NORWAY, 'WIVES' AND 'TEN YEARS AFTER'
description: Anja Breien's ''Wives'' was shown at the New Directors/New Films series in New York in 1976. It was a charmer, about three women in their upper 20's, who had been high school chums. Meeting at a class reunion, they spend the next 48 hours or so fooling around in Oslo and environs.

title: JAZZ: SAXOPHONE QUARTET
description: In the 10 years of its existence, the World Saxophone Quartet has brought its avant-garde origins into increasing accessibility to mainstream jazz while maintaining its basic adventurous characteristics. In the setting of a restaurant such as Carlos I (Avenue of the Americas between Ninth and Tenth Streets), where the group will be playing through Sunday, it is using a repertory focused on skillfully arranged Duke Ellington tunes that places these familiar melodies in fresh and distinctive voicings.

title: F.C.C. Denies A.T.&T. Raise
description: The American Telephone and Telegraph Company's proposal to raise the price of weekend and nighttime long-distance phone calls was rejected today by the Federal Communications Commission.

title: MUSIC: VIOLIN, DAVIDOVICI
description: The violinist Robert Davidovici won the 1983 Carnegie Hall International American Music Competition, and therefore it is no surprise that the 20th-century American works on his Wednesday night concert at the 92d Street Y were particularly rewarding.

title: Maria Harris Wed To Gabriel Moran
description: Maria Harris, the Howard Professor of Religious Education at Andover Newton Theological School in Newton Centre, Mass., was married yesterday to Gabriel Moran, director of the graduate program for religious education at New York University. Msgr. Frederick F. Schaefer performed the ceremony at the chapel of the Catholic Center of N.Y.U.

title: GRETZKY SURPASSES OWN POINTS RECORD
description: Wayne Gretzky broke his own National Hockey League single-season points record with three assists for Edmonton tonight, but two goals by Joey Mullen led the Calgary Flames to a 9-3 rout of the Oilers.

title: GRAPHIC MEDIA reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-Includes tax credits of $24,652 for the latest year and $70,350 for the prior year. Corrected from Thursday's editions.

title: DEFENSE LAWYER IN TRIAL ON ALIENS ASSAILED FOR RELIGIOUS ARGUMENTS
description: A Federal district judge reacted sharply today to closing statements by a defense lawyer in the trial of 11 church workers accused of smuggling Central Americans into the United States.

title: Tough E.E.C. Trade Stance
description: The member countries of the European Economic Community today backed the tough stance of the community's executive commission in its latest trade dispute with Washington, according to diplomatic sources.

title: GENETIC ENGINEERING PROMISES FARM GAINS, BUT ITS DANGERS ARE A PUZZLE FOR REGULATORS
description: A new era in American agriculture opened Oct. 9, 1985, when a 27-year-old veterinarian, Roger Saline, injected a live, genetically altered virus into 250 piglets on a farm in Bradford, Ill. It was the first time that a living organism created by the techniques of genetic engineering was used in the field.

title: BATTLE OF THE DOCTORS VS. THE LAWYERS CONTINUES
description: To the Editor:

title: CORRECTION
description: An article in Metropolitan Report on Thursday about two police officers who were suspended from duty on accusations of brutality misstated the departmental charges against one of them. Only Officer Charles M. Ferranti - not Francis T. Sancineto -was accused of threatening to kill people he searched for drugs.

title: MUSIC: JOE PASS AND JIM HALL
description: Joe Pass and Jim Hall, the jazz guitar giants who are sharing the bill at the Blue Note (131 West Third Street) through Sunday, offer an interesting study in contrasting jazz-guitar styles. Mr. Pass is an impeccable sculptor of musical form whose performances maintain a scrupulous balance between melody and bass line. His attention to form is matched by a remarkably fleet-fingered technique that tosses off long improvisations without a ruffle. Mr. Hall, who is leading a trio that includes the bassist Steve LaSpina and the drummer Akira Tana, is less concerned with song form than with communicating a swinging involvement with his material while exploring his instrument's finer textual nuances.

title: COLLEGES THAT HAVE RID THEMSELVES OF HOLDINGS IN PROTEST
description: According to the Africa Fund, an educational and humanitarian organization based in New York, the following colleges and universities have divested themselves since 1977 of all stocks in corporations doing business in South Africa. 1986: Bates College Clark University University of Minnesota Foundation Roosevelt University Seattle University 1985: Arizona State University Barnard College California State University, Northridge Columbia University Evergreen State College Hartford Seminary University of Iowa Iowa State University University of Louisville University of Miami University of Minnesota Mount Holyoke College State University of New York State University of New York, Stonybrook Foundation Ohio State University University of Rhode Island Foundation Rutgers University Temple University University of Vermont Fairfield University University of Kentucky Sarah Lawrence College Teacher's College, New York Western Washington University 1984: Wayne State University City University of New York 1983: Western Michigan University 1982: University of Maine 1981: Lutheran School of Theology 1980: Michigan State University 1978: Antioch College Howard University Ohio University University of Wisconsin 1977: Hampshire College University of Massachusetts

title: PLEASE STOP USING MY FIRST NAME
description: The note to my husband attached to the mortgage confirmation form said ''Ralph, please review the. . .'' There it was again - a first name being used by an utter stranger. A month before, a bank employee nearly half my age, who had never before seen my face, peered over my application for a certificate of deposit and quietly cooed, ''Now, Jill, let me explain how this works.''

title: Ups and Downs
description: Mike Gminski of the Nets, whose wife is a stockbroker: ''The way I've got it figured, she'll be moving into six figures just about the time I'm moving out.''

title: PEACE MARCH RESUMES
description: The Great Peace March for Nuclear Disarmament set off again today for the Nevada border. An officer on the scene counted 320 marchers, said Tine Schmitt, a dispatcher with the California Highway Patrol; 1,200 set out March 1.

title: TEXAS-SIZE DREAM GETS OFF BROADWAY NIGHT
description: Chuck Castleberry, a tall, thin drink of water from East Texas, turned to Susan Hamilton as they were waiting on tables at an East Side restaurant and proclaimed: ''Susan, we're going to put on a show!''

title: ACTIVIST GROUPS BARRED FROM U.S. CHARITY DRIVE
description: A charity drive among Federal employees would benefit only traditional health and welfare charities under revised regulations issued today by the Reagan Administration, but not organizations engaged in political advocacy or legal actions.

title: CHRIS ANDERSON, PIANIST
description: The pianist Chris Anderson will lead his trio tonight at the Jazz Cultural Theater, 368 Eighth Avenue, above 28th Street (502-4300). Sets are at 10 and 11:30 P.M. and 1 A.M.; admission is $8, or $5 for students and the elderly.

title: NORMAN HILBERRY: PHYSICIST DIRECTED ATOMIC LABORATORY
description: Norman Hilberry, a physicist and educator who was director of the Argonne National Laboratory from 1957 to 1961, died March 28 at Humana Desert Hospital in Phoenix of complications arising from influenza. He was 87 years old and lived in Scottsdale, Ariz.

title: GALLERY OF THE REPELLENT
description: RECKLESS EYEBALLING. By Ishmael Reed. 148 pages. St. Martin's Press. $12.95. The way ''Reckless Eyeballing'' starts off reminds you of a seedy 1940's detective novel gussied up with some contemporary bigotry and anger: a large man, wearing sunglasses and a raincoat, has been assaulting prominent feminists. He ties them up, shaves off their hair, chastises them for giving black men a bad name, and leaves a chrysanthemum behind as his calling card. His explanation is that this is what the Resistance did to whores who collaborated with the Nazis, and that women today who help perpetuate ugly stereotypes about black men deserve a similar punishment for their sins.

title: BALANCE
description: The newest in the never-ending stream of Washington newsletters, The O'Leary-Kamber Report, describes itself as ''politically balanced'' in discussing politics. It provides election-year news notes, contrasting left-and-right analyses of Senate and gubernatorial races and a one-page issue debate between its two authors, Victor Kamber and Brad O'Leary, both Washington political consultants.

title: Jury Acquits Officer In a Slaying in Bronx
description: A police officer charged in the 1985 slaying of a young man on a Bronx subway platform was acquitted yesterday by a jury in State Supreme Court in the Bronx.

title: How Monetary System Works
description: The European Monetary System, which was set up in 1979, links eight European currencies to promote monetary stability and encourage trade within Europe. Its members are West Germany, France, Italy, the Netherlands, Belgium, Denmark, Luxembourg and Ireland.

title: A GOOD WORD FOR POTHOLES - YES, POTHOLES
description: I salute the misunderstood pothole, victim of the slings and arrows of outraged motorists, innocent progeny of inferior pavers, unconscious benefactor of auto repair shops, unwelcome accompaniment to the symphony of spring.

title: Houston Thrift Unit Closed
description: The Federal Home Loan Bank Board announced today that it had closed the Mainland Savings Association, a $1 billion institution, in what apperaed to be the largest failure ever of a thrift institution.

title: ANTIDOTE FOR AGING: THE ACTIVE LIFE
description: Alice Phillips, who is 78 years old, said that as she got older she noticed she was not remembering things as well, and her mind felt rusty. ''I thought it was the way my brain worked,'' she said.

title: ...AND A BUSINESSMAN WORRIED ABOUT TRAVEL
description: Alberto Ospina stood in a Federal courtroom six years ago, his right hand held high, and recited the oath of United States citizenship.

title: MET ROSTER IN PLACE FOR PENNANT CHASE
description: ''That's it,'' Dave Johnson said today, anointing the 24 players picked for the job. ''Those are the guys, those are the Mets. We'll go with them.''

title: NEW SUMMARY: SATURDAY, APRIL 5, 1986
description: International The shape of U.S.-Soviet relations for years to come is being defined in a fundamental policy struggle between Moscow and Washington, Reagan Administration officials said. Moscow, the officials say, is seeking to make nuclear arms control the focal point, as was largely the case during the Nixon and Carter Administrations. The Reagan Administration, they say, is resisting this narrow focus and wants equal attention for settlement of regional disputes such as Afghanistan and Angola and for human rights issues. [ Page 1, Column 6. ] The Soviet Union told the U.S. that it was ready to discuss the date for its foreign minister to go to Washington for talks expected to center on the next Soviet-American summit meeting, Reagan Administration officials said. Moscow delayed its expected announcement for months. [ 1:5. ] The T.W.A. explosion inquiry seems to center on two questions: Who was the woamn who sat in seat 10F on an earlier leg of the plane's journey and did she plant the bomb that later exploded under the seat? Some of the investigators among the Greeks, Egyptians, Italians and Americans believe that the passenger might be a woman with a Lebanese passport who traveled under the name of May Elias Mansur. [ 1:4. ] The Gaza Strip seems forgotten in Middle East politics, though it is jammed with Palestinian refugees, while the Israeli-occupied West Bank always seems to be at the center of political debates about the Middle East and the focus of international diplomacy.

title: 2 Men in Brooklyn Hts. Die in Apartment Fire
description: Two men were killed and a woman was injured yesterday when a fire swept through their 29th-floor apartment in Brooklyn Heights, the authorities said.

title: SENSORMATIC ELECTRONICS reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
description: b-Net income The latest third quarter and 9 months results were adversely affected by $15.2 million, pre-tax, of writeoffs and increased reserves due primarily to the discontinuance of certain products and reserves for potentially uncollectable accounts receivable.

title: Warnaco Appeals Hostile Bid Ruling
description: Warnaco Inc. today appealed a Federal judge's decision not to block an investor group's hostile takeover bid of $40 a share, or about $409 million, for the apparel maker.

title: CHINESE DIVER IS LEARNING NEW RULES
description: In the 1980's, Chinese divers have entered international competition with a vengeance, winning Olympic, world and World Cup championships. Last night, a Chinese diver was the favorite to win an American collegiate title.

title: Rivers Is Elusive
description: Last year the Miami Marlins of the Class A Florida State League attracted national attention by signing several former major-leaguers, including Mike Torrez, Eric Rasmussen, Derrel Thomas and Santo Alcala.

title: COURT BARS BRANDING OF DAIRY COWS' FACES
description: Federal agriculture officials may not force farmers to brand the faces of dairy cows destined for slaughter or export to end a national milk surplus, Federal District Judge Michael Telesca ruled today.

title: Record Price Rise of 3%-5%
description: For the first time in several years, record companies are raising their suggested prices to retailers by 3 to 5 percent. The move, which appears to be industry wide, includes CBS Inc., Warner Communications Inc., MCA Inc. and the RCA Corporation, among others.

title: NICARAGUAN DISTILLERY BURNS
description: Fire destroyed the distillery that makes Flor de Cana rum and two workers were seriously injured in the blaze 90 miles northwest of Managua today, officials reported. ''Preliminary investigations indicate that, while the two workers were soldering an empty tank, a spark flew and made contact with another tank full of alcohol,'' said Lieut. Edwin Aleman of the Managua Fire Department.

title: TOO MANY DOGS AND CATS IN THE CITIES
description: The findings of a study recently published by the American Veterinary Medical Association underscore the fact that New York City and other large urban centers are faced with a growing pet overpopulation crisis, one that must receive more attention from citizens, and, particularly, city planners.

title: SIGNALS TO REAGAN'S PLANE MIGHT BE AFFECTING DOORS
description: When President Reagan visits his California ranch, remote controls on automatic garage doors here fail, and residents believe the President's visit might have something to do with it.

title: LESSONS OF NEW YORK CITY'S SCANDALS
description: Let's not overreact. New York is not a town in which every politician and government official has a hand in someone else's pocket. It is not a place where corruption and bribery are the ordinary price for doing business. It is not a city that runs on sleaze.

title: QUEMOY (REMEMBER?) BRISTLES WITH READINESS
description: For Americans who remember the period, this cluster of islands off the China coast belongs somewhere between British troops seizing the Suez Canal and Nikita S. Khrushchev banging his shoe at the United Nations.

title: 4 ANTI-APARTHEID LEADERS TARGETS OF ARSON
description: The homes of four anti-apartheid activists, including the head of South Africa's leading black business association, were set on fire early today in a township near Pretoria.

title: NEW WEAPON ARRIVES IN WAR ON FARE CHEATERS
description: Starting today, 163 Transit Authority buses in Manhattan will go into service with new computerized fare boxes intended to outwit bus riders who fail to deposit the correct fare.

title: Yokohama Wins
description: The Yokohama Taiyo Whales defeated last year's Japan Series champion, the Hanshin Tigers, by 8-7 in the season opener today. Carlos Ponce hit two home runs for Taiyo.

title: Another Challenge
description: Jeff Blatnick, the wrestler who survived cancer in the form of Hodgkin's disease and two years later won a gold medal at the 1984 Summer Olympics, has been challenged by the cancer again, and again he hopes to meet the challenge and resume his athletic career. The 28-year-old Blatnick, from Niskayuna, N.Y., near Albany, was diagnosed as having Hodgkin's disease last fall when a tumor near his groin was found to be malignant.

title: GIULIANI SEES A NEED FOR FURTHER REFORMS IN LOCAL CAMPAIGNS
description: Rudolph W. Giuliani, the United States Attorney in Manhattan, called yesterday for changes in campaign financing and criminal procedure to deter corruption. He said reforms were especially necessary because of the lack of a vibrant two-party system in New York City.

title: In the Family
description: Nancy Grunfeld, wife of the Knicks' Ernie, was out running near her home in Franklin Lakes, N.J., the other day when she got a taste of what her husband and the rest of the team have been going through. Mrs. Grunfeld, a competitive runner who had been stepping up her training in preparation for the Trevira Twosome 10-mile race in Central Park later this month, suddenly hit a hole in the roadway, tearing ligaments in her left ankle. When she showed up for the Knicks' game at the Garden that night, she was wearing a cast, which abetted a perception that she was, after all, just one of the guys. At season's end a week from now, the Knicks will have lost at least 386 man-games to injury - an unofficial, but very painful, N.B.A. record.

title: BANCO POPULAR DE PUERTO RICO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
WHAT A POSITIVE MEANS
description: To the Editor:

title: TSENG LABORATORIES reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-Includes a tax credit of $23,500.

title: On TRANSMISSION
description: To the Editor:

title: FEW BENEFITS YET OF DOLLAR'S DROP
description: Although the dollar has fallen sharply in recent months, business executives say foreign competitors have not raised prices as much as expected.

title: DR. HELEN NOWLIS
description: Dr. Helen Nowlis, director of a Federal drug education project for a decade, died of cancer Wednesday at home in Rochester. She was 72 years old.

title: Chevron Offer To Huntington
description: The Chevron Corporation said yesterday that it would offer to acquire the stake of the Huntington Beach Company that it does not already own in an exchange of stock that it valued at $66.3 million. Chevron currently holds 66 percent in the California real estate development company's 300,000 shares.

title: S-T-E-N-Y
description: Secretary of State George P. Shultz may think people have trouble spelling his name, as was reported in this space last month, but he'll get little sympathy from Representative Steny H. Hoyer.

title: SAVOY INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-Includes net from discontinued operations of $2,177,000, or 22 cents a share. c-Net income and includes net from discontinued operations of $1,658,000, or 17 cents a share. The results also include minority interest in profits and losses of a $832,000 pre-tax charge for the latest year, compared with a pre-tax gain of $190,000 for the previous year. Corrected from Thursday's editions.

title: WATSCO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes income from discontinued operations of $184,000 for the quarter and $2,960,000 for the year.

title: INKSTER, BRADLEY TIE FOR LEAD
description: Pat Bradley is in another of her many close fights for a Ladies Professional Golf Association victory. This time it's the Nabisco-Dinah Shore halfway point, with Miss Bradley and Juli Inkster tied for the lead at four-under-par 140.

title: SO ARE THE SANDINISTAS ANTI-SEMITIC? OF COURSE, THEY ARE
description: To the Editor:

title: Comings and Goings
description: Bengt Gustaffson, the center for the Washington Capitals, underwent surgery on his right leg, which he fractured against the Islanders last week. He will miss the rest of the season. . . . The Golden State Warriors' Chris Mullin, who has missed the last 16 games with a heel injury, will not return this season.

title: Your Money; Retirees Adjust To Rate Drops
description: WHEN Emanuel Raices, a New York executive, retired about three years ago, interest rates that could be earned by the small investor and saver were a lot higher than they are today. So he put a large portion of his assets in money market mutual funds and enjoyed the luxury of double-digit rates.

title: PRE-PAID LEGAL SERVICES reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Preferred dividend requirements exceeded net income in 1984. Revenue figures for 1984 fourth quarter and year are restated.

title: LOMAS & NETTLETON MTGE INFVESTORS reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
GIBRALTAR FINANCIAL reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-Includes extraordinary gain of $2,424,000.

title: JERSEY FOCUSING ON PRESCHOOLERS IN MEASLES CRISIS
description: Two-year-old Robert McClinton looked at the hypodermic syringe that held measles vaccine and let out a wail. The wail grew to a scream as Dr. John D. Porter, a state endocrinologist, stuck the needle into Robert's left arm.

title: STATES ACT TO FIGHT FALSE ADS ON FOOD
description: More and more food companies are adjusting national advertising campaigns to conform to requirements of states. In the past, states seldom took action against false or misleading ads and commercials: the job was handled by the Federal Trade Commission.

title: PRESS AGENCY GIVES COURT PLAN ON REORGANIZATION
description: United Press International asked permission yesterday in Federal Bankruptcy Court to file its long-awaited plan for a reorganization that could deliver the news agency out of its financial difficulties.

title: FRANCE SEEKS TO DEVALUE THE FRANC
description: France's new conservative Government is seeking immediate devaluation of the French franc barely two weeks after taking office, monetary officials said tonight.

title: HAMILTON AND SULLIVAN
description: The saxophonist Scott Hamilton and the singer Maxine Sullivan are appearing together tonight and tomorrow at Fat Tuesday's, 190 Third Avenue, at 17th Street (533-7902). Sets begin at 8 and 10 P.M. and midnight tonight, and at 8 and 10 P.M. tomorrow; there is a $12.50 cover and a $7.50 minimum.

title: A SWITCH FROM LONG BONDS
description: William H. Gross, Edgar Reed and Harvey M. Spiro each manage portfolios of bonds for different investment firms and have different approaches to making money for their clients. But these days they are making similar moves - selling hundreds of millions of dollars worth of long-term Treasury bonds and buying a mix of shorter-term securities.

title: STEELWORKERS RATIFY LTV PACT
description: United Steelworkers members have approved a 40-month contract with the LTV Steel Company, which cuts wages and benefits by more than $3 an hour at the nation's No. 2 steelmaker, union officials said today.

title: CARROLS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
description: b-Net income c-Includes an after-tax loss of $433,000 from the closing of several candy and nut shops. Last year's third quarter and 9 months figures include net after-tax gains of $272,000 and $621,000, or 4 cents and 8 cents a share, respectively, relating to disposition of units.

title: HAWTHORNE FINANCIAL reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
PROGRAM FOR JOBLESS FAILS TO HELP THEM ECONOMIST REPORTS
description: A tax credit enacted in 1978 to help the hard-core unemployed get jobs may actually hurt their chances of employment, according to a study published by the Brookings Institution.

title: ACCORD ON EXCHANGES SIGNED BY U.S. AND SOVIET SCIENTISTS
description: Two of the most important scientific organizations in the United States and the Soviet Union announced Friday that they had signed a new cooperative agreement for meetings and exchanges of scientists.

title: SATOR WOULD PREFER CAPITALS IN PLAYOFF
description: With the objective in sight, Ted Sator sat in his office at the Rangers' practice complex here today and considered the possibilities.

title: EXPENSIVE RENOVATION MISTAKES
description: FINALLY, after more than three months of washing dishes in the bathroom sink, cooking tortelloni in the toaster oven and cleaning plaster dust from toothbrushes, the residents of an Upper West Side apartment thought the renovation of their kitchen was finished.

title: POLICY STRUGGLES BY U.S. AND SOVIET ON VERGE OF SHIFT
description: The United States and the Soviet Union are engaged in a fundamental struggle to define the shape and content of Soviet-American relations for years to come, according to Administration officials.

title: THE DERELICTS OF 40th ST.: AN UNSETTLING PRESENCE
description: The middle-aged woman fell about noon yesterday and could not get up. She sat in her fake fur coat on the sidewalk at 40th Street and Eighth Avenue at the feet of two Port Authority police officers at the southern edge of the bus terminal.

title: THE U.S., SOVIET STAKES IN THE U.N.
description: The United Nations is rapidly going bankrupt. Old Soviet and new American arrears have turned a political crisis into a financial nightmare. And what do the superpowers have to say as their creation sinks into the East River?

title: CORRECTION
description: An article in Business Day Thursday about the previous day's stock trading misstated the movement in the stock of Prime Computer Inc. It rose 1/8, to 19 5/8.

title: BILLIONS TO PUNISH AIDS WON'T PROTECT SOCIETY
description: To the Editor:

title: BONN IS CRITICIZED OVER 'STAR WARS'
description: The Soviet Union lodged a formal protest with the Bonn Government today over an accord covering West German participation in the Reagan Administration's missile-defense research program.

title: Volunteer Flag-Raiser
description: This morning at 7:30, Philip Goldstein is to raise the flag in Joyce Kilmer Square, at Kings Highway and East 12th Street in the Flatbush section of Brooklyn.

title: MARCOS SAYS U.S. HELPED REBELS
description: Ferdinand E. Marcos, in an interview broadcast last night, asserted that the United States aided Philippine military forces who rebelled against him in the final hours of his presidency. He said Americans had refueled and rearmed helicopters that attacked his presidential palace.

title: NEW SEISMIC STUDIES IN CITY INCREASE CONCERN
description: Recently identified faults under the East River have reawakened concern that, contrary to widespread belief, New York City may be vulnerable to moderately severe earthquakes, according to an authority on the geology of the New York area.

title: DELTA QUEEN STEAMBOAT reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
SOME SEE A THREAT TO LOW AIR FARES
description: The rapid consolidation occurring in the airline industry will create pressure points that could restrict some deeply discounted fares, most airline experts say.

title: AUCTION OF DISPUTED GOYA TO PROCEED AT CHRISTIE'S
description: The auction of Goya's ''Marquesa de Santa Cruz,'' one of very few masterpieces by the Spanish artist still in private hands, is set for Friday at Christie's in London, despite efforts by the Spanish Government to block the sale.

title: DEATHS UNKNOWN
description: An explosion and fire leveled a huge warehouse complex in an industrial neighborhood here today, injuring at least 19 people and possibly trapping many more in the flames.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''I guess you could say we have fallen off the map.

title: IN THE GAZA STRIP: AN IGNORED, RESTLESS LAND
description: Tawfik Abu Ghazaleh, a middle-aged Palestinian lawyer, was trying to express to a visitor what it is like living in the Gaza Strip these days.

title: FED'S FEBRUARY VOTE: NO SHIFT
description: Policy makers at the Federal Reserve Board, in disagreement over the condition of the economy, voted by 10 to 2 in mid-February to leave monetary policy unchanged, according to minutes of the meeting released today.

title: CARDS' COX GIVEN PROMISING REPORT
description: The St. Louis Cardinals thought that a fishing accident would keep Danny Cox on the injured list for at least two months, but it seems now that Cox, an 18-game winner last season, could be back from an ankle injury in a couple of weeks.

title: Inflatable Pyramid For Rescues at Sea
description: A floating search and rescue inflatable pyramid is being produced by Survivco Inc. of Bellingham, Wash.

title: Key Rates
description: n.a.- Not available due to observance of Good Friday * Municipal Bond Index, The Bond Buyer Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: MDS HEALTH GROUP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: The company is listed on the Toronto Stock Exchange.

title: CANADIANS AND M.I.S.L. AT ODDS FOR CUP
description: Canada is in the World Cup in a first-round group with France, Hungary and the Soviet Union, but its first adversary for the tournament in Mexico in June is the Major Indoor Soccer League.

title: CRUTCHER RESOURCES reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $800,000 for the quarter and $1 million for the year. c-After losses from discontinued operations of $10,519,000 for the quarter and $13,793,000 for the year. The latest year loss is after non- recurring charges of $27.6 million, of which $25 million is in the fourth quarter, from the value of its land well servicing rigs, unsold land drilling rigs and related assets.

title: DEAVER STIRS A HORNET'S NEST
description: As a senior White House official and longtime friend of Ronald and Nancy Reagan, Michael K. Deaver could always be counted on to try to shield the President from any indiscretion or wrongdoing committed by subordinates.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: SATURDAY, APRIL 5, 1986
description: Markets

title: Ewing Settlement
description: Patrick Ewing of the Knicks has offered to pay a total of $125,717, plus medical and dental bills, over the next 20 years for his 1-year-old son, Patrick Jr. The offer was made in Middlesex Superior Court in Cambridge, Mass., as a response to the claim made by the child's mother, Sharon Stanford of Lowell, Mass., last February, who was seeking $2 million and wanted $50,000 to go to the son annually for the first 20 years.

title: 'Coup de l'Empereur' Allows An Imperial Gesture at Table
description: The most dramatic defensive play in the game is what the French call the ''coup de l'empereur.'' It calls for a player to discard, with an imperial gesture, a winning card, often an ace, in a suit that the declarer hopes to establish.

title: UNLIKE DETROIT, WEST COAST PORTS FIND JAPANESE CAR IMPORTS ARE A BLESSING
description: What seems to be a never-ending flow of new automobiles and trucks moves across the valley behind the old Navy piers off Elliott Bay to be loaded onto railroad cars or trucks for the trip to sales showrooms across the Pacific Northwest.

title: BATTLE OF THE DOCTORS VS. THE LAWYERS CONTINUES
description: To the Editor:

title: IN 3 LANDS, FAULT FOR BOMB IS ELSEWHERE
description: Since the bombing Wednesday of an American airliner, Italy, Greece and Egypt have been reacting in turn defensively, cautiously and angrily at the idea that they might once again have to bear a major burden of blame.

title: Bonds Fall After Early Gains
description: Bond prices vacillated in concert with oil prices yesterday and ended off more than a half-point.

title: 70,000 PAKISTANIS PROTEST AGAINST GENERAL ZIA
description: Crowds burned effigies of Pakistan's President and Prime Minister today as up to 70,000 people gathered to mark the seventh anniversary of the execution of former Prime Minister Zulkifar Ali Bhutto.

title:
PATENTS;
A World Clock
description: A world clock described as displaying the exact time at every location on earth simultaneously was patented this week by Thomas D. Shannon of New York. According to patent 4,579,460, the clock may be a wristwatch or a pocket watch. The clock includes a planisphere of the earth, the time scale and a drive for rotating the planisphere every 24 hours in synchronism with the rotation of the earth.

title: STALIN'S GRANDDAUGHTER GETS A BRITISH VISA
description: Britain today granted a visa to Olga Peters, the American-born teen-age granddaughter of Stalin, who was taken to the Soviet Union by her mother, Svetlana Alliluyeva, in 1984.

title:
GARDENING;
FRUIT TREES CAN COMPLEMENT LANDSCAPE
description: THE stone fruits, those with a single hard-coated seed surrounded by a layer of edible flesh, are popular for eating fresh as well as in processed forms. All are sufficiently attractive to be included in a garden that might otherwise be classified as strictly ornamental. Yet, they are grown less frequently than apples.

title: Reds Turn Back Clock
description: As the oldest team in organized baseball, the Cincinnati Reds are traditionally given the honor of being the host to the official opening game of the major-league season, and tomorrow, at 2:05 P.M., the Reds will continue the tradition by playing the Philadelphia Phillies. Trouble is, the Cincinnati game is due to start 35 minutes after the Tigers take on the Boston Red Sox in Detroit.

title: NEW CURTIS INSTITUTE DIRECTOR
description: GARY GRAFFMAN, the American pianist, has been named artistic director of the Curtis Institute of Music in Philadelphia. Mr. Graffman is a graduate of the school and has been on its piano faculty since 1980.

title: REBELS WITH MANY A CAUSE
description: THE CONTENTIOUS FRENCH By Charles Tilly. Illustrated. 456 pp. Cambridge, Mass.: The Belknap Press of Harvard University Press. $25.

title: RECENT RELEASES
description: Ricky Skaggs Live in London CBS/Fox Video Music 39 minutes. $19.98 Ricky Skaggs is country music's brightest hope among those who champion a more roots-oriented sound than the adulterated country-pop that has become Nashville's common currency. Mr. Skaggs's keening tenor and his band's spirited arrangements, which feature banjo, fiddles and acoustic guitars, fuse traditional bluegrass music with oldtime honky-tonk.

title: DON'T LOOK FOR LOGIC IN 'PARSIFAL'
description: Even those who despise ''Parsifal'' - and they have always constituted a mighty legion - must feel a twinge of pleasure when Wagner's last opera makes its annual appearance. No matter what the thermometer may say, we know that the arrival of ''Parsifal'' at the Metropolitan Opera this week spells spring. It is difficult to think of this music, which Thomas Mann penetratingly described as ''filled with a majestic sclerotic weariness,'' along with robins and crocuses, but perhaps more than any other Wagner work ''Parsifal'' is capable of arousing violently ambivalent feelings.

title: MEARS'S CAREER IS BACK AT FULL SPEED
description: After a year and a half that was more or less lost to serious leg injuries, Rick Mears will mark his return to full-time duty as a racing driver today at Phoenix, where the P.P.G. Indy Car World Series opens its 17-race season. Although he competed in just five of 15 races last year, Mears will start today's 200-mile race with the No. 1, symbolic of the series championship, painted on his bright yellow March-Cosworth racer.

title:
BOEING'S JOINT VENTURE;
MULTINATIONAL VENTURES ARE A FACT OF LIFE
description: BOEING'S planned joint venture with the Japanese in the production of a new generation of commercial aircraft, the 7J7, is being depicted in some quarters as the beginning of the end for the American commercial aircraft industry.

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL BALTIMORE (AL) - Placed Floyd Rayford, infielder, on 15-day disabled list.

title: CONCERT: PRIDONOFF DUO AND PERCUSSION GROUP
description: UP until the last piece, the concert of its faculty members presented Thursday night at Alice Tully Hall by the Cincinnati College Conservatory of Music was very winning indeed. The performers were the Pridonoff Piano Duo and the Percussion Group/Cincinnati. They alternated pieces until the final Bartok Sonata for Two Pianos and Percussion, which enlisted the duo and two of the three members of the percussion group.

title: His Own Ambulance Service
description: A Medicaid recipient who founded an ambulance service was arrested Friday on charges of billing Medicaid for taking himself to the hospital 269 times, the State Attorney General's office said. The charges of Medicaid fraud and forgery were filed against Donald Bowman Jr., 22 years old, whose company, the Georges Township Individual C.D. Ambulance Corporation, was also charged with 391 counts of fraud.

title: SUSAN E. WEISSELBERG PLANS TO MARRY IN JUNE
description: A June wedding is planned by Susan E. Weisselberg, counsel to the Democrats in the Connecticut House of Representatives, and Nicholas E. Neeley, the executive assistant to the chairman of Connecticut's Department of Public Utility Control.

title: Recent Sales In New Jersey
description: Hazlet $94,500 5 Rosemary Drive *2*3-bedroom, 1-bath, 30-year-old ranch; central *2*air-conditioning, attached garage, new windows; taxes $1,568. Hillsborough $72,000 3104 Cromwell Court *2*1-bedroom, 1-bath, 8-year-old town-house condominium; *2*balcony, electric heat, $61 monthly charges; taxes $1,115. Livingston $125,000 35 Mount Pleasant Parkway *2*3-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 50-year-old colonial; *2*modern kitchen, den; taxes $1,914. Metuchen $92,000 38 Hickory Street *2*4-bedroom, 1-bath, 45-year-old Cape Cod; fenced yard, *2*enclosed porch, 2-car garage; taxes $1,684. Somerville $80,500 73-0 Farm Road South *2*1-bedroom, 1-bath, 4-year-old town-house condominium; *2*wall-to-wall carpeting, $60 monthly charges; taxes $1,224. Tewksbury $314,000 Boulder Hill Road *2*4-bedroom, 2-bath, 8-year-old farmhouse; *2*pegged oak floors, tile foyer, 3 acres; taxes $3,866. OTHER AREAS Crompond, N.Y. $89,000 Baron de Hirsch Road *2*3-bedroom, 1-bath, 46-year-old frame ranch; *2*eat-in kitchen, enclosed porch, 2 decks, pool; taxes $1,744. Goshen, Conn. $139,500 43 Ashley Drive *2*4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 8-year-old colonial; *2*private-lake community, 2-car garage, 1 acre; taxes $1,800. Sayville, L.I. $219,000 154 Sunset Drive *2*4-bedroom, 2-bath, 30-year-old waterfront colonial; *2*family room, eat-in kitchen, bulkheading; taxes $4,000.

title: A Red Smith Story
description: I was pleased to see the article on Red Smith, arguably the best sportswriter ever (''A Writer Called Red Smith,'' by Ira Berkow, March 2). I would like to share my own Red Smith story.

title: DAVID RAYFIEL'S SCRIPT MAGIC
description: IT WAS A TYPICAL HOLLYWOOD plot. The screenplay for a murder mystery called ''The Morning After'' was offered a few years ago to Tri-Star Pictures, which showed it to Jane Fonda. She was interested, but the script needed work. Tri-Star ''put the property into turnaround,'' meaning it offered the screenplay for sale. Warner Brothers bought it and Mark H. Rosenberg, then president of production at that studio, assigned it to another writer for revisions. Still there were problems. ''It needed narrative work and some character development,'' Rosenberg recalls.

title: JAVITS CENTER PUTS ON SHOW FOR ITS FIRST PUBLIC AUDIENCE
description: The Jacob K. Javits Convention Center opened its doors to the general public yesterday and attracted not only those interested in the shows and exhibits but also those curious about the center itself.

title: OAKES AGAINST THE SPOOKS
description: HIGH JINX By William F. Buckley Jr. 261 pp. New York: Doubleday & Company. $16.95. THE language they speak in Albania is called Shqip and is divided into two dialects, Gheg and Tosk. More than one-third of the country is covered by forest, and there was no rail transport before 1948. On the face of it, this smallest member of the Communist community hardly seems a logical choice as the scene for mounting ''the most important countersalient since the beginning of the cold war.''

title: THE ISLAND'S ROLE IN DES SUITS
description: ILEEN SCHAEFFER of Nassau County is considered one of the lucky ones among the unlucky.

title: RANGERS SECURE SPOT IN PLAYOFFS
description: In game 79, on the night before the final day of the season, the Rangers finally nailed down their playoff spot. And they could say they did it themselves.

title: SINGING RECITALS IS NO WAY TO MAKE A LIVING
description: Song - the cherished realm where Milton's ''blest pair of Sirens'' meet, where music and poetry marry -is the first and best love of many musicians. From around the end of the 18th century to the early 20th, composers have built a vast and treasured repertory of poems set to music for voice and piano accompaniment. Schubert devoted the greater portion of his life's work to it, winning meager financial rewards. Ditto singers in America today whose devotions run likewise.

title: REAGAN ACKNOWLEDGES CARTER'S MILITARY BUILDUP
description: President Reagan today publicly acknowledged that his predecessor, President Carter, had recognized the need to rebuild the nation's armed forces.

title:
NEW JERSEY OPINION;
THE TURNPIKE CAN BE STOPPED
description: ALMOST every day, somebody asks me, ''Do you really think you can stop the turnpike?'' My answer is always a resounding ''Yes!''

title: 5 in Sex Case Forced To Quit Annapolis
description: Five United States Naval Academy midshipmen, four men and a woman, have been forced to resign over sexual misconduct in Bancroft Hall, the school's coeducational dormitory.

title: SEAFOOD IN A NAUTICAL SETTING
description: WORD of a new restaurant in Bridgeport evokes hope in this long-declining city. That is why news of Captain's Cove Seaport, a new marina with a restaurant and shops, sparked considerable interest.

title: KATHERINE GROVER BECOMES A BRIDE
description: Katherine Marsh Grover and Michael John Campbell were married yesterday in the Central Presbyterian Church in Montclair, N.J., by the Rev. Ernest Fogg.

title: IS KHAKI CHIC OR ANTI-CHIC?
description: To the Editor:

title: NEW JERSEYANS
description: IN TRENTON, Governor Kean calls him ''New Jersey's urban maven.'' In Washington, they say he's a Democrat who makes things work.

title: NEW YORK INSPECTORS CITE 31 FOOD OUTLETS FOR HEALTH OFFENSES
description: The New York City Department of Health last week released a list of 31 food establishments cited for violating the health code.

title: SPRING SEASON GROWS MORE POPULAR AND LESS PASTORAL
description: GEORGE PLIMPTON leaned out of the press box high behind home plate in the picture-postcard little ball park here and winced in the direction of the tall glass building across the street. ''Spring training used to be baseball as it should be,'' he said. ''There was a different murmur to the crowd. No Federal building across the street. Bucolic.''

title: O'Neill Takes An Early Lead In Delegate Count
description: The fight for Connecticut's Democratic gubernatorial nomination began in earnest last week, and the initial returns augured well for the incumbent, William A. O'Neill.

title: MARYLAND, FOR NOW, WILL NOT REGULATE LYRICS
description: It's only rock-and-roll and they may not really like it, but members of the Maryland General Assembly will not attempt to regulate rock music.

title: PIKE RAISES QUESTIONS ON PLANNING
description: THE controversial plan to widen the New Jersey Turnpike has spawned a broader debate about the adequacy of transportation planning in the state. Much of the public criticism of the proposed $2 billion turnpike project has focused on the costs to the environment and communities through which the road would cut a wider swath.

title: FAMILY RECORDS LIFE IN WILDS OF INTERIOR BRAZIL
description: LOGGING companies are said to be felling the world's rain forests at the rate of 50 acres a minute. Because the equatorial and tropical growth acts as the lungs of the globe, chances are that by the century's end humans will be wearing spacesuits whether they defect to other planets or not. This wasn't what Buckminster Fuller had in mind when he coined the term, ''Spaceship Earth.''

title: The Reluctant Chauvinist
description: I have long felt that the remaining problem with the women's movement is that it is still somewhat respectable to be a sexist. It is still considered cute (by some benighted folks) to be a male chauvinist and to advertise these attitudes at bars and parties. How many of these same people would ever say, ''I'm a racist and proud of it''? MALVINA WASSERMAN New York City

title: COURT ASKED TO DECIDE IF CASINO IS A 'PALACE'
description: WHO CAN call a casino a palace? That is the burning legal issue in Federal District Court here.

title: THE MODERATION OF GOV. WALLACE
description: BOTH ailing and trailing many of his prospective opponents in the polls, George Corley Wallace, near the end of his fourth term as Alabama's Governor, announced last week that he would run no more. ''After much prayerful consideration, I feel that I must say I have climbed my last political mountain,'' he said. ''I must pass the rope and the pick to another climber.''

title: RENT DEPOSITS WOULD HELP BUILD HOUSING
description: CONNECTICUT would become the first state in the country to use renters' security deposits to help solve its housing problems, if a proposal before the state legislature becomes law.

title: TRADES FRUITFUL AT SHEA
description: THEY found Dwight Gooden pitching in Hillsborough High School in Tampa, Fla. They found Darryl Strawberry hitting in Crenshaw High in Los Angeles. They spotted Mookie Wilson at the University of South Carolina, and Rick Aguilera at Brigham Young, and they noticed Wally Backman at Aloha High in Oregon.

title: SHOWDOWN NEARS ON HUGHES GUN BILL
description: AS AN assistant prosecutor trying three men accused of double murder, William J. Hughes leaned heavily on New Jersey's tight handgun control regulations to trace the murder weapon.

title:
NUMISMATICS;
A MEDAL FOR HISTORY
description: Benjamin Franklin, one of this nation's founding fathers, appears on a new medal of the United States Capitol Historical Society. The new issue, the latest in a series, bears the imprimatur of the Commission on the Bicentennial of the United States Constitution.

title: THE RECORD BOOK OF GUINNESS
description: BLESSINGS IN DISGUISE By Alec Guinness. Illustrated. 238 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $17.95.

title: HELPING HANDS IN ZONING SUIT
description: To the Editor:

title: CAROL TARANTINO PLANNING TO WED
description: Mr. and Mrs. Samuel Tarantino of Franklin Lakes, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter Carol Tarantino to Mario Biaggi Jr., a son of Representative and Mrs. Biaggi of the Bronx.

title: PAPERBACK BEST SELLERS: April 6, 1986
description: Fiction

title: NYSTROM GOES OUT WINNING
description: What figured to be a routine game between the Islanders and the Devils gained a nostalgic quality when Bob Nystrom, the 14-year veteran, made what will probably be his last appearance at right wing.

title: Jazz
description: Bill Cosby is an enthusiastic jazz fan, a supporter of the music, the musicians and the places where jazz can be heard. He has often been master of ceremonies at jazz concerts and is an habitue of the Blue Note, the jazz club at 131 West Third Street, where he frequently makes the presentation of plaques of appreciation that the club's manager, Sal Haries, gives to performers at the conclusion of their engagements.

title: MISSING THE TITANIC, DROWNING IN THE BATH
description: AN EARTHQUAKE IN MY FAMILY By J. F. Federspiel. Translated by Eveline L. Kanes. 249 pp. New York: E. P. Dutton. $17.95.

title: Bulgaria Adopts Gorbachev's Course
description: The Bulgarian Communist Party ended a congress today that marked the country's adoption of the course Mikhail S. Gorbachev charted for the Soviet Union at the party congress in Moscow.

title: Asking Civil Questions
description: There was an hour between planes. A man behind two brochure-laden card tables was calling out in a midway voice, ''Step up and learn about our space program.''

title: NOTED WITH PLEASURE
description: Prose Draws Blood In a piece called ''Polyclinic,'' the German critic Walter Benjamin compares a writer setting to work in a cafe to a surgeon in an operating theater. This is from ''Walter Benjamin: Reflections'' (Schocken), edited by Peter Demetz.

title: STATE WARY OF CONTRACTS BY COUNTIES ON GARBAGE
description: AS Long Island towns prepare to build garbage-burning incinerators that must replace landfill dumps by 1990, a state watchdog commission has raised questions about whether local governments, based on past performances, can undertake such projects without wasting millions of dollars in public money.

title: THE ENVIRONMENT
description: THE state's Hazardous Waste Facilities Siting Commission expected vocal opposition when it announced potential disposal sites in February, but it could not have anticipated the strong criticism it has received from Representative James J. Florio, New Jersey's most outspoken Congressional proponent of safer waste disposal.

title: Jersey Inspectors to Check Purple-Tinted Marsh Water
description: State inspectors will take samples Monday at a marshy, wooded area where a man discovered several hundred industrial drums and purple-tinted water while taking a walk, a state official said today.

title: LISA KOENIGSBERG PLANNING TO MARRY KEVIN DAVID WEIR, A BANK EXECUTIVE
description: Mr. and Mrs. Harry L. Koenigsberg of New York have announced the engagement of their daughter, Lisa Koenigsberg, to Kevin David Weir, a son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Irvin Weir of Riverside, Calif. A May 11 wedding is planned.

title: CONCERT: ORIGINAL 'NO, NO, NANETTE'
description: AS we have come to expect from John McGinn's period-perfect revivials of early American musicals, his current ministrations on behalf of ''No, No, Nanette'' at Carnegie Recital Hall make for a perfectly charming evening (or afternoon, since the fifth and final performance is this afternoon at 3).

title: THE FORCE IS WITH US
description: THE UNFINISHED UNIVERSE By Louise B. Young. Illustrated. 239 pp. New York: Simon & Schuster. $17.95.

title: Women and American Poetry
description: To the Editor:

title: ON HER 40TH BIRTHDAY, A WOMAN TRIES OUT HER WINGS
