description: ''HAPPY BIRTHDAY, Dearie'' I heard my husband say on a beautiful, crisp November morning. My 40th birthday, inevitable as it was, didn't mean I was ready for it yet. Many things had changed since my husband and I met at college, but I felt remarkably unchanged. Yes, my hair is more gray than brown now and we won't discuss the wrinkles, but there are more similarities than differences between the person I am today and the young woman of 20 years ago.

title: JAPAN'S FUCHA RYORI, A MEAL FIT FOR A MONK
description: The vegetarian dishes of Japanese Zen temples are prepared in a manner that reveals and enhances the purity, simplicity and freshness of the ingredients. This cuisine, called shojin ryori (which means a method of cooking in which one pursues the pure way of the Buddha), has developed mainly within the Rinzai sect of Zen, with its emphasis on meditative practices and sudden enlightenment, brought to Japan from China in the 12th century. In Rinzai temples, preparation of the food is a kind of religious discipline, and during the meal, to which each monk brings his own utensils, one must not speak and must sit formally and adhere to various other rules.

title: MASTERING EQUIPMENT IN CLOSE-UP PHOTOGRAPHY
description: Spring is a good time to think about close-up photography. The arrival of buds, flowers and insects provides photographers with ready subjects that are small, colorful and provocative.

title: Energy Bill on Appliances
description: Governor Cuomo has proposed legislation that would impose stricter energy-efficiency standards on some appliances sold in the state. The bill is designed to reduce the need for new power plants and to save consumers money, Mr. Cuomo said today. Under the bill, it would be illegal to advertise, display, sell or install such appliances as refrigerators.

title: BISON HUNT IS OVER BUT DEBATE LIVES
description: A hunt for bison that strayed out of Yellowstone Park has ended for the season, and park officials say they will try to keep the animals away from hunters next year.

title: A RIVER WATCHDOG IS TURNING 20
description: Last year, as part of a tributary-by-tributary look at the Hudson River watershed, the Hudson River Fishermen's Association began an investigation of pollution on Quassaick Creek in Newburgh.

title: NORTHEAST JOURNAL
description: IN CAMBRIDGE, SELF-DEFENSE PLEA UNLESS he receives a pardon from the Governor, a Cambridge, Mass., man will soon go to prison for using an unlicensed pistol to shoot a man who lunged at him with a knife.

title: Corsica
description: To the Editor: In his March 2 piece on Corsica, Richard Reeves noted that he stayed in Calvi ''on a street named, incongruously, for President Woodrow Wilson.''

title: Bradley Fires 69 to Lead Shore Golf by 3
description: Pat Bradley birdied the par-5 18th hole at Mission Hills Country Club today as Juli Inkster bogeyed at the island green, giving Miss Bradley a three-shot lead over Mrs. Inkster after three rounds of the 15th annual Nabisco-Dinah Shore tournament.

title: IN CHAD, THE PEASANTS WORK AND WAIT
description: AS cars kicked up dust along the dirt track that pushes through this small town, groups of women pulled bright printed cotton shawls across their faces and glanced curiously. The procession was headed toward an acre of open ground on which 44 small booths had been erected. At one, samples of cotton plants were displayed. At another, cans of insecticide were stacked, with photographs of vegetables free from insect damage. Two small water pumps were laid out at a third booth, along with simple steel plows and rakes.

title: WAITING FOR THE HARBINGERS OF SPRING
description: LIKE an idle child I peer through the plastic-encased window of my living room. Across the yard the March wind swirls, blowing without mercy the unraked leaves of the fall. Winter was fierce, cold and unrelenting, forever reminding me of what should have been accomplished in milder days and of what remains to be done in the times ahead.

title: MEESE'S HARVARD AWARD RUED
description: A dean at Harvard University has reportedly apologized to the faculty for choosing Attorney General Edwin Meese 3d for a public service award.

title: IMPROVING THE BIG PICTURE PROJECTION TV MAKES STRIDES
description: Videophiles are thinking big - and that's official. The Electronics Industries Association reports sharply rising sales of projection TV sets - 41 percent ahead of just a year ago - and despite their considerable bulk and cost, the vogue for such models keeps gaining momentum.

title: Topics; In the Driver's Seat Two Stars
description: France's two-headed Government will debut on the world stage next month when President Francois Mitterrand and Jacques Chirac, the new Prime Minister, attend the economic summit meeting in Tokyo together.

title: JOSEPH KENNEDY GETS A WIDER FIELD
description: The Democratic primary for Congress in the Eighth District of Massachusetts is months away, but the field of candidates, which once numbered more than a dozen, is thinning rapidly.

title: REMEMBERING THE MASTERS, GOLF'S BLACK TIE AFFAIR
description: MASTERS week is upon us again, a golfing spectacle not only to be played and watched but to be celebrated as some ancient ritual and savored as an unforgettable experience.

title: U.S. SEES METHODS OF LIBYA IN ATTACK
description: The Reagan Administration said today that the bombing in a West Berlin nightclub in which an American soldier was killed appeared to be part of a ''pattern of indiscriminate violence'' against Americans by Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi, the Libyan leader.

title: THORPE: EVOLVING ENVIRONMENTS
description: ONE enters one room through a hallway strewn with hay.

title: PENTAGON TO TIGHTEN REVIEW OF AIR CHARTERS
description: The Defense Department is tightening its review of charter airlines that carry military people after a study found major shortcomings in the monitoring of the carriers.

title: BUSINESS NOTES
description: PEAT, Marwick, Mitchell & Company, one of the nation's ''big eight'' international accounting concerns, will move its administrative offices, communications department, computer facilities and 600 employees from New York City to Montvale, in Bergen county, in September.

title: FABIAN MOTHER SUPERIOR
description: THE DIARY OF BEATRICE WEBB Volume Four: 1924-1943. ''The Wheel of Life.'' Edited by Norman MacKenzie and Jeanne MacKenzie. Illustrated. 519 pp. Cambridge, Mass.: The Belknap Press of Harvard University Press. $25.

title: A Novel Strain of Recklessness
description: The dazzling new techniques of genetic engineering have been safely practiced behind laboratory doors for a decade. But now that engineers are getting ready to release the first genetically altered agricultural organisms into the environment, they have stumbled badly. The problem lies not in the technology but in the deceit and recklessness of some early practitioners.

title: VIVIAN KOCH MARRIED TO ANDREW MATHEWS
description: Vivian Marie Koch, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Karl W. Koch 3d of Manhasset, L.I., was married yesterday to Andrew Guy Mathews, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Geoffrey Stephen Mathews of Stoke Poges, Buckinghamshire, England. The Rev. Lawrence Costello performed the ceremony at St. Mary's Roman Catholic Church in Manhasset.

title: ALTAR GIRLS: A QUIET DEFIANCE OF POLICY
description: In long white robes corded at the waist, 12-year-old Christy A. Baker and Eileen K. Dalessandro, 13, resembled miniature monks as they carefully lighted candles at the wooden altar of St. Mary's Church in Colts Neck, N.J., just before the Sunday noon mass.

title: 2 ROOKIES WHO FAILED IN '85 GET SECOND CHANCES
description: WHEN Dwight Gooden began the 1984 season with the Mets as a widely heralded rookie, he responded by matching - or even exceeding - the team's expectations of him. Not all such heralded youngsters have Gooden's instant success. Some never have much success. Some have delayed success. When Eric Davis of Cincinnati and Shawon Dunston of the Chicago Cubs began the 1985 season in the opening-day starting lineups, their teams believed they were ready to play regularly and productively in the major leagues. Neither one lasted in the majors the first half of the season.

title:
INVESTING;
TRACKING THE FOREIGN EQUITY MARKETS
description: MORE and more professional money managers are looking abroad, especially since the surge in the American market has made it difficult to find bargains in domestic equities. The overseas equity markets taken together are about as large as those of the United States, but the amount of information readily available to American money managers who want to invest abroad is comparatively sparse.

title: Antitrust Reform
description: To the Editor:

title: Classical Music
description: Igor Stravinsky is reported to have said that he liked Arnold Schoenberg's ''Pierrot Lunaire'' very much except for the fact that there always seemed to be some woman screaming during performances of it. He was referring, of course, to the sprechstimme element (a kind of sung-speech) of the 1912 work by Schoenberg that incorporates 21 poems by Albert Giraud.

title: BENEFACTORS OF L.I.'S WILD CREATURES
description: Sallie Hicks Ruppert knows it is spring when little birds start falling from trees.

title: LES BAUX, MEDIEVAL PERCH IN PROVENCE
description: Les Baux is a rocky plateau cutting into the gentle breeze of Provence.

title: MISS MANEE PLANS TO WED
description: Mrs. John Templeton Strong of Greenwich, Conn., and Monte Stewart Manee of Scarsdale, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter Sandra Manee to George Monroe Evans Jr., the son of Mr. and Mrs. Evans of Greenwich. The wedding is planned for Dec. 6.

title: GLITTERING JAVITS CENTER KINDLES DREAMS FOR WEST SIDE
description: THE shimmering crystalline cubes of the newly opened Jacob K. Javits Convention Center reflect not only the unparalleled New York skyline, but also the visions and dreams of scores of developers.

title: DANCE: TAYLOR COMPANY PRESENTS THREE WORKS
description: ALL three works that the Paul Taylor Dance Company presented Thursday night at the City Center were plotless. Nevertheless, thanks to Mr. Taylor's choreographic control of movement qualities, each became dramatic in its own way.

title: Canute's Bum Rap
description: ADAM YARMOLINSKY, who is located somewhere between Adam Walinsky and Daniel Yankelovich, wrote an Op-Ed piece last month opposing the President's attempt to reverse the ebb tide of defense spending. Before jumping on this good man for his mangled metaphor, let me hoot at the identification at the bottom of his piece: ''professor of policy sciences at the University of Maryland.''

title: KAREN A. O'BRIEN TO WED IN AUGUST
description: Mr. and Mrs. Kevin J. O'Brien of Harrison, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter Karen A. O'Brien to Stephen C. Lichtenauer, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert A. Lichtenauer of Indianapolis. The wedding is planned for August.

title: BLYTHE HAMER IS WED TO BRADLEY C. GEWEHR
description: Blythe Hamer, a daughter of Marilou Hamer of East Hampton, L.I., and Warren G. Hamer of New York and Southampton, L.I., was married yesterday to Bradley Charles Gewehr, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Herbert Gewehr of Windsor, Conn. The Rev. Charles P. Henderson performed the ceremony at the Central Presbyterian Church in New York.

title: RABIES UP IN PENNSYLVANIA
description: Pennsylvania health officials confirmed 111 cases of rabies in animals over the first three months of 1986, almost twice the 60 cases found by this time a year ago, the state health department says.

title: Access and Influence
description: Did Michael K. Deaver, the former White House deputy chief of staff, breach the Federal ethics law while serving as a consultant for the Canadian Government?

title: STATE COURT UPSETS BOSTON LAW FORCING BUILDERS TO AID POOR
description: A Massachusetts judge has reversed a Boston law requiring downtown developers to give to a fund designed to aid the city's poorer residential communities.

title: TRAVELING TO NICARAGUA YIELDS NO EASY ANSWERS
description: REPRESENTATIVE Sander M. Levin held up La Prensa, the main opposition newspaper in Nicaragua. The editors had marked stories subjected to censorship by the Sandinista Government. Almost every front-page article was checked.

title: SPACEPLANE WORK SET TO START SOON
description: In an important step toward developing an aerospace plane, a potential successor to the space shuttle, the Government plans to award contracts this month for the first full-scale test engines and structural components.

title: Participatory Democracy Engenders Strange Results; Primaries by Lot
description: To the Editor:

title: HUGUENOT SOCIETY OF AMERICA KEEPS HISTORY ALIVE
description: THE names from the past and the present carry a common heritage: Paul Revere. Pierre Bowdoin. John Jay. John Paul Jones. All have one thing in common - they are descended from the Huguenots who came here from France during the colonial period to enjoy religious freedom.

title: Reagan Plans to Reform Pentagon
description: Falling in step with a Presidential commission, the White House announced last week that Commander in Chief Ronald Reagan had decided to give the Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff more firepower. And in his radio address yesterday, the President urged Congress to approve legislation needed to expand the chairman's role and to establish a new position, that of Under Secretary of Defense for Acquisition, who would oversee - and presumably make less wasteful - the way the Pentagon designs and buys weapons.

title: THOU SHALT NOT
description: A WHILE ago, I advocated licensing drug sales alongside a national educational effort to persuade potential users, on purely utilitarian grounds, that, on the whole, they were better off not amputating mind and body in exchange for quick nervous highs. None of the reactions to my suggestion surprised me, save one, by Dr. Mitchell Rosenthal. He is the head of Phoenix House, and he said that drugs should continue to be illegal, pending the day when they were universally shunned. He explained that the only way to lick marijuana, targeted merely as an example, was to engender ''societal disapproval'' and bring on ''informal social sanctions'' of a kind that would make marijuana simply not accepted. His objective is nothing less than to ''revive an ethos.'' Make drug-taking . . . ''sinful''? What exactly is that?

title: Press Freedoms Under Pressure in Southeast Asia
description: Journalists in non-Communist Southeast Asian countries have come under growing pressure from governments worried about unauthorized disclosures of information and the preservation of ''national images.''

title: TESTING PLAN SENT TO PLAYERS
description: Baseball Commissioner Peter Ueberroth has distributed a letter to all major-league players that states drug testing will take place only during the next two years with four samples being submitted between March and October, United Press International learned tonight.

title: WHO'S TOP DOG IN THIS HOUSE?
description: LATELY I came across a snapshot of my dog Tanya, taken on an April morning six years ago. The sun is pouring through the front door, and she sits alertly in a puddle of light, tulip ears erect and nose tilted high to soak up the smells coming through the screen.

title: THE BOYS OF SPRING
description: THE SHORT SEASON The Hard Work and High Times of Baseball in the Spring. By David Falkner. 276 pp. New York: Times Books. $16.95.

title: ROSE AND PEREZ CAN DO IT SO WHY NOT ME, TOO?
description: TOMORROW could have been a big day for me. It could have been my 22d Opening Day in the major leagues. That's right, it could have been. After all, two guys I started with back in 1960 are still playing.

title: DELI FOOD ON A GRAND SCALE: 500,000 FRANKFURTERS A DAY
description: OPEN the door to the refrigerator in the home of Isadore (Skip) Pines in Old Westbury, and doubtless there will be a salami and some frankfurters inside.

title: U.S. Neglect of the Mideast Is Myopic
description: For all the flurry of concern in Washington last week about the repercussions of Saudi oil policy, there has on the whole been a major lapse of official American interest in the Middle East. The decline of concern has been evident for some time, and the collapse of the oil market only accelerated the process, encouraging officials in Washington to believe that the United States is no longer hostage to the oil shortage and could therefore disengage from the Middle East.

title: WORTHY SPEAKERS FOR LOW BUDGETS
description: Fledgling audio fans tend toward budget-priced components, and when it comes to picking a pair of speakers, the price range preferred by novices is usually somewhere between $150 and $200.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: PUBLIC DOMAIN, PRIVATE DOMINION: A History of Public Mineral Policy in America. By Carl J. Mayer and George A. Riley. (Sierra Club, $25.)

title: DANCE: HARLEM TROUPE'S 'STREETCAR'
description: IT is interesting to see how Arthur Mitchell has built a repertory for the Dance Theater of Harlem. The company began with ballets by Mr. Mitchell, its founder and director, that were tailored to its young needs, with evocative ethnic-flavored romps, and with classical standard-setting ballets by George Balanchine. There was a Balanchine work -''Stars and Stripes'' - on Thursday's program at City College's Aaron Davis Hall, and it was danced with a light-hearted appreciation of the ballet's pizazz. But the two dances that made up the balance of the program, acquired more recently, took the company in new directions. ''A Streetcar Named Desire'' is a narrative ballet by Valerie Bettis that serves as a showcase for the vivid but easy dramatic sounds that are an indentifying chracteristic of the company. And in David Gordon's ''Piano Movers,'' new last season, Dance Theater has a first and fashionable post-modernist piece.

title: '80's ITEMS COLLECTED FOR TIME CAPSULE
description: THEY are collecting books and diapers, and hope to acquire a Cuisinart, a videocassette of break-dancing, some athletic wear and jewelry.

title: TESTING THE PERSUASIVE POWERS OF VCR'S
description: After changing the way Americans live, the video cassette recorder is increasingly being used to change the way they think.

title: A TOWN POISED FOR GROWTH PAUSES TO DO IT RIGHT
description: THE little town of Scotland had long been quiet, but developers wanted to change that. So the town decided to take 60 days to think things through.

title: AUSTRALIA COMES UP WITH ITS OWN ANSWER TO 'DALLAS'
description: At least they didn't call it ''Sydney.''

title: PROSPECTS
description: Unemployed and Illegal Last Friday's report that overall unemployment dipped to 7.1 percent in March, a drop of only one-tenth of 1 percent from February, may have surprised economists who predicted the rate would go below 7 percent. But Sam Nakagama of Nakagama & Wallace Inc., says one reason the rate may be stuck is that in January the Government began including millions of illegal immigrants in its jobless calculations.

title: Thais Let Coup Suspect Leave for Japan
description: A former Prime Minister who is a leading suspect in an attempt to overthrow the Thai Government last September was allowed to leave Thailand today for a meeting in Japan of former political leaders.

title: Women and American Poetry
description: To the Editor:

title: The Role-Model Game
description: THE TROUBLE WITH baseball is that it believes its own advertising. How else are we to explain the constant talk about ''role models''?

title: Texas A&M Freshman Sets Shot-Put Mark
description: Texas A&M's Randy Barnes made the third best shot-put throw in Southwest Conference history today and the best ever nationally by a freshman, taking first place at the 59th Texas Relays with a throw of 69 feet 2 1/4 inches.

title: YALE MEMORIAL IS LABOR OF LOVE
description: WHEN George Levine set out to build a memorial to his son Matthew, he wanted to be certain that the project was carried out with the utmost of care. After all, the memorial would not only keep the memory of Matthew alive, but would represent the first major architectural change in one of Yale University's most beloved courtyards.

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS
description: A PORCUPINE NAMED FLUFFY. By Helen Lester. Illustrated by Lynn Munsinger. 32 pages. Boston: Houghton Mifflin Company. $12.95. (Ages 4 to 7) WHEN I was growing up, I knew lots of children who hated their names. I certainly hated mine. ''It's a lovely name,'' my mother told me. '' 'Grave Alice' is from Longfellow's ''Children's Hour.'' Since I felt I had to live up to my name, I wished she had chosen ''Laughing Allegra.'' My problem was minor compared to Fluffy's! His proud parents rejected names like Spike and Lance and Needleroozer - any of which would have been easier for a porcupine to live up to. But oh, no. ''Let's call him Fluffy.'' they say. ''It's such a pretty name.'' And it doesn't take Fluffy long to realize that he isn't. ''He first became suspicious when he backed into a door and stuck fast. That was not a fluffy thing to do.'' So he tries to live up to his name. But it's not easy being a cloud when you're a porcupine - it's hard to stay up. And it's dangerous to pretend you're a fluffy pillow. ''When his mother sat on him, she was not pleased.''

title: Market-Oriented Energy Policies Are the Answer to Our Needs
description: To the Editor:

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: C. B. GREENFIELD: A LITTLE MADNESS. By Lucille Kallen. (Random House, $14.95.) Charlie Greenfield, suburban news editor, has solved some murders, but only fine music can bring him to a state resembling animation.

title: 33 BAROQUE MASTERPIECES FROM RINGLING COLLECTION ON VIEW IN WASHINGTON
description: IN the 1920's, John Ringling traveled to Europe at least once a year in search of new acts for the Ringling Brothers circus. But he would also often steal away from business to indulge another more personal pleasure: collecting masterpieces of Baroque art by painters like Peter Paul Rubens, Nicolas Poussin and Francesco del Cairo.

title: WAITING OUT A PREGNANCY SCARE
description: EVERY morning during those long tumultuous days when I was convinced I was pregnant, I woke with two images. One was of a child of about 8 years old, shouting as he climbed an endless green slope, and then, just as he reached the top, vanishing, like a character in a Bergman movie, into white, nightgown-like shadows. The other image was of a thimble-sized embryo with eyes, fingers, knees and toes, curled up, like some precious but forgotten ring, in a wad of cotton at the bottom of a hospital trash bin.

title: ALL ABOARD THE FLYING CARPET
description: ARAB FOLKTALES Edited and translated by Inea Bushnaq. Illustrated. 386 pp. New York: Pantheon Books. $19.95.

title: CUOMO PROPOSES REPEAL OF LAW ON PUBLIC-BUILDING CONTRACTORS
description: Governor Cuomo proposed legislation yesterday to eliminate a 65-year- old law that bars the use of general contractors on big public building projects.

title: FATHERS AND TODDLERS LEARN TOGETHER IN ARDSLEY PROGRAM
description: IMAGINE a 175-pound man in his 30's wobbling around on a tricycle built for a 25-pound 2-year-old. Pedaling with his legs bent and his knees awkwardly pointed out, he looks more like a clown delighting children of all ages.

title: LONG ISLAND JOURNAL
description: GOING, GOING...

title: Participatory Democracy Engenders Strange Results
description: To the Editor:

title: HILARY PHELPS MARRIES LIEUT. W. H. FISHER 3D
description: Hilary Ann Phelps, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edwin J. Phelps Jr. of Ridgefield, Conn., was married yesterday to Lieut. William H. Fisher 3d, U.S.A.F., the son of Dr. and Mrs. Fisher Jr. of Woodbury, Conn.

title: KATHLEEN BORIE TO MARRY JEREMY D. TAYLOR MAY 10
description: Martine O'Connor of Bellport, L.I., and Bernard Borie of Oak Ridge, Tenn., have announced the engagement of their daughter Kathleen Nathalie Borie to Jeremy Dakin Taylor, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Noel Taylor of Ottawa. A May 10 wedding is planned.

title: JODY WEINFLASH IS ENGAGED TO DR. STEVEN N. KONSTADT
description: Jody Ann Weinflash, a third-year medical student at the Mount Sinai School of Medicine, and Dr. Steven Neal Konstadt, an assistant professor of anesthesiology at Mount Sinai Hospital, plan to be married in June. The announcement was made by the future bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Bernard Weinflash of Cresskill, N.J.

title: By the Clock, Newark Style
description: While the long waits cause many police officers to despise appearing as witnesses in court, some of Newark's finest apparently like nothing better. A state grand jury said last week that between 1981 and 1984 officers in New Jersey's largest city routinely collected thousands of dollars in unwarranted overtime pay by appearing as witnesses for cases that were not ready for trial.

title: EPILEPTIC SEAL GETS AN ADOPTIVE HOME
description: LIKE other epileptics, Barney has to watch his diet and weight to ward off seizures that could leave him vulnerable in an unforgiving world. At 250 pounds, his doctors say, he is normal for a 4-year-old male.

title: READING BEFORE WRITING
description: IN the beginning, it is said, was the ''word.'' But the archeological record of the Old Stone Age or Paleolithic period is silent. What one finds instead in the soil is the image. And what extraordinary images. The unfleshed, time-cleansed shadow of man: a grinning skull, emptied eyes, some disarticulated skeletal fragments, a few finer bones, some loose teeth, a jaw, a broken hip, the remains of meals, a habitation floor or workplace, the stone-hard tools, and then, seemingly suddenly in the archeological record of some 32,000 years ago, images made by man - animals, humans (especially females) and strange signs and symbols. It is these images that have recently begun to speak.

title:
DINING OUT;
GOLF CLUB FARE: PAR FOR THE COURSE
description: PRINCE MAXIMILIAN, a restaurant in the Tamcrest Country Club in Alpine, opened last year with a blaze of eye-catching publicity. The tongue-in-cheek advertisements and the news releases promised an experience unequaled in the annals of New Jersey dining. The funny thing is, they were almost right. We have become accustomed to exaggerated claims by new restaurants opening in the state, but who could resist calling the bluff of one that includes the following in its advertisements:

title: THE DANGER IN SOCIAL CRUSADES
description: Dr. David Musto's timely and perceptive observations [ ''New Temperance Movement Seen by Historian,'' March 16 ] were of enormous interest. Given the opportunity, he might have noted some other things.

title: WINNIE MANDELA ASSAILS PRETORIA
description: The black nationalist Winnie Mandela today described South African Government officials as terrorists and called for ''direct action'' against them.

title: NANCY TALBOT BROADBENT IS MARRIED TO DOMINIC JAMES ANDREW CASSERLEY
description: Nancy Talbot Broadbent and Dominic James Andrew Casserley were married yesterday at St. Thomas Church in New York. The Rev. Dr. John Andrew officiated at the Episcopal ceremony.

title: MASSACHUSETTS IS MULLING MUFFINS
description: The Massachusetts House of Representatives has voted to make corn muffins the official state muffin, but the proposal faces opposition in the Senate from Cape Cod lawmakers who think the cranberry muffin would better represent the state.

title: Pattern of Abuse Found at Georgia
description: During his tenure as President of the University of Georgia, the school's budget tripled, as did money for scientific research; the faculty increased by half, and the student body grew even more; graduate enrollment and doctoral degrees doubled. But according to a report last week by the Board of Regents of the University System of Georgia, Dr. Fred C. Davison may well be remembered for what he did not do - stop what was said to be a pattern of abuse involving the admission and advancement of student athletes.

title: MURDOCH OFFERS PRINTERS A $17 MILLION PLANT
description: Rupert Murdoch, the Australian-born newspaper publisher, offered Friday night to give printing unions his abandoned plant in central London as a way of settling a dispute with them over his move to a computerized site in January, when he dismissed nearly 6,000 workers.

title: LEBANESE WOMAN DENIES A ROLE IN BOMBING OF T.W.A. AIRLINER
description: A Lebanese woman identified as a suspect in the bomb explosion that killed four Americans aboard a Trans World Airlines plane held a news conference in northern Lebanon today at which she denounced the incident as a crime and said she had nothing to do with it.

title: BLACKS IN DOVER SEE A CLOSED SYSTEM
description: For years the local chapter of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People has sought to elect blacks to the City Council. Now the civil rights organization is opposed to a black's candidacy in the April 21 election.

title: STATE LAWMAKERS VOTE $41.5 BILLION IN SPENDING PLAN
description: The Legislature early today completed passage of a $41.5 billion budget that cuts taxes and reduces state debt while providing record increases in education aid and transit subsidies and a program to finance low-cost housing in New York City.

title: PLAY'S DIFFICULT PATH TO A STRIKING END
description: IT cannot be said that Kevin Heelan's ''Distant Fires,'' the new play at the Hartford Stage Company, goes nowhere. It arrives at an unanswerable question in memorable verbal and visual terms, but getting there is like groping about in a void.

title: GARDEN-APARTMENT RENTALS: SWITCH IN SUFFOLK
description: Something unusual is occurring at Artist Lake in Middle Island, L.I.

title: A REPORTER'S NOTEBOOK: SLOW BIRTH OF A BUDGET
description: In the end, it was a dispute over a favorite project of Donald R. Manes - a medical school in Queens - that held up final passage of the state's $41.5 billion budget until 3:10 this morning.

title: ANNE FLANAGAN MARRIES IN RYE
description: Anne Louise Flanagan, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Eugene J. T. Flanagan of Rye, N.Y., was married yesterday to Paul Thomas Kawas, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Kawas of Brooklyn. The Rev. Edward Whalen performed the ceremony at the Roman Catholic Church of the Resurrection in Rye, N.Y.

title: A CANADIAN RAIDER DOES IT AGAIN
description: ONLY a month ago, in an interview conducted in his Park Avenue office, Samuel Belzberg, one of Canada's wealthiest and most controversial businessmen, was lamenting his reputation as a corporate greenmailer - a raider who accumulates stock in a company, threatens a takeover and then sells back the stock to the threatened company for a plump profit.

title: Marcos Attacks From Honolulu
description: At first, Ferdinand E. Marcos contended last week that he was still President of the Philippines, attacking his successor, Corazon C. Aquino, as a dictator. But on Saturday he called a Manila radio station to say that Filipinos, especially the Army, should support Mrs. Aquino. He referred to the woman who supplanted him with an odd mixture of respect and familiarity, as ''Madame Cory Aquino,'' using her nickname. Mentioning that his wife, Imelda, was weeping as he spoke, he said among other things: ''Let's be happy,'' ''I have no intention of starting a civil war'' and ''I am irrelevant.''

title: ATLANTIC CITY RAILS DATE TO JULY 1854
description: A March 23 article erred in stating that Atlantic City's railroad service dates from the Philadelphia & Atlantic City Railway of 1877.

title: DANCE: LOUIS'S 'REVELS'
description: THERE is a terrific new group of dancers in the Murray Louis Dance Company, which is performing through April 20 at the Joyce Theater, and they are letting loose with the kind of energy one rarely sees amid the multitude of high-powered dancers elsewhere this season.

title: 3 TEEN-AGERS WIN SHORE COMPETITION
description: BEFORE sampling the concert schedule in what seems to be the busiest musical week so far this year in the state, let us congratulate some recent competition winners.

title: NETS SEND KNICKS TO 8TH LOSS IN ROW
description: Winning is supposed to elicit joy, but tonight's 107-93 shellacking of the Knicks - New York's eighth consecutive defeat - could not even bring smiles to the Nets' dour faces.

title: THE CAREFUL SHOPPER
description: Children's Items Up to 60% Off The first anniversary at The Children's Chest in Yonkers means that prices, usually set storewide at 25 percent below suggested retail, drop even further on first-quality selected items, in some cases to 60 percent off, until April 20. The children's clothes are from newborn to size 14 for both boys and girls - from christening suits and gowns and First Communion dresses to spring outerwear and bathing suits. Children's books, a slide and a scooter are on hand to alleviate the strains of shopping, plus free helium balloons for each child present.

title: Mystifying Maps
description: To the Editor: Betsy Wade's essay ''How Scenic 1A Leads the Traveler Astray'' (Travel, Feb. 9) warns about relying on out-of-date maps, but other maps may be equally misleading.

title: From Russia, Without Fuss
description: Stalin's American-born granddaughter will leave the Soviet Union to study in England, a British Embassy official in Moscow confirmed late last week.

title: NAEDINE HAZELL IS WED
description: Naedine Joy Hazell, a reporter for The Rockland Journal News in Nyack, N.Y., and Stanley E. Godlewski, a photographer for The Daily Record in Morristown, N.J., were married yesterday at St. Joseph's Roman Catholic Church in Bogota, N.J. The Rev. John Lord performed the ceremony. The couple's parents are Mr. and Mrs. Edward E. Hazell of Pompton Plains, N.J., and Mr. and Mrs. Edmund Godlewski of Bogota.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: NINE-HEADED DRAGON RIVER: Zen Journals 1969-1985. By Peter Matthiessen. (Shambala, 314 Dartmouth St., Boston, Mass. 02116, $16.95.) Peter Matthies-sen's intimate mutterings on his infatuation with Zen have arrived too late.

title: WYOMING IS TRYING TO WIDEN ITS HORIZONS
description: THERE is a legend in Wyoming that the Cowboy State stumbled into the cattle business after early teamsters abandoned their oxen in winter storms only to find them thriving on the High Plains grass the next spring.

title: LONG ISLAND GUIDE
description: FAMLI AFFAIR There may be merit to the saying ''If you've got it, flaunt it,'' but more is generally required of art collections than merely displaying treasures; they usually have to be put into some kind of context. And in ''Connections '86,'' its newest exhibition opening today, the Fine Arts Museum of Long Island has taken an interesting approach by showing its growing collection in juxtaposition with other exhibitions. So ''Three Thousand Years of Tradition,'' Famli's pre-Columbian textiles, ceramics and artifacts, appears with ''Guatemala: A Testimony,'' a traveling show of contemporary photographs; the Hempstead museum's Chinese collection of Sung, Ming and Ching porcelains and jade is complemented by calligraphic artworks by Dr. Le'on Chang, a leading artist in that traditional style; and recent acquisitions of contemporary works, along with pieces from its print archives, are hung with a private collection of CoBrA art, abstract works created in post-World War II Copenhagen, Brussels and Amsterdam. The opening reception, complete with a 2 P.M. concert of authentic music from the Andes by Llactimasmi, is from 1 to 5 P.M. at the museum, 295 Fulton Avenue. After the opening, the exhibition can be seen from 10 A.M. to 4:30 P.M. Wednesdays through Saturdays and noon to 4:30 P.M. Sundays through June 8. Admission is by donation.

title: MOVIE MUSIC SPICES A VARIETY OF SCENARIOS
description: Motion picture soundtracks have been a crucial part of movie making since the onset of the talking picture era, but only quite recently have entertainment entrepreneurs conceived of the soundtrack album as more than an offshoot of a film. Eight years ago, ''Saturday Night Fever'' demonstrated that the crossmarketing of a movie and its pop-rock soundtrack album could create a double blockbuster, both film and record, and the role of movie music hasn't been the same since.

title: Norwalk Has Its Day in Fairfield's Boom
description: A LARGE blue and white Victorian house went on the market a couple of weeks ago in the Golden Hill section of Norwalk. The price was $240,000. This would not have been remarkable except that Golden Hill, a neighborhood of older and historic homes sandwiched between the business district and the heavy traffic rumbling along I-95, was long considered one of the more downtrodden areas of that city.

title: NEW SET OF ISSUES IN CONDOS
description: IN the good old days when life seemed less complex, most people who rented an apartment became tenants in buildings owned and operated by professional landlords. Today, with the proliferation of investor-owned condominium units, that is no longer so.

title: MISS HUGHES PLANS TO WED
description: Katherine C. Hughes, a fund raiser for Boston University, and John D. Halpern, a founder, and a director of Bain & Company, a managment consulting firm in Boston, plan to be married June 28. The couple's parents are Mr. and Mrs. P. Edward Hughes of Wilmington, Del., and Helen Halpern of New York and Palm Beach, Fla. and the late Raymond O. Halpern.

title: SUSAN MIRAGLIA IS WED
description: Susan Elizabeth Miraglia, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph M. Miraglia of Redding, Conn., and Andrew Ahern Tamoney, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas H. Tamoney of West Hartford, Conn., were married yesterday. The Rev. David Blanchfield performed the ceremony at St. Mary's Roman Catholic Church in Ridgefield, Conn. The bride is an assistant account executive at Ogilvy & Mather Advertising in New York and her husband is an associate in the investment banking division at Merrill Lynch Capital Markets in New York.

title: Small Quake in California
description: A small earthquake that struck north of this coastal city startled some residents but caused no damage, officials said. The temblor, which measured 3.8 on the Richter scale, struck at 10:50 Friday night and was centered five miles north of here, 35 miles south of downtown Los Angeles.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: JAPAN'S WAR: The Great Pacific Conflict 1853 to 1952. By Edwin P. Hoyt. (McGraw-Hill, $19.95.) The kingdom of Japan, says Edwin P. Hoyt, suffered neither military defeat nor foreign occupation until 1945, making it the oldest government of its kind.

title: MARCOS, TALKING ON MANILA RADIO, CALLS ON FILIPINOS TO BACK AQUINO
description: Former President Ferdinand E. Marcos today called on Filipinos to support the new Manila Government.

title: The Reluctant Chauvinist
description: David Huddle's article ''Ingrained Reflexes'' (About Men, March 9) was an exercise in self-flagellation. Why Mr. Huddle should be so ashamed of his sexual feelings toward female friends is beyond me. There is no doubt that the potential sexual dimension of male-female relationships makes life more complicated, but it hardly qualifies as ''sexism.'' HERB ERKOWITZ Anchorage

title: NEW FEAR ON DRUG USE AND AIDS
description: A top Federal official responsible for battling the AIDS epidemic has warned that cases linked to intravenous drug use, once concentrated in two states, are rapidly spreading throughout the nation.

title: April 6, 1986
description: Weeks This Last on Week Fiction Week List 1 THE BOURNE SUPREMACY, by Robert Ludlum. 1 5 (Random House, $19.95.) The hero of ''The Bourne Identity'' foils a plot to seize Hong Kong. 2 BREAK IN, by Dick Francis. (Putnam, $17.95.) 5 3 Mystery, melodrama and bitter family rivalry in the world of British steeplechase racing. 3 LAKE WOBEGON DAYS, by Garrison Keillor. 2 32 (Viking, $17.95.) Yarns about life in a small Minnesota town. 4 THE MAMMOTH HUNTERS, by Jean M. Auel. 3 20 (Crown, $19.95.) Ayla continues her adventures in the prehistoric world. 5 LIE DOWN WITH LIONS, by Ken Follett. 4 10 (Morrow, $18.95.) An Englishwoman caught between the C.I.A. and the K.G.B. in Afghanistan. 6 HOME FRONT, by Patti Davis with Maureen 9 2 Strange Foster. (Crown, $15.95.) A semi-autobiographical novel by the daughter of President and Mrs. Reagan. 7 SEASONS OF THE HEART, by Cynthia Freeman. 7 2 (Putnam, $17.95.) Two sides of a marriage revealed through diary entries. 9 THE HANDMAID'S TALE, by Margaret Atwood. 6 6 (Houghton Mifflin, $16.95.) In the America of the future, men and women perform assigned services. 10 PRIVATE AFFAIRS, by Judith Michael. 8 6 (Poseidon, $17.95.) A couple's marriage is seriously strained when they strike it rich in journalism. 11 NERILKA'S STORY, by Anne McCaffrey. (Del 1 Rey/Ballantine, $12.95.) While fighting a plague on the planet Pern, Nerilka finds a true love. 12 TEXAS, by James A. Michener. (Random House, 10 26 $21.95.) Four hundred fifty years of history in fictional form. 13 CYCLOPS, by Clive Cussler. (Simon & 11 11 Schuster, $18.95.) Another trip with the ebullient advocate of the virtues of love. 3 THE GREAT GETTY, by Robert Lenzner. (Crown, 6 5 $18.95.) The life and loves of J. Paul Getty, who was the richest man in the world. 4 IACOCCA: An Autobiography, by Lee Iacocca 3 75 with William Novak. (Bantam, $19.95.) The rise of an immigrants' son to top jobs at Ford and Chrysler. 5 WISEGUY, by Nicholas Pileggi. (Simon & 4 8 Schuster, $17.95.) The experiences of Henry Hill as a member of a Mafia family. 6 YEAGER: An Autobiography, by Chuck Yeager 5 39 and Leo Janos. (Bantam, $17.95.) From West Virginia hillbilly to World War II fighter pilot to the first man to fly faster than sound. 7 ADRIFT, by Steven Callahan. (Houghton 7 6 Mifflin, $15.95.) One man's survival for 76 days on an inflatable raft in the Atlantic. 8 BLESSINGS IN DISGUISE, by Alec Guinness. 15 2 (Knopf, $17.95.) The autobiography of the distinguished English actor. 9 THE MAN WHO MISTOOK HIS WIFE FOR A HAT, by 1 Oliver Sacks. (Summit, $15.95.) The loss of the faculty of recognition and other strange neurological disabilities. 10 GREED AND GLORY ON WALL STREET, by Ken 8 8 Auletta. (Random House, $19.95.) The fall of the investment banking firm of Lehman Brothers Kuhn Loeb. 11* ARCTIC DREAMS, by Barry Lopez. (Scribners, 1 $22.95.) A rhapsodic report on human and animal life north of the Arctic Circle. 12 HOUSE, by Tracy Kidder. (Houghton Mifflin, 10 24 $17.95.) An account of the construction of a Greek Revival house in Massachusetts. 13 A LIGHT IN THE ATTIC, by Shel Silverstein. 12 161 (Harper & Row, $13.50.) Light verse, with drawings by the author. 14 ON THE ROAD WITH CHARLES KURALT, by Charles 14 26 Kuralt. (Putnam, $16.95.) The television reporter tells of people he's encountered while journeying around America. 15 DANCING IN THE LIGHT, by Shirley MacLaine. 13 28 (Bantam, $17.95.) In her 51st year, the entertainer wins an Oscar, survives a stormy romance and has new visions of the past and future. And Bear in Mind (Editors' choices of other recent books of particular interest)

title: Damage Award Limits Proposed
description: In distributing to Federal agencies last week a legislative proposal that would sharply limit the damages citizens could collect from the Federal Government, the Reagan Administration delivered its first response to the crisis that has left manufacturers and municipalities, doctors and corporate directors facing huge bills for liability insurance if they can find coverage at all.

title: WEINBERGER URGES JAPAN TO TAKE 'STAR WARS' ROLE
description: Defense Secretary Caspar W. Weinberger urged Japan today to take part in the Reagan Administration's space-based defense research, saying Japan's ''great technological genius'' would enhance the program.

title: LAROUCHE BACKER'S BID FOR HOUSE SPURS DISMAY IN CALIFORNIA
description: It is the images of luxurious California living and the actor John Wayne's brand of political conservatism that come to many minds at the mention of towns like Newport Beach, Laguna Beach and Irvine. But this wealthy region of Orange County is one area that an adherent of Lyndon H. LaRouche Jr.'s extremist views is seeking to represent in the United States House of Representatives.

title: Brooklyn Runner Excels
description: At 5 feet 7 inches and 120 pounds, Roger Blackman is not your typical middle-distance power runner. But the 17-year-old Prospect Heights High School junior does have talent, and in the 12th annual Kearny/adidas Relays this weekend, he showed enough of it to be voted the meet's most valuable boys performer.

title: NASA May Face Sweeping Change Before It Flies
description: If a Presidential commission has its way - and there seems reason to believe that it will - the National Aeronautics and Space Administration will have to change some of its software as well as some of its hardware before the shuttle next flies.

title: GERALDINE PAGE: OUT OF MARENGO, ILL., AND BOUND FOR GLORY
description: The line originates at a point in the center of the lower lip and proceeds to the left and the right, as if being drawn by an ambidextrous cartoonist with a pencil in each hand. It's a noncommittal line. Also unpredictable. Sometimes it curves up to become a broad, basic grin. At other times, the ends of the line collapse, to leave a failed smile that droops over the strong, no-nonsense chin, and an expression that can be read as anything from fury to disappointment, reproach or hauteur.

title: COMPUTER SPEEDS POISON CENTER CALLS
description: WORKERS at the Connecticut Poison Control Center have acquired a computer to help them keep up with the increasing number of calls they receive.

title: Lyle Leads by 3
description: Sandy Lyle struggled to a 73 and saw his lead dwindle to three shots today after three rounds of the $500,000 Greater Greensboro Open Golf Tournament.

title: The Reluctant Chauvinist
description: David Huddle was baffled by the New York woman's lethal stare in response to his question: ''Excuse me, but why is your blouse unbuttoned like that?'' His question was an aggressive act of appropriation. Wouldn't it have been more enriching for him simply to remember walking beside a woman who looked a little like Lady Liberty rather than assaulting her with a stare and a question? TONI SALDIVAR West Point, N.Y.

title: WESTCHESTER GUIDE
description: INTO INNOVATION The Yaseen Lecture Series, inaugurated at the State University of New York campus at Purchase in 1976, is dedicated to creativity in the arts, scholarship and criticism. Speakers have included Claes Oldenburg, Isaac Azimov, Carlos Fuentes, Arthur Schlesinger Jr., Thomas Hoving, George Segal and Christo.

title: THE DOCTOR AS GUINEA PIG
description: ON CHRISTMAS EVE, 1961, A BOSTON hematologist named Victor Herbert went to bed feeling a little weak. For three months he had been conducting an experiment on himself, attempting to prove that a debilitating condition known as megaloblastic folic acid deficiency anemia could be caused by a diet poor in folic acid. Folic acid, also called folate, is a vitamin that takes its name from the Latin word for leaf, a reflection of its abundance in green leafy vegetables. It is also plentiful in yeast, liver and mushrooms. Folate is present in most foods, in fact, but it is destroyed by heating and other forms of processing. Since October, Herbert had been on a bland diet specially designed for his experiment, and in recent days he had not felt quite up to par.

title: CAROLINE C. CURME MARRIES PETER ANGELICA IN VIRGINIA
description: Caroline C. Curme and Peter M. Angelica, assistant vice presidents of the Bank of New York, were married yesterday in Ivy, Va. The Rev. George M. Wyer performed the ceremony at St. Paul's Episcopal Church.

title: Yurchenko in Moscow: 'I'm Alive and Kicking'
description: Vitaly S. Yurchenko, the Soviet intelligence agent who returned to the Soviet Union last year after defecting to the West, reappeared in Moscow last month.

title: I & R BILL FACES TEST IN TRENTON
description: NEW JERSEY could become the 24th state to give voters the power to affect state law and policy through the ballot if enabling legislation passes its test in the Assembly in the next few weeks.

title: OUR PUBLIC WORKS NEED ATTENTION NOW
description: WHEN there is a fire, we call the fire department.

title: CONVICTED PROSECUTOR FLEES, SPURRING INQUIRY
description: A senior county prosecutor, convicted of sexually abusing his two daughters, has disappeared, and the authorities are investigating to determine whether he was aided in his flight by colleagues in the District Attorney's office.

title: ALACK
description: When the President's Commission on Organized Crime issued its final report, some members of Congress requested copies, only to be told there were none available for them.

title: Who Regulates The Regulators?
description: The city agency that oversees New York's taxi industry is so marred by corruption and mismanagement that consideration should be given to abolishing it, the head of the State Commission of Investigation said last week.

title:
CONNECTICUT OPINION;
RURAL VS. CITY RUNNING
description: PITY the city. It has been maligned, condemned, abused and neglected - by runners.

title: JENNIFER SCHOEN IS TO WED R. MARK JEFFREY ON MAY 24
description: Dr. and Mrs. Sterling H. Schoen of St. Louis have announced the engagement of their daughter, Jennifer Leigh Schoen, to R. Mark Jeffrey, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Louis R. Jeffrey of Summit, N.J. A May 24 wedding is planned.

title: CONNECTICUT GUIDE
description: TERRIERS ON DISPLAY Asta fans, Fala-philes and other terrier lovers will have lots to admire today at an all-terrier breed and obedience match at the Greenwich Civic Center on Harding Road.

title: CONNECTION ON FIFTH
description: Two loft-style buildings on Fifth Avenue, wedged together at the northwest corner of 17th Street since the turn-of-the-century, are about to experience an even closer relationship.

title: WESTCHESTER JOURNAL
description: Young Shakespearens EVERYONE agrees that Cordelia will be resplendent in her mother's old pink prom dress, cut down for size, and so what if Romeo's magnificent doublet bears some resemblance to old upholstery fabric?

title: ON THE FITNESS TRAIL
description: It is 6:30 A.M. at Canyon Ranch in Tucson, Ariz., not yet daylight, but the main house is crowded with men and women in warmup suits, sipping herbal tea. Somebody yells, ''Hikers!'' and we all troop outside for five minutes of stretching and bending. Then we're off for what is called an aerobic walk. Around us the mountain peaks catch the rising sun and the desert is bathed in a rosy glow, but we are working too hard to appreciate the show. Novices puff to cover two miles in half an hour; veterans lope four miles up and down hill in an hour.

title: No Headline
description: The article ''Derelict Alcoholics: Hard People to Help'' [ March 9 ] was a welcome item, as this has been a problem for some years in the Bridgeport area, as well as in other parts of Connecticut. However, Donald J. McConnell's closing comment, ''Does a person have a right to die the way he wants to die?'' ignores the fact that the compulsive drinking of the alcoholic overrules his or her control regarding all other factors of life and thus he or she is not exercising any right at all.

title: ON THE EVE OF A HISTORIC ECONOMIC BOOM
description: JUST a year ago, most economists fretted that the American economy was headed for shipwreck on the reefs of budgetary and external deficits. Yet today, thanks to favorable trade winds, skies look brighter as the economy gathers steam for a sustained and powerful boom.

title: OF PINGS, PUMPS AND MISLABELED GASOLINE
description: AT Jack's Service Station at 17-46 Clintonville Street in Queens, you could buy premium unleaded gasoline for $1.24 a gallon last week. That is a pretty good price in New York, but the city's Consumer Affairs Department fears that the gasoline may not really be premium. The department has fined Jack's six times in the last eight months - $1,580 so far, with the amounts of two fines still unsettled - for selling regular-grade gasoline as premium.

title: CORRECTION
description: A report last Sunday on the engagement of Meredith B. Mack and Bradford S. Elvidge misstated the month in which they plan to marry. It is October.

title: MICHAEL THOMAS BICKFORD WEDS PATRICE ELAINE BILZI
description: The wedding of Patrice Elaine Bilzi, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. August W. Bilzi of Huntington, L.I., to Michael Thomas Bickford, a son of Robert D. Bickford of Rochelle, Ill., and Carol V. Bickford of New Providence, N.J., took place yesterday. The Rev. Allan B. Ramirez performed the ceremony at the Brookville (L.I.) Reformed Church.

title: SISTERS, BUT WE LIVE IN DIFFERENT WORLDS
description: WE are sisters. According to the lyrics of a song sung long ago, we are alike in every sense. But the drummer that beats the pace for my sister and me plays distinctly different tunes.

title: Scallop Boat Joins Search
description: A 96-foot scallop boat was added today to the salvage fleet of the space shuttle Challenger and assigned to recovering remaining crew cabin wreckage from silt on the ocean floor.

title: U.S. Restricts Aid For Alien Housing
description: Saying that it was responding to complaints that bona fide Americans are being crowded out of subsidized housing, the Government ordered last week that local authorities end all Federal housing assistance for illegal aliens.

title: A POLKA-DOT FANTASY
description: THOSE who determine what is fashionable, whoever they are, certainly have dotted the eyes this spring.

title: Hagia Sophia Proposal Offensive to Moslems
description: To the Editor:

title: Kent State Memorial To Honor Dead of 1970
description: Four large circular depressions in the earth will represent Allison Krause, Sandra Scheuer, Jeffrey Miller and William Schroeder, the Kent State University students who were shot to death by National Guardsmen on May 4, 1970.

title: FINDING ANSWERS TO THE SCIENCE TEACHING CRISIS
description: HARDLY anyone thinks American schoolchildren are getting first-rate training in science -least of all the people responsible for providing it. At the annual convention of the National Science Teachers Association, which ended last weekend in San Francisco, educators offered a blunt assessment of science instruction and what is required to improve it. Excerpts from the discussions and papers follow. 'DRASTICALLY UNQUALIFIED'

title: Machiavelli
description: To the Editor:

title: THINKING SMALL FARMHOUSE FOR OFFICES
description: In the last several years, Danbury, Conn., has gained a reputation as a site for huge corporate headquarters, such as Union Carbide's futuristic compound of offices and parking areas that sits on a square mile of land.

title: Liverpool and Everton In English Soccer Final
description: Liverpool and its city rival, Everton, set up the first all-Merseyside English Cup soccer final and stayed on course for the English League and Cup double by winning semifinal matches in overtime today.

title: SHARON L. BICKUS TO WED JOHN E. HAGGERTY IN MAY
description: Mr. and Mrs. Frederick A. Bickus of Newtown, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter Sharon Lynne Bickus to John Ernest Haggerty, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Robert J. Haggerty of New York and Canandaigua, N.Y. A May wedding is planned.

title: Data Bank: April 6, 1986
BUDGET LAW IMPOSING CUTS AT NATIONAL PARKS
description: In New Jersey, schoolchildren will have to settle for abbreviated tours of Revolutionary War sites inMorris County. At historic buildings in Hyde Park, N.Y., boxes for visitor donations will be set out for the first time. And on Sundays in Manhattan, tourists eager to visit Grant's Tomb will be greeted by locked gates.

title: REFORM JEWS' DEBATE ON DAY SCHOOLS
description: Encouraged by the Reform Jewish movement's endorsement of religious day schools several months ago, several congregations in the New York metropolitan area are taking steps to open their own schools.

title: PREPARED FOR SPONTANEITY
description: NEXT-TO-LAST THINGS New Poems and Essays. By Stanley Kunitz. 130 pp. Boston: The Atlantic Monthly Press. $17.95. THE sharp and seasoned good humor Stanley Kunitz brings to the poems, essays, interview and aphorisms in ''Next-to-Last Things'' is a tonic in our literary life. Mr. Kunitz, who is now 80 years old, was remarkably prescient about his own eventual reputation when he once wrote of E. E. Cummings that ''more than any other poet of his generation Cummings cherished and nurtured the image of himself as poet. . . . In a society of gladhanders and backslappers and self-advertisers he insisted not so much on his own uniqueness as on his right to be unique.'' The work of a much battered, ceaselessly active veteran of around 60 years of effort to keep bright his own and the world's esteem for poetry, this brief new book is strikingly youthful. A maxim in the section ''Seedcorn and Windfall'' puts it nicely: ''Be prepared for everything - even spontaneity.''

title:
INVESTING;
DYNALECTRON'S NERVOUS RESTRUCTURING
description: For years the Dynalectron Corporation has disappointed those who hoped its huge revenue flow could be translated into earnings of a couple of dollars a share. The diversified technical services company, which trades on the New York Stock Exchange, reported revenues last year of $640 million, equivalent to about $67 for each of its 9.5 million shares.

title: NEW RENT CODE SETS OFF HEATED DEBATE
description: WHO has the right to inherit a rent-stabilized apartment when the tenant named in a lease dies or moves away? This issue, and a half-dozen others, will be the focus of sharp debate at hearings this week on a proposed revision of administrative laws that affect 25,000 landlords and more than 4 million people living in nearly a million rent-stabilized apartments in New York City.

title: Lawyers' Fees
description: To the Editor:

title: City Is Moving to Take Children From Mother
description: City officials have begun proceedings to have David Bright, the 10-year-old who testified in Washington about hunger among the homeless, and his brother and sister, 9 and 11, removed from the custody of their mother.

title: HOME SALES
description: To the Editor:

title: A LARGE, AND AILING, FARM ECONOMY
description: A CORNELL University task force reported recently that nearly a third of New York's 25,000 farmers might be forced out of business by 1990, and perhaps the most surprising statistic in the study was that New York had so many farmers to start with.

title: FOR KELVIN CHAPMAN, LIFE AFTER BASEBALL
description: KELVIN CHAPMAN likes to tell his wife that he's thinking of becoming a point guard for some Division II college basketball team. Going on 30, he's probably got a few years of eligibility, he tells her. It's always good for a few laughs at breakfast - except he just might be serious.

title: DISPLAYS FROM ROOMS OF EARLY ERAS
description: WITH the renovation of the 107-year-old State Capitol in Hartford still under way and the construction of a new legislative office building and parking garage not yet complete, the area around the adjacent State Armory at Capital Avenue and Broad Street is a bit of a mess. But inside the Armory, a panorama of neat tableaux of an earlier era in American life is nearing completion.

title: SHIPPING TRASH FROM ISLAND: JUST WHERE WILL IT GO?
description: AS LANDFILL space in the Towns of Oyster Bay, Huntington and Islip begins to run out, the towns are preparing to spend an estimated $21 million to $40 million a year each to ship their garbage off Long Island.

title: BARBARA K. FEINSTEIN TO WED JON M. SILVERI
description: Barbara Karen Feinstein and Jon M. Silveri, both lawyers, plan to be married May 31. The announcement was made by the future bride's parents, Dr. and Mrs. Clifford Feinstein of New York.

title: SUNDAY SPORTS
description: Baseball Mets vs. Pittsburgh Pirates, exhibition game, at St. Petersburg, Fla., 12:30 P.M. The next time the Mets play the Pirates will be opening day in Pittsburgh on Tuesday. (Radio - WHN 1050, 12:30 P.M.) Yankees vs. Toronto Blue Jays, at Fort Lauderdale, Fla., 1:30 P.M. (Radio - WABC 770, 1:30 P.M.) Basketball 76ers vs. Boston Celtics, at Philadelphia, and Rockets vs. Los Angeles Lakers, at Houston. (Television -Channel 2, 1 P.M. and 3:30 P.M.) Boxing Sammy Fuentes vs. Frankie Warren, 10 rounds, junior welterweights, at Corpus Christi, Tex. Fuentes, 13-2 with 10 knockouts, is from Loiza, Puerto Rico. The undefeated Warren (18-0) is from Corpus Christi. (Television - Channel 7, 3:30 P.M.) Amateur: United States Championships, finals, at Beaumont, Tex. (Television - Channel 7, 4:30 P.M. tape.) Hockey Devils vs. Islanders, at Byrne Meadowlands Arena, 1:35 P.M. This is the finale for the Devils, who are out of the playoffs again. (Television - MSG Network, 1:30 P.M. Radio - WMCA 570 and WOR 710, 1:30 P.M.) Rangers vs. Pittsburgh Penguins, at Madison Square Garden, 7:35 P.M. (Television - Channel 9, 7:30 P.M.) Flyers vs. Washington Capitals, at Philadelphia. (Television - ESPN, 7:30 P.M.) Thoroughbred Racing Aqueduct, 1 P.M. The $60,000-added DeWitt Clinton Handicap for New York-bred 3-year-olds at seven furlongs is the feature. (Television - SportsChannel, 6:30 P.M. and 11 P.M.) Santa Anita, Arcadia, Calif. The $500,000-added Santa Anita Derby for Kentucky Derby hopefuls at a mile and an eighth is the feature, and among the favorites is racing's youngest millionaire, Snow Chief, who won the Florida Derby.

title: NINA HARKRADER WEDS DR. JOHN DAVID MEYER
description: The wedding of Nina Elizabeth Harkrader, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Milton Keene Harkrader Jr. of Weston, Conn., to Dr. John David Meyer, a son of Dr. and Mrs. John A. Meyer of Syracuse, took place yesterday at the United Methodist Church in Westport, Conn. The Rev. Elizabeth Braddon performed the ceremony.

title: Vatican Lifts A Silencing Order
description: At a time when the Vatican is cracking down on dissent, it tried a bit of clemency this week, lifting a month earlier than expected an order of ''penitential silence'' it had imposed on the Rev. Leonardo Boff. The order, issued 11 months ago, barred the Brazilian theologian from writing, editing and making speeches.

title: ONE MAN'S FORMULA FOR SURE-FIRE HITS
description: For better or worse, television may never be the same after Alfred M. Masini.

title: A NEW OLD-TIME FEELING
description: THERE IS A REVIVALIST SPIRIT AT this spring's Southern Furniture Market, opening in High Point, N.C., on Thursday and running through April 18. Not unexpectedly, there is a wealth of new designs inspired by the 18th and 19th centuries. But, more importantly, there is a plethora of pieces based on early 20th-century styles.

title: BUSINESSES WARY OF DALLAS ECONOMY
description: Rick Cline has been noticing something of late.

title: HOW COME? IT HAPPENS
description: If ever you are in the mood to get a Frenchman's goat, just remark that his language, as compared to English, is sadly impoverished as to vocabulary.

title: THREE IN WHITE FAMILY ADMIT HARASSING BLACK NEIGHBORS
description: Three members of a white family in Sharon, Mass., have pleaded guilty to charges of harassing a neighboring black family and have been given suspended sentences.

title: Sailor's Dedication Knows No Season
description: THE boatyards of the north are coming to life now that the weather has cleared. The sounds of electric sanders and grinders, drills and hammers -and occasionally the muffled tones of a human voice from the depths of a bilge - are filling in the silences of colder months.

title: ARIZONA STATE FIRST
description: Key performances in the final event by the twins Dan and Dennis Hayden, combined with a penalty levied against Nebraska, helped Arizona State capture the men's gymnastics crown today.

title: Biondi Is Trying to Do Better Than His World-Record Year
description: NORT THORNTON, the University of California coach, was talking about last year's accomplishments of his star swimmer, Matt Biondi.

title: A SEXUAL RECTANGLE
description: STONE VIRGIN By Barry Unsworth. 309 pp. Boston: Houghton Mifflin Company. $17.95.

title: COULD INJURIES TRIP UP THE CARDINALS AND DODGERS?
description: The following National League preview was prepared and written by Joseph Durso. Teams are listed in predicted order of finish, with the Mets picked for first place in the East. EASTERN DIVISION: St. Louis Cardinals The team with the most in 1985, the Cardinals won 101 games, led the league in hitting and stealing and got to the seventh game of the World Series with exceptional dash. Now: the seawall.

title:
ON LONG ISLAND;
Trend Toward Bigger Houses Is Growing
description: BUOYED by a local economy that just seems to keep growing, and by interest rates that seem to keep dropping, the housing market on Long Island is taking a whole new direction.

title: Mailbox; Giving Athletes An Education
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: CORRECTION
description: An Associated Press dispatch from Pine River, Minn., last Sunday on a man who was dismissed after leaving his job at a Baker Industries plant to help two victims of heart attacks misidentified the company that owns Baker Industries. It is the Sonoco Products Company, not Sunoco, the oil company.

title:
FOOD;
SAUCE IS THE THING
description: WESTERN fascination with Chinese food often begins with the memorable sauces that flavor the dishes. From our dining-out tradition, we Americans acquired a taste for the sauces, and now want to have them on hand when we come home at night too tired to spend hours in the kitchen but wanting something to eat that is not less than special.

title: Cable TV
description: Two dandy suspense film thrillers new to cable bow in this week, beginning with ''Nosferatu, the Vampire'' (1979), starring Klaus Kinski, on Bravo on Sunday at 8 P.M. and 1 A.M. Then on Saturday night at 8 on HBO there is ''Cat's Eye'' (1984), a stylish package of three macabre tales by Stephen King, with Drew Barrymore and James Woods. For something different, grab this one.

title: CORRECTION
description: Because of a transmission error, an article last Sunday about a shopping complex proposed by the Heritage Development Group gave the population of Somers incorrectly. There are 16,000 residents in the town.

title: PROGRAM MONITORS SEISMIC ACTIVITY
description: AS the autumn night gave way to daybreak, most of the animals slept, and a quiescent silence covered the Bronx Zoo. But shortly after 6 A.M. last Oct. 19, the stillness was punctuated by the sudden and inexplicable din of howling wolves and trumpeting cranes. A few moments later the ground began to rumble as one of the most powerful earthquakes to hit the New York City area in a century jolted thousands of people from their slumber.

title: JAZZ ARTISTS OF THE PAST EMERGE FROM THE SHADOWS
description: As time has passed, the various periods and styles of jazz during the last 60 years tend to be remembered in terms of dominant musical personalities - Louis Armstrong and Jelly Roll Morton in the 20's, Benny Goodman and Count Basie in the 30's, Charlie Parker and Dizzy Gillespie in the 40's, Miles Davis and Sonny Rollins and John Coltrane in the 50's and 60's. Of course, in such decade-by-decade pigeonholing, Duke Ellington was, to use one of his favorite descriptions, ''beyond category.''

title: HOSTAGE SAFE
description: A man who the police said killed his landlord and a police officer and held a 74-year-old woman hostage for 35 hours surrendered early today and released his captive unharmed.

title: Scientists Plan to Dig Hole Six Miles Deep
description: Scientists have outlined plans for drilling a hole six miles deep in southeastern Illinois that would take them back 600 million years in geologic time.

title: AN ISRAELI POPULIST ROAMS THE CORRIDORS OF POWER
description: FOR many years David Levy, Israel's 48-year-old Minister of Housing, has been largely unknown to foreign observers. He speaks only Hebrew and French, so Americans in particular have not had much contact with him.

title: THE NEW ECONOMICS OF CUSTODY SUITS
description: MOTHERS virtually always get custody of their children if both parties to a divorce agree to that arrangement. But when couples disagree, an increasing number of fathers are winning custody. Various studies estimate that men have been the victors in recent contested custody proceedings between 51 percent and 70 percent of the time. One reason: Most states have switched to ''gender neutral'' language to avoid unlawfully discriminating against men on the basis of sex. In addition, men have more money to foot the enormous bill. A custody fight can cost tens of thousands of dollars, not only to pay lawyers, but also expert witnesses such as child psychiatrists.

title: SUDDENLY, A NEW BURST OF UNCERTAIN FRUSTRATION
description: THE explosion aboard TWA Flight 840 over Athens last week was a classic act of terrorism. It took place suddenly, with devastating results, and left the United States and other countries frustrated, juggling the blame for evident security lapses, unsure who carried it out, uncertain what to do about it. ''The shadow of terrorism is spreading over the Mediterranean,'' said Defense Minister Giovanni Spadolini of Italy.

title:
ANTIQUES;
OLD HOME, IN ITS ENTIRETY, FOR SALE
description: PROSPECTIVE owners of a stately, 250-year-old house here will have the rare opportunity to acquire not only the house and property, but antique furnishings as well.

title: THE CITY SCANDAL TAKES A NEW TURN
description: THE municipal scandal that has preoccupied New York City since January widened significantly last week, with the indictment of John J. McLaughlin, a former president of the city's Health and Hospitals Corporation. Nearly a dozen people have been indicted or implicated in the corruption investigations, but Mr. McLaughlin, who was accused of taking a 50,000 bribe, was the first of them to have been appointed to his city job by Mayor Koch, and his indictment was the first involving an agency other than the Parking Violations Bureau.

title: 'GEORGE M!' IS QUITE DANDY
description: JUST about the only thing really wrong with ''George M!'' at An Evening Dinner Theater is the bad timing of its booking. Here's the super show that ought to be running beyond, or at least through, the Fourth of July. Even so, it is clearly being produced to commemorate the Statue of Liberty's centennial, and it is on virtually all other counts ideally staged and far superior to the 1968 Broadway original.

title: Painting Attributed To the Wrong Artist
description: The thoughtful March 23 Speaking Personally article by Ernest Paolino about the sweet rewards of being a bibliophile was accompanied by a reproduction of a painting depicting an elderly gentleman standing on his library ladder and totally immersed in the study of several volumes.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: Appreciation has been growing for the era of spectacular building that spanned the end of the 19th century and the beginning of the 20th. Those were the days, as illustrated by John Tauranac's ELEGANT NEW YORK: The Builders and the Buildings 1885-1915 (Abbeville, $49.95), when municipal buildings disguised as Italian palazzi sprang up everywhere.

title: AROUND THE GARDEN
description: This Week The ground is dry; water sod and newly seeded lawn patches and recently planted shrubs. . . . Plant hardy vegetables - peas, spinach, lettuce, garlic bulbs and onion sets. . . . Spray rosebushes with fungicide to protect them from diseases.. . . Control wild onion by carefully hand spraying herbicide on each weed. Forsythia

title: PENNSYLVANIA IN POULTRY PLEA
description: The State Agriculture Secretary, saying an outbreak of avian influenza has ended, has asked 17 states and six nations to lift embargoes on Pennsylvania poultry products.

title: Verbatim; Hard Choices
description: 'It comes down to running for President or running for Governor.

title: A NONSMOKER'S GUIDE TO STATE'S RESTAURANTS
description: A NEW guide to restaurants in the state is to be published next month, but it will not rate cuisine.

title: In the Driver's Seat Cherchez La Femme
description: To remember the 50's is to remember Elvis Presley, boomerang-shaped coffee tables, crinoline petticoats, Gloria Grahame, the rise of split-level ranch homes and the smell of scorched meat arising from the barbecues in the yard behind them. For a lucky few people, it is also to remember La Femme.

title: HOWARD JAY DYMM IS WED TO ELIZABETH DORE LANNIK
description: Elizabeth Dore Lannik, a daughter of Mrs. Milton M. Gardner of Old Westbury and Water Mill, L.I., was married yesterday to Howard Jay Dymm, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Mandel Dymm of Westbury, L.I. Rabbi Maurice Aranov performed the ceremony at Temple Emanuel of Great Neck, L.I., assisted by Cantor Henry Weintraub.

title: ON THE ISLAND, COMDEN AND GREEN
description: MUSICAL comedy devotees might rightfully declare next Saturday as Comden and Green Day on the Island. Preceding the matinee performance of ''On the Town,'' a highlight of the 19th annual American Theater Festival at Long Island University's C. W. Post campus in Brookville, the team that wrote the legendary musical's libretto and lyrics - and made their Broadway debuts in the original 1944 cast - will speak at a special noontime luncheon.

title: Carbide Faces $1.4 Million Fine For Safety Lapses
description: While the chemical industry has one of the better employee-safety records in manufacturing, the Reagan Administration has been criticized for failing to regulate it more closely. That criticism grew more heated when the industry - and the Union Carbide Corporation in particular - suffered a major loss of credibility after leaks at Carbide plants in Bhopal, India, and Institute, W. Va.

title: Queen Victoria's Sweet Tooth
description: In ''Victoria's Sweet Tooth'' (Food, March 2), Joanna Pruess draws an endearing image of Queen Victoria bustling about the kitchens of Windsor Castle, finding ''great pleasure in the wifely arts of cooking and baking.''

title: Vanlandingham Hurt; Career Probably Over
description: Vanlandingham, last year's Eclipse Award winner in the handicap division, injured his left front foot in the Razorback Handicap at Oaklawn Park today, and his owner said that his racing career is probably over.

title: Home Sales
description: To the Editor:

title: ABOUT BOOKS
description: LOOKING for answers in the world of business often leads us to agree with Leonard Silk, author of ''Economics in Plain English'' (Simon & Schuster, New York, $7.95, updated edition), that ''the job of the economist calls for a genius.''

title: Q AND A
description: Question:A business associate says he has flown around the world, taking in a multitude of countries, at one low price. Is this fact or fantasy? - H. R., Terryville, Conn. Answer:Passengers certainly can fly around the world, with unlimited stopovers, at a price that is lower than the regular cost of a global trip. The low-cost tickets, which come with some restrictions, cost from about $2,099 in economy to $5,399 in first class, depending on which airlines are used. They are advance-purchase fares, which usually have to be bought 21 days ahead of departure. The regular fares, which carry few if any restrictions, are at least $1,000 more in economy or first. Most major international airlines sell cheaper round-the-world tickets under a joint arrangement with other airlines with which they have aligned. With the joint ticket, passengers are limited to two carriers in one group of airlines. They transfer from one airline to the other when the first's route ends and the second's begins. Travelers with more money to spend will ask an airline to construct a route using any number of airlines, and therefore enjoy greater flexibility in routing.

title: 7 IN SAN FRANCISCO FIRE ARE REPORTED MISSING AND PRESUMED DEAD
description: Fire Department officials said today that seven people were missing and presumed dead as a result of an explosion and fire that devastated a blocklong industrial complex here.

title: MISS HEPWORTH PLANNING TO WED
description: Mr. and Mrs. Derek Graham Hepworth of Lynnfield, Mass, have announced the engagement of their daughter, Suzanne Judith Hepworth, to Olavo Grasseschi Panico, a son of Emir Paulo Panico of Ribeirao Preto, Sao Paulo, Brazil, and the late Mrs. Panico. An August wedding is planned.

title: Cardiologist Sentenced In Medicare Fraud Case
description: Dr. Felix M. Balasco, a cardiologist who the authorities say implanted pacemakers in 29 people who did not need them has been sentenced to 10 years in prison for Medicare fraud, extortion and conspiracy.

title: PENGUINS ARE OUT
description: Ilkka Sinisalo scored his second goal of the game 1 minute 49 seconds into overtime tonight to give the Philadelphia Flyers a 4-3 victory over Pittsburgh and eliminate the Penguins from postseason play for the fourth consecutive year.

title: Shorthand
description: To the Editor:

title:
DINING OUT;
SOUTHERN ITALIAN FIRE IN SCARSDALE
description: WALKING through the preponderance of white wrought-iron bars in Anthony's curved entry makes one uneasily aware of what life in a bird cage must be like. The commodious bar area, the dining rooms's dance floor under a ceiling of mirrors, and stained-glass panels of kitsch Art Nouveau odalisque types are geared more to meeting than to eating, but felicitous service and entertainment helped make dining in this hard, bright, open space surprisingly agreeable. On weekends Al DiMarco with his electric piano belts out a sampler of the grand old tunes. Dancing is invited, although on our visits no one worked the floor.

title: NEW JERSEY JOURNAL
description: A SURVEY by the New Jersey Research and Development Council shows that the state accounts for more than 10 percent of all private- and government-sponsored research and development in the country and that even more money will be spent in this area this year than last.

title: Women and American Poetry
description: To the Editor:

title: NEW OFFICE PREPARES TO OVERSEE ROADWORK
description: IN a small irony that may presage larger changes, the State Department of Transportation harkened to the days of the horse and buggy when it opened a new office last month. The office, which will manage and monitor a number of county construction projects, is in what was once the carriage house of a Pleasantville estate. Given what a department official said were delays and congestion resulting from the projects, and his acknowledgment that the days of high-speed highway travel may soon be part of the county's past, the location seemed appropriate.

title: ROUTES TO BRONX VARIED
description: WHEN Bob Sheppard, the public address announcer, officially opens the 1986 season at Yankee Stadium Tuesday by introducing the team's 24 players, only four of the players who emerge from the dugout and stand along the first-base line will be purebred Yankees. Ron Guidry, Don Mattingly, Mike Pagliarulo and Bob Tewksbury were signed by the Yankees to their first professional contracts and played their way up the minor league ladder until they gained major league jobs.

title: SUSAN O'CONNELL INTENDS TO MARRY OFFICER OF A BANK
description: Mr. and Mrs. Thomas R.
