O'Connell of Short Hills, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter Susan Dorothy O'Connell to Robert Kelly Doherty, a son of Brucie Hennessy of New York and Southampton, L.I., and Robert Doherty of Raleigh, N.C. A June wedding is planned. The future bride is an associate vice president in the corporate bond trading division of Prudential-Bache Securities in New York.

title: Reagan Isn't Buoying Freedom Abroad
description: ''How sad it is,'' said President Reagan in his Easter homily to the American people, ''that this season has been marred by crises and violence.'' He was referring specifically to the Gulf of Sidra and the Nicaraguan ''invasion'' of Honduras.

title: Optimism for Guerrrero
description: They suffered the same type of injury and they had the same type of surgery by the same surgeon. Now if Pedro Guerrero can make the same comeback as Wilt Chamberlain did 16 years ago, the Dodgers should win the pennant this season and a world championship in 1988.

title: THOUSANDS MARCH IN A SOUTH KOREAN PROTEST
description: Tens of thousands of people marched peacefully Saturday as the opposition party continued to draw enthusiastic support for constitutional change.

title: A DESPOT, NOW AND FOREVER
description: I THE SUPREME By Augusto Roa Bastos. Translated by Helen Lane. 438 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $18.95.

title: A DIPLOMA MUST MEAN WHAT IT'S SUPPOSED TO MEAN
description: I HAVE read with astonished amazement the commentaries of top educators who decry underachievement and the decreases of black enrollment in our state colleges.

title: Bush Foresees Problems If Oil Prices Stay Low
description: Vice President Bush warned today that if oil prices stayed below $12 a barrel, ''substantial financial institutions in this country could be hurt.''

title: The Makeup Mystique
description: LAST NOVEMBER, 13-YEAR-old Dinah Posner got something she really wanted: a trip to Marshall Field in Chicago for a makeover.

title: NANCY SUE GOLDING IS WED TO ROBERT H. HARTHEIMER
description: The wedding of Nancy Sue Golding and Robert Herman Hartheimer took place yesterday at Temple Sinai in Pittsburgh. Rabbi Edward Cohn performed the ceremony.

title: NEW JERSEY GUIDE
description: VONNEGUT IN CAMDEN In a free lecture at Rutgers-Camden Friday evening, the novelist Kurt Vonnegut promises to ''discuss my own work in a whimsical manner, touch on current events and give the best advice I can to those who would like to become writers.''

title: SPECIAL PLATES LET MOTORISTS X-PRESS THMSLVS
description: IN a room of the State Department of Motor Vehicles in Wallingford, beyond the usual hustle and bustle, lines of harried customers and counters flooded with forms, one employee finds work amusing.

title: AS VIOLENCE THRIVES, THE DEBATE GOES ON
description: Comes now once again the question, along with the old replies. What have the media to do with sex and violence?

title: HELPING EXPECTANT SIBLINGS, AGES 2 TO 10
description: THE session started slowly. Earnest-looking parents trickled in with children from 22 months to 10 years old. The youngsters took off their shoes and sat on exercise mats and slowly inched forward as Lynn Ritchie, a nurse midwife and parent educator at the Maternity Center Association, began to talk about the experience of becoming a sibling. All of their mothers were expecting to give birth in the next few months.

title: A TEXAS WEDDING FOR MISS MENNEN
description: E. Christina Mennen and Paul W. Longworth were married yesterday in the Perkins Chapel at Southern Methodist University in Dallas. The Rev. Dr. Michael McGregor performed the Methodist ceremony.

title: Q AND A
description: RESIDENTIAL PROPERTY TAX Question: After many years it occurred to me to look up the definition of the Class 2 property-tax category in which my house in Manhattan is listed. I discovered that Class 2 pertains to a multiple dwelling and not a private house. Since mine is the latter, does that mean that my real-estate taxes have been incorrectly calculated? . . . V. S., Manhattan Answer: They apparently have been, but it is not likely that you can get a refund. According to William Block, deputy commision of finance for real property assessment, the Class 2 tax category does indeed refer to multiple dwellings. Class 1 refers to a residence with one, two or three units, while Class 2 is for buildings with four or more residences. A subclass of Class 2, 2-a, covers residences with four, five or six units.

title: BEHIND THE SAVING OF OTTER POND BRIDGE
description: It appears that in the Long Island Journal on March 9, sufficient research was not done for ''A Problem Bridged.'' Although Betty Friedan, Wilfrid Sheed and Richard Reeves jumped onto a bandwagon already in motion, they played little or no part in the outcome of the fight to save the Otter Pond Bridge in Sag Harbor.

title: MAGICIANS SHARE THEIR STAGE WITH DOVES
description: THE beauty of doves has long been celebrated in story and verse, but the doves of Anthony Hawes must do more than just look pretty - they must perform.

title:
WINE;
POPULAR CHOICES FOR SEASONAL FARE
description: RECEIVING little respect from connoisseurs, but achieving great popularity among average consumers, Asti Spumante, Beaujolais and kosher wines are each excellent mates for fare of the season. And the results of some recent informal tastings reveal a number of locally available bargains.

title:
GARDENING;
FRUIT TREES CAN COMPLEMENT LANDSCAPE
description: THE stone fruits, those with a single hard-coated seed surrounded by a layer of edible flesh, are popular for eating fresh as well as in processed forms. All are sufficiently attractive to be included in a garden that might otherwise be classified as strictly ornamental. Yet, they are grown less frequently than apples.

title:
GARDENING;
FRUIT TREES CAN COMPLEMENT LANDSCAPE
description: THE stone fruits, those with a single hard-coated seed surrounded by a layer of edible flesh, are popular for eating fresh as well as in processed forms. All are sufficiently attractive to be included in a garden that might otherwise be classified as strictly ornamental. Yet, they are grown less frequently than apples.

title: The Missing .328 Hitter
description: AS he settled into the batter's box one night during the 1977 season, Rod Carew noticed Toby Harrah, the Texas Rangers' third baseman, moving in on the grass.

title: PUTTING IT TOGETHER: A PRODUCER'S WEEK ON BROADWAY
description: In Fred Zollo's office, 11 floors above Broadway, the signs of Monday morning abound: a half-eaten bagel, a takeout cup of coffee, an empty contact lens case. Mr. Zollo dials the number for a major theatrical lawyer and, as the telephone rings on the receiving end, leans back into his chair and puts up his feet. The week has begun.

title: HOUSING THE AGED: 118 of 1,200
description: When Rosehill Apartments, a new housing development for the elderly and handicapped in the Bronx, opened its selection process last fall, it was deluged by more than 1,200 applications.

title: SWEPT AWAY ON THE NORTH FORK
description: ONE of the best-kept secrets of Long Island has been the rural charm of the area across the water from the Hamptons, known as the North Fork. It is a hundred miles out of Manhattan and, on its back-road farms, a century removed.

title: EXPO HAS PLENTY, BUT LACKS HEART OF ART WORLD
description: In its eighth year, Art Expo has become one of the largest art fairs in the world. Occupying about 250,000 square feet of space in the new Jacob K. Javits Convention Center, the Expo is like a miniature city of art boutiques.

title: FROM SOHO TO 104TH STREET
description: Art From the Courtauld April 8 - After nine years in a temporary home, the nonprofit Drawing Center at 137 Greene Street, just south of Houston Street, which has mounted major exhibitions of Old Master drawings from Europe, is moving into new quarters three blocks away at 35 Wooster Street. A benefit evening will start with cocktails at 6 P.M. at the old gallery where Dutch, Flemish and British drawings from the Courtauld Institute in London will be displayed. Dinner follows at the new quarters at 8:15 P.M. Tickets, $250, from 212-874-4098. Madison Club Benefit April 8 - ''Big Deal'' is the name of Bob Fosse's new musical and an 8 P.M. preview performance at the Broadway Theater at 53d Street and a dinner-dance afterward at the Plaza will benefit the 102-year old Madison Boys and Girls Club. The club serves some 5,800 persons, ages 6 to 21, in the South Bronx, Manhattan and Brooklyn and maintains a summer camp. Tickets, $250 for performance and dinner-dance including bus transportation to the Plaza, or $175 for show alone, from 212-679-1241. For Israel's Land April 9 - One of the oldest of all Jewish philanthropies, the Jewish National Fund was established in 1901 and is concerned now with land reclamation, afforestation and other land uses in Israel. Its annual Tree of Life Award will go to Arthur G. Cohen and Steven Goodstein at a black-tie dinner-dance at the Marriott Marquis starting with cocktails at 6 P.M. Tickets, $350, from 212-737-7441.

title: MYSTIFYING MAPS
description: To the Editor: After several disastrous experiences trying to follow maps with glitches, my eldest son, then 7, explained the phenomenon to me.

title: CARLA J. HAMANN IS WED IN JERSEY
description: Carla Jane Hamann, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Richard E. Hamann of Camillus, N.Y., was married yesterday to William Joseph Hoenigmann, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Frank W. Hoenigmann of Short Hills, N.J. The Rev. David Earnest performed the ceremony at Christ Episcopal Church in Short Hills.

title: ON COAST OF ENGLAND, JOBS VS. ATOMS
description: Invariably, superlatives clash in the continuing clamor over Sellafield, Britain's largest nuclear installation here where the grassy hills of West Cumbria drop down to the Irish Sea. For instance, it is the largest known source of radioactive discharges in the world and the site of Europe's biggest civil engineering project.

title: The Reluctant Chauvinist
description: Part of the answer to the implied question (i.e., what are women saying when they dress provocatively?) lies in the issue of power.

title: FRANCE'S COLORFUL COUNTRY FABRICS
description: French country fabrics - the cheerfully sophisticated prints inspired 300 years ago by chintz and calicoes from India - are at home these days from Tokyo to London to New York. The fabrics have also been rediscovered by the French with a passion that rivals the reception that 17th-century aristocrats once gave the first French-made indiennes.

title: SARAH FELDMAN IS MARRIED TO DAVID SCHARFSTEIN
description: Sarah Feldman, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Franklin Feldman of New York and Lakeville, Conn., was married yesterday to David Scharfstein, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Bernard Scharfstein of New York. Rabbi Haskel Lookstein performed the ceremony at the Water Club restaurant in New York.

title: MET ERROR ON WAIVERS SCRAMBLES ROSTER
description: The Mets said today that they had misinterpreted the waiver rules in reducing the team roster this week and now would be forced to open the season with two players they had cut but without two others they had meant to keep.

title: OLDER WORKERS ARE NO 'PANACEA'
description: In ''Long Island Retirees Heading Back to the Job'' [ March 9 ] , older workers were erroneously endorsed as a panacea to Long Island's chronic labor shortage. Seniors have never actually come forward ''en masse'' with a demonstrated desire to fill full-time jobs or temporary all-day jobs.

title: CHIRAC IS PLEDGED TO STICK WITH NATO AND BONN
description: THE conservative Government that came to power in France last month plans to break with Socialism in virtually every field except national defense, an area where left and right have often been bitter opponents.

title: THE GUERRILLA NETWORK
description: A REGION IN CONFLICT:

title: ATLANTA
description: There are still visitors who come to Atlanta each year in the hope of discovering Tara amid the city's growing thicket of glass and steel skyscrapers. Instead, they find a city that does not seem so very different in its physical appearance from Dallas or Denver or a half-dozen of the other new citadels of the Sun Belt economy.

title: SUNKEN SHIPS LURE DIVERS AND STIR DEBATE
description: SOMEWHERE off the South Shore of Long Island, beneath the shifting currents, lies the steamship Savannah.

title: HIS PICTURES SOLD PROSPERITY DURING THE DEPRESSION
description: You can search through all the books devoted to photography's history and not find the name W. Grancel Fitz. Yet Fitz, as he was known professionally, was once a commanding figure in his medium, admired for his technical skills and courted by the largest of this country's large corporations. During his heyday in the late 1920's and 30's he was a star, but by the time of his death in 1964 his artistic reputation was in total eclipse. This is not surprising, however, since his metier was advertising photography.

title: PLAYING FIELDS OF FICTION
description: SINCE the 1950's, when I was a budding boy reader who zipped through my share of sports stories, there's been a big change in what librarians, critics and even writers consider sports books for boys. Back then, a book wouldn't qualify if it contained more than a smidgen of ''real life'' blurring the focus on pure sports; now, a book is wedged into the classification if it has an athlete as a character or a little sports action to cut the ''real life'' themes. This attempt to broaden the genre shows there's been no change in the belief that sports books are almost the only books boys will read.

title: KEEPING TRACK OF THE BEST SELLER AND THE OBSCURE
description: INVISIBLE but indispensable is one way to describe the Westchester Library System in Elmsford, whose behind-the-scenes work benefits all users of the county's 38 public libraries.

title: DEBRA ANN DEROO IS WED
description: Debra Ann DeRoo, the daughter of Beth Louise DeRoo of Park Ridge, Ill., and Richard Allen DeRoo of Chicago, was married yesterday to David Pitt Ballard, the son of Mr. and Mrs. David Wills Ballard of San Miguel de Allende, Mexico. The Rev. J. Douglas Ousley performed the ceremony at the Episcopal Church of the Incarnation in Manhattan. The bride, who will keep her name professionally, is an account executive with Knight-Ridder Newspapers in New York. Mr. Ballard is a lawyer with A.T.&T. Communications in Basking Ridge, N.J. His father is retired president of Time-Life International de Mexico SA de CV in Mexico City.

title: COLD SPRING HARBOR LAB CAPTURED IN TV SERIES
description: THERE are more than 100 sites singled out by the architect Robert A. M. Stern, host-narrator of a new Public Broadcasting series called ''Pride of Place: Building the American Dream,'' and Long Island plays a prominent role in the eight-part television series.

title: THE PERIL OF COUNTING ON FEDERAL FUNDS
description: RESEARCH institutes have been getting assignments from the Federal Government ever since 1830, when Philadelphia's Franklin Institute conducted a five-year study of why so many steam boilers had been exploding around the country. These days, independent nonprofit research institutes get about $1.2 billion annually from the Government, more than half their funding, for everything from weapons development to studies of illnesses among factory workers.

title: 'THE ROSE TATTOO' PLAYED FOR LAUGHS
description: TENNESSEE WILLIAMS'S play ''The Rose Tattoo'' was made into a movie in 1955 starring Burt Lancaster and Anna Magnani. Miss Magnani won an Oscar for her portrayal of the earthy widow in a Gulf Coast city. Now the Arena Players Repertory Theater has, perhaps unintentionally, turned this touching drama into a comedy.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: LITTLE TALES OF MISOGYNY. By Patricia Highsmith. (Penzler Books, $15.95.) Punishment is the central theme of this collection of stories about women that was first published in a German translation in the mid-70's.

title: Reluctant Homecoming
description: Arturo Durazo, the Mexico City Police Chief from 1976 to 1982, was back in the Mexican capital again last week.

title: THE NEXT STEP IN DATA MANAGEMENT
description: BY now, those who have worked at personal computing for a year or so have discovered that the technology's biggest limitations involve entering information to be processed and retrieving the results of that processing. Computers are designed to manipulate information, be it numerical or textual. Hence the term ''processing,'' as in ''data processing.'' They are not, however, designed to manipulate information in human fashion. Therein lies the problem.

title: HISTORIC YACHT SET FOR DISPLAY IN U.S.
description: While the America's Cup Races and their fleet of modern 12-Meters may have moved on to Australia, an important vestige of the event's yachting history is expected to return here.

title: MORE OFFICE SPACE ON EIGHTH AVE.
description: WHEN Manhattan's office space is measured, the conversion of manufacturing space in loft buildings is often ignored.

title: Soviet Admits an Astronaut Was Killed in 1961 Accident
description: The Soviet Union has admitted, apparently for the first time, that an astronaut was burned to death while training for a flight in the early days of the Soviet space program.

title: THE 'OTHER' NASSAU COUNTY
description: The following is excerpted from a study conducted by the Health and Welfare Council of Nassau County Inc., a private, nonprofit human services planning agency.

title: CUOMO TO SUBMIT REFORM MEASURES
description: Governor Cuomo said yesterday that he would ask a commission working on anticorruption reforms to consider new laws for public financing of political races, sharper lines between the roles of politicians and public officials and tighter ethics rules for appointed officials.

title: MAJOR ISSUES IN PROPOSED CODE
description: Following are some of the major issues in the proposal for a new rent-stabilization code that concern both landlords and tenants:

title: STATE GUIDELINES ON RECYCLING WASTE
description: The recent article ''Instant Waste: One Paper, 2 Bags'' quoted the counsel for the Village of Lindenhurst. S. B. Latham, representing the village, stated, ''The fact that we could get a commitment without litigation, and without being the agency that issues permits, is a sad commentary on the D.E.C.''

title: VATICAN BACKS STRUGGLE BY POOR TO END INJUSTICE
description: The Vatican today issued its long-awaited document on ''Christian Freedom and Liberation,'' a defense of the right of the poor to struggle against injustice and a warning against totalitarianism and revolutions that lead to ''new forms of slavery.''

title: ASPIRATION GIVES WAY TO APATHY
description: COMMUNIST leaders in Eastern Europe usually speak of ''normalizing'' their countries when they crack down after an eruption from the discontented populace. But ''normalization'' has worked out differently in Poland than in Hungary or Czechoslovakia.

title: RECENT RELEASES
description: Dr. Jekyll and Mr. Hyde Starring Spencer Tracy, Ingrid Bergman, Ian Hunter, Lana Turner, Donald Crisp; directed by Victor Fleming, 1941 MGM/UA Home Video 114 minutes. $24.95 In two major adaptations, Hollywood has done right by Robert Louis Stevenson's horror classic of good and evil, personified by a visionary 19th-century Edinburgh doctor.

title: STATE RENEWS PLAN FOR HORSE ARENA
description: A PROPOSAL to build an equestrian center in Connecticut, a project first conceived in the late 1970's, is being revived by the State Department of Agriculture.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: AN UNNATURAL PURSUIT & OTHER PIECES. By Simon Gray. (St. Martin's, $15.95.) Simon Gray, the witty author of ''Butley,'' ''Otherwise Engaged'' and other plays, is, he would have us believe, totally lacking in the equipoise of his leading characters.

title: AGENCY OFFERS $10,000 FOR YOUR THOUGHTS
description: CONNECTICUT should plant roses or alfalfa along its highways; redesign various signs and offices, and join with Rhode Island to form a new state, according to some residents who have responded to the state's new suggestion program.

title: CAN ANYONE FORETELL A BOOM OR A BUST?
description: ONLY a few months ago, the prospects of falling oil prices, a falling dollar and lower inflation and interest rates were building confidence in the economic outlook. Now, pessimists are debating optimists on the meaning of such trends, especially when viewed against the background of other important statistics that suggest lackluster economic growth.

title: NEW IN A SERIES
description: The United States Postal Service recently issued a stamp to honor William Jennings Bryan. The $2 value was a late addition to the Great Americans series and was released with little advance notice. First day of issue was March 19 in Mr. Bryan's birthplace, Salem, Ill.

title: EXHIBIT IN FAIRFIELD IS A FAMILY AFFAIR
description: THE exhibit of art by Enid Munroe and her daughters Olivia and Antonia that is now on view at the Center for Financial Studies at Fairfield University marks the first time the family members have brought their distinct professional careers together for a joint show, aptly titled ''A Family of Artists.''

title: THE C.I.A.'S HERETICAL VIEW OF SOVIET STRENGTH
description: THE Central Intelligence Agency touched off a behind-the-scenes debate in January by concluding that its previous assessments of the size of Soviet underground nuclear explosions were too high and deciding that its procedures for making such estimates should be altered.

title: EMILY DICKINSON TRIBUTE
description: A TWO-DAY ''Celebration of Emily Dickinson and American Women's Poetry,'' is expected to draw a distinguished assemblage of female poets to Seton Hall University Thursday and Friday.

title:
SPEAKING PERSONALLY;
WHEN THE PHILLIPINES' FUTURE PRESIDENT WAS A CLASSMATE
description: IN SEPTEMBER 1949, I was a 17-year-old from the Bronx who was starting her freshman year at the College of Mount St. Vincent, a small liberal-arts school in Riverdale, the Bronx.

title: FAITH J. BREMEN, TV AIDE, TO WED
description: Ruth M. Bremen of Pennsauken, N.J., has announced the engagement of her daughter Faith Janice Bremen to Philip Richard Ruppel, a son of Irmgard Ruppel of New York and Oxford, Conn., and the late Richard S. Ruppel. A May wedding is planned.

title: West Tip Wins National
description: West Tip, ridden by Richard Dunwoody, won the Grand National, the world's most grueling steeplechase race, today at Aintree.

title: JENNIFER OLSHAN TO WED MAY 10
description: Malchia S. Olshan of Carpinteria, Calif., and Marvin L. Olshan of New York have announced the engagement of their daughter, Jennifer Sanford Olshan, to Scott Graham Estabrook, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Kenneth L. Estabrook of Far Hills and Beach Haven, N.J. A May 10 wedding is planned. Miss Olshan is an alumna of the Dalton School, and she and Mr. Estabrook graduated from Trinity College in Hartford, where he was elected to Phi Beta Kappa.

title: DANCE: MURRAY LOUIS TROUPE OPENS
description: THE Murray Louis Dance Company quietly opened on Wednesday at the Joyce Theater (175 Eighth Avenue, at 19th Street), where it will perform through April 20 in three different programs. Small-scaled, carefully crafted miniatures danced to perfection, the four pieces on this program were not the exuberantly physicalized kind of dance that is especially popular these days, although it was clear that being a Louis dancer requires exceptionally fine physical tuning. These were dances, too, that unfolded at a distance, tempered by the immediacy of the performing. In the midst of the bustle and roar of the spring dance season's first few weeks, Mr. Louis and his very good performers offered the special pleasure of dance for the mind.

title: CARLA SCHNEIDER WED TO TIMOTHY MUSKAT
description: Carla Schneider, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Martin L. Schneider of Brooklyn and Ancram, N.Y., was married yesterday to Timothy Wallace Muskat, a son of Katherine Appel Muskat of Deerfield Beach, Fla., and Carl S. Muskat of Upper Montclair, N.J. Helen E. Freedman, Acting Justice of the New York State Supreme Court, performed the ceremony at the Water Club restaurant in Manhattan.

title: WESTLAKE HIGH SCHOOL STUDENTS RETURN FRENCH HOSPITALITY
description: THE nine American students from Westlake High School in Mount Pleasant who visited France in February and their 12 French ''siblings'' who returned the visit last month say they could ''talk for weeks'' about the special kind of learning experience the exchange has offered.

title: WHEN COLLECTING WHETS THE APPETITE FOR A MUSEUM OF ONE'S OWN
description: For an art collector, the ultimate status symbol is a museum of his own. It's a big step up the ego ladder from simply acquiring pictures. And after three years of preparation, Edward R. Broida, the California architect who made a fortune building apartment complexes, had almost achieved it. But last month, not long after winning a crucial zoning change that would permit the opening of his Broida Museum for contemporary art in SoHo, he threw in the towel and went home. He would pursue the project in Los Angeles, he said.

title: Good Start in the Philippines
description: Cries of ''dictator'' have greeted President Corazon Aquino's proclamation of an interim Philippine regime in which she will exercise legislative as well as executive powers. But the outcry comes from a discredited National Assembly whose majority only recently anointed Ferdinand Marcos after a fraudulent vote. That Assembly found nothing to protest in Mr. Marcos's usurpation of legislative powers in 1972. These born-again democrats are lamenting loss of office, not freedom.

title: CONSUMER RATES
HEART DRUG TESTED AT TWO HOSPITALS
description: A NEW drug that dissolves blood clots - a major cause of heart attacks - is being tested at Yale-New Haven Hospital and Bridgeport Hospital as part of a nationwide study.

title: George Bush's Candidacy
description: Perhaps the greatest hurdle facing Vice President Bush is historical precedent: In the nuclear age, no sitting Vice President has been able to capture the Presidency via the ballot box.

title: BONN'S SWING PARTY REBOUNDING AFTER A FALL
description: Wearing a medieval sky-blue academic cap, matching cape and lace-covered sleeves on a black gown, the longest-serving Foreign Minister in the West knelt at the altar in the heart of Salamanca University and vowed in Latin to uphold the ancient institution's rights and privileges.

title: AUDOBON'S SUMMER CAMP FOR ADULTS
description: Arriving at the dock across from Hog Island, the 333-acre wildlife sanctuary in Maine where the National Audubon Society holds two-week summer ecology camps for adults, new campers are directed simply to stand at the water's edge and wave.

title: NEIGHBORS DEFEND SAFETY AT CARBIDE
description: A whiff of phosgene, says Wayne Schafer, who has worked for more than 35 years at the Union Carbide Corporation plant near here that manufactures the highly toxic gas, ''smells just like new-mowed hay or fresh-cut grass.

title: EUROPEANS TO PRESS U.S. ON THIRD WORLD
description: European Economic Community countries are seeking to put pressure on the Reagan Administration to adopt a more generous approach to the third world at development aid talks in Washington next week.

title: TRYING TO MAKE A PROFIT ON THE SIDE
description: IN their search for more revenue, research institutes are increasingly setting up their own profit-making, tax-paying subsidiaries to market their inventions.

title: No Headline
description: THE state's Department of Higher Education plans to pay for comprehensive programs for learning-disabled students at three colleges to be selected through a competitive application process.

title: STAGE: ONE-ACT PLAYS ABOUT HEROINES
description: PIONEERS in literature, sports and public life are celebrated in ''Women Heroes: In Praise of Exceptional Women,'' two evenings of one-act plays presented by the Women's Project of the American Place Theater. The two evenings alternate at the Samuel Beckett Theater. In real life, most of the women fulfilled themselves. The plays, however, are principally exercises in missed opportunities.

title: PROMISE AND BETRAYAL
description: ARGENTINA 1516-1982 From Spanish Colonization to the Falklands War. By David Rock. Illustrated. 478 pp. Berkeley: University of California Press. $35.

title: FOUGHT NIXON AT FANNIE MAE
description: Raymond H. Lapin, a former head of the Federal National Mortgage Association who in 1969 briefly challenged President Nixon's decision to remove him from that post, died Wednesday of complications from heart disease at Marin General Hospital in Greenbrae, Calif., near San Francisco. He was 67 years old and was a resident of Sausalito, a San Francisco suburb.

title: DORO BACHRACH, A FILM PRODUCER, BECOMES A BRIDE
description: Dorothy Locke Bachrach, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Bradford Bachrach of Wellesley Hills, Mass., was married yesterday to Graham Mackenzie Gordon in the chapel of the Episcopal Church of the Heavenly Rest in Manhattan. The Rev. C. Hugh Hildesley performed the ceremony.

title: CORRECTION
description: Because of an editing error, a review of ''The Fanciest Dive'' by Christopher M. Byron on March 9 incorrectly stated the number of Sports Illustrated writers whose jobs were scheduled to be eliminated. Five writers left, of whom four took voluntary retirement.

title: GONE IN GEORGIA WITHOUT A TRACE
description: IT was six years ago this week that Charles R. Romer, a 73-year-old retired oil executive, and his wife, Catherine, 75, checked into a motel at Brunswick, Ga., and - in the words of the county police - ''disappeared off the face of the earth.''

title: BIONDI, MORALES COMPLETE TRIPLES
description: Matt Biondi of California and Pablo Morales of Stanford completed triples tonight as the National Collegiate Athletic Association's 63d annual swimming championships ended. Stanford easily retained the team title by winning four of the night's six swimming finals.

title: WHERE THE DOOR IS STILL CLOSED TO LEG OF LAMB
description: Surprising as it may seem, the food served at embassy dinner parties in Washington more often than not is strictly continental - leg of lamb, say, along with asparagus and roasted potatoes.

title: EX-OFFICIAL SEES N.A.A.C.P. IN RETREAT ON DESEGREGATION
description: The present and former chief lawyers for the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People are trading accusations over the organization's handling of a major school desegregation case.

title: CRUEL AND UNUSUAL MEDICINE
description: GREAT AND DESPERATE CURES The Rise and Decline of Psychosurgery and Other Radical Treatments for Mental Illness. By Elliot S. Valenstein. Illustrated. 338 pp. New York: Basic Books. $19.95.

title: MOGAMBO IS FIRST IN GOTHAM STAKES
description: Mogambo displayed his finishing kick by racing past Groovy and Tasso in the final yards at Aqueduct yesterday to capture the $312,000 Gotham Stakes by three-quarters of a length.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''Don't worry about my plans. I have no intention of starting a civil war.

title: WHAT'S NEW AT THE RESEARCH INSTITUTES
description: INDEPENDENT nonprofit research institutes rarely grab headlines, even when they are the developers of popular products or processes.

title: MARY BONEY TO WED J. W. DENISON 3D
description: Mr. and Mrs. Leslie Norwood Boney Jr. of Wilmington, N.C. have announced the engagement of their daughter Mary Grist Bellamy Boney to James Wholley Denison 3d, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Denison Jr. of Orlando, Fla. A May 17 wedding is planned.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: AN HONEST WOMAN. By Anne Christie. (St. Martin's, $17.95.) Alison Salveson's assets would seem to outweigh her liabilities. She shares a smashing London town house with her architect husband, Philip, and two remarkably presentable teen-agers.

title: GREENWICH BRIDAL FOR MISS TANSEY AND P.K. LARKIN
description: Victoria Lee Tansey, a daughter of Judith Valle-Cloutier of Cumberland Foreside, Me., and George Milton Tansey of Falmouth Foreside, Me., was married yesterday to Paton Kendall Larkin, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Sylvester P. Larkin Jr., of Greenwich, Conn. The Rev. John Olofson, a Methodist minister, performed the ceremony at the First Church of Round Hill in Greenwich.

title: BOB FOSSE - DANCING WITH DANGER
description: ''Big Deal on Madonna Street,'' an Italian movie starring Marcello Mastroianni and Vittorio Gassman as small-time hustlers trying to pull off a not-quite-big-time heist, came out in 1960. During the mid-1960's, it was optioned by Bob Fosse, who started working on a stage version and thinking about making the project into a film musical.

title: DOWN TO THE WIRE
description: When victory in the prestigious Vanderbilt Knockout Team Championship hangs in the balance with 16 deals remaining to be played, the tension in the two playing rooms is always electric: For the players it is not just a title, for possible world championship honors are at stake.

title: EVEN A COMMUTER CAN GROW AND HARVEST CROPS
description: There is no reason why commuters can't enjoy fresh-picked vegetables at the end of a long day. The key is an easy-care vegetable garden with a limited amount of produce that does not need constant attention. Care just means a few minutes spent in the garden at the end of the day and the harvest is generous in spite of the small space.

title: The Right King Charles
description: To the Editor:

title: REVISITING A REALM OF BROKEN DREAMS
description: ''For my dreams, I need a passport and shots. I travel the whole world.'' So says Artie Shaughnessy, the optimistic hero of ''The House of Blue Leaves.'' This was John Guare's breakthrough play (in 1971) and, as we see in Jerry Zaks's splendid revival at Lincoln Center (starring John Mahoney, Stockard Channing and Swoosie Kurtz), it is still his most euphoric work. ''Optimistic'' and ''euphoric'' would seem to be curious adjectives to use in reference to a play in which a young man plots to assassinate the Pope; in which one of the principal characters is out of her mind; and in which the hero himself is driven to a violent act of desperation. Yet, for all the mania and mayhem, ''Blue Leaves'' remains a joyful affirmation of life - and of Mr. Guare's artistry.

title: MARSHA N. KOHLMAN WED TO GLENN MORAK
description: Marsha Nathan Kohlman, an assistant district attorney in Brooklyn, and Glenn Howard Morak, a staff lawyer for the Legal Aid Society of Brooklyn, were married yesterday at the New Orleans Hilton.

title: U.S. Steel
description: To the Editor:

title: More Bang for the Foreign Aid Buck
description: President Reagan has proposed a 9 percent increase in foreign aid next year. Budget conscious members of both parties have said he may not get it. But the debate over dollars and cents misses a key point: foreign aid, whatever the amount decided upon, is likely to flow to countries whose economic policies neutralize the intended benefits of that aid.

title: UTILITY SEEKS RATE RISES FOR 19 SCHOOLS
description: SCHOOL officials across the state are upset about a proposed rate reclassification that would cause electric bills at 19 schools to increase as much as 100 percent.

title: BALLET: JOFFREY PERFORMS
description: THERE was a good deal of bustling about the stage on Friday at the New York State Theater. It was an unfortunate bit of programming by the Joffrey Ballet, though the bustle was in service of three very different goals.

title: DEMOCRATS LOSING ON JUDGES
description: DESPITE appeals from several Republican judges, including Chief Judge Sol Wachtler of the State Court of Appeals, the Nassau County Republican leader, Joseph N. Mondello, said last week that Nassau Republicans would not offer bipartisan endorsement to four Nassau Democratic judges seeking re-election this year.

title: James J. Mueller Dead at 69; A Developer of Shuttle Shield
description: James I. Mueller, a University of Washington professor who helped develop the ceramic tiles for space shuttles' heat shields, died Wednesday of cancer.

title: 6 POLICEMEN SLAIN IN PUNJAB AS GUNMEN FREE 3 SIKH PRISONERS
description: Sikh extremists shot dead six policemen at a courthouse in Punjab state today and freed three prisoners who were accused of killing a Hindu editor, an Indian official said.

title: CHARITY MATCHES DONORS WITH POOR
description: IN her Branford living room, Carol Hoadley was busy packing four boxes. In one of them she carefully placed a white bedsheet, a red nightshirt, a large box of Cheerios, raisins, toothpaste, Reader's Digest condensed books, jeans and bags of gumdrops and jelly beans.

title: JOYCE ORMSBY MARRIES
description: Joyce Elaine Ormsby, a staff writer in the Office of Communication and Interpretation of the Lutheran Council in the U.S.A. in New York, was married yesterday to Dr. Saris E. Segarra Jr., chief resident in internal medicine at the Maimonides Medical Center in Brooklyn. The Rev. Dr. William H. Lazareth performed the ceremony at the Holy Trinity Lutheran Church in New York. Mrs. Segarra is a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Francis Ormsby of Warren, Ohio. Dr. Segarra is a son of Mr. Segarra of Houston and the late Delia Medina Segarra of New York.

title: Authorities in West Report Seizing Big Cocaine Supply
description: The police and Federal agents seized 1,700 pounds of cocaine three days after a raid netted up to 2,400 pounds of the drug in Tijuana, Mexico, the authorities said today.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article in The Week in Review last Sunday on municipal corruption scandals of the past incorrectly described the location of the old Tweed Courthouse. The former courthouse is on Chambers Street, just north of City Hall.

title: RUTGERS-NEWARK GETS $1 MILLION GRANT
description: A DESIRE to broaden educational opportunities for urban students and to enhance the role of small businesses has brought the Prudential Insurance Company of America and Rutgers University together in a million-dollar partnership.

title: A Shot Not Heard Round the World
description: Critics of genetic engineering have feared two things: unpredictable consequences and inadequate controls. On the second point, it turns out, they may have had cause for concern.

title: PENN CREW WINS
description: The University of Pennsylvania's heavyweight crew won the Copley Cup in stunning style today in the final race of the San Diego Crew Classic, upsetting Washington, which had won the previous three years.

title: HOMERIC GREEK FARE IN MERRICK
description: TAKE the trendy California open kitchen plus the theatrics of a whole baby lamb and a suckling pig turning on a spit. Add the olive oil-based Mediterranean diet, and you can understand the appeal of Islands of Greece in Merrick. If this is not the very best Greek restaurant on the Island, it does not have to worry about much competition.

title: EX-SUDAN AIDE GETS 2 JAIL TERMS FOR ROLE IN ETHIOPIAN AIRLIFT
description: A former First Vice President in the Government of President Gaafar al-Nimeiry, who was overthrown last April, was sentenced today to two consecutive 30-year jail terms for his role in secretly airlifting Ethiopian Jews out of the Sudan to Israel.

title: George Bush's Candidacy
description: George Bush may be making progress in winning over the reluctant right wing of the Republican Party, but he is losing those of us who preferred him in the first place (''The Front-Runner,'' by Gerald M. Boyd, Feb. 23).

title: THE I.R.S. LOSES ITS MUSCLE
description: AT Internal Revenue Service processing centers across the country, the orderly routine today is in sharp constrast to the horrifying mayhem of last year. The new computers are finally running smoothly. Tax returns are being processed without major bottlenecks. And refund checks are going out to taxpayers without long delays. The system, I.R.S. officials declare, is back to normal.

title: A PRINCE'S GIFT TO AN AILING BOY
description: PRINCE KHALED BIN SULTAN BIN ABDULAZIZ, a 36-year-old nephew of King Fahd of Saudi Arabia, was vacationing in Bermuda when he learned over television about Billy Bostick, then 14 and living in the Florida Keys.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: THE TURKEY SHOOT: Tracking the Attica Cover-Up. By Malcolm Bell. (Grove, $19.50.) It has been almost 15 years since New York state troopers charged through clouds of tear gas, their guns blazing, to retake the state prison at Attica from the rebellious inmates who had held it at knifepoint for five days. The troopers' gunfire made it clear to those outside the rain-streaked upstate New York prison walls that there would be casualties. In short order it would also become clear that the troopers who had reclaimed the prison on Sept. 13, 1971, used deadly force, killing 29 inmates and 10 hostages and wounding 89 others. Malcolm Bell, a former member of the state-appointed Attica investigation and prosecution team, has written ''The Turkey Shoot,'' a flawed but informative book about the riot and its aftermath. Attica has fallen into the creases of modern history; it is too recent to be included in textbooks and too long ago to be sharply remembered. Sections of Mr. Bell's book about the police assault on the prison will acquaint new readers with events that will always be a bloodstain on law and justice in America. He makes a good case that the state police covered up the crimes of their own. Mr. Bell's book is not a scholarly work. In this first-person account, he attempts to make a cover-up case against his former colleagues in the Attica investigation. He claims that the investigation was turned away from po-lice crimes to protect Governor Rockefeller, who ordered the retaking of Attica, and who at the time was seeking confirmation as Vice President of the United States. Mr. Bell made the same charges publicly in 1975 and sparked another state investigation, whose members thanked him but found his allegations unfounded.

title: Shultz's Modest Proposal
description: When Secretary of State Shultz came back from Europe the other day, he said that ''we're not going anywhere'' in U.S.-Soviet relations until we're able to have ''some discussions that are relatively quiet and direct.''

title: SALVATION THROUGH MEMORY
description: THE BOOK OF ABRAHAM By Marek Halter. Translated by Lowell Bair. 722 pp. New York: Henry Holt & Company. $19.95. ''BEING elsewhere,'' said the French writer Charles Peguy, ''is the great secret vice of the Jews, their great secret virtue, the great vocation of this people.'' In Marek Halter's spectacular novel, ''The Book of Abraham,'' the ''elsewhereness'' of one Jewish family pervades 100 generations succeeding one another over a period of almost 2,000 years. Mr. Halter, tapping in part the documented experience of his own forebears, has expanded Peguy's sentence into a saga.

title: 7 FROM JERSEY KILLED IN CRASH ON SINGER CO. PLANE IN TEXAS
description: Seven New Jersey men employed by the Singer Company were killed Friday night when their twin-engine corporate jet crashed in a violent thunderstorm in northeast Texas on a flight from Dallas to Teterboro Airport.

title: HELPING BUSINESS SORT OUT THE WORLD
description: ONE money maker for many institutes these days is their work helping company executives and Government policy makers understand and adapt to what is called the globalization of business. Advances in telecommunications and transportation have increased world trade and tied the economies of different countries ever more closely together. Governments are struggling to cope with the impact of this trend, while businesses are simultaneously fighting to expand overseas and to defend domestic markets.

title: WENDY CARVER MARRIES
description: Wendy Susan Carver, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Michael Carver of Scarsdale, N.Y., was married yesterday to Thomas Joseph Reno, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Albert Reno, also of Scarsdale.

title: REBELS STILL WAGING FIERCE WAR IN CAMBODIA
description: A year after the Vietnamese overran guerrilla camps along the Thai-Cambodian border, rebels are increasing their activity in almost every Cambodian province, according to guerrilla leaders and diplomats.

title: HOW FAR THE CANADIAN DOLLAR STRETCHES FOR AMERICANS
description: A couple can stay at the Four Seasons Olympic Hotel in Seattle this spring for $145 a night. Or they can stay at the Four Seasons in Vancouver, British Columbia, for $150. At first glance this may not seem like much of a difference, but it is. The Vancouver rate is in Canadian dollars, which at this writing is worth only 71 cents. So in United States terms, the price in Vancouver is only $106.50, or a considerable saving.

title: LEDGERS OF THE LATTER-DAY SAINTS
description: THE MORMON CORPORATE EMPIRE By John Heinerman and Anson Shupe. 293 pp. Boston: Beacon Press. $19.95. ONLY 156 years have passed since Joseph Smith

title: Neurology and the Psalms
description: To the Editor:

title: ANTIQUES
description: Kilims. They dazzle and delight the eye with bold, pulsing colors, arresting patterns and robust weaves.

title: Comings and Goings
description: The Philadelphia 76ers activated the forward Bobby Jones and put the center Moses Malone on the injured list, making Malone unavailable until the playoffs. He suffered a fracture of the socket of his right eye March 28 against the Milwaukee Bucks. . . . Wayne Stofsky, a reserve infielder for Louisiana State, has been hospitalized with contagious meningitis.

title: AHA
description: After being hidden for two years behind scaffolding, a bronze statue of King Neptune, who is attended by a court of creatures both fantastic and humanoid, has been returned to public view in front of the Library of Congress. The statue had been covered while broken concrete and leaking pipes in its fountain were repaired.

title: Photo of Dick Howser (NYT/Anthony Neste)ROYALS; HOWSER AWARE OF BURDEN
description: ARE the defending baseball champions of the planet overconfident? Why did the Kansas City Royals make only one trade in the offseason? Are the Royals a fluke?

title: New & Noteworthy
description: BETSEY BROWN, by Ntozake Shange. (St. Martin's, $6.95.) This work by the poet, playwright and novelist Ntozake Shange focuses on a 13-year-old black girl, Betsey Brown, who lives with her large, eccentric family in St. Louis in 1959, as the city is embarking on school desegregation. Nancy Willard said in The Book Review last year that Miss Shange ''is a superb storyteller'' who ''has an extraordinary ear for the spoken word.'' This novel, she said, ''creates a place that is both new and familiar, where both black and white readers will feel at home.'' THE TRUE CONFESSIONS OF AN ALBINO TERRORIST, by Breyten Breytenbach. (McGraw-Hill, $5.95.) In 1975 Breyten Breytenbach, the pre-eminent living Afrikaans poet, was sent to prison under South Africa's Terrorism Act on a trumped-up charge of plotting to blow up a monument to his native language. ''They took seven years from him, and he has now struck back with a volume that seems to have been ripped from his entrails,'' our reviewer, Joseph Lelyveld, said of this memoir in 1985. The book, he said, is ''mocking and sensitive, offhand and bombastic, mystical and raging'' and is ''an important contribution to a corpus of South African prison literature that has been steadily, painfully accumulating over the last quarter-century.'' SHAKESPEARE'S DOG, by Leon Rooke. (Ecco Press, $8.50.) This humorous, revisionist look at Shakespeare's pre-London days is told from the point of view of his best friend - Hooker, his dog. Our reviewer, Jerome Charyn, said in 1983 that the book would be silly, ''were it not for the vitality that Leon Rooke brings to the squabbling household of Hooker, Will Shakespeare and Anne Hathaway.

title: STAMFORD CELEBRATING ITSELF WITH $137,000 MARATHON
description: IT is a lot easier to run in a marathon than to plan one, as far as Dr. Robert Rinaldi of the Stamford Running Club is concerned.

title: LARRY RIVERS AND FRIENDS: EXUBERANT COLLABORATION
description: COLLABORATIONS in art can add dramatically to the power of a theme, and their potential as mind-expanding situations will usually lead to unexpected results.

title: O'NEILL BESTS MOFFETT IN STATEWIDE CAUCUSES
description: Gov. William A. O'Neill won the first round this week in his fight with former United States Representative Toby Moffett for the Democratic nomination for governor.

title:
ART;
'SYMBOLIC EXPRESSIONS': 5 WOMEN ARTISTS AT SUMMIT CENTER
description: WOMEN'S, or feminist, art was a hotly debated phenomenon in the late 1970's and early 1980's. Critics used much ink in probing what was distinctly feminine about this art and what issues female artists explored in common.

title: White House Says Insurgents Need Stingers
description: The Stinger is a shoulder-fired guided missile system about 5 feet long and weighing 34.5 pounds that uses an infrared system to home in on low-flying planes and helicopters. One man can operate the $75,000 weapon, sighting the target and firing the high-explosive missile through a disposable launch tube. Stingers are among the weapons included in military and other aid the Reagan Administration wants to supply the anti-Government rebels in Nicaragua for use against Soviet-made MI-24 helicopter gunships of the Sandinista air force.

title: BOARD WEIGHS GLEN ISLAND LEASE
description: THE Westchester Board of Legislators appears ready to deny any immediate 10-year extension of a long-term lease for the operators of the Glen Island Casino, the county-owned historic restaurant and banquet facility in New Rochelle.

title: NEW YORKERS ARE SELDOM THE FIRST TO SEE NEW BALLETS
description: The Joffrey Ballet is celebrating its 30th anniversary this year. As a touring ensemble, the company will probably stretch out its birthday festivities throughout 1986 in various parts of the country and rightly so. Those of us who see the Joffrey in New York tend to forget that we are able to see it here precisely because its months on the road have enabled the company to survive and keep its dancers employed. The current season at the New York State Theater at Lincoln Center, for example, features three repertory works created for the Joffrey - and all, in fact, received their first performances outside New York City.

title: TALKS AT BETHLEHEM STEEL BREAK OFF AS LTV WINS A CONTRACT
description: The United Steelworkers of America broke off contract talks today with the Bethlehem Steel Corporation, a day after union workers at the LTV Steel Company approved cuts in wages and benefits in exchange for stock and a share in future profits.

title: PROFICIENCY TEST SET FOR 86,500
description: THE state's 86,500 public-school ninth-graders who take the High School Proficiency Test on April 15, 16 and 17 will be the first to do so as a requirement for graduation.

title: PARLEY REFLECTS CONCERN ON COPING WITH DISASTERS
description: A conference here has made it clear that part of the medical profession is concerned about how Americans might cope with an act of terrorism, a major earthquake or another large-scale disaster.

title: DR. DEMAS WEDS DR. MARK ARNOLD
description: Dr. Joanna Marie Demas and Dr. Mark William Arnold, residents in medicine and surgery, respectively, at the University of Miami/Jackson Memorial Medical Center, were married last night at the St. Sophia Greek Orthodox Cathedral in Coral Gables, Fla. The Rev. Demosthenes J. Mekras officiated.

title: RECENT RELEASES
description: Mozart's 'Abduction From the Seraglio' A Glyndebourne Festival Opera production, featuring Ryland Davies, Willard White, Valerie Masterson, Lillian Watson; with the London Philharmonic Orchestra conducted by Gustav Kuhn Video Arts International 145 minutes. $69.95 Mozart's first great opera is here heard in a 1980 production from Glyndebourne, and it has the famous Glyndebourne characteristics.

title: FRANCE EXPELLING 2 LIBYANS, CITING TERRORIST LINKS
description: France has ordered two Libyan diplomats to leave the country and expelled at least two other Arabs in connection with efforts to prevent terrorist attacks on American installations in Europe, an Interior Ministry spokesman said today.

title: GERIATRIC PROGRAM AIDS THE ELDERLY AND THEIR FAMILIES
description: EDITH SMITH is 76 years old.

title: Teaming Up Against AIDS
description: An encouraging addendum to Morton Hunt's excellent article: Progress is evidently being made in overcoming a crucial problem raised by the Harvard AIDS researchers -getting an antiviral drug to penetrate the body's blood-brain barrier. Dr. Nicholas Bodor, at the University of Florida in Gainesville, has developed a fat-soluble ''carrier'' compound that, when linked to a drug, passes the drug through the barrier. A natural enzyme then converts the drug to a water-soluble form that ''locks'' it into the brain.

title: CORRECTION
description: A Northeast Journal item last Sunday on a Massachusetts program to preserve 300 parks designed by the landscape architect who also designed New York's Central Park, or by his firm, misspelled his name. It is Frederick Law Olmsted.

title: SHARYN M. FRANK BECOMES A BRIDE
description: Sharyn Marion Frank, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur B. Frank of Charlotte, N.C., was married yesterday to Richard Alan Sarner, the son of Mr. and Mrs. George Sarner of Stamford, Conn. Rabbi Marc Wilson performed the ceremony at the Charlotte Marriott Executive Park hotel.

title: CAPITALIST CRUSADERS
description: INVENTING REALITY The Politics of the Mass Media. By Michael Parenti. 258 pp. New York: St. Martin's Press. $16.95. FREEDOM of the press, A. J. Liebling wrote, belongs to the man who owns one. Taking Liebling's maxim as his point of departure, Michael Parenti, the author of ''Democracy for the Few,'' has written a forceful though flawed critique of the American news media. By documenting patterns of conservative bias in a dozen major news stories in the printed and broadcast press, ''Inventing Reality'' provides a valuable rebuttal to the drumbeat of criticism of the news media from the right. Unfortunately, Mr. Parenti is so simplistic and doctrinaire in accounting for this bias that he makes his book easy to dismiss.

title: Sudan's Military Keeps a Promise
description: It may have been out of practice, but the Sudan has not forgotten how to hold an election. In fact, the country's first contested election since 1968 saw about 30 parties field candidates last week for 301 seats in a new National Assembly that will choose a government and write a constitution.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: WINTER IN THE MORNING: A Young Girl's Life in the Warsaw Ghetto and Beyond 1939-1945. By Janina Bauman. (The Free Press, $16.95.)

title: EX-OFFICER IS SENTENCED
description: A former Philadelphia police officer convicted of extorting money from a bar has been sentenced to three months in prison and fined $2,000. The officer, John R. Steele, sentenced Thursday in Federal District Court, was convicted last July of collecting about $120 a month for five years in exchange for a promise not to harass the bar's homosexual patrons.

title: KEY SECTIONS FROM VATICAN DOCUMENT ON LIBERATION THEOLOGY
description: Following, in official translation, are key sections from ''Instruction on Christian Freedom and Liberation,'' issued today by the Vatican's Congregation for the Doctrine of the Faith:

title: SUMMARY IS SHORT, EVENING IS LONG
description: IN CONTRAST to the three-part, nine-play marathon ''The Greeks'' - a chronicle of the Trojan War and its aftermath - the Whole Theatre's ''Electra: the Legend,'' which lasts less than three hours, is a short, short summary, even though it turns out to be a long, long evening. (''The Greeks'' has been presented by the Royal Shakespeare Company in England, the Williamstown Theater Festival in Massachusetts, the Hartford Stage Company in Connecticut and the ACT Theater in Seattle, and will open in Hollywood's Back Alley Theater on Wednesday.) For yet another contrast, the Offenbach operetta ''La Belle Helene,'' a comic view of the Trojan War, was recently and farcically revived Off Off Broadway.

title: U.S. Pledges to Help Haiti More
description: Although the departure of President Jean-Claude Duvalier was cause for national rejoicing, it is becoming more and more apparent in Haiti these days that the party is over. Two months after Mr. Duvalier fled to France, the country he left is struggling economically; the ruling council that replaced him, dominated by the military, is losing popularity, and small leftist groups are worrying some diplomats.

title: LABOR OF LOVE AT YORK MINSTER
description: LEADERS at York Minster in England moved quickly to make repairs after fire had ravaged part of the Anglican cathedral, the largest medieval church in northern Europe.

title: RECITAL: DELORES STEVENS, PIANIST, PERFORMS AT FORUM
description: DELORES STEVENS'S piano recital at the NYU Composers Forum on Thursday night sent 20th-century composition in four different directions. George Heussenstamm's ''Reflections II'' was Impressionism revisited, but cast here in a darker light and using a post-tonal language that floats free of harmonic gravitational pull.

title: MAN AND MYTH ON WALL STREET
description: PETER M. DAWKINS, Heisman Trophy winner, Rhodes Scholar and Army hero, arrived at Lehman Brothers nearly three years ago, bringing with him the resume of a lifelong overachiever. It was enough to inspire envy, if not fear, in the hearts of his Wall Street competitors. There was the childhood triumph over polio, followed by a brilliant academic and football career at West Point. A quarter-century stint in the Army brought yards of combat ribbons for service in Vietnam; at 43 he was named brigadier general, and he seemed on the way to fulfilling his football coach Earl Blaik's early prediction, ''He's a cinch to make Chief of Staff.''

title: CHRISTINGE LAHTI: A SECOND BANANA WREATHED IN LAURELS
description: Funny things happen to Christine Lahti when she gets into a movie. She starts off as second banana - or at most co-banana. Then, the moment the film opens, critics, and audiences, agree very quickly that she has all but stolen the show.

title: DR. LAURAINE EFFINGER WED
description: Dr. Lauraine Jean Effinger, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William L. Effinger Jr. of Atlanta, was married yesterday to Dr. Peter Killip Davidson, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Samuel Davidson of Rochester.

title: PLEASANTLY GHASTLY
description: THE MAUL AND THE PEAR TREE The Ratcliffe Highway Murders 1811. By P. D. James and T. A. Critchley. Illustrated. 234 pp. New York: Mysterious Press. $17.95.

title: AT THE GAP, A BOLD NEW LOOK
description: THREE years ago, the company that once exhorted customers to ''Fall into The Gap,'' seemed ready to plunge into a deep hole itself. The blue jeans craze, which had propelled the growth of The Gap stores, had been slowing for years as the chain's biggest customers, the baby-boomers, were leaving their teen-age years - and their blue jeans - behind. The Gap was subsisting from one big sale to another without a clear direction, unable to diversify.

title: CORRECTION
description: A picture caption on page 27 of the Arts and Leisure section today gives an incorrect date for the showing of the film ''My Two Loves.'' It will be shown Monday night at 9 on ABC.

title: GEORGIA RELEASES ATHLETES
description: Dr. Ruth Sabol, who holds Dr. Jan Kemp's old job at the University of Georgia, says that times have changed for academically deficient athletes at the school - as shown by the fact that four were dismissed last week.

title: Teaming Up Against AIDS
description: Morton Hunt's article ''Teaming Up Against AIDS'' (March 2) not only contributes to an understanding of current scientific thought on this devastating human problem, but also sheds light on some glaring deficiencies in the way modern medical research is conducted.

title: DANCE: PAUL TAYLOR'S TROUPE AT CITY CENTER
description: PAUL TAYLOR'S choreography makes the ordinary extraordinary. That was evident Wednesday night when the Paul Taylor Dance Company presented three works from its repertory at the City Center.

title: Sports People; Handshakes Instead
description: Cleburne Price has $1,500 worth of trophies and medals and nobody to give them to. Price, the director of the Texas Relays at the University of Texas this weekend, said the awards for high school winners had been purchased before he learned of an obscure National Collegiate Athletic Association rule adopted last January.

title: CAPE COD HUNTING FOR SUMMER HELP
description: To Cape Cod each year, April brings cold, wind-driven rains, flocks of northbound Canada geese and the start of the spring hunt for workers to fill thousands of summer jobs.

title: WHAT BARTOK AND LEGS DIAMOND HAD IN COMMON
description: SARANAC America's Magic Mountain. By Robert Taylor. Illustrated. 308 pp. Boston: Houghton Mifflin Company. $17.95.

title: TIGERS MOVE BACK TO TOP; ROYALS HOLD THEIR SPOT
description: The following American League preview was prepared and written by Murray Chass. Teams are listed in the predicted order of finish, with the Yankees picked for second place in the East. EASTERN DIVISION: Detroit Tigers Sparky Anderson, the master of hyperbolic assessment of his baseball teams, never would have admitted it then, but now he admits that he cannot explain how his 1984 Tigers won 104 games en route to the World Series championship. ''It was a miracle,'' he says. ''Everything went right. It's one of those things that nobody can explain. We deserved to win maybe 94, but not 104.''

title: LUDWIG'S CASTLES: FORMS OF FANTASY
description: Form without function and splendor without taste, slavish imitation of other places and other eras carried out by inferior artists, all for the pleasure of one man who may have understood music but to whom art and architecture remained a closed book: those are the characteristics of three castles in Bavaria that, in the last few years, have become one of the most popular tourist attractions in Europe. That a great deal of money was spent on them is incontrovertible; that it was wasted is equally plain, at least in terms of beauty and quality; but, as the guide at Schloss Linderhof kept proudly repeating on a recent visit, ''The money has come back.'' Indeed, what King Ludwig II of Bavaria, all unknowing, invented in the 1860's and 1870's is none other than the very first Disneyland.

title: BADGER LAND WINS FLAMINGO STAKES
description: Badger Land continued his march toward the Kentucky Derby today with a four-length romp in the $300,000 Flamingo Stakes at Hialeah Park.

title: QUALITY FISH, NOW WIDELY AVAILABLE, IN PROPER-DIET VANGUARD
description: YEARS ago I had a Sudanese friend who was a United Nations diplomat, and a superb cook. When he lived in New York City he used to give extraordinary dinner parties - lavish spreads of complicated native dishes, all of which he would make himself (without the aid of a food processor) in his tiny Manhattan kitchen. And when everything was set out on the table, he would stand back, clasping his hands in front of him and announce to the assembled company with enormous pride, ''No animal fats!''

title:
GARDENING;
FRUIT TREES CAN COMPLEMENT LANDSCAPE
description: THE stone fruits, those with a single hard-coated seed surrounded by a layer of edible flesh, are popular for eating fresh as well as in processed forms. All are sufficiently attractive to be included in a garden that might otherwise be classified as strictly ornamental. Yet, they are grown less frequently than apples.

title: Seaweed
description: To the Editor: As a native of Swansea, South Wales, I was delighted to read Gloria Levitas's article ''Seaweed Supper in Wales (Travel, Feb. 9).

title: Anything for a Butt
description: The tough antismoking laws proposed by Mayor Koch have left some New Yorkers looking for reasons to object. But nobody's straining further than the people at Philip Morris. In an essay prepared for readers of the city's black newspapers, Guy Smith, a vice president, says the antismoking bill ''has serious implications for the metropolitan minority community.''

title: U.S. OFFERS TO BUY FLOOD SITES
description: THE Federal Emergency Management Agency (FEMA) has come up with a $5 million offer to buy flood-damaged property from 141 New Jersey homeowners and then turn the land into public open space.

title: ANDEAN CAMPING FLOATING IN FLOWERS
description: Deluxe Tour Of Peru's Forest Wilderness By plane, by bus and ultimately by boat, a summer journey will take its participants into the heart of a vast South American wilderness teeming with wildlife.

title: HOW TO KEEP ELECTRICITY BILLS DOWN: LEARN TO READ THE METER
description: IN most homes, electric bills still account for a high percentage of the monthly budget - especially if there is an electric stove and oven and if electricity is used for heating hot water. In the summer, of course, costs climb even higher if the house is centrally air-conditioned - even if only one or two bedrooms are air-conditioned.

title: TACTICAL TURMOIL
description: It is well known that games in which opponents castle on opposite wings give rise to spirited play because neither player need hold anything back in a mating attack. Much rarer are games in which both players castle on the same wing and try to snatch the mating attack from each other. Yet these can be equally exciting.

title: PROJECTS UNDER WAY TO STEM TEEN-AGE DRINKING
description: WITH the black lights, sirens, strobes and vintage parachutes hung and ready to go, students last week were preparing to turn on their $4,000 sound system and inaugurate Westchester's first student-run nightclub.

title: Soba
description: To the Editor: Noel Perrin's article on soba (''Learning to Love Noodles,'' Travel, Feb. 16) recalled many a delicious helping of that uniquely Japanese noodle.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: SHEPHERD AVENUE. By Charles Carillo. (Atlantic Monthly, $16.95.) Absence is the dominant note of Charles Carillo's first novel, told by 10-year-old Joey Ambrosio, whose mother has just died and whose father has taken his own grief on some solitary pilgrimage.

title: FILIPINOS PLAN A NEW DRIVE FOR TOURISM
description: Perhaps no one was more pleased than Jose Antonio Gonzalez after President Corazon C. Aquino proclaimed a provisional constitution last week but carefully avoided any talk of revolution.

title: Art
description: Among many members of the art public who are dissatisfied with mainstream art, if not with modernism itself, there is an ongoing search for artists to believe in. The requirements include an absolute commitment to craft, composition and form, as well as a belief in figuration as the means by which art can partake of the complexity, mystery and density of the world around us.

title: George Bush's Candidacy
description: George Bush can win, and he does have a message. That message is his desire to return to a standard of excellence in all facets of American life.

title: GOING ON IN THE NORTHEAST
description: CHAUCER IN PHILADELPHIA Works by Chaucer and those who influenced him are the subject of ''Sixty Bokes Olde and Newe,'' an exhibition in Philadelphia that includes fragments from 14th- and 15th-century manuscripts of his ''Canterbury Tales.''

title: ROSE EXPECTS TO MISS 2 WEEKS
description: Pete Rose, the Reds' player-manager, said today he would probably open the season on the disabled list, reducing Cincinnati's roster to the agreed 24-man limit.

title: J. PATRICK DOWD MARRIES ANN M. REILLY
description: Ann Marie Reilly, an associate editor of Fortune magazine in Washington, and J. Patrick Dowd, a vice president of the Coastal Carriers Corporation, a shipping concern in Annapolis, Md., were married in New York yesterday. The Rev. Thomas Peterson performed the ceremony at the Convent of the Sacred Heart.

title: IF YOU'RE THINKING OF LIVING IN TRUMBULL
description: FROM Trumbull's Tashua Hill, 608 feet above sea level, the waters of Long Island Sound can be seen glistening 12 miles away, off neighboring Bridgeport's shore. During the Revolutionary War the hill, named for the Tamtashua Indians, served as an observation point.

title: Bookshelf
description: Additional titles of interest:

title: T.W.A. BOMB CALLED TYPE USED BY TERRORISTS
description: A highly potent plastic explosive and a miniature detonation device apparently similar to those used by a Palestinian terrorist group were components of the bomb that exploded Wednesday aboard a Trans World Airlines jet over Greece, investigators said today.

title: COMMENTS BY BUSH RALLY OIL MARKETS
description: Vice President Bush indicated he would tell Saudi Arabia that action was needed to halt the precipitous drop in oil prices. He hinted that the United States was willing to work with the Saudis to that end, although talks with OPEC are not likely. His remarks caused a furor in the rest of the Administration, which scrambled to attempt to reassure the Saudis and other oil producers that there had been no change in the stated policy of letting the free market control prices. But some analysts said Mr. Bush would not have spoken out so strongly unless there was some backing to his remarks. Indeed, the Administration's statements lately seem to address the problems, rather than the benefits, of the price drop.

title: PATRICIA JACKMAN IS MARRIED ON L.I.
description: Patricia Elizabeth Jackman, a daughter of Henry R. Jackman Jr. of Rockville Centre, L.I., and the late Mrs. Jackman, was married yesterday to Christopher Paul Meyering, a son of Mr. and Mrs. John R. Meyering of Riverside, Conn. The Rev. John McGeever officiated at the Roman Catholic ceremony in St. Agnes Cathedral in Rockville Centre.

title: PAGLIARULO'S PROBLEMS AT PLATE PRESENT OPPORTUNITY FOR BERRA
description: The Toronto Blue Jays thought the season starts Tuesday; no one told them the Yankees were starting it today. But the Yankees, given fair warning by George Steinbrenner, played the game more like the real thing and easily defeated the defending American League East champions, 6-1.

title: SAVORING THE VILLAGES OF FRANCE'S MIDI
description: The dessert is not on the table; it hangs in lush clusters among the greenery, and all I have to do is reach up a lazy hand and pick. These are our own grapes - velvety muscat and plump, golden-green Italia - hanging down from the vines covering our tonnelle, a cool leafy arbor for summer meals in the Midi.

title: Mellon Bank
description: To the Editor:

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: JUDGE SPENCER DISSENTS. By Henry Denker. (Morrow, $17.95.) The action of this made-for-a-television-movie novel starts when the ''eccentric and unconventional'' Judge Harry Spencer hands down a legal opinion written in Spanish.

title: IN QUOTES
description: ''I think it is essential that we talk about stability and that we not just have a continued free fall like a parachutist jumping out without a parachute.''

title: GENIUS WAS NOT ENOUGH
description: LOUIS SULLIVAN His Life and Work. By Robert Twombly. Illustrated. 530 pp. New York: Elisabeth Sifton Books/Viking. $29.95.

title: EXPERTS LOOK TO OTHER COUNTRIES' APPROACHES TO PROBLEM OF LIABILITY CLAIMS
description: With the Federal Government and many states struggling to find solutions to widespread difficulties in obtaining liability insurance, some experts are seeking insights in the legal systems of other countries.

title: Fireworks-Plant Blast Kills 11 in Philippines
description: Three explosions at a firecracker factory in the suburb of Bocaue killed 11 young workers and damaged homes more than a quarter-mile away, the police said today.

title: Participatory Democracy Engenders Strange Results; One Date for All
description: To the Editor:

title: Defining Terrorism
description: To the Editor:

title: ROBIN HOPE HELFAND MARRIED TO JAMES G. GLICKER
description: The marriage of Robin Hope Helfand, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Eugene Helfand of Berkeley Heights, N.J., to James G. Glicker, a son of Mr. and Mrs. George Glicker of Myrtle Beach, S.C., took place yesterday. The Rev. Alan Wells, a Unitarian minister, officiated at the Chapel of the Church Center for the United Nations.

title: JORDON SCORES 30 TO PROVE HIS POINT
description: Michael Jordan, in his longest stint since returning from a layoff of four and a half months with a broken foot, scored 30 points in leading the Chicago Bulls to a 102-97 victory over the Atlanta Hawks tonight.

title: FAIRFIELD STATUS: YOU ARE WHAT YOU EAT
description: YOU are lined up at the cash register at the local farmers market. It's Saturday so everyone's there, including that celebrity couple everyone cooly ignores. The renovated barn full of fresh food, flowers, prestigious bottled goods, and just-baked goodies, is full of shoppers in Reeboks and fur jackets. You look in all the other baskets crushed in the line with you to make sure you haven't missed anything new.

title: MAKING SENSE OF CRICKET
description: Stationed far apart on an enormous manicured lawn, 13 men in white clothing attempt languid semaphore, refusing or pleading, with now a scamper and now a spastic crouch. A red ball rolls among them, to no decisive purpose, it seems, because this has been going on for three or four days already, scheduled for five but not counting Sunday, and everyone who understands is hoping for rain or a draw. Yet a team has come all the way from Australia to do it on various fields in England, and clearly national honor is at stake.

title: DR. DUPONT IS MARRIED TO DR. ROBERT VARNEY
description: Dr. Renee Marie Dupont, a chief resident in psychiatry at the Tufts Medical Center in Boston, was married yesterday to Dr. Robert Ralph Varney, chief resident in diagnostic radiology at the Massachusetts General Hospital in Boston. The Rev. Robert J. Sullivan performed the Roman Catholic ceremony at the Harvard Memorial Church in Cambridge, Mass.

title: Being a Jr.
description: THERE IS A PHOTOGRAPH in my parents' house in Brooklyn which never fails to grab a gaze as I pass by.

title: DR. VINCENT D. ROMEO TO WED DARIA SENALDI
description: Dr. and Mrs. A. Fred Senaldi of Passaic, N.J., have announced that their daughter, Daria Lynn Senaldi, a pharmacist, plans to marry Dr. Vincent D. Romeo, a pharmaceutical scientist. An August wedding is planned.

title: Eternal Light
description: To the Editor:

title: NEW LIFE FOR FADING DOWNTOWN DENVILLE
description: WHEN the first phase of the 1.5 million-square-foot Rockaway Townsquare mall opened in 1977, there was not much reason to be optimistic about the future of nearby Denville's downtown shopping area.

title: ONE BAD APPLE
description: THE KILLING OF YESTERDAY'S CHILDREN By M. S. Power. 264 pp. New York: Viking. $16.95.

title: TRADING TAUNTS WITH MOSCOW
description: MIKHAIL S. GORBACHEV seemed ubiquitious last week, appearing here almost every day on television or in the newspapers with a new appeal for President Reagan to negotiate an end to nuclear weapons testing.

title: Mob Said to Take $80 Per Capita
description: In its final report, issued last week, the President's Commission on Organized Crime said the mob would salt away as much as $75 billion this year, in the process costing the country more than 400,000 jobs (because of reduced competiton in several industries) and reducing the income of every law-abiding American by nearly $80.

title: SCREEN: 'KOMBA'
description: THE main attraction of the misleadingly titled ''Komba, God of the Pygmies,'' is its glimpses of the life of an African people who have long exercised a fascination for Westerners. We see the pygmies hunting, grubbing for caterpillars, thatching straw for huts, grieving, praying, making magic. They can't help being interesting.

title:
ABOUT WESTCHESTER;
NO PLACE LIKE HOME
description: ONE night when Dmitry Yablonsky was 13 years old, he left his Moscow home to go to a party with some friends. While he was gone, his mother received a phone call. ''We are going to kill your son,'' said the voice on the other end.

title: Curren-Wilkison Final
description: Third-seeded Kevin Curren never lost his serve and broke Brian Teacher's serve three times tonight to advance to the final of the $279,000 W.C.T.-Atlanta Championships.

title: Europe Consistent on Intermediate Forces
description: To the Editor:

title: NEWS SUMMARY: SUNDAY, APRIL 6, 1986
description: International

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: THE PROBITY CHORUS. By Richard Lemon. (Norton, $15.95.) Billy Buffum, a journalist whose wife of 18 years has left him for a richer man, is nevertheless surrounded by infatuated women.

title: CHERYL KEAN BECOMES BRIDE
description: The Osceola Presbyterian Church in Clark, N.J., was the setting yesterday for the wedding of Cheryl Diane Kean, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Herbert F. Kean of Cranford, N.J., and Sag Harbor, L.I., to Thomas Patrick Crohan, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas F. Crohan of Springfield, Mass. The Rev. Edward Zaragoza performed the ceremony assisted by the Rev. Paul Cannariato, a Roman Catholic priest.

title: ALAS
description: In the nation's capital, as in the National Football League, a good offense is the best defense. So it was last week when members of the Farm Animal Reform Movement demonstrated at the Department of Agriculture to protest face-branding of cattle.

title: A FAUSTIAN BARGAIN WITH THE JAPANESE
description: AMERICA'S industrial policy for commercial aircraft is at a turning point, but it is turning in the wrong direction. Once again, we are about to give our expertise to the Japanese so they can fly with it.

title: SEGOVIA'S LEGACY: HALF A CENTURY OF GUITAR DISKS
description: The life Andres Segovia has led since the 1920's, when he began touring the world, has often seemed more like an evangelical crusade than a normal performing career. But that has been of necessity, for his chosen instrument, the guitar, has been something of a handicap. For Mr. Segovia, the guitar was a stately vessel through which a composer's inspiration could flow directly to the heart. But to much of the musical world he hoped to conquer, it was a crude, folk instrument. Mr. Segovia has fought his battle on many fronts. At 93, he continues to give concerts - in fact, he is performing at Avery Fisher Hall on Wednesday. Behind him lies a string of works he commissioned, an extensive series of performing editions, and a catalogue of modern refinements he has brought to modern guitar technique.

title: Earthquake in Peru Kills 5 and Hurts 30
description: An earthquake jolted the ancient Incan city of Cuzco today, killing 5 people, injuring at least 30 and sending panicked residents racing from crumbling homes into the streets, authorities said.

title: Mailbox; Sticking Up For Red Sox
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: SELLING TO THE COUNTY'S FOREIGN MARKET
description: WHEN mortgage interest rates dropped in the county, activity at the Furumoto Realty offices in Tokyo quickened. It is there that Japanese businessmen, scheduled for job assignments in the United States, study property listings in Hartsdale, Scarsdale, Rye, Pound Ridge and Harrison, and sometimes make decisions to buy houses sight-unseen before they leave Japan.

title:
WESTCHESTER OPINION;
ENOUGH IS ENOUGH! WE'LL FIND AN APARTMENT BY OURSELVES
