description: MY grown-up years have taken me away from New York, in search of other experiences -professional and personal. Part of the last five years I spent living in New England and the rest of the time in Australia. But the lure of New York, where my family and friends are, has been great despite my wanderlust.

title: EVE ROBINSON MARRIES
description: Eve Robinson, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Irving Robinson of West Trenton, N.J., was married yesterday in her parents' home to Thomas Fraioli, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Anthony V. Fraioli of Hawthorne Woods, Ill. Rabbi Susan Schnur officiated. Mrs. Fraioli is a staff trainer at the New York State Child Welfare Training Institute in New York City. Her husband, a violinist, is a music instructor at the York Preparatory School.

title: AN OPERA QUOTED BY MOZART IS ABOUT TO BE GIVEN HERE
description: This Friday night, the Vineyard Opera Shop, 309 East 26th Street, will present what is thought to be the first professional American performance of ''Una Cosa Rara,'' an opera by Vicente Martin y Soler that had its premiere in Vienna on Nov. 17, 1786, some six months after the first staging of Mozart's ''Marriage of Figaro.''

title: WHY THINGS LOOK GOOD
description: THE AESTHETIC EXPERIENCE An Anthropologist Looks at the Visual Arts. By Jacques Maquet. Illustrated. 272 pp. New Haven: Yale University Press. $35. A LARGE and noble ambition informs ''The Aesthetic Experience'' by Jacques Maquet, a distinguished anthropologist, philosopher, art lover and sometime denizen of several Buddhist monasteries who teaches at the University of California, Los Angeles. It seeks to frame nothing less than a comparative science of esthetic experience. Mr. Maquet does not shilly-shally - he reckons there is a distinctively esthetic attitude, and he is happy to delineate its precise contours in broad, clear strokes.

title: 2 KILLED, 155 HURT IN BOMB EXPLOSION AT CLUB IN BERLIN
description: A bomb ripped through a West Berlin discotheque popular with American troops early today, killing an American soldier and a Turkish woman. A total of 155 people were wounded, including 50 to 60 Americans, the police said.

title: QUALITY FISH, NOW WIDELY AVAILABLE, IN PROPER-DIET VANGAURD
description: YEARS ago I had a Sudanese friend who was a United Nations diplomat, and a superb cook. When he lived in New York City he used to give extraordinary dinner parties - lavish spreads of complicated native dishes, all of which he would make himself (without the aid of a food processor) in his tiny Manhattan kitchen. And when everything was set out on the table, he would stand back, clasping his hands in front of him and announce to the assembled company with enormous pride, ''No animal fats!''

title: A PLEA FOR STABILITY, NOT PRICE-SETTING, ON THE OIL MARKET
description: JUST when many Americans were happily contemplating the shriveling of inflation and other payoffs of plummeting oil prices, Vice President Bush came along with a different message. Embarking on a Middle Eastern trip last week, Mr. Bush said he would be telling Saudi Arabia that steep decreases in prices were harming ''our own domestic interest and thus the interest of our national security.''

title: THATCHER FACING BY-ELECTION TEST
description: The main battlefield in British politics right now is a socially diverse neighborhood, here in a bend in the River Thames, that is about to be the scene of an important political test for Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher.

title: COGAN WINS INDY-CAR RACE
description: Kevin Cogan, taking advantage of Michael Andretti's misfortune, drove to his first Indy-car victory today in the Dana 200 at Phoenix International Raceway.

title: Stake in Reuters Sold
description: United Newspapers, owners of Britain's Express group of newspapers, said Friday that it had sold its stake of 17.5 million common B shares in Reuters Holdings to raise $110 million for new investment and to pay debts.

title: 3 DERBY PROSPECTS HAVE DIFFERENT STYLES
description: Snow Chief, Badger Land and Mogambo, who crossed the wire in that order in the Florida Derby at Gulfstream Park last month, emerged from important victories this weekend as the favorites for the Kentucky Derby on May 3.

title: People
description: * Neil Costa and Eugene Tashoff have been named group senior vice presidents at Campbell-Ewald, Warren, Mich.

title: New Handicaps
description: Handicaps are supposed to enable golfers with unequal skills to play as equals. In reality, however, handicaps don't travel well. A player who earns, say, a 15 handicap at a pussycat course such as Van Cortlandt Park will find himself hopelessly outclassed by a player whose 15 handicap was won on the tiger layout at Winged Foot. The problem has been that although handicaps are adjusted to reflect a given course's degree-of-difficulty rating, the course ratings themselves have been relatively crude affairs based largely on yardage.

title: Stephanie Mills, Singer, With Atlantic Starr
description: Stephanie Mills and Atlantic Starr represent sharply divergent approaches to mainstream pop-soul music. Miss Mills, who originated the role of Dorothy in ''The Wiz,'' on Broadway more than a decade ago, has grown into an aggressively flamboyant performer whose acrobatics, audacious sexiness, and roof-raising pop-gospel delivery exemplify pop showmanship at its most extreme.

title: Newest U.N. Diplomat Is Thomas A. Edison
description: The Ed of Con Ed returned last week to the city he once electrified and brought brief peace to a labor battle at the United Nations.

title: REPUBLICAN IS ENDORSED BY UNIONS IN KEY RACE
description: Two politically active unions that usually support Democrats have endorsed the Republican candidate for the State Senate in a key special election this month in the northeast Bronx and southeastern Westchester County.

title: REALISTS VS. ADMINISTRATION IDEOLOGUES ON NICARAGUA
description: To the Editor:

title: CONSERVATIONIST FILLS A TALL ORDER: SAVING THE GIRAFFES
description: Dozens of giggling schoolchildren gathered around as the walking skyscraper ambled over to Betty Leslie-Melville and plucked a carrot from her mouth.

title: Samuel Beckett Tribute At New York University
description: New York University's Center for French Civilization and Culture will pay tribute to Samuel Beckett's 80th birthday with a series of readings from and lectures about his drama, poetry and prose, today through next Sunday.

title: ANGOLA SAYS PRETORIA PLANE AIDING REBELS WAS DOWNED
description: Angola said today that its air force shot down a South African Air Force transport plane last week while it was dropping supplies to anti-Government rebels over the central province of Bie.

title: Reading Co. Chairman
description: The Reading Company, a Philadelphia-based developer of commercial real estate, announced on Friday that John W. Sullivan, president and chief executive officer, had been named chairman. He will replace Thomas A. Reynolds Jr., who will continue to serve as director and chairman of the executive committee. Charles M. Carter, executive vice president, will become president and chief operating officer.

title: 'THE LITTLE SISTER,' DRAMA ON PBS
description: THE Boston waterfront and that city's back streets, which are a long way from life in Harvard Square, serve as the interesting backdrop for ''The Little Sister,'' tonight's ''American Playhouse'' drama (9 o'clock on WNET/Channel 13).

title: COURTS WRESTLE WITH CLAIMS OF CHURCH FRAUD
description: For the past five weeks a jury here has listened to accusations that the Church of Scientology defrauded a man when it promised him emotional and financial security and higher intelligence through Scientology.

title: LOLA S. WACHSBERG WEDS IRWIN A. ZUCKER IN JERSEY
description: Lola Sue Wachsberg and Irwin A. Zucker were married yesterday by Rabbi Reuben Levine at the bride's home in Mountainside, N.J.

title: AFGHAN REBELS REPORT MAJOR SOVIET OFFENSIVE
description: Afghan guerrillas said today that waves of Soviet and Afghan jets blasted rebel positions in Afghanistan's strategic Paktia Province as elite commando units backed by tanks fought to encircle the insurgents in a major offensive.

title: Maryland Bank Rules Backed
description: New rules designed to halt the kind of insider dealings and risky investments that pushed Maryland's privately insured savings and loan industry to the brink of bankruptcy last May got unanimous approval on final votes in the Maryland Senate and House of Delegates on Saturday and need only the signature of Gov. Harry Hughes, who introduced the legislation, to become law.

title: LIBRARY OF CONGRESS USE IS BEYOND POLITICS
description: To the Editor:

title: T.W.A. Magazine Shift
description: Trans World Airlines has selected East/West Network to publish its in-flight magazine, Ambassador. Each month a total of 280,000 copies are distributed aboard the 166 T.W.A. aircraft. East/West's Los Angeles office will handle the job, formerly done by Paulsen Publishing.

title: PIANO: JANINA FIALKOWSKA
description: THE pianist Janina Fialkowska's Thursday evening Liszt recital at the 92d Street Y proved an exciting concert, even for a listener who doesn't really like most of the composer's music very much.

title: SNOW CHIEF 6-LENGTH WINNER
description: Snow Chief continued his methodical march toward the Kentucky Derby with a six-length victory in the $500,000 Santa Anita Derby here today.

title: LYLE VICTOR ON A 70
description: Sandy Lyle of Scotland turned back Andy Bean's strong bid and scored his first American victory today in winning the Greater Greensboro Open by two strokes.

title: MISS BAYER WEDS A YALE PROFESSOR
description: Sambra Lynn Bayer and Dr. Sherman Morton Weissman were married yesterday in Dwight Chapel at Yale University. Rabbi Mark Panoff officiated.

title: Temporary Impact On Oil Prices Seen
description: Oil analysts in the United States expect the price of oil to rise today in reaction to statements Vice President Bush made yesterday in Saudi Arabia that United States national security could be threatened by further declines in oil prices, even though they maintained that his remarks seemed to retreat from comments he made last week.

title: WHERE TO START?
description: Representative Fortney H. (Pete) Stark, a California Democrat, was amused the other day to receive a publication from the South African Embassy entitled ''A New Beginning.''

title: PUTTING THE V.I.P.'S ON CANVAS
description: Along with the power and perks that accompany the office of the Presidency, or a top Cabinet position, usually comes the opportunity to be immortalized in an official portrait for future generations to gaze upon.

title: TOTAL BILL CAN EXCEED $16,000
description: American colleges and universities are planning to raise tuition charges next fall by an average of 7 to 8 percent, about the same rate as last year, according to a spot check.

title: Shamrock Broadens Stake in Foote, Cone
description: The Roy E. Disney family's Shamrock Holdings disclosed not only has gotten clearance from the Securities and Exchange Commission under the Hart-Scott-Rodino Antitrust Improvements Act to buy up to 25 percent of the outstanding stock of Foote, Cone & Belding Communications, but also has purchased an additional 94,500 shares to add to the 280,900 it had in early March, bringing its holdings to 9.9 percent of all of the ad agency's outstanding shares.

title: 2,000TH RABBI IS ORDAINED AT SEMINARY'S CENTENNIAL
description: Yeshiva University honored 100 recently ordained rabbis at its affiliated seminary yesterday in a celebration culminating in the ordination of the 2,000th rabbi in the school's 100-year history.

title: DIANE J. LESSER, AN OBOIST, MARRIES RICHARD J. POLLAN
description: Diane Joan Lesser, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Laurence M. Lesser of Norwalk, Conn., and Richard Jay Pollan, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Bert Irwin Pollan of Chicago, were married yesterday by Rabbi Jonas Goldberg at the Terrace restaurant at Butler Hall, Columbia University.

title: EXECUTIVES
description: * American Express Bank Ltd. assigned four senior executives: R. Paul Fukuda will head the Hong Kong merchant banking group, which has been joined by Kuen B. Kim, and Axel Hirschberg will head the London group, which has been joined by Salim M. Lalani.

title: INTERNATIONAL MINERALS COPES
description: The International Minerals and Chemical Corporation has long boasted of being the biggest and most profitable fertilizer company in the world. Now, with the farm economy hitting its lowest point since the Depression, the company is counting on its size and savvy to help it survive.

title: GUARDING PATENTS
description: Government officials estimate that the American economy loses $12 billion to $20 billion a year as a result of foreign copying of intellectual property: American patents, trademarks and copyrights.

title: INKSTER FADES TO 5TH
description: Pat Bradley was just not going to let victory in the 15th annual Nabisco-Dinah Shore tournament get away from her as it did two years ago.

title: WEST GERMANY TO INVESTIGATE ROLE OF OTHER COUNTRIES IN BERLIN BLAST
description: The West German Government appointed a panel today to evaluate the possibility that foreign governments had some involvement in a bombing at a discotheque here that killed an American soldier and a Turkish woman.

title: FIREFIGHTERS RECOVER BODY FROM RUBBLE
description: Firefighters today recovered a charred body from the rubble of a warehouse that was destroyed Friday night in a fire that may have killed seven people, the police said.

title: Bidder for Tesoro Seen As a Persistent Suitor
description: From the Bass brothers of Fort Worth to Joseph C. Frates of Tulsa, in recent years the Southwest has developed a reputation as home to powerful, behind-the-scenes investors.

title: Middle Eastern Fair Set for Lincoln Center
description: The sounds, sights and aromas of the Middle East will fill the areas in and around Lincoln Center in early May at a four-day festival devoted to the varied cultures of the Middle East. Sponsored by the Symphony for United Nations and the New York Society for Ethical Culture, the event will feature performances of dance, music and theater, a crafts and foods festival, an art exhibition and film screenings.

title: USAdvertising Gets A Paperback Project
description: USAdvertising, the Lorimar-Telepictures subsidiary that opened its doors Jan. 1 with $30 millions in billings squeezed out of Kenyon & Eckhardt and Bozell & Jacobs when they merged, has just gotten its first new account since then.

title: 'THE CIVILIZING HAND'
description: A judge orders a newspaper not to publish something. The editors believe - correctly, as it turns out later - that the order is unconstitutional. Without appealing it, they go ahead and publish. Should they be punished for violating the order? Does the First Amendment override the obligation to respect court orders unless and until they are set aside?

title: AT A PARTY IN THE SKY 150 SEE HALLEY'S COMET
description: In a festive quest for a sighting of Halley's Comet, a group of 150 star-struck New Yorkers boarded a Pan American World Airways 727 jet at about 1:30 yesterday morning and flew 35,000 feet up into the night sky. Eating, sipping Champagne and jockeying for window space as they began their journey, they flew southeast over the Atlantic Ocean.

title: GANDHI ACTS TO HALT VIOLENCE IN PUNJAB
description: Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi, jolted by spreading violence in Punjab, has shaken up police operations in the state and pressed moderate Sikh leaders to take a tougher line against the killings.

title: Question Box
description: QUESTION: Rickey Henderson of the Yankees led the American League last season by scoring 146 runs, and he did it in only 143 games. How often has the league leader averaged better than a run per game, and who did it last before Henderson?

title: The Fitzwilliam Quartet Opens With Beethoven
description: The Fitzwilliam String Quartet opened its Alice Tully Hall program yesterday afternoon with Beethoven's Sixth Quartet, begun in standard allegro style; it was in the slow movements that the group let its intriguing modernist affinities show through. The four players (Daniel Zisman, Jonathan Sparey, Alan George, Ioan Davies) adopted a drained, weird, otherworldly tone; smooth but not lyrical, the lines inched like spiders toward their destinations.

title: WILL IT BE THE SENATE - OR RERUNS OF 'M*A*S*H'?
description: The Senate is making a historic, though somewhat tentative, approach to 20th century public relations. Its proceedings are already heard on radio, and after June 1 it hopes to be ready to allow voters to see its members in full cry, gavel to gavel, on cable television. But even then it will be some months before it makes up its mind whether or not to commit itself to a permanent ratings contest with cinema gems of the past, college basketball and reruns of ''M*A*S*H.''

title: U.S. PLANS TO DEFEND ITS PATENTS
description: Countries that do not protect American copyrights, trademarks and patents could be denied tariff concessions by the United States, while American laws would be stiffened to prevent sales of pirated or counterfeit goods here under new Reagan Administration proposals to be announced this week.

title: KEY CORRUPTION FIGURE CAME FROM OBSCURITY
description: Robert R. Richards, a man who spent much of his 44 years in the world where computer systems are promoted, perfected and built, walked into a vast and dusty Manhattan courtroom on the morning of March 27 and turned his life upside down.

title: 17 Transit Employees Said to Lack Licenses
description: Seventeen Transit Authority employees are believed to be performing engineering work without proper state licenses, according to the Inspector General of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority.

title: Economic Calendar
description: Listed below are the target release dates for major economic indicators scheduled to be released this week. Monday

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''It's not something the U.S. can do by itself.'' - Robert B. Oakley, head of the State Department's office of counterterrorism, on international cooperation against terrorism. [ A6:2. ]

title: Washington Watch; Administration Energy Plans
description: THE Reagan Administration, even as it vehemently defends the idea that an unfettered market should set the price of oil, is trying to bring the price drop to an end. Vice President Bush, for example, has gone to the Middle East to, among other things, tell Saudi Arabia that a healthy American oil industry is ''vital'' to the national security of the United States.

title: LAURIE LIKOFF IS A BRIDE
description: Laurie Ellen Likoff, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Stanley L. Likoff of Bellerose, Queens, was married yesterday to John Henry Frolich, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Harry Frolich of New York.

title: HANDLING OF PRESS DURING LIBYA FIGHTING FAULTED
description: The president of the American Society of Newspaper Editors and other journalists have expressed fresh concern about the Pentagon's handling of news coverage of the fighting in late March between American and Libyan forces off the Libyan coast.

title: AMERICANS TO INSPECT DEBRIS IN T.W.A. BOMBING INQUIRY
description: American explosives experts will perform laboratory tests on bits of clothing and aircraft debris in an effort to determine precisely what kind of bomb exploded on a Trans World Airlines jet last week, investigators said here today.

title: Officer at Key Set For Schering Tie
description: Key Pharmaceuticals Inc., which recently announced that it would merge with the Schering-Plough Corporation in a stock transaction valued at around $600 million, has announced that Daniel M. Bell, an officer since 1983, had been named to the new position of executive vice president/chief operating officer.

title: HELPING WIDOWS TO COPE
description: THE last two decades have seen a revolution in social scientists' thinking about widowhood and have brought a host of new insights about the way in which widows can best cope with their loss. It is becoming increasingly important to spread this knowledge, Dr. Phyllis R. Silverman says, ''because so many of us will be widowed.''

title: FOR OPEN NEGOTIATION OF PUBLIC CONTRACTS
description: To the Editor:

title: ELAINE A. ETKIN IS WED TO PETER A. SCHWEITZER
description: Elaine Ann Etkin, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Stanley N. Etkin of Coral Springs, Fla., was married yesterday to Peter Alan Schweitzer, a son of Mr. and Mrs. John J. Schweitzer of Battle Creek, Mich., and Sebastian, Fla. Rabbi Gerald I. Weider performed the ceremony at La Belle Epoque, a Manhattan reception hall.

title: EARLY SIGNS OF PROMISE IN UNION 'PARTNERSHIP' AT STEEL COMPANY
description: Not long ago, George A. Ferris was living at a place he and his wife own near Black Lake in the pine forests of northern Michigan, enjoying retirement after a long career at the Ford Motor Company's steel works.

title: Lookout Masuku Dies at 46; Commanded Nkomo Forces
description: Lieut. Gen. Lookout Masuku, a former guerrilla leader and Zimbabwean Army official who was released last month after four years in detention, died Saturday, a hospital spokesman said. He was 46 years old.

title: 'UNFINISHED BUSINESS,' BY AND WITH BOB ELLIS
description: THAT which warms the hearts of some can give others indigestion. Beware of ''Unfinished Business,'' the comparatively short (78 minutes), semisweet Australian film that will be shown at the Museum of Modern Art today at 6 P.M., and tomorrow at 8:30 P.M., in the New Directors/New Films Festival.

title: VIEW FROM THE BOTTOM: A LONG, LOST SEASON
description: EVERY time Johnnie LeMaster played on a team last season, it ended up in last place.

title: A COSTLIER YEN IS NOT ENOUGH
description: The Japanese yen has appreciated by 30 percent since summer, retaking all the ground it lost to the dollar in the last four years. That should make it harder for the Japanese to compete in America and easier for Americans to compete in Japan. But Japan's big trade surplus persists, still feeding protectionist sentiment in Congress. How come?

title: CIVILIANS USE SATELLITE PHOTOS FOR SPYING ON SOVIET MILITARY
description: Aerospace experts say a new era has dawned in which civilians are beginning to use satellite cameras to spy on military targets, including ships, submarines and missiles.

title: TWO COMMUNIST BUSINESSMEN, YUGOSLAV STYLE
description: Stanislav Valant is 35 years old and executive vice president of Yugoslavia's third-largest bank. Matija Skof is 38 and president of an industrial conglomerate that does a yearly business of more than $500 million.

title: MUSIC: MOZART PROGRAM BY ENGLISH BAROQUE
description: WHAT sets John Eliot Gardiner apart from many other early-music scholars is his singular lack of didacticism. His interpretations do not seem calculated to prove that everything we know about Baroque and Classical period music is wrong - to shock us out of our Beecham-Stokowski trances with the fervor of a Modernist in the Academy. Mr. Gardiner has done his musicological homework, and his orchestra, the English Baroque Soloists, performs on period instruments with a minimum of vibrato and 19th-century grandeur, but the results are not characterized by the rapid, rigid tempos and wispy scholasticism that has sometimes characterized such performances. Everything Mr. Gardiner led at the English Baroque Soloists' Friday evening concert at Alice Tully Hall was played ''correctly,'' but the correctness seemed a natural impulse rather than received wisdom. Mr. Gardiner transcends syntax and goes directly to the heart of the music.

title: Occidental Tenneco Bar
description: A judge has temporarily blocked the Occidental Petroleum Corporation's proposed $70 million purchase of some plastic-production assets of Houston-based Tenneco Inc. Federal District Judge Harold H. Greene, in Washington, granted the 10-day restraining order Thursday at the request of the Federal Trade Commission, which argued that the transaction could violate the Clayton Antitrust Act by reducing competition in three types of polyvinyl chloride resins. Occidental is seeking to acquire portions of Tenneco Polymers Inc., a subsidiary of Tenneco.

title: THOUSANDS IN HAITI MOBILIZE FOR A GIANT SPRING-CLEANING
description: Gaspar Jocelyn set up a roadblock early this morning and handed out the day's weapons to his cohorts, lean and barefoot teen-agers like himself. With shovels and machetes they hacked at weeds and clumps of litter by the roadside and with brooms of dry grass poked at a gutter full of soggy debris.

title: A VINTAGE YEAR FOR ECONOMIC TALKS
description: Beginning in Washington this week and until the seven-nation economic summit conference in Tokyo the first week of May, hundreds of policy makers will convene in world capitals to confront problems of the international economy - new rumblings of protectionism in world trade, the quest for ways to control the sometimes volatile dollar and the developing world's debt of nearly $1 trillion.

title: NO TEEPEE, BUT MAYBE A SWITCH-PITCHER
description: ANOTHER season calls. It comes like clockwork, but it remains so thoroughly unpredictable. Baseball is the same because it is always changing.

title: SOVIET SEEKS STATUS IN GATT
description: Faced with falling foreign trade volume and declining oil prices, the Soviet Union has recently made public its interest in becoming an observer at the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade.

title: THROUGH A SOVIET LENS: GOMORRAH ON HUDSON
description: New York City, never depicted very favorably in the Soviet Union, was the subject of a scathingly critical documentary that was broadcast on Soviet television last Wednesday evening in prime time.

title: OTB'S BRIGHT PROMISE FADES TO UNEASY FUTURE
description: Fifteen years ago this week, Mayor John V. Lindsay walked up to a window at Grand Central Terminal, wagered $2 on a horse named Money Wise, and announced that New York City offtrack betting, the first such legal operation in the country, was in business.

title: Davis to Coach Iowa Basketball
description: Tom Davis, whose Stanford teams had a 58-59 record in four seasons, was named the basketball coach at Iowa today.

title: TILLINGER'S FASCINATION WITH ORTON
description: It was as a young actor 20 years ago in London that John Tillinger first read a play by Joe Orton.

title: YANKS SAY HE'LL PLAY
description: Just as the Yankees were on the verge of concluding a relatively safe spring training, Rickey Henderson injured his left ankle today for the second time in 11 days. The Yankees said the injury was not serious and that Henderson would be ready for Tuesday's season-opening game. However, after Henderson sprained the same ankle during spring training last year, the Yankees kept saying he would be ready for opening day and he missed the first 10 games of the season.

title: Oil Exporters Issue Warning
description: Oil-exporting developing countries have warned poorer nations that the sharp drop in oil prices will severely cut into the money available for development aid, monetary sources said.

title: MEMBER OF RIGHTS PANEL ASSAILS CHAIRMAN AND ASKS HIM TO QUIT
description: A member of the United States Commission on Civil Rights, John H. Bunzel, called today for the commission's chairman, Clarence M. Pendleton Jr., to resign.

title: Fed Expected to Ease Policy
description: Weaker-than-expected employment statistics published Friday helped revive speculation in the credit markets that the Federal Reserve Board may ease monetary policy another notch and help reduce short-term interest rates.

title: CURREN WINS IN ATLANTA
description: Kevin Curren served 11 aces and won two tie-breakers today to defeat Tim Wilkison, 7-6, 7-6, in the final of the $279,000 W.C.T.-Atlanta Championships for his first tournament title in almost 14 months.

title: TOMORROW'S STARS ARE HERE TODAY
description: BECAUSE of the timing of their arrival in the major leagues and the abundance of their talent, Don Mattingly and Dwight Gooden will forever be linked in New York baseball specifically and baseball generally. The baseball world, particularly New York's share of it, will watch eagerly this season to see if Mattingly and Gooden can link their teams in the World Series for the first time. Mattingly, in the past two seasons, has won the American League batting title, has led the major leagues in runs batted in and has won the A.L. most valuable player award. Gooden, in the same time, has won 41 games and the National League Cy Young award and has become the standard by which other pitchers, virtually all of them older than the 21-year-old master of the mound, are rated.

title: SECT MEMBERS ARRAIGNED IN CHILD ABUSE CASE
description: Seven members of a religious sect in Jamaica, Queens, were arraigned last night in Queens Criminal Court after their arrest early Saturday on charges that they beat children and forced them to beg for money.

title: Presidents Set N.C.A.A. Agenda
description: The Presidents' Commission of the National Collegiate Athletic Association has agreed to explore the questions of freshman eligibility, length of seasons, reduction of athletic costs and the question of what a grant-in-aid should cover.

title: A NEW PATH FOR ANDRE OLIVER
description: When a store closes, it's usually a sad occasion, the end of a dream. But the quiet closing of the Andre Oliver men's wear store on East 57th Street recently was a dream come true for the designer and his partner, Danny Zarem. What the two have wanted since they opened for business in 1977 was to license the name of Andre Oliver for men's wear.

title: DR. BROWNSTEIN IS BRIDE OF DR. TED R. FRIEDMAN
description: Dr. Meryl-Ann Brownstein, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Daniel Brownstein of Astoria, Queens, was married yesterday to Dr. Ted Richard Friedman, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Arthur Friedman of Whitestone, Queens.

title: FIRE PRECEDED MEXICAN CRASH
description: Examination of the wreckage of the Mexican jetliner that crashed a week ago shows that the Boeing 727 caught fire in flight, sources close to the inquiry said yesterday.

title: United Technologies Reviewing Accounts
description: The United Technologies Corporation, based in Hartford, has just begun a review of its own that will lead to a consolidation of agencies for both the corporation and its operating subsidiaries.

title: Mainland's Deposits Moved
description: Officials of the Federal Home Loan Bank Board spent the weekend transferring the insured deposits of the Mainland Savings Association of Houston, which it closed Friday in what was apparently the largest failure ever of a thrift institution.

title: 2 SOUTH AFRICAN PAPERS QUOTE WINNIE MANDELA
description: Winnie Mandela was quoted today in the South African press for the first time in 11 years.

title: PURCHASING AGENTS OPTIMISTIC
description: The economy grew in March at a moderate pace, according to the National Association of Purchasing Management.

title: HOW THEY DO IT: LESSONS FROM SIX EXPERTS
description: The play's the thing. And as the new baseball season approached, Joseph Durso of The New York Times asked five players and one coach to describe the type of execution that makes them experts. Here is how they do it. DALE MURPHY SETS UP THE PITCHER

title: HOW TO ASSIST MOSCOW IN AFRICA
description: In sending Stinger missiles and other arms to Unita, the Angolan insurgent movement, President Reagan would be joining South Africa in a broad offensive against virtually all its neighbors. Advocates of the policy argue that American military involvement in an African civil war raises the cost to the Soviet Union of supporting leftist regimes like that in Angola. In fact, such involvement would create openings for Moscow while helping lay waste to the region.

title: NEGOTIATORS TRY TO END IMPASSE ON A CENTRAL AMERICA TREATY
description: Latin American officials met for a second day Sunday in an effort to end an impasse in negotiations on a regional peace treaty for Central America. The talks continued unexpectedly into the early morning hours with no decisions anticipated until later today.

title: DEVILS END SEASON WITH 9-7 VICTORY
description: The Devils and the Islanders approached the last game of the regular season in contrasting ways and it resulted in an open and entertaining game.

title: DANCE: HARLEM TROUPE IN 'FALL RIVER LEGEND'
description: ON Saturday at City College's Aaron Davis Hall, the Dance Theater of Harlem offered two mostly different casts in Agnes de Mille's ''Fall River Legend'' - a classic, as the Dance Theater production makes us realize, of American narrative ballet. The results were fascinating.

title: New Baytree Bid Rejected
description: The board of directors of Carson Pirie Scott & Company, the Chicago-based retailer, today rejected a sweetened acquisition bid made by Baytree Investors.

title: DANCE: KAYE AND ECCENTRIC MOTIONS
description: POOH KAYE calls her company Eccentric Motions, which was also the appropriate name of her first dance on Saturday night at St. Mark's Church. Miss Kaye creates choreographic nonsense reminiscent of both the whimsicality of Edward Lear in the 19th century and the anarchistic prankishness of Spike Jones in our own time.

title: POLICE KIN, BARE SKIN, BINGO SIN?
description: Police Chief Penny Harrington of Portland, Ore., has ordered an investigation of her husband, a patrolman.

title: U.S. Wins Curling
description: Steve Brown and his United States rink took advantage of mistakes by the Swedish veteran Stefan Hasselborg in the first four ends today to steal 6 points on the way to a 7-2 victory in the bronze-medal game at the men's world curling championship. Brown, from Madison, Wis., took full advantage of the uncharacteristic play of Hasselborg to steal a point in the first, third and fourth ends, and 3 points in the second before the Swedes finally scored.

title: NICARAGUA AT TOP OF LIST FOR RETURN OF CONGRESS TOMORROW
description: When Congress returns to Capitol Hill from its Easter recess on Tuesday, legislators are likely to adopt a compromise that allocates some military aid to the guerrillas trying to oust the Sandinista Government in Nicaragua. The real fight will be over whether Congress directs President Reagan to negotiate seriously with the Sandinistas before the money is released.

title: Winter Without Palms
description: Before desert palms come to lower Manhattan's Wintergarden, another winter will have elapsed, contrary to original plans.

title: CHESS PRODIGY, 9, BEATS 7 ADULTS IN TOURNEY
description: The three chess-playing Polgar sisters from Hungary are doing well in the New York Open at the Hotel Penta. But it is 9-year-old Judith who is tearing her section apart.

title: TRUCE QUIETS FIGHTING AT BEIRUT REFUGEE AREAS
description: A cease-fire took effect today at the Sabra and Shatila refugee districts, ending 10 days of battles between Palestinian guerrillas and Shiite Moslems in which at least 46 people died.

title: APPLE TO ELIMINATE 600 OF ITS DEALERS
description: Apple Computer Inc. is cutting off 600 dealers, a move that will reduce the number of stores authorized to carry Apple products in the United States by about 23 percent.

title: TRIAL BEGINS TODAY FOR POLICEMEN ACCUSED OF USING STUN GUN ON PRISONERS IN QUEENS
description: A year ago this month, Mark Davidson, then a high school senior, was arrested on a street near his home in South Ozone Park, Queens, on charges of selling $10 worth of marijuana to an undercover police officer.

title: NOT SO QUIET, PLEASE
description: Everybody is patting George Shultz on the back for his call for a return to ''quiet and direct'' diplomacy.

title: ILLINOIS CHEMICAL PLANT BURNS
description: Fire engulfed a chemical plant today, send-ing clouds of toxic smoke into the air and forcing the evacuation of 2,000 residents within a half-mile radius, the police said.

title: IRANIANS ATTACK A SAUDI TANKER
description: Two Iranian helicopters firing rockets attacked a Saudi Arabian oil tanker in the Persian Gulf, setting it ablaze and seriously wounding six sailors, marine salvage executives said today.

title: MEDICARE PAYMENT DELAYS IMPERIL HEALTH CARE
description: To the Editor:

title: LINDA NEWMAN WEDS NEIL GOLDSTEIN, LAWYER
description: Linda J. Newman and Neil S. Goldstein were married yesterday at Congregation Baith Israel Anshei Emes in Brooklyn. Rabbi Jonathan Ginsburg officiated.

title: BISHOPS MAY VETO MERGER OF LUTHERANS
description: Bishops from one of three Lutheran denominations that had agreed to merge into a 5.3 million-member group now say they may not.

title: SENATORS ASSERT CITY'S SCANDALS HURT AID PLANS
description: New York City's corruption scandal is tarnishing the city's reputation in Washington and could embolden members of Congress who are seeking to eliminate various urban aid programs, Senators Daniel Patrick Moynihan and Alfonse M. D'Amato said yesterday.

title: DISTANCE SWIMMER BACK IN TRAINING
description: For such 1984 Olympic gold medalists as Matt Biondi of California and Pablo Morales of Stanford, the National Collegiate Athletic Association swimming championships, which ended here Saturday night, were a bonanza. Each won three titles and broke an American record.

title: A TAXI BILL OF RIGHTS
description: The first thing I saw on entering the taxi was a large sign, ''No Smoking.'' The second thing was the driver lighting up.

title: Steel Curbs Questioned
description: The chairman of the United States Steel Corporation said that President Reagan's steel import restraints had been effective even though the five-year program was behind in reaching its goal after more than a year.

title: Wage Floor In Argentina
description: Under the pressure of frequent labor strikes and continuing inflation, the Government of President Raul Alfonsin announced Friday that it would permit wages and salaries to rise 18 percent to 25 percent during the remainder of 1986.

title: Roy Rogers Headed Off At the 5th Ave Pass
description: It was Roy Rogers versus the esthetes. Possibly because the polite showdown occurred on a fashionable stretch of Fifth Avenue, the esthetes won.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: MONDAY, APRIL 7, 1986
description: International

title: A.M.C. Plans to Lay Off 750
description: The American Motors Corporation will lay off 750 hourly workers at its Jeep assembly plant in Toledo, Ohio, in the American auto industry's second large employee cutback in a week, a spokesman said tonight.

title: WHOSE PLAN FOR MIDEAST?
description: Israeli and American officials were reported last week to be urging a ''Marshall Plan'' for the Middle East to induce the region's antagonists to make peace, but a writer says it was a flamboyant Saudi Arabian businessman who first proposed the idea three years ago.

title: METS ANGER JOHNSON WITH THEIR CARELESS PLAY
description: The Mets ended Florida spring training in a bit of a shambles today when Rafael Santana bruised his left thumb, Dwight Gooden was fined for misleading the manager about an automobile accident and the team lost its fourth straight game.

title: CHICAGO STRUGGLING TO KEEP ITS TEAMS
description: Late last week, as his grounds crew hurried to ready baseball's oldest active stadium for Monday's season opener against the Milwaukee Brewers, Jerry Reinsdorf, the chairman of the board of the Chicago White Sox, wondered where his ball club would be playing on future opening days.

title: PROTESTANT GROUP RAIDED AFTER ATTACKS ON POLICE
description: The police raided the headquarters of the main Protestant paramilitary group before dawn today after extremists burned or stoned the homes of 16 police officers and six Roman Catholics, officials said.

title: D'Arcy-Wiltshire
description: D'Arcy Masius Benton & Bowles/ New York has become the ad agency for Wiltshire Internatonal, which is planning to introduce its self-sharpening cutlery in North America. It will spend $5 million in the fourth quarter alone. Wiltshire is a subsidiary of McPherson's in Australia.

title: NEW MANAGERS
description: Chuck Tanner/ATLANTA He's new with the Braves, but he has the longest continuous major league service of any manager, having managed the Chicago White Sox from late September 1970 through 1975, the Oakland A's in 1976 and the Pittsburgh Pirates from 1977 through 1985. His '79 Pirates won the World Series. The highest-paid manager with a $500,000-a-year contract, the 56-year-old Tanner is considered the biggest optimist in baseball. Hal Lanier/HOUSTON A major league infielder for 10 years, he is one of four new managers who never managed in the majors. Lanier, 43, managed in the minors for four seasons, then served as a coach with the St. Louis Cardinals for the last five seasons, the last two as third-base coach. The Astros hired him to instill a more aggressive style of play in the team that is not known for power. Lanier is the son of Max Lanier, former major league pitcher. Jim Leyland/PITTSBURGH A candidate for several major league managerial jobs before getting the Pirates' assignment, Leyland has the most difficult task of all the new managers. He brings to the job 11 years of minor league managing experience in the Detroit organization and, most recently, a four-year term as third-base coach of the Chicago White Sox. Leyland, 41, was a minor league catcher but never made it past the Class AA level. Steve Boros/SAN DIEGO The Padres, who named Boros manager after Dick Williams suddenly resigned in February, have the only manager who was an English literature major in college.

title:
SPORTS WORLD SPECIALS;
Discovering Talent
description: As many as 100 scouts and executives from the National Basketball Association, minor leagues and European leagues converged on Portsmouth, Va., last week for the 34th annual Portsmouth Invitational Tournament, in which 64 college seniors try to impress the pros while competing in an eight-team, four-day elimination format at a local high school.

title: HAWKINS INTERRUPTING SENATE RACE FOR OPERATION
description: Senator Paula Hawkins will undergo surgery Tuesday to relieve chronic back and neck pain. The surgery will interrupt her re-election campaign, already marked by questions about her health.

title: OCCIDENTAL PETROLEUM IS COMPLYING WITH U.S. LIBYAN SANCTIONS
description: To the Editor:

title: YESHIVA U. AT 100: TIMELESS VALUES
description: The two young Yeshiva University scholars sat across from each other at a long table piled with large volumes of the Talmud, chanting a text to each other, elucidating, persuading, their hands rising and falling in a ballet of argumentation.

title: PRISON MURDER TRIAL STARTING
description: Opening arguments are to begin Monday in the trial of a lawyer charged with two counts of murder and one count of conspiracy in a San Quentin prison shooting in 1971 that left George Jackson and five other people dead.

title: Amputee Boxer Scores Knockout
description: Craig Bodzianowski, who has an artifical right leg, stopped Ric Enis at 1:46 of the third round of their scheduled eight-round cruiserweight bout today.

title: Book Assails Reaganomics
description: David Stockman, the former White House budget director who left his post last summer to join Salomon Brothers, the investment bankers, called President Reagan a ''terminal optimist'' in his new book ''The Triumph of Politics,'' U.S. News & World Report said in its April 14 issue.

title: WAGES, DISCIPLINE GIVE KOREA AN EDGE
description: In a factory the size of an airplane hangar, beyond lines of workers bending over huge machines, stands a solitary assembly line with no workers - operated by a room full of computers that program the manufacture of engine cylinder blocks. It is the Daewoo Corporation's first fully automated assembly line, part of its effort to keep manufacturing costs low.

title: MARIA HARRIS WED TO GABRIEL MORAN
description: Maria Harris, the Howard Professor of Religious Education at Andover Newton Theological School in Newton Centre, Mass., was married yesterday to Gabriel Moran, director of the graduate program for religious education at New York University. Msgr. Frederick F. Schaefer performed the ceremony at the chapel of the Catholic Center of N.Y.U.

title: Kurnit to Establish Consulting Concern
description: Shepard Kurnit, at age 61, is going out on his own as a consultant.

title: Market Place; Mixed Views On U.S. Steel
description: SHARES of the United States Steel Corporation traded Friday at 20 7/8, their lowest price since early 1983, reflecting the once-mighty steel giant's transformation into a company now heavily dependent upon the fortunes of the oil and gas business.

title: LINCOLN BRIGADE VETERANS ASSEMBLE
description: It was half a century ago that the Spanish Civil War began, a bitter curtain raiser for World War II that drew some 3,000 American volunteers into the fighting on the side of Spain's democratically elected Government.

title: Catching Up
description: When Milwaukee opens its season against the Chicago White Sox today, only one of the Brewers injured in the explosion at the team's spring-training clubhouse Feb. 27 will be missing from his usual post.

title: ONE CUP IS NEVER ENOUGH
description: IN hockey, the possibility of parlaying one Stanley Cup championship into several - a dynasty - beckons like a siren; winning once is simply not enough.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: MONDAY, APRIL 7, 1986
description: International Falling petroleum prices were discussed by Vice President Bush at a meeting in Saudi Arabia. He said he was not seeking oil production controls from Saudi Arabia but that the falling prices could reach a point where they threaten the security of the United States. He spoke at a meeting of the American Businessmen's Group in Riyadh and then went on to Dhahran, for an official meeting with King Fahd and that was to be followed by a business meeting. He is also scheduled to visit Bahrain, Oman and North Yemen on an eight-day visit to the Middle East. [ Page A1, Column 6. ]

title: LONG ERVING SHOT BEATS CELTICS, 95-94
description: Julius Erving made a desperation off-balance 3-point field goal as time expired today to give the Philadelphia 76ers a 95-94 victory that ended the Boston Celtics' 14-game winning streak.

title: EDWARD O. SULLIVAN Jr
description: Edward O. Sullivan Jr., a Westchester real-estate agent and insurance broker who was active in the county's Republican Party, died Wednesday at Lincoln Hospital in the Bronx after a heart attack. He was 60 years old and lived in Mount Kisco, N.Y.

title: FLYERS BEAT CAPITALS, 5-3, TO FINISH FIRST
description: Brian Propp scored three goals tonight to lead the Philadelphia Flyers to a 5-3 victory over the Washington Capitals that clinched the Patrick Division championship.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: Catalogue Advertising At American Express
description: Next fall, for the first time, the American Express Christmas catalogue will carry advertising - six pages at $67,500 a page.

title: U.S. GROUP ARRIVES FOR MANILA TALKS
description: Secretary of Defense Caspar W. Weinberger arrived here today for the highest-level meetings yet held between the United States and the new Government of President Corazon C. Aquino.

title: DUMB ECONOMIES FOR EXPOSED DIPLOMATS
description: Secretary of State Shultz has been stalking Capitol Hill like an ancient mariner, begging a fair hearing for a doleful story: ''Mr. Chairman, the Department of State does not have weapons systems to stretch out. We do not have programs we can transfer to state or local governments. We cannot 'privatize' our diplomatic activities . . . The massive cuts under consideration by the House Budget Committee would ravage this country's international presence and seriously harm our national security.'' He has a powerful case.

title: GOINT OUT GUIDE
description: TIGHT STRINGS The classical guitarist Andres Segovia will take to the concert hall tonight, but he will pluck no strings, make no mellifluous sounds. The maestro, along with Alicia de Larrocha and Alice Artz will be only listening. Avidly. They will be judging three finalists in the competition for the Andres Segovia Fellowship in Classical Guitar and Lute. The three have survived a winnowing process that began with the playing of tapes from the world over.

title: 'LET THERE BE LIGHT,' ISRAELI PROTEST INSISTS
description: Many Israelis observed a daylight saving time schedule today after the Minister of Interior, Yitzhak Peretz, refused to proclaim it officially.

title: After Merger, 2 White Units
description: White Consolidated Industries, the Cleveland-based appliance maker, will be reorganized into two operational units following its takeover by Electrolux A.B., the Swedish appliance company said yesterday.

title: Ammirati Gets Cruise Account
description: The Norwegian Caribbean Lines, looking for a proper berth for its $10 million to $15 million advertising account, has chosen the facilities at Ammirati & Puris (which also handles advertising for BMW).

title: THE U.N. TODAY: April 7, 1986
description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY Human Rights Committee - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: STATE CORRECTION COMMISSION CALLED LAX BY A REVIEW PANEL
description: The State Commission of Correction has failed to deal with major inadequacies in the 400 prisons, jails and police lockups it oversees, a legislative review panel asserted in a report issued today.

title: Iran-Zimbabwe Oil Plan
description: Iran is discussing building an oil refinery in Zimbabwe that would use Iranian oil as feedstock, Iran's national news agency, Irna, reported today. Zimbabwe's Foreign Minister, Witness Mangwende, here on a visit, said the extent of Iranian participation had not yet been decided, but if the project went ahead it would be mostly financed by Zimbabwe and would process Iranian oil.

title: COMPUTER LIKES METS, DODGERS, YANKEES, ROYALS
description: THE way the computer sees it, the Dodgers are a strong choice and the Yankees are the narrowest of favorites, with the Mets and the Royals somewhere in between, clear but not overwhelming picks.

title: U.S. AGAIN SEEKING TO INDUCE ALLIES TO ACT ON LIBYA
description: In the aftermath of the two terrorist bombings in Europe last week, the United States will press its European allies again to take political and economic actions against Libya, a senior Reagan Administration official said today.

title: Grey Wins Jonathan Logan Job
description: GREY Advertising has won the competition for the Jonathan Logan account, which means it will be doing advertising for all of the apparel and accessory items from the seven operating divisions as well as image advertising for Jonathan Logan itself.

title: CANCELED DINNERS, STUCK DOORS AND OTHER NOTES
description: The prime news last week among the White House staff and the reporters accompanying them here was the latest outbreaks of terrorism.

title: Martha Warner Is Dead at 98
description: Martha Stuart Budd Warner, mother of Senator John W. Warner, Republican of Virginia, died of a stroke in a Washington nursing home Friday and will be buried Monday at Arlington Cemetery, the Senator's office said. Mrs. Warner, who was 98, campaigned with her son in his 1978 and 1984 Senate races. Besides the Senator, she is survived by her son Charles, of Washington; a brother, George Budd of Philadelphia and three grandchildren.

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL CINCINNATI (NL) - Placed Pete Rose, first baseman-manager, on 15-day disabled list.

title: Washington Watch; Economic Activity by States
description: The Commerce Department is at an advanced stage in its efforts to calculate aggregate economic activity on a state-by-state basis. Its Bureau of Economic Analysis expects to publish by the end of next year figures on gross state products for 1982, thereby catching up to the latest census data on which the numbers are based.

title: SOUND-AND-LIGHT SHOW ON A SCALE FIT FOR HOUSTON
description: Barbara McGlory stood by her parked car in the middle of a Houston freeway, her 3-month-old niece in her arms and a beatific look on her face as she watched the Houston skyline transformed into a welter of light Saturday night.

title: WHAT TO NEGOTIATE
description: To the Editor:

title: FAHD SAID TO DENY CAUSING OIL CHAOS IN TALKS WITH BUSH
description: King Fahd of Saudi Arabia met with Vice President Bush into the early morning today and indicated that his country has ''been given a bum rap'' for chaos in oil markets, according to a senior American official.

title: CHEMICALS THAT CAUSE MUTATIONS IN BACTERIA FOUND IN SOME FOODS
description: Tests of common cooked foods have shown that many contain traces of chemicals that cause mutations in bacteria, according to a new study, and the researchers found that the amounts of these mutagens increased as food was cooked longer and at hotter temperatures.

title: Dollar Higher In Realignment
description: The United States dollar opened higher against West European currencies today after realignment of the European Monetary System, dealers said.

title: DENKINGER: CELEBRITY ARRIVED IN A SPLIT SECOND
description: AS the jet headed upward and New York began to look smaller and smaller, the man sitting in first class was nearing the end of what had not been an enjoyable day on the job. This was nearly 15 years ago, when Vida Blue was baseball's hottest attraction and the Oakland A's had drawn more than 50,000 people to Yankee Stadium on a summer afternoon. ''And we had a little problem at second base,'' Don Denkinger said.

title: ROSA PONSELLE'S VILLA TO BE SOLD
description: An era will come to an end for opera this year when the Rosa Ponselle Foundation sells Villa Pace, the mansion outside Baltimore from which one of the Metropolitan's greatest divas watched over the fortunes of her proteges and the Baltimore Opera during her 44-year retirement. The foundation, to which Ponselle bequeathed her estate upon her death in 1981, has operated Villa Pace as a museum for four years. But according to its president, Elayne Duke, the endowment income of the estate was being spent mostly on maintenance and staffing of the villa and its 40-acre grounds, with relatively little left over for the scholarships and competitions that carried on the soprano's own work with younger singers.

title: MARY CANNAMELA WED TO BRIAN J. NICHOLSON
description: Mary Claire Cannamela, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Vincent J. Cannamela of Metuchen, N.J., was married yesterday to Brian Joseph Nicholson, a son of Mrs. John G. Nicholson of Ocean, N.J., and the late Mr. Nicholson. The Rev. William Reilly and Msgr.

title: AUTHORITIES IN WEST REPORT SEIZING BIG COCAINE SUPPLY
description: The police and Federal agents seized 1,700 pounds of cocaine three days after a raid netted up to 2,400 pounds of the drug in Tijuana, Mexico, the authorities said Saturday.

title: James P. Bacon Dies at 46; Manager of San Diego's Zoo
description: James P. Bacon Jr., general manager of the San Diego Zoo and an authority on reptiles and amphibians, died Friday after returning from a morning run. He was 46 years old.

title: Young Uck Kim, Violin, Performs 'Kreutzer'
description: When Young Uck Kim played the violin at the 92d Street Y on Saturday night, all roughness or rudeness became unimaginable. Mr. Kim pursued grace of phrase and bloom of sound with unremitting ardor - the famous beginning of Beethoven's ''Kreutzer'' Sonata became a study in elegance, and everything that followed a model of symmetry.

title: SATURN'S UNCERTAIN FUTURE
description: Owen F. Bieber, the president of the United Automobile Workers union, calls it ''one last stab at retaining small-car production in the United States.'' Yet, as the General Motors Corporation prepares to dedicate the site for its Saturn Corporation plant in Spring Hill, Tenn., on Tuesday, questions are being raised within the industry about the outlook for the new organization.

title: Account
description: Virgin Holidays, a tour operator, to Korey, Kay & Partners.

title: Bridge: A National Event for Those Who Are Not Top-Ranked
description: Opportunities for players who are rising in the tournament world but not yet able to challenge top-ranked experts have multiplied in recent years.

title: FELLOW COMPUTER BUFF IS ARRESTED
description: A 15-year-old Queens youth was slain Friday in his bedroom, and last night a 15-year-old friend was arrested and charged in the killing, the police said.

title: RELIEF FOR CRIMINAL COURT
description: The chaotic condition of New York City's Criminal Court cheapens justice for thousands each year. The remedy has long been obvious: more judges.

title: QUEENS BOROUGH PRESIDENT TO SEEK RESIGNATIONS OF 35
description: Queens Borough President Claire Shulman said yesterday that she would ask today for the resignations of about 35 key members of the borough government staff as a step toward ''increasing excellence at Borough Hall'' and allowing her to ''have a free hand'' in office.

title: CRENSHAW SPEAKS UP FOR MASTERS TRADITION
description: FOR Ben Crenshaw the Masters represents something special and not just because it was the last tournament he won. ''I'm one of those people who believes in traditions,'' Crenshaw said, ''and everybody knows it.'' The 34-year-old Texan, winner of the 1984 Masters, then provided his definition of the tradition-laden event that begins on Thursday: ''It's not a festival or celebration of golf as some think, but it has a certain statement to make about golf that pervades the whole week. This was first made by the two founding members, Bobby Jones and Cliff Roberts. It was a simple statement that they had a club and a great golf course for playing golf and the rest of the membership of Augusta National did not want to tamper with the game in any shape or fashion. They would not tamper with the true spirit of the game as it is. So the Masters statement is that here is something for the game in its true form and spirit.''

title: YOUTH TAKES COMMAND: DARRYL STAWBERRY
description: HIGH in the grandstand, three rows fromthe back, the scout for the Los Angeles Dodgers sits among the paying customers for one afternoon in spring training and watches Darryl Strawberry take his hacks.

title: BIG CHUNKS OF SHUTTLE RECOVERED
description: A salvage vessel returned to port today with a large, jagged piece of the shuttle Challenger's right wing and a chunk of the fuselage emblazoned with an American flag.

title: YOUTH TAKES COMMAND: DAVE RIGHETTI
description: As the curtain goes up on the baseball season, there they are: Today's most recognizable young stars excelling at bat and on the mound and in the field, and everybody shouting their names. But to win, the contending teams know that certain other stars must supply an added dimension, the extra ingredient to carry their teams to the WorldSeries. The Cincinnati Reds, on the rise with Pete Rose, need Mario Soto to rebound from his only losing season.The Detroit Tigers need Kirk Gibson to blossom and to forget that he spent the winter trying to become a free agent but heard no calls. The Mets need Darryl Strawberry to fulfill his potential as a power player (Page C11). Last year, he was injured for seven weeks, and they had a losing record in that time. And the Yankees need virtuoso performances from Dave Righetti (Page C11), the no-hit pitcher who was converted to the stopper of the bullpen. Here are several who must provide the extra ingredent:

title: Bartlett Robinson Dead at 73; Radio Voice of Perry Mason
description: Bartlett (Bart) Robinson, an actor who played Perry Mason on radio, died March 26 at a Fallbrook retirement home. He was 73 years old.

title: POLICE KILL GUNMAN AFTER HOSTAGE IS SLAIN
description: A gunman who held his former wife hostage in a convenience store here for 48 hours was shot to death by police officers who raided the building tonight after he killed her, the authorities said.

title: Testing Plan Is Disclosed
description: Commissioner Peter Ueberroth's drug-testing program for major leaguers has been distributed to the players. Under the program no player would be tested no more than four times a year between March and October.

title: 'MY TWO LOVES,' ABC MOVIE AT 9
description: TELEVISION has generally been uneasy about lesbians.

title: YOUTH TAKES COMMAND: KIRK GIBSON
description: As the curtain goes up on the baseball season, there they are: Today's most recognizable young stars excelling at bat and on the mound and in the field, and everybody shouting their names. But to win, the contending teams know that certain other stars must supply an added dimension, the extra ingredient to carry their teams to the WorldSeries. The Cincinnati Reds, on the rise with Pete Rose, need Mario Soto to rebound from his only losing season.The Detroit Tigers need Kirk Gibson to blossom and to forget that he spent the winter trying to become a free agent but heard no calls. The Mets need Darryl Strawberry to fulfill his potential as a power player (Page C11). Last year, he was injured for seven weeks, and they had a losing record in that time. And the Yankees need virtuoso performances from Dave Righetti (Page C11), the no-hit pithcer who was converted to the stopper of the bullpen. Here are several who must provide the extra ingredent:

title: Margaret Price Sings At Avery Fisher Hall
description: It would be foolish to undervalue the great virtues Margaret Price brings to the singing of lieder. They begin with her hall-filling soprano sound, and extend to excitingly clean attacks, pinpoint definition of pitch, steadiness of tone and really outstanding German diction.

title: YOUTH TAKES COMMAND: MARIO SOTO
description: As the curtain goes up on the baseball season, there they are: Today's most recognizable young stars excelling at bat and on the mound and in the field, and everybody shouting their names. But to win, the contending teams know that certain other stars must supply an added dimension, the extra ingredient to carry their teams to the WorldSeries. The Cincinnati Reds, on the rise with Pete Rose, need Mario Soto to rebound from his only losing season. The Detroit Tigers need Kirk Gibson to blossom and to forget that he spent the winter trying to become a free agent but heard no calls. The Mets need Darryl Strawberry to fulfill his potential as a power player (Page C11). Last year, he was injured for seven weeks, and they had a losing record in that time. And the Yankees need virtuoso performances from Dave Righetti (Page C11), the no-hit pitcher who was converted to the stopper of the bullpen. Here are several who must provide the extra ingredent:

title: STRIKE IDLES NORWAY OIL PRODUCTION
description: A strike by offshore workers stopped all Norwegian oil and gas production today, increasing the likelihood that world oil prices will rise at least temporarily.

title: EARTHQUAKE KILLS 7 IN PERUVIAN ANDES
description: An earthquake killed at least seven people, injured 35 and left 600 families homeless in this Andean region, officials said today. Two Inca sites and five colonial churches were also damaged.

title: SUSAN B. ON THE BUS
description: To the Editor:

title: RETURN TO THE PALACE
description: When the Helen Hayes Awards are given at a National Theater gala on April 28 to honor theatrical achievement in Washington, Miss Hayes will perform a scene from ''Victoria Regina,'' a play in which she starred in that same theater in 1935.

title: MONDAY SPORTS
description: Baseball Reds vs. Philadelphia Phillies, at Cincinnati, the traditional Opening Day game. The Dodgers open against the San Diego Padres at Los Angeles in the National League, and there are three games in the American League: the Tigers vs. the Boston Red Sox in Detroit, Orioles vs. the Cleveland Indians in Baltimore and the White Sox vs. the Milwaukee Brewers in Chicago.

title: DR. SUSAN MENDLEY WEDS IN WESTCHESTER CEREMONY
description: Dr. Susan Mendley and Dr. Jason Umans, residents in internal medicine at University of Chicago Hospitals and Clinics, were married yesterday at the Free Synagogue of Westchester in Mount Vernon, N.Y. Rabbi James H. Perman performed the ceremony.

title: A MARCOS MYSTERY SOLVED
description: A Philippine-owned passenger liner, which was thought to have been at sea with some of Ferdinand E. Marcos's wealth perhaps aboard, has been in Hong Kong for 14 months, according to Hong Kong officials.

title: LINER HIJACKED IN '85 RUNS ONTO SANDBANK
description: The Achille Lauro, the Italian cruise ship seized by Palestinian gunmen in October, ran aground off Alexandria today with about 600 passengers aboard, port officials said.

title: FRANCE DEVALUING FRANC IN PROGRAM TO BUOY EXPORTS
description: France won approval today to reduce the value of the franc and announced economic measures designed to break with the legacy of four years of Socialist rule.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: NUCLEAR ETHICS, by Joseph S. Nye Jr. 162 pages. Free Press/Macmillan. $14.95. THE main targets of Joseph S. Nye's ''Nuclear Ethics'' are people who purport to have the answers to the dilemmas of nuclear deterrence. He mistrusts the military strategists who see the hydrogen bomb as merely a variation on conventional weapons, but his heaviest attack is leveled at those he calls moral ''absolutists'' in the anti-nuclear camp.

title: Japan Pushing Imports
description: The Japanese Government said Friday that it would ask department stores and supermarkets nationwide to cut prices of imported goods so consumers can benefit from the yen's recent rapid rise against the dollar. Another aim is to promote sales of foreign merchandise, an official said.

title: BASEBALL MEANS BUSINESS
description: BASEBALL returns this afternoon with a no-frills motif comparable to some of the nonscale airlines. No more luggage checking, no more reserved seats, not even any more macadamia nuts.

title: Washington Watch; I.M.F. Group of 10 Meeting
description: The meeting of the G-10 group of countries that takes place tomorrow at the International Monetary Fund is expected to run considerably longer than usual, perhaps three hours instead of the traditional and often perfunctory one hour.

title: RANGERS TO FACE FLYERS
description: On Saturday, they made the playoffs.

title: IS PUBLIC TV BECOMING OVERLY COMMERCIAL?
description: Moments after the end of ''Lone Star,'' a program about Texas history broadcast on public-television station KERA-TV in Dallas, the chairman of the Texas American Bank in Dallas appeared to say a few words.

title: 17 Writers Honored By Academy-Institute
description: The American Academy and Institute of Arts and Letters has given its 1986 awards to 17 writers ''for work of distinction,'' it was announced by Alfred Kazin, chairman of the organization's literary awards committee.

title: MISS MILLHEISER WED TO DAVID BARNETT, COMPOSER
description: Wendy Millheiser, a daughter of Alma Millheiser of North Bellmore, L.I., and the late Melvin Millheiser, was married yesterday to David Barnett, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Eliott Barnett of Sands Point, L.I. The ceremony was performed at the Community Synagogue in Sands Point by Rabbis Martin Rosenberg and Bennett Hermann.

title: Commonwealth Names Chiefs in Revamping
description: The Commonwealth Financial Group, the nation's sixth-largest mortgage banking organization, has reorganized its businesses into five operational groups and named executives to head each of the units.

title: MANAGERS ON THE SPOT
description: DAVEY JOHNSON boldly expects the Mets to win while Lou Piniella knowingly expects what he calls ''big trouble'' if the Yankees don't. As the baseball season opens, each of New York's two managers understands the different spot he is on.

title: Outdoors: Natural for Fish to Bite
description: WHILE it's apparent that what rouses the angling spirit come spring is more emotional than biological, the fact that the fish oblige eager anglers by schooling inshore, or rising from the mud of river and bay bottoms to come up to baited hooks, is most emphatically a result of biological demand. Fishermen are warm-blooded, fish are poikilothermal, their body temperatures change with that of the waters in which they swim.

title: An Olympic Policy
description: It may be a while before the United States Olympic Committee becomes a John Hancock subsidiary, but the big insurance company seems determined to write its name in oversize script across the face of American amateur athletics. Nobody is happier about it than the U.S.O.C. and the national governing bodies of the 38 Olympic sports.

title: MISS CASEY WEDS PAUL R. TUROVSKY
description: Monica Elizabeth Casey, an assistant treasurer of the Chase Manhattan Bank, and Paul R. Turovsky, a vice president of the Bankers Trust Company, were married yesterday in Manhattan. Judge Bruce M. Kaplan of the Family Court in New York officiated.

title: THE DANCE: PATRELLE AND GUEST STARS
description: FRANCIS PATRELLE assembled quite a cast for ''Dances . . . Patrelle,'' his program of choreography Friday night at the Theater of the Riverside Church.

title: U.S. SALES FOCUS IS ON SHORT TERM
description: Treasury financings this week are confined to the short-term market, with today's regular auctions of three-month and six-month bills to be followed Thursday by a one-year issue.

title: AMERICAN GREETINGS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
FOCUS OF SPYING TRIAL SHIFTS TO KEY WITNESS
description: As the espionage trial of Jerry A. Whitworth entered its third week here today, Federal prosecutors were shifting the focus of evidence from the defendant to the key Government witness, John A. Walker Jr. Mr. Walker has confessed that he headed a spy ring that sold information to the Soviet Union and to which Mr. Whitworth is accused of belonging.

title: BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: TAYLOR DEVICES reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
NOW, SOME SERIOUS HOCKEY
description: For more than six months, they grappled with one another. At times it seemed deadly serious. The Capitals wanted first place for the ''psychological edge''; the Flyers wanted first for the home advantage. Hartford wanted fourth to reach the playoffs for the first time since 1980; the Rangers wanted fourth to avoid missing the playoffs for the first time since 1980. The Islanders and Oilers sat back near the end while everyone else knocked heads. Whew! The regular season is over. After 80 games and all the struggles that eliminated only 5 of 21 teams, the National Hockey League finally begins its real season on Wednesday - the Stanley Cup playoffs. They will last seven weeks and will start with apparent mismatches like the Oilers against the Vanouver Canucks and the Flyers against the Rangers.

title: Reagan News Conference
description: President Reagan will hold a nationally broadcast news conference at 8 P.M. Wednesday, his first since Feb. 11, the White House announced today. The news conference, his 35th since taking office, will be held in the East Room.

title: Jury Chosen for Retrial Of Louisiana Governor
description: A jury was seated in Federal District Court today for the second trial of Gov. Edwin W. Edwards on charges that he schemed to use his influence to obtain state approval for hospital and nursing home projects in which he held interests.

title: A SPECIAL DEBUT FOR PINIELLA
description: Lou Piniella, who has had 12 opening days as a Yankee player and coach, receives his first taste of Opening Day as the Yankees' manager today. Ron Guidry, who will be pitching his seventh season-opening game, hopes to get his first taste of an opening day victory.

title: COMPUTER BUFF DENIES CHARGES IN BOY'S DEATH
description: A shaken, 15-year-old Queens boy charged with murdering a longtime friend and fellow computer buff in a fight over an $85 printer pleaded not guilty in Queens Criminal Court yesterday. His lawyer contended that the victim had started the fatal fight.

title: RESCUE EXPERT JOINS ALLENPARK THRIFT UNIT
description: At the end of his first day on a job he did not want, J. Tull Westmoreland, the acting president and chief executive of the Allenpark Federal Savings and Loan Association, was exuding the cautious optimism expected from a man whose primary job is to restore stability to a troubled financial institution.

title: A YOUTH SHOT BY GOETZ IS CONVICTED IN A RAPE
description: James Ramseur, one of four youths shot by Bernhard H. Goetz aboard a subway train, was convicted yesterday of taking part in the rape of an 18-year-old woman in the Bronx housing project where they both lived.

title: WEINBERGER GIVES A PLEDGE TO AQUINO ON AID
description: Secretary of Defense Caspar W. Weinberger met today with President Corazon C. Aquino and promised that the United States would emphasize economic aid over military assistance to the Philippines.

title: HOW TO MAKE THE MOST OF SCHOOL HOMEWORK
description: SOME years ago, during a Meet-the-Teacher evening at the school of one of our sons, I told his homeroom teacher I had only one complaint: too much homework. She stared at me in disbelief. All the other parents had asked for more homework. They probably considered a hefty workload a ticket to college.

title: CENTRAL BANCSHARES OF THE SOUTH INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
ART'S WAY MANUFACTURING CO reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 22
FOR SOVIET ANNIVERSARY, EXPLOITS ARE EXPECTED
description: The Soviet Union is expected to mark the 25th anniversary of manned flight in space Saturday with some new orbital achievements to call attention to steady Soviet progress while the American shuttles are grounded, according to American experts on the Soviet space program.

title: SWEET VICTORY reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: The year-earlier period began Feb. 24, 1984 to Dec. 31, 1984.

title: BARNETT IN DEAL FOR THRIFT UNIT
description: In an unusual move to increase its stake in the lucrative St. Petersburg area, Barnett Banks of Florida Inc. said it had signed a nonbinding agreement to acquire Home Federal Bank of Florida in a deal valued at about $155 million.

title: ONLY 2 REMAIN IN DIOXIN GHOST TOWN
description: An exit on Interstate 44 was once called ''Lewis Road-Times Beach.'' Now it reads merely ''Lewis Road.''

title: INTEREST RATES FINISH MIXED
description: Interest rates were mixed yesterday as long-term bond yields rose modestly while short-term rates were little changed.

title: New Tanning Aids May Raise Long-Term Risks, Data Show
description: Newer devices for skin tanning that emit what has been thought to be a safer type of ultraviolet radiation may be less likely to produce a bad sunburn than older machines, scientists said today, but they said cell culture tests indicate using the machines may also have adverse long-term effects.

title: LOTUS GIVES PRESIDENT CHIEF EXECUTIVE TITLE
description: The Lotus Development Corporation yesterday named Jim P. Manzi, its president, to the additional position of chief executive officer. He succeeds Mitchell D. Kapor, the company's 35-year-old founder, who will continue as chairman.

title: GOODYEAR HURT BY OIL SLUMP
description: The Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company said today that it might lose up to $70 million in the first quarter because of falling prices on its oil and gas reserves.

title: CHRYSLER PRICE RISE
description: The Chrysler Corporation said it had raised prices on its cars imported from Mitsubishi Motors of Japan by 3.9 percent, effective today. Chrysler attributed the higher price to the rise of the yen. The company said there were no changes in destination charges or dealer discounts.

title: STAGE: 'WASTED,' AT WPA THEATER
description: AS if to mark last weekend's sad anniversary of Martin Luther King's assassination, the WPA Theater is presenting a new play, ''Wasted,'' that takes us right back to that cataclysmic day in April 1968. The author, a first-time dramatist named Fred Gamel, portrays the response of a representative urban community as the unspeakable news from Memphis arrives by radio. His characters are black, white and Hispanic Americans of varied credos and prejudices -most of them poised to boil over into the violence that would soon set the cities of the nation aflame.

title: NOTES OFFERING BY SALLIE MAE
description: The Student Loan Marketing Association, known as Sallie Mae, is offering $300 million of floating-rate notes due Oct. 9, 1986, through various securities dealers.

title: INITIO INC reports earnings for Year to Feb 7
description: b-After net from discontinued operations of $79,000. c-Net loss after a loss from discontinued operations of $847,850.

title: Topics; Turned Off: Brakes, Teachers / Classroom Motivation
description: How to keep teachers from quitting? State legislators talk about more money for salaries. Educators emphasize that better working conditions and more respect are equally important.

title: BANPONCE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
GEOTEL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After income from discontinued operations of $854,277 for the quarter and $972,664 for the year. c-After income from discontinued operations of $102,082 for the quarter and $264,932 for the year.

title: STATE INVESTIGATES DUAL ROLE OF BRONX SENATOR IN PROJECTS
description: The State Attorney General announced an investigation today into whether a State Senator from the Bronx improperly withheld information about his financial stake in neighborhood development projects when applying for state funds.

title: Q&A
description: Q.

title: DATA DIMENSIONS INC reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: The results for 1985 and 1984 adjusted include the results of Software Builders Inc., which was acquired Nov. 30, 1985.

title: 'ALTERNATIVE SCHOOLS' REVIVED
description: Discouraged and disillusioned, Edith Casimir dropped out of high school in the 10th grade and moved to Manhattan, where she found a menial job in a bakery.

title: MEESE DELAYS HARVARD SPEECH
description: Attorney General Edwin Meese 3d has rescheduled an appearance at Harvard University that had provoked protests, a spokesman for the John F. Kennedy School of Government said today.

title: MURPHY INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
description: b-Includes losses from discontinued operations of $380,299 and $131,766 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively.

title: U.S. SUPREME COURT LETS STAND A RULING ON ATTORNEY'S FEES
description: An attempt to overturn a decision requiring a defense lawyer to testify about fees from a reputed Mafia member was rejected yesterday by the United States Supreme Court.

title: POTLATCH CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The company said first quarter earnings comparisons were affected negatively by an increase in stock appreciation rights expense of $1.8 million.

title: Article 783586 -- No Title
description: The Union Carbide Corporation, the giant chemical company pummeled by industrial accidents and a hostile takeover offer, yesterday announced a plan to sell off $1 billion in assets, including its 611-acre headquarters site in Danbury, Conn., and its intention to cut an additional 1,200 jobs.

title: LAIDLAW TRANSPORTATION LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
description: b-After special gains of $6,068,000 for the quarter and $11,091,000 for the 6 months. The company is also listed on the Toronto and Montreal stock exchanges.

title: SHELDAHL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
Nuclear Test Is About Politics, Not Science
description: To the Editor:

title: EFFECTS DEBATED
