description: A regional primary is now a reality for 1988, adding a major new element to Presidential politics.

title: HELD MANY POSITIONS AT YALE
description: George D. Vaill, a former associate secretary of Yale University and for many years its master of ceremonies, died of cancer Friday at his sister's home in Colebrook, Conn. He was 75 years old and lived in Bethany, Conn.

title: NEW THEORIES PIERCE MYSTERY OF EL NINO
description: FOR once, the forecast may be even more significant than the weather itself. Climate experts recently predicted that El Nino, the momentous shift in the winds and waters of the tropical Pacific that plays havoc with the weather on several continents, will strike this summer and fall, though not with the turmoil it inflicted three years ago.

title: FURNITURE MARKET SET
description: Despite a stable economy, furniture makers will not be straying from traditional big sellers such as bedroom suites and family room pieces when the Southern Furniture Market opens Thursday, an industry official said. ''These are not fat enough times to see the major manufacturers introducing new styles,'' said Rick Barentine, the executive director of the Furniture Factories Marketing Association of the South. About 1,500 domestic and foreign manufacturers will display their wares to retail dealers at the market.

title: Fuel Blast Kills Airman Along With 15 Koreans
description: A weekend explosion of a jet fuel tank at the Osan Air Base in South Korea killed 15 South Koreans and an American Air Force sergeant, the authorities said today.

title: EFFORT GROWS TO CREATE SENSITIVE DOCTORS
description: ''When they ask me, as of late they frequently do, how I have for so many years continued an equal interest in medicine and the poem, I reply that they amount for me to nearly the same thing.'' WILLIAM CARLOS WILLIAMS

title: WHEN A STOCK JOINS THE '500'
description: LAST Thursday, when the Dow Jones industrial average tumbled 28.86 points, the Lorimar-Telepictures Corporation was starring on the American Stock Exchange. In trading of more than 1 million shares as the Amex volume leader, Lorimar's stock hit a record price of 28 before closing at 26 1/2, up 1/2.

title: PRINCIPAL FIGURES IN TRIAL
description: Following are key figures in the Federal racketeering trial that involves men reputed to be members of the Gambino organized-crime family. Of the 10 original defendants, 2 are missing and 1, Aniello Dellacroce, is dead. Mr. Dellacroce, described as the underboss, or second in command, of the Gambino family, died last Dec. 2 of heart disease at the age of 71. Also missing is a key witness.

title: 22 TALL SHIPS ACCEPT BID TO LEAD PARADE ON JULY 4
description: Twenty-two of the world's tallest sailing ships have so far accepted the invitation to lead the parade of ships up the Hudson River on July 4 for the Statue of Liberty centennial.

title: Fact, Fiction And Politics
description: IT'S an old pitch, common to both political parties, and this time it comes over Bob Dole's signature. Fork over $1,000, the appeal says, and you too can join the Republican Senatorial Inner Circle.

title: AUDITORS RULE ON CONTROL DATA
description: The 1985 results of the Control Data Corporation received a qualified opinion from its auditor, Peat Marwick & Company, the company said in a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission.

title: GOODEN READY TO DO HIS PART
description: The difference, Dwight Gooden said as he stood on the threshold of his third season in the big leagues, is this: ''No one man has to carry this team now - including me.''

title: MECHANICAL TECHNOLOGY INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 29
VIDEO LIBRARY INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income

title: GRAHAM-MCCORMICK OIL & GAS PARTNERSHIP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income The company became a partnership Jan. 31, 1984 and therefore had 11 months results for that year. The per share earnings represent units.

title: AUSTRIA TO INSPECT FILE ON WALDHEIM
description: Austria asked the United Nations today for permission to examine a secret file on former Secretary General Kurt Waldheim, and the world body agreed.

title: PRESIDENTIAL PANEL URGES PENTAGON TO BUY ALL IT CAN READY-MADE
description: A Presidential commission urged the Pentagon today to make a fundamental change in its procurement, buying more ready-made items in the commercial market instead of having them made to order.

title: Public Housing for Staten Island's South Shore
description: To the Editor:

title: MAGAZINE AD SALES UP
description: In February, magazines belonging to the Magazine Publishers Association pulled in 21,513 pages of advertising, an improvement of four-tenths of 1 percent from the same month in 1985. Ad revenues for that month came to $383.6 million, up 1.9 percent.

title: Testing Blood For Blood
description: Last week's announcement by the United States Olympic Committee that all 38 national sports federations had agreed to participate in the committee's drug-testing program was an admitted publicity grab - the last of the federations had actually come on board months before - but it did serve to remind athletes of the U.S.O.C.'s step-up in substance-abuse enforcement as America heads for the 1988 Games in Calgary and Seoul. In the three years since United States efforts at the Pan American Games were marred by drug controversy, the U.S.O.C. has administered tests to some 3,000 athletes; the total this year alone is expected to exceed that.

title: Bassett Gains In Tourney
description: Carling Bassett, the only seeded player in action today in the Family Circle Magazine Cup women's tennis tournament, survived a first-round scare from Nathalie Herreman of France.

title: SASCHA GORODNITZKI, PIANIST, AND JUILLIARD FACULTY MEMBER
description: Sascha Gorodnitzki, a pianist and a teacher associated with the Juilliard School for more than half a century, died of cardiac arrest Friday at the New York Hospital-Cornell Medical Center. He was 81 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: CLUB MED reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
FILIPINO LOBBIES IN WASHINGTON FOR MORE AID
description: The Finance Minister of the Philippines vowed today that his nation would become ''one of the success stories of Southeast Asia'' but warned that American financial help was needed quickly.

title: ELLEN Z. McCLOY, 87, LEADER IN RELIEF EFFORTS IN GERMANY
description: Ellen Zinsser McCloy, who as the wife of the United States High Commissioner in Germany from 1949 to 1952 was active in relief and reorientation activities, died Sunday at Greenwich (Conn.) Hospital. She was 87 years old and lived in Stamford, Conn.

title: HUGE WINDMILL WITH ONE BLADE IS PLANNED
description: SANDIA National Laboratories have announced plans to build the largest windmill of its kind ever to be erected in the United States. It would be an experimental machine expected to achieve the greatest efficiency yet by application of new design principles.

title: IN FASHION, SOME PROMISING NEW TALENT
description: ''For the past two years, we feel we have been pushing a very heavy load up a very steep hill,'' Christian Knaust said. ''But now we have a feeling that it's finally happening, people are beginning to know we are here,'' said Kenth Andersson, his partner and codesigner in the company they call Christian Kenth.

title: A Lesson in Limits
description: When the United States Navy recently displayed its power against Libyan forces in the Gulf of Sidra, some were tempted to claim that only such shows of force could make people like Colonel Qaddafi call a halt to terrorist attacks.

title: DASA CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-Net loss

title: MERRILL, SHEARSON SHARE A SURPRISE
description: In an extraordinary about-face, Merrill Lynch & Company announced yesterday that Richard F. Morrison, an executive hired from Shearson Lehman Brothers less than a month ago to serve as its top technology officer, had changed his mind and would remain at Shearson Lehman.

title: SEWER BOND PLAN FROM CAPE MAY
description: The Cape May (N.J.) Municipal Utility Authority is tentatively offering $166 million of sewer refunding revenue bonds with a maximum yield of approximately 7.29 percent for a 7 1/4 percent bond due in 2016 through underwriters led by Prudential-Bache Securities.

title: BUSINESSLAND'S PRESIDENT QUITS
description: Ronald R. Watkins has resigned as president and chief operating officer of Businessland Inc., a retail computer store chain based in San Jose, Calif.

title: Once-Abused Alligator Dispatched to the Wild
description: An alligator that was rescued from an owner who had wired its jaw shut has been put on its way to freedom in the wild.

title: Safety Panel Urges Review of Jet Engines
description: Government safety experts recommended today that a special review board be established to investigate the maintenance program for Pratt & Whitney engines, the most widely used engines in commercial aviation.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: TUESDAY, APRIL 8, 1986
description: International

title: Who Gets Stung in Angola?
description: Though the war is still called covert, everybody knows that the United States intends to send Stinger missiles to rebels battling Angola's Marxist regime. Stingers are heat-seeking missiles said to cost $60,000 each. They weigh 35 pounds loaded, and enable a guerrilla to shoot down hostile aircraft. Two questions arise: How will thus arming Jonas Savimbi's Unita rebels advance America's interests in southern Africa? And has anyone considered the risks of supplying Stingers to irregular forces, not only in Angola but also Nicaragua?

title: GRUNTAL FINANCIAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
description: b-Net loss Share earnings are fully diluted.

title: JOCKEY INTERNATIONAL CAMPAIGN BY WARWICK
description: The thinking that won Warwick Advertising the Jockey International account will soon become apparent in print advertising in about 15 publications and on spot television in some dozen markets.

title: UNITED STATIONERS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
Pennsylvania Bell Offering at 8 3/4%
description: The Bell Telephone Company of Pennsylvania is offering $275 million of 8 3/4 percent debentures due 2026 at a price of par through underwriters led by Morgan Stanley & Company.

title:
NEW YORK DAY BY DAY;
STAKING OUT NEW TERRITORY
description: For years the Gray Line has taken visitors on New York City tours to places like Chinatown and Rockefeller Center. But until last week, its buses never journeyed beyond Manhattan.

title: Just as Rare
description: Julius Erving, who hit the game-winning 3-pointer at the buzzer for the 76ers Sunday, reflects on Larry Bird's missing two foul shots for the Celtics just seconds before: ''It was like watching the sun come up on the wrong side of the world.''

title: TENANT WINS RENT CASE BUT MAY LOSE HER HOME
description: In the Byzantine world of New York's rent-regulation laws, the saga of Rita Ebenhart is the stuff of which housing legends are made.

title: FILM: ARGENTINA 'TANGO'
description: IN ''La Hora de Los Hornos'' (The Hour of the Furnaces), made in 1968 but not released in this country until 1971, Fernando Solanas, the gifted Argentine film maker, presented his own, highly subjective interpretation of the legacy of Juan Domingo Peron.

title: PACIFIC SAID TO BE LURE FOR LLOYDS
description: With a $1.7 billion bid for Standard Chartered P.L.C. last Friday, Lloyds Bank P.L.C., Britain's fourth-largest bank, is trying to become a truly global enterprise with a strong network in the fast-growing Pacific Basin market.

title: Royals' Jackson Out
description: Danny Jackson, a 14-12 pitcher for the Kansas City Royals last season, was placed on the 15-day disabled list, retroactive to Friday with a possible bone chip in his left ankle. ''We don't think it's real serious, but we don't think he can pitch yet,'' said Manager Dick Howser.

title: ANITA C. MANSHEL
description: Anita Coleman Manshel, founding director of the Hansa Gallery in Manhattan, died Sunday at Lenox Hill Hospital, after having suffered a heart attack. She was 57 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: To Buy the Votes of the Elderly
description: Congress attached a cost-of-living bonus plan to Social Security in 1972 hoping to end the scramble for political advantage whenever inflation dictated an increase in benefits. The plan called for a raise whenever the Consumer Price Index rose 3 percent or more in any year. It now seems certain, for the first time since then, that the index won't rise 3 points. So what's afoot in Congress? A scramble to raise the benefits anyhow.

title: LAIDLAW INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
description: b-Includes an extraordinary gain of $4,344,000, or 25 cents a share.

title: Froese Voted Tops
description: As the Flyers were battling for first place in the Patrick Division, Bob Froese was the game-winning goalie for their final four games, which earned him the National Hockey League's final player-of-the-week award for the regular season.

title: Flamboyant Criminal Is Caught in India
description: A man sought for crimes in several countries who embarrassed Indian security officials by drugging his jailers and fleeing the country's maximum security prison last month was captured Sunday night at a bar in the southern resort area of Goa.

title: NATIONAL BANK OF ALASKA reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
TOMAHAWK INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
POLYMERIC RESOURCES CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Survey Says Most Americans Have Greater Expectations
description: Americans' economic expectations for the near future have improved sharply since the beginning of the year, according to the latest poll by the Gallup Organization.

title: A CITY'S WALLS ARE DEFACED WITH GRAFFITI
description: The walls of Swift Cleaners are dirty with graffiti - there are RON's and SPADE's and EDDIE DEE's in reds and blues and browns.

title: CABINET IN ISRAEL ENTERS NEW CRISIS
description: Israel's national unity Government was embroiled in another crisis today, with the Labor Prime Minister and the Likud Foreign Minister seemingly locked on a collision course.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''A reorientation toward the private sector doesn't offer a magic quick fix.

title: PACERS JOIN KNICKS IN DRAFT LOTTERY
description: The Knicks ended an eight-game losing streak last night against a team that had been a playoff contender. But the opponents - the Indiana Pacers - came into the game with an eight-game slide of their own, and it took a basket with three seconds left to win the game.

title: Topics; Turned Off: Brakes, Teachers / Dangerous Myth
description: Disconnect your front brakes, say drivers of big trucks, because when front wheels lock too abruptly they can make a truck jackknife. Besides, operating without the front brakes reduces maintenance and fuel costs.

title: THE NONPROFIT STAGE IS THRIVING BUT IN DEBT
description: For the third consecutive year, the nation's leading noncommercial theaters in 1985 earned more money, played to larger audiences - and yet fell deeper in debt. These findings, among others, emerge from the Theater Facts 85, the leading annual study of the financial state of America's noncommercial theater.

title: AMERIHEALTH INC reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
COMPACT DISK PLAYERS
description: HERE we go again, taking a giant step for hardware and one small step for software. Computers are about to acquire their own compact disk players.

title: HENDERSON ADVERTISING IS SOLD TO 8 EXECUTIVES
description: James M. Henderson, 65, has sold his Henderson Advertising in Greenville, S.C., to eight executives in the agency and has retired.

title: EUROPE'S TRADE POLICIES ARE TERMED DISRUPTIVE
description: A senior Reagan Administration official today called Europe ''probably the most disruptive factor in the world trading system,'' in what appeared to be a shift in the Administration's target of such concern away from Japan.

title: The Summit - a Crucial Time for Japan
description: Japan's heightened global role will occupy center stage in May when leaders of the seven industrial nations meet in Tokyo for the annual economic summit meeting. The site, fixed by rotation, symbolically provides a rare opportunity for Japan to exercise more assertive global economic leadership and for the United States to affirm Japan's new status by supportive domestic and international policies.

title: FRANCE'S DRIVE ON TERRORISM: THE ARREST OF A KEY SUSPECT
description: The French police appear to have scored a major success in their fight against terrorism in France with the arrest 10 days ago of leading members of Direct Action, a far-leftist group believed responsible for the killing of a French military officer last year.

title: I.B.M. INTRODUCES NEW PC SYSTEM
description: The International Business Machines Corporation introduced a new experimental personal computer system yesterday that transcribes sentences from human speech. I.B.M.'s latest version of the voice recognizer computer packs into a PC what 18 months ago filled the company's first prototype, a room-sized mainframe computer. The system transcribes sentences from a 5,000-word vocabulary and is 97 percent accurate, the company said.

title: Volunteers Begin Effort To Fingerprint Children
description: Volunteers began setting up stands in 2,800 shopping malls across the United States and Canada yesterday in a campaign to fingerprint 10 million children to protect them against abduction.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: TUESDAY, APRIL 8, 1986
description: Companies Union Carbide plans to sell $1 billion in assets, including its headquarters site in Danbury, Conn., and the chemical company will cut 1,200 more jobs. Carbide, which had previously put its consumer products business up for sale, also announced that Ralston Purina would buy its battery operations for $1.4 billion. Carbide intends to remain as a tenant in its Danbury building. [ Page D1. ] For Ralston Purina, the battery business represents a big jump from its present products - food for animals and people - but its leaders are confident the new line has great growth potential. [ D4. ]

title: CONSUMERS POWER
description: The Consumers Power Company of Jackson, Mich., said today, as expected, that it would convert its idled Midland nuclear plant to a natural gas-fired facility by 1990 if it could secure approval of the Michigan Public Service Commission and Federal officials. The conversion would cost an additional $500 million when complete. Work on the troubled Midland plant was suspended in July 1984 when the company was unable to finance completion of the project after investing more than $4 billion.

title: VIGILANTE ACTION-DRAMA IN NBC'S 'STINGRAY'
description: STEPHEN J. CANNELL has looked at ''Miami Vice,'' obviously, and believes he has seen the future. The producer of such ''hard-hitting'' shows as ''The A-Team'' and ''Hunter'' has now expanded his action domain on the NBC schedule with ''Stingray.'' All three programs are broadcast on Tuesdays, giving Mr. Cannell an unusual straight flush on prime time. Complete with Nick Mancuso as a dark-haired Don Johnson, ''Stingray,'' offered at 10 P.M., is awash in tight close-ups, jumpy editing and pop/ rock recordings, all employed in the service of standard sex 'n' violence. In the new television action formula, the style is the substance.

title: Allergy to Aspartame
description: It is almost inevitable that when a new substance comes into widespread use, some people have adverse reactions to it. Aspartame, marketed under the trade names of NutraSweet and Equal, has been blamed for such idiosyncratic reactions as depression, severe headache and epileptic seizures.

title: LIEBERMAN ENTERPRISES reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: FRANKLIN OF PHILADELPHIA. By Esmond Wright. Illustrated. 404 pages. Harvard University Press. $25. BENJAMIN FRANKLIN sat for his portrait more often than any of his American contemporaries, and fashioned an even more durable image of himself in his writings. He was a man who thoroughly understood the arts of publicity - in fact it rather serves him right, you feel, that in 1956 the Poor Richard Club of Philadelphia should have marked his 250th anniversary by issuing a pamphlet entitled ''Benjamin Franklin, Patron Saint of Advertising.''

title: Presidential Toss
description: President Reagan made a quick trip to Baltimore to help open the baseball season, firing a ceremonial toss to the catcher Rick Dempsey after his first throw went astray. ''You'd better get out of the way,'' the President said as he prepared to throw the second and third pitches at Memorial Stadium.

title: LATIN PEACE TALKS END IN WRANGLING
description: After three days of at times heated discussions, negotiations to find a settlement to the conflicts of Central America broke up here this afternoon in a cloud of recriminations without any formal agreements being reached.

title: Health Care in the New Medical-Enterprise Mills
description: To the Editor:

title: Federal Fugitive Arrested
description: A man wanted by the Federal Bureau of Investigation in the slaying of two men who were shot and set on fire in a robbery in Atlanta last year was arrested today. The man, Brian Malverty, 26 years old, was arrested without incident at his apartment here, the F.B.I. said.

title: The New Jersey Yankees?
description: With the sureness of spring's arrival, the baseball season has begun. But less certain is whether the ''House That Ruth Built'' - Yankee Stadium - will be the home of the Yankees when this season is over.

title: Status of Grizzlies Debated
description: Researchers are finding fewer and fewer grizzlies at Yellowstone National Park each year, but the giant bears are too unruly for the special protections of endangered species, a Federal wildlife official contends.

title: LETTER ON DRUG TESTS STIR IRE
description: The opening day of the baseball season brought with it a new dispute over drug testing involving the commissioner's office and the union representing major league players.

title: TELEBYTE TECHNOLOGY reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-Net income

title: BAYTREE TO PURSUE CARSON ACQUISITION
description: Baytree Investors Inc., a Chicago investment firm, said it would pursue its efforts to buy Carson Pirie Scott & Company even though the Chicago retailer rejected Baytree's sweetened $36-a-share bid on Sunday.

title: COMARCO INC reports earnings for Year to Jan 31
description: Results restated to reflect change to a Jan. 31 year and for the acquisition of a comapny accounted for as a pooling of interest. Share earnings adjusted for 3-for-2 split Jan. 6.

title: LOU PINIELLA'S DESK
description: No photos, paintings or plaques adorn the white and blue walls of his Yankee Stadium office yet, befitting a rookie manager awaiting his first Opening Day. But on Lou Piniella's desk a small furry brown teddy bear sits atop a book. The teddy bear has a small homemade ''14'' on it.

title: UNITED EDUCATION & SOFTARE reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-After tax credits of $119,000 for the quarter and $479,000 for the year. c-Net loss

title: DOW OFF BY 3.71 AFTER LATE RECOVERY
description: The correction that began last week on Wall Street continued yesterday, but the decline in stock prices was not nearly as steep despite another increase in the cost of crude oil.

title: TRANZONIC COMPANIES reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
Key Rates
description: * Municipal Bond Index, The Bond Buyer Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: BANK OF NEW HAMPSHIRE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
On Reading
description: When Seymour Martin Lipset was going through New York City's public schools, he was not considered very bright. In fact, he did not learn to read until he was in the third grade and was regularly tracked with the slow learners.

title: Transactions
description: SUNDAY BASEBALL CINCINNATI (NL) - Placed Pete Rose, first baseman-manager, on 15-day disabled list.

title: Health Care in the New Medical-Enterprise Mills
description: To the Editor:

title: PATENT BILLS SUBMITTED
description: The Reagan Administration, as expected, formally submitted a package of bills today intended to protect American holders of patents, copyrights and trademarks from foreign copiers.

title: BIG-TRUCK ACCIDENTS SPUR SAFETY EXPERTS' DEBATE
description: Reports of accidents and fatalities involving large trucks have risen sharply, setting off a debate among highway safety experts over whether deregulation of the trucking industry has made the roads more hazardous.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: A LITTLE WATER, PLEASE Venturesome New Yorkers love to explore ethnic restaurants, including those of China, India, Thailand and the Philippines. To somewhat chart the course of the kinds of food available, the New York Public Library is sponsoring a short series of Tuesday talks, ''The Spices of Life: Spices and Food of the Orient.'' The second lecture will be held today at 6 P.M. at the Mid-Manhattan Library, 455 Fifth Avenue, at 40th Street.

title: Testing in Tennis
description: Men's professional tennis now has its own drug-tester. He is Dr. Joseph A. Pursch, who will oversee mandatory testing of players under the aegis of the Men's International Professional Tennis Council, the governing body of men's tennis. According to the program, all main-draw singles players are subject to testing at any two of five tournaments - Wimbledon, the United States Open, the French Open, Australian Open and the Lipton International Players Championships.

title: PROTESTANT POLICE ARE NEW TARGET OF ULSTER LOYALISTS
description: Elizabeth Johnston, a reserve police officer in Northern Ireland, lives with her widowed mother near Shankill Road in the heart of Protestant West Belfast. They thought their home was as far as possible from the reach of the Irish Republican Army and as safe a place as any in which Miss Johnston could possibly be.

title: ENVOY TO MEXICO LEAVING FOR PRIVATE SECTOR
description: The United States Ambassador to Mexico, John Gavin, announced today that he was resigning next month ''to return to the private sector.''

title: A Job Exchange
description: Even as terrorism bids to become the leading international concern of the Reagan Administration, the State Department's point man on the subject, Robert B. Oakley, is switching to another job.

title: AMERICAN PACESETTER reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $342,000 for the quarter and $829,000 for the year. c-Net income d-After income from discontinued operations of $85,000 for the quarter and $427,000 for the year. The company is listed on the Pacific Stock Exchange.

title: ON ALERT AT THE CAIRO AIRPORT: AN ELABORATE SECURITY SCREEN
description: Perched on a balcony overlooking the cacophonous departure hall of Cairo International Airport, Khyrat Ali Sherby looks through the sight of his rifle, pointed at the entrance doors. From a distance of two football fields, individual faces swim into focus in the cross hairs of his sniperscope.

title: TRIAL STARTS FOR EX-ARMY OFFICIAL ACCUSED AS SPY
description: Federal prosecutors today portrayed a former Army counterintelligence agent, accused of spying for the Soviet Union, as a failed businessman who sold classified information to a Soviet official to help pay off his personal debts.

title: BOL'S CAREER HITS A HIGH NOTE OF SORTS
description: Since Manute Bol put a baskeball uniform over his 7-foot-7-inch, 190-pound frame and highlighted his stork-like legs and soda-straw body, he has attracted attention wherever he played. At the University of Bridgeport, where he played for one season, a rock group composed and sang ''Bolaphobia.'' Last summer, when he played for the Rhode Island Gulls of the United States Basketball League, his blocked shots were recorded on something called the ''Manute Block Board.''

title: CHEROKEE GROUP reports earnings for Qtr to March 1
INQUIRY AT VARIAN
description: Varian Associates Inc. said an internal investigation has shown that engineering hours may have been inaccurately reported in conjunction with the pricing of several Government purchase orders before late 1983.

title: PESACH BURNSTEIN, YIDDISH STAR, DIES
description: Pesach Burstein, a Yiddish actor whose singing, dancing and whistling delighted audiences here and abroad for more than 70 years, died Sunday at Lenox Hill Hospital after suffering a heart attack last Monday. Mr. Burstein was 89 years old and a resident of Manhattan and Tel Aviv.

title: PUBLISHER WITHDRAWS IN BOOK FAIR DISPUTE
description: Distressed that the Frankfurt Book Fair this fall is again scheduled during an important Jewish holiday, the Putnam Publishing Group, one of America's largest book publishers, has decided not to exhibit at the fair.

title: FLEXWATT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
6 DEATHS FROM 1971 INCIDENT EVOKED AT EX-RADICAL'S TRIAL
description: A prosecutor said today that he would use circumstantial evidence to prove that Stephen M. Bingham, a Yale-educated lawyer who embraced the radical movement of the 1960's, smuggled a gun into San Quentin Prison in 1971 and touched off a bloody series of events that left six people dead.

title: 7 IN CHORUS TO FILL IN FOR INJURED CHITA RIVERA
description: When Chita Rivera breaks her leg, it takes seven chorus girls to replace her.

title: CHAMPION WRESTLER FIGHTS BACK
description: The Olympic champion disliked the blight, as he put it, that had come over his sport. He had been considering ways to show the world that ''Mr. Hulk Hogan and Mr. Rowdy Roddy Piper and Mr. King Kong Bundy aren't wrestlers, they're entertainers.''

title: MEXICO ASKS DEBT AID
description: Finance Minister Jesus Silva Herzog of Mexico today called on industrial countries to share the benefits of falling oil prices with debtor countries that produce oil.

title: SOUTHWEST BANCORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After tax credits of $47,000 for the latest quarter and $89,000 for the year- earlier period.

title: GOLDEN ENTERPRISES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
BTR REALTY INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
TUESDAY SPORTS
description: Baseball Yankees vs. Kansas City Royals, at Yankee Stadium, 1 P.M. This is the season opener for the Yankees and the Royals, who begin the defense of their World Series championship.

title: Office Bombed in Stockholm
description: A bomb in a rucksack exploded tonight outside the office of Northwest Orient Airlines, shattering a window but causing no injuries, the police said. There was no immediate claim of responsibility. A police spokesman said security was tightened outside the United States Embassy and other American institutions and companies in Stockholm after the explosion at the American air carrier's office.

title: INTENSE H.M.O. RIVALRY SEEN
description: Health maintenance organizations, which provide medical care for a fixed prepaid fee, are the fastest-growing segment of a rapidly changing health care industry. It is estimated that in 1985 H.M.O.'s accounted for about $16 billion of the total health care market and that figure could more than triple by 1990.

title: 11 Injured After Plane Hits Air Turbulence
description: A Sabena Airlines jetliner bound here from Detroit with 78 people aboard dropped suddenly when it hit an air pocket today, slamming passengers and food trays into the cabin ceiling and injuring at least 11 passengers and a flight attendant, none seriously.

title: BURNHAM SERVICE CORPORATION reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Chess: Vienna I.B.M. Contest Won By Korchnoi and Belyavsky
description: Viktor Korchnoi of Switzerland and Aleksandr Belyavsky of the Soviet Union tied for first place in the Vienna I.B.M. International Tournament. They each scored 6 1/2-2 1/2 in the nine-round Swiss-system competition of 48 invited players, and each was awarded $3,100.

title: JURY SELECTION BEGINS FOR GOTTI TRIAL
description: Jury selection began yesterday in the Federal trial of John Gotti, the reputed head of the Gambino organized-crime family, and six others who are accused of taking part in a ''criminal enterprise'' involving loan-sharking, gambling, hijackings and at least three murders.

title: DISNEY'S DEAL WITH Y.&R. UNIT
description: GORDON WEAVER, president of the Young & Rubicam Entertainment division, and Stephen Rose, executive vice president, left New York yesterday afternoon for Orlando, Fla., for some meetings dealing with advertising for Walt Disney World's 15th anniversary.

title: FLORIDA CHALLENGED ON DETERMINING SANITY OF THE CONDEMNED
description: On the eve of his execution date in November 1984, Gary Alvord was interviewed by three psychiatrists who asked him about his understanding of of how and why he was to die in the electric chair.

title: 12 MONTHS OF TERROR: THE MIDEAST CONNECTION
description: Links between groups and countries made by American experts on terrorism. 1985 April 12, Madrid. Bomb explodes at restaurant outside city frequented by U.S. servicemen, killing 18 Spaniards and wounding 82 people, including 14 Americans. Claim: Islamic Holy War. Link: Syria and Iran.

title: NORWAY OILFIELD STRIKE LIFTS CRUDE ABOVE $14
description: A strike that shut down Norway's oilfields lifted the prices of crude oil yesterday to their highest levels in nearly six weeks. Prices in the world oil market were over $14 a barrel, up more than $1.50 from Friday's close.

title: CHILDHOOD DEATH: RESPIRATORY AILMENTS ARE NOW NO. 1 CAUSE
description: NEW surveys and medical data reveal that pneumonia and other respiratory infections are now the leading cause of death among infants and small children worldwide, killing perhaps 6.5 million each year.

title: NICARAGUA CHURCH DEFENDS ACTIONS
description: Nicaragua's 10 Roman Catholic bishops issued a statement today in which they replied sharply to recent Government attacks. They also criticized the pro-Sandinista ''People's Church'' in the strongest terms they have yet used.

title: SAKS AND SWISS BANK TO BUILD TOWER
description: A 36-story skyscraper combining an extension of Saks Fifth Avenue's flagship store with the United States headquarters of the Swiss Bank Corporation would rise directly behind Saks's landmark building under a proposal announced yesterday.

title: 'THE PAPER CURTAIN' ON CHANNEL 13
description: ''THE PAPER CURTAIN'' refutes, even if unintentionally, an argument that public-television documentary makers have raised for years: that a documentary cannot offer a point of view, or take a political position, if it practices balanced journalism. ''The Paper Curtain'' takes a political position: The McCarran-Walter Act must go. It also practices balanced journalism. The documentary, on Channel 13 at 11 o'clock tonight, is a splendid piece of work.

title: FIRST OAK BROOK BANCSHARES reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
FUR VAULT INC reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
SHAKEUP REPORTED FOR JUSTICE DEPT.
description: Attorney General Edwin Meese 3d is planning a shakeup of his senior staff and will nominate as his chief deputy Arnold I. Burns, a Manhattan lawyer who is the Associate Attorney General, Justice Department officials said today.

title: MUSTANG DRILLING & EXPLORAION reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss

title: Indelible Smile
description: As George Brett sat in the visitors' clubhouse yesterday, he noted that he'd had ''some great games'' at Yankee Stadium, where he and the Kansas City Royals will play today in the Yanks' season opener. Which was his fondest memory? ''The third game of the 1980 playoffs,'' he said without hesitation, alluding to the pennant-clinching three-run homer he hit against Rich Gossage.

title: AUTOCLAVE ENGINEERS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
description: b-Net income

title: U.S. NAVY WINNER IN VOTE IN JAPAN
description: The United States Navy gained a surprising victory today as voters in a waterfront city near Tokyo installed a local council led by supporters of a proposed housing complex for American sailors.

title: SPECIAL COUNSEL: TICKLISH ROLE
description: Over the past 15 years, companies have routinely turned to special outside counsel to help them investigate ticklish ethical or legal matters.

title: HEAD OF GEORGIA U., REGENTS IN TRUCE
description: After months of public trial and debate that have damaged the morale and standing of the University of Georgia, its outgoing president and the State Board of Regents struck a gentlemen's agreement today, declining to engage in their expected showdown over charges of favorable treatment given to student-athletes at the university.

title: NOTES ON FASHION
description: THERE is no rest for the weary fashion army, returned from its latest European campaign. Though just back from Paris, Sara Foley, an agent at Name Model Manaagement, said she wouldn't miss Bruce Weber's recent 40th birthday party at Atmospheres, a TriBeCa restaurant. Aficionados of fashion ads watched familiar faces from Mr. Weber's photos quaffing margaritas. And who shoots photos at a fashion lens's fete? Nothing came between Brooke Shields and her camera.

title: They Were Opposed To Queens Grand Prix
description: To the Editor:

title: AS 2d LANGUAGE, JAPANESE GAINS NEW POPULARITY
description: Brad Como and Terry Hochton stood in front of their seventh-grade class at Dawnwood Junior High School here, bantering in Japanese.

title: SECURITY GUARD AT JAVITS CENTER DISMISSED AMID REPORTS OF PAYOFFS
description: The head of the new Jacob K. Javits Convention Center said yesterday that one security guard had been dismissed and that others would be dismissed soon following complaints by exhibitors that they had to pay bribes to get cars and vans unloaded quickly.

title: New Optical Fibers
description: Navy researchers have developed an optical fiber so efficient in transmitting data that it could be used for transoceanic communications with few, if any, repeaters - midocean booster stations in ocean cables.

title: SPACE-PLANE CONTRACTS
description: The Defense Department said today that contracts worth almost $90 million had been awarded for development of the National Aerospace Plane, a craft intended to take off from a runway and accelerate to 18,000 miles per hour into a low orbit. Propulsion-system design contracts were given to Pratt & Whitney, for $28.5 million, and the General Electric Company, for $26 million. Airframe-design contracts of $7 million each went to Boeing, General Dynamics, Lockheed, McDonnell Douglas and Rockwell International.

title: JAPAN MOVES ON ECONOMY
description: The Japanese Government today announced a plan to invigorate the domestic economy by cutting some import prices, speeding up public works spending and promoting housing construction.

title: PIPE BOMB EXPLODES, SEVERELY INJURING MAN
description: A pipe bomb exploded in an apartment in the Crown Heights section of Brooklyn early this morning, severely injuring one man, the police said. The police evacuated the building when two additional pipe bombs were found in the apartment.

title: BROKEN HILL REJECTS BID
description: Robert Holmes a Court, the Australian investor, began another unsolicited bid for control of the Broken Hill Proprietary Company, Australia's largest company, valued at up to $1.45 billion.

title: VIRATEK INC reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
description: b-Net loss The company said the difference between the two sales figures represents the latest first quarter royalty payments received from the sale of Virazole by its SPI Pharmaceuticals Inc. subsidiary.

title: BRAZILIANS GROW IMPATIENT FOR THE PROMISED LAND
description: In the company of a half-dozen other blond, blue-eyed peasants, their bare feet caked with the red soil of this region, Sergio Schmidt sat in the shade of a lakeside camp and recounted his family's struggle to remain on the land.

title: PEOPLE
description: * James H. Miller has been appointed executive vice president of Frank J. Corbett Inc., Chicago.

title: LIBERAL ARTS JOBS IN HIGH TECH FIELDS
description: LIBERAL ARTS majors should consider careers with high-technology companies, according to Betsy Collard. A 1962 Stanford University graduate, she is director of employment services at the Resource Center for Women, which provides counseling for 15,000 men and women a year in the San Francisco area.

title: AIDE SAYS U.S. ERRED IN ALLOWING GENETIC TESTING
description: The Agriculture Department's chief science policy administrator said today that a division of the department erred last year when it approved the first field test of a living genetically-altered organism.

title: EXECUTIVES
description: * ARA Services Inc., Philadelphia, a management services organization, named James Ksansnak senior vice president and a member of the executive council.

title: SOCIAL WORKERS JUDGMENT FAULTED IN ABUSE CASE
description: Mayor Koch and city social-service officials said yesterday that child welfare workers had made ''an error in judgment'' by waiting two weeks before notifying the District Attorney of reports of child abuse by a Queens religious sect. But they said the workers had obeyed rules requiring immediate notification only in cases of sexual abuse.

title: DANCE: TORVILL AND DEAN, ICE SKATERS
description: IT doesn't matter what you call them. Jayne Torvill and Christopher Dean dance on skates, skate as they dance and more than excel both at dancing and skating. If you class them among the great performing artists on this planet, you simply don't have to worry about whether they are dancers or skaters.

title: International Center To Honor 3 at Dinner
description: A Nobel Prize-winning physicist, a museum director and an author will be honored at a dinner marking the 25th anniversary of the International Center in New York tonight at 6:30 at the Plaza Hotel.

title: Working Profile: Hyman Bookbinder; Of Lobbying And 'Precious Dimensions'
description: ''You really come to rely on the Hyman Bookbinders of this world with their institutional memories,'' said Anne Wexler, who was a senior assistant to President Carter for public liaison. ''I think many Administrations have relied on Bookie for counsel on a variety of issues. He's one of the best.'' Mrs. Wexler, now a lobbyist and public relations consultant, was talking about a familiar Washington figure. Mr. Bookbinder, 70 years old, is Washington representative of the American Jewish Committee. He has been working the capital for 35 years, and he will be honored for that work Thursday by members of Congress, Administration officials and others from the Washington establishment at a luncheon sponsored by the publication Washington Jewish Week.

title: CUOMO ASKS CURBS ON LIABILITY RISKS
description: Faced with rapidly rising liability-insurance rates throughout the state, Governor Cuomo today endorsed tighter controls on the insurance industry and changes in the way courts award money to people who have been injured.

title: U.S. URGED TO END AID TO BUSINESSES RUN BY MINORITIES
description: In a draft report, the United States Commission on Civil Rights calls for a one-year suspension of Federal programs that reserve money or contracts for businesses owned by blacks, Hispanic Americans or women.

title: Leading U.S. Economists in Brisk Debate
description: With large areas of the Southwest ailing because of falling oil prices, many respected economists are making what until recently might have seemed an outlandish argument: that the United States as a whole is worse off with very cheap oil.

title: Secretary of Air Force Planning to Quit Soon
description: The Secretary of the Air Force, Russell A. Rourke, plans to resign soon for personal reasons, Administration officials said today.

title: HEALTH IMAGES INC reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-After a loss from discontinued operations of $36,032 and a tax credit of $1,000.

title: 5 Convicted as Murderers Are Executed by Zimbabwe
description: Five convicted murderers, including two rebels who killed two Americans and four other foreign tourists in southern Zimbabwe in 1982, were hanged today.

title: FASHION VS. STYLE
description: Last night, at the Fashion Critics Awards dinner of the Parsons School of Design, Mayor Koch was honored with a miniature silver Parsons table for embodying ''the spirit and vitality of this city of which fashion is the largest industry.''

title: U.N. ARCHIVES: DETAILS 'WORD FOR WORD'
description: There are the handwritten notes of Secretary General U Thant from his Havana hotel room during the 1962 Cuban missile crisis, the secret investigation into the plane crash that killed Secretary General Dag Hammarskjold and the working papers, drafts and verbatim minutes of the San Francisco conference at which the United Nations Charter was drafted.

title: BUSH SEEKS TO END CONFUSION STIRRED BY OIL PRICE VIEWS
description: As Vice President Bush ended the first part of his four-nation tour of the Middle East today, he sought to end the confusion over his views on oil pricing.

title: INFINITE GRAPHICS reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
BASES OF PALESTINIANS IN LEBANON ARE AGAIN RAIDED BY ISRAELI JETS
description: Israeli planes attacked Palestinian guerrilla bases around Sidon in southern Lebanon today. It was the second such attack on the port city in 12 days.

title: Tracksters in Accord
description: Ninety-three percent of Britain's top track stars have agreed to random drug testing in Britain this season. The Olympic gold-medalists Steve Ovett, Daley Thompson, Sebastian Coe, Tessa Sanderson and Allan Wells have agreed to be tested, according to the British Amateur Athletics Board.

title: STOCK MARKET BID IN CHINA
description: Stock exchanges should be opened in four cities and a capital market created to finance China's economic growth, an analysis in the Communist Party newspaper People's Daily said today.

title: SOVIET SEEKS A LARGER ROLE IN SOUTHEAST ASIA
description: The Soviet Union, as it continues to build its military strength in Southeast Asia and the Pacific, is at the same time trying to increase its economic and diplomatic influence in the area, according to regional officials and diplomats.

title: BANK RELIEF BILL OPPOSED BY BAKER
description: Treasury Secretary James A. Baker 3d, in a letter addressed to the Senate majority leader, Bob Dole, and the Banking Committee chairman, Jake Garn, said the Administration opposes passage of an emergency relief bill for banks that lend heavily to farmers and oil and gas companies.

title: TEXAS BANKS WORRY ANALYSTS
description: Texas banks begin reporting first-quarter results this week, and Wall Street is steeling itself in anticipation.

title: U.S. AND SOVIET TO PAVE WAY TO SUMMIT
description: Secretary of State George P. Shultz and the Soviet Foreign Minister, Eduard A. Shevardnadze, will probably meet in Washington in the second half of May to prepare the way for a summit meeting that could be held in July, Reagan Administration officials said today.

title: COMPUTER NETWORK CORP reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: The company is in the development stage and reported no revenue.

title: Bridge: A Player From Manhattan Was Surprise in Nationals
description: Most of the players who did well in the recent Spring Nationals in Portland, Ore., had predictable results. All the winners of the major events had won titles before.

title: 3 ON T.W.A. JET REPORTEDLY DIED ON GROUND
description: Two American women and a baby were killed last week when they hit the ground, not by the bomb that blew them out of a Trans World Airlines jet, pathologists who examined the bodies said today.

title: REDS SET BACK CARLTON AND THE CLOCK IN OPENER
description: It was not yet 11 o'clock, but the crowds had already begun making their way down the streets that lead toward Riverfront Stadium. Inside, players were caught up in the rituals of the regular season, lazily chasing fly balls and taking batting practice. Outside, two young fans wearing Cincinnati Reds' caps peered anxiously through locked gates and waited.

title: STUDIES POINT TO POWER OF NONVERBAL SIGNALS
description: THE nonverbal messages people send, with a look, a gesture, a tone of voice, are far more pervasive and important in the workaday world than have been generally realized, researchers are finding. But they are concluding, too, that these messages are more complex and subtle than the popular accounts of ''body language'' that have appeared in recent years have indicated.

title: NEW SOFTWARE ABOUNDS FROM SMALL COMPANIES
description: THIS is the year of cute, handy little programs. Lotus is getting its act together and has announced that it expects to make no major new releases until 1987. The other superpower software companies such as Ashton-Tate, Borland International, Micropro International, Microsoft and Software Publishing have not publicly declared this to be a period of consolidation. Nevertheless, the writing is on the disk.

title: FLORIDA NATIONAL BANKS OF FLORIDA INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes a gain on the sale of a mortgage company of $38,413,000.

title: NEW CHINA TIES
description: More than 15,000 Chinese students now study in American universities, the highest number of foreign students from any nation, according to Han Xu, Chinese Ambassador to the United States.

title: A Path Across Manhattan
description: The most excruciating trips in Manhattan are east-west. Traversing the island's width in half an hour would set a record on the average weekday. With offices and hotels pushing toward the rivers, crosstown jams can become economically fatal. So once again City Hall offers a remedy and once again it is an effort to clear 49th and 50th Streets for buses and taxis. Despite opposition from some merchants and building owners, the effort deserves an extended test, including energetic enforcement.

title: Congress; Discipline? This Is Discipline?
description: Well, they've done it again.

title: Blacks Resume Boycott In South African City
description: Blacks resumed a consumer boycott in Port Elizabeth today that crippled white businesses in the industrial city on the Indian Ocean.

title: BROOKLYN GETS WALL ST. DATA GROUP
description: The company that operates the computer and communications systems for the New York and American Stock Exchanges will move its corporate headquarters from Wall Street to a new complex in downtown Brooklyn, Mayor Koch announced yesterday.

title: What Reagan Means by Military Investment
description: To the Editor:

title: RALSTON AIMING AT NEW AREA
description: The Ralston Purina Company, the pet food, breakfast cereal and tuna company based in St. Louis, is making a big jump into the battery business.

title: CORRECTION
description: A picture caption on the Style page yesterday with an article about the closing of the Andre Oliver men's wear store was published in error. The man shown was not Mr. Oliver; he was Peter Langsam, president of the Colonial Corporation of America, which manufactures and distributes sportswear bearing the Oliver label.

title: Questions About Waldheim
description: Four weeks ago, officials of the World Jewish Congress retained me as a paid concultant to do research on the wartime career of Kurt Waldheim, the former Secretary General of the United Nations. I flew to Washington to work in the collection of captured German records stored in the National Archives, and completed my assignment in 11 days.

title: HAMMERMILL PAPER CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 23
Police Kill Gunman After Hostage Is Slain
description: A gunman who held his former wife hostage in a convenience store here for 48 hours was shot to death by police officers who raided the building Sunday night after he killed her, the authorities said.

title: BUSINESS IS STILL BRISK IN MORTGAGE SECURITIES
description: Activity in the mortgage securities market continues brisk, as the record difference between the yield of mortgage pass-through securities and Treasury notes encourages securities dealers to package new issues of collateralized mortgage obligations.

title: OIL STATES SLASHING SERVICES AS PRICE PLUNGES
description: The collapse in the American oil industry from the sudden plunge of world oil prices is forcing drastic curtailment of government services throughout the energy-producing states. Teachers are being put out of work, and welfare, public health programs and police protection are being cut.

title: US HEALTH RESOURCES reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
TOTAL ASSETS PROTECTION INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss after a reversal of a tax loss carryforward of $82,469. c-Net income including a tax credit of $79,331. Revenue results represent contract revenue.

title: 2 Reagan Aides Said to Plan To Aid Kemp Presidential Bid
description: President Reagan's top speechwriter and another aide plan to resign to work for Representative Jack F. Kemp in a Presidential bid, a spokesman for the New York Republican said today.

title: Afghan Rebels Claim A 7th Enemy Plane
description: Moslem rebels said today that they had downed a seventh enemy plane as they slowly pushed back a Communist offensive on a major guerrilla base in eastern Afghanistan near the Pakistan border.

title: SONOCO PRODUCTS CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
A Name Exchange
description: The other day, Representative James H. Scheuer of Queens was on his way to his office to catch up with some desk work while the House was out of session, when he drove past the Tidal Basin and encountered the cherry trees in full spring mufti. So, naturally, he decided to catch up on his reading first.

title: The Benefits of Schizophrenia Research
description: To the Editor:

title: KODAK AND SONY IN 8-MM. VENTURES
description: The Eastman Kodak Company and the Sony Corporation of America yesterday announced plans to distribute motion pictures and other programs on 8-millimeter video cassettes, actions experts say will bolster the market for that product.

title: SINCLAIR RESEARCH SOLD
description: Sir Clive Sinclair, whose computer empire was once valued at $197 million, sold his company to a rival concern today for $7.3 million.

title: Dept. of Classification
description: In the bureaucratic world it is difficult to keep track of what is Secret, Confidential, Eyes Only, Need to Know or Cosmic Top.

title: WEST GERMANY STEPS UP WATCH ON LIBYANS AFTER BERLIN BOMBING
description: Security officials said today that they were stepping up surveillance of Libyans in West Germany as part of an effort to guard against new terrorist attacks.

title: PHILLIP B. THURSTON, EX-JUDGE IN POLICE AND FAMILY COURTS
description: Phillip B. Thurston, a retired judge who spent more than 30 years on the New York City Police and Family Courts, died last Thursday in Northern Westchester Hospital Center in Mount Kisco, N.Y. He was 77 years old and lived in Manhattan and Yorktown Heights, N.Y.

title: The U.N. Today: April 8, 1986
description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY Ad Hoc Committee on World Disarmament Conference - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: DEVILS ANTICIPATE CHANGES
description: Although they won six more games than ever before and equaled the franchise record for points, several changes await the Devils, one of the five teams that failed to make the National Hockey League playoffs.

title: 'INSIDE THE JURY ROOM'
description: IT is rare for a documentary film to be as suspenseful as a fine drama, where a writer can invent characters and juggle scenes, but no writer is required for tonight's unusual edition of public television's ''Frontline'' series. ''Inside the Jury Room'' (10 P.M., WNET/Channel 13) doesn't have to be dramatized. It already is.

title: CORRECTION
description: An Albany dispatch by United Press International on Friday about a Court of Appeals decision over rights to the story of the film ''Casablanca'' incorrectly quoted the plaintiffs' lawyer on the subject of movie contracts. The lawyer, Michael Zissu, said, ''It's a sad day for all the authors who entered into these blanket-type arrangements with the big motion-picture studios like Warner Brothers or 20th Century-Fox or M-G-M.''

title: MAYOR URGES VISITORS TO PITCH TENTS JULY 4
description: Mayor Koch has extended an invitation to the masses yearning to come free to the Statue of Liberty centennial the Fourth of July weekend.

title: COURT SAYS VIOLATING A RIGHT DOES NOT REQUIRE UPSET OF RULING
description: The Supreme Court ruled 7 to 2 today that violation of a defendant's constitutional right to cross-examine a prosecution witness fully does not automatically require reversal of the defendant's conviction.

title: TSENG LABORATORIES reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-Includes a tax credit of $23,500.

title: Lincoln Center Studio Dedicated to Dario Soria
description: The New York Public Library at Lincoln Center joined the Metropolitan Opera in honoring the late record producer Dario Soria yesterday at the formal dedication of the Soria Studio at the library.

title: U.S. AIDES THINK LIBYA WAS LINKED TO AT LEAST ONE BOMBING LAST WEEK
description: Reagan Administration officials said today that their general view was that at least one of the terrorist attacks in Europe last week was a Libyan response to American naval action in the Gulf of Sidra last month, and that the Administration anticipated more such attacks in the coming weeks.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Farm and Home Savings Association, Nevada, Mo., said it had signed a letter of intent with the Bass brothers and other investors to sell about 2.2 million newly issued common shares for $23.88 a share. The investors will own 24.9 percent of the fully diluted common shares.

title: REEBOK INTERNATIONAL LTD reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
WANG OFFICER RESIGNS
description: Wang Laboratories Inc. said yesterday that J. Carl Masi, executive vice president for sales and marketing, had resigned to pursue other interests. The computer company also announced the reorganization of its sales and marketing operations to increase the responsibility of three of its management teams: United States operations; Europe, Africa and Mideast operations, and Americas and Asia-Pacific operations.

title: RUSSIAN ASTRONAUTS ANSWER QUESTIONS FROM SPACECRAFT
description: Two Soviet astronauts orbiting the earth in the space station Mir answered reporters' questions today in a live closed-circuit television link with a mission control center on the outskirts of Moscow.

title: G.M. PROMOTES TECHNICAL AIDE
description: The General Motors Corporation said today that it had promoted Robert J. Eaton to vice president and group executive in charge of the Technical Staffs Group, effective May 1. He replaces Alex C. Mair, who is retiring.

title: PRESIDENT MEETS WITH SOVIET ENVOY ON SUMMIT PLANS
description: President Reagan and Anatoly F. Dobrynin, the departing Soviet Ambassador, agreed today to lay the groundwork for a United States-Soviet summit meeting in the United States this year.

title: Advertising; Pepsi's Humorous Approach
description: BECAUSE Philip B. Dusenberry has gotten to feel very close to the Coca-Cola Company over the years as the leading creative force at Batten, Barton, Durstine & Osborn, Pepsi-Cola's agency, he is particularly pleased that the agency has not overlooked the older soft drink company's 100th anniversary.

title: SENATOR HAWKINS HAS SIX HOURS OF SURGERY
description: Senator Paula Hawkins, Republican of Florida, underwent six hours of surgery today to relieve back pain caused by a 1982 accident.

title: INTERSTATE SHOPPING
description: To the Editor:

title: JETLINER DAMAGED IN LANDING
description: The left engine on a United Airlines jet burst into flame today after the left main landing gear collapsed as the plane landed at O'Hare International Airport, officials said. A spokesman for the airline said the 109 passengers and five crew members aboard Flight 732 from Omaha escaped on emergency chutes without serious injury.

title: Shakespeare Theater Cancels Productions
description: The management of the American Shakespeare Theater has canceled its planned 1986 summer production season, its first since bankruptcy proceedings in 1982, to complete the renovation of its 31-year-old building, officials said.

title: Advertising; D.D.B. Resigns Account At Brown & Williamson
description: Doyle Dane Bernbach officially resigned its Brown & Williamson Tobacco business yesterday and the tobacco people officially accepted it. However, according to other agencies working for B.& W., its agencies were notified last Friday of the company's plan to go from five agencies to two.

title: EASTWOOD IN A NEW ROLE: MR. MAYOR
description: Clint Eastwood, the Hollywood actor who became one of the world's biggest box ofice draws playing tough cowboys and revenge-minded policemen, today won a landslide victory as Mayor of this resort town of 4,700 people.

title: RAI RESEARCH CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
description: b-Includes income from discontinued operations of $15,598 for the quarter and a loss of $49,040 from discontinued operations for the 9 months. c-Includes losses from discontinued operations of $44,485 for the quarter and $86,397 for the 9 months, and a loss from a reversal of a DISC tax credit of $15,000 for the quarter and a gain of $252,000 from the reversal of DISC taxes for the 9 months.

title: E & B MARINE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes approximately $900,000 in interest expense incurred in connection with the acquisition of James Bliss & Co. and the purchase of stock from a former company chairman.

title: APOLOGY IS DEMANDED
description: Larry Holmes, the former heavyweight champion, must apologize publicly for comments he made about Nevada fight officials or risk not being licensed for his April 19 title fight against Michael Spinks, the head of the Nevada State Athletic Commission said yesterday. Sig Rogich, the chairman, said Holmes ''not only questioned the competency of our officials but the honesty and integrity of the commission as a whole'' in a television interview last week.

title: FIRST NATIONAL CINCINNATI CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
U.S. APPROVES BID FOR AN INDICTMENT AGAINST FRIEDMAN
description: The Justice Department has decided to let Federal prosecutors in Manhattan seek the indictment of Stanley M. Friedman, the Bronx Democratic leader, on racketeering charges stemming from his role representing contractors with the city's Parking Violations Bureau, according to lawyers familiar with the case.

title: INDIA IS REVISITED AT BLOOMINGDALE'S
description: ANYTHING worth doing is worth doing again, they say.

title: BOMB AT WEINBERGER HOTEL IN BANGKOK
description: A bomb exploded Tuesday evening at the entrance to a parking lot at the hotel where Defense Secretary Caspar W. Weinberger was scheduled to attend a state dinner with Thailand's Prime Minister.

title: Journal for Sale
description: The National Journal, the Washington-based weekly on politics and public affairs, is up for sale. Its principal owner, Anthony C. Stout, has assured its 40-odd employees that no interruption in publication is foreseen and that he will remain as chairman, but negotiations for the imminent transfer of ownership have caused some understandable nervousness on the staff.

title: ARLINGTON REALTY INVESTORS reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
Cannon Group and MCI Make High-Yield Offers
description: The Cannon Group Inc., a motion picture production and distribution company, and MCI Communications, in separate offerings, yesterday began what is expected to be a heavy week of financing in the high-yield, low-grade sector of the bond market.

title: GORDON JEWELRY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
PERES REAFFIRMS PLAN TO OUST AIDE
description: Prime Minister Shimon Peres today affirmed his intention to dismiss Finance Minister Yitzhak Modai, increasing the chances that Israel's coalition Government will soon collapse.

title: BIG MILITARY HIGH-TECH SALE TO CHINA
description: The Reagan Administration said today that it planned to sell $550 million worth of aviation electronics to China.

title: Kinder-Care Deal
description: Kinder-Care Learning Centers Inc. said it had agreed to acquire the Pioneer Western Corporation, a financial services company, from Kansas City Southern Industries for about $65 million.

title: LLOYD GAINS AFTER STRUGGLE
description: Chris Evert Lloyd survived a suprisingly strong challenge from Sylvia Hanika in the second round of the Family Circle Magazine Cup women's tennis tournament today.

title: FILMS TO GET STRICTER RATINGS
description: Films that depict or refer to the use of illegal drugs or that use sexually graphic language will be subject to stricter rating classifications, the Motion Picture Association of America and the National Association of Theater Owners said yesterday.

title: TYCO LABORATORIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
description: b-Includes a gain on the partial settlement of an insurance claim ammounting to $3.1 million, or 18 cents a share, for the quarter and 9 months. c-Includes an extraordinary gain of $2.3 million, or 14 cents a share, on the replacement of a pension plan. d-Includes a gain on the sale of non- operating assets of $500,000, or 3 cents a share. Share earnings have been adjusted for 2-for-1 stock split paid Feb. 28, 1986. The results include operations of ITT Grinnell Corp. as of Jan. 31, 1986.

title: HOW TO ESCAPE THE INSURANCE CRISIS
description: Along with oil and credit, American society runs on insurance. How to address the national crisis created by its sudden scarcity? (A) Crack down on the lawyers who manipulate juries to win outlandish settlements - and fat contingency fees. (B) Crack down on the insurance industry, which seems unable to manage its cash flows responsibly. (C) Try to teach the public that enormous liability judgments are not cost-free. (D) All of the above.

title: STRESS: FAILURE TO SEE CHOICES
description: MANY women often view the decisions they make as irreversible, and thus find themselves confronting stress that otherwise might have been avoided, according to an administrator at St. Luke's-Roosevelt Hospital Center.

title: HUSSEIN'S HAND SEEN IN ANTI-ARAFAT ACTIVITY
description: The former chief of intelligence in the Palestine Liberation Organization was reported today to be leading a movement in Jordan against Yasir Arafat.

title: CARRIER IS WITHDRAWN FROM LIBERTY CEREMONY
description: The aircraft carrier John F. Kennedy will not take part in the Statue of Liberty centennial festivities the weekend of July 4, the organizer of the event said last night.

title: HOTEL INVESTORS TRUST reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
description: b-After an extraordinary gain of $778,000 on the sale of a hotel for the quarter and 6 months.

title: Advertising; People
description: * William Kurth has been named senior vice president-creative of Doyle Graf Mabley.

title: CORRECTION
description: The cast listing with a theater review of ''Wasted'' yesterday gave an incorrect address for the WPA Theater. It is at 519 West 23d Street.

title: PLOT AGAINST AQUINO CHARGED
description: Officials charged with protecting President Corazon C. Aquino are investigating a robbery suspect's assertion that he was hired to assassinate her at an outdoor rally early last month but backed out at the last minute.

title: BINKS MANUFACTURING CO reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
REPUBLICBANK CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
CBS INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After a loss from discontinued operations of $9.7 million.

title: FOOD NOTES
description: Gloom Food The gloom ratings are out. Open-ended like the Richter scale, they are said to be a measure of how disastrous fast foods may be for the diet.

title: CBS DRAMATIZES KILLING OF A BLACK BY THE POLICE
description: TONIGHT at 9 o'clock on CBS, ''A Case of Deadly Force'' goes to Boston for a dramatization of one of the more explosive incidents ever to hit that city. In 1975, a 25-year-old black man named James Bowden was killed by two white officers of the city's Tactical Patrol Force, a plainclothes police unit. The officers said Mr. Bowden had been a robbery suspect and had threatened them with a gun. Three department investigations backed their stories. But the widowed Mrs. Bowden, insisting her husband was not a criminal, would not accept the story. After scouring Boston for a lawyer willing to confront the Police Department, she found Lawrence O'Donnell Sr. The case would not get to court until 1980 and would not be fully resolved until 1984.

title: Rep. Fish Seeks 10th Term
description: Representative Hamilton Fish Jr., Republican from Millbrook, announced today that he would seek his tenth term in Congress.

title: CENTRAL AMERICA: ACCORD IS STILL REMOTE
description: A negotiated settlement of the conflicts in Central America seems more distant than ever in the aftermath of the latest failure of the so-called Contadora peace process, according to several Latin American delegates who attended the talks here.

title: U.S. TO REQUEST ACCESS TO U.N. FILE ON WALDHEIM
description: A senior Reagan Adminstration official said today that the United States would formally ask the United Nations in ''the next few days'' for the secret file kept by the United Nations War Crimes Commission on former Secretary General Kurt Waldheim.

title: FOR LARGE PEOPLE, LIFE CAN BE TAXING
description: EVER since way back when, there has been consistent tax discrimination against large people. It costs large people more to live, yet they are paid no more for their work and taxed no less. Why does it cost more? For one thing, they eat more.

title: A SCOURGE'S RESURGENCE
description: The barriers that protect the public from infectious disease are strong but need constant tending. An effective vaccine, and a vigorous immunization campaign, have almost eradicated measles as an indigenous disease in America. Yet in Jersey City, the worst outbreak of measles in several years has already infected more than 400 children. Did public health authorities let down their guard? Was the Federal goal of eradicating measles by 1982 absurdly ambitious?

title: An Alliance Is Slain Over Gun Control
description: On Capitol Hill, where friendship sometimes endures only until the next Congressional vote, they were unusually close allies for many years.

title: REAGAN PARLEY TONIGHT AT 8
description: President Reagan's news conference tonight will be broadcast live at 8 P.M. on the ABC, CBS and NBC television networks, and on CNN, the Cable News Network.

title: MODERATE LEVEL OF EXERCISE BRINGS LIFE-SAVING BENEFITS
description: MANY people were pleasantly surprised by a recent finding that demanding exercise routines are not needed to reap the life-saving benefits of physical activity. Apparently you don't have to run marathons or even minimarathons to be fit. According to the new study of 17,000 Harvard alumni, a brisk three-mile ''daily constitutional'' should do the trick.

title: FACTORY BECOMING AN OFFICE BUILDING ON EAST 21st ST.
description: A HANDFUL of the city's bolder advertising agencies have been credited with discovering a few years ago the abundant space and cheap rents in the old loft buildings that line lower Fifth Avenue and Broadway.

title: CBS PROFIT DECLINES IN QUARTER
description: Smarting from a high debt burden and lower advertising revenues, CBS Inc. said yesterday that earnings from continuing operations fell 38 percent in the first quarter. Its net income was off 3 percent.

title: Virginia Housing Mortgage Bonds
description: The Virginia Housing Development Authority is offering $93.7 million of residential mortgage bonds with a maximum yield of 7.55 percent for an issue due in 2012 through underwriters led by the First Boston Corporation.

title: BACK TO THE YANKS
description: Scott Patterson, a minor league Yankee pitcher who was claimed by the Texas Rangers in the December draft of unprotected players, has been returned to the Yankee organization after failing to make the Rangers' 24-man roster. The Yankees, who had been paid a $50,000 draft price when Patterson was plucked from the Columbus roster, agreed to take Patterson back for $25,000, as specified by the terms of the draft. . . . Ronnie Giddens, a Montreal infielder, and Ben Abner, a minor league outfielder, were sent to the Pittsburgh Pirates to complete the trade in which the Expos got Jason Thompson, a first baseman, from the Pirates last week.

title: CROMPTON & KNOWLES CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Nuts for Sale
description: The National Conservative Political Action Committee announced this year that it planned to spend $250,000 to defeat the Senate bid of Representative Timothy E. Wirth, Democrat of Colorado. Supporters of the Congressman hope to turn this opposition to their advantage, initially tomorrow evening with a ''Nuts to NCPAC'' reception at the National Press Club.

title: WARNACO INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 29
description: b-After an extraordinary charge of $3,750,000 consisting of the after-tax cost incurred by Warnaco in connection with the proposed recapitalization.

title: Benefit Auction
description: More than 80 items by artisans from New York State will be on sale at a benefit auction tomorrow at 6:30 P.M. at Steuben Glass, Fifth Avenue and 56th Street.

title: Bank Rejects Offer by Lloyds
description: Standard Chartered P.L.C. said its directors had formally rejected a $1.7 billion acquisition offer from Lloyds Bank P.L.C.

title: Economic Scene; Quiet Shapers Of History
description: TRADITIONAL history is preoccupied with kings, generals and presidents, sometimes even with vice presidents. Indeed, Vice President Bush made some sort of history this week by journeying to the Middle East to meet with King Fahd of Saudi Arabia to discuss - what? The Vice President first said he would discuss the need for greater stability of oil prices but wound up saying, according to his press spokesmen, that he discussed the commitment of the Reagan Administration to a free market in oil and everything else.

title: CONCERT: E.A.R. UNIT
description: COMPOSERS' FORUM, a New York-based organization celebrating its 50th year, brought some West Coast friends to town Saturday night, when the California E.A.R. Unit played a concert of contemporary works at the Cathedral of St. John the Divine.

title: NIGHTSPOTS OFFER FOODS THAT SIZZLE
description: TWO sizzling nightspots in town -Sugar Reef and Bayamo - are among the restaurants that serve that tropical smorgasbord collectively known as Caribbean food. Both offer island specialties such as barbecued shrimp wrapped in banana leaves, conch fritters and peppery jerk chicken. A third restaurant, the palmy West Village spot called Caribe, offers everything from Jamaican-style curried goat to Barbados codfish stew with tomatoes and onions.

title: U.S. APPROVAL NEAR FOR RADIATION USE ON FRESH FOODS
description: The head of the Food and Drug Administration said today that the agency would shortly approve the use of irradiation to preserve fresh fruits and vegetables.

title: MISTRIAL FOR REPUTED MOBSTER
description: A Federal district judge declared a mistrial today in the racketeering trial of a reputed mobster, Anthony Spilotro, and eight other defendants after reports that a bribe might have been offered to a juror.

title: LIBYAN SAYS THE U.S. KILLED 56 IN SIDRA FIGHT
description: Libya's top military commander was quoted by a weekly Egyptian newspaper today as saying American missiles killed 56 people in the Gulf of Sidra fighting.

title: BALLET: JOFFREY PRESENTS 'TAMING OF THE SHREW'
description: ''THE TAMING OF THE SHREW,'' John Cranko's balletic adaptation of Shakespeare's comedy, contains two acts and lasts just over two hours. It might be funnier if it had only one act and lasted just under an hour. Though he has devised some real choreographic jokes, Mr. Cranko stretches them so thin that a ballet that should be chock-full of chuckles seems a protracted wheeze.

title: RETRIAL FOR FRAUD OPENS FOR LOUISIANA GOVERNOR
description: A Federal prosecutor today made his opening statement in his second attempt to convict Gov. Edwin Edwards on charges of racketeering and fraud.

title: BOMB SCARE FORCES JET INTO EMERGENCY LANDING
description: An Eastern Airlines 727 jetliner, bound from New York's La Guardia Airport to Atlanta with 112 passengers, made an emergency landing in Philadelphia today after an Egyptian passenger said he had a bomb in his briefcase, the authorities said.

title: N.B.A. FINES BRAWLERS
description: The National Basketball Association fined Sedale Threatt of the Philadelphia 76ers $2,000 and Danny Ainge of the Boston Celtics $1,000 for their roles in a fight during Sunday's game in Philadedelphia. Six others, including Matt Guokas, the 76ers' coach, each drew $500 fines.

title: Market Place; Nuclear Plants: New Options
description: THIS week, the Consumers Power Company, Michigan's largest utility, proposed to convert part of its mothballed Midland nuclear power plant to a gas-fired facility. That is the latest of several recent developments that could lessen the troubles of utilities with nuclear plants.

title: CLOSE AS CAN BE
description: The race for the National Basketball Association's scoring title may well turn out to be the closest in the league's 40-year history. Yesterday, with three games left for each of the top three scorers, only 14-hundredths of a point per game separated No. 1 from No. 3. Dominique Wilkins of Atlanta led with 29.84, followed by Adrian Dantley of Utah (29.78) and Alex English of Denver (29.70).

title: THE NEW REAGAN DOCTRINE RESTS ON MISPLACED OPTIMISM
description: The President's message to Congress last month titled ''Freedom, Regional Security and Global Peace'' was a statement of major significance - the Reagan Administration's considered response to the problem of how to deal with the challenge of Soviet power in the third world. Gradually taking shape in the course of the past year, this response has become known as the Reagan Doctrine. It is a policy of ambitious ends and modest means, a policy that is ultimately dependent on a tendentious reading of the current tides of history.

title: GORBACHEV SAYS SOVIET PUTS NO CONDITIONS ON MEETING
description: Mikhail S. Gorbachev said today that he set no conditions for a second summit meeting with President Reagan, but that he wanted the talks to produce ''practical results.''

title: SARA FREDERICKS 83, RETAILER OF DESIGNER CLOTHES, IS DEAD
description: Sara Fredericks, a retailer who specialized in high-priced fashion for more than 50 years, died Tuesday at St. Mary's Hospital in Palm Beach, Fla. She was 83 years old. Miss Fredericks lived in Palm Beach, where her shop on Worth Avenue was the hub of a chain that included stores in the Copley Place shopping center in Boston, on Park Avenue in New York and in Fort Lauderdale and Sarasota, Fla. She was planning to open a shop in Short Hills, N.J., next fall.

title: GOTTI PROSECUTOR SAYS WITNESS WAS APPROACHED
