description: The prosecutor in the Federal racketeering trial of the reputed crime boss John Gotti told the court yesterday that one of the Government's prospective witnesses had been approached twice within a week by two men and that these encounters represented ''a threat to the witness.''

title: NEWS SUMMARY: WEDNESDAY, APRIL 9, 1986
description: International Expulsion of Libyan diplomats from West Germany and some other key allies was urged by the United States because of evidence linking Libya to last weekend's bombing of a discotheque in West Berlin that was frequented by American soldiers. Reagan Administration officials said Washington was supplying Bonn and other European countries with what one official called ''absolutely convincing evidence'' linking Libya to the bombing. [ Page A1, Column 6. ]

title: RELEASE OF A GENE-ALTERED VIRUS IS HALTED BY U.S. AFTER CHALLENGE
description: The Department of Agriculture today suspended the license and halted the sale of the first live genetically altered virus to be released into the environment.

title: OMELETS: ALL IN THE WRIST
description: I HIRED many cooks in my years as a professional chef, and over the years I developed a reliable test for evaluating an applicant's skills. ''Make me an omelet,'' I would say.

title: GERMAN REPORT ON SAKHAROV
description: A television station said today that Andrei D. Sakharov, the dissident Soviet physicist, would be freed in exchange for East-bloc spies by May.

title: GTE Unit Sets Bond Offering
description: The General Telephone Company of the Northwest, a subsidiary of the GTE Corporation, is offering $125 million of 8 3/4 percent first-mortgage bonds due in 2016 at a price of 98.50 to yield 8.89 percent through underwriters led by Morgan Stanley & Company. Rather than negotiating an interest rate with underwriters, or asking underwriters to bid for the bonds on short notice, the bonds were sold through competitive bidding at a date announced in advance.

title: STAGE: 'ONE FINE DAY' WEAVES TALES OF AFRICA
description: THE plot of ''One Fine Day'' by Nicholas Wright, performed by the Soho Rep at Greenwich House, is the education of an English university teacher by poor, rural Tanzanian students and one of their professors. But Mr. Wright has enlivened that tired routine by scattering through the play a series of stories recited and acted out by the students as their way of interpreting events, and the world, for their visitor.

title: U.S. POSTPONES NUCLEAR TEST THAT COULD END THE SOVIET MORATORIUM
description: The United States postponed a nuclear test today that some Administration critics had feared would lead the Soviet Union to abandon its moratorium on the underground testing of nuclear weapons.

title: MARGUERITE DURAS WINS RITZ HEMINGWAY PRIZE
description: Marguerite Duras has won the $50,000 Ritz Paris Hemingway Award for ''L'Amant'' (''The Lover''), her intense, lyric novel about the love affair she had with a wealthy Chinese when she was 15 years old in French Indochina.

title: STEWART & STEVENSON SERVCES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-Net income

title: TAUBMAN RAISES PULITZER BID
description: A. Alfred Taubman, the Detroit entrepreneur and real estate developer, has raised his bid for the Pulitzer Publishing Company to $625 million from $500 million. The new offer consists of $450 million in cash and $175 million in preferred stock.

title: INDOORS FOR PROTECTION
description: To the Editor:

title: DOW RISES BY 34.25, TO 1,769.76
description: The stock market staged an impressive comeback yesterday after a week's decline, as investors were relieved by lower oil prices and encouraged by rumors that there may soon be a cut in the Federal Reserve Board's discount rate.

title: WEDNESDAY SPORTS
description: Baseball Yankees vs. Kansas City Royals, at Yankee Stadium, 7:35 P.M. The controversy over the 7:30 P.M. start by the Yankees has been resolved and WPIX will do the games from the beginning.

title: CHOOSING CANDIDATES
description: To the Editor:

title: LACK OF OFFENSE STIFLES ROYALS
description: Dick Howser sat on a stool in the visiting team's clubhouse yesterday afternoon and smiled meekly. A small swarm of reporters had already filed in, waiting for the words that would put the day's events in some kind of perspective.

title: SWISS ISSUE A WARNING ON WINES FROM ITALY
description: The effects of the Italian wine scandal spread to Switzerland today after the Swiss Department of Public Health issued a warning against drinking any wines from Italy until they could be checked for methanol contamination.

title: GUN REFORM MUST BE A BALANCE OF INTERESTS
description: To the Editor:

title: Tax Writers Back at Work
description: The Senate Finance Committee resumed its tax bill drafting today. Opponents of the plan it is considering issued studies finding that one proposal would weigh heaviest on low-income people.

title: LEHIGH U. STUDENT HELD IN SLAYING AT BRYN MAWR
description: Josoph M. Henry, a sophomore at Lehigh University, was arraigned Monday in Northampton Common Pleas Court on charges of criminal homicide and rape in connection with the assault and strangulation of a Bryn Mawr freshman in her dormitory room.

title: Carson's Head Resisting Unwanted Suitor's Offer
description: Three years ago when Peter S. Willmott became chief executive of Carson Pirie Scott & Company, the Chicago-based retailer, the company was a ''sleepy'' giant, analysts said.

title: REPORT ON THE NEWARK POLICE CRITICIZED AS 'WISHY-WASHY'
description: George L. Schneider, the Essex County Prosecutor, has called a presentment handed up by a state grand jury on overtime abuses by Newark police officers ''wishy-washy'' and said the abuses cited in the document ''looked like out-and-out fraud.''

title: TEMPLETON GLOBAL I FUND reports earnings for As of March 31
ITALY ACTING TO END THE SALE OF METHANOL-TAINTED WINE
description: The Government moved quickly today to prevent further sales of tainted table wine and to deal with what is becoming a crisis and scandal in Italy's nationally important wine industry.

title: TEMPLETON WORLD FUND reports earnings for As of March 31
description: All assets represent net assets.

title: CBS TO REVAMP 'MORNING NEWS' AGAIN
description: CBS News, starting over once again in its long-frustrated effort to compete successfully for morning viewers, has hired one of its former competitors, Susan Winston, to develop a new version of the ''CBS Morning News,'' the network announced yesterday.

title: Closing of Shelter Sought Over Lead
description: The Legal Aid Society filed a class-action lawsuit yesterday asking that the city's Catherine Street shelter for homeless families, where extensive lead-paint hazards have been found, be shut until all problems have been corrected.

title: STATEWIDE BANCORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
WINE TALK
description: ''He was drinking one of the frozen daiquiris with no sugar in it and as he lifted it, heavy and the glass frost-rimmed, he looked at the clear part below the frappeed top and it reminded him of the sea. The frappeed part of the drink was like the wake of a ship and the clear part was the way the water looked when the bow cut it when you were in shallow water over marl bottom. That was almost the exact color.''

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''To make the matter absolutely clear, I will repeat anew: I stand for holding such a meeting.

title: BOMB KILLS 11 IN A CHRISTIAN ENCLAVE NEAR BEIRUT
description: A car bomb exploded in Lebanon's largest Christian town today, killing at least 11 people, wounding 100 others and setting several buildings ablaze.

title: IIS INTELLIGENT INFORMAION SYSTEMS reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
DISPUTE SURROUNDS PROPOSAL TO CUT MINORITY BUSINESS AID
description: A proposal to suspend Federal programs reserving contracts for businesses owned by women and members of minority groups drew criticism today from several civil rights advocates and members of Congress. But it was warmly praised by a spokesman for the construction industry.

title: CONGRESS SPLITS OVER REMARKS BY BUSH ON OIL
description: Some Republicans in the Senate say Vice President Bush's handling of the issue of oil pricing has created doubts about the Reagan Administration's policy and may also have done some damage his standing as a Presidential aspirant.

title: SUN TRUST BANKS INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
New Building Set For Postal Site
description: A plan to build a 20-story office building over the Grand Central Post Office on 45th Street and Lexington Avenue was approved yesterday by the board of governors of the United States Postal Service.

title: NATIONAL HOMES CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net loss The latest first quarter results include a $560,000 gain from sale of closed plants. The year-ago figures include a $446,000 gain from the purchase of the company's 4 3/4 percent convertible subordinated debentures.

title: HORIZON AIRLINES reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income The latest year results include a fourth-quarter provision for a loss of $4 million on termination of the Cascade Air acquisition and a charge of $500,000 for the cumulative effect on prior years of a change in accounting for pilot training costs.

title: DEFENDANT TERMED SCAPEGOAT IN ABORTED 1971 PRISON BREAK
description: A defense attorney depicted Stephen M. Bingham today as a driven, idealistic young man who in 1971 became the ''scapegoat'' in a plot by unidentified law-enforcement officials to murder George Jackson, one of the nation's best-known black revolutionaries in the early 1970's.

title: CHICAGO PNEUMATIC TOOL CO reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 3
description: b-Includes losses from discontinued operations of $896,000 for the quarter and $619,000 for the year. c-Net income and includes extraordinary tax credits of $1,468,000, or 30 cents a share, for the quarter and $2,485,000, or 50 cents a share, for the year. The year also included a loss from discontinued operations of $26,000.

title: 2 KINDS OF HOUSING FOR 2 FACES OF HARLEM
description: Before the Mayor's eyes were two of the most remarkably different faces that Harlem wears - one a menacing canyon that has belonged to the desperate; the other a welcoming mews that has belonged to the aspiring.

title: TECHDYNE INC reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
LANGER TO CUT BACK ON PLAY IN THE U.S.
description: Bernhard Langer, who won the Masters last year, will defend his title at the 50th Masters here this week and then play in only three more tournaments in the United States this year because of a new tax regulation.

title: Advertising; Sale of the Century
description: I. Goldberg & Partners has been named by the American Publishing Corporation of Watertown, Mass., to do the advertising for its new board game, Sale of the Century, which is named for the three-year-old TV game show. This is a very special board game, since it contains a computer chip. But does it play by itself? According to Irwin Goldberg, billings will be about $1 million this year and will probably double, next. American has another agency, Griffin Bacal Inc.

title: New Morgan Unit
description: J. P. Morgan & Company announced that a subsidiary to underwrite and deal in government securities and money market instruments would begin operating Monday. Morgan's decision to begin the operations of J. P. Morgan Securities Inc. comes before a ruling from the Board of Governors of the Federal Reserve on whether the unit will be allowed to engage in a number of activities that until now have been the province of investment banking firms, including the underwriting of commercial paper. David W. Fisher, 43, a senior vice president at the Morgan Guaranty Trust Company, was named president of the unit.

title: HOW A SPORT GOT A NEEDED LIFT
description: After 17 years at The Philadelphia Inquirer, Mel Greenberg, a 38-year-old journalism graduate of Temple University, holds the title ''news aide,'' which means that he's not a full-fledged reporter. Instead, he performs such tasks as typing up the radio listings and, when the computer system comes a cropper, trying to find articles filed by staff writers.

title: TUDOR TURNS BACK CUBS, 2-1
description: John Tudor pitched a five-hitter tonight as the Cardinals opened defense of their National League title with a 2-1 victory over the Chicago Cubs.

title: Dean's Roast
description: For 19 years, the ''Law Revue,'' a show produced by students at the Columbia University Law School, has been a rite of spring, a chance to flaunt talents and roast professors after the winter's toil.

title: ROYAL BUSINESS GROUP reports earnings for Qtr to March 2
description: b-Includes a tax benefit of $25,000. c-Net loss The company's stock is traded on the Boston Stock Exchange.

title: Youngsters Volunteer To Tidy Central Park
description: ''I never knew,'' 7-year-old Andrew Schlanger said yesterday as he struggled with a man-sized shovel in Central Park, ''that when there was a big pile of leaves it was so hard to get your shovel under it.''

title: SEQUENCE OF SHUTTLE FAILURES SEEN LEADING TO SPACE BLAST
description: A leader of an investigation into the space shuttle disaster outlined today what he called a ''plausible and probable'' sequence of failures leading up to the explosion of the Challenger. He said these failures probably began with one or more faulty parts in the right booster rocket and ended when unusually stiff winds buffeted the spaceship and caused the rupture of a rocket seal.

title: JAMAICA IS SOURCE FOR CARIBBEAN PRODUCE
description: NEW YORKERS who were unable to go to Jamaica last winter may be surprised to learn that the island, one of the largest exporters of produce in the Caribbean, came to them in the form of fresh winter vegetables.

title: FIRST ILLINOIS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
THE NO-PAY PHONES OF HACKENSACK
description: For weeks, people had been traveling from far and wide to reach the pay phones in Hackensack. The attraction was free international telephone calls.

title: GINNIE MAE HALTS GUARANTEES
description: A Government agency that guarantees payments on some $250 billion in outstanding mortgage-backed securities said today that it had stopped granting any new commitments to guarantee securities because it had almost reached its legal limit set by Congress.

title: BEEBA'S CREATIONS reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
55,602 IS RECORD
description: The Yankees brought New York baseball out of its six-month storage yesterday and played the kind of exciting, winning game area fans hope will establish the tone for both the Yankees and the Mets for the next six months.

title: Advertising; Fahlgren & Swink
description: Out in Cincinnati, Fahlgren & Swink has joined the Drackett Company's agency roster already occupied by Grey Advertising and Laurence, Charles, Free & Lawson, both of New York.

title: DESIGNING TOMORROW'S CITY
description: When Alexander Cooper goes down to the water's edge, he takes with him a teaspoon and measuring cup instead of a shovel and pail. Where others would construct futuristic stages with buildings rocketing skyward from vast plazas, this 49-year-old architect imagines a series of modest parks, rows of benches and a rather traditional New York neighborhood.

title: CENTRAL FIDELITY BANKS INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
TESTS SHOW AIDS VIRUS CAN LIVE UP TO 15 DAYS OUTSIDE THE BODY
description: The AIDS virus remains active outside the body much longer than previously believed, but common disinfectants are sufficient to neutralize it, according to a new study.

title: WICKES BIDS FOR NATIONAL GYPSUM
description: The Wickes Companies, which has rapidly reshaped its operations since emerging from bankruptcy proceedings little more than a year ago, announced a tender offer today for all outstanding shares of the National Gypsum Company.

title: Man Dies in Blast From Pipe Bomb
description: A 20-year-old man died early yesterday of wounds sustained in the explosion of a pipe bomb that he was making in a Brooklyn apartment, the police said.

title: THE F.A.O. SCHWARZ MOVE
description: On paper it looks like the most daunting relocation ever on Fifth Avenue: herds of bears and dinosaurs of various hues, enough houses to simulate the clutter of several city blocks and a roundhouse full of hundreds of intricately detailed locomotives are to be moved from their landmark location of the last 54 years.

title: ACADEMIC RESEARCH WINS A REPRIEVE
description: To the Editor:

title: INTERNATIONAL RED CROSS IN TALKS WITH AFGHANS
description: The International Committee of the Red Cross has opened negotiations with Afghanistan on resuming humanitarian visits to prisoners and wounded war victims interrupted three and a half years ago, Red Cross officials said today.

title: DANCE: LUBOVITCH TROUPE
description: THERE is something to cheer about when an already good choreographer comes gloriously into his own - and that is exactly what Monday night's audience stood up to do in Carnegie Hall at the local premiere of Lar Lubovitch's ''Concerto Six Twenty-Two.'' As thousands cheered, the dancers in the Lar Lubovitch Dance Company received huge white lilies at the curtain calls.

title: CORNERSTONE FINANCIAL reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Offer by U S West
description: U S West Inc. said it had agreed to buy Applied Communications Inc., a maker of software for machines that transfer money electronically, for $27 a share, or a total of about $120 million. If approved by Federal court, the move would be U S West's first into electronic funds transfer. In over-the-counter trading today, Applied Communications closed at $18, up 75 cents a share.

title: PRICE GOAL REVISED FOR G.M.'S SATURN
description: Officials of the General Motors Corporation confirmed today that the upcoming Saturn line of cars would not attempt to compete with the cheapest imports.

title: DERBY HOPEFUL INJURED
description: Rare Brick, a speedy colt who had been the heavy favorite to win the Arkansas Derby on April 19 and had been expected to help Snow Chief set the pace in the Kentucky Derby two weeks later, has been scratched from both races, leaving the Arkansas Derby's $500,000 purse virtually up for grabs.

title: IMMUCOR INC reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
description: b-Net loss

title: CITY TO EVICT ILLEGAL ALIENS FROM PUBLIC HOUSING
description: New York City will seek out and evict illegal aliens from public housing in compliance with new Federal rules, Mayor Koch said yesterday.

title: SAY, IS THIS THE WAY TO ARMAGEDDON?
description: To the Editor:

title: RIGHETTI SAVES TOLLS,TOO
description: Dave Righetti heard the talk on the radio yesterday morning, the speculation that the State of New Jersey is trying to lure the New York Yankees over to the swamplands.

title: POSTAL CONTRACT WON BY GRUMMAN
description: The Grumman Corporation, winning its biggest contract ever, received a $1.1 billion order yesterday to provide 99,150 delivery vehicles to the United States Postal Service over the next seven years.

title: WEDGESTONE REALTY INVESORS TRUST reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
THE COLLEGES' VERDICTS: WHO'S IN, WHO'S NOT
description: This is the time, known in some circles as ''trauma week,'' when many perfectly intelligent, normally stable parents and teen-agers start behaving rather strangely.

title: CATTLE RANCHERS SUE TO STOP GOVERNMENT SLAUGHTER OF DAIRY COWS
description: The National Cattlemen's Association filed a suit today in an effort to stop an Agriculture Department program to slaughter nearly a million dairy cows, saying the influx of beef was seriously depressing the cattle markets.

title: NEW YORKER IN A RUSSIAN'S-EYE VIEW OF THE CITY
description: Joseph Mauri, the man featured in a new, harshly critical Soviet documentary film about New York City, is a 58-year-old resident of the Upper West Side who says he works occasionally doing ''odd jobs'' and participated in the film after a Soviet journalist had written about his troubles with a former landlord.

title: CHEAP FUEL AND TERROR FEARS STEER VACATIONERS TO THE ROAD
description: With gasoline prices falling, the value of the dollar declining and fears of terrorism rising, thousands of American vacationers are making plans to stay closer to home this summer.

title: POLITICS AND THE PRESS
description: The American Society of Newspaper Editors met here this week, which tempts me to butt in with an observation and a suggestion about politics and the press.

title: DANCE: SOFIAN BELLY DANCERS
description: THE Anahid Sofian Dance Company offered some swaying and quivering dances Sunday night at the Theater of the Riverside Church. The items came from various regions of the Middle East, but many were similar because they derived from the Middle Eastern form that, in America, is familiarly known as belly dancing.

title: DOW JONES & CO INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After an after-tax gain of $31,358,000 from the sale of 2 million common shares of Continental Cablevision Inc.

title: IONA PICKS BROKAW
description: Gary Brokaw, who spent the last six years as an assistant basketball coach at Notre Dame, was named head coach at Iona College. He replaces Pat Kennedy, who abrubtly broke his Iona contract last month to take over the Florida State program.

title: 'CINEMA IN CHINA,' A 50-YEAR SURVEY ON CHANNEL 13
description: ''CINEMA IN CHINA'' surveys, respectfully, some 50 years of Chinese film making. Are the films any good? It's hard to tell. Most of what we see looks wooden, although perhaps Western standards shouldn't apply. Chinese films, the documentary tells us, have been ''inextricably involved with the political and social changes'' in China. The documentary will be seen on Channel 13 at 9 o'clock tonight.

title: LEADER OF ZULUS CRITICIZES BOTHA
description: The leader of the Zulus, Chief Gatsha Buthelezi, one of the few black leaders still willing to talk to the white Government, has made a scathing personal attack on President P. W. Botha.

title: SCIENCE PROPOSAL PRESSED BY JAPAN
description: Japan is asking the United States and other Western countries attending next month's annual economic summit meeting in Tokyo to join a new international effort to explore the frontiers of science.

title: NO FREE RIDES
description: From the time he first grasps a bat that's bigger than he is and toddles to the plate with an oversized helmet all but covering his eyes, a young ballplayer is reminded by chatterbox third-base coaches that ''a walk's as good as a hit.'' There's always somebody, of course, who doesn't get the word.

title: EXECUTIVES
description: * Broadcast Music Inc. has named Frances Preston executive vice president and chief operating officer.

title: ENERSERV PRODUCTS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
SOME PERSONAL TOUCHES
FIRST NATIONAL BANCORPORATION (GEORIA) reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
INTERNATIONAL PAPER CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
HAVE YOU HEARD THE ONE ABOUT MICHELIN'S SCOUT?
description: ANDRE SOLTNER, owner-chef at Lutece, heard it, he thinks, from a customer.

title: BULLETS BEATEN
description: Vern Fleming scored 18 points as the Indiana Pacers snapped a nine-game losing streak with a 111-104 victory tonight over the Washington Bullets.

title: METS WIN BY 4-2
description: The Mets began the great chase for their first pennant in 13 years tonight with a 4-2 victory over the Pittsburgh Pirates, and the main men did it: Dwight Gooden pitched six-hit ball and stayed the distance, and Keith Hernandez knocked in two runs with two clutch hits.

title: BUNT BACKFIRES FOR WINFIELD
description: Dave Winfield had no sacrifice bunts on his statistical sheet for the 1985 season, but he uncharacteristically tried to get one yesterday in the first game of the 1986 season. Willie Randolph and Don

title: U.S. PRESSES BONN AND OTHER ALLIES TO EXPEL LIBYANS
description: The United States has urged West Germany and some other key allies to expel all or most of Libya's diplomats from their capitals because of evidence linking Libya to the bombing last weekend of a discotheque in West Berlin, Administration officials said today.

title: Capital Inflow Buoys Mexico
description: Although Mexico's finances have been hurt by the plunge in oil prices, it has experienced a net inflow of capital in the last three months that gives it ''more room to maneuver'' in dealing with foreign creditors and international financial institutions, Finance Minister Jesus Silva Herzog said today.

title: COMINGS AND GOINGS
description: Kelvin Bryant and the Baltimore Stars, who have been squabbling in court over the running back's efforts to get out of his United States Football League contract and sign with the Washington Redskins, have agreed to arbitration by the U.S.F.L. Players Association, with a decision due by June 30. . . . The Toronto Blue Jays have placed Bill Caudill, the relief pitcher, on the 15-day disabled list with stiffness in his right shoulder. . . . Rogie Vachon has signed a new multiyear contract as the general manager of the Los Angeles Kings.

title: JAPAN APPROVES MOVES TO STIMULATE ECONOMY
description: The Japanese Government today approved a multibillion-dollar package of incentives and price cuts intended to help an economy threatened with a slowdown because of the strengthened yen.

title: Tenneco Job Cut
description: Tenneco Inc. will cut its work force by about 700 employees at its corporate headquarters and several of its Houston-based subsidiaries, officials said. The company eliminated 470 jobs in mid-March in its oil exploration and production unit; the additional cuts by midsummer will bring the employee reduction to about 1,200.

title: TEMPLETON GLOBAL II FUND reports earnings for As of March 31
FIRST WESTERN FINANCIAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After an extraordinary gain of $366,000 from the early extinguishment of debt.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: PEACEFUL REPOSE Among the city's permanent residents are the more than half a million people buried or entombed in Brooklyn's 148-year-old Green-Wood Cemetery - one of the city's largest and wealthiest necropolises. Among those in their final resting place in Green-Wood's 478 acres are Lola Montez, Henry George, William Marcy (Boss) Tweed, DeWitt Clinton, Mr. and Mrs. Henry Steinway, Charles Ebbets and Henry Ward Beecher.

title: U.S. Petroleum Data
description: In millions of barrels except refinery utilization

title: MICROPOLIS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 28
description: b-Net loss

title: OFFICIALS FAULT TAXI PANEL'S INQUIRIES
description: Three years before state investigators uncovered evidence of corruption in an experimental city taxi program, two investigations by the city's taxi agency failed to find any wrongdoing, city officials said yesterday.

title: SOUTHEAST BANKING reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes an after-tax gain of $4.9 million, or 29 cents per share, from the sale of real estate.

title: Writing on the Wall I
description: Washington is devoting increasing money and attention to keeping up with the Japanese. The Department of Commerce, for example, has given a qualified blessing to legislation to spend $1 million on more extensive translation and distribution of Japanese scientific and technical literature in this country.

title: U.S. MOVES TO DEPORT THREE AS EX-SS GUARDS
description: The Justice Department announced today that it had begun deportation proceedings against three men accused of working as guards in Nazi concentration camps in World War II and participating in the persecution of thousands of people.

title: Writing on the Wall II
description: One of the most firmly settled principles up at the Supreme Court is stare decisis, the Latin phrase that describes courts' insistence on following the precedents of past decisions and, generally, not disturbing settled matters. That, it de-velops, is the way Associate Justice William J. Brennan Jr. views the process of writing and the inroads made on the quill pen by more recent developments.

title: THE U.N. TODAY: April 9, 1986
description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY

title: U.S. PLEASED BUT WARY ABOUT NEW JAPAN PLAN
description: In an apparent warming of Administration attitudes toward Japan, President Reagan is planning to salute Prime Minister Yasuhiro Nakasone's new economic policies following a meeting of the two leaders at Camp David on Sunday, Administration officials said today.

title: 4 ARE ARRESTED OVER AN INJURY DURING HAZING
description: Two current and two former students at Manhattan College were arrested today and charged with the hazing of a fraternity pledge that resulted in severe frostbite.

title: OPENING-DAY OPTIMISM REFLECTS A BRONX ON THE REBOUND
description: It is arguable that, yesterday at least, Edna Mandelbaum, had just about the best view in New York City.

title: TEMPLETON GROWTH FUND LTD reports earnings for As of March 31
Law Imperils Imasco's Deal
description: Imasco Ltd.'s $2.34 billion agreement to acquire the Genstar Corporation is endangered by a law introduced Monday by the Mulroney administration.

title: LUTHERAN CHURCH MERGER PLANS ARE SNAGGED
description: Plans to merge three Lutheran denominations into a single one are faltering over such issues as congregational independence, minority quotas for official posts and the size of pension contributions.

title: Daiwa Fills Adviser Post
description: Owen B. Butler, who retired last month as chairman of Procter & Gamble, has been named a senior adviser at Daiwa Securities America, the Japanese-based securities firm announced yesterday. Takuro Isoda, Daiwa America's chairman, said that Mr. Butler would consult with Daiwa executives on developing a long-term strategy for the firm in its growing United States operations. Mr. Butler retired from Procter & Gamble after more than 40 years at the giant consumer products company.

title: Working Profile: Arnold I. Burns; The Newest 'Star' On Foggy Bottom
description: The transition from senior partner in a New York law firm to a top position in the Justice Department takes a bit longer than the flight from La Guardia Airport to National Airport.

title: Renault Seeks Aid
description: The chairman of Regie Nationale des Usines Renault said the state-owned car group would require more capital from the French Government to turn around a loss of about $1.45 billion in 1985. The chairman, Georges Besse, said he hoped Renault would start to break even by the second half of next year. The state granted Renault about $436 million last year and has promised about $396 million this year.

title: RITES OF SPRING BUSINESS AS USUAL
description: Senate majority leader Dole was in a hurry before the Easter recess to win approval of a constitutional amendment supposedly balancing the Federal budget. Yet he appears to feel no urgency at all about reducing next year's deficit now.

title: SAUDI ARMS DEAL PROPOSED
description: The Administration officially notified Congress today of its intent to sell a $354 million missile package to Saudi Arabia to boost the oil kingdom's defenses and help deter expansion of the Iran-Iraq war. Congress, which was informally notified of the arms package March 11, has 30 days in which to disapprove the proposed sale. Israel does not plan to fight the proposed sale even though Israel opposes United States weapons deals with Arab countries as a matter of policy.

title: Advertising; AC&R Advertising
description: The Williams Hospitality Corporation, a subsidiary of Williams Electronics, has assigned its Condado Plaza Hotel and Casino in San Juan, P.R., to AC&R Advertising, a subsidiary of Ted Bates Worldwide, for both advertising and public relations. The agency said billings would exceed $1 million. The former agency was Robinson, Yesawich & Pepperdine of Orlando, Fla.

title: CB&T BANCSHARES INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
BUSINESS DIGEST: WEDNESDAY, APRIL 9, 1986
description: Markets

title: SPRINGTIME TRADITION OF YOUNG LAMB: IDEAS FOR THE TABLE
description: THE link between lamb and springtime is probably as old as civilization itself. Quite apart from the lamb's symbolic place in both Jewish and Christian rites of spring, the serving of young lamb, often accompanied by ''primeurs,'' vegetables available at the beginning of the growing season, has been a highlight of many of the world's cuisines.

title: ITT Delaying Army Radios
description: Reliability problems have delayed output of a new generation of jam-proof military radios to be built by the ITT Corporation under a $400 million contract, the Army said today.

title: SCREEN: 'SEQUENCES'
description: AT the center of ''Sequences'' is a Pirandellian idea, but Alexandru Tatos, the director, is a little slow in letting us at it. This work from Rumania, which will be shown at the Museum of Modern Art tonight at 6 o'clock and tomorrow night at 8:30, trails a film company that is making a movie called ''Happiness.'' From hints and glimpses, the movie-within-a-movie has to do with World War II resistance fighters and their children in the present generation.

title: Republicbank Net Falls
description: Battered by the fall in oil prices, the Republicbank Corporation of Dallas said yesterday that its first-quarter earnings dropped 34.7 percent, to $23.1 million, or 75 cents a share, from $35.4 million, or $1.19 a share, a year ago. The earnings for Republic, the largest bank holding company in Texas, with $23 billion in assets, were in line with analysts' expectations.

title: Standard-E.C.D.
description: The Standard Oil Company, buffeted by falling oil prices, has sold its $90 million investment in a solar cell partnership with Energy Conversion Devices Inc. for $12 million in E.C.D. stock, E.C.D. said.

title: WNET REFUSES TO AIR PBS PROGRAM ON ISRAEL
description: A public-television program consisting of three films with sharply divergent views on the borders of Israel has stirred a heated dispute within public broadcasting. Some stations, including WNET in New York and WETA in Washington, have refused to carry the broadcast, scheduled for tonight.

title: WE HAVE THE KNOW-HOW TO LET ADM. FARRAGUT STAY OUTDOORS
description: To the Editor:

title: AMES DEPARTMENT STORES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 25
GANDER CRASH INQUIRY IS TOLD OF JET'S PROBLEMS
description: Investigators looking into the plane crash that killed 248 American servicemen and eight crew members in Gander, Newfoundland, in December said today that the Arrow Air jet had several unusual problems during flights just before the accident.

title: THRIFTY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
How Congress Travels on Its Stomach
description: Displaced Californians yearning for a snack from home should drop by Senator Pete Wilson's office, where they will find fresh California raisins in three varieties.

title: THE DUALITY IN 'HOUSE OF BLUE LEAVES'
description: From the moment the curtain goes up on the set of ''The House of Blue Leaves,'' the play begins to weave its intricate mixture of the weirdly comic and the tragic, shuttling back and forth so deftly that the split-second switches are breathtaking in their impact. In the middle of a laugh, the audience freezes as the uproariously funny becomes suddenly heartbreaking; the most awful catastrophe inspires humor. Even the characters' names suggest the duality at the heart of the play: the ravaged, ghostly woman who has been deemed insane is named Bananas, while her rival for her husband's affections - a blowzy neighbor given to skintight dresses, spike-heeled boots trimmed with feathered plumes, platinum hair and hilariously dizzy pronouncements - is called Bunny.

title: HOW TO RUN NEW YORK CITY
description: Only when a major scandal loosens the grip of entrenched politicians and calls into question the legitimacy of a basic political system - as it surely has in New York City - does real reform become possible.

title: PROSECUTORS SEEK TO TIE $400,000 IN RETIREMENT FUNDS TO CITISOURCE
description: Six days after his indictment on charges related to the Citisource bribery scandal, the company's chairman, Marvin B. Kaplan, tried to transfer $400,000 in retirement funds from another company to his stockbroker's account, prosecutors said yesterday.

title: G.O.P. LEADERS IN SENATE VOICING IRRITATION WITH REAGAN ON BUDGET
description: As Congress returned to Capitol Hill today from the Easter recess, Republican leaders in the Senate expressed rising irritation with the Reagan Administration, saying it had refused to enter serious negotiations on a Federal budget for the next fiscal year.

title: THE VANISHING MUSEUM
description: After more than a decade of searching, a solution to the problem of where to house the Museum of the American Indian is within reach - but only if New York's Congressional delegation remains united. Unfortunately, Senator Alfonse D'Amato has chosen to push when he could be pulling.

title: Two New Columns
description: Beginning with this issue, The Living Section is publishing new columns on healthful eating and on the techniques of preparing food.

title: ISLANDERS CONFIDENT; FLYERS HOLD SEASON EDGE
description: The Rangers sweated out all the ups and downs of the long regular season, including a hectic final weekend in which they finally clinched a position in the playoffs. Their reward for this tenacity is the Philadelphia Flyers, who finished with 110 points and come in to the Stanley Cup playoffs a hot team. They won their last five games and 11 of the last 13. They have also beaten the Rangers 18 times out the last 19 times they have faced each other.

title: Advertising; Jarcom Is Named Agency for Isoptin
description: Jarcom Inc., a health care agency of recent vintage in New Providence, N.J., has been assigned Isoptin, a cardiovascular treatment drug, by Knoll Pharmaceuticals division of BASF.

title: MADE TRADITIONAL SCULPTURES
description: Dorothea Greenbaum, a representational sculptor who determinedly resisted artistic experimentation and abstraction, died Sunday at her studio-home in Princeton, N.J. She was 92 years old.

title: INSURERS, LAWYERS QUESTION CUOMO PLAN
description: Representatives of both the insurance industry and some lawyers groups said yesterday that they were unhappy with Governor Cuomo's proposals to deal with the soaring costs of liability insurance in New York.

title: KIN OF MAN SLAIN IN HIJACKING SEEK $20 MILLION FROM T.W.A.
description: The family of the Navy diver killed by hijackers last year sues Trans World Airlines today, saying the airline mishandled passenger and aircraft security. The lawsuit seeks $20 million in damages.

title: NEW YORK EMBRACES ISLAND FARE
description: NEW YORK seems to be bouncing to a Caribbean beat these days. From the insistent throb of reggae along Brooklyn's Nostrand Avenue, headquarters for the city's large and still growing West Indian population, to the infectious samba rhythms on Bergenline Avenue, across the Hudson in Union City, N.J., home base to the region's Cubans, large sections of the metropolitan area are beginning to look, sound and feel like outposts of the Caribbean.

title: Treasury Bond Prices Climb
description: Treasury bond prices rose by nearly three points yesterday on the strength of revived demand from securities dealers and other speculators after nearly a week of more cautious trading.

title: HOUSE BILL IS BETTER
description: To the Editor:

title: Key Rates
description: * Municipal Bond Index, The Bond Buyer Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: St. Bart's Is Suing City On Office Tower Plan
description: St. Bartholomew's Church filed a lawsuit in Federal District Court in Manhattan yesterday contending that New York City and the Landmarks Preservation Commission violated the First Amendment by refusing to allow the church to build a high-rise office tower on its property.

title: FIRST OF AMERICA BANK CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
GREEN TREE ACCEPTANCE INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
IMMUNOGENETICS INC reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-Includes losses from discontinued operations of $732,924 for the latest year and $3,842 for the year-earlier period. The 1984 year also includes an extraordinary gain of $571,700. c-Net income The latest year figures also include a $900,000 writedown of cattle and swine operations and a $300,000 loss from accelerated devaluation of the Mexican peso.

title: USF&G CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After investment gains of $52,140,000 for the quarter and $150,062,000 for the year. c-Includes investment gains of $481,000 for the quarter and investment losses of $23,344,000 for the year. The company said its first three quarters of 1985 and the 1984 full year have been reclassified and restated.

title: PROFESSIONAL INVESTORS INURANCE GROUP reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
OIL PLUNGES ON SOVIET SALES HINT
description: Oil prices, reversing direction, plunged yesterday on traders' reports that the Soviet Union would sharply increase its oil exports.

title: 60-MINUTE GOURMET
description: I AM convinced that in all of fish cookery, the preparation that is the simplest and easiest to prepare is poached cod. It is also a dish that can rival many of the most elaborate fish creations, including bouillabaisse or zuppa di pesce. The technique is simple: Cut the cod fillets into serving pieces, put them in a pan and add cold water, milk and seasonings such as cloves, peppercorns, parsley and bay leaf. Bring the liquid to a boil and let the fish simmer gently about two minutes or slightly longer, depending on the thickness of the pieces. Then drain and serve.

title: TEMPLETON FOREIGN FUND reports earnings for As of March 31
I.R.A. BOMB IN ULSTER KILLS A MILITIAMAN
description: An Irish Republican Army bomb killed an off-duty militiaman today and Protestant radicals attacked the homes of four police officers on the ninth day of violence against a British-Irish agreement.

title: Phillip B. Thurston, Ex-Judge In Police and Family Courts
description: Phillip B. Thurston, a retired judge who spent more than 30 years on the New York City Police and Family Courts, died last Thursday in Northern Westchester Hospital Center in Mount Kisco, N.Y. He was 77 years old and lived in Manhattan and Yorktown Heights, N.Y.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL CHICAGO (AL) - Placed Julio Cruz, infielder, on 15-day disabled list. Recalled Bryan Little, infielder, from Buffalo of the American Association.

title: FOR SOME IN ZAIRE, SELLING FLOWERS IS ALL THERE IS
description: As the sun nudged into the oyster-colored dawn sky, Jean began arranging his small bundles of flowers in the three large tin cans on a curb outside the Gombe Cemetery.

title: FABULOUS THUNDERBIRDS AND BLUES-BASED ROCK
description: THE Fabulous Thunderbirds, a Texas-based quartet that has been playing blues-based music in countless clubs and bars for 12 years now, is suddenly a hot item. ''Tuff Enuff,'' the group's first album for CBS/Epic, is number 47 on the charts and rising, and the group is booked solid for months in advance. They will be at the Beacon Theater on Friday, April 18, on a bill with the Del-Lords and Brian Setzer.

title: Advertising; Addenda
description: * Michael Dainard Associates Inc., 31 East 28th St., is a new marketing services company.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: * Automatic Data Processing Inc., Roseland, N.J., said it had signed an agreement to sell the U.S. banking operations of its recently acquired Bunker Ramo division to Ing. C. Olivetti & Co. Terms were not disclosed.

title: SECRET BRITISH SHIP LAUNCH
description: Britain's newest warship, the frigate Coventry, was launched in a no-frills ceremony before dawn today to sidestep a shipyard strike. The secret launch of the Coventry, whose namesake was sunk in the Falkland Islands war, was arranged after 2,500 workers struck the Swan Hunter shipyard over a wage dispute and threatened to block the ceremony, originally scheduled for this afternoon.

title: METROPOLITAN DIARY
description: SPRING . . . a young man's fancy . . . the April breeze humming I love you. You've got the picture. Somehow, though, as Andrea Lowen can attest, there is always still one more variation on the theme.

title: CALCIUM VS. FAT
description: WE know the rules already: Eat more fiber and less fat; more calcium and less salt; add cruciferous vegetables, cut out processed meats, increase fish, especially fatty fish, and add whole grains and legumes. These and other dietary proposals, most of them based on new findings about the relationship between good nutrition and good health, are now ubiquitous: Every day, it seems, medical experts add another rule.

title: Roughing It In the East River
description: A small island, shaped like a door key, lies in the East River, about 1,000 feet from shore. It is one of the seven islands in the Borough of Manhattan, and perhaps the least well known.

title: MEROLA'S TEAM SWINGS AND MISSES
description: A sweet sting went sour in the Bronx yesterday. The police hoped to lure 950 fugitives into a trap and caught only 3. Perhaps baseball has lost its appeal, or perhaps P. T. Barnum was wrong after all.

title: Bridge: The Five-Card Major Style Is Steadily Gaining Support
description: A battle that has lasted for a quarter of a century seems to have been decided. The five-card major style for opening bids has been adopted, and the four-card major opening rejected, by most experts, most average players and most traditional authorities on the game.

title: RITES OF SPRING GRANDMA'S FUNERAL
description: ''Remember the rueful part of 'Casey at the Bat,' just before he strikes out,'' a friend asked yesterday after Opening Day at Yankee Stadium, ''the part that says 'Oh! somewhere in this favored land the sun is shining bright, the band is playing somewhere, and somewhere hearts are light'? Well, there was no joy in Mudville, but for the moment, New York is that somewhere. Today, New York sure did work.''

title: STRIKE IN NORWAY FORCES VISITORS OUT OF HOTELS
description: Visitors were asked to leave hotels in Norway today in a labor dispute, hotel residents said.

title: TENDER LOVING HEALTH CARE SERVICES reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
description: b-Net loss.

title: 2 OF THOSE SHOT BY GOETZ FACE NEW JAIL TERMS
description: Sixteen months after Bernhard H. Goetz shot four Bronx youths on a subway train, three are in jail or under court supervision and one is crippled for life by the shot Mr. Goetz fired that severed his spinal cord.

title: Ex-Jefferies Officer Joins Dillon, Read
description: Ronald A. Alghini, who resigned in January as president and chief operating officer of the Jefferies Group, parent of the Los Angeles-based securities house, has joined Dillon, Read & Company as co-head of its equity trading operation.

title: MEAD CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
FIRST JERSEY NATIONAL BANK reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: THE WAR. A Memoir. By Marguerite Duras. 183 pages. Pantheon. $13.95.

title: ISLANDERS CONFIDENT; TOUGH FOES FOR CAPITALS
description: If history is a friend to the Islanders, they can approach their series with the Washington Capitals in the first round of the playoffs with composure. In the last three seasons, the two teams have come together in the playoffs three times, and on each occasion the Islanders have been the victors.

title: INVESTMENT TECHNOLOGIES reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
CALIFORNIA RE-CREATES BARREL-TASTING DINNER
description: After 10 years in New York, the California Barrell Tasting Dinner came home last night. The vaulted splendors of the Four Seasons were replaced by the more intimate but no less elegant surroundings of the Stanford Court Hotel, but everything else was familiar. The owner or wine makers from 13 wineries, one less than in the past, each offered an example of the 1985 vintage along with a representative wine from some other recent vintage. As in the past, about 280 people -wine makers, wine merchants, wine writers and wine drinkers - sampled the wares. Most of the guests were Californian, but there was a substantial delegation of Easterners, curious to see how San Francisco would handle the dinner, which had been a sellout in New York for a decade. ''They've done a superb job,'' said Tom Margittai, co-owner of the Four Seasons.

title: PRISON FOR ALIENS OPENS IN LOUISIANA
description: Forty-six illegal aliens arrived at the new Federal Detention Center tonight, the first of nearly 1,300 who will be kept there behind a 12-foot-high fence topped with razor wire.

title: MEDICORE INC reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-Includes a loss from discontinued operations of $335,666 and a gain on the disposal of discontinued operations of $1,064,489. c-Includes a loss from discontinued operations of $82,709 and a tax loss carryforward of $223,000.

title: AMERICANS PRESS WEST GERMANS TO SHUT LIBYAN EMBASSY IN BONN
description: An American appeal to West Germany to close the Libyan Embassy here has placed Chancellor Helmut Kohl's Government in a difficult situation, with West German officials still showing little inclination to adopt stern measures against Libya.

title: The Rev. Matthew M. Warren; Ex-Head of St. Paul's School
description: The Rev. Matthew Madison Warren, rector of St. Paul's School in Concord, N.H., from 1954 until his retirement in 1970, died of a heart attack Monday. He was 78 years old and lived in North Hampton, N.H.

title: CZECH WINS NEW YORK CHESS EVENT
description: Jan Smejkal won the New York International Open Chess Tournament yesterday afternoon, but the 40-year-old Czech grandmaster had to share most of the prize money with Gyula Sax of Hungary, his 34-year-old grandmaster colleague.

title: FIRST BANKERS CORPORATION OF FLORIDA reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
FIRST MICHIGAN BANCORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After a tax credit of $336,000.

title: Ballet and Politics
description: Washington, generally speaking, has a lot more political firsts than artistic firsts, so local balletomanes are eagerly anticipating tonight's world premiere at the Kennedy Center of ''Sabattini pour Christofle,'' starring Mikhail Baryshnikov of the American Ballet Theater. Choreographed by Karole Armitage with set and costumes by David Salle, the ballet is said to be based on the life of Mr. Baryshnikov, the popular Russian emigre dancer and motion picture star.

title: PAULINE NEWMAN, AN EARLY ORGANIZER OF CLOTHING WORKERS
description: Pauline M. Newman, one of the first women to work as an organizer for the International Ladies Garment Workers' Union, died Tuesday at the home of friends in Manhattan, after suffering a stroke. She was 98 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: INTERFERENCE CONTROL TECHOLOGIES reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
Don W. Moore, Writer Of 'Flash Gordon,' Dies
description: Don W. Moore, who wrote the ''Flash Gordon'' comic strip for 20 years and wrote scripts for such television favorites as ''Rawhide,'' ''Sea Hunt'' and ''Death Valley Days,'' died Monday in Venice, Fla. He was 81 years old.

title: JERSEY MAN ACCUSED AS NAZI IS PREPARING A DEPORTATION FIGHT
description: A Clifton, N.J., man the Justice Department is seeking to deport said yesterday that he had retained a lawyer to defend him because he was worried that ''they can take away my citizenship papers.''

title: AT LONG LAST, A LITTLE SOFT SHOE FOR NEW YORK'S WEARY FLATFOOT
description: Ever since the neighborhood mouth used to yell ''flatfoot'' to the man with the blue tunic and fallen arches, the police have worn the same kind of shoe -plain, black, hard-soled and often unbearable.

title: GENERAL ELECTRIC CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
El Al to Cannon
description: El Al Israel Airlines has selected as its new agency Cannon Advertising Associates, which recently became a subsidiary of Van Brunt & Company.

title: FOR LONG, LEISURELY SITTING, TRADITIONAL CHAIRS ARE BEST
description: THE 1960 Bantam edition of Tolstoy's ''Anna Karenina'' is 873 pages long, with about 460 words per page. Sitting down and reading straight through the book, a person averaging 400 words a minute will spend approximately 17 hours sitting. The chair should be comfortable.

title: LEONID V. KANTOROVICH DIES; WON NOBEL ECONOMICS PRIZE
description: Leonid V. Kantorovich, a Soviet economist and mathematician who was co-winner of the Nobel Prize for economics in 1975, died Monday, Tass, the Soviet press agency, reported yesterday. He was 74 years old.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: McDonnell, Textron in Bid
description: The McDonnell Douglas Corporation and Textron Inc., military contractors that have bitterly competed for work, said today that they would cooperate to seek a $2.5 billion contract for development of a lightweight Army helicopter.

title: HELP IN CURBING CLUTTER
description: THERE are many devices to help eliminate clutter in refrigerators and freezers.

title: Opposition Leader Returns to Pakistan
description: Benazir Bhutto, the exiled Pakistani opposition leader, returned home from exile today to the cheers of tens of thousands of supporters.

title: MONTICELLO WILL GROW HISTORIC PLANTS
description: A garden center where horticulturists will work to restore and cultivate historic plants will open at Thomas Jefferson's Monticello home next spring, estate officials said.

title: SMALL LUXURIES MAKE A DIFFERENCE
description: READING enjoyment, obviously, begins with a good book, but that pleasure can be increased by some comfort-enhancing extras. What could be better, for instance, than curling up with a friend against a double overstuffed reading pillow?

title: Polish Debt Talks Stall
description: Polish and Western bankers failed today in their latest round of negotiations on rescheduling part of Poland's commercial debt falling due this year, banking sources said. Talks were scheduled to continue in London in three weeks, the sources said.

title: STAGE: 'PRINCIPIA SCRIPTORIAE' BY RICHARD NELSON
description: IN ''Principia Scriptoriae,'' his new play at the Manhattan Theater Club, Richard Nelson seems to ask every tough question about what it means to be a writer in the world we live in now. Although the drama's action is set in an unnamed Latin American country, its issues recall the rancor of New York's recent PEN conference - or any forum that might attract a Mario Vargas Llosa, a Gunter Grass and a Cynthia Ozick in full moral or ideological cry. Mr. Nelson's characters are writers of various nationalities whose principles, both esthetic and political, are constantly under fire. In ''Principia Scriptoriae,'' unlike contentious symposiums, some of that fire emanates from guns.

title: PENTAGON AGAIN ACTS TO TRANSFER OFFICIAL WHO QUESTIONED TESTING
description: Despite a promise last year, the Pentagon plans to transfer an Air Force colonel who questioned the effectiveness of tests of a new Army armored personnel carrier.

title: THE QUEEN MAY NOT BE AMUSED, BUT MILLIONS ARE
description: In 1729, Jonathan Swift published his ''Modest Proposal for Preventing the Children of Poor People from Being a Burden to Their Parents or the Country.'' Two and a half centuries later, his proposal was purloined by the scriptwriters of a determinedly offensive and scurrilous television series here called ''Spitting Image'' and placed in the mouth of a foam rubber caricature of Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher.

title: WILL GODOT EVER SHOW? BECKETT WAITS IN SILENCE
description: IN one of his rare published statements on art, Samuel Beckett defined the artistic dilemma:

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: A LITERARY GALA Columbia: A Magazine of Poetry and Prose is sponsoring its 10th anniversary gala today.

title: Move Awaited On Warnaco
description: The next move in the battle for control of Warnaco Inc. belongs to a hostile suitor, the W Acquisition Corporation, analysts and W Acquisition's chairman said yesterday.

title: SELF-HELP PROJECT BY BUSINESSMEN
description: Thirty years ago, a group of businessmen in the Bensonhurst, Coney Island and Sheepshead Bay sections of Brooklyn established a small credit union. The businessmen, seeking easier lending terms than they could obtain at banks, dubbed the institution Hyfin - an acronym for Help Your Friend in Need.

title: William B. Groat, 86, Ex-Queens State Judge
description: William Budge Groat, a former State Supreme Court justice in Queens, died of a stroke Friday at the Booth Memorial Medical Center in Queens. He was 86 years old and lived in Queens Village.

title: Bridge: The 'Discard' of a Trump Helped a Pair at Nationals
description: A discard is normally defined as the play of a card that is not a trump when failing to follow suit. But there are circumstances, of a strange kind, in which a trump can be a ''discard.''

title: U.S. POSTPONES TEST OF A NUCLEAR DEVICE FOR 2D STRAIGHT DAY
description: The United States postponed an underground nuclear test today for the second consecutive day, Administration officials said.

title: HOME IMPROVEMENT
description: ALTHOUGH most amateurs use twist bits to drill holes in wood, metal and plastic, they are normally used only for holes up to 1/4 or 3/8 inch in diameter - larger bits are very expensive and mostly used by commercial and industrial workers. To bore a larger hole, the home handyman needs another type of boring bit or a hole saw.

title: Council Chiefs Propose Lobbying Law Change
description: Changes in the city's lobbying and financial disclosure laws, closely resembling recommendations by Mayor Koch, were proposed yesterday by two City Council leaders.

title: AMERICANA HOTELS & REALTY CORP reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-Includes a previously announced provision of $16 million for investment losses. c-Net income

title: Derailed Freight Train Disrupts Amtrak Service
description: A freight train carrying hazardous material derailed today, prompting a brief evacuation of 150 nearby residents and forcing thousands of Amtrak passengers to use buses between Baltimore and Washington.

title: GROUP SEEKS RESTRAINTS ON USE OF ART MATERIALS
description: A consumer group that seeks Federal controls on the use of potentially hazardous art materials in the classroom is meeting resistance from manufacturers who say their voluntary labeling system ensures child safety.

title: Q&A
description: Q. My house is heated by a hot water system with baseboard convectors in each room. We would like to turn the heat off in two empty rooms. Can you tell me how to do this? Can you also tell me why, after our thermostat turns the heat down at 10 P.M., I sometimes hear the heat coming up in the middle of the night? A. Whether you can turn off heat to two rooms depends on how your system is set up. Usually the convectors are part of a continuous piping system that goes from one room to the next, so you cannot shut off part without shutting off everything. However, some systems have separate valves for each room so they can be shut off. You should ask your plumber to check. If you have no such valves he may be able to install them (again, depending on how the system is set up).

title: G.M. Sets Offering
description: The General Motors Corporation is offering $500 million of 8 1/8 percent debentures due 2016 at a price of 99.167, to yield 8.20 percent, through underwriters led by Salomon Brothers Inc. The debentures, which are rated Aa-1 by Moody's and AA+ by S.&P., yield about 7/8 percentage point above 30-year Treasury bonds and are not refundable for 10 years.

title: BNH BANCSHARES reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
U.S. ENVOY ASSAILS DELEGATION
description: The United States Ambassador to Argentina has cabled the State Department to complain that several members of a Congressional delegation put pressure on Argentine political leaders to oppose Administration positions on Central America, according to aides to the Representatives.

title: FROM THEOLOGICAL MALPRACTICE TO WRESTLING ON '20/20'
description: WHAT makes a successful magazine show? Diversity, for one thing; a little of this, a little of that, and a balanced texture of sincerity, worry and charm. One story may leave a viewer cold, but another story is coming up soon. ABC's ''20/20'' is a successful magazine show. Consider the program on Channel 7 at 10 tonight.

title: TEAM INC reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
description: b-Net income. c-After a writedown of $1.3 million primarily on its oil field services and products business and additional charges of $570,000 to general and administrative expenses.

title: BUTLER MANUFACTURING CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
FIRST AMERICAN BANK & TRUST reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
CAMERON IRON WORKS reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Good and Bad in Our Vanishing Regulatory Agencies
description: To the Editor:

title: WASHINGTON FEDERAL SAVINGS & LOAN ASSN (DC)(O) reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
GETTING IN: A MATTER OF PATIENCE AND PRIORITY
description: There are about as many people on the waiting list for public housing in New York City as live in Washington.

title: Stock Firms' Capital Rises
description: The capital of Wall Street's 10 largest brokerage houses jumped 30 percent in 1985 to $14.68 billion at the end of the year, reflecting the huge increase in earnings of many firms and the favorable market for raising fresh capital, according to preliminary figures issued by the Securities Industry Association yesterday.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: A PERFECT SPY. John le Carre. 475 pages. Knopf. $18.95.

title: MUSIC: ALL-CZECHOSLOVAK PROGRAM
description: THE New York Philharmonic has an all-Czechoslovak program at Avery Fisher Hall this month, and its schedule seems downright serpentine. First heard on Saturday evening, it was repeated on Tuesday and will be given again on the next two Tuesday nights with Friday afternoon, April 18, in between.

title: Unocal Job Trims
description: A continuing drop in oil prices has prompted the Unocal Corporation to try to pare its work force with an early retirement offer that it expects to attract about 1,000 of the 1,600 eligible workers.

title: Comings and Goings
description: The former heavyweight champion, Larry Holmes, has apologized for questioning the integrity of Nevada fight judges, saying he had no intention of offending anyone when he claimed in a television interview last week that the judges drank before fights and accepted payoffs. Holmes meets Michael Spinks in a title rematch April 19 in Las Vegas, Nev. . . . Jimmy Connors will not be invited to this year's 100th Beckenham grass court tournament in England, according to organizers, because of the 10-week ban he incurred after defaulting during a semifinal against Ivan Lendl at the Lipton International in Florida. The suspension covers the June 2-8 tournament.

title: A Plea on New Flights
description: Prime Minister Nakasone, in an unusual personal appeal that cites his ''great political difficulties,'' has called on President Reagan to allow additional flights to the United States for a new Japanese air freight carrier owned by major Japanese financial interests.

title: What Makes Housing Cost So Much to Build
description: To the Editor:

title: FRISCH'S RESTAURANTS INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 9
WHALERS TOP NORDIQUES IN OVERTIME, 3-2
description: Sylvain Turgeon, who led the Whalers with 45 goals during the regular season, scored 2 minutes 36 seconds into overtime tonight to give Hartford an upset 3-2 triumph over the Quebec Nordiques at the Colisee.

title: STATE TAKES OVER BROOKLYN CREDIT UNION
description: State banking officials yesterday took control of the Brooklyn credit union whose officers are under investigation for possible misuse of millions of dollars and for business ties with City Taxi Commission officials and the former Taxi Commissioner, Jay L. Turoff.

title: CABBIES' PROTEST AGAINST AGENCY TANGLES TRAFFIC
description: Horns blaring and fists waving, hundreds of New York cabdrivers clogged the streets around City Hall yesterday to protest the policies and practices of the agency that regulates the taxi industry.

title: 9TH FRENCHMAN MISSING IN BEIRUT
description: A French citizen was reported kidnapped in West Beirut today, bringing to nine the number of Frenchmen who have disappeared here in the last 14 months.

title: Well-Connected Writer
description: His byline is Ron Reagan. ''As long as Ron has a relative working for the Government,'' the executive editor of Playboy, G. Barry Golson, said, ''it's O.K. - if he's also a good writer.''

title: J.P. MORGAN PROFITS UP 42.1% IN QUARTER
description: J. P. Morgan & Company, parent of the Morgan Guaranty Trust Company, said yesterday that its earnings soared 42.1 percent in the first quarter. It attributed the increase to a sizable jump in non-interest income, and Wall Street analysts were impressed by Morgan's ability to realize such gains.

title: CITY NATIONAL reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
LITERARY FOLK LOOK FOR SOLID COMFORT
description: ''READING is an intimate act, perhaps more intimate than any other human act,'' says Harold Brodkey, a writer who has been known to stay home with a good book or even a bad book. He lives on the 14th floor of an Upper West Side apartment building and often reads on a futon that sits on a platform in front of a window. From time to time he glances up from his reading and out the window in order to exercise a different set of eye muscles. He can see birds, clouds in the distance and a little bit of New Jersey. ''Once I saw a hawk kill a pigeon,'' he said. ''Of course, I may have made it up.'' Mr. Brodkey, whose short stories appear in The New Yorker, has two other reading spots - a wing chair, if he is feeling formal, and an early 19th-century country bed, if he is tired. He prefers to read by natural light or in the ''clouds of light'' produced by high-intensity halogen lamps. To ease his back, he tries to remember to vary his reading position at the end of each chap>ter. ''But I like being prone and holding the book up,'' he says. ''These are old habits.

title: Gruppo Editoriale To Test U.S. Waters
description: Enrico Pistolese, who heads up Gruppo Editoriale Crochet in Milan, Italy, is going to introduce a number of his magazines into the United States this year.

title: PEOPLE'S LIAISON BUREAUS, QADDAFI OUTPOSTS, ARE TROUBLE SPOTS
description: The people's liaison bureaus, or embassies, of Libya do not operate by the pin-stripe diplomatic code of the the Vienna Convention.

title: Trade Plan Wins in Panel
description: Trade legislation intended to open overseas markets to the American telecommunications industry cleared a committee hurdle today. The 33-to-2 vote in the House Ways and Means Committee was seen as a rebuff to the Reagan Administration.

title: A TAKEOVER WAVE IN CANADA
description: Just as takeover fever gripped the United States last year, Canada is rife these days with news of hostile takeover bids and hastily arranged corporate marriages. In recent weeks powerful investors, including the Reichmann and Belzberg families and Canada's largest tobacco company, have gone after major corporate targets in Canada and the United States.

title: MANILA CABINET CONSIDERS SCRAPPING ATOMIC PLANT
description: The Government of President Corazon C. Aquino is considering halting construction of a $2.1 billion nuclear power plant and taking its American manufacturer to court to scrap the contract.

title: MARCOS, IN INTERVIEW, SAYS HE'S LESS BITTER AND JOKES ABOUT WIFE'S SHOES
description: Over a lunch of Philippine greens and boiled meat, Ferdinand E. Marcos joked that if all else failed he could open a second-hand shoe store with the 3,000 pairs of his wife's shoes found in his palace in Manila.

title: A 90'S FORECAST: WIDE GAINS IN JOBS
description: The New York-New Jersey metropolitan region will gain nearly 600,000 jobs over the next decade and approach what many economists traditionally have considered full employment, according to an economic forecast released yesterday by the Port Authority.

title: TRANSIT POLICE ACT ON CRIME INCREASE
description: Felony crime in the city's subways increased 10.6 percent in the first three months of 1986, and extra officers will be assigned on overtime starting today to combat the rise, the transit police said yesterday.

title: FRIEDMAN CASE RAISES DOUBLE JEOPARDY ISSUE
description: The state and Federal indictments of Stanley M. Friedman and a business associate raise the complex legal question of whether they be prosecuted twice.

title: FIRST OHIO BANCSHARES reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Levine Wins Sport Account
description: Donald E. Hanrahan, one-time professional basketball player and longtime publisher of Sport magazine, led one of the groups that has purchased the magazine from Ray Hunt's Dallas-based Sports Media Corporation. Levine, Huntley, Schmidt &

title: Now Hear This
description: What hath Jim McMahon wrought? A touch of madness, from the sound of a promotion cooked up by the Chicago White Sox. Sunday has been declared Musical Headband Day at Comiskey Park, where fans will receive headbands that at the touch of a button will play the unofficial Sox theme, ''Na Na Hey Hey (Goodbye).''

title: UNITED ARTISTS COMMUNICAIONS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 27
description: Results include pre-tax gains on disposal of property of $3,094,000 for the latest quarter and $3,603,000 for the latest 6 months, compared with $263,000 and $3,074,000 for the year- earlier quarter and 6 months, respectively.

title: Cynthia Ozick Chosen For Short-Story Award
description: Cynthia Ozick has been named to receive the first $25,000 Rea Award for the Short Story. The award is scheduled to be given annually to a living American writer whose short stories ''have made a significant contribution to this art form.''

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: THURSDAY, APRIL 10, 1986
description: The Economy

title: PENOBSCOT SHOE CO reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
description: b-Net loss

title: Surgeon Who Operated On Reagan Is Suspended
description: The doctor who was credited with saving President Reagan's life after he was shot in 1981 is under investigation in the death of a patient last month at George Washington University Hospital, according to a spokesman there.

title: Calling Watchdogs On the Watchdogs
description: Conservation groups frequently play a watchdog role in this city, keeping a sharp eye on Government to make sure the environmental laws are followed to the letter. But now the tables have turned. Two members of Congress have asked the Congressional watchdog agency, the General Accounting Office, to investigate the influence exercised by environmental groups.

title: PROGRAM WAS BEGUN TO STOP VIOLATORS OF CITY PARKING LAW
description: When Mayor Koch announced ''Operation Scofflock'' last year at a City Hall news conference, he described it as a major enforcement program to crack down on ''hard-core'' parking violators.

title: MORGAN, J P & CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The net investment securities gains in the latest first quarter rose to $58.1 million from $7.1 million in year- earlier period.

title: Decline in Rates Spurs Issues
description: Short- and long-term interest rates declined yesterday and the corporate bond market was flooded with new issues as credit market participants became more convinced that the Federal Reserve will soon ease monetary policy a notch.

title: Quake Rattles Greece
description: An earthquake registering 4.3 on the Richter scale jolted western Greece today, but no damage or injuries were reported, the Athens Seismological Institute said.

title: Education Financing Is Begun by Alabama
description: The Alabama Public School and College Authority is offering $310 million of bonds with yields ranging from 4.25 percent in 1986 to 5.75 percent in 1991, 6.50 percent in 1996 and 7.10 percent in 2005 through underwriters led by Merrill Lynch Capital Markets..

title: ABBOTT LABORATORIES reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes losses on foreign exchange of $4,381,000 for the latest quarter and $362,000 for the year- earlier period. c-Includes a gain from an accounting change of $4.4 million, or 4 cents a share.

title: MEHTA PLANS SABBATICAL
description: Zubin Mehta, music director of the New York Philharmonic, will take a yearlong sabbatical beginning in January, the orchestra announced yesterday.

title: CHIRAC PLANS TO SELL STATE-OWNED COMPANIES
description: Prime Minister Jacques Chirac, in his first major public statement since taking office two weeks ago, said today that his Government would move quickly to return nationalized industries to private hands, reduce regulation, and increase the powers of the police to fight crime.

title: ISC SYSTEMS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 28
NAKASONE SEES TRADE TURNABOUT
description: Prime Minister Yasuhiro Nakasone predicted today that Japan's exports would stop growing by next fall as a result of the suddenly stronger yen and ''we will begin to see an increase in imports.''

title: BARNETT BANKS OF FLA reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
TAX PANEL VOTES TO KEEP OIL-GAS-TIMBER BENEFITS
description: In its first conclusive action on tax-revision legislation, the Senate Finance Committee voted today to retain all the special tax breaks now enjoyed by the oil, gas and timber industries.

title: Illegal Explosives Cited In Fire Fatal to 9
description: An illegal explosives factory disguised as a computer store was the principal cause of the explosion and fire that demolished a block-square industrial complex and killed up to nine people, the authorities said today.

title: U.S. SCIENCE GROUP IN SAKHAROV PLEA
description: The National Academy of Sciences announced today that it had urged the Soviet Academy of Sciences to help improve the condition of Andrei D. Sakharov, the nuclear physicist and political activist who has been in internal exile in the Volga River city of Gorky since 1980.

title: NEW JERSEY NATIONAL reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The per share earnings reflect a 3-for-2 stock split paid March 31.

title: Worthwhile Canadian Initiative
description: Canada is asking for negotiations on a free-trade zone with the United States. Few in the U.S. have paid attention, but it is an enormous issue here.

title: The Russians Are Still Coming
description: President Reagan has been turning up the pressure against Soviet clients in Libya, Nicaragua, Angola and Afghanistan and hanging tough against Soviet demands for a test-ban moratorium. The Soviet leader, Mikhail Gorbachev, has been floating a series of arms control proposals calculated to divide the Western alliance and hinting that he won't accept another broad summit agenda. Yet he now signals that he intends to visit Mr. Reagan this year after all, as agreed at the Geneva summit meeting. The Russians are still coming. To the pugilists in the Pentagon, this portends an American ascendancy that ought to be exploited. They would press ahead with heavy military budgets and ''Star Wars,'' cancel old arms agreements, avoid new ones and raise the stakes in regional conflicts.

title: A Quick Fix In Nicaragua?
description: The Reagan Administration's proposal to send $100 million worth of aid to the contras may be occupying much of the Nicaraguan public's attention, but there is the occasional distraction. The latest is a suggestion of scandal that has beset the waning baseball season in Nicaragua, where passion for the sport is such that it's at least as big a national pastime as it is in the States.

title: DEFENDANT KNEW OF 21 DOUBLE AGENTS, JURY HEARS
description: Richard Craig Smith, a former Army civilian intelligence official charged with espionage, either controlled or had full knowledge of 21 double-agent operations, his onetime Army superviser testified today.

title: MANPOWER INC reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
description: b-Net loss and includes a loss from discontinued operations of $7,165,000. c-Includes a loss from discontinued operations of $51,327,000. d-Net income and includes a loss from discontinued operations of $10,467,000.

title: On Target
description: Coach Doug Moe tosses a salute of sorts to the Denver Nuggets' Bill Hanzlik, who's still noted more for his defense than for his improved offense: ''He's a 100-percent shooter -75 in practice and 25 in games.''

title: REPORT WARNS U.S. ON STATE OF PHYSICS RESEARCH
description: A survey on the state of physics says a series of important discoveries may await the world in the 1990's, but the study warns that a critical shortage of qualified physicists and physics teachers will severely impede the required research in the United States.

title: Richardson Moves On
description: In a transaction involving former major leaguers, the Yankee second baseman Bobby Richardson has resigned as Coastal Carolina baseball coach, effective July 1, to take over the baseball program at Liberty University, succeeding Al Worthington, the Giants and Minnesota Twins pitcher, who has moved up to athletic director at Liberty. Richardson said he was leaving the school in Conway, S.C., because of differences he had with Chancellor Ron Eaglin and a concern that his job was not secure.

title: BLAST BLAMED IN MEXICAN CRASH
description: A senior Mexican Government aviation official said today that the crash of a Mexicana Airlines jet last month appeared to have been caused by an explosion.

title: Contac Coming Back Next Fall
description: Contac, the cold medicine that was pulled from store shelves last month because of tampering, will be reintroduced next fall, according to the SmithKline Beckman Corporation. Contac will still be available in capsules as well as new forms, including tablets, Jeremy Heymsfeld, a company spokesman, said Tuesday.

title: Western Group Urges Steps for Latin Peace
description: A panel of 60 private citizens in the Western Hemisphere called on the United States today to end its support for Nicaraguan rebels and also urged the Sandinista Government to renounce subversion and reduce its military ties to the Soviet bloc.

title: HYDE ATHLETIC INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-Net income

title: For Vietnam Veterans, the War Refuses to End
description: To the Editor:

title: BILL TO CURB ACID RAIN POLLUTION GAINS BROAD SUPPORT IN HOUSE
description: A nonpartisan coalition of members of the House of Representatives plans to introduce legislation Thursday to impose strict curbs on the pollution that causes acid rain.

title: Ribbons at Javits Center
description: The Jacob K. Javits Convention Center, which over the last week has been celebrated and opened, yesterday got what no publicly financed project is ever without - a formal ribbon-cutting, with speeches by scores of officials.

title: National Gypsum
description: The National Gypsum Company said it had adjourned until April 25 a stockholders meeting scheduled for Thursday.

title: GREEK JEWS CHALLENGING WALDHEIM
description: Jewish leaders in Greece today challenged assertions by Kurt Waldheim, the former United Nations Secretary General, that he had been unaware of the deportation of the Jews of Salonika and the rest of Greece.

title: McDONALD'S SWITCHING TO 'OLD' COKE FORMULA
