description: Coca-Cola Classic has been given a resounding vote of confidence, at the expense of ''new'' Coke. The McDonald's Corporation, the nation's largest fountain service user of Coke, confirmed today that it would switch from ''new'' Coke to Coke Classic effective April 28.

title: MONETARY PLAN URGED BY BAKER
description: Saying that ''we need to improve the functioning'' of the world's currency market, Treasury Secretary James A. Baker 3d today offered a prescription for a more regulated monetary system.

title: LAROUCHE SEES RISING TIDE OF VOTER SUPPORT
description: Lyndon H. LaRouche Jr., leader of an extremist political movement that succeeded in capturing two statewide nominations in last month's Democratic primary in Illinois, today predicted a rising tide of support from voters who ''want me to stick it to Washington.''

title: CONSOLIDATED PAPERS INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
WESTINGHOUSE ELECTRIC CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
INTERNATIONAL INFORMATION NETWORK reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income

title: PRIMAGES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Punjab Police Chief Vows 4-to-1 Vengeance
description: Punjab's new police chief vowed today over the body of a slain policeman to take four lives for every police officer killed by Sikh extremists.

title: Chairman Resigns At Columbia Studio
description: Guy McElwaine, chairman and chief executive officer of Columbia Pictures, resigned yesterday. The resignation was no surprise to the movie industry, which has been waiting for the other shoe to drop at Columbia for the last nine months.

title: Serious Bent Ascribed To Ally-MCA Talks
description: The acquisition discussions going on between Ally & Gargano, a publicly held company, and MCA Advertising, a subsidiary of the privately held Marketing Corporation of America, were characterized as serious yesterday by Amil Gargano, chairman of the former agency, which is currently billing at the rate of $130 million.

title: New York State Spring Borrowing
description: Interest rates at this year's spring borrowing by New York State were the lowest since 1977, but still offered many investors a greater after-tax yield than is available on high-quality short-term investments whose interest is subject to Federal, state and city income tax.

title: Confederate Recognition on Capitol Hill
description: It has been 121 years to the day since Lee surrendered to Grant at Appomattox, ending the Civil War. So if it was not coincidence, it nevertheless seemed fitting when the Senate took a small step Tuesday toward further reconciliation of North and South.

title: PRESIDENT'S NEWS CONFERENCE ON FOREIGN AND DOMESTIC ISSUES
description: Following is a transcript of President Reagan's news conference last night in Washington, as recorded by The New York Times:

title: FIGURE IN ANOTHER CASE IS BLAMED
description: John Gotti, the reputed crime boss, was leaving the Federal Courthouse in Brooklyn yesterday morning after a telephoned bomb threat forced the evacuation of the building. Turning to a friend, he said: ''Tell them it's not me. They'll be blaming this one on me.'' A little later, a police spokesman, Officer Joseph McConville, said the threat to ''blow up'' the courthouse had come from a man who identified himself as John Gotti, who law-enforcement officials say is the head of the Gambino crime family. Still later, Charles E. Healey, the United States Marshal in Brooklyn, identified the caller as a hospitalized mental patient, Alexander J. Galka, 52 years old.

title: Ford Incentives
description: The Ford Motor Company said it would end its discounted financing loan incentive program next Wednesday. The program, in effect since Feb. 26, offers 9.9 percent loans on several car and light-truck models and 7.7 percent financing on several subcompact cars. The General Motors Corporation announced earlier that its financing program would end April 12.

title: OFF-DUTY CORRECTION OFFICER KILLS 2 MEN HE SAYS TRIED TO ROB HIM
description: An off-duty New York State correction officer shot and killed two apparently unarmed men who tried to rob him on a Brooklyn street early yesterday, the police said.

title: SPEARHEAD INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
BRANCH CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
LIGHT BULBS THAT CAN MAKE A DIFFERENCE
description: OF the three kinds of bulbs on the market, standard incandescent, halogen incandescent and fluorescent, some are better for reading than others.

title: EUROPEAN WARN U.S. OF FOOD TRADE CURBS
description: The European Economic Community, raising the stakes in a trade dispute with the United States, today announced retaliatory measures it will take if Washington carries out its threat to impose new restrictions on imports of certain European agricultural goods.

title: PRESENT CO reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 1
A CHANNEL 4 PROGRAM FOR AND ABOUT 'KIDS'
description: ''KIDS JUST KIDS,'' a winning half-hour program for young people, intermittently shown, will be seen on Channel 4 at 7:30 P.M. This will be only its seventh presentation. Why doesn't it turn up more often?

title: MILLER, HERMAN INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 1
PHILLIES DEFEAT REDS IN 11th, 5-3
description: Glenn Wilson broke a 1-1 tie with a sacrifice fly in the 11th inning and John Russell followed with a two-run homer tonight to give the Philadelphia Phillies a 5-3 victory over the Cincinnati Reds.

title: Freedom Fighters
description: I have in front of me some clippings from Swiss newspapers, the text of a brief speech, a snapshot. They tell a story that is difficult to write.

title: U.S. TRUST reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
New York City Should Not Lead Its Employees Into Temptation
description: To the Editor:

title: Oil Prices Turn Upward After Gasoline Report
description: Prices of crude oil and petroleum products made moderate gains yesterday for their second turnaround in two days.

title: LIMITS ON EX-AIDES' LOBBYING TO BE SOUGHT
description: The chairman of the Senate Judiciary Committee said today that he planned to introduce legislation severely restricting lobbying by former high-ranking Government officials.

title: 5 LINKED TO GAMBINO FAMILY SENTENCED IN A CAR-THEFT RING
description: Five reputed members of the Gambino organized-crime family received the maximum sentences yesterday for their roles in an international car-theft ring.

title: Inland Steel Buys Tull
description: The Inland Steel Company of Chicago announced yesterday that it had agreed to buy Tull Industries, a Southern steel distributor, from the Bethlehem Steel Corporation for $100 million.

title: ISRAELI EXAMINES U.N. FILE ON WALDHEIM
description: An Israeli diplomat examined a secret United Nations file on Kurt Waldheim today and said afterward that there was ''clear need for further comprehensive investigation'' of Mr. Waldheim's war record.

title: LIBYA SAYS U.S. ATTACK WOULD BRING RESPONSE
description: Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi said today that if the United States attacked Libya, he would issue orders for attacks against American targets worldwide.

title: A Winning Diet
description: When last we looked in on George Martens, the 1981 Belmont Stakes winner had just resumed his riding career at Aqueduct after a three-year weight problem that had seen him balloon to as much as 137 pounds (Scouting, April 5). Yesterday, he had his third mount since his return, and he made it a memorable one. The horse was Mr. Van Dell, who, though never a winner in six prior career starts, triumphed by three-quarters of a length and rewarded followers of the previously overweight Martens with a portly payoff of $77.

title: NO TAINTED WINE YET FOUND IN U.S.
description: The inspection of Italian wines has been stepped up in the United States since reports of deaths were received from Italy last week, a Federal official said today. But so far no evidence has been found of contaminated wines in this country.

title: DANCE: TAYLOR'S 'MUSICAL OFFERING'
description: EVERY time Paul Taylor and Johann Sebastian Bach get together, the result, to put it mildly, is a surprise. The collaboration, of course, comes through the music rather than any ghostly communing over the centuries.

title: Incentives, Not Sanctions, for Poland
description: American relations with Poland, at a standstill since martial law was declared in December 1981, have begun to inch forward. The United States' substantial political and economic stakes in Poland encourage us to move toward more normal relations by ending economic sanctions and extending Western credits to ease Poland's $30 billion debt. But such steps would also raise serious questions about Washington's commitment to Polish human rights.

title: Programs That Design Chips
description: WILL computers be used to design other computers? That is the purpose of computer systems that design computer chips. The systems are known as silicon compilers -programs that act like a trusted assistant. Give the compilers a general idea of what you want them to do and they will take care of the details.

title: CITY FORCES CLUBS TO RESTRICT JAZZ
description: Saxophones and drums are out, pianos and guitars are in at the Angry Squire and the West End Cafe, two long-running jazz clubs that changed their music policies yesterday. The clubs, both of which have booked jazz quartets and quintets for more than a decade, were fined for operating without cabaret licenses after inspection by the city's Department of Consumer Affairs.

title: SILVER STATE MINING CORPORATION reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: The previous year's results include a gain of $417,471 on the sale of assets.

title: Brooklyn Boy Charged In Shooting of a Friend
description: A 14-year-old Brooklyn boy was charged with second-degree murder yesterday and is to be prosecuted as an adult in the fatal shooting of a 12-year-old friend, according to the Brooklyn District Attorney.

title: Catholicism, Liberation and Democracy
description: Two years ago, exponents of the ''theology of liberation'' worried that they were about to become casualties in a new Vatican campaign to enforce orthodoxy in the Roman Catholic Church. Now, following the publication last weekend of Rome's second statement on the subject, the teaching appears to have won cautious acceptance from Pope John Paul II.

title: Dr. Ira V. Hiscock, Ex-Head Of Yale's Public Health Unit
description: Dr. Ira V. Hiscock, a leading authority on public health and a member of the Yale University faculty for 40 years, died last Friday at his home in Doylestown, Pa. He was 94 years old.

title: U.S. PLAN FOR DAIRY MARKET PUTS BEEF INDUSTRY IN A VISE
description: The Federal program to reduce dairy surpluses by slaughtering cows has wreaked havoc with the cattle industry and depressed beef prices far beyond expectations, cattle ranchers say.

title: Congress; More Lessons in the Secrecy Trade
description: Rumors swirled around Capitol Hill Tuesday that the Reagan Administration was planning a major attack against Libyan-based terrorists, reported Senator Dave Durenberger. So when Republican leaders met with the President at the White House this morning, ''half the people in the room expected him to say something about Libya,'' said Mr. Durenberger, who heads the intelligence committee.

title: ACADEMIC APPROACH TO LANES
description: It is called ''The Physics of a Bowling Ball Going Down the Lane,'' and, says an amused Walter Ray Williams Jr., no one else but him on the bowling tour understands it.

title: FAMILY DOLLAR STORES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
TRANSCRIPT OF PRESIDENT'S SESSION WITH NEWSPAPER EDITORS
description: Following is a transcript of President Reagan's address to the American Society of Newspaper Editors in Washington yesterday and questions and answers, as recorded by The New York Times through the facilities of Cable News Network:

title: RAYTHEON CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
ALEXANDER & BALDWIN INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
California Cooler Ads Go Macho
description: AT first glance, each of the five new spots for California Cooler might strike you as ''just another bouncy soft drink lifestyle commercial.'' But there is more to them than that.

title: WHIRLPOOL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Ads Promoting Ads
description: Joseph J. Hanson, chairman of the board of Inside Print magazine, which grew out of the acquired Magazine Age, has prepared an advertising campaign to promote advertising in print he is offering to magazine and newspaper publishers for their own use. It is a form of public relations aimed at the target audience of his trade publication. In addition to the offer being made via direct mail to more than 2,000 publishers, Mr. Hanson is spreading the word that the ads are available.

title: HOME BEAT
description: INCREDIBLY, the wood ceiling was already there, as were the slim solid cherry columns. But it was up to Robert Currie, far left, to incorporate the elements in his striking design of the new Luten Clarey Stern, a to-the-trade furniture and fabrics showroom.

title: AN OUSTER AT GROVE PRESS RAISES WRITERS' IRE
description: Barney Rosset has been removed as president and chief executive officer of Grove Press, the avant-garde book publishing company he founded in Greenwich Village in 1951, and news of his ouster immediately sparked complaints from authors and literary agents.

title: CITYTRUST BANCORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
WEIS MARKETS INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
DOW GAINS 8.86 AFTER WIDE SWINGS
description: Stock prices closed moderately higher yesterday after fluctuating wildly.

title: WHAT SUITORS SAW IN ALAMITO
description: Until a few months ago, the Alamito Company was an obscure electricity wholesaler in Tucson, Ariz. But then a frenzied takeover battle suddenly turned it into one of the most sought-after utilities in the country.

title: Morgan Securities Unit Expects a Challenge
description: David W. Fisher, the freshly named president of J.P. Morgan Securities Inc., a new subsidiary of J.P. Morgan & Company, takes a modest view of the unit, saying it ''really isn't a very big deal.''

title: TIDEWATER CLAIMS GARDENHIRE AND SISK
description: The Mets survived their self-inflicted roster crisis today when Doug Sisk and Ron Gardenhire cleared waivers without being claimed by other teams.

title: CORRECTION
description: Because of an editing error, a brief dispatch yesterday from Easton, Pa., about a killing in a dormitory misidentified the victim's college affiliation, and the headline misstated the murder site. The killing occurred at Lehigh University in Bethlehem, not at Bryn Mawr College. The victim, a freshman at Lehigh, resided in Bryn Mawr, Pa.

title: PRESIDENT ACCUSES CONGRESS OF DRAGGING FEET ON BUDGET
description: President Reagan tonight accused Congress of dragging its feet on a 1987 budget, asserting that lawmakers appeared unable to break a 50-year habit of ''running up debt.''

title: Yield Fall Continues
description: Yields on certificates of deposit, bank money market accounts and money market mutual funds fell for the fifth consecutive week in the period ended yesterday.

title: PLANNED AUCTION OF A GOYA IS DEBATED
description: The auction of Goya's ''Marquessa de Santa Cruz,'' scheduled in London for tomorrow, has stirred up unusually strong international criticism among art dealers, museum curators and government officials. They object to the sale because there are questions about its export from Spain.

title: KEY PROVISION OF BUDGET-BALANCING ACT ASSAILED
description: The Justice Department urged the Supreme Court today to strike down the central provision of the budget-balancing law as a Congressional invasion of the President's constitutional authority.

title: CLAROSTAT MANUFACTURING CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 29
STUDENT LOAN MARKETING ASSN reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Court Denies Challenge To U.P.I. Financial Plan
description: A Federal bankruptcy judge dismissed a challenge to United Press International's financial reorganization plan Tuesday, moving the sale of the news agency to Mexico's largest publisher one step closer to fulfillment.

title: Art Swap
description: At the Solomon R. Guggenheim Museum on Fifth Avenue, at 88th Street, an institution associated closely with the works of Kandinsky, there is not a single Kandinsky on view. In addition, there are none of the museum's cherished collection of Mondrians, Chagalls and Klees to be seen.

title: Spurs in Playoffs
description: Mike Mitchell scored 22 points tonight to help the San Antonio Spurs beat the Phoenix Suns, 114-102, and clinch the eighth and final playoff berth in the Western Conference. The loss eliminated Phoenix (30-49) from playoff contention for the first time in nine seasons. San Antonio is heading for the playoffs despite a 34-47 record, the worst in the history of the franchise.

title: New Boeing Order
description: KLM Royal Dutch Airlines and the Boeing Commercial Airplane Company said that the Netherlands carrier had ordered six new 747-400 jetliners in a deal valued at about $900 million.

title: CARRIERS STAY AT SEA
description: The Reagan Administration is positioning itself for possible military action against Libya by retaining two aircraft carriers in the Mediterranean, Administration officials said today.

title: FRIGITRONICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
Samuel Rothstein, 82, Dies; Ex-Leader of Jewish Groups
description: Samuel Rothstein, a lay leader of world Jewry and former president of the United Synagogues of America, died of a heart attack Monday at his home in Belvedere, Calif. He was 82 years old.

title: Mislabeled Aspirin Recalled
description: A shipment of children's chewable aspirin that was mistakenly labeled as an aspirin substitute, acetaminophen, is being recalled by its manufacturer, the Food and Drug Administration said today. The agency said Gendex Inc. of Jersey City was recalling 216 thousand-tablet bottles of aspirin that were sent to the H. L. Moore Company of New Britain, Conn. The agency said it was concerned lest the mislabeled product be given to a child sensitive to aspirin.

title: ROBERTSHAW CONTROLS CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Ulster Protestant Urges End to Attacks on Police
description: The Rev. Ian Paisley, a leader of hard-line Protestants, today urged an end to nine days of Protestant attacks on the police in Northern Ireland.

title: THE U.S.S. KENNEDY WILL STILL PARTICIPATE IN STATUE FESTIVITIES
description: The carrier John F. Kennedy will be in New York Harbor for the Statue of Liberty centennial on the Fourth of July weekend, even though she will not be used for the opening-night ceremony, as had originally been announced, a Navy spokesman said yesterday.

title: GIMBELS GIRDS FOR TAKEOVER
description: Gimbels East, the 20-store group in New York and Philadelphia, has sharply cut back its orders for merchandise in anticipation of a sale of the troubled department store division, a spokesman for Batus Inc., the holding company, said yesterday in Louisville, Ky.

title: June Summit Talks? Reagan Is Doubtful
description: President Reagan expressed doubt tonight that he would meet in June with Mikhail S. Gorbachev, the Soviet leader, and said that July or late Autumn were possible times for a United States-Soviet summit meeting.

title: NOVUS PROPERTY reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income c-Includes a tax credit of $1,033,000, or 54 cents a share. The company said its prior year revenue and earnings also includes $30 million and $15 million, respectivley, arising from the recognition in 1984 of revenue on transactions initiated in 1983. The company is 87 percent owned by Southmark Corp.

title: BALLESTEROS IS 'READY TO WIN'
description: Seve Ballesteros said he felt good about his game and was ''ready to win'' the 50th Masters Tournament, which opens with a field of 88 golfers Thursday at Augusta National Golf Club.

title: GRACE IS NEGOTIATING SALE OF RETAIL STORES
description: W. R. Grace & Company said yesterday that it was negotiating to sell the nation's largest group of home-improvement stores and several specialty store chains to an investment group headed by David Mahoney, the former chairman of Norton Simon Inc., and Harold Geneen, the former chairman of the ITT Corporation, for $500 million.

title: PROPOSED AUCTION RULES WOULD REVEAL NO-SALES
description: New York City's Department of Consumer Affairs has proposed a regulation requiring auction houses to announce immediately after bidding if a work of art was not sold, thus ending the common industry practice of leaving the results of sales unclear at the end of rounds of bidding.

title: Texas American
description: Texas American Bancshares, worried by both the recent drop and the future of oil prices, has predicted a first-quarter net loss of about $22 million, compared with a $7.5 million profit in the same period last year. The expected loss largely reflects a fourfold increase in its reserve against loan losses to $44 million, from $11 million in the first quarter of 1985. The regular quarterly dividend will be cut to 25 cents a share, from 38 cents a share.

title: Motor Homes: Analysts Wary
description: CHEAP gasoline, the experts say, should mean a big increase this year in the number of recreational vehicles sold in the United States to vacation-hungry Americans worried about terrorism overseas.

title: FOR A PERIPATETIC BOOKWORM, THE QUEST FOR A PROPER PLACE
description: WHAT to read is never a problem. Lifelong, instinctive, inbuilt priorities guide us. What not to read is not a problem, either. An early warning system - unknown to science, but none the less effective for that - takes care of it. As for what to reread, that too is easy, except that the list gets longer every year. (The American expatriate writer Logan Pearsall Smith wanted the words ''Thrice did he read Saint-Simon'' to be put on his tombstone, so rare was the boast.) But where to read? To that question all answers are personal, and reveal something of our inmost nature. It is my own feeling - once again, unsanctioned by science - that in this matter there is such a thing as a primal posture. Anyone who has been around clever children will have noticed that when they settle in to read they instinctively lie flat on the floor, fronts down. It is as if they drew strength from the earth, like Antaeus, and poured it back into the act of reading.

title: WINNERS' CRAFT WORK DISPLAYED
description: AN exhibition of the work of 10 craftsmen who won New York State art awards opens today at the Carlyn Gallery. This is the first time fellowships in the category of crafts have been awarded by the New York Foundation for the Arts.

title: CORRECTION
description: A Houston dispatch last Thursday on astronauts in the National Aeronautics and Space Administration incorrectly described the career plans of Bruce McCandless 2d, a veteran astronaut. He says he intends to remain with the agency for the foreseeable future.

title: TELEDYNE INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The latest first quarter included a $4 million gain from sale of investments, compared with a similar gain of $91.6 million a year ago.

title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT ANSWERS
description: Often an event captures headlines, then fades from view with important questions unanswered - questions that defy news reporting, at least for a while. This column periodically offers a selection of such questions.

title: CHALLENGER BLAST LEFT CABIN INTACT
description: The crew cabin survived the explosion of the space shuttle Challenger and plunged through the atmosphere intact until it struck the ocean, a chief Federal safety inspector said today. Then, he said, it broke apart on impact.

title: RIVER FOREST BANCORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
SPI PHARMACEUTICALS reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
NEW LIFE ON VIDEO FOR BLACKLISTED FILM
description: ''Salt of the Earth'' has been released on video cassette, and the Communist controversy that caused the film to be blacklisted in 1954 appears to be aiding sales.

title: AIDS RESEARCHERS BEGIN TESTING NEW VERSION OF SMALLPOX VACCINE
description: Scientists have remodeled the most successful of all vaccines and plan to seek approval before the end of the year to test it on humans as a protection against AIDS.

title: TRANSCANADA MAKES BID FOR WALKER
description: The takeover battle for Hiram Walker Resources Ltd. approached a climax yesterday as Canada's No. 1 pipeline operator, Transcanada Pipelines Ltd., offered to pay $26.39 a share, or $3 billion in cash, for the big oil and liquor producer.

title: 2 Army Copters Crash At Georgia Post, Killing 8
description: Two Army helicopters crashed tonight at Fort Stewart Army Base, killing all eight soldiers aboard, an Army spokesman said.

title: WITNESS OFFERS A GRIM PICTURE IN JOHNSON TRIAL
description: A prominent Broadway and Hollywood producer gave a hushed audience in Manhattan Surrogate's Court yesterday a grim but vivid picture of life in the family of his multimillionaire father-in-law, the late J. Seward Johnson, and his third wife, Barbara.

title: DATA TRANSLATION INC reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
DOBRYNIN'S FAREWELL: QUIPS AND CAVIAR
description: After 24 years as the Soviet Ambassador to Washington, Anatoly F. Dobrynin said his official farewells today. He had lunch with Secretary of State George P. Shultz and then was the host of a reception at the Soviet Embassy.

title: Arrest That Peanut
description: If peanuts are subjected to severe heat or cold before curing, they produce alcohol.

title: FIRST BANCORP OF OHIO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
MUSIC: ANDRES SEGOVIA PERFORMS AT FISHER HALL
description: THERE has always been an element of ritual to an Andres Segovia recital. And now, at 93 years old, the pope of the Spanish guitar still attracts audiences for whom his hieratic presence seems its own reward. His followers, intent on every note, direct the kind of angry glances at coughers and other disturbers of the Segovia hush that all heretics deserve. It was that way again Wednesday night at Avery Fisher Hall where Mr. Segovia gave his annual recital, an event that set off standing ovations at every opportunity.

title: An Oil-Import Tax Means Lost U.S. Jobs
description: To the Editor:

title: 'GETTING OFF WELFARE' IS TOPIC OF 'METROLINE'
description: ''METROLINE,'' the Channel 13 series that grapples with issues confronting metropolitan New York, cannot be faulted for not coming up with the answers to the welfare problem. Neither can public officials. ''Getting Off Welfare,'' tonight at 10, belabors the obvious for a very long hour. Despite the presence of a roundelay of professional voices, the sounds they make are despairingly familiar.

title: 2 BRETT HOMERS BEAT YANKS
description: Lou Piniella knew that he would lose a game as manager somewhere along the way this season, but the Yankees hoped that Ed Whitson would be able to win one before too much of the season passed. His first start, they felt, would be ideal.

title: COLUMBIA CHASE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
description: b-Net income The company is listed on the Boston Stock Exchange.

title: EXECUTIVES ADMIT LINK TO MARCOSES
description: After months of denials to the press that they had anything to do with the family of Ferdinand E. Marcos, two New York real estate executives told a House subcommittee today that they managed some $300 million worth of property in New York City for the Marcos family.

title: PIEDMONT FEDERAL SAVINGS & LOAN reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The year ago quarter per share figure is not available since the company converted to a stock form in December 1985.

title: In Rose's Wake
description: Dick Allen, Jim Lefebvre, Tommy Helms, Johnny Bench, Ted Sizemore, Carl Morton, Earl Williams, Jon Matlack, Bake McBride, Butch Metzger and Pat Zachry. What do those players have in common? Simply a barometer of Pete Rose's longevity. Each of them won the National League's Rookie of the Year Award after Rose had won it in 1963, and each of them is now retired.

title: The U.N. Today: April 10, 1986
description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY Human Rights Committee - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: WESTINGHOUSE UP 4.2%
description: The General Electric Company reported yesterday that earnings in the first quarter rose 5 percent on a 5 percent drop in sales.

title: FIRST EASTERN reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
HERS
description: FOR most of my adult life, I have been an emotional hit-and-run driver, that is, a reporter. I made people like me, trust me, open their hearts and their minds to me and cry and bleed onto the pages of my neat little notebooks, and then I went back to a safe place and I made a story out of it. I am good at what I do, and so often the people who read those stories cried too. When they were done they turned the page and when I was done I went on to another person, another story, went from the cop's wife whose husband had never come home to the impoverished 80-year-old Holocaust survivor to the family with the missing child. I stepped in and out of their lives as easily as I did a pair of shoes in the morning, and when I was done I wrote my piece and I went home, to the husband who had not been killed, the bank account that was full, the child safe in his high chair. Sometimes I carried within me, for a day or a week or sometimes even longer, the resonances of their pain. But they were left with the pain itself.

title: Son Succeeds Father As Stephens President
description: Stephens Inc., the quiet, enormously profitable investment banking house based in Little Rock, Ark., has announced that its leadership is passing to the next generation of Stephenses.

title: PRESIDENT DEFENDS RIGHT TO PROTECT AGAINST LEAKS
description: President Reagan said today that the Government had the right to protect itself against leaks of information in instances where American troops are involved in hostilities.

title: AIR MERGER QUESTIONED
description: The Department of Transportation today said the proposed takeover of Eastern Airlines by the Texas Air Corporation ''presents serious competitive issues'' and ordered public hearings on the proposal, starting May 27.

title: REPUBLICANS OPPOSE O'NEILL OVER METHOD OF CONTRA AID VOTE
description: The Administration and House Republicans said today that they were opposed to attaching legislation for aid to the Nicaraguan rebels to an urgent budget measure that Administration officials have said President Reagan would veto.

title: Shumate to Return
description: John Shumate, a former Notre Dame star who spent the last three years as head basketball coach at Grand Canyon College in Phoenix, Ariz., has accepted an offer to return to Notre Dame as an assistant to Digger Phelps, the man who was his head coach there. Shumate, a 1974 all-American who was the Phoenix Suns' first-round draft choice and played seven years in the National Basketball Association, replaces Gary Brokaw, who left Notre Dame to become head coach at Iona.

title: IP TIMBERLANDS LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: IP Timberlands commenced operations on March 14, 1985. Share earnings represent earnings per Class A depositary unit.

title: Plea by Bank Regulators
description: In a joint appeal to Congress today, the Government's three banking regulators asked for new powers to take over weakened institutions before they fail. They also asked for authority to merge a failing bank in one state with a healthy bank in another state, and to include the parent holding company of the failing bank as well as any healthy subsidiaries in the deal.

title: WROTE ADVERTISING COLUMNS
description: Joseph Kaselow, who as advertising columnist for The New York Herald Tribune was required reading in the trade, died of a stroke early yesterday at Valley Hospital in Ridgewood, N.J. Mr. Kaselow, who was 73 years old, entered the hospital last Thursday, after having been injured in a fall. He lived in Glen Rock, N.J.

title: WISE WORDS
description: Edgar Jones of the Cleveland Cavaliers explains why he's loquacious only most of the time: ''You can say so much about so many things so often. But if you do, then you'll be saying nothing about anything all the time.''

title: FOTOMAT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 2
The Subject Is Arms
description: Three influential Senators, two Republicans and a Democrat, will meet today with a former chief arms negotiator to discuss Congressional responses in the event President Reagan decides to breach a limit on missile launchers that was established in the second strategic arms limitation agreement.

title: DEMOCRATS FEAR SCANDALS' EFFECT
description: State Democratic leaders are to meet next week to discuss ways of blunting the impact of the corruption scandals that have enveloped some New York City Democratic leaders and are threatening the party's ''integrity,'' a top party official said yesterday.

title: FLEET FINANCIAL GROUP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The year-ago figures were restated for the acquisitions in March of First Connecticut Bancorp and Merrill Bankshares Co. accounted for as a pooling of interests.

title: COLT INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 30
description: b-Includes income from discontinued operations of $1,224,000, or 6 cents a share.

title: FOR FAMILIES STRUGGLING TO GET BY, CITY PROJECTS OFFER A HOME FOR HOPE
description: The moving van rumbled across Eighth Street, unsettling the quiet of a Saturday morning on the Lower East Side.

title: Key Rates
description: * Municipal Bond Index, The Bond Buyer Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: CELANESE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Sale by Hercules
description: Hercules Inc. said it had sold its 13 percent interest, or about 5.6 million shares, of Erbamont N.V. to Montedison for about $125 million. Montedision, based in Italy, is the principal shareholder of Erbamont, an international pharmaceutical company in Stamford, Conn. Hercules said it had received its Erbamont shares in 1983 in exchange for its 50 percent interest in Adria Laboratories, a joint venture pharmaceutical company of Hercules and Montedison, and as compensation from Montedison in connection with the formation of Himont Inc.

title: LUXURY IN BOTH COMFORT AND PRICE
description: INSPIRED by an ingenious chaise longue and desk devised by Thomas Jefferson for reading and writing, Niels Diffrient has designed this adjustable leather upholstered chair for SunarHauserman. A luxury statement in both comfort and price, the chair and ottoman will cost $5,000 when they become available in June through designers and decorators. Like Jefferson, who invented a two-pen desk copying machine and equipped his chair with candleholders, Mr. Diffrient has also designed work apparatus to accompany the chair: an adjustable lamp and writing table, as shown here, and a swiveling computer table that is to be available in the fall.

title: Case of AIDS Is Traced To Vaginal Intercourse
description: The case of a bisexual man who gave AIDS to his wife, who in turn infected a next-door neighbor, provides additional evidence that the virus can be spread from women to men through vaginal intercourse, a new report concludes.

title: BIG CHARGE EXPECTED BY JOHNSON
description: Johnson & Johnson said yesterday that it expects to report its first quarterly loss ever because of about $600 million in pretax charges against earnings for the first three months of this year.

title: EECO INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net loss

title: JUSTICE DEPT. AIDES FACING AN INQUIRY
description: The United States Attorney for Boston is overseeing an investigation into possible wrongdoing by Justice Department lawyers who decided several years ago to withhold documents of the Environmental Protection Agency from Congress, department officials said today.

title: CORRECTION
description: A picture in Metropolitan Report yesterday with an article about housing in Harlem was published in error. It showed a vacant building oppposite the site where the Harriet Tubman Family Center is being built on West 143d Street, not the Dickens Garden apartment house on West 139th Street.

title: CONCESSIONS AND COMPANY-BY-COMPANY STEEL TALKS
description: The progress of steel industry negotiations so far indicates that company-by-company bargaining, while difficult, can be at least as useful as the unified industry bargaining that went on for three decades. So far, two companies, LTV Steel and National Steel, have reached agreement with the United Steelworkers of America.

title: COMPUTER DATA SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes gains of $184,000, or 6 cents a share, from a cash distribution from building a partnership for the quarter and 9 months.

title: REAGAN PREPARED TO STRIKE IF LIBYA IS TIED TO TERROR
description: President Reagan said tonight that the United States was analyzing intelligence information on Libya and was prepared to strike militarily if evidence pointed directly to Libyan support for terrorists.

title: OFFICIAL FAULTS ACTIONS BY STAFF IN ABUSE CASE
description: A city official, reversing himself, said yesterday that a violation of procedures - not just poor judgment by caseworkers - had caused a two-week delay in notifying the Queens District Attorney about charges of child abuse by members of a religious sect.

title: THURSDAY SPORTS
description: Baseball Yankees vs. Kansas City Royals, at Yankee Stadium, 1:35 P.M. (Television -SportsChannel, 1 P.M. live and 11 P.M. tape. Radio - WABC, 770; 1 P.M.) Mets vs. Pirates, at Pittsburgh, 7:35 P.M. (Television - Channel 9, 7:30 P.M. Radio - WHN, 1050; 7:30 P.M.) Braves vs. Montreal Expos, at Atlanta (Television - WTBS, 7:35 P.M.) Basketball Nets vs. Hawks, at Atlanta. (Radio -WPAT, 930; 7:30 P.M.) Los Angeles Lakers vs. Houston Rockets, at Inglewood, Calif. (Television -WTBS, 10:30 P.M.) Bowling Long Island Open, at Garden City, L.I., Garden City Bowl, Meadowbrook Parkway and Stewart Avenue. Golf The Masters, at Augusta, Ga., opening round. Bernhard Langer of West Germany is the defending champion in this tournament, which has been won by foreigners three of the last four years. (Television - Channel 2, 11:30 P..M. to 11:45 P.M. taped highlights. USA Network, 4 P.M. to 6 P.M. live and 8 P.M. to 10 P.M. tape.) L.P.G.A. Kyocera Inamori Classic, at San Diego, opening round. Hockey Islanders vs. Washington Capitals, at Landover, Md. Game 2 of the Patrick Division semifinal series. (Television -SportsChannel, 7:30 P.M. Radio -WOR, 710; 7:30 P.M.) Rangers vs. Flyers, at Philadelphia. Game 2 of the Patrick Division semifinal series. (Television - MSG Network, 7:30 P.M. Channel 9, 10 P.M. tape delay following the Mets game. Radio -WNBC, 660; 7:30 P.M.) St. Louis Blues vs.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: THURSDAY, APRIL 10, 1986
description: International The U.S. is prepared to strike militarily against Libya if the intelligence information it is studying points directly to Libyan support for terrorists, President Reagan said in a nationally broadcast news conference. Mr. Reagan denounced Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi, the Libyan leader, as the ''mad dog of the Middle East'' and said evidence existed that he had sponsored terrorist acts aimed at Americans. [ Page A1: Column 6. ]

title: Test of Strength
description: When the word got around that Robbie Bosco, the acclaimed Brigham Young quarterback, had ''failed'' an arm strength test at a recent National Football League scouting camp, Bosco, concerned about his chances in the N.F.L. draft, decided to set the record straight. ''The story was sensationalized, blown out of proportion,'' he said.

title: ORDER THAT TOUCHES THE HEART
description: A GARDENER'S eye goes with him everywhere. It lights on landscapes, on pictures, on plants and parts of plants. A cabbage leaf in the gutter sends it a signal. Wallpapers and parkways are equally grist to its mill. It suffers the busy irritation of one environment and enjoys the serenity of another, with the sensibility of one who is involved. It recoils from garbage and morbidity. It is drawn to rich detail, to healthy living matter, and everywhere to green.

title: Javits's Will Filed for Probate
description: Former Senator Jacob K. Javits, who died last month at the age of 81, left most of his estate to his wife, Marion, but directed that $50,000 be spent on the study of his papers at the State University at Stony Brook, L.I.

title: The Editorial Notebook; The Vulnerable Paper City
description: Like any metropolis, New York embraces at least two cities, one concrete and visible, the other paper and generally invisible. The Paper City bursts into view only when something dramatic occurs, like the recent announcement that Warner LeRoy, the restaurateur, has dropped his plan for a restaurant in Bryant Park, above an expansion of the underground stacks of the Public Library.

title: WEST GERMANY IS EXPELLING TWO OF LIBYA'S DIPLOMATS
description: The West German Government announced today that it was expelling two Libyan diplomats for ''activities incompatible with their diplomatic status.''

title: Stay of Execution for Boy, 16
description: A 16-year-old boy believed to be the youngest inmate on death row in the country has been granted a stay of execution while his conviction in a triple slaying is appealed.

title: The Air Force vs. the Yarmulke
description: The yarmulke lost its latest legal battle March 25, when a black-robed but bareheaded Justice William H. Rehnquist announced the Supreme Court's 5-4 decision that the Air Force need not bend its dress code to allow a Jewish officer to wear his yarmulke while on duty.

title: Mexico Gets 4 Loans
description: Mexico signed four loans - worth a total of a $574 million - from the World Bank today. Most of the loans are designed to help finance reconstruction work after last September's devastating earthquake, the Finance Ministry said. The money will go towards repairing 23,700 houses and building 34,300 more, as well as providing 11 hospitals, several schools and patching up 13 municipal markets within the capital.

title: NETS DOWN CELTICS: GMINSKI SCORES 41
description: The week began with the Boston Celtics trying to become the first National Basketball Association team to go through a season without losing to the same opponent more than once. The Philadelphia 76ers ended that bid Sunday with their second victory of the season over Boston. Tonight, with an 108-98 victory at Byrne Meadowlands Arena, the Nets became the second team to beat the Celtics a second time.

title: Charges in Cyanide Death
description: Lewis Allen Harry, 32 years old, has been formally accused of dumping cyanide into a water cooler at the office of his wife, Sandra, the authorities said Tuesday. A co-worker, Julie Williams, died after drinking the water. Mr. Harry was charged with one count of murder and four of attempted murder. He was being held in the Maricopa County jail in $1.37 million bail.

title: 'ALL-AMERICAN HIGH,' A SCHOOL DOCUMENTARY
description: IF Keva Rosenfeld's vividly satiric ''All-American High'' is to be believed, this country is headed for hell on a surfboard, with a smile of dazzling white and a miracle-fiber mind to which no barnacles of thought will ever stick.

title: SAN JOSE TEAM GOES TO BAT FOR EX-BIG LEAGUERS
description: Harry Steve interrupted the workout one sunny afternoon last week at Municipal Stadium and gathered his team about him. The president, general manager and manager of the San Jose Bees of the Class A California League was not happy.

title: Patient With Artificial Heart Dies at Pittsburgh Hospital
description: A 43-year-old factory worker who received a Jarvik-7 artificial heart last month died today of complications from a lung infection, a hospital spokesman said.

title: BALTIMORE BANCORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Judge Refuses to Block Rail Strike Expansion
description: A Federal district judge early today rejected a request by the nation's railroads to stop a union of maintenance employees from expanding nationwide its strike against a small New England carrier.

title: ISLANDERS LOSE, 3-1
description: The formula was simple tonight as the Washington Capitals beat the Islanders, 3-1, in the opening game of their playoff series. They smothered everybody from Mike Bossy to the goaltender Kelly Hrudey in their eagerness to bring the Islanders to a standstill while advancing, albeit conservatively, their own cause.

title: KRUEGER, W A CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
STRIDE RITE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
G.E. Notes Priced
description: The General Electric Company is offering $500 million of triple-A-rated 6 7/8 percent notes due in 1989 at a price of 100 through underwriters led by Merrill Lynch Capital Markets. The interest rate on the notes was the lowest seen on a par-priced corporate issue in many years. The G.E. issue yields about 15-hundredths of a percentage point more than three-year Treasury notes.

title: REAGAN AFFIRMS SUPPORT OF BUSH ON OIL REMARKS
description: President Reagan tonight firmly restated his position that market forces should determine the price of oil and rejected suggestions that Vice President Bush had created confusion about the Administration's policy on this issue.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: * B.F. Goodrich Co., Akron, Ohio, said it had sold its Continental Conveyor and Equipment Co. unit to the closely held Nesco Inc. of Cleveland. Terms were not disclosed.

title: U.S. EXPECTS TO SAVE BILLIONS ON ITS DEBT SERVICE
description: The sharp drop in interest rates over the last few months is likely to save the Government as much as $4 billion in the current fiscal year, and up to $12 billion in the fiscal year 1987, according to Administration officials and private analysts.

title: CALENDAR: FURNITURE, FIBER ART
description: Furniture Art, Gallery at Workbench, 470 Park Avenue South (32d Street); 212-481-5454.

title: Seeing Red
description: As a result of the summit meeting last November, the Russians agreed to lend the United States treasured French Impressionist and Post-Impressionist art from their museums in Moscow and Leningrad. The exhibition was announced for the National Gallery of Art in Washington, and now comes word that May 1 has been selected as the opening day.

title: HOUSE ADJOURNS GUN CONTROL DEBATE TO CUT COSTS
description: The House of Representatives was close tonight to relaxing Federal gun controls. But with one hour of scheduled debate remaining, the session adjourned abruptly at the urging of the Speaker, Thomas P. O'Neill Jr., who told the members that under new budget contraints the House could no longer afford to pay overtime to the Capitol police for late-night sessions.

title: 3,000 More Seats for Busch Stadium
description: The company that owns Busch Stadium, home of the St. Louis baseball and football Cardinals, announced today a plan to increase the number of seats by 3,000 and add 14 new luxury boxes.

title: Reagan Questioner Offers Him an Award
description: As President Reagan concluded his news conference tonight, an eager questioner pushed her way to the podium to ask that he accept an award from an international body builders' organization.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * First Southern Federal Savings and Loan Association, Mobile, Ala., said Roland V. Lee Jr. had been named senior vice president and manager of the construction and income property lending division.

title: Berndt Accused
description: Jens-Peter Berndt, the swimmer who defected from East Germany last year and has been a star performer for the University of Alabama, has been removed from a sophomore English course but allowed to remain in school after being accused by his instructor of cheating on a test. According to a university statement, Berndt, who had been reprimanded after admitting two previous cheating incidents, denied the latest accusation and was spared stiffer punishment because his instructor's observations could not be confirmed ''with full certainty.'' Berndt, who held the world record for the 400-meter individual medley in 1984, turned in a strong performance at the National Collegiate Athletic Association national swimming championships last week, finishing second in the 400-meter medley, third in the 200-meter medley and fourth in the 200-meter backstroke.

title: EASTWOOD MARKS LANDSLIDE VICTORY
description: Clint Eastwood, who has made a career out of portraying taciturn cowboys and lawmen bent on righteous revenge, got even Tuesday with leaders of this scenic community who rebuffed him last year when he sought to put up an office building here.

title: EXPERT ADVICE ON SELECTING A GOOD READING LAMP
description: ''THE problem with lighting today is that lights are so specific,'' says Paul Marantz, a lighting consultant at Jules Fisher & Paul Marantz Inc. in Manhattan. ''The glowing light that Grandma's silk-shaded floor and table lamps provided made good reading light. But this kind of lamp is no longer in fashion.''

title: RANGERS STUN FLYERS AND CAPTURE PLAYOFF OPENER
description: Against the Flyers and their roughhouse tactics and against all the data that seemed to tell them they were out of Philadelphia's league, the Rangers began their playoff season tonight with a stunning upset.

title: Campaign Largesse
description: To the Editor:

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''I awaken sometimes with some kind of nightmares about me leading troops and killing people, killing my own soldiers.

title: ISRAELI COALITION NEARS FALL OVER OUSTING MINISTER
description: Israel's 19-month-old coalition Government reached the brink of collapse today amid an exchange of new threats by the Likud bloc and Labor Party.

title: Kelesi, 16, Scores Upset of Bassett
description: Steffi Graf, Claudia Kohde-Kilsch, Zina Garrison and Helena Sukova advanced in the Family Circle Magazine Cup women's tennis tournament today, but Carling Bassett was upset by a fellow Canadian, Helen Kelesi, 2-6, 6-3, 6-4.

title: More Layoffs at G.M.
description: The General Motors Corporation said today that it had placed 1,200 workers on indefinite layoff at its car body assembly plant in Flint, Mich. The workers had been temporarily laid off in January when G.M. reduced production of some models. G.M. also said it would close its Westland parts distribution center and warehouse at the end of the year and lay off 100 G.M. employees and 350 contract workers.

title: Turner in Talks
description: Ted Turner, the owner of Turner Broadcasting System Inc., has begun discussions with the head of the nation's largest cable television operation on possible joint ventures. Mr. Turner and John Malone, the president of Tele-Communications Inc., based in Denver, talked for three and a half hours Tuesday and agreed to meet again at an unspecified date, a Turner spokesman, Arthur Sando, said. Mr. Sando also said that Mr. Malone, whose company owns 3 percent of Turner, confirmed he would join the Turner board at its annual meeting in June. The discussions follow Turner's acquisition of the MGM/UA Entertainment Company, which he financed by borrowing $2.6 billion.

title: U.S. JURY INDICTS FRIEDMAN AND SIX ON BRIBERY COUNTS
description: Stanley M. Friedman, the Bronx Democratic chairman, was indicted yesterday by a Federal grand jury and accused of bribing city officials as part of a racketeering conspiracy that transformed the City Parking Violations Bureau into ''a vehicle for the corrupt profit'' of politicians and business executives.

title: POLISH AIDE VISITS BONN, BUT TRIP TO LONDON IS OFF
description: The Polish Government has announced that its Foreign Minister will not go to London as planned this month, apparently because Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher has refused to meet him.

title: WALGREEN CO reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
description: All the share earnings have been adjusted to reflect a 2-for-1 stock split effected in the form of a stockdividend distributed to shareholders on May 8, 1985.

title: CO-CAPTAIN WILLIE
description: In the spring of 1976, three auspicious events took place: Billy Martin began his first full term as Yankee manager, the new Yankee Stadium was opened and the Yankees unveiled a new second baseman named Willie Randolph.

title: FIRST COLONIAL BANKSHARES reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
A TENSE TIME NOW FOR JEWS OF VIENNA
description: Hitler slept there, as did Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi on his only visit ever to a Western capital.

title: RUSSIANS DESCRIBE TEST AS A DANGER
description: The official Soviet press agency denounced the nuclear test today, calling it a ''dangerous destabilizing step'' that cast doubt on American reliability as a negotiating partner.

title: INTEL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes an extraordinary gain of $7,596,000 from the prepayment of a low-interest debt. c-Net income

title: Yankees Win on Berra's Squeeze in 10th
description: Entering their half of the fifth inning yesterday, the Yankees were losing, 5-0, and they had yet to get a hit against Bret Saberhagen, the Cy Young Award winner, who was pitching in a game that counted for the ing in a game that counted for the first time since he shut out the St. Louis Cardinals in the game that made the Kansas City Royals the World Series champions. In other words, the Yankees seemed to have little chance of winning this particular game.

title: GLORY DAYS FOR THE CHERRY TREES
description: In the wistful stanzas of a Japanese haiku we are told, ''Life is short, like the three-day glory of the cherry blossom.'' In the New York area, however, where various parks and gardens are home to nearly three dozen kinds of cherry trees, it is possible to witness the blossoms' transitory spectacle continually from the beginning of April until the middle of May.

title: French Honor Reinhart
description: The French Government has granted the rank of ''Officer'' in its Order of Arts and Letters to Charles Reinhart, director of the American Dance Festival. Jean-Marie Guehenno, cultural counselor of the French Embassy, will make the presentation on Monday in New York. Mr. Reinhart introduced France's new modern-dance groups to the United States when the festival, at Duke University in Durham, N.C., presented five French troupes in 1983. These were followed by other leading groups, including the debut of the Paris Opera Ballet's modern-dance company, the Groupe de Recherche Choregraphique de l'Opera de Paris.

title: Matthew Rubinstein, Sportswear Innovator
description: Matthew N. Rubinstein, who helped develop the concept of designer sportswear, died Tuesday at Mount Sinai Medical Center. He had been in a coma since suffering a heart attack in his apartment in Boca Raton, Fla., six weeks ago.

title: McNAMARA AND BROWN QUESTION MISSILE DEFENSE
description: Two former Secretaries of Defense suggested today that the pace of research in defenses against long-range missiles be slowed and that spending for them be cut.

title: CORRECTION
description: Because of an editing error, an article in Business Day on Monday about manufacturing in South Korea misstated the extent of assembly-line use there. While fully automated lines are still rare, assembly lines are common.

title: BRONX ZOO'S AIRBORNE HERALDS OF SPRING
description: ELEPHANTS are O.K., and camels, giraffes and lions have their place, but in springtime there is nothing like a bird. That is why bird watchers are out in force now, keeping tabs on the migratory species as they come north with their bright colors of blue, yellow, orange and red. But most bird watchers (they prefer to be called birders) usually lead lives of quiet desperation, forced to watch the birds in their backyards or their own towns, unless they can afford to travel frequently. There is one place, however, where you can see, on the same day and in the the same place, a common mallard duck and a South African shelduck, or a native scarlet tanager and a silver-beaked mountain tanager from South America -and that is the Bronx Zoo.

title: SAVINGS BANK OF PUGET SOUND reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Ford Splits Stock, Raises Dividend
description: The Ford Motor Company announced a 3-for-2 stock split, raising the number of shares outstanding to 270 million from 180 million.

title: SUDBURY HOLDINGS INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 1
description: b-After tax credits of $1,445,000 for the quarter and $3,755,000 for the 9 months. c-After tax credits of $622,000 for the quarter and $1,570,000 for the 9 months.

title: HOUSE PASSES BILL EASING CONTROLS ON SALE OF GUNS
description: The House of Representatives today approved a bill making it easier to buy, sell and transport firearms across state lines, but supporters of gun control succeeded in preserving the Federal ban on the interstate sale of pistols.

title: CONRAC CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes $1,404,000 of shipments by a division that has since been sold.

title: ON THE RUN
description: Like musicians before them, elite athletes and recreational runners alike are coming to the relief of Africa's famine-stricken regions. Unicef and Bob Geldof, the musician who last year organized Live Aid, announced at a midtown news conference yesterday that a series of events called Sport Aid, to run from May 17 to 25, would culminate in a 10-kilometer Race Against Time, in which ''more than a million people'' worldwide will compete simultaneously.

title: FEDERAL NATIONAL MORTGAGE ASSN (FNMA)(N) reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net loss

title: A.M.C.'S TROUBLES IN CHINA
description: At 3 o'clock on a dusty weekday afternoon, little stirred in the final assembly building of the Beijing Jeep Corporation Ltd., one of the bellwether American investments in China.

title: ASK COMPUTER SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
POP AND JAZZ GUIDE
description: ''1,000 Years of Jazz,'' Lehman Center for the Performing Arts, Bedford Park Boulevard West and Goulden Avenue, the Bronx (960-8833). The title is pure hyperbole, of course, although back in the early 70's, when this ensemble of veteran New Orleans jazz musicians and Harlem hoofers first went on the road, the justification for the title was that it represented the combined ages of the musicians and dancers. Attrition has effected changes in the cast and the age total, but the personnel remain venerable and talented. The dancers are the Original Hoofers, who are sometimes a quartet but on this occasion are a quintet made up of Chuck Green, Lon Chaney, George Hillman, Ralph Brown and the gliding septuagenarian Jimmy Slyde. The musicians are the Legends of Jazz, a group organized in 1972 by the British-born drummer and aficionado of New Orleans jazz, Barry Martyn. It currently includes a relatively young and superbly brash trombonist from New Orleans, Freddy Lonzo, along with Herbert Permilion on trumpet, Floyd Turnham on clarinet, Walter Lewis on piano, and two longterm members, Benny Booker on bass and Mr. Martyn on drums, and a young Georgia-bred singer, Deborah Woodson. The show is at 3 P.M. Sunday. Tickets are $14, $12 and $10.

title: ADAMS EXPRESS CO reports earnings for As of March 31
description: Assets reflect net assets.

title: BLOUNT INC reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
description: b-Includes extraordinary gains of $4,896,000 for the quarter and $8,873,000 for the year.

title:
Advertising;
Alfred Dunhill Ltd. Turns to BBDO Direct
description: When Alfred Dunhill Ltd. of London needed help in this country of a direct marketing nature, it had to look no further than BBDO Direct, a sister company under the BBDO International banner of Waring & LaRosa, the Dunhill general agency for 15 years.

title: CENTERRE BANCORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Results include extraordinary gains of 11 cents per share in the latest quarter and 4 cents per share in the year-earlier period.

title: SOUTH AFRICANS BRING A NEW PLAY TO HARLEM
description: From South Africa, Mbongeni Ngema, musician, actor, director and playwright, has come to Harlem, bringing with him his country - its contradictions, its pain and injustices, and the unquenchable spirit of its people.

title: Insurer Under Supervision
description: The TMIC Insurance Company, formerly the Ticor Mortgage Insurance Company, has been placed under state conservatorship and will receive $30 million from its parent as part of a rehabilitation plan that will allow the insurer to participate in a larger workout plan for the bankrupt Equity Programs Investment Corporation.

title: 'Westside Cabaret'
description: An evening of music, dance, comedy and drama is planned this weekend at a ''Westside Cabaret'' at the Church of St. Paul the Apostle, Columbus Avenue and 59th Street.

title: What Might Have Been
description: To the Editor:

title: OLD NUREMBERG ON VIEW AT MET: A WORLD BUILT TO LAST FOREVER
description: FORTY years ago, the once-great city of Nuremberg was held in universal execration. People remembered the Nuremberg rallies of 1933-39. They remembered the despicable Nuremberg Laws of 1935. They had under their eyes and noses the Nuremberg trials, during which crimes as hideous as any ever recorded were spelled out in open court. How could they think well of Nuremberg, or be sorry that, as of the end of World War II, the destruction of the city was virtually complete? That particular picturesqueness at that particular time had too many associations of recent date.

title: John O'Connor Dies; Book Publishing Aide
description: John O'Connor, who began his book publishing career as a secretary in 1907 and eventually became chairman of Bantam Books, died Wednesday at his son's home in Groveland, Mass. He was 94 years old.

title: St. Louis Symphony
description: The St. Louis Symphony, under the direction of Leonard Slatkin, will play the New York premiere of Steve Reich's ''Three Movements for Orchestra'' tonight at 8 at Carnegie Hall.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article in Metropolitan Report last Friday about building designs that opponents say are attempts to circumvent New York City's ban on so-called sliver towers misstated the position of one such group. Residents near the site of a proposed 40-story building at 52-54 East End Avenue say the plans are a legal violation and are challenging the design before the City Board of Standards and Appeals.

title: Economic Scene; Reagan, Bush And Oil Prices
description: PRESIDENT REAGAN, in his news conference this week, sought to come to the rescue of Vice President Bush over his recent remarks about the need for stabilizing oil prices.

title: AIDS GUIDE FOR HEALTH FIELD
description: Federal officials today cautioned health care workers engaged in surgical or dental procedures to use gloves, gowns, masks and eye coverings to prevent the spread of AIDS.

description: Army investigators confirmed today that two helicopters carrying eight soldiers collided in flight and crashed, killing all aboard.

Norway Rig Plan
description: A complex rescue plan, involving the raising of six oil rigs, has been proposed to save Norway's slowly sinking Ekofisk oilfield platforms in the North Sea, the field's operator, Phillips Petroleum, said. The operation, to be carried out this summer pending Norwegian approval, is expected to cost $205 million.

title: NBC Drops Pair
description: NBC's program before National Football League games will have a new lineup next season.

title: Cedeno a Dodger
description: Cesar Cedeno, the 35-year-old outfielder-first baseman, is back in the major leagues for the second time in two years because of an injury to a key hitter. Cedeno signed yesterday with the Los Angeles Dodgers to help fill the void created by the knee injury that will keep Pedro Guerrero out until July.

title: ENSECO INC reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: The company went public in April 1984. Figures for the earlier year cover the period from April 28 to Dec. 31, 1984.

title: What Price The Playoffs?
description: With its announcement two years ago that an annual lottery would determine the worst seven teams' order of selection in the draft, the National Basketball Association trumpeted the luck of the draw as a good way to help protect the sport's integrity. In reality, however, the lottery has merely raised the stakes of an age-old game in which teams frequently find bountiful incentive to lose as they approach season's end. Whereas that incentive - the No. 1 pick - was previously a lure only to the lowliest clubs in each conference, it's now calling out to those closer to the middle of the pack.

title: LEAFS SURPRISE HAWKS, LEAD SERIES, 2-0
description: Walt Poddubny of Toronto scored a tiebreaking goal with 56 seconds remaining tonight and the Maple Leafs, the team with the worst regular-season mark among playoff teams, went on to a 6-4 victory over the Chicago Black Hawks. Toronto has now won the first two games of the three-of-five-game Norris Division semifinal series.

title: Walker Backs Transcanada
description: Hiram Walker Resources Ltd., as expected, yesterday endorsed a $3 billion takeover bid from Transcanada Pipelines Ltd., Canada's largest pipeline operator. The oil and liquor producer said its directors had agreed to recommend that stockholders accept Transcanada's $26.39-a-share offer.

title: SIX EXEMPLARY DANCERS DEFINE THEIR STYLE ON NEW YORK STAGES
description: A WOMAN dressed in black sits at a table on the stage, leafing carefully through a large book as the audience enters. Her concentration is mesmerizing. There are no whispers. No programs get shuffled or coats eased out of. Though nearly motionless, that quiet figure has the audience in her thrall.

title: GEOLOGISTS WARN OF SEA LEVEL RISE
description: The continuing rise in the global sea level, which is expected to pose a major threat to coastline communities over the next century, can be stemmed through large-scale storage of water on land, two geologists say in a new report.

description: THE average investor might not always remember that securities and commodities exchanges are businesses as much as anything else, engaged in a hotly competitive game of trying to win the investment dollars of both large and small investors.

SCREEN: 'OFF BEAT,' COP CAPER
description: THE little play on words in the title ''Off Beat,'' which opens today at the RKO National and other theaters, refers to a young fellow (Judge Reinhold) who poses as a New York City police officer as a favor for a friend (Cleavant Derricks) who doesn't want to dance in a policemen's show. Hanging on that slight premise are some predictable proceedings. The impostor falls for a pretty police officer (Meg Tilly) who has resolved not to marry a cop. Should he tell or shouldn't he? As soon as we learn that Miss Tilly's specialty is ''hostage negotiation,'' it's a fair guess that the climactic scene will have hostages in it. Indeed so, and with the help of quirky performances by Harvey Keitel and Victor Argo, the conclusion has an offbeat quality missing from most of ''Off Beat.''

title: HILTON HOTELS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
WEEKENDER GUIDE
description: Friday BIBLIOPHILIC BIRTHDAY The New York Public Library is celebrating its 75th birthday this year, and a new exhibition to mark the anniversary opens today. ''A Building to Celebrate,'' whose subject is the architecture of the 42d Street building itself, will feature original architectural drawings, actual library furnishings, and historic and modern photographs. The library's architects, Thomas Hastings and John Merven Carrere, won the commission to construct the library in 1897 after a widely publicized architectural competition, and the building was dedicated in 1911. This year's anniversary celebration also includes two different types of tours. At 12:30 P.M. each day, Monday through Saturday, a guided tour of the exhibition will focus on the evolution of the library's design; at 11 A.M. and 2 P.M., one-hour tours will discuss the history of the library, its famous users, and aspects of its collection, which numbers 29 million items. A series of lectures on the architecture of the library is also scheduled for six Tuesday evenings, starting April 29. The library is open today and tomorrow from 10 A.M. to 6 P.M., and admission is free. Information: 930-0501.

title: Destinations IV
description: Offhand, Utah does not look like very fertile territory for the Democrats this year. Ronald Reagan won 73 percent of the Presidential vote there in 1980 and increased his share to 75 percent four years later.

title: COMPROMISE OFFERED TO END ISRAELI CABINET CRISIS
description: The Likud bloc leader, Yitzhak Shamir, backed down today from his threat to leave the Cabinet and suggested a compromise to Prime Minister Shimon Peres that could enable the coalition Government to continue, Likud sources said.

title: CORRECTION
description: A Washington Talk article on March 20 about the renovation of the Willard Hotel misidentified the designer of the Waldorf-Astoria in New York. It was the architectural firm of Schultze & Weaver, not Henry Hardenbergh.

title: HEROIN RAIDS SAID TO BREAK VAST CITY RING
description: Leaders of a drug network that distributed almost all the heroin sold on the Lower East Side and one-third of the heroin in the New York metropolitan area were among 38 people arrested yesterday in early morning raids, authorities said.

title: HOUSE ROLL-CALL VOTE ON GUNS
description: Following is the roll-call of 286 to 136 by which the House voted today to adopt the wording of legislation by Representative Harold L. Volkmer, Democrat of Missouri, to ease many restrictions of the Gun Control Act of 1968. The bill was then formally sent to the Senate by a vote of 292 to 130. A yes vote is a vote for the Volkmer language. A no vote was a vote against it. Voting yes were 128 Democrats and 158 Republicans. Voting no were 118 Democrats and 18 Republicans. An xxx denotes those not voting. Present denotes those who voted they were present at the time of the vote but did not vote yes or no on the issue. There are no vacancies in the 435-member House. ALABAMA

description: When he got the idea of loading up his Class A minor-league team with former major-leaguers, Harry Steve, the president of the San Jose Bees, apparently neglected the potential conflict between major-league expectations and minor-league standards.

title: Circus Show Called Off
description: The Ringling Brothers and Barnum & Bailey Circus will not go on tomorrow night at 7:30 at Madison Square Garden because of a Stanley Cup hockey playoff game between the New York Rangers and the Philadelphia Flyers. Tickets can be exchanged or refunded at the box office or through Ticketron or Teletron. Garden box office: 564-4400.

title: Moussa to Focus Again On French Interests
description: Pierre Moussa, the former chairman of Banque Paribas and a star in the world of international banking, has sold his interest in the investment bank Dillon, Read Ltd., the European arm of the Wall Street firm Dillon, Read & Company. He plans to devote more time to investing in his native France, which will mark something of a comeback for Mr. Moussa.

title: BIG GAINS REPORTED BY 4 BANKS
description: The Chemical New York Corporation reported yesterday that first-quarter profits rose 14.4 percent from a year earlier. Several other New York banks also posted strong results, helped by the decline in interest rates and the buoyant securities markets.

title: COMINGS AND GOINGS
description: Steve Bartkowski, the 33-year-old quarterback who was released by the Atlanta Falcons and by the Washington Redskins last season, signed a one-year, $250,000 contract with the Los Angeles Rams. . . . The National Football League has hired a prominent Los Angeles-based entertainment lawyer, Frank Rothman, to help its legal team in the antitrust suit brought by the United States Football League and scheduled to go to trial May 12. Rothman was the chairman and chief executive officer of MGM/UA Entertainment Company for four years until he resigned earlier this year after MGM/UA was purchased by Turner Broadcasting Inc.

title: CARDS DEFEAT CUBS WITH OWNBEY, 4-2
description: Ozzie Smith singled home two runs to break a fourth-inning tie, and Rick Ownbey earned his first major-league victory in almost three years today, leading the St. Louis Cardinals to a 4-2 victory over the Chicago Cubs.

description: The Athletics Congress has agreed to conduct the women's Olympic marathon trials as part of the Boston Marathon schedule in 1988 if race officials agree to a separate start for the contestants.

description: THE striking images of ''Yellow Earth,'' a Chinese movie about the forced marriages inflicted on teen-age peasant women before the Communist takeover, offer respite from a plot that bears the impress of the cultural arm of the Chinese Communist Party's Central Committee.

description: Despite pledges to provide emergency funds to Haiti after the fall of the Duvalier Government, the Reagan Administration has been unable to find a way to fund a $25 million grant needed to allow Haiti to import oil and meet other critical needs, Administration officials said today.

Interest on the bonds for the first five years will be paid in one cumulative installment, in 1991, and annually thereafter.

title: Bridge: A Course for Schoolchildren Begins Tomorrow at Beverly
description: Attempts to provide bridge instruction for children of school age succeed in Europe, particularly in the Netherlands and Sweden. In Manhattan, a beginners' course, for students in grades 5 through 12, will offer six free lessons on consecutive Saturdays. It begins at 9:30 A.M. tomorrow at the Beverly Club, 130 East 57th Street. Preregistration is not required. The instructor is Danny Kotok, a mathematics teacher in Manhattan. On the diagramed deal, played recently at the Beverly, he held the South cards and was surprised to find himself playing a game after West had opened the bidding.

description: When the Tappan Zee Bridge across the Hudson River opened in 1955, S. J. Schulman remembers, traffic was so light ''you could play baseball on it.''

description: To the Editor:

title: THE EVENING HOURS
description: IT was, Blanchette Rockefeller said, the only Hanae Mori she owned - beaded navy silk crepe and purchased in Tokyo - and Wednesday night seemed an appropriate time to wear it. The formal occasion, in the Grand Ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria, was the 30th anniversary dinner dance of the Asia Society, founded by her late husband, John D. Rockefeller 3d. The intent of the nonpolitical public-education organization is to help Americans better understand Asia and the Pacific.

Diners who are in the mood for jazz with their jambalaya or blues with their bouillabaisse face a formidable challenge. One serendipitous exception is Greene Street, the vast, dramatic nightclub and restaurant in SoHo.

description: Business is pleasure for Malcolm S. Forbes.

description: ''I DON'T think an actor should act every single day,'' says Steven Hill. ''I don't think it's good for the so-called creative process. You must have periods when you leave the land fallow, let it revitalize itself.''

description: The United States Embassy said today that it had assisted the National Police in breaking up a kidnap-for-profit ring said to involve several high-ranking military officers.

description: Four elderly black women have been slain in an Atlanta neighborhood and the police say they have no leads in the slayings, which are being investigated by a special team because of similarities.

title: Don't Kill Set-Asides; Fix Them
description: Should Washington halt the practice of reserving contracts for minority businesses in Federal programs? A staff report for the U.S. Commission on Civil Rights concludes that these ''ill-conceived and ineffective'' set-aside programs should be suspended for a year. The commission meets today to consider the report. The White House, meanwhile, continues to support set-asides. The White House has the right idea.

SCANDAL NOT HURTING CITY YET, CONGRESSMEN SAY
description: Democratic and Republican Congressmen and party professionals believe that New York City's corruption scandal has left the city's fiscal and political standing largely untouched, so far.

title: CHARITY AUCTIONS UP THE ANTE
description: With the price of oil falling and the number of charity events climbing, raising benevolent dollars has become tough, even in this can-do city. To compete, charities need a driven ball committee with a record of high-dollar success, a Fortune 500 guest list, tasteful food, decor and entertainment, friends in high places and lots of time to work connections and retrieve favors.

title: WITNESS TELLS HOW MRS. JOHNSON DISPOSED OF PRENUPTIAL AGREEMENT

title: THE SCREEN: 'CRITTERS' FROM SPACE
description: CREATURES from outer space who drop in on movie families come in two types -cute and cuddly or mean and nasty. In ''Critters,'' Dee Wallace Stone - the mom who got a visit from the quintessentially cute E. T. -meets up with some extreme nasties called krites. Upright porcupines with apelike faces, these aliens are so mean they break out of a maximum-security prison in another galaxy and arrive in Kansas, ready to munch on anyone in their path.

title: A DAUGHTER RETURNS TO PAKISTAN TO CRY FOR VICTORY
description: Hundreds of thousands of people thronged the streets here today demanding the ouster of President Mohammad Zia ul-Haq in the biggest anti-Government rally in Pakistan since General Zia seized power in a military coup in 1977.

INDIANA NATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The latest first quarter figures include results of operations of four Indiana banks purchased in the last quarter of 1985. The per share earnings are fully diluted.

title: Bareback Pas de Deux
