title: C.I.A. REVAMPS ITS HANDLING OF DEFECTORS LIKE YURCHENKO
description: A senior C.I.A. official said today that the agency had made major changes in its procedures for handling defectors like Vitaly S. Yurchenko, the high-level Soviet official who fled to the West last year and then returned to Moscow.

title: WHITSON TO START ROAD GAMES ONLY
description: Manager Lou Piniella, concerned about Ed Whitson's emotional state and its effect on his pitching, said yesterday he was changing his pitching plans so that Whitson would start games on the road and Bob Shirley would start in his place at Yankee Stadium. The decision followed Whitson's relatively brief appearance in his first start of the season against Kansas City Wednesday night.

title: Scraping By
description: Because it was cold and blustery yesterday morning, not too many regulars were walking across the Brooklyn Bridge to their jobs in Manhattan. But Bill Epes was there, and he had an extra little adventure.

title: OFFICIALS SAY U.S. WARNED OF BOMB, MINUTES TOO LATE
description: Administration officials said today that military aides in West Berlin had obtained such convincing evidence of a planned terrorist attack against Americans there that they were within five minutes of alerting off-duty American soldiers when a bomb exploded at a discotheque in the city last Saturday.

title: Destinations I
description: The decline in the value of the dollar in foreign currency markets is bad news for Americans planning to seek bargains abroad this year. But, according to the Department of Commerce, it's good news for the travel industry in this country, which is expecting more foreign travelers to visit here.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Apricot Computers P.L.C., London, said it had won a three-year contract to supply microcomputers to General Electric Co.'s W.&T. Avery Ltd. unit.

title: AMERICAN MEDICAL ELECTRONCS INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Pope Rebukes Dissent On Sexual Teachings
description: Pope John Paul II, in a particularly severe rebuke of theologians who dissent from Roman Catholicism's traditional view of sexuality, said today that unorthodox teachings were ''spreading confusion in the conscience of the faithful.''

title: ATTITUDE OF THE LIBYANS: ONE OF PASSIVE WAITING
description: There is about the residents of this capital a sense of being playgoers passively watching an unfolding drama.

title: SCREEN: 'VIOLETS ARE BLUE'
description: ''VIOLETS ARE BLUE,'' which opens today at the Coronet and other theaters, is about pretty, talented Gussie Sawyer (Sissy Spacek), a successful news photographer (for what seems to be Newsweek), the sort of woman who is based permanently in Paris but who may be in Beirut on Monday and Managua on Wednesday. She's risen to the top of her profession, but at the cost of a rewarding private life - one completed by a loving husband and bright, untroublesome children.

title: HOUSE SETS CLOCK TO AUSTERITY TIME
description: The House of Representatives, in its own version of daylight saving time, will no longer hold formal sessions after 7 P.M.

title: Dow Gains 15.68 As Volume Surges
description: Record first-hour volume on Wall Street yesterday sent trading activity for the day sharply higher as stock prices continued to improve on expectations that interest rates would soon retreat further.

title: ROBINS AGREES ON PLAN FOR DIRECTOR
description: The A. H. Robins Company agreed yesterday to an unusual plan under which a ''prominent individual'' would be named to the company's board of directors, and given broad powers to negotiate a reorganization plan for the company.

title: THEATER: 'BIG DEAL,' FROM BOB FOSSE
description: FOR a generation, one of the few durable thrills of the constantly eroding Broadway musical has been the choreography of Bob Fosse. With the death of Gower Champion, Mr. Fosse may now be the last active theater choreographer who knows how to assemble an old-fashioned, roof-raising show stopper in which every step bears the unmistakable signature of its creator. ''Big Deal,'' the new Fosse musical at the Broadway, contains exactly one of those show stoppers, and attention must be paid. If only for 10 minutes or so just before the end of Act I, Mr. Fosse makes an audience remember what is (and has been) missing from virtually every other musical in town.

title: ART: LOPEZ GARCIA WORK IN FIRST SHOW SINCE '68
description: THE Antonio Lopez Garcia exhibition at the Marlborough Gallery is something of an event. The Spanish artist, 50 years old, has not had a one-man show in the United States since 1968, and he remains largely unknown here. Yet within artistic circles that have little or no voice in major European and American modern art museums, he is an inspiration and a master.

title: WALDHEIM UPROAR: WHERE IT STANDS
description: Almost daily, new documents from German, Yugoslav and United Nations archives emerge about the war record of former Secretary General Kurt Waldheim. The part he played in the war has become an issue in the coming Austrian presidential election, in which he is a candidate. Mr. Waldheim had said in his official biography, since amended, that his wartime service ended when he was wounded in the leg on the Russian front in 1941. Documents made public by the World Jewish Congress say Mr. Waldheim served as a staff officer in a German Army unit that fought brutal campaigns against Yugoslav partisans and took part in a large-scale deportation of Greek Jews.

title: OPERA: 'PARSIFAL' AT THE MET
description: THE Metropolitan Opera is a strange company, one that has been unable recently to mount a credible ''Carmen'' or ''Tosca'' but can put on a ''Parsifal'' of the highest quality, as it did last night. Wagner's final and most problematical opera, in its first performance of this flickering season, gave off a continual glow of excellence in spite of a cast that sagged seriously in several places.

title: It All Adds Up
description: Phil Regan, the Seattle Mariners' pitching coach, asked how the team can threaten without a 20-victory hurler, displays sound arithmetic but excessive optimism: ''If we have two guys who can win 17 games, a couple of guys who can win 13 or 14 games and one guy who can win 10 games, we're going to be in the race.''

title: LABOR WINS LONDON TORY SEAT
description: The opposition Labor Party won a Conservative parliamentary seat in a London by-election today, its first such victory in the city in 29 years.

title: INDIANA JUDGE ALLOWS AIDS VICTIM BACK IN SCHOOL
description: A 14-year-old victim of AIDS returned to his seventh-grade classes today less than two hours after a judge threw out an injunction barring him from school. Parents of 27 other children at the school took them home, fearful that they might contract the deadly disease.

title: Defuse Southern Lebanon Now
description: It may take a week, a month or even a year, but if the disturbing developments in southern Lebanon are allowed to continue, there is likely to be a serious eruption of violence.

title: James Phillip Brown Jr., 44, An Official of the N.A.A.C.P.
description: James Phillip Brown Jr., the Northeast regional director of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People, died of cancer Monday at Calvary Hospital in the Bronx. He was 44 years old and lived in Brooklyn.

title: ART: ISAMU NOGUCHI'S SEVEN STONES
description: THERE are commonplace pebbles that are a nondescript tan on the outside, but have centers that seem to be made of another stone altogether -smoother and dark gray in color. At Pace Gallery, 32 East 57th Street, it's as if Isamu Noguchi, with his extraordinary nose for unusual and beautiful materials, had discovered giant versions of these pebbles and, slicing them here, piercing them there, had turned them into sculptures.

title: GERMANS REPORTED AT ODDS OVER LIBYAN TERRORIST TIES
description: West German officials and intelligence analysts disagree over the implications of the information supplied by the United States to demonstrate Libyan involvement in the bombing of a West Berlin discotheque, Government sources said today.

title: CHEMICAL NEW YORK CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Short-Term Rates Up Slightly
description: Short-term interest rates rose slightly yesterday, while yields of notes and bonds fell by small amounts.

title: Destinations III
description: Robert C. McFarlane, the former White House national security adviser, has opened a legal counterattack against publications that printed what he says were untrue and defamatory references to his personal life in articles about reputed romantic liaisons. The first public evidence of his effort was a 180-word retraction and apology that appeared this week in the April issue of Washington Dossier, a slick monthly that concentrates heavily on coverage of social life in the capital.

title: FRIDAY SPORTS
description: Baseball Yankees vs. Milwaukee Brewers, at Yankee Stadium, 7:35 P.M. Opener of a three-game series. (Radio -WABC 770, 7:30 P.M.) Mets vs. Phillies, at Philadelphia, 7:35 P.M. Opener of a three-game series. (Television - SportsChannel, 7:30 P.M. Radio - WHN 1050, 7:30 P.M.) Atlanta Braves vs. Astros, at Houston (Television -WTBS, 8:35 P.M.) Basketball Knicks vs. Detroit Pistons, at Madison Square Garden. Final home game of the season for the Knicks. (Television - MSG, 8:00 P.M. Radio - WNBC 660, 8 P.M.) Bowling Long Island Open, at the Garden City Bowl, Meadowbrook Parkway and Stewart Avenue, Garden City, L.I. Second day of match play. 11 A.M. and 6:15 P.M. Boxing Freddie Pendleton vs. Shelton LeBlanc, lightweights, 10 rounds, at Las Vegas, Nev. Although Pendleton, from Philadelphia, is only 14-13-1 as a professional, he knocked out Roger Mayweather, the former World Boxing Association junior-lightweight titleholder, in his last bout. LeBlanc, from Lafayette, La., is 19-2 with 11 knockouts. (Television - ESPN, 9 P.M.) Golf The Masters, at Augusta, Ga., second round (Television - Channel 2, 11:30 to 11:45 P.M. taped highlights; USA Network, 4 P.M. to 6 P.M. live and 8 P.M. to 10 P.M. tape.) L.P.G.A. Kyocera Inamori Classic, at San Diego, second round. Tennis W.C.T. Championship, at Dallas. Quarterfinal action features Boris Becker. (Television - MSG, 10:30 P.M. tape delay.) Family Circle Magazine Cup, at Sea Pines Plantation, Hilton Head, S.C. Track and Field Redmen High School Invitational Relay Carnival, at St. John's University, Utopia and Grand Central Parkways, Jamaica, Queens, opening day, 3:45 P.M. to 5:30 P.M. Admission free.

title: FILM: 'VALENTINE'S DAY' FROM HORTON FOOTE
description: IT'S spring 1917, and George Tyler - ''Mister George'' as he's called - is having a bad day. The way it's put is that ''he's off again.'' However, because he's the richest man in Harrison, Tex., and kin to almost everybody, people try not to notice that anything is odd when he appears on the front porch to ask what day it is. He may seem lucid, but then he does eccentric things, like press little brown envelopes of crisp, $100 bills into the hands of startled passers-by.

title: KOCH IS QUERIED IN BRONX ON SERVICES, NOT SCANDAL
description: Almost shouting his words to a community gathering in the South Bronx last night, Mayor Koch offered a strenuous defense of his conduct in office.

title: THE REBEL IN RED SLACKS
description: At the white table on the Augusta National clubhouse lawn, Mac O'Grady hardly ate the chicken sandwich he had ordered. He was too busy talking about Isaac Newton, never a competitor in the Masters but always an influence.

title: TRUSTCORP INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
ADMINISTRATION CHALLENGES PLAN BY RIGHTS PANEL
description: The chief White House spokesman today took issue with a draft report from the United States Commission on Civil Rights that recommended a one-year suspension of Federal programs that reserve contracts for businesses owned by blacks, Hispanic people or women.

title: RUBBERMAID INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The shares outstanding and share earnings have been adjusted for the 2-for-1 stock split effected in September 1985.

title: WHALERS SKATING WITH 'RIGHT MOVES'
description: The woman approached the diminutive man who was talking hockey here this morning and handed him a pencil and paper.

title: GUNMEN SEIZE WIFE OF DUBLIN BANKER
description: Three hooded gunmen kidnapped the wife of a wealthy Dublin banker Tuesday and are holding her for a ransom of $2.6 million, the police in Dublin announced today.

title: Councilman Protected After Threats on Phone
description: A City Councilman, who is a minister, was given police protection yesterday after vandals broke into his South Bronx church and damaged his car, and after he received telephone threats, apparently because he voted last month for a homosexual-rights bill.

title:
ADVERTISING;
People
description: * Eric Brenner has been promoted to senior vice president at SSC&B; Lintas Worldwide.

title: Academy of Design
description: Since 1825, the National Academy of Design, 1083 Fifth Avenue, at 89th Street, has held a juried exhibition of paintings, drawings and prints by members and, recently, nonmembers.

title: POTLATCH CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Picketing Spreads In Railroad Strike
description: The threat of a national railroad stike over a dispute between 123 maintenance workers and a small New England carrier grew today as picket lines expanded south to Richmond, Va., and west to Ohio.

title: Dedication Omissions
description: When the list of speakers was assembled for the dedication Wednesday of the Jacob K. Javits Convention Center, neither former Gov. Hugh L. Carey, who supported the center, nor Richard A. Kahan, former president of the State Urban Development Corporation, which built the center, was asked to talk.

title: Big 'Junk Bond' Offering
description: Speculative-grade debt securities continue to offer investors unusually high yields compared with Treasury securities, as shown by a $2.35 billion offering of BCI Holdings Corporation, a company formed to acquire Beatrice Companies.

title: DEMOCRATS BATTLE OVER FOREIGN POLICY ISSUES
description: Still struggling to build a consensus on foreign and military policy, Democrats will open two days of hearings here Friday amid signs of strong competition among party factions for control of the debate.

title: MOTOROLA INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
21 Vietnam War Dead Given to U.S. by Hanoi
description: Vietnam today turned over to the United States the bodies of 21 people believed to be missing American servicemen. It was the first repatriation of war dead this year and the third largest since 1975.

title: GOYA PORTRAIT TO GO BACK TO SPAIN
description: Goya's ''Marquesa de Santa Cruz,'' a luminous portrait that had been expected to bring a record price at auction here Friday, will be returned instead to Spain and go on display at the Prado Museum next week.

title: Conviction of Boy, 12, Upset
description: The Florida Supreme Court has overturned the 1984 conviction of a 12-year-old boy on charges of sexually abusing and murdering an 8-month-old baby, saying the trial judge should have held a competency hearing.

title: Jean Van Heijenoort, Former Trotsky Aide
description: Jean Van Heijenoort, a former secretary, bodyguard and general assistant to Leon Trotsky, died in Mexico City on March 25. He was 73 years old and lived in Palo Alto, Calif.

title: INQUIRY REPORTED INTO CONTRA ARMS
description: A Federal investigation is under way into assertions that Nicaraguan rebels and some of their non-governmental American backers have engaged in gun-running and drug trafficking, according to United States officials and sources close to the inquiry.

title: BROADWAY
description: ''ME AND MY GIRL'' has won just about every major musical award in the British theater, and although honors from over there don't guarantee box-office success over here, they don't hurt. The actors assembling Monday to begin rehearsals for the American production are gung-ho to prove that anything they can do, we can do maybe even better. But the verdict won't be in until Aug. 10 when the show opens at the new Marquis Theater. It will be in Los Angeles for two months prior to that, but Broadway is where it counts.

title:
Advertising;
Agency, 19, Simplifies Its Lineup
description: THE management of Lord, Geller, Federico, Einstein, one of the survivors of the 1967 bumper crop of new agencies, as it prepared to celebrate its 19th anniversary, paused for a moment to look at the forest and as a result has realigned the trees. That gave it something to bark about.

title: 2 Newspapers In Jersey Sold
description: The Allbritton Communications Company said yesterday that it had sold two New Jersey newspapers, The News of Paterson and The Dispatch of Union City, to Garden State Newspapers Inc., a group that already owns five newspapers in the state. Terms of the deal were not disclosed.

title: 'Shuffle' Is Moving
description: Sales are continuing and the final tally will not be known for a while, but according to an Illinois state audit, ''Super Bowl Shuffle,'' the music video made by the Chicago Bears, has grossed nearly $600,000, an estimated 7.5 percent of which will go to local charities. According to Mike Hayes, an assistant Illinois Attorney General, the money has been frozen in a bank account pending the resolution of a suit against the record company, but he said the case would not interefere with the charitable contributions.

title: FROM WINE SELLERS, DISMAY AND CONCERN
description: The nation's largest chain of wine, beer and spirits stores, Liquor Barn, pulled all Italian wines off its shelves yesterday after the Federal Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco and Firearms advised Americans not to drink Italian wines until they could be tested for methanol contamination, which has been linked to 18 deaths in Italy.

title: LOFT CONVERSION EXTENDS BOUNDARY OF COBBLE HILL
description: In some minds the cut of the Brooklyn-Queens Expressway off Hicks Street represents something of a boundary for the Cobble Hill section of Brooklyn. It is in fact the boundary of the Cobble Hill Historic District.

title: 'Return to Mayberry' On NBC Sunday
description: A little more than half a century ago, a fellow named Thomas Wolfe, who was kind of an authority on the subject, handed down some pretty good advice about going back to those little towns in North Carolina: ''You Can't Go Home Again.''

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: FRIDAY, APRIL 11, 1986
description: The Economy

title: ELECTRO RENT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
Mets-Pirates: Too Cold
description: Wintry weather wiped out the Mets' second game of the season against the Pittsburgh Pirates tonight, and caused the first switch of the season in their pitching rotation.

title: DELMED INC reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $14,557,000 for the latest year and $7,796,000 for 1984 and extraordinary credits of $2,365,000 and $7,133,000 for the latest year and 1984, respectively.

title: TURMOIL CLOUDS HOSPITAL UNION AS TALKS NEAR
description: Mounting dissension within the largest union of hospital workers in New York City threatens to undermine the union's coming negotiations with 45 hospitals and nursing homes in the metropolitan area, according to labor officials and experts.

title: Diner's Journal
description: THE onset of spring usually sees the blooming of seasonal food festivals in restaurants around town, and this year is no exception. Asparagus are popping up as daily specials at Cafe des Artistes (1 West 67th Street, 877-3500), in various guises - with Stilton cheese, wrapped with dried beef or gravlax or prosciutto, or just plain with butter and Parmesan cheese; Trumpet's, the restaurant at the Grand Hyatt New York, on 42d Street at Grand Central Terminal (883-1234), is offering a whole menu of asparagus specials at lunch as well as several at dinner.

title: Reading New York's Tea Leaves
description: What hints of future events can be discerned in the final budget adopted by a state whose Governor, Mario Cuomo, seeks re-election amid speculation about his national future? When the mutual congratulations between him and Albany's legislative leaders are poured off, what can be discerned in the 1987 budget is a resolve by the Governor to make friends, not waves. The observer need only know how hard Mr. Cuomo drives against something he really hates - like the unopened Shoreham nuclear power plant - to recognize budgetary conciliation at work.

title: The Wrong Race
description: After a two-day delay, the Reagan Administration has conducted a nuclear test that will cause the Soviet Union to end its testing moratorium and bring about a resumption of the wrong race between the superpowers.

title: Elders Buys 19.9% Of Broken Hill
description: Complicating the takeover battle for Australia's largest company, Broken Hill Proprietary Ltd., Elders IXL Ltd. disclosed today that it holds 19.9 percent of Broken Hill's 1.25 billion outstanding shares.

title: FEDERAL PAPER BOARD CO INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 22
HIGHLAND SUPERSTORES reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: Year-ago share earnings are pro forma, since the company did not go public until May 1985.

title: EXECUTIVES
description: * Alternacare Corp., Los Angeles, an outpatient-care facilities concern, said Paul Dinkel had been elected chief executive officer and president.

title: U.S., 'FOR NOW,' ADVISES AGAINST ITALIAN WINES
description: A Federal agency today advised American consumers not to drink Italian wines until tests prove that the wines are not contaminated with methanol, which has been linked to 18 deaths in Italy.

title: ISLANDERS ON THE BRINK; FLYERS 2, RANGERS 1
description: He stopped Kerr and he stopped Poulin and Propp and Sinisalo tonight, but John Vanbiesbrouck could not produce a miracle by himself.

title: Roll Out the Barrel - Out, Out, Out
description: Large brown envelopes from the Office of the Vice President began arriving in press offices throughout town today in the latest attempt by George Bush's staff to end the political furor over his comments about the potential pitfalls of cheap oil.

title: ISLANDERS ON THE BRINK; CAPITALS 5, ISLANDERS 2
description: At one time, a two-goal deficit in a playoff game would not have intimidated the Islanders, especially with almost an entire period left to overcome it. And the two-game deficit that they brought on themselves by losing, 5-2, to the Washington Capitals tonight, would not have been so daunting.

title: PETROLEUM & RESOURCES CORP reports earnings for As of March 31
description: Assets represent net assets. The 1986 assets per share was after a capital gain distribution of $2.06 paid in February.

title: DANCE: MURRAY LOUIS AT THE JOYCE THEATER
description: DANCERS never seem to stop scampering in the choreography of Murray Louis.

title: BAYBANKS INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
FILM: 'BROKEN RAINBOW,' DOCUMENTARY
description: ''BROKEN RAINBOW,'' which won the Academy Award as the year's best documentary, is a moving plea on behalf of several thousand Navajos who are resisting relocation from their homes in Arizona. Using interviews with several of the Indians, archival footage, old photographs, clips from westerns and other material, Victoria Mudd, an anthropologist, and Maria Florio, a graphic designer, connect the present troubles of the Navajos with the force and fraud they have endured since the coming of the whites.

title: DEFENDANT IN SPY CASE TELLS WHY HE SOLD SECRETS TO SOVIET OFFICIALS
description: A former Army intelligence officer testified today that he sold secrets to the Soviet Union as part of a mission to infiltrate the Kremlin's intelligence apparatus in the Far East.

title: RENT CODE PLAN ATTACKED AT HEARING
description: Booing, hissing and shouting epithets at one another, hundreds of landlords and tenants gathered at a public hearing in Manhattan last night to attack proposed changes in the rent stabilization code, which governs nearly one million apartments in New York City.

title: Qualified Praise for Wallace
description: One of the prized trophies on my office wall is a picture of my oldest and fondest political foe. It is a picture of George C. Wallace and me, eyes locked in civil but stubborn opposition. On it, he wrote, ''No big problems we can't settle; that is, if you see it my way.'' As it turned out, Mr. Wallace, who announced his retirement from politics last week, came to see the great issue of the South my way. But he taught me something valuable about the people he so vividly championed.

title: COMPUTER RESEARCH CO reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
TWO TIED FOR MASTERS LEAD
description: Billy Kratzert dismissed his regular caddie Wednesday morning, recruited a hometown friend to carry his bag in the 50th Masters, and then went over the beautiful Augusta National Golf Club course today in four-under-par 68.

title: Thrift Unit Sale to Marine
description: In an unusual move to expand its market share in Westchester County, Marine Midland Banks Inc. agreed yesterday to acquire the Westchester Financial Services Corporation for $53 a share, or a total of about $106 million.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: FRIDAY, APRIL 11, 1986
description: International U.S. officials nearly alerted off-duty American soldiers at clubs in West Berlin before a bomb blast took place at a discotheque there last Saturday, Reagan Administration officials said. The officials said the United States was ''within five minutes'' of alerting various clubs of a bombing threat against Americans. Administration officials also claimed they now had ''incontrovertible evidence'' that Libya was linked to the West Berlin bombing. [ Page A1, Column 6. ]

title: ROBERT W. ABBETT
description: Robert W. Abbett, an engineer who designed the Broadway Bridge over the Harlem River and the Roosevelt Island Bridge, died Monday at Roosevelt Hospital. He was 83 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: CHARGES ASSERT PARKING BRIBES OF $3.8 MILLION
description: Nearly $3.8 million in bribes was paid or promised to city officials, Democratic Party officials and business executives in exchange for contracts at the city's Parking Violations Bureau, according to an analysis of recent state and Federal indictments.

title: PROSECUTORS SHIFTING EFFORTS AWAY FROM PARKING BUREAU
description: Prosecutors said yesterday that they had largely completed their investigations of the City Parking Violations Bureau and were now pursuing allegations of corruption elsewhere in municipal government.

title:
Advertising;
Diener/Hauser Seeks A Billings Showdown
description: Henry Weintraub, president of Diener/Hauser/Bates, is willing to disclose an audited report on the agency's 1985 billing figures in response to the contention by Stephen Rose, executive vice president of Y.&R.; Entertainment, that his is now the biggest show-biz specialty agency. At the same time, Mr. Rose said he doubted the published $115 million billings for Diener.

title: POP/JAZZ
description: FRANK SINATRA calls her Buddha, and she calls him Francis. Billie Holiday, whom she called Eleanor (her given name), was a close friend and unofficial tutor. And one night in the early 1940's, Eleanor, who was performing at a club on 52d Street called the Three Deuces, dragged Buddha and Francis across the street to a rival club, Tony's, where they saw Mabel Mercer for the first time.

title: INDUSTRIAL NATIONS SHUN ACTION ON OIL
description: Energy ministers from major industrial democracies today ruled out any joint action to stabilize world oil prices. This was their first meeting since prices began their downward march last autumn.

title: RATIONALE FOR DIESEL TEST WAS CURBING POLLUTION
description: In 1979, the city's Taxi and Limousine Commission began a program to test diesel-powered taxicabs, calling it another step in the city's effort to clean up its air.

title: Amex Head Buys Paper
description: Arthur Levitt Jr., chairman of the American Stock Exchange, has bought Roll Call, a 31-year-old weekly newspaper published here that covers Capitol Hill, according to Sidney Yudain, the paper's founder and editor. Mr. Levitt is not a newcomer to journalism, having worked for The Berkshire Eagle and Time Inc. before going to Wall Street. Mr. Yudain will continue to have a minority interest in the paper, which has a circulation of 7,000.

title: The Right Price of Oil
description: I think it essential that we talk about stability [ in oil prices ] and that we not just have a continuing free fall. . . . - Vice President Bush, April 1. [ America ] benefits greatly from low [ oil ] prices and ought to be pleased. - Vice President Bush, April 7.

title: 2 SOUTH AFRICANS IN DEBATE IN U.S.
description: In an exchange that was both sharp and conciliatory, South Africa's Ambassador to the United States and a black South African leader traded views before the nation's newspaper editors today on how to accomplish profound political changes in South Africa that both agreed were necessary.

title: Wildflowers Are Topic At Brooklyn Garden
description: They are as practical as they are beautiful, and many are slowly becoming extinct. They are wildflowers, the subject of a two-part series beginning tomorrow at the Brooklyn Botanic Garden, 1000 Washington Avenue.

title: UNITED TELECOMMUNICATIONS INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $7,435,000 for the latest quarter and $1,457,000 for the year- earlier period.

title: ENERGY DEPT. UNDER SCRUTINY OVER WASTE SITE, E.P.A. SAYS
description: The Environmental Protection Agency is investigating the Department of Energy for a possible criminal violation of the hazardous waste disposal law, a House committee was told today.

title: ALBANY'S WEEK OF GIVING: LITTLE EXTRAS THAT MEAN A LOT
description: Whether taxpayers realize it or not, the State Legislature voted this week to give $75,000 of their money to the Museum of Cheese, $40,000 to the Massena Rod and Gun Club, $10,000 to the Cadets of Pearl River drum and bugle corps for uniforms, $10,000 to the Southampton Antique Fire Truck Committee.

title: Q&A: Charles Murray; Of Babies And Stick
description: One of the Reagan Administration's main sources of inspiration on social welfare policy is a book by Charles Murray, a conservative social scientist.

title: AQUINO PLANNING VOTE ON U.S. BASES
description: President Corazon C. Aquino said Thursday that she would hold a referendum to ask the Filipino people if they wanted to keep two major American bases in the Philippines after 1991.

title: Credit Where Due
description: To the Editor:

title: SMALL TOWN IN VIRGINIA TENSE HOST TO LaROUCHE
description: The Leesburg Garden Club, according to Lyndon H. LaRouche Jr., is a ''nest of Soviet fellow travelers,'' and its members are ''clacking busybodies in this Soviet jellyfish front, sitting here in Leesburg oozing out their funny little propaganda and making nuisances of themselves.''

title: GIRL, 10, TELLS OF SEX ATTACKS IN TRIAL OF 4 IN WESTCHESTER
description: In a voice sometimes barely audible but in language that was graphic, a 10-year-old girl in pigtails told a jury in Westchester County Court today of her encounters with two of the defendants in a sexual abuse case.

title: FIRST BANK SYSTEM INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
HNG/Internorth Name
description: HNG/Internorth Inc. said today that shareholders had approved changing its name to the Enron Corporation.

title: Payments Cited So Far in Corruption Inquiry
description: From indictments handed up in Federal District Court on April 9, a criminal complaint filed March 26 and a March 27 State Supreme Court indictment in Manhattan. All amounts are cash or securities except $12,000 payment in '84-'85, which included a video cassette recorder and a color television set.

title: Money Fund Assets Up
description: Assets of the nation's money market mutual funds rose $4.83 billion, to $221.99 billion, for the week ended Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute said yesterday.

title: HOUSE PLANS LATIN AID COURSE
description: Democratic leaders in the House insisted today on following a procedure for the vote on aid to the rebels in Nicaragua that Administration supporters said could delay the aid.

title: Judge Schedules Trial For Friedman Aug. 4
description: A four-month agenda of motions and replies - culminating in a trial beginning Aug. 4 - was set yesterday for Stanley M. Friedman, the Bronx Democratic leader, and five other defendants indicted last month on state charges related to the Parking Violations Bureau scandal.

title: When a Group Home Joins the Community
description: To the Editor:

title: AUTODIE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
description: b-Includes a gain of $510,000 on the sale of equipment.

title: FOR PARIS, TOUGHER LINE ON TERRORISM
description: In its first few weeks in office, France's new conservative Government has been mapping out what officials here call a new approach to terrorism, an issue that preoccupied this country in the recent election campaign.

title: NORTH AMERICAN PHILIPS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The latest quarter net includes a gain of $5.4 million, or 19 cents a share, resulting from a change in accounting methods. The year-earlier quarter's net includes a gain of $6 million, or 21 cents a share, from the sale of bus transportation and attendant TV businesses.

title: KAISER ALUMINUM & CHEMICAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net loss and includes a loss from discontinued operations of $800,000.

title: WOMAN DIES HOURS AFTER AN AMBULANCE DEPARTS FROM SCENE
description: A Brooklyn woman died last night hours after an Emergency Medical Services ambulance crew that was summoned to aid her at her sister's home left without taking her to a hospital, the police said.

title: AUCTIONS
description: A CARTIER mystery clock that experts say once belonged to Eva Peron will be auctioned on Tuesday at Christie's, Park Avenue at 59th Street.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''The time has come to be united and push out the dictator who has ruled us for these nine years.'' -Benazir Bhutto, on her return to Pakistan, referring to President Mohammad Zia ul-Haq. [ A2:3. ]

title: BANK OF NEW YORK CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
New Chairman At Genesco
description: Genesco Inc., the financially troubled footwear and apparel company based in Nashville, said yesterday that its president, William S. Wire 2d, had been named chairman and chief executive. Mr. Wire, 54 years old, succeeds David K. Wilson, who resigned last week along with two other directors.

title: FEDERAL HOME LOAN BANK OF NY reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
FIRST VIRGINIA BANKS INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The year-ago figures were adjusted to reflect accounts of three acquired banks.

title: NATIONAL BANCSHARES OF TEXAS reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The company said the lower results are primarily due to a provision of $10.9 million made to its reserve for possible loan losses.

title: Tobi Kahn Is Wed To Miss Rapoport
description: Nessa Judith Rapoport, an author and senior editor at Bantam Books, and Tobi Aaron Kahn, a painter and sculptor who teaches at the School of Visual Arts, were married yesterday at the Park East Synagogue. Rabbi Yehuda Amital performed the ceremony.

title: Capital Cities Drop Seen
description: Capital Cities/ABC Inc. told Wall Street analysts yesterday that it expected 1986 earnings to drop to level of $7-to-$8 a share, because of the poor advertising environment and ABC's disappointing ratings.

title: BANDAG INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
AMERICAN SECURITY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
EARLY CLUES FOUND TO WOMB DISORDER BY TEAM AT HARVARD
description: Women with longer, heavier and more frequent menstrual periods are more likely to develop endometriosis, a disorder that can cause infertility and tumor growth, Harvard researchers said today.

title: UNITED BANCORP OF ARIZONA reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
GISLER'S 'TAGEDIEBE'
description: IN its spare, black-and-white photography and its feeling for earnestly pursued indolence, there's something familiar -second-hand, really - about ''Tagediebe,'' the first feature to be made by a young West German film maker named Marcel Gisler.

title: FRIEDRICH STAGES STRAUSS'S 'ELEKTRA'
description: GOTZ FRIEDRICH, the West German director, once explained his basic approach to opera: ''Anything is permitted, as long as the music isn't hurt and as long as the staging isn't boring.'' In his determined effort to avoid boredom, Mr. Friedrich has stretched his operatic interpretations to lengths that leave some traditionalists incensed while admirers talk about his audacious imagination. A striking example of his work can be seen tonight at 9 o'clock on Channel 13's ''Great Performances'' presentation of Richard Strauss's ''Elektra, a Tragedy in One Act.''

title: CULT LEADER AND SON CONVICTED IN NEBRASKA TORTURE AND MURDER
description: A jury today found a leader of a survivalist cult guilty of first-degree murder and his 16-year-old son guilty of second-degree murder in the torture-slaying of a cult member whose legs were flayed before he died.

title: CALIFORNIA BIOTECHNOLOGY reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
description: b-Net loss

title: SABATINI WINS LONG MATCH
description: An unseeded player at the 14th Family Circle Magazine Cup today toppled a highly-seeded one, and a relatively new pro came back in her match to defeat a tour veteran.

title: JEFFERSON BANCORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Results include net gains of $35,144 for the latest quarter and $115,651 for the year-earlier period from the sale of investment securities.

title: STATE INQUIRY SAYS TUROFF DEVISED CAB PLOT THAT EARNED $20 MILLION
description: The head of the State Commission of Investigation yesterday accused the former chairman of the city's Taxi and Limousine Commission, Jay L. Turoff, of masterminding a fraudulent environmental test that generated more than $20 million in revenue for a taxi company.

title: No Charge Limit Bill
description: A House Banking subcommittee chairman said he would not push legislation to limit credit card interest rates because he does not have enough votes to pass it.

title: Dining Guide: Tex-Mex
description: Following is a summary of reviews of restaurants that have appeared in The New York Times. Stars are followed by the date of original publication. Prices are current, and only weekend hours are given. ARIZONA 206, #206 East 60th Street (838-0440) -

title: OWENS-ILLINOIS INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The 1986 results include an after-tax charge of $1.7 million for capacity curtailments. The 1985 results include an after-tax charge of $10.3 million as part of the company's program to reduce overhead costs and an after-tax gain of $4.7 million from the sale of timeberlands.

title: Orders and Shipments of Chips Increase
description: Semiconductor companies based in the United States, Europe and Japan reported increased orders and shipments today for the month of March.

title: PENALTIES INCREASED IN MOVE BY ITALIANS ON WINE POISONINGS
description: The government decreed new measures today to police the wine industry as a result of the scandal caused by the poisoning of some inexpensive table wines with wood alcohol.

title: INTERFIRST PLUNGES 86.1%
description: The First Chicago Corporation, the nation's 10th-largest bank-holding company and Chicago's largest, yesterday reported record earnings in the first quarter, as its profits jumped 57.9 percent from the period a year earlier.

title: New York Mistreats Jazz
description: New York's historic lack of interest in the well-being of its artistic community is nowhere more blatant than in its suppression of jazz music through the enforcement of a section of the administrative code known as the ''cabaret law,'' a regulation that severely limits the performance of music in any but the approximately 180 establishments officially licensed as cabarets throughout the five boroughs.

title: Drug Use at Home Can Affect Safety on the Job
description: To the Editor:

title: THE DANCE: PAUL TAYLOR'S 'JUNCTION'
description: Paul Taylor created ''Junction'' in the 1960's, early in his career and at a time when the choreographer was performing with Martha Graham. One suspects that the pretty, mostly lighthearted dance, revived by the Paul Taylor Dance Company on Wednesday at City Center after an 11-year absence from the repertory, might have been a response to the often dark theatrical vision of Miss Graham and the angry and anxious views of life that earlier helped to define American modern dance.

title: BOILING RICE AND BUBBLY SODA
description: A discussion in this column dealing with the disappearance of the effervescence from soft drinks has drawn several new explanations from readers. And a column on cooking rice and other grains also elicited a flurry of mail.

title: PARK COMMUNICATIONS reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
ELECTRO-CATHETER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
description: b-Net income

title: AMSOUTH BANCORPORATION reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
OFFICERS ARREST BRONX MAN, 24, IN 20 BURGLARIES
description: A 24-year-old Bronx man has been charged with 20 apartment burglaries and robberies in fashionable Manhattan neighborhoods since last August, the police said.

title:
SCOUTING;
PULLING WEIGHT
description: Some more on weight problems from Coach Frank Layden of the Utah Jazz: ''When I was a kid, my coach once told me to haul my rear end. It took me two trips.''

title: DOW OFF 4.12, TO 1,790.18
description: Stock prices declined slightly yesterday, as investors, already concerned about the Libyan situation, decided to take some profits while waiting to see whether the Federal Reserve cuts the discount rate.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article in some copies of Metropolitan Report on March 12 about the relative dates of Passover and Easter misstated a rule about when Passover may begin. Because of the Jewish calendar provision for other holidays, the first day of Passover may fall on any day but Monday, Wednesday or Friday.

title: HAZARDOUS HOUSEHOLD APPLIANCES
description: Every year the Consumer Product Safety Commission, an independent Federal agency created by Congress in 1973 to protect consumers from hazards, negotiates the recall or modification of dozens of products that it feels are dangerous.

title: CONGRESSMAN'S DEATH STARTS BATTLE FOR SEAT FROM QUEENS
description: The death of Representative Joseph P. Addabbo set off a political battle yesterday in Queens and left the House without one of its most influential critics of the Pentagon.

title: ITALIAN WINE: HARD-WON IMAGE IS SHATTERED
description: The Italian wine scandal is a disaster for that country's wine industry whose effects may be felt for many years to come. What is more, its impact may cast a shadow over all European wines.

title: CUOMO FAULTS PARTY OFFICIALS IN ALBANY JOBS
description: Governor Cuomo said today that he would ''encourage'' the Assembly and Senate to prohibit political-party officials from holding staff jobs in the Legislature.

title: ARGUELLO ENDS CAREER
description: Alexis Arguello, the former three-division boxing champion who returned to the ring last October after a two-year retirement, has abandoned his quest for an unprecedented fourth championship after learning that he suffers from coronary artery disease. The diagnosis was made after the 34-year-old boxer knocked out Billy Costello in Reno Feb. 9.

title: SEUNKE'S 'PERVOLA,' A DUTCH FAMILY DRAMA
description: ''Pervola: Tracks in the Snow,'' a new Dutch film written (in part) and directed by Orlow Seunke, is the kind of movie that demands interpretation, not because it's so dense with associations but because the only apparent meanings are too slim to justify the effort that went into the production.

title: KOHL WARNS U.S. AGAINST A STRIKE
description: Chancellor Helmut Kohl cautioned the United States today against taking retaliatory military action against Libya. He acknowledged that West Germany had ''a whole lot of indications'' of Libyan involvement in the bombing of a West Berlin discotheque.

title: ROWAN COMPANIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income

title: RANGERS' AIM: MORE GOALS
description: They have the hot goalie. The other guys have the cold, nervous goalie. So the Rangers' two most important playoff wishes have been granted. And yet there is still a sticking point in their master plan to upset the Flyers. The Rangers are again looking for the strategy that would circumvent that stonewalling Philadelphia defense.

title: SAFETY-KLEEN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 22
description: b-Includes a gain of $3,706,000 resulting from an accounting change.

title: HIBERNIA CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
BROWN SENIOR ACCUSED AGAIN IN PROSTITUTION CASE
description: A Brown University senior and a Providence insurance agent were indicted today on charges of participating in a prostitution ring.

title: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS MAHINES CORP (IBM) (N) reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
U.S. CALLED 'CLOSE' TO 'FINAL' DECISION ON ROLE OF LIBYA
description: The White House chief of staff said today that the Administration was ''coming close'' to a ''final conclusion'' on whether Libya was responsible for the bombing last week of a West Berlin discotheque frequented by American soldiers.

title: 2 GUNMEN HELD AFTER SHOOT-OUT
description: The owner of a midtown jewelry concern, who had survived Nazi labor camps, was killed in a robbery yesterday by thugs who wounded a bystander and narrowly missed a police officer in a running gun battle on the crowded streets of the diamond district.

title: U.S. Aid to Contras Is Chief Obstacle to Peace With Nicaragua
description: To the Editor:

title: WINNING DEBUT FOR TEWKSBURY
description: Unlike the reception given a certain other pitcher on the Yankees' staff, Yankee Stadium fans saluted Bob Tewksbury with a standing ovation last night. But then, Tewksbury had just pitched the longest of any of the team's starters in this first week of the season.

title: SECURITY AIDE TELLS COURT JOHNSON FEARED WIFE MIGHT TRY TO KILL HIM
description: J. Seward Johnson, the heir to the Johnson & Johnson pharmaceutical fortune, was afraid in the mid-1970's that his wife might try to kill him, the former chief of security at the Johnson estate testified yesterday.

title: O'SULLIVAN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
U.S. and Soviet Agree On Germany Sentries
description: The United States and the Soviet Union have negotiated an agreement that American officials hope will reduce the possibility that Soviet sentries will fire on United States soldiers authorized to work inside East Germany, the Pentagon said today.

title: BALLESTEROS LEADING MASTERS
description: Seve Ballesteros, limited in his United States appearances this year by the PGA Tour and its commissioner, Deane Beman, came to the 50th Masters a determined man who said he was ready to win. The skilled Spaniard today began proving he meant just that, despite the enforced layoff.

title: BEATRICE-KOHLBERG
description: The shareholders of the Beatrice Companies voted overwhelmingly today to approve the $6.2 billion acquisition by Kohlberg Kravis Roberts & Company, the New York-based investment firm. In a meeting in New York, the shareholders of the Chicago-based food and consumer goods company voted to accept the bid for $40 in cash and $10 in preferred stock in what is the largest leveraged buyout in history. Over 97 percent of the shares voted at the meeting, representing more than 81 percent of the shares outstanding, favored the acquisition, which is expected to be completed next Thursday.

title: HISTORIC CEMETERY
description: So many famous - and some infamous - people have been buried in the Green-Wood Cemetery in Brooklyn that one could get the idea that the 425-acre tract of green hills, lakes and flowering trees has no more room for the dead.

title: RESORTS STOCK UP SHARPLY
description: The stock of Resorts International Inc., which owns a casino in Atlantic City and other valuable properties, soared yesterday after the death of its chairman, James M. Crosby. Wall Street perceives that the company will now be up for sale, analysts said.

title: ARIZONA BANCWEST reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
HEAD OF KEY DEFENSE PANEL
description: Representative Joseph P. Addabbo, a Queens Democrat who had a powerful hand in shaping national defense policy as chairman of a key House subcommittee, died late Thursday at Walter Reed Army Medical Center in Washington. He was 61 years old.

title: HEILIG-MEYERS reports earnings for Year to Feb 28
description: The company changed its fiscal year-end to Feb. 28 to reflect a more natural business cycle within a 12- month period. The latest period consisted of only 11 months, while the prior year included 12 months.

title: REAGANS PAID $122,703 IN TAX ON GROSS INCOME OF $394,492
description: President Reagan and Nancy Reagan paid $122,703 in Federal income tax on their 1985 gross income of $394,492, according to their tax return, which they disclosed today.

title: BOY SCOUT RECRUITER, SECT MEMBER, HELD IN CHILD ABUSE CASE
description: Two members of a religious sect in Jamaica, Queens, one of whom was identified as an executive in a local Boy Scouts organization, were arraigned early this morning in Queens Criminal Court after their arrest yesterday on charges that they beat children and forced them to beg for money.

title: DENISON MINES LTD reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: After preferred share dividends there were no common share earnings in the latest period. Denison Mines is listed on the Toronto stock exchange.

title: YUGOSLAV AUTO EXPORTS
description: The Yugoslav car manufacturer Zavodi Crvena Zastava will export 295,000 cars worth $1 billion to the United States in 1990, the Tanyug press agency said.

title:
PATENTS;
SENSOR ON ARM AIDS LIP-READING BY DEAF
description: A device to be worn on the arm can provide a profoundly deaf person with tactile sensations that represent voice pitch and intonation patterns.

title: CAPITALS LIKE THEIR CHANCES
description: The Washington Capitals, up by two games and needing just one victory to topple their opponents from the playoffs, are no longer haunted by the Islanders. That is obvious in the methodical play of Rod Langway, the Capitals' paragon of poise. It can be glimpsed in the eyes of Bobby Carpenter, who senses his team is on solid footing against the Islanders for the first time in four playoff seasons and who, although hobbled by a knee injury, cannot bear to miss this opportunity to dismiss them from the series.

title: CLASH OF COASTS: WEST AND EAST PLAN THE 4TH
description: At first, the team from Los Angeles that is in New York to stage festivities for the Statue of Liberty centennial was a bit sniffy about the concert in Central Park over the July 4 weekend. It would draw maybe 50,000 people? Astonished New York officials, accustomed to crowds of half a million or more for events in the park, replied that if so, the concert would probably be canceled out of sheer humiliation.

title: MOLEX INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
TREASURY BILLS, BONDS MIXED
description: Short-term interest rates edged lower yesterday, while bond prices gave up some ground amid profit taking and worries over tensions between the United States and Libya.

title: JAMES M. CROSBY, 58, FOUNDER OF HOTEL AND CASINO CONCERN
description: James M. Crosby, the founder and chairman of Resorts International Inc., died during surgery Thursday at New York University Medical Center. Mr. Crosby, who had suffered from severe emphysema for years, was 58 years old and had homes in Manhattan, Atlantic City, and Paradise Island, the Bahamas.

title: GIRL TELLS OF RAPE AT DAY-CARE CENTER
description: An 11-year-old girl told a jury today that she had been raped and sodomized as a 6-year-old by James Watt, one of four Mount Vernon residents who are on trial in a sex abuse case.

title: Vive La France
description: At a champagne and dessert reception at the French Embassy the other night, Washington's music community wished a happy 70th birthday to the composer Henri Dutilleux after two of his works were performed by the National Symphony Orchestra. Then Ambassador Em-manuel de Margerie introduced a second guest, this one a surprise: Alice Tully, the arts patron whose gifts include the New York concert hall bearing her name. Mr. de Margerie, with a kiss and a flourish, presented a medal designating Miss Tully an Officer in the Legion of Honor.

title: BURR AND GRIFFITH BACK IN FAMILIAR TV ROLES
description: Actors who try to re-create beloved characters after a long absence recognize the risks of such revivals. Nevertheless, Raymond Burr agreed to star in a two-hour television movie, ''Perry Mason Returns,'' 20 years after the cancellation of the old ''Perry Mason'' series.

title: CAREMARK INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 30
SATURDAY NEWS QUIZ
description: Questions are based on news reports in The Times this week. 1. This footware is the latest in traffic-stopping accessories. Explain. 2. ''I am irrelevant,'' someone said in a surprise telephone call to ''Let's Be Happy,'' an early-morning radio program. Who made the call and what did he urge listeners to do? 3. ''I can't find myself quarreling with any of the remarks he made,'' President Reagan said, referring to Vice President Bush. What were the circumstances? 4. According to the decision of a Federal appeals court, the health warnings mandated by Federal law on cigarette packages protect tobacco companies from claims that they failed to provide adequate notice of the hazards of smoking. True or false? 5. Most of the damage to the space shuttle Challenger was caused by (fire/explosion/impact with the ocean), according to scientists who have analyzed the debris. 6. Although the portrait ''Marquesa de Santa Cruz'' had been expected to bring a record price of more than $10 million at auction in London, its owner sold it for only $6 million in last-minute private negotiations. What was at issue and who was the artist? 7. For some governments in Western Europe, people's liaison bureaus have often meant trouble. What are they and why were they in the news? 8. In some circles, this was ''trauma week,'' a time of truth and consequences. Explain. 9. A 25-minute gap ended a long-time Cincinnati baseball tradition. What happened? 10.

title: EX-MANES AIDE BACKED FOR A STATE SENATE SEAT
description: Democratic district leaders in Queens have pushed aside a longtime state legislator, Senator Leonard P. Stavisky, and endorsed a former top aide of Donald R. Manes for the seat.

title: STUN GUN USED ON YOUTH, JURY IS TOLD
description: A prosecutor said in court yesterday that a Queens teen-ager had confessed to a minor drug charge after a police sergeant repeatedly shocked him with an electric stun gun and threatened to apply it to the youth's testicles.

title: NEW FARES MATCHED BY 2
description: Two major carriers, Delta Air Lines and Northwest Airlines, said yesterday that they would match the new discount fare introduced by American Airlines on Thursday.

title: Ransom Deadline Passes In Guinness Kidnapping
description: A deadline for payment of a $2.6 million ransom for the wife of a prominent banker passed today, but the police said that it had not been paid and that there had been no word from the kidnappers.

title: U.N. LETS U.S. SEE FILE ON WALDHEIM
description: The United Nations today permitted the United States to examine a secret United Nations War Crimes Commission file on former Secretary General Kurt Waldheim.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: THIRTY-NINE The Baby Grand thinks of itself as ''a Harlem landmark.'' Its doors, at 319 West 125th Street, have been open since 1947. Patrons there laughed at Nipsey Russell before he was seen on national television, when he was known simply as the comedian at the Baby Grand. Lena Horne sang there. Ruth Brown, another singer, had a long, long run. Recently, Bill Cosby used the club as a setting in one of his shows and so has a beer commercial. And musicians working at the nearby Apollo theater would sometimes duck into the Baby Grand between shows for a quick refresher. The club has survived because it is small, inexpensive, well appointed and hospitable.

title: UNITED BISCUITS ENDS IMPERIAL BID
description: United Biscuits P.L.C., the largest cookie maker outside the United States, today dropped its $3.8 billion bid for Imperial Group P.L.C., which produces beer, cigarettes and snack foods.That allows a rival British conglomerate, Hanson Trust P.L.C., to forge ahead unimpeded with a hostile $3.4 billion bid for Imperial, whose directors had backed the United Biscuits offer - one of the largest in British corporate history.

title: G.M. INCENTIVE PLAN
description: The General Motors Corporation will offer a new auto sales incentive program Sunday, with the centerpiece a prevailing loan interest rate of slightly more than 8 percent, WWJ radio in Detroit reported today. The program will contain as many as three interest rate programs on cars financed through its in-house credit subsidiary, the General Motors Acceptance Corporation.

title: Shevardnadze Visit Set
description: The Soviet Foreign Minister, Eduard A. Shevardnadze, will visit Washington on May 14-16 for talks to prepare for a summit meeting between Mikhail S. Gorbachev, the Soviet leader, and President Reagan, Ambassador Anatoly F. Dobrynin said today.

title: CLAROSTATE MANUFACTURING CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 29
description: Corrected from Thursday's editions.

title: AETNA IS SUED
description: A class action lawsuit has been filed against the insurer for the A.H. Robins Company, maker of the Dalkon Shield intrauterine device that was taken off the market in 1974 because of injuries suffered by women who used it. The suit, filed Thursday in Federal District Court in St. Paul, is the first against the Aetna Casualty and Surety Company in connection with the Dalkon Shield. Robins filed for bankruptcy protection last year, and the approximately 250,000 women who claim injuries from the Dalkon Shield will be paid along with other creditors.

title: RIGHTS STAFF TOLD TO REWORK MINORITY BUSINESS REPORT
description: The United States Commission on Civil Rights today directed its staff to rework a report that recommended a one-year suspension of Federal programs that reserve contracts for black, Hispanic or female employers.

title: PEC ISRAEL ECONOMIC CORP reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-Includes a tax benefit of $2,059,388. The latest year revenue includes about $1.3 million realized as a result of the exchange of shares of Canada Israel Development.

title: NIAGARA SHARE CORP reports earnings for As of March 31
description: Assets represent net assets.

title: EPSILON DATA MANAGEMENT reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
description: b-Net Income.

title: MARYLAND NATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
AN AFGHAN TALE: AN AMERICAN'S BODY FOR RANSOM
description: An Afghan religious leader says he has the body of an American reporter killed last fall in Afghanistan and will not release it until an American doctor fulfills a pledge to provide rebels with a hospital.

title: FLEET NATIONAL BANK INDICTED
description: A grand jury investigating corruption at the state mortgage agency today indicted the Fleet National Bank and three top bank officials on fraud charges.

title: NICHOLS, S.E. INC reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 1
CORRECTION
description: A report by The Associated Press about British Airways in some copies of Business Day yesterday misstated the airline's new round-trip fare between New York and London. It is $458.

title: ANSWERS TO QUIZ
description: Questions appear on page 14. 1. The New York City Police Department has authorized the shoes, a semisoft-soled model, for its officers. 2. In a call from his exile in Honolulu to the Manila station, former President Ferdinand E. Marcos of the Philippines urged his countrymen to unite behind President Corazon C. Aquino. 3. The President appeared to be trying to extricate Mr. Bush from a situation created by his appeal for ''stability'' in oil prices, which appeared to contradict Mr. Reagan's advocacy of a free market for oil. 4. True. 5. Impact with the ocean. 6. The Spanish Government, which contends that the portrait by Goya was exported from Spain illegally, paid the British owner $6 million in ''compensation'' and the work will be returned to Spain. 7. They are embassies of Libya. The Reagan Administration has pressed allies to shut the bureaus, contending they are targeting Americans and American institutions for terrorist acts. 8. It was the week when colleges mailed out their admissions letters. 9. The Reds traditionally are hosts for the opening game in the major leagues, but this year the Detroit Tigers opened at home with the Red Sox, starting their game 25 minutes before Cincinnati's game with the Phillies. 10. Smallpox vaccine. 11. The bag was used to cut out light inside a plane cruising at 35,000 feet, which had been chartered for a Halley's comet-viewing party. 12. Tainted wines. 13. A ban on the interstate sale of pistols was preserved. 14.

title: BURR-BROWN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes a charge of 8 cents a share from the cumulative effect of an accounting change.

title:
SCOUTING;
MAKING THE POINT
description: If peacock feathers are supposed to be plucked gently, then somebody had better pass the word to the Fairfield University baseball team. Playing a doubleheader against the Peacocks from St. Peter's last Saturday, the Stags, who went in with a record of 2-11, opted for howitzers instead of tweezers and came away with a sweep by scores of 24-5 and 27-3.

title: AGENCY FREES OIL FUNDS
description: Yielding to the threat of a lawsuit from Congress, the Office of Management and Budget today released $156.8 million that Congress has appropriated to expand the capacity of the Strategic Petroleum Reserve.

title: SCHULMAN, A. INC reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
description: The share earnings reflect 10 percent stock dividend paid in November.

title: BRADLEY REAL ESTATE TRUST reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
description: b-Includes capital gains of $53,165 for the quarter and 6 months. c-Includes capital gains of $154,483 for the quarter and $381,181 for the 6 months.

title: COMINGS AND GOINGS
description: Ray Burris, the 35-year-old pitcher who has worked for the Mets, Yankees, Chicago Cubs, Montreal Expos and Oakland A's, signed a free-agent contract to pitch for the St. Louis Cardinals' farm club in Louisville. . . . The Vancouver Canucks were fined $5,000 because of the March 21 outburst by Coach Tom Watts, who accused Referee Don Koharski, of ''deliberately cheating us out of two points,'' in a game against the Calgary Flames. . . . Lisa Larsen, who won the women's division of the Boston Marathon last year, said she would miss the race April 21 because of a stress fracture she suffered in her left leg during a 15-kilometer race in Florida last month.

title: STRYKER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
MUSIC: BROOKLYN ORCHESTRA
description: Henry Cowell wrote a three-movement Harmonica Concerto in 1962 for the late John Sebastian, who became ill shortly thereafter and never played the work. It was left to the young harmonica virtuoso Robert Bonfiglio and the indefatigably adventuresome conductor Lukas Foss and his Brooklyn Philharmonic Symphony Orchestra to provide a premiere of the concerto, which they did last weekend at the Brooklyn Academy of Music.

title: FIRST AMARILLO BANCORPORATION INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income and includes income from discontinued operations of $273,303.

title: WILLAMETTE INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
The Defeat of Gotbaum Is a Major Loss for Unions
description: It was a clean election at New York City's Central Labor Council last month. But it was not a good day for the future of organized labor.

title: JONES INTERCABLE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
description: b-Includes gains on the sale of assets, including the sale of a cable television system serving Jerseyville, Illinois, which resulted in a pre-tax gain of about $358,600, or 2 cents a share. Also, an investment in an unaffiliated corporation with cable television operations in the Denver area was sold, resulting in a pre-tax gain of $2,550,000.

title: LITTLE, ARTHUR D. INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
QUAREX INDUS reports earnings for Year to Jan 3
Florida Says Pharmacists May Prescribe Drugs
description: Pharmacists in Florida will be able to prescribe drugs for minor ailments under rules approved today.

title: THOMPSON MEDICAL CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
HELMS RESOURCES CO reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-Includes a loss from discontinued operations of $1,590,000 and an extraordinary gain of $1,941,000, as well as a pre-tax gain of $271,000. c-Includes a loss from discontinued operations of $10,235,000 and a pre-tax gain of $1,295,000.

title: Battle Near Volcano Reported in Salvador
description: A battalion of about 360 soldiers battled leftist guerrillas Friday along the San Salvador Volcano ridge, leaving at least two rebels dead and four wounded, an army officer said.

title:
PATENTS;
5 RECEIVE HONORS AS INVENTORS
description: THREE staff members of the Cetus Corporation, a genetic engineering company in Emeryville, Calif., received Inventor of the Year awards this week from Intellectual Property Owners Inc., an association that represents holders of patents, trademarks and copyrights.

title: No Deals Until We Hear the Afghans and Pakistanis
description: To the Editor:

title: GRAND AUTO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 26
description: b-Net income. The latest quarter loss is after a charge of $871,000 for inventory shrinkage.

title: OTB'S SURE THING
description: I saw the future of offtrack betting yesterday, and it works. Not quite well enough to make a thoroughly law-abiding citizen out of a horseplayer such as The Russian, but well enough to suggest that OTB, a social embarrassment in New York for a decade, is ready to move the horse-racing industry forward.

title: Clear Up Contra Charge, U.S. Lawmakers Say
description: Congressional backers of President Reagan's $100 million aid package for Nicaraguan rebels said today that allegations of corruption and drug trafficking by rebels must be cleared up, and one said Mr. Reagan had personally promised to get the answers.

title: KNICKS ARE BEATEN IN THE HOME FINALE
description: The evening was really nothing more than a chance for the Knicks to breathe a collective sigh of relief. They played their final home game of the season last night, and it ended in typical misery: a 108-95 defeat to the Detroit Pistons before 14,022 at the Garden.

title: CAVALIERS ELIMINATED
description: Kevin McHale scored 30 points as Boston helped to eliminate Cleveland from the playoff race with a 117-104 victory.

title: WINE BUYERS' REACTION MIXED
description: Customer resistance to Italian wines was reported mixed yesterday in a random check of wine stores and restaurants around the United States.

title: The Sweet Smell of 'Success' Isn't All That Sweet
description: John Milton was a failure. In writing ''Paradise Lost,'' his stated aim was to ''justify the ways of God to men.'' Inevitably, he fell short of accomplishing that and only wrote a monumental poem. Beethoven, whose music was conceived to transcend Fate, was a failure, as was Socrates, whose ambition was to make people happy by making them reasonable and just. The inescapable conclusion seems to be that the surest, noblest way to fail is to set one's own standards titanically high.

title: MINISCRIBE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31

description: The Economy

title:
PATENTS;
GAINS IN ELIMINATING A SATELLITE'S HEAT
description: An earth-orbiting satellite, with improved facilities to get rid of the heat generated by its electronic equipment, was patented this week for Satellite Business Systems of McLean, Va. James F. Dalby is the inventor named in patent 4,580,748.

title: HYDE ATHLETIC INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-Net income Corrected from Thursday's editions.

title: MAKEOVERS: WHAT YOU GET FOR THE MONEY
description: Some people go through life always looking the same. They may visibly age a bit, but they don't really alter their style. Other people change with the times; women go from long hair to short, men go from clean-shaven to bearded. Still other people change their looks the way they change their clothes - by the season, for special occasions, or simply on a whim.

title: HARD TIMES FOR GARRISON
description: It was a match she was expected to win. On a sun-dappled court - the morning sun was finding its persistent way through the nearby tall pine trees - she looked coolly proficient in a white blouse and flouncy turquoise tennis skirt.

title: A STEAM PIPE BURSTS AND DISRUPTS SUBWAY
description: An underground steam pipe in midtown Manhattan burst last night, sending steam and what were said to be asbestos particles into the street and halting subway service early this morning on portions of the West Side, authorities said.

title: ABC MORNING NEWS CANCELS TRIP TO EUROPE
description: ABC, citing recent anti-American terrorist acts in Europe, has canceled a weeklong trip to France and Italy planned for its morning news program, ''Good Morning America.''

title: MUSIC: ROREM WORK BY ATLANTA SYMPHONY
description: The Atlanta Symphony came to Carnegie Hall Sunday night, bringing with it Ned Rorem's new String Symphony. The orchestra and its music director, Robert Shaw, had commissioned the piece, and this was its first performance in New York.

title: TERRAMAR CORP reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
Raise the Toll to $10
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S. SAID TO SEEK SOVIET TERROR AID
description: Senior Western diplomats said today that the United States had unsuccessfully sought Soviet help in an effort to prevent terrorist attacks in Europe by Libyans based in East Germany.

title: RUMORS SPUR SPERRY, NCR
description: Rumors of a possible merger between the NCR Corporation and the Sperry Corporation sent the stocks of both computer companies higher on Wall Street yesterday in heavy trading.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: A report in the Briefing column of the Washington Talk page yesterday misidentified the Utah House district in which Wayne Owens is a 1986 Democratic candidate and misidentified the Representative he seeks to replace. Mr. Owens is running in the Second District, centered on Salt Lake City, where the prospective retirement of Representative David Smith Monson, a Republican, has created a vacancy. Representative Howard C. Nielson, a Republican, is running for re-election in the Third District and is not retiring.

title: Stanley Friedman's Jeopardies
description: Indicted a second time in New York's corruption inquiry, Stanley Friedman, the Democratic boss of the Bronx, repleads his innocence. He has every right to the presumption of innocence and to defend himself against both state and Federal fraud charges. He has less of a case when he pleads double jeopardy. He has no case at all when he claims constitutional support for clinging to office.

COMPUTONE SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
description: b-Net income

title: SATURDAY SPORTS
description: Baseball Yankees vs. Milwaukee Brewers, at Yankee Stadium, 1:35 P.M. (Television - SportsChannel, 1:30 P.M. Radio - WABC 770, 1:30 P.M.) Mets vs. Phillies, at Philadelphia, 1:20 P.M. The backup game is the Royals vs. the Toronto Blue Jays, at Kansas City. (Television -Channel 4, 1:15 P.M. Radio -WHN 1050 1:15 P.M.) Atlanta Braves vs. Astros, at Houston. (Television - WTBS, 8:35 P.M.) Basketball Knicks vs. Bucks, at Milwaukee, 9 P.M. The season ends for the Knicks. (Television - Channel 9, 9 P.M.) Bowling $125,000 Long Island Open, at Garden City Bowl, Meadowbrook Parkway and Stewart Avenue, Garden City, L.I., 3 P.M. Championship round.(Television - Channel 7, 3 P.M.) Boxing Mark Breland vs. Darryl Anthony, 10 rounds, welterweights, at Ice World, Route 46 and Union Blvd., Totowa, N.J. First preliminary, 3 P.M. Breland, the five-time Golden Gloves champion and 1984 Olympic gold-medal winner, tries to avenge the only blemish on his record in 121 amateur and professional fights. He was 110-1 as an amateur, losing in a three-round split decision to Anthony in the 1981 National Championships. (Television - Channel 7, 4:30 P.M.) Amateurs: United States Box-Off for the Goodwill Games at Lake Tahoe, Nev. The current United States champions in 12 weight classes will be competing against their worthiest opponents for the right to attend the 1986 Goodwill Games in Moscow. (Television -WTBS, 3 P.M.) Golf The Masters, at Augusta, Ga., third round. (Television - Channel 2, 3:30 P.M. to 6 P.M., live.) L.P.G.A. Kyocera Inamori Classic, third round, at San Diego.

title: RETAIL SALES FALL SHARP 0.8%
description: Sales at the retail level declined a sharp eight-tenths of 1 percent in March, the steepest drop in five months, the Government said today. Analysts said the decline had been expected because of the weakness in car sales and the plummeting price of gasoline.

description: Prime Minister Yasuhiro Nakasone will arrive in Washington on Saturday, eager to silence criticism of Japan's trade policies.

description: The Soviet Union renounced its moratorium on underground nuclear testing today, saying continued American tests threatened Soviet security.

title: TEXACO JUDGE SAID TO WAVER
description: Texaco's stock price rose yesterday in heavy trading and the Pennzoil Company's fell following a report that a Texas judge believes he may have misinterpreted the law that was the basis for a jury's multibillion-dollar verdict against Texaco.

title: Stranger Than Fiction
description: BIGFOOT DREAMS. By Francine Prose. 280 pages. Pantheon. $16.95.

description: Richard Craig Smith, the former Army intelligence officer who said he sold information about United States spying operations to the Soviet Union as part of a plot to infiltrate the Soviet intelligence agency, was found not guilty today at his espionage trial.

title: BURLINGTON NORTHERN INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
BARRAGE AT FORT SUMTER STILL ECHOES IN THE SOUTH
description: Just before dawn on April 12, 1861, a Confederate artillery battery fired a shell over the ramparts of Fort Sumter, S.C., the first round in a 34-hour bombardment that marked the beginning of the Civil War.

title: TWO END ATTEMPT TO BUY MINEBEA
description: The first hostile takeover attempt ever mounted by a foreign concern in Japan ended today when Trafalgar Holdings and Glen International Financial Services sold their shares in the Minebea Company.

description: The latest quarter results include earnings of NS&T Bankshares, acquired Dec. 27, 1985.

title: 59 MORE CUTS EXPECTED
description: In the latest round of continuing staff cutbacks at Capital Cities/ABC, 36 employees were laid off yesterday by WABC-TV, the network-owned station in New York. At least 95 positions will be eliminated by the end of the year, station officials said.

description: b-Net income and after tax credits of $167,471 for the quarter and $85,087 for the 6 months. c-Includes a gain of $565,000 on the sale of a subsidiary's fixed assets and a charge of $191,176 for a minority interest in a subsidiary.

title: NIEKRO LOSES IN INDIAN DEBUT
description: Forty-seven-year-old Phil Niekro yielded only one earned run today but lost in his debut with the Cleveland Indians, who signed the knuckleball pitcher after the Yankees cut him just before the season opened.

title: INVESTOR RAISES SEA-LAND OFFER
description: Harold Simmons, the Dallas investor who has been seeking control of the Sea-Land Corporation since July, said yesterday that he had raised his bid by $1 a share, to $26 in cash.

title: TRAFFIC OFFICER BEATEN BY MAN GIVEN SUMMONS
description: A New York City traffic officer was beaten unconscious yesterday after he issued a summons to a man who had illegally parked his car on a sidewalk in Greenwich Village, the authorities said.

title: 7-Eleven Stores to End Sales of Adult Magazines
description: The parent company of the 7-Eleven stores has announced it will stop selling adult magazines, and fundamentalist religious leaders immediately ended a boycott of the establishments.

title: PULTE HOME CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After a charge of $3,300,000 related to mortgage hedging losses.

title: LIVING IN A CASTLE BY ROYAL FAVOR
description: The most exclusive residences in Britain, never offered for sale or rent, are the ''grace and favor'' apartments in the royal palaces and castles. They are available only at the Queen's request.

title: BATTLE INTENSIFIES IN BID FOR WALKER
description: The bidding for Hiram Walker Resources Ltd. intensified yesterday as the Reichmann family of Canada, operating through the Gulf Canada Corporation, offered to pay $27.40 a share, or $2.3 billion, for the 76 percent of the oil and liquor producer it does not already own or control.

title: BROKEN HILL, ELDERS IN TALKS
description: Leaders of Elders IXL Ltd. and the Broken Hill Proprietary Company met today to discuss Elders' one-day purchase of nearly 19 percent of Broken Hill's stock on the open market Thursday. But John Elliott, Elders chairman, and Broken Hill's directors refused comment after the meeting, which was hurriedly called after Elders bought the stock for the equivalent of $1.2 billion.

title: BAR TO CANADA TRADE TALKS IS SEEN
description: A majority of the Senate Finance Committee, expressing home state interests and irritation with Reagan trade policies, said today that it would vote against giving the Administration the authority to conclude a free trade agreement with Canada.

title: Low-Sulfur Coal in the Battle on Acid Rain
description: To the Editor:
