SCREEN: 'BAND OF THE HAND'
description: Take five apparently incorrigible young criminals. Put them into the hands of a combination of Rambo and Tarzan, who takes them into the wild, teaches them the arts of survival, self-esteem and sensitivity, and brings them back to Miami to wipe out the city's drug dealers and low lifes.

title: CORRECTION
description: A Washington dispatch yesterday on the House's adoption of a bill on the sale and transportation of guns misstated a provision of the 1968 law that would be amended. Under that law, states and localities kept the authority to regulate the transportation of firearms if they chose. The new House bill provides that regardless of any local regulations, a person has a guaranteed Federal right to carry firearms across state lines if the weapons are unloaded, inaccessible and intended for a legal purpose.

title: LINDBERG CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes a one-time gain of $108,000, or 2 cents a share, from final proceeds of land that was taken by eminent domain.

title: MARK SET IN SAIL OF GLOBE
description: Dodge Morgan, a 54-year-old electronics entrepreneur from Maine, touched land today after reducing by nearly half the previous best time for sailing alone around the world nonstop.

title: SPIRIT SOCCER CLUB FOLDS
description: The Pittsburgh Spirit indoor soccer team, which lost a reported $2.4 million this season, has folded and no buyer will be sought, according to Paul Martha, a club vice president.

title:
SCOUTING;
KEEPING ROWING FOR ITS OWN SAKE
description: A poor sister among preoccupied and far more glamorous relatives has found the strength to save herself, and her admirers point to a tidy moral theme. This happened, of course, in Hollywood, or thereabouts.

title: I.B.M. NET RISES 3.5% IN QUARTER
description: The International Business Machines Corporation yesterday posted a scant 3.5 percent increase in its first-quarter net income amid evidence that the company was still in the grip of a computer slump that analysts now say may not end until next year.

title: PACIFIC LIGHTING CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
MARGUERITE HARRIS TURNS 90 AND REMAINS ACTIVE AT CLUB
description: Those who work devotedly for the American Contract Bridge League on a full-time basis seem to have long lives. One example is George Beynon, an authority on tournament directing and an editor of the league's Bulletin, who reached the age of 100.

title: ALGOREX CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes a one-time adjustment of $2,230,000 associated with the writedown of the company's New Hampshire facility and certain relocation costs.

title:
PATENTS;
PROCESS ADVANCES CIRCUIT BOARDS
description: Printed circuit boards are regarded as the heart of all electronic gear.

title: BHUTTO, ELATED, DEMANDS AN ELECTION
description: Benazir Bhutto, elated by the tumultuous turnout at her anti-Government rally Thursday, demanded Friday that new elections be held in Pakistan but pledged not to resort to violence in seeking the ouster of President Mohammad Zia ul-Haq.

title: MORTGAGE & REALTY TRUST reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes a gain of $530,000, or 7 cents a share, from the payoff of a participating loan. c-Includes a gain of $3,033,000, or 38 cents a share, from the payoff of five participating loans.

title: JAZZY APPLES
description: ''Why can't we have jazz awards here in New York City?'' the Mayor wondered aloud. The subject was be-bop, the Mayor's guest was Lionel Hampton, and - suddenly -Mr. Koch was on to this new idea.

title: LIBYAN LINK: SORTING IT OUT
description: Since the most recent terrorist acts against American targets, the information about possible Libyan involvement and American strategy provided by Administration officials has often been either sketchy and cryptic or bold but undocumented.

title: DEMOCRATS CLASH ON FOREIGN POLICY
description: The Democratic Party today managed to conduct a harmonious public discussion on foreign policy, but the illusion of a party consensus on this issue was shattered in an impromptu argument outside the meeting room.

title: PERES AND SHAMIR MEET ON ENDING CRISIS
description: Prime Minister Shimon Peres and Foreign Minister Yitzhak Shamir held more talks today on the details of a proposal to resolve the problems in Israel's coalition Government, but they failed to work out a final accord.

title: Back to the Libyan Brink
description: Americans are upset about terrorism. A new New York Times/CBS News survey shows that one in seven now regards it as the nation's biggest problem. If Libya's Colonel Qaddafi had a demonstrable hand in the recent terror incidents in Greece and Berlin, President Reagan would surely find wide support for giving him another bloody nose. With the Sixth Fleet sailing menacingly toward Libya, the hard part lies in the word ''demonstrable.'' What Mr. Reagan has failed to do is produce the evidence needed to justify another attack.

title: The Subject Is Taxes
description: A lobbying group, the Coalition Against Double Taxation, says it will start a seven-state advertising campaign Monday, the eve of the tax-filing deadline, encouraging taxpayers to telephone their Senators to urge them to retain the full state and local tax deduction in computing Federal taxes.

title: LADD FURNITURE INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 29
description: Figures adjusted for a 4-for-3 stock split paid Jan. 10.

title: SQUARE D CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After a loss from discontinued operations of $741,000.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: SATURDAY, APRIL 12, 1986
description: International

title: 2 F.B.I. AGENTS KILLED IN MIAMI
description: Two agents of the Federal Bureau of Investigation were killed and five others wounded in a wild gun battle here this morning. Witnesses said more than 100 shots were fired, apparently from shotguns and automatic weapons.

title: BANKEAST CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The 1985 quarter results restated to reflect the acquisition of First Citizens National Bank of Newport, N.H., in December 1985. The per share earnings and shares outstanding are fully diluted.

title: Ducking Duty on Local School Boards
description: How should a New York community school board respond when a principal is accused of soliciting loans from a teacher? The nine board members of District 32 in Brooklyn recently faced that question but failed to act, forcing Chancellor Nathan Quinones to supersede them. Their inaction shamed one board and weakened the faith in school decentralization.

title: SENATE TACKLES WRITE-OFFS
description: A closer look at the new approach to writing off the cost of capital equipment that was approved in large part Thursday by the Senate Finance Committee shows it to be considerably less favorable to business than the current law.

title: FILES SAY LINDENAUER WAS URGED TO VANISH
description: As investigators closed in on an extortion ring at the city's Parking Violations Bureau, Donald R. Manes gave Geoffrey G. Lindenauer, the agency's deputy director, $58,000 and urged him to flee to a foreign country, according to state and Federal indictments. But, they said, Mr. Lindenauer could not pick one to his liking.

title: AT 91, A NEW ARTIST
description: An Impressionist painter tiptoed onto the East Village art scene when a show of 45 of her works recently attracted a crowd of more than 100 art lovers. The new artist's work recalls not the boisterous art of a young Keith Haring, but rather the peaceful art of Grandma Moses.

title: UTAH POWER & LIGHT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
It'll Be Heavy Going on Contra Aid
description: When legislation comes to floor of the House of Representatives, it is accompanied by a rule that establishes, among other things, how much time will be allowed for debate and how amndments may be offered. It is a procedure often designed to bring order and efficiency to an otherwise unwieldy 435-member legislature.

title: EMPLOYEES WIN $482 MILLION IN SEX BIAS DISPUTE
description: A $482 million settlement of a dispute between Washington and state employees on sexual bias in pay scales cleared its final hurdle today with approval by Federal District Judge Jack Tanner in Tacoma, where the case began in 1982.

title: CITY MAY REJECT STATE AID FOR TEACHER RAISES
description: Mayor Koch said yesterday that he would reject a payment of $30 million in state education aid before he would allow that money to be added permanently to teachers' salaries, if accepting it meant increased costs to the city.

title: Agreement Is Reported On Security for Berlin
description: After several days of discussion, the Western powers responsible for West Berlin - Britain, France and the United States - were reported late tonight to have reached a compromise accord to increase the security of the city.

title: TERROR ISSUE CITED IN POLL
description: After two terrorist bombings in Europe last week and the international attention that followed, Americans now call terrorism the most important problem facing the nation, according to a New York Times/CBS News Poll completed Thursday night.

title: A BROOKLYN CREDIT UNION MISUSED $20 MILLION, INVESTIGATORS ASSERT
description: About $20 million in depositors' funds was embezzled or otherwise misused at a Brooklyn credit union that is under investigation for its business ties to the city's former taxi chief, Jay L. Turoff, Federal and state investigators said yesterday.

title: APPLIED MAGNETICS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After a net gain of $982,000 on the sale of land and building.

title: PLAN FOR NOVEL UPSETS SENATOR
description: Sam Nunn of Georgia, the senior Democrat on the Senate Armed Services Committee, has written to President Reagan expressing strong concern over a Defense Department official's plans to write a novel based on his experience in Washington.

title: Beirut Shiites Oppose Christian Presidencies
description: The largest Shiite Moslem organizations in the country have announced that they intend to begin moves to end 43 years of Christian presidencies in Lebanon.

title: ATLAS CONSOLIDATED MINING & DEVELOPMENT CORP reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
NEW CENTURY BANK reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
HOME-PLATE REUNION
description: He's spent his entire career in the National League, but when Joaquin Andujar, the former St. Louis Cardinal who now pitches for the Oakland A's, makes his first American League start today, he should feel right at home. There will be a familiar face behind the plate - Don Denkinger, the American League umpire who ejected Andujar from the last game of the 1985 World Series against Kansas City after the Cardinal pitcher charged off the mound to protest a call and bumped the umpire. Andujar received a 10-day suspension for the incident, effective at the start of this season, but last month the ban was reduced to five days, and that's how the paths of the pitcher and umpire came to cross today.

title: THOMAS INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Share earnings were adjusted to reflect a 5 percent stock dividend paid Jan. 1, 1986.

title: ANTITRUST ACTION URGED FOR PRESS
description: Saying that acquisitions by large communications companies threaten free speech and the quality of newspapers, a journalism school dean told the nation's newspaper editors here today that they should support Federal antitrust action to prevent further consolidation of ownership.

title: 3d Conviction in Death Spree
description: Alton Coleman of Waukegan, Ill. was convicted today of murdering a 7-year-old girl and raping her 11-year-old aunt. The guilty verdict, returned by a jury that deliberated for one hour and 45 minutes, was the third murder conviction for Mr. Coleman, 30. Prosecutors say he took part in a 1984 crime spree across the Middle West that left at least eight people dead.

title: BIG BANDS ON 8TH AVE.
description: The Jazz Cultural Theater, 368 Eighth Avenue, above 28th Street (502-4300), are presenting two modern big bands this weekend. Tonight, the pianist Jaki Byard will lead the Apollo Stompers, with sets at 10 o'clock and midnight; admission is $8, $5 for students and the elderly. Tomorrow, the keyboardist Sun Ra will bring his 21st Century Jazz Approach Orchestra for sets at 7 and 10 P.M. Tickets are $12 in advance, $15 tomorrow.

title: A Palestinian Guerrilla Chief Reported Seized Near Beirut
description: A Palestinian guerrilla commander was kidnapped by unidentified gunmen near Beirut today, according to the Palestinian group Al Fatah, whose leader is Yasir Arafat, chairman of the Palestine Liberation Organization.

QUICK & REILLY GROUP INC reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28

description: The White House vowed today to continue President Reagan's push to overhaul the Federal tax code, saying that Congress should keep the issue separate from budget considerations.

Young Playwrights
description: A Washington-based group, Children's Radio Theater, each year selects and produces four radio plays in a competition among young playwrights ages 7 through 15. This year, the eighth annual Henny Penny Playwriting contest drew 1,900 entries from 47 states, Canada and western Europe, and the four winning scripts are to be produced today at 10 A.M. before a live audience at the Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts and simultaneously beamed by satellite to public radio stations around the country.

title: Penalties Are Trimmed For Dartmouth Students
description: Ten students suspended from Dartmouth College for attacking shanties built to protest South Africa's racial policies have been given lighter sentences, a move recommended by an alumnus appointed to hear their appeals.

title: BROADWAY STARS JOIN LINCOLN CENTER BENEFIT
description: Two hundred Broadway stars, musicians, and singers will join forces on Monday night to present a program of Broadway show stoppers called ''Broadway Applauds Lincoln Center,'' a benefit for the cultural conglomerate.

description: b-Net income and includes a tax credit of $109,000.

description: Paced by a record 21.9 percent drop in gasoline prices, the Producer Price Index fell in March for the third consecutive month, the Labor Department reported today.

title: Crash Kills Idaho Democrats
description: A candidate for Congress and a candidate for Lieutenant Governor were among three people killed late Thursday when a single-engine plane hit a hillside on a flight from Coeur d'Alene to Idaho Falls. The victims were Pete Busch, 51 years old, a Democratic candidate for Congress, who was piloting the plane; former state Senator Terry Reilly, 39, a Democratic candidate for Lieutenant Governor, and Mr. Busch's wife, Charlene, 42. Mr. Busch was the only announced candidate challenging Representative Larry E. Craig, the Republican incumbent.

title: TRI-STAR PICTURES reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net loss.

title: SULLIVAN STADIUM PACT
description: The New England Patriots confirmed that a group headed by the former Secretary of Transportation, Drew Lewis, had purchased Sullivan Stadium from the financially strapped Sullivan family along with a three-year option to buy the team. Under the terms of the $32-million deal, the Lewis group is also getting the adjacent Foxboro harness track and 220 acres of land, but the Patriots will remain in Sullivan hands at least temporarily.

title: PHOTOGRAPH FANS U.S.-FRENCH DISPUTE ON AIDS
description: American scientists said yesterday that when they published their discovery of the AIDS virus in 1984 they inadvertently illustrated it with a photograph of a similar one that rival French scientists say they had already established as the cause of AIDS.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''The U.S.S.R. Government declares that from now on it is free from the unilateral commitment made by it to refrain from conducting any nuclear explosions.

title: ITALY, FEARING U.S. ATTACK ON LIBYA, ASKS WEST EUROPEAN MEETING
description: Italy, concerned about the possibility of military action by the United States against Libya, called today for an urgent meeting of the European Community's foreign ministers. [ The Dutch Government later announced that the meeting would be held next week, The Associated Press reported from The Hague. The Netherlands acted in its capacity as current chairman of the European Community, a Foreign Ministry spokesman said. ] A statement from the Italian Foreign Ministry said Rome had asked for the meeting to discuss the ''situation created in the Mediterranean following the most recent acts of terrorism and to seek political and diplomatic solutions.''

title: U.S. AGENCY CANCELS BIG COMPUTER CONTRACT
description: The Immigration and Naturalization Service said yesterday that it was canceling a $64 million contract with two of the nation's largest computer companies to automate its field offices and headquarters, two weeks after the General Accounting Office charged that the agency had manipulated bidding when it awarded the contract.

description: The people who live along this stretch of New England coastline have much in common with their neighbors in Suffolk and Nassau Counties, just across Long Island Sound.

Money and the Record
description: One victim of the mandatory budget cuts required by the new budget-balancing law might well be the time-honored practice of inserting all sorts of things into the Congressional Record.

title: OPERA: 'PARSIFAL' AT MET WITH PETER HOFMANN
description: The Metropolitan Opera is a strange company, one that has been unable recently to mount a credible ''Carmen'' or ''Tosca'' but can put on a ''Parsifal'' of the highest quality, as it did Thursday night. Wagner's final and most problematical opera, in its first performance of this flickering season, gave off a continual glow of excellence in spite of a cast that sagged seriously in several places.

FRANCIS B. BOWEN
description: Francis B. Bowen, an investment banker and authority on public finance, died April 4 at Pomerado Hospital in San Diego. He was 80 years old and lived in Rancho Bernardo, Calif.

title: A COLLECTOR ADMITS PAYING $132,000 FOR CITY CONTRACT
description: The owner of a Long Island debt collection agency admitted in Federal court yesterday that he had given $132,000 in cash payoffs to obtain a contract with New York City's Parking Violations Bureau.

BANKSOUTH CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
2 TEXAS CITIES RALLY IN BID TO DISPEL GLOOM OF OIL PRICE SLUMP
description: There were brassy high school bands, bouncy cheerleaders, can-do pep talks and slick commercials featuring country music stars reliving the tough times they went through before hitting it big.

title: MORTGAGE LOAN PARTNERSHIPS
description: MORTGAGE loan partnerships, a little-known category of limited partnerships, may be suitable for investors looking for higher-than-average returns in tax-deferred accounts. Since such partnerships, however, offer more risk than the more common selections for Individual Retirement Accounts and Keogh accounts, they should be carefully considered before purchase. Thus, while they may not be an appropriate last-minute choice in the few days remaining for 1985 I.R.A. investments, mortgage partnerships may be attractive to some investors planning 1986 contributions.

title: PITCHING A PROBLEM, BUT METS HOLD ON
description: The Mets made it two in a row tonight when they defeated the Philadelphia Phillies, 9-7, with Gary Carter knocking in five runs and Bob Ojeda pitching three innings in relief for his first victory in the National League.

title: THE MISSING BOOM IN LASERS
description: Once the stuff of science fiction, the laser has found applications beyond even its inventors' imaginations. Lasers weld transmissions for General Motors, analyze chemicals at Stanford University and play music on more than a million compact disk players.

title: PARAMEDICS SUSPENDED IN INQUIRY
description: Two city paramedics were suspended without pay yesterday as investigations were begun into their handling of the case of a pregnant woman who called for help on Thursday night and later died.

title: RUMANIA DEBT PROBLEM
description: Rumania, facing a severe economic crisis and under growing American pressure about human rights abuse, is in danger of failing to meet debt repayments due this summer, North Atlantic Treaty Organization experts said today. One NATO expert said that removal by Washington of the country's ''most favored nation'' status would virtually insure that debt repayments of $2.2 billion would not be met. Congress was considering canceling the favored status, under which Rumania gets certain trade preferences, because of its poor record on human rights.

title: BEAR, STEARNS AIDE RETURNING
description: Lawrence A. Kudlow, who resigned his post as chief economist at Bear, Stearns & Company in 1980 to become associate director for economics and planning at the Office of Management and Budget, will return to the firm as chief economist and associate director, Bear, Stearns said.

title: LOMAS MORTGAGE reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The company began operations in September 1985, and comparative results are unavailable.

title: Violence Erupts at Rally For Meatpackers' Union
description: Police officers clashed with about 250 union sympathizers blocking the George A. Hormel & Company packinghouse here early this morning in one of the most violent confrontations of the eight-month meatpackers' strike.

title: DAUPHIN DEPOSIT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
WILLIAM A. CALDWELL, PRIZE-WINNING WRITER
description: William A. Caldwell, a Pulitzer Prize-winning columnist and retired associate editor of The Record of Hackensack, N.J., died yesterday at Martha's Vineyard (Mass.) Hospital after a long illness.

title: STUDY FAULTS U.S. RESPONSE TO 1985 WINE THREAT
description: A report by the General Accounting Office says Federal investigators made only ''limited'' efforts to assure that contaminated Austrian wines would not harm the public.

title: The Cops vs. the Big Guns
description: Chalk up another win - but also two unaccustomed losses - for the National Rifle Association. The rich gun lobby's publicity agents are crowing over Thursday's House vote to weaken the 1968 gun control act. But they also lost part of what they wanted, and lost all respect from the cops who opposed them. The police managed to deny the N.R.A. a clear win, and deserve credit for finally shaking the gun lobby's lock on Washington.

title: FRENCHMAN SEIZED IN BEIRUT IS RESCUED BY RABBIT HUNTERS
description: A Frenchman kidnapped in Moslem West Beirut earlier this week was rescued today in the Bekaa region of eastern Lebanon.

title: INTERFIRST CORPORATION reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes a gain of $55.7 million on the sale of its headquarters in Dallas.

title: TAINTED WINE TOLL RISES TO 20 IN ITALY
description: Two more deaths have been attributed to wine contaminated with wood alcohol, the authorities said today, bringing the number of victims of tainted wine to 20.

title: SUPERIOR INDUSTRIES INTERNATIONAL reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The year-earlier quarter's share earnings and shares outstanding were adjusted for a 5-for-4 stock split paid July 1985. The shares outstanding for the latest quarter reflects the public sale of 500,000 shares of common stock in September 1985.

title: ELI'S GIFT TO THE SCREEN
description: MEMBERS of the Yale Corporation have a sense of the dramatic. In December 1977, when they tapped A. Bartlett Giamatti to be Yale's 19th president, he was appearing in the nondancing role of Herr Drosselmeyer in the Connecticut Ballet's production of ''The Nutcracker.''

title: TALMUD IN MIDDLE OF SYNAGOGUE ROW
description: THE Village of Great Neck has filed suit against the Great Neck Synagogue over noise complaints from neighbors. But the synagogue is using the code of Jewish laws known as the Talmud as a defense.

title: KARATE: CHILDREN GET MORE THAN KICKS
description: THE walls and the high ceilings of the Mas Oyama Dojo are painted pure white and the raised platform floor is covered with white canvas. The walls are encompassed with floor-to-ceiling mirrors, and the various types of training equipment rest in the corners of the room.

title: Tenniel's Duchess's Ancestors
description: To the Editor:

title: WHAT'S NEW IN ELEVATORS
description: Elevators are usually taken for granted -until they break down. ''That's when everybody starts yelling,'' observes Larry Lynch, the Otis Elevator Company's service development manager.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: GAMES. By Vera Cowie. (Doubleday, $16.95.) Under the best circumstances, it would be hard to take seriously a book whose chief male character answers to Brad Bradford.

title: ANONYMITY FOR JURY SOUGHT IN BONANNO TRIAL
description: Federal prosecutors, expressing concern over possible attempts at jury tampering, have asked that the identities of jurors in the upcoming racketeering trial of Philip Rastelli be kept confidential and that additional safeguards be taken to protect them from intimidation.

title: Q AND A
description: Question:Are there any travel books directed to the Jewish traveler going to Europe? - J. C., Fort Worth Answer:''Traveller's Guide to Jewish Landmarks of Europe'' (Fleet Press, $11.95) has been praised by some booksellers and Jewish travelers. This city-by-city guide concentrates on describing historic sites, including synagogues, memorials and shrines and Jewish communities that flourished before the Holocaust. Practical information for the tourist is provided in ''The Jewish Travel Guide'' (Jewish Chronicle, London, $9.25), which is worldwide, including Europe. The book lists synagogues, kosher restaurants and local Jewish organizations. Some sightseeing is also given. ''World Guide for the Jewish Traveler'' (Dutton, $8.95) combines historical and practical information in about 100 countries.

title: THE WHITE HOUSE WASN'T LIKE HOME
description: BESS W. TRUMAN By Margaret Truman. Illustrated. 445 pp. New York: Macmillan Publishing Company. $19.95.

title: Photography
description: Even at an age well into his 60's, John Coplans remains something of an enfant terrible. A former painter, editor (of Artforum), museum director and writer, Mr. Coplans decided six years ago to become, of all things, a photographer.

title: DEALING THE PC A BIGGER MEMORY
description: PROBABLY the most elegant hardware device to have come out of Silicon Valley last year is Plus Development's Hardcard. This 10-megabyte hard disk drive for the I.B.M. PC and compatibles has all the requisite electronics crammed onto a single add-on card. The card has no wires to connect and no external clutter, and comes with a preprogrammed batch file that allows the user simply to enter a couple of commands and sit back while the disk installs itself. The Hardcard comes awfully close to making the addition of a hard disk to a computer system almost as easy as purchasing and plugging in a toaster.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: LIGHT YEARS. By Maggie Gee. (St. Martin's, $17.95.) Maggie Gee's third novel is a witty, hyperbolic portrait of a marriage gone awry.

title:
WORKING ABROAD IN TERROR'S SHADOW;
ATHENS
description: Every morning Gordon Ball, who directs a consulting firm for American companies in Greece, scans the street as he sets off for work from his home in an exclusive Athens suburb. He says he feels uneasy as he turns on the car ignition, and often checks to see if any suspicious-looking individuals are watching. He relaxes only when he enters his office.

title: FAST TIMES IN THE (DEREGULATED) WORLD OF AIR FARES
description: Last Nov. 15, Margaret Keene and her friend Edith Briggs, both of Rossmoor, an adult community in central New Jersey, bought two unrestricted round-trip coach tickets on New York Air from Newark to New Orleans. They paid $238 each - top dollar, because they they did not plan to travel until mid-March and did not want to risk a penalty that might apply to a restricted lower fare if they changed their plans. Miss Keene, a retired legal secretary, said that when she checked in at the Newark departure gate for her flight on March 14, she suspected that because of fare wars that had been reported in the press, they might be entitled to a reduction in fare. The New York Air clerk to whom she spoke said this was untrue.

title: LACK OF INDICTMENT IN NEWARK POLICE CASE FAULTED
description: Law-enforcement officials continue to express surprise and frustration at a state grand jury's failure to issue indictments in an inquiry into purported payroll abuses by several Newark police officers.

title: Intricacies of 'Proud Beggar'
description: To the Editor:

title: Headliners; They Made His Day
description: The City Council of scenic Carmel-by-the-Sea, Calif., at first rebuffed Clint Eastwood, a longtime resident, when he sought to put up an office building last year. Riding a wave of resentment over what Mr. Eastwood called ''repressive, heavy-handed and insensitive'' policies aimed at restricting commercial development and maintaining the character of the tiny resort town, the movie actor decided to run for Mayor.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: THE WILD BIRDS: Six Stories of the Port William Membership. By Wendell Berry. (North Point, $13.95.) Where could a country visitor to Prohibition-era Louisville, Ky., get his hands on a pint of whisky during a family emergency? Why would an elderly hill farmer deliberately venture so far down into a wooded gorge that he has to crawl out inch by inch at the risk of his life? How does a scrupulously honest small-town lawyer preserve what he knows is the true intention of a friend whose notion of a binding codicil is a ''slow, crooked legend'' in a tattered pocket notebook that says: ''Wheeler see the boy has his place''? These are some of the central considerations of Wendell Berry's six interconnected stories in this leisurely and engaging collection. In ''Thicker Than Liquor'' young Wheeler Catlett, just married and admitted to the bar, travels to Louisville to retrieve improvident Uncle Peach from his annual binge in the city. It is a hilarious and revealing odyssey through stockyards, train depots, fleabag hotels and hole-in-wall speak-easies. Later in his career, Wheeler has more complex commitments to honor. In a tale called ''It Wasn't Me,'' and again in the title story, his task is to unravel the underlying design of wills written to maintain the ''membership'' of a tight local network of relatives, friends and neighbors dedicated to one another and to their farms. Best known as an accomplished essayist, Mr. Berry sometimes slows down the narrative drive of his fiction with lengthy genealogies, anecdotes and explanations.

title: SHEEHAN LEADS BY 3 IN SAN DIEGO GOLF
description: Patty Sheehan shot a 68 today for 208 and a three-stroke lead after three rounds of the $200,000 Kyocera Inamori Classic at Bernardo Heights Country Club.

title: DAILY BREAD
description: To the Editor:

title:
BLACKBOARD NOTES;
IMPORTING TEACHERS
description: UNEMPLOYED Canadian teachers from the Toronto and Vancouver areas are being lured by the prospect of teaching jobs in the United States - with a warm climate as an added incentive.

title: RECORD-SETTER ALMOST HAD 62
description: Virtually assured of a Masters record round of 63 today, Nick Price had a 30-foot birdie putt on the 18th green for a 62. Stroking it firmly, the 29-year-old touring pro who grew up in Zimbabwe watched his ball spin completely around the cup and stay out.

title: LAND CLAIMS BY INDIANS IN NEW YORK ARE AIRED AT SYMPOSIUM
description: To Irving Powless Jr., the chief of the Onondaga Indian Nation, the people of New York are his guests - guests in an Iroquois longhouse that ''covers what is now called New York State.''

title: IN EUROPE, P.L.O. COMES UNDER CLOSE WATCH
description: In a period of heightened vigilance against terrorism in Europe, Palestine Liberation Organization offices in 18 non-Communist countries are under close scrutiny by security and intelligence agencies.

title: Gentlemen, Fairness And Golf
description: When Roberto de Vicenzo blamed himself for the scoring mistake that cost him the 1968 Masters, he was right (''Gentlemen Prefer Golf,'' by Dave Anderson, March 9).

title: SWEET ADULTERY
description: ANOTHER MARVELOUS THING By Laurie Colwin. 130 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $13.95.

title: NEW AND OLD WORLD APPROACHES TO BEETHOVEN AND MOZART
description: Mozart and Beethoven:

title: EUROPEANS STILL WARY OF A LIBYAN QUARANTINE
description: THE diplomatic choreography had been rehearsed after the savage Christmas-time attacks on Vienna and Rome airports. But last week the diplomatic moves were made with a new, ghastly backdrop, the bombing of a West Berlin discotheque that killed 2 people and injured 230. The Reagan Administration railed at Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi as the master terrorist and string-puller, demanding West European sanctions against Libya, then watching as the NATO allies responded half-heartedly and with deep private reservations.

title: JEWELER DID NOT PROVOKE SLAYING POLICE SAY, AS 3D ROBBER IS HUNTED
description: Detectives investigating the slaying of a jewler in Manhattan's diamond district said yesterday that the victim had apparently been shot without provocation by a robber who put a gun to his head and fired as soon as he entered the victim's office.

title: NEW CASSETTES: FROM WAR STORIES TO FAIRY TALES
description: Idiot's Delight Starring Clark Gable, Norma Shearer, Edward Arnold, Joseph Schildkraut, Charles Coburn; directed by Clarence Brown, 1939 MGM/UA Home Video 107 minutes. $24.95 The sight of Clark Gable strutting, tapping and warbling ''Puttin' on the Ritz'' is reason enough to view this video - a good, clear print.

title: Cheap Oil, Dear Oil and the National Security
description: To the Editor:

title: SAMUEL BECKETT: PUTTING LANGUAGE IN ITS PLACE
description: SAMUEL BECKETT, who celebrates his 80th birthday today, graduated from Jonathan Swift's college, Trinity of Dublin, where the library had contained a Sextus Empiricus for Swift to scan. Sextus Empiricus, who flourished circa A.D. 190 (it gets put that way, though his tone seems not that of a flourisher) was a physician whose three volumes of ''Pyrrhonean Sketches'' tended to reduce all knowledge to ashes. For centuries he seemed an amusing spoilsport. But the signs that Swift read him in the 1680's go with other ominous signs, notably the popularity in those years of languages designed on the drawing board, never spoken by human lips, never stammered by babes, and thus inert to the skeptical acids. Such languages will contain no terms to which meaning cannot be assigned, since the terms will be produced not in the usual careless way, but at the inflexible behest of the meanings themselves. Their designers start with a taxonomy of all that can possibly be meant.

title: CARAMOOR OPENING MUSIC ROOM AGAIN
description: A busy and exciting cultural week begins today, one that includes visits from two of the most famous trios in the world, the inauguration of an indoor series at Caramoor, opera and musical comedy productions.

title: 3 BERLIN POWERS ACT ON TERRORISM
description: Responding to the bombing of a West Berlin discotheque a week ago, the three Western powers responsible for security in that city announced today that they were taking measures to check ''international terrorism'' and eject persons ''posing a threat to the population of Berlin.''

title: OWEN KROLL IS MARRIED TO DEBORAH LISA ROSE
description: Deborah Lisa Rose, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Herbert Rose of Daytona Beach, Fla., was married yesterday to Oren Kroll, a son of Marilyn Kroll of Astoria, Queens, and Eliezer L. Kroll of Jerusalem. Rabbi Richard Fagan performed the ceremony at Temple Israel in Daytona Beach, Fla.

title: PEKING HAPPILY DEALS WITH BOTH SIDES
description: A SOVIET diplomat ushered an American reporter to a quiet spot during an embassy reception recently and whispered a request. ''Tell me, please,'' he said, ''what is it that your David Rockefeller is doing here? Will he be meeting with Deng Xiaoping?'' There was, in fact, no secret about Mr. Rockefeller's trip. The retired banker, a frequent visitor, had arrived on Chase Manhattan's jet plane for talks at the Bank of China.

title: CONNECTICUT GUIDE
description: THE STATE'S PARADE Almost all of Connecticut's 169 towns and cities will participate in the state's 350th birthday celebration, set for Saturday in New Haven.

title: ROSALEEN GEMBALA WEDS R. E. PARSONS
description: The wedding of Rosaleen Bridgette Broncha Gembala, a fourth-year student at the Medical College of Pennsylvania, to Richard Evans Parsons, a third-year student at the Temple University School of Medicine, took place yesterday in Philadelphia. The Rev. Bernard Witkowski performed the ceremony at St. Ladislaus Roman Catholic Church assisted by Brother Patrick Ellis, president of La Salle University.

title: ROCK OF PROTEST IN NASSAU COUNTY
description: BEFORE he left Long Island disillusioned in 1982, Arnold Carlson, a builder, left behind a weighty memento to sum up his feelings.

title: Padua
description: To the Editor: Padua, of course, is a feast for eye and psyche, and the subject is well pursued by Olivier Bernier (Travel, Feb. 2). However, one might linger a bit longer at the Palazzo della Ragione.

title:
INTERVENING IN THE OIL MARKET;
THE MARKET WILL CUSHION PRICE SHOCKS
description: BOTH before and after his talks with the Saudis about oil prices, Vice President Bush roiled the oil markets by repeatedly mentioning the need for stability and the threat to national security posed by falling oil prices, implicitly suggesting that the United States might establish a price floor to protect domestic production. Although at a news conference last week, President Reagan reaffirmed his intention to let the market set oil prices, Mr. Bush's remarks provided fresh ammunition for proponents of an import fee or other devices to prop up prices.

title: EX-GOV. ROBB CALLS FOR SHIFT IN VIEW OF BLACKS' PROBLEMS
description: Former Gov. Charles S. Robb of Virginia today called for an end to ''the conspiracy of silence'' that he said had inhibited ''a frank public discussion of the new obstacles to black progress.''

title: THE DATE WE BREAK, AND OTHER LESSONS FOR YOUTH
description: THE evidence is in: rising juvenile crime, truancy, drug use, teen-age alcoholism. Where have our values gone, and how can we recapture them for our children?

title: A SEASON OF GLOOM ENDS FOR THE KNICKS
description: The dark, turbulent cloud that hovered over the Knicks' season followed them here. All this week, Milwaukee enjoyed sunny skies and uncharacteristically warm temperatures. But when the Knicks' plane arrived this morning, the skies grayed and cold winds blew, providing a fitting backdrop for an ending that could not come soon enough.

title: CAN MIGHTY GOLDMAN STAY PRIVATE?
description: When Gereral Electric got serious last fall about taking over RCA - the biggest-ever merger outside of the oil patch - one of the first things G.E.'s chairman did was to phone John L. Weinberg, the 61-year-old senior partner of Goldman, Sachs & Company.

title:
CAMPAIGN '86: POLITICS OF MONEY;
A CONGRESSIONAL RACE WITH A BIG PRICE TAG
description: ''I'D love to have a million dollars to run against him,'' says Town Councilman Joseph Guarino of North Hempstead, who will oppose Representative Robert J. Mrazek, Democrat of Centerport, this November in Long Island's Third Congressional District.

title: A PLACE RECALLED
description: BEFORE THERE was a superhighway, the house, about 30 kilometers from town, was not easy to reach. If you went there for the weekend, and left Paris at the same time as everyone else, you invariably were caught in the traffic jams that preceded the Porte d'Orleans, the city's gateway to the south and southwest. Once past the Porte, you drove through one of the grayest, dreariest sections of the city's industrial belt, a place where streets had names like rue de Stalingrad and avenue du Marechal Staline.

title: IS CLIO A FEMINIST? THE NEW HISTORY
description: ITEM: More than 2,000 historians gathered at Smith College in June 1984 for the Sixth Berkshire Conference on the History of Women, rivaling the attendance at the annual convention of the American Historical Association six months earlier.

title: An Incident of Wolves
description: THE IDEA ITSELF was simple, but it required a maximum of stealth.

title: DOLLARS FOR DIPLOMAS
description: One of the reasons college seniors can feel better this spring is that starting salaries for college graduates are up ''significantly.'' That's the word from the 1986 Endicott Report, an annual survey conducted at Northwestern University of the hiring plans of 230 major companies.

title: IN NEW BRUNSWICK, A WORLD PREMIERE
description: WITH all honors comes a hitch. Or so a new play -''The Colored Museum,'' a world premiere at the Crossroads Theatre Company through next Sunday - could confirm.

title: TEACHER SHORTAGE SPELLS DISASTER
description: THE approaching crisis in education could make our recent infrastructure problems look like child's play.

title: MARJORIE KAPLAN TO MARRY
description: Mr. and Mrs. William Kaplan of White Plains have announced the engagement of their daughter Marjorie Kaplan to Francis Sweeney of Arlington, Va., a son of Mr. and Mrs. John Sweeney of Cleveland Heights, Ohio. A July 12 wedding is planned. The future bride is an environmental consultant in White Plains and a doctoral candidate at the Columbia University School of Public Health. Mr. Sweeney is an environmental consultant with the Science Applications International Corporation in McLean, Va.

title: AN ARTFUL DANISH SANDWICH TO GO
description: It all starts with a thin, dense piece of bread, lightly buttered. Add a variety of meats, fish or shellfish, salad and condiments, garnish with fresh vegetables and colorful sauces, and you have smorrebrod, the open-face sandwich that is the preferred lunch of Scandinavia and the very hallmark of north country cuisine.

title: MELINDA H. WERBER AND JOHN PETTIT MARRY IN JERSEY
description: Melinda Hinckley Werber, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles J. Werber of Rumson, N.J., was married yesterday to John Charles Pettit, a son of Mrs. John J. Pettit and the late Mr. Pettit of Red Bank, N.J. The Rev. George Willis performed the ceremony at St. George's-by-the-River Episcopal Church in Rumson.

title: DATA BANK: April 13, 1986
IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: TRACKING MARCO POLO. By Tim Severin. (Peter Bedrick Books, $15.95.) One of the most appealing kinds of travel literature is that in which ill-prepared but intrepid young men (or women) set off on peculiar vehicles in search of adventure in strange places.

title: WILLIAM M. HYLAND, JR. MARRIES SUSAN BARTOK
description: Susan Elizabeth Bartok, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Lewis M. Bartok of Perryville, N.J., was married yesterday to William M. Hyland Jr., a son of Mr. and Mrs. Hyland of Candlewood Knolls, New Fairfield, Conn., and Brooklyn. The Rev. Robert Ferro performed the ceremony at St. Ann's Roman Catholic Church in Hampton, N.J.

title: LIBYA TO PUT FOREIGNERS IN ARMY BASES
description: Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi said in a statement early this morning that the Libyan Army had evacuated the camps it considers to be targets for the United States and ordered that foreign companies house their workers in them.

title: WHAT DANIEL TOLD ROBERTA ABOUT HENRY
description: THE CATHOLIC By David Plante. 151 pp. New York: Atheneum. $11.95. WHERE I grew up, in North Cambridge, Mass., the local French-Canadian community produced boys who were ferocious ice hockey players while the girls - who usually attended the Francophone Catholic high school, Notre Dame, a feeder institution for the nuns - often seemed shy and pious. As a community, the French appeared somewhat claustral, rarely making a figure in local politics or involving themselves in such general cultural activities as offered, apart from sports.

title: Time Out and Time Again
description: To the Editor:

title: LONG ISLAND JOURNAL
description: LOVE ON THE WING THE loud screams behind the home of Edmond and Marie Rabut this time of year may cause a head or two to turn in the normally quiet and picturesque community of Dix Hills. But the sounds won't last much longer.

title: THE TOUGHEST JOB IN EDUCATION
description: The eight perpetrators, looking contrite, are lined up facing Stanley Witty, the principal of Intermediate School 70 in the Chelsea section of Manhattan. Their offense: joining a snowball fight during lunch period in which a student was slightly injured.

title:
BLACKBOARD NOTES;
HOW TO FIND A SHEEPSKIN IN THE ATTIC
description: STUDENTS looking for scholarships to some of America's best universities might check their attics. They may find themselves the beneficiaries of what are known as ''perpetual scholarships.''

title: NEW KINDS OF PROMISE
description: HEROES AND HUSTLERS, HARD HATS AND HOLY MEN Inside the New Israel. By Ze'ev Chafets. 249 pp. New York: William Morrow & Company. $17.95.

title: ASSSESSMENTS VARY
description: The brouhaha over projected results on the High School Proficiency Test has drawn statewide concern over these fundamental questions:

title: NEW JERSEY GUIDE
description: BRENDEL IN PRINCETON Alfred Brendel, the Austrian pianist making his annual tour of North America, will perform in Princeton tomorrow evening, his fourth appearance as part of Princeton University's Concerts Virtuosi series.

title: ILISSA A. KIMBALL WED TO LON FREDERICH POVICH
description: Ilissa Ann Kimball, the daughter of Judge and Mrs. Sherman P. Kimball of Bethesda, Md., and Lon Fredric Povich, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Donald M. Povich of Bath, Me., were married yesterday. Rabbi Samuel Scolnic performed the ceremony at the Vista International Hotel in Washington.

title: NOTHING SACRED: KELLOGG ENDS TOURS
description: First they upended the telephone company. Then they switched the formula for Coca-Cola. And now, the last straw: They have stopped the public tours at the Kellogg Company. No longer can you watch a machine press 40 tons of force on a raw bit of corn and yield a cornflake.

title: NEW THRILLER ISN'T ALL FICTION
description: IN 1876, on a hillside in Wateska, Ill., a young girl and a middle-aged man meet. What happens thereafter forms the plot of ''Before I Wake,'' a new thriller by William Wesbrooks that is premiering at Theater Three in Port Jefferson.

title: THE LURE OF LONDON'S CHELSEA FLOWER SHOW
description: You are in England. It is springtime.

title: South Africa Protests End at Two Universities
description: Students protesting the University of Illinois's investments in companies doing business with South Africa tore down their campus shantytown yesterday rather than risk expulsion.

title:
DINING OUT;
GETTING A KICK OUT OF FOOD
description: GIORGIO CHINAGLIA, high-scoring star of the defunct Cosmos soccer team, is the latest sports celebrity to launch a restaurant. With Giovanni Di Saverrio, owner of Manhattan's Tre Scalini and Gian Marino restaurants, he opened Il Calcio four months ago in Harrington Park, in northern Bergen County.

title: Fireworks Maker Identified
description: A man who officials believe operated an illegal fireworks factory has been identified as one of eight people killed in an explosion and fire linked to the factory, the authorities said Friday. The remains of Thomas C. Cuyos, 28 years old, were identified by the San Francisco coroner's office. Fire officials have said the illegal fireworks factory, disguised as a computer-paper concern, was the main cause of the April 4 explosion at the Bay View Industrial Park that killed six people.

title: ISLANDERS ELIMINATED; FLURRY STUNS FLYERS, 5-2
description: With one sudden, incredible flurry, the Rangers are just a step away from pulling off the upset.

title: THE SCHEDULE OF GODARD TV
description: Television by Godard opens Wednesday at Film Forum 1 (57 Watts Street, at Avenue of the Americas two blocks north of Canal Street), and will run through April 29. The 20 hours of material will be shown in 10 two-hour segments, which may be viewed sequentially or individually.

title: WHAT IT TAKES TO PLAY THE BARD
description: To the Editor:

title: A More Realistic Summit
description: The approach to the second Reagan-Gorbachev meeting later this year is different in two respects from the first. In recent days, the statements of both the President and the General Secretary have been more temperate and the private discussion of objectives more moderate and realistic.

title: POPE TO STEP ACROSS CENTURIES INTO SYNAGOGUE
description: By making the first recorded visit by a Pope to a synagogue, Pope John Paul II will be turning his back Sunday on centuries of anti-Semitism in a place where the fate of Jews was long decided by the Pope.

title: EARLY SCHOOLING IS NOW THE RAGE
description: Lizzie Leahy was only three weeks old when she had her first contact with the public-school system of Missouri. A ''parent educator'' from the neighborhood school district in suburban St. Louis visited Lizzie and her parents, Patrick and Colleen Leahy, to show them what to expect from their firstborn child. ''She taught us to notice little things that Lizzie was doing, like reaching out to grasp things,'' Mrs. Leahy recalls. ''She showed us that Lizzie wasn't just a cute little baby lying there, but that she was already a maturing human being.''

title: THEATER OF DEAF TO TOUR CHINA
description: NEXT month the National Theater of the Deaf, based in Chester, will become the first theater company from the United States to tour China since cultural relations between the two countries were resumed in the 1970's. Aided by two Chinese performers, the troupe will introduce Chinese audiences to its unusual performance style.

title: THE THEATER: WILDE'S 'EARNEST' AT YALE
description: Playing Algernon Moncrieff's manservant, Ben Halley Jr. arranges the tea service on a sideboard, pats the plates of cucumber and bread-and-butter sandwiches and looks around the morning room to make sure that everything is in place. Is Algernon late, or has Jack Worthing decided to upset all of Oscar Wilde's carefully laid plans and arrive early? Or is Mr. Halley waiting for water to boil? Such vagrant thoughts go through one's mind, as we wait, with increasing impatience, for ''The Importance of Being Earnest'' to begin.

title: BALLET: THE JOFFREY OFFERS KYLIAN AND CRANKO WORKS
description: ''FORGOTTEN LAND'' by Jiri Kylian and ''Jeu de Cartes'' by John Cranko were given for the first time this season by the Joffrey Ballet Wednesday night at the State Theater. Very different, both ballets are nonetheless linked through their choreographers.

title: METS LOSE, 9-8, TO PHILLIES IN 14
description: The game took 5 hours 3 minutes and 14 pitchers and more twists than a soap opera to complete, and the Mets would rather forget that it happened. But it did: They blew a three-run lead in the bottom of the ninth inning and a one-run lead in the bottom of the 14th today, and suffered a galling 9-8 defeat to the Philadelphia Phillies.

title: CHILD-CARE QUESTIONS AND RESPONSES
description: In response to ''Quality Child Care: The Need Is Real'' [ March 9 ] :

title: ''KRAZY KAT'': HIGHBROW BURLESQUE
description: SEVENTY-FIVE YEARS AGO, A MOUSE threw a brick at a cat, beginning that most celebrated comic strip, George Herriman's ''Krazy Kat.'' Born to Creole parents in New Orleans in 1880, Herriman started his career in 1897, when the medium was young. With ''Krazy Kat,'' he perfected his fantastical approach and bemused generations. New York's Graham Gallery will show his work, May 20 to June 5.

title: DAVID EPSTEIN TO WED TAMARA JACOBS IN MAY
description: Tamara Eileen Louise Jacobs and David Bernard Epstein plan to be married May 31, her parents, Mr. and Mrs. Bernard Raymond Jacobs of East Lansing, Mich., have announced. Mr. Epstein is a son of Barbara Epstein of Newport, R.I., and the late Herbert W. Epstein.

title: 5 U.S. Establishments Are Dynamited in Peru
description: Leftist rebels dynamited five United States targets here Friday night, the police said.

title: VIOLIST AND TWO PIANISTS IN RECITALS
description: Marc Laforet Marc Laforet, a 1985 Young Concert Artists winner and also the holder of second prize from the same year's Chopin Competition in Warsaw, played an impressive Chopin recital at the 92d St. Y Tuesday.

title: SATIRIC 'COMIC MAGAZINE' LOOKS AT JAPANESE TV
description: BEHIND the opening credits, during which we see a man receiving a touch-up haircut, a stern voice on the soundtrack warns that ''sex in the theater is strictly forbidden.'' If it's funny - and it is - it's because the narrator has raised the possibility of sex, which probably wasn't on too many people's minds anyway, only to deny it.

title:
DINING OUT;
BISTRO INFORMALITY IN WHITE PLAINS
description: TRANSPLANTED after seven years in Fort Lauderdale, Fla., La Bonne Auberge is the welcome and most recent arrival in a succession of French restaurants that have opened on this East Post Road spot. The sophisticated dining rooms remain almost unchanged from the restaurant's past lives as Pascal's and Pierre's and The Place. To these chic quarters, the present owners, Marie and Claude Pottier, bring a family-run bistro informality.

title: CORRECTION
description: The headline over a chart in the World section on March 23 about nuclear testing gave a misleading impression of the Soviet Union's program. In addition to its weapons testing, the Soviet Union conducts other explosions that it says are for peaceful construction purposes, and the chart lumped the two together. Its headline therefore should not have used the word ''bomb,'' and should have said, ''known nuclear explosions.''

title: CAIRO
description: There is a strong Cairo connection in several of the recent incidents -last summer's Trans World Airlines hijacking, the Egyptair hijacking in Malta in the fall and the recent T.W.A. bombing. All the planes were on runs with a leg through Cairo, raising suspicion that hijackers or weapons could have been put aboard here.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: STRANGERS IN THEIR OWN LAND: Young Jews in Germany and Austria Today. By Peter Sichrovsky. (Basic, $14.95.) Chancellor Helmut Kohl likes to describe himself to visitors as the first truly postwar West German leader, the implication being that his generation -teen-agers when the war ended - can no longer be held responsible for wartime atrocities, including the Holocaust.

title: U.S.-SOVIET DIVING
description: They will be a couple of years late for the Olympics, but a squad of top divers from the Soviet Union is coming to Los Angeles next month for a dual meet against the United States in the poll used for the 1984 Games. Robert H. Helmick, the United States Olympic Committee president, said that the event, May 3-4 at the Los Angeles Olympic Swim Stadium, the site of the 1984 Olympic competition, would mark the first time Soviet divers have competed in the United States since 1983 and the first Soviet-American dual meet since 1979.

title: MUSIC: PINNOCK LEADS ST. LUKE'S GROUP
description: A CONCERT that promised much turned strange very quickly at Carnegie Hall Thursday night. Its premise was a fascinating one -Trevor Pinnock, the enormously talented purveyor of Baroque and Classical style as it might have been heard two centuries ago, together with the Orchestra of St. Luke's, a thoroughly modern ensemble playing thoroughly modern instruments.

title: Inspector Says Impact, Not Blast, Destroyed Shuttle
description: The impression that the Challenger was blown to bits Jan. 28 was wrong, it now seems clear. And though that knowledge does not allay the grief over seven lost lives - indeed, the effect could be just the opposite - it may prove important to those who are studying ways to make the shuttle safer.

title: NEW CELTICS ADD TO GREATNESS
description: THE BOSTON Celtics were running The Fist. Bill Walton was in the low post. Kevin McHale was posted low on the other side, Larry Bird was on the right wing, Jerry Sichting on left wing and Dennis Johnson was handling the ball. Johnson passed the ball to Bird, and he in turn made a pass into Walton. As two Cleveland Cavaliers came over to double-team him, Walton gave the ball over to Sichting, who was all alone after a pick by Johnson. He canned a 20-foot jumper.

title: THE EARLY EDUCATION OF A FUTURE KING
description: AT THE AGE of 3 years and 3 months, Prince William, the world's best-known preschooler, made history of sorts last fall when he became the first prospective heir to the British throne to attend a private nursery school. He attends Mrs. Mynors' Nursery School, in a Victorian row house just five minutes from Kensington Palace, where he lives with his parents, Prince Charles and Princess Diana.

title: NEW CASSETTES: FROM WAR STORIES TO FAIRY TALES
description: Bach and Vivaldi Concertos The Huberman Festival, featuring Pinchas Zukerman, Daniel Benyamini, Isaac Stern, Ida Haendel, Ivry Gitlis and Shlomo Mintz; with Zubin Mehta conducting the Israel Philharmonic Orchestra Pacific Arts Video Records 37 minutes. $39.95 The 1983 Huberman Festival was a week-long celebration of violins and violinists named for the late Bronislaw Huberman, who worked heroically in behalf of persecuted Jewish musicians during the 1930's and 40's and helped assemble an embryonic version of what is now the Israel Philhamonic Orchestra.

title: PRICE'S 63 HUMBLES MASTERS COURSE
description: Virtually assured of a Masters record round of 63 today, Nick Price had a 30-foot birdie putt on the 18th green for a 62. Stroking it firmly, the 29-year-old touring pro who grew up in Zimbabwe watched his ball spin completely around the cup and stay out.

title: Controlled Breathing
description: In response to Amy Singer's article ''Classic Shape-Ups'' (Fashions of the Times, March 2), a moderate exercise that many people are adopting is controlled breathing.

title: LAW SHIELDING HUNTERS PUT TO THE TEST
description: THE arrest of an East Lyme woman on a charge of harassing hunters has become a test of a new state law that prohibits such activity.

title: NATIONAL ISSUES TAKE A BACK SEAT IN SENATE RACES
description: AS a key part of their strategy for unseating Senator Mack Mattingly, a first-term Republican, Democrats here are openly urging voters to help restore their party's control of the Senate. That makes Georgia one of the few places where such a pitch is being made this year, and there is a strictly parochial reason for it: The state's senior Senator, Sam Nunn, will be in line for the chairmanship of the Armed Services Committee if Democrats retake the Senate.

title: STOPPING ILLNESSES BEFORE THEY START
description: CORPORATIONS in Connecticut, seeking to raise production and to lower absences and health care costs, are trying a new range of programs to head off health problems before they become serious.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: SUNDAY, APRIL 13, 1986
description: International

title: OPTOMETRISTS MAY ADMINISTER DRUGS
description: OPTOMETRISTS will soon be able to administer certain drugs to eye patients, under a bill signed into law last week by Governor O'Neill.

title: 'MYSTICAL TALE' AT THE THORPE
description: THE Thorpe Intermedia Gallery has been put through the hoop a few times in its 10-year career but never so strenuously as by its present show, which has made the premises all but unrecognizable.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: UNBALANCED ACCOUNTS. By Kate Gallison. (Little, Brown, $14.95.) An author treads on treacherous ground when trying to parody a style somewhat tongue-in-cheek to begin with.

title: HAWKS' WILKINS WINS SCORING RACE
description: Dominique Wilkins won the National Basketball Association scoring title tonight by getting 34 points as the Atlanta Hawks defeated the Indiana Pacers, 108-91, in the regular-season finale for both teams.

title: FRAUD SUGGESTED IN LaROUCHE FUND-RAISING
description: A Federal prosecutor's affidavit says preliminary findings in a grand jury investigation indicate that organizations affiliated with Lyndon H. LaRouche Jr. have raised money by defrauding hundreds of people across the country.

title: QUEENS WOMAN, 82, IS KILLED IN SUBWAY PURSE-SNATCHING
description: An 82-year-old Queens woman returning home from work was killed in a purse-snatching assault on an elevated subway platform in Brooklyn yesterday afternoon, the police said.

title: THE 7-MONTH RIVALRY
description: TOMORROW is more than just Opening Day at Shea Stadium. It is the first meeting of the season between those two ancient rivals, the Cardinals and the Mets, whose blood feud goes back far into the dimly remembered past - oh, at least seven months.

title: KING OF THE RODEO
description: RAIN OR SHINE A Family Memoir. By Cyra McFadden. Illustrated. 178 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $16.95.

title: MRS. JOHNSON TO WED JOHN HAROLD REDMOND
description: Dianne Yvonne Johnson and John Harold Redmond plan to be married May 10, the future bride's mother, Yvonne Kenney of Boynton Beach, The future bride, a widow, is a daughter also of the late Clifford Kenney of Forest Hills Gardens, Queens. She is an associate at Sotheby's International Realty in New York.

title: Foreign Exchange In Hackensack
description: From far and wide in recent weeks, people have traveled to pay phones in Hackensack, N.J., to reach out to friends and relatives abroad. It was on New Jersey Bell, however, that they put the touch.

title: WHEN THE CHILD SUPPORT PAYMENTS STOP
description: WHEN the divorce decree is finally entered, many people believe they have at last put a chapter of their past behind them. But if a noncustodial parent has been ordered to pay child support, nothing could be further from the truth.

title: PLAYWRIGHT, 13, A WINNER
description: FOR 13-year-old Marisa Kantor of the Monmouth County community of Aberdeen, it was a first attempt at writing a play. It took her several days, but was well worth the effort, for she came up with a winner.

title: The Sun Was Eclipsed by Fields of Ice
description: To the Editor:

title: HOW TO HELP YOUR YOUNG CHILD - TIPS FROM AN EXPERT
description: The most important -- and often, the most difficult -- decision may parents will make during their child's preschool years is the choice of other adults to help care for their children. What happens during a child's early years makes a difference in growth and development -- both intellectual and emotional. The right kinds of interactions with those who care for the child are crucial. Fortunately, determining what is right is usually a matter of common sense, as is evident in the following checklist.

title: JERSEY PROBLEM SOLVER: AN UNSINKABLE STYLE
description: On a busy day - when she is meeting with her agoraphobics and anorexics, her youth commission and her senior citizen group - Edythe Deiches Gutman loses track of all the problems she solves. She cannot explain how she squeezes so much social work into a single day - she just does.

title: LOOKING FOR THOSE HARD-TO-FIND HEIRLOOM ROSES
description: Maybe it's the latest hybrid tea rose you want, the flamboyant Just Joey admired in an English garden last summer. Or maybe it's Sombreuil, the impossibly-fragrant antique that climbed the pillars of your grandmother's porch.

title: EFFORT PRESSED ON TEEN-AGE PREGNANCY
description: A COALITION of school and community groups in Peekskill is considering recommending major changes in the city school system to combat an increasing problem with teen-age pregnancies, according to coalition members.

title: ASSEMBLY CONTEST WILL BE A FAMILY AFFAIR
description: WHEN Robert P. Zimmerman received the Democratic Party's nomination last month to run against Assemblyman Daniel Frisa, a Republican, for the 15th Assembly District seat from Long Island, ''there was a definite party atmosphere at Democratic headquarters,'' Mr. Zimmerman said. But the candidate himself says he ''sipped on a quick Irish coffee - then I got to taking care of business.''

title: MISS SPORN WED TO N. M. TAVAKOLI
description: Jessica Beth Sporn and Nader M. Tavakoli were married yesterday at the Tower Suite in Manhattan by Rabbi Joseph Gelberman. The bride is a daughter of Samuel P. Sporn and Dr. Ellen Sporn of Brooklyn. Mr. Tavakoli is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Akbar Tavakoli of Mystic Islands, N.J.

title: ROBIN L. FULLER BECOMES BRIDE IN MOUNT KISCO
description: Robin Lockwood Fuller and Peter Robinson Russell were married yesterday at the Millwood Presbyterian Church in Mount Kisco, N.Y. The Rev. Jack Silvey Miller performed the ceremony.

title: STACIA ALLEN MARRIES
description: Stacia Jean Allen, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. George F. Allen Jr. of Tampa, Fla., was married yesterday at the Church of St. Thomas More in New York to Theodore S. Williams Jr., a son of Sara Williams of Dallas and Mr. Williams of Newark, Del. The Rev. William L. Scully, the bride's uncle, performed the Roman Catholic ceremony. Mrs. Williams is a graduate of the Academy of the Holy Names and Rollins College. Mr. Williams, also a Rollins graduate, is a specialist clerk on the floor of the New York Stock Exchange for Adler, Coleman & Company in New York.

title: CONSUMER RATES
Summer House By the Sea
description: ARCHITECTS, IN AN EFFORT to design houses that meld unobtrusively with their neighbors, are constructing new versions of the century-old shingle-style house. Built primarily in summer colonies along the shores of the Northeast where the wood shingles weather gracefully in the salt air, these new houses, with their commodious porches, simple layouts and natural landscapes, are pared-down versions of their imposing Victorian predecessors.

title:
BLACKBOARD NOTES;
GRADE 'A' BURGERS
description: ACADEMIC success in Elgin and Streamwood, Ill., can now be measured in cheeseburgers. That's because local McDonald's outlets have offered a free cheesburger to every student with an A on a report card.

title: TERRORISM POTENTIAL PUTS MILITARY BASES ON THE ALERT
description: BECAUSE of the potential of terrorism following the Libya-United States confrontation in the Gulf of Sidra last month, New Jersey military installations are on a heightened security alert.

title: THE LONG MARCH TO ELECTION NIGHT
description: MY dictionary defines the word ''campaign'' as a ''number of connected military operations in a war which are aimed at some special purpose.'' Used as a verb, in a figurative sense, it provides this sentence: ''The candidates campaigned by sending out letters, speaking at public places and ringing doorbells.'' It is derived from the French word, ''campagne,'' meaning ''field,'' and that accounts for the silent letter ''g.''

title: SCANDAL IN CITY BRINGING ADDED FAME TO GIULIANI
description: The investigation of corruption in New York City government has focused new attention on Rudolph W. Giuliani, the United States Attorney in Manhattan, and Mr. Giuliani seems to be basking in it.

title: BIDS OPEN ON I-287
description: AFTER years of often-bitter controversy, the state's Department of Transportation has opened for bids the first of 12 contracts to complete Interstate 287 between Montville in Morris County and the New York border.

title: UNIVERSITIES MUST WALK BETWEEN TRADITION AND CHANGE
description: THESE are times of introspection and change in American higher education. Declining enrollments and uncertain financial conditions have made many of us rethink old assumptions and welcome new perspectives.

title: AIR FORCE CAPTURES COLLEGIATE BOXING TITLE
description: Led by Steve Stedman and Steve Greene, the Air Force Academy boxing team captured its third consecutive National Collegiate Boxing Championship by winning five of the nine bouts team members had tonight.

title: HELP FOR WOMEN IN BUSINESS
description: WHEN Mallory Mercaldi decided to go into business for herself as a freelance business writer, she sat down and assessed her situation.

title: YOUNG MOTHERS REFLECT
description: A TALL, willowy young woman with high cheekbones and expressive dark eyes, Sharon Jackson sometimes fantasizes about becoming a fashion model, wearing beautiful clothes and dining at elegant restaurants.

title: MANY ARE FEARFUL OF PROFICIENCY TEST
description: ''WHEN I heard how difficult this test would be,'' confessed Sandee De Leon of the Middlesex County town of Spotswood, ''I was scared. But I've been preparing very hard and I think I'll do all right.''

title: CHURCH COMES DOWN
description: THE wrecker said he felt ''a little weird'' about tearing down a church, and the priest said he felt ''sad, but awestruck'' when the 73-year-old Holy Innocents Church of Pleasantville was reduced to a few piles of stones and splintered boards in only an hour and a half.

title:
BLACKBOARD NOTES;
AND NOW, A MAJOR IN ROBOTICS
description: AN army of robots has invaded the nation's high schools. About 2,000 automatons of varying descriptions have been incorporated into curriculums across the nation, a reflection of the need to train specialists who can direct the increasing use of robots in industry and in such fields as microbiology, space exploration and bioengineering.

title: MARGARET SEGAL PLANS TO WED IN SEPTEMBER
description: Dr. and Mrs. Robert L. Segal of New York and East Hampton, L.I., have announced the engagement of his daughter Margaret J. Segal to David J. Topper, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Yale Topper of Rockville, Md. A September wedding is planned.

title: COAST TO COAST
description: ''I CAN'T do this. This is so different from what I did before. My writing didn't have to have all these, these things in it in my other school.'' Panic welled up in my student's eyes. How, she thought, could this California woman ever understand?

title: SPRUCING UP REJUVENATES SOME SUPERB FRAGONARDS
description: One of the best things that Henry Clay Frick ever did for New York City was to buy the series of big decorative paintings by Fragonard that is generally known as ''The Progress of Love.'' For 70 years, first privately and later on permanent public view, they have been one of the great inducements of a visit to New York. And the happy news is that, after a month or two away for cleaning in the Conservation Institute of the Metropolitan Museum, they are back in the Frick Collection and look better than ever.

title: A CASE OF HIDE-AND-SEEK ARCHITECTURE
description: There is a Washington that tourists rarely get to see but that architects view as distinctive.

title: BRELAND STOPS ANTHONY IN 3D
description: In 1981, an amateur fighter from St. Louis, Darryl Anthony, scored a decision over a 17-year-old Brooklyn athlete named Mark Breland in the national Amateur Athletic Union championships in Concord, Calif.

title: PUTTING KIDS FIRST
description: IT WAS A BLIZZARD THAT FINALLY FORCED THE issue into the open. As snow began to fall at noon one wintry New York day, Kenneth S. Schuman, then an associate at the Wall Street investment banking firm of Lehman Brothers Kuhn Loeb, was asked by a senior partner to stand by. A major deal was in the wind, and Schuman soon would be asked to put together a rush report on the project. At 4:45 P.M., his orders finally came through.

title: COACH'S DISPLAY OF TEMPER CAN BE A BAD EXAMPLE
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: U.S. Warning on Adulterated Wine
description: The scandal in Italy over contaminated wine, which has been linked to at least 20 deaths there, has also poisoned the Italian wine industry's thriving export business with the United States. The United States Government warned American consumers last week not to drink any Italian wines until tests prove that they are not contaminated with methanol, or wood alcohol, an additive sometimes placed in cheap wine to increase its alcoholic content.

title: NORTHEAST JOURNAL
description: Summer's Near, And So Is Bad Air The brisk weather of the past week may have had Northeasterners looking forward to summer, but that anticipation was dampened by the news that one of summer's lesser joys, ozone pollution, would return with those hot humid days.

title: VINTAGE CALIFORNIA HOTELS
description: When I was growing up in California, hotels like the Huntington in Pasadena and the Del Coronado near San Diego were legendary. The stories of Presidents and other famous people who stayed there, the photos of dinners or receptions in the society columns, might have been something that happened on another planet. Even though we were not poor, when we went on our vacations we stayed in tourist camps or clean but inexpensive motels. As for restaurants - dinner at Taix's French restaurant in downtown Los Angeles was 50 cents for the table d'hote, $1 if you wanted a private table. That was where we went.

title: WESTCHESTER POPS
description: The singer Ray Charles will appear in concert with the New Orchestra of Westchester on April 26 at 8 P.M. at the County Center in ''Benefit Pops '86,'' a joint fund-raising effort sponsored by the orchestra and the Westchester division of the American Cancer Society. This is a first-time partnership for the two groups. They say they hope to make the pops concert an annual event.

title: STORYTELLER FESTIVAL RENEWS A TRADITION
description: PEOPLE who weave tales using dance, music and even sign language will meet next month for the fifth annual Connecticut Storytelling Festival.

title: MUSIC: HOGWOOD AND PHILHARMONIC
description: TWO days running in New York, British harpsichordist-conductors known for their work with period instruments confronted modern ensembles in big modern halls. Thursday it was Trevor Pinnock and the Orchestra of St. Luke's in Carnegie Hall, Friday afternoon it was Christopher Hogwood in a guest appearance with the New York Philharmonic at Avery Fisher Hall.

title: COFFEE AS 'FAD'
description: When four members of a Scarsdale church volunteered to create a special fund-raising event to benefit the weekday nursery school, everyone realized the event would be decidedly professional.

title:
INVESTING;
THE HERD MOVES TO GROWTH STOCKS
description: WALL STREET professionals often are as swept up by fads as Seventh Avenue's designers. Much of the market's drama is in watching investors chase groups of stocks for several years, driving prices to excessive levels - only to cast these stocks aside when fashions change.

title: Costantini and Argentina's Legacy
description: To the Editor:

title: ROBIN ACKERMAN. ENGINEER, IS WED TO PAUL M. FOLEY
description: Robin Cooper Ackerman, a civil engineer with the Turner Construction Company in New York, was married yesterday to Paul Michael Foley, an assistant vice president of E. F. Hutton & Company in New York. The Rev. Neil Doherty performed the Roman Catholic ceremony at the Manhattanville College Chapel in Purchase, N.Y.

title: ASHLEY JANEWAY, DANCER, MARRIED TO PAUL S. WARREN
description: Ashley Janeway, a dancer with the New York City Opera Ballet, was married yesterday to Paul S. Warren, a New York City stockbroker, at the Episcopal Church of the Heavenly Rest in Manhattan. The Rev. C. Hugh Hildesley performed the ceremony.

title: Leaving Mexico
description: In his five years as the United States Ambassador to Mexico, John Gavin was often at odds with the Mexican press and leaders in various sectors; last week he took senior White House and State Department officials by surprise, resigning as of next month. He offered no explanations and announced no plans, saying only, ''after five years it is time to return to the private sector and meet new challenges.''

title: COMPANY FINDS KEY IS LABOR POOL
description: MUCH has been made of the new American business hero, the entrepreneur who runs a company and whose enthusiasm and appetite for work are boundless. It was those entreprenurial traits that Ultrasonix Inc., a small medical-equipment manufacturer in Yonkers, looked for when hiring its employees, many of whom spend 60 hours a week on the job.

title: TRAVELERS GO ON THE RECORD
description: Travelers in search of the exotic always have had various ways of recording the places they visited. In Victorian times, they would whip out their sketch pads and limn a scene with a few swift strokes. Later, they lugged cameras. Today, the portable cassette recorder has joined the camera as an indispensable travel accessory.

title: Let Corporate Felons Pay for the Harm They Do
description: To the Editor:

title: SAN FRANCISCO OFFICIALS CITE SUCCESS WITH LAW
description: After more than two years of experience with one of the nation's toughest smoking ordinances, enforcers of the law and employers here say the program has proceeded smoothly.

title:
ART;
WINNERS IN A JURIED SHOW WHOSE NOVELTY IS IN CONCEPT
description: LIVING in a region that boasts a unusually large population of artist-residents, one can easily forget that there are plenty of active artists elsewhere. For those of us who do not have occasion to travel the country in search of their work, the Isis Gallery in Port Washington has conducted a nationwide juried competition to bring some of their art to the attention of Long Islanders.

title:
ANTIQUES;
INTEREST AND EXPERTISE BECOME COLLABORATORS IN A MANALAPAN GALLERY
description: WEINSTEIN Galleries, which opened here little more than a month ago, is a collaboration of interest and expertise between the owners, Harvey and Eileen Weinstein, and the shop's urbane and knowledgeable manager, Odetto Lastra.

title: LAST WEEK'S TALLY IN KEY EASTERN STATES
description: SENATE

title: POLICE SEEKING BOY, 5
description: PEEKSKILL police are searching for a 5-year-old boy who they believe was abducted by his mother and grandmother late last month while he was walking to school near his foster home in that city. Warrants were issued March 26 for the arrest of his mother, Betty Bady Gordon, and his grandmother, Ida Bryant, according to Judge Sandra M. Miller of Family Court, who issued them.

title: YOUTH REVITALIZES THE SYMPHONY ORCHESTRA
description: For some they are big families, for others big machines. Every year, as American symphony orchestras open their doors a crack and admit more members, newcomers look around them and decide for themselves which face fits.

title: RACHEL LEE IJAMS WED IN PRINCETON TO J. P. SCHMADER
description: Rachel Lee Ijams, a daughter of Mrs. Edwards Mathews Crane Jr. of Princeton, N.J., and Fishers Island, L.I., and Porter Ijams of Locust Valley, L.I., was married yesterday to James Peter Schmader, a son of Mr. and Mrs. John Jacob Schmader Jr. of Solon, Ohio. The Rev. Frederick S. Baldwin performed the ceremony at Trinity Episcopal Church in Princeton.

title: LITTLE MATCH GIRL
description: COURTING FAME The Perilous Road to Women's Tennis Stardom. By Karen Stabiner. Illustrated. 254 pp. New York: Harper & Row. $16.95.

title: DEATHS OF WOMEN TROUBLE ATLANTA
description: On Monday night, when Catherine Jones came home on the bus from her job as a maid in an affluent white part of Atlanta, she and her cousin Grace Hill, who lived in the corner apartment of the next building, hung out their wash together and gossiped in the evening air. They talked of the three black women, elderly and living alone like themselves, who had been raped and suffocated in their section of the city's west side since March 1.

title:
WORKING ABROAD IN TERROR'S SHADOW;
TEL AVIV
