description: ''Living here day to day, you can't believe anything can happen because the Israelis are so friendly,'' said Thomas J. Roesch, Counsellor for Commercial Affairs at the United States Embassy here. But ''there is always a possibility.''

title: STUDY CITES CREATION OF JOBS
description: The 60 private colleges and universities in Massachusetts generate at least $3.7 billion in spending annually and have created 155,668 jobs in the state, according to a study commissioned by the institutions that was released Thursday. The survey concluded that the institutions provided one in every 20 jobs in the state and were responsible for $3.43 of every $100 spent in Massachusetts.

title: Glass Shards Prompt Recall Of Three Types of Rye Bread
description: Glass shards discovered in bulk packages of caraway seeds imported from the Netherlands have prompted Stroehmann Bakeries Inc. to withdraw three types of rye bread from the market in the Northeast, the company announced Friday.

title: DANCE: JIM SELF AND DANCERS IN TRILOGY SET TO MOZART
description: CHARM and playfulness - qualities often associated with Mozart - were much in evidence in Jim Self's choreography for ''The Mozart Pieces,'' the trilogy to Mozart symphonies that Jim Self and Dancers presented Thursday night at the Bessie Schonberg Theater.

title: THE N.R.A.'S LOBBYING IS AS EFFECTIVE AS EVER
description: UNIFORMED police officers, their badges glinting, provided a striking backdrop for last week's gun control debate in the House of Representatives. Assembled by the hundreds on Capitol Hill, officers representing 13 national organizations tried to persuade Congress not to gut Federal gun control.

title: HOLLY S. KENNEDY BECOMES A BRIDE
description: Holly Sean Kennedy and Philip James Passantino were married yesterday at the Inn at Lambertville Station in New Jersey. The Rev. Cynthia Jarvis performed the Presbyterian ceremony.

title: BARBARA BERZIN TO WED
description: Mr. and Mrs. Ben Berzin of Bridgewater, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter Barbara Jane Berzin to Peter Frischman, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Henry Frischman of Livingston, N.J. The wedding is planned for next month.

title: Just Keep It to Yourself
description: HE WAS WEARING A $500 jacket and a cashmere sweater that would have had ''Big Bucks'' written all over it if it hadn't been too highbrow to carry on like a T-shirt.

title: British Precision
description: The English may well be eccentric and peculiar, but all of the visual evidence offered in Neal Slavin's splendid photographs would seem to confirm the opposite (''Portrait of the British,'' by John Russell, March 9). Indeed, what the pictures show are precise, regular rows of costumed Britons. MARK WILSON West Cornwall, Conn.

title: Waldheim Alters His Biography
description: Kurt Waldheim rewrote his official biography last week to add information about his military service as allegations that he had not been candid about it drew attention in at least five countries.

title: L.I. Judge Finds Man Guilty in Sex Assault
description: A Suffolk County Court judge who accused county prosecutors and homicide detectives of misconduct during the rape and murder trial of a 22-year-old drifter last fall has found the same defendant guilty on separate charges of sexually abusing and assaulting a female acquaintance.

title: NURSING-HOME CARE: VIEWS AND OVERVIEWS
description: I viewed with concern and dismay your Feb. 16 article by Lucille G. Natkins entitled ''My Mother Would Be Treated Better if She Were a Dog.'' [ Opinion Page ] Frankly I believed it incumbent upon the part of The New York Times when determining whether an article should be published, to assess both the validity and the impact of the content.

title: Cable TV
description: Cable's movie event of the week is the long-awaited television bow of Charlie Chaplin's ''Limelight'' (1952) in Showtime's parade of masterworks by the great comedian - Monday at 8 P.M. and Saturday at 7:30 A.M. This sensitive tale of an aging vaudevillian and a despairing young ballerina has a luminous performance by Claire Bloom, in her screen debut, and a hilarious sequence of a stage act with Chaplin and the deadpan Buster Keaton - plus that haunting musical theme, by Chaplin himself.

title: The Focus Shifts To New York's Taxi Regulators
description: Officials at the State Commission of Investigation had been saying recently that they had evidence of corruption at the agency that oversees New York City's taxi industry. But not until last week, at the first of two public hearings, did state investigators disclose the magnitude of their allegations.

title: GENEROUS HELPINGS OF SEAFOOD
description: CONTRARY to many restaurateurs' perceptions, all restaurant reviewers are not curmudgeons whose day is made when they can criticize a restaurant mercilessly. Nothing gives a reviewer greater pleasure than finding a culinary paradise, fit for lavish praise.

title: OVERSEAS MARKETS BECKON STATE FIRMS
description: TO increase the amount of goods exported from Connecticut, trade specialists from the Federal Department of Commerce are helping state business owners determine how to find a market overseas, how to get licensing, ship their products and, most importantly, how to get paid.

title: Merry Christmas, Senator Packwood
description: It's mainly tactics, the Senate vote to hold tax reform hostage until the President agrees to negotiate on the budget. But sooner or later, the senators will have to get back to the tax bill - and the one emerging from the Finance Committee reeks of privilege. Tax reform is meant to close loopholes; this bill bulldozes new ones for favored industries. It might well be worse than no bill at all.

title: A POET ONCE JAILED AS A TERRORIST IS BACK IN PRETORIA
description: Breyten Breytenbach, South Africa's leading poet in the Afrikaans language who once served seven years in prison for terrorism, has returned quietly to this country after four years of self-imposed exile.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''It is a cursedly intricate situation.'' - Prime Minister Bettino Craxi of Italy, describing possible retaliation against terrorists. [ 14:4. ]

title: Article 869286 -- No Title
description: IF the town of Mount Pleasant gives up on its plan to widen a three-quarter-mile strip of Kensico Road, it will face a possible $84 million in damages from a disappointed developer, who says he is obligated to turn over his building rent free to a division of the Columbia Broadcasting System if the new road is not built.

title: LEARNING TO LIVE IN AN AGE OF STRICT LIMITS
description: AS state legislators have been sitting down to business this year, the economy has caused their governors' messages to dwell even more than usually on regional issues. The farm belt is in recession, and oil producers have been hard hit by falling prices, while the Northeast and the industrial Middle West are doing relatively well. But the governors' new and common concern is what can or should be done when Federal budget cuts are forcing a redefinition of the relationships among national, state and local governments. According to a recent report by the National Governors Association and the National Association of State Budget Officers, 17 states have had to redo their balance sheets to avoid deficits in this fiscal year. In 1985, only three states did so. Following are excerpts from eight governors' messages, delivered since January, that highlight these major themes. VERMONT: Private Partnerships

title: Primo Levi's 'Germans'
description: To the Editor:

title: 3d Death Sentence Asked For Crime Spree Figure
description: Alton Coleman, already under two death sentences for slayings in Ohio, stood impassively today as he heard a jury recommend that he be executed for the strangling of a 7-year-old girl during a six-state crime spree in 1984.

title: MITCHELL-LAMA
description: To the Editor:

title: TAKING RISKS: THE WRITER AS EFFECTIVE TEACHER
description: Forty-eight years ago, when she was 15 years old, Grace Paley entered the freshman class at Hunter College. But she dropped out after a year, horrifying her parents. ''They didn't know that 25 years later everyone would be doing it,'' Miss Paley recalls, smiling. Her worried parents insisted that she take a typing course so she could support herself. They may have known she would become a writer - she had been writing poetry since she was a small child. They may have suspected that their feisty daughter would also become a social activist. But they never dreamed she would also become a teacher - one of the most popular on the Sarah Lawrence campus in Bronxville, N.Y.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article last Sunday about legislative passage of the New York State budget misstated the source of funds for a $400 million plan to build or rehabilitate low- and moderate-income housing in New York City. It also gave an inconsistent account of the amount allocated for aid to local school districts. The housing funds will be raised by borrowing against future revenues of the Battery Park City Authority; school aid was increased this year by $605 million, including $95 million that is to be used exclusively for raising teacher salaries.

title: City to Seize 7,500 Occupied Apartments in Brooklyn
description: IN less than a month, the city will become the new landlord for at least 7,500 occupied Brooklyn apartments in 1,600 properties that are to be seized for nonpayment of taxes, according to the Department of Housing Preservation and Development.

title: SPRING BECKONS, AND SO DO REPAIRS AROUND THE HOUSE
description: SPRING is traditionally fixup time for homeowners in this area, and with good reason. Winter exposes a house to some of its worst wear, so there is often a need for minor repairs and preventive maintenance to keep small breakdowns from becoming major problems later on - and this is the best time of year to attend to this.

title: STUDY FINDS POOR WRITING SKILLS IN SCHOOLCHILDREN
description: Writing skills of elementary and secondary school students have remained poor despite a decade of emphasis on writing instruction, a federally financed study reported yesterday.

title: VANDALS WHO WON'T QUIT
description: AS long as people ride them, elevators will in all likelihood suffer from some familiar problems. Because of the privacy they afford, they are prime targets of vandals. And, according to industry estimates, they still kill about 15 people a year, usually young thrill-seekers riding on top of the cabs.

title: DRESSING UP ONYX AND EBONY
description: SINCE elevators provide people with an important first impression of a building, architects and developers these days are devoting more thought - and considerably more money - to the cabs' design.

title: THE CALDER IS COMING
description: According to the Architect of the Capitol, the giant mobile-stabile by Alexander Calder in the atrium of the Hart Senate Office Building is only two months or so away from complete installation.

title: QUAKER-RUN SCHOOL, AT 200, PRIZES ITS INFORMALITY
description: Any time Thomas Sellar tells other teen-agers that he attends Friends Seminary, he knows what to expect. Eyes widen, brows go up and then, the high school junior says, comes some variation of the inevitable question:

title: Eating Dogs in 'Whites'
description: To the Editor:

title: DIANA M. HENRY TO WED IN JUNE
description: Carl Henry of New York has announced the engagement of his daughter, Diana Mara Henry, to Noel Oard Mapstead, a son of Ruth Mapstead of Carmel, Calif., and the late Raymond Mapstead. A June wedding is planned.

title: Ost-West Express
description: To the Editor: Rick Sinding's essay ''Mystery on the Ost-West Express'' (Travel, Feb. 2) brings back to me the experience I had with the Czech Communists some years ago. I was in Stockholm and my next destination was East Berlin to visit for three days a professor from Humboldt University. In New York I had booked that portion of my travel, Stockholm via Copenhagen to the East Berlin airport, on Czech Airlines. Americans wanting to visit East Berlin for a day ordinarily would go to West Berlin and then through Checkpoint Charlie.

title: BROADWAY NEED NOT BECOME A DOORMAT FOR SKYSCRAPERS
description: There was once a time when a legitimate theater was of value mainly for what was produced on its stage. Those times are past in New York.

title: STOCKMAN BOOK IS A HARSH LOOK AT THE COLLEAGUES HE LEFT BEHIND
description: President Reagan had little grasp of the large cuts in Government spending that his Administration sought upon taking office five years ago, according to his former budget director, David A. Stockman.

title: Bangkok
description: To the Editor: Barbara Crossette (''What's Doing in Bangkok,'' Feb. 16) rightly notes that Bangkok's fumes and traffic can overpower the tourist. Visitors hoping to gulp some fresh air might do well to take a day trip to Thailand's ancient capital, Ayutthaya, 60 miles north of Bangkok.

title: LISA WEATHERFORD AND GILBERT OTT JR. ARE MARRIED IN A KENTUCKY CEREMONY
description: Lisa Stuart Weatherford, an account executive at Needham Harper Worldwide in New York, and Gilbert R. Ott Jr., a vice president, associate general counsel and director of Kidder, Peabody & Company, were married yesterday at the First Presbyterian Church in Frankfort, Ky. The Rev. John Calloway performed the ceremony.

title: Funding Public TV
description: To the Editor:

title: DASH OF PIZZAZZ FOR SUBARU
description: THE world of car-crazies has many camps. There are Ferrari freaks. There are Corvette people. There are those who flip for Honda Civics. But there is another major subdivision, and the ''sub'' probably ought to be capitalized. It consists of those who love Subarus and those who couldn't care less.

title: HALLIE FOOTE RELIVES HER FAMILY'S PAST
description: Hallie Foote gazes silently at the black and white picture of a genteel Southern woman with a wistful air about her. ''This was taken before she eloped,'' Miss Foote says, smiling. ''You can tell that she knows something. She has a special knowledge.''

title: MERCURY SOUP
description: The Library of Congress, which has antagonized some patrons by shortening its hours in an economy move, is trying to compensate with a food special.

title: Et Voila! Le Minitel
description: Just as the French have made their videotex system profitable, two of our color-graphic videotex systems, including the largest, Knight-Ridder's Viewtron, are folding (''Et Voila! Le Minitel,'' by Nadine Epstein, March 9).

title: Postings; Seamen's Haven to Co-op
description: For decades, the Romanesque church served as the center of New York's Norwegian community, drawing seamen whose ships docked in Brooklyn's ports.

title: ERRANT ROOKS ASK FOR TROUBLE
description: Rooks should not go wandering in any usual type of middle game thick with pawns, but every once in a while someone thinks he has found an exception to this rule.

title: KATHERINE CHENEY WED IN GREENWICH
description: The wedding of Katherine Mitchell Cheney, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William G. Cheney of Greenwich, Conn., to Russell Lamont Creighton, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Roger Lamont Creighton of Delmar, N.Y., took place yesterday. Msgr. Thomas P. Guinan performed the ceremony at St. Michael's Roman Catholic Church in Greenwich.

title: PIPE BREAK FORCES ASBESTOS CLEANUP
description: Subway service on the West Side of Manhattan was shut down for five hours and traffic was detoured for more than 12 hours yesterday after a ruptured steam line spewed asbestos-contaminated debris over a three-block stretch of Eighth Avenue.

title: BUSH WAS RIGHT - STABILIZE OIL PRICES
description: WHAT should we do when Saudi Arabia deliberately floods the market by doubling oil production, dumps its oil stockpiles, and collapses the price in a few weeks' time from $27 a barrel to $15 or less? The purpose of this price war is certainly not to benefit American consumers, but to raise prices even higher after OPEC puts its act together and cuts back production.

title: Fred Karpin, Author of Books On Contract Bridge, Is Dead
description: Fred Karpin, an authority on contract bridge who lectured and wrote about the game, died Friday at the Washington Home Hospice. Mr. Karpin, who had suffered from cancer, was 73 years old and lived in Silver Spring, Md.

title: EGGPLANT NEEDS A HEAD START
description: Eggplant, a native of tropical Asia, needs warmth and care to prosper. Many ask is it worth the effort?

title: LOAFS IN SMALL SIZES ARE GOOD FOR ENTERTAINING AND FREEZING
description: ALTHOUGH most loaf cake or bread recipes call for pans that measure 9 by 5 by 3 inches or 8 1/2 by 4 1/2 by 2 inches, there are other pan sizes on the market. In fact, using smaller pans often makes good sense.

title: A Garden Tapestry
description: THE SLOPING PROPERTY was a tangle of briars, rocks and roots. Hardly a dream site for a garden. Yet 30 years ago, when Ruth and Jim Levitan first settled in a Connecticut suburb, this was not a consideration, since the couple had no intention of creating an elaborate landscape.

title: A COOLING TREND FOR BIOTECHNOLOGY
description: THE Animal and Plant Health Inspection Service, a regulatory division of the Department of Agriculture, has approved thousands of licenses to sell livestock vaccines and other animal health-care products since 1913. But none has attracted more attention than the permit issued Jan. 16 for a swine vaccine made by the Biologics Corporation of Omaha. It was the world's first license to market a living genetically engineered organism, although neither the Government nor the manufacturer chose to advertise the event.

title: JOG WITH GENEROUS JOE
description: A new and different kind of public attraction is going up on the Mall, dedicated not to government, history or culture but to fitness. Courtesy of Joseph H. Kanter, a former Washington businessman now in banking and communications in Florida, the National Park Service is installing exercise equipment for joggers between the National Air and Space Museum and the pool below the west front of the Capitol.

title: Liberals: Their Own Worst Enemy
description: Harry Stein describes liberals as intolerant of any dissent in their ranks on the subject of abortion. In fact, there is no single liberal position on abortion itself: Roman Catholic liberals, like Mario Cuomo, have not abandoned Catholic teaching on the morality of abortion. Liberals are united, however, in opposing the use of American law to enforce church rules of conduct. EDGAR VILLCHUR Woodstock, N.Y.

title: A PLAYWRIGHT WHO TAKES COMEDY VERY, VERY SERIOUSLY
description: ''Comedy,'' says Andrew Bergman, ''is a very delicate thing. There's nothing harder. It requires an enormous commitment from the audience.

title: SECOND JURY IS SAID TO REVIEW F.B.I. LINK TO TEAMSTER CHIEF
description: A Federal grand jury here is trying to determine whether agents of the Federal Bureau of Investigation lied to Justice Department lawyers about the bureau's ties to Jackie Presser, president of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters, a Federal law-enforcement official said today.

title: FINLAND RALLIES TO BEAT U.S. IN WORLD HOCKEY
description: The top two goaltenders of the Buffalo Sabres - Jacques Cloutier and Tom Barrasso - played simultaneously today in arenas a short walk apart but split their games as the World Ice Hockey Championships opened here.

title: ISLANDERS ELIMINATED; CAPITALS WIN, 3-1, FOR SWEEP
description: They made Pete Peeters look good and made their own goalie miserable. They let the Capitals operate like a battering ram for two periods, and by the time the Islanders started to skate as if they had something to lose, they had already lost it. The result was a 3-1 victory for Washington tonight, a sweep of their opening-round playoff series and an invitation to the Patrick Division final.

title: SARAH E. FRIES IS ENGAGED TO WED JON DURELL PACKER
description: Sarah Elizabeth Fries and Jon Durell Packer of Stamford, Conn., plan to be married May 10.

title: THE BLACK MOSES AND HIS IMPERIAL DREAM
description: THE WORLD OF MARCUS GARVEY Race and Class in Modern Society. By Judith Stein. Illustrated. 294 pp. Baton Rouge: Louisiana State University Press. $22.50.

title: Canada's Friendly Advice
description: Canadian Prime Minister Brian Mulroney is a tall, handsome, vigorous man determined to be amiable, which to him means being on good terms with the U.S.

title: DEREGULATION
description: To the Editor:

title: OLD TRAVELERS REMEMBER EVERY STEP
description: Rummaging through the closet recently, I suddenly had the keen sense that something was missing.

title: WHAT IT TAKES TO PLAY THE BARD
description: To the Editor: In response to Frank Rich's astute review of Kevin Kline's ''Hamlet'' at the Public [ ''A Heroic Hamlet That Might Have Been Outstanding,'' March 30 ] , one thing again becomes apparent: that theatrical producers in New York City cannot properly cast Shakespearean or other classics with top-quality actors in featured roles.

title: BULGARIA JEWS' HOPES, AND NUMBERS, DWINDLE
description: In the small prayer hall adjoining the Grand Synagogue, 16 men, 16 women and a small boy chanted the traditional Friday evening prayers to greet the coming of the Sabbath.

title: ERIK BRUHN - EPITOME OF THE DANSEUR NOBLE
description: Erik Bruhn, ballet's noblest prince, has left us. He died in Toronto on April 1 at the age of 57, only a few short weeks after it was learned that he had lung cancer. His unexpected passing will rob the dance world of a moral force whose influence has been continuously felt - even in the decade and a half since he retired from the roles that established him as one of history's greatest classical dancers.

title: RECASTING A TENANT'S RIGHT TO RENEW
description: ALMOST hidden by the debate over proposed changes in the code that governs New York City's 950,000 rent-stabilized apartments, the subject of noisy hearings in Manhattan last week, is a drift toward restoration of stricter controls resembling those first established over rental housing at the end of World War II.

title: LONG ISLAND'S ECONOMY IS GROWING AT A GALLOP
description: THE announcement last week that the Grumman Corporation had received a $1.1 billion Government contract, its largest ever, added a few more decibels to Long Island's resounding economic boom.

title: REAGAN DISPUTED ON WORK PROGRAM
description: California's experience with a program to put welfare recipients to work, which began when Ronald Reagan was Governor, has become an element in a debate over how the Federal Government can best help poor Americans find jobs and break the cycle of dependency on benefits.

title: Miss Bhutto Is Back in Pakistan
description: The daughter of Zulfikar Ali Bhutto made her first public move toward power in Pakistan last week and was cheered by several hundred thousand people on the streets of Lahore.

title: A Watchung Tower With a Skyline View
description: THE easternmost elevation of the Watchung Mountains is often referred to simply as First Mountain because it is the first significant ridge west of the Palisades, 12 miles away.

title: DUKE FAN'S EMPTY FEELING COMES AGAIN THIS YEAR
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: BRAND NAMES
description: To the Editor:

title: Rabbi Israel Goldstein, A Founder of Brandeis
description: Rabbi Israel Goldstein, a former head of the 161-year-old congregation B'nai Jeshurun in Manhattan and one of the founders of Brandeis University, died of cancer Friday at his home in Jerusalem. He was 89 years old.

title: ARCHITECTURAL-HERITAGE CAMPAIGN UNDER WAY COUNTYWIDE
description: IN the coming months, Westchester residents will be given the opportunity to sample 18th-century treats at the Wayside Cottage in Scarsdale, learn wood and masonry restoration techniques as part of a curatorial workshop, compete in architectural photography contests and visit the weir chamber of the old Croton Reservoir. These and many other lectures, exhibitions, competitions and tours are being offered by groups and organizations countywide as part of Architectural Heritage Year, proclaimed by Governor Cuomo.

title: HARMS CENTER TO BE HONORED
description: THE John Harms Center here will receive the first Englewood Historical Society Award Wednesday ''for making a significant contribution to historic preservation/restoration to a property of historic value.''

title: WHAT'S GOING ON WITH HAZARDOUS WASTE?
description: NEW JERSEY, as every kid on the street knows, has more disgusting hazardous-waste sites than any other state. Almost 100 of them are even on the so-called National Priorities List.

title: ON FINDING HIGHLY IMPROBABLE THINGS TO COMPLAIN ABOUT
description: Tournament bridge-players are chronic complainers, though they have trouble finding listeners. They grumble about smoking, noise-level, temperature, lighting and crowded tables. They moan about the quality of the coffee, the absence of soda, and iced water that is warm. They scream about their luck, their partners and their teammates.

title: West Coast Whimsy
description: WHERE ELSE BUT IN LOS Angeles would a house front and a curb be painted hot pink to match the smoggy sunsets? Or would the sight of a corrugated fiberglass roof and a porch adorned with a bent exhaust pipe not offend the neighbors?

title: MASTERS' TOUGHEST SHOT
description: AT the Masters, it always boils down to the back nine in the final round. There, some say, is where the Masters always begins. And there, of course, is where it always ends. Even a sudden-death playoff starts at the 10th tee.

title:
GARDENING;
TIMELY CARE BETWEEN SPRING'S SHOWERS
description: APRIL showers may, indeed, bring May flowers, but if the flowers are to last the season, the gardener must get into the act.

title: Courtroom Gunman Is Freed in Bail
description: A man whose daughter was killed in Golden Gate park in 1983 has been freed on $25,000 bail after he pulled out a gun during a court hearing and shot the man accused in the girl's slaying.

title: NEW JERSEYANS
description: SOME people think that being sent to New Jersey is like going to Coventry, says Gloria M. Rojas, who covers the state for WNBC-TV News (Channel 4).

title: Greece's State of War With Albania to End
description: Greece will announce the lifting of a 46-year-old technical state of war with Albania next month, the Greek national news agency said today.

title: THOUGHTS ON SPRING,VIA THE CHAISE LOUNGE
description: FOR all I know, three inches of snow might be on the ground by the time this advice arrives at your door on how to cope with spring. Nothing is more dangerous than writing about weather that hasn't happened yet, a peril enhanced because I don't have the foggiest notion of what the television people, with their isobars and jet streams, are up to.

title: GASOLINE LEADS FALL IN PRODUCER PRICES
description: Producer prices plunged at an annualized rate of 12.4 percent in the first quarter, the biggest drop ever. March's prices were 1.1 percent below February's, primarily because gasoline prices dropped 21.9 percent, and crude oil overall fell 24.8 percent. Auto sales, meanwhile, were off so much that retail sales as a whole fell eight-tenths of 1 percent in March, the biggest drop in five months.

title: CAPT. ANN VRTIS IS MARRIED TO CAPT. ROBERT P. KADLEC
description: Capt. Ann Marie Vrtis, an anesthesiologist at Wilford Hall Medical Center at Lackland Air Force Base in Texas, was married yesterday to Capt. Robert P. Kadlec, a flight surgeon at Hurlburt Field in Florida. The Rev. Maurice Dillane performed the ceremony in the chapel at Randolph Air Force Base in Texas.

title: FOR EQUAL, IF SEPARATE, NEIGHBORHOODS
description: THE WRONG SIDE OF THE TRACKS A Revolutionary Rediscovery of the Common Law Tradition of Fairness in the Struggle Against Inequality. By Charles M. Haar and Daniel Wm. Fessler. Illustrated. 335 pp. New York: Simon & Schuster. $18.95.

title: Verbatim; Off the Shelf
description: 'No matter how the Department of Defense improves its organization or procedures, the defense acquisition system is unlikely to manufacture products as cheaply as the commercial marketplace.'

title: The South Sets An Early Primary
description: The next Presidential campaign may seem a long way off, but March 8, 1988, has just been circled on the political calendar as what could be a make-or-break day for Republican and Democratic candidates. Seven Southern and border states have scheduled primaries for that date; Mississippi and Maryland added their names to the list last weekend, and four more states may soon join.

title: THE BATTLE FOR BARCELONA NECK
description: CONCERN is growing in Suffolk County over the clouded future of Barcelona Neck -one of the two largest undeveloped, privately owned tracts in the Town of East Hampton.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: HALF LAUGHING HALF CRYING. By Malcolm Boyd. (St. Martin's, $15.95.) The subtitle on this book's dust jacket - ''Songs for Myself'' - was obviously intended to relate Malcolm Boyd's items, prose or poetry, to the verse and personality of Walt Whitman.

title: PATRICIA GUCKER WEDS
description: Patricia Ann Gucker, a division planning analyst for Citibank, and Frank Ronald Millo, a lawyer in the New York law firm of Abady & Jaffe, were married yesterday at St. Joseph's of Yorkville Roman Catholic Church. The Rev. Peter Colapietro performed the ceremony. Mrs. Millo, a daughter of the late Mr. and Mrs. Henry John Gucker of New York, is a graduate of Wheaton College. Mr. Millo, the son of Mrs. Frank M. Millo of Wilkes-Barre, Pa., and the late Mr. Millo, graduated from Pennsylvania State University and received a law degree from Southwestern University.

title: COME MUDTIME, COME HONEYTIME
description: A COUNTRY YEAR Living the Questions. By Sue Hubbell. Illustrations by Lauren Jarrett. 221 pp. New York: Random House. $17.95.

title: CORRECTION
description: A Jerusalem dispatch in the World section last Sunday about Israel's Housing Minister, David Levy, described his language facility incompletely. While he speaks no English, he is fluent in Arabic, as well as French and Hebrew.

title: Plans for Summit Proceed Despite U.S. Nuclear Test
description: The United States set off a nuclear test under the Nevada desert last week, and the Soviet Union promptly announced it would end the testing moratorium it began in August. But the explosion apparently did not upset plans for President Reagan to meet this year with Mikhail S. Gorbachev, the Soviet leader.

title: NOTED WITH PLEASURE
description: Talking Infinitely Henry James was almost as famous for his personal mannerisms as he was for his novels. In ''The Legend of the Master'' (Oxford University), edited by Simon Nowell-Smith, the novelist Hugh Walpole describes James's style of speech.

title: 'FAST-FOOD' FIBER ART AND 'KILIMS'
description: TWO textile events this month are furthering the current renaissance of culture and business in this Bergen County community.

title: NEW CASSETTES: FROM WAR STORIES TO FAIRY TALES
description: Pack Up the Plantation Live! Featuring Tom Petty and the Heartbreakers MCA Home Video 96 minutes. $29.95 Tom Petty, who grew up in Gainesville, Fla., is a mainstream rocker whose soul-flavored folk-rock songs evoke a pungent sense of place.

title: PUZZLING MALADY THAT KILLS GIRAFFES
description: THE rare Angolan giraffes at the Baltimore Zoo began dying five years ago, and by last year a herd of nine had been reduced to two.

title: SUNDAY SPORTS
description: Auto Racing Nascar Transouth 500, at Darlington, S.C. (Television - ESPN, 1 P.M.) Formula I Grand Prix, at Jerez, Spain (Television -ESPN, 10 A.M. delayed tape) Baseball Yankees vs. Milwaukee Brewers, at Yankee Stadium, 1:35 P.M. Ron Guidry, a winner opening day, makes his second start of the season. (Television - Channel 11, 1:30 P.M. Radio - WABC, 770; 1:30 P.M.) Mets vs. Phillies, at Philadelphia, 3:05 P.M. (Television - Channel 9, 3 P.M. Radio - WHN, 1050; 3 P.M.) Royals vs. Toronto Blue Jays, at Kansas City. (Television - Channel 7, 3 P.M.) Atlanta Braves vs. Astros, at Houston (Television -WTBS, 3:05 P.M.) Basketball Nets vs. Celtics, at Boston, regular-season finale. (Television - SportsChannel, 12:30 P.M.) Cleveland Cavaliers vs. Chicago Bulls, at Richfield, Ohio. (Television - WTBS, 12:30 P.M.) Golf The Masters, final round, at Augusta, Ga., (Television - Channel 2, 3 P.M.) L.P.G.A. Kyocera Inamori Classic, at San Diego, final round. Hockey Islanders vs. Washington Capitals, at Uniondale, L.I., Nassau Coliseum, Game 4, if necessary, of the Patrick Division semifinals (Television - SportsChannel, 7 P.M. Radio - WOR, 710; 7 P.M.) Rangers vs. Philadelphia Flyers, Game 4 of the Patrick Division semifinals, at Madison Square Garden (Television - MSG, 7:30 P.M. Radio - WNBC, 660; 7:20 P.M.) Tennis Family Circle Magazine Cup, at Sea Pines Plantation, Hilton Head, S.C., final. (Television - Channel 4, 2 P.M.) W.C.T. Championship, at Dallas, men's final (Television - Channel 2, noon.) Thoroughbred Racing Aqueduct, 1 P.M. The $100,000-added Bold Ruler for 3-year-olds and up at six furlongs is the feature.

title: Liberals: Their Own Worst Enemy
description: Harry Stein puts forth one criticism of liberals, usually sounded by the conservative view, that I have never been able to comprehend.

title: MARY L. HALSEY AND PETER MCALOON PLAN TO WED
description: Mrs. Benjamin Schuyler Halsey Jr. of Scarborough, N.Y., has announced the engagement of her daughter Mary Lynn Halsey to Peter William McAloon, a son of William McAloon of Miami and the late Mrs. McAloon. The wedding is planned for May 10.

title: PADUA
description: To the Editor: Although the patron of wheelwrights and millers because of the torture wheels with which the Emperor Maxentius tried to put her to death, St. Catherine of Alexandria did not die from these devious devices. The spiked wheels were destroyed by God before they could harm the young maiden's beauty.

title: Modular Housing Gains in Westchester
description: PORT CHESTER'S newest housing is being built in Point of Rocks, Md.; Peekskill's in Scranton, Pa., and Mamaroneck's in Claremont, N.H.

title: F.D.A. TELLS COMPANY TO REVISE DRUG DESCRIPTION
description: The Food and Drug Administration has taken the unusual step of telling a drug manufacturer to recall a press release it had issued on the safety and effectiveness of one of its medicines.

title: OLD LAMPS FOR NEW, AND SO ON
description: In DREAMING IN THE DUST: Restoring an Old House (Houghton Mifflin, $16.95), Katherine Chrisman shows us that the reality of replacing rickety handrails and redoing rooms is a difficult one. This two-year chronicle of one family's experience begins the day Mrs. Chrisman and her husband first visit the slightly tilting, 100-year-old Victorian mansion that will later become their home.

title: Mitchell-Lama
description: To the Editor:

title: GRAF, LLOYD IN FINAL
description: For Steffi Graf, the convincing 6-2, 6-4 victory she achieved over Hana Mandlikova today in the semifinals of the Family Circle Magazine Cup tournament at Sea Pines Plantation was exhilarating. It also worked up an appetite.

title: ELIZABETH GRIFFIN TO MARRY K. J. ROLLENHAGEN IN MAY
description: Mr. and Mrs. John Aloysius Griffin of Short Hills, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter Elizabeth Graham Griffin to Kristoph Justus Rollenhagen, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Frederick vonMinden Rollenhagen Jr. of Summit, N.J., and Guilford, Vt.

title: CAPTURING THE ARTISTS AT WORK IS OBJECT OF SERIES' FILM MAKER
description: ATTACKING a huge block of limestone, the artist wields a chisel in one hand, a mallet in the other, and fashions a monumental, curving sculpture. Brandishing a paintbrush as if it were a sword, another artist sets dazzling and brilliant colors to a huge canvas, covering the entire surface in masterful strokes. Stepping back, he surveys his creation and proclaims: ''Color is life.''

title: INSTITUTIONAL STRUCTURE BLUES
description: TURNING THE TIDE U.S. Intervention in Central America and the Struggle for Peace. By Noam Chomsky. 298 pp. Boston: Sound End Press. Cloth, $30. Paper, $10.

title: LET'S HEAR IT FOR THOSE TREASURE HOUSES -- OUR LIBRARIES
description: THE part of a homeowner's tax bill allotted to public-library maintenance is a very small wedge of the entire tax pie, but it may be the best bargain going.

title: ARIANNA STASSINOPOULOS, AUTHOR, WED TO R. MICHAEL HUFFINGTON, EXECUTIVE
description: Arianna Stassinopoulos, an author and lecturer, was married yesterday to R. Michael Huffington, a petroleum executive, at St. Bartholomew's Church. Bishop Paul Moore Jr. of the Episcopal Diocese of New York officiated, assisted by the Rev. Canon Edward N. West and the Rev. Andrew J. W. Mullins, in an Episcopal service with portions of the Greek Orthodox service incorporated.

title: THE EXQUISITE TURNIP
description: I AM PERSUADED THAT AMERICANS WHO OTHER-wise boast of impeccable taste form unnatural prejudices against certain food items because of the sound of their names. Sea slugs - those odd but savory creatures cherished by the Chinese and prepared with pork, or fresh bacon, occasionally with shrimp eggs - simply sound unappetizing. The sea urchin, another marine delicacy whose roe has long been prized by the French and Japanese, has suffered from the same bias; only recently have we discovered its exotic, briny taste.

title: PENN CREWS VICTORIOUS IN CHILDS CUP REGATTA
description: The University of Pennsylvania heavyweight crews made a clean sweep of the Childs Cup Regatta yesterday on a blustery Harlem River course. The Quaker varsity, which won the featured Copley Cup race last Saturday in the San Diego Crew Classic, added the Childs Cup to its trophy case yesterday.

title: HANG ON TO THAT ANCIENT TEDDY BEAR
description: Ever since teddy bears first appeared at the turn of the century, inspired, it is said, by a 1902 cartoon showing President Theodore Roosevelt refusing to shoot a bear cub, they have always commanded very special attention. Over the years, virtually every variation of huggable bears - Winnie the Pooh, Bully Bear and Paddington - has won the hearts of millions.

title: Poll Says Most Think Nuclear Parity Exists
description: A majority of Americans now believe that the United States and the Soviet Union are ''about equal in nuclear strength,'' according to the Gallup Poll.

title: THE MATERIAL ART
description: WITH ITS CRISP, white exterior walls and clean outlines, the famous and influential International Style house the German architect Walter Gropius designed for himself in Lincoln, Mass., in 1938 could be almost anywhere - except that it rests on a foundation of New England field stones and originally had a screened-in porch around the back, like a local farmhouse. Gathered from the land on which the house is located, the boulders alone indicate that this is inland Massachusetts rather than, say, Germany, or even Long Island.

title: IN ZAIRE, LAND OF LEGENDARY ABUSES, A BIT OF HOPE
description: After more than three years of economic austerity intended to revive Zaire's moribund economy, there are still no signs of economic growth or development, according to Western diplomats, economists and bankers.

title: Remodeling a Vaccine for AIDS
description: In the fight against AIDS, scientists have borrowed more than inspiration from one of medicine's greatest success stories. Using gene-splicing techniques, two research teams have remodeled the vaccine that eradicated smallpox, and one of them plans to seek Federal approval this year to test it on humans as a protection against AIDS.

title: COUNTY WEIGHS INSURING ITSELF
description: CHILDREN better not fall off the roller coaster at Playland, surgeons at the Westchester County Medical Center better not leave sponges in the stomachs of their patients and elderly residents better not trip over county curbs. They had better not - aside from health reasons - because the county, which owns Playland, the Medical Center and many curbs, has no liability insurance. It has not been able to buy any since the beginning of the year.

title: MUSIC VIDEOS TRY A NEW TACK
description: When the 1980's began, music videos shook up television with their barrage of sound and image. Close-ups of electric guitars, smoke caught by spotlights, teen-agers in tight clothes, amateurish acting, trick photography, stunts, old movies, frenzied dancing, computer-generated images, animation - just about anything can get packed into four or five minutes of quick-cut, wild-angled footage. Some observers considered videos a new, syncretic art form; others foresaw the end of Western civilization. But in just a few years, music videos have changed from a novelty to a television staple -and perhaps a cliche.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: ROBERT K. MERTON: An Intellectual Profile. By Piotr Sztompka. (St. Martins, $29.95.) Given that sociology is under close scrutiny not only by the ''critical school'' but also by conservative political philosophers and scholars in the humanities, this intellectual profile of Robert Merton is of considerable interest. Mr. Merton tried more than any other sociologist to make the discipline a hard science, an objective, precise and universal codification of terms, theorems and principles.

title: HUNTING ANOTHER ANSWER FOR ASH
description: A NUMBER of state and Long Island officials are aggressively looking for alternatives to the controversial proposed regional ash fill in Yaphank.

title: Prime Properties Lure Japanese Investors
description: FUDOSAN is a word that signifies real-estate business in Japan. Literally translated, though, it means unmoving assets -anathema to the quickly changing world of real estate in the United States.

title: HUNGARIAN 'RESOLUTION,' A FARM DOCUMENTARY
description: FAILING a certain interest in Hungarian agriculture, you may find that sitting through ''The Resolution'' is as exciting as attending a meeting of the New Life Agricultural Cooperative in Felscut - which, in fact, is largely what this artlessly photographed and edited documentary by Judit Ember and Gyula Gazdag is. Yet the movie's very awkwardness and literalness give it a strong claim to authenticity, as it offers a close-in look at how decisions are made in this particular Communist nation. ''The Resolution'' can be seen tonight at 6 and Tuesday at 8:30 as part of the New Directors/ New Films series at the Museum of Modern Art.

title:
GARDENING;
TIMELY CARE BETWEEN SPRING'S SHOWERS
description: APRIL showers may, indeed, bring May flowers, but if the flowers are to last the season, the gardener must get into the act.

title: L.I. Man Seized in an Assault On Agent Who Issued Ticket
description: A construction worker from Long Island has been arrested and charged with assaulting a New York City traffic agent who had ticketed the worker's illegally parked car in Greenwich Village, the police said yesterday.

title: UPGRADING SAFETY AT RAIL CROSSINGS
description: MOST Stamford motorists who turn onto Crescent Street from Glenbrook Road are accustomed to seeing trains from the New Canaan line of Metro-North hurtling across the road in front of them just seconds after they have negotiated the turn.

title: Man Recovers Land Farmers Helped Save
description: Oscar Lorick, who with the help of 100 armed farmers kept a sheriff with an eviction notice off his family's land last fall, paid off his mortgage today with donated funds, burned his note and reclaimed his farm.

title: LEONARD'S 3-HITTER STOPS JAYS, 1-0
description: Through three years, four operations and thousands of lonely hours of rehabilitation, Dennis Leonard never gave up on himself.

title: Homework Pays
description: A quiet, serious 9-year-old faced eight adults, one after another, across a chessboard last week, and beat seven of them; the eighth game was a draw. Judith Polgar, of Hungary, won in her section of the New York International Open Chess Tournament in the Penta Hotel, competing against other unrated players.

title: Discounted Dialogues; Overusages
description: In a talk to the American Society of Newspaper Editors the other day, Dr. Ruth Westheimer deplored the sexual ignorance of Americans. ''We can send a man to the moon, but we cannot prevent 1.5 million unwanted pregnancies each year,'' she said.

title: BALLOON LIFTS SPIRITS
description: WHEN Carol Hillman, a teacher at The Nursery School at the Westchester Ethical Humanist Society in White Plains, visited her farm in western Massachusetts on March 23, she walked into the apple orchard and found a balloon.

title: Mr. Gotti's Days in Court
description: The first witness has yet to be heard in the racketeering trial of John Gotti, the reputed head of New York's largest and most powerful organized-crime faction, but already the trial promises to be notable.

title: British Precision
description: John Russell mentions, as an example of English eccentricity, the heroic officer who led his men at Arnhem with an unfurled umbrella.

title: REBECCA C. MURPHY PLANS MARRIAGE TO JEFFREY FLYNN
description: Mr. and Mrs. Samuel W. Murphy Jr. of Madison, N.J., and Menauhant, Mass., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Rebecca Cort Murphy, to Jeffrey Young Flynn, a son of Mr. and Mrs. John D. Flynn of Baltimore and Edgartown, Mass. A September wedding is planned.

title: 'NEW WAVE' KOSHER
description: WAS 5744 A GOOD YEAR FOR GOLAN HEIGHTS sauvignon blanc? Any Beaujolais-Villages left? Champagne? Such questions, relevant at the Passover table, reflect growing interest in what a Manhattan merchant calls ''the new wave'' in kosher wines.

title: DYLAN THOMAS IN AMERICA - DOWN AND UP IN NEW YORK AND SAN FRANCISCO
description: THE Welsh poet Dylan Thomas culti-vated his public persona as intently as he did his art. Even as he turned out the work that made him famous - the poems ''Fern Hill,'' ''Do not go gentle into that good night'' and others; the tale ''A Child's Christmas in Wales''; the radio play ''Under Milk Wood'' - he lived a life of apparently deliberate emotional turmoil, financial insecurity and alcoholism that finally led to his death in 1953, at the age of 39, on his fourth quest for fame and fortune in the United States. He wrote the following previously unpublished letters to his wife, Caitlin, on his first trip to America, sponsored by John Malcolm Brinnin, the American poet who also acted as Thomas's agent for the trip. The text has been slightly abridged from ''Dylan Thomas: The Collected Letters,'' edited by Thomas's biographer Paul Ferris, to be published shortly by Macmillan. Saturday Feb 25 '50

title: Correction Officer, Off-Duty, Is Shot by Gunman in Harlem
description: On off-duty New York City Correction officer was shot in Harlem yesterday afternoon when he tried to come to the aid of a man who had been shot in the head, the police said.

title: THE ENVIRONMENT
description: A BILL establishing a program to protect endangered plants has begun to move through the Legislature.

title: CORRECTION
description: Because of a technical failure, part of a caption that accompanied an article about Provence was omitted from the Travel section last Sunday. The caption on page 29 should have read: Statue of Sabine, Hadrian's wife, in Vaison-la-Romaine.

title: DOROTHEA DICKERMAN PLANS A MAY WEDDING
description: Mr. and Mrs. John M. Dickerman of Potomac, Md., have announced the engagement of their daughter Dorothea Wilhelmina Dickerman to Richard K. A. Becker, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Richard H. Becker of Philadelphia. A May wedding is planned.

title: A ROLL OF FILM NEEDS LOTS OF TENDER, LOVING CARE
description: ALTHOUGH the analogy may seem unlikely, a roll of film has a life cycle surprisingly similar to the humble tomato. It is, in its own way, organic. It has a lifetime, during which it matures to ripeness and deteriorates. The important lesson here for someone handling film is that all elements that affect a tomato - heat, moisture and cold - affect the quality of sensitized photographic products.

title: STAGE: JOHN GUARE'S 'BOSOMS AND NEGLECT'
description: A BLIND, 83-year-old woman whose body is being destroyed by cancer; her middle-aged son who suffers from severe anxiety attacks, and a younger woman who has her own deep emotional troubles - these are the characters in John Guare's ''Bosoms and Neglect.'' The three always seem to be plotting ways to undermine and even to kill one another. The fact that the play is at least partly a comedy is the author's bitter commentary on the malign neglect that he sees within interpersonal relationships.

title: SARAH PEIRCE WEDS EDGAR T. MEAD 3D
description: St. John's Episcopal Church in West Hartford, Conn., was the setting yesterday for the wedding of Sarah Griffith Peirce, a daughter of Mrs. R. Thomas B. Peirce Jr. of Beach Haven and Marlton, N.J., and the late Mr. Peirce, to Edgar Thorn Mead 3d, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Edgar T. Mead of Etna, N.H. The Rev. Allan O'Neil performed the ceremony and was assisted by the Rev. Goldthwaite Sherrill, a cousin of the bride.

title: PLAYOFF STORY: WHY THE ENDING CHANGES
description: MANY pro basketball fans are already conceding a third straight Boston Celtics-Los Angeles Lakers championship series. This is certainly not unreasonable, given recent history and each team's regular-season record. However, they must still get to the final series. The Celtics will have a tough road because the teams in their conference are generally tougher. Of course, the Lakers have the burden of trying to repeat as champion, which no team has done for 17 years. The playoffs are so different from the regular season, and it is so difficult to repeat as champion. Believe me, I know.

title: Passing On Apartments to Relatives
description: THE intention of the state's proposed rent-stabilization code in dealing with the question of succession rights, says Manuel Mirabal, the rent administrator, is to provide a ''safety net'' against eviction for people who have lived in rent-regulated apartments for a substantial period of time.

title: THE AMERICAN DREAM MOVES TO CENTER STAGE
description: How fares this land, in the view of our leading dramatists?

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS
description: NIGHT KITES By E. M. Kerr. 216 pp. New York: Harper & Row. $11.50. (Ages 12 and up).

title: THE MEN IN THE SIZE 10 HELMETS
description: MAKERS OF MODERN STRATEGY From Machiavelli to the Nuclear Age. Edited by Peter Paret with Gordon A. Craig and Felix Gilbert. 941 pp. New Jersey: Princeton University Press. Cloth, $45. Paper, $12.95. WHO makes modern strategy? Have the theorists of war exercised much direct or indirect influence on the battlefield, or has their impact been overshadowed by that of the makers and wielders of weapons? Two hundred years ago, when resources were limited -both in numbers and kind - and goals no less so, and when the science of warfare was in its infancy, the answer to both these questions was fairly straightforward. Princes and generals were the big players in the war game; the most skillful practitioner won the laurels and intellectual application mattered little. Voltaire thought war a chancy business and regarded soldiering as one of a pair of bloody professions that had yet to come of age. ''The art of medicine, like that of war,'' he pronounced, ''is murderous and conjectural.''

title: BEST SELLERS: APRIL 13, 1986
description: Weeks This Last on Week Fiction Week List 1 THE BOURNE SUPREMACY, by Robert Ludlum. 1 6 (Random House, $19.95.) The hero of ''The Bourne Identity'' foils a plot to seize Hong Kong. 2 BREAK IN, by Dick Francis. (Putnam, $17.95.) 2 4 Mystery, melodrama and bitter family rivalry in the world of British steeplechase racing. 3 LAKE WOBEGON DAYS, by Garrison Keillor. 3 33 (Viking, $17.95.) Yarns about life in a small Minnesota town. 4 LIE DOWN WITH LIONS, by Ken Follett. 5 11 (Morrow, $18.95.) An Englishwoman caught between the C.I.A. and the K.G.B. in Afghanistan. 5 THE MAMMOTH HUNTERS, by Jean M. Auel. 21 (Crown, $19.95.) Ayla continues her adventures in the prehistoric world. 6 HOME FRONT, by Patti Davis with Maureen 6 3 Strange Foster. (Crown, $15.95.) A semi-autobiographical novel by the daughter of President and Mrs. Reagan. 7 JOANNA'S HUSBAND AND DAVID'S WIFE, by 8 4 Elizabeth Forsythe Hailey. (Delacorte, $17.95.) Two sides of a marriage revealed through diary entries. 8 SEASONS OF THE HEART, by Cynthia Freeman. 7 3 (Putnam, $17.95.) A businesswoman is tor n between devotion to her husband and her mentor. 9 THE HANDMAID'S TALE, by Margaret Atwood. 9 7 (Houghton Mifflin, $16.95.) In the America of the future men and women perform assigned services. 10 PRIVATE AFFAIRS, by Judith Michael. 10 7 (Poseidon, $17.95.) A couple's marriage is seriously strained when they strike it rich in journalism. 11 TEXAS, by James A. Michener. (Random House, 12 27 $21.95.) Four hundred fifty years of history in fictional form. 12 NERILKA'S STORY, by Anne McCaffrey. (Del 11 2 Rey/Ballantine, $12.95.) While fighting a plague on the planet Pern, Nerilka finds a true love. 13* CYCLOPS, by Clive Cussler. (Simon & 13 2 Schuster, $18.95.) The quest for a vanished ship involves Fidel Castro, the Kremlin, the White House and the moon. 14 STONE 588, by Gerald A. Browne. (Arbor 16 10 House, $17.95.) The pursuit of a stolen crystal with curative powers climaxes atop St. Patrick's Cathedral. 15 HIGH JINX, by William F. Buckley Jr. 1 (Doubleday, $16.95.) Blackford Oakes on the trail of the traitor who spoiled a plan to liberate Albania. 16* BLACK GENESIS, by L. Ron Hubbard. (Bridge 14 2 Publications, $18.95.) Continuing the science fiction epic begun in ''The Invaders Plan.'' Nonfiction 1 YOU'RE ONLY OLD ONCE! by Dr. Seuss. (Random 1 5 House, $9.95.) A checkup at the Golden Years Clinic in pictures and rhyme; the first Dr. Seuss book for adults. 2 BUS 9 TO PARADISE, by Leo Buscaglia. (Slack/ 2 9 Morrow, $16.95.) Another trip with the ebullient advocate of the virtues of love. 3 THE GREAT GETTY, by Robert Lenzner. (Crown, 3 6 $18.95.) The life and loves of J. Paul Getty, who was the richest man in the world. 4 IACOCCA: An Autobiography, by Lee Iacocca 4 76 with William Novak. (Bantam, $19.95.) The rise of an immigrants' son to top jobs at Ford and Chrysler. 5 YEAGER: An Autobiography, by Chuck Yeager 6 40 and Leo Janos. (Bantam, $17.95.) From West Virginia hillbilly to World War II fighter pilot to the first man to fly faster than sound. 6 WISEGUY, by Nicholas Pileggi. (Simon & 5 9 Schuster, $17.95.) The experiences of Henry Hill as a member of a Mafia family. 7 BLESSINGS IN DISGUISE, by Alec Guinness. 8 3 (Knopf, $17.95.) The autobiography of the distinguished English actor. 8 THE MAN WHO MISTOOK HIS WIFE FOR A HAT, by 9 2 Oliver Sacks. (Summit, $15.95.) The loss of the faculty of recognition and other strange neurological disabilities. 9 ADRIFT, by Steven Callahan. (Houghton 7 7 Mifflin, $15.95.) One man's survival for 76 days on an inflatable raft in the Atlantic. 10 GREED AND GLORY ON WALL STREET, by Ken 10 9 Auletta. (Random House, $19.95.) The fall of the investment bankers Lehman Brothers Kuhn Loeb. 11 A LIGHT IN THE ATTIC, by Shel Silverstein. 13 162 (Harper & Row, $13.50.) Light verse, with drawings by the author. 12* ARCTIC DREAMS, by Barry Lopez. (Scribners, 11 2 $22.95.) A rhapsodic report on human and life north of the Arctic Circle. 13 ON THE ROAD WITH CHARLES KURALT, by Charles 11 2 Kuralt. (Putnam, $16.95.) The television reporter tells of people he's encountered while journeying around America. 14 DANCING IN THE LIGHT, by Shirley MacLaine. 15 29 (Bantam, $17.95.) In her 51st year, the entertainer wins an Oscar, survives a stormy romance and has new visions of the past and future. 15 NO LAUGHING MATTER, by Joseph Heller and 4 Speed Vogel. (Putnam, $18.95.) The novelist's encounter with a nearly fatal disease narrated by Mr. Heller and his friend Mr. Vogel. Advice and Self-Help 1 FIT FOR LIFE, by Harvey Diamond and Marilyn 1 34 Diamond. (Warner, $17.50.) A diet for weight loss and physical fitness. 2 CALLANETICS, by Callan Pinckney with Sallie 2 20 Batson. (Morrow, $17.95.) Exercises to enable women to look ''10 years younger in 10 hours.'' 3 WOMEN WHO LOVE TOO MUCH, by Robin Norwood. 3 28 Tarcher/St. Martin's, $14.95.) Ways to avoid or end addictive, unhealthy relationships with men. 4 THE BE (HAPPY) ATTITUDES, by Robert 4 23 Schuller. (Word, $12.95.) Inspiration from a California clergyman. 5 THE RICE DIET REPORT, by Judy Moscovitz. 5 2 (Putnam, $16.95.) A diet developed more than 40 years ago at a clinic in North Carolina is explained by a successful user.

title: THE FERRARO FILE
description: When Geraldine A. Ferraro announced last December that she would not seek the Democratic Senate nomination in New York, she said the only factor deterring her was a pending investigation by the Justice Department into the financing of one of her past campaigns for the House of Representatives and some of her financial disclosure statements as a member. Six weeks later, Justice officials made it known that the inquiry was all but completed and that no indictment of the 1984 Vice-Presidential candidate would result.

title: INCONTINENCE PROJECT TESTED
description: VERONICA TUTKO did not know that her embarrassing problem had a name. She just knew that she urinated at least once an hour during the day and up to five times at night.

title: DARA FRIEDMAN TO WED
description: The engagement of Dara Beth Friedman to Philip Marks Pinkert has been announced by the future bride's mother, Mrs. Eugene H. Friedman of New York. A June wedding is planned. Mr. Pinkert is a son of Mrs. Isadore L. Pinkert of Cos Cob, Conn., and the late Dr. Pinkert. Miss Friedman is a public health nurse in Greenwich, Conn. Mr. Pinkert is a financial consultant for the Stuart-James Company, investment bankers in Darien, Conn.

title: CARDS WIN ON TUDOR SHUTOUT
description: John Tudor scattered five hits over six and one-third innings for his 18th straight victory at home and also singled and drove home two runs tonight, helping the St. Louis Cardinals remain the only unbeaten team in the major leagues with a 6-3 victory over the Montreal Expos.

title: LONG ISLAND GUIDE
description: FAMLI AFFAIR There may be merit to the saying ''If you've got it, flaunt it,'' but more is generally required of art collections than merely displaying treasures; they usually have to be put into some kind of context. And in ''Connections '86,'' its newest exhibition opening today, the Fine Arts Museum of Long Island has taken an interesting approach by showing its growing collection in juxtaposition with other exhibitions.

title: NEW DIRECTIONS IN BIOLOGY
description: Biology has entered a golden age. Students today live in a world with test-tube babies, synthetic vaccines, miracle crops and cloned mice. On the horizon are such developments as supercows and magic-bullet cancer cures.

title: PALERMO
description: The ancient Greeks complained that they could not hunt in Sicily in the springtime because their hounds were bewildered by the scent of the wildflowers. There's not much game left nowadays, but the flowers, still extravagant in their color and profusion, continue to offer a compelling reason for visiting the island during the coming weeks. Whether one strikes out to admire the wildflowers carpeting the slopes below Erice and the excavations at Selinunte, or settles for the brilliant displays in the flower stalls and public gardens of Palermo, spring with its mild weather and warm sun adds an extra coat of color to the multifaceted charm of Sicily and its capital city, where the museums and monuments span almost three milleniums. A Past Preserved Although Palermo itself was Phoenician rather than Greek, the city boasts an important collection of Greek art from excavations throughout western Sicily, on view at the National Archeological Museum (Piazza Olivella 4; open every morning, Tuesday and Friday afternoons; admission $1.25), and most of the important sites are within a few hours' drive. From April through September Suntours Holidays (Via Enrico Amari 34; telephone 587144) organizes daylong bus trips to Segesta and Selinunte (Monday), to Agrigento (Wednesday) and to Erice and the Phoenician site at Motya (Thursday); about $30, including lunch.

title: CHILDREN'S AUDIO: FROM BIG BIRD TO MERYL STREEP
description: With so much audio-visual entertainment available on every front and in every medium, what recordings do you get for children nowadays? The gift-giving aunt, conscientious parent or doting grandparent might start by listening to Bruno Bettelheim, the psychologist and child-rearing expert, reading the chapter on Hansel and Gretel from his book about fairy tales, ''The Uses of Enchantment'' (Spoken Arts cassette SAC 1162).

title: TOWN FINDS HOUSE BUYERS ARE EAGER TO TAKE A CHANCE
description: DAYNA AHERN of Manchester is hoping that Thursday will be her lucky day.

title: LESSONS FROM A NURSING HOME
description: It was refreshing to read Mr. Gentile's response to nursing home care for his father. As director of social services in a skilled nursing home and health-related facility, I know only too well how much effort the staff expends to care for and maintain the dignity of the patients.

title: Becker Gains Final; Jarryd Upsets Wilander
description: Boris Becker of West Germany advanced to the final of the World Championship Tennis tournament with a 7-6, 7-6, 4-6, 7-6 victory today over Sweden's Stefan Edberg.

title: ENDANGERED CATALOGUES
description: ALTHOUGH Cliff Sjogren is an admissions director, not a literary critic, he has decided that college catalogues are ''probably the Western world's most boring piece of literature.'' As a result, the University of Michigan, where he works, has stopped send-ing them out.

title: PRIVATE L.I. BLOOD BANK OPENS
description: A PHYSICIAN has opened Long Island's first private for-profit blood bank where clients can freeze their own supply for up to three years for use in surgery.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: KITTY COLLINS. By Philip Gould. (Algonquin, $15.95.) Philip Gould's first novel, chronicling the rise of a talented Middle Western girl of undistinguished origins, has at least one notable literary predecessor - but a ''Sister Carrie'' it isn't.

title: In Quotes
description: ''We have seen some success in cooperation as far as interest rates are concerned. We hope that's going to continue.''

title: WORKING ABROAD IN TERROR'S SHADOW
description: FOR more than 35 years, Michael H. Dann, a former production head at NBC and CBS and now a consultant for ABC and I.B.M., traveled the world with little fear and a great deal of enjoyment.

title: PROSPECTS
description: JAPAN'S FOREIGN FUNDINGS The talks between President Reagan and Japanese Prime Minister Yasuhiro Nakasone, scheduled for today at Camp David, will inevitably focus on Japan's trade surplus with the United States - and on the flip side of that surplus, Japan's sizable investments in this country.

title: AN EAST END QUILT STARS IN MANHATTAN
description: AFTER 10 years of meeting weekly to quilt for themselves and for charity - one quilt brought in more than $5,000 in a raffle - the 10 members of the Friday Quilters have gone professional.

title: IN NEW PRESTON, A COZY SPOT FOR VIEWING ART
description: AT the Almquist Gallery in the western Connecticut village of New Preston, ''the door is open and the coffee's always on,'' says its owner, Jennifer Almquist.

title: Israelis Struggle To Avert a Crisis
description: The coalition Government of Israel began to crack last week, but efforts to mend it were expected to be on the table at a Cabinet meeting today. The trouble began when Shimon Peres, the Labor Prime Minister, said he had been insulted by the Likud Finance Minister, Yitzhak Modai, and would fire him.

title: GRANT ASSISTS IN SCHOOLING AFTER MOVES
description: For thousands of teen-agers who move back and forth each year between high schools in New York and Puerto Rico, a new ''Education Passport'' - a Passaporte Educativo - is helping to eliminate confusion and dislocation.

title: Supreme Court Rejects Florida Execution Stay
description: The Supreme Court of the United States has refused to block the execution Tuesday of Daniel Morris Thomas, who was convicted of murder and rape, in Florida.

title: ROME
description: Despite the mounting concern over Middle East-inspired violence, Italy is a somewhat calmer place now than it was in the late 1970's, when restaurateurs would bar their doors and peer out peepholes at would-be customers to make sure they were not terrorists. ''We have always maintained a basic security system,'' said the general manager of a large American pharmaceutical company. ''For instance, for the last few years we have used bulletproof glass in all our windows and attack dogs guard our factories.''

title: BROWN SHIRTS AND RED FACES
description: SELLING HITLER By Robert Harris. Illustrated. 402 pp. New York: Pantheon Books. $18.95.

title:
INVESTING;
FOLLOWING THE TAKEOVER TRAIL
description: Time was when the stocks of companies making acquisitions fell in price and only the targets rose. Now occasionally both go up.

title: DANCE: JHUNG TROUPE IN TUDOR 'SUNFLOWERS'
description: FINIS Jhung's Chamber Ballet USA, which is performing through this afternoon at Symphony Space (95th Street and Broadway), has done us the favor of restaging one of Antony Tudor's rarely seen ballets.

title: A LIABILITY-INSURANCE CRISIS, CONTINUED
description: WHEN Governor Cuomo was presented last week with the 203-page report of his commission investigating the state's liability-insurance crisis, he noted wryly, ''Not everyone will agree with all of the conclusions.''

title: WESTCHESTER GUIDE
description: 'MUSIC MAN' RETURNS Those 76 trombones are back for a single performance of Meredith Willson's ''Music Man,'' at 8 P.M. Saturday at Peekskill's Paramount Center for the Arts.

title: NEW JERSEY JOURNAL
description: WITH the return of balmy spring days, runners, joggers and strollers are outdoors in force once again. They can add an extra sense of purpose to their efforts next Sunday, when the 10-mile Spaulding for Children Stride-A-Thon will be held in Tamaques Park, Westfield, from 10 A.M. to 4 P.M. .

title: LIBERIA OPPOSITION CALLS ON DOE TO STEP DOWN
description: Liberia's opposition political parties, rejecting appeals for national reconciliation, called this week for Gen. Samuel K. Doe to step down as President of the West African country.

title: THE LESSONS OF EICHMANN ARE HARD TO APPLY
description: IT has been a quarter century since a balding, bespectacled man stood in a glass box to face charges that he had played a leading role in the crime of the century. In the years since the prosecution of Lieut. Col. Adolf Eichmann, chief of the Jewish section of the Gestapo and the man responsible for Nazi concentration camps that administered the ''Final Solution,'' it has been not so much his conviction, or even his execution, but rather his capture in Argentina and trial in Israel that continue to be debated by scholars and international lawyers. Indeed, when each week brings new reports of human rights violations, bombings and hijackings, the issues raised by the Eichmann case seem as fresh as today's headlines. What can one nation do to change the internal policies of another? Can a terrorist be seized, like Eichmann, and transported for trial? Why does international law seem so ineffective? Last weekend, at a forum organized by the Jewish Museum in New York, these issues were discussed by a panel that included Louis Henkin, University Professor at Columbia University; Marvin E. Frankel, a former Federal judge and chairman of the Lawyers Committee for Human Rights; Abraham D. Sofaer, another former judge who is legal adviser to the State Department, and Telford Taylor, former chief prosecutor at the Nuremberg trials and a professor at Benjamin Cardozo Law School. Excerpts follow.

title: LAURA N. SAMMIS TO BECOME BRIDE
description: The engagement of Laura Nason Sammis to Thomas McCallum Pearce Jr. has been announced by the future bride's parents, William N. Sammis of Stamford, Conn., and Pauline Anderson Sammis of Darien, Conn. A September wedding is planned.

title: UNIONS SEEK TO GROW WITH NEW TECHNOLOGIES
description: The American workplace is being changed rapidly and profoundly by computer technologies and other forces, but often these developments remain undetected and thus cannot be shaped by union or government policy.

title: BURGER DISCUSSES USE OF TV
description: Broadcasting Supreme Court proceedings in their entirety ''might open things up,'' according to Chief Justice Warren E. Burger.

title: A VALLEY TOUR AMID WYETHS AND DU PONTS
description: In St. Peters Village on the northern rim of the Brandywine Valley, a wild trout stream called French Creek tumbles down over huge boulders of black granite, rushing toward the meadows, swales, pastures and wooded hills not far below. Near those French Creek falls, in 1778, a Continental lieutenant named Arthur Carrington was trapped by redcoats as he foraged for food for George Washington's army. He hid in a cave, but gunfire dislodged boulders that sealed him in. His skeleton was found a century later by quarrymen who opened the cave. They also found a letter inside a bottle. Addressed to his sweetheart in Virginia, who died in 1780 of a broken heart, it told of his own long, slow death. Or so the legend says. Today, it's a peaceful spot. A Victorian inn, called the Inn at St. Peters, stands by the falls, and a few feet away fishermen cast their lines. In the inn's dining room, under a canopy of evergreens and hardwoods, you can eat fresh poached salmon or fettucini Alfredo, and wonder at the region's myths, legends and very real present-day allure.

title: THE WIMP WHO KNEW TOO MUCH
description: THE LIFTED VEIL By George Eliot. 91 pp. New York: Penguin Books/ Virago Press. Paper, $5.95.

title: TAPPING INTO AMERICA'S TURBULENT PAST
description: Manifest Destiny, expansion to the Pacific and even beyond to China, mapping the new continent, buffalo stampedes, avalanches and, of course, a love affair, brought to living-color life by Richard Chamberlain, prince of mini-series (''Shogun,'' ''The Thorn Birds,'' ''Wallenberg: A Hero's Story''), and Alice Krige, an exceptionally appealing leading lady (''Chariots of Fire,'' ''Ellis Island,'' also ''Wallenberg''). This is the epical stuff of CBS's ''Dream West,'' based on the exploits of John Charles Fremont, American adventurer, and his wife Jessie, daughter of the influential Senator Thomas Hart Benton. For seven hours this week - beginning tonight at 9 and continuing Monday at 9 and Tuesday at 8 - ''Dream West'' mixes fact and fiction, history and literary license, with plenty of action and lots of romance in a saga that, starting in 1839, spans nearly five decades of United States history.

title: Music
description: Olivier Messiaen is one of the great composers of this century, yet it took him until his mid-70's to complete his first opera. That score, ''St. Francoise d'Assise,'' received its first performances at the Paris Opera in late 1983 and amounted to a grandiose, five-hour summation of his life's work.

title: A Debate Over U.S. 'Set-Asides'
description: For more than a decade, the Government has reserved a few slices of the immense Federal pie for businesses owned by blacks, Hispanic people and other minorities, all part of a ''set-aside'' program that has been endorsed by Congress and a succession of recent Presidents, including Ronald Reagan. Last week a debate flared over the merits of set-asides after the staff of the United States Commission on Civil Rights recommended a one-year suspension of the program.

title: PAUL A. BILSKY MARRIES TERRY LEE IN VERMONT
description: Terry C. Lee, a daughter of the late Mr. and Mrs. Patrick J. Lee, was married yesterday to Paul A. Bilsky, a son of Mr. and Mrs. George Bilsky of Teaneck, N.J., and East Hampton, L.I. Justice of the Peace Barbara DeWolf of Bondeville, Vt., performed the ceremony at the Arlington (Vt.) Inn.

title: TOO SMART TO BE CORRECT
description: LIONEL TRILLING AND THE FATE OF CULTURAL CRITICISM By Mark Krupnick. Illustrated. 207 pp. Evanston, Ill.: Northwestern University Press. Cloth, $21.95. Paper, $10.95. BY the time Lionel Trilling died in 1975 he no longer seemed the central figure in American intellectual life he had been in earlier decades.

title: Anti-Zionist Lecturer Supported on Tenure
description: The Chancellor of the State University of New York has been urged to overturn a decision denying tenure to a lecturer whose course equated Zionism with racism, according to a member of the committee that made the recommendation to the Chancellor.

title: I.R.S. NETTING LOAN DEFAULTERS
description: INCOME TAX filing time may bring frowns to taxpayers, but it's causing smiles this year at the Department of Education. That's because the Internal Revenue Service has begun withholding tax refunds from students and former students who have defaulted on federally guaranteed student loans. ''It's a collector's dream,'' glowed Richard Hastings, who runs the department's Debt Collection and Management Assistance Service. ''It's working beautifully.''

title: CHARLES F. DARLINGTON JR., 81, ENVOY AND ECONOMIST, DIES
description: Charles F. Darlington Jr., one of a handful of Americans who worked for the League of Nations and the first resident United States Ambassador to Gabon, died Friday at New York Hospital-Cornell Medical Center. He was 81 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: OUT OF THE BAG AND ON WITH THE NEW
description: THERE are people in this world who actually like to fiddle around with figures and for whom preparing an income tax return is, if not enjoyable, no big deal. My husband and I are not among them, and I suspect that most people are like us and find the process tedious, boring and unpleasant.

title: MOSCOW MUST START COMPLYING WITH THE 1975 HELSINKI AGREEMENT
description: This statement is to be delivered tomorrow in Berne, Switzerland, at the Parallel Helsinki Review Conference, a meeting of nongovernmental representatives designed to coincide with the official Helsinki review conference. The meeting was organized by the Andrei Sakharov Institute and by Resistance International, human rights organizations.

title: THE ROYAL RUBY: WILL IT BE A TREND?
description: DIAMONDS may be forever, but rubies and sapphires are for sometimes. One of those times is now, many jewelers think. When Prince Andrew of Britain presented a pigeon blood ruby and diamond ring to Sarah Ferguson to seal their engagement, jewelers readied themselves for a surge of interest in rubies. After all, they had noted increased interest in sapphires when Prince Charles gave a sapphire and diamond engagement ring to Lady Diana Spencer in 1981.

title: U.S. SENDS ENVOY TO ELICIT SUPPORT ON LIBYA RESPONSE
description: President Reagan has sent Vernon A. Walters, the chief American delegate to the United Nations, to European capitals to seek support for possible American action against Libya and to discuss Libyan involvement in terrorism, Administration officials said today.

title: Senate Votes To Put the Budget Ahead of Taxes
description: A 72-to-24 vote taking issue with the White House in a Senate controlled by the President's party is a signal of solid legislative determination. Last week, just such a vote to put budget compromise ahead of tax revision was also a sign of rising frustration and, some senators who favor rewriting the tax law charged, general disinclination to tackle what they call reform.

title: 272 TO SHARE $5.9 MILLION IN GUGGENHEIM AWARDS
description: The John Simon Guggenheim Memorial Foundation has announced fellowship awards totaling $5,899,000 to 272 artists, scholars and scientists.

title: CELEBRATING THE HAMPTONS
description: EVEN the threat of snow flurries could not dispel the feeling of summer. Men in blazers and white boaters were stationed along a grass carpet in front of Lord & Taylor, where a white picket fence had been erected. Up on the store's eighth floor, women in long white dresses holding baskets of daisies welcomed guests to ''Focus America: The Hamptons.''

title: 5,000 FILIPINOS ASK FOR MARCOS BACK
description: Some 5,000 demonstrators urging the return of Ferdinand E. Marcos blocked a major highway here tonight as they waved placards and danced to the beat of drums and chanted the former President's campaign slogans.

title: Suburban Serenity
description: DURING THE 1920'S AND 30'S, as suburban communities proliferated in this country, architects drew on styles from the past that they felt would give these newly emerging neighborhoods a sense of continuity. A host of revival styles resulted.

title: CAREFUL SHOPPER
description: A Stand of Umbrellas At Elmsford Outlet Zip Jack Umbrella continued its migration northward from the Bronx and then Yonkers by resettling its factory and showroom in Elmsford in January. The Saturday-only hours of 10 A.M. to 4 P.M. begin this week for the factory outlet, during a time that the rest of the cutting and assembling of wood frames and the custom silkscreening and sewing of the panels are not under way. The sun umbrellas are made from American materials, whether set on wood, fiberglass or metal frames, and most of the rain umbrellas are imported.

title: Discounted Dialogues; Growing Amounts
description: In the 1960's, the musical group The Association sang of a word (''Cherish'') that ''has the right amount of letters.'' The misuse of the word amount was obvious, but the song was pretty and besides, songwriters have a certain poetic license.

title: IS THERE TOO LITTLE ORDER IN THE TRANSPLANT BUSINESS?
description: A traffic-accident victim is pronounced dead in a hospital emergency room and a nurse approaches the grieving family. Papers are signed and life-support machinery is kept going. Within 24 hours a half-dozen people across the country have one of the victim's organs inside their body.

title: THE WORLD OF AUCTIONS
description: DESPITE ALL THE TALK about ''the international art market,'' national barriers remain as strong as ever. Neither in the way they are conducted nor in content are auctions alike from one country to another. Depending on the city where they are held, they are regulated by different sets of rules, are attended by different kinds of people, and offer markedly different opportunities. This is apparent in the capitals of the auction world, Paris, London, New York and, to some extent, Monte Carlo.

title: ROOKIES GETTING PLENTY OF ACTION AT SEASON'S START
description: WHAT do three first basemen, four second basemen, four left fielders, two center fielders, one right fielder, one catcher, one designated hitter and one pitcher have in common? They are rookies who started in their teams' opening games. Since those first games of the season, two first baseman, one second baseman, one left fielder, one center fielder and six pitchers also have started at least one time, giving major league teams 28 rookies in starting lineups.

title: PANEL IS SEEKING NEW HEAD FOR TAXI AGENCY
description: The Mayor's Committee on Appointments has not yet settled into its office space or received its stationery. But since it was created last month, it has interviewed more than 20 candidates for the chairmanship of the Taxi and Limousine Commission.

title: Two Views of President Botha
