description: President Reagan has jumped to the defense of a fellow president: ''It's just like me, dealing with the Hill up here,'' he said in his news conference last week. ''Sometimes he can't get all that he seeks . . . I can tell you that he agrees with us and finds the past system repugnant and is trying to get changes as quickly as possible.'' To describe all this understanding for South Africa's President P. W. Botha as wishful is too kind. It verges on insult to those in South Africa whom Mr. Botha has misled - including his own Foreign Minister and the least militant of black leaders, Chief Gatsha Buthelezi.

title: ELEVATORS AS TRAFFIC COPS
description: IN the late 1970's, elevators got brains - microprocessors that began to phase out the electro-mechanical systems found in most elevators servicing buildings higher than six floors.

title:
ANTIQUES;
SPECIAL ITEMS TO BEAUTIFY A GARDEN
description: THIS year's Southport-Westport Antiques Show will be at the Fairfield County Hunt Club in Westport Friday through Sunday and will raise funds for various charities, channeled through the Near and Far Aid Association.

title: Navy Reinstates Cadet In Cocaine Case
description: A midshipman at the United States Naval Academy in Annapolis who was suspended for allegedly using cocaine has been reinstated and will be allowed to complete his studies, the Navy says.

title:
GARDENING;
TIMELY CARE BETWEEN SPRING'S SHOWERS
description: APRIL showers may, indeed, bring May flowers, but if the flowers are to last the season, the gardener must get into the act.

title: THE SCOURGE OF ADULT ILLITERACY
description: The wind made it bitingly cold on Wednesday night late in February, but in the second-floor cafeteria of the J.C. Penney Company's corporate headquarters in Manhattan, some 60 people, men and women ranging in age from their early 20's to their late 50's, have braved the elements to listen to tutors and students from Literacy Volunteers of New York City tell them that no matter how old they may be, it is never too late to learn to read and write.

title: Postings; The Most for a Slope
description: At first, Anthony J. LaSala thought his steeply sloping site overlooking the Hudson in North Yonkers would be the perfect place to build 40 town-house condominiums.

title: PEOPLE MOVING BACK TO CITIES, U.S. STUDY SAYS
description: Rural areas, which for most of the past decade have drawn residents from bigger cities and their environs, now appear to be losing ground once again.

title: HOLDUP TIE SOUGHT IN MIAMI SLAYINGS
description: Two men who killed two agents of the Federal Bureau of Investigation and wounded five others before dying themselves in a furious exchange of gunfire Friday were described by law-enforcement officials today as ruthless criminals living behind a mask of suburban respectability.

title: NEW START FOR PHIL NIEKRO HELPS EASE THE BITTERNESS
description: Phil Niekro dipped into his banana-laced Special K and chewed slowly this morning. Not just another gray-haired man having breakfast in a hotel coffee shop. The anger - perhaps touched with sadness - showed in his eyes.

title: LISTENERS ARE CAPTIVES OF MUSICAL HISTORY
description: The annual meeting of the Association for the Advancement of Anonymous Art will now come to order. The first order of business is your secretary's report on this season's concerts, many of which featured ''blind'' performances by musicians, both famous and unknown, seated behind screens. As specified in our bylaws, no work was identified beforehand either by composer or title and no program notes were provided. Listeners were left entirely on their own, without the crutches of appreciation provided at most concerts. Understandably, many of the randomly selected auditors at this season's concerts found the uncertainty unbearable and left in anger or agitation. Others stayed to the end but went away in apparent confusion, refusing to fill out the Association's brief questionnaire about the quality of the music and the proficiency of the players. Only a few eccentrics, stimulated by the idea of listening to music in a historical vacuum, dared to offer opinions. If there is no objection, their thoughts will be entered into the minutes. . . .

title: NEW CASSETTES: FROM WAR STORIES TO FAIRY TALES
description: Alice in Wonderland A Lou Bunin production, featuring Carol Marsh, Pamela Brown and Felix Aylmer; 1950 Monterey Home Video 80 minutes. $39.95 Curious and curiouser.

title: PEACE EFFORTS ON RISE
description: PEACE and disarmament groups in the state report increasing support on their behalf as a result of United States intervention in Central America and the recent confrontation with Libya.

title: BAD HANDOFF IS PIVOTAL IN THE DOGWOOD RELAYS
description: Allen Franklin of Tennessee took advantage of a fumbled handoff between Georgia's Stanley Blalock and Norman Edwards on the last leg of the men's 400-meter relay and sprinted to victory today in the 20th annual Dogwood Relays at Tom Black Track.

title: PRESERVING RURAL ALSACE
description: Neither history nor the gods have been particularly kind to Alsace. An easy prey during wars, revolutions and occupations, it has been exchanged piecemeal by France and Germany five times since the 17th century. Since World War II, the province, now French, has known rapid and largely unplanned development. Today, factories, billboards and low-cost housing projects scar parts of its landscape, especially along the major traffic routes. There are still some lovely little towns and pretty vineyards but many buildings that bespeak its rich cultural heritage have been abandoned or razed to make way for what politicians like to call progress.

title:
IF YOU'RE THINKING OF LIVING IN;
NEW DORP
description: DESPITE its name, New Dorp is one of Staten Island's oldest neighborhoods, settled ''in 1690 or so,'' according to the Staten Island Historical Society. That is about 30 years after nearby Old Town was established. It is also one of its most stable neighborhoods.

title: POINTS ARE UNDERLINED IN RESTRAINT CASE
description: In response to my essay stating that my mother was being tied up against her will in a nursing facility, [ ''My Mother Would Be Treated Better if She Were a Dog,'' Opinion Page, Feb. 16 ] Nathan Lipsen of the State Department of Health writes that ''patients have the right to refuse medical treatment after being fully informed as to the potential medical consequences'' and ''in no case may a facility discharge a patient because of his or her refusal of treatment.'' [ Letter to the Westchester Editor, March 23. ] Would it were so. The patients' Bill of Rights issued by his department specifically states that a patient ''is free from . . . physical restraints except those restraints authorized by a physician . . . or when necessary to protect the patient from injury to himself.'' The nursing facility's contract states that ''the facility retains its right to discharge residents who, as a result of refusing [ treatment), render them beyond the facility's capabilities to provide appropriate care.'' Mr. Lipsen himself weakens his own case, noting first that a facility ''may request a waiver of liability'' but adding, a paragraph later, that ''unresolved legal issues (are) associated with this question'' and he understands ''a facility's concern for potential liability.''

title: KEEPING THE 1830'S ALIVE
description: When the historians and collectors at Old Sturbridge Village finished arranging the meetinghouse, the general store, the tavern and other 18th- and 19th-century buildings around the village green, they thought they had created a scene that looked just like a typical New England town of a century and a half ago. But then the designers of the 200-acre living history museum considered the green itself and realized they had erred. The grass was too even.

title:
COLLEGE SPORTS '86: TENNIS;
A 17-YEAR-OLD HAS THE POWER NEEDED TO REACH THE TOP
description: IT is a windy spring day and the women tennis players are struggling with ''ughs'' and ''oophs'' to keep the balls in play.

title: YOU ARE WHERE YOU EAT
description: WHILE their colleagues worry about the cosmos, clusters of students at Harvard College have turned their attention to less-exalted causes, such as the preservation of Boston accents, the glories of junk food and the dignity of Kansas.

title: YUGOSLAVIA SINCE TITO
description: ON MAY 9, 1985, BENEATH A SLATY SKY, LONG COLUMNS OF goose-stepping soldiers, sailors and marines marched through the center of Belgrade, the capital city of Yugoslavia. Jet fighters screeched overhead. Tanks churned at the pavement. Field artillery and armored cars roared past stands filled with the leaders of the Yugoslav republics, the members of the country's one-party Government, and the now paunchy, bespectacled veterans of the partisan war against the Nazis.

title: PLAN TO RESTRICT SMOKING IN NEW YORK CITY FACES CONSIDERABLE OPPOSITION
description: Mayor Koch's sweeping proposal to restrict smoking in private office buildings and public facilities in New York City is in trouble. The plan is opposed not only by businesses, which fear it would cost them money, but also in the City Council, which would have to enact it.

title: SQUEEZING OPEC - AND THE U.S.
description: IT was 8 A.M. on a mid-March day, and Sheik Ahmed Zaki Yamani bounded past a knot of sleepy reporters into the Hotel Inter-Continental, on a rise above Lake Geneva. For a full week Saudi Arabia's oil minister had been under pressure from Iran, Libya and other members of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries, who blamed stepped up Saudi oil production for the steep drop in crude oil prices. Sheik Yamani had had enough, and he was here for a one-on-one meeting with Gholam Reza Aghazadeh, his Iranian counterpart and severest critic, to see if things could be amicably worked out.

title: CTW's Status
description: To the Editor:

title: LIVERPOOL AND EVERTON WIN IN ENGLISH SOCCER
description: Liverpool defeated Coventry City, 5-0, and Everton won by 1-0 at Arsenal today as the First Division rivals continued their battle in the English League soccer title race.

title: Student Was Elected To Local School Board
description: The March 16 article on students' roles on school boards offered insights about how students may make contributions to local school districts.

title: JANICE A. COLEMAN WED TO DR. JEFFREY GRAHAM
description: Janice A. Coleman, a lawyer, and Dr. Jeffrey Graham, a physician, both in Anchorage, were married yesterday at St. Peter of Alcantara Roman Catholic Church in Port Washington, L.I. Msgr. Walter Simmons performed the ceremony.

title: SELLING OUT: HOW AN EX-C.I.A. AGENT MADE MILLIONS WORKING FOR QADDAFI
description: LIKE MOST PEOPLE, I first read about Edwin P. Wilson in the newspapers in 1981. He was said to be a former operative for the Central Intelligence Agency who had placed himself in the service of the Libyan dictator and godfather of international terrorism, Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi.

title: A SENSE OF PLACE
description: TODAY'S RESIDENTIAL ARCHITECTURE, THOUGH UNMISTAKABLY CONTEMPORARY, POSSESSES AN AIR OF COMFORT and familiarity. Whether it is a new shingle-style house with a commodious porch perched on a slope of land overlooking the sea or the addition of a glass solarium tucked into the setbacks of a 1920's Park Avenue apartment building, architects these days talk of their designs as being ''good neighbors'' to the buildings around them. By using traditional elements, not in a copybook fashion, but as a point from which to create original work, an increasing number of new houses and apartments are being produced to reflect a definite sense of their place.

title: WHALERS SWEEP WITH 9-4 VICTORY
description: John Anderson scored two goals and assisted on four others while Kevin Dineen scored twice and set up three others tonight to spark the Hartford Whalers to a 9-4 victory over the Quebec Nordiques and a 3-0 sweep of their Adams Division semifinal playoff series.

title: CUSTOMERS AS VICTIMS
description: THE PRICE OF A LIFE One Woman's Death From Toxic Shock. By Tom Riley. 293 pp. Bethesda, Md.: Adler & Adler. 5.95.

title: HONORING THE LIFE AND ARTISTRY OF A GIFTED YOUNG PIANIST
description: The University of Maryland International Piano Festival has announced the first William Kapell Competition, which will be held at the University of Maryland in College Park and at the Kennedy Center Concert Hall in Washington, D.C., from July 10 through 19.

title: BE WARY OF SEED CATALOGUES
description: THE catalogues from the seed companies are in, replete with sumptuous color pictures of the latest hybrids, the finest of shrubs. Everything shown is nearly foolproof, even for the beginner.

title: Q and A
description: Suburban Rent Controls Question: I am considering buying a six-unit apartment building in Port Washington in Nassau County. I do not know when the building was built, but would like to know its status in regards to rent-stabilization or rent-control laws . . . C. B., Port Washington, L.I. Answer: According to Thomas R. Viola, spokesman for the state's Division of Housing and Community Renewal, in Nassau, Rockland and Westchester Counties, each municipality has the option of adopting the rent-stabilization or rent-control codes as they are written in the Emergency Tenant Protection Act of 1974. According to Mr. Viola, Port Washington is not among the Nassau County towns or villages that have so far adopted the rent-regulation measures. Taking a Roommate Question: I live in a rent-stabilized apartment and I am considering taking a roommate. Is there a rule I must follow in order to calculate the monthly rent or am I allowed to charge whatever I feel is reasonable, taking into account the use of my furniture, appliances, utilities, etc. Also, must the landlord be advised of my intentions? . . . R. C., Manhattan Answer: The regulations that pertain to rent-stabilized units do not restrict the Michael Bartalos amount of rent a tenant occupying such a unit can charge a roommate. However, the tenant is required to notify the landlord within 30 days if another person moves in. Lot-Line Windows Question: I live in a nine-story building that has lot-line windows on the west side beginning at the sixth floor in front and the fourth floor in the rear.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: PEOPLE OF CHANCE: Gambling in American Society from Jamestown to Las Vegas. By John M. Findlay. (Oxford University, $19.95.) John M. Findlay, who teaches history at Pennsylvania State University, sees the riverboat gambler and the Old West cardsharp as pioneers of the American frontier.

title: TENSIONS IN HAITI REPORTED ON RISE UNDER NEW CHIEFS
description: Two months after the ouster of the Duvalier regime, Haiti is drifting without direction or leadership, according to diplomats, foreign experts and local business executives.

title: Nicaragua Rejects Any Limit On Strength of Armed Forces
description: President Daniel Ortega Saavedra said today that Nicaragua would not accept any limitation on its military strength as long as the United States continued to support anti-Government rebels.

title: WILLIAM C. BLUM WEDS MISS SCHARON IN CINCINNATI
description: Tracy Ann Scharon, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Francis Joseph Scharon of Oklahoma City, was married yesterday to William Charles Blum, a son of Mr. and Mrs. William Lee Blum of Cincinnati. Msgr. Robert A. Amann performed the Roman Catholic ceremony at the chapel of the Summit Country Day School in Cincinnati.

title:
GARDENING;
TIMELY CARE BETWEEN SPRING'S SHOWERS
description: APRIL showers may, indeed, bring May flowers, but if the flowers are to last the season, the gardener must get into the act.

title: POLICE QUIZ: WHO KNEW WHAT AND WHEN?
description: THE scene was remarkable. Behind microphones and under television lights, Suffolk County's top law-enforcement officials underwent tough questioning in Hauppauge last week by members of the County Legislature's Public Safety Committee.

title:
WORKING ABROAD IN TERROR'S SHADOW;
MADRID
description: To many Americans working here, the latest alert about terrorist attacks against United States targets is just one more step in a growing concern for security. ''When something like this happens you just emphasize the tightness of the system,'' said one executive. ''There's no dramatic change, we're just tightening the nuts and bolts.''

title: AND NOW THE PULITZERS GO TO WAR
description: SEATED in his office last week, Joseph Pulitzer 3d, chairman of the Pulitzer Publishing Company, said, ''I was not trained by my father to liquidate this company.'' He is an intense, dapper man who wears a bracelet of fine gold links, and his gravelly voice carries the accents of the patrician East rather than the Middle West. At his right, Michael Pulitzer, his younger half-brother and the vice chairman, soberly nodded in assent.

title: MISS MCCARTHY TO WED REINSURANCE EXECUTIVE
description: Mr. and Mrs. Vincent T. McCarthy of Valley Cottage, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter Diane Wilmot McCarthy to John William Rutledge Jr., the son of Mr. and Mrs. Rutledge of New Canaan, Conn. The wedding is planned for next month.

title: TAMING THE LATEST INSURANCE 'CRISIS'
description: THE latest liability insurance ''crisis,'' like its predecessors, is widely attributed to overly generous juries and court decisions expanding manufacturers' liability. As in the preceding ''crisis,'' in 1975, little is said about the fundamental cause - the sharp ups and downs of the insurance industry's profit cycle.

title: MISS PURCELL HAS WEDDING
description: Wendy Lynn Purcell, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John R. Purcell of Darien, Conn., and Vero Beach, Fla., was married yesterday to Dennis Francis Mahoney, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Francis D. Mahoney of Chelmsford, Mass. The Rev. Walter Taylor performed the ceremony at St. Luke's Episcopal Church in Darien.

title: Bomb Threat Routs 10,000
description: The authorities evacuated as many as 10,000 people from the Pueblo Reservoir recreation area today after an anonymous caller, declaring ''Qaddafi lives,'' said three bombs had been planted in the park. No bombs were found, said Mike Dowd, a park ranger.

title: Decriminalizing Marijuana Would Reverse Hard-Won Progress
description: To the Editor:

title: DUPREE A PROSPECT
description: Marcus Dupree, the running back who dropped out of Oklahoma in 1983 to play in the United States Football League, has been declared eligible for the National Football League draft, along with seven other players, including David Fulcher, a safety who had lost his eligibility at Arizona State and is considered a certain first-round pick. But a knee injury that knocked Dupree out of last season might jeopardize him after the April 29 draft.

title: YOUTHS FIGHTING RATINGS OF RECORDS
description: ONE side takes its cue from the title of a popular song of an earlier era, ''Teach Your Children Well.'' They say parents need to protect their teen-age children from rock records that urge listeners to take drugs or indulge in sex.

title: Liberals: Their Own Worst Enemy
description: By his use of words such as ''geek'' and ''boob,'' even if intended ironically, Harry Stein implies something I wish more liberals had the honesty simply to come out and say: ''We're more intelligent than you are.'' It seems to me that the image of ''the conservative'' as a straitlaced, heartless, Bible-thumping rube is as much an insult and a stereotype as any current.

title: THE ROMANCE OF BACK ROADS
description: NOW that spring is here, it's time to hit the road again - the back roads, that is.

title: WITH HORSES EVERYWHERE, ALAS, MANURE
description: SOME wags divide the citizenry of this northern Westchester town into ''the cavalry and the foot soldiers,'' for North Salem is a fox-hunting, trail-riding and horse-showing enclave surrounded by encroaching suburban subdivisions. Real estate ads proclaim the town as ''horse country.'' But where horses roam, manure piles up behind barns and in fields. Some town officials view the stockpiles as threats to the environment, while other townspeople just don't like the smell or sight of the stuff.

title: GARTHORN IS FIRST IN EXCELSIOR STAKES
description: Garthorn, the best handicap horse in New York, scored an easy 4 3/4-length victory over a small field in the $168,900 Excelsior Handicap yesterday at Aqueduct.

title: WESLEYAN AND A COUNTY DISPUTE LAND AND TAXES
description: Eight years ago, Wesleyan University stopped paying taxes on 600 acres of woods and hills in this Putnam County town. At the time, school officials believed the town would consider the land tax-exempt.

title: CELEBRATING A SPANISH FILM RENAISSANCE
description: Those who assume that Spanish film consists merely of seductive, flamenco-dancing senoritas or surreal Bunuelian satire might want to visit ''The Second Festival of Films from Spain in New York.'' From Friday through April 26, the Guild 50th Street Theater will present a sample of nine films that demonstrate the range, vitality and recent freedom of the new Spanish cinema.

title: TELEVISION BY GODARD
description: ''WHAT I love,'' Jean-Luc Godard once wrote, ''is to put two images together so that they make a third one, which isn't an image but which is what one makes of the two images.''

title: ELLEN C. FEINBERG TO MARRY KENNETH P. NADEL IN JUNE
description: Plans for the June wedding of Ellen Carole Feinberg and Kenneth Paul Nadel have been announced by the bride-to-be's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Norman Feinberg of Glen Cove, L.I. Mr. Nadel is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Eugene Nadel of Millwood, N.Y.

title: CAMDEN AQUARIUM HAS TURTLE WAITING
description: THE Camden Aquarium probably will not be completed until 1989, but its first resident, an alligator snapping turtle, is standing - or swimming -by at the Philadelphia Zoo across the Delaware.

title: A ROYAL DUTCH MIXTURE
description: The Hague is vastly different from its bustling sister city of Amsterdam, for somehow its pace and ambiance seem to reflect a gentler time. And although it is the third largest city in the Netherlands, it is nonetheless the seat of the Dutch Parliament and the diplomatic center of the country, with more than 60 embassies and consulates. It is also the home of the International Court of Justice and the European Council of Human Rights, among other international institutions, as well as of scores of civil service offices.

title: PACE OF WORK ON BRIDGES AND ROADS PICKS UP
description: AS New Jersey's highways continue to undergo long-awaited major repairs, motorists, whose patience is taxed by even half of a day's commuting drive, are beginning to see that progress has its price.

title: New & Noteworthy
description: THE KINDNESS OF STRANGERS: The Life of Tennessee Williams, by Donald Spoto. (Ballantine, $4.95.) This biography follows the playwright from his Mississippi boyhood to his death in New York in 1983. Frank Rich said here last year that although Tennessee Williams himself is an elusive presence in the book, and it reveals few surprises, Donald Spoto ''does reconcile conflicting versions of events, add footnotes and flesh out familiar anecdotes with fresh, if mostly unexamined, observations from surviving Williams friends.'' Plume/New American Library has reissued TENNESSEE: CRY OF THE HEART ($8.95), by Dotson Rader, who knew Williams. Mr. Rich found it a ''slapdash but entertaining memoir,'' a mix of gossip, confessions and ''strident self-promotion.'' However, ''the pathos of Williams's decline does seep through.'' MEN AND ANGELS, by Mary Gordon. (Ballantine, $4.50.) Anne Foster, the heroine of Mary Gordon's third novel, is an art historian whose husband has gone abroad for a year, leaving her to resume her interrupted career and to cope with the strange misgivings she feels about the fanatically religious young woman she has hired as a mother's helper. In these pages last year Margaret Drabble said the book's ''rich, informal, imagery-packed prose beautifully reveals the poetry of domesticity. . . . It disturbs, rather than reassures, for it demonstrates that family life itself, that safest, most traditional, most approved of female choices, is not a sanctuary: it is, perpetually, a dangerous place.'' A ROOM WITH A VIEW, by E. M. Forster. (Vintage, $3.95.) E. M. Forster's modest novel explores the love of a proper Englishwoman, Lucy Honeychurch, for a freethinking British expatriate she meets in Florence.

title: FROM THE FAR EAST
description: While diplomats negotiate and nations go to war over international boundaries, stamp collectors remain unaffected by the winds of change. Nowhere is that better found than in the treatment of China. In stamp catalogues there are two Chinas.

title: Facts Behind 'Eclipse'
description: To the Editor:

title: ITALIAN DOESN'T EXPECT U.S. STRIKE BEFORE MEETING
description: Prime Minister Bettino Craxi said today that he did not expect any planned military action by the United States against Libya to come before Monday, when a White House envoy will brief Italian officials.

title: THE NEW BAR SCENE: SOFT DRINKS AND FENCES
description: PARIS, N.Y., a nightclub in Huntington, is stocking up on Yoo-Hoo. ''The kids, they like the Yoo-Hoo,'' the club manager, Gilles Martin, said in a French accent.

title: HAKIM WINS L.I. OPEN FOR FIRST PRO VICTORY
description: Peter Hakim of Forest Hills, Queens, a nonwinner in nine years on the Professional Bowlers Association tour, defeated top-seeded Storm De Vincent of Tamarac, Fla., 216-206, today to capture the $125,000 Long Island Open championship at Garden City Bowl.

title: A Victory for Tobacco Industry
description: Cigarette manufacturers, threatened by nearly 100 pending lawsuits, breathed a bit easier last week. A Federal appeals court ruled that the health warnings the law requires on cigarette packages protect the tobacco companies against claims that they failed to provide adequate notice of the hazards of smoking.

title: Midblock Zoning Victors Turn Sights on 5 East Side Avenues
description: CIVITAS, that band of East Side movers and shakers that last year won a downzoning of the midblocks in its neighborhood in the face of strong opposition from real-estate developers and investors, is seeking to widen its victory.

title: AMID BOOM, JOBS PROGRAMS FOR SUMMER FACE CUTBACKS
description: THE state's strong economy is a mixed blessing, officials say, because although it means more work for adults, it also means the Federal Government will provide less help for teen-agers looking for summer jobs this year.

title: ARTIFICE AND ARTIFACTS IN SMITHSONIAN SHOW
description: Outside the Mall entrance of the National Museum of American History at the Smithsonian Institution, a whimsical sculpture by Red Grooms depicts D. W. Griffith shouting commands through a megaphone to Lillian Gish on an ice floe as the cameraman Billy Bitzer films a scene for the 1920 movie ''Way Down East.'' The sculpture sets the festive tone for the museum's new exhibition, ''Hollywood: Legend and Reality.''

title: Flames 4, Jets 3
description: Lanny McDonald scored at 8:25 of overtime as Calgary swept the Smythe Division semifinal in three striaght games.

title: Budget Amendment A Rein on Congress
description: To the Editor:

title: GENETIC-CONTROL BILL GETS NEW SUPPORT
description: A STATE SENATE bill that would regulate the release of genetically engineered organisms into the environment received unexpected support from events in Washington last week.

title: XAVERIAN HIGH SCHOOL WINS TWO-MILE RELAY
description: Xaverian High School of Brooklyn won the two-mile relay at the Redmen Relays on the St. John's campus yesterday. The team of James Jean Pierre, Steve Monaghan, Paul Whittaker and Jerry Sullivan captured the event in 8 minutes 1.1 seconds.

title: On Language; But It Would Be Wrong
description: RIGHT IS NOT ALWAYS the right word.

title: THE CARE AND FEEDING OF UNDERGRADUATES
description: Although the University of Pennsylvania's spirited party for new students seems the same year in and year out, the freshmen do not. An earnest question asked over the punch bowl last September provides a clue to the priorities of today's undergraduates.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: THE POWER OF THE IMAGE: Essays on Representation and Sexuality. By Annette Kuhn. (Routledge & Kegan Paul, Cloth, $19.95. Paper, $9.95.) Writing in a tradition of feminist film theory that questions the portrayal of women in commercial cinema, Annette Kuhn claims that feminist analysis supersedes previous views of the world.

title: TIA MAGGIO AND LAWYER PLAN TO WED
description: Mr. and Mrs. Joseph P. Maggio of Brooklyn Heights and South Egremont, Mass., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Christina Barrett Maggio, to Kim Hoyt Sperduto, a son of the Rev. Dr. and Mrs. Theodore C. Sperduto of Annandale, Va. A May 24 wedding is planned.

title: PARK AVENUE ELEGANCE
description: A CITY'S AMBIANCE IS frequently thought of in terms of neighborhoods. But often it is a street, not an entire quarter, that has the more clearly defined character. That is the case with the stretch of Park Avenue on Manhattan's Upper East Side. This great, wide street, its sides lined with apartment houses to form a nearly even wall and its center a mall of grass and shrubs, is a strong, consistent presence as it proceeds for nearly two miles through otherwise changeable blocks.

title: Postings; Saving A Heritage
description: ''Politics, Power and Preservation'' is the theme chosen by the Preservation League of New York State for its 13th annual statewide conference to be held in Albany from Friday to next Sunday.

title: A STATE PREMIERE: MOZART'S FIRST OPERA
description: MOZART'S first opera, ''Apollo et Hyacinthus,'' written when he was 11 years old, will have its New Jersey premiere on April 22 after a week of free public lectures, seminars and open rehearsals at the Rutgers University campus here.

title:
NUMISMATICS;
NOTED SCULPTOR DESIGNS AN INNOVATIVE MEDAL
description: A new medal released by the The Society of Medalists represents a breakthrough.

title: 'TALLEY'S FOLLY' AT BOSTON POST RD.
description: WHEN the audience is heard emitting a collective sigh as Sally Talley, the reluctant ''radical and eccentric old maid'' finally falls into the arms of the 42-year-old accountant, Matt Friedman, one knows something is working.

title: NICOLA BELZER TO MARRY IN JULY
description: Nicola Alys Belzer, the daughter of Sheldon A. Belzer of New York and Sheila Belzer of Forest Hills, Queens, is planning a July wedding to Conan Shalom Freud, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Edgar L. Freud of New York and Hopatcong, N.J.

title:
ON LONG ISLAND;
7 Major Hotels Near Construction Stage
description: DESPITE the need on the Island for first-class hotels catering to business travelers, few proposals in recent years have reached the construction stage. Either there were problems getting the necessary permits or financing has been hard to come by.

title: PRIZEWINNING SHORTS IN ANIMATION 'TOURNEE'
description: ACCUSTOMED to Disney classics and stereotypical Saturday-morning heroes, we no longer think of animated films as wonders. But there are a handful of daring and a good number of accomplished works among the 20 animated shorts selected from recent international festivals and compiled in ''The 19th International Tournee of Animation,'' which opens today at the Metro. Nearly all head straight for what animators do best, creating those before-your-eyes transformations that turn imaginary scenes into visual realities - a man has a nightmare and is suddenly in a collapsing building, a heartbroken woman turns to glass and shatters.

title: Liberals: Their Own Worst Enemy
description: Harry Stein's account of the demise of liberalism as the conscience of America is compelling, but importantly incomplete (''Liberals: Their Own Worst Enemy,'' March 9). He tells us that Americans now want to hear about the limits or boundaries of appropriate conduct, and that neo-conservatism is the only current source of ideas and discussion of those limits.

title: REAGAN MISUSES U.S. HISTORY IN SEEKING AID FOR THE CONTRAS
description: As the Reagan Administration presses Congress to authorize aid to the contras in Nicaragua, Jonas Savimbi's Unita in Angola and the ''freedom fighters'' in Afghanistan, its foreign policy strategists are trying to establish a morally principled guideline for aiding guerrilla movements abroad. As a result, they have adopted the criteria of democracy and freedom, particularly as each is understood in the United States political tradition, to justify aid to the contras, the Afghan guerrillas and Mr. Savimbi's forces, and to deny support to such groups as the guerrillas in El Salvador, the New People's Army in the Philippines, the Irish Republican Army in Northern Ireland and the various Palestinian ''liberation'' groups in the Middle East.

title: TRENDS FROM EUROPE
description: FOR MOST AMERICAN men, European clothes conjure up an image of outfits outside the mainstream, of garments that, at times, have raised eyebrows at the expense of good taste. Interestingly, however, the European men's-wear collections do have a way of influencing how men in the United States dress. Not necessarily in toto, but certainly in part. The recent showings in Florence and Milan of clothes for next fall are a case in point.

title: ENDING CHILD ABUSE IS A JOB FOR ALL
description: THE enactment of the Child Protective Services Act in 1973 and the establishment of the New York State Central Register focused public awareness on the issue of child abuse and maltreatment. This legislation set up a central register to receive reports of suspected abuse or maltreatment of a child by his or her parent or guardian. By law, teachers, social workers, doctors, police, school personnel and others who work regularly with children are mandated to report any reasonable suspicions.

title: NICARAGUA SAYS U.S. BLOCKS $58 MILLION LOAN
description: The president of the Nicaraguan Central Bank has charged that the United States is making it impossible for his Government to win approval of a $58.4 million agricultural loan from the Inter-American Development Bank.

title: CARRIE FEINER IS AFFIANCED TO MICHAEL HOWARD TRENK
description: Mr. and Mrs. Philip Alan Feiner of Scarsdale, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Carrie Feiner, to Michael Howard Trenk, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Trenk of New York, and Mahopac, N.Y. A June 8 wedding is planned.

title: AN ARTIST OF RANGE KEEPS BUSY
description: FROM covering surfaces the size of thimbles with intricate designs, to drawing huge figures on wall-filling canvases, Jake Bell of West Cornwall is accustomed to working on a multitude of different-sized surfaces. Or, he may deal in sound waves, which take up no room at all.

title: DISAPPOINTED COMET-GAZERS BIDDING HALLEY'S FAREWELL
description: The consensus is in: Halley's comet was a fizzle. The celebrated once-in-a-lifetime visitor from space, which triggered mass hysteria in 1910 and mass merchandising in 1986, surprised astronomers last week by fading and losing most of its tail just as it was making its closest approach to Earth.

title: A CALL FOR A NEW WRITING CLASSROOM IN OUR SCHOOLS
description: AS a teacher of English, I have heard my share of excuses from students for not having work done on time. However, I have begun to receive notes from parents with a new kind of excuse.

title: COLLEGE SURVIVAL TIED TO COED ROLE
description: FACED with dwindling enrollments and increasing financial pressures, two of New Jersey's five private liberal-arts colleges for women are turning coeducational.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: BODY BLOWS. By Steven Simmons. (Dutton, $16.95.) If ''Body Blows'' were a snapshot, it would look intriguing, but also blurry, vague.

title: AROUND THE GARDEN
description: This Week:

title: ELUDING THE TUITION BLUES
description: The first freshmen of the 21st century are starting to advance through nursery school, and their farsighted parents already have financial plans in motion to pay for their college educations. As costs mount rapidly and projections of expenses offer added anxiety, parents cannot afford to wait.

title: LISA AMY RAVIN IS WED
description: Lisa Amy Ravin, the daughter of Allen Ravin of Sea Bright, N.J., and Irene Weiss of Florham Park, N.J., was wed yesterday to Jeffrey Libman, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Morris Libman of Tamarac, Fla. Rabbi Joseph Goldman officiated. Mrs. Libman, a graduate of Boston University with a master's degree in social work from Rutgers University, is a medical social worker at Neurological Institute of the Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center in New York. Her husband, a graduate of George Washington University, owns the Edison Rubber Company, a tire recycling concern in South Plainfield, N.J.

title: YOUNG FILM STAR FROM ISLAND IS NOW TAKING OT THE STAGE
description: EARLY in the script of the new movie ''Crossroads,'' Joe Seneca, playing an institutionalized old Mississippi jazzman named Willie Brown, grows weary of the persistent curiosity of a young music student named Eugene Martone, played by Ralph Macchio.

title: ENDPAPER: BREAKING AWAY
description: After nearly a decade as president of Mary Baldwin, a small women's college in Staunton, Va., I felt it was time for a change. A good new direction, I thought, would be law school. It was a lifetime dream I wanted to follow, and an understanding of the law was clearly a plus for a college president. And frankly, study was going to be a luxury after all those 16-hour days spent keeping 20 administrative balls in the air.

title: YANKEES WIN, 7-3
description: George Steinbrenner never promised Lou Piniella a rose garden, but Piniella promised Steinbrenner a fast start and the manager is keeping his promise.

title: LESSONS FROM A NURSING HOME
description: Negative stereotypes of care provided for the aging are not only prevalent, but are sometimes nurtured by media coverage of isolated problems that might occur. All too often, such stories unnecessarily frighten the public about the prospect of growing old and becoming dependent. The article by Salvatore Gentile, ''Nursing Home: Lesson in Life'' [ Opinion Page, March 2 ] , therefore was most welcome.

title: A FAMILY FEUD STAYS FRIENDLY AT WALDBAUM
description: SHOWING a visitor around one of his Long Island supermarkets, Ira Waldbaum, president and chief executive of Waldbaum Supermarkets, points to a counter top featuring a convoy of miniature Waldbaum delivery trucks.

title:
CRITICS' CHOICES;
Art
description: He was one of Uruguay's leading painters, to be sure. But Pedro Figari (1861-1938) does not share the fame of those South Americans who contributed to the modernist era: Orozco, Siqueiros, Wifredo Lam, Roberto Matta or even his own Uruguayan compatriot, Joaquin Torres-Garcia.

title: Primo Levi's 'Germans'
description: To the Editor:

title: JAN ROCK IS WED TO BARRY ZUBROW
description: Jan Debra Rock, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Leon Rock of Woodbury, L.I., was married yesterday to Barry Lee Zubrow, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Sol E. Zubrow of Philadelphia. Rabbi Gilbert Rosenthal performed the ceremony at Temple Beth El in Cedarhurst, L.I.

title: Managers Link Marcos, Buildings
description: Ferdinand E. Marcos and his family have been called multibillionaires, but Mr. Marcos was still insisting last week that some $300 million worth of New York real estate was not theirs. His case was undermined, however, when two New York businessmen, Joseph E. Bernstein and his brother Ralph, testified before a House subcommmittee that they had managed the New York properties for the Marcos family.

title: MORRISON ATTACKS REGIME IN CHILE
description: UNITED STATES REPRESENTATIVE BRUCE A. MORRISON, back in Connecticut from a weeklong trip to Chile, plans to push for new human rights restrictions on aid to the South American nation.

title: PAPERBACK BEST SELLERS: APRIL 13, 1986
description: Fiction

title: 20 GROUPS SET SEASON CONCLUSIONS
description: THE next few weeks will bring us nearly two dozen seasonal finales. Today alone four chamber cycles bid farewell.

title: Kunstler to Take Jersey Case
description: A judge said he would allow one of two men charged with the 1981 slaying of a state trooper to be defended by the attorney William Kunstler. Mr. Kunstler, a New York City lawyer who is not a member of the New Jersey bar, was given tentative permission to represent Thomas Manning by Judge Michael Imbriani on Friday, pending resolution of technicalities. The trial of Mr. Manning and Richard Williams for the killing of the trooper, Philip Lamonaco, is expected to start in September.

title: CANADIAN EQUESTRIAN A WINNER IN SWEDEN
description: Ian Millar, the Canadian Olympian, won the $13,300 Goteborg Equestrian Grand Prix today.

title: SHUNPIKING THROUGH DELAWARE
description: As spring creeps into the shallow creeks along the Delaware and Chesapeake Bays and a fresh flush of green tinges reeds and trees, the pleasures of backroad jaunting return once again. So - forget frantic freeways and the hypnotic detachment of long-distance driving and enjoy instead the surprises of shunpiking in the northern part of the Delmarva peninsula. This is by far the best way to travel between New York and the Washington, D.C., area. You're only a few miles away from the I-95 but in another time, another world of winding rivers, old inns, towns cocooned in long histories, odd characters and all the enticing idiosyncracies of a slower-paced America.

title: PAGAN INTO SAINT
description: VLADIMIR THE RUSSIAN VIKING By Vladimir Volkoff. Illustrated. 384 pp. Woodstock, N.Y.: The Overlook Press. $18.95. THIS is an impressive biography of Vladimir I (960?-1015), the sainted ruler of Russia who brought Christianity to that pagan land by the force of his imperial power. Born the bastard son of Prince Svyatoslav of Kiev and a lady-in-waiting, he distinguished himself early for his uncommon wisdom, courage and guile in battle. He also distinguished himself for his prowess with women, and ''Vladimir the Russian Viking,'' by the novelist Vladimir Volkoff (''The Turn-Around'' and ''The Set-Up''), is to a great extent a lurching from gory battles to carnal sprees of gargantuan proportions.

title: Security Council Meets On U.S.-Libya Dispute
description: Malta proposed to an emergency meeting of the Security Council today that the United Nations Secretary General intervene to stave off new United States-Libyan clashes.

title: REAGAN CONFRONTS AN INTRACTABLE QADDAFI
description: OF all the problems that have confronted Ronald Reagan as President, none has proved so intractable as terrorism.

title: BRENDA O'BRIEN AND WILLIAM BRAZIER JR. ARE WED
description: Brenda O'Brien, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert O'Brien of Westport, Conn., was married yesterday to William Steele Brazier Jr., a son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Brazier of Fairfield, Conn. The Rev. Stephen J. Chinlund performed the ceremony at the Trinity Episcopal Church in Southport, Conn.

title: NEW YORK INSPECTORS CITE 51 FOOD OUTLETS FOR HEALTH OFFENSES
description: The New York City Department of Health last week released a list of 51 food establishments cited for violating the health code.

title: OFFICIALS OUTLINE EFFECTS OF NEW BUDGET
description: THE $41.5 billion state budget approved in Albany last weekend contained ''a little of everything for everybody,'' according to Assemblyman Gordon W. Burrows, the Yonkers Republican, with Westchester getting new funds for schools, countywide projects and scores of local organizations.

title: GOING ON IN THE NORTHEAST
description: COLORED LIGHT On a sunny day, the brilliance of stained-glass windows by two modern masters, Henri Matisse and Marc Chagall, fills the little sanctuary of the Union Church of Pocantico Hills, N.Y., with abstract light and pure colors.

title: Linda Creed, Songwriter, 37; Known for the 'Philly Sound'
description: Linda Creed, a songwriter considered one of the pillars of the ''Philly Sound,'' died at home Thursday in this suburb of Philadelphia after a long illness. She was 37 years old.

title: URBAN EDUCATION THAT REALLY WORKS
description: After Dr. Alonzo A. Crim arrived here from Compton, Calif., in the summer of 1973, he plunged two or three times a week into a swimming pool for a long series of laps. ''I called it my baptism,'' he says. But the aquatic workouts were not enough to counter the stress of the job that brought him here, a job that no one of his race had ever held before, and so he took up running. He ran farther and farther. He even ran a marathon.

title: JODI D. GOLDSTEIN TO WED L. EDWIN SPROUL 3d IN '87
description: Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Goldstein of Bedford Village, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter Jodi Dana Goldstein to L. Edwin Sproul 3d, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Sproul of Mystic, Conn.

title: BENEFITS, LARGE AND SMALL
description: Lincoln Center Benefit April 14 - A chorus line of 100, an orchestra of 60 and scores of Hollywood and Broadway stars will perform at a musical and dance benefit for Lincoln Center's nine performing arts companies. The show, ''Broadway Salutes Lincoln Center,'' starts at 8 P.M. at Avery Fisher Hall. Tickets for the black-tie evening range from $35 to $150 for the performance alone, from the box office or Center Charge at 212-874-6770. Tickets at $200 include a 7 P.M. cocktail reception at Avery Fisher Hall and the performance, while tickets at $500 and $1,000 include the cocktail party, performance and dinner afterward at the New York State Theater, from 212-877-1800, extension 537. Corporate Theater Aid April 15 - Eight regional theaters, from the Long Wharf Theater in New Haven to the American Conservatory Theater in San Francisco, are the beneficiaries of the National Corporate Theater Fund, which receives money from corporations and its annual benefit. This year's benefit will be Bob Fosse's new musical ''Big Deal'' at 8 P.M. at the Broadway Theater followed by a dinner-dance at the Pierre. Tickets, $300, from 212-393-6252. Briefly Noted: April 15 - The American Friends of Hebrew University will hold its tribute dinner at the Plaza starting with cocktails at 6 P.M. Tickets, $500, from 212-472-9800 or 212-472-0040. April 16 - Cocktails at 6 P.M. followed by dinner at Mortimer's Restaurant, Lexington Avenue at 75th Street, then ''Sweet Charity'' at 8 P.M. at the Minskoff Theater will benefit Babies Hospital of Presbyterian Hospital.

title: ZOE BAIRD PLANS TO BE JUNE BRIDE
description: Zoe Baird, a partner in the Washington office of the law firm of O'Melveny & Myers, and Paul Gerwitz, a professor of law at the Yale Law School, plan to be married in June.

title: AMERICAN POTTERY
description: POTTERY IS THE OLDEST art in most regions of the world. Can anyone hold the shard of an ancient pot without the familiar sense that, regardless of how exotic a civilization's other rituals, people ate and drank from pots and bowls made as they are now, out of clay by local artisans? Another common thread running through all pottery is regional distinction. Certain traditional styles have been the marks of a place, a school, even an entire culture.

title: SOFTER SUITS WITH A SENSE OF FREEDOM
description: THEY'RE called ''dressmaker suits'' and this spring they're showing up all over. No wonder. While most businesswomen would find them appropriate for a day at the office, the stylishness of these ensembles lends itself to a whole range of activities, dressy to pure fun.

title: A STYLISH TURN, A FEW DETOURS
description: ALTHOUGH Villa D'Ric in Syosset became Chez Arturo back in August and the sign out front has been changed, the menus are still labeled with the previous name. But under the new owner and chef, much of the cooking has taken a stylish, sophisticated turn. There are some bumpy detours as well, which prevent the restaurant from reaching a two-star destination.

title: THE DIFFICULT ART OF COUNTERINSURGENCY ELUDES THE RUSSIANS
description: THE Soviet armed forces, which have been fighting longer in Afghanistan than they did in World War II, have apparently learned relatively few military lessons there, Western experts say. Indeed, perhaps the Russians' most important decision in Afghanistan has been to resist the temptation to escalate the hostilities. With an estimated total of 110,000 men, ''the Limited Contingent of Soviet Forces in Afghanistan,'' as it is called in Moscow, has lived up to its name, having grown only insignificantly since it entered Afghanistan in December 1979.

title: A ROVER'S GUIDE TO THE 'IN' STUDENT UNIONS
description: Here's one visitor's list of what he considers to be the 10 best student centers in America. They were chosen not only because of their effectiveness as hubs for campus organizations but also, more importantly, for their success as magnets for student life. Perhaps because these centers are among those most actively run with student participation they are the ''in'' places on campus, with popular restaurants and bars, well-attended dances and other activities contributing to student well-being. 1: University of Texas Union, at Austin. This supercenter, with Texas-size bar, is the leader in student-run activities and organizations, 575 of them, and home of such drinkeries and eateries as Dillingham's Pasture and Steer Here. 2: Wilson Commons of the Universtiy of Rochester. An I.M. Pei building whose atrium sports 18,000 square feet of glass and Florida trees complete with lizards. Three tons of fudge are sold here annually. 3: Indiana Memorial Union, at Indiana University in Bloomington. The world's largest student union, with 475,000 square feet. Art and antiques abound. A city under one roof. 4: Aztec Center at San Diego State University. It offers access to the most extensive collegiate waterfront facility in the world, on Mission Bay, with boats, tanned student lifeguards, and, recently, a sign reading ''76 degrees air and 66 degrees water -- another bland day in paradise.'' 5: K-State Union at Kansas State in Manhattan. The ''Host of the Campus'' boasts a Hyatt-style atrium with a large Wildcat mobile.

title: PIROUETTE IN JAPAN, 'FORE' IN NORTH CAROLINA
description: Dance Lover's Tour of Japan Although some journeys are footloose, a tour scheduled for Japan in June is very much choreographed. Sponsored by the Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater, it is ''A Dance Lover's Tour of Japan.''

title: SOVIET CELEBRATES START OF AGE OF SPACE TRAVEL
description: In this factory town where Yuri A. Gagarin grew up, the 25th anniversary of manned space flight was marked today much as the Fourth of July is marked in small-town America, with bands and footraces, self-conscious pomp and simple pride.

title: A BIT OF THE GREEN
description: Standing on the seventh tee of the old Ballybunion Golf Club course, with the Atlantic over the right shoulder and a gentle northwest wind boosting a hacker's drive over the scrub rough and sand onto the southbound fairway, we were beginning to feel that golf was really created for Ireland.

title: UNMASKING A TERROR GROUP: TYPICAL PATTERN OF TRAVEL, HAVENS AND KILLINGS
description: It was still before dawn as the train rumbled through rocky hills above Trieste. Italian customs policemen had come aboard at the Yugoslav border, and they were routinely checking the passengers when they came to a nervous young man.

title: S.A.T. SCORES LAG
description: HIGH SCHOOL seniors tend to be unenthusiastic about taking the Scholastic Aptitude Test, and even more so about reviewing it - and their answers - once the ordeal is over.

title: BUREAUCRATS ARE UNEASY TARGETS
description: THE law requiring a balanced Federal budget by 1991 has given new impetus to the longtime drive for a reduced public payroll and lent greater urgency to the contention of many state and local officials that money can be saved by turning Government services over to the private sector.

title: MARYLAND LEGISLATURE PUTS CEILING ON PERSONAL INJURY AWARDS
description: Maryland legislators leaped into the liability insurance fray this week, approving the nation's most sweeping ceiling on personal injury awards. They also overhauled state laws governing thrift institutions in the wake of a savings-and-loan scandal.

title: Assault on Families
description: To the Editor:

title: BETSEY BENEDICT ENGAGED
description: Mr. and Mrs. John P. Benedict of Essex Fells and Mantoloking, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter Betsey Brinkerhoff Benedict to Kenneth Elliott Higgins Jr., a son of Dr. and Mrs. Higgins of Fairfield, Conn.

title: Recent Sales
description: Butler $159,900 12 Homestead Avenue *2*3-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 1883 colonial; *2*slate roof, pool, 2-story barn; taxes $2,140. Howell $73,000 5 Brookside Drive *2*3-bedroom, 1-bath, 28-year-old ranch; new *2*natural-gas furnace, attached garage; taxes $1,049. Manalapan $220,000 45 Ivanhoe Drive *2*4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, new colonial; in-ground sprinkler, *2*central air-conditioning, fireplace; taxes to be assessed. Montville $375,000 13 Rand Road *2*5-bedroom, 3 1/2-bath, 3-year-old contemporary; *2*stone fireplace, gourmet kitchen, master suite with Jacuzzi; taxes $5,171. Watchung $150,000 188 Stirling Road *2*4-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 100-year-old colonial; *2*stucco exterior, den, 2-car detached garage; taxes $1,873. West Orange $185,000 27 Ralph Road *2*4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 25-year-old bilevel; *2*central air-conditioning, den, rec room with fireplace; taxes $4,712. OTHER AREAS North Haven, Conn. $117,500 6 Bowling Green Drive *2*4-bedroom, 3-bath, 20-year-old ranch; wooded lot, finished *2*basement, 0.9 acre; taxes $1,680. Purdy Station, N.Y. $160,000 Mills Road *2*3-bedroom, 2-bath, 21-year-old raised ranch; *2*family room, deck, 1-car garage; 0.65 acre; taxes $3,077. Levittown, L.I. $125,000 147 Blacksmith Road *2*4-bedroom, 2-bath, 35-year-old Cape Cod; *2*eat-in kitchen, 1-car garage; taxes $2,800.

title: A SKEPTIC IN MECCA
description: LOST IN THE CROWD By Jalal Al-e Ahmad. Translated by John Green. Introduction by Michael Hillman. l57 pp. Washington: Three Continents Press. Cloth, $20. Paper, $9. EARLY in April 1964, Jalal Al-e Ahmad (1923-1969), one of Iran's leading writers and social critics, undertook a hajj, or pilgrimage to the Moslem shrines in Saudi Arabia. Some three weeks later he returned to Teheran with a bleeding foot and a travel diary - now available in its first English-language edition as ''Lost in the Crowd'' - that ranks among his finest works.

title: Reagan Says He And Bush Agree On Oil Prices
description: Vice President Bush was out of sight much of last week, traveling in the Middle East. But his Washington friends and enemies were still discussing his statement on April 1 that it was essential to include ''stability'' in any consideration of oil prices and that ''we not just have a continued free fall like a parachutist jumping out without a parachute.'' The remark was widely taken to mean that he favored higher prices.

title: DAVID RICHARDSON ELLIOTT WEDS AGNETA HOFVERBERG
description: Agneta Hofverberg, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Bengt Hofverberg of Freeport, L.I., was married yesterday to David Richardson Elliott, a son of the Rev. and Mrs. John Pool Elliott Jr. of Richmond. The bridegroom's father, a retired Southern Baptist minister, performed the ceremony at the Church of Sweden in New York, assisted by the Rev. Evert Olson, a Lutheran minister.

title: A FINE DEBUT BY TEWKSBURY
description: Bob Tewksbury is learning the high cost of winning in the major leagues, at least with the Yankees. With Ron Guidry the chief magistrate, the Yankees fine each other for various outrageous offenses.

title: RULING CITED IN SCHOOL FIGHT
description: OPPONENTS are citing a recent State Court of Appeals decision in their five-year fight to stop the Hewlett-Woodmere Board of Education from selling two unused school buildings in Woodmere.

title: NEALL BURGER WILL MARRY WESLEY OSTERTAG IN JULY
description: Neall Margaret Burger, an environmentalist with the sloop Clearwater, and Wesley Ostertag, a mathematics instructor at Dutchess County Community College, plan to be married in July. Their parents are Knox Burger and Mrs. Otis Kidwell Burger, both of New York, and the Rev. and Mrs. Frank Ostertag of East Orange, N.J.

title: Police in Ireland Search For Banker's Wife
description: The Irish police raided the homes of dozens of suspects today in a fruitless search for evidence leading to the kidnappers of Jennifer Guinness, wife of the banker John Guinness.

title: Should Boys Play on Girls' Teams?
description: Last August an administrative law judge in New Jersey ruled that a 15-year-old girl named Elizabeth Balsley had a constitutional right to play high school football. She joined the North Hunterdon High team, if only as a bench-warmer. But if she isn't much of a football player, other girls might be - and now can be, thanks to her.

title: COMINGS AND GOINGS
description: Ted Kluszewski was listed in stable condition at St. Joseph Hospital in Tampa, Fla., recovering from a heart attack, according to Janet Gorman, the intensive-care unit supervisor. The former Cincinnati Reds' slugger, who is 61 years old, was admitted to the coronary unit Friday. . . . Tom Abatemarco of Brentwood, L.I., a former assistant coach at North Carolina State, was named to replace Pat Foster as Lamar's head basketball coach.

title: MISS MINOR WED TO STOCKBROKER
description: Barbara Gail Minor, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Lance Cabell Minor Jr. of New Canaan, Conn., and Haigh Scott Reiniger, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Haigh McDiarmid Reiniger of Boston, were married yesterday. The Rev. Roland M. Jones performed the ceremony at St. Mark's Episcopal Church in New Canaan.

title: WITH STANLEY IN LOFTIEST AFGHANISTAN
description: Because you can look at movies every day for a year and not know where they're coming from, I'm always glad to talk to Stanley, my film producer friend. When you get down to it, Stanley is Hollywood. He's seen all the greats and near-greats come and go, including (briefly) himself. He's survived television, CinemaScope, James Bond, ''The Sound of Music,'' the sexual revolution, ''Easy Rider,'' the rating system, Dolby sound, the invasion of the ''body-snatchers'' (which is what he calls conglomerates), the rise of Steven Spielberg, the fall of various dictatorships extravagantly fond of movie people, plus a cocaine charge that was thrown out of court.

title: HANOI SIGNALS A NEW CHILL IN RELATIONS WITH U.S.
description: Hanoi, saying it is disappointed that progress in the search for Americans missing since the Vietnam War has not elicited ''cooperation and good will'' from the United States, has suddenly shifted to a much harsher public stance toward Washington.

title: BEING NOT GOOD ENOUGH OR ALMOST GOOD ENOUGH
description: IN my tenure as a college baseball coach, I dealt with hundreds of ballplayers. And never, at any time in my coaching experience, has a young man ever said to me, ''Coach, I'm really not that interested in playing pro ball.''

title: HOLIDAY STUDY: ADULTS CAN MIX TRAVEL AND EDUCATION
description: In a classroom that spans the world from Hempstead to the Himalayas, American adults are educating themselves in subjects from art to zoology in programs that combine travel and study. While expert guides have long brought knowledge of history, science, art and geography to tours, there has been a more recent growth in travel that emphasizes close, sometimes academic study of the subject matter.

title: ARE THE AUDIO AND AUTO INDUSTRIES ON A COLLISION COURSE?
description: Conspiracy in restraint of trade is illegal in the United States, though one would hardly gain that impression from observing current practices in the car stereo business. Granted, the sheer number of companies making automotive sound equipment suggests a market invigorated by lively competition. At the same time, it is difficult to overlook the fairly blatant efforts - mostly on the part of car dealers and manufacturers - to limit the customer's choice.

title: WOODSTOCK: A TOWN AFRAID TO DRINK WATER
description: LIKE MANY OF HER WOODSTOCK neighbors, Tara Roberts first heard the news on the radio. New York State Health Department tests had shown the town water supply to be so highly contaminated with asbestos that residents were advised not to drink or cook with the water, to limit their showering and to discontinue the use of humidifiers, which might cause asbestos fibers to become airborne.

title: REPORTS OF TAXI FRAUD WERE IGNORED, INQUIRY FINDS
description: Three warnings about fraud in a special taxi-medallion program were ignored or dismissed by city investigators, largely on the advice of Jay L. Turoff, the city's former taxi chief now accused of engineering the fraud, according to new testimony and records.

title: 'FRONTIER' CRIME ON I-95 IN FLORIDA
description: MOTORISTS on a stretch of Interstate 95 in downtown Miami at this time last year faced experiences reminiscent of the Wild West.

title: KATHLEEN GROGAN BECOMES A BRIDE
description: Kathleen Susan Grogan was married yesterday to Gregory J. Gorup at the Roman Catholic Church of St. Ignatius Loyola in New York. The Rev. Robert C. Collins officiated.

title: THAT SHORT CUT TO THE MALL
description: I couldn't help but smile when I read the article ''Short Cut to Mall Disputed'' [ March 16 ] .

title: FRUITCAKES IN THE CAROLINAS
description: HANDLING SIN By Michael Malone. 544 pp. Boston: Little, Brown & Company. $17.95.

title: HEAVY METAL'S STARS BLAZE ON
description: When Mr. Clean changes its formula, it doesn't change its name to ''E-Z Wipe''; the label on the bottle remains the same, even if the chemicals inside have changed. Hard rock groups rely on brand name identification - band name identification - like any other consumer product.

title: COUNTRY MUSIC MARKS A BIRTHDAY
description: On many counts, it has been rough riding for country music since its apex of popularity in the early 1980's. Sales of records have tumbled, concert audiences have ebbed and radio stations have turned away from country-music formats. Similarly, the cable industry has been slumping for the past few seasons, with the number of subscribers to most services leveling off after years of heady gains.

title: ALL GROWN UP AT LAST -- NOW THAT I'M RETIRED
description: THE major goal of any child is to be a grown-up - because grown-ups can do what they want. They get to go to bed late, and eat anything they want, and anyone over 6 years old can fill in the rest.

title: GOOD YEAR IS FORECAST AT RESORTS
description: With five weeks to go before the start of the summer season, workers at Jones Beach on Long Island are sifting bottle caps, driftwood and broken glass from the sand, while bulldozers ease back into place umbrella shacks that were spun to new locations last fall by Hurricane Gloria.

title: Tailored to Urban Living
description: TWO SUMMERS AGO, ROBERT M. Greenberg, a partner of R/ Greenberg Associates, a film-design and production company, was advised for tax reasons to buy a piece of real estate. ''I was willing to buy but was very busy at the time and didn't want to look,'' recalls Greenberg, 37, who promptly ignored the matter and escaped to Fire Island for the weekend. Coincidentally, on the train ride out he found the real-estate section of a newspaper and began perusing the classifieds. One ad - the first he read - caught his attention.

title: MAHLER: MUSIC'S UGLY DUCKLING BECOMES A SWAN
description: By now, the symphonies of Gustav Mahler have become almost as amply recorded as those of Ludwig van Beethoven. New versions pour forth constantly, given these scores' popularity and their suitability for digital high-fidelity display. What's remarkable about this Mahlerian onslaught is that a mere 20 years ago, it was considered daring and exciting for Leonard Bernstein and the New York Philharmonic to risk integral cycles of these symphonies, which for years had been disparaged as the chaotic and overblown products of a played-out late-Romantic sensibility.

title: THE HUMANITIES: CASTLES FOR THE MASSES?
description: Several humanists gathered in New Haven last weekend for a Yale University symposium on ''The Humanities and the Public Interest.'' Excerpts from the remarks of Norman Podhoretz, the editor of Commentary magazine, and A. Bartlett Giamatti, Yale's president, follow. PODHORETZ: Contempt and Conformity

title: Postings; Units With Lofts
description: The narrow strip, at the corner of Amsterdam Avenue and 86th Street, has been a site of controversy for at least a decade. At first, the community bitterly opposed a proposed McDonald's.

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS
description: UP GOES THE SKYSCRAPER! Written and illustrated by Gail Gibbons. Unpaged. New York: Four Winds Press. $12.95. (Ages 5 to 8) UNLIKE ''The Little House,'' Virginia Lee Burton's 1943 classic story of a sweet little house that gets swallowed up by successive urban growth until it is finally rescued and moved back to the country where it can regain the bucolic countryside once again, Gail Gibbons's ''Up Goes the Skyscraper!'' presents a completely optimistic message about the development of the cityscape. There is no smog, no congestion, no suggestion that urban progress brings a loss of light and added density - only the exciting and unrelenting progress of a skyscraper being built just around anybody's corner.

title: NEW CASSETTES: FROM WAR STORIES TO FAIRY TALES
description: Soldier of Orange Starring Rutger Hauer, Jeroen Krabbe, Edward Fox, Susan Penhaligon; directed by Paul Verhoeven, 1978 Cinematheque Collection 144 minutes. $59.95 Inspired by the autobiographical novel by Eric Hazelhoff, the Dutch war hero, Paul Verhoeven's ''Soldier of Orange'' offers a swashbuckling movie-view of World War II as seen in the Netherlands by civilians and members of the underground during the Nazi occupation.

title: SINS OF THE FATHER
description: A PERFECT SPY By John le Carre. 475 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $18.95.

title:
ART;
HIGH-TECH IMAGES ON VIEW IN GREENWICH
description: HOOFBEATS sounding the arrival of computer art have been heard for years, but now a full-fledged exhibition has arrived.

title: NEW CASSETTES: FROM WAR STORIES TO FAIRY TALES
description: Hans Christian Andersen's 'Ugly Duckling and Other Classic Tales' A Children's Circle production CC Studios 45 minutes. $29.95 It is absolutely the closest that video can come to offering children the experience of being read to: a hypnotic narrator spinning a tale while talented illustrators' images evoke the story.

title: A BOLDER WAY TO TEACH WRITING
description: Last May I got a call from a dean at Gustavus Adolphus College, a small liberal-arts college in St. Peter, Minn., telling me about a new program that he thought would interest me. It did. It coincided with my own belief that the teaching of writing should no longer be left only to English teachers but should be made an organic part of every subject. The idea, which goes by the catch phrase of ''writing across the curriculum,'' is very much in the air these days among educators. But I had never heard of anyone actually trying it.

title: ELIZABETH CARTER BOOKER TO WED DONALD BOND JR.
description: Dr. and Mrs. Armistead Page Booker of Charlottesville, Va., have announced the engagement of their daughter Elizabeth Carter Booker to Donald Matthew Bond Jr., a son of Mr. and Mrs. Bond of Great River, N.Y. A Sept. 27 wedding is planned.

title:
ABOUT WESTCHESTER;
SCHOOL NURSE
description: ACCORDING to the log, Lindsay Goldsmith had a ''tumeac'' - that is, a tummy ache. So did Julie Reinitz -only she spelled it ''tameak.'' Alex Low was suffering from ''bits,'' those nasty, itchy things bugs give you, and Raj Inamdar was treated for that condition known to strike pen chewers ''ink in the mouth.''

title: Bookshelf
description: Additional titles of interest:

title: NAVY SPY CASE EVIDENCE LINKED TO DEFENDANT
description: Prosecutors in the espionage trial of Jerry A. Whitworth have presented evidence, seized in searches of two homes, linking him to the theft of classified Navy materials.

title: GLOBAL SAILOR RECOUNTS A RECORD-SETTING VOYAGE
description: Dodge Morgan hadn't been ashore for even a full day yesterday when his 12-year-old son, Hoyt, talked him into tossing a few balls on the lawn outside their rented house in Bermuda. Morgan was game, but his limbs weren't. After being on a boat for 150 consecutive days, he noticed that his legs were still wobbling.

title: RAVES ABOUT JACKSON
description: According to Leeman Bennett, the coach of the Tampa Bay Buccaneers, there is not much question about how high Bo Jackson will go in the N.F.L. draft. ''We're in agreement with all the scouting combines that Bo Jackson is the best player in the country,'' Bennett said.

title: TURNING LIBERTY INTO AN ART FORM
description: LONG ISLAND'S first emotional link with the Statue of Liberty might be said to date from 1876, when William Cullen Bryant met with leading citizens to establish the American committee to raise funds for the monument's installation.

title: QUESTION FOR SPINKS
description: Leon Spinks will be summoned before the Nevada State Athletic Commission to explain why he had taken a banned depressant, phenobarbital, before his unsuccessful bout against the World Boxing Association the junior heavyweight champion, Dwight Muhammad Qawi, in Reno last month. Spinks, a former heavyweight champion, was stopped in the sixth round, and afterward traces of the drug were detected in his urine.

title: SOME NOW OFFERING MORTGAGES
description: FOR much of this century the chance to use a credit union has been considered one of the perks associated with having a job with a large company or government agency. Since a credit union is a nonprofit organization, it normally can offer financial services at lower cost than a regular lending institution.

title: DESIGNING BY COMPUTER
description: Home design, interior decoration and landscape architecture can be avid amateur pursuits. If there is a universal pitfall to working without the help of a professional, however, it is the embarrassing gap between plan and result. A new generation of powerful, graphics-oriented personal computers now offers a way of narrowing, if not closing, that gap. From rearranging a living room to planning a garden, dividing a loft space, adding windows, building bookshelves or plotting seating at a dinner party, when used with the appropriate software, these computers save pencils, paper, time and money. They allow for virtually effortless design ''doodling'' and the creation of two-dimensional blueprints that give more than a hint of the finished product. They obviate the need for both drawing ability and drafting tools.

title: FOR $3.3 MILLION, A THIMBLE CAN BE YOURS
description: ''ISLAND Paradise on Earth,'' the ad reads in bold letters. Then, in smaller type, is, ''Distress sale, $3.3 million.''

title: Wickes Chief Seeks More Challenges
description: If the name ''Ming'' appears on a dusty mirror somewhere in a Builders Emporium store these days, out come the dust cloths. Like the mark of Zorro, it is the signature of Ming the Merciless, known in corporate circles as Sanford C. Sigoloff.

title: JUST IN CASE, S.I. DRILLS IN MOCK SPILL
description: Less than 48 hours after a real environmental emergency in Manhattan, authorities yesterday staged the largest emergency drill in city history, ordering the mock evacuation of two Staten Island neighborhoods.

title: PHONE TRICK WINS BOLD RULER HANDICAP
description: Phone Trick, heralded by Californians as the fastest sprinter in years, convinced New Yorkers by making his Eastern debut a winning one yesterday, scoring an impressive victory in the $117,800 Bold Ruler Handicap at Aqueduct. Phone Trick is now undefeated in eight career starts, the best record of any stakes horse in the country.

title: A Homecoming for the Man Running Liberty Weekend
description: David Wolper has returned to his roots. And some prominent New Yorkers turned out at the Regency Hotel the other night to welcome the former student of P.S. 73, P.S. 6, Columbia Grammar and DeWitt Clinton High School in the Bronx.

title: Man Found Dead In Cesspool on L.I.
description: The Suffolk County police are investigating the death of an unidentified man whose body was found in a cesspool behind an automotive shop Saturday.

title: NEW YORK G.O.P. PLANS A BUSY WEEK
description: New York Republicans will be in the spotlight for three hectic days this week as the front-runner for the gubernatorial nomination formally announces his candidacy and President Reagan and Vice President Bush make fund-raising appearances.

title: Grenade Found in Yard
description: The state police bomb squad was called today after a woman raking leaves in her yard discovered a World War II hand grenade on the ground. Experts examined the rusty grenade, which still had its pin intact, and took it to the state police explosives range in Simsbury for disposal.

title: Duranceau Dance Program
description: New and recent dances by Jesse Duranceau will be performed tonight and tomorrow night at 8 at Washington Square Church, 135 West Fourth Street.

title: COPPER INDUSTRY LAG ALTERS LABOR STANCE IN TALKS
description: When the Kennecott Company sits down with its copper workers' unions to negotiate a new contract, the arguments will not be about how much more the workers should earn but how much less.

title: Dr. Schwartzberg Wed to Physician
description: Dr. Diane Willa Schwartzberg, a dentist, and Dr. Jonathan David Weiss, a resident in radiology, were married yesterday at the Mamaroneck (N.Y) Beach and Yacht Club. Rabbi Kenneth Brickman officiated.

title: STERN PLAYS FOR STERN AT YALE CONCERT
description: David Stern, a 22-year-old senior at Yale University, wanted his last concert as music director of the Yale Bach Society to be truly memorable. So he invited his father to perform.

title: Utter Confusion
description: Members of the House of Representatives should expect a sharp, if temporary, drop in calls from business executives and others served by the Chamber of Commerc of the United States.

title: RANGERS ROUTED AS SERIES IS TIED
description: Just when everything was in place and everyone was primed for the big upset, the Flyers - that team that thrashed the Rangers during the regular season - reappeared. And they did it in a blowout.

title: Official Leaves At Texas Air
description: Frank Lorenzo's silent partner in the Texas Air Corporation has quietly severed his ties with the company.

title: IN LOBBY OF LOWER EAST SIDE PROJECT, TENANTS DRAW LINE AGAINST ADDICTS
description: There are 19 buildings at Jacob Riis Houses, each a red-brick world with its own community, its own spirit. In one, neighbors are so close that one family adopted the children down the hall when the uncle they had lived with died. In another, there is so little contact that a mother could not give any neighbor's phone number to her child's day care center in case of an emergency.

title: MUSIC: KIRI TE KANAWA AND PLACIDO DOMINGO
description: LAST night the Metropolitan Opera offered us two stars who, of late, have been heading in opposite directions - at least for New York audiences. The event was a recital by Placido Domingo, the tenor, and the soprano Kiri Te Kanawa. James Levine and the Met Orchestra and Chorus were there on stage as well in this benefit evening for the company's pension fund.

title: Stockman's Security
description: With David A. Stockman's memoirs finally at Harper & Row's Scranton, Pa., print shop, participants in the endeavor are talking a little more freely now about the planning and security needed to protect Newsweek's exclusive rights to pre-publication excerpts, and to protect the publisher's clockwork orchestration of the book's progress toward what Harper hopes will be best-sellerdom.

title:
SPORTS WORLD SPECIALS;
THE FEDERAL LINKS
description: The beautiful Thornapple Creek Golf Course of Kalamazoo, Mich., opened for the season last week under new management. The majority owner and administrator of the five-year-old public course is the United States Department of Justice.

title: MANY CITIES HIRE SERVICES TO GET PARKING REVENUE
description: Investigations into political corruption charges in New York and Chicago have spotlighted a growing effort by financially distressed cities to tap unpaid parking fines as a source of revenue.

title: Foote, Cone Talks With Leber Katz
description: FOOTE, CONE & BELDING COMMUNICATIONS, a publicly held international communications company, disclosed from its Chicago headquarters Friday that it was having merger discussions with 32-year-old Leber Katz Partners of New York, which bills some $290 million in its sole office.

title: 'Wisely and Justly'
description: President Reagan's push for military aid to the Nicaraguan contras, with all its strident rhetoric, has a puzzling side to it: the evident futility of the policy. The contras hold no territory in Nicaragua and have attracted no significant popular support. They have no chance of winning, with or without $100 million from the United States.

title: GUIDRY IS SHARP AS YANKEES COMPLETE SWEEP OF BREWERS
description: Probably not everyone in the American League knows about Ron Guidry's transformation, Butch Wynegar said. Certainly, the fans at Yankee Stadium yesterday appeared to be unaware that Guidry's fastball -the ''really good one,'' he called it -is reserved for special occasions nowadays. So the fans filled the air with the familiar sound of rhythmic applause whenever Guidry had two strikes on a hitter, fully anticipating a strikeout.

title: STARTING THE STRIPER SEASON
description: A CALM mid-April evening is when I usually slide my thumb into the jaws of that first chilled, bright striper of the year, before lifting it out of the water and giving it a ritualistic kiss to help insure my striped-bass fishing fortunes for the long season ahead. Then, in celebration, it is placed gently back into the bay.

title: Jazz Benefit Show
description: A jazz benefit will be held today at the Blue Note, 131 West Third Street (475-8592), to pay medical expenses for the drummer Frankie Dunlop, known for his work with Thelonious Monk, Lionel Hampton and Duke Ellington. The ''Two Franks'' - the saxophonists Frank Foster and Frank Wess - will lead their quintet, and a jam session will feature Mr. Hampton, the trumpeters Dizzy Gillespie, Ted Curson, Jon Faddis and Woody Shaw; the pianists Tommy Flanagan, Cedar Walton, Stanley Cowell and Walter Bishop Jr.; the saxophonists John Stubblefield, C. Sharpe and Arnie Lawrence; the bassists John Ore, Charles Fambrough, Mike Richmond and Red Mitchell; the drummers Ben Riley and Kenny Washington, and many other musicians. The music will begin at 9 P.M. There is a $7.50 cover charge with a $5 minimum at tables, $5 with a one-drink minimum at the bar.

title: 38 DEANS URGE OVERHAUL IN TRAINING OF TEACHERS
description: Deans of 38 leading schools of education have proposed radical changes in the way public school teachers are trained and employed, including abolition of the undergraduate degree in education now taken by 125,000 students a year.

title: Fisherman Asserts His Son Was Killed by Shuttle Debris
