description: A Brazilian fisherman says that a 20-foot piece of metal fell from the sky, killed his son and sank their boat 37 minutes after the space shuttle Challenger exploded Jan. 28.

title: PLAN TO CUT BANK RATES REPORTED BY JAPAN PRESS
description: Japan and the United States have agreed to lower interest rates concurrently, according to several press reports here.

title: BOMBING VICTIM TRIED TO STRADDLE 2 MAFIA WORLDS
description: Frank DeCicco, the reputed underboss of the Gambino family killed in yesterday's car bombing in Brooklyn, tried to straddle the two major feuding factions of the Mafia family and managed to succeed only fleetingly, law enforcement officials said.

title: Korean Retains Title In Unanimous Decision
description: Chang Jung-koo of South Korea retained his World Boxing Council light-flyweight title today with a unanimous 12-round decision over German Torres of Mexico.

title: To Experience Space Firsthand
description: To the Editor:

title: AIR FORCE PLANS SEMINAR ON 'CATCH-22'
description: Yossarian, the bombardier who wanted to stop the bombing and beat the system, lives - in, of all places, the United States Air Force Academy.

title: NORTH STARS EVEN SERIES
description: Brian Bellows and Neal Broten each scored two goals as the Minnesota North Stars staved off elimination from the playoffs tonight with a 7-4 victory over the St. Louis Blues.

title: QUESTION BOX
description: QUESTION: In full acknowledgment of Phil Niekro's ranking among the 300-game winners, is he nearing any major-league mark for defeats in a career?

title: Action on Judicial Post Stalled
description: The nomination of Daniel Manion, a conservative Indiana lawyer, to a seat on a Federal appeals court in Chicago has been delayed after a lawyers' group said the nominee lacked Federal court experience.

title: A PEEK AT ARTHUR KRIM, ADVISER TO PRESIDENTS
description: For 20 years, Democratic Presidents slipped into an elegant East Side town house to seek advice from its owner, raise money from the well-to-do and, once in a while, revel at grand parties.

title: Westchester Bars A Brand of Clams
description: The threat of botulism prompted Westchester County health officials to bar the sales of one type of canned clams today after a man ate them and became seriously ill.

title: SPINKS LEARNS VALUE OF HIS WORK
description: IN 1976, after he and his brother Leon won gold medals in boxing at the Montreal Olympics, Michael Spinks declined to turn professional.

title: Stevenson Is Injured In Fall From Horse
description: Adlai E. Stevenson 3d, the Democratic candidate for Governor of Illinois, injured his back today when he was thrown from a horse he was trying to break at his farm here, a campaign aide said. It was not clear how the accident would change Mr. Stevenson's campaign for the Governorship.

title: Bolshoi May Be Coming To Town Next Summer
description: The Bolshoi Ballet is planning to come to New York in the summer next year.

title: Becker Upset by Jarryd
description: Anders Jarryd, a late tournament entry, upset Boris Becker of West Germany, 6-7, 6-1, 6-1, 6-4, today in the final of the World Championship Tennis tournament.

title: POLICE SEEKING A 4TH SUSPECT IN SLAYING OF JEWELER
description: A third suspect in the holdup-murder of a jeweler in Manhattan's midtown diamond district has been arrested and a fourth is still being sought, the police said yesterday.

title: Repairs to Close Part Of Manhattan Bridge
description: The two Manhattan-bound lanes on the upper roadway of the Manhattan Bridge are to close for a year starting this morning as workers rebuild that portion of the roadway, according to the State Department of Transportation.

title: Nets Lose to Celtics
description: The Nets went into their regular-season finale today needing a victory over the Boston Celtics or help from the Philadelphia 76ers to improve their playoff position in the Eastern Conference. They got neither.

title: MARKETING GETS BRITISH RESPECT
description: When Sir Clive Sinclair sold off his computer business last week, it had to be the most widely followed $7 million corporate transaction in British history.

title: G.M. OFFERS NEW LOAN FINANCINGS
description: The General Motors Corporation, as expected, began a broad round of low-rate financing sales incentives today in an apparent effort to avoid cutting back production.

title: Some Beauty for Approach To the Verrazano Bridge
description: Come July, or maybe as early as June, the Staten Island approach to the Verrazano-Narrows Bridge should be a lot prettier because of the work of Ellen O'Flaherty Pratt and a small group of volunteers.

title: THOUSANDS RALLY FOR MARCOS IN MANILA
description: On the eve of a legislative challenge to Corazon C. Aquino, the supporters of Ferdinand E. Marcos held their biggest rally today since the deposed President fled the Philippines nearly seven weeks ago.

title: Letter: On Arms Control; Let's Make the Test Ban a U.S. Card
description: To the Editor:

title: Orioles 3, Rangers 2
description: Cal Ripken hit a two-run single in the eighth inning to catapult Baltimore to a victory.

title: OUTLASTING RIVAL
description: THIS is no small thing to say in the chaotic world of the New York Rangers: For the first time in seven years, the Rangers' season has lasted longer than the season of their suburban tormentors, the New York Islanders.

title: MORE WORKERS' COMPUTERS ARE STARING BACK
description: Finger strokes, anxiety levels, bathroom breaks and other actions of workers at video display terminals are increasingly being monitored by computers, according to a group representing office workers.

title: ECONOMIC CALENDAR
description: Listed below are the target release dates for major economic indicators scheduled to be released this week. Monday

title: Sudanese Centrists Lead In Early Election Tally
description: The centrist Umma Party of former Prime Minister Sadiq el-Mahdi took two of the first three seats declared today as ballots were counted after the Sudan's first multiparty elections in 18 years.

title: TEXT OF POPE'S SPEECH AT ROME SYNAGOGUE: 'YOU ARE OUR ELDER BROTHERS'
description: Following is the official text of Pope John Paul II's speech today at the Rome synagogue, translated from Italian by the Vatican:

title: VERGIL D. REED
description: Vergil D. Reed, professor emeritus of marketing at Columbia University and a former vice president of the J. Walter Thompson Company, died of pnuemonia Wednesday at his home in Washington. He was 89 years old.

title: Revised Offer For Gypsum
description: The National Gypsum Company said yesterday that an investment group led by senior management of the company had sweetened its leveraged buyout proposal.

title: The Uses of Bilingual Education
description: To the Editor:

title: A Close Call
description: The Knicks' only hope of salvaging something from their dark season ended with their loss in Milwaukee on Saturday night. But before the Bucks' guard Craig Hodges converted four of his six 3-point shots to win the league's 3-point shooting title from the Knicks' guard Trent Tucker, the chase provided a dismal evening with its only drama.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Businessland Inc., San Jose, Calif., a retailer of microcomputers, said Ronald Watkins had resigned as president, chief operating officer and a director.

title: PIANO: BROWNING IN RECITAL
description: FOR his piano recital at Carnegie Hall on Wednesday night, John Browning resurrected the original 1913 version of Rachmaninoff's Sonata No. 2 in B-flat minor, a work the composer shortened and revised in 1931. Up to now, the piece has never loomed large in the Rachmaninoff canon, and to this listener's ears, the original is no more impressive than the revision.

title: MONDAY, APRIL 14, 1986
description: International

title: On Being, and Not Being, on a First-Name Basis
description: To the Editor:

title: On Being, and Not Being, on a First-Name Basis
description: To the Editor:

title: Afghanistan Differs With Rebels on Clash
description: Afghanistan said today that its troops had killed 700 Moslem rebels in an offensive along the Pakistan border.

title: FINDING RECORDS OF CRIME IN A HAYSTACK OF PAPER
description: Two scenes in Washington that might be out of a John le Carre film:

title: JAPAN SAID TO VOW 'HISTORIC' ACTION ON EASING TRADE
description: President Reagan received assurances from Prime Minister Yasuhiro Nakasone today that Japan was determined to effect a ''historic change'' that could help ease the United States-Japan trade imbalance, Administration officials said.

title: Whitson in Relief for Now
description: After Ed Whitson lost his first start in front of a hostile home crowd at Yankee Stadium last week, Manager Lou Piniella decided that the embattled pitcher would start on the road in the foreseeable future. Now, Piniella has temporarily removed Whitson from the starting rotation and is planning to use him in the bullpen.

title: Liz Claiborne To Needham
description: Needham Harper Worldwide's New York office has emerged the victor in a 12-way competition for the $5 million account of Liz Claiborne Cosmetics, which will be for a new fragrance to be marketed under the designer's name. Billings could be $5 million.

title: C.I.A. AID TO REBELS REPORTED
description: The Central Intelligence Agency, barred from providing military aid to Nicaraguan rebels, secretly sent several million dollars to the contras for political projects over the past year, United States Government officials say.

title: Post Runner Sets Two Meet Marks
description: Elton Lewis, a freshman at C. W. Post College, set meet records of 3 minutes 48.96 seconds in the 1,500-meter run and 1:50.6 in the 800 meters yesterday in the fourth annual Redmen Invitational track and field meet at St. John's University.

title: Scrutiny Starts for Islanders
description: They were accustomed to making history in other ways. But this season, for the first time in 12 playoff appearances, the New York Islanders made a first-round exit. Worse, they went down without resistance, swept by the Washington Capitals, the very team they had eliminated from the playoffs for the past three seasons.

title: Monetarist Hue To Advisers
description: TREASURY SECRETARY JAMES A. BAKER 3d has recruited a new chief economist, a position of some consequence. It is the second-highest ranking economist position in the Government, after Beryl W. Sprinkel, chairman of the Council of Economic Advisers.

title: Amoco Prices Decline
description: The Amoco Oil Company said yesterday that its average wholesale gasoline price to its service station dealers dropped 30 cents a gallon during the first three months of the year, to about 56 cents. The decline reflected the steep fall in crude oil prices, the company said.

title: PROFESSIONALS' ADVICE: START EARLY
description: ''I.R.A.'s have sounded the alarm to a younger generation of women,'' said Henry Wallfesh, a Manhattan retirement adviser, speaking of Individual Retirement Accounts. ''I.R.A.'s have even started women in their 20's thinking about retirement.''

title: Yale Crew Tops Syracuse, Purdue
description: Yale's varsity heavyweight crew remained unbeaten in eastern rowing today, defeating Syracuse and Purdue under ideal racing conditions on its home Housatonic River course.

title: WOES ENGULF MEXICAN STORES
description: While inspecting one of his stores recently, Felipe Garcia, president of Almacenes Garcia, a chain of discount variety stores here and in other major Mexican cities, spied a female mannequin without hands.

title: BRAZILIAN CAPTURES SPAIN'S GRAND PRIX
description: Ayrton Senna of Brazil won the Spanish Grand Prix today by the tightest margin in modern Grand Prix racing, edging Nigel Mansell of Britain in a dramatic wheel-to-wheel duel.

title: Daniels To U.N.L.V.
description: Lloyd Daniels has signed a letter of intent to play basketball for the University of Nevada-Las Vegas and will be flying from New York to Las Vegas tomorrow to begin study toward a General Equivalency Diploma, according to his adviser, Lou d'Almeida.

title: Bridge: Championship Final Pits Mother Against Daughter
description: The New York City final of the Grand National Team Championship yesterday featured a unique clash. For the first time anywhere on a major occasion in head-to-head open-team play, mother and daughter were in opposition.

title: Wives of 2 Slain Gunmen Both Met Violent Deaths
description: Both of the slain robbery suspects who killed two agents of the Federal Bureau of Investigation and wounded five others had remarried after their first wives died violently, according to the authorities.

title:
SPORTS WORLD SPECIALS;
Catching Up
description: * Pat Denning made headlines last fall when she became the first woman to be named assistant coach with on-the-court duties in the history of men's Division I basketball. Her appointment, by the University of Illinois-Chicago, was ''a dream come true,'' she said.

title: Getting Into the Game
description: Tom McMillan, a professional basketball player who is running for Congress, will get some national political exposure tomorrow at an A.F.L.-C.I.O. dinner, having been promoted to the starting line-up for the event. Senator Bill Bradley of New Jersey, a former New York Knick, was to have been a host of the affair, a tribute to athletes to benefit diabetes research, along with Representative Jack F. Kemp of New York, a former Buffalo Bill quarterback.

title: INFLATION WAR MAKES BRAZIL BANKS ACT LIKE BANKS
description: Having grown and profited from the rampant inflation that was an anathema to virtually every other sector of the economy, Brazil's private banks are now reeling from the ''shock'' measures announced here six weeks ago to end inflation.

title: Oresman President of New BBDO Unit
description: After seven years as an outside director of BBDO International, Stephen Oresman will be coming in from the cold on May 1.

title: Midwives and Other Untouchables
description: Nurse-midwives, who help women have babies in hospitals or in small ''birth centers,'' know how to be resourceful in crisis. Now they face a crisis of insurance: an industry spooked by soaring losses on obstetricians refuses to protect midwives against malpractice claims. That seems especially unfair; unlike obstetricians, midwives are rarely sued. Ever resourceful, however, they propose to insure themselves through their association.

title: WALDHEIM EXPRESSES REGRET ON PORTRAYAL HE GAVE OF HIS PAST
description: Kurt Waldheim said yesterday that he was sorry for not revealing until recently that he was a staff officer from 1942 to 1945 in a German Army command that fought Yugoslav partisans and oversaw a large-scale deportation of Greek Jews.

title: DANCE: 'SHINING SEA,' PAUL TAYLOR'S COMPANY
description: THE Paul Taylor Dance Company presented the kind of program Saturday at City Center that makes one wonder anew at the fecundity of Mr. Taylor's imagination and gifts. ''From Sea to Shining Sea,'' first performed in 1965, is one of Mr. Taylor's ''cartoon'' dances, and is clearly the work of a younger choreographer than the one who created ''Mercuric Tidings,'' first performed in 1982. But it is just as assured a dance.

title: Drug Crackdown At Electric Boat
description: The sole builder of Trident nuclear submarines, the Electric Boat division of the General Dynamics Corporation, has said it plans to launch a major crackdown on the use of illegal drugs and alcohol that will include locker searches and sniffing dogs.

title: EDITORS' MOOD IS OPTIMISTIC DESPITE WORRIES ON ECONOMY
description: Many of the nation's newspaper editors, gathered in record numbers here this week for an annual convention, grumbled in hotel corridors with the sophistication of publishers about flat advertising revenues that threaten to squeeze news budgets.

title: Anida Rossman Weds Dr. Edwin J. Rosman
description: Congregation Beth Sholom in Lawrence, L.I., was the setting yesterday for the wedding of Anida D. Rossman, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Warren Rossman of Oceanside, L.I., to Dr. Edwin J. Rosman, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Romy Rosman of Beverly Hills and Palm Springs, Calif. Rabbi Abner Weiss performed the ceremony, assisted by Rabbi Gilbert Rosenthal.

title: ITALY TAKES FIRST STEP TO BAN SUSPECT WINES AFTER POISONING DEATHS
description: The Italian Government will prohibit the distribution, sale or serving of any wines suspected of having been poisoned with wood alcohol, officials here said today.

title: MEETING HIS OR HER PARENTS
description: DO you just drop by for coffee or agree to stay for dinner? Find out in advance what the parents are like or decide not to make a big deal about it? Dig out some conservative clothes or feel it is more honest to meet them in the punky stuff you normally wear?

title: NEWS SUMMARY: MONDAY, APRIL 14, 1986
description: International A decision by President Reagan on whether to order an attack against Libya was near, senior Administration officials said. Tension continued to build as Vernon A. Walters, the chief American representative at the United Nations, held confidential briefings in key allied capitals about American plans, and two United States Navy carrier battle groups exercised in the central Mediterranean not far from Libya. Senator Richard G. Lugar, chairman of the Foreign Relations Committee, who complained to Secretary of State George P. Shultz about not being briefed on possible war plans, said he was reached by Mr. Shultz and told to come to the White House today for a meeting with Mr. Reagan that is expected to discuss the possible response. [ Page A1, Column 6. ]

title: Trade Aids For Mexico Suggested
description: Mexico could lessen its dependence on oil and in turn improve the United States-Mexico border economy if it adopted free trade measures, trade representatives told members of the International Trade Commission last week.

title: CORRECTION
description: An Athens dispatch on April 3 about the bombing of a Trans World Airlines jet incorrectly described the eponym of a previously unknown group that claimed responsibility. The group - the Arab Revolutionary Cells, Ezzedine al-Kassam Unit - is named for a Palestinian cleric who led a revolt in Palestine against the British authorities and Zionists in 1935. He was killed later that year in a clash with the British in Jenin in what was then northern Palestine.

title: Burger and the Press
description: The challenge of organizing next year's bicentennial celebration for the Constitution has had the unpredictable side effect of bringing Chief Justice Warren E. Burger and the press closer. The Chief Justice, chairman of the commission on the bicentennial, has long been famous in Washington for his resistance to news coverage.

title: The U.N. Today; April 14, 1986
description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY Special Committee on U.N. Charter - 10:30 A.M and 3 p.m. ECONOMIC AND

title: BALLET: HARTFORD TROUPE
description: THREE of Pilobolus Dance Theater's choreographers have collaborated on a wonderful suspense tale for the Hartford Ballet. Annoyingly called ''Untitled Work,'' the piece had its world premiere Saturday night when the company from Connecticut performed at Brooklyn College's Whitman Hall under the auspices of the Brooklyn Center for the Performing Arts.

title: SHEA GETS DRESSED UP FOR METS' OPENER
description: Today, some 55,000 spectators will converge on Shea Stadium in hopeful masses, their hearts pinned on the Mets, their minds fixed on the home opener against the St. Louis Cardinals. Only the game will matter.

title: Shultz Urges Support For Anti-Soviet Forces
description: Secretary of State George P. Shultz, in a speech to be delivered Monday, says it is the duty of the United States to support popular democratic movements challenging the Soviet Union and its allies.

title: GRAF DEFEATS LLOYD TO CAPTURE TITLE
description: Steffi Graf, the 16-year-old West German who had never won a major tournament, had played Chris Evert Lloyd six times previously, and each time, Mrs. Lloyd won in straight sets.

title: Interest Rate Cycle
description: To the Editor:

title: STALIN DAUGHTER SET TO LEAVE
description: Svetlana Alliluyeva, Stalin's daughter, said today that she had received permission from the Government to leave the Soviet Union once again and planned to do so before the end of the month.

title: Tactic Fizzles
description: First there were amphetamines and other stimulants used by elite athletes to improve performance. Then came steroids and blood doping. Now, according to sports scientists, the relentless quest for a competitive edge through chemistry has led some athletes to turn from esoterica to the medicine cabinet.

title: AGREEMENT BY OPEC IS ELUSIVE
description: The emergency session of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries that begins Tuesday is expected to prolong the bitter dispute that blocked agreement when the organization last met in mid-March and keep oil prices low in the short term, according to oil analysts and industry experts.

title: A Novel Model
description: When Assistant Secretary of Defense Richard N. Perle writes the Washington novel he plans, the first attempt at pure fiction by this former Congressional aide, he will not be operating entirely in the dark. The other day his boss, Under Secretary Fred C. Ikle, gave him a copy of ''The Ides of March,'' a 1948 effort by Thornton Wilder, noting that it was an epistolary novel of the sort Mr. Perle had proposed to various publishers and thus might serve as a model.

title: To Catch Reagan's Eye
description: If you see several dozen women marching in front of the White House this morning wearing red dresses, it is almost certainly a group called ''Nancys Against Contra Aid.'' They are not all named Nancy but all are opposed to the bill to provide $100 million in aid to the Nicaraguan rebels. This comes up for a House vote this week, and they thought they might catch the President's attention more readily by wearing his wife's favorite color.

title: POPE SPEAKS IN ROME SYNAGOGUE, IN THE FIRST SUCH VISIT ON RECORD
description: Pope John Paul II, embracing the world's Jews as ''our elder brothers,'' today paid the first recorded papal visit to a synagogue and condemned persecution and displays of anti-Semitism ''at any time and by anyone.''

title: MONDAY SPORTS
description: Baseball Mets vs. St. Louis Cardinals, at Shea Stadium, home opener. The Cy Young Award winner Dwight Gooden, who tamed the Pittsburgh Pirates in their season opener last Tuesday, gets his second start of the season, against the defending National League champions.

title: FAN OF LENIN, FOE OF APARTHEID, NOW UNSHACKLED
description: Roley Arenstein, who sports a graying goatee and calls Lenin his political uncle, seems unused to even relative freedom, and that is not really surprising.

title: Books: Offstage Journal
description: Fifth Row Center. By Benedict Nightingale. 346 pages. Times Books. $17.95. IN September 1983, Benedict

title: KNICKS' MISFORTUNES HELP NEWCOMERS
description: CHRIS McNEALY was going to give it one more shot, just one more season in the minor-league Continental Basketball Association. Then it was on to Europe, where players like him, unknown in the United States, are appreciated, even idolized and, most important, well-paid.

title: ISRAELI PACT ENDS CRISIS IN CABINET
description: The eight-day crisis in Israel's coalition Government was resolved late tonight when the Likud bloc agreed that two of its ministers should switch jobs to satisfy the demands of Prime Minister Shimon Peres of the Labor Party.

title: CORRECTION
description: A Washington dispatch on March 28 about reaction to education guidelines proposed by the Vatican incorrectly characterized the views of Damian P. Fedoryka, president of Christendom College. Dr. Fedoryka said that Catholic colleges could accept the Vatican document without jeopardizing their accreditation, not that they could do so without endangering their Federal financial aid status.

title: Airline Safety Without Re-regulation
description: Recent publicity over airline safety has presented some opponents of airline deregulation with an opportunity to scare Congress into turning back the clock. Senator John Glenn, for instance, who is not an advocate of re-regulation, is suggesting that the Federal Aviation Administration temporarily stop certifying new air carriers in order to devote more of its limited staff to inspecting those already flying.

title: EUROPE'S UNEASE
description: The prospect of an American military strike against Libya has touched off deep apprehension in Western Europe and highlighted the differing European and American perspectives on terrorism and how best to combat it, European officials and defense experts said in interviews this weekend. The current tour of

title: Distribute Homeless Shelters Fairly Throughout New York City
description: To the Editor:

title: Nilsson Master Class
description: Birgit Nilsson will give a master class in operatic literature on Wednesday at the Manhattan School of Music.

title: AS TUITIONS RISE, COLLEGES ADOPT BANKS' ROLE
description: With the cost of tuition soaring and Federal assistance eroding, American colleges and universities are moving aggressively into the business of providing financial services to students and their parents.

title: TOP U.S. COMPANY: BUSINESS MAGAZINES DIFFER
description: Call it a battle of lists. Amid much ballyhoo, the leading business magazines have weighed in with their annual rankings of America's largest companies.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: WORLD PRESS PHOTOS In the exhibition of the 29th annual World Press Photo Contest winners, which has just opened at Nikon House, 13 nations are represented. This competition, run by the World Press Photo Holland Foundation in the Netherlands, received 5,400 entries for 1985. These pictures were the work of 867 photographers in 55 countries.

title: DICK, JANE AND SPOT - SORT OF
description: Remember Dick and Jane? Remember Spot, too? Remember seeing him run?

title: Lisa D. Unger Is Married To K. J. Fleisher in Queens
description: Lisa D. Unger, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Unger of New York, was married yesterday to Kenneth J. Fleisher, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Allan H. Fleisher of Merion Station, Pa., and Atlantic City. Rabbi Rafael Saffra performed the ceremony at the Rockwood Park Jewish Center in Howard Beach, Queens.

title: KEEPING THE KID IN GOODEN
description: EVERY two weeks, the check arrives at the bank in Florida and is automatically deposited into his account. Dwight Gooden says he doesn't know how big it is, and he doesn't go around spending much of it. But it's for something near $50,000, which isn't bad for a 21-year-old high school graduate.

title: REAGAN TO CONFER WITH AIDES TODAY ON LIBYA RESPONSE
description: President Reagan was described by senior Administration officials today as near a decision on whether to order a military attack against Libya. A move could be ordered as early as Monday, a key Senator said.

title: Look Who's Shortchanging I.R.S.
description: With April 15 almost upon us, this is a moment to sympathize with taxpayers and, for those with breadth of soul, to spare some regard for the tax collector as well. The Internal Revenue Service is looking better this year. That's hardly surprising. Anything sloppier than last year would be disaster. But smoother computer operations and faster refunds can't quickly repair years of neglect by an Administration that has been penny-wise and pound foolish. Inefficient collection is unfair to taxpayers and costly to the Government. Both deserve better.

title: Bishop Sidney Metzger Dies; Aided Union's Boycott Effort
description: Bishop Sidney Matthew Metzger, retired Bishop of El Paso, died Saturday at the Hotel Dieu Hospital. He was 83 years old.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article in Business Day on Thursday about brokerage houses' capital misstated the amount reported by Shearson Lehman Brothers. It was $2.25 billion at the end of 1985.

title: NICKLAUS WINS SIXTH MASTERS
description: Jack Nicklaus, who was four shots off the lead with four holes left, got an eagle and two birdies in those closing holes to win the Masters Tournament for a record sixth time today with a stunning 7-under-par 65.

title: 12 SEPARATE TABLES FOR BONANNO TRIAL DEFENSE
description: When the racketeering trial of a reputed crime boss, Philip Rastelli, and 12 co-defendants starts Wednesday, there will be an unusual look to the courtroom.

title: RIDING A WHIRLWIND OF FARM ISSUES
description: Late last year, Richard E. Lyng, who recently became the 22d Secretary of Agriculture, decided not to plant tulips in the garden of his home in Arlington, Va. He was heading to Italy to spend this month vacationing with his wife, Bethyl.

title: RIDING A NURSING HOME BOOM
description: Robert Van Tuyle, the chairman of Beverly Enterprises, knows a lot about coping with old age. Not only does the 73-year-old executive run the nation's largest nursing home company, but he achieved his greatest successes after turning 65.

title: ON 13, LIFE OF A PUERTO RICAN FAMILY
description: ALTHOUGH Hispanic Americans may be well on their way to becoming the nation's largest ethnic minority, they remain oddly invisible on television prime time. Occasionally Latinos pop up in weekly series as a jiving junkie or as a comedy stereotype with a funny accent, but they are generally excluded from being the centerpieces of sitcoms, action-adventures and television movies. When they are allowed to step forward, the initial shock of nonrecognition can be somewhat jolting. That's part of the effect achieved by tonight's fine ''American Playhouse'' presentation on WNET/Channel 13 at 9.

title: Ecuador Seeks Help
description: Mexico is not alone among Latin oil producers who have been in town looking for help. Ecuador was around too, cup in hand, during the meetings here last week of the International Monetary Fund and the World Bank.

title: Baritone in Recital
description: Thomas Hampson, a baritone, will make his New York recital debut at 8 o'clock tonight at Town Hall, 123 West 43d Street.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: THE GOLDEN GATE. By Vikram Seth. 307 pages. Random House. $17.95.

title: Man Seized at White House
description: A man who refused to give his name was arrested Saturday night after he poured gasoline onto a driveway in front of the White House, the police said. They said the man, who carried no identification, poured gasoline onto the driveway at the northwest gate shortly after 9 P.M.

title: Heavy Calendar of Corporate Issues
description: Securities dealers expect a substantial supply of new corporate and tax-exempt bond issues this week, while the only Treasury offerings will be the regular weekly auction of new bills due in three months and six months.

title: CAR BOMB KILLS THE NO. 2 MAN IN CRIME FAMILY
description: A Staten Island man described by law-enforcement authorities as the No. 2 leader in the Gambino crime family was killed yesterday by a bomb that exploded when he opened the door of a car in the Bensonhurst section of Brooklyn.

title: STATE ADDS 2,018 ACRES TO ITS FOREST PRESERVE
description: New York State has bought seven parcels of land in the Adirondack and Catskill Mountains, totaling 2,018 acres, to add to the state's Forest Preserve, according to the State Environmental Conservation Department.

title: CONGRESSMEN SEEK DETAIL ON BOMBER
description: The Democratic chairman and the ranking Republican member of the House Armed Services Committee have questioned the Pentagon's decision to keep secret the costs of the radar-eluding Stealth bomber and the Air Force's program for an advanced cruise missile.

title: The Two Possibilities
description: There are always two possibilities, said Jacobowsky to the Colonel in a play a generation ago.

title: Pope Speaks in Rome Synagogue, in the First Such Visit on Record
description: ROME, April 13  Pope John Paul II, embracing the world's Jews as ''our elder brothers,'' today paid the first recorded papal visit to a synagogue and condemned persecution and displays of anti-Semitism ''at any time and by anyone.''

title: ROYALS' 3 HOMERS BEAT BLUE JAYS, 7-4
description: Bases-empty home runs by Willie Wilson, George Brett and Steve Balboni today powered the Kansas City Royals to a 7-4 victory over the Toronto Blue Jays.

title: David Watson Weds Cynthia Renee Shoss
description: Cynthia Renee Shoss, a lawyer, and David Goodwin Watson, a theatrical producer and director, were married in their New York home yesterday by Acting Justice David B. Saxe of New York State Supreme Court. The couple's parents are Dr. and Mrs. Milton Shoss of Cape Girardeau, Mo., and Hilton Head, N.C., and Barbara Bellow Watson of New York and the late Goodwin B. Watson.

title: Kansas in View
description: For those whose chief recollection of Kansas scenery involves Dorothy's house revolving in the cyclone, the state's seven-member Congressional delegation is sponsoring an exhibit of colorful paintings and drawings called ''The Kansas Landscape'' in the rotunda of the Cannon House Office Building. Having toured the state, the show of 32 work begins a two-week stand tonight with a reception given by Senators Bob Dole and Nancy Landon Kassebaum and their House colleagues.

title: DIPLOMATS SAY LIBYA IS DISTURBED AT A LACK OF SUPPORT FROM SOVIET
description: The Libyan Government is disturbed at what it considers a lack of support from the Soviet Union as Libya's confrontation with the United States grows more critical, according to Western and Soviet-bloc diplomats.

title: The Right Signals for Cabs
description: New York City created the Taxi and Limousine Commission 15 years ago to deliver efficient and clean cab service. Now the commission stands accused of its own inefficiencies and dirty dealings with private taxi interests. So ingrained are the tendencies that David Trager, chairman of the State Investigation Commission, calls for creating an entirely new regulatory system.

title: AM RADIO EXPANSION TO BE DECIDED
description: Representatives of governments from throughout the Western Hemisphere will begin discussions Monday in Geneva on the process for expanding the AM radio broadcast spectrum by 10 channels, to 1705 kilohertz from the present 1605, creating the opportunity to start nearly 500 new AM radio stations in the United States.

title: Technical Data Signal Danger
description: ARE technical indicators flashing a correction ahead for the stock market?

title: Jordan, Case, Taylor
description: Jordan, Case, Taylor & McGrath has just gotten the Snack Foods Group from Borden.

title: Susan Maureen Sie and Thomas Brener Are Wed
description: Susan Maureen Sie, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John J. Sie of Aurora, Colo., and Thomas Brooks Brener, the son of Mrs. Carl Ruff of New York and the late Daniel A. Brener, were married yesterday at The Terrace, a restaurant at Butler Hall at Columbia University. The Rev. Dr. Richard Leonard of the Unitarian Church of All Souls performed the ceremony.

title: 1st-QUARTER GROWTH RATE IS AWAITED
description: When the Commerce Department issues its first-quarter report on the gross national product on Thursday, the hardships created by plunging oil prices for oil producers and related businesses are expected to dampen overall growth in the nation's output of goods and services to an annualized rate of about 3 percent or less, after inflation.

title: Warnaco Gets Improved Bid
description: The W Acquisition Corporation, an investor group based in Encino, Calif., yesterday increased its bid for Warnaco Inc. for the second time, by offering offered $44 a share in cash, or about $448.8 million, for the leading apparel maker.

title: NEWS RACE HEATS UP WITH TIE
description: When the latest evening news ratings arrived at the networks, members of the NBC ''Nightly News'' staff were so pleased that they canceled lunch plans, ordered pizza and threw a little party for themselves. And they hadn't even won.

title: SUPPORT GROWS IN CONGRESS FOR LEGISLATION ON PICKET LINE VIOLENCE
description: In the wake of a report by the President's Commission on Organized Crime, support appears to be growing in Congress for legislation to make it a Federal crime to commit violence on a picket line or in other labor disputes.

title: THE ARTS OF GENTLE PERSUASION
description: While New Yorkers admire the sparkling new Jacob K. Javits Convention Center on Manhattan's West Side, some Philadelphians are increasingly frustrated over stalled plans for a convention center east of Center City.

title: PARTS FAILURE SEEN IN MEXICAN CRASH
description: Investigators seeking the cause of the March 31 crash of a Mexican jetliner have found strong evidence that it could have been caused by an explosion in a wheel well for the landing gear, according to sources close to the inquiry.

title: RETIREMENT PLANNERS FOCUSING ON WOMEN
description: Retirement advice for women has come a long way since the time ''when the central characters of all the retirement booklets were men and the women were pictured crocheting,'' said Henry M. Wallfesh, president of Retirement Advisors Inc. in Manhattan, one of the largest retirement planning companies.

title: FLYERS RECAPTURE WINNING TOUCH
description: All the elements that brought success during the regular season returned in the playoffs for the Flyers last night in their 7-1 thrashing of the Rangers at Madison Square Garden.

title: Lloyds Chairman, Keen On Chess, Makes Bid...
description: It surprised London financial circles when, on April 4, Lloyds Bank P.L.C., the smallest of Britain's four clearing banks, offered $1.75 billion for Standard Chartered P.L.C., the London-based international bank.

title: Volunteers Caught in Insurance Crossfire
description: To the Editor:

title: POPULARITY AND PAPER CRUNCH HOBBLE GINNIE MAE
description: The American homebuyer's rush for lower-rate mortgages, and Wall Street's insatiable appetite for mortgage-backed securities with a Government guarantee, have created a double headache for the Government National Mortgage Association, also known as Ginnie Mae.

title: A TAX ACCOUNTANT'S FINEST HOUR
description: YOUR next week will be filled with happiness and mirth,'' a Chinese fortune cookie informed Stuart Kessler a week ago. Mr. Kessler knew better. He is the senior tax partner at the accounting firm of Goldstein Golub Kessler, and what filled his week was something between 100 and 140 individual tax returns.

title: The Bear Who Wept
description: EVEN some golf people who cherished Jack Nicklaus thought he would never win another tournament, much less the Masters.

title: World Bank Asks Increase
description: World Bank policy makers agreed Friday to seek to nearly double the level of loans the bank makes to debt-burdened developing nations, to $21.5 billion a year by 1990.

title: Getting Marcos's Billions
description: The former President of the Philippines, Ferdinand E. Marcos, has complained that he is not receiving the ''respected dignity'' promised him by President Reagan. Hounded by Congressional investigations and civil lawsuits to recover the vast wealth he accumulated on his modest salary as President, Mr. Marcos has sought haven in friendlier ports, only to be excluded wherever he turned.

title: But Target's Leader is Expert in Escaping
description: Lord Barber, chairman of Standard Chartered P.L.C., the target of a hostile $1.76 takeover bid by Lloyds Bank, is a man used to tight corners. A World War II veteran, he was a member of the committee that organized one of the most famous and well-documented escapes in history - the ''Wooden Horse'' breakout from a German prison camp.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''With Judaism, therefore, we have a relationship which we do not have with any other religion.

title: F.D.A. Finds Estrogen Impedes Bone Disorder
description: Estrogen, taken daily after the onset of menopause, slows or prevents a bone disorder that often cripples older women, although it increases the risk of uterine cancer, according to the Food and Drug Administration.

title: STIMULANTS AND THE LITERARY ART
description: ONE of the strengths of Robert Stone's new novel, ''Children of Light,'' is the power with which the author writes about people strung out on drugs and alcohol. He is somehow able to penetrate the chaos inside his characters' heads and convey it with remarkable coherence. Yet paradoxically, one of the weaknesses of the book, which is about a screenwriter and an actress who together wreck the production of a movie, is that the drugs and alcohol don't mean anything beyond what they are. In particular, Mr. Stone tells us nothing about their relationship to the creative act. They are simply givens, and they are evil, destructive givens at that, or else why would the actress end up dead and the screenwriter wind up on the wagon?

title: RAWLEY GOES 9 INNINGS TO DEFEAT METS
description: This time, it didn't take five hours and 14 innings, and the Mets didn't blow two late leads to the Philadelphia Phillies. This time, it took only half as much time and the basic nine innings. This time, the Phillies simply took the lead, held it, beat the Mets, 4-2, and sent them home with a two-game losing streak.

title: ABC FILM ON ONE-ARMED OUTFIELDER
description: IT doesn't matter that Pete Gray, the one-armed outfielder, didn't last very long in the major leagues; what matters is that he got there at all. What also matters is that ''A Winner Never Quits,'' a ''biographical dramatization'' of his life, on ABC at 9 o'clock tonight, is a dandy television movie. It has an edge. The edge is in the lean, literate script (by Burt Prelutsky), a couple of interesting performances and a general air of no nonsense. This is not a movie about a man's handicap; it is a movie about a baseball player who happens to have a handicap. On this distinction hangs the difference between sentiment and sentimentality.

title: PRESSURE BY U.S. IS SAID TO INTENSIFY MAFIA FEUDS
description: The bombing death yesterday of Frank DeCicco, the reputed underboss of the country's largest and most powerful Mafia family, came less than four months after the family's top leaders, Paul Castellano and Thomas Bilotti, were shot dead by underworld gunmen.

title: People
description: * Peter A. Schweitzer named executive vice president and general manager of J. Walter Thompson, Detroit, succeeding Joseph G. Schulte, who becomes client service director of Ford Worldwide.

title: MAHER UTTERLY SERIOUS ABOUT ORTON'S COMEDY
description: The first time he is alone on stage in ''Loot,'' the black comedy by Joe Orton at the Music Box Theater, Joseph Maher spots what appears to be a glass ball on the floor.

title: Trucker Turns His Plight Into Bonanza for Needy
description: A trucker who lost $1,500 in wages when the H J. Heinz Company refused to accept delivery of 48,000 pounds of sweet potatoes was in good spirits after hundreds of needy people gathered at his rig to cart them away.

title: Airline Merger Review
description: Consummation of the big airline mergers that have been arranged in recent months could face some delays. The flurry of mergers and the controversy they have stirred has prompted the House Judiciary Committee's chairman, Peter W. Rodino Jr., Democrat of New Jersey, to order a staff review of the Department of Transportation's merger rules.

title: TAXING TAKEOVER'S GOOD WILL
description: The surge of corporate takeovers in recent years has produced a tangled, high-stakes dispute between the Treasury Department and dozens of corporations over the tax treatment of the companies they acquired.

title: FOREIGNERS CAUTIONED ABOUT STAYING IN LIBYA
description: As tensions continued to rise here tonight over possible United States military action against Libyan targets, a number of embassies issued advisories to their nationals to reconsider their positions in the country. None of the embassies recommended evacuation, however.

title: G.I.'S IN GERMANY APPEAR FAR FROM PANICKY
description: A ragged wooden fence in the vast American shopping mall here encloses a group of low-slung buildings that were blown apart by a powerful car bomb last November - a mute memorial to the 35 Americans and others wounded then.

title: WALTERS LOBBIES ALLIES TO ACT AGAINST QADDAFI
description: Vernon A. Walters, Washington's delegate to the United Nations, held high-level consultations on Libya today with the West German and French Governments amid indications of heightened allied concern about a possible American military strike against the North African nation.

title: A Day for Mays
description: Gov. George Deukmejian of California proclaimed yesterday as ''Willie Mays Day'' as he was host to the Hall of Famer in Sacramento. As Mays received the proclamation from the Governor, Assemblyman Art Agnos of San Francisco advised him, ''You can drive anywhere on California freeways and the California Highway Patrol won't stop you.''

title: DAMON BIOTECH reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28

title: ATHENS AIRPORT SPINS A HIGH-TECH SECURITY WEB
description: From the cafe deck of Hellenikon Airport, Greece's top security official was pointing out some of the Government's latest antiterrorism measures when a visitor noticed that the roof, a public area, freely overlooked a restricted zone. Could not some weapon or other contraband be dropped to a confederate below? the guest asked.

title: CORRECTION
description: An obituary of the poet John Ciardi on April 2 misidentified a school where he had been an English instructor. It was the University of Kansas City, not Kansas State University.

title: WHO WILL VOLUNTEER FOR AN AIDS VACCINE?
description: IF doctors develop an AIDS vaccine, will anyone want to be immunized? In the rush to develop a vaccine against acquired immune deficiency syndrome, a number of serious questions like this are not being adequately addressed, health care experts say.

title: CRUCIAL PORTION OF SHUTTLE JOINT FOUND IN OCEAN
description: Salvage crews off the Florida coast have recovered a burned-out section of the booster rocket joint whose rupture is thought to have led to the destruction of the space shuttle Challenger, the Navy said yesterday.

title: Theodore C. Achilles, A Longtime Diplomat
description: Theodore C. Achilles, a member of the United States Foreign Service for more than 30 years, died here last week. He was 80 years old.

title: Ray of Hope
description: In the three months since the big fire at Belmont Park killed 36 of his horses, John Campo had saddled a total of 50, and not one of them had made it to the winner's circle.

ART CRITIC AND MUSEUM HEAD
description: James Johnson Sweeney, an art critic, historian, exhibition organizer and museum director who served in prominent posts at the Museum of Modern Art and the Guggenheim, died yesterday at his home in Manhattan. He was 86 years old, and had suffered a stroke last month.

title: United Technologies Net Falls 7.3%
description: The United Technologies Corporation said yesterday that its earnings dropped 7.3 percent in the first quarter and that revenues fell 3.8 percent.

description: The availability of Government-backed home mortgages could be ''severely curtailed'' by next month if the Government National Mortgage Association is not granted fresh authority to guarantee mortgage-backed securities, groups in the mortgage and home building industries asserted today.

title: A 'Plan' to End the Arms Race?
description: The Administration has a ''secret plan'' to end the nuclear arms race. It must have. What other possible excuse could there be for the nuclear explosions carried out recently in the Nevada desert?

title: Buyer for Spirit?
description: Although Edward J. DeBartolo has said he would fold the Pittsburgh Spirit of the Major Indoor Soccer League, the league plans to contact groups that once said they were interested in buying the team. DeBartolo's vice president, Paul Martha, doesn't sound sanguine about that possibility, saying, ''Remember, those people who may indicate an early interest haven't delved into the facts.'' The team has lost an estimated $9 million in five years.

title: A FORMER RANGER LEARNS TO COACH
description: The New Haven Nighthawks have had 71 players this season, a record by far for the American Hockey League, now 50 years old. One was a plumber from nearby Guilford, another a retired Nighthawk pressed into service for eight games. A third came off the street asking for a tryout and was thrown into action that evening.

title: Broken Hill's Elders Deal
description: Broken Hill Proprietary, the giant Australian natural resources company, today announced its latest move to fight a takeover bid by the investor Robert Holmes a Court.

description: Business sales fell by 1.1 percent in February, the biggest drop in eight months, as American industry continued to be plagued by weak demand.

IN LOUISIANA, IT'S LONG SEASON ONCE AGAIN-RUSSELL LONG, THAT IS

One who called the White House to ask for him was told no one knew where he was, and the caller was given another number to call. That number had been disconnected.

description: Nearly 50 performing artists and arts administrators said yesterday at a state legislative hearing that the real-estate boom in Manhattan, and what they depicted as the indifference of the Koch administration, were threatening to push cultural groups out of the borough, the city or existence.

description: MCA Advertising has been named agency for Waldenbooks, and William W. Bishop, president of the agency, says the billings could go to $10 million, based on the number of bookstores the client is planning to open. Waldenbooks, based in Stamford, Conn., is a subsidiary of K Mart and has 1,000 stores.

title: Burrough to Generals
description: Gene Burrough, who had been general manager for the last two seasons of the Houston Gamblers of the United States Football League, has been named general manager of the New Jersey Generals, who are merging with the Houston team.

GOING OUT GUIDE
description: A MEDIUM WITH A MESSAGE After World War II, the Berlin-born German television director Egon Monk began his career by learning the rudiments of theatrical drama. He moved on to film directing - his goal - with the East German state film industry. And as an assistant to Bertolt Brecht (and Erich Engel and Berthold Viertel), he worked with the Berliner Ensemble. In 1954, then 27 years old and in West Germany, he produced radio plays, becoming in 1960 the first television director for North West German Radio, a state broadcasting outlet in Hamburg.

description: A NEW tool has been found for determining the latitude at which ancient lands lay as far back as 3.5 billion years ago. It has been identified in bacterial structures growing in the hot waters of Yellowstone National Park and in the marine environment of Shark Bay, Western Australia.

title: Economic Freedom Receives a Boost

description: The final report of the Attorney General's Commission on Pornography is at least two months away, but already the panel may be affecting what Americans see and read.

title: DANGER OF MATHEMATICIAN SHORTAGE
description: THE nation's leading mathematicians want to multiply support for mathematics by appealing to the public. They see ''American mathematics in a state of crisis'' and hope to sound a general alarm by proclaiming this month Mathematics Awareness Month. In a taped public service anouncement, the Joint Policy Board for Mathematics warns, ''In an age of high technology and supercomputers, we face a dangerous shortfall of trained minds to advance our frontiers.''

title: FROM EITHER BENCH, AN INTENSE RIVALRY
description: A year ago, he sat in the other dugout. Now, Clint Hurdle is watching the rivalry from another perspective. And he senses the same kind of intensity that inspired him when he was employed by the New York Mets.

title: Bass Group Cuts Walt Disney Stake
description: An investment group led by the Bass family of Fort Worth disclosed that it sold more than 2.2 million common shares of the Walt Disney Company in the last 60 days. In a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, the Bass group said that the sales reduced its Disney stake from 20.8 percent of the shares outstanding to 19.3 percent.

description: b-Net loss

title: CHEAP OIL STIRRING CLAMOR FOR RELIEF IN SOUTHWEST
description: The collapse of world oil prices is creating a political clamor in the Southwest for the Reagan Administration to help rescue the domestic oil and gas industry.

description: b-Includes a writeoff of about $2 million on abandoned leaseholds as well as writedowns and liquidation of inventories and operating losses in 20 stores that the company is closing. c-Net income

title: Tass View of Attack: 'State Terror' by U.S.
description: The Soviet press agency Tass said today that the United States had committed ''state terrorism'' with its air strikes against Libya but that it was too early to speak of consequences.

title: TRW INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Included income of $200,000 from discontinued operations.

title: U.S. DISREGARDED WARNINGS OF ALLIES, ITALIAN SAYS
description: A senior Italian official said this morning that the United States carried out its attack against Libya against the advice of virtually all the European allies.

title: TAX CHECKOFF: DOLLAR HERE, DOLLAR THERE
description: Never mindall those taxpayers still struggling with line 19(b) or line 22(c) whichever is larger. If you are a Michigan piping plover or an Ohio river otter or an Illinois bat, April 15 means money in the bank.

title: Identify All Helsinki Violators
description: President Reagan's statement last month attacking human rights violators on the right as well as the left drew great attention from the American press and public - and it was indeed newsworthy that a President known for chiding the Soviet Union began to chastise right-wing oppressors. But will the press remain interested when the camera focuses once again on the authenticated evils of the Soviet empire?

title: PEANUT SHACK OF AMERICA reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
description: The company said the share earnings reflect the issuance of 647,000 shares in conjunction with its initial public offering.

title: First Chicago Unites 2 Divisions
description: The First Chicago Corporation announced a major revamping today in which it will combine its commercial and investment banking operations.

title: ANGLICANS ELECT TUTU AS ARCHBISHOP
description: Bishop Desmond Tutu, the outspoken opponent of apartheid and Nobel peace laureate, was elected the first black Anglican Archbishop of Cape Town this evening. As Archbishop, he will be the titular head of the Anglican Church in South Africa.

title: GENESIS OF A DECISION: HOW THE PRESIDENT APPROVED RETALIATORY STRIKES
description: Shortly after President Reagan returned to Washington on April 6 from an Easter vacation at his California ranch, he approved a plan by the Joint Chiefs of Staff for surgical bombing strikes against Libya.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Amfesco Industries, Plainview, L.I., a shoe manufacturer, said Joseph Kantrowitz had resigned as a director and senior vice president-finance.

title: LINEAR CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
description: b-Net loss.

title: PLOTS ON GLOBAL SCALE CHARGED
description: Secretary of State George P. Shultz said tonight that Libyan agents had been deployed around the world for attacks against United States embassies in as many as 30 countries.

title: RTE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
76ers AILING AS PLAYOFFS BEGIN
description: As 16 teams prepare for the opening round of the National Basketball Association playoffs Thursday and Friday nights, the effects of one of the worst seasons for injuries still linger.

title: Schwarz Toy Chain Is Sold
description: F.A.O. Schwarz, the 124-year old retailer noted for its lavish toys and sophisticated games for both children and adults, has been sold for the fifth time in little more than 20 years.

title: Prudent Nuclear-Weapons Planning Leads to a Secure Peace
description: To the Editor:

title: Andrew Tsu of China, Anglican Bishop, 100
description: Bishop Andrew Yu Yue Tsu, an Anglican leader in China for many years until the Communist takeover, died Sunday. He was 100 years old.

title: MAYFAIR SUPER MARKETS INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 1
Thiokol Net Drops 66.2%
description: Morton Thiokol, the maker of the solid-fuel booster rockets for the space shuttle program, said today that its third-quarter earnings fell 66.2 percent, to $36.1 million, or 76 cents a share, from $106.9 million, or $2.18 a share, a year earlier. Sales increased 4.4 percent, to $518.5 million, from $496.9 million a year earlier.

title: U.S. RACKETEERING TRIAL FOR 6 ON TRASH COLLECTIONS BEGINS
description: A Federal prosecutor and a defense lawyer presented sharply conflicting views yesterday in the trial of a reputed Mafia leader and five others accused of controlling the collection of refuse from the Consolidated Edison Company.

title: ICN PHARMACEUTICALS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
Radical Group Member Sentenced to Jail
description: The only adult member of the radical group Move to survive a confrontation with the police last May that killed 11 people was sentenced to jail today.

title: CRAWFORD & CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Share earnings reflect a 3-for-2 stock split paid in December.

title: Ortega Needs Contras
description: To the Editor:

title: TREACHEROUS TRIP FOR BICYCLISTS
description: When Sean Kelly mounted the winner's podium after his victory in Sunday's Paris-Roubaix bicycle race, he did not look like the first-place finisher of one of Europe's most prestigious sporting events. The Irishman's weary, unsmiling face indicated that he had just fought his way out of hell - and that, quite literally, is what he had done.

title: HELPFUL ADDRESSES
description: Following is a selection of ''little dressmakers'':

title: CORVUS SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
description: b-Includes a tax credit of $17,000. c-Includes a loss from discontinued operations of $4,097,000 and a tax credit of $77,000. Corvus said its results have been restated to reflect its acquisition of Onyx & IMI Inc. and Oemtek Inc., which is accounted for on a pooling of interests basis. The company said it is laying off 16 percent of its workforce, or 74 employees, in all areas of operations, effective immediately.

title: PATRIOT BANCORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
CORRECTION
description: An article on the Washington Talk page on April 4 about keepsakes for lawyers who argue cases before the Supreme Court described the gifts incorrectly. All lawyers are given quill pens; the Court's pewter inkwells are reserved for visiting dignitaries and other special recipients.

title: TRIALS OF REPUTED MOB FIGURES
description: All trials, unless otherwise noted are being held in Federal District Court in Manhattan. Concluded

title: REPCO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income and after extraordinary credits of $203,000 for the quarter and $261,000 for the year. The latest quarter and year results include a non-recurring charge of $1,132,614 for the writedown of inventory.

title: BACKER OF MAYOR UPHELD IN CHICAGO
description: The Illinois Appellate Court today upheld two lower court decisions favoring a supporter of Mayor Harold Washington in a hotly contested City Council race. That seat is critical in the Mayor's bid to gain control of the council.

title: The Keeper of Secrets in Chief
description: Nestled in the back corridors of the General Services Administration headquarters in Foggy Bottom, near the State Department, behind a metal door wired with burglar alarms, Steven Garfinkel keeps tabs on millions of Government secrets.

title: FIRST TENNESSEE NATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
April 15, 1986
description: SECURITY COUNCIL Meets at 11 A.M. on situation in central Mediterranean. >GENERAL ASSEMBLY Special Committee on U.N. Charter - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M. >ECONOMIC AND SOCIAL COUNCIL Commission on Transnational Corporations - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M. >UNITED NATIONS CHILDREN'S FUND Executive Board - 10 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: FROM CAPITOL HILL, WORDS OF SUPPORT ARE MIXED WITH SOME RESERVATIONS
description: Congressional leaders generally expressed support today for President Reagan's attack on Libya, but a leading Democrat warned that the raid could lead to more violence.

title: CANRAD INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Rescuing a Rain Forest
description: In a move hailed by ecologists, President Luis Alberto Monge of Costa Rica has dedicated a new nature reserve to protect a unique area of dwindling rain forest. Scientists consider the area vital for research on tropical plants and animals.

title: ROYALS DEFEAT RED SOX
description: Willie Wilson triggered a six-run eighth inning with his third consecutive single today as the Kansas City Royals beat Boston, 8-2, spoiling the Red Sox's home opener.

title: 2 PAPERS IN DETROIT PLAN TIE
description: One of the bitterest battles for newspaper supremacy in a major American city ended today as the owners of The Detroit News and The Detroit Free Press agreed to merge all but the news operations of the two papers.

title: RADIATION TECHNOLOGY INC reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
BUSINESS DIGEST: TUESDAY, APRIL 15, 1986
description: International

title: Harboring a Murderer
description: To the Editor:

title: Mandlikova Withdraws
description: First Chris Evert Lloyd and Martina Navratilova declined to play, and Carling Bassett had to drop out because her father, John Bassett, the Toronto sportsman, is ill.

title: HALLEY AND THE COSMIC STAMPEDE
description: FOR those of us who missed it, there's scant solace in knowing that Halley's Comet will be back again on April 29, 2061. On the positive side, fuel shortages may have so darkened night skies by then that our city-dwelling descendants will be able to see the comet with their naked eyes. But on the other hand, who can predict with certainty that any cities will be left standing 75 years hence?

title: WEIGH-TRONIX INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Cuban Exiles in Paris Tell of Prison Torture
description: A group of anti-Government Cubans, now living in exile, testified at a conference here over the weekend that they were tortured and otherwise abused during long terms of imprisonment in Cuba.

title: HOROWITZ RETURNS TO HIS HOMELAND
description: Sixty-one years after leaving the Soviet Union by saying he was going to Germany to study music, Vladimir Horowitz returned today to the country where he was born and made his first mark as a pianist.

title: PARENT UNION ACTS ON HORMEL LOCAL
description: The United Food and Commercial Workers made a formal move today to end the eight-month strike by a dissident local at the Geo. A. Hormel & Company plant in Austin, Minn.

title: Voting for Bloodshed
description: Members of the House who are unwilling to face ''soft on Communism'' charges in next fall's election apparently will give the Administration a victory this week on the issue of military aid to the ''contras'' in Nicaragua. But those who cast an important vote for such a sorry reason may hear some tough questions from concerned voters.

title: Opening Day: 'The Thing to Do'
description: ''It gets me out of the office,'' said Mayor Koch, eating a foot-long frankfurter at Nelson Doubleday's opening-day lunch under a blue-and-white-striped tent at Shea Stadium.

title: Syrian-Backed Force To Patrol South Beirut
description: A Syrian-sponsored force of 200 militiamen was formed today to take up positions around two Palestinian refugee districts in southern Beirut where Palestinians and Shiite Moslems have fought two weeks of gun battles.

title: VICTIM IN CALIFORNIA CASE SOBS IN RECALLING ORDEAL
description: A young woman collapsed into sobs on the witness stand today as she described how an intruder shot her husband in the head, raped her while her husband lay dying, then sodomized their 8-year-old son.

title: GERIATRIC & MEDICAL CENTERS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
NEW MILFORD SAVINGS BANK reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The bank said the figures are pro- forma since it converted from a mutual savings bank to stock form on Feb. 14.

title: New Tandem Computer
description: Tandem Computers Inc. introduced a new computer today that could help the company's battle against the International Business Machines Corporation. The machine, called the Nonstop VLX system, handles such transactions as banking, telecommunications and airline reservations.

title: CHIEF IS OUT AT UNITED ARTISTS
description: In a shake-up that startled Hollywood executives, the United Artists Corporation said that Jerry Weintraub was no longer its chairman and chief executive. Mr. Weintraub had joined the company five months ago.

title: CHASE INCOME RISES 7.5% IN QUARTER
description: Continuing a string of positive earnings reports by the nation's big money-center banks, the Chase Manhattan Corporation said yesterday that it had earned $144 million, or $1.63 a share, in the quarter ended March 31, up 7.5 percent from $134 million, or $1.46 a share, in 1985's first quarter.

title: 'VOICE' TALKS TO LIBYANS OF QADDAFI'S ACTIONS
description: Within an hour of the American air raids on Libya, the Voice of America was on the air with an editorial stating that the United States ''bore no enmity toward the Libyan people.'' But, it reminded Libyans in Arabic and English, ''Colonel Qaddafi is your head of state'' and the Libyan people thus were ''collectively responsible'' for the results of his leadership.

title: Ketchup Is as Chinese as Rice (Well, Almost)
description: To the Editor:

title: Ulster Protestant, Wounded by Police, Dies
description: A man died today after being hit by a plastic bullet fired by the police during clashes last month between Protestant demonstrators and security forces, the police said.

title: U.S. REPORTS A SOVIET FAILURE IN TESTING LARGE NEW MISSILE
description: United States Government experts said today that the Soviet Union had recently tested its largest new land-based missile, but that the test had apparently failed and that there were indications the missile might have exploded.

title: 'UNCERTAIN HARVEST,' FARMING IN U.S.
description: THEY don't make many documentaries like ''An Uncertain Harvest'' any more. It is earnest, informative and just this side of somnolent. It examines a fascinating subject - American agriculture - but is so grimly determined we hear all sides that we tend to lose our bearings. It will be seen on Channel 13 at 11 o'clock tonight.

title: STUDY FINDS ACID RAIN THREATENS MANY LAKES NEAR BEAR MOUNTAINS
description: Acid rain is reported threatening to wipe out fish populations and to change the chemical composition of the water in many of 43 lakes examined by a conservation group in the hills of the lower Hudson River Valley near Bear Mountain.

title: EUROPEANS ACT TO LIMIT MOVES OF LIBYA ENVOYS
description: The European Community countries, blaming Libya for recent terrorist attacks, decided Monday to reduce the size of Libyan Embassies in Europe and to restrict the movements of Libyan diplomats.

title: PENTAGON DETAILS 2-PRONGED ATTACK
description: Officials said tonight that the United States attack on five Libyan targets was a complex operation that involved separate attacks by Air Force and Navy planes and the use of aircraft for refueling, intelligence and electronic jamming, The operation involved two strikes on separate regions of Libya, the officials said.

title: SUMMIT SAVINGS ASSOCATION reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
I.R.S. Chief to Join Price Waterhouse
description: Roscoe L. Egger Jr., the departing Commissioner of the Internal Revenue Service, will rejoin the Washington office of Price Waterhouse in June, the Big Eight accounting firm announced yesterday.

title: NAKASONE SEES CUT IN TRADE GAP
description: Prime Minister Yasuhiro Nakasone said today that expansionary economic policies and measures to encourage imports should lead to a decline in the Japanese trade surplus with the United States by fall.

title: IN THE SKIES OVER LIBYA'S CAPITAL, PLANES ROAR AND BOMBS RESOUND
description: For nearly 10 minutes, the night sky was ablaze with explosions from missiles and tracers as the American planes soared out of the distance.

title: BROCK HOTEL CORP reports earnings for Year to March 31
description: b-After a writeoff of $59.3 million related to assets and loss on restaurant dispositions and closings and a $17.6 million gain from sale of hotels and related assets. c-After a charge of $26.6 million related to the disposition of a subsidiary and restaurant closings. The loss is also after net income from discontinued operations of $2,376,000.

title: Dow, Up 15.13, Is Above 1,800 Again
description: The Dow Jones industrial average closed above the 1,800 level yesterday for the first time in April as stock prices, reacting again to falling interest rates, scored moderate gains.

title: Perno Resigns
description: Dom Perno resigned as basketball coach at the University of Connecticut after a 12-16 season and a last-place finish in the Big East Conference.

title: Birth Rate of Pets Has to Be Decreased
description: To the Editor: John F. Kullberg of the American Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals (Op-Ed, April 5) suggests a tax on pet food, modeled on cigarette taxes, to provide funds for animal shelters and spay-neuter clinics. But that is not a legitimate comparison.

title: D'Arcy Masius
description: D'Arcy Masius Benton & Bowles and the Jos. Garneau Company have decided to split, putting up for grabs Bolla and Cella wines and Old Bushmills Irish whisky. Garneau is a division of the Brown-Forman Corporation.

title: AT A GUN SHOW, ENTHUSIASTS ARE IN HIGH SPIRITS
description: For several months, Jeff Thomassetti, a sanitation worker, and Laura Russo, a data processor, had been shopping all over Westchester County, looking for a good price on an AR-15 semiautomatic rifle.

title: XICOR INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 23
description: b-Net income.

title: Consumer Debt Rise Is Slowed
description: Americans took on $4.97 billion more in consumer debt than they paid off in February, the smallest monthly increase in eight months, the Government reported today.

title: LEHIGH PRESS INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
CHANGE IN DATA CODING OF COMPUTERS EXPECTED
description: The National Security Agency has decided to replace the coding system widely used by Government agencies, companies and banks to protect their most sensitive computer data, according to Government and computer and banking industry officials. The new system, which is being developed by the intelligence agency, will be sharply different.

BEAUTICONTROL COSMETICS reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
WOMAN PINNED BY A CRANE TELLS OF FEAR SHE WAS DYING
description: Nearly 11 months after a 35-ton crane fell and crushed her legs, Brigitte Gerney entered a Manhattan courtroom yesterday - on crutches but on her own - to tell her story to a State Supreme Court jury.

FLORIDA PROGRESS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
GCA CORPORATION reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
