title: SOMERSET BANCORP INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Despite an increase in shares outstanding of 320,000, due to the sale of common stock in September 1985, the per share earnings were the same.

title: The Milk Gimmick Nightmare
description: The Department of Agriculture will soon be stuck with 1.5 million cows, and if cattle ranchers have their way, the department won't even be permitted to slaughter them for meat. The predicament might be funny if it were an isolated incident. It's not. It's just another example of the costly nightmares that result when Congress ducks farm problems instead of confronting them.

title: MARK TWAIN BANCSHARES INC (ST. LOUIS, MO)(O) reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
INTERNATIONAL MULTIFOODS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
description: The company said fiscal 1985 results include a net gain of 27 cents a share from a divestiture and realignment of operations.

title: Panama Canal Picks Advisers
description: Bear Stearns Companies Inc. announced yesterday that it had been appointed by the Panama Canal Commission to study the financing needed to widen part of the canal. Samuel Montagu & Company, a London-based merchant banking house known for its expertise in project financing, is co-adviser for the project.

title: PRICE AND PROMISE OF COMPACT DISKS
description: THE compact disk player is a marvelous piece of technology that is giving the recorded music industry a much needed boost in sales. Now, the same laser disk technology is being applied to vastly increase the memory storage capacity of the personal computer.

title: PACIFIC FIRST FINANCIAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
DIVORCES UP, MARRIAGES DOWN
description: Americans were about twice as likely to marry as to divorce last year, new Government statistics show, but the divorce rate is rising while marriage is on the decline.

title: NEW PORTABLE FROM I.B.M.
description: MANY companies have discovered how difficult it is to produce a popular portable computer. But not many have had the resources of the International Business Machines Corporation, which recently introduced the Convertible, a battery-powered model that will sell for $1,995 when it reaches the stores next month.

title: VICTORIA BANKSHARES INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
ARCHER-DANIELS-MIDLAND CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes extraordinary charge of $6,479,000 on the redemption of debt.

title: Thrift Gets Conservator
description: The Federal Home Loan Bank Board today appointed a conservator to run the First American Savings and Loan Association in Oak Brook, Ill., on the ground that it was mismanaged by its owners, Dan Walker, a former Governor of Illinois, and his wife, Roberta.

title: SILICON SYSTEMS reports earnings for Qtr to March 29
description: b-Net income. The results included tax credits of $122,000 in the year-ago quarter and $1,584,000 in the year-ago 6 months.

title: FLUKE, JOHN MANUFACTURING CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 28
description: Share earnings are adjusted for a 5 percent stock dividend paid in February 1986.

title: FIRST FEDERAL SAVINGS & LOAN ASSN (S C)(O) reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After a tax credit of $621,000 for the quarter and $1,739,000 for the 9 months. c-Net loss and includes an extraordinary charge of $479,000 from reversal of a tax credit. d-Includes an extraordinary gain of $628,000 from dividend paid by the Federal Home Loan Bank Board and a tax credit $108,000. The share earnings reflect a 10 percent stock dividend to be paid today.

title: YANKS' FAST START TO GET ROAD TEST
description: What constitutes a fast start? Is it one week of the baseball season, two weeks, or is it a month? If the Yankees return from a nine-game road trip, beginning tonight in Cleveland, with a .500 record, will the rave notices they have received thus far be rendered premature? Does it really matter when George Steinbrenner critiques every game as if it were a Broadway opening and he has the power to close the show?

title: Imperial Group
description: The board of Imperial Group P.L.C. unanimously recommended that Imperial shareholders accept Hanson Trust P.L.C.'s $4.11 billion bid for the company. The industrial conglomerate Hanson Trust and associated parties already have a 44 percent stake in Imperial, which produces beer, cigarettes and snack foods. Hanson had earlier extended its offer for Imperial until Friday.

title: RANGERS' CHANCES SUDDENLY SLIMMER
description: To begin with, they never thought they would get this far. Now that they have, the Rangers wish it had never gotten to this point: one more game with the Flyers, one more game back in Philadelphia.

title: BOISE CASCADE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes a pre-tax gain of $7 million, or 13 cents a share after tax, as a result of the sale of its envelope division.

title: DECOR CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 1
description: The operations of Art Explosion Inc. have been consolidated with the resluts of Decor since Oct. 17, 1985.

title: INTERNATIONAL RESEARCH & DEVELOPMENT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
GREAT EXPECTATIONS
description: Long before the double-play ball slithered from Howard Johnson's grasp, great gaps had appeared in the orange seats near the dugouts, where the persons known as dignitaries had once been placed.

title: NCR CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
FAB INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 1
Notes From Spy Trial Detail Navy Satellite
description: A Navy communications expert testified today in the espionage trial of Jerry A. Whitworth that sketches and notes seized in connection with the case show the Navy's transition to a satellite communications system in the late 1970's.

title: The Editorial Notebook; Alas, Not EZ Enough
description: Everyone understands why President and Mrs. Reagan needed professional help with their tax return. Many of us whose financial affairs are much less complicated pay someone to relieve us of this annual agony. Increasingly, hiring an accountant is the American way.

title: ARRAYS INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net loss

title: GREAT NORTHERN NEKOOSA CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes investment tax credits of $3.1 million for the latest quarter and $2.1 million for the year-earlier period. The year-ago net also included an insurance settlement of casualty losses in prior years which added 8 cents a share.

title: Phibro-Salomon Notes Yield 8.029%
description: Phibro-Salomon Inc. is offering $150 million of 8 percent notes due in 1996 at a price of 99.80 to yield 8.029 percent through its principal subsidiary, Salomon Brothers Inc.

title: BALLET: 'SECRET PLACES' BY THE JOFFREY
description: MENTION ''Secret Places'' to balletomanes who cut their dance teeth in New York City in the 1960's and you are likely to get a sigh of nostalgia. The romantic pas de deux was a signature work for the Joffrey Ballet, choreographed by Gerald Arpino to Mozart's Concerto for Piano and Orchestra (No. 21), which was then referred to as ''the 'Elvira Madigan' music'' after a popular film in which it was used. Somehow the ballet, first performed in 1968, seemed to typify the youth and sweetness of the Joffrey dancers.

title: HONEYWELL INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 30
SIMONE DE BEAUVOIR, AUTHOR AND INTELLECTUAL, DIES IN PARIS AT 78
description: Simone de Beauvoir, the author whose work included ''The Second Sex,'' a provocative and influential polemic on the status of women, died yesterday at Cochin Hospital in Paris. She was 78 years old and lived in Paris.

title: RECITAL: JEFFREY BIEGEL, PIANIST, AT TULLY HALL
description: JEFFREY BIEGEL'S recital last night at Alice Tully Hall was the sort of event that can propel a young career into orbit. The 24-year-old pianist, a doctoral candidate at the Juilliard School, won the first prize in the 1985 University of Maryland International Piano Festival and Competition and already has toured in this country and abroad, but this recital was listed as his official solo debut in New York (he received this year's William Petschek Piano Debut Award at Juilliard). Mr. Biegel plays with remarkable assurance and maturity. If he continues on his present track, he will soon be mentioned with the best of the current crop of pianists.

title: Chess: 2 Minds Come to a Meeting, And a Major Clash Results
description: Some of the most exciting play arises when the two opponents produce a clash of ideas because, however plausible the motivation each one may have, someone has got to be wrong.

title: Why Money Can't Make the Contras Effective
description: To the Editor:

title: Intel Computers
description: The Intel Corporation introduced a new family of high-speed computers for scientific uses. The new machines use many processors working in parallel to achieve speeds of up to 424 million operations a second, for only a tenth of the cost of supercomputers normally used for such tasks, the company said. However, not much software is available for parallel-processing computers, therefore movement into the market is expected to be gradual.

title: Rates Slip in Light Trading
description: Short- and long-term interest rates declined modestly yesterday in light trading activity.

title: Saudi Refinery Status
description: Saudi Arabia has no plans to expand the capacity of its oil refineries, the governor of the State Oil Organization said. ''We have to make the most use of the existing refineries; expansion is out of the question,'' Abdul-Hadi Taher said Sunday night. Saudi Arabia halted work last year on two major refinery projects.

title: 78 ARE ARRESTED IN YALE PROTEST OVER APARTHEID
description: Yale University police officers today arrested 78 people who passively resisted efforts to dismantle a symbolic shantytown built 10 days ago to protest Yale's investments in companies that do business in South Africa.

title: On the Rebel Aid Plan
description: With the House set to begin a new round of voting this week on President Reagan's $100 million aid plan for the Nicaragua rebels, the President's chief grass-roots political pressure group has been conducting a last-minute advertising blitz aimed at some members of Congress who helped defeat the plan, 222 to 210, in the House's first vote, on March 20.

title: 3-Week-Old Brothers Found Dead at Home
description: Twin 3-week-old boys died early Monday in the Bay Ridge section of Brooklyn after their parents awoke to find one of the boys on the floor in a hallway and the other in his crib, the police said.

title: 'DESERT BLOOM'
description: ''DESERT BLOOM,'' the first theatrical film to be written and directed by Eugene Corr, is a family drama whose domestic crises coincide - all too neatly - with the dawn of the nuclear age in Las Vegas, Nev., where, in the nearby proving grounds, the United States Government began its atomic-bomb test program in 1951.

title: Bees Suspend Norris
description: Now Mike Norris is having attendance problems, but the one-time A's pitching star contends they are not related to his past history of drug and alcohol abuse.

title: AMOSKEAG BANK SHARES reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The company said securities gains before taxes were $5.8 million in the latest quarter and $1.2 million in the year-earlier period.

title: JOHN E. BERTRAM

title: NOT JUST FIGHTING WORDS
description: American air strikes tonight on military targets in Tripoli and Benghazi, Libya, banished any lingering doubt that President Reagan would bring American military power directly to bear on those he considers the sponsors of terrorism. For many months Mr. Reagan was criticized for failing to back up his pugnacious words with bold action. But beginning last October with the seizure of an Egyptian airliner carrying the hijackers of a cruise liner, continuing with the attacks last month on Libyan missile sites and fast attack craft in the Gulf of Sidra and culminating in tonight's action, the President has gotten tougher.

title: Iowa Lottery Winner Dies
description: A man who suffered a stroke hours after becoming the first big winner in the Iowa Lottery died at a hospital. Charles Caskey, 77 years old, of Akron, was felled by the stroke Wednesday, less than four hours after collecting part of his $50,000 grand prize in the lottery's instant ''Hog Wild'' game. Mr. Caskey, a semiretired car salesman, purchased the ticket that morning.

title: Careers; New Focus Urged for Chemists
description: THE demand for young chemists and chemical engineers is not as large this year as it was in 1985, but the job outlook is still quite good, according to the American Chemical Society, the chemical industry's professional group. This year, however, there has been a change in focus that those entering the industry need to be aware of.

title: A Rock Effort To Support Man's Rights
description: BILL GRAHAM, the Live Aid impresario, and Amnesty International U.S.A. have made their deal. The ''Caravan for Human Rights'' is about to begin. And so it falls to Sting and U2, the rock stars, to take the cause of unjustly imprisoned and tortured political dissidents to the heartlands. Now what does that say about America?

title: 46 DIE

title: T.W.A. TRIMS CAIRO RUNS

title: STAGE: BILL C. DAVIS'S 'WRESTLERS,' ON SIBLING STRIFE
description: AS Sam Shepard has most recently demonstrated in ''True West'' and ''A Lie of the Mind,'' neither Eugene O'Neill nor Arthur Miller had the last theatrical word on the subject of contentious American brothers. There is still drama to be found in this timeworn battleground, provided the playwright looks beneath the primal childhood shoving match with which most fratricidal struggles begin. Should a writer fail to take that essential leap past mere domestic detail, however, the result is likely to resemble ''Wrestlers,'' a heartfelt, competently crafted but pallid new play by Bill C. Davis at the Hudson Guild.

title: Businessland Pact

Mortimer Howell Cobb, who was traveling aboard the ship as a 7-year-old boy with his German governess, died of cancer Monday at the age of 81. He had been a member of the United States Maritime Service and a champion croquet player.

title: The Bombs of April

The Senate majority leader, Bob Dole, said: ''It's my view that once you start down this road, there is no turning back.'' The minority leader, Robert Byrd, asked, ''Are we going to do this again and again?'' Would the Bombs of April, like the Guns of August of 72 years ago, lead uncontrollably to much worse?

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: MELLOW MOODS Although Kenny Burrell is considered a major hard-bop guitarist on both Spanish and electric guitar, he has worked with musicians who manifest myriad styles - Dizzy Gillespie, Stan Getz, Gil Evans, Benny Goodman, Astrud Gilberto and Jimmy Smith. Today, Mr. Burrell will perform with his trio at the Highlights in Jazz program, at 8 P.M. in the New York University Loeb Student Center (598-2027), 566 La Guardia Place, at Washington Square South.

title: What the Waldheim Case Says About the U.N.
description: To the Editor:

title: ABRAMS SEEKS TO LIMIT ROLES OF TOP DEMOCRATS
description: State Attorney General Robert Abrams, reacting to the New York City scandals, proposed yesterday that the state's Democratic Party prohibit party leaders from doing business with or representing clients before government agencies.

title: WEDNESDAY SPORTS
description: Baseball Mets vs. St. Louis Cardinals, 1:35 P.M. Second home game of the season for the Mets, who lost their Shea Stadium opener to the Cardinals Monday in 13 innings. (Television - SportsChannel, 1:30 P.M. Radio - WHN 1050, 1:35 P.M.) Yankees vs.

title: CHARGEIT INC reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
GALLAGHER, ARTHUR J & CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Eastwood Is Sworn In As Mayor of Carmel
description: The actor Clint Eastwood was sworn in as Mayor here today in a brief ceremony before about 1,000 tourists and residents.

title: TECO ENERGY INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
EVEN FOR THE PURIST, PASSOVER CAN BE GOURMET'S DELIGHT
description: PASSOVER is the Jewish holiday most closely associated with food. It starts with a specially prepared meal, the seder, many of whose elements symbolize the Jews' captivity in Egypt and subsequent release. For the eight days of Passover, leavened foods are forbidden but it is not, as many think, a time of limited food choices monotonously repeated.

title: MANUFACTURERS HANOVER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Gains on sales of securities in the latest first quarter were $8 million, down from $22.4 million in the year- earlier period.

title: Stocks Shrug Off Libya and Go Up
description: The Libyan situation caused prices to decline somewhat on Wall Street at the beginning of trading yesterday, but when the price of oil did not rise the stock market managed to finish with a modest gain.

title: YALE ACTS TO BAN BIAS ON SEXUAL ORIENTATION
description: Yale University has adopted an equal-opportunity statement that for the first time explicitly forbids discrimination against homosexuals, Yale President A. Bartlett Giamatti announced today.

title: Pitt Player Dropped
description: The University of Pittsburgh football team has lost another player for disciplinary reasons.

title: Beatrice Net Off 91%
description: The Beatrice Companies, the food and consumer goods concern, today reported that its net earnings were $16 million in its fourth quarter ending Feb. 28, down 91 percent from $179 million in the year-earlier quarter.

title: GREECE MAKES BID ON GAMES
description: With a unanimity rare in this deeply politicized nation, Greece is mounting a national campaign to stage the centennial Olympic Games of 1996 in this city, where the modern Olympics were born, and even to move the Games permanently to their place of birth.

title: OIL SUPPLY CURB RULED OUT BY ANALYSTS
description: Oil analysts in the United States said yesterday that because of important changes in the oil market over the last decade there was virtually no threat of an oil embargo in retaliation for the American actions against Libya.

title: COMMERCE UNION CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The per share earnings reflect the 2-for-1 stock split declared yesterday.

title: Bernard Malamud Memorial
description: A memorial service for the writer Bernard Malamud, who died March 18, will be held Sunday at 10:30 A.M. at the 92d Street Y, Lexington Avenue and 92d Street. Among those scheduled to speak are Roger Straus, Robert Giroux, Daniel Stern and Cynthia Ozick.

title: Quotron Turns Down Citicorp
description: Quotron Systems Inc. said today that its board had unanimously rejected as inadequate a $680 million takeover bid by Citicorp, the nation's largest banking concern.

title: NORSTAR BANCORP INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
FINANCIAL NEWS NETWORK reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
description: b-Net loss

title: TORCHMARK CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes capital gains of $15,411,000 for the latest quarter and $2,034,000 for the year-earlier period.

title: MIDLANTIC BANKS INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
FIRST FLORIDA BANKS INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
CABARET: A TOPICAL REVUE
description: ''I'M a radical conservative with anarchistic leanings, I support the revolution to support the status quo,'' goes Ira Gasman's lyric for ''Liberal's Lament,'' one of the wittier songs in the latest version of the long-running topical revue, ''What's a Nice Country Like You . . . Doing in a State Like This?'' The show, which has played in several locales over the last 14 years, has found a new home and a new production Backstage at Hisae's Cabaret (318 West 45th Street), where it is playing eight performances a week.

title: NATIONAL CITY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
THE DANCE: ANDERSON TROUPE
description: JUDGING from the vivid passages in her dances, June Anderson is concerned with women's longings and attachments. But the two works choreographed by her that the June Anderson Dance Company presented Saturday night at the Field kept going in and out of focus.

title: EASING OF CURBS IN LAW ON FOREIGN BRIBES SOUGHT
description: Business lobbyists and their allies in Congress say that a Democratic trade bill in the House of Representatives looks like their best opportunity in years to ease the 1977 prohibition against the bribing of foreign officials by American companies.

title: Real Estate; A Gamble On Offices In Jersey
description: LESS than two years after the Lincoln Property Company, a Dallas commercial development concern, moved into the Northeast by acquiring a large tract of undeveloped land in Morris County, N.J., the company's first office project is nearing completion.

title: OLD NATIONAL BANCORP (INDIANA) reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
COUNTRYWIDE MORTGAGE reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The company began operations in September 1985.

title: U.S. Petroleum Data
description: In millions of barrels except refinery utilization

title: 1,125 World Executions Are Documented in 1985
description: There were more than 1,125 documented executions throughout the world in 1985, according to a human-rights monitoring group.

title: SHAW INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 29
Know Your Constitution
description: With the blessing of the Commission on the Bicentennial of the Constitution, a youth group is organizing a competition for as many as 24,000 high schools across the country that would test their top students' knowledge of the Constitution, producing a national winner in a final round to be held on Constitution Day, Sept. 17, 1987.

title: DANCE: JOFFREY'S 'HEART OF THE MATTER'
description: ''THE HEART OF THE MATTER,'' James Kudelka's new work for the Joffrey Ballet, retained its passion and mystery when Denise Jackson and Philip Jerry took over its principal roles on Sunday afternoon at the New York State Theater.

title: PPG INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Included interest charges of about $7 million related to a stock buyback. c-Included a gain on recovery of insurance totaling $10 million, or 14 cents a share.

title: U.N. Chief Sees Threat In New Financial Crisis
description: The largest financial crisis in the history of the United Nations threatens its viability, according to a report issued today by Secretary General Javier Perez de Cuellar.

title: CENTRAL BANKING SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
G.M.A.C. Issue
description: The General Motors Acceptance Corporation is issuing in the Eurobond market $200 million of 10 percent, three-year bonds tied to the long-term United States Treasury securities.

title: Comings and Goings
description: Ted Kluszewski, the 61-year-old former Cincinnati Reds star slugger, underwent triple bypass heart surgery in Tampa, Fla., and was reported in stable condition. . . . The Chicago White Sox sent Joe Cowley, the former Yankee pitcher, to their Class AAA club in Buffalo, and signed Bill Dawley, a free-agent relief pitcher. . . . The Phillies signed Tom Gorman, the former Met pitcher, to a one-year contract with the Portland Beavers of the Pacific Coast League.

title: Northrop Net Off 13.6%
description: The Northrop Corporation reported today that earnings fell 13.6 percent in the first quarter of 1986, despite an 18.2 percent increase in revenues. Earnings totaled $39.3 million, or 85 cents a share. Revenues rose to $1.3 billion.

title: CORESTATES FINANCIAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After income of $200,000 from discontinued operations.

title: PARLEY IN INDIA CONDEMNS BOMBINGS
description: The foreign ministers of 21 nations espousing nonalignment joined today with Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi, chairman of the nonaligned movement, in sharply condemning the American bombings in Libya and likening them to acts of terrorism.

title: SHERWIN WILLIAMS CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Share earnings reflect a 2-for-l stock split paid March 31.

title: Mexico to Let the U.S. Monitor Drug Program
description: Mexico has agreed to permit the United States to monitor the Mexican antinarcotics program more closely, a State Department official said here today.

title: PRESCRIPTIONS FOR DINING OUT: 2 HEALTH EXPERTS FACE MENUS
description: ''LOOK, there's no whole wheat bread in that basket,'' exclaims Joan Gussow, professor of nutrition and education at Teachers College at Columbia University, taking in the scene at Marcello, an East Side Italian restaurant. Not one to let such an oversight spoil her dinner, Mrs. Gussow reaches into the basket and tears off a portion of bleached-white, fiber-poor, vitamin-depleted (yet oddly satisfying) Italian bread. She smears a thin coating of butter over it.

title: HIS CONDITION IS SERIOUS; KHARTOUM SECURITY REVIEWED
description: An American communications specialist at the United States Embassy in the Sudan was shot in the head today by an unknown assailant while driving his car, the State Department said tonight.

title: CLOWNING IS MORE THAN JUST LAUGHING IT UP
description: ''Listen up!'' Frosty Little snapped at the platoon of clowns milling around backstage. ''This is Madison Square Garden. New York, New York. The big time. It's 'The Greatest Show on Earth,' and you, you are the greatest clowns on earth.''

title: PICCADILLY CAFETERIAS reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
CHARLES H. DeBOW Jr.
description: Charles Henry DeBow Jr., one of the first black pilots to serve in the Army Air Force during World War II, died in his home April 4.

title: Lionel Train Unit
description: Kenner Parker Toys Inc., spun off as a separate company by General Mills Inc. late last year, sold its Lionel train division to Richard P. Kughn, a Detroit real estate developer and avid toy train collector. Terms of the deal were not disclosed.

title: DISCOVERIES
AMERICAN FLETCHER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Severance Plan At Union Carbide
description: The Union Carbide Corporation, battered by industrial accidents and a hostile takover bid, said that it would create a special severance program for about half of the 1,200 employees it intends lay off by Sept. 30.

title: London Stock Exchange
description: Responding to demands from international traders, the London Stock Exchange said today that its trading floor would open half an hour earlier, at 9 A.M., local time (4 A.M., New York time), starting April 28.

title: From Eureka, Alaska, To a Dog's Life in the City
description: Susan Butcher and her dog Rye were in town yesterday, and Rye was not very happy.

title: CLAYTON HOMES INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
HOW TO RETURN ETHICS TO NEW YORK
description: The allegations of crimes involving New York City officials, politicians and businessmen are of grave concern to all of us. Except for two convictions, however, the criminal charges are nothing more than that -charges - and final judgment and evaluation of them must await disposition in the courts. But final judgment and evaluation of unethical conduct need not be suspended.

title: Denver Offering
description: Denver is offering $160.4 million of general obligation water refunding bonds through underwriters led by Bankers Trust.

title: CP NATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
OVERNITE TRANSPORTATION CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The share earnings were adjusted for 2-for-1 stock split paid in February.

title: INTENSE TALKS LED TO THATCHER RULING
description: Intensive negotiations over much of last week preceded Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher's politically difficult decision to agree to a request from President Reagan that American bases in Britain be used in a raid on Libya, British and American officials who took part in the discussions said here today.

title: Baylor Returns
description: As a player, he gave new meaning to the term ''hang time.'' Elgin Baylor fairly floated toward the basket as a forward for 14 years with the Minneapolis and Los Angeles Lakers.

title: ALL THAT JAZZ STILL PLAYS EVEN WITHOUT SPONSORS
description: THIS is a year of crisis for New York's two major jazz festivals. The festival that was started in Newport, R.I., 32 years ago as the Newport Jazz Festival, but was called the Kool Jazz Festival after the cigarette manufacturer took over sponsorship in 1980, was dropped by its sponsor after last year's programs. The Greenwich Village Jazz Festival, sponsored for the past four years by Dewar's White Label Scotch, learned only a few weeks ago that the whisky company would not support this summer's festival.

title: Schroeder at Piano In Stockhausen Works
description: Marianne Schroeder's afternoon of contemporary piano music at Carnegie Recital Hall Sunday gave us the kind of generous look at Karlheinz Stockhausen's piano music New Yorkers are not used to. Miss Schroeder, a young Swiss pianist, played three of Mr. Stockhausen's ''Klavierstucke'' - Nos. 8 and 9 from 1954, and the more recent No. 12.

title: N.H.L. Playoffs; Blues Advance In Norris
description: Greg Paslawski recorded three goals and two assists and Doug Gilmour added five assists tonight as the St. Louis Blues defeated the Minnesota North Stars, 6-3, in the decisive fifth game of their first-round playoff series.

title: Housing Is More Affordable Under Reagan
description: To the Editor:

title: NATHAN GOLDSTEIN, EX-CHIEF OF CIRCULATION AT TIMES, DIES
description: Nathan W. Goldstein, a longtime circulation director of The New York Times and a man legendary for his worldwide friendships, died yesterday at the Hollywood Medical Center in Hollywood, Fla. He was 78 years old and lived in Hollywood.

title: U.S. ON WORLD ALERT
description: The United States Army in Europe today ordered a curfew from midnight to 5 A.M. on 225,000 soldiers. The Air Force sent 200 more security policemen to Europe. Marines carrying submachine guns patrolled the American Embassy grounds in Mexico City.

title: CAPITAL FEDERAL SAVINGS & LOAN reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The company went public last November.

title: WINE TALK
description: ON Feb. 5, this space was used for a discussion - a criticism, actually - of the way one California concern, the William Hill Winery, has made a practice of comparing its product with first-growth Bordeaux in well-publicized public tastings around the country.

title: CONFLICT OVER AID TO VETERANS SEEN
description: The Army and Navy have begun advertising special college tuition benefits that are tied to a veterans' assistance law that President Reagan is seeking to eliminate.

title: SUPPORTERS OF MARCOS MARCH ON U.S. EMBASSY IN MANILA
description: Several thousand Filipinos supporting Ferdinand E. Marcos marched on the United States Embassy today, and hundreds camped outside overnight in anticipation of a larger demonstration called Wednesday against the United States treatment of the former President.

title: Delay Won't Improve the Contra War
description: President Reagan has yet to make any case for waging war against Nicaragua. Nobody believes that providing $100 million in supplies to the ''contra'' rebels will unseat the Sandinistas or force them to abandon power in negotiations. Since the President has defined no other objective and vows never to commit Americans to the conflict, he is asking for an indefinite commitment to an unachievable goal. On the merits, the policy still deserves rejection by the House today.

title: Economic Scene; Stockman Role In 'Revolution'
description: DAVID STOCKMAN'S new book, ''The Triumph of Politics: Why the Reagan Revolution Failed,'' paints a devastating picture of the economic incompetence and fiscal irresponsibility of the authors of that would-be revolution, including, Mr. Stockman sometimes confesses, himself.

title: TEXAS AMERICAN BANCSHARES INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income

title: BAIRNCO CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Drama Criticism Award Will Go to Jan Kott
description: Jan Kott, a writer, critic and professor, has been awarded the George Jean Nathan Award for Dramatic Criticism, it was announced by Manufacturers Hanover Trust Company, the administrators. Mr. Kott, who began his academic career in Poland, won the award for his collection of critical essays titled ''The Theater of Essence.'' He will receive a $5,000 cash award and a silver medallion.

title: PLASMA-THERM INC reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
description: b-Net loss.

title: WELLS FARGO & CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Sharp Gains At First Boston
description: First Boston Inc. said yesterday that its net income more than doubled in the first quarter, to $70.25 million, or $2.15 a share, from $26.2 million, or 93 cents a share, a year ago. Total revenues also more than doubled, to $393.9 million from $192.6 million.

title: BANCTEXAS GROUP INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Included gains from the sale of securities of $4.4 million and a gain on the sale of BancTexas Tyler of $3.4 million.

title: Worker, 32, Is Killed In Fall From Scaffold
description: A worker was killed and another was critically injured yesterday morning when their scaffold gave way and they fell 14 stories to the street, the police said.

title: Berkshire's Media Stock
description: Berkshire Hathaway Inc., a diversified holding company controlled by the Omaha investor Warren E. Buffett, sold its 8.6 percent stake in Affiliated Publications Inc. in two separate deals yesterday for a total of about $75.1 million.

title: Topics; Destinies; Bird's Luck
description: No one knows how a peregrine falcon happened to get its right wing tangled in a rope that construction workers left hanging from the deck of the Throgs Neck bridge. The creature would have died there had it not been seen by a passing barge captain.

title: GIANT YELLOWKNIFE MINES LTD reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
MARRIOTT CORPORATION reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Swanson Is the Man in Motion at ABC
description: When we last heard from him, in the middle of February, Dennis Swanson had been president of ABC Sports for only about two weeks. He talked then in confident, albeit general, terms about his determination to snap his new domain out of its financial and emotional doldrums.

title: UPJOHN CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes $673,000 in earnings from minority interest. c-Includes loss on minority interest of $1,013,000 and a loss from discontinued operations of $3,344,000. Share earnings adjusted to reflect 2-for-l stock split to be issued May 1. Company had pre-tax currency exchange losses for the latest quarter of $3.6 million, compared with a $6.4 million loss in the year-erarlier quarter.

title: In Testing Teacher Competence, New York City Leads the Way
description: To the Editor:

title: Music and Pantomime Combine in 'The Cure'
description: A bearded, hairy-chested Humpty Dumpty in white makeup and a bowler hat sits behind the door to what looks like a giant washing machine that is labeled ''clinic.'' A woman wearing a parrot beak and bright blue plumage with matching nail polish stalks around the stage with a large orange-and-black striped flashlight.

title: POLENTA MARRIES WELL WITH EVERYTHING
description: ODDLY enough, although Americans have warmly embraced Italian cooking in recent years, many people remain aloof to the joys of polenta, that sublime yet earthy creation of cornmeal whose character varies from sauce to sauce, ingredient to ingredient. Polenta, tender, moist and smacking marvelously of corn, marries well with everything from roast quail to green vegetables to basic tomato sauce.

title: BURST AGRITECH INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net loss

title: L.I.R.R. TRAINS DELAYED DURING CONTRACT DISPUTE
description: Commuters on the Long Island Rail Road ran into delays for a second consecutive day yesterday. Some trains ran as much as an hour and a half behind schedule amid a continuing dispute between labor and management over the pace of negotiations on a new contract.

title: YANKEES WIN BEHIND NIEKRO
description: Playing in near-freezing weather and a near-empty canyon of a stadium, the Yankees added another victory tonight to their most torrid start in nearly 30 years.

title: LATEST MILITARY EQUIPMENT USED IN THE LIBYAN ATTACK
description: An air and sea search for two downed Air Force crewmen - a pilot and radar-weapons officer - missing after the bombing of Libya on Monday continued after dark tonight in the Mediterranean. Late today, a Pentagon spokesman said, ''We have no evidence of survivors.''

title: Washburn Turning Pro
description: The National Basketball Association college draft, which figured to bring in more quality guards than centers, got a big lift yesterday. Jim Valvano, the North Carolina State coach, said that Chris Washburn, the Wolfpack's 6-foot-11-inch center, would give up his final two years of college eligibility and enter the June 17 draft.

title: MUSIC: NEW REICH WORK
description: MURRAY PERAHIA reached his eloquent best with the Chopin pieces that closed his piano recital at Avery Fisher Hall Sunday evening. After a generation of pianists bent on emancipating Chopin from softness and sentiment, Mr. Perahia is not afraid to let that side of the composer show. His treatment of the hesitant little theme in the A flat Ballade - and indeed of the falling octave ''filler'' that usually introduces it - was tender; one felt it as an expression of affection for the music and the instrument. The Impromptu in F sharp sang and shimmered, its mood reflective but ready to soar into fantasy for the quick filigree (superbly played) near the end.

title: Vice Chairman Leaving Occidental Petroleum
description: The Occidental Petroleum Corporation said that Zoltan Merszei, vice chairman, would resign on April 25. No explanation was given for the resignation, which was disclosed in a proxy filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission.

title: WAR COMES TO A NICARAGUAN VILLAGE
description: A force of several hundred rebels raided this remote northern village on Wednesday, burning a state-owned coffee warehouse and several homes and capturing two Sandinista militiamen and a public health worker.

title: RANGERS SHOCK FLYERS IN DECISIVE PLAYOFF GAME, 5-2
description: The Rangers, defying all the logic and all the numbers that cast them plainly as the underdog, pulled off the hockey upset of the season, this team's most magnificent moment in years.

title: COMP-U-CHECK INC reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
CANYON RESOURCES CORP reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
LSB BANCSHARES reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
NEW YORK STEPS UP SECURITY
description: Security at airports, diplomatic offices and government buildings in the New York metropolitan area was stiffened yesterday against possible retaliation for the United States attacks on Libya, law-enforcement officials said.

title: TRYING TO PUT THE PARK BACK IN CITY HALL PARK
description: These days, early green and lavender, yellow and white grace the triangular plot of City Hall Park, New York's 250-year-old common.

title: METROBANC FEDERAL SAVINGS BANK reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
LAW EASES VISITS TO CHILDREN
description: Grandparents in Nebraska can legally visit their estranged grandchildren as the result of a new law that gives the state the last word in such disputes.

title: Who Killed Frank DeCicco?
description: Will the killers of Frank DeCicco ever be brought to justice? The underboss of New York's Gambino crime family died Sunday when a bomb exploded as he opened his car door on a Brooklyn street. Does anyone care? Everyone should.

title: DOCTOR DESCRIBES 'TERROR' AMONG QADDAFI FAMILY
description: The youngest child of Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi, a 15-month-old adopted daughter named Hana, died in the attack by American fighter-bombers early this morning, according to the family pediatrician.

title: BANC ONE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
HOROWITZ PLAYS AT SCRIABIN'S HOME
description: As a steady, cold rain fell outside the yellow and white house at No. 11 Vakhtangov Street in downtown Moscow, Vladimir Horowitz rediscovered some of his musical roots by playing two Scriabin etudes on the piano in the composer's home.

title: Stan Merritt to Handle Blistex Lip Products
description: Stan Merritt Advertising of New York, a new-products development company that evolved into an agency, has just won the lip care division of Blistex Inc. of Oak Brook, Ill. Earlier this year, Merritt announced that it had landed Blistex's Health Care division.

title: ANTIFREEZE POISON FOUND IN 10 WINES
description: Federal authorities said today that they had found a toxic chemical used in some kinds of antifreeze in 10 wines from Austria, Germany and Italy, most of them premium brands. Although the level of contamination is not considered toxic, officials urged Americans not to drink the wines.

title: PRO-ISRAELI MILITIA REPORTED TO MISTREAT ARAB-AMERICAN
description: The State Department and the Israeli Embassy said today that an Arab-American was mistreated after his arrest in southern Lebanon by an Israeli-backed militia in February.

title: Philadelphia Fire Victim Is Sought in a Shooting
description: A man who lost his home in the fire after the police confrontation May 13 with the radical group Move shot and wounded his lawyer. then threatened an official in a city office building today, the police said.

title: MAYOR URGES LIMITS ON HOW CANDIDATES RAISE AND USE FUNDS
description: Mayor Koch yesterday called for sweeping changes in the state's election laws, including new limits on when a candidate could solicit campaign contributions and what they could be used for.

title: MOST ARAB NATIONS CONDEMN U.S. AS TERRORIST GROUPS ISSUE THREATS
description: Arab countries reacted today with almost universal condemnation of the American air strikes against Libya, but there were discernable differences between moderate governments that have long looked askance at Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi and radical groups who vowed immediate vengence.

title: JEAN GENET, THE PLAYWRIGHT, DIES AT 75
description: Jean Genet - playwright, novelist, poet and one of the revolutionary artists of the 20th century - died yesterday morning in the Paris hotel where he lived. He was 75 years old.

title: CASABLANCA INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes losses from discontinued operations of $74,000 for the quarter and $161,000 for the 9 months.

title: WASHINGTON MUTUAL SAVINGS BANK reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes an after-tax extraordinary loss of $1,528,000 resulting from the prepayment of Federal Home Loan Bank advances.

title: Ceco Industries Gets Buyout Offer
description: Ceco Industries said that an investment group led by senior management had proposed to buy the company for $37 a share, or $185 million. Ceco, a construction industry supplier based in Oak Brook, Ill., said the offer consisted of $34.50 in cash and $2.50 in junior subordinated debentures.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: WEDNESDAY, APRIL 16, 1986
description: Attack on Libya

title: KOPPERS CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
SECURITY PACIFIC CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
South Korea Compared To the 'Old' Philippines
description: Two Democratic Senators today compared South Korea with the Philippines before Ferdinand E. Marcos was overthrown and said the United States should do more to promote democracy in Seoul's Government.

title: U.S. COMPANIES STILL IN LIBYA
description: A Treasury official said yesterday that 10 or 11 American companies were operating in Libya under special licenses granted in February after President Reagan's severed economic relations with Tripoli.

title: AFFILIATED BANKSHARES OF COLORADO INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
EXCHANGE INTERNATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
CELTICS AND LAKERS FAVORED, BUT DON'T VIEW FOES LIGHTLY
description: Gambling that they would beat out the Cleveland Cavaliers for the Eastern Conference's eighth and final playoff berth, the Chicago Bulls began scouting the Boston Celtics. It was a wise gamble, because the Bulls will face the Celtics in the first round of the National Basketball Association playoffs.

title: ENGRAPH INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes a net gain of $136,000, or 3 cents a share, from the sale of surplus land.

title: VF CORP reports earnings for Qtr to April 5
A LOOK AT JAPAN TRADE
description: PRIME Minister Yasuhiro Nakasone visited Washington this week for talks about United States-Japanese trade; ''Adam Smith's Money World'' does a special report tonight on what the talks were about. Is it possible this is World War II-B? Mr. Smith hopes it is not, although some of the guests on the imaginative program, on Channel 13 at 10 P.M., aren't hopeful.

title: That Summit Agenda
description: On the assumption that the Libyan tensions will not wash out plans by President Reagan and Mikhail S. Gorbachev to hold a summit meeting this year, the National Conference on Soviet Jewry wants to press the participants to keep human rights on their agenda.

title: 2 BUCKLEYS BECOME BEST SELLERS
description: Being on the best-seller list is nothing new for William F. Buckley Jr. -but being on the list with his son is. And that is what will happen this Sunday, when the 60-year-old Mr. Buckley, who has written nine best sellers in the past 10 years, is joined on The New York Times fiction best-seller list by his 33-year-old son, Christopher.

title: Hull's Son Leads 9-2 U.S. Victory
description: Brett Hull, the son of the former National Hockey League star Bobby Hull, scored three goals today to lead Team USA to a 9-2 victory over West Germany in the world hockey championships.

title: Comic Strip Suspended For Political Criticism
description: The Los Angeles Times has suspended the comic strip Doonesbury for its criticism of Reagan Administration appointees accused of misconduct.

title: House of What?
description: Frank Layden, pro basketball's quotable coach: ''We got a pretty good reading on one player when we looked at the information sheet he filled out for the public relations department. On the line for church preference, he wrote down, 'Red brick.' ''

title: China Condemns Raid And All Acts of Terror
description: China officially condemned the United States attack on Libya today, but the wording of the statement and balanced coverage given the attack in the official press suggested at least some understanding for the American decision to strike.

title: FOOD NOTES
description: Tracking Bad Brie Over the last several months, bacterial contamination has been detected in some French Brie cheeses in the course of random testing by the Federal Food and Drug Administration. The affected cheeses were taken off the market and now the French Ministry of Agriculture has announced new labeling regulations for soft ripened and soft cheeses intended for export.

title: A.T.&T to Shun South Africa
description: The American Telephone and Telegraph Company, responding to a challenge by shareholding employees, will eliminate most of its direct contact with South Africa as a way to highlight its opposition to apartheid.

title: DRUG TAMPERING DATA CIRCULATED
description: The Federal Bureau of Investigation today released a tape recording and two composite sketches of a suspect in the recent contamination of Contac, Teldrin and Dietac capsules.

title: Technical Knocokut
description: Dick Young, a columnist for The New York Post, was ejected from Larry Holmes's workout yesterday on the orders of the former heavyweight boxing champion. Young was taken from the Las Vegas, Nev., workout area by three members of Holmes's camp.

description: b-Reflects loss of $3,027,714 from discontinued operations. c-Net income reflecting loss of $396,833 from discontinued operations.

title: REAGAN'S REMARKS ON RAID
description: Following is a transcript of opening remarks by President Reagan to the American Business Conference yesterday at the Old Executive Office Building in Washington, as recorded by The New York Times:

title: PPG Industries Net Off
description: PPG Industries said today that its first-quarter profits fell 14 percent, to $69.2 million, from $80.4 million a year ago. Earnings per share edged up, however, to $1.17 a share, from $1.15 in the 1985 period, after PPG bought back nearly 10.8 million shares of its common stock last fall. PPG, which makes glass, chemicals, coatings and resins, said sales rose 10 percent, to $1.14 billion, from $1.04 billion.

title: PERSONAL HEALTH
description: IN recent years, premenstrual syndrome has achieved both medical respectability and popular notoriety. After years of suffering in silence, millions of women now readily admit to experiencing premenstrual symptoms that in some cases seriously disrupt their lives. They and their families are relieved to know that the symptoms may be both biologically based and amenable to treatment.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''We would prefer not to have to repeat the events of last night.

title: MERCHANTS NATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes income of $449,000 from Farmers National Bank of Shelbyville and Central National Bank of Greencastle, acquired in January.

title: Political Novelties II
description: Then there is D. P. Given, who is challenging Representative Harley O. Staggers Jr. for the Democratic nomination in the West Virginia House district he has represented for the past two terms and his father for 16 terms before. In an effort to dislodge the Staggers family, Mr. Given is campaigning on a platform that includes requiring Congress to sit five days a week during political campaigns, fining members $100 a day for absence from the floor, limiting House members to five two-year terms, eliminating their free mailing privilege and cutting each member's staff from 18 to 3 people. This program is likely to prove more popular with the electorate than it would with the other lawmakers who would have to approve it if Mr. Given captures the House seat.

title: Marriott Income Rises
description: The Marriott Corporation said today that its first-quarter profits climbed 23.4 percent, to $34.2 million, or $1.25 a share, from $27.7 million, or $1.04 a share, a year earlier. Revenues increased to $1.03 billion, from $874.2 million a year earlier.

title: FLYERS FOILED BY RANGERS' DEFENSEMEN
description: The surprising elimination of the Flyers in the fifth and deciding game was particularly gratifying to the Rangers, a team that went through plenty of adversity during the regular season and was not supposed to be where it is now.

title: CITIZENS FINANCIAL GROUP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The year-ago quarter per share figure was not reported since the company went public in June 1985.

title: 10 ARE INDICTED IN BRIBE SCHEME AT L.I. LANDFILL
description: Five carting company officials and five employees at the Islip town landfill have been indicted for participating in a bribery scheme to cheat the town of dumping fees, officials said today. They estimated that the scheme cost the town more than half a million dollars a year.

description: b-Includes an extraordinary credit of $226,000.

title: Airman's Espionage Trial Opens
description: A court-martial opened today for an Air Force clerk accused of trying to give classified information to Soviet agents, with the defense urging the Government to pay for a psychiatrist to help prepare an insanity defense.

title: MERRY LAND & INVESTMENT reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
FIRST BOSTON INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
EASTERN CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
OFF-DUTY POLICEMAN IS ARRESTED ON ROBBERY AND DRUG CHARGES
description: An off-duty New York City police officer pulled a gun and robbed a man with whom he was waiting to buy drugs in a Bronx apartment building yesterday, the police said.

title: Republic Hearing
description: The Transportation Department rejected requests for expedited action and ordered a full hearing on the merits of the proposed acquisition of Republic Airlines Inc. by Northwest Airlines Inc. The transportation agency said it was worried that a combined Republic and Northwest might make it more difficult for a new air carrier to enter 45 pairs of cities served by the two carriers.

title: DOMINION BANKSHARES CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
FIRST VALLEY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
What Do You Play To Get a QB?
description: A young musician, about 22 years old, Lloyd Kaplan estimates, was playing a Mendelssohn violin concerto the other day on a crowded BMT platform at Union Square. Mr. Kaplan, who works in public relations, and dozens of others stood quietly in awe because, he said, ''the guy was so good.''

title: Bridge: Many Family Combinations Had Role in Playoff Events
description: The New York City Grand National playoffs last weekend were full of family features.

title: STAGE: MEREDITH MONK CHANBER-THEATER PIECE
description: FOR more than two decades, Meredith Monk has been offering up her warmly eclectic, pan-media performance events. If her latest effort, a 90-minute, two-part chamber-theater piece with music called ''Acts From Under and Above'' - presented Wednesday through Sunday nights through this weekend at La Mama E.T.C., 74A East Fourth Street - is less compelling than some of her past work, it still offers moments of real beauty and a true seismic record of the latest tremors of her soul.

title: Mother of G.I. Killed by Bomb Fears for Other Soldiers' Kin
description: The mother of Sgt. Kenneth Ford, the American soldier killed in the bombing of a West Berlin discotheque on April 5, says now that the United States has attacked Libya, she fears for mothers of other American soldiers.

title: Product Introductions Climbed Again in March
description: March new-product introductions continued strong and ahead of the same month last year, just as January and February did, according to the Dancer Fitzgerald Sample New Product News.

title: IN ONE AREA OF TRIPOLI, BOMBED HOUSES AND IRATE SURVIVORS
description: Taher Mohamed Gubbia, his voice shaking in rage, called it terrorism.

title: JAPAN ELECTIONS ARE CALLED LIKELY
description: Prime Minister Yasuhiro Nakasone seems increasingly likely to dissolve the Japanese Parliament soon and hold national elections in late June, members of his ruling Liberal Democratic Party say.

title: WEST EUROPE GENERALLY CRITICAL OF U.S.
description: Most of the allies in Western Europe criticized the attack on Libya today, and France defended its decision not to allow American planes to fly over its territory, saying that the European countries themselves should respond to the Libyan terrorist threat in Europe.

title: New York City Water Bonds
description: The New York City Municipal Water Finance Authority is offering $200 million of bonds with a maximum yield of 7.94 percent for a 7 7/8 percent issue due 2016 at a price of 99.25 through underwriters led by Morgan Stanley & Company.

title: DISCOVERY OIL LTD reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-After an extraordinary gain of $2,997,000 on debt restructuring. c-Net loss after a loss from discontinued operations of $1,017,000.

title: PILOT SAYS LIBYAN MISSILES MAY HAVE HIT TRIPOLI
description: United States airmen who took part in the bombing runs over Libya on Monday night said today that Libyan missiles might have contributed to the damage in the target cities.

title: LAWMAKERS SAY U.S. FAILED TO CONSULT THEM PROPERLY
description: Congressional leaders from both parties asserted today that the Administration had failed to consider their views adequately before ordering the air raid against Libya on Monday and that Congress should be consulted more closely before any future counterterrorist actions.

title: Enough Diplomacy in Public; Now, Quiet Talks at Geneva
description: Secretary of State George P. Shultz was absolutely right when he noted last month that arms control negotiations between the United States and the Soviet Union ''are not going anywhere'' until Moscow and Washington agree to stop conducting their diplomacy in public. My own 10 years' experience of negotiating with the Soviet Union convince me that no satisfactory agreements can be arrived at so long as proposals and counterproposals are made publicly. The time has long since passed for a return to quiet negotiations.

title: TRANSCANADA ENDS LATEST WALKER BID
description: Transcanada Pipelines Ltd. said in Toronto yesterday that, in view of a higher bid from the Reichmann family of Canada, it was withdrawing its own offer to pay $26.39 a share, or $3 billion, for Hiram Walker Resources Ltd.

title: Key Rates
description: * Municipal Bond Index, The Bond Buyer Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: SAN FRANCISCO BATTLES TORPOR ON QUAKE PLANNING
description: While Californians have begun to do more to prepare for a major earthquake than previously, public safety officials say much remains to be done and that the state is in a race against time to reduce the casualties in an inevitable disaster.

title: CALIFORNIA FIRST BANK reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Resorts Appoints President as Chief
description: Resorts International Inc., the hotel and gambling concern, has named its president, I.G. (Jack) Davis Jr., to the additional position of chief executive. Mr. Davis, 61 years old, succeeds James M. Crosby, the former chairman and chief executive, who died last week.

title: Barnett to Acquire Thrift Institution
description: Barnett Banks of Florida Inc. said that it had agreed to acquire the United First Federal Savings and Loan Association, a thrift institution based in Sarasota, Fla., for $116 million.

title: CUOMO'S RADIO SPOT: A FADE-OUT AMID MIXED REVIEWS
description: After 10 months and 96 broadcasts, Governor Cuomo's commentary spot on nationwide radio has been halted. While Mr. Cuomo and his partner in the program, former Senator Howard H. Baker Jr., said they had to withdraw because of other commitments, some radio stations said they had been unable to attract listener or advertiser interest in it.

title: Pavelich Refuses To Sing the Blues
description: He quit the Rangers more than a month ago, saying he could no longer play for Coach Ted Sator, and last night, with his old teammates embarked on their biggest mission in a very long while, Mark Pavelich said he felt no pangs, no regrets about missing out on a climactic moment. He wished the guys well, he said, but he wasn't planning to even watch on TV while they faced the Philadelphia Flyers in a decisive first-round playoff game.

title: 60-MINUTE GOURMET
description: IN recent months countless words have been written about a ''resurgence'' of American cooking and an interest in American products, including goat cheese and foie gras. This culinary American pride has been reflected in subtle ways in my own kitchen, which is, of course, basically French. I have experimented, for example, with crepes made of cornmeal as a base for caviar and sour cream. Most recently, my family and friends found pleasure in platters of assorted seafoods that were dipped in a cornmeal batter before deep frying. The cornmeal gave the food an admirable texture and a nutty flavor.

title: Living and Working in the Gaza Strip
description: To the Editor:

description: b-Net loss. Company didn't report share earnings because it was still a wholly owned subsidiary of MGM-UA Entertainment Co. during the periods covered; it became an independent public company in March 1986.

title: STAGE: TAIT'S 'SH-BOOM!'
description: ERIC V. TAIT JR.'s musical ''Sh-Boom!'' remembers a momentous turning point in American pop history, when the black vocal-group sound now known as ''doo-wop'' began to infuse the sanitized mainstream with an irresistible, open sensuality.

description: A Communist Party newspaper published an article by the poet Yevgeny Yevtushenko today in which he criticized censorship and dogmatism in Soviet life and said ''public silence is a hidden form of anarchy.''

title: CONTRAS' BACKERS LOSE A CLOSE VOTE ON HOUSE DEBATE
description: The House of Representatives, opening its second round of debate on military aid to the rebels in Nicaragua, approved a debating procedure today that supporters of the aid said was designed to kill or delay it.

description: More than 1,500 people, including three busloads of Congressmen and Capitol Hill staff, Mayor Koch and Governor Cuomo, crowded St. Patrick's Cathedral yesterday to mourn Representative Joseph P. Addabbo of Queens.

title: Change Ordered in 747's
description: The Federal Aviation Administration has ordered a modification of all Boeing 747 jets in an effort to avert accidents like the one that killed 520 people aboard a Japan Air Lines flight last year. The directive requires that a cover plate be placed over an access door in the tail section of the plane, to prevent a rush of pressurized air from damaging the tail and critical control lines if the rear cabin wall fails. The Boeing Company made a similar recommendation last year.

title: APRIL 1-10 CAR SALES UP BY 2.3%
description: Sales of new American-made automobiles bounced up slightly in early April, the manufacturers reported today, finishing 2.3 percent ahead of the 1985 period.

title: KREMLIN CALLS OFF TALKS ON SUMMIT
description: The Soviet Union responded today to the American military attack on Libya by canceling a planned meeting between Secretary of State George P. Shultz and Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze in mid-May.

No Arrests in Khartoum
description: There were no arrests by early this morning in the shooting of the American Embassy employee, and it was unclear whether the attack was connected to protests here over the American attack on Libya.

description: OLIVE oil is good for you. Indeed, the latest research indicates that olive oil is probably better for you than any other kind of fat.

description: For a brief moment a few hours before dusk today, this tiny, isolated island between Libya and Sicily became enmeshed in the conflict between Libya and the United States.

STAGE: 'COUNTRY DOCTOR,' AN ADAPTION OF KAFKA
description: IN the current Nuremberg exhibition at the Metropolitan Museum of Art, there is a sculpture entitled ''The Prince of the World.'' From the front, we see the figure of an elegant young man, but, from the rear, he is being eaten alive by grotesque creatures. The image in that sculpture, a representation of the Devil himself, is evoked in Franz Kafka's haunting short story ''A Country Doctor.''

title: CAMPAIGN AGAINST HOLIDAY GOUGING
description: AS Passover approaches and consumers stock up on kosher foods, one New York City inspector and 40 volunteers - in separate citywide operations - are recording prices in campaigns against gouging. Indeed, New York State officials consider the problem so serious that this month they plan to begin a study of preholiday and year-round kosher food costs.

title: Infant Twin Boys Died From Skull Fractures
description: A preliminary autopsy report on twin 3-week-old boys found dead Monday in their apartment in Brooklyn showed yesterday that both died of skull fractures, the police said.

title: S.E.C. Cites Spangler
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission has charged a prominent financial consultant, Mark E. Spangler, with violating Federal law by lying about his academic credentials, forging an audit document and misrepresenting his record on Wall Street.

title: LED STATE DURING RACE BATTLE
description: J. Lindsay Almond Jr., who was Governor of Virginia through the stormy school integration battles of the late 1950's, died of pnuemonia Monday at Humana Hospital-St. Luke's in Richmond. He was 87 years old and lived in Roanoke.

title: SULZBERGER HONORED FOR HIS DEDICATION TO FIRST AMENDMENT
description: The Center for Communication yesterday presented Arthur Ochs Sulzberger, the publisher of The New York Times, with its annual Communication Award for his commitment to the First Amendment and journalistic excellence.

title: PILOTS' GROUP VOTES TO BOYCOTT NATIONS PROMOTING TERRORISM
description: The International Air Line Pilots Association has authorized boycotts of countries that promote terrorist acts against civil aviation or fail to provide adequate airport security, the 60-nation group announced yesterday.

title: Keep TV Cameras Out of Courtrooms
description: To the Editor:

title: Art Blakey Performs With Jazz Messengers
description: Art Blakey's Jazz Messengers, which has usually been a quintet since the group was founded in 1956 but has occasionally expanded to a sextet or a septet, was in a septet phase at Sweet Basil, where it played through Sunday.

title: SUNDSTRAND CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Latest quarter results reflect the acquisition of Turbomach in July 1985.

title: DOCUMENTARY EXAMINES CAREER OF JACK KEROUAC
description: WHATEVER one thinks of Jack Kerouac's work, more than 16 years after his death, his career continues to exert fascination. That may have less to do with his books than with his role as the inventor of the beat movement, which William Burroughs claims in ''What Happened to Kerouac?'' incited ''a worldwide unprecedented cultural revolution.''

title: NYNEX CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The share earnings reflect 2-for-1 stock split in the form of a 100-percent stock dividend announced on March 20, 1986, payable May 1.

title: SECRET CREDIT UNION FILES FOUND
description: Secret numbered accounts and accounts in fictitious names were illegally set up at a Brooklyn credit union under investigation for misuse of funds and for business links to the city's former taxi chief, Jay L. Turoff, state and Federal banking authorities said yesterday.

title: Elder to Defend
description: Lee Elder will defend his $250,000 Commemorative Pro-Am Golf Championship at Sleepy Hollow Country Club in Scarborough-on-Hudson, N.Y., July 31-Aug. 3. Tickets can be obtained through the March of Dimes, the official tournament beneficiary. Tickets will be limited to 5,000 season badges and 2,000 daily tickets.

title: CHI CHI AND THE BEAR
description: In winning his sixth Masters at age 46, Jack Nicklaus fulfilled Chi Chi Rodriguez's description of him as ''a legend in his spare time.'' The twist is that the Golden Bear credits the sharpening of his short-game claws at Augusta National to tips his oldest son and caddie, Jackie, received last year during Chi Chi's spare time in Puerto Rico.

title: CRUMP, E H COMPANIES reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes equity in earnings of Southern American Insurance Co. of $352,000 in the latest quarter and $346,000 in the earlier period. c-Includes income of $41,000 from discontinued operations.

title: IS RADIATION THE ANSWER TO SPOILED FOOD?
description: Last week, the Commissioner of the Food and Drug Administration, Dr. Frank E. Young, announced at a Congressional hearing that his agency would soon permit the irradiation of fresh fruits and vegetables. Tuesday, the F.D.A. made that approval official.

title: CONSOLIDATED OIL & GAS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
description: b-Includes an extraordinary gain from early retirement of debentures of $5,000. c-Net income includes an extraordinary gain of $24,000.

title: U.S. AIRFIELDS IN BRITAIN: LEGACY OF WORLD WAR II
description: This air base is British property, comes under the nominal command of a Royal Air Force officer, operates under British air traffic control and is called R.A.F. Mildenhall. But the servicemen stationed here use American dollars, buy American-style hamburgers, watch United States television shows at the Bob Hope Recreation Center, and this morning, while viewing the first reports on the Libyan raid, let out some unmistakably American cheers.

title: ON CBS, AN HOURLONG CELEBRATION OF THE CIRCUS
description: JUST when you might feel too jaded for still another look at the circus, along comes the 116th edition of the Ringling Brothers and Barnum & Bailey extravaganza and, ladies and gentlemen and children of all ages, you're hooked once again. Or at least I was while watching a condensed version of the show in a CBS special that can be seen at 8 o'clock this evening.

title: SIERRACIN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income c-Includes tax credit of $582,000.

CENTURY COMMUNICATIONS reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
