title: MUSIC: 'PIERROT LUNAIRE'
description: THE tension between poetry and music is heightened to hypersensitivity in Schoenberg's ''Pierrot Lunaire.'' In this setting of 21 poems by Albert Giraud - by turns cruel, sentimental, sensual, wistful, garish - the two media skirmish endlessly, each making its dangerous incursions.

title: 10 Are Arrested In Soccer Betting
description: Ten Italians have been arrested and two others are sought in connection with the country's second major illegal soccer betting scandal in six years, officials said today.

title: BANKERS TRUST NEW YORK CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Investment securities gains in the latest first quarter were $570,000, compared with $9.3 million for the year-earlier period.

title: 6 GOVERNORS ASK FOR FEDERAL TAX ON IMPORTED OIL
description: Arguing that the plunge in world oil prices was posing a grave threat to national security, the Governors of six major energy-producing states called on President Reagan and Congress today to impose a temporary tax on imported oil to prop up the faltering domestic oil and gas industry.

title: AT COLLABORATOR'S TRIAL, YUGOSLAVS FACE THEIR PAST
description: Andrija Artukovic, the Croat accused of being a war criminal, said today that when he was Interior Minister in the Nazi puppet regime he never knew that Serbs, Jews and Gypsies were being killed, and he denied he ever visited any of the death camps established by the Government he served.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: WEDNESDAY, APRIL 16, 1986
description: International

title: DAUGHTER OF QADDAFI IS SAID TO HAVE DIED
description: The American planes that attacked early today struck a number of military targets, including the headquarters compound of the Libyan leader, Colonel Muammar el-Qaddafi, a naval academy and air bases here and in Bengazi. There was also damage in a residential neighborhood in the capital.

title: G.N.P. COULD FORCE DEFICIT-LAW VOTE
description: Congressional aides have started to plan for the possibility that weakness in the economy will soon prompt an automatic reconsideration of the new budget-balancing law.

title: Hank Crawford Plays Alto Saxophone Solos
description: The alto saxophonist Hank Crawford, on one of his infrequent New York visits, held listeners spellbound with solo after solo Sunday at the Apollo Theater. As the special guest of the keyboardist Jimmy McGriff's quintet, he made an afternoon of suave blues and funk into an occasion.

title: KILLERS EXECUTED IN SEPARATE CASES
description: Two men convicted of murder were executed a half day apart yesterday and today, one for the killing of a professor and the raping of his wife in Florda and the other for the strangulation of a minister's wife in Texas.

title: CARNEGIE HALL'S PLANS
description: Carnegie Hall's truncated 1986-87 season will formally open on Dec. 16 with a concert by the Orchestra of St. Luke's conducted by Michael Tilson Thomas, the hall announced yesterday. But prior to the Dec. 16 concert will be an as-yet-unannounced gala reopening of the hall, following its seven-month closing for renovation.

title: BOMB THREATS DISRUPT DAY AT BUILDINGS IN WASHINGTON
description: Bomb threats to offices of Government agencies and news organizations briefly disrupted activities around the capital today. The police said the telephoned threats had apparently been the work of cranks rather than terrorists.

title: STALIN GRANDCHILD IS BACK IN BRITAIN
description: The American granddaughter of Stalin returned to Britain today after 18 months in the Soviet Union, saying she was glad for the experience but happy to be back in the West.

title: Sharp Moves in Bond Trading
description: The bond market fluctuated sharply yesterday but ended little changed as many investors took to the sidelines worried by possible repercussions from the military attack on Libya.

title: Supreme Court; Brennan: 30 Years and the Thrill Is Not Gone
description: Associate Justice William J. Brennan Jr., hero to many liberals, target of conservative ire, laughed softly when asked if it had been a thrill to be part of the liberal majority under Chief Justice Earl Warren two decades ago that transformed constitutional law and made the Supreme Court an engine of social reform.

title: Berra's Hot Topic
description: Yogi Berra, feeling at home in Houston, on why he doesn't miss Yankee pinstripes: ''Uniforms weigh the same. Some are just hotter than others.''

title: CATERPILLAR TRACTOR CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes a tax credit of $16,000,000. c-Net loss

title: Books of The Times: 'The Private Life of Axie Reed'
description: In ''A Separate Peace,'' his most famous novel, and in such lesser-known works as ''The Paragon'' and ''Morning in Antibes,'' John Knowles demonstrated a seemingly durable, if slender, talent for delineating the emotional geometry connecting members of certain rarefied worlds (prep school, Yale University, the Riviera) in deft, coolly-refined prose. ''The Private Life of Axie Reed'' also takes place against a backdrop of wealth and privilege -most of it is set in Southampton, L.I. - but it surprisingly evinces none of Mr. Knowles's usual gifts. The book is obvious, poorly written and perfunctory in both tone and execution. It reads like the sort of name-brand schlock novel one might buy at an airport, though it lacks the tarted-up sex scenes and epic length associated with that form. <TD WIDTH=2

title: MUSIC: A TRIBUTE TO ENSLEY
description: ERNIE ENSLEY, a black New Yorker who grew up in Harlem and the Bronx, first encountered Latin Music when he visited the Palladium Ballroom as a teen-ager. ''As I climbed the long stairs up to the ballroom, I heard this exotic music,'' he recently told the Latin music historian Max Salazar. ''All of a sudden, I felt the adrenalin working, my heart pounding. When I passed the entrance to the dance floor and I saw the dancers' slick moves and turns to Machito's 'Asia Minor,' I was hooked.''

title: Political Novelties I
description: Venturesome candidates around the country may or may not want to follow the lead of Walter Dartland, a Democrat who is running for Attorney General of Florida. He has served as consumer advocate of Dade County since 1975, and his campaign literature for state office reflects that background.

title: Volcker Plea On Policy
description: Paul A. Volcker, the Federal Reserve chairman, said today that coordinated action by the major industrial countries is needed to spur economic growth and bring down interest rates.

title: Getting Chicken in Shape
description: I LEARNED early in my career that the secret to good cooking is treating the simplest dish with the same care lavished on more elaborate preparations. This can be most clearly seen in homespun roast chicken, which, to my taste, is among the most succulent meals - when done properly.

title: FIFTH THIRD BANCORP (CINCINNATI, OHIO)(O) reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
ELDORADO BANCORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
OUTLOOK IS SHAKY FOR A TRADITIONAL SOCCER POWER
description: Three times world soccer champion and perennial star of the world's most popular sports event, Brazil is bracing itself for disappointment in the quadrennial World Cup tournament that begins May 31 in Mexico.

title: SWITZERLAND FREEZES DUVALIER ACCOUNTS
description: The Swiss Government has notified Haiti that it has frozen the Swiss bank assets of former President Jean-Claude Duvalier, Haiti's Minister of Justice said today.

title: BOOKLET CITES FINANCIAL TRAPS
description: They are young and strong and have been exposed to college - and many of them do not have the foggiest idea about what to do with the $150,000, or more, that suddenly is theirs every season if they make it in pro football.

title: CALIFORNIA IS OFFERING PRISON AND WATER BONDS
description: Bonds for prison construction were among the larger deals in the tax-exempt market yesterday when California began offering $395 million of general obligation bonds for the purpose of financing the construction of new state prisons and for water treatment facilities, as well as sewer treatment facilities.

title: CORRECTION
description: A chart in Business Day yesterday with an article about The Detroit News and The Detroit Free Press reversed the ''Publications'' listings for the two papers' parent companies. The Gannett Company, parent of The News, owns 91 daily newspapers, 40 non-daily papers and a Sunday magazine. Knight-Ridder Newspapers Inc., parent of The Free Press, owns 28 daily newspapers and 5 suburban papers and partly owns 2 other daily papers.

title: Bronfmans Bickering In the Press Over Heir
description: Veteran watchers of the Seagram Company are scratching their heads over a highly unusual spat being conducted in the press between Edgar M. Bronfman and his younger brother, Charles. The issue is who will run the company when Edgar, Seagram's 56-year-old chairman and chief executive, finally decides to retire.

title: Advertising; Hutton Enlists Bill Cosby
description: E.F. HUTTON, in the process of rebuilding its image after last year's bank-draft scandal, has signed a ''long-term'' advertising deal with Bill Cosby, who has become America's most-trusted entertainer.

title: COMPUTER PRODUCTS INC reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: Results are revised for 1985 because of internal accounting irregularities. The company originally reported a year-end net of $6,545,000, or 34 cents a share, and sales of $92,482,000.

title: AT HIGH POINT MARKET: COMFORT IS MOTORIZED
description: FURNITURE buyers from around the nation convene here at the Southern Furniture Market twice a year to buy for department and furniture stores back home. At the spring market, which began April 10 and will continue through April 18, they found that new furniture introductions generally avoided extremes in favor of conservative designs and the perennial classics.

title: HELIONETICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes a loss from discontinued operations of $7,682,200 for the latest quarter and income from discontinued operations of $307,100 for year- ago quarter. c-Net income. d-Includes a loss from discontinued operations of $8,365,600 for the latest year and net from discontinued operations of $564,400 for the prior year.

title: TELEFLEX INCORPORATED reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes a charge of $680,000 for settlement of a legal matter.

title: ROHM & HAAS CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
MARINE CORP (WISCONSIN)(O) reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The per share earnings are fully diluted.

title: SOME PLANES DIDN'T DROP THEIR BOMBS
description: Military officials concluded today that two Air Force aviators missing after a bombing strike on Libya died when their plane crashed, and reported that several of the 33 American attack aircraft never dropped their bombs.

title: GREEK CYPRIOT IS CALLED COOL TO THE LATEST U.N. UNITY PLAN
description: President Spyros Kyprianou, the Greek Cypriot leader, has decided to ask for major revisions of a United Nations plan for the reunification of Cyprus, according to an informed Cypriot source.

title: UNIVERSITY PRESIDENTS LOBBY TO STOP U.S. EDUCATION CUTS
description: President Reagan's proposed cuts in education spending will force most of the five million students receiving Government financial aid to drop out of school or change their college plans, more than 50 college and university presidents said in a joint statement today.

title: But Can the 4-Year-Olds Get Quality Schooling?
description: To the Editor:

title: CROWN CORK & SEAL CO INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
INTERSTATE BAKERIES CORP reports earnings for 16wks to March 8
description: b-Includes net from discontinued operations of $2,550,000 and after an extraordinary credit of $120,000. c-Includes income tax benefit of $188,000 and after an extraordinary credit of $190,000. d-Includes plant closing expenses of $3,750,000, an income tax benefit of $1,305,000, income from discontinued operations of $2,550,000 and an extraordinary credit of $790,000. e-Includes after an extraordinary credit of $1,498,000.

title: Advertising; Mellon Account Goes To Saatchi & Saatchi
description: Saatchi & Saatchi Compton is soon to get a payback on the investment it made in acquiring the Siegel & Gale agency here last year.

title: CORRECTION
description: Our Tuesday editorial ''A Reunion of Brothers'' erred in stating that Pope John XXIII presided at the 1965 Vatican Council. He inspired it but died two years before its landmark declaration, ''Nostra Aetate.''

title: CHINESE REBUFFING SOVIET ON PARLEY
description: The Chinese Government today rejected a Soviet suggestion that the two nations hold a summit meeting, calling the idea ''unrealistic.''

title: COURSE FOR MASTERS IS PLAYING LONGER
description: Hubert Green, last year's PGA champion and the United States Open champion in 1977, said it was not the fast greens at Augusta National Golf Club that made putting such an adventure in the first two rounds of the Masters last week.

title: ATHENS FEDERAL SAVINGS BANK reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Brendel to Play Liszt
description: The pianist Alfred Brendel will play an all-Liszt program at Carnegie Hall Monday night to commemorate the 100th anniversary of the composer's death. In his only solo New York recital of the season, Mr. Brendel will play ''Les Annees de Pelerinage,'' a two-part work consisting of ''Premiere Annee: Suisse'' and ''Deuxieme Annee: Italie.'' Mr. Brendel also will appear in concert with the New York Philharmonic on May 1, 2, 3 and 6, playing concertos by Mozart and by Schoenberg.

title: DANCE: SECOND AVENUE COMPANY
description: ARTISTIC theory and practice were happily united when the Second Avenue Dance Company, a student group from New York University, appeared Monday night at the university's Tisch School of the Arts.

title: REYNOLDS METALS CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes a gain of $4.2 million, or 19 cents a share, from use of tax credits. c-Includes a $2.5 million gain from settlement of legal actions.

title: SOUTHEASTERN MICHIGAN GAS ENTERPRISES INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
On Alert
description: With the exception of a few high-security buildings such as the Pentagon, State Department offices, the White House and the Capitol that are guarded by the Secret Service or other police, most Government-owned buildings in the District of Columbia are protected by the General Services Administration. Since a bomb attack on the Capitol in 1983, all those guards have been on a permanent state of ''gray alert,'' the lowest of three alert categories.

title: N.C.A.A. Backs Move
description: The National Collegiate Athletic Association Council has upheld the decision by its infractions committee to declare Chana Perry ineligible for the women's basketball team at Northeast Louisiana University, Jack Davis, president of the N.C.A.A., said. Officials of Northeast Louisiana said the school would not pursue the matter in the courts. In January, the N.C.A.A. made Northeast Louisiana the first women's program to receive a public penalty in connection with the recruitment of Miss Perry, a 6-4 sophomore forward from Mississippi.

title: SMALL RISE IN OUTLAYS EXPECTED
description: United States manufacturers expect to increase capital spending this year by only nine-tenths of 1 percent, the smallest increase since 1983, the Commerce Department reported yesterday.

title: PIANO: MURRAY PERAHIA
description: MURRAY PERAHIA reached his eloquent best with the Chopin pieces that closed his piano recital at Avery Fisher Hall Sunday evening. After a generation of pianists bent on emancipating Chopin from softness and sentiment, Mr. Perahia is not afraid to let that side of the composer show. His treatment of the hesitant little theme in the A flat Ballade - and indeed of the falling octave ''filler'' that usually introduces it - was tender; one felt it as an expression of affection for the music and the instrument. The Impromptu in F sharp sang and shimmered, its mood reflective but ready to soar into fantasy for the quick filigree (superbly played) near the end.

title: SISTER SUSPECTED IN TWINS' DEATH
description: Police investigators now believe that twin 3-week-old boys who died Monday in Brooklyn were fatally injured by their 3 1/2-year-old sister, law-enforcement officials said yesterday.

title: 4 Transit Employees Burned in Explosion
description: Four employees of the Transit Authority were burned yesterday, one seriously, when an electrical transformer exploded at a substation at 126 West 53d Street, between the Avenue of the Americas and Seventh Avenue.

title: DAYTON POWER & LIGHT INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
KOCH URGES MAJOR REZONING IN 4 BOROUGHS TO ADD HOUSING
description: Mayor Koch announced yesterday that his administration wants to rezone almost half the city - allowing greater population density in many of the residential neighborhoods outside Manhattan - as one way to spur private developers to build ''large-scale, moderate-income housing.''

title: HELIX TECHNOLOGY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Tax-Free Bonds That Subsidize Business
description: To the Editor:

title: HARTFORD NATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
A Toy Train Collector Finds a Niche at Lionel
description: Richard P. Kughn has been collecting toy trains since he was 7 years old. Now 56, the Detroit real estate developer has amassed thousands of train cars.

title: MUSIC: NEW WORK BY LIFCHITZ
description: MANNES COLLEGE OF MUSIC, the venturesome school on West 85th Street, began a two-part ''Contemporary Music Festival'' Tuesday with a recital dominated by the Mannes Percussion Ensemble under Howard Van Hyning. One new work was on the bill: ''Rhythmic Soundscape No. 5'' by Max Lifchitz, who completed it this year and was on hand to make some engaging remarks about it and to play the piano part.

title: G.E. Is Offering Notes, Eurobonds
description: The General Electric Company, selling debt for the third time in a week, is offering $500 million of 6 7/8 percent notes due 1991 at a price of 99 7/8, to yield 6.905 percent, through underwriters led by Morgan Stanley & Company.

title: A REAGAN AIDE ASSERTS TAX BILL IS 'MORIBUND'
description: With the Senate Finance Committee continuing to approve generous tax benefits for a wide variety of Americans, a senior White House official questioned today whether the drive for tax-revision legislation could be sustained.

title: COMMERCE BANCSHARES INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
HERMAN'S SPORTING GOODS reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Merck Posts 20% Rise
description: Merck & Company, citing the positive impact of the weakening dollar, said earnings in the first quarter rose 20 percent, to $157.8 million, or $2.25 a share, from $131.5 million, or $1.83 a share in the period a year ago.

title: CONRAIL BOARD MEMBER IS REMOVED BY DOLE
description: Transportation Secretary Elizabeth Hanford Dole removed Daniel B. Burke from the board of directors of Conrail today and replaced him with Claud L. Gingrich, a former general counsel to the Office of the United States Trade Representative.

title: Topics; Proposal/Disposal; Sidewalk Surplus
description: The cherry trees have already bloomed; magnolia and dogwood can't be far behind; and New York's sidewalks are blooming too, with couches, ironing boards, loudspeakers, lamps.

title: Comings and Goings
description: Denny Crum, coach of the Louisville team that won the national championship, has been named college basketball coach of the year by The Sporting News. Crum also won the award in 1983. . . . Jack Nicklaus will play in the $500,000 Houston Open at the Woodlands Country Club April 24-27, for the first time since 1977. . . . John Candelaria, the California Angels' 31-year-old left-hander, underwent elbow surgery and will miss at least two months of the season, He was placed on the 21-day disabled list retroactive to April 11. . . .Jim Ryun, the former world-record holder in the mile, acquired a partner for the Trevira Twosome 10-mile run April 26 in Central Park. She is Jan Merrill of New London, Conn., who between 1976 and 1980 broke every American record from 1,000 to 5,000 meters.

title: BARD, C R INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
KANSAS CITY SOUTHERN RY reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes a gain from the sale of a television station of $11.3 million.

title: SOCIETY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
FLORIDA FEDERAL SAVINGS & LOAN ASSN reports earnings for Qtr March 31
description: b-Includes gains of $8.4 million on the sale of securities and a charge of $8.4 million from a provision for loan losses. c-Includes an extraordinary credit of $1,622,644.

title: A Monument to Immigration Takes Form in New York Harbor
description: To the Editor:

title: FOES OF PRETORIA SEEK WHITE ALLIES
description: To the strains of a black nationalist anthem, and in the face of reported bomb threats, South Africa's largest nonparliamentary opposition movement has begun a new campaign to draw whites into its battle against minority rule.

title: BANKAMERICA CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
U.S., FEARING 'ANOTHER TEHERAN,' PLANS PARTIAL PULLOUT FROM SUDAN
description: The United States has ordered the evacuation of the 200 dependents of American Embassy personnel in the Sudan because of concern over Libyan-directed violence against Americans there, Administration officials said today.

title: HOUGHTON MIFFLIN CHANGE
description: Houghton Mifflin has merged its trade book and reference book opera-tions into a single division headed by Austin G. Olney, who has been named director. Nan Talese, editor in chief of adult trade books, has been named to the additional post of publisher of adult trade books.

title: SOVRAN FINANCIAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The latest first quarter includes results of D.C. National Bancorp from the date of its acquisition March 10. The year-ago results have been restated on a pooling-of-interests basis, effective March 31, 1986.

title: TUROFF LAWYER DECLARES PANEL LACKS EVIDENCE
description: The lawyer for Jay L. Turoff, the city's former Taxi Commissioner, said yesterday that state investigators had no evidence to support allegations that his client committed corrupt acts while in office.

title: Some Shifts at Top At Republic Bank
description: The Republic Bank of New York, the principal subsidiary of the Republic New York Corporation, announced a number of shifts in its top management yesterday.

title: 2 MORE DISTRICTS TOLD NOT TO SHUT OVER PASSOVER
description: Schools Chancellor Nathan Quinones overruled two Community School Boards yesterday and ordered that schools in their districts remain open for the first two days of Passover.

title: MUSIC: OZAWA CONDUCTS MESSIAEN
description: OLIVIER MESSIAEN'S first and thus far only opera, ''St. Francis of Assisi,'' had its world premiere in Paris three years ago under the baton of Seiji Ozawa, who brought the work to Carnegie Hall Wednesday night in an abridged concert version. Mr. Ozawa, the Boston Symphony, the Tanglewood Festival Chorus and a quartet of vocal soloists performed three of the opera's eight scenes, thereby allowing us a generous sample of a major effort by a celebrated composer. Mr. Messiaen, who has served as scout master and guardian angel to an entire generation of the musical avant-garde, labored for nearly eight years over this work and his struggles are all too evident at times.

title: STORAGE TECHNOLOGY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes a tax credit of $2,005,000, or 6 cents a share. c-Net loss and includes a charge of $16,191,000 from the cumulative effect of an accounting change related to the company's policy on recognition of revenue.

title: INMATE IS GIVEN LETHAL INJECTION AFTER APOLOGIZING FOR HIS CRIMES
description: A man convicted of raping and killing the wife of a minister who had befriended him was executed by injection early today after telling witnesses that he deserved to die.

title: TOWN PUTS PRIDE IN HOLMES CORNER
description: This is the week when many local people hope for many happy returns.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: CRABGRASS FRONTIER: The Suburbanization of the United States. By Kenneth T. Jackson. 396 pages. Illustrated. Oxford University Press. $21.95.

title: EUROPEAN TRIP CANCELLATIONS GROWING AFTER RAID ON LIBYA
description: Officials in the travel industry across the country yesterday reported a surge in cancellations by travelers to Europe in the two days since the American bombing raids against Libya.

title: THE DANCE: JESSE DURANCEAU
description: JESSE DURANCEAU and the Gathering Wood company of dancers, musicians and visual artists presented an ambitious program on Tuesday at the Washington Square Church. Mr. Duranceau, a likable-looking performer who has appeared with the Erick Hawkins Dance Company, created sets, headdresses and snowshoes as well as choreography for the program. With all those interests, it wasn't surprising that his dance seemed the work of someone who wasn't driven to choreograph but enjoyed arranging movement around given situations, rather in the way of a musical theater choreographer.

title: HUNTINGTON BANCSHARES INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The year-ago figures were adjusted to reflect the merger with Commonwealth Trust Bancorp in January. The per share earnings reflect a 2-for-1 stock split paid in July.

title: Advertising; McCann-Erickson Gets More A.H.P. Business
description: When McCann-Erickson was assigned Dristan Mist and a new product by the Whitehall division of American Home Products last September, it was the office's first A.H.P. assignment. Yesterday, it announced that the company's Boyle-Midway division was slipping it four brands that collectively bill between $10 million and $15 million.

title: Advertising; New York Woman Magazine
description: ''WE are not linear; we are talking about a sensibility defined by a locale,'' Betsy Carter said, explaining the special New York woman who lives all over the world and will be the target audience of New York Woman magazine.

title: HAWAIIAN ELECTRIC INDUSRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
JAZZ: HAMPTON FESTIVAL
description: THE second of the three professional nights of the Lionel Hampton Jazz Festival at Manhattan Community College last weekend, preceded by an evening devoted to high school jazz groups, was divided between four diverse aspects of jazz: the Joe Newman Quintet representing mainstream jazz; the Dave Valentin Quintet, which was more contemporary, both in its choice of material and its use of an electric bass; the singer Betty Carter, who put standard songs through her own mill of stylization, and the Manhattan School of Music Jazz Ensemble, a ''stage band'' that drew on jazz material from the 1920's to the present.

title: LANDMARK BANCSHARES CORPORATION reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Finding Services
description: A free guide on finding what one needs among the thousands of health and social-service sources has been published by the Community Council of Greater New York.

title: GREAT WESTERN SYSTEMS reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
RANGERS SAVOR UNLIKELY VICTORY
description: One player said he was finally able to sleep well. Another said he could hardly sleep at all. Coach Ted Sator sat in his office and, as rationally and unemotionally as ever, discussed the whys and hows of the great upset. But then he finished by saying: ''Don't get me wrong. This was a victory against all odds.''

title: FIRST KENTUCKY NATIONAL CORPORATION reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Dealing With Development
description: The humanizing effect of art can be seen in a small exhibition of photographs and sculpture models of works in La Defense, the huge commercial zone north of Paris.

title: SPACE PANEL DOUBTS IT CAN PINPOINT DISASTER CAUSE
description: Members of the Presidential commission investigating the space shuttle disaster said today that they do not expect to be able to identify the precise cause of the explosion that destroyed the Challenger on Jan. 28.

title: UNITED JERSEY BANKS INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
UNION PACIFIC CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
APPLE BANK FOR SAVINGS reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After an extraordinary tax credit of $1,503,000.

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL BOSTON (AL) - Placed Wes Gardner, pitcher, on the 15-day disabled list retroactive to Monday.

title: NETS' KEY MATCHUP: WOHL VS. NELSON
description: When studying the matchup between two teams in the National Basketball Association playoffs, most observers tend to focus on the players. But when the Nets take the floor at the Mecca in Milwaukee tomorrow night for the opener of their three-of-five-game series against the Bucks, the most intriguing - and perhaps the most critical - matchup will not be on the floor, but on the sidelines, where Dave Wohl, the Nets' rookie coach, will work against one of pro basketball's most successful and respected coaches, Don Nelson.

title: Hutton Group Restitution
description: The E.F. Hutton Group has calculated that it will have to pay banks less than $4 million as restitution for an illegal check overdrafting scheme that it pleaded guilty to last year.

title: Embassy Threatened
description: Several hundred demonstrators twice tried to storm the United States Embassy on foot and in vehicles this afternoon to protest the American air strikes on Libya.

title: NORTH CAROLINA DISCOUNTERS OFFER FURNITURE BARGAINS
description: It's 80 degrees outside, the dogwood trees are in full bloom and the sky is the brilliant shade known throughout the state as Carolina Blue. But visitors here couldn't care less - they're too busy shopping for furniture.

title: Enterprise Zones, More or Less
description: Governor Cuomo of New York wants to establish ''opportunity zones'' to revitalize economically disadvantaged areas. The State Senate likes the idea so much it wants to run it into the ground. Though hardly a panacea for economic stagnation, the zones are worth trying on a limited basis.

title: NEW FINERY FOR JOFFREY IN 'ROMEO' 12>
description: When Juliet's dress got caught on a plant during rehearsals for ''Romeo and Juliet'' the other day, Robert Joffrey gasped. It is easy to understand why. That dress - a diaphanous orange and gold number with custom-designed threads and brocade embroidery along the hem - is part of the Joffrey Ballet's new production of the full-length work that opened last night and will be at the New York State Theater through Sunday.

title: FIRST AMERICAN FEDERAL SAVINGS & LOAN reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Year-ago share earnings reflect a 2-for-1 stock split paid in March.

title: 7 Indicted in Arms Smuggling
description: Seven men have been indicted on charges of operating a group that illegally exported firearms and rockets to Ireland and imported more than a ton of marijuana into the United States, the Justice Department said today.

title: Iveco Truck Deal
description: Ford Motor Ltd., the British arm of the American auto maker, and Iveco, the truck unit of the Italian manufacturer Fiat, said they would merge heavy-truck operations in Britain. Iveco Ford Truck Ltd. will make vehicles of more than four tons in Britain, the companies said. The agreement takes effect July 1.

title: Politics; Jackson Brings His Discontent to Town
description: As the Democratic Party struggles to move itself closer to the political center, the Rev. Jesse Jackson is offering himself as a leader to those who don't want to go along.

title: A Real Evil
description: Those of us who have criticized adventurism in President Reagan's foreign policy naturally look with a wary eye at the air strike on Libya. But it is the obligation of critics to see differences. And there are decisive differences between the Libyan action and, for example, the Reagan policy on Nicaragua.

title: ICM PROPERTY INVESTORS reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The year-earlier results were for the company's first two months of operations.

title: STOCKS IN SURGE AS FEARS ABATE ON LIBYA CRISIS
description: Wall Street recorded one of its biggest gains ever yesterday, as investors concluded that the Libyan crisis did not threaten the American economy.

title: 35,000 SPECIES OF ORCHID AT SHOW IN THE BRONX
description: ORCHID hobbyists must be the most patient people in the world. They may have to wait two, three or even seven years for their plants to flower. Their rewards and those of many professional growers may be seen today through Sunday at the New York Botanical Garden in the Bronx.

title: CASTLE INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
Dyneer Buyout At $100 Million
description: The Dyneer Corporation, which makes parts for trucks and heavy equipment, agreed yesterday to sell its assets to a holding company formed by a Citicorp subsidiary and two Dyneer executives for $28.45 a share, or about $100 million.

title: JOURNALISTS SELECTED AS 100 SEMIFINALISTS FOR A SPACE MISSION
description: One hundred journalists, 64 of them from newspapers and other publications and 36 broadcasters, were named today as semifinalists among the applicants to become the first reporter on a space mission.

title: FIRST RAILROAD & BANKING CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
DUN & BRADSTREET CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
GLEASON CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
LOST FLIERS' FAMILIES VOICE SUPPORT AND DOUBT ON RAID
description: The mother of one of the two American fliers believed killed in Monday's attacks on Libya said yesterday that her family supported President Reagan's decision on the raids.

title: JAZZ: GROVE STREET STOMPERS
description: WITH the disappearance of such jazz clubs as Eddie Condon's and Jimmy Ryan's, both of which were on West 54th Street, one of the few remaining places where musicians gather regularly for traditional jam sessions is Arthur's, at 57 Grove Street. Every Monday evening since 1962, the Grove Street Stompers, a six-piece band of avocational musicians, is on the bandstand along with others sitting in, giving it a long-run record for combos that surpasses the big-band run of Mel Lewis's Band, which recently celebrated its 20th anniversary at the Village Vanguard.

title: ROADWAY SERVICES INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
First Jersey Investigations
description: Federal authorities are investigating First Jersey Securities Inc. and its founder, Robert E. Brennan, in what a Congressman says is a look at charges of stock manipulation, illegal campaign contributions and laundering of drug money.

title: 2 SITCOMS, 'MR. SUNSHINE' AND 'JOE BASH,' ON ABC
description: OFFICIAL ''seasons'' being things of the past, the networks now tinker with their schedules all year round. Among the new series introduced over the past several weeks, for instance, are ''Mr. Sunshine'' and ''Joe Bash,'' both on ABC. Neither has been especially promising as far as ratings are concerned, but both certainly try to be different.

title: QUARTER NET UP 49.7% AT A.T.& T.
description: The American Telephone and Telegraph Company said today that earnings for the first quarter of 1986 rose 49.7 percent because of strong results in its long-distance business and a significant accounting change involving pension fund expenses.

title: EASTERN GAS & FUEL ASSOCIATION reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes a loss of $267,000 from discontinued operations.

title: Jockey Injured
description: A jockey was seriously injured yesterday in the eighth race at Santa Anita Race Track.

title: Required Reading
description: Judicial Isolation Excerpts from a speech by Associate Justice William H. Rehnquist of the Supreme Court on ''Constitutional Law and Public Opinion,'' delivered April 10 at the Suffolk University School of Law in Boston:

title: Ohio Thrift Unit
description: An agreement has been reached for the sale of the only state-chartered savings and loan institution still not open for full service after last year's crisis, Gov. Richard Celeste's office said.

title: HUBBELL, HARVEY INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
JUKEBOXES THAT RUN ON NICKELS OR BILLS
description: The Wurlitzer jukebox, an inspired blend of furniture, popular music and kitsch, graced countless local gathering spots during the 1940's. For a nickel, the glittery boxes dispensed songs while their liquid-filled tubes bubbled and their motorized cylinders spun out a kaleidoscope of colored light.

title: THURSDAY SPORTS
description: Baseball Mets vs. St. Louis Cardinals, at Shea Stadium, 1:35 P.M. Rain has already postponed two games scheduled this season for the Mets, who are on a three-game losing streak. (Television - Channel 9, 1:30 P.M.) Yankees vs. Indians, at Cleveland, 7:35 P.M. Yesterday's rained-out pitchers will oppose each other: Bob Tewksbury, the Yankee rookie, and Phil Niekro, the former Yankee veteran. (Television -Channel 11, 7:30 P.M. Radio -WABC 770). Basketball Celtics vs. Chicago Bulls, at Boston, 8 P.M. First game of the three-of-five-game Eastern Conference first-round series. (Television - WTBS, 8 P.M.) Lakers vs. San Antonio Spurs, at Inglewood, Calif., 10:30 P.M. Opener of the Western Conference first-round series. (Television - WTBS, 10:30 P.M.) Boxing Johnny de la Rosa vs. Adrian Arreola, 12 rounds, for the vacant Continental Americas superfeatherweight championship, at Felt Forum. First preliminary, 7:30 P.M. (Television - MSG, 7:30 P.M.) Golf Sea Pines Heritage Classic, at Hilton Head Island, S.C., opening round. Bernhard Langer, who won the Masters last year also won this championship by shooting a par on the first extra hole. Bobby Watkins was second in the playoff. Hockey Rangers vs. Washington Capitals, at Landover, Md., 7:30 P.M. First game of the four-of-seven Patrick Division final. Ron Greschner, who fractured his right hand in Tuesday's upset of the Flyers in Philadelphia, will be replaced on the Ranger roster by Kjell Samuelsson. (Television - ESPN, 7:30 P.M.) Other Events BOWLING: $125,000 Greater Hartford Open, at Windsor Locks, Conn.

title: Ford Financing
description: The Ford Motor Company said it had advised dealers that the program offering financing rates of 7.7 percent and 9.9 percent on some cars and trucks would be extended through Sunday. The program began Feb. 26 and had been scheduled to end today.

title: Yugoslavs Try to Freeze Collaborator's Assets
description: A Yugoslav family is trying to freeze the American assets of Andrija Artukovic, on trial as a war criminal, a newspaper here said today.

title: AFFILIATED PUBLICATIONS INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Share earnings reflect a 3-for-2 stock split paid in January.

title: STARTS IN HOUSING DROP 2.4%
description: Construction of new homes and apartments dipped 2.4 percent in March but remained at the highest rate since 1978, the Government said today, as plunging mortgage rates made the housing industry one of the economy's few bright spots.

title: AMERITECH CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Brown at Bat
description: J. Carter Brown, director of the National Gallery of Art, welcomed a group of Internationl Business Machines Corporation executives to Washington this week.

description: b-Includes income from discontinued operations of $934,000 and a gain of $8,233,000 from the cumulative effect of a change in accounting for pensions. c-After income from discontinued operations of $6,109,000. The year-ago first quarter results include operating results of Stauffer Chemical Co. since the acquisition date of March 15, 1985.

title: Do Us No Favors
description: It was one of those small favors that members of Congress often do for their constituents. Representative Stephen J. Solarz, Democrat of Brooklyn, received a book of poetry from a constituent, the wife of the author, with a request that the volume be placed in the Library of Congress. Mr. Solarz sent the book over and later received a letter acknowledging its receipt, with a promise that the book would indeed be made part of the library's collection.

title: HEXCEL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
U.S. OFFICIAL REPORTS CONTACT WITH QADDAFI FOES
description: A senior White House official said today that the Administration had made periodic contact in Libya over the last several years with opponents of Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi, the Libyan leader.

title: KIDNAPPED IRISH WOMAN IS FREED
description: After a five-hour siege by the police in Dublin today, kidnappers freed the wife of a banker who is related to the Guinness brewing family. She had been held for eight days.

title: MUSIC: MUSSORGSKY 'PICTURES'
description: A RARE performance of Mussorgsky's ''Pictures at an Exhibition'' in an orchestration other than Ravel's provided most of the interest in the Philadelphia Orchestra's concert Tuesday night at Carnegie Hall, under the direction of William Smith.

title: MURRAY OHIO MANUFACTURING reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
GORBACHEV ASSURES QADDAFI HIS DEFENSE WILL BE REINFORCED
description: The Soviet Union announced today that it had promised the Libyans to strengthen their defenses in the wake of the American air strike on Tuesday.

title: GULF OF DISTRUST DIVIDES 2 JERUSALEM SUBURBS
description: A mile or two of desert and fathoms of distrust separate Maale Adumim and El Azariye, two eastern suburbs of Jerusalem on the road to Jericho. The neighboring towns have populations of roughly 10,000 each, but there most similarity ends.

title: BATTLE OVER AN IMPROBABLE HOUSE
description: The small 20th-century house in a remote spot on the West Sussex downs would seem to be anything but a preservationist's dream: the front is a blotchy metallic lavender, and the classical, disproportionately grandiose door case is painted pink and flanked by a pair of carved fiberglass palm trees.

title: Lotus Net Up; Microsoft Rises
description: The Lotus Development Corporation and the Microsoft Corporation, the two leading suppliers of software for personal computers, both announced today that they had increased earnings and sales. Lotus, which is based in

GODFREY CO reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 22
BONNER, AT PRESS DINNER, WARNS OF 'FLOOD OF DISINFORMATION'
description: Yelena G. Bonner was honored by the Overseas Press Club on Tuesday night for her advocacy of human rights. She warned against a ''flood of disinformation'' about her husband, Andrei D. Sakharov, the Soviet physicist and dissident.

title: Targeted-Jobs Credit Is Helping Parolees
description: To the Editor:

I.B.M. Adds To Network
description: The International Business Machines Corporation introduced enhancements to its primary computer communications network yesterday, enabling users to connect the company's most popular office system computers and terminals to the network.

description: b-Includes charges for estimated cost of hazardous waste removal of $1,850,000 for the quarter and $2,575,000 for the 6 months. c-Includes a net gain of $515,000 for the quarter and 6 months from the sale of a plant.

title: NEW HAMPSHIRE SAVINGS BANK CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
MICROSOFT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
VOULKOS'S CERAMIC POTS: TOTAL INVOLVEMENT IN CLAY
description: IN the 1950's and 1960's, Peter Voulkos slashed, punctured and stacked up his damp clay pots, shredding traditions in the process. With his students at the Otis Art Institute in Los Angeles, he redefined the vessel. This is the theme of the show, ''Voulkos & Company,'' currently at the Garth Clark Gallery.

title: JEFFERSON BANKSHARES INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The per share earnings reflect a 3-for-2 stock split payable April 30.

title: Books: A Midwest Tale
description: FINAL HARVEST: An American Tragedy. By Andrew H. Malcolm. 320 pages. Times Books. $17.95. THIS is the dark side of Lake Wobegon. The victims and villains of ''Final Harvest'' are not stronger, smarter or above average. Like other Americans, they were swept up in the tornado of social and economic change in American agriculture. When the twister landed in homicidal fury on a 10-acre spread in southern Minnesota, the events provided Andrew Malcolm with a page 1 story in The New York Times and now this follow-up saga.

title: HERS
description: NOT long ago, I tried to lay bets with my editor on when the first book about the year 2000 would be published. (Canny woman, she refused the bet.) My earliest date was 1990. That seemed far enough away until I realized this year's date. Only four years . . . . Someone, somewhere in America, is working on that book right now. Many someones probably. Consider this a pre-emptive strike. Once upon a time, before E - mc#2, the language of time was a leisurely affair. The long series of ''begats'' in the Bible, the sensuality of madeleines, the leaves falling in Mrs. Dalloway's garden - there was time for time.

title: Kroger's Profit Up 2.9%
description: The Kroger Company said today that it earned $32.3 million, or 74 cents a share, in the first quarter, up 2.9 percent from $31.4 million, or 70 cents a share, a year ago.

title: CONTINENTAL BANCORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
KNIT ONE, PURL TWO, BUT WITH A TWIST
description: WHEN Mona Reynolds opened the Knitting Corner in Ramsey, N.J. five years ago, few visitors to the store could identify the odd-looking devices on display.

title: GREAT WESTERN FINANCIAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Berger to Read Works
description: Thomas Berger, the author of ''Little Big Man,'' ''Neighbors'' and ''The Feud,'' will read from his works on Monday at Brooklyn College. The event will take place at 7 P.M. in the Oriental Lounge of the Student Union Building, at Campus Road and East 27th Street. The reading is free.

title: FIRST CITY BANCORP OF TEXAS INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income The latest quarter loss includes a $275 million special provision for possible loan losses.

title: Market Place; Buying Surge From Overseas
description: STOCK purchases by overseas investors receive scant notice, but they are helping to nurture the bull market in the United States. The Securities Industry Association reported yesterday that buying demand from abroad surged to record levels in the fourth quarter of last year and, in the opening months of 1986, appears to be running at close to the same pace.

title: MERCK & CO INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
AUDITORS' HUTTON STUDY URGES TIGHTER CONTROLS
description: Two independent auditors, requested by the Securities and Exchange Commission to examine the brokerage and mutual funds operations of the E.F. Hutton Group Inc., recommended today that the firm take a series of steps to tighten control of its operations to insure that customer funds are handled properly and that customers are paid on time.

title: MAN CHARGED IN 1980 MURDER
description: Nearly six years after a United States customs agent was killed in Queens when four youths tried to rob him as he stopped for a traffic light, a 23-year-old Brooklyn man has been charged with the murder, the police said yesterday.

title: INTEGRATED GENETICS reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
2 Israelis Switch Jobs, Ending Political Crisis
description: Two Israeli Cabinet ministers exchanged portfolios today, officially ending a political crisis that had threatened the coalition Government.

title: KENTUCKY UTILITIES CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
GORMAN-RUPP CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
COCA-COLA CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes net from discontinued operations of $1,295,000.

title: GLORY OF DAFFODILS, GREAT AND SMALL
description: THE most foolish and also the wisest thing I did 15 summers ago, when my wife and I bought our first and only house and started to turn a lawn and a few bushes into a garden, was to send for some bulb catalogues and order far more daffodils than we could really afford. Since I wanted a great splash of color the next April, I didn't give the slightest consideration to daffodils with modest names like Minnow and Little Witch, whose heights were less than 10 inches. I wanted big daffodils, 17 inches or higher, with bold cups or huge trumpets and forceful names such as Bravura and Spellbinder.

title: APPEALS PANEL SAYS QUADRIPLEGIC HAS RIGHT TO END FORCED FEEDING
description: A state appeals court panel declared today that ''the right to refuse medical treatment is basic and fundamental'' and ruled that Elizabeth Bouvia, a quadriplegic cerebral palsy victim, has the right to refuse to be force-fed.

title: NOXELL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The share earnings reflect a 2-for-1 stock split in March.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: ''WRITE DOWN EVERYTHING'' In Latvia in 1941, a Jewish historian being taken into custody by German police is said to have yelled to those left behind: ''Brothers, write down everything you see and hear. Keep a record of it all.'' Isabella Leitner did just that. Her records are ''Fragments of Isabella'' and ''Saving the Fragments.'' They record some of her World War II experiences. The Germans imprisoned her in 1944 at Auschwitz, in Poland. In January 1945, during a march to a camp in Germany, she and her two sisters escaped. Their arrival in the United States in May 1945 is believed to have been the first of any concentration camp inmates.

title: CORRECTION
description: A recipe in The Living Section yesterday for making steamed salmon for Passover incorrectly described the cut of fish used. It should be center-cut salmon, boned and skinned, 3 inches wide, 6 inches long and approximately 1 inch thick. Unsalted margarine or butter is also recommended.

title: Motion for Secret Jury In Rackets Trial Denied
description: A motion by the prosecution for an anonymous jury in the racketeering trial of Philip Rastelli was denied yesterday by a Federal judge in Brooklyn.

title: DAMSON ENERGY CORP reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-Includes a gain of $1,137,000 from early extinguishment of debt.

title: Topics; Proposal/Disposal; Light, Not Fright
description: Many overseas manufacturers of watches, cameras and other consumer goods sell them in America through authorized distributors at high prices. Some American importers and retailers bring in the same products from other countries and sell them for less.

title: Blue-Chip Son
description: Before he's through, Danny Tartabull will have redefined the relationship between the chip and the old block. Heading into the Seattle Mariners' game at California last night, Tartabull had seven major league home runs in 115 times at bat. That's 350 percent of the homers in 6 percent of the chances that his father, Jose, had during a nine-year career.

title: Advertising; First Woman Publisher For Hearst Magazines
description: Marcia Miller, one-time Manhasset, L.I., interior decorator, has become the first woman publisher in the 83-year history of Hearst Magazines.

title: GRACO INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
U.S. AIDES WORRIED OVER LIBYA CABLES
description: The public disclosure of decoded Libyan diplomatic cables has caused American intelligence analysts to lose a valuable source of information that may take weeks or months to replace, Administration officials said today.

title: STAGE: 'LOVERS' AT INTAR
description: THE infelicities of domestic life among three Florida couples are explored to a salsa beat in ''Lovers and Keepers,'' an evening of three short musicals, written and directed by Maria Irene Fornes. Musically, the trio has a certain ingenuous appeal even as the dramatic situations are spotted with banalities. The show, with music by Fernando Rivas, Francisco Rodriguez and Tito Puente, is at Intar.

title: 12 SENATORS OPPOSING REAGAN ON CANADA TRADE
description: A majority of the Senate Finance Committee asked President Reagan today to withdraw his request to Congress for authority to conclude a free trade agreement with Canada.

title: Holders Vote At Dow Jones
description: Shareholders of Dow Jones & Company, which owns The Wall Street Journal and Barron's magazine, approved, as expected, anti-takeover measures that give directors substantially more leeway to combat a hostile bid. One provision staggers the election of directors to prevent a rapid change in the composition of the board.

description: b-Net income.

The Gannett Company, owner of The News, will receive 55 percent of the profits or losses in the first year, with its share declining one percentage point a year until the split with Knight-Ridder Newspapers Inc., owner of The Free Press, reaches 50-50.

title: SHOULD EMPLOYERS BE ABLE TO TEST FOR DRUG USE?
description: Driven by growing illegal drug use among millions of Americans and the inability of law-enforcement officials to curb it, many employers over the last decade have quietly instituted a policy that they hope will keep drugs out of the workplace: the mass screening of workers to detect the presence of drugs in their bodies.

title: SOMALIA ARGUING WITH U.N. ON REFUGEES FROM ETHIOPIA
description: A recent surge in the number of Ethiopian refugees going to northwest Somalia has set off a sharp dispute between the Government in Mogadishu and the office of the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees here.

title: What Are Allies For?
description: Sgt. Kenneth Ford, the American killed in the Berlin disco bombing that precipitated the attack on Libya, was stationed in Europe to serve an extraordinary 40-year American commitment to an extraordinary alliance. Like 300,000 Americans on the Continent, he was defending our allies, and also American interests that extend into the heart of Europe. If his murder, America's reprisal and Europe's demurrals were now to weaken that commitment and that alliance, Colonel Qaddafi would have scored a mighty victory indeed.

title: AMERICAN TELEPHONE & TELERAPH CO INC (AT&T)(N) reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes a gain of $100 million, or 9 cents a share, for a change in accounting for pension expenses.

title: DR. CALVIN CALMON
description: Dr. Calvin Calmon, a research chemist and an authority on desalination and other water-treatment processes, died April 2 at his home in Princeton, N.J. He was 77 years old. Dr. Calmon helped perfect ion exchange methods - for which he held 20 patents - used to remove metals and other unwanted substances from waste water. He also published nearly 100 scientific papers and edited two books.

title: POP: THE GUITARIST LES PAUL
description: WHEN the guitarist Les Paul played a Monday night engagement at Fat Tuesday's in March 1984, it was hoped that he might be able to perform there on Monday nights for a few weeks.

BANKAMERICA POSTS QUARTERLY PROFIT
description: The BankAmerica Corporation said yesterday that it had returned to profitability for the first time since the first quarter of 1985.

title: How the U.S. Became a 'Demon'
description: We should see the military strike against Libya for what it is: a reprisal for a specific act of terror, and an invitation to the Libyan ruler to rethink his ways. We should also refrain from expecting great results.

title: FORT HOWARD PAPER CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
EXOTIC CARPETS IN SOHO
description: HE said he wanted ''to try a new wrinkle,'' so Mark Shilen, left, once a peripatetic rug dealer, has opened a store with Turkish, Indian and Persian carpets and textiles.

UPBEAT CANDIDATE
description: After being chosen County Executive three years ago, Andrew P. O'Rourke was asked by a friend how it felt.

DANCE: '...BYZANTIUM' BY TAYLOR, REARRANGED
description: IT used to be a joke that the school of writing known as the French Nouveau Roman was so little concerned with linear narrative that you could shuffle the pages in any of its novels and no one would know the difference.

title: OPPOSITION IN SEOUL SAYS CIVILIAN DIED WHILE DEFENDING HIS BELIEFS

description: Teen-agers took over the City Council yesterday, easing themselves into their elders' seats, and the clashes over prospective legislation often were as hot as at the real thing.

title: ASTRONAUTS' FAMILIES EXPECT TO GET REMAINS NEXT MONTH
description: The space agency has privately told the families of some members of the Challenger crew that their bodies will probably not be released for burial until next month.

title: JUST HOW MUCH REALITY CAN MUSIC REALLY BEAR?
description: WRITING record reviews for this newspaper, I come always to the terrible place where I have to talk about how real the recorded sound is. I am paralyzed with inadequacy at these moments - as my audiophile readers must be paralyzed with boredom - mainly because I have so little idea what ''real'' means.

description: The latest quarter results include Bostitch Stapler & Fastening Tools, acquired in February, and Peugeot Hand Tools, acquired in March. The year-earlier quarter results include a 6 cents a share gain on the sale of land and a 4 cents a share loss on the sale of an operation in Canada.

description: Giorgio Inc., the fragrance company, said yesterday that Michael Gould, former chairman and chief executive of J. W. Robinson, had been named president and chief operating officer.

title: Right the First Time on Turning Off Radio Marti
description: To the Editor:

title: BUYING FURNITURE: CHANGING PATTERNS
description: IN Paramus, N.J., last weekend, Andrew R. Amato Jr. and his wife, Linda, walked into the Huffman-Koos Design Center and asked a decorator to fill their new house with black lacquer furniture and a six-foot television screen.

title: LINCOLN FINANCIAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Technology; A System Aids Use of Robots
description: A TECHNICIAN confronted a cranky ASEA robot that was refusing to start. Once again, he went through the starting routine, pressing the buttons on the front of the robot's free-standing control cabinet in the correct sequence. Still a warning light glowed red and the big orange robot arm refused to budge.

title: INTRAWEST FINANCIAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
NONFICTION IS SURGING IN MOVIES
description: The serious, feature-length documentary, never a crowd pleaser at the nation's movie theaters, has been having surprising success in recent months.

title: DIOCESE PROHIBITS MASS AT MOB FIGURE'S BURIAL
description: Frank DeCicco, the reputed mob leader killed by a car bomb Sunday, will not be given a funeral mass before his burial today, a spokesman for the Roman Catholic Diocese of Brooklyn said yesterday.

title: FUQUA INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes income from discontinued operations of $10,148,000, which includes a $11,171,000 gain from sales of investment in Triton Group Ltd. c-Includes income from discontinued operations of $360,000. 1985 Results are restated for discontinued operations.

title: Start and Starters Bring Joy To Yankees
description: A typically wet and cold April day in Cleveland slowed the Yankees today as little else has this season. The Indians postponed tonight's game eight hours before its scheduled start, preventing the Yankees from adding more luster - and perhaps another victory - to their 6-1 season-opening record.

title: GUARANTY NATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
CROSSLAND SAVINGS FSB reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes an extraordinary tax credit of $12,298,000. The company went public in October 1985 and it did not report per share earnings for the year-earlier period.

title: Georgia Tries For Better Image
description: When the storm created by the Jan Kemp case threatened to all but blow the roof off the University of Georgia, Vince Dooley, the athletic director and football coach, had something to hold on to: an unwavering posture. Whatever the extent of athlete-favoring abuses in the school's Developmental Studies Program - and court testimony as well as other disclosures made clear that they were substantial - neither Dooley nor his staff, he said, had ever applied any pressure that might have caused them.

title: Poll Finds Support For Pupils With AIDS
description: Two-thirds of American adults would permit their children to attend school with a student who had AIDS, while one-fourth would not, according to the latest Gallup Poll.

title: U.S. IS STEPPING UP REBUKE TO ALLIES ON WORLD TERROR
description: The Administration stepped up public criticism today of what it said was the failure of American allies to combat international terrorism, and a senior White House official said President Reagan would make the issue a top priority at the economic summit meeting in Tokyo in May.

title: SURGE OF DEVELOPMENT ON L.I. IMPERILS STRUGGLING BAYMEN
description: A construction boom that has brought more marinas, motels and homes to the oceanfront is posing severe environmental and economic problems for the shellfish industry along the Long Island coast.

title: MICKEY AND KEITH
description: The co-author, the one who thumps baseballs for a living, autographed books in a corner of the restaurant. He was wearing neither baseball uniform nor sackcloth, but was attired in a black suit and silver tie. His dark hair was brushed as smoothly as his dark mustache.

title: French Report Letters From 4 in Lebanon
description: The Government received handwritten letters today from four French hostages in Lebanon, officials and French television reports said.

title: Bridge: Rookies of the Year Chosen With Ranking by Computer
description: In recent years players who are new to the game have received considerable encouragement from the American Contract Bridge League. Computerized master-point rankings allow a player who began with fewer than 5 master points to be nominated ''Rookie of the Year'' at the national or local level.

title: AMR Profits Plummet 93%
description: The AMR Corporation, parent company of American Airlines, said yesterday that first-quarter earnings plunged 93 percent, to $4.2 million, or 4 cents a share, from $60.2 million, or $1.07 a share, a year ago. Revenue totaled $1.46 billion, up 5 percent from $1.39 billion in the period last year.

title: Reynolds Metals Chief
description: The Reynolds Metals Company said yesterday that William O. Bourke, its president, had been named chief executive. Mr. Bourke, 59 years old, succeeds David P. Reynolds. Mr. Reynolds, 70, whose father, Richard S. Reynolds, founded the aluminum products company in 1919, will continue to serve as chairman. Mr. Bourke will be the first chief who is not a member of the Reynolds family. Reynolds also said yesterday that Richard G. Holder, 54, a vice president, had been named executive vice president and chief operating officer. R. Bern Crowl, also 54, was re-elected executive vice president and chief financial officer.

title: AGENCY IN CITY SUED OVER BOND REDEMPTION
description: The New York City Housing Development Corporation's plan to redeem more than $170 million of bonds it sold in 1982 has prompted a lawsuit by John Nuveen & Company, a Chicago securities firm, to stop the financing plan.

title: The Concern Is Results
description: There are many more doubts about the wisdom of the U.S. attack on Libya here at Indiana University than TV reports indicate among the public at large. A college climate encourages thinking about motives and consequences.

title: OCE-VAN DER GRINTEN reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
description: The results are in U.S. currency which were converted from Dutch florins at 2.5185 equals U.S. $1.00

title: RECITAL: HAMPSON DEBUT
description: THE question about most debut recitalists is whether they're any good. The question about the American baritone Thomas Hampson, who made his debut at Town Hall Monday night, is just how good he is. Chances are, he will rank among the leading lyric baritones of the late century.

title: Generosity Washington Can Afford
description: Armed with a favorable Supreme Court ruling, the Reagan Administration has finally succeeded in removing groups it doesn't like from the roster of charitable organizations that benefit from annual fund drives among Federal workers. Congress should reverse this narrow-minded policy.

title: Expansion Plans At Woolworth
description: The F.W. Woolworth Company, continuing to expand beyond its traditional line of variety stores, said that it would open 548 specialty stores worldwide in 1986.

title: Uninviting Invitation
description: A few weeks ago, Cecily Firestein was in the elevator of her Upper East Side apartment house. She was returning from a trip to the printer, where she had ordered invitations to an exhibition of her prints.

HAZELTINE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Medal Versus Hearns
description: Next opponent for Thomas Hearns, the World Boxing Council's superwelterweight champion, will be Mark Medal of Jersey City, who is 24-2 with 20 knockouts.

title: INTERGRAPH CORPORATION reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
STALIN'S DAUGHTER FLYING TO U.S.
description: Svetlana Alliluyeva, the daughter of Josef Stalin, left the Soviet Union Wednesday for Chicago via Zurich, Heinz Lanz, manager of the Swissair office in Moscow, said today.

title: CONTRAS WON'T GET ANTIAIRCRAFT WEAPON
description: The United States has decided not to send the Stinger, its most advanced portable antiaircraft weapon, to the Nicaraguan rebels, Administration officials said today.

title: Local in Hormel Strike waits Union Decision
description: A decision whether Local P-9 of the United Food and Commercial Workers should be place in trusteeship by its parent union for refusing to end an eight-month strike against Geo. A. Hormel & Company is expected in about three weeks, union officials said today.

title: WALDHEIM REJECTS ENDING CANDIDACY
description: Kurt Waldheim today spurned the idea of abandoning his bid for the Austrian presidency because of questions about his World War II record, and he said he was ''quite confident'' of being elected.

title: STANADYNE INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The year-earlier quarter results were restated to reflect the change in pension costs resulting from the early adoption of financial accounting standard number 87 last December.

title: TRUS JOIST CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
CITY'S PLASTIC CARDS FOR CASH REPLACING CHECKS FOR WELFARE
description: New York City, which once mailed out half a million welfare checks every two weeks, has completed a major switchover to a system that distributes benefits on presentation of a plastic card.

title: Questionable Contract
description: To the Editor:

title: HOSPITAL BOARD PROHIBITS PARTY TIES
description: Political party officials have been barred from holding management jobs at city hospitals and serving on the board of directors of the Health and Hospitals Corporation, which administers them.

title: Article 034386 -- No Title
description: The First City Bancorporation of Texas, hit hard by troubled energy loans, reported today a loss of $232.4 million in the first quarter, in contrast to a profit of $8.8 million, or 13 cents a share, a year ago.

title: Reading by Ionesco
description: The playwright Eugene Ionesco will read from his work and answer questions from the audience Monday at 6 P.M. at the Maison Francaise of New York University, 16 Washington Mews. Admission is free, but reservations are necessary. To reserve: 598-2161, extension 2162.

title: U.S. AND MEXICO SEIZE FUGITIVES IN A JOINT EFFORT
description: Federal officials said today that 3,506 fugitives, most of them Americans, had been arrested in an eight-week effort along the Mexican border that included the first collaborative roundup by American and Mexican law-enforcement officers.

title: MICHAEL JACKSON, PEPSI PLAN VENTURES
description: A soda pop brand and a singing star will make their debuts on fashion labels this fall, it was disclosed in separate announcements yesterday.

title: LYNCH TO UNDERGO SURGERY ON KNEE
description: The Mets, who already had a three-game losing streak and the worst pitching record in the National League, got more gloom yesterday: Ed Lynch, one of their regular pitchers for the last five years, went on the disabled list with torn cartilage in the left knee, and will be gone for perhaps six weeks.

title: The U.N. Today: April 17, 1986
description: SECURITY COUNCIL Meets at 10:30 A.M. on Libyan complaint against the United States. ECONOMIC AND

title: BROOKLYN ACTIVIST IS GUILTY OF GRAND LARCENY
description: A Brooklyn community activist who was accused of seizing control of a newly completed federally subsidized housing project and collecting $40,000 in illegal fees from prospective tenants has been convicted of grand larceny and scheming to defraud.

title: ENSERCH EXPLORATION PARTERS reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The partnership was formed in April 1985, and per share figures for the year-ago first quarter were not reported.

title: G.O.P. TACTIC PUTS CONTRA AID ON HOLD
description: Using a surprise parliamentary maneuver, House Republicans today ambushed the Democratic leadership and foiled attempts to attach President Reagan's request to aid the Nicaraguan rebels to a supplemental spending bill.

title: BILL MCCARTHY, FORMER COACH AT N.Y.U., DIES
description: Bill McCarthy, who coached baseball at New York University from 1922 to 1961 and saw four of his players become regulars in the major leagues, died Tuesday in Palm Beach, Fla., after his second stroke in three months. He was 91 years old.

title: Plant Use Falls to a Two-Year Low
description: American industry operated at just 79.4 percent of capacity in March, the lowest level in more than two years, the Government reported today.

title: Dantley Lost to Jazz
description: Adrian Dantley, the Utah Jazz forward who is sidelined by muscle spasms in his lower back, will not play in the first round of the playoff series opening tomorrow in Dallas, Bill Kreifeldt, a team spokesman said yesterday. The 6-foot-5-inch Dantley, the N.B.A.'s second-leading scorer, missed the Jazz's season finale against the Denver Nuggets last Saturday because of the spasms.

RCA said its year-ago net from discontinued operations is from Hertz Corp., which RCA sold Aug. 30, 1985, to UAL Inc. Hertz' sales of $330.6 million in the year-ago first quarter were not consolidated in the sales figures.

title: SABERHAGEN BLANKS RED SOX ON 2-HITTER
description: Steve Balboni clouted a long homer and Bret Saberhagen allowed only two hits today as the Kansas City Royals defeated the Boston Red Sox, 1-0, for their fourth victory in a row.

ESTATE WORKERS BREAK UP TRIAL IN JOHNSON SUIT
description: Shouting ''liar'' and ''communist,'' 15 workers from the Princeton, N.J., estate of Barbara Johnson, broke up the trial over her late husband J. Seward Johnson's will in Manhattan Surrogate's Court yesterday. They were quickly rounded up, and Surrogate Marie M. Lambert sentenced their leader, John Stroczynski, the estate manager, to two weeks in jail.

title: Eberhart and Ginsberg Win Frost Poetry Medal
description: Richard Eberhart and Allen Ginsberg have been named winners of the Frost Medal for distinguished poetic achievement by the Poetry Society of America.

title: C.D., Fund Yields Fall
description: Yields for certificates of deposit, bank money market accounts and money market mutual funds were all down for the week ended yesterday, continuing a trend that began six weeks ago.

title: 'IN BELLY OF THE WHALE'
description: DORIS DORRIE'S ''In the Belly of the Whale'' (''Im Innern des Wals'') is a small, sad German movie about the sadomasochistic relationship between Carla, a pretty, 15-year-old girl, and her father, Erwin, a policeman. To all outward appearances, Erwin is a model law officer, though he treats Carla, who's a slob around the house, as if she were some kind of beloved thief. He beats her one minute and showers her with presents the next.

title: AMERICAN HOME PRODUCTS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31

title: Alarming Game
description: A sixth-inning hit in San Diego on Tuesday night may have saved a life in Phoenix six innings later.

title: A Get-Together
description: Representative Robert G. Torricelli of New Jersey, a second-term Democrat who is a friend of Gary Hart, who is giving up his Senate seat to run for President, is giving a lunch for Mr. Hart today, and the guest list is substantial.

title: Give Us No Lunch
description: Japan's Ambassador, Nobuo Matsunaga, invited key legislators with interest in Japanese economic and political issues to a lunch at the embassy Monday with Prime Minister Yasuhiro Nakasone. But several had longstanding previous commitments outside Washington and could not be there. These included Representative Marcy Kaptur, Democrat from Toledo, Ohio, a city heavily dependent on the domestic auto industry, and Senator John C. Danforth, Republican of Missouri, chairman of the Senate trade subcommittee. Mr. Danforth has been a frequent critic of Japanese trading policy and for a while refused to see any Japanese delegation that came to Washington.

title: PARKER-HANNIFAN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The latest periods' results include a gain equal to 4 cents a share from a change in pension accounting methods for the quarter and 12 cents a share for the 9 months.

title: Manila Charges Marcos With Embezzlement
description: The Government, seeking to recover millions of dollars that it says Ferdinand E. Marcos hid in Swiss banks, has charged the deposed President and 25 others with embezzlement, a Government spokesman said today.

title: BILL ON PICKET LINE VIOLENCE WITHDRAWN AFTER SENATE VOTE
description: Legislation that would make it a Federal crime to commit violence in labor disputes was withdrawn today after its supporters lost a key Senate vote.

description: Andrew P. O'Rourke, the Westchester County Executive, announced his candidacy for Governor yesterday with the virtual assurance that he would be the Republican-Conservative challenger of Governor Cuomo.

title: ACCENT IS ON POLITICS AT BIRTHDAY PARTY IN CHICAGO
description: When the Mayor of Chicago has a birthday, even people who differ with him politically can enjoy his party.

Additionally, results for 1985 were adversely affected by LIFO adjustments in the third quarter of $3.5 million, or 4 cents a share. Results for the year and fourth quarter of 1984 were adversely affected by a $54,969,000, or 67 cents a share, writedown of Sharon's equity investment in Evans Products Co.; a $16,677,000, or 20 cents a share, writedown of certain mining properties; a provision of $9.7 million, or 12 cents a share, for a judgment awarded to Howell Industries; a charge of $3 million, or 4 cents a share, for the estimated cost of construction of waste containment facilities under a consent decree; and a charge of $2.6 million, or 3 cents a share, resulting from the valuation of certain LIFO inventories at the lower cost of market at Dec. 31, 1984.

title: Gooden in Incident
description: Dwight Gooden said yesterday that he and his sister and his fiancee were the victims, not the perpetrators, of an incident at La Guardia Airport that resulted in a summons to his sister for ''harassment'' of a car-rental clerk. ''We have nothing to apologize for,'' the 21-year-old ace of the Mets' pitching staff said.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: THURSDAY, APRIL 17, 1986
description: Tension in Libya Washington stepped up criticism of the failure of American allies to combat international terrorism. A senior White House official said President Reagan would make the issue a top priority at the economic summit meeting of the seven leading industrial democracies in Tokyo next month. [ Page A1, Column 6. ]

title: REAGAN IS WEIGHING THE FUTURE OF '79 ARMS PACT
description: President Reagan and his top advisers met today to consider whether the United States should continue to abide by the unratified 1979 treaty on strategic arms limitation. Officials said no decision was taken.

title: DEFENSE ARGUMENTS FORESHADOWED IN SPYING TRIAL
description: A lawyer representing Jerry A. Whitworth in his trial on espionage charges gave the first indication today of the direction that the defense might take.

title: 'Jerry's Girls' to Close
description: ''Jerry's Girls,'' a compilation of music from various Jerry Herman musicals, will close after the matinee on Sunday at the St. James Theater. Directed by Larry Alford, the musical will have run for 139 regular performances and 14 previews.

title: QADDAFI, ON TV, CONDEMNS ATTACK
description: Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi, in his first public statement since the United States bombing raid, condemned the attack and Britain's role in its execution. He thanked France for refusing to take part and pledged to continue his support for ''popular revolution.''

title: MERRILL NET UP 56.1% IN QUARTER
description: Merrill Lynch & Company yesterday reported a 56.1 percent jump in first-quarter profits, benefiting from rallies in the securities markets.

title: Reagan Honors Teacher
description: Guy R. Doud, 32 years old, of Brainerd, Minn., was honored Monday at the White House as the 1986 Teacher of the Year. Mr. Doud, who teaches high school English, said his own teachers had inspired him by helping him overcome his ''very low self-esteem'' as a child. President Reagan presented Mr. Doud with a crystal apple.

All the President's Air Force Ones

And although their engines are still sound and their trappings still plush, the Air Force has decided that enough is enough.

title: RAPID GROWTH AT BELL CANADA

title: Rikers Inmate Kills Himself
description: An inmate on Rikers Island hanged himself in his cell yesterday morning, the first suicide by a prisoner in city custody this year, officials said. The prisoner, 38-year-old Alejandro Arroyo, was arrested April 8 on rape and incest charges and was being held in $50,000 bail. He was found hanging from a metal cabinet at 9:30 A.M. He used two shoelaces, according to James Whitford, a spokesman for the City Correction Department.

title: THE GOALS OF 'AUTOMATICITY'
description: Last week, Treasury Secretary James A. Baker 3d offered some of the ''qualities'' he would seek in a better-organized world. Two of the qualities, he said, were ''automaticity'' and ''flexibility.''

description: The American people overwhelmingly support the bombing of Libya, despite widespread fears that it will lead to more international terrorism and even to war with that country, a New York Times/CBS News Poll shows. But a poll in Britain found very heavy disapproval.
