title: Mrs. Calandra Loses Ruling
description: The widow of State Senator John Calandra today lost her attempt to win the Republican nomination to run for her husband's Senate seat in a special election next week. The State Court of Appeals refused to hear JoAnn Calandra's appeal of a lower court decision denying her the Republican nomination in the special election for the State Senate seat representing the Bronx and Westchester County. But Mrs. Calandra will still be on the ballot because she has been designated an independent candidate.

title: Q&A
description: Q. We are moving to a rural home and would like to put up a roadside mailbox. How should we do this? How deep should the post hole be and should there be gravel at the bottom of the hole? A. For solid support the post hole should go down to the frost line (usually 30 or 36 inches). There should be about three inches of gravel on the bottom of the hole to promote drainage. The post, which should be made of pressure-treated lumber or should be soaked in preservative, rests on this gravel, and concrete is then poured in to fill the hole. To hold the post in position while pouring the concrete, use temporary braces nailed to opposite sides of the post. The lower end of each brace should be nailed to a temporary stake driven into the ground a few feet away. Q. My family room and one of my bathrooms share a common wall. Every time the toilet is flushed or water is run you can hear it clearly in the family room. What remedy can you suggest? A. Putting insulation inside the wall spaces might help, but not much. Your best bet is to put up an extra stud partition wall in the family room, a couple of inches in front of the existing wall and not physically attached to it. The space between the two walls is then filled with unfaced fiberglass blankets or batts to help absorb sounds, and the partition is covered with 1/2-inch- or 5/8-inch-thick gypsum board. Q. The wood siding on our house was treated with a mixture of linseed oil and turpentine every few years.

title: GETTY THE COMPOSER SAVORS THE RICHES OF MUSIC
description: A few years ago, Forbes magazine named Gordon Getty as the richest man in America. Whether or not the magazine is correct, he is certainly the richest composer of our time. For Mr. Getty in recent years has been concentrating on music and has created a small body of works that is beginning to make the rounds. Tomorrow night at 8, for instance, the Collegiate Chorale in Carnegie Hall will present the New York premiere of six of Mr. Getty's a cappella choruses and the world premiere of a seventh.

title: FILM: ROCK MUSICAL, 'BEGINNERS'
description: MORE than the stylish movie it is, more than the two-hour music video it threatens to become, ''Absolute Beginners'' is a movie about style - the 50's roots of 80's clothes and music, echoed through 40's musicals. Set in a neon-bright London in 1958, it has some of the 40's artifice of boys and girls bursting into song, yet is full of 80's rock stars and 70's survivors like David Bowie and Ray Davies. Looking through these layers of time, this flashy, extravagant rock musical, which opens today at the Ziegfeld, elevates style to a symptom and cause of social change. And though it aims for more coherence than it delivers, it has endless flair with no self-importance.

title: The Tempest Over Passover
description: A needless confrontation is building in New York's schools over the observance of Passover. Schools Chancellor Nathan Quinones has ordered schools to remain open on April 24 and 25, when the holiday begins. But 9 of the 32 local school boards threaten to defy him and close their schools. This tempest didn't have to happen, and there's plenty of blame to go around, but at this juncture Mr. Quinones is right.

title: POP AND JAZZ GUIDE
description: ''Beehive,'' Top of the Gate, 160 Bleecker, at Thompson Street. (475-5120). Sixties nostalgia wafts like a cloud of Aquanet through ''Beehive,'' a light-hearted revue that looks back with fond amusement at the changing image of women in 60's pop, from the girl groups to Janis Joplin. The show, which takes its name from the vintage hairdo, has been fine-tuned since it opened last year at Sweetwater's, and is now set inside a giant glowing jukebox. Softening the decade's politics while emphasizing its frivolity, ''Beehive'' seamlessly blends nostalgic kidding with powerful vocal remembrances of Janis Joplin, Aretha Franklin, Tina Turner and others by its six-woman cast. What ''Grease'' did for the 50's, ''Beehive'' does for the go-go decade, as it follows female pop styles from ''The Name Game'' to ''A Natural Woman,'' all in a spirit of pure, irresistible fun. Showtime tonight is at 8, Saturday at 7 and 10 P.M., and Sunday at 2 and 5 P.M. Tickets are $25. Tom Paxton, Public School 41 Auditorium, 116 West 11th Street (594-8833). Tom Paxton continues to turn out probing topical songs that cover everything from yuppies to battered women to South Africa, and he also writes sensitive love songs. Though Mr. Paxton is basically very serious, he can also be funny. In ''Yuppies in the Sky,'' which parodies ''Riders in the Sky,'' a ghostly band of young real-estate experts flies down Columbus Avenue crying ''Condos for sale!'' His more harrowing songs, like ''The Death of Steven Biko,'' also reveal an acute eye for the details that humanize tragedy.

title: KEACH RETURNS AS MIKE HAMMER
description: BEING presented on CBS tonight at 9, ''The Return of Mickey Spillane's Mike Hammer'' should have a question mark in the title. This is indeed a new television movie, and the series starring Stacy Keach in the main role is indeed returning to the schedule on Tuesdays at 9 P.M. But, at least for the time being, those weekly episodes will be reruns. Following Mr. Keach's imprisonment in England stemming from drug charges in 1984 and 1985, the network is evidently testing the public-reaction waters before ordering new installments.

3 Charged in Warehouse Fire
description: Federal authorities charged three people today with illegally manufacturing fireworks that caused an explosion and fire in a sprawling warehouse, killing at least eight people. The three, Wayne Quan, 28 years old, his sister, Laureen Quan, 25, and Steven Leong, 28, were charged with violating Federal explosives laws, which carry a maximum punishment of 15 years in prison and a $500,000 fine, officials said.

description: Another afternoon of persistent rain forced the Mets to call off the final game of their series with the St. Louis Cardinals yesterday, although they are not the only two clubs feeling the effects of the foul weather.

description: In a small apartment, a woman in her 20's cooked the stalks and leaves of dried poppy plants on a hot plate. Her companion, a bearded house painter, laid out his collection of syringes on the bed, picking out a needle least likely to bring infection.

THE HIDDEN CHARMS OF THE FAR WEST VILLAGE
description: GREENWICH VILLAGE is undoubtedly one of New York's best-known neighborhoods. Its very mention evokes an assortment of familiar images - a cultural underground of bohemians and beatniks; the stately world of Henry James's Washington Square; jazz clubs galore; throngs of tourists on Eighth and Bleecker Streets, and the booming art scene of the alphabet avenues to the east.

In fact, the air is so full of dandelion fluff that it would seem to be more hazardous to the health than asbestos, which the fluff suggests, at least metaphorically.

title: DINER'S JOURNAL
description: OVER the last year and a half, I have received more than a few complaints from readers who visit a restaurant after a favorable review only to encounter a barely controlled mob scene amid a loud and cramped dining room where service all but breaks down under the pressure. While the strains on such newly popular establishments are often severe, some restaurateurs exacerbate the situation by adding extra seats in an attempt to cash in on a good thing. Overbooking also is common, which often backfires and leaves hungry and impatient diners cooling their heels at the bar for up to an hour.

title: And Now, the Saudi Arms Sale
description: Most of the time, the White House is relatively free to pursue foreign policy initiatives without much interference. But when it wants to use arms as a tool of diplomacy, the law requires it to get Congress's permission in most cases. And that gives the lawmakers a rare chance to help shape the direction of foreign policy.

title: Woman Dies in Queens Fire
description: A 35-year-old Queens woman died last night in a fire apparently caused by a cigarette she dropped in her living room, according to authorities. The fire destroyed a two-story frame house at 107-05 121st Street in Richmond Hill, according to the police. The woman, whose identity was withheld pending notification of relatives, was pronounced dead at 10:30 P.M.

description: China today announced a slowdown in its soaring industrial growth rate and a likely rise in grain output, but it conceded that prices were still rising at a high rate and that efficiency was deteriorating throughout industry.

BAYLOR SLAM LEADS RED SOX

title: FIGHT NICARAGUA? -- OR LET IT BE
description: More than anything else, this week's Congressional action - a series of parliamentary maneuvers that resulted in inaction - on aid to the ''contras'' reflected a desire to avoid the basic issues. The debate is stalled, but not over. Next month, the House will probably be asked again to approve a compromise measure -military aid that would not be released unless the Administration made a good-faith effort to negotiate with the Sandinistas. Such a compromise might be good domestic politics, but it would do nothing to resolve the contradictions in United States policy toward Nicaragua.

WEEKENDER GUIDE
description: Friday LITERARY LECTURES Two of the most engaging voices in literature, Isaac Bashevis Singer and John Ashbery, will speak at Adelphi University in Garden City, L.I., today and tomorrow as part of a series of artistic and cultural events in celebration of the university's 90th anniversary and the inauguration of its seventh president. Mr. Singer, who, like Mr. Ashbery, has won a Pulitzer Prize for his writing, will deliver a lecture on ''Literature and Freedom.'' The Yiddish writer of stories about Jewish life in Europe and America will speak at 8 o'clock tonight at Woodruff Hall. Tomorrow, from 10 A.M. to 4 P.M. in the University Center Gallery, Mr. Ashbery, a poet and journalist, will read from his works and discuss the theme of artists as collaborators. His workshop will examine the process by which artists exchange ideas. He will use the exhibitions of Larry Rivers as examples. The university is currently showing two Rivers exhibitions that span 35 years of collaboration with other artists. One of Mr. Rivers's canvases, ''Poem and Portrait of John Ashbery,'' features Mr. Ashbery's poem ''Pyrography.'' Both events are free. Information: (516) 663-1112.

title: Vive le Pinprick
description: My knee was primed to jerk in praise of our long-delayed attack on a source of terrorism, and in contempt of France's craven refusal of our request to fly through its airspace on the way to the target.

Mr. Doyle said he does about 1,000 sweeps a year and considers the service one of the galleries' major functions.

title: POP AND JAZZ GUIDE
description: Tabou Combo, S.O.B.'s, 204 Varick Street (243-4940). Compas, the popular music of Haiti, has yet to receive the attention accorded to Jamaica's reggae, Trinidad's soca or the Cuban-derived salsa sound. But compas can be riveting, especially when played by Haiti's most respected band, Tabou Combo. Electric guitar is the primary solo instrument; the electric bass anchors the rhythms with forceful, interestingly syncopated lines. Much Caribbean pop tends to groove at medium tempo, but Tabou Combo can play fast and furious, inspiring dancers to maximum exertion. Shows are around 9 and 11:30 tonight and tomorrow night. Admission is $12.

STAGE: 'SOCIAL SECURITY,' WITH RON SILVER AND MARLO THOMAS
description: ANY crackpot can risk writing a play, but it takes a genuine madman to try to concoct two acts' worth of jokes. When a play falters for a spell, the audience can always contemplate the plot or characters or themes while waiting for things to get moving again. In a potpourri of gags like ''Social Security,'' the new offering at the Barrymore, there is far less margin for sloughing off. By opting for a sitcom premise instead of a story, stock figures instead of characters and fortune-cookie messages instead of feelings, this entertainment bets all on its jokes: like a stand-up comedy act, ''Social Security'' either gets its laughs or drops dead.

title: Travels With Mrs. Reagan

title: ART: 19 PAINTINGS OFFER CROSS SECTION OF VARLIN

This incisive and occasionally sardonic artist painted in an expressive, blustery style that could fill his paintings with affection and humor. His work reflects not only the 20th-century art of his own country, but also the art of Germany, France and Italy - three essential but largely distinct ingredients of Swiss culture.

title: 3 BRITISH VICTIMS IN LEBANON
description: Alec Collett New York-based freelance journalist . . . Seized by gunmen south of Beirut on March 25, 1985, while on a writing assignment for the United Nations Relief and Works Agency, which works with Palestinian refugees . . . Resident of Tudor City on the East Side of Manhattan with his American wife, Elaine, and 12-year-old son, Karim . . . United Nations correspondent for The Associated Press from 1967 to 1972 . . . A British citizen, born in London . . . 64 years old and a diabetic . . . Elected honorary president of the United Nations Correspondents Association in December . . . Director of the United Nations Information Center in Ghana from 1979 to 1982 . . . Father of two sons from a previous marriage . . . Said in a videotape received from his kidnappers last May that he was ''alive and well, doing some writing and a little gardening.'' Leigh Douglas

title: SCREEN: 'WISE GUYS'
description: FROM its cartoony credits to its knish-and-cannoli close, ''Wise Guys'' is one funny movie. The director, Brian De Palma, displaying a light touch that he has not used lately, keeps the plot about two bumbling gangsters in Newark bubbling. As Harry Valentini and Moe Dickstein, pals to the death, darn near, Danny DeVito and Joe Piscopo mug their way maniacally through George Gallo's winning tale of a pair of losers who get involved in a $250,000 misunderstanding and have to squirm out of it, or else. The story may sound familiar, but the twists of script, direction and performance make it fresh.

title: Better Training Urged For Security at Airports

title: NIEKRO SHOWS YANKS HE CAN STILL PITCH

description: ONE of the more unpredictable institutions in New York City is the Drawing Center at 137 Greene Street. Since it began in 1977, the center has had a twofold function. Every year it holds four shows of work by living artists whom it believes to be promising. Anyone can apply for an appointment to show work and, in all, 346 artists have been given wall space in one of the more stylish of SoHo interiors. The good intentions of the center are exemplary, even if the definition of both ''drawing'' and ''promising'' has sometimes been open to debate.

title: HODEL ACTS TO PROTECT OIL IN U.S.
description: Interior Secretary Donald P. Hodel said today that his department was taking steps to protect domestic oil capacity in the face of declining domestic production and increasing consumption resulting from the lower prices that could threaten to increase the nation's reliance on imported oil.

title: ALLIES' MINISTERS PLAY DOWN SPLIT WITH U.S.
description: West European foreign ministers, meeting today for the first time since the American raid on Libya, played down the differences between themselves and the United States over the attack, vowing that Europe would press ahead with a new set of anti-terrorist measures.

title: ANTI-SANDINISTA PAPER SCORNS OFFER
description: A backer of the Nicaraguan Government has offered to buy the opposition newspaper La Prensa ''for an excellent price,'' according to the newspaper's editor.

title: AT CRAVATH, $65,000 TO START
description: Cravath, Swaine & Moore is raising its pay for beginning lawyers by a whopping $12,000 a year - to $65,000 - and in the process is setting the pace for a round of similar increases at other top New York law firms.

title: BUSH SEEKS NEW HAMPSHIRE SUPPORT
description: With the next Presidential election still two years away, Vice President Bush made a major appearance in New Hampshire today in an effort to solidify his support among its Republican voters.

title: FAMILIES' RELOCATION ORDERED AT SHELTER WITH PAINT HAZARD
description: A State Supreme Court judge late yesterday ordered the immediate relocation of residents of a city shelter for homeless families in Lower Manhattan where extensive lead-paint hazards have been found.

title: BAKER URGES O.E.C.D. TO ACCELERATE GROWTH
description: Warning that protectionism in the United States was ''far from dead,'' the Reagan Administration urged other industrial nations today to speed economic growth to help the United States reduce its huge trade deficit.

title: No Substitute For Charity
description: For a while, it appeared that the University of Cincinnati baseball team was going to make the big time in a big way - by taking on the Reds at Riverfront Stadium last night.

title: DEEP DIVISIONS STALL OPEC TALKS
description: OPEC oil ministers remained deeply divided today over a production and price agreement, threatening to send crude oil prices plunging further.

title: REAGAN'S BOND PLAN IS REBUFFED
description: The Senate Finance Committee today rejected President Reagan's proposal to limit the kinds of tax-exempt bonds that states and municipalities can issue. Instead, it voted for an expansion of bonding authority.

title: Of Diplomacy And Software
description: Diplomatic cables, the paper lifeline between the State Department and its far-flung embassies around the world, may soon become artifacts for the archives.

title: 2 SONGBIRDS, 2 TRADITIONS WITH SPIRIT
description: LONG before television or newspapers, songs carried news, history and opinion. Melodies and rhyme schemes were aids to memory as well as occasions for art; a well-made song might start out as a topical dispatch and survive as a ballad, a parable or an epic. Even in our own information-blitzed century, such songs are still being written. Tomorrow night, two programs featuring female singers will survey two oral traditions - the blues and norteno music from the border of Texas and Mexico.

description: President Jose Azcona acknowledged tonight that some Nicaraguan rebels were based in Honduras. But he said his Government had no intention of sending a large number of soldiers to the border to keep them out.

title: SCREEN: 'MURPHY'S LAW'
description: TELEVISION ads for ''Murphy's Law'' have been appearing, in which Charles Bronson, as the film's main character, confronts some off-camera enemy and proclaims his philosophy of life: ''Don't mess with Jack Murphy.'' In fact, Mr. Bronson never says that line in the movie, which opens today at the RKO Warner Twin and other theaters. Instead of ''mess'' he uses an unprintable but common four-letter word, and what matters is not that the language is stronger than television allows, but that watered-down snippets suggest this movie is a fairly innocuous shoot-em-up, a Dirty Harry by another name. Truth-in-packaging would have shown that ''Murphy's Law'' is not tough; it's sleazy.

title: Swiss Won't Send U.S. a Bill
description: A Swiss Government spokesman, retreating from an earlier statement, said today that there was no need to send the United States Government a bill for damage to the Swiss Ambassador's residence in the American raid on Tripoli. The official, Achille Casanova, said a review of the issue had shown there was no cause to ask Washington to pay. At a news conference Wednesday, Mr. Casanova said the bill would be in line with past practice, although he said it was an open question whether the Americans would meet repair costs.

title: WHALERS SET BACK CANADIENS BY 4-1

title: TESTS OF BRADLEY ARMORED VEHICLE CRITICIZED
description: A simulated combat test of the Bradley armored personnel carrier was criticized today by a group of Congressmen as misleading and unrealistic.

description: The Xerox Corporation said today that it earned $101 million, or 92 cents a share, in the first quarter, down 11.4 percent from last year's $114 million, or $1.06 a share.

title: F.R. LIVINGSTON, LAWYER, DIES
description: Frederick R. Livingston, a New York lawyer and labor arbitrator who was an adviser to eight Secretaries of Labor, died Monday at Mount Sinai Hospital. He was 73 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Politics and Brothers
description: Political Trivia Department, Brotherhood Division: If Senator Alan K. Simpson's brother, Peter K. Simpson, is elected governor of Wyoming in November - he is one of a half-dozen candidates in the Republican primary - they will not be the first set of brothers to serve simultaneously as senator and governor.

title: DIGITAL PROFITS UP 85.7% AS NEW PRODUCTS EXCEL
description: The Digital Equipment Corporation, benefiting from its revamped computer line, said yesterday that earnings in its third fiscal quarter soared 85.7 percent on a 14.2 percent increase in revenues. Digital's earnings were higher than analysts had expected and are exceptional when compared with the flat or lower earnings that many of its competitors have been or are expected to report.

title: DEMOCRATIC DISSIDENTS BACK JACKSON
description: A coalition of labor leaders, black elected officials, farmers and liberal activists today rallied behind the Rev. Jesse Jackson's effort to organize a ''progressive force'' within the Democratic Party.

title: WINN-DIXIE STORES INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 2
AIR RAID ON LIBYA: MINUTE BY MINUTE
description: All times are Eastern Standard. 12:13 P.M.Twenty-eight KC and KC135 refueling planes leave from Royal Air Force bases Fairford and Mildenhall. 12:36 P.M.Twenty-four F-111 bombers leave from R.A.F. base Lakenheath and five EF-111 Raven electronic jamming planes take off from R.A.F. base Heyford. Four silent refuelings take place on the way to the target area. Six of the F-111's were spare planes that returned to Britain, as planned, after the first refueling. One spare EF-111 also returns. 5:45-6:15 P.M.The aircraft carrier America launches six A-6E strike and six A-7 strike support aircraft. 5:20-6:20 P.M.The carrier Coral Sea launches eight A-6E strike and six F/A-18 strike support aircraft. 6:54 P.M.Three EF-111's commence electronic jamming while A-7's and F/A-18's begin missile attacks on SAM missile sites. The fourth EF-111 is held in reserve. 7 P.M.Simultaneous attacks begin at Benghazi and Tripoli. The Benina Airfield and military barracks near Benghazi are hit by bombs from twelve A-6E's and the Azzizyah barracks and the Sidi Bilal training camp near Tripoli are attacked by eight F-111's. 7:06-7:11 P.M.Five F-111's bomb the Tripoli military airport, the final target. 7:13 P.M.All Navy strike aircraft confirm ''feet wet'' (over the ocean, away from Libyan land). Unable to confirm all Air Force aircraft ''feet wet.'' 7:15 P.M.Search and rescue forces are alerted to search for a possible missing aircraft. 7:46 P.M.All Coral Sea strike aircraft are back on deck. 7:53 P.M.All America strike and primary support aircraft are back on deck. 8:14 P.M.First return refueling confirms one F-111 is missing. 10:16 P.M.One F-111 returning to Britain is diverted to Rota, Spain, because of an overheated engine. 11:24 P.M.The diverted F-111 is reported safe at Rota.

title: Comings and Goings
description: John McEnroe has entered the French Open, which begins May 26, and thus will end his absence from tournament tennis. McEnroe last played competitively in the Masters Tournament in mid-January. . . . John Ferguson, the general manager of the Winnipeg Jets, who also coached the team for its last 17 games this season, is stepping down as coach and will hire another one for next season. . . . The first baseman Greg Walker was placed on the 15-day disabled list by the Chicago White Sox, who called up Rodney Craig from Buffalo as his replacement.

title: MARTHA GRAHAM TO REVIVE 3 RARITIES
description: The Martha Graham Dance Company will celebrate the 60th anniversary of Miss Graham's first concert as an independent artist with the revival of three rare solos associated with the start of her career, the company announced yesterday.

title: FOOTE, CONE-LEBER DEAL
description: YESTERDAY in the chichi confines of the ''21'' Club, the top managements of Foote, Cone & Belding Communications and Leber Katz Partners made the announcement Madison Avenue knew was coming. The publicly held F.C.&B. will acquire Leber Katz. The deal will be accomplished through an exchange of stock. No further details were available.

title: EAST GERMAN LEADER CONDEMNS ATTACKS ON LIBYA
description: With the leader of the Soviet Union looking on, the East German party chief today denounced the United States for its ''barbaric bombardment of peaceful Libyan cities.'' He said the action could lead to greater East-West tensions.

title: Big Top in Brooklyn
description: The big top of the Big Apple Circus will be up through the weekend in Brooklyn's Prospect Park, near the Wollman Rink.

description: With 4,300 miles to go, the United States maxiyacht Atlantic Privateer sped past U.B.S. Switzerland today to take the lead in the Whitbread Round-the-World yacht race, organizers said.

title: A PILGRIMS' PROGRESS ENDS ON GANGES
description: Observing a tight schedule, hundreds of swamis, yogis, ascetics and other holy men strode toward the Ganges River in the morning heat. Some wore scarlet or saffron robes. Others wore tiny loincloths. Dozens were naked, smeared lightly with ash.

title: FRANCE ACTS TO EXPEL 4 MORE LIBYANS
description: France said today that it was expelling four Libyans from the country because their activities were likely to ''trouble public order.''

TITAN ROCKET EXPLODES OVER CALIFORNIA AIR BASE
description: A Titan rocket carrying a secret military payload exploded today in a large orange fireball seconds after liftoff here, Air Force officials said.

title: BRITAIN CITES 'EVIDENCE' OF LIBYAN ROLE
description: Britain said today that it had ''firm evidence of direct Libyan involvement'' in the kidnapping of two British teachers who were killed in Lebanon in reprisal for the bombing raid by American F-111's flying from British bases.

title: MCDONNELL DOUGLAS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
FOSTER DRAWS A FEW CHEERS
description: For a fleeting moment, George Foster could hear the adoring cheers. But they stopped too quickly last night. He singled, two runs scored, and then the seventh inning was over. He was ready for more boos. It has been that way for the last couple of seasons. Foster has endured the wrath of Shea Stadium fans almost daily, including last night during the Mets' 5-2 victory over the Philadelphia Phillies.

title: FIRST FEDERAL SAVINGS F.A.  reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
David Lindley At Lone Star Cafe
description: David Lindley is best known as a Los Angeles studio musician who works with Jackson Browne. But he also carries on a fitful solo career that brought him to the Lone Star Cafe Wednesday and Thursday, along with a half-dozen fretted instruments that he played with unassuming virtuosity.

title: L.S.U. AIDE SENTENCED
description: When the National Collegiate Athletic Association was interviewing basketball players from Louisiana State last year as part of its investigation of the school's recruiting practices, someone else intended to listen. That someone was Bob Brodhead, the L.S.U. athletic director, who admitted in Federal Court that he had bugged his office to eavesdrop on the conversations. Yesterday, Brodhead, who agreed to plead guilty to charges of a misdemeanor count of conspiracy to intercept radio communications, was fined the maximum $1,000 and sentenced to perform 200 hours of unspecified community work by Judge John Parker, who told Brodhead that ''playing by the rules of the game is the minimum to be expected of a person in your position.''

title: Waldheim Called a 'Liar' By Jewish Leader
description: Edgar M. Bronfman, president of the World Jewish Congress, called former Secretary General Kurt Waldheim ''a man who is a proven liar'' in a letter to Secretary of State George P. Shultz made public by the Jewish organization today.

PATENTS;
BREATHING DEVICE
description: Lilly Ferrer of Island Park, L.I., has invented a breathing apparatus to be worn as a face mask and supplied with oxygen-rich gas from an aerosol-type canister to prevent smoke inhalation. Patent 4,582,054, issued this week, says the gas mixture can be released by finger pressure. Mrs. Ferrer, a restaurant chef, has made a model.

description: The city has emptied a lower Manhattan shelter for homeless families, moving the last four families to welfare hotels yesterday after a State Supreme Court justice ordered their immediate relocation, according to a spokesman for the Human Resources Administration.

description: Saying he did not want ''to run the risk of killing this bill,'' Senator Bob Packwood, the chairman of the Finance Committee, today indefinitely postponed further voting on tax-revision legislation.

description: The Federal Emergency Management Agency has issued a generally favorable assessment of the emergency evacuation drill conducted in February at the Shoreham nuclear power plant.

description: Last year, the Giants emerged from their long offensive hibernation with some big numbers: Joe Morris ran for 1,336 yards, the fourth-highest total in the National Football League, and Phil Simms passed for 3,829, again fourth-highest. Given that newly discovered firepower, what is Coach Bill Parcells looking for in the April 29 draft? ''Firepower,'' he says.

title: HERMAN GRAEBE, 85, GERMAN WHO SAVED JEWS FROM NAZIS
description: Herman Graebe, a non-Jewish engineer who repeatedly risked his life to save Jews from the Nazis in World War II, died of a heart attack Thursday at St. Luke's Hospital in San Francisco. He was 85 years old. Mr. Graebe, who joined the Nazi party in 1931, later renounced his membership and subsequently became the only German citizen to volunteer to testify for the prosecution at the Nuremberg trials.

The Kansas basketball coach, Larry Brown, underwent successful surgery on his hip yesterday in Columbia, Mo., a school spokesman said. . . . Chana Perry, the outstanding center on Northeast Louisiana's basketball team, said she intended to transfer to San Diego State in the fall to resume her career. She was suspended during the past season because of N.C.A.A. sanctions against Northeast Louisiana for recruiting violations involving her. . . . The Islanders have signed the free agent Eric Oakman, a left wing from the College of St. Scholastica in Duluth, Minn., a Division III school in hockey. Oakman, who is 21 years old, scored 87 goals with 81 assists in four college seasons.

title: SATURDAY SPORTS
description: Baseball Mets vs. Phillies, at Shea Stadium, 1:35 P.M. Dwight Gooden will pitch against Shane Rawley, who beat the Mets last Sunday in Philadelphia. (Television -SportsChannel, 1:15 P.M. and 7:15 P.M. Radio -WHN 1050, 1:30 P.M.) Yankees vs. Brewers, at Milwaukee, 2:35 P.M. (Television - Channel 4, 1:15 P.M.) Red Sox vs. Chicago White Sox, at Boston, 4 P.M. (Television - Channel 4, 4 P.M.) Basketball Hawks vs. Detroit Pistons, at Atlanta, 3:30 P.M. Second game of this series, which the Rockets lead. (Television - WTBS, 8 P.M.) Boxing Michael Spinks vs. Larry Holmes, 15 rounds, for the International Boxing Federation Heavyweight Title, at Las Vegas, Nev., 10 P.M. A rematch, only this time Holmes is the challenger. (Television - HBO, 10 P.M.) Bowling The $125,000 Greater Hartford Open, at Windsor Locks, Conn. (Television - Channel 7, 3 P.M.) Golf Heritage Classic, at Hilton Head, S.C. Third round. (Television - Channel 2, 2 P.M.). College: Metro Atlantic Athletic Conference men's championships, at Pelham Country Club, Pelham Manor, N.Y., 9:30 A.M. Hockey Rangers vs. Washington Capitals, at Landover, Md., 7:35 P.M. The Rangers will be trying seeking to bring a 2-0 advantage back to New York.

title: CHARLES F. DETMAR Jr.
description: Charles F. Detmar Jr., a former senior partner in the New York law firm of Cahill Gordon & Reindel, died yesterday at his home in Westhampton, L.I., after having suffered a stroke March 10. He was 80 years old.

title: LOUGANIS FALTERS BUT GAINS FINAL
description: Greg Louganis survived missing a dive to reach the men's 3-meter springboard finals, and the eight-time National Collegiate Athletic Association champion, Megan Neyer, captured top honors in the women's 1-meter event today in the United States Diving Indoor Championships.

title: Velella for State Senator
description: The death last January of New York State Senator John Calandra, the Bronx's only Republican legislator, requires a special election Tuesday to fill the vacancy to the end of the year. The voters of the northern Bronx and southern Westchester are asked to choose among three candidates.

title: 59 OF 90 BRITT AIRWAYS CO-PILOTS ARE GROUNDED BY F.A.A. ORDER
description: The Federal Aviation Administration today barred 59 of the 90 co-pilots of the commuter carrier Britt Airways from flying after some of them failed in-flight performance checks.

title: TRUCK COMPANY IN TROUBLE
description: In the mid-1930's, the Hall's Motor Transit Company, a small carrier in Pennsylvania, filed for bankruptcy protection, hobbled by losses from the Depression. It emerged from Chapter 11 in 1938, growing into a national powerhouse with 5,000 employees and annual sales of more than $250 million by 1981.

title: INSIDE STORY

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: EXISTENTIAL ENTERTAINMENT Samuel Beckett's 80th birthday was last Sunday. And the celebration, which began then with Beckett readings, continues. This weekend a nine-day film festival begins, screening movies inspired by his work. A series of relatively short films will be shown today and tomorrow at 2, 5 and 8 P.M. The 2 P.M. films, which will be repeated at 8 P.M., are ''Act Without Words,'' based on a short play and featuring the adult-oriented Theater of Puppets with no dialogue and no character description; ''Rockaby,'' the making of a play on Mr. Beckett's 75th birthday; ''Film,'' Mr. Beckett's only screenplay, which stars Buster Keaton and is devoid of dialogue, and ''Eh Joe,'' which originated as a Beckett play written for British television in the form of a dialogue between Joe and his dead wife.

title: RIDER OUT INDEFINITELY
description: Don MacBeth, the jockey who was injured in a spill aboard Fleet Halo at Aqueduct April 5, said that his back injury would keep him away from riding indefinitely. MacBeth, who is 36 years old, said he suffered muscle and nerve damage and was experiencing a lot of pain. He also said that he did not know when he would be able to leave Long Island Jewish Hospital and that after he did, he would need two months of outpatient therapy.

title: NO THANKS

Asked who was favored for the division title, Tom Landry of Dallas, Joe Gibbs of Washington, Buddy Ryan of Philadelphia and Gene Stallings of St. Louis all picked the Giants. And how did Parcells care for that burden? ''Like going to lunch in Tripoli,'' he said.

INSULIN TAKEN ORALLY
description: An orally administered form of insulin that could free diabetics from injections may result from an invention patented this week. Lin-nar L. Teng, research assistant professor in medicinal chemistry at the University of Washington's School of Pharmacy, was granted patent No. 4,582,820. Dr. Teng creates a ''sandwich complex'' and a protective coating to increase absorption of the insulin. The patent is assigned to the Research Corporation, a foundation with offices in Tucson, Ariz., and New York, which is offering licenses to the pharmaceutical industry.

title: THE SCREEN: 'HEATHCLIFF,' TALES OF COMIC-STRIP CAT
description: Don't confuse Heathcliff with Garfield, the cartoon cat so successful he stars in his own line of best-selling books, so upwardly mobile he has an American Express commercial. The downwardly mobile Heathcliff is also a comic-strip tabby, of a peculiarly dull and outdated sort. In this full-length feature, Heathcliff tries to amuse his three nephews with tales of his youthful exploits - an appropriate trip to the past, for the creators of ''Heathcliff the Movie'' have their hearts in the Nancy and Sluggo school of cartoons.

title: Kurt Waldheim Remembers
description: Kurt Waldheim now remembers that yes, he did prepare battlefield reports while serving as a German Army lieutenant in the Balkans. And yes, he was aware of atrocities and heard about measures against Jews; he knew Jews were taken to an unknown fate, but ''I didn't know it was such a mass affair.'' World War II was a ''nasty, dirty'' conflict - German soldiers, too, were seized as hostages and executed.

SATURDAY NEWS QUIZ
description: Questions are based on news reports in The Times this week. Answers appear on page 32. 1. This Spot belongs to someone who has made Spot run again. Explain. 2. ''You are our dearly beloved brothers, and, in a certain way, it could be said that you are our elder brothers.'' This was said on a historic occasion. Who made the remark and what was the occasion? 3. ''He basically put his finger up in the air to see where the President was and he was always there regardless of whether the arguments were overwhelmingly on the other side.'' In a new book, a former member of the Reagan Administration says that about a current Administration official. Identify them. 4. ''It looks like someone took a giant bite out of it,'' said a Navy observer about a two-foot-wide hole in a two-ton metal object. What object was it and why was the hole significant? 5. A man who has written nine best sellers in the last 10 years will be joined by his son tomorrow on The New York Times fiction best-seller list, the first time a father and son have had simultanous best-selling novels, according to publishing officials. Identify them. 6. A Pentagon spokesman said the American raid on Libya was ''near-flawless,'' even though (1/3/5/7/9) of the 18 Air Force F-111-F bombers aborted their missions and did not carry out their planned attacks. 7. title: Books of The Times; A Poet's Complaints
description: SELECTED LETTERS OF CHARLES BAUDELAIRE. The Conquest of Solitude. Translated and Edited by Rosemary Lloyd. 268 pages. The University of Chicago Press. $24.95. The life of Charles Baudelaire quite blatantly contradicts Chesterton's famous observation that the artistic temperament is a disease afflicting amateurs. While his meticulously crafted work was strict, indeed almost classical in form, Baudelaire himself led a manic, disordered existence that sounds awfully like a grade-B movie parody of 19th-century bohemian life. Besides overindulgence in alcohol, opium and hashish, there were pernicious debts, syphilis -which resulted in assorted nervous disorders, dizzy spells and death at the age of 46 - noisy, fragmented relationships with women and incessant attacks of what the poet would call spleen. In fact, Baudelaire was almost always in a bad mood - either enraged by the horrors and indignities of the world around him, tormented by the loneliness of his self-inflicted solitude, or simply bored with himself and everyone around him.

title: BELLSOUTH CORPORATION BELLWETHER EXPLORATION reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
DOLLAR FALLS SHARPLY IN HECTIC DAY
description: The dollar went through one of its most volatile days in months on the foreign exchange markets yesterday, falling sharply to a record low against the Japanese yen and tumbling in value against other currencies before staging a small recovery late in the day.

title: JORDAN MAKES UP FOR LOST TIME
description: The Chicago Bulls' playbook, designed by Coach Stan Albeck during the offseason, is geared to take full advantage of Michael Jordan's ability to go one-on-one, something he does better than any other player in the National Basketball Association.

title: APACHE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
NORTHROP'S CRUCIAL BOMBER
description: Behind three layers of barbed-wire fence in this desert town north of Los Angeles, the finishing touches are being put on the assembly site of one of the most expensive programs in military history.

title: GUINNESS BESTS ARGYLL TO ACQUIRE DISTILLERS CO.
description: Guinness P.L.C., the brewing company, said today that it had won a $4.1 billion, four-and-a-half-month takeover battle for Britain's largest Scotch whisky and gin concern, the Distillers Company. The losing bidder was Argyll Foods P.L.C, a supermarket chain.

title: ANSWERS TO QUIZ
description: Questions appear on page 14. 1. The dog belongs to Marc Gallant, the author of ''More Fun With Dick and Jane,'' a recently published satire of the Dick and Jane Basic Readers. 2. Pope John Paul II made the remark at a service in Rome's central synagogue, in what was the first recorded papal visit to a synogogue. 3. David Stockman, the former Budget Director, referred to Donald T. Regan, formerly the Treasury Secretary and now the President's chief of staff. 4. The hole, in a burned-out section of the booster rocket joint whose rupture is thought to have led to the destruction of the space shuttle Challenger, provides the first tangible evidence that a failure of the joint caused the disaster. 5. William F. Buckley Jr. and his son, Christopher. 6. 7. 7. Jack Nicklaus won his sixth Masters golf tournament. 8. The Detroit News and The Detroit Free Press. 9. Vladimir Horowitz, in his first visit to the Soviet Union in 61 years, played two Scriabin etudes for the composer's 86-year-old daughter on the piano in the composer's home. Isaac Stern was the guest soloist at a Yale Bach Society concert conducted by his son, David. 10. Public tours of the Kellogg Company plant in Battle Creek, Mich., ended after 80 years and 6.5 million visitors. 11. Haiti. 12. Procedure 4272 of the Internal Revenue Service code provides for ''mandatory examinations'' for returns of the President and Vice President. 13.

title: G.E. UNIT SALE IN SOUTH AFRICA
description: The General Electric Company has completed the sale of its operations in South Africa to local management. G.E. did not disclose terms of the agreement, which was concluded last week and involved units with annual sales of between $30 million and $40 million. G.E. said the operations employ 600 people and that the new owners had pledged to continue to observe ''fair employment practices'' that G.E. had introduced.

title: PO FOLKS INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 30
description: b-Net income.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''Tax bills have a life of their own. They go up and down.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: SATURDAY, APRIL 19, 1986
description: The Economy

title: ANALYSTS INTERNATIONAL reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income

title: GENERAL AERO PRODUCTS CORP reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
What Is a Fair Day's Work?
description: Nearly 100 years ago, America's attention was on Chicago and on the Haymarket Square riot of May 4, 1886. Newspaper headlines screamed about anarchists, drunken mobs, policemen being ''mowed down with dynamite'' and warned of ''danger lurking.''

title: DELCHAMPS INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 29
CHURCH'S FRIED CHICKEN INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 23
Croat Becomes Confused At War Crimes Trial
description: Andrija Artukovic, the 86-year-old former minister in Croatia's Nazi puppet Government, lapsed into disorientation at his war crimes trial today, saying he did not know where he was or what year it was.

title: FIRST FEDERAL SAVINGS & LOAN (KALAMAOO) reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
TRIPOLI BURIES ITS DEAD WITH TEARS AND THREATS
description: Tripoli today buried some of its dead from the raid early Tuesday by American planes as the country's No. 2 leader dismissed reports of internal dissension.

title: TV: 'MARILYN MONROE,' CABLE CHANNEL SPECIAL
description: Viewers who enjoy looking at Marilyn Monroe, and there are still millions who do, will find reminiscent pleasures in the otherwise very routine documentary about her life that comes to the pay-cable service Cinemax at 10 tomorrow night.

title: DESIGNATRONICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
description: b-Net income

title: Philippines Seeks to Put 4 Buildings in Trust
description: Lawyers for the Philippine Government said in United States Federal Court in Manhattan yesterday that they would seek to place four New York City buildings that they contend belong to Ferdinand E. Marcos, the former President, in receivership.

title: CHARTER FEDERAL SAVINGS & LOAN reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The latest quarter net income includes an unspecified gain on the sale of certain investments. The company declined to specify the gain, but said it represented more than half of the latest quarter net.

title: A NEW CLIMATE AT CITY HALL
description: Mayor Koch's abrupt decision to withdraw a sharply disputed housing plan just hours before it was to go before the Board of Estimate Thursday suggests for the first time that the corruption scandal shaking his administration is affecting more than the tone of City Hall.

title: TYING INSURERS TO HOSPITALS
description: THE recent trend of hospitals and hospital chains acquiring or affiliating with insurance companies is likely to have a major effect in the future on employees and their employee benefit plans.

title: MISSION WEST PROPERTIES reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
description: b-Includes a tax credit of $293,000 for the latest quarter and $37,000 for the year-ago period. The company said that most of its latest first quarter net resulted from a sale of an office-industrial project in San Diego and of unimproved land in Mississippi.

title: Key Rates
description: * Municipal Bond Index, The Bond Buyer Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: LABOR LOBBYISTS SMILING
description: For some years organized labor has been bemoaning its decline as a political force. Only one in five nonfarm workers is now a member of a labor union, compared to better than one in three in labor's heyday after World War II.

title:
PATENTS;
SPURRING DNA BONDING TO PROTECT PROTEINS
description: Two staff members at the National Institutes of Health in Bethesda, Md., were awarded a patent for a procedure to stimulate the bonding of DNA for the protection of proteins. Steven B. Zimmerman and Barbara H. Pfeiffer assigned patent No. 4,582,802 to the Department of Health and Human Services.

title: OPEC MINISTERS AWAIT REPORT ON OIL OUTLOOK
description: A conference of oil ministers of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries was marking time in its fourth day today as yet another committee of 13 economic experts was asked to prepare supply-and-demand estimates for the remainder of this year.

title: SPY SUSPECT SAYS HE WAS MISLED INTO CONFESSING
description: A former employee of the National Security Agency testified today that he had admitted spying for the Soviet Union because he thought cooperation with the authorities would win him immunity from prosecution.

title: Adoptees, Without Stigmas
description: In recent years, adopted persons, especially adolescents, have increasingly been descibed as dependent, fearful, hostile, insecure and abnormal. The popular myth has it that adopted children have more mental health problems than the nonadopted, simply because they are adopted.

title: REAGAN DENIES LIBYA RAID WAS MEANT TO KILL QADDAFI
description: President Reagan denied today that the United States was trying to kill Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi in its attack on the Libyan leader's command post at El Azziziya barracks in Tripoli.

title: COURIER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 29
GENERAL HOUSEWARES CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net loss

title: NICOR INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes a loss from discontinued operations of $4.8 million.

title: DOUBLE THREAT
description: For good or ill, pop-music numbers in praise of young athletic demigods continue to proliferate.

title: KIMBALL INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After an extraordinary gain of $980,000 for the quarter and 9 months. The share earnings shown above are on class 'B' shares. The class 'A' shares are 51 cents a share for the quarter and $1.71 a share for the 9 months, compared with 66 cents a share and $2.09 a share for the year- earlier quarter and 9 months, respectively.

title: WOMAN FOUND SHOT TO DEATH IN CAR ON HIGHWAY IN QUEENS
description: A woman was found shot to death yesterday afternoon in the front seat of a car parked on the Van Wyck Expressway in Queens, and the police said she had apparently been shot by someone who had been inside the vehicle.

title: USAIR GROUP INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income

title: APACHE PETROLEUM reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
READING FOR IDEAS
description: ''Orchards'' is a collection of one-act plays by contemporary playwrights based on stories by Chekhov. Performed by the Acting Company, it will open Tuesday at the Lucille Lortel Theater.

title: GREAT LAKES FEDERAL SAVINGS & LOAN reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
SURPRISING RANGERS AT A PLAYOFF PEAK
description: By now it is clear. The Rangers, at some point near the end of the regular season, hired a plastic surgeon. He went around the league, took the best players, and reshaped their faces so they would look like Rangers. That's why the Flyers were stunned. That's why the Washington Capitals are wondering what's going to happen next. That's why just about everyone around New York is wondering, ''Is this for real?''

title: CONCERT 'TRISTAN' SCHEDULED
description: FRESH from its Carnegie Hall debut, the Westfield Symphony Orchestra is about to undertake what its music director, Brad Keimach, calls a ''musical pilgrimage.''

title: ANTIQUE GARMENTS ON VIEW IN DARIEN
description: TO Babs White and Sue Ann Evans of Darien, clothing is not just something to cover the body. The women share a passion for vintage garments, a background in fashion design and an interest in the history of clothing. And they are able to put their talents to work as curators of the Darien Historical Society's extensive costume collection.

title: Tax Reform En Route to a Rout
description: What passes for tax reform in the Senate Finance Committee looks more and more like an effort to sabotage this chance for invigorating change. Day after day, section by section, the committee members are solidifying old loopholes in the tax laws and opening up new ones. Though it's hard to believe, they are actually writing a tax code even worse than the one we have.

title: TINY TIMBALES
description: IT IS NO SECRET THAT the evolution of cuisine is based, in no small way, on the wholesale appropriation by one culture of another culture's tastes, ingredients, even techniques. Recently, my thoughts have again wandered over this ancient truism. They have been impelled by my encounters - in such disparate centers of American culinary experimentation as California, Texas and Georgia - with a figment of the past, that enormously appetizing and elegant representative of classic French cuisine, the timbale.

title: RX FOR HOSPITAL ADMISSIONS: COMPASSION
description: ''ONLY sick people belong in the hospital,'' said one of my professors during my training. As a consequence, I have never admitted many patients to the hospital, as I prefer to obtain the necessary tests and X-rays on an outpatient basis when feasible.

title: Special School Planned To Avoid AIDS Victim
description: The parents of at least 15 students plan to enroll their children at a makeshift school in nearby Russiaville rather than expose them to a classmate who has AIDS, a parents' spokesman says.

title: A QUIET GIANT OF CORPORATE TRAVEL
description: IN the days that followed last week's bombing attacks on Libya, business travelers began calling many of the 1,250 travel offices of Woodside Management System, asking for guidance on the dangers of traveling to, say, Rome, Athens or London. Concerned about their safety, some travelers canceled trips or switched from United States airlines to European-flag carriers.

title: FREE AGENCY AT THE TOP OF N.F.L. PLAYERS' AGENDA
description: By the end of the week, owners in the National Football League will have a better idea of what they may encounter in collective bargaining with the N.F.L. Players Association.

title: Post-Tripoli Tremors?
description: Patrons in the Longworth House Office Building Cafeteria one day last week were shaken when a building guard suddenly let loose a chirrup on his whistle, held up a package and asked the owner to claim it. A diner quickly came forward to pick up the package, which had been left outside the door of the cafeteria. But most diners seemed suddenly to feel a need to be elsewhere, and in a twinkle the cafeteria was all but deserted.

title: NEW JERSEY GUIDE
description: CASH AND CARTER The country-music singers Johnny Cash and June Carter, his wife, will give two concerts in Trenton Saturday to benefit the Hun School in Princeton.

title: Time To Agree
description: Sitting in the T.W.A. lounge at Kennedy Airport waiting for the overnight flight to Italy induced a dull fatalism. Passengers watched the news in silence while Dan Rather told about the warnings, the fears, the precautions being taken by the U.S. Government. When the newscast was over, one young woman blurted out, ''If my livelihood didn't depend on it, I wouldn't take this trip.'' Later, another said with a nervous giggle: ''There's always been terrorism in Italy, hasn't there? We'll keep a low profile, not let on that we're Americans.''

title: PUTTING PLOTTERS TO WORK IN THE OFFICE
description: WHETHER the growing use of charts in business that has accompanied the spread of personal computing is really productive or simply a visual firestorm sweeping through a mine field of information cluttered with paper is debatable. Much of the current emphasis on a graphic summation of data can be compared to the studied mindlessness of today's average television sitcom, wherein life's vital details are deleted in favor of an easily recognized, simplified representation of existence.

title: Michelle Wechsler to Wed
description: Mr. and Mrs. Walter Wechsler of Wantagh, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Michelle Robin Wechsler, to Robert Warren Smith, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Sidney S. Smith of Manhattan. A July wedding is planned. Miss Wechsler is a sales administrator at Trans-Action Marketing in New York and Mr. Smith is a vice president of Sidney S. Smith Associates, a New York manufacturers' representative.

title: NEW LINE IN BULGARIA: TURKS? WHAT TURKS?
description: Having completed the forced adoption of Bulgarian names by the minority ethnic Turks last year, the Bulgarian Government is now pressing a campaign to deny that the Turkish minority ever existed.

title: DRIVERS HAPPY TO ENLIST FOR NEW GAS WARS
description: Ruben Lugo of the Texaco station on Route 4 here has often been called upon of late to interrupt his duties pumping gas and provide economic forecasts.

title: ARE THE RATINGS JUST ALPHABET SOUP?
description: The press release that announced the change was of modest length, the wording straight and to the point. Issued jointly by the Motion Picture Association of America and the National Association of Theater Owners, the release betrayed no sense of panic, hysteria, hopelessness or doom. Coming through - loud and clear - was the unstated, inspiriting subtext: ''This is still the best of all possible worlds. What we do here today is simply another in our continuing efforts to increase the efficiency of our service.'' Con Ed says much the same thing when it raises its rates.

title: Janet Wess Is Engaged
description: Mr. and Mrs. Carl Wess of Woodmere, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter Janet Wess to Ira Tilchen, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Alvin Tilchen of Brooklyn. Miss Wess is a tax administrator in the personal trust income tax department at the Morgan Guaranty Trust Company in New York. Mr. Tilchen is assistant manager of financial reporting for the F. W. Woolworth Company in New York.

title: ROAD RAMPS STUDY IS VOTED
description: THE Smithtown Town Board has taken a step toward development of a plan to construct new on and off ramps for the Northern State Parkway in the Hauppauge Industrial Park.

title: VANQUISHING THE VARNISH RUN
description: A VARNISH finish that is smooth, lustrous and free of tiny bubbles, dust marks or other blemishes greatly enhances the appearance of wood paneling, cabinets or furniture. However, a varnish finish that is full of runs, drips and blotchy streaks can ruin the appearance of even the finest woods.

title: 6 Thrown Into Bayou; Houston Mother Jailed
description: A woman accused of throwing six of her young children into a bayou, drowning a daughter and critically injuring a son, was charged with murder and attempted murder today.

title: Rose Wants to Play
description: Pete Rose wants his hypen back. Rose, who has been a nonplaying player-manager since his managing self put his player self on the disabled list at the start of the season, said both selves wanted him back on the active list but that neither would rush things.

title: COUNTY CURB ON BOARDINGHOUSE PERMITS IS SOUGHT IN SUFFOLK
description: THE Suffolk County Legislature will be asked to vote on a proposal to prevent the county's Department of Health Services from issuing occupancy permits to boardinghouses that are in violation of town zoning codes.

title:
NUMISMATICS;
WILL CANADA'S NEW ROUND DOLLAR BE A SUCCESS?
description: The overwhelming failure of the Susan B. Anthony dollar has not discouraged other government mints from introducing similar coins. In January 1987, Canadian officials plan to begin issuing a new $1 coin that is 26.5 millimeters in diameter - the same width as the ill-fated Anthony dollar. Like its United States cousin, this will replace a larger $1 coin. And, in another parallel, the new coin is intended to take the place of Canada's dollar bill.

title: ELECTRIC USE SURGES ACROSS ISLAND
description: WHY does electricity consumption on Long Island keep climbing?

title: THERE IS MORE THAN ONE BASIL TO CULTIVATE
description: The Greeks and Romans thought one should curse and stamp upon basil seed when sowing it to ensure germination. The Hindus consider one of its forms sacred. In India, basil is a passport to Paradise. And not so very long ago, if a young lady placed a pot of basil on her windowsill, it was a sure sign to her lover that she was expecting him.

title:
ABOUT WESTCHESTER;
MARKING THE SABBATH
description: ARLENE FREUDENBERGER has a dream: ''It's a Friday night, or a Saturday,'' she said recently, ''and there are hundreds of people walking in the streets. Hundreds of people walking in the streets, to each other's homes, and they are all thinking the same thing: This is the celebration of the Sabbath, and we are participating in it.''

title: The Things Poker Teaches
description: IN 20 YEARS OF PLAYING poker, I have seen very few poor losers. Poker is a game of skill and chance.

title: RACIAL INCIDENTS BESET 2 TOWNS
description: ALBERT CALLOWAY, a black resident of this affluent Essex County suburb, heard a car pulling up near the bushes in front of his house at 4 A.M. recently. He jumped out of bed, afraid that his tires were about to be slashed again, or that his house would be painted once more with racial slurs.

title: BASKING IN THE TWILIGHT GLOW OF AN OLD MASTER
description: Sitting in Andre Segovia's sacerdotal presence the other evening, listening to the 93-year-old guitarist play his annual New York recital, one had to wonder what the younger members of the audience must be thinking. Were they regretting that the fabled mastery that can be experienced on his recordings could be heard only faintly, as if from a great distance? Or were they simply happy to have the chance once more to pay tribute to a legendary artist whose performing career cannot have many more recitals to run? Probably they experienced, as I did, the intertwining of happiness and regret that is inevitably felt during most such appearances by musical patriarchs.

title: 'EDUCATION' AND THE HANDICAPPED CHILD
description: I would appreciate an opportunity to reply to the excellent article ''Handicapped Aid: A Fight on Costs'' [ March 23 ] .

title: NEEME JARVI: HE LETS THE MUSIC BREATHE
description: Those who attended the new production of Mussorgsky's ''Khovanshchina'' at the Metropolitan Opera this season will have noticed the fine work of the conductor, Neeme Jarvi. Mr. Jarvi was born in Estonia in 1937, studied in Leningrad (his teachers included the 20th-century Russian conducting master Eugen Mravinsky) and enjoyed a distinguished career in Russia and Soviet Estonia before emigrating in 1980.

title: Karen Leahy a Bride
description: Karen Leahy, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James N. Leahy of Canton, Ohio, was married yesterday to Dr. Fred Barbaro, the son of Maria Barbaro of New York and the late Salvatore Barbaro. The Rev. F. Forrester Church, minister of the All Souls Unitarian Church, performed the ceremony at the Union Theological Seminary, where the bride had been an assistant to the president. Dr. Barbaro, whose previous marriage ended in divorce, is professor of social theory and founding director of the Center for Learning Disabled Students at Adelphi University.

title: HOT CEVAPCICI ON THE EAST END
description: AT MIRKO'S in Water Mill, the Continental menu is interpreted more broadly than usual. It includes Yugoslavian specialties prepared by the chef and owner, Mirko Zagar, who is from Yugoslavia.

title: BERGEN IS OPTIMISTIC ON EXECUTIVE POST
description: BERGEN County voters will elect their first County Executive in November, and both Republicans and Democrats say county management should become more efficient.

title: AT COUNTY RALLY, O'ROURKE OPENS HIS CAMPAIGN FOR GOVERNOR
description: COUNTY Executive Andrew P. O'Rourke finally made it official last week, declaring before cheering supporters at a breakfast rally that he was seeking the Republican nomination for Governor of New York.

title: LIBEL SUIT TO RECALL INCIDENT OF THE McCARTHY ERA
description: In 1951 the newspaper columnist Victor Lasky appeared at an ''antisubversive seminar'' sponsored by the American Legion post in Fairmont, W. Va. He spoke on ''Soviet and Communist Espionage,'' themes then being aired throughout the country by Senator Joseph McCarthy.

title: BIG GAIN IN G.N.P. IS GREETED WARILY
description: The 3.2 percent growth rate in the G.N.P. in the first quarter could be misleading, many economists warned,They noted that individual economic indicators show an underlying weakness that is masked by the overall figure. For example, industrial production fell five-tenths of 1 percent in March, business inventories rose and capacity utilization slipped to 79.4 percent in March, all indications of sluggishness. The big picture is distorted, the economists say, by such factors as low oil prices, which help keep inflation down but make the economy seem stronger than it is.

title: Read It Now I
description: The 1986 Spring Award for Most Penetrating Washington Book Title goes to Susan Trausch, a reporter for The Boston Globe, whose irreverent account of life in the nation's capital is based, in part, on the historical origin of much of the city's topography. Due next month from Houghton Mifflin Company, the book is called ''It Came From the Swamp; Your Federal Government at Work.''

title: JACKSON LEADS 3-DAY ASSAULT ON PARTY'S DIRECTION
description: The Rev. Jesse Jackson led a three-day assault this week on the Democratic Party's drift to the right in an event designed to consolidate his political authority as he considers a Presidential bid in 1988.

title: TOPICS
description: MOST of us spend a lifetime trying to get lucky.

title: Making a Match
description: Toy train buffs around the world may have dreamed of doing what Richard P. Kughn actually did. The 56-year-old Detroit real estate developer, who has been collecting toy trains since he was 7, disclosed last week that he has agreed to buy the Lionel train division from its most recent owner, Kenner Parker Toys Inc. The division was part of the Lionel Corporation until 1969, when General Mills bought the rights to manufacture the trains and use the Lionel name.

title: F.A.A. CHIEF IS SEEKING TO ASSURE U.S. PUBLIC
description: The head of the Federal Aviation Administration warned last week that terrorists could strike targets in the United States. But he sought to assure the public that his agency was taking measures to counter terrorist attacks.

title: Mekonnen Wins
description: Abebe Mekonnen of Ethiopia won the sixth Rotterdam Marathon in 2 hours 9 minutes 9 seconds today, followed closely by countryman Belaneh Dinsimo in 2:09:15. Both are police officers. Eliinor Lunroos of Sweden was the first woman to finish, in 2:41:00.

title: WESTCHESTER GUIDE
description: GLASS OF EVERY KIND There will be no need to wade through other antiques to get to the see-through stuff at The Westchester Glass Club's 10th Annual All-Glass Show. Experienced collectors and novices will have 12 hours of nothing but glass to revel in from 10 A.M. to 5 P.M. Saturday and noon to 5 P.M. next Sunday at The Woman's Club at 305 Ridgeway Avenue in White Plains.

title: SPRING ANNUALS ARRIVE
description: IT may not be June, but it's spring - and annual reports are busting out all over. Glossier than ever, they keep looking less like financial documents required by Rule 14a-3 of the Securities Exchange Act of 1934 and more like high-quality, color-drenched magazines.

title: NEW REQUIREMENTS FOR HIGH SCHOOL DIPLOMAS PROPOSED
description: A PANEL appointed by Dr. Saul Cooperman, the state Education Commissioner, to review high school graduation requirements has recommended a substantial increase in the number of requirements students must complete for a state-endorsed diploma.

title: CONCERT: DRESDEN ORCHESTRA
description: THE Dresden Chamber Orchestra's Friday night concert at Carnegie Hall can be likened to a meal made up mostly of airy desserts. It contained symphonies by Luigi Boccherini and the 13-year-old Felix Mendelssohn, Mozart's ''Eine Kleine Nachtmusik'' (K.525) and ''Adagio and Fugue in C minor'' (K.546), as well as one recent work ''Fixx Visionen'' by Siegfried Matthus.

title: False Passports Found On Airliner in Cairo
description: Three forged Bahraini passports found aboard a New York-bound T.W.A. Boeing 747 airliner prompted extra security checks and a prolonged stopover in Cairo today, a senior security official said.

title: TENSE DRAMA OF LIFE AND DEATH
description: IN ''Split Second,'' at the Studio Theater in Lindenhurst, the playwright Dennis McIntyre has taken an ordinary situation and colored it with varying shades of moral complexity.

title: A NEW PLAYER PULLS UP TO THE TABLE IN PAKISTAN
description: THE huge crowds that greeted Benazir Bhutto upon her return to Pakistan last weekend were unlike anything seen here since President Mohammad Zia ul-Haq seized power in 1977. The reception accorded the charismatic opposition leader posed a serious test for the 13-month-old civilian Government. It seemed to open a new, potentially turbulent chapter, but ''there are almost as many theories about what could happen,'' one diplomat said, ''as there are people to offer them.''

title: Cheryl S. Glicker, Lawyer, Married
description: Cheryl Sue Glicker, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Stanley Glicker of New Rochelle, N.Y., was married last night to Philip Lloyd Milstein, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Seymour Milstein of Scarsdale, N.Y. Rabbi Robert Kaiser performed the ceremony at the Jewish Community Center of Harrison, N.Y.

title: SOCIAL WORKERS PLAN CONFERENCE ON MEN
description: ''My commitment is to men and to helping them build alliances with women,'' James M. O'Neill, a psychologist at the University of Connecticut, said. Dr. O'Neill will deliver the keynote address at The First National Association of Social Workers Westchester Men's Conference scheduled for May 3 at Westchester Community College.

title: AUCTION AT UCONN TO BENEFIT STUDENTS
description: ARTWORK ranging from well-known artists like Reuben Nakian and Alfredo Zalce to an original drawing that appeared as a ''Katzenjammer Kids'' comic strip will be among some 300 art and antique items to be auctioned by UConn's School of Fine Arts on Saturday.

title: JOURNEY AMONG TYRANTS
description: It's about time that someone said, right out loud, that this country appears to be swapping democracy for hypocrisy.

title: The Cruncher Crunch
description: With Congress, insurers and lawyers grappling over the issue of soaring liability insurance rates and cancellations, insurers met in the capital last week, and the problem was brought home dramatically. Among those attending were representatives of the American Academy of Actuaries, the people who crunch the numbers to determine who gets insured at what rates. The group had just had its liability insurance canceled.

title:
ART;
AN 'ART EXPLORATION' AT GLEN COVE GALLERIES
description: ''TOP of the Eighties,'' a series of exhibitions launched last month by the Hempstead Harbor Artists Association, is an effort to expand the organization's horizons and attract exhibitors from elsewhere.

title: A SAFER WAY TO PLAY JUNK BONDS
description: RARELY have the rewards for shunning quality been greater, which is why ''junk'' bonds - corporate bonds rated BB or lower - are attracting investors. The Treasury bond yield, as charted by Salomon Brothers Inc., is down from 11.6 percent a year ago to near 7 percent, a level not seen in 13 years. But the yield on Salomon's High-Yield Industrial Bond Index is at about 14 percent, a drop of only 1.6 percent from a year ago.

title: Sending a Message
description: The only intimidating performed in last night's hockey game was performed by the referee, Denis Morel, and that's the way it should be.

title: 350th-BIRTHDAY PARTY ENDING WITH CELEBRATION AND CRITIQUE
description: THE ghost of P. T. Barnum will help close out the state's celebration of its 350th birthday next Saturday - and the legendary huckster is a fitting symbol for both organizers and critics of the yearlong party.

title: Alison Lehr, Lawyer, Wed To Executive
description: Alison Whitney Lehr, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. David Lehr of Miami Beach and Lexington, Va., was married yesterday to Jonathan Marc Prusky, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Paul Prusky of Philadelphia. The ceremony was performed at Temple Israel in Miami by Rabbis Rex Perlmeter and Louis Frishman.

title: EAST AND WEST ARE KNOCKING ON INDONESIA'S DOOR
description: The Russians come offering aid. China wants trade; Australia wants friendship. New Zealand lobbies for a nuclear-free zone, and both sides in the Cambodian war seek a peacemaker in Jakarta.

title: QADDAFI IS ALSO FACING HOMEGROWN OPPOSITION
description: LONG before the Americans began their step-by-step escalation of force in retaliation for Libyan-sponsored terrorism in Europe, Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi was facing the worst internal problem he has confronted as the leader of Libya - the sharp drop in oil prices.

title: QUARTETS REVEAL MILHAUD AND PISTON
description: For some composers (Haydn, Beethoven and Bartok immediately spring to mind) the string quartet seems to have been the medium into which they poured their deepest thoughts and most innovative ideas. For others - Mozart, Mendelssohn, and in our century, Shostakovich -string quartets seem more to reflect insights gained composing in other media: keyboard, orchestral and perhaps even theatrical. Into this category fall the quartets of two 20th-century composers, the American Walter Piston (1894-1976) and the Frenchman Darius Milhaud (1892-1974).

title: Women Learn Skills of Sailing
description: It takes more than a fair share of determination for a woman with two children to pack her bags and take off alone for a week to go sailing. But that is exactly the kind of behavior that is being encouraged by a unusual sailing school in Annapolis, Md.

title: THE LARGER QUESTION OF BELLEROSE VILLAGE
description: I am glad that the recent article by Solomon Kunis [ ''Three Faces of Bellerose: Charms and Disputes,'' Opinion Page ] has brought the matter of Bellerose Village to public attention.

title: PERVASIVE SEX BIAS FOUND IN COURTS
description: Bias against women in the New York State court system is so pervasive that ''they are often denied equal justice,'' according to a report by a special state task force that studied the courts for almost two years.

title: The 'Pioneers'
description: To the Editor:

title: Miss Richardson Engaged to Wed C. R. Macdonald
description: Announcement has been made by R. Randolph Richardson of New York and Dalton Arnold Andrews of Bethesda, Md., of the engagement of their daughter, Catharine Dalton Richardson, to Charles Richard Macdonald, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Donald Arthur Macdonald of Rumson, N.J. An August wedding is planned. The future bride, who is known as Cassie, is a graduate of the Holton Arms School and Brown University.

title: Seeking Perfection At Science Hall
description: THE New York Hall of Science, undergoing a $10 million renovation since it closed in 1981, took a scientific approach to creating exhibits as it prepared to reopen.

title: MODERN ITALIAN IN COLONIAL SETTING
description: WHAT was once a modest Italian eatery has metamorphosed, under new ownership, into a modern, stylized version of a colonial tavern, with a wooded fireplace frame and mantle tacked against a wall, Windsor chairs, and two homey bookcases filled with old volumes.

title: A BRASH YANKEE AND A SOUTHERN DANDY
description: ON THE EDGE By Kenneth Koch. 98 pp. New York: Elisabeth Sifton Books/Viking. Cloth, $18.95. Penguin Books. Paper, $8.95. HURRICANE LAMP By Turner Cassity. 68 pp. Illinois: The University of Chicago Press. Cloth, $15. Paper, $6.95. ''IS there some way to ride to old age and to fame and acceptance,'' Kenneth Koch asks in a poem called ''The Art of Poetry,'' ''And pride in oneself and the knowledge society approves one / Without getting lousier and lousier and depleted of talent?'' He answers his question with an emphatic ''Yes,'' invoking the careers of Yeats and Sophocles as evidence.

title: OFT-PRODUCED PLAY GETS STATE PREMIERE AT HARTFORD STAGE
description: THE least known, most frequently performed new play in regional theaters this season may be ''On the Verge,'' the offbeat comedy by Eric Overmyer that will have its state premiere at the Hartford Stage Company on Friday.

title: 'HI, WE NEED $1 MILLION FOR A FILM''
description: My work is a combination of film, music, electronics, storytelling, dancing, social commentary, impersonation, animation and anything else I come up with. What I do has been described as ''high-tech opera,'' ''live art,'' ''electronic stand-up comedy,'' ''avant-rock'' and that clumsy label ''performance art,'' which has always sounded to me like a bad translation from German. Fortunately, nobody knows what ''performance art'' refers to. This frees artists to experiment outside the traditions of dance, theater, music and narrative and still be included in festivals.

title: WHALERS LOSE, 3-1; SERIES TIED AT 1-1
description: Guy Carbonneau, a defensive specialist, scored two goals tonight to lead the Montreal Canadiens to a 3-1 triumph over the Hartford Whalers and tie their four-of-seven-game Adams Division final series at 1-1. The third game will be Monday at Hartford Civic Center.

title: A Broker Is Wed To Miss Andreae
description: The Episcopal Church of the Heavenly Rest was the setting yesterday for the wedding of Elizabeth Ann Andreae, the daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Eric Andreae of Tenafly, N.J., to Henry Overstreet Booth 3d. The bridegroom is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Booth Jr. of Nashville.

title: Elizabeth Birkelund Becomes Bride Of C. L. Oberbeck, Development Aide
description: Elizabeth Birkelund, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John P. Birkelund of New York and New Canaan, Conn., was married yesterday to Christian Long Oberbeck, a son of Paul A. Oberbeck and Cecil A. Oberbeck of Englewood, N.J., at the Roman Catholic Church of St. Ignatius Loyola in New York. Msgr. George F. Bardes officiated.

title: IN LIFTING HIS GAME HIGHER, NICKLAUS LIFTED US ALL
description: WHEN Jack Nicklaus sank his birdie putt on the 71st hole of the Masters last Sunday, the smile he flashed beamed across the pines of Augusta and back through the years of great tournaments and great champions to the origins of the game. It was the smile of a man who had fulfilled his aspirations and had for all time secured his place in the history of a game that has fashioned prodigious heros. Even if Tom Kite or Greg Norman had tied or beaten him, his golfing reputation would have been burnished forever. And when Kite's tying putt just shuddered past the hole, and Norman's second shot at No. 18 went astray, Jack Nicklaus did what many had thought impossible, even for Jack. At the age of 46, he won his sixth Masters and 20th major tournament, perhaps the most awesome record in all of sports.

title: I.B.M. TO BEGIN WORK ON ROAD
description: International Business Machines, which is building a corporate headquarters on Route 138 in Somers, has announced that it will begin work on the entrance road that was originally approved by the town, following the failure of negotiations that would have permitted an alternative road, preferred by the town, to be built.

title: Art
description: Mark Tobey (1890-1976) may no longer be the world figure that he was around 25 years ago, but he does not deserve to be forgotten. At the height of his fame, not long after World War II, he was regarded by many Europeans as the archetypal American painter of the day.

title: YALE PANEL RULES PROTESTERS CAN BUILD NEW SHANTYTOWN
description: Less than a week after Yale University ordered the demolition of a shantytown built by anti-apartheid protesters on a campus plaza, a special Yale faculty committee granted permission today to build a new shantytown on the same site.

title: 2 MANSIONS TO STAR IN DESIGN SHOW
description: THE Spring Designers' Showcase opens its 13th season tomorrow with a six-week-long decorative arts show at two mansions that are part of Nassau County's Sands Point Preserve, Hempstead House and Mille Fleurs.

title: The Subjective Split Decision
description: IN a subjective split decision that also split the subjective ringside opinion in the most subjective sport, Michael Spinks maintained his reign as the International Boxing Federation heavyweight champion last night over 15 busy rounds. And with a second loss to Spinks after a 48-0 record, Larry Holmes walked off into the sunset in his white satin robe, growling and grumbling.
