title: POTTERY INSPIRED BY THE RENAISSANCE
description: William Andrews Clark collected Italian majolica at the turn of the century at a time when these colorful Renaissance ceramics were sought by American self-made industrialists in much the same way that Tiffany lamps are today. Until the opening here at the Mount Holyoke College Art Museum of ''Italian Renaissance Majolica,'' however, most of his painted pottery collection has never been seen by the public.

title: A TRAINING SERIES FOR YOUNG DRIVERS
description: For young racing drivers intent on competing in the Indy Car World Series, the step up from existing training series has been a large one, both from the driving and the financial perspective. But if a new, limited-cost training series that made its debut earlier this month works out as well as its proponents hope, a driver with ambitions to compete at Indianapolis will have a clear path to follow with no big gaps in the steps along the way.

title: Broad Brush Is Winner
description: Broad Brush, a frequent winner against mediocre horses, took advantage of some top horses having a bad day to score a major upset victory in the $297,500 Wood Memorial at Aqueduct yesterday.

title: 'Zia Will Go,' Bhutto Promises
description: The opposition leader Benazir Bhutto said today that Gen. Mohammad Zia ul-Haq must give up power this year and that elections must be held by fall.

title: A Car Bomb In Brooklyn
description: In Brooklyn and Manhattan courtrooms and on the streets of Bensonhurst, evidence mounted last week that a Federal crackdown has created turmoil in New York City's major organized crime factions.

title: Brisk Sales Reported For $20 Million Lotto
description: Sales of New York State Lotto tickets reached a peak of $731,000 an hour yesterday about noon, with buyers lured by the prospect of winning $20 million in last night's drawing.

title: BEWARE THE UNDERDOG
description: TEFUGA Peter Dickinson. 256 pp. New York: Pantheon Books. $14.95. IT isn't surprising that ''Tefuga,'' Peter Dickinson's amusing and elegantly structured tour de force about Nigeria, is very English. At the time of the recent PEN conference, Edward Hoagland pointed out on The New York Times's Op-Ed page the great deficiency of American writers in being so unconcerned about the rest of the world: ''I would guess that five times as many have been to Tuscany as to the whole continent of Africa; that more have visited Barcelona than all of South America. . . . Much of the extraordinary ignorance of most Amercans about what has been happening elsewhere . . . is due to the fact that their eyes and ears - their writers - have stayed home.''

title: HUNTING TURKEYS IN SPRING CALLS FOR PATIENCE AND DEVOTION
description: IF a turkey hunter is among your acquaintances, you will soon begin to notice a certain restlessness in him, and if you drop in at his home next weekend, you may find a spade in an empty wheelbarrow beside a plot of earth that should have been readied for planting a fortnight before.

title: EMELIN TO BEGIN PRODUCING PLAYS
description: THE dream of having a home-grown production company at Mamaroneck's popular booking house, the Emelin Theater, will no longer be deferred. In May, the theater's managing director, Norman Kline, will turn from presenting to producing as well. After two preview performances, Tina Howe's lyrical play, ''Painting Churches,'' a critical success of the 1983-84 Off Broadway season, will run for eight performances.

title: Dream Homes Often a Reality in Madison
description: EVER since the turn of the century, Madison has been considered a fashionable Connecticut seafaring community favored by vacation-home buyers as well as year-round residents.

title:
NATURE WATCH;
GLOSSY IBIS
description: Plegadis falcinallus Size: 20 to 26 inches long.

title: Did Justice Fall From the Skies Over Tripoli?; Forgetful France
description: To the Editor:

title: SUMMER RENTALS BOOMING
description: LAST year at this time, the East End summer rental market seemed to be at low tide.

title: LASERS GLORIFY OLD TAPES
description: W. H. Auden, who on occasion was as much a philosopher as a poet, observed that ''for many of us, some of our most important 'new' experiences are the discoveries about the hitherto unknown past.'' This may explain the recent surge of interest in historical recordings.

title: POLITICS ASIDE, IS GRAMM-RUDMAN LEGAL?
description: ONE of the most potentially far-reaching constitutional battles of the century will be fought Wednesday before the Supreme Court as the justices hear oral argument on the new law that mandates a balanced Federal budget by 1991. The question is whether it violates the separation of powers or unduly delegates authority to unelected officials. The law, sponsored by Senators Phil Gramm of Texas and Warren B. Rudman of New Hampshire, Republicans, and Ernest F. Hollings of South Carolina, Democrat, requires that the deficit be reduced in large installments over the next five years. Federal spending is to be reduced automatically if the anticipated deficit exceeds the statutory target for any year. The cuts are computed by the Comptroller General of the United States, who is head of the General Accounting Office, a widely respected auditing and investigative agency. The role of the Comptroller General and of his predecessor, the Comptroller of the Treasury, has generated fierce debate since the founding of the Republic because, in a sense, the office embodies the power of the purse. As demonstrated by the following excerpts from briefs filed with the Supreme Court by parties in the case, the debate continues still. ARGUING AGAINST: Representative Mike Synar, Democrat of Oklahoma, and 11 members of Congress Congress cannot delegate its constitutional responsibility to determine how taxpayer moneys are to be spent in the way that it did here. . . .

title: A Roundup On the Border
description: Law officers from Mexico and the United States have cooperated over the last two months in rounding up along the Mexican border more than 3,500 fugitives from justice, Federal officials announced last week.

title: CONCERT: SHELTON, DeGAETANI AND KALISH
description: THe theme of the evening was ''Music for Mobilization,'' and the thread of vocal duets that ran through this concert at Holy Trinity Church on Friday evoked an appropriate sense of solidarity. The program, to be specific, was given in the name of peace, justice and disarmament.

title: NEW YORK INSPECTORS CITE 45 FOOD OUTLETS FOR HEALTH OFFENSES
description: The New York City Department of Health last week released a list of 45 food establishments cited for violating the health code.

title: LIFE ON THE LANES: HAVE DRILL, WILL TRAVEL
description: LIKE athletes in many other sports, professional bowlers are inclined to blame their equipment when things suddenly go wrong.

title: A SHOW THAT EDUCATES AS WELL AS DELIGHTS
description: In the days when we could still speak of ''a liberal education'' without getting run out of town on a rail, it was taken for granted that access to original works of art was fundamental to higher education. ''Art education'' was not a matter of listening to someone droning away in front of beat-up old slides of Raphael and Michelangelo. Ideally, it was an active, participatory affair, in which a charismatic scholar put an unfamiliar painting on the table in front of his students and asked them to identify, as best they could, its date, place of origin, medium, subject and possible author. That was the real thing, the one-on-one thing, the dialogue in which an art historian doubled as a friendly neighborhood Socrates.

title: PRESERVING REMINDERS OF COLONIAL PAST
description: Some of Boston's most popular tourist attractions are dead. They have names like Hancock and Revere and Adams and they lie in 16 historic burying grounds that the city oversees, the oldest three dating to 1630.

title: REJUVENATING OLDER OFFICE BUILDINGS
description: AS the office-construction boom gives tenants the advantage over owners in today's rental market, more and more owners of older buildings are attempting to maintain competitiveness by renovating or refreshing their properties.

title:
GARDENING;
WISTERIA: A VINE WORTH ITS TROUBLE
description: WISTERIA grows rapidly, as much as four to five feet a year, and can literally choke a tree to death. Yet, it is valued as being one of the more attractive ornamental vines.

title: CORRECTION
description: The caption on a photograph with the New Jersey Journal on April 6 was incorrect. It showed Deborah L. Sivco with a molecular beam epitaxi chamber at the A.T. & T. Bell Laboratories.

title: 1 KILLED, 90 HURT AS TORNADOES STRIKE TEXAS TOWN
description: Two tornadoes spawned by thunderstorms struck this west Texas city today, killing at least one person, injuring 90 and causing millions of dollars in damage, the authorities said.

title: Bangladesh Teachers Sit-In
description: More than 10,000 striking teachers from non-Government schools held a sit-in outside Bangladesh's main Government offices today, blocking roads and halting traffic for several hours. About 150,000 teachers from nearly 10,000 non-Government secondary schools are on strike because, they contend, they are being discriminated against compared to teachers working in government schools.

title: THE IMPERILED LANDSCAPES OF THE HUDSON RIVER VALLEY
description: ACID rain, long suspected of damaging lakes and forests in the Adirondacks, is also endangering lakes within 50 miles of Manhattan, an environmental group contended last week.

title: Mary E. Newcombe Wed To Peter Dij Vogl, Lawyer
description: Mary Elizabeth Newcombe, a fashion designer, and Peter Dij Vogl, a lawyer, were married yesterday at the Community Congregational Church in Lathrup Village, Mich., by the Rev. Dr. Thomas Beaven.

title: SAND MINE PLAN IS DISPUTED
description: THE Town of Smithtown and the state are involved in a dispute over whether sand mining should be allowed to pay for renovating a park.

title: ASTRONAUT RETURNS
description: The Westchester astronaut Jeffrey A. Hoffman will make a special guest appearance this afternoon at the Hudson River Museum's grand farewell to Halley's comet.

title: RECENT RELEASES OF VIDEO CASSETTES
description: A Year in the Life of Placido Domingo Featuring Placido Domingo, Kiri Te Kanawa, Marilyn Zschau, Katia Ricciarelli and Colin Davis Kultur 105 minutes. $39.95 ''A Year in the Life of Placido Domingo'' is sheer, unadulterated puffery, but contains some first-class singing and can therefore be recommended to Mr. Domingo's many admirers.

title: RECENT RELEASES OF VIDEO CASSETTES
description: Putting It Together The Making of the Broadway Album, featuring Barbra Streisand CBS/Fox Video Music 60 minutes. $29.98 Only diehard Barbra Streisand fans will treasure ''Putting It Together,'' a behind-the-scenes look at the making of her landmark ''Broadway Album.''

title: From Manhattan to Montvale
description: For most corporations, a prime Park Avenue address is for headquarters offices only. But the ''Big Eight'' accounting firm of Peat, Marwick, Mitchell & Company now has its computer operations in 425 Park Avenue at 56th Street.

title: Did Justice Fall From the Skies Over Tripoli?; Fighting Fire
description: To the Editor:

title: Jazz
description: Last fall, Kay Starr returned to New York night life for the first time in 15 years and created such a stir at Freddy's, 308 West 49th Street, that Frank Nolan, the club's owner, is bringing her back for a two-week encore starting Tuesday. From her beginnings in the 1940's, when the country and Western music of her native Oklahoma mixed with her jazz training with Joe Venuti's band, Charlie Barnet's hard swinging crew and Bob Crosby's big Dixieland band, Miss Starr has had a lusty, forthright singing style that added zest to any song she sang.

title: MAYORS' SUIT STALLS RESORT RAIL LINE
description: A GROUP of Camden County mayors, arguing that Federal authorities too hastily gave the go-ahead to reconstruct the Philadelphia-Atlantic City rail line, have filed suit in Federal Court to force a full review of the environmental implications.

title: REAGAN CREDITS DECONTROL FOR LOW OIL PRICES, URGING SAME FOR GAS
description: President Reagan, attributing falling oil and gasoline prices to his Administration's lifting of controls on all domestic oil, today called for the complete decontrol of natural gas prices and production to further reduce energy prices.

title: Talking Buyouts; Windfall Gains in a Conversion
description: ONE of the more appealing aspects of a co-op or condominium conversion in New York City is the chance for a tenant to make money even if he cannot - or prefers not to - buy his apartment.

title:
DINING OUT;
A CASE OF COURAGE IN LAMBERTVILLE
description: ALMOST a year ago, a man named Alan Aptner, who was without formal culinary training, was courageous enough to buy a restaurant in Lambertville called Cafe Renni and reopen it under the name Savoir Fare.

title: THIS TIME AROUND, BRONSON PORTRAYS THE VICTIM
description: The title, ''Act of Vengeance,'' sounds like the usual fare for its star, Charles Bronson, whose heroics in the ''Death Wish'' movie trilogy have made him a popular icon of the incensed loner challenging an array of evil forces. But in this original HBO film, which has its premiere tonight at 8, Mr. Bronson, while playing a similar role, turns a twist on his steely image. This time he is the victim.

title: TEXAS FINDS SYMPATHY IN SHORT SUPPLY
description: WHEN Governors from six oil-producing states gathered outside Dallas last week, the frustrations they voiced about their economic problems went beyond the beleaguered petroleum industry. At issue was a more fundamental question that is becoming an increasingly persistent theme throughout the oil patch - are regional differences and antagonisms rather than long-term policy considerations dominating the national response to oil's travail?

title: Stacye Goldberg Wed To Alan Joel Zauzmer
description: Stacye April Goldberg and Alan Joel Zauzmer were married yesterday at the Stronghold Mansion in Bernardsville, N.J. Rabbi Alexander M. Shapiro officiated.

title: CREATING MESSAGES IN FILM
description: ''IT IS extremely important not to talk down to the viewer,'' said Newton E. Meltzer of Rosyln Heights. ''You're taking someone by the hand and guiding him like an old trusted friend into a place where you've been, so he can feel the same amazement or emotion or pleasure or distaste, if you will, that you did. Essentially, that is my philosophy.''

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: HIGH HEARTS. By Rita Mae Brown. (Bantam, $17.95.) This expansive novel of the Civil War contains what must surely be the first in-saddle marital squabble between two members of a Virginia cavalry regiment. Geneva Chatfield, tall for her 18 years and an excellent horsewoman, can't stand the idea of her new husband, Nash Hart, running off to the cavalry and leaving her back on the plantation. So she cuts off her hair, convinces her mother and her best slave friend, Di-Peachy, to stay quiet about it, and sneaks off to join up. Nash seems as much turned off as surprised by this, and that's where the conjugal discord begins. (She's a much better rider; he's in the Ashley Wilkes part, the unfortunate kind of soldier who quickly earns the nickname ''Piggy Woo.'') The war is also beginning, and here Rita Mae Brown's childhood fascination with Virginia battlefields -and her extensive research for this book - serve her well. She knows her horses, and the movements of a cavalry unit in the battles of First Manassas and the Seven Days are excitingly painted. Women did indeed dress as men and fight in the war, and this idea comes alive. While the story rides breathlessly in Geneva's saddle, all is well. But the author's intention is to render the larger story of women's roles in the war, to create, she says, a ''monument'' to them. After all the careful interweaving of feuding slaves, sainted mothers, gossiping Richmond hostesses and the inevitable gold-hearted madam, the sound of guns comes to seem a relief.

title: Barbara Anderson and David McDonald Are Wed
description: Barbara A. Anderson and David Calvin McDonald were married yesterday at Christ Episcopal Church in Greenwich, Conn. The Rev. John Bishop officiated.

title: ''Very Glad''
description: Vladimir Horowitz announced in January that although he had intended never to return to his homeland, he would visit the Soviet Union this spring to give recitals in Moscow and Leningrad as part of the cultural exchange arranged at the Geneva summit. ''Before I die,'' said the pianist, who is 81 years old, ''I want to see the country in which I was born.''

title: KILLED, HOLDING ACES AND EIGHTS
description: DEADWOOD By Pete Dexter. 365 pp. New York: Random House. $17.95.

title: MIXED RESULTS IN APARTHEID ACTIONS
description: A WAVE of organizing campaigns has produced mixed results this month for groups in the state seeking to exert pressure on the Government of South Africa.

title: Diane Flannery, an M.B.A. Candidate, To Marry James T. Knight, a Lawyer
description: The engagement of Diane Marie Flannery, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph P. Flannery of Cheshire, Conn., and Harwich Port, Mass., to James Thomas Knight, a son of Virginia A. Knight of Manchester, N.H., and the late James Vincent Knight, has been announced by the parents of the bride-to-be.

title: New & Noteworthy
description: MIAMI AND THE SIEGE OF CHICAGO: An Informal History of the Republican and Democratic Conventions of 1968, by Norman Mailer. (Primus/Donald I. Fine, $7.95.) These pieces of interpretive reporting re-create the 1968 conventions and in the process dramatize the political life of the nation in a turbulent year. Wilfrid Sheed wrote here in 1968 that the Miami essay was disappointing, ''partly because of the flatness of the occasion.'' But in the essay on the Democratic gathering in Chicago, ''the city itself excited Mailer and unleashed in him the child-observer, resident in every great descriptive novelist.'' The vignettes, Mr. Sheed said, ''have imperial authority.'' THE MACKEREL PLAZA, by Peter De Vries. (Penguin, $6.95.) In this comic novel, the widowed Rev. Andrew (Holy) Mackerel, of People's Liberal Church, wishes to remarry but his congregation is set on canonizing his dear departed wife. A. C. Spectorsky said in The Book Review in 1958 that ''the risible resources inherent in a raunchy, reform-reverend's race down the road to self-ruin are exploited with tireless ingenuity and wit.'' The same publisher has reissued THE PRICK OF NOON ($5.95), in which Peter De Vries's hero, Eddie Teeters, leads a double life as a porn king and a Connecticut social climber. In these pages in 1985, Clancy Sigal found the book thin on plot and character but said ''the hero sprays puns and smart-aleck ripostes like a machine gun gone out of control.'' ALMA MATER: Design and Experience in the Women's Colleges From Their Nineteenth-Century Beginnings to the 1930s, by Helen Lefkowitz Horowitz.

title: POLITICS WITH A PENCHANT FOR MELODRAMA
description: Several years ago a Secretary of the Israeli Cabinet was asked during a boisterous demonstration outside the Prime Minister's office whether the ministers inside were being disturbed. ''No,'' he told reporters with a wry grin, ''the Cabinet room is well insulated from the outside world.''

title: Easing the Chore For Developers
description: To stimulate the construction of housing for middle-income New Yorkers, Mayor Koch said last week, the city must dust off the welcome mat for developers.

title: JERSEY CITY DEVELOPMENT BEGINS TO TURN SKYWARD
description: ''FOR generations, we have looked across the Hudson River and admired the Manhattan skyline,'' said Thomas J. Stanton Jr., chairman of the First Jersey National Corporation, a $3.4 billion bank holding company here. ''Now we are going to give the people of Manhattan a skyline to look at.''

title: SAFETY OF SHELLFISH AND OF SWIMMERS
description: Obviously Gordon Colvin of the State Department of Environmental Conservation can afford to sit behind his desk and talk about cooperation from the clammers while his agency helps to put these baymen out of business [ ''Controversy Intensifies on Shellfish Safety,'' March 23 ] . Meanwhile our resources continue to be lost at the rate of hundreds of underwater acres annually in the name of ''development.''

title: REBORN WILKES-BARRE COUNTS '72 FLOOD AS BLESSING
description: Like a bowling ball jumping lanes, the swollen Susquehanna River crashed through its banks here in 1972, carving a channel through the narrow Wyoming Valley and crushing this low-lying town.

title: Did Justice Fall From the Skies Over Tripoli?; When Hitler Ranted
description: To the Editor:

title: VANCOUVER
description: Vancouver is getting ready for a glittering summer celebrating its 100th birthday with a world's fair, Expo 86, which opens a five-month run May 2 with more than 50 nations taking part. Visitors exhausted by Expo will find that Vancouver is also a fine city for relaxation. Its many well-groomed parks are made for quiet picnics. Its backdrop of 4,000-foot peaks in the Coast Mountains range is spectacularly beautiful.

title: Village for Sale
description: FOR the fourth time in 27 years, Shadyside Village, Pa., a community with 21 houses, 12 garages and a chapel on 32.9 acres, was for sale.

title: Elizabeth McKendry To Wed R. S. Anderson
description: Elizabeth Phillips of Fitzwilliam, N.H., and George McKendry of Wilton, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter Elizabeth Phillips McKendry to Richard Sanford Anderson, a son of State Senator Warren M. Anderson and Mrs. Anderson of Binghamton, N.Y. A September wedding is planned.

title: HOSPITAL FEES IN STATE BELOW AREA'S AVERAGE
description: THE state's innovative pay-by-the-illness system for controlling hospital costs has saved patients money, according to the latest statistical report by the Princeton-based New Jersey Hospital Association.

title: FEMALE VETERANS: MORE AID ASKED
description: JILL MISHKEL of Glastonbury, a former Army nurse in Vietnam, says she believes that the 16,000 female veterans in Connecticut deserve more counseling, better medical care at Veterans Administration hospitals and, most importantly, she said, better access to information on the services they are entitled to.

title: AUSTRALIA
description: To the Editor: I read with great interest your article on traveling by train in Australia. My daughter and I traveled in Australia last summer and did quite a bit of it by train.

title: DON'T GET MAD, GET THE MOP
description: THERE'S been a fight in our house. Words were carelessly thrown. Feelings were hurt. Good intentions went ignored, unrecognized. I feel absolutely terrible. But in a way - secretly, inside - I'm a little glad. The house is dirty. I know it will get cleaned today.

title: Leave It To the People?
description: There's a popular notion, almost a rule in Washington, that you can criticize anybody or anything except the American people. They would know what to do on earth or even in outer space.

title: FROM STRIP TO SHINING STRIP
description: MAIN STREET TO MIRACLE MILE American Roadside Architecture. By Chester H. Liebs. Illustrated. 259 pp. Boston: New York Graphic Society/ Little, Brown & Company. Cloth, $40. Paper, $19.95.

title: Hobart Downs Syracuse
description: Ray Gilliam scored three goals to power Division III Hobart College to a 16-13 victory over Division I Syracuse University today in a battle between college lacrosse's two top-ranked teams. Syracuse is now 9-2, while Hobart improved its record to 8-1 and 2-1 against Division I competition.

title: Verbatim; Controlling Destiny
description: 'It is incongruous, if not monstrous, for medical practitioners to assert their right to preserve a life that someone else must live, or, more accurately, endure, for 15 to 20 years. The right to die is an integral part of our right to control our own destinies so long as the rights of others are not affected.

title: Alexander Hadjiyane Wed to Miss Ippolito
description: Carylann Ippolito, a fourth-year student at the Downstate Medical Center of the State University of New York, and Alexander Hadjiyane, an architect with George W. Clark Associates in New York, were married yesterday.

title: CYCLES OF CONFLICT
description: A HISTORY OF THE ISRAELI ARMY #1874 to the Present. By Ze'ev Schiff. Illustrated. 274 pp. New York: Macmillan Publishing Company. $25.

title: Going On in the Northeast
description: ORNAMENTAL GARDENS Live but motionless, a hunter on horseback leaps over a gate at the Ladew Topiary Gardens north of Jacksonville, Md., one of dozens of achievements there in the art of training and trimming trees and shrubs into ornamental shapes.

title: NAUTILUS MUSEUM OPENING TOMORROW
description: ABOUT 2,500 people were expected to attend opening ceremonies today for the Submarine Force Library and Museum in Groton, which features as its centerpiece the decommissioned Nautilus, the world's first nuclear submarine.

title: LONG ISLAND GUIDE
description: CURRIER AND IVES Currier and Ives, the 19th-century lithographers, are alive and well and flourishing at Hofstra University; at least 40 of their prized prints - including the 1840 ''Awful Conflagration of the Steamboat 'Lexington' in Long Island Sound,'' which established the firm's reputation when it was used as a pioneering news-story illustration - are on display. Part of the university's permanent collection, the prints have just undergone extensive restoration and are being shown at the Cultural Center Gallery on the 10th floor of the library on the Hempstead campus. ''Preserving Our Heritage: A Celebration of the Restoration of Hofstra's Collection of Currier and Ives Prints'' runs through June 13 and can be seen from 9 A.M. to 4:45 P.M. weekdays; to 9 P.M. Tuesdays; and from 1 to 5 P.M. weekends.DOUBLE SOLISTI

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: THE INDIANS IN AMERICAN SOCIETY: From the Revolutionary War to the Present. By Francis Paul Prucha. (University of California, $15.95.) Generations of interpreters have used Indians as exhibits - as savages bravely conquered, or as heroes treacherously dispossessed - in making the case for our national virtue or villainy.

title: Q AND A
description: Adult Communities Question: I am interested in purchasing a town house in a condominium complex in New Jersey, and I would like my new home to be in the type of community where there is a requirement that the minimum age for residents be 18 years. How can I obtain information on where they are situated? . . . B. H., Brooklyn Answer: There is no central listing for such communities, said a spokesman for the New Jersey chapter of the Community Associations Institute, a member of a national network of condominium directors and their professional advisers. He suggested that you inquire among real-estate dealers in the area in which you would like to live and let them know your requirements. Turn-of-the-Century Bank Question: We have recently moved to lower Manhattan and have noticed a very handsome building on the northwest corner of William and Beaver Streets. The building is unoccupied and bricked up and is beginning to show signs of neglect. Could you tell us something about its history and about any plans for its future use? . . . V. T., Manhattan Answer: The 11-story structure to which you refer, at 15 William Street, was built in 1894 by the Corn Exchange Bank. It is part of a property foreclosed by the city in 1979 that also includes 23 William Street and 51-53 Beaver Street. According to Chistopher Gray, the architectural historian, the building at 15 William Street and the adjoining 20-story structure at 51-53 Beaver Street, erected by the bank in 1903, were designed in a neo-Romanesque style by R. H. Robertson.

title: Topics; Back to the Future; Mass Transit
description: A woman who hasn't pushed a stroller in years found herself in SoHo recently just as two groups of children from day-care centers took to the street. The safe airing of 3-year-olds en masse in the city requires sophisticated logistics.

title: JOHN C. MUNN
description: Lieut. Gen. John C. Munn of the Marine Corps. retired, a former assistant commandant of the corps, died here Monday. He was 79 years old.

title: Elizabeth McNamara Marries L. W. Dexheimer
description: Elizabeth Dobson McNamara, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William B. McNamara of Greenwich, Conn., was married yesterday to Lawrence William Dexheimer, a son of Harold Dexheimer of Hackensack, N.J., and the late Gretchen Bartel Dexheimer, in the Dingletown Community Church in Greenwich. The Rev. Harry Adams performed the Episcopal ceremony.

title: G.N.P. Grew At Faster Pace In First Quarter
description: At last week's report of markedly faster economic growth in the first three months of 1986 than in the last quarter of 1985, the Reagan Administration was characteristically upbeat. And characteristically, many private economists were less so.

title: NEW HOPE FOR INFERTILE COUPLES
description: MRS. R., a 30-year-old lawyer who wants to have a baby, recently sought medical help at University Hospital in Stony Brook when she did not menstruate for several months after she stopped taking birth-control pills.

title: Cervantes Translated
description: To the Editor:

title: CANADIAN BORDER FACES ALIEN PROBLEM OF ITS OWN
description: Blaine G. Davis stepped from his dusty, green patrol car, pushed back his hat and let his eyes wander up the desolate dirt road stretching toward the northern horizon.

title: GUITARIST WITH A TASTE FOR NEW FRONTIERS
description: Like the speaker in the Robert Frost poem, the guitarist John Williams chanced upon a pair of divergent roads. But while the poet felt compelled to choose between them, Mr. Williams has found a way to take them both. In the late 1950's - before he was 20 - he had developed a technique so dazzling and precise that his mentor, Andres Segovia, described him as ''a prince of the guitar.'' By the mid-1960's, he was voraciously exploring the guitar's literature and doing everything Mr. Segovia had mandated: he commissioned new works, rediscovered and transcribed old ones, toured the world and made dozens of exemplary recordings.

title: BOLIVIA'S STRUGGLE FOR A STABLE ECONOMY
description: MOST Latin American countries today remain locked in a desperate struggle to restore economic stability and to promote recovery. Fragile democracies must grapple with a crippling debt burden, high inflation and falling living standards, in societies that are polarized over fundamental issues of political and economic organization.

title: METS WIN, 3-2, ON CARTER'S HIT
description: The lineup seemed strangely out of order. A rookie began the day in center field and batted leadoff. Another was making his first appearance in the big leagues. The catcher played in left field.

title: CITY CANCELS CONTRACT FOR S.I. SITE: CITES ROLE OF LAMBERTI IN THE SALE
description: The Koch administration announced yesterday that it had canceled the sale of a 50-acre site for a shopping center to a former business partner of Borough President Ralph J. Lamberti of Staten Island.

title: Teaching Girls The Right Moves
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: MUSIC IN BRITAIN, HOURS AT THE SMITHSONIAN
description: Curtain Up In England For admirers of those very merry gentlemen named Gilbert and Sullivan, the touristic curtain goes up June 2, with an encore July 7. Those are the departure dates of a tour called ''A Behind the Scene Look at Gilbert and Sullivan British Opera,'' resulting from a collaboration between the New York Gilbert and Sullivan Players, an organization devoted to the presentation of Gilbert and Sullivan operettas, and American Express.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: BARDOT DENEUVE FONDA. By Roger Vadim. (Simon & Schuster, $17.95.) Roger Vadim is somewhat of a relic, a living erotosaurus who here exposes, so to speak, his own fossil record of love among the stars. As might be expected, the principal effect of this memoir of his famous wives and lovers is titillation. We join Mr. Vadim as he initiates the adolescent Brigitte Bardot into the rites of the boudoir. ''We had never gone beyond flirting,'' Mr. Vadim confides. ''She took me in her arms, and very gently I began making love to her.'' In movies as in love, Mr. Vadim directs Miss Bardot, and with the release of ''And God Created Woman'' in 1956 she enters stardom. But Miss Bardot is a troubled sex kitten, more complex than her popular image suggests. He writes, ''I knew that if she didn't follow her endless search through other men, she would die.'' Mr. Vadim heads off, and eventually moves in with 17-year-old Catherine Deneuve, whose ''finely drawn lips,'' he tells us, ''concealed deep sexuality.'' Despite such allure, Miss Deneuve gets rather short shrift here, roughly a third the space devoted to Bardot, perhaps because Mr. Vadim thinks she became a domestic tyrant as soon as she was a mother and a star in her own right. By 1965, the author is solo again, browsing through starlets of two continents, when he meets Jane Fonda. It is with Miss Fonda that he fully reveals one of the less endearing traits of the erotosaurus - the pronounced need to settle unmentioned (to the reader) old scores.

title: Code Revisions
description: To the Editor:

title: Linda W. Denney Wed in Pittsburgh
description: Linda Wainwright Denney, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas Lilley Denney of Pittsburgh, Pa., and Steven Lee Wagner, a son of Mrs. Samuel Good Wagner of Hudson, Ohio, and the late Mr. Wagner, were married yesterday. The Rev. Arthur McNulty performed the ceremony at Calvary Episcopal Church in Pittsburgh.

title: Wanderer Returns
description: For three years, 33-year-old John Weymouth has been wandering through the West and Alaska, making his way with the help of villagers and by finding odd jobs. That's why he has come to be known as ''The Wanderer.''

title: Cable TV
description: Cable's most rewarding film newcomer this week is ''1918,'' Horton Foote's story of life in a small Texas town during World War I. This 1985 feature is muted in tone, with no stepped-up pacing or narrative emphasis. Yet it remains a striking, artful drama, beautifully played by a relatively unknown cast, including Mr. Foote's daughter, Hallie, under Ken Harrison's astute direction. Cinemax is showing ''1918'' on Tuesday at 8 P.M. and Saturday at 6:30 P.M.

title: The Greatest Modern Writer
description: To the Editor:

title: DEATH ROW IN TRENTON STATE PRISON NOW HAS AN ODD-MAN IN
description: ROBERT O. MARSHALL, the newest resident of Trenton State Prison's death row, fits a separate category from the 17 other murderers he now lives with.

title: Syon Park
description: To the Editor: In ''The Pleasures of the Neighborhood'' (Travel, Jan. 19) Donald Goddard says that Syon Park contains ''eating facilities of the sort usually associated with highway service areas.'' I would hope that nobody will decide to pass up Syon House because there is no good eating place nearby.

title: WHEN THE EMPTY NEST FILLS AGAIN
description: AFTER all the chaotic family meals, my husband and I were enjoying an intimate dinner together. I was admiring the wisps of gray in his hair when the doorbell rang and our daughter arrived unexpectedly.

title: Knossos
description: To the Editor: The article ''Land of the Labyrinth'' (Travel, March 16) reminded me of my visit to the palace at Knossos several years ago.

title: GREENVALE
description: AT the heart of the North Shore of Nassau County lies Greenvale, the small community that calls itself ''the key to the Gold Coast.''

title: TURKEY ARRESTS 4, FOILING A BOMBING OF AMERICAN CLUB
description: Four Libyans were arrested in Turkey in connection with what was apparently a plot to attack a United States officers' club in Ankara, State Department officials said today.

title: TAILORING A BOOK TO EVERY TASTE
description: IT is not easy to make a phone book seem special.

title: U.S.F.L. TO LIST DAMAGES
description: The figure is formidable, $440 million in damages, which exceeds what a hurricane did to Massachusetts, though that was in 1955 dollars.

title: Gallup Poll Finds the French Approve of U.S. Raid on Libya
description: The French people approve of the United States bombing of Libya despite their Government's refusal to let American jets fly over France, according to a Newsweek poll made public yesterday.

title: OUI, MONSIEUR, IT'S THEIR BABY, BUT NOT FOR LONG
description: The most popular movie in France these days has no sex, no violence, only a little action and a leading lady who wears diapers. It sounds like a recipe for financial disaster, but ''Three Men and a Cradle,'' which opens Friday at the 68th Street Playhouse, has broken all box-office records to become one of the most successful films ever to be shown in France.

title: Utah Gymnasts Win Sixth Consecutive Title
description: Despite having only one performer in the individual top 10, Utah claimed its sixth straight National Collegiate Athletic Association women's gymnastics national championships Friday night at the McConnell Center.

title: THE NORTHWEST'S SUCCULENT MUSSELS
description: A decade ago it was difficult to find a mussel in Seattle unless it was hanging from a piling by its beard. They still decorate pilings on the shores of Elliott Bay - and rocks and boat bottoms - their iridescent, blue-black shells glistening when the water recedes. But now they are also in every seafood restaurant and market in town. Once mostly the province of hardy beachcombers, they've become an elegant, sought-after regional specialty.

title: A 2d Planeload of Americans Leaves the Sudan for Kenya
description: The United States Embassy, reacting to what it calls Libya-directed violence against Americans, evacuated a second and final official planeload of Americans from the Sudan tonight.

title: Kellogg Recalls Cereal Contaminated by Metal
description: The Kellogg Company has ordered a 16-state recall of Just Right cereal after metal shavings were found in two batches, but it says the tainted cereal would not be harmful if eaten.

title: To Save the Next Natasha Simpson
description: Three out of four Americans approve the air attacks on Libya but many citizens are tormented, even angry. Oregon's Senator Hatfield calls attention (see our Letters) to Libyan hospital beds ''filled with bloodied children.'' Other readers suspect America made merely a perfunctory pass at diplomatic or economic action before dispatching the bombers. Still others fear that a bellicose Reagan Administration has succeeded only in provoking a new wave of terror.

title:
WESTCHESTER JOURNAL;
TERRORISM FORUM
description: The recent upsurge in terrorist acts worldwide makes the forthcoming forum, ''World Terrorism: Americans Taken Hostage,'' particularly timely. The forum scheduled for 3 P.M. Saturday is sponsored by the Family Service of Westchester and is a fund-raising event for the group. It will be held at the White Plains High School auditorium.

title: LONG ISLAND JOURNAL
description: A FIRST IN THE FOREST HE DOESN'T have a fire tower yet, and his sidekick is a dog named Max rather than Smokey the Bear, but Long Island's only forest ranger, Frederick J. Dearstyne, says that when it's fire season, as it is now, he's as watchful as any of his counterparts out West.

title: VOLUNTEER AWARDS TOMORROW
description: SELECTED individuals and groups will receive awards for their 1986 volunteer service at a luncheon tomorrow. A panel of community leaders chose the winners from nominations submitted to the Volunteer Service Bureau of Westchester from county organizations, schools, agencies, corporations and service clubs. The Corporate Volunteer Council will be presenting its first award at the luncheon, to a nonprofit agency that uses corporate volunteers.

title: Alison C. Corvington Wed to Paul Dickard
description: The wedding of Alison Claudia Corvington, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Mark Corvington of Garden City, L.I., to Paul A. Dickard, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Gene Dickard of Chagrin Falls, Ohio, took place yesterday in Garden City. The Rev. David B. Lowery performed the Episcopal ceremony at the Cathedral of the Incarnation.

title: A TOTALITARIANISM OF PLEASURE
description: THE RUSTLE OF LANGUAGE By Roland Barthes. Translated by Richard Howard. 373 pp. New York: Hill & Wang/Farrar Straus & Giroux. $25.

title: A 'NEW' ASBURY PARK IS ON THE WAY
description: AFTER three years of conceptual work, a $500 million redevelopment plan for this city officially began last week with the signing of documents.

title: OFFICER SUSPENDED AFTER SLAYING
description: A man who appeared to be breaking into a parked car was shot and killed early yesterday in a scuffle with an off-duty police officer in the Morris Park section of the Bronx, the police said.

title: BREWERS DEFEAT YANKEES IN 11 INNINGS
description: The relief corps that is considered a key to the Yankees' pennant chances turned the wrong way again today. Following Brian Fisher's failure Friday night, Dave Righetti allowed Milwaukee back in the game and Rod Scurry let the Brewers win it.

title: Soviet Court Orders Inquiry Of Letters Citing Wrongdoing
description: The Soviet Supreme Court has instructed lower courts to crack down on people who denounce their fellow citizens in anonymous letters, the official press agency Tass reported today.

title: THE RAJIV GENERATION
description: WHEN ANAND MAHINDRA LEAFS through his parents' old photo albums, he sometimes pauses at the pictures of his father and friends wearing the white homespun cotton tunic and cap of the successful Indian independence movement. ''I feel a tremendous sense of envy looking at the optimism on their faces,'' he says. ''They had such dreams. It was such a beautiful time to be young. When I grew up, there was nothing but decline.''

title: FRANCE SET TO PRESS IRAN ON HOSTAGES IN LEBANON
description: The French Government is ready to put pressure on Iran, through increased arms sales to Iraq, if the Iranian Government does not help to secure the release of seven French hostages being held in Lebanon, according to officials here.

title: Oil Prices
description: To the Editor:

title: PHILADELPHIA SURVIVORS SUFFER WHILE BURNED AREA IS REBUILT
description: Ernest Bostic was known to residents of the Osage-Pine neighborhood as a quiet and gentle man, the neighborhood barber. He rented a room in a house behind the one where, at this time last year, members of the radical group Move were creating a small fortress. There the 48-year-old man was said by acquaintances to have kept equipment and products he had been accumulating to open a hairdressing business.

title: Maybe We Can Learn to Save From the Japanese
description: To the Editor:

title: A WINNING GAME PLAN FOR MINOR SPORTS
description: It was to be a summer show, designed to attract the modest number of viewers interested in ''minor'' sports at a time when rival networks were showing the ''major'' ones. Its first season was nearly canceled by a lack of advertising support and there was much uncertainty over its being renewed for even a second season.

title: U.S. BOMBS, MISSING TARGET, STRUCK FARMS NEAR AIR BASE
description: More than a dozen bombs and missiles from the American air raids early Tuesday appear to have missed an air base and hit two farms about two miles away, according to evidence seen by reporters on visits to the farms today.

title: DOWN, MEXICO WAY
description: A DANGEROUS PLACE By Hugh Fleetwood. 198 pp. North Pomfret, Vt.: Hamish Hamilton/ David & Charles. $22.50.

title: SCIENCE FICTION
description: When Theodore Sturgeon died last May at the age of 67, he held a place in the affections of the science fiction community that cannot be explained simply by the popularity of such award-winning stories as ''Slow Sculpture'' and the trail-blazing novel ''More Than Human,'' which told of the evolution of humanity toward a new form of group identity. He was, in several senses, the conscience of modern science fiction. While most of his colleagues were content to entertain, he aspired to instruct, to uplift. In a subculture that seemed to offer no middle ground between reason and passion, he insisted that an allegiance to one without the other was a prescription for suicide. He periodically outraged the sensibilities of science fiction readers by reminding them that the body, too, has its reasons. His literary standards were high, and no one grieved more than he when his own work failed to meet them. Occasionally, as in the flawed but fascinating novel ''Venus Plus X,'' he let his narrative sink beneath the weight of his message. But even his failures helped raise the sights of other writers in the genre, and when he succeeded in fusing story, style and science, as in ''More Than Human,'' the results were dazzling.

title: AT NEW YORK HOSPITALS, EMPTY BEDS
description: Hospitals in New York City had more empty beds last year than ever before, as new cost-cutting rules produced a sharp decline in hospitalization, according to state health officials.

title: FREED FROM POLITICAL RESTRAINTS, EXILED ARTISTS FLOURISH IN NEW YORK CITY
description: A poem about hunger in a Cuban prison; a collage of Persian miniatures and New York City skyscrapers; a dance about a mountain tribe in the Philippines, a painting of Jews drifting down a river.

title: Cynthia Forrest Is Wed in Ardsley
description: Cynthia Forrest, the daughter of Mrs. John Charles Forrest of Somers, N.Y., and the late Mr. Forrest, was married yesterday to Peter Vernon Herndon, a son of Vernon Herndon of Chicago and Malaga, Spain, and the late Mrs. Herndon. The Rev. Wendell C. Shepherd performed the ceremony at the United Methodist Church in Ardsley, N.Y.

title: NEW JERSEY JOURNAL
description: WHEN it comes to choosing between higher taxes or police protection, Tuckerton residents say there can be only one choice.

title: Vanessa Weber Marries a Lawyer
description: Vanessa Norman Weber and Daniel C. Rydholm were married at the Grace Church in New York yesterday in an Episcopal ceremony performed by the Rev. Kenneth B. Swanson. The bride is a daughter of Dr. John J. Weber of New York and Deep River, Conn., and the late Clara Lloyd-Smith Weber. Mr. Rydholm is a son of Mr. and Mrs. C. Fred Rydholm of Marquette, Mich.

title: Koch and Abrams Propose Reforms; Turoff Is Silent
description: The winds of change seemed to be rattling governmental windows throughout New York State last week as both Mayor Koch and State Attorney General Robert Abrams added to the growing list of suggestions for loosening the ties between politics and government.

title: JAZZ'S ODD COUPLE JOIN FORCES TO MAKE SPLENDID MELODY
description: At first glance, the Pat Metheny-Ornette Coleman album, ''Song X,'' seems to be the work of an odd couple indeed.

title:
CRAFTS;
UTENSILS AND INFUENCE FROM THE ORIENT
description: ''I KICK off the show with a modern pair of chopsticks in obsidian and ivory that are made in China but designed by a group of American designers; this is to say that the cultures have come together from both directions,'' said Nancy C. Campbell, director of the General Foods collection of food utensils at the corporation's offices in Rye Brook. She was discussing ''Half of the Earth,'' the current exhibition of food and beverage items from China, Korea and Japan, on display through May.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''More was found in this examination of gender bias in the courts than bruised feelings resulting from rude or callous behavior.

title: UNEXPECTED FRAY SHAKES UP MASSACHUSETTS RACE
description: Only two months ago the people who live and breathe politics in Massachusetts were expecting a lackluster election year. Five of the six statewide offices were occupied by Democrats who faced little serious opposition inside or outside their party.

title: BUILDING A FIRM BY BUYING ITS RIVALS
description: FOR a class assignment as a Stanford Business School student in the 1950's, Harold A. Ellis Jr. analyzed the expansion opportunities available to a tiny real estate brokerage company run by John M. Grubb, an old college friend for whom he had worked part-time.

title: THERE ARE RECORDERS FOR EVERY TASTE
description: There's a lot to be said for having less to lug when you're out shooting your own tapes. The majority of video fans regard size and weight as decisive factors when choosing portable equipment, which accounts for the growing popularity of miniaturized camcorders, as camera-recorder combinations are commonly called. But there are other considerations, too, and full-sized camcorders - though rather cumbersome by comparison - retain a loyal following.

title: NEW YORKERS ETC.
description: SOMETIMES there's a reason and sometimes there isn't, but whether there's a cause or not doesn't really matter. What matters is waking up in the morning feeling down in the dumps or depressed. Or maybe with just a small case of the blahs, which isn't all that bad but then again isn't all that great. On most emotional scales, none of this is end-of-the-world time; rather it's a cotton wool feeling out of which oozes a little voice repeating such phrases as ''It's too much effort,'' ''Who cares?'' ''Why bother?'' ''Is any of this worthwhile?'' Lethargy replaces bounce, smiles go into hiding, resignation reigns.

title: WHY STRATEGIC PLANNING GOES AWRY
description: LET'S face it. Strategic planning, as practiced by most American companies, is not working very well. This is embarrassing, because we essentially invented the idea, and have poured more resources into it than any other country in the world.

title: RIVERTON: HISTORIC TOUR SET
description: SEVEN of the most unusual homes in this Delaware River borough will be open to the public on May 15, including a pillared 1851 riverside mansion and an 1868 rectory.

title: THE MARATHONER'S ''WIDOW''
description: THE loneliness of the long-distance runner is well documented, but has anyone ever considered the frustrations of his wife?

title: Athletes And Gentlemen
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: NEW AFGHAN TALKS TO FOCUS ON SOVIET TROOPS
description: Afghanistan and Pakistan have accepted a new document as a basis for a new round of talks focused on reaching an agreement on the withdrawal of Soviet troops from Afghanistan, a high-ranking United Nations official said today.

title: JAZZ: SCAT AND BALLADS BY JUDY NIEMACK
description: FOR several years Judy Niemack has been singing around town in a variety of situations - as a band singer with the Cayenne Jazz Band, as a member of singing groups and as a single. Her format at Gregory's, First Avenue at 63d Street, where she sang with the guitarist Mitch Stein and the bassist Dennis Irwin in an engagement that ended last night, is one of her best.

title: CORRECTION
description: The wrong caption appeared last week under a photograph with an article about the John Harms Center. The published photograph showed, from left, Luisa Kuhn, Barbara Erskine, Bowie Kuhn and Joan Van Alstyne Johnson.

title: PEOPLE POWER AND SUPERPOWERS
description: MAKING EUROPE UNCONQUERABLE The Potential of Civilian-Based Deterrence and Defence. By Gene Sharp. 250 pp. Cambridge, Mass.: Ballinger Publishing Company. Paper, $14.95.

title: U.S. TRIES TO DAMPEN SPECULATION OVER OUSTERS OF FRIENDLY DESPOTS
description: The Reagan Administration has no intention of destabilizing right-wing, pro-American dictatorships in Asia or Latin America, Administration officials say, despite the American role in the departures of Ferdinand E. Marcos from the Philippines and Jean-Claude Duvalier from Haiti.

title: PHILIP GLASS TURNS TO THE SONG
description: What is a song? In order to be called a song, must a piece of music have a recognizable melody? Philip Glass's often hauntingly ethereal ''Songs From Liquid Days'' (CBS Masterworks 39564; album, cassette, compact disc) is a record that raises such questions. After many listenings, one can hear the textures of the music resonate in the mind and recall many of the lyrics by Mr. Glass's four collaborators but still not be able to call up more than a few snatches of melody. Yet Mr. Glass specifically designates as songs this sequence of vocalized poems performed mostly by ''pop'' singers.

title: NO RELIEF IN SIGHT FOR WHITSON AS ORDEAL GOES ON
description: THE DATE is Oct. 4, 1984, the place San Diego. The Padres have lost the first two games of the National League playoff to the Chicago Cubs, but Ed Whitson pitches the third game and his eight-inning, one-run performance marks the turnaround for the Padres that will carry them into the World Series.

title: BEAUTY AND SAFETY ON L.I. PARKWAYS
description: Have you noted, when you visit Washington's home, Mount Vernon, that they have introduced electricity, plumbing and central heat? Probably not. They have brought this 18th-century house into the 20th century without destroying its architectural integrity. Not so with our well-designed parkway system here on Long Island.

title: Topics; Back to the Future; Calling Up
description: A man who recently boarded an airplane for the Midwest suffered a dose of future shock when he spied a telephone mounted on the passenger cabin's front bulkhead. It was, a sign said, a pay phone for public use.

title: May 24 Wedding For Joanne Grady
description: Mr. and Mrs. John H. Grady Jr. of Livingston, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter Joanne Grady to Dr. James Layton Huskey, a son of Mrs. Arthur Morris of Dothan, Ala. and the late Dr. Dow T. Huskey. A May 24 wedding is planned.

title: Did Justice Fall From the Skies Over Tripoli?
description: To the Editor:

title: MARCOS SUPPORTERS COME OUT OF THE SHADOWS
description: ''YOU'LL find me at Zip's pad, where the shiftless congregate,'' said a former Marcos adviser. ''We play cards, poker, while the time away. One of the most difficult things is to wake up in the morning and not know what you're going to do all day.'' That was two weeks ago. These days, the Marcos folks congregate on the streets, and they have plenty to do. First, they sat in at a radio station, ostensibly to protect an announcer who had broadcast a tearful interview with Ferdinand E. Marcos. Then they gathered 15,000 people for a rally, unintentionally mimicking the former President's ill-fated election campaign. Then they demonstrated in support of a show session of the defunct National Assembly.

title: Historic Visit To a Synagogue
description: John Paul II has traveled more than any other pope, but no journey was more significant than his short trip last weekend to a synagogue in Rome - the first recorded papal visit to a Jewish house of worship.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: THE MAKING OF A MODERN PSYCHIATRIST. By Mark Warren. (Doubleday, $16.95.) Most of the action in ''The Making of a Modern Psychiatrist'' takes place in a large psychiatric hospital called Asylum.

title: Gutierrez Recital Canceled
description: The pianist Horacio Gutierrez has canceled today's scheduled recital at Avery Fisher Hall, because of illness. Ticketholders may obtain refunds at the box office, or by writing to Avery Fisher Hall Box Office, Lincoln Center, New York, N.Y. 10023.

title: OLD HARTFORD IS BROUGHT BACK IN EXHIBIT OF PHOTOGRAPHS
description: A TIME when Hartford's skyline was unbroken by tall buildings, when trolleys were powered by horses and when people could still walk to the banks of the Connecticut River is chronicled in a photographic exhibit that will be at the Old State House in Hartford until May 4.

title: THE REPUBLICANS FACE UP TO THE STRUGGLE AHEAD
description: ANTHONY J. COLAVITA had just been elected Republican State Chairman last fall when he had to start shopping for a candidate who could slow down, if not stop, Governor Cuomo's march to a second term in Albany this November and, perhaps, the White House in 1988.

title: STAMPING OUT CORRUPTION
description: I would certainly like to endorse Robert Gottlieb's Opinion Page article of March 23, ''Steps to Stamp Out Corruption.'' It is essentially true that the price of honest government is a kind of eternal vigilance.

title: THREE PIANISTS PERFORM AT CARNEGIE RECITAL HALL: ROBERT NOLAND
description: Robert Noland played his Carnegie Recital Hall debut last Saturday to an audience even smaller than the traditional assembly of friends and relatives; there can hardly have been a dozen listeners in the hall. It was a lucky dozen, though that didn't become fully apparent until the second half of the program: Mr. Noland has it in him to be a compelling advocate for some music that merits advocacy.

title: MAKING A SAFETY PLAY
description: Players around the world will soon have a unique opportunity: To play in a world championship in the comfort of their own club. The event is the Epson Simultaneous Pairs to be played June 14 under the auspices of the World Bridge Federation.

title: NEW LIFE FOR A SMALL SCHUBERTIAN GEM
description: In his short life, Franz Schubert produced symphonies, piano music and chamber music in a relatively large quantity as well as over 600 songs. He also tried to break into the theater by writing some 20 operas, singspiels and a melodrama. In these, which might have given him more fame than he had and made him prosperous, he was unlucky. Most of them went unstaged in his time, and the couple that were staged had little or no success. Nor have they proved to be unjustly neglected masterpieces when finally given in modern times.

title: Selling Your Home Without a Broker
description: IN Fairfield County, Conn., where home buyers are said to be lining up to purchase prime properties, Maria Yolanda O'Donnell saw no need to pay a real-estate broker $20,000 to sell her 130-year-old, riverside house in Weston. But before her own best prospect had a chance to see the property, brokers provided two full-price offers of $357,500 -and she accepted one. Mrs. O'Donnell is not complaining.

title: The Greatest Modern Writer
description: To the Editor:

title: CAMPGROUND VACATIONERS FACE HIGHER FEES
description: VACATIONERS visiting private campgrounds around the state this season will be paying more for their view of the great outdoors, according to the head of a camp owners group.

title: THE CIGARETTE CENTURY
description: IN the 1940's, a tobacco company proudly advertised that ''more doctors smoke Camels than any other cigarettes.'' If members of the American College of Physicians who met here earlier this month felt that way, they were not admitting it. Through lung cancer, heart disease and chronic lung disease, experts say, cigarettes are implicated in 350,000 deaths each year - one out of every six in the United States. But while the percentage of adult American smokers has dropped from 55 to about 30 (and to less than 17 percent of physicians) researchers have found that many of those who are still puffing do not even want to stop. Would higher taxes or stronger warning labels change their minds? What about a ban on cigarette advertising, which the American Medical Association recently endorsed but the tobacco industry contends would be unconstitutional and ineffective? Or rules that restrict lighting up in public places, such as those recently passed in Long Island and proposed by Mayor Koch? What more can doctors do about what many believe is public health enemy No. 1? These were among the questions considered at the College of Physicians meeting by a panel that comprised Dr. C. Everett Koop, the United States Surgeon General; Dr. Elizabeth M. Whelan, executive director of the American Council on Science and Health; Dr. Alan Blum, founder of Doctors Ought to Care, a coalition of community health groups, and Dr. David P. L. Sachs, an expert in smoking cessation research who is on the clinical faculty of the Stanford University School of Medicine.

title: New Maronite Patriarch
description: A new Patriarch for the Roman Catholic Maronite Church of Antioch and the East was elected in Lebanon today. He is Nasrallah Sfeir, a 66-year-old bishop from the mountains that make up the heartland of Lebanese Christians.

title:
PHOTOGRAPHY VIEW;
IMAGES THAT REVEAL A WORLD OF STARK MORAL CONTRASTS
description: The first thing to be said in praise of the exhibition ''W.

title: D. W. Schnitzer And Miss Ainslie Exchange Vows
description: Deborah Dawn Ainslie, an interior design student, was married yesterday to Douglas Weingarten Schnitzer, a real-estate executive, at Congregation Beth Israel in Houston. Dr. Hyman J. Schachtel and Rabbi Carole Meyers officiated.

title: ERNEST BUEDING
description: Ernest Bueding, a scientist at Johns Hopkins University who discovered a cure for potentially fatal tropical diseases, died Friday of cancer.

title: COMPUTER LISTS USED CARS FOR SALE
description: GERALD GRANATOWSKI has been mixing cars and computers lately, with promising results.

title: AT 41, SWARTS WINS THE DISCUS AT 195-7
description: Art Swarts of Mountainside, N.J., admits he may not be the normal guy next door.

title: IN PRINTING, THE PAPER CAN MAKE ALL THE DIFFERENCE
description: When the late photographer Edward Weston was introduced to a new printing paper, Velour Black, he became so enthralled with the quality that he reprinted his negatives on the new paper for an exhibition. To Weston, the difference between the old and new prints made from the same negatives was dramatic. He wrote enthusiastically in his journal about the new material: ''It is so much superior to the paper I had been using. The blacks are richer, the whites clearer and despite the fact that it has more contrast, the shadows actually have more detail.'' Weston concluded that the new prints gave him the feeling that he was printing from different negatives.

title: NOTED WITH PLEASURE
description: Phantoms of Conscience In Robert Stone's novel ''Children Of Light'' (Knopf), a screenwriter muses in the shower on the confusion of sentiments, the professional insincerities, that arise out of his work.

title: World Theater Festival Set for Baltimore in June
description: The 20th Theater of Nations, an international festival of performers from around the world, will be held in June in Baltimore - the first time the event has been held in the United States since its inception in France in 1956. About a dozen individuals and ensembles from 11 nations will take part in the two-week festival, which has been presented in a different country every two years since 1982; in the 1970's, it was presented annually.

title: HIKING WITH LLAMAS IN MONTANA
description: ''What else can we take?'' asked Will Gavin, peering around in the dim barn at piles of camping gear. ''I need more weight to balance the llamas' packs.''

title: Rehab
description: ''A great cry went up from the multitude in Bond Street and Broadway, and there was a general stampede for places of safety as the fourth, fifth and sixth stories of the handsome iron front fell into the street with a tremendous crash.''

title: A Loss Of U.S. Influence
description: The Reagan Administration is apparently bent on seeing Col.

title: BLACK MOPED DEALER WINS BIAS LAWSUIT IN BLOCK ISLAND CASE
description: A Federal District Court has ruled that officials on Block Island, who have long fought against the use of motorized bicycles there, discriminated against a moped dealer because he is black.

title: OPERA: 'DON GIOVANNI'
description: THE American Opera Center at Juilliard balances its seasonal program between rarely heard works like the ''Mireille'' offered in February and repertory staples like the ''Don Giovanni'' that is its current production. Friday night's cast (the second of two) introduced several capable young singers, some of whom will surely be heard from in the future. But although the performance as a whole was creditable, it must be noted that the school's description of its purpose (providing ''performance experience between the final stages of training and the beginning of full-time careers in opera'') implies something closer to high professional standards than was achieved here.

title: WITNESS TELLS OF BID-RIGGING BY GARBAGE CARTERS
description: Private garbage collection in the New York metropolitan area is controlled by secret agreements, rigged bids and physical force, a witness testified last week in a Federal racketeering trial.

title: Bethany Novak Engaged
description: Mr. and Mrs. Daniel Novak of Stamford, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter Bethany Randi Novak to Lawrence D. Engle, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Morton Engle of Cedarhurst, L.I. A September wedding is planned by Miss Novak, a registered nurse at Mount Sinai Hospital who received a B.S. degree in nursing from Skidmore College. Mr. Engle, a lawyer with the New York law firm of Kahn & Gordon, graduated from the State University of New York at Buffalo and received a J.D. degree from the law school there.

title: World Judaica Fair Set
description: The first International Judaica Fair will take place in Jerusalem from May 4 to 8, under the auspices of Mayor Teddy Kollek, with new editions of the Passover Haggadah and other art works on display.

title: A FUNGUS ATTACKS FLOWERING DOGWOODS
description: COMMONLY found throughout the so-called understory setting of Northeastern forests and planted to decorate Westchester's landscapes, the flowering dogwood (Cornus florida) is slowly being choked by a fungal infection.

title: BLOW TO SECURITY SEEN IN THE LOSS OF TITAN MISSILE
description: The loss of a Titan rocket and its secret military payload here Friday appears to be a serious blow to the national security interests of the United States, according to aerospace experts outside the Government.

title:
DINING OUT;
STYLISH AND INVENTIVE IN OSSINING
description: CAFE is a misnomer for this stylish restaurant. Behind the demure, lacy half-curtains in the storefront window stretches a serene dining room, simplicity itself in line and shape - just a hint of curve in the ornamental curlicues of the mirror frames - with a modern-classic juxtaposition of style contrived to surprise and please, one that is echoed enthusiastically in the kitchen's culinary efforts.

title: FIRST TOGETHER, THEN APART
description: LOVERS & COHORTS By Herbert Gold. 331 pp. New York: Donald I. Fine. $17.95.

title: Solon Geer, 85, Co-Founder Of Advertising Agency, Dies
description: Solon Geer, a co-founder of Geer, DuBois Inc., an advertising agency in Manhattan, died Friday, after a brief illness, at St. Joseph's Hospital in Stamford, Conn. He was 85 years old and lived in Manhattan and Stamford.

title: Votes in Congress; Last Week's Tally in Key Eastern States
description: Senate 1. Picket Violence Procedural vote, requiring 60 yeas, to limit debate on a bill that would make it a Federal crime to commit violence in labor disputes. Rejected April 16, with 44 voting yea and 54 voting nay. (Had the motion passed, it would have cleared the way for the bill to be considered.)

title:
INVESTING;
THE NAVISTAR RENAISSANCE
description: The Navistar International Corporation, which, as International Harvester, barely escaped bankruptcy several years ago, is coming back into favor with analysts and institutions. After getting out of the farm equipment business, the company has focused on medium and heavy-duty trucks, of which it holds about a 25 percent combined market share.

title: Miss Mason Now a Bride
description: St. Bartholomew's Episcopal Church was the setting yesterday for the wedding of Kristen Ann Mason and Richard Townley Buchanan. The Rev. William Roberts performed the ceremony.

title: OFFICIALS, IN VISITS TO FACTORIES, EXPLORE MODULAR HOMES
description: WHILE officials from a dozen Westchester communities watched, workers put a floor together in minutes, dropped walls around it, roofed it, insulated it, dropped in a bathroom and kitchen, and wheeled it down the tracks - a basic house, almost ready to live in.

title:
GARDENING;
WISTERIA: A VINE WORTH ITS TROUBLE
description: WISTERIA grows rapidly, as much as four to five feet a year, and can literally choke a tree to death. Yet, it is valued as being one of the more attractive ornamental vines.

title: 'Front Page' to 'J.O.A.' in Detroit
description: Such are the economics of journalism that while fewer and fewer two-newspaper towns remain, there are more two-newspaper newspapers.

title: For Financial Center, a Moat of Electronic Security
description: WHAT the drawbridge or turnkey was to a bygone age's concern for security, the comprehensive computer-based electronic security system now being installed in the World Financial Center in Battery Park City is to the late 20th century.

title: Australia
description: To the Editor: One of the more eccentric stops along the route of Australia's Indian Pacific (Travel, Feb. 23) is the town of Cook, South Australia.

title: Ex-Officer Pleads Guilty
description: Alonzo Giordano, a former Philadelphia police inspector, has pleaded guilty to failing to report about $57,000 in bribes from vice figures on his Federal tax returns for 1979 and 1980.

title: 1989: The Year of Congress
description: History being chronological by nature, it should hardly surprise that the 200th annversary of the Constitution, to be celebrated next year, will merely clear the decks for the 200th anniversary of Congress in 1989, for which another round of festivities is being planned.

title: Banking
description: To the Editor:

title: HISTORICAL RESOURCES ARE PRESERVED IN NEW YORK STATE ARCHIVES PROJECT
description: Seventy-five years after the great Capitol fire that destroyed thousands of precious documents, the New York State Archives are undergoing a major program of restoration and expansion. Charred papers, many untouched for years, are being carefully preserved by the latest methods.

title: NEW TOKENS MAKE DEBUT TOMORROW
description: Starting tomorrow, new ''antislug'' subway and bus tokens will go on sale in the Transit Authority's latest effort to fight fare-cheaters.

title: SPRING COVER-UP: NAVY COATS
description: LATELY, spring has been typically fickle - temperatures in the high 60's one day and the low 40's the next. The day after that is anybody's guess.

title: Alison Bjorklund Engaged
description: Mr. and Mrs. Bruce Bjorklund of Mill Neck, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Alison Jane Bjorklund, to John M. Collins, the son of Mr. and Mrs. George J. Collins of Oyster Bay, L.I. A June wedding is planned. The future bride is an investment banker with John Nuveen & Company in New York. Her father is a vice president in municipal securities with the Bankers Trust Company. Mr. Collins is an architectural historian and preservation consultant. His father is president of Royal Offset Repair, a division of CKM Industries in Long Island City, N.Y.

title: Power Failure in Jersey
description: A malfunction at an electric-power substation in Teaneck, N.J., blacked out 5,290 homes and businesses in that township for more than an hour last night, the Public Service Electric & Gas Company reported. A spokesman, Priscilla Suber, said the power failure had occurred at 6:14 P.M. with the loss of a 4,000-volt circuit. It was confined to portions of Teaneck and power was restored at 8:01 P.M., she said.

title: Lagging Memorial For Roosevelt
description: THIRTY-ONE years ago, Congress authorized the building of a memorial to Franklin D. Roosevelt, who died 41 years ago this month in his fourth term as President.

title: IN FRANCE, THE MEAL AS METAPHOR
description: There comes a time, oh about every two years or so, when we begin to dream of France. This usually coincides with a creeping recognition that the meals we sit down to three times a day - whether the cuisine be haute or bas - are about as satisfying as curling up in front of a gas-fueled fireplace.

title: CRITICISM OF BILL TO RECYCLE LESSENS
description: THE LATEST version of a bill mandating recycling statewide differs only slightly from last year's draft, but criticism has diminished.

title: STRIKING GOLD IN A CANADIAN COURT
description: THIS is a tale of how one small company wrenched one of the planet's richest gold mines from a giant competitor. The characters are the stuff of a good bad movie: There are the pair of rumpled prospectors who became millionaires by turning up gold in Canada's limitless ''moose pasture,'' the Vancouver stock promoter whom comedian Joey Bishop called the ''Jewish Howard Hughes,'' and the seventyish Maryland widow who discovered that a hunk of forest she had reluctantly paid taxes on for years had overnight become Canada's hottest mining prospect.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: PRESENT DANGER. By William J. Buchanan. (Macmillan, $16.95.) Throughout William J. Buchanan's absorbing but flawed first novel depicting corruption in the United States Air Force's upper echelon, one question predominates: What caused the XR-2100, a sophisticated reconnaissance aircraft, to veer a thousand miles off course and crash in the South Pacific during a test flight? Maj. Jonathan Ward, a maverick with an aptitude for electronics, seeks the answer.

title: Laura Bonomo Becomes Bride
description: Laura Marie Bonomo, the daughter of the late Mr. and Mrs. Gerard V. Bonomo of Upper Montclair, N.J., was married yesterday to Richard Benjamin Colton, the son of Mr. and Mrs. William Colton of Baltimore. Msgr. Edward J. Larkin performed the ceremony at St. Cassian's Roman Catholic Church in Upper Montclair.

title: Andrea Warshaw to Marry
description: The engagement of Andrea Ruth Warshaw to Lawrence Scot Deitch, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Ralph Deitch of New York, has been announced by her parents, Mrs. Rosenthal Warshaw and Jerome Warshaw of New York. Miss Warshaw is the editor in chief of The College Digest in Mamaroneck, N.Y. Her fiance is a vice president and account supervisor of Geers Gross Advertising in New York. A May 18 wedding is planned.

title: Jeffrey J. Coniaris Is Wed in Jersey To Miss Thomas
description: Tara Ann Thomas, an art consultant, and Jeffrey John Coniaris, a lawyer, were married yesterday in St. Rose of Lima Roman Catholic Church in Short Hills, N.J. Msgr. Harrold A. Murray officiated.

title: OPEC Said to Lean Toward New Limits
description: Most of OPEC's 13 member nations favor a proposal to reimpose oil production limits for the summer quarter, officials said today after a fifth day of talks.

title: A SEDER DINNER ABROAD...
description: IN late March, I received a wedding invitation. The daughter of friends was to be married in April of that year in Florence, Italy. I had vacationed in Florence many times and have a circle of dear friends who welcome me. I speak a fine White Plains High School Adult Ed Italian. In accepting the invitation my only regret was that I would miss my yearly trek to the second night of Passover dinner at the White Plains Jewish Community Center.

title: CONNECTICUT GUIDE
description: CONCERT OF THE '50's Three great pompadours of the 50's will be united on the stage of the Palace Theater in New Haven when Frankie Avalon, Fabian and Bobby Rydell give a joint concert at 7:30 and 10 P.M. Saturday.

title: KISSINGER MEANS BUSINESS
description: ON THE CORNER OF PARK Avenue and 52d street in New York City sits an office building whose lobby contains the First American Bank of New York, Chase Private Banking International and, embedded in a marble post, a computerized building directory. Punch ''U'' and such names as Peter Ueberroth, the commissioner of major-league baseball, come up. But punch ''K'' and you will not find Kissinger Associates, for Henry A. Kissinger still receives threats, so, for security reasons, you have to be invited to learn what floor his firm is on.

title: BUCKS' HEAD COACH IS A GOOD LISTENER
description: When Craig Hodges arrived here in the fall of 1984 after two seasons of considerable obscurity with the San Diego Clippers, he knew very little about his new environment or his new team, the Milwaukee Bucks. He knew only that the city was usually cold, that the Bucks usually won and that their coach, Don Nelson, was loud. Usually. ''He takes pride in his system,'' Hodges says. ''So if you don't run it correctly, you hear from him.''

title: Less Agony of Defeat
description: It was one of those fateful miscues that can spell the difference between fame and oblivion, but when Vinko Bogataj tumbled off the side of a chute during the 1970 World Cup Ski Jumping Championships at Oberstdorff, West Germany, fate got turned upside down. Instead of a momentary word of consolation, the mishap brought the Yugoslav skier more fame than he counted on.

title: Ronni Linowitz Weds in Capital
description: Ronni Linowitz and Robert L. Jolles were married yesterday at the Four Seasons Hotel in Washington. Rabbi Oscar Groner officiated. The couple's parents are Mr. and Mrs. Sol M. Linowitz of Washington and Mr. and Mrs. Lee Jolles of Bethesda, Md.

title: 'Angels of September'
description: To the Editor:

title: CHOPIN'S PIANO MUSIC FROM ETUDES TO MAZURKAS
description: No one has suffered from success as has Frederic Chopin. In principle, the popularity of a sophisticated and original mind is cause for celebration, but Chopin shows us also celebrity's self-destructive side.

title: Botha Promises A Revision Of the Pass Laws
description: President P. W. Botha told South Africa's Parliament last week that blacks jailed or awaiting trial for violating the country's pass laws would be released immediately and that new standard identity cards for all races would be issued in July.

title: Did Justice Fall From the Skies Over Tripoli?; Ethical Questions
description: To the Editor:

title: DEATH AND THE FAMILY FARM
description: FINAL HARVEST An American Tragedy. By Andrew H. Malcolm. 320 pp. New York: Times Books. $17.95. WHEN the report of a double murder in rural Ruthton, Minn., broke in the press, readers responded viscerally. Although it has been over two years, the story has not been easy to forget, as the agricultural depression that began in the Midwest in 1981 has deepened and spread. Now, in ''Final Harvest,'' a native Midwesterner, Andrew H. Malcolm, has written a powerful and provocative account of the inexorable progression of events leading up to that cold, drizzly morning of Sept. 29, 1983, when Rudy Blythe, president of Ruthton's small Buffalo Ridge State Bank, and Toby Thulin, his chief loan officer, were called out to an abandoned, dilapidated 10-acre farm that the bank had earlier repossessed, where the farm's previous owner, James Jenkins, and his 18-year-old son, Steve, were waiting.

title: CRIME
description: If EVERY BRILLIANT EYE by Loren D. Estleman (Houghton Mifflin, $15.95) does not end with a whimper, it does wind up in a miasma of disillusion. But Amos Walker, the private eye in this series, does not have many illusions. He does, however, have ideals; he is a perfectionist and moralist living in an imperfect and amoral world. At least he is always true to himself.

title: Q and A
description: Question:My daughter and I will be arriving in Paris the evening before Bastille Day, July 14. What special events are planned on Bastille Day? Will tourist attractions and restaurants be open and will public transportation be operating? - J. S., Piermont, N.Y. Answer:Bastille Day, which falls on a Monday this year, is a national holiday.
