The main event in Paris will be the annual parade along the Champs-Elysees, with military units and bands marching past the President, Francois Mitterand, on the reviewing stand. French Air Force planes will fly overhead. The parade, which lasts about an hour, usually attracts large crowds. Before the parade, Mr. Mitterand will lay a wreath at the Tomb of the Unknown Soldier beneath the Arc de Triomphe. In the evening there is a fireworks display over the Seine, and one good place to watch it is the Place du Trocadero. There are no other major events, although by tradition Parisians in some areas celebrate informally by dancing in and outside cafes, as they do the night before the holiday.

title: Stalin's Daughter Returns to West
description: ''To go visiting is fine,'' says a Russian proverb, ''but it is better at home.'' For Stalin's 60-year-old daughter, Svetlana Alliluyeva, and his 14-year-old granddaughter, Olga Peters, the location of home has long been a problem, and last week they switched residences again, leaving the Soviet Union and returning to live in the West.

title: A GENTLEMAN'S COUNTRY RESIDENCE
description: A visit to many of the great country houses of England can be a pleasurable but frustrating experience.

title: MIAMI HOPES TO ENTICE MORE RIDERS WITH A 'PEOPLE MOVER' GOING DOWNTOWN
description: Automated cars rolling smoothly on an elevated track began service this weekend on a 1.9-mile loop through downtown, carrying passengers and the hopes of this city's beleagured mass transit system.

title: Staci Wall Plans to Marry Herbert Bagel, Accountant
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Morton W. Wall of Aberdeen, N.J., and Gouldsboro, Pa., of the engagement of their daughter Staci Beth Wall to Herbert Bagel, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Samuel Bagel of Hightstown, N.J., and Hallandale, Fla. A June wedding is planned.

title: JAZZ: ECKSTINE AND TRIO
description: BILLY ECKSTINE, at 71, remains an impressive model of jazz singing versatility. Equally at home swinging a Count Basie tune as he is applying his suave imprint on a pop ballad, Mr. Eckstine has been a direct inspiration on bass-baritone singers such as Joe Williams, Arthur Prysock and Lou Rawls, who like to give their material an expressive shape by tailoring the material to show off the bottom ends of their voices.

title: WHY THE BELLS ARE CROSSING BORDERS
description: IS the yellow-pages business profitable enough to warrant the continuing onslaught of competing companies and products?

title: HOW MUCH WOULD IT HAVE COST TO SAY 'I'M SORRY'?
description: DEAR SIR:

title: Lynn Rosenthal Becomes a Bride
description: Lynn Ellen Rosenthal and Robert Parker Fletcher, Washington lawyers who received law degrees from Duke University in 1983, were married yesterday at the Sans Souci of Sea Cliff Restaurant on Long Island. Judge Arthur Goldberg, the village justice of East Hills, L.I., officiated.

title: PERFORMING ARTS SERIES HONORS 'THE MASTER'
description: The United States Postal Service will issue a 22-cent commemorative stamp on April 29 in New York City to honor Edward Kennedy ''Duke'' Ellington. It will go on sale at local post offices the next day.

title:
ON LONG ISLAND;
East End Summer Rental Demand Up 25%
description: DEMAND for summer rentals on the East End is up 25 percent this year over last, according to brokers in the area. House sales, which were slow in 1985 because of proposed tax changes, are doing even better.

title: ON THE 6:10, A DRAMA IN TWO ACTS
description: THE drama on the 6:10 for Port Washington began when the conductor asked a young woman for her ticket.

title: Mary C. Conger Becomes a Bride
description: The wedding of Mary Calvert Conger, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Stephen McCrea Conger of Lovettsville, Va., to William Scott Miller 3d, a son of Mr. and Mrs. William Scott Miller Jr. of Louisville, Ky., took place yesterday. The Rev. Bayard Stockton Clark, a cousin of the bride, performed the Presbyterian ceremony at the Church of the Pilgrims in Washington.

title: HUNGER IN U.S. IS WIDENING, STUDY OF 'NEW POOR' REPORTS
description: Lotus Franks, a 41-year-old former construction worker, has a heart ailment and is almost blind from eye disease. He has a wife and six children, and mounting medical bills that wreck his budget. So he does something many mountain men refuse to do, no matter how destitute: He applies for food stamps.

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS
description: THE BRAVE LITTLE TOASTER By Thomas Disch. Illustrated by Karen Lee Schmidt. 78 pp. New York: Doubleday & Company. $10.95. (All ages) I'VE always had a ridiculous fantasy that book contracts were made on the basis of sudden bolts from the blue. A writer described an idea, an editor smacked his desk blotter and shouted ''I love it!'' and money changed hands. While that is not exactly the way it works in publishing, it is the way it works with ''The Brave Little Toaster.'' If you love the concept, you will love Thomas Disch's book. Quite simply, it is the story of five small appliances, living in a summer cottage, who set off to find their missing owner. It either tickles you or it doesn't.

title: 4 Die at Rail Crossing
description: A motor home burst into flames when struck by a freight train at a crossing today, killing 4 of the 10 people in the motor home and critically injuring 2 others, the authorities said. No one on the 109-car Southern Pacific train was injured in the crash.

title: LAW PROPOSED FOR WITHHOLDING EMERGENCY CARE
description: A panel appointed by Governor Cuomo has recommended legislation that would authorize hospitals and nursing homes in New York State to withhold emergency life-saving care from patients under certain circumstances.

title: Melissa Jones Is Wed To Thomas P. Marotta
description: Melissa Church Jones and Thomas P. Marotta were married yesterday by the Rev. Dr. Paul Zeckhausen, a Protestant minister, assisted by the Rev. Joseph Arevalo, a Roman Catholic priest, at the Manhasset (L.I.) Congregational Church.

title: Susan Dauber Plans To Wed in December
description: A December wedding is planned by Susan G. Dauber, the daughter of Edith Feldman of Brooklyn and the late Gerald Dauber, to Benni Jakubovic, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Jakubovic of Brooklyn.

title: A QUARTET OF STYLES IN NEW HAVEN
description: SUCH are the resources of Yale University Art Gallery that even one of its small shows mounted by a graduate student is liable to hog critical attention. And justifiably so for the most part, except that this helps perpetuate the impression that there is no art in New Haven outside of Yale unless it is in New York City.

title: FOR TANDY AND CRONYN, A NEW PLAY ECHOES YEARS OF PARTNERSHIP
description: ''Bees. Terriers. Rats,'' Jessica Tandy was saying, stopping herself midsentence. ''I hate that line.'' It was afternoon and Miss

title: HOSPITALS, COMPETING FOR SCARCE PATIENTS, TURN TO ADVERTISING
description: One hospital offers free baby blankets, cute T-shirts and candlelight dinners in bed for new parents. Others offer free blood-pressure and cholesterol tests. Yet another has hired the former director of the ''I Love New York'' campaign to sharpen its competitive edge.

title:
PERSONAL FINANCE;
HUNTING FOR RICHES IN THE ATTIC CHEST
description: NEARLY everyone has run across old stock or bond certificates in a trunk in the attic, among the belongings of a deceased relative, or even at a garage sale. But how to determine if they are treasure or trash? Going through the safe of my late father, I found stacks of obsolete certificates, mainly Canadian mining stocks, and embarked upon a quest to determine whether they had financial, collectible or simply sentimental value.

title: CABARET: 'JUST ONCE'
description: WHEN the music is surging from the stage, ''Just Once,'' a book musical built around 23 songs written by Barry Mann and Cynthia Weil, has almost as much visceral clout as the original nightclub version of ''Leader of the Pack.'' ''Just Once,'' like ''Leader'' before it was produced to death on Broadway, is a production of the Greenwich Village nightclub the Bottom Line (15 West Fourth Street), at which it is playing a six- to 10-week engagement. And many of the same hands, including the musical director Jimmy Vivino and the book writer Melanie Mintz, were involved in creating both shows.

title: VANBIESBROUCK AND PEETERS: DIFFERENT STYLES, IN GOAL AND OUT
description: These two goaltenders have been the appointed starters in all of their teams' playoff games this spring, and each has won a game in this series to determine the Patrick Division's champion. But that 1-1 statistical standoff, along with a weakness for allowing the puck to slip between their knees, is the only resemblance they share.

title: Kathleen Marie Buckley Marries Bracken O'Neill
description: Kathleen Marie Buckley and Bracken Charles O'Neill were married yesterday at St. Joseph's Church in Andover, Mass. The Rev. Thomas J. Meehan performed the Catholic ceremony.

title: London Transport
description: To the Editor: In ''Cutting the Cost of a Trip to Europe'' (Travel, March 2) Stanley Carr suggests reducing transportation costs within London by buying a London Explorer Ticket for seven days of travel on bus and underground at $20. The London Explorer Ticket also includes a trip to the airport.

title: UNION HEAD CALLS PUPIL PROMOTIONS FORCED
description: The president of the city's teachers union said yesterday that New York's public schools have ''an unwritten but pervasive'' system of forced promotions that automatically sends thousands of unprepared children on to the next grade each year.

title: WESTCHESTER BOOKCASE
description: ''THE RED BANNER MUTINY'' by Andrew P. O'Rourke. Bantam Books. $3.50.

title: Regina Meyer Engaged
description: The engagement of Regina Anne Meyer, a daughter of Mrs. Kenneth E. Meyer of Wayne, Pa., and the late Mr. Meyer, to J. Allen Gray of Rosemont, Pa., a son of Joan Gray-Hurley of Manasquan, N.J., and William B. Gray Jr. of Neptune, N.J., has been announced by the future bride's mother. A November wedding is planned.

title:
GARDENING;
WISTERIA: A VINE WORTH ITS TROUBLE
description: WISTERIA grows rapidly, as much as four to five feet a year, and can literally choke a tree to death. Yet, it is valued as being one of the more attractive ornamental vines.

title: CRAB APPLE FLOWERS TO GRACE EACH TOWN
description: IF all goes well, Connecticut will be a showcase of crab-apple flowers in a few years. Each town is being provided with crab-apple trees - all free - thanks to the Trees for Towns program.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article last Sunday on Architectural Heritage Year events gave an incorrect time for the April 26 tour of the Octagon House in Irvington-on-Hudson. The tour, sponsored by the Greenburgh Public Library, will be at 11 A.M.

title: MUSEUM ON INDIANS MARKS ITS 55th YEAR
description: THE University of Connecticut and the Town of Montville are among those honoring 87-year-old Gladys Tantaquidgeon and her family this year for their work in preserving their Mohegan Indian heritage. But on a recent morning, Miss Tantaquidgeon had more immediate concerns.

title: THE HARD REALITIES OF CULTURAL EXCHANGE
description: In the coming months, if all goes as planned, American audiences will be watching and listening to the Leningrad Symphony, the Kirov Ballet, the Bolshoi Opera and Ballet, the Moiseyev Folklore Ensemble, the Moscow Children's Music Theater and other esteemed groups and soloists from the Soviet Union. Before the year is out, an exhibition of Impressionist and post-Impressionist paintings from the Hermitage in Leningrad and the Pushkin Museum in Moscow are to be shown in Washington, Los Angeles and New York.

title: SENATORS WILL TRY AGAIN, IN PRIVATE
description: ONE WEEKEND last fall, when tax-revision legislation seemed close to death, Representative Dan Rostenkowski locked the members of his Ways and Means Committee in a large, windowless room across the street from the Capitol and applied the kind of political muscle that so often allows the democratic process to function.

title:
WESTCHESTER JOURNAL;
BONJOUR
description: Two years ago, Martine Guerin and Beatrice Gervais, two French women who were living in the county, decided that there was a need to help the growing number of French families avoid the many problems of ''settling in'' to a new country and community. They established a voluntary organization, the French Welcome Service.

title: TO EAT, PERCHANCE TO DREAM
description: THERE we were, wolfing down hot falafel (with a side order of hummus and pita) at Noah's Ark Restaurant in Oceanside (''Everything in a pita''), when I looked through the window and noticed across the parking lot the Gourmet Restaurant (''Continental cuisine and Indian cuisine'') and an Italian restaurant right next door. I realized for the first time that Long Island, this quintessentially American suburb, was not just the fast-food capital of the world - although it also has good credentials for that title too.

title: EVOLVING AN ASTRONOMY TEXT
description: AS VOYAGER 2 zipped past Uranus in January, the spacecraft's camera twisted and turned like an eager tourist to snap once-in-a-lifetime photos of the aquamarine planet, its cratered moons and string-like rings. The images were transmitted to the Jet Propulsion Laboratory in Pasadena, Calif., where in only a few hours computers processed the shots in color. The world soon saw more marvels of the space age.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: THE JOURNEY IS HOME. By Nelle Morton. (Beacon Press, $21.95.) This collection of essays traces the personal, political and spiritual pilgrimage of Nelle Mor-ton.

title:
COLLEGE SPORTS '86: SPRING FOOTBALL;
OKLAHOMA ROOTERS THINK NEXT FALL ISN'T ENOUGH
description: WHILE much of the athletic world was preoccupied in recent weeks with Louisville's basketball championship, Jack Nicklaus's victory in the Masters and the opening of the major league baseball season, the most discussed name among University of Oklahoma sports fans was that of Curtice Williams. The most discussed sport was spring football practice.

title: THREE PIANISTS PERFORM AT CARNEGIE RECITAL HALL: LESLIE AMPER
description: Leslie Amper played the same Griffes sonata the following afternoon in the same hall, in a performance less rich and surging than Mr. Noland's, but still persuasive; it's a piece that deserves a place in the repertory. The Boston-based pianist began her program with three of Messiaen's ''Vingt Regards sur L'Enfant Jesus,'' in which her concentrated and detailed playing was somewhat compromised by the gummy, guitarlike sound of the deep bass notes on the hall's piano.

title: MADE IN THE U.S.A., BUT AVOIDED IN JAPAN
description: THERE is little doubt, a Japanese pediatrician told two Americans last week, that Japan's techniques for vaccinating infants are superior to those used in the United States. At some length and unsolicited, he went on to assert that Japanese babies are inoculated at a more sensible age and that the serum used here produces one-fifth the incidence of fever associated with the American variety.

title: Angela King to Marry
description: The engagement of Angela Yvette King to D'Artagnan Gontran Bebel has been announced by the parents of the bride-to-be, Col. William Sturgeon King, U.S.A.F., and Mrs. King of Wheaton, Md. The wedding is planned for next month. Miss King, a graduate of American University, is a marketing representative for the International Business Machines Corporation in Bethesda, Md. Mr. Bebel, a cum laude graduate of Howard University who received an M.B.A. from Columbia University, is an account executive for WCBS-FM Radio in New York.

title: THE POLITICS OF VIRILITY
description: FRENCH FASCISM The First Wave, 1924-1933. By Robert Soucy. Illustrated. 276 pp. New Haven: Yale University Press. $25. IN his new book on French fascism, Robert Soucy reminds us that, between the world wars, powerful conservative figures in France were not averse to supporting or associating with fascist movements in their efforts to defeat the left. Perhaps it is the memory of such associations that has led contemporary political analysts to watch with growing concern the emergence of Jean-Marie Le Pen's National Front, which won about 10 percent of the vote in last month's legislative elections, and to attend closely to Mr. Le Pen's flirtations with conservatives - the obvious candidates for political alliances with his ultranationalist organization.

title: Yvonne Monteagudo Weds a TV Engineer
description: N. Yvonne Monteagudo, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Michael Perez of Miami, was married yesterday to Micha Kroll, a son of Marilyn Kroll of Astoria, Queens, and Eliezer L. Kroll of Jerusalem. The ceremony was performed by Rabbi Sheldon Harr at Temple Kol Ami in Plantation, Fla.

title:
GARDENING;
WISTERIA: A VINE WORTH ITS TROUBLE
description: WISTERIA grows rapidly, as much as four to five feet a year, and can literally choke a tree to death. Yet, it is valued as being one of the more attractive ornamental vines.

title: WITH THE GODDESS IN HER SEASONS
description: ON PERSEPHONE'S ISLAND A Sicilian Journal. By Mary Taylor Simeti. Illustrated. 329 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $18.95.

title: PLAY IT AGAIN, MAX
description: THE SOLOIST By Nicholas Christopher. 306 pp. New York: Viking. $17.95.

title: Free Fall Onto a Sandbag
description: FAIN WOULD I climb,'' wrote Sir Walter Raleigh on a windowpane of some English palace, ''yet fear I to fall.''

title: SWISS GETTING TOUGHER ON REFUGEES
description: On Palm Sunday, the Zurich police took a 29-year-old Polish citizen who had been refused asylum in Switzerland to Kloten International Airport and put him aboard a flight for Warsaw.

title: 'OFF RECORD' KISSINGER TALK ISN'T
description: Former Secretary of State Henry A. Kissinger, speaking at what he thought was a private symposium, said Friday that both sides were spouting nonsense in the debate over aid to the Nicaraguan rebels.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: MR. JUSTICE AND MRS. BLACK: The Memoirs of Hugo L. Black and Elizabeth Black. (Random House, $22.95.) Unfortunately for historians and students of the Supreme Court, Justice Hugo Black was 82 years old and only three years from death when he started writing his memoirs in 1968.

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS
description: MOSES IN THE BULRUSHES Written and illustrated by Warwick Hutton. Unpaged. New York: Margaret K. McElderry/ Atheneum. $12.95. (Ages 5 and up) IN the strange and gaudy world of children's picture books, Warwick Hutton is something of a rarity. He is an honest artist. He can draw, beautifully; and he is not ashamed of it. He does not seek to recommend himself to a child by drawing childishly. Nor does he go to the other extreme of using the picture book as a shop window for self-indulgent color fantasies, more suited to the psychiatrist's couch than to the child's bed. His most recent books include ''Jonah and the Great Fish'' and ''Beauty and the Beast.''

title: State's Most Wanted Fugitive Taken Into Custody in Texas
description: New York State's most wanted fugitive, Kenneth Lee Rieman, was arrested today at a storage warehouse near Fort Worth, authorities said.

title: FUND FOR ROAD REPAIRS HELD IMPERILED
description: THE multibillion-dollar road rehabilitation program financed by New Jersey's Transportation Trust Fund will end prematurely next year unless a new reliable mechanism for money is established in time.

title: ZOELLER SHOOTS A 69 TO LEAD BY 2 SHOTS
description: Fuzzy Zoeller scattered seven birdies across his card of 69 that provided him with a two-shot lead today in the third round of the $450,000 Sea Pines Heritage Classic.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: BLACK POPULAR MUSIC IN AMERICA. By Arnold Shaw. (Schirmer Books, $19.95.) A former music publishing executive and the author of several books about black popular music, Arnold Shaw here attempts to survey the history of the entire field in one short volume.

title: JOURNEY AMONG TYRANTS
description: Mr. Rosenthal's article was moving and instructive. It is also a path-breaking argument about the right journalistic standards to use when covering such countries as the Philippines, the Koreas, Indonesia and the Soviet Union.

title: Zimbabwe Honors Army
description: President Canaan Banana said today that Zimbabwean military must be fully equipped to meet any war threat from neighboring South Africa. Mr. Banana, speaking in Harare at celebrations in honor of the armed forces, said Zimbabwe was in the ''firing line'' of what he called destabilization by South Africa.

title: ROLLING IN MONEY IN LONDON
description: TWO years ago, P. Joan Beck had the kind of job few young investment bankers would abandon - he was a managing director in London for prestigious Morgan Stanley & Company, specializing in Eurobonds. But when Mr. Beck had a chance to take a similar post at rival Credit Suisse First Boston Ltd., he jumped without hesitation.

title: Norris Released
description: When Harry Steve, the owner of the minor league San Jose Bees, signed Mike Norris, the former major league pitcher whose career had been shattered by cocaine, both knew it was a gamble. Steve, whose team is one of the few minor league clubs without a major league player development contract, loaded his roster with seven former big leaguers, including four who had experienced problems with drugs.

title: THE VICTORIOUS PERSONALITY
description: THE BOMB drop near me while I'm eating. Surprise attack. Everybody in the dining hall runs. To tell the truth, I don't feel frightened at all. Just keep on eating.

title: Claire Sokoloff, Consultant, And Robert Gifford Marry
description: Claire Ellen Sokoloff and Robert Gary Gifford were married yesterday at the Sheraton-Carlton Hotel in Washington.

title: GREAT TREES: ONE CHAMP IS 16 FEET OF TROUBLE
description: The Louis Vieux, reigning king of American elms, has been dethroned.

title: ISAAC STERN'S MUSICAL LEGACY IS ASSEMBLED
description: Isaac Stern has been a commanding presence in the musical world for more than four decades. He has always seemed more than a mere virtuoso violinist; rather he has been the quintessential humanitarian, ready to devote himself to causes that extend far beyond the confines of musical life. As a performer, he has reached past the standard solo repertory into the realms of chamber music and 20th-century music. As a nurturer of young talent, he has lovingly guided the careers of Itzhak Perlman, Pinchas Zukerman, Shlomo Mintz, Yo-Yo Ma and Cho-Liang Lin. And as a tireless champion of civic causes, he has found time to save Carnegie Hall from demolition and to serve as chairman of the American-Israel Cultural Foundation.

title: ITALIAN PROMISES TO ANSWER TERROR
description: Prime Minister Bettino Craxi said today that Italy would respond with ''severity'' to any new Libyan attacks on Italian territory, and a senior aide said this meant Italy would take military action.

title: A SPLIT ON PHASE-IN OF SHOREHAM RATES
description: THE State Public Service Commission is nearing a decision on how to phase the cost of the $4.5 billion Shoreham Nuclear Power Station into Long Island electric rates if the plant gains a Federal license to operate.

title: IT'S A BIRD, IT'S A...IT'S REALLY AN ACTOR
description: WHAT does a young actor who yearns for serious classical and contemporary roles do when he looks like a muscleman and has become known as Captain America and Spider-Man?

title: SANDINISTAS FEAR WORLD'S REACTION TO RAID ON LIBYA IS WEAK
description: Sandinista leaders have expressed surprise and concern at what they view as insufficient worldwide condemnation of the United States air raid on Libya last week.

title: GROUPS PREPARE TO CLOSE SEASONS
description: A GREAT many musical organizations are preparing to close out their seasons, making the concert calendar for the next fortnight more crowded than usual.

title: Another Setback In U.S. Military's Satellite Program
description: The military's ability to gather information from space suffered another major setback last week when a Titan 34D rocket exploded seconds after liftoff at Vandenberg Air Force Base, Calif., destroying its secret military payload.

title: YALE ROWERS HAND PENN ITS FIRST LOSS
description: Yale's varsity heavyweight crew toppled Pennsylvania from the unbeaten ranks of Eastern crews, besting the Quakers by 1.3 seconds today in the varsity race for the Blackwell Cup.

title: WHERE WILL REAGAN'S LIBYAN BATTLE PLAN LEAD?
description: DURING just 11 minutes in the night skies over Libya, United States warplanes opened a new chapter last week in the confrontation between the technological power of the West and the ideological fervor of Middle East terrorism.

title:
ART;
INDIAN MINIATURES AT NEWARK MUSEUM
description: A MUSEUM lobby is usually a place to pause, to acclimate one's self before an encounter with art treasures. But upon entering the Newark Museum these days, you find yourself captured right away by a major show: 127 vivid Indian miniatures.

title: U.S. WILL RESTRICT EUROPE'S EXPORTS IN TRADE DISPUTE
description: The Reagan Administration will start placing unspecified new restrictions on West European exports to the United States next month in retaliation for lost American food sales to Portugal and Spain, senior European and American trade officials disclosed today.

title: Pictures of Malamud
description: IN February 1961 I traveled west from Iowa City, where I was teaching in the Writers' Workshop of the university and finishing a second book, to give a lecture called ''Writing American Fiction'' at a small community college in Monmouth, Ore. A close buddy from my graduate school days at the University of Chicago was teaching there and had arranged the invitation. I accepted not only because of the opportunity the trip afforded me to see, for the first time in five years, my friends Bob and Ida Baker and their small children, but because Baker promised that if I came out he'd arrange for me to meet Bernard Malamud.

title: Did Justice Fall From the Skies Over Tripoli?; Congress Acquiesced
description: To the Editor:

title: AMONG JEWS OF NICARAGUA: MUCH DEBATE
description: Jews who left Nicaragua after the 1979 revolution disagree sharply with the handful who still live there over whether the victorious Sandinistas engaged in anti-Semitic acts and threats.

title: LOOKING IN ON LAKE WOBEGONE
description: The news from Lake Wobegon is that ''A Prairie Home Companion,'' perhaps the best-known variety program on radio, can be seen next Saturday night on public television. A tape-delay of the homespun, two-hour show and its host, Garrison Keillor, will be carried at 9 on WNYC/ Channel 31; WNET/Channel 13 has it scheduled for next Sunday night at 10.

title: PICTURES OF MALAMUD
description: ''Mourning is a hard business,'' Cesare said.

title: VIOLINS STOLEN FROM A VISITING GERMAN ORCHESTRA
description: Six stringed instruments belonging to an East German chamber orchestra were stolen from a bus parked overnight Friday at the Port Authority Bus Terminal in midtown Manhattan, leaving an audience in Wilmington, Del. last night with a reduced orchestra playing a modified program.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: MY FRIENDS. By Emmanuel Bove. (Carcanet, $15.95.) A poor sad sack named Victor Baton, a French veteran of the First World War, wakes in his shabby attic room in Paris and sets out to do what he does most days: to find a friend. Emmanuel Bove's ''My Friends,'' admired by Colette, Rilke and Beckett, and published in 1924, is the story of Victor's hapless, comical, heart-rending attempts to find love. One night he sleeps with Lucie Dunois, the proprietor of a wine shop, only to be chucked out in the morning without so much as a cup of coffee. One day he meets Henri Billard in a crowd gawking at a swooning dwarf. Victor is of no interest to him - until he lends Henri money - and the two never meet again. When Blanche, a cafe artiste, takes Victor home for the night and in the morning says he can come back the next day, he leaves and never tries to see her again. As the novel ends, Victor has been evicted from his apartment and has set up in a dingy hotel. He believes he has been thrown out because he does not work, because people could not forgive him ''for being free and for not being afraid of poverty.'' Bove claimed that he had created a genre, the novel of ''impoverished solitude.'' Both Victor's obsessive, often hilarious honesty about himself as well as his childish mythomania about love and friendship are forms of passive resistance, of imaginative delirium which are the only defenses a poor, weak, lonely man who wishes to be free has.

title: VANCOUVER UNWRAPS ITS WORLD'S FAIR
description: On May 2, Britain's most celebrated couple, the Prince and the Princess of Wales, will appear in Vancouver to open Expo 86, the only official world's fair planned in North America for the rest of this century. The show will run until Oct. 13 against a spectacular backdrop of the city's mountains and harbor.

title: WHEN BEDBUGS ATE THE FLEAS -- POLITICS AND WRITING IN POLAND
description: THE subject, as always, is collaboration.

title: DID LEONARDO INVENT THE HOME RUN?
description: THE IOWA BASEBALL CONFEDERACY By W. P. Kinsella. 310 pp. Boston: Houghton Mifflin Company. $16.95.

title: 30 Strikeouts Set Record
description: The Oakland A's and the Mariners combined for 30 strikeouts tonight to set a modern major-league record for a nine-inning game.

title: Louis Bellson on Radio
description: The jazz drummer Louis Bellson will be the guest today from 6 to 8:30 P.M. on ''The Swing Years,'' a radio program on WRHU, Hostra University's FM station, 88.7 FM. The host, Lloyd Rauch, will talk with Mr. Bellson and will play records on which the drummer is featured. Mr. Bellson will be appearing next week in person at Fat Tuesday's.

title: OPERA: VLADIMIR POPOV JOINS MET 'CARMEN' CAST
description: THE principals in the Metropolitan Opera's cast for ''Carmen'' Thursday night contained mostly names already reviewed this season, except for Vladimir Popov as Don Jose. Mr. Popov's bellowing was of little interest in itself, apart from what it tells us about tertiary casting at the Met (casting that is not sweetened by tertiary ticket pricing, to be sure).

title: THE DANCE: MICHIYO AND GROUP
description: MICHIYO TANAKA got her dances off to lively starts at the Theater of the Riverside Church. Thanks to her company, Michiyo and Dancers, they continued in a spirited fashion. Yet, because she did not always develop or clarify the themes she introduced, the dances did not end as interestingly as they began.

title: JOURNEY AMONG TYRANTS
description: A. M. Rosenthal's article ''Journey Among Tyrants'' (March 23) has the eloquence that comes from simple truth clearly seen. At a stroke, he demolishes the ''sophistication'' and ''realism'' that have permitted us to blind ourselves to the fact that foreign policy is not, in the end, about governments or nation states, but about people. JONATHAN J. MARGOLIS Boston

title: JOURNEY AMONG TYRANTS
description: Mr. Rosenthal writes that ''where we have the power to change [ dictatorships ] , we should,'' and that ''we intervene wherever we can and however we can . . . as we would wish others to intervene were we the imprisoned.''

title: WHY ASIAN CULTURE ANSWERS THE NEEDS OF WESTERN ARTISTS
description: In the last 10 years, Western art, particularly in America, has set both feet on the shores of the Orient for the first time. Numerous artists, coming from a great many directions, have been roaming through the artistic landscapes of Japan, India and China. The journeys have usually been solitary and silent. What artists have found there is essential.

title: AROUND THE GARDEN
description: This Week:

title: Wendy Friedberg Wed To Dr. David Cawthon
description: The wedding of Wendy Lou Friedberg, a daughter of Harriett Sue Friedberg of New York and the late Robert M. Friedberg, to Dr. David Franklin Cawthon, the son of Dr. William and Dr. Kathleen Cawthon of Montgomery, Ala., took place yesterday. Acting Justice Robert L. Cohen of the State Supreme Court officiated at the 24 Fifth Avenue Restaurant.

title: BELGIUM'S ELEGANT LEATHERCRAFT
description: In 1820, in the heart of Brussels, at 7 Rue de l'Empereur, Delvaux-Createur opened its doors, offering steamer trunks and luggage. Delvaux soon acquired a reputation for producing well-made goods at fair prices and thrived during the 19th century. During the years following World War I, the company and its reputation for quality survived.

title: LE BERNARDIN'S FOUR-STAR RECIPES
description: FEW EVENTS ENERGIZE the souls of food-loving New Yorkers like the opening of an important new restaurant. Le Bernardin, the marvelous new creation of brother-and-sister team Gilbert and Maguy Le Coze, has generated an excitement not felt for a long time among seasoned restaurantgoers.

title: IN MARATHONS, U.S. MEN ARE RUNNING BEHIND
description: AN eminent economist, the late Jules Backman, once told me that statistics are a marvelously supple commodity. One can twist them, bend them, slant them to suit his purpose and yet never deviate from truth. ''You fellows in sports do it all the time,'' he said.

title: The Greatest Modern Writer
description: To the Editor:

title: INS AND OUTS OF COLLEGE ADMISSIONS
description: ONCE upon a time, a long time ago, before people ran out of money, there was a recurring phenomenon every year. In the spring, heavily ladened mailmen could be seen dodging high school seniors who demanded their mail immediately. Would it be a thick envelope or a thin one? Their parents talked about nothing else - at home, at work, and especially at cocktail parties.

title: Susan Lewis Engaged
description: Mr. and Mrs. Arnold Lewis of Dix Hills, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Susan Lewis, to Richard T. Chavis, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Nathan Chavis of Rosedale, L.I. Miss Lewis, a graduate of the Fashion Institute of Technology, attended the State University of New York at Buffalo. She is a senior production artist at the Matthew Bender Company, a law-book publisher in New York. Mr. Chavis, an owner of Optical Contact in Manhattan, attended Hofstra University.

title: Married or Not?
description: To the Editor:

title: STAR WARS PLANNERS ARE DIGGING THEMSELVES IN
description: Although many scientists doubt that an effective array of antimissile weapons can be developed any time soon without all but bankrupting the country, President Reagan's Strategic Defense Initiative has become a well-entrenched part of the Federal bureaucracy, apparently impervious to counterattack.

title: AIDS CHILDREN TO GET DAY CARE AT BRONX CENTER
description: New York City's first day-care center for children with AIDS will open at Bronx Municipal Hospital within a few months.

title: AT THE END OF THE TRAIL
description: East of the sun and west of the moon, as seen from Vancouver, is Chilcotin. The handful of Indians and whites who have been trying, with indifferent success, to inhabit it, call it the Chilcotin Country. They are very proud of it. Some outsiders instantly see why. Others don't get the point. In an age when rapid travel has ceased to be a miracle and become the commonplace, Chilcotin lies only two hoots and a holler from Greater Vancouver, Canada's third largest metropolitan area. Somehow, so far, Chilcotin remains distant in spirit, aloof in its own stubborn way, from the big city, isolated as well in time. It will change. All things do. But not yet.

title: 'STAR WARS' PACT DISCLOSURE UPSETS BONN
description: Chancellor Helmut Kohl's Government has been embarrassed by the disclosure to the press of a secret accord governing West Germany's industrial role in the Reagan Administration's research program on antimissile defenses.

title: SCHOOL DISTRICTS DEBATE SEAT-BELT ISSUE
description: DESPITE concern that seat belts on school buses may increase the chance of injuries to young riders, a small but growing number of the nation's school districts has decided the belts promote safety and are mandating their use - particularly in Westchester County.

title:
ART;
FROM ANATOLIA TO THE AMERICAN WEST, TEXTILES AND WEAVING
description: A FLYING carpet would be both useful and appropriate this week for getting to sharply related exhibitions at opposite ends of the county. At the Katonah Gallery, the culture of the largest group of American Indians is examined through weavings and reproductions of sandpaintings in ''Navajo Weaving, Navajo Ways,'' through May 25. At the Sarah Lawrence College gallery in Yonkers, the walls and some floor space are decked with textiles known as kilims from Anatolia through May 27.

title: KIROV BALLET WILL PERFORM AT WOLF TRAP IN JUNE
description: This year's Wolf Trap Farm Park season, which begins May 28, will include performances by the New York City Opera, Ella Fitzgerald, the Preservation Hall Jazz Band, Pete Seeger and Arlo Guthrie, and the Kirov Ballet of Leningrad in its first appearance in the United States since 1964, the company announced last week.

title: Nancy A. Fink to Be Wed To Brett R. Gingold in June
description: Mr. and Mrs. Harold L. Fink of Stamford, Conn., have announced that their daughter, Nancy Anne Fink, and Brett Roy Gingold, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Stanley Gingold of New York, plan to marry June 29. Miss Fink, an advertising sales representative for Mademoiselle magazine, graduated from Michigan State University, where she also received a master's degree in advertising. Her father is president of Hank Fink Inc., a textile manufacturing concern in Kings Mountain, N.C.

title: ALL SHUTTLE CREW REMAINS RECOVERED, NASA SAYS
description: The National Aeronautics and Space Administration said today that it had recovered remains of each of the seven Challenger astronauts and had finished its operations to retrieve the wreckage of the space shuttle's crew compartment from the ocean floor.

title: Swedes, Finns Advance In Hockey Tournament
description: Sweden and Finland achieved victories today to qualify for the medal round at the World Hockey Championships.

title: Dawn Wheatley Wed To Robert B. Schaller
description: Dawn Susan Wheatley, a teacher at the Ethical Culture School in Manhattan, and Robert Bruce Schaller, deputy director for management planning and analysis of the New York City Department of Parks and Recreation, were married yesterday. The Rev. A. Finley Schaef performed the ceremony at the Park Slope United Methodist Church in Brooklyn.

title: Why Europeans Are Angry
description: Americans still do not understand the shock and outrage felt throughout Europe, Britain not excluded. Most people in the United States, if they care at all what we think of the Libyan raid, are puzzled, indignant or scornful. It seems to them obvious that Muammar el-Qaddafi had to be punished and that to fuss about the method is typical of the flabby yellow-bellied response they have come to expect from their allies.

title: WHEN CHILDREN HAVE CHILDREN
description: WHEN a teen-age girl becomes an unwed mother, the odds are stacked against her from the start. The odds are that she won't finish high school, that she won't be able to support herself and her new child on her own and that she will be alone - isolated from her peers, abandoned by the child's father and cut off from her family.

title: Julia Keough Marries R.B. Esser in Colorado
description: Julia Alden Keough and Richard Boice Esser were married yesterday at the Rocky Mountain Church in Frisco, Colo. The Rev. Donald Cutler performed the Episcopal ceremony.

title: CARDS BEAT EXPOS BY 9-6 IN 17
description: Tim Conroy, batting for his first time in the major leagues, drew a bases-loaded walk with two outs in the 17th inning and Willie McGee followed with a two-run single today, lifting the Cardinals over the Montreal Expos, 9-6.

title: BRINGING THE ARTS TO THE CLASSROOM
description: IT WAS a difficult choice for Amy Mandel to make, and the Plainview-Old Bethpage High School junior was clearly distressed.

title: PAUL TAYLOR USES BACH TO EVOKE PRIMITIVE RITES
description: Choreographers who ask us to absorb their dances on many levels at once take the risk that we will not be able to understand their work completely. This is very different from choreographers who operate on a very private or hermetic plane - as do so many poets - and who cannot possibly expect the public to ascertain the exact meaning of their thoughts.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: SUNDAY, APRIL 20, 1986
description: International

title: A Tale Of Tresses
description: Hairpieces are taking on a new role. Where once wigs and switches were used to disguise a woman's real hair, they are now employed as fashion accessories, much the same as a ribbon or scarf might be wrapped around the head.

title: JOURNEY AMONG TYRANTS
description: I was relieved and warmed to read A. M. Rosenthal's cogent argument for democracy for others as well as for ourselves. Our image in other countries, of course, rests on the integrity of our concept of ''freedom as religion.''

title: AFTER WINNING RIGHT TO STARVE, A NEW FIGHT
description: Elizabeth Bouvia, who won a court decision to stop doctors from force-feeding her, says she still wants to die, but not in High Desert Hospital here.

title: WHEN NO ONE WORE PANTS
description: THE CREATION OF PATRIARCHY By Gerda Lerner. Illustrated. 318 pp. New York: Oxford University Press. $21.95.

title: INSTITUTIONS BY, OF AND FOR THE LITTLE GUY
description: SINCE its start in 1909 in Manchester, N.H., as a cooperative effort to make credit more widely available to the working class, the American credit union movement - with 18,000 institutions and 52 million members - has earned a comfortable niche in the financial services industry. And despite that phenomenal growth, credit unions remain faithful to their original aims in spirit and structure.

title: A Bomb Plot Foiled in London
description: Israeli airline security guards at Heathrow Airport in London took a hard look at Anne-Marie Murphy and her luggage last week as she was about to board an El Al flight for Tel Aviv. Beneath a false bottom in her bag they found 10 pounds of plastic explosive rolled paper-thin -enough, the police said, to destroy the El Al Boeing 747 and its 340 passengers.

title: EUPHORIC HARTFORD CHEERS ON WHALERS
description: SINCE Hartford is far removed from the Atlantic Ocean, the name of its hockey team, the Whalers, is a bit of a misnomer. In fact, when the club was moved from Boston a decade ago, some wags suggested that the name be changed to the Hartford Actuaries, or something similar in keeping with the city's reputation as insurance capital of the nation.

title: FARMS ON DECREASE IN SIZE AND NUMBER
description: LIKE most farmers' sons, David Polidoro had very little chance to play baseball as a boy. ''The start of the baseball season was the same as the start of the growing season,'' he recalled. ''And I had to rush home from school to help my father with the planting.'' A usual occurrence in a farming family, but what makes Mr. Polidoro's experience somewhat unusual is the location of the family farm - not in Iowa or Nebraska, but in Hartsdale.

title: A Lost Cause
description: SPEAKING FOR ME and my house, in the past there has been nothing quite so charged with promise as the start of a new baseball season. But this summer, like many another timorous Canadian, with dread my heart will be laden. Let me explain. Last year, the surprising Toronto Blue Jays all but won the American League pennant before the Kansas City Royals, coming from behind, finally wiped them out. An immense relief to all of us in the north. What's worrying us now is that this season the Toronto Blue Jays just might win everything. Losing a pennant or, still better, a World Series is something my country can handle, but winning one - a historical first -would go against the Canadian grain.

title: Six Hostile Years
RED WINE: GOOD EVEN IN FISH SAUCES
description: I ONCE had a friend who was an excellent cook, particularly when it came to sauces. But he had a disconcerting habit during dinner of corking up a bottle of wine when there was less than a glassful left and carting it off to the kitchen. I used to think that this was the manifestation of some secret meanness - or a comment on the lushness of his guests. Then I figured out the reason: he was hoarding for his sauces. Not wishing to open a fresh bottle of Saint Emilion or Macon when he only needed half a cup, he would set some aside in advance, knowing that it would do for cooking later, even if left for several days.

title: USRY'S STATUS GAINS AT MAYORAL PARLEY
description: A LOT of points were scored by Mayor James L. Usry, host at the recent National Conference of Black Mayors here, and his ''good friend'' Governor Kean.

title: ...AND CELEBRATING AT HOME
description: IT was 15 years ago that my mother told me, ''I just can't do it anymore.'' What she meant was that she was no longer able to make all the necessary preparations for Passover, the spring festival commemorating the Exodus of the Israelites from slavery in Egypt. And so, from that time on, we began inviting my parents to spend the eight days of the holiday with us.

title: Kathryn Iacocca To Marry in June
description: The engagement of Kathryn Lisa Iacocca to Ned Carlton Hentz has been announced by her father, Lee A. Iacocca, chairman of the Chrysler Corporation.

title: RISING COSTS BRING INQUIRY ON GARBAGE
description: WESTCHESTER'S Board of Legislators has begun a comprehensive investigation of ways to stem soaring costs at the trash-to-energy plant in Peekskill. The rising costs, a result of the recent drop in oil prices, have caused steep increases in county-levied garbage taxes to the 38 municipalities using the facility.

title: BUSINESS NOTES
description: EXECUTIVE Women of New Jersey, a 70-member organization founded in 1978 to help the advancement of female executives, raised about $70,000 for its scholarship fund at its annual dinner in West Orange.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: THE HEART IN THE CASKET. By Colleen Klein. (Century Hutchinson/David & Charles, $18.95.) Mothers and daughters: a relationship fraught with discovery, delight, tension and sacrifice.

title: Grantchester
description: To the Editor: Thomas Mallon, in his March 9 piece ''In Grantchester, a Poet Remembered'' states that a long-ago proposal to fix the hands of the church clock at 10 to 3 was thought better of.

title: IN QUOTES
description: ''Protectionist sentiment is in full bloom again, with legislation in both houses of Congress.'' James A. Baker 3d

title: Bookshelf
description: Additional titles of interest:

title: LETTING TRANSIT COPS COME UP FOR AIR
description: WHEN the New York City Transit Authority was created by the state in 1953, the city gave it the job of policing as well as running the subway system. But almost ever since, municipal officials have been debating whether to take the policing job back.

title: STAGE: 'LIFE AND DEATH,' BY ROSALYN DREXLER
description: ANYONE who comes out of a Rosalyn Drexler play not feeling he has been totally deprived of his wits has not been paying attention. Her current effort, ''A Matter of Life and Death,'' at the Theater for the New City, is inspired by the Green River murders, a series of killings of more than 30 prostitutes along a strip of highway near Seattle in the early 1980's. Those crimes are unsolved. No matter. Mrs. Drexler has invented a killer, Tod Calvin, and an accomplice, Jimmy Otis, who are already convicted and facing execution. The action occurs in a cell surrounded by a towering forest of iron bars and gates.

title: BERGEN FAMILY'S SEDER: A TRULY DIFFERENT NIGHT
description: FOR MANY of the 60 people who will gather at Congregation Shomrei Torah here Wednesday night for the start of Passover, the seder will be their first.

title: CHURCH AND HEIRESS'S FAMILY FIGHT OVER GIFTS
description: In the last two years Elizabeth Dayton Dovydenas, a retailing heiress and society figure here, gave $6.6 million to a fundamentalist church. Now she and her family are trying to get the money back, saying she was manipulated into making the gifts.

title: CAREFUL SHOPPER
description: Renovation Sale At Bally Outlet Shoppers already on the mailing list and those who drop in at the Bally Outlet in New Rochelle know of the additional 25 percent off on the red-dotted items - men's and ladies' shoes, boots, jackets, briefcases, wallets, handbags, belts and ties. When the remodeling sale ends next Sunday, the outlet will close for six weeks, reopening after renovation. Two other Bally Outlets are in Secaucus, N.J. and Orlando, Fla.

title: SYRIA REPORTS SERIES OF BLASTS ON BUSES AND BLAMES ISRAELIS
description: Syria said today that several people were killed and wounded in a series of explosions aboard buses in Syria last Wednesday.

title: MUSIC: FRENCH PROGRAM
description: THE pleasures of Thursday's Music Spectrum concert at Merkin Concert Hall appeared where one did not expect them to. The initial lure of this evening was a solo flute piece by Pierre Boulez called ''. . . Explosante/fixe,'' which Aurele Nicolet was to have played for the first time in this country. Mr. Nicolet suffered an unspecified accident beforehand, however, so Robert Stallman came in his place, substituting Messiaen's ''Merle Noir'' and also playing the Franck Sonata in A. The real beauties of this concert came at the beginning, when Doris Yarick-Cross sang four of Duparc's loveliest creations - ''L'Invitation au voyage,'' ''Lamento,'' ''Extase'' and ''Le Manoir de Rosamonde.''

title: JOURNEY AMONG TYRANTS
description: A. M. Rosenthal's observations of South Korea are disappointingly cursory. Some of his criticisms of the current Government are, in my view, extreme.

title: GIFTS FOR THE AGED: WHAT'S RIGHT?
description: MY INTEREST in appropriate gifts for the very old - and Mother's Day is fast approaching -began when the topic arose at a family-support group meeting I was leading at a large geriatric facility where I am a psychology consultant.

title: Social Events; Performing for a Cause
description: Helping Summer Stock April 20 - Geraldine Fitzgerald, E. G. Marshall, Celeste Holm, Treat Williams, Blythe Danner, Marsha Mason, Teri Garr, Ken Howard and Sam Waterston are some of the actors due to perform at an 8 P.M. party at the Palladium to benefit the Williamstown Theater Festival. The theater, which opens its 32d year on June 26 in Williamstown, Mass., has become one of the nation's leading stock companies, presenting new and established actors and productions. Tickets, $25, at the door. Virtuosos Aid Novices April 21 - Some accomplished musicians will be on hand for the annual Champagne dinner-dance at the Carlyle Hotel for the Third Street Music School Settlement. Founded in 1894, it is New York's oldest music school, serving some 1,500 students as young as 3 years old at little or no cost. Bobby Short, Marian McPartland and Richard Stoltzman will head the entertainment at the black-tie benefit, starting with cocktails at 7:30 P.M. Tickets, $225, from 212-777-3240. For a New Theater April 21 - Joshua Logan and his wife, Nedda Harrigan Logan, will be onstage in ''Musical Moments'' from his shows, appearing at the Theater of the Open Eye, on 89th Street near Broadway. Cocktails, at 6:45 P.M., will precede the performance, and dinner with the Logans will follow it, all for the benefit of a new home for the 15-year-old theater group. Tickets, $80 for cocktails and reception, $125 including dinner at the Cafe Montana, 88th Street and Broadway, from 212-769-4142.

title: Harold Kramer Wed To Adrienne Corman
description: Adrienne Corman, the daughter of Morie Corman of Needham, Mass., and the late Charlotte Corman, was married there yesterday evening to Harold Kramer, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Franklin Kramer of Briarcliff Manor, N.Y. Rabbi Rivat Sonsino performed the ceremony at Temple Beth Shalom.

title: A PAWN SACRIFICE
description: It is unquestionable that a pawn sacrifice has an unsettling effect that may go beyond its purely logical value, yet, as in all other things, one must meet it with a clear head.

title: DAIRYMEN BIDDING RELUCTANT FAREWELL
description: ALL John and Marie Kalenauskas said they wanted was to make a living in the dairy business.

title: A Seminar
description: Many New Yorkers care more about what they see out of their windows than about the windows themselves. Savvy apartment owners also care about the energy efficiency of their windows.

title: Economic Boom
description: To the Editor:

title: Read It Now II
description: The Award for Most Impenetrable News Release, on the other hand, goes to George Washington University Medical Center Office of Public Relations. It opens as follows: ''The George Washington University/Holy Cross Hospital Magnetic Resonance Academic Imaging Center opens today at Holy Cross Hospital in Silver Spring.''

title: TORT REFORM: THE CRUCIAL STEP IN RELIEVING INSURANCE CRISIS
description: VIRTUALLY every business or other entity that requires liability insurance today finds itself in the midst of an insurance cost and availability crisis. The crisis has grown to such proportions that many states are beginning to take action. Connecticut's General Assembly and other state governmental bodies will give the insurance issue considerable attention in the coming weeks. But will the problem be solved? The Connecticut Business and Industry Association represents about 6,300 companies that employ more than 700,000 state residents. The vast majority of the association's members are consumers of casualty liability insurance. They are the state's manufacturers, retailers, financial and service industries. These companies need insurance coverage if they are going to continue to produce and sell useful products and services and provide jobs.

title: Nancy Steinen Is Married To Richard Mark Burman
description: Nancy Meryl Steinen and Richard Mark Burman were married yesterday in the Community Congregational Church in Short Hills, N.J., by the Rev. Dr. Kenyon J. Wildrick.

title: Tentative Pact With Amtrak To Improve L.I.R.R. Service
description: Long Island Rail Road trains should reach Pennsylvania Station more quickly and commuters should be able to move more easily through the station, under a tentative agreement between Amtrak and the Metropolitan Transportation Authority.

title: TOPICS
description: ONE summer day as I waited for my 13-year-old son to finish his sailing lesson at Centerport Beach, I was trying to amuse my 3-year-old daughter at the water's edge. I was very hot and very tired. Even though little circles of foam were swirling around our feet and cooling us, the sun's noontime high felt oppressive.

title: U.S. URGES LIBERIAN TALKS BY DOE AND OPPOSITION
description: A high United States official ended a two-day visit to Liberia yesterday during which he sought to resolve a political standoff between President Samuel K. Doe and opposition leaders demanding his resignation, a Reagan Administration aide said.

title: With Rates Down, Builders Consider 'Going Rental'
description: IS the wheel of housing production in the city turning back from condominiums to rentals? Maybe not, but a few substantial developers in Manhattan are showing a greater interest in producing rental housing as the decline in interest rates makes them more confident that apartments can achieve required levels of income as rentals.

title: NEW JERSEYANS
description: AT THE ripe young age of 23, Kayla M. Bergeron of Randolph Township is already an ''old pol.''

title: STATUS OF IMMIGRANTS FROM INDIA IS DEBATED
description: Scholars and community leaders met for three days last week to exchange views, sometimes impassioned, about immigrants from India, one of this country's newest and least-examined minority groups.

title: STATE'S CONSERVATIVE PARTY TO GET NEW LEADER
description: In an era when political leaderships are constantly revolving, the Conservative Party of New York will change leaders next Wednesday for the first time in 24 years.

title: PARING AND SHARING COMMISSIONS
description: Perhaps no practice is as controversial within the travel industry as rebating, in which travel agents share with their customers the commisssions that they get from the airlines, hotels, cruise companies, auto-rental concerns and tour operators whose services they sell. In recent months, however, the practice has gradually begun to spread, with new agencies offering rebates to vacationers who are prepared to do much of the research for their trips. In most cases this rebating is legal, although the way it is conducted may violate some contracts between agencies and airlines.

title: CITY SCANDAL ACCELERATES PROPOSALS TO CUT ABUSE
description: Three months after the city's corruption scandal erupted, plans intended to stem abuses are being shaped, debated and put into effect with a momentum unseen in years. The surge, many officials say, could bring major changes to government and politics in New York City and the state.

title: Dance
description: The New York City Ballet returns to the New York State Theater this week for its two-month spring season. The opening night's performance alone, on Tuesday, suggests the range of styles and themes represented by the 40 ballets, new and old, that will be presented this season.

title: A COMPLETE 'CANDIDE,' TREASURES FROM FURTWANGLER
description: The New York City Opera's production of Leonard Bernstein's ''Candide,'' acclaimed as brilliant when it was presented at the State Theater in 1982 (and scheduled for two weeks of revival this year - July 1 to 6 and Nov. 11 to 16), is scheduled for release next month by New World Records, which is issuing it in LP, cassette and CD formats.

title: FEDERAL JUDICIARY STRUGGLES TO MAKE BUDGET CUTBACKS
description: Federal judges and court officials around the country are racing the clock to achieve mandatory budget cuts. If they fail, administrators say, the courts could be closed temporarily in September.

title: STATE'S PROSPECTS HELD HIGH
description: A 10-YEAR forecast showing northern New Jersey taking a strong lead in jobs and population growth within the area embraced by the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey tells only half of the good news for New Jersey, according to Joseph J. Seneca, chairman of the state's Economic Policy Council.

title: Unearthing Past At Valley Forge
description: WHILE the British were sitting comfortably by Philadelphia firesides in the winters of 1776-78, George Washington and 11,000 of his soldiers were encamped about 25 miles to the west at Valley Forge. Historians know that about 3,000 soldiers died in what is often called the ''winter of despair,'' but they know little of the daily life of those Continental soldiers.

title: BALANCED JOURNALISM NEEDN'T PRECLUDE A POINT OF VIEW
description: Once more an argument in public television; once more the same ramparts are mounted.

title: Linda A. Simpson Becomes a Bride
description: Linda Ann Simpson, a daughter of Judge and Mrs. Arthur J. Simpson Jr. of Oradell, N.J., was married yesterday to John Riche Ettinger. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Austen A. Ettinger of Manhattan.

title: 1,000 Protestants Attack Ulster Police Station
description: A 1,000-strong Protestant crowd attacked a police station at Portadown, 30 miles from Belfast, tonight after badly injuring a policeman who was knocked to the ground and kicked by dozens of rioters.

title: STATES TO MEET ON A-FUEL SHIPPING
description: AFTER months of bitter dispute over whether spent nuclear fuel from New York could be transported through Connecticut, officials from both states last week agreed to discuss alternative shipping routes.

title: TAKING AN EXPEDITION VACATION
description: I don't take vacations anymore, at least not the standard kind. I love to get away, but a crowded beach doesn't do it for me. I also don't relax like other people do. I have to be doing something on my time off. And I don't mean reading - I do that for a living.

title: NEW INVESTIGATIONS AIMED AT CARTERS
description: CORRUPTION charges brought last week by the Suffolk County District Attorney's office against Islip Town employees and garbage carters at the Islip landfill come at a time when a number of other local, state and Federal law enforcement agencies are investigating the Long Island carting industry for a variety of alleged criminal activities.

title: A GATHERING OF JAYS
description: IT was not supposed to be a family reunion, but on Monday night seven descendents of John Jay, the first Chief Justice of the United States, rallied at Rye City Hall.

title: IN THE HOUSE, MANEUVERING OVER NICARAGUA
description: MOST Americans are not sure what, if anything, they want the United States to do about Nicaragua, a New York Times/CBS News Poll disclosed last week. Sixty-two percent of the respondents said they opposed aid for the rebels fighting the Sandinista Government.

title: Lyle J. Mayne Is Engaged To Gregory Scott Owens
description: Mrs. Fred J. Mayne of Saddle River, N.J., has announced the engagement of her daughter, Lyle Jenne Mayne, to Gregory Scott Owens, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Ronald Owens of Wayne, N.J.

title: THE ENVIRONMENT
description: NEW JERSEY and New York legislators have formed a joint committee to examine the problem of pollution that crosses state lines. The committee held its first public hearing at the World Trade Center two weeks ago.

title: OPERA: MARTIN Y SOLER'S 'COSA RARA'
description: A CURRENT vogue in the art world is for exhibitions that present the visual context from which masterpieces arose - as in the ''From Courbet to Cezanne'' preview of the new Musee d'Orsay of Paris now at the Brooklyn Museum.

title: THREE PIANISTS PERFORM AT CARNEGIE RECITAL HALL: EUGENIE RUSSO
description: The third pianist of the week was Eugenie Russo, who gave a very well attended but puzzling recital in the same hall Monday evening. For the first half of her program she chose Brahms - six pieces from Op. 76 and the Sonata Op. 2 No. 2, all played very loudly and rather roughly.

title: MUMMENSCHANZ IS BACK, WITH A NEW BAG OF TRICKS
description: Covered by the great black velvet body masks they wear in their new show, the performers of Mummenschanz can barely see the audiences arrayed before them. But they can hear them. They must hear them, in fact. ''We work to the chuckles, the coughs, the sighs,'' said Andres Bossard, one of the trio of performers who created the Zurich-based masked theater 14 years ago. ''We work in silence, and we play with the silence. We shape it.''

title: SUNDAY SPORTS
description: Auto Racing Nascar First Union 400, at North Wilkesboro, N.C., 1 P.M. (Television - ESPN, 1 P.M.) Grand Prix of Long Beach, at Long Beach, Calif. (Television - Channel 4, 2 P.M.) Baseball Yankees vs.

title: Miss Frederick Engaged to Wed Herbert Terrace
description: Kathleen A. Frederick, a lawyer for the American Express Bank in New York, and Herbert S. Terrace, a psychology professor at Columbia University, plan to be married in July, the future bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Robert E. Frederick of Phillipsburg, N.J., have announced.

title: WILKINS HITS 50 AS HAWKS BEAT PISTONS
description: Dominique Wilkins scored 50 points and Randy Wittman a career-high 35 today as the Atlanta Hawks pulled away in the final quarter and downed the Detroit Pistons, 137-125, in a first-round playoff game.

title: 7 South Africans Killed in New Unrest
description: Two black children and five men have died in new violence in South Africa, and an anti-apartheid clergyman warned today that blacks see the nation's crisis deepening.

title:
ANTIQUES;
LEARNING TO 'READ' FURNITURE
description: LEARNING to interpret what the eye perceives - to ''read'' a piece of furniture and understand it in terms of its historical context, regionality, craftsmanship, style, component parts, materials and use - will be the focus of a five-session course on ''American Furniture for Collectors and Enthusiasts.''

title: SHAD ARE RETURNING AND LAMBERTVILLE WILL CELEBRATE
description: FRED LEWIS has been netting shad from his family's small island in the Delaware River for 56 years. Before him, his father did the same.

title: PAPERBACK BEST SELLERS: April 20, 1986
description: Fiction

title: LaRouche Connection To S.D.S. Disavowed
description: To the Editor:

title: A DAUGHTER REMEMBERS
description: MY mother died last April, almost a week after Easter. She had a heart attack and a stroke on a Thursday morning while baking bread. She managed to write a note telling us that she had just taken her high-blood pressure medicine and that her ''head hurt something awful.'' And she held on to life while I flew from Connecticut to Kansas to be with her.

title: Did Justice Fall From the Skies Over Tripoli?; Tonkin Gulf Parallel
description: To the Editor:

title: THE DANCE: BRUBECK JOINS LOUIS
description: WHEN the members of the Murray Louis Dance Company made their bounding entrances in Mr. Louis's ''Four Brubeck Pieces'' on Thursday night, on stage with them was the Dave Brubeck Quartet playing the accompanying score by Mr. Brubeck and Paul Desmond.

title: Jennifer Lerner Becomes Bride
description: Jennifer Lerner, a daughter of Alan Jay Lerner of New York and London, and Mrs. Alan W. Livingston of Beverly Hills, Calif., was married in Santa Monica, Calif., on April 12 to Carlyle Fraser 2d, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Richard M. Fraser of Weston, Mass. The Rev. Dr. Ernest D. Pipes Jr. performed the ceremony at the Unitarian Community Church.

title: APPEARANCE IS REALITY TOO
description: What manufactured goods look like is almost as important as what they do; that is the simplified argument of OBJECTS OF DESIRE. (Pantheon, $24.95), a book that looks at industrial design as the art of the 20th Century.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: ''LET THE EAGLE SOAR!'': The Foreign Policy of Andrew Jackson. By John M. Belohlavek. (University of Nebraska, $28.95.) Historians traditionally have given scant attention to Andrew Jackson's foreign policy despite Old Hickory's unambiguous contribution to this nation's emergence as a world power.

title: TOUR BOOKINGS TO CARIBBEAN RISE ALONG WITH AMERICANS' FEAR OF EUROPE
description: Richard Steck is an executive for the Royal Caribbean Cruise Line, which operates out of the sprawling port here on sparkling Biscayne Bay.

title: ROLE MODELS FOR TEEN-AGERS
description: Bravo for Dr. Robert Ricken's excellent article, ''Role Models, but Not Good Models,'' on the Opinion Page of March 9.

title: A 'Simple' Condo
description: The four-story brownstone at 108 Fifth Avenue started out as a private residence and then it became the home of the Athenaeum Club, a patrician watering hole for men of arts and letters. In its last days, just before it was demolished last fall, it was a shabby relic of its former elegance and it housed a Chinese takeout restaurant.

title: WHAT'S NEW WITH THE YELLOW PAGES
description: ''MY fingers have better things to do than to walk through two books,'' says a guitar-strumming B. B. King in radio ads for the yellow-page directory Southwestern Bell will introduce in Manhattan in November.

title: A U.S. ECONOMIST REPORTS ON HAITI
description: A prominent American economist was in Haiti last week on a Reagan Administration mission to recommend ways of rescuing the country's economy.

title: HER DESIRE WON'T LET GO
description: FAMILY RESEMBLANCES By Lowry Pei. 264 pp. New York: Random House. $16.95.

title: Elspeth Ritchie Marries R. H. Dale Jr.
description: Elspeth Cameron Ritchie, a fourth-year medical student at the George Washington University Medical School, and Richard Hawkins Dale Jr., a computer programmer at Blue Cross and Blue Shield of the Washington area, were married in Washington yesterday. The Rev. Vienna Anderson performed the ceremony at the National Cathedral.

title: CAPITALS ROUT RANGERS BY 8-1
description: It cannot be dramatic all the time.

title: Alice Anne Cohen Planning to Wed
description: Dr. and Mrs. Herbert George Cohen of New York and Danbury, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Alice Anne Cohen, to Dr. Albert Bruce Knapp, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Russell S. Knapp of New York and Ridgefield, Conn. A September wedding is planned.

title: Recent Sales
description: Englishtown $57,000 18 Station Street *2*1-bedroom, 1-bath, 50-year-old ranch; *2*attached garage, enclosed porch; taxes $600. Freehold $135,000 109 Wellington Road *2*3-bedroom, 2-bath, 13-year-old ranch; central *2*air-conditioning, fenced yard, new roof; taxes $2,093. Holland Township $114,900 Ellis Road *2*3-bedroom, 1-bath, 35-year-old ranch; large family *2*room, full basement, 2-car garage; taxes $610. Hopatcong $115,440 4 Temple Trail *2*3-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 15-year-old bilevel; *2*wall-to-wall carpeting, 2-car garage, family room; taxes $2,059. Madison $749,000 49 Midwood Terrace *2*7-bedroom, 6-bath, 75-year-old Tudor; stained-glass windows, *2*solarium, billiard room with wet bar; taxes $9,050. Princeton Junction $227,000 4 Columbia Place *2*4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 2-year-old town-house condominium; *2*central air-conditioning, fireplace, patio, $69 monthly maintenance; taxes $3,298. OTHER AREAS Ardsley, N.Y. $220,000 20 McKinley Place *2*3-bedroom, 2-bath, 47-year-old *2*Cape Cod; den, playroom, patio; taxes $3,513. Hamden, Conn. $116,000 60 Patterson Road *2*3-bedroom, 2 bath, 4-year-old raised ranch; *2*skylights, 2 fireplaces; taxes $2,148. Kings Park, L.I. $205,000 55 Twin Oaks Road *2*4-bedroom, 2-bath, 12-year-old ranch; finished basement, *2*central air-conditioning, screened porch, pool; taxes $5,100.

title: JOURNEY AMONG TYRANTS
description: I share Mr. Rosenthal's passionate belief that ''all people should be given the opportunity granted to Americans by accident of birth . . . - the right to live in freedom.'' And I share also his inability to comprehend how free Americans can collaborate with tyrannies, either of the right or the left.

title: Eastern Avoids A Pentagon Ban
description: Eastern Airlines, hit last month with a record-setting fine for having failed to abide by some Government safety regulations, has narrowly avoided another patch of turbulence in Washington.

title: FILIPINO-AMERICANS AIM TO REVITALIZE HOMELAND
description: Federico Macaranas, an economics professor at Manhattan College, said he would will be ''going home'' to the Philippines this month for the first time in 12 years to see how he and other Filipino-Americans could can help the new Government.

title: SPINKS WINNER IN SPLIT DECISION
description: Michael Spinks proved he is no fluke as a heavyweight champion.

title: He's Now Mr. April
description: The season is still young, but if Reggie Jackson keeps on the way he has started, Mr. October is going to need a personal statistician just to get through April. Playing in the 11th game of the season Friday night, against the Minnesota Twins in Anaheim, Calif., the Angels' designated hitter got three hits and moved up a notch in two sections of the record book.

title: DANCE: ROBERT KOVICH IN 'TARANTULA (PART II)
description: ROBERT KOVICH made an exotic entrance into the gallery at the New York Studio School, in its grubby way a rather exotic dance space, in ''Technicolor Tarantula (Part II)'' on Friday. The air crackled exotically,in fact, from the audience - composed of Merce Cunningham dancers and youngsters murmuring avidly in French - to the dancers and the dance.

title: Jody Brown Wed To Bank Analyst
description: Jody Lynne Brown, a facilities planner, and Fred Woods DeBussey, a bank analyst, were married yesterday at the Hyatt Regency Hotel in Baltimore. Cantor Mel Lutterman officiated.

title: A SPACE INVADER IN CHINA
description: I can't sleep. My mind's abuzz with the sound of bicycle bells - 1.2 billion of them. Partly I'm jet-lagging, but it's more than that: It's a question someone asked me a few hours ago when I got home from a month in the off-the-beaten province of Shandong, China - that peninsula sticking out like a hitchhiker's thumb through the Yellow Sea toward Korea. The question was whether I ever felt at home in China, and by it the questioner meant: Was there ever a moment when I felt my sensibility fused with the Chinese people, when we were brethren despite our astonishing barriers? Briiiing, briiiing!

title: AT FIRST, MERGED WITH MOTHER
description: COLLABORATORS By Janet Kauffman. 129 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $13.95.

title: A BRITISH HOME AWAY FROM HOME
description: WHAT OFTEN INTRIGUES AMERICANS about British homes is the way in which layer upon layer of furniture and objects, all accumulated for generations, seem to effortlessly produce glorious and terribly personal rooms. Interestingly, this same culling process is repeated even on the Government level. A highboy, say, that has been sitting in a just-vacant Government-owned London flat can find its way to another official property, whether it be on the Continent, in the United States, or elsewhere. Somehow, though, the end result is always accomplished with stunning grace.

title: IN THE WAKE OF THE ATTACK ON LIBYA...
description: President Reagan has chosen to personalize the current crisis with Libya by depicting Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi as an aberrant ''mad dog.'' But the Administration surely knows that Qaddafism - an irrational, violent hatred of the West and its values - goes far beyond Colonel Qaddafi. In itself, however, this is not enough to explain why America's friends and allies in the Arab world - the so-called ''Arab moderates'' - have not made more of an effort to put some distance between themselves and the Libyan dictator.

title: EXPERTS ASSERT RAID WILL STIFLE LIBYAN OPPOSITION TO QADDAFI
description: The American bombing of Libya is likely to stifle rather than fuel opposition to Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi, the Libyan leader, according to several Libyan exiles, Western and Arab political analysts and diplomats.

title: Woman Arrested With Bomb At Airport in Britain Is Freed
description: An Irishwoman arrested in connection with an attempt to blow up a crowded Israeli airliner was freed tonight after two days of questioning with no charges brought against her, the police said.

title: BLUE JAYS DOWN ROYALS, 6-5
description: Doyle Alexander scattered three hits over seven and one-third innings, and Lloyd Moseby drove in four runs with a two-run homer and a bases-loaded single today to lead the Blue Jays to a 6-5 victory over the Kansas City Royals.

title: Cleaning Up the Act in 100 Municipalities
description: LAST January, Governor Kean signed a bill establishing a State Planning Commission to guide the state's growth.

title: THE DANCE: MOVING SOUND CONCERT
description: MOVING SOUND CONCERT is a presenting organization dedicated to the proposal that live performances shared by solo dancers and musicians are peculiarly vibrant and immediate. But the dance it presented on Thursday at St. Mark's Church was, with few exceptions, surprisingly self-indulgent in view of the sophistication of the staging and production.

title: Data Bank: April 20, 1986
Make That Schweppes
description: The other day Briefing reported that a guest at a reception at the French Embassy was a bit taken aback when he asked for a Perrier and was given Canada Dry club soda instead. ''I wondered which embassy I was in,'' mused the fellow. Another guest at the same reception wandered into the Ambassador's family room, and there on the piano were autographed photographs of the British royal family. He found the concierge and asked, ''Which embassy am I in?''

title: PROSPECTS
description: Banking's Vanishing Act Windfall profits, reaped from plummeting interest rates, had many banks reporting large first-quarter earnings gains last week. But these figures mask serious problems in banking: Loan losses are at sky-high levels, even though the economy is in its fourth year of recovery. Energy and agricultural lenders have been especially hard-hit. The First City Bancorporation of Texas, for example, reported a $232 million loss for the quarter.

title: Books After Death
description: To the Editor:

title: MATTINGLY IS HAVING TROUBLE FINDING HIS LONG-BALL STROKE
description: He won the batting championship two years ago, then turned on the power last season and hit 35 home runs and led the world in runs batted in. This year Don Mattingly figured he would do something still different. ''They could hit me ninth,'' Mattingly suggested. ''I'll be a singles hitter and walk and get on base.''

title: IBSEN'S 'WILD DUCK,' ALIVE WITH THE MODERNIST SPIRIT
description: ''The Wild Duck'' is one of Ibsen's most introspective and self-critical plays, a work that assails the idealism that was the foundation of his previous art (including ''A Doll's House'' and ''An Enemy of the People''). A household is engulfed by moralistic fervor as Gregers Werle awakens his old friend Hjalmar Ekdal from his complacency - from what could be regarded as a lie of the mind. That lie, the illusionary vision that Hjalmar has of himself and of his marriage, is his sustenance. Without it, he is psychologically destitute. In Ibsen's altered attitude toward liberalism, Gregers, the meddling idealist, becomes the true enemy of the people. At the same time, the victim, Hjalmar, never could be considered a hero. The single tragic figure is Hjalmar's teen-age daughter, who keeps a maimed wild duck as a pet, a symbolic representation of her own and her family's fantasy life.

title: The Swiss Freeze Duvalier's Assets
description: Contrary to the widely held public notion, ill-gotten money deposited in Swiss banks has never been perfectly safe from prying foreign governments, and last month, Switzerland, saying that it ''does not protect criminals,'' froze the holdings of the former Philippine President, Ferdinand E. Marcos, his family and entourage.

title: Bradley and His Interest in Foreign Affairs
description: Senator Bill Bradley's office is busy these days sending out more than 7,000 three-page letters to constituents who called or wrote after Mr. Bradley switched his positions and voted for President Reagan's request to send $100 million in aid to the Nicaragua rebels.

title: RECENT RELEASES OF VIDEO CASSETTES
description: Anna Christie Starring Greta Garbo, Charles Bickford, George Marion, Marie Dressler, Lee Phelps; directed by Clarence Brown, 1930 MGM/UA Home Video 92 minutes. $39.95 One of the great screen entrances of all time: The magnificent Greta Garbo materializes out of the fog, walks through the ladies' entrance to Johnny-the-Priest's waterfront saloon and says in a husky voice that's still being heard round-the-world: ''Gimme a whisky.

title: JOURNEY AMONG TYRANTS
description: It is a relief to hear someone say so directly, ''I still find myself puzzled and pained'' and then do the work to figure out why.

title: FAREWELL DINNER TO HONOR YALE'S GIAMATTI
description: RICHARD C. LEE, Mayor of New Haven from 1953 to 1969, will miss the late evening telephone conversations he has had for many years with A. Bartlett Giamatti, the president of Yale University, who will be leaving the post in June.

title: FARM IMPORTS RISE AS EXPORTS PLUNGE
description: Global demand for United States farm products is dropping sharply, while Americans' taste for imported food is rising.

title: HIGHER RATES OF DISEASE TROUBLE WEST CAPE COD
