description: Two perplexing health problems that may be linked have caused concern in recent weeks among residents at the western end of Cape Cod.

title: 3,090 Fires Reported In Subway Cars in '85
description: Reports of subway car fires increased almost 50 percent last year, David L. Gunn, president of the Transit Authority, said Friday, but he attributed the increase to stricter reporting.

title: SUPREME COURT REJECTS RADIO COVERAGE OF BUDGET ARGUMENT
description: The Supreme Court has rejected a request to allow radio broadcasting of next Wednesday's oral arguments on the constitutionality of the new Federal budget-balancing law.

title: Duran Scores Knockout Over Suero in 2d Round
description: Roberto Duran, who held three world titles, took another step in his boxing comeback with a second consecutive second-round knockout, defeating Jorge Suero of the Dominican Republic in a middleweight fight.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: HAMMERTOWN TALES. By Hilary Masters. (Stuart Wright, Box 7527, Reynolda Station, Winston-Salem, N.C. 27109, $15.) This book of fine stories traces its lineage to Sherwood Anderson's ''Winesburg, Ohio'' and beyond to ''Spoon River Anthology,'' the one masterpiece among the many books written by Hilary Masters' father, Edgar Lee Masters.

title: Atheists Group's Head Resigns After 26 Years
description: The founder of the nation's leading atheist group, American Atheists, said today she would resign as its president because Americans no longer equated atheism with Communism.

title: DIRECTORIES THAT TALK
description: TRYING to find a locksmith, a jeweler, an optician - any kind of special store or service man - by wandering through the streets is a futile endeavor. Pay phones rarely sport yellow pages, and directory assistance operators are no help at all.

title: CONSUMER RATES
GLOVE FACILITY OPPOSED
description: RESIDENTS of the North Lawrence section of the Town of Hempstead are opposing a developer's request to rezone for commercial use a 7,500-square-foot parcel on Rockaway Turnpike. They say they are trying to protect their area, now zoned for residential use, against the kind of commercial development that the Village of Cedarhurst has allowed just across the street.

title: 4 Die at Rail Crossing
description: A motor home burst into flames when struck by a freight train at a crossing Saturday, killing 4 of the 10 people in the motor home and critically injuring 2 others, the authorities said. No one on the 109-car Southern Pacific train was injured in the crash.

title: Market Place; 'Connector' Issues Favored
description: SHARES of companies that make electronic and electrical connection devices were lackluster market performers in 1985. But thanks to prospects of an improved industry environment, several so-called connector stocks have sold lately at or near record prices.

title: Foster G. McGaw, 89; Sold Medical Supplies
description: Foster G. McGaw, founder of the American Hospital Supply Corporation and a philanthropist who gave away more than $100 million, died at Lake Forest Hospital Wednesday after a brief illness, the company announced. He was 89 years old.

title: Live From Washington, It's the U.S. Senate
description: To the Editor:

title: THE STAGE: 'VIENNA,' FROM MARTHA CLARKE
description: THE pre-World War I Vienna of ''Vienna: Lusthaus,'' the new theater piece conceived and directed by Martha Clarke, is the place where civilization had the nervous breakdown from which it has never recovered. In ''Vienna: Lusthaus,'' now at St. Clement's, Miss Clarke seeks to evoke that cataclysmic historical and cultural turning point in a mere 60 minutes of hallucinations sculpted with dance, words, music and light. She has succeeded beyond one's wildest dreams - perhaps because she has tapped into everyone's wildest dreams. As Vienna was where Freud intersected with Hitler, so the visions of ''Vienna: Lusthaus'' keep pulling us, with a delicacy so light as to be nearly subliminal, from sex to death.

title: GRUMBLING IN THE PHILIPPINES: CAN AQUINO GOVERN NATION?
description: As President Corazon C. Aquino approaches the end of her second month in power, the euphoria of her victory has faded, and many Filipinos have begun to question her ability to exercise power and to make her Government work.

title: The Salvation of Land-Based Missiles
description: How many warheads can dance on the head of a Midgetman missile?

title: U.S. RESEARCHERS FORESEE A BIG RISE IN NUCLEAR TESTS
description: The number of nuclear explosions needed to perfect new types of nuclear arms is rising dramatically, according to Government scientists in Los Alamos, N.M.

title: TOKYO TAKING ON HONG KONG
description: As Japan gradually eases the restrictions on its financial markets, Tokyo is posing an increasingly stiff challenge to Hong Kong's pre-eminence as a financial center.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: DEATH OF THE SOUL: From Descartes to the Computer. By William Barrett. 173 pages. Anchor Press and Doubleday. $16.95. WILLIAM BARRETT'S

title: SWISS WORRIED ABOUT FREEZE ON MARCOS ASSETS
description: The Swiss Government's controversial emergency order last month freezing the assets of Ferdinand Marcos, which sidestepped formal legal procedures, may lead to embarrassment if the Philippine Government continues its failure to file the formal request that had been anticipated, according to a number of Swiss bankers and Government officials.

title: Bridge: Expert Who Struck a Blow Against Culbertson Method
description: Almost 40 years ago, at a turning point in bridge history, the first blow was struck against Ely Culbertson's honor-trick method of valuation. The striker was Fred Karpin, who died earlier this month in Washington. He took the 4-3-2-1 point-count of Milton Work, with whom he had been associated, and added a distributional count based on long suits.

title: A BANKER'S ACQUISITION MARATHON
description: On the rare occasions when he is not arranging deals, Charles E. Rice, the 50-year-old chairman and chief executive of Barnett Banks of Florida, unwinds by running. But Mr. Rice is not content to take a jog around the park. He runs marathons.

title: Gain for Soviet Industry
description: Soviet industrial output was 6.7 percent higher in the first quarter of 1986 than in the corresponding period of last year, the Communist daily Pravda reported. It said that a 6.3 percent increase in labor productivity accounted for 94 percent of the improvement.

title: 'NO PLACE TO CALL HOME' ON CHANNEL 2
description: THE children are not to blame, but clearly they suffer. Some 11,000 children live in the city's 58 welfare hotels, caught in a system neither they, nor we, can understand. We see some of them in ''No Place to Call Home'' on Channel 2 at 10 o'clock tonight. It is an effective, and disturbing, program.

title: BARKLEY STARS AS 76ERS WIN
description: Charles Barkley scored 14 of his 27 points in the fourth quarter as the Philadelphia 76ers rallied today for a 102-97 victory over the Washington Bullets that evened their first-round National Basketball Association playoff series at one game apiece.

title: Carl S. Miller, a Chemist, 73; Built First Copying Machine
description: Carl S. Miller, the inventor of a duplicating process that made carbon paper almost obsolete and created the modern copying industry, died here Tuesday. He was 73 years old.

title: Katherine Blenko Wed To Joseph K. Belanoff
description: Katherine Ardis Blenko, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Don Balman Blenko of Haverford, Pa., was married yesterday to Joseph Kenneth Belanoff, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Sidney Belanoff of Mount Kisco, N.Y. Judge William W. Vogel of the Court of Common Pleas for Montgomery County, Pa., performed the ceremony at the Thomas Great Hall at Bryn Mawr College.

title: WEARY RANGERS COULD USE A LIFT
description: DON MALONEY will be the only Ranger in uniform tonight who can remember all the way back to the spring of 1979, when New York was gripped by Rangermania. ''Crazy,'' he recalls. ''I remember one night we were in a restaurant and 1,000 people tried to climb up to a window to take a look at us.''

title: Jill A. Tarlov a Bride
description: The wedding of Jill A. Tarlov and H. Michael Wittman took place yesterday at the Stonehenge Inn in Ridgefield, Conn. Lea Mintz, a justice of the peace, officiated. The bride, the daughter of Harriett Tarlov of Norwalk, Conn., and the late Malcolm Tarlov, is a media consultant for Network International, a nonprofit educational organization in New York. Mr. Wittman, the controller of WINS-AM radio in New York, is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Herbert Wittman of Pittsburgh.

title: Zoeller Sinks Birdie On 18th for Victory
description: Fuzzy Zoeller, rebounding after a shaky front nine, rolled in a 12-foot birdie putt at the 18th hole to break a four-way tie today and win the Heritage Classic for the second time in four years.

title: CUOMO ASKS FOR A LAW TO SET PAYMENTS FOR CHILD SUPPORT
description: New York courts would use state guidelines in setting child support payments under a bill proposed yesterday by Governor Cuomo.

title: EX-REAGAN AIDES' LOBBYING LEADS TO CALLS FOR NEW RULES
description: Congressional critics of lobbying by some former White House officials are considering new rules to limit lobbyists' activities.

title: Advertising; Time Inc.'s Real Estate Magazine
description: THE upstarts have had their turn.

title: YANKS TOP BREWERS TO END SLIDE
description: Whatever happens to Lou Piniella the rest of this season, whether he manages the Yankees the entire year or disappears somewhere along the way, he was assured today of having managed more victories than Yogi Berra did last year.

title: Mexicans Seek Japanese Loan
description: The Mexican Finance Minister, Jesus Silva Herzog, has started a four-day trip to Japan for talks expected to center on debt, oil and Japanese investment, the official Notimex news agency said today. Angel Gurria, Mexico's director of public credit and chief debt negotiator, is accompanying him.

title: EXPERTS STUDY THE HABITS OF GENUS BABY BOOMER
description: As the 1988 Presidential election draws ever closer, Lee Atwater, a Republican campaign consultant, is conducting political research in some unexpected places: Disney World, the downtown Washington YMCA and a Manhattan rock-and-roll nightclub blasting 60's music.

title: METS COMPLETE SWEEP OF PHILS
description: Sid Fernandez sat quietly amid the postgame clubhouse crush, his hands folded neatly in his lap, his uniform still on, his answers brief and barely audible. His pitching yesterday afternoon was more eloquent and more revealing.

title: MONDAY SPORTS
description: Baseball Yankees vs. Royals, at Kansas City, 8:35 P.M. The Yankees head home after the three-game series that begins tonight.

title: Dr. Brad Mitchell Wed To Lori M. Krichmar
description: Lori Merrill Krichmar, an instructor in nursing at the New York University Medical center, and Dr. Brad Mitchell, a dentist in Middletown, N.Y., were married yesterday. Rabbi Joel Zion performed the ceremony at Temple Israel in Lawrence, L.I.

title: GORBACHEV SAYS SUMMIT IS POSSIBLE IF U.S. SHIFTS LINE
description: Mikhail S. Gorbachev, the Soviet leader, held out the possibility today that a Soviet-American summit meeting might still be held this year if the Reagan Administration altered a foreign policy course that he said was poisoning the international atmosphere.

title: DEFINING A GENERATION OF WRITERS
description: LAST month, Scribners brought out ''20 Under 30,'' an anthology of stories by ''America's New Young Writers'' - that is, apparently, writers born no earlier than March 1956. The title and organizing principle, of course, are entirely arbitrary - picked more for neatness than anything else. After all, one hardly defines a generation by lopping it off at some nice round integer or setting up birthdate qualifications as though one were taking a census poll or running an amateur tennis tournament. Does the fact that Philip Roth (1933) is a decade younger than Norman Mailer (1923) mean that they should not be regarded as contemporaries? Should Roth and John Updike (1932), then, be placed in a separate category from Mailer and William Styron (1925) and they, in turn, in a separate one from Saul Bellow (1915), J. D. Salinger (1919) and the late Bernard Malamud (1914)?

title: 12 Cities Seeking 1992 Olympics
description: A tap-dancing moose from Anchorage stole the show today as the 12 cities vying for the 1992 Olympics unveiled colorful exhibits that they hope will sway the vote of the International Olympic Committee.

title: THE AMERICAN WOMAN'S LIBERATION: IS IT A MYTH?
description: In 1939, American women earned 63 cents for every dollar earned by men. Forty-seven years later, after a world war, a sexual revolution and the emergence of the most radical and vocal feminist movement in the world, American women earn 64 cents for every dollar.

title: IN LENIN'S HOMETOWN: NOW IT'S BACK TO GASLIGHTS
description: ''Lenin lived, lives and will live,'' reads the neon sign atop a building at the foot of Goncharov Street, the main boulevard.

title: Advertising; Racz & Dessimoz Gets Pressman Toy Account
description: Racz & Dessimoz Advertising, which fashions itself expert in special interest advertising and last week announced winning the Viking Yacht Company account, now has become the creative-only agency for Pressman Toy, specialists in games.

title: Two Officials Critical Of Board of Estimate
description: Two public officials said yesterday that the Board of Estimate's structure allows opportunities for corruption to develop and that it gives the appearance that its members may be involved in conflicts of interest.

title: THE HORMEL STRIKE: A UNION DIVIDED
description: An important labor struggle, one of the most publicized in the nation, grinds on as another season begins in this stark prairie city, the cold grudgingly letting go, trees showing tips of green, ducks bobbing on the Cedar River.

title: Dr. Abby S. Van Voorhees Married in Connecticut
description: Dr. Abby Susan Van Voorhees, a resident in dermatology, and Dr. Jeffrey Allan Chodakewitz, a fellow in infectious diseases, both at the Yale University School of Medicine, were married yesterday at Congregation B'nai Jacob in Woodbridge, Conn. Rabbis Stuart Geller and Michael Menitoff performed the ceremony.

title: Barbara Leyden Wed To Dr. Adam J. Rowen
description: Barbara L. Leyden and Dr. Adam J. Rowen were married yesterday at the Plaza Hotel in Manhattan by Rabbi Pinchas Teitz and Rabbi Elazar Teitz. The bride is a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas F. Leyden of Spring Hill, Fla., and her husband is the son of Dr. and Mrs. Manuel J. Rowen of Elizabeth, N.J.

title: A MOUNTAIN OF MUD, A SHORTAGE OF SYRUP
description: Virginia Garrison's first mistake was to try to pass a neighbor's car stuck in the mud on the dirt road leading to her home in Moretown, Vt.

title: Earnhardt Winner In Stock-Car Race
description: Dale Earnhardt came out of the pits with 45 laps to go and held off a challenge by Ricky Rudd to win the First Union 400 Nascar stock car race today at North Wilkesboro Speedway.

title: RANGERS IMPRESS CAPITALS
description: The 4-3 Ranger victory in overtime that started the Patrick Division final Thursday night against Washington was not wasted on the Capitals. After losing, Washington remarked approvingly on the Ranger strategy that had not been in evidence during the regular season.

title: FOSTER SITS AND WATCHES
description: For two days, George Foster spent his mornings in the batting cage and his afternoons on the bench. While he sat, he thought. And he has begun to accept the realization that one day -although nothing has been revealed by Dave Johnson, the Met manager -he may wind up as part of a platoon in left field.

title: Equal Treatment for Refugees Is the Law
description: To the Editor:

title: MANES WAS TO MEET WITH THE F.B.I., SANTUCCI SAYS
description: An apparent suicide attempt by Donald R. Manes in January came just hours before he was to meet with F.B.I. agents investigating municipal corruption, the Queens District Attorney, John J. Santucci, said yesterday.

title: Charges Are Dropped In Oregon Guru Case
description: Federal charges of harboring a fugitive that were pending against six followers of the guru Bhagwan Shree Rajneesh have been dismissed at the request of prosecutors.

title: Airline Business as Usual
description: The Russians may have canceled the May date they had to plan for a meeting between President Reagan and Mikhail S. Gorbachev, but they have not gotten so angry over the bombing of Libya that they are dropping a junket to the United States next week for tourism and transportation officials. This visit is planned in conjunction with the resumption of direct air service between the United States and the Soviet Union.

title: JORDAN SCORES 63 IN LOSS
description: Michael Jordan came, he scored but he did not conquer.

title: FOR HOROWITZ IN MOSCOW, BRAVOS AND TEARS
description: Vladimir Horowitz returned to the Soviet musical stage today, giving a recital that dazzled the audience and left many in tears.

title: OILERS WIN IN OVERTIME
description: Glenn Anderson scored his second goal of the game 64 seconds into overtime tonight to lift the Edmonton Oilers to a 6-5 comeback victory over the Calgary Flames and even their second-round playoff series at a game each.

title: BALLET: 'MOLLINO' IN CAPITAL
description: ''The Mollino Room,'' a new ballet by the imaginative modern-dance choreographer Karole Armitage, is a high-powered collaboration: it stars Mikhail Baryshnikov and has overwhelmingly visible decor by a current and controversial painter, David Salle.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: FROM LITTLE ACORNS The Chelsea Theater Center lives. Founded in 1965, the center oversaw more than 150 productions that won many awards, including five Tony Awards. After its beginning in St. Peter's Church on West 20th Street, the center moved to the Church of Holy Apostles. It operated out of the Brooklyn Academy of Music for nine years, simultaneously producing in a West 43d Street converted church. The new venue is St. Mary's Church at 145 West 46th Street, between Sixth and Seventh Avenues.

title: Leaflets on Airwaves
description: A senior White House official, acknowledging that the Voice of America aimed a strongly anti-Qaddafi ''editorial'' at Libya at the time of the air raids, reports the broadcast was a substitute for more conventional efforts to undermine their target. ''Often when you're trying to explain to a nation what you're doing,'' he said, ''you drop leaflets. This time there was no time to drop leaflets.''

title: I.T.C. Ruling on Brass
description: The United States International Trade Commission ruled provisionally Friday that imports of brass sheet and strip from seven countries were in danger of damaging domestic manufacturers.

title: GAME SUSPENDED
description: Keith Moreland hit a two-run, two-out, homer in the bottom of the ninth to lift the Chicago Cubs into an 8-8 tie against the Pitts-burgh Pirates in a game that was sus-pended after 13 innings because of darkness at Wrigley Field. The game will be resumed Aug. 11.

title: 'Don't Stop,' But He Did
description: THREE hours later, in the frustration of his farewell address, Larry Holmes talked quietly but firmly about how the judges had ''lying eyes'' in awarding Michael Spinks a split 15-round decision. But the moment of truth for the 36-year-old ex-champion had occurred during the 14th round of their International Boxing Federation heavyweight title bout. Suddenly he stunned his 29-year-old successor with a right hand. In other years, Holmes would have pounced on a dazed foe, trying for a knockout. But strangely, Holmes stood there watching Spinks stroll to the other side of the ring. By then, Spinks's cobwebs had cleared.

title: U.S. WARNS NEW YORK ON DRINKING-AGE LAW
description: A Federal agency has warned Governor Cuomo that New York State could lose up to $66 million a year in Federal highway aid because the state's new minimum drinking-age law does not prohibit the possession of alcoholic beverages by people under 21 years old.

title: 7 TO SHARE $10 MILLION FROM LOTTO
description: Calling itself ''The Magnificent Seven,'' a family from the Bronx last night claimed to hold one of the two winning New York State Lotto tickets that will split a $20 million prize.

title: KOCH SAYS HE IS NOT UPSET OVER CONTRIBUTIONS INQUIRY
description: Mayor Koch said yesterday that he was not disturbed that the city's Department of Investigation was examining his campaign contribution records as part of its investigation into the Taxi and Limousine Commission.

title: LIBYA COMMANDO BASE AND A SCHOOL WERE HIT
description: American warplanes hit a Libyan Navy commando training center near here during their raid early Tuesday and badly damaged an adjacent high school for cadet seamen, according to evidence collected in a visit to the school.

title: FROM O'ROURKE THE CANDIDATE, A NOVEL OF HIGH-SEAS INTRIGUE
description: Yes, the novel's plot is a bit melodramatic. And, yes, the writing is sometimes strained. (''I want more out of life than dancing 'Swan Lake,' '' says one of the book's main characters, a Russian ballet star.) But this is not just any first novel. This is the work of a man who would be Governor - Andrew P. O'Rourke, the Westchester County Executive, who is almost certain to be the Republican challenger to Governor Cuomo in November. And surely somewhere in the 209 pages of the book, ''The Red Banner Mutiny,'' published this month as a paperback, there are insights into the personality and idiosyncracies of its author. Personal Involvement Denied

title: SPORTS UNITS CRITICIZE APARTHEID JOHANNESBURG, April 20 (Reuters) -
description: South Africa's two major sports agencies called today for an end to the country's apartheid policies as the Dutch Reformed Church made a new attempt to gain peace between blacks and whites.

title: EXPERT IN TREATING DRUG ADDICTS
description: Dr. Marie Nyswander, a psychiatrist who helped develop the use of methadone to treat heroin addiction, died of cancer in her home in Manhattan yesterday. She was 67 years old.

title: Washington Watch; Farm Belt Bank Rescue
description: Another lifeline has been found to rescue troubled Farm Belt banks in danger of being shut down by regulators, one that has just saved the Talmage State Bank of Talmage, Kan. Talmage was about to go under last week when the tiny, $9.6 million bank grabbed hold of an obscure provision of the Federal Deposit Insurance Act to get a $1.7 million loan from the Government to keep it going for several years until the farm economy can rebound.

title: Washington Watch; Briefcases
description: * The Federal Trade Commission is reviewing its ''negative option'' rule that specifies terms under which mail-order houses, book clubs and others may send merchandise to consumers - and expect them to pay for it - unless specifically instructed that an item is unwanted.

title: SEKO AND WAITZ WINNERS IN LONDON
description: Toshihiko Seko of Japan proved he was on the comeback trail by winning the sixth London Marathon today, while Grete Waitz of Norway ran her fastest time ever to win the women's race.

title: Advertising; A Campaign to Fight Drinking by Children
description: On Friday in San Francisco, N. W. Ayer and the National Council on Alcoholism introduced a new Advertising Council campaign demanded by a horror of our times: drinking by pre-teen children.

title: Gypsum Backs Managers' Bid
description: The National Gypsum Company, a Dallas-based maker of building products, said yesterday that its board had approved the latest leveraged buyout offer from a group of investors headed by its senior management.

title: Florida Bank Closed
description: Florida banking regulators Friday closed the Florida Center Bank in Orlando, the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation said.

title: DU PONT TO DEFEND KEVLAR USE
description: E. I. du Pont de Nemours & Company has been selling its ''miracle'' Kevlar fiber for 15 years to manufacturers of everything from tires to army helmets. But a Federal judge in Virginia this week is being asked to decide whether the Delaware chemical giant has been doing so in violation of another company's patent.

title: 'AMERICAN ALMANAC' PLANNED FOR FALL
description: After more than a year of false starts, NBC has decided to put a reshaped, retitled version of the prime-time news program ''American Almanac'' on its fall schedule, according to network executives.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: Washington Watch; Successor to Fed's Martin
description: Insiders say the search for a successor to Preston Martin, the Federal Reserve vice chairman who leaves office next week, is at an advanced stage with the White House now scrutinizing a ''short list'' of perhaps half a dozen candidates.

title: Reasons for Doubt
description: The attack on Libya has left the United States and its European allies profoundly divided: a gulf not only of policy but of perception. Americans tend to react in anger to the doubting Europeans. We would do better to try to understand the reasons for doubt.

title: DANCE: 'DOWNSTAIRS,' FESTIVAL PIECES
description: BECAUSE the Horace Mann Theater is in a basement at 120th Street and Broadway, it was appropriate that the program presented there Saturday night was called ''Dance Downstairs.'' Consisting of works by students at, or recent graduates of, Teachers College of Columbia University, it was an attraction in the college's Morningside Dance Festival. Yet only rarely did the offerings appear worthy of being transferred from a studio to a public performance on a stage.

title: Dahar Captures Capistrano Race
description: Dahar, the favorite, rallied late in the stretch to overhaul the English-bred mare Mountain Bear today and capture the $400,000 San Juan Capistrano Invitational Handicap at Santa Anita.

title: A 'Living' Memorial To Honor an Astronaut
description: Dr. Marvin Resnik's weekend began and ended at home in Akron, Ohio. But on Saturday night, he attended a reception on East End Avenue to help raise money for a memorial honoring his daughter, the astronaut Judith A. Resnik.

title: FOLK: JEAN REDPATH, SINGER
description: ''SCOTTISH songs are a brew of pure flavor and pure emotion - so distilled that it is hard to take after two spoonfuls,'' reflected Jean Redpath, the definitive Scottish folk singer, at her Town Hall concert Friday evening.

title: CONCERT: SPECTRUM, ENGLISH NEW-MUSIC GROUP
description: LIKE all good guests, Spectrum, the English new-music group, made appropriate gestures toward its hosts Saturday night but also brought gifts of its own. Thus, the poorly attended concert by this excellent British ensemble at the Cathedral of St. John the Divine included American pieces by Elliott Carter, Michael Gordon and James Sellars, two by English composers -Anthony Payne and John Marlow Rhys - and finally ''Ikhoor,'' the string trio by Iannis Xenakis.

title: Student Held in Cat Killings
description: A Windham High School student has been arrested as part of an investigation of the killings of cats in town, the police here said Saturday.

title: LIBYA FREES CATHOLIC BISHOP
description: Libya has freed the head of the country's Roman Catholic Church, church sources said today.

title: Make Foreign Flights More Familiar
description: The British Government says American air carriers hold an unfair advantage in trans-Atlantic service. It wants to guarantee British carriers a minimum share of the market. The complaint is just, but the proposed remedy is not. America could serve its own interests as well as Britain's by giving British carriers greater freedom to compete, rather than by hobbling American carriers. Indeed, allowing British airlines to offer some point-to-point service in this country could encourage a free world market in air travel.

title: All-Male 'As You Like It'
description: Keith McDermott, who starred on Broadway in ''Equus,'' is performing in Shakespeare's ''As You Like It'' at Washington Square United Methodist Church, 135 West Fourth Street, on Thursday and Friday at 8 P.M. and next Sunday at 3 and 7 P.M. Directed by Charles Barber, the production has an all-male cast in the tradition of the play's original production and of the National Theater of Great Britain's 1967 production. Tickets are $6; Theater Development Fund vouchers accepted. Reservations: 279-4200.

title: Vatican Still Stereotypes Liberation Theology
description: To the Editor:

title: FREE TRADE: DOUBTS GROW IN CANADA
description: In the wake of stiff opposition from the United States Senate Finance Committee to beginning free-trade talks with Canada, there is mounting evidence in Canada that the idea may be losing some of its early popular appeal even as Ottawa steps up efforts to get things moving.

title: Waldheim's Secret Life
description: ''What I am accused of are lies,'' says Kurt Waldheim.

title: Lisa Feder Wed To Charles Feitel
description: Lisa Simeon Feder and Charles Daniel Feitel were married yesterday at the home of her parents, Mr. and Mrs. Elliot Feder, in Manhattan. Rabbi Barry Green performed the ceremony.

title: 300 Peace Marchers Cross Into Arizona
description: The Great Peace March for Nuclear Disarmament entered Arizona today to begin a 14.5-mile walk through the state as part of a 13-state, 3,200-mile journey to the nation's capital. About 300 members of the group, which left Los Angeles March 1 with a contingent of more than 1,200, headed for a campsite on Bureau of Land Management land near Littlefield in the northwest corner of Arizona.

title: Dr. Geraldine Summa Weds Robert E. Farina
description: Dr. Geraldine M. Summa, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Vito Summa of Eastchester, N.Y., was married yesterday to Robert E. Farina, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Patrick L. Farina of Bridgewater, N.J. The Rev. Christopher H. Daly, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony at the Butler Memorial Chapel of the Marymount Convent in Tarrytown, N.Y.

title: CENTRIST LEADS VOTE RETURNS AS SUDAN SEEKS CIVILIAN RULE
description: The Umma Party, a centrist political party whose leader has the approval of both Libya and the United States, has won a plurality of Assembly seats in the Sudan's first multiparty elections in 18 years and is now struggling to pull together an effective civilian government, local politicians said today.

title: HILLY BOSTON COURSE A PLUS FOR DE CASTELLA
description: SINCE 1979, Rob de Castella has been one of the world's best marathon runners. He was ranked first in the world in 1983, when he won the world championship. He has won six of his 12 career marathons and has never finished worse than 10th. He has run three marathons faster than 2 hours 9 minutes, a feat only Steve Jones has matched. He has the speed to run fast races on the track, as he did eight weeks ago in his native Australia, and superb strength built by running Australian hills.

title: Time to Halt the Las Vegasing of Atlantic City
description: To the Editor:

title: MUSIC: CONLON NANCARROW
description: NEW YORK welcomed the composer Conlon Nancarrow back to America after a 40-year absence with a packed house and a standing ovation at Alice Tully Hall.

title: 'SILENT SPRING' LED TO SAFER PESTICIDES, BUT USE IS UP
description: At the beginning of her landmark book, ''The Silent Spring,'' Rachel Carson quoted these lines from John Keats:

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: MONDAY, APRIL 21, 1986
description: International

title: A JAILBREAK BY A ROGUE JOLTS INDIA
description: He escaped dramatically from a maximum-security prison last month after drugging his guards with a spiked birthday cake. Three weeks later, he was captured in a bar in Goa by policemen posing as waiters.

title: Economic Calendar
description: Listed below are the target release dates for major economic indicators scheduled to be released this week. Monday

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Centrust Savings Bank, Miami, named Thomas G. O'Brien 3d executive vice president, secretary and general counsel.

title: Susan R. Kneller Wed in Virginia
description: Susan Ruth Kneller, a lawyer, and Alan Leonard Madian, an economist, were married yesterday at Selma, a private residence in Leesburg, Va., by Rabbi Roger Herst.

title: A Country-Like Parish Surrounded by Change
description: St. Stephen's Methodist Episcopal Church was built in 1897 on Terrace View Avenue on Manhattan Island. Not having moved an inch, it stands today at 144 West 228th Street in the Bronx.

title: CALIFORNIA AGENCIES BEGIN TO FEEL TAX REVOLT
description: Schools and government agencies in California face drastic new limits on spending, in a delayed reaction to tax referendums passed in the 1970's.

title: FOR SPINKS, TACTICS UNDERGO CHANGE, BUT RESULT IS SAME
description: From the moment he stepped into the ring Saturday night, the former heavyweight champion Larry Holmes appeared ''psyched'' for his International Boxing Federation heavyweight title rematch with the champion Michael Spinks.

title: BUSINESS TRIPS GO ON, BUT WITH MORE CAUTION
description: Business travelers say they are still making their trips and keeping their commitments in foreign countries, although many say they have become more cautious and afraid.

title: Tax-Exempt Offerings on the Rise
description: The supply of new tax-exempt bonds is increasing, and helping to raise yields on state and local government issues to record high levels in comparison to Treasury bonds. Although sales of new tax-exempt issues is below the record-setting pace of 1985, new issuing activity this month is averaging more than $2 billion per week.

title: Weeklong Film Festival To Show Nordic Works
description: Recent feature films from Sweden, Norway, Finland, Iceland and Denmark will be shown here for the first time during a weeklong festival beginning April 28 at the Eastside Cinema, Third Avenue and 55th Street.

title: New York City Needs Zoning for the Year 2000
description: To the Editor:

title: Limits of Ethics Laws
description: To the Editor:

title: GOVERNOR REVIEWS TORNADOES' TOLL
description: Damage from a pair of tornadoes that slashed through homes here Saturday, killing one person and injuring 100, was estimated today at up to $20 million, and Gov. Mark W. White Jr. toured the city to see what state aid was needed.

title: Long Distance
description: The news that college basketball has instituted a 3-point field goal for next season must have brought a big ho-hum to those familiar with the experience in the National Basketball Association.

title: M. R. Lange Wed To Ellen Metzger
description: Ellen Metzger and Marvin Robert Lange, both lawyers, were married yesterday at the Stouffer Westchester Hotel in White Plains by Rabbi Lawrence Pinsker.

title: SOME GRASPABLE COMPARISONS OF MIND-BENDERS LIKE DEFICITS
description: Just how big is the much-discussed Federal deficit? Is every Government agency spending more than it can afford? How dependent are state and local governments on Washington?

title: TRADE DISPUTE TESTS DIPLOMAT
description: Willy de Clercq, external relations commissioner of the Common Market, surprised a group of reporters recently when he described American trade policy as ''Rambo-like diplomacy.''

title: CORRECTION
description: The front-page article on Friday about the Pulitzer Prizes gave an incomplete performance history for Robert Wilson's ''Civil WarS: A Tree Is Best Measured When It Is Down.'' A two-and-a-half-hour section of the play was produced in March 1985 at the American Repertory Theater in Cambridge, Mass.; it prompted the Pulitzer jury's unanimous recommendation of the work for this year's drama prize.

title: Cash Deal For Eckerd
description: The Jack Eckerd Corporation said Friday that Merrill Lynch Capital Partners Inc. and a management group exercised their option to pay $33 a share in cash for each of the company's outstanding shares. Previously, the group had said it would pay $28 a share in cash and $5 market value of a discount subordinated debenture.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''He was fantastic, as if from another world.'' - Aleksei Bataschev, a Soviet music expert, on Moscow concert by Vladimir Horowitz. [ A1:2. ]

title: NASA Is Investigating Rockets on 2d Shuttle
description: Engineers worked to disassemble a space shuttle booster rocket today to look for anything unusual that might shed light on whether assembly problems played a role in the Challenger disaster.

title: 13% OF U.S. ADULTS ARE ILLITERATE IN ENGLISH, A FEDERAL STUDY FINDS
description: Thirteen percent of the adults living in the United States are illiterate in English, a study by the Census Bureau has found.

title: Chinese Leader to Slow Free-Market Techniques
description: Deng Xiaoping has announced that he would slow the pace of his market-oriented changes and scale back China's goal of catching up with advanced industrial nations by 2050, the Communist Party newspaper reported today.

title: Louganis Keeps U.S. Diving Title
description: Greg Louganis overcame the challenge of Mike Wantuck to successfully defend his national platform diving championship today in the United States Diving Indoor Championships and then presented his gold medal to Ryan White, a 14-year-old victim of AIDS, the acquired immune deficience syndrome.

title: HOT STATE SENATE RACE NEARS END IN THE BRONX
description: Stanley M. Friedman, the indicted Bronx Democratic leader, has become a major issue in a special State Senate election tomorrow, with one candidate attacking him, another defending him and a third trying to ignore him.

title: Bank of Japan Buys Dollars
description: The Bank of Japan intervened in the foreign exchange market this morning and bought dollars when the American currency fell below 173 yen, dealers said.

title: Radio and TV Units Attract a Publisher
description: Eleven years ago, when he was in his early 30's, Peter J. Callahan had to fight to save his job when the company he was working for, MacFadden/Bartel Inc., was considering a takeover proposal.

title: 1,000 Protestants Riot In Northern Ireland
description: About 1,000 Protestant youths rampaged through a provincial Ulster town, attacked the police and stoned property early today, the authorities said.

title: Thai Tin Mining Stops
description: Thailand's two biggest tin mining companies, Aokam Thai Ltd. and Tongkah Harbor Ltd., have suspended operations indefinitely because of depressed world tin prices, labor leaders said. About 435 workers and managers will be left unemployed as a result of the decision by the two affiliated companies, said the union leaders, who plan to petition the Government for a reversal of the decision.

title: CORRECTION
description: A front-page diagram of the space shuttle Challenger on Tuesday mislocated the hole that burned through the right booster rocket. The point labeled 180 degrees should have been labeled 0 degrees. Thus the hole should have been shown on the side of the booster opposite the orbiter rather than near it.

title: U.S. TEAM SUFFERS FOURTH DEFEAT
description: Brent Sutter scored two goals and set up another to help Team Canada to a 4-2 victory over the United States today in the World hockey championships.

title: Why Derail Trade With Canada?
description: ''We had a train wreck this morning,'' explained an unhappy Senator Moynihan. He was referring to the Senate Finance Committee's recent informal decision to oppose trade negotiations with Canada, subsequently confirmed in a letter to President Reagan. Mr. Moynihan is right to be unhappy. The committee's position collides with decent diplomacy and economic sense.

title: OPEC STILL DIVIDED ON OIL CURBS
description: Ministers of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries muddled through a sixth day of talks today, but remained at odds over proposals for new production ceilings to stop the oil price slide.

title: 34 WESTERNERS, FEARING FURTHER RETALIATION FOR LIBYA RAIDS, EVACUATE WEST BEIRUT
description: Thirty-two Britons, an American and an Irishman were evacuated from Moslem West Beirut to the relative safety of Christian East Beirut today amid fears of further retaliation against foreigners over last week's American raid on Libya.

title: Dr. Feit Is Wed To a Psychiatrist
description: Dr. Sheila Feit, an endocrinologist, was married yesterday to Dr. Mort Rubinstein, a psychiatrist, at the Brotherhood Synagogue in New York by Rabbis David Kahane and Irving Block.

title: NEW CITY FOR LEFRAK: JERSEY
description: Nobody has built more apartments in New York City than the LeFrak family, whose holdings numbered more than 50,000 at latest count. But after the current patriarch of the clan, Samuel J. LeFrak, finishes a building under construction on the Upper West Side, he is not going to undertake any more -not on the New York side of the Hudson River at least.

title: Question Box
description: QUESTION: Has a gelding ever won the Kentucky Derby?

title: GIANT STEP FOR BOSTON
description: THE sound of the gun that starts the 90th running of the Boston Marathon today will also signal a new era for the race itself. For the first time, the top finishers will receive prize money.

title: INDIANIAN STUDIES CONRAIL PLAN
description: When President Reagan takes head counts of supporters in the House, he almost always finds Representative Daniel R. Coats among his backers. It has been that way since the 42-year-old conservative Republican was elected to Congress in 1980 in the first Reagan landslide.

title: South to Lead in U.S. Growth
description: More than half of the nation's population growth through the year 2000 will be in just five states, California, Florida, Texas, Arizona and Massachusetts, according to a study by a private research group.

title: Fed-Watching Still Popular
description: No sooner had the Federal Reserve reduced the discount rate late Friday than credit market participants began debating whether the Fed might make another move toward an easier monetary policy and lower short-term interest rates.

title: RANGERS GIVEN DAY OFF
description: The whole thing has been a blur, with the Rangers roaring through these past two weeks, shocking one team after another and suddenly making this city hockey-conscious again. They have been busy, busy, busy, sort of like a businessman who leaves his house early in the morning, runs around all day, finally gets back to his doorstep around midnight, tells himself he's exhausted and, with that, collapses.

title: Georgians on Hustings
description: The contest for the Democratic Senate nomination in Georgia is heating up. A few weeks ago Hamilton Jordan, the former White House chief of staff, held a Washington fund-raising event to tap some of his confederates in the Carter Administration.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: MONDAY, APRIL 21, 1986
description: International

title: AT A BURIAL OF AFRICAN, BITTERNESS
description: They buried King Sabata Dalindyebo here today under a jacaranda tree.

title: TOKYO POLICE SET TO DEFEND SUMMIT
description: Across a wind-skimmed courtyard the other day, police officers fought police officers near the front steps of a baroque state guesthouse modeled after the Palace of Versailles.

title: REGAN AIDES DRAFT BILL TO PRE-EMPT STATES' PRODUCT-LIABILITY LAWS
description: The Reagan Administration has drafted a bill that would pre-empt state laws and make it more difficult for many consumers to win damages for injuries in product liability lawsuits.

title: AQUINO SAYS SHE WILL SOON CALL FOR A FORMAL TRUCE WITH REBELS
description: President Corazon C. Aquino announced today that she would soon call for a formal cease-fire with Communist rebels. She said the cease-fire would last for a ''definite and inextendable period'' during which ''a just resolution'' of the insurgency problem might be found.

title: USING MEDIATORS TO RESOLVE FAMILY DISPUTES
description: The role of the professional family mediator, once confined to divorce and child custody disputes, has expanded in recent years to cover other questions, large and small, that divide families: Should an elderly relative be placed in a nursing home? Should a child attend a public or private school? What happens when three siblings inherit one piece of property? How do parents handle a rebellious teen-ager? Is it time to redecorate the living room?

title: UNSETTLED LIVES: GROWING UP IN CITY FOSTER CARE
description: Most of their years have been spent on the move, being shuffled in and out of temporary homes and psychiatric hospitals, falling behind in school, and eventually ending up on park benches, in subways or shelters for the homeless.

title: Advertising; Lowe Wins Ponderosa
description: Ponderosa Steak Houses of Dayton, Ohio, has switched its $21 million account to Lowe Marschalk, which will serve it from both its New York and Cleveland offices.

title: CORRECTION
description: A report by The Associated Press in Business Day on Friday about telephone company earnings misstated the timing of a special gain at the Southwestern Bell Corporation. It was in the first quarter of last year.

title: ARTIS, CO-DEFENDANT WITH RUBIN CARTER, HELD ON DRUG CHARGE
description: John Artis, the co-defendant with the boxer Rubin (Hurricane) Carter in one of New Jersey's most protracted murder cases, has been charged with conspiring in a cocaine ring with 10 other suspects, the Passaic County Prosecutor's Office said yesterday.

title: Nuclear Plant Delays
description: The Texas Utilities Company said its present schedule for commercial operation of the two-unit Comanche Peak nuclear plant is no longer achievable.

title: Bates Student, 20, Acquitted In Shooting of Dean Last Fall
description: A Superior Court jury has found a suspended Bates College student not guilty of attempted murder in last year's shooting of the college's dean.

title: Dance School Lectures
description: Frank Hodsoll, chairman of the National Endowment for the Arts, and Antony Tudor, the choreographer, will speak at the Martha Graham School of Contemporary Dance, 316 East 63d Street. Mr. Hodsoll will speak on Thursday and Mr. Tudor on May 8.

title: Catching Up
description: * Raymond Smith, the 465-pound tackle from H. D. Woodson High School in Washington, has decided to attend Tennessee State, a I-AA school in football, if his S.A.T. scores meet the N.C.A.A. minimum. If not, according to his coach, Bob Headen, he plans to attend Virginia State, a Division II school, where there is no such minimum.

title: Lalique Windows Are Going But Just for Restoration
description: Some day soon, work crews are to begin removing the expansive Lalique windows from the old Coty Building at 714 Fifth Avenue.

title: MUSIC: JOHN WILLIAMS IN SOLO GUITAR RECITAL
description: IT was hard to know exactly what to make of the recital that John Williams performed last night at Avery Fisher Hall. Not that the British classic guitarist is an unknown or the technical quality of his playing suspect in any way. Ever since his debut nearly 30 years ago Mr. Williams has been acknowledged as one of the instrument's elite. In fact, from the beginning he was spoken of as a leading candidate to inherit the mantle of Andres Segovia if the legendary Spanish guitarist were ever to retire.

title: QUESTIONS FAILED TO HALT RISE OF SCANDAL FIGURE
description: Twice in Alex Liberman's long career in city government, investigators found that he had engaged in improper or questionable dealings with business executives. Once, they publicly recommended that charges be filed against him.

title: Mount St. Helens Spews Plume of Fine Ash
description: Mount St. Helens emitted a small amount of gas and ash today in the latest episode of what geologists consider to be normal activity for the volcano.

title: EXPERTS SAY ATTACK ON LIBYA WILL DO MAJOR DAMAGE TO U.S. IN ARAB WORLD
description: The United States bombing raids on Libya will significantly damage American interests in the Arab world, several well-known experts on the region contend, but the Reagan Administration says that the raids will have little such effect.

title: Tuning In
description: Scrambling may have cost them some of their free movies, but the 1.5 million Americans with home satellite dishes have been assured at least one more season of baseball nirvana.

title: Cows, Not Contras
description: To the Editor:

title: TASSO PULLED OUT OF KENTUCKY DERBY
description: For the seventh year in a row, the champion 2-year-old will not win the Kentucky Derby. Tasso, the early winter-book favorite for the May 3 Derby, today was declared out of the race because of superficial cuts suffered during the Wood Memorial at Aqueduct Saturday.

title: Advertising; N.A.B. Election
description: In San Francisco, the board of the Newspaper Advertising Bureau elected a new slate of officers. Frank A. Daniels Jr., president and publisher of The Raleigh News & Observer and Times, became chairman; Bob Marbut, president and chief executive of Harte-Hanks Communications, vice chairman, and James Hoge, publisher of The New York Daily News, secretary and assistant treasurer. Richard E. Diamond, publisher of The Staten Island Advance, was re-elected treasurer.

title: Castro Criticizes Reagan As He Marks Bay of Pigs
description: Fidel Castro marked the 25th anniversary of Cuba's Bay of Pigs victory with an attack this weekend on President Reagan and a pledge to fight laziness and corruption in Cuban society.

title: RISKS WERE SPELLED OUT, SHUTTLE 'SURVIVOR' SAYS
description: Christa McAuliffe climbed aboard the space shuttle Challenger well informed of the risk she was taking as the first private citizen to participate in a space mission, according to Barbara R. Morgan, her backup for the flight.

title: ROYALS DEFEAT JAYS, 6-4
description: Frank White's three-run home run highlighted a four-run seventh inning today that carried the Kansas City Royals to a 6-4 victory over the Toronto Blue Jays.

title: Israeli Bankers Assailed
description: A commission investigating a 1983 crash of Israeli bank shares called today for the resignations of the governor of the state bank and top executives of the country's four largest commercial banking chains.

title: The Crime Commission's Value
description: The President's Commission on Organized Crime has closed its books and filed its final report. A few columns of news have announced that fact. Normally, it would be proper at this point to let the report speak for itself. Yet the document is hundreds of pages long; it has, moreover, become the subject of debate and, in some cases, simplistic interpretation. Among other irresponsible comments was the erroneous report that the commission had recommended universal and mandatory drug testing.

title: WHEN SON MOVES IN WITH DAD
description: THE couple had been divorced when their son was 7 years old, and the living arrangements in the separation agreement were standard. The mother had custody and the father spent one evening a week and every other weekend with the son. ''And when I was with him, it was always fun, fun, fun,'' Stephen Manna of Brooklyn said of his son.

title: Covert Lawyers Wanted
description: The Central Intelligence Agency, which naturally does most of its recruiting on the sly, has begun an overt operation to get some of the nation's lawyers out from behind their desks and into its clandestine service. In an advertisement in Legal Times, the agency announced that it values ''the diverse skills and powers of persuasion and communication that you have developed in your years of legal training and experience.''

title: Sri Lanka Town Swept By Reservoir's Water
description: A reservoir holding nearly five billion cubic feet of water burst from its earthen embankment today, and 100 people may have been killed, the police said. The state radio said up to 20,000 families were left homeless.

title: Washington Watch; Protectionist Move on Steel
description: PROTECTIONIST sentiment remains strong on Capitol Hill despite some long-awaited -though perhaps overstated - improvement in the nation's balance of trade.

title: Rudolf Serkin, Guest Soloist
description: The pianist Rudolf Serkin will be guest soloist with the Orchestra of St. Luke's in a performance of Beethoven's Piano Concerto No. 3 in C minor (Op. 37), under the direction of James Levine, tomorrow at the Metropolitan Museum of Art.

title: Fans' Behavior Penalizes Team
description: Europe's governing soccer body today banned FC Cologne from playing the second leg of its U.E.F.A. Cup final against Real Madrid at its stadium because of unruly fans, the West German sports news agency said.

title: Mexico Names Oil Chief
description: President Miguel de la Madrid named Alfredo del Mazo to succeed Francisco Labastida Ochoa as Mexico's oil minister, a statement Friday said. Mr. del Mazo has a background of senior financial positions in the Government, and diplomats said he was personally close to the President. His move from a position of relative obscurity brings him into the front rank as a possible presidential successor when Mr. de la Madrid's term ends in 1988, they said.

title: CONNORS DEFEATS WILANDER IN TOKYO
description: Jimmy Connors defeated Mats Wilander of Sweden, 6-4, 6-0, today to win the $250,000 Suntory Cup exhibition tennis tournament.

title: Raids Protested in Britain; German Rally Turns Violent
description: Rallies were held today at seven United States and British military bases to protest the American air raid on Libya, and officials said 154 people were arrested.

title: A COMMON SENSE OF MUTUAL DANGERS
description: There are several remarkable parallels between the arms control proposals of General Secretary Mikhail Gorbachev in his comprehensive statement of January 15, 1986, and the recommendations of American religious organizations, contained in the Pastoral Letter of the Catholic Bishops of 1983, and in the recent report of a committee of the Episcopal Diocese in Washington. It may well be that Gorbachev's proposals were motivated by political and propaganda aims rather than by a sincere will to arrive at a more peaceful world, but the similarity of approach by groups of such divergent basic views suggests that the proposals have a significance beyond ideological differences.

title: TELEVISION 'HALL OF FAME' CEREMONY
description: WHILE the movies have their Oscars, television can claim its Emmys.

title: OUTDOORS: GADGETS FOR THE ANGLER
description: I HAVE before me an advertising agency's broadside on the ''Fish Master,'' which, I am informed, will banish speculation as to the size of the big one that got away.

title: DIVERSE GROUP WEIGHS TEACHING JOBS
description: Ken Skorski, a 34-year-old food salesman from Westchester County who earns $40,000 a year, was inquiring yesterday about a $20,000-a-year teaching job in the New York City school system.

title: GOLD'S STEPSISTER FACING HARD TIMES
description: Silver, long a low-priced stepsister of gold, has little allure these days. In fact, it has been priced so low recently that earlier this month the Hecla Mining Company, a major silver miner, announced the closing of its Lucky Friday mine in Mullan, Idaho, the layoff of 241 miners and 56 laboratory and exploration workers, as well as sharp pay cuts for other workers and executives.

title: Optimism on Economy Found in Gallup Poll
description: Most Americans are optimistic about the economy and think that good times will prevail for the remainder of this year and possibly into 1988, according to the latest Gallup Poll.

title: Workshop on Stage Fright
description: The cellist Janos Starker will be the guest speaker at a workshop for amateur and professional musicians on eliminating stage fright, tonight at 8 o'clock at the 92d Street Y, at Lexington Avenue.

title: THE DANCE: 'SOFT SELL'
description: MARTA RENZI'S ''Soft Sell'' is a kind of canape tray on which are prettily arrayed such philosophical issues as the differences between the sensual and sexual, between pornography and art and between public and private behavior. Miss Renzi has created sensuous, amusing and poignant choreography that unfolds on a wittily confectionary set designed by the sculptor Harry Roseman to a taped script by the poet Daniel Wolff. The three fine female performers - Kaja Gam, Hetty King and Cathy Zimmerman - illuminate the production with their simplicity and conviction. But ultimately there is a sense of incompleteness to ''Soft Sell,'' performed on Saturday night at La Mama, 74A East Fourth Street, where it will be seen through April 27.

title: CONCERT: COLLEGIATE CHORALE
description: IT was difficult to understand the Collegiate Chorale's choice of ''Carmina Burana'' for its Carnegie Hall concert Saturday, since it performed without the orchestral accompaniment that is so organic a component of Orff's colorful primitivism. This city has plenty of full ''Carmina'' performances, and there is no shortage of wonderful music for chorus that does not depend on orchestration.

title: TRIAL OF LAWYER ENTERING 3D WEEK
description: The prosecutor in Stephen M. Bingham's murder trial has so far presented seven prison guards as witnesses as he attempts to link the radical lawyer to an outbreak at San Quentin Prison in 1971 that left six people dead.

title: All Within the Church
description: To the Editor:

title: Another Child Dies Of 6 Thrown in Bayou
description: A second child has died of six children who the authorities say were thrown into a muddy bayou by their mother; three of the children remained hospitalized today in stable condition.

title: GETTY SAID TO SEEK AILING SAVINGS UNIT
description: Gordon P. Getty, who allows that he is probably the richest man in the country, has pitted himself against Citicorp, the nation's biggest bank, in an attempt to buy a large and ailing savings bank here, banking authorities said today.

title: New Standard
description: Once upon a time pitchers were pitchers and that was pretty much that. They took their turns in the rotation, and if one pitcher couldn't finish a game another pitcher would be called in to take his place. Sometimes that meant the replacement pitcher would be too tired to make his next scheduled start and might not play until he was needed as a replacement again.

title: COLUMBIA WOMEN EDGE NAVY ROWERS
description: The Columbia women's crew scored the biggest victory in its three years of competition yesterday, defeating Navy's women's varsity in the featured race on the choppy Harlem River course.

title: BUCKS TOP NETS, LEAD 2-0
description: With their playoff prospects dimmed by an opening-game loss to the Milwaukee Bucks, the Nets brought back the injured Darryl Dawkins this evening, just two days after Coach Dave Wohl stated unequivocally that the 6-foot-11-inch center would not play.

title: Meryl Schreiber Wed
description: Meryl Adrienne Schreiber, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Julian Schreiber of Oceanside, L.I., and Sunrise, Fla., was married yesterday to Dennis H. Hanowitz, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Louis Hanowitz of Paterson, N.J., at Hewlett-East Rockaway Jewish Center in East Rockaway, L.I. Rabbi Stanley Platek officiated. The bride is a speech and language pathologist. The bridegroom, whose previous marriage ended in divorce, is president and owner of Dirtbusters Carpet Cleaning Inc. of Fairlawn, N.J.

title: NASA LAUNCHING OF SATELLITE IN MAY TO GET CLOSE SCRUTINY
description: When the space agency sends an 885-pound weather satellite into orbit atop a Delta rocket May 1, a lot of people will be watching closely, both along the beaches of central Florida and inside the agency itself.

title: Advertising; Accounts
description: * Master Drug in Chelmsford, Mass., to Hill, Holliday, Connors, Cosmopulos, Boston.

title: Merger of Ohio Utilities Excites Centerior Chief
description: He has spent the last 37 years with the same company, but next week Robert M. Ginn will start working for somebody else. Mr. Ginn is not exactly upset about the change, though. He spent the better part of a year working to bring it off.

title: BLUE GETS 200TH CAREER VICTORY AS GIANTS WIN, 4-0
description: The left-hander Vida Blue today became the 85th major league pitcher to win 200 games as the San Francisco Giants beat the San Diego Padres, 4-0, for a sweep of their four-game series.

title: LIBYA'S RAID DID NOT ESCAPE CRETE'S NOTICE
description: Missiles fired by Libya last week at American installations on the Italian island of Lampedusa may have missed their intended target, but they have made a strong impact on the minds of many people in Crete. The American bases on Crete are bigger and more important than those on Lampedusa, and, like the Italian island, they are only about 100 miles across the Mediterranean north of Libya.

title: Marcos Tells Paper He Owns Two Properties in New Jersey
description: Ferdinand E. Marcos says he owns two homes in New Jersey, one worth more than $3 million, but says they are ''about the only property we have in the United States,'' a newspaper reported today.

title: FOOD OUTLOOK POOR IN 6 AFRICAN NATIONS
description: Six African nations, including Ethiopia and the Sudan, continue to face food emergencies because of drought or civil strife and despite a general improvement in harvests on the continent, the Food and Agriculture Organization said in a report made public here today.

title: BIARRITZ ENJOYS 'VIDEOPHONE'
description: On stormy nights, when the rollers pound the wide beaches of this fashionable summer resort, many inhabitants close the curtains, reach for their phones and dial 01-28-62.

title: AROUND THE NATION;
description: A man troubled by the Federal debt left his $200,000 estate to the Government, but his brother may contest the will.

title: CIRO INC reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-Includes a reserve of $357,000 set up for termination of certain executive employment agreements and other matters.

title: Rates Mixed in Quiet Trading
description: Interest rates were mixed in quiet trading yesterday as short-term rates rose slightly while long-term bond yields fell.

title: EUROPEAN AMERICAN BANCORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
LIUT INJURED IN WHALER LOSS
description: Tonight the Whalers lost their most valuable playoff weapon, the veteran goalie Mike Liut, and his absence proved painful. To their credit, the youthful Whalers did not collapse after the injured Liut's removal, but they failed to recover.

title: GENERAL INSTRUMENT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
description: b-Includes losses from discontinued operations of $853,000 for the quarter and $5,108,000 for the year, as well as loss on disposal of discontinued operations of $14,543,000 for the year. c-Net loss includes losses from discontinued operations of $5,306,000 for the quarter and $10,778,000 for the year.

title: Bridge: Cautious Approach Dictated In Unfavorable Vulnerability
description: Artificial overcalls showing two suits are somewhat safer than natural one-suited overcalls. There is likely to be safety in one of the suits, and if not, the opponents may not be able to find a way to double.

title: HBO & CO (ATLANTIC, GA)(O) reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
BROTHER OF ARAB IN HEATHROW CASE IS HELD IN BERLIN
description: A Jordanian was reported today to have been arrested in connection with the bombing of a West Berlin discotheque, and authorities here identified him as a brother of a man seized in London last week on suspicion of trying to blow up an Israeli airliner.

title: COMBUSTION ENGINEERING INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes a loss from discontinued operations of $2,759,000 and a net from a tax benefit of $1,552,000. The 1985 results have been restated.

title: EAST GERMANY: HOW MUCH LEEWAY?
description: Over the last five days the East German Communist Party has broadcast its conviction that it is the most successful, and thus the weightiest, of the Soviet Union's Eastern European allies.

title: ADMINISTRATION BACKS RISE IN EXCISE TAXES
description: The Reagan Administration today generally endorsed Senator Bob Packwood's plan to raise excise taxes by about $75 billion over the next five years to pay for lower income tax rates and the retention of various tax subsidies.

title: ASHLAND POSTS BIG GAIN
description: The Amoco Corporation, one of the nation's leading integrated oil companies, yesterday reported a 30 percent decline in first-quarter earnings compared with the first quarter of 1985.

title: CORRECTION
description: The Critic's Choices column in The Guide on Sunday gave outdated information for a group of dance concerts by Phyllis Lamhut. The performances (originally scheduled this Thursday through Saturday) have been rescheduled for June 12-14 and June 17-21 at Playhouse 46, 423 West 46th Street.

title: BANKVERMONT CORPORATION reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
CARLISLE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
SCHERING-PLOUGH CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Appeal Is Planned On Hilton Ruling
description: Barron Hilton, son of the hotel chain's founder, intends to appeal a probate judge's ruling that set back his bid to wrest his father's stock in the company from a charitable trust. Mr. Hilton, 57 years old, is chairman of the Hilton Hotels Corporation of Beverly Hills, Calif., a $3 billion hotel-casino empire founded by his father, Conrad N. Hilton, who died in 1979 at age 91.

title: DOLLAR FALLS TO A LOW VS. YEN
description: The dollar continued to fall sharply yesterday, reaching a postwar low against the yen despite efforts by Japan's central bank to stabilize the market.

title: Forest Service Finds Space for a Footnote
description: When President Theodore Roosevelt created the Nezperce National Forest in 1908, the United States Forest Service says, he missed the mark by a space.

title: Gotbaum Can Use His Influence to Check Interunion Bitterness
description: To the Editor:

title: VALLEY FEDERAL SAVINGS & LOAN ASSN reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The latest quarter reflects a 10 percent stock dividend declared Jan. 23, 1986.

title: HUTTON, E F GROUP INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes an extraordinary credit of $5.2 million, or 17 cents a share, relating to the recognition of a tax benefit carryforward. c-Includes income of $3.3 million from discontinued operations.

title: PAINE WEBBER GROUP INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
UNITED MEDICAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Black Residents End Boycott of Schools
description: Students returned to classes today as a boycott by black residents of the Indianola public schools came to an end.

title: STUN-GUN ACCUSER FAILS TO RECALL DETAILS OF ARREST
description: A teen-ager who testified that he had been tortured by police officers with an electric stun gun at a Queens station house was cross-examined yesterday and was unable to recall certain details about the night he was arrested.

title: PACERS SHOPPING FOR GUARDS
description: Donnie Walsh spent his first day as general manager yesterday trying to determine the interest and worth of the Indiana Pacers' first-round draft choice. Walsh is not interested in selling the pick, the position of which will be decided in the May 11 lottery with the other six teams that failed to make the playoffs. He is looking for players, primarily experienced guards, the glaring weakness of the Pacers, who finished with a 29-53 record, the second-worst in the league behind the Knicks.

title: Fancy Cooking
description: A cookbook with a certain appeal appeared yesterday, the ''Gourmet Guide for Busy People by Famous People,'' with sales to benefit the New York City division of the American Cancer Society.

title: Judge Refuses to Block Execution in Florida
description: A Fedral judge late tonight denied a stay of execution for David Livingston Funchess, a Vietnam veteran who was to die in Florida's electric chair at 7 A.M. Tuesday for killing a couple in a tavern in 1974.

title: American Shot in the Sudan Is Out of Danger in Hospital
description: The technician from the United States Embassy in Sudan who underwent surgery here after being shot in Khartoum is out of danger, hospital sources reported today.

title: STATE TO BAN ALL COMMERCIAL STRIPED BASS FISHING
description: New York State will ban all commercial fishing for striped bass in its waters because of unsafe levels of PCB's in the fish. As a result, striped bass will be virtually unavailable in restaurants or stores in the metropolitan area.

title: NORTH FORK BANCORPORATION reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
KENKICHI OKI, AD EXECUTIVE
description: Kenkichi Oki, the president of a worldwide advertising agency and a United States Government witness in the postwar treason trial of ''Tokyo Rose,'' died Sunday at a Tokyo hospital of liver failure. He was 72 years old.

title: REAGAN LOBBIES PANEL ON CANADA TRADE TALKS
description: President Reagan appealed to the Senate Finance Committee today to back trade negotiations with Canada, saying that failure to do so ''would adversely color the tone of our political and economic relationships with Canada for many years to come.''

title: For Trade Talks With Canada
description: The Senate Finance Committee may well make a major foreign policy blunder by refusing to authorize the Administration to move forward quickly with proposed trade negotiations with Canada. Without such negotiations, Canada is almost sure to withdraw its request for a trade agreement. But that is not the only reason why the committee should vote to proceed with the talks.

title: S.I. Terminal Sale By Chevron USA
description: Chevron USA Inc., which is leaving the Northeast light petroleum products business after the sale of its assets to Cumberland Farms, said it plans to sell its terminal on Staten Island.

title: TITAN LOSS MAY FORCE EARLY USE OF SHUTTLE
description: The crisis in the nation's ability to launch key reconnaissance satellites has spurred speculation among aerospace experts that the Government might attempt an emergency mission of the space shuttle from a new launching facility here.

title: COLECO INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Honoring Shcharansky
description: Just before emerging from a meeting on the budget late yesterday, Speaker O'Neill and the Senate majority leader, Bob Dole, reached bipartisan agreement on an entirely unrelated matter. Mr. O'Neill suggested, and Mr. Dole agreed, that they co-sponsor a joint resolution to authorize a House-Senate ceremony to honor the Soviet human rights advocate Anatoly B. Shcharansky when he visits the capital next month. They set a date of May 13, the day after Mr. Shcharansky is to meet with President Reagan. The ceremony would be held in the Capitol Rotunda; by tradition, honorary ceremonies in Congressional chambers are restricted to heads of state.

title: TWIN DISC INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes a one-time charge of $2,892,000 associated with the termination of manufacturing operations at the company's plant in Rockford, Ill., as well as severance and related provisions covering manpower reductions in Europe. c-Net income

title: China Accuses Concerns
description: China today accused some foreign companies of doing business illegally in the country and hiring local staff members without official permission. The Peking Review said that, while most offices of foreign companies in China were law-abiding, 13 were charged with breaking the law last year, and one, C.G.A. Sakuraba of Japan, had had its license revoked.

title: Tanker in Bayonne Explodes, Killing Chemical-Truck Driver
description: A truck driver died today when a liquid in his tanker exploded at a chemical warehouse, starting a fire that burned for an hour, authorities said.

title: Pastorini Wins
description: Dan Pastorini endured some frustrations in his years as a National Football League quarterback, notably when his Houston Oilers couldn't get to the Super Bowl because they had to play the Pittsburgh Steelers first. But he has enjoyed considerable success in his new career as a race-car driver. Yesterday, Pastorini, 37, running in only his seventh National Hot Rod Association event, earned approximately $20,000 for the victory over Gene Snow of Fort Worth in the Top Fuel event in the rain-delayed completion of the Southern National drag races. Pastorini was timed in 5.561 seconds at an average speed of 256.70 mile an hour.

title: VAN DORN & CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Explaining Athens' Plague
description: What caused the plague of 430 to 427 B.C. that weakened Athens during the disastrous Peloponnesian War with Sparta?

title: ITALIANS ARREST LIBYAN AIDE IN '85 PLOT AGAINST ENVOYS
description: A former Libyan diplomat has been arrested here on suspicion of plotting at least a year ago to kill the United States Ambassador to Italy and the Saudi Arabian and Egyptian Ambassadors, Italian authorities announced today.

title: Ex-President of Chili's Gets Top Chi-Chi's Post
description: Chi-Chi's Inc., the family-style Mexican restaurant chain, announced yesterday that Hal W. Smith, formerly president of Chili's Inc. in Dallas, had been named chairman and chief executive.

title: Iroquois Head In Court Pact
description: A Hartford court has agreed to drop charges of cocaine possession against Terence J. Fox, chairman and chief executive of Iroquois Brands Ltd., after two years if he is not convicted of a crime during that time.

title: Award for '85 Fiction
description: Peter Taylor's ''Old Forest and Other Stories'' (Dial Press/Doubleday), a collection of 14 stories set in large cities of the middle South, has been selected for the PEN/Faulkner award as the best work of fiction in 1985. Judges for the $5,000 award, which will be presented on May 10 at the Folger Shakespeare Library in Washington, were Alice Adams, Richard Bausch and Beverly Lowry.

title: Illinois Bell Price Sets 8.68% Yield
description: The Illinois Bell Telephone Company, a subsidiary of Ameritech, is offering $275 million of 8 1/2 percent debentures, due in 2026, at a price of 98, to yield 8.68 percent, through underwriters led by the First Boston Corporation.

title: STANDARD PRODUCTS CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Share earnings reflect a 3-for-2 stock split to be paid April 25, 1986.

title: Libonati to Create Ads For Jackson Clothing
description: Entertainment Properties, which announced last week that it would be manufacturing, under a licensing agreement, a line of Michael Jackson clothing for boys and girls, has announced that the advertising would be done by Libonati Productions, with marketing and media handled by Myers/Brady Associates, which opened in Fairfield, N.J., earlier this year.

title: SQUIBB CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
MIDLAND-ROSS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes a gain of $2,265,000, or 16 cents a share, from a change in pension accounting methods.

title: SHORT INTEREST ON BIG BOARD OFF SLIGHTLY IN MONTH
description: The following Big Board companies show large changes:

title: Rigging the Oil Rigs
description: Representative Douglas Bosco has a sure-fire way to bring jobs and profits to his northern California district. The only catch is that it would reduce Federal revenues, increase America's dependence on foreign energy and undermine the economy of an ally, South Korea. That Mr. Bosco's incredible proposal, to require all offshore oil rigs to be built in America, has a chance of becoming law is a sad comment indeed on our legislative process.

title: CHESS: 4 Players Tie for First Place At National Open Tourney
description: The National Open Tournament in Las Vegas, Nev., ended in a tie for first place among Joseph Bradford of Bullard, Tex., and the grandmasters Dmitry Gurevich of Brooklyn, Walter Browne of Berkeley, Calif., and Sergei Kudrin of Stamford, Conn. Each scored 5 1/2- 1/2 in the 238-player Swiss-system competition held at the Imperial Palace Hotel and each won $1,775.

title: AIRCAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income

title: FIRST COMMERCE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
CHEMED CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Economic Euphoria Is Overoptimistic
description: To the Editor:

title: THE JAPANESE SIT ON FENCE ON U.S. RAIDS
description: Japan, rarely bold in its foreign policy, has been thrown into a state of virtual diplomatic paralysis for the last week by the American air strikes against Libya.

title: QUEENS INDICTMENT REPORTED IN INQUIRY ON MENTAL HEALTH
description: A Queens grand jury investigating the circumstances surrounding governmental approval of Holliswood Hospital has returned an indictment in the case, a source close to the investigation said yesterday.

title: ZIEGLER CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
NEW U.S. JUSTIFICATION ON NUCLEAR TESTS
description: The Reagan Administration, in a new justification for underground nuclear testing, said today that a total test ban might encourage other nations to develop their own atomic weapons.

title: ROSPATCH CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
A DIFFERENT VIEW OF JAPAN
description: THE scene is a classroom in adult behavior for employees of a department store in Tokyo. At the blackboard, a supervisor is giving a chalk talk about how to bow. Stick figures are drawn, bent at different degrees, their heads down. The lower the job and pay scale, the deeper the bow to the superior. A junior executive will bow more deeply to his boss than he does to a colleague, and any woman must bow deeply to men of any rank. What, on the surface, looks like a lesson in good manners and customer relations is fundamentally a reminder of a person's place in a traditional culture.

title: Loss Widens At Armco
description: Armco Inc., the diversified maker of carbon and specialty steel, said today that losses in the first quarter almost tripled, to $62.9 million, from a $22.5 million deficit a year earlier.

title: PHIBRO, HUTTON, PAINE ARE UP
description: Three major securities houses yesterday reported sharply increased earnings for the first quarter as Wall Street brokerages continued to show powerful earnings reflecting the bull market.

title: WESTERN CO OF NORTH AMERCA reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes an after-tax $6 million loss from the sale of oil and gas properties investments, a sale which netted it cash of about $18 million.
