IMPERIAL OIL CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
UAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes loss from a combination of greater airline operating losses, foreign exchange losses and increased interest expense.

title: Resistance to Fluoridation
description: More than 40 years after the first city in the United States adopted water fluoridation to reduce tooth decay, some 70 million Americans are served by public water supplies that remain unfluoridated.

title: STAGE: 'RICH RELATIONS,' FROM DAVID HWANG
description: AT first glance, ''Rich Relations,'' the new David Hwang play at the Second Stage, would seem to be a radical departure from its author's previous work. Mr. Hwang, a Chinese-American writer still in his 20's, has written of the Chinese-American experience in three of this decade's most invigorating plays - ''FOB,'' ''The Dance and the Railroad'' and ''Family Devotions.'' In ''Rich Relations,'' by contrast, there's not a Chinese-American to be found. The story of a millionaire real-estate baron (Joe Silver) and his drifting prodigal son (Keith Szarabajka), this comedy is about Caucasian Americans with no discernible roots, let alone ethnic roots, at all.

title: Article 230486 -- No Title
description: Shedding the last of its major consumer products businesses, the Union Carbide Corporation announced agreement yesterday to sell its home and auto products businesses in a leveraged buyout to First Boston Inc. for $800 million in cash.

title: TEXANS MARK THE 150TH ANNIVERSARY OF 18-MINUTE BATTLE FOR INDEPENDENCE
description: Texas today celebrated the 150th anniversary of the 18-minute battle that secured its independence from Mexico with music, fireworks, speeches and a hearty dose of Texas chauvinism.

title: DYNAPAC INC reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-Includes a tax credit of $7,069. Prior year figures are not available because the company was in start-up status until September 1985.

title: SUMMIT ISSUE IS RAISED ANEW
description: Mikhail S. Gorbachev, the Soviet leader, said today that a meeting with President Reagan was possible only if it promised ''real progress in disarmament.''

title: MARK GREEN JOINS RACE TO OPPOSE D'AMATO
description: Mark Green, a public-interest writer and lawyer, announced yesterday that he would seek the Democratic nomination to oppose Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato.

title: School Cancels Trip to England
description: The Central Connecticut State University football team has canceled an 18-day instructional trip to London next month because of the heightened threat of terrorism.

title: HOMESTEAD FINANCIAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The per share figures reflect a 5-for- 4 stock split paid earlier this month.

title: Nets Quiet on Dawkins Move
description: Dave Wohl has been subjected to more pressures and controversies during his rookie season as a head coach than he might have imagined possible. This weekend, he gave in to pressure from management and one of his own players.

description: b-Includes a tax benefit of $1,500,000. c-Net income

title: POLICE IN SAN JUAN TIE KILLING OF L.I. VACATIONER TO FUGITIVE
description: A tourist from Long Island who was shot to death during a holdup Jan. 2 was apparently slain by a fugitive from Federal racketeering charges in Indianapolis, the police said today.

title: FERRY DISASTER IN BANGLADESH
description: A double-decker ferry sank in a storm in the Dhaleswari River on Sunday night, leaving nearly 500 passengers feared drowned, the authorities reported today.

title: FRANCE TESTING ITALIAN WINE
description: France is continuing to test imported Italian table wine after finding five million contaminated quarts of apparently the same types of wines that have been linked to 22 deaths in Italy, according to a Government official.

title: Market Place; Western Union Maneuvers
description: FOR months, Drexel Burnham Lambert worked to devise a plan to restructure the Western Union Corporation. In mid-March, the blueprint for getting the communications company back on its feet was announced. Western Union's banks applauded the proposal, which is subject to approval by the company's debt and stock holders, but it has generally received a cool reception on Wall Street.

title: PAWLING SAVINGS BANK reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
U.N. CHIEF AND WIESENTHAL DENY DEFENDING WALDHEIM
description: A United Nations spokesman denied today that Secretary General Javier Perez de Cuellar had made a statement attributed to him about his predecessor, Kurt Waldheim, who is running for the Austrian presidency.

title: CHEMISTS DABBLE IN WHIMSY
description: DRAWN by a range of attractions reminiscent of a state fair, some 10,000 members of the American Chemical Society packed meeting rooms in 11 midtown Manhattan hotels last week to sample one another's discoveries, inventions, commercial products and job-hunting prospects.

title: AMERICAN MANAGEMENT SYSEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
FIRST FEDERAL SAVINGS & LOAN (CHARLESON)(O) reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
A Lobbying War Between the States
description: A decade ago, when the Sun Belt was booming, the states of the Northeast and Middle West set up the Northeast-Midwest Institute in Washington to help draw the attention of Congress and other Federal agencies to the problems that a stagnating economy had brought to their area. Sun Belt states, economically fat and happy, paid little attention.

title: BARRY, RG CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 29

title: PIANO: ALFRED BRENDEL PLAYS LISZT
description: EVEN in this Liszt year, pianists have not rushed to program his ''Annees de Pelerinage,'' partly because to play all 16 pieces that make up the first two books requires extraordinary dedication to the composer by the performer and a keyboard technique to match. Alfred Brendel, who traversed both the Swiss and Italian books in his Carnegie Hall recital last evening, qualifies on both counts. Not surprisingly, much of the local piano fraternity turned out for the occasion, knowing that the next integral undertaking of this music by a musician of Mr. Brendel's qualifications probably will not happen soon.

title: 7 ENVISIONING A 'NICER' LIFE ON LOTTO PLAY
description: As a Bronx family continued to celebrate its $10 million good fortune in the New York State Lottery, officials waited yesterday for the owner of the second winning ticket to come forward.

description: b-Net loss includes the cumulative effect of an accounting change.

title: IN JAKARTA: SMALL-TOWN DREAMERS AND BIG-CITY ILLS
description: This capital at the edge of the Java Sea is rapidly becoming one of the world's largest cities. It has seven million people now, with 17 million expected by 2005.

description: b-Includes a non-recurring credit of $270 million. Results include net income from discontinued operations of $6 million for latest quarter and $21 million for year-ago quarter.

description: The Financial Corporation of America said it was setting up a real estate division to develop or sell properties with which the troubled thrift company is saddled. Merrill Butler, a builder and developer, was named to head the division.

title: Alvin Childress Dead; Starred as TV's 'Amos'
description: Alvin Childress, who portrayed the philosophical cabdriver Amos Jones in the popular 1950's television series ''Amos 'n' Andy,'' died Saturday at St. Erne Sanitarium in suburban Inglewood. He was 78 years old.

title: DUKE POWER CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Pirates Sue Parker For Breach of Pact
description: The Pittsburgh Pirates sued Dave Parker yesterday for breach of contract on the ground that his use of cocaine had defrauded the team, and they asked a court in Pittsburgh to wipe out the $5.3 million in deferred payments that he is supposed to collect over a 20-year period.

title: QADDAFI'S WIFE IS ANGRY
description: Safia el-Qaddafi, the wife of the Libyan leader, vowed tonight to kill the American pilot who dropped bombs on her house if she ever finds him. Her adopted infant daughter was reported killed in the attack.

title: TEACHERS WHO QUIT OFFER THEIR REASONS
description: IN the clamor for reform of the nation's elementary and secondary schools, parents, legislators and panels of experts have had much to say over the past few years. Teachers' groups have usually been in the position of reacting to proposals, endorsing some, rejecting or studying others.

title: MAJOR STUDY POINTS TO FAULTY RESEARCH AT TWO UNIVERSITIES
description: A major study has found that scientists at two leading medical schools engaged in ''questionable practices'' and some ''fairly serious misconduct'' in performing research and writing scientific papers.

title: IN BENGHAZI, BOMB DAMAGE ON DISPLAY
description: The row of craters extended from a pockmarked elementary school to a demolished house about 500 yards away. But a navy building behind the school stood largely unscathed.

description: A survey by a State Senate committee has found that state government units hired private concerns last year to collect a total of $100 million under a selection process that the committee chairman called ''an open door to corruption and abuse.''

title: PLEA AGREEMENT IS EXPECTED FOR 22 IN RACKETEERING CASE
description: A plea-bargaining agreement appears to be near in the case against three sons of the late Joseph A. Colombo and 19 other purported members and associates of the Colombo organized-crime family, a Federal prosecutor said yesterday.

title: Reprimand Sought

title: On Not Reclining at Passover
description: In another country and in another age, I recited, as the youngest at the Passover table, the traditional Four Questions, of which the last one is: ''Why on all other nights do we sit and drink, some of us reclined, some not, whereas on this night do all of us recline at our ease?''

description: b-Includes a gain of $900,000 and a loss of $1,328,000 from cumulative effect on prior change in method of providing loss reserves on debt securities.

title: A 'STAR WARS' ANALYSIS
description: THE Strategic Defense Initiative, or ''Star Wars,'' may change ''the course of human history,'' which is what President Reagan said it would do; it may also be a colossal disaster. Either way, it is the biggest defense issue of our time. ''Visions of 'Star Wars,' '' a joint effort by public television's ''Nova'' and ''Frontline,'' examines the possibilities. The two-hour program will be seen on Channel 13 at 8 o'clock tonight.

title: Black Loses Delaware Vote In a System Under Challenge
description: A former City Councilman who is black lost a bid to recapture his seat today in an election system that has been challenged as discriminatory. The winner was a political newcomer, Patrick Lynn, who got 1,513 votes to James Hardcastle's 901.

title: Long Stretch
description: The man walking around with the unfamiliar feeling is Dennis Lamp, the Toronto reliever, whose loss on Sunday was the first he had suffered in 19 months. Lamp had gone 11-0 since last being beaten, on Sept. 21, 1984.

title: STUDIES LINK MISLED SALMON AND ACID RAIN
description: EXPERIMENTS at the University of New Hampshire suggest that acid rain may threaten Atlantic salmon by interfering with their ability to find their home streams for spawning.

description: Baseball Yankees vs. Royals, at Kansas City, 8:35 P.M. As a manager, Lou Piniella has already topped Yogi Berra's 1985 victory total.

title: PRESCHOOL PROGRAMS
description: SHOULD 3- or 4-year-old children be given preschool education? Most other industrial countries have long answered yes, and so have affluent American parents who send their tots to nursery school. Politicians have recently begun to respond to public pressure to do as much for poor children, but many experts warn that placing children in an early educational pressure cooker can do serious harm. A new study documents that danger but also shows how to avoid it and still give youngsters the benefit of a good program at an early age.

title: 3 South African Blacks Wounded by Land Mines
description: Three people were wounded by land-mine explosions today after a weekend of violence in South Africa in which a black policeman and eight other people died, authorities reported.

description: The New York City Board of Education intends to spend up to $7 million for 70 vans and to park them outside parochial schools for use as remedial classrooms to overcome restrictions imposed last year by the United States Supreme Court.

title: Mellon Profit Climbs 45.5%
description: The Mellon Bank Corporation said today that its profit for the first quarter reached $60.4 million, or $2.13 a share, up 45.5 percent from $41.5 million, or $1.46 a share, a year ago.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY;
description: Monotony and low pay characterize the job of airport security employees. So the life-and-death importance of their work is being reflected in a cash-bonus program started by the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey and airlines.

title: The Stakes in Reagan's SALT Decision
description: Ronald Reagan has made one of the most important decisions of his Presidency. The disclosure yesterday that he would uphold the SALT II treaty could be a long-awaited first step toward a more comprehensive United States-Soviet arms control regime. At the very least, he has narrowly avoided a long-lasting setback for nuclear sanity.

title: Drilling Rig Usage Drops
description: The number of drilling rigs working in the United States has fallen below the weekly average for 1971, the worst year for drilling activity since World War II, according to data compiled by the Hughes Tool Company. It said 865 rotary rigs were in operation during the week ended yesterday, a decline of nearly 1,100 from the number operating in December.

title: U.S. SAYS ALLIES ASKED FOR MORE IN LIBYA ATTACK
description: President Reagan said today that before the American bombing attack on Libya last week, some allies proposed an ''all out'' attack against that nation.

title: SALES RISE FOR ROBOTS
description: The American robotics industry had its best year in history in 1985 with sales totaling $442.7 million, compared with $332.5 million in 1984, according to the Robotic Industries Association, However, the industry's order backlog has shrunk somewhat and sales growth for the year is not expected to exceed 5 percent, according to officials of the trade association. In the early 1980's, the growth rate was 30 percent in some years.

description: The 12 foreign ministers of the European Community agreed today to a package of measures aimed at limiting Libya's ability to sponsor terrorist attacks.

title: THREATS PROMPT SECURITY MOVES AT FEDERAL SITE
description: Two of the four entrances to the main Federal office building in New York City were closed yesterday, and security guards began using metal detectors to check all visitors for weapons in the wake of threats received since the American attack on Libya.

title: South Koreans Reject North Bid
description: The Secretary General of the Seoul Olympic Organizing Committee has again rejected North Korea as a co-host of the 1988 Summer Games.

description: Nine people were inducted into the Theater Hall of Fame yesterday in ceremonies at the Gershwin Theater.

title: Warnaco Plan

Warnaco said it was able to increase the cash stake because it had privately sold a series of 13.75 percent senior subordinated notes with a face value of $15 a share, raising about $152 million.

title: Colombian Landslide Kills 7
description: A landslide engulfed seven homes under mud and rocks in a mining region of central Colombia, killing seven people and leaving eight others unaccounted for, civil defense officials said today. The landslide, set off by heavy rains, occurred Sunday in La Victoria, a village in Boyaca Province about 60 miles north of Bogota.

description: The erratic but brilliant career of Marcus Dupree appeared to take an upward turn last week when he was made eligible for the National Football League draft. But the running back sounded yesterday as if his career were over.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: CHINA The Grand Central Art Galleries (867-3344), now at 24 West 57th Street, once were actually housed in Grand Central Terminal, beginning in 1922. Rent was cheap because the president of the terminal's parent company, the New York Central Railroad, was sympathetic to the gallery's objectives. From 1959 to 1981 the gallery operated at the Hotel Biltmore, and after the hotel's demolition, the gallery moved to its present site. For decades it displayed realistic American paintings and sculpture. Today, keeping the realism but broadening the geographic scope, the gallery opens an exhibition, ''Realism From the People's Republic of China.''

title: OPEC Ends Session Without Quotas on Output
description: A majority of 10 OPEC ministers concluded a weeklong meeting saying they had reached an accord to impose a global production ceiling of 16.7 million barrels a day on the group's annual oil output.

description: Pick the spot on the ice. Any spot. For a second straight game, the Rangers were outplayed there by the Washington Capitals. Now, all the anticipation and drama the Rangers had created in recent days for this city is in danger of dying away.

description: Forty-three countries, including the Soviet Union and the United States, have taken the first steps toward establishing a set of international guidelines on liability when nuclear-powered orbital satellites malfunction and fall to earth.

Wright Jr. of Texas, who a year ago let it be known that he would very much like to succeed Thomas P. O'Neill Jr. as Speaker and claimed he already had enough backers to get the job.

title: Pretoria at the Pass
description: If South Africa's President, P.W. Botha, truly means to scrap rather than rename the hateful pass laws, it will be time to remove the quotation marks from his current series of ''reforms.'' He has stopped enforcement of the laws, one of the most degrading features of apartheid. But real cheering must wait a few more days until he defines a new, universal identity system. If that allows blacks to live and work where they choose, a new era may indeed be at hand.

title: New Surgery for Hawkins
description: Senator Paula Hawkins, Republican of Florida, successfully underwent her second back operation in two weeks today, an aide said. Mrs. Hawkins has been at Duke University Medical Center in Durham, N.C., since surgery April 8 to ease neck pain caused by an auto accident 20 years ago. She received only a local anesthetic today for removal of a piece of disk from her lower spine to ease pain unrelated to the first operation, her doctors said.

PRIME RATE IS CUT TO 8 1/2% BY BANKS
description: Banks across the nation yesterday lowered their prime lending rate, to which a broad spectrum of loans is tied, by half a point, to 8 1/2 percent. That is its lowest level since 1978. The action quickly followed the Federal Reserve's decision Friday to lower the rate it charges on loans to financial institutions to 6 1/2 percent from 7 percent.

description: Though Rob de Castella of Australia and Ingrid Kristiansen of Norway ran the Boston Marathon today for the first time, both were the favorites and both won by large margins. The main difference was that de Castella finished with a smile, Mrs. Kristiansen with a frown.

title: Light on the Supreme Court
description: At the approach of next year's bicentennial of the Constitution, Chief Justice Warren Burger challenges television to use its educational powers to heighten the celebration. Yet the Supreme Court at which he presides in interpretations of that document remains closed to cameras and dark to many Americans. Having held that states may experiment with photographic coverage of criminal trials, the high court nevertheless refuses to let the nation see oral arguments before it.

title: Out of the Chase, But in the Chips
description: Last week the owners of the National Basketball Association decided to fine-tune their draft structure so as to make it more fair. (By cutting the number of selections determined by lottery from seven to three, effective next year, the owners assured that the N.B.A.'s worst team would pick no lower than fourth.) The National Hockey League has no immediate plans to follow suit with any tinkering of its own, but the standings of the regular season just past suggest a need.

title: AN ADLER COMES HOME TO THE YIDDISH THEATER
description: The sounds of an immigrant past, in English and Yiddish, as assembled in ''The Golden Land,'' fill the Second Avenue Theater, at 12th Street, a house that opened as a Yiddish theater for Maurice Schwartz just 60 years ago. In those days, Second Avenue, with its abundance of Yiddish houses, was known, euphorically, as the Jewish Rialto, and, less reverently, as ''knish alley.''

title: JACKSON NATIONAL LIFE INSURANCE CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes net realized investment gains of $4.2 million. c-Includes net realized losses of $134,000 and a fresh start adjustment of $138,000. The share earnings reflect a 3-for-2 stock split paid in March 1986.

title: LOWEST CHARGE RATES SOUGHT
description: Urging consumers to give their credit card business to banks that charge the lowest interest rates, Representative Charles E. Schumer today issued a list of 51 banks with rates of less than 18 percent for Visa and Mastercard credit purchases.

title: NOTES ON FASHION
description: IN the weeks before the presentation of their all-important fall collections, fashion designers traditionally hide from the world before pulling fashion rabbits from their hats. But this week, two of the biggest names on Seventh Avenue made news by making statements that had to do with more than fashion. One has created an instant retail institution. The other made a fortuitous contribution to an ongoing crusade.

title: 2 Issues in Dollars Of New Zealand
description: Two issues of fixed-rate notes denominated in New Zealand dollars were offered in the American capital market the last few days.

title: 'STROKES' ON CHANNEL 13
description: THE word ''informative'' is sometimes a code word to describe a program that is respectably knowledgeable, perhaps a bit on the tedious side. That is too bad because informative, in the best sense of presenting vitally useful information in a clear and interesting way, is a word that accurately, and meritoriously, applies to the installment of ''Innovation'' on Channel 13 at 8:30 tonight.

title: The Hole in Landmarks Law
description: The frustrated effort of New York's St. Bartholomew's Church to cash in on the boom in Park Avenue real estate is now headed for court, and that is just as well. The city's Landmarks Preservation Commission has shown in this and other cases that it lacks both the standards and standing to resolve a conflict between architectural quality and the social or religious ambitions of a nonprofit institution.

title: AMERICAN MAIZE-PRODUCTS CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes an extraordinary charge of $499,000 from the early retirement of debt.

description: The biggest flotation of shares in West German history was announced today when Deutsche Bank gave details of plans to sell the former Flick conglomerate's industrial core to the public.

description: b-Net loss

title: Facing Up to Terrorism
description: Even before the Reagan Administration's bombing raids on Libya, the fear of terrorism was causing a sharp decline in Americans' air travel to Europe, particularly to the Mediterranean. The raids may well have increased the danger, but the traveling public has no need to exaggerate its risks.

title: AN EX-WAITRESS'S WRITING SUCCESS
description: ''I'm kind of petrified,'' Deborah Eisenberg says, crossing her legs and folding her arms tightly. ''I'm not used to interviews. People don't generally interview waitresses.''

WHITSON IMPRESSIVE WINNER
description: He wore a smile of satisfaction. It had been months since Ed Whitson's performance in a game left him believing that he may yet return home and pitch in triumph.

title: FORD INCENTIVES
description: The Ford Motor Company joined its major competitors in offering financing rates as low as 6.9 percent.

title: CAPONE'S VAULT: CRIME'S EMPTY CLOSET
description: All-in-all, the much-touted mystery of Al Capone's vault underneath the old Lexington Hotel was a bust.

FIRST ALBANY COMPANIES reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Gavin's Replacement
description: President Reagan is understood to be ready to nominate Charles J. Pilliod Jr., former chairman of the Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company, as Ambassador to Mexico to replace John Gavin, the actor and businessman who has held the post since 1981 and plans to retire soon.

title: REAGAN REPORTED TO FAVOR KEEPING 1979 LIMIT ON ARMS
description: President Reagan has decided to stay within the limits of the unratified 1979 treaty on strategic arms limitation by dismantling two Poseidon submarines, Administration officials said today.

title: SEACOAST BANKING CORP OF FLA reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Centel Announces 2 Key Job Switches
description: The Centel Corporation, a Chicago-based communications conglomorate, announced two job switches yesterday that the company said were ''in line with the company's management development and succession planning.''

description: Coach Frank Layden, after his undermanned Utah Jazz had fallen behind the Mavericks by two games to none in the playoffs: ''If Dallas doesn't win this, they should go to Division III.''

PHILIPS INDUSTRIES LTD reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Fleet Ferocity
description: It used to be that football players who also ran track were regarded, well, as perhaps not having the right tough stuff. Any lingering sentiment in support of that tarnished belief is about to take a beating.

title: CONTROL DATA REPORTS WIDER LOSS IN QUARTER
description: The Control Data Corporation, the troubled computer manufacturer, said today that losses for the first quarter more than doubled, to $21.2 million, from $9.2 million, a year earlier.

title: HAWORTH CONTINUES TO EXCEL AT CENTER
description: Alan Haworth and his linemates named themselves the plumbers, because they fixed things that didn't work for the Washington Capitals.

AFFIRMATIVE ACTION EFFORT ON AMTRAK CORRIDOR PRAISED AS EFFECTIVE
description: A major Federal program to reserve contracts for businesses owned by members of minority groups and women in the Northeast has been highly effective, according to a regional advisory panel of the United States Commission on Civil Rights.

title: CORRECTION
description: A picture caption in The Home Section last Thursday with an article about changing patterns in furniture buying misidentified Cheryl Piaggio. She is an interior designer at the Huffman-Koos Design Center.

title: SMITHKLINE BECKMAN CORPORATION reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes non-recurring charges related to its early retirement program and withdrawal due to tempering of three products, Contac, Peldrin and Dietac.

description: b-Includes tax credits of $92,000 for the latest quarter and $84,000 for the year-ago period.

title: Yuppies Under Glass
description: FOR a week or so, it looked as if the trend-spotters and pundits had finally tired of the young upwardly mobile professionals. You could read whole newspapers and magazines without encountering them, their fast tracks, their naked ambition, their latest acquisitions or even their increasing financial dilemmas.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: TUESDAY, APRIL 22, 1986
description: The Economy

SUNAIR ELECTRONICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
DANAHER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31

BLUE JAYS RALLY TO DEFEAT RANGERS, 7-6
description: Cliff Johnson's three-run double in the eighth inning gave the Toronto Blue Jays a 7-6 victory over the Texas Rangers tonight.

title: Interest Deferred to '91 On Citicorp Eurobonds
description: Citicorp yesterday offered $100 million of 8 1/8 percent deferred interest Eurobonds, due in 1993, at a price of 101 3/8 through underwriters led by Daiwa Europe Ltd.

title: Judge Reserves U.S.F.L. Ruling
description: Another preview of the United States Football League's antitrust suit against the National Football League took place in Federal District Court in lower Manhattan yesterday at a hearing before Judge Peter Leisure, who reserved decision on the N.F.L. motion to dismiss the suit.

title: A Word to All Those Debbies on the Phone
description: To the Editor:

title: HIGH COURT ADDS PROTECTION FOR NEWS MEDIA IN LIBEL SUITS
description: The Supreme Court ruled 5 to 4 today that a person suing a news organization for libel must prove damaging statements are false, at least ''on matters of public concern.''

title: AN EX-GOALIE WATCHES AND REMEMBERS
description: The link, these days, is preserved with the aid of cable television, and the satellite dish that brings distant hockey games into John Davidson's home in Calgary, Alberta, and his new career, and the vivid memories of another spring in New York. He has attended nearly 100 games as a television analyst this season, including a few recent trips to Madison Square Garden when the habits that formed the playoff successes of the Rangers were beginning to take shape.

title: TACTICAL SHIFT AT HOLIDAY CORP.
description: Holiday Inns, the flagship product of the Holiday Corporation, are everywhere - and that is both the biggest asset and the biggest problem of the Memphis-based hotelier, the nation's largest.

title: BANKERS FIRST CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Bank Seeks a New Image
description: The beleaguered Bank of America has begun what it called its first new corporate advertising campaign in 20 years in an attempt to shore up its image in California and attract new customers.

title: WICKES'S NEW LOOK IN EUROPE
description: Four years ago, Henry Sweetbaum saw nothing but problems when he took command of the troubled European operations of the Wickes Companies, a California building-supply retailer.

title: RAN BANK OF BOSTON
description: Lloyd D. Brace, former chairman of the board of the First National Bank of Boston, died here Sunday night after a long illness. He was 83 years old. Mr. Brace, who lived in Needham, was chairman from 1959 to 1966.

description: b-Includes an extraordinary credit of $297,040 from proferred stock distributed by the Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corp.

description: b-Net loss

title: NICARAGUA POLICY ENDORSED BY NIXON
description: Former President Richard M. Nixon mixed political analysis and Watergate jokes in an address here today to North American newspaper publishers that drew a standing ovation from about half the audience.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: THE COLLECTED LETTERS OF W. B. YEATS. Volume I 1865-1895. Edited by John Kelly. Illustrated. 548 pages. Oxford University Press. $29.95. WHEN John Kelly and his colleagues set out to produce a collected edition of the letters of W. B. Yeats they envisaged it running to four volumes - something altogether more substantial than the one-volume edition (long out of print) that had appeared in 1954, 15 years after the poet's death. In fact they seriously underestimated the scope of their task; so many letters have come to light in the course of their researches that the project will now stretch to 12 volumes, if not more. In the first volume, which takes Yeats up to the age of 30, nearly half the letters are printed for the first time, and Mr. Kelly tells us that the proportion of new material will increase in every subsequent volume.

title: Carson Rejects 3d Baytree Bid
description: Carson Pirie Scott & Company, the Chicago-based retailing and food service company, today rejected a third takeover bid by Baytree Investors.

title: ULTRA BANCORPORATION reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The per share figures reflect a 2-for- 1 stock split paid in December.

title: MELLON BANK CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The latest quarter results reflected higher trading revenue and large gains on the sale of investment securities, offset by a $62 million increase in the reserve for possible credit losses.

title: 3-Part Offering By WC Capital
description: The WC Capital Corporation, a subsidiary of Bank Western of Denver, is offering $300 million of collateralized mortgage obligations through underwriters led by Salomon Brothers Inc. The obligations, rated triple-A by Moody's Investors Service and the Standard & Poor's Corporation, are backed by Government National Mortgage Association pass-through securities.

title: HARVARD PRESIDENT SEES U.S. 'PINCERS' CREATING A CRISIS FOR COLLEGES
description: The Federal Government is attacking higher education with a ''pincer movement,'' cutting Federal aid while also taking action that would inhibit private donations to universities, Derek Bok, the president of Harvard University, asserted today.

title: BRIGHT DISPLAY BREAKTHROUGH
description: THE I.B.M. standard that has foisted itself upon personal computing is a real asset only because it is a standard, and as such has given both hardware and software developers a standing target to shoot at. In many ways, however, this standard, which evolved from marketing clout rather than technical prowess, has had a negative impact on the development of the personal computer.

title: TAX RECEIPTS BELOW ESTIMATE
description: For the second year in a row, New York City's tax revenue has not increased as much as expected, officials said yesterday.

title: NEW DATE IS GIVEN FOR MANES'S F.B.I. APPOINTMENT
description: The F.B.I. said yesterday that when Donald R. Manes killed himself on March 13, he was scheduled to appear at the bureau's New York office in ''a day or two'' to be photographed and fingerprinted.

title: ACCURAY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
House Backs Mortgage Aid
description: The House passed emergency legislation today to extend the credit authorities of two Government agencies that help provide mortgage money to home buyers.

title: ABC Morning Schedule To Have a New Chief
description: Capital Cities/ABC, hoping to get ''Good Morning America'' back to the top of the ratings, will announce today the appointment of Philip R. Beuth as vice president of early-morning programming.

description: Outside, like Irish mist, rain clouds floated above and below.

title: U.S. Embassy in Peru Damaged by Explosion
description: A car bomb exploded here early today outside the residence of the United States Ambassador, blasting a hole in the outer concrete wall and breaking windows. An embassy spokesman said no one was injured.

New Pact at Chrysler Plant
description: The United Automobile Workers union has approved a new contract reducing the number of job classifications at the Chrysler plant here, which guarantees that a new line of cars will be built at the plant in 1987, union officials said today. A tentative agreement was reached Thursday after four days of negotiating.

title: EXECUTIVE OF CREDIT UNION AGREES TO TESTIFY IN TUROFF BRIBE INQUIRY
description: The top executive of a Brooklyn credit union has agreed to testify that he participated in multimillion-dollar frauds and paid a $30,000 bribe to the city's former taxi commissioner, Jay L. Turoff, state and Federal law-enforcement officials said yesterday.

title: People
description: * Ralph D. Hirsch has been named executive vice president and Richard Geyer, senior vice president, at Kornhauser & Calene.

title: SOVIET GOES ALL-OUT FOR GOODWILL GAMES
description: The publicity build-up for the Goodwill Games, a mini-Olympics scheduled to take place in Moscow in July, began in earnest in the Soviet Union today with a news conference and free samples of Pepsi Cola.

title: DOLING OUT JOBS UNDER KOCH: THE MAYOR KEPT HIS DISTANCE
description: The municipal scandal in New York City has put a sharp focus on a compelling and elusive question: How has patronage in its most basic form - the doling out of jobs to the party faithful -worked in the Koch administration and what role has it played in making corruption possible?

description: Comparable share earnings are not presented for prior quarter, as the company had not yet converted from mutual to stock form.

description: The Supreme Court ruled today that in order to obtain an overall settlement in a civil rights case, the lawyers for the plaintiffs may agree to give up any right to collect fees from the defendants.

A TRIUMPHANT NBC FACES UNCERTAIN FUTURE
description: When the national television ratings are released this morning, ranking NBC, CBS and ABC by the popularity of their prime-time programs, they will confirm what has been a foregone conclusion in the industry for weeks: NBC has won the 1985-86 television season, its first clear victory ever.

description: Charles Koshetz, senior editor of Venture magazine, died of a heart attack Saturday at his home in Brooklyn.

description: Sears, Roebuck & Company, the nation's largest retailer, reported today that its first-quarter net income fell 12.5 percent from the 1985 quarter largely because of poorer results in its merchandise group.

title: RALPH LAUREN'S STORE: PART PALAZZO, PART CLUB
description: Ralph Lauren's message is loud and clear. Championing traditionalism and Old World values, the fashion designer has built an empire on a reinterpretation of classical clothing, restyling it for a modern customer.

description: All through the day of the first New York performance of ''Big Deal,'' workmen were scrambling around the Broadway Theater, laying carpeting, putting the final touches on the new paint job and hanging the last of the chandeliers. Half an hour before curtain time, the ''no smoking'' signs were being hung, just as the doors opened to admit the first New York audience for the show.

title: UAL Shows Steeper Loss
description: UAL Inc., the holding company that owns United Airlines, yesterday reported a loss of $103 million for the first quarter, mainly as a result of a large decline at the airline, which had a loss of $107.3 million.

title: JUSTICES, IN 6-3 RULING, EASE CURB ON SEIZURE OF X-RATED MATERIALS
description: The Supreme Court today made it somewhat easier for the authorities to seize materials alleged to be obscene, ruling that Federal law requires no more evidence of criminality to support a warrant for the seizure of books or movies than for guns, drugs or other materials.

description: b-Includes realized investment losses of $31,000 for the latest quarter and $12,000 for the earlier period.

description: Two of Silicon Valley's most celebrated entrepreneurs -Stephen G. Wozniak and Nolan K. Bushnell - are planning to join forces, officials of their companies said today.

title: HOUSE VOTES LOWER PENSION FOR FUTURE MILITARY RETIREES
description: In a move to cut costs and convince military personnel to remain in the service, the House voted today to reduce military pensions in the future for those who retire after 20 years.

title: Sweet Onions
description: Second only to themselves, members of Congress like to promote food products from their districts. In that spirit, Representative E. (Kika) de la Garza plans to give away a truckload of Texas 1015 SuperSweet Onions this morning at the corner of Independence and New Jersey Avenues S.E., across the street from the Capitol.

title: Kemp Award Reduced
description: A Federal judge yesterday reduced the amount by $1.9 million yesterday from a jury's award to the former University of Georgia instructor, Jan Kemp, who contended that she was dismissed for protesting preferential academic treatment for athletes. Mrs. Kemp said she might refuse the reduced amount and force a new trial because ''I think the public will learn a great deal more . . . about the goings on at the University of Georgia.'' United States District Judge Horace Ward said a Federal jury tried to send a message in support of free speech with its $2,579,681.95 award to Mrs. Kemp, but ''the reach and coverage of the award far outdistance the aim and purpose.''

title: HOW LIBYA MESSAGES INFORMED U.S.
description: Within a few hours of the terrorist bombing of a West Berlin discotheque, the United States intercepted two messages that clearly pointed to Libyan involvement, according to Reagan Administration officials.

title: PITNEY BOWES INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes a gain from the disposition of discontinued operations of $1.3 million and a gain from discontinued operations of $569,000. c-Includes a gain from discontinued operations of $554,000.

title: U.S. EMPLOYEES GET REFUNDS
description: Eleven months after they were announced, refunds of $270 million have begun flowing to Federal employees and retirees as a result of a program to hold down Blue Cross and Blue Shield payments to hospitals and doctors in 1984.

title: HONDA MOTOR CO LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
description: The 1985 year and fourth quarter results are converted at 180.55 yen to the dollar, which was the prevailing rate at the Feb. 28 year end.

title: SPECIAL COINS AND SPECIAL CAUSES
description: The Treasury Department does not make coins for just anyone. But in two cases where Congress has found a particularly compelling cause, it has marshaled the resources of the United States Mint to produce commemorative coins for sale to the public.

title: U.S. STILL DIVIDED ON 1979 ARMS TREATY
description: President Reagan's tentative decision to remain within the limits of the unratified 1979 treaty on strategic arms has put off, but not settled, the issue within the Administration, officials said today.

title: Time Runs Out On Gift Watches
description: For 91 years, high school athletes who have done well at the Penn Relays have gone home with medallions and other tokens of their success, including watches for the winners of the championship events. Not this year.

title: Debating the Future Of a Movie Palace
description: It is a realm of jumbled and sumptuous fantasy, where gilded icons of lost civilizations were piled atop one another to serve a 20th century deity: the moving picture.

title: U.S. BOND PRICES FALL SHARPLY
description: In a sharp break with the euphoria that has sent interest rates sharply lower in the last few months, prices of Treasury bonds fell nearly three points yesterday as yields rose sharply in active and hectic trading.

title: RULING UPSETS ORDER TO LIMIT TRIAL PUBLICITY
description: A state appeals court yesterday overturned a judge's order prohibiting lawyers and witnesses from talking to reporters about the Queens trial of two police officers.

title: VIETNAM VETERAN IS PUT TO DEATH IN FLORIDA

title: Borg-Warner Elects President as Chief
description: The Borg-Warner Corporation, a diversified manufacturing and service company, announced yesterday that Clarence E. Johnson, its president and chief operating officer, had been elected chief executive.

BRITAIN MOVES TO EXPEL 21 LIBYANS IT CALLS 'REVOLUTIONARY' ACTIVISTS
description: Britain said today that it planned to expel 21 Libyan students for suspected involvement in ''student revolutionary activities.''

title: Mr. Reagan's Twin Tax Surrender
description: President Reagan has once again abandoned his unalterable opposition to any tax increase. The Treasury now indicates that he's open to ''selective'' increases in excise taxes if that will pay for the size cut he wants in personal and corporate income tax rates. But that is the wrong new tax for the wrong reason.

title: EQUIFAX INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes income of $119,000 from discontinued operations.

title: Topics; Liberations; Aid to Addicts
description: When Dr. Vincent P. Dole, then at Rockefeller University, began planning to study the biology of addictive diseases in 1962, he could find only one significant book on street addicts. It was ''The Drug Addict as a Patient,'' by Dr. Marie Nyswander, a psychiatrist who treated junkies out of a New York City storefront. Dr. Dole asked her to join him in his research project and, eventually, in marriage.

title: CILCORP INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
AUSTRIAN FINDS NO CASE AGAINST WALDHEIM
description: The President of Austria said tonight that documents about Kurt Waldheim's wartime activities showed that he must have been aware of German reprisals against partisans in the Balkans.

title: Ohio Abortion Law On Minors Is Overturned
description: A Federal district judge today declared unconstitutional Ohio's one-month-old law requiring parental notification for minors seeking abortions.

title: MICHIGAN NATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
GHOST CHEF'S PASSION IS CREATING
description: THERE have been ghost writers, but there has not been a ghost cook - until now. Martin Rapp, a director of the Traveller's Bookstore at Rockefeller Center, is a man who adapts, improvises and occasionally invents dishes and cooks them for friends who are restaurateurs, caterers and food writers. Yet he receives neither remuneration nor credit for his efforts or recipes. He is also a man whose close friends call him and say that they will give a dinner party - if he will cook.

description: b-Includes a gain from recovery of pension assets of $80 million, and reflects a loss of $10 million from the proposed sale of Amax's interest in a zinc mine. c-Net loss

description: Prof. Mircea Eliade, a prolific writer and a leading scholar of religion, died Tuesday at Bernard Mitchell Hospital at the University of Chicago. He was 79 years old and lived in Chicago.

title: Sun Chemical Chairman Shifts to Defender Role
description: Norman E. Alexander, the 71-year-old chairman and chief executive of the Sun Chemical Corporation, has won and lost his share of takeover struggles during his almost 30 years with the producer of printing inks and graphic arts equipment.

title: Advertising; BBDO International
description: BBDO International released its first-quarter earnings figures yesterday. Revenues were $81.6 million, up 8 percent from the $75.8 million in the comparable period last year, while net income rose 16 percent, to $4.8 million, or 38 cents a share, from $4.2 million, or 33 cents a share.

title: SECOND NATIONAL BUILDING & LOAN INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes gains on the sale of loans and securities of $464,000 for the latest quarter and $254,000 for the year- earlier period.

description: The chief executive of the International Business Machines Corporation, John F. Akers, says the company is growing ''increasingly discouraged'' about its ability to continue business operations in South Africa.

title: FOR MADISON AVE., 4 LONG DAYS ON HOLD
description: It was one of those unavoidable urban catastrophes, and all Neal Schwartzberg could say, looking back on it yesterday, was thank goodness he has a telephone in his BMW.

description: b-After a writedown of $149,578,000 on oil and gas assets. c-Net income
