description: A Brooklyn credit union executive swore in Federal court yesterday that he gave a $30,000 bribe to the city's former taxi commission chairman, Jay L. Turoff, in 1984 - providing law-enforcement officials with what they said was enough evidence to prosecute Mr. Turoff.

title: Indian Museum Should Combine With Natural History Museum
description: To the Editor:

title: DURABLES ORDERS FALL BY 2.5%
description: Orders to factories for ''big ticket'' durable goods fell 2.5 percent in March, the biggest decline in a year, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: YONKERS GETS DEADLINE TO BEGIN SCHOOL INTEGRATION
description: A Federal judge yesterday ordered Yonkers education officials to begin the racial integration of their schools by September, largely by closing some schools, using new elementary school district lines and developing ''magnet,'' or enriched, academic programs.

title: 'MISSING III,' THOSE WHO DISAPPEAR
description: THE cases of people - adults and children - who are missing constitute the sadder mysteries of life. Disappearance occurs with a shocking suddenness and leaves in the bereft a desolation like that felt only at a death and sharpened by the inconclusiveness of it all. ''Missing III -Have You Seen This Person?,'' at 10 o'clock tonight on NBC, is a program about missing people, one that deals not so much with sensitivities as with attempts to find those who have vanished.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''No nation - friend or foe, ally or adversary - should be surprised by the events of last week and the United States Government's determination to protect American lives and the world from terrorism.'' - President Reagan. [ A7:2. ]

title: MAGNA GROUP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
MARGARET DE VECCHI
description: Margaret Anna Shaw De Vecchi, a vice president of the Protestant Welfare Agencies from 1948 to 1971, died April 15 at the Sibley Memorial Hospital in Washington.

title: DUQUESNE LIGHT CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Contingent Fees Help The Injured Get Justice
description: To the Editor:

title: The U.N. Today: April 23, 1986
description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY Preparatory Committee on the Critical Economic Situation in Africa - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: THE ROUTES TO SUMMIT
description: The superpowers' feints and parries over when, and whether, to hold a summit meeting in Washington this year have grown into more than a matter of protocol and timing. In the last two days, Mikhail S. Gorbachev, the Soviet leader, has linked a session with President Reagan to ''the international atmosphere,'' saying that such a meeting ''can occur only when the necessary international atmosphere exists'' and when the United States stops ''attempting to poison the international atmosphere.''

title: MEREDITH CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes a net gain of $6,164,000 from the sale of radio properties.

title: BRISTOL-MYERS CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The 1985 figures are restated to reflect the acquisition in 1986 of Genetic Systems Corp. on a pooling of interests basis.

title: Firefighter Rescues 5 In Westchester Crash
description: A chief's aide in the New York City Fire Department rescued five people involved in a fiery traffic accident early yesterday on Interstate 95 near New Rochelle, authorities said.

title: Control of Walker
description: The Reichmanns of Canada, who own 80 percent of the Gulf Canada Corporation, will take control today of Hiram Walker Resources Ltd., the oil and liquor producer, sources close to the family said.

title: OPERA: MONIUSZKO'S 'HAUNTED CASTLE'
description: STANISLAW MONIUSZKO'S ''Haunted Castle'' is one of those operas that uplift the Central European heart but never reach very far beyond distinct national boundaries. Moniuszko was a contemporary of Chopin and still shares with him the affections of the Polish people. Yet for all his devotion to his country's ethnicity and his long and successful series of operas, he is - for now at least - a footnote rather than a chapter in music history.

title: PAN AM TO SHIFT OVERSEAS FLIGHTS
description: Pan American World Airways, citing a sharp fall in bookings to some overseas markets because of fears of terrorism, said yesterday that it had decided to shift about 5 percent of its aircraft capacity from European destinations to the United States.

title: Local Costs Unchanged Last Month
description: Consumer prices in March remained essentially unchanged from February in the New York-northeastern New Jersey area as a sharp decrease in energy prices was offset by an increase in costs for shelter, restaurant meals and medical care, the regional Bureau of Labor Statistics reported yesterday.

title: John McCloskey Dies; First Citywide Sheriff
description: John J. McCloskey, New York's first citywide sheriff, died Monday at his home in Stony Brook, L.I. He was 83 years old.

title: PERU BLAMES DRUGS IN U.S. AID PROGRAM IN 4 INFANTS' DEATHS
description: United States authorities are investigating a New York company in connection with the deaths of four Peruvian infants who had been treated with an anti-diarrhea medication manufactured by the company, the Agency for International Development said today.

title: CRAY RESEARCH INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
GENERALS DRAFT GREEN, BYARS
description: The New Jersey Generals went for some blue-chip players yesterday in the territorial draft of the United States Football League. Tim Green, the all-America defensive end from Syracuse, was one selection and Keith Byars, the celebrated running back from Ohio State, another.

title: SCREEN: 'FAST TALKING,' AUSTRALIAN DELINQUENTS
description: FAST TALKING'' resembles the broken-down cars that keep appearing in its background, one of those heaps that has been put together with used parts by a mechanic with more enthusiasm than experience, and it takes only a few minutes of jolting along to know it isn't going to take us very far.

title: The Political Presses Keep Rolling
description: Over the last three decades, political books have become fixtures in campaigns for high office. John F. Kennedy wrote ''Profiles in Courage'' and Barry Goldwater ''The Conscience of a Conservative.'' Ronald Reagan wanted to know ''Where's the Rest of Me?'' while Jimmy Carter asked ''Why Not the Best?''

title: DREYFUS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
House Panel Opposes Missile Sale to Saudis
description: A House subcommittee recommended today that Congress reject the proposed $354 million sale of American defensive missiles to Saudi Arabia.

title: Baytree Ends Bid For Carson Pirie
description: Baytree Investors Inc., the private investment banking group, said that it was withdrawing its bid for Carson Pirie Scott & Company but that it was looking to acquire three other retail chains.

title: AN OIL GLUT AND A WAR CLOSE IN ON KUWAIT'S UTOPIA
description: On a still day, you can hear the boom of artillery and bombs rolling across the Persian Gulf past the futuristic needle towers on the shoreline, the symbol of Kuwait's oil opulence.

title: BUSINESSLAND INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes a tax loss carryforward of $688,000. c-Includes a tax credit of $1,159,000. d-Net loss

title: PITTSTON COMPANY reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After tax credits of $147,000 for the latest quarter and $1,634,000 for the year-earlier period.

title: Academic-Job Picture Still Bleak
description: To the Editor:

title: Slugged Slugger
description: If Jason Felice doesn't make it to the majors as an outfielder, he has a fallback position of sorts - on his back as a Hollywood punching bag.

title: NORFOLK SOUTHERN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
MUSICIANS REUNITED WITH STOLEN FIDDLES
description: At first, it seemed to be a self-fulfilling prophecy. A group of musicians from East Germany, warned to be watchful during their four-week tour of the United States, fell victim to thieves who stole six of their valued instruments.

title: Saudi Denies Shift on Oil
description: Saudi Arabia's oil minister denied today that OPEC's decision on Monday to rein in its unrestrained oil production represented a fundamental shift from its policy of keeping prices low to force out other producers.

title: FREEPORT-MCMORAN GOLD reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net loss

title: LEONARD RETURNS IN FINE STYLE
description: On April 12, Dennis Leonard, once the premier right-handed pitcher in the American League, made his first major league start after a three-year absence and four major knee operations. He pitched a three-hit, 1-0 shutout against the Toronto Blue Jays in the spring sunshine that Saturday at Royals Stadium in Kansas City before more than 24,000 screaming fans and a national television audience.

title: ROBINS, A H CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After an extraordinary gain of $8,490,000.

title: COMPUTER SCIENCES CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 28
description: b-Includes $20.5 million in provisions for doubtful accounts receivable and other costs.

title: TEWKSBURY PITCHES YANKEES TO VICTORY
description: When the night was done, Bob Tewksbury had an injured fingernail and slightly bruised feelings. He lost a shutout, but not the game, and his parting shot was a near-brawl with Willie Wilson.

title: BUDGET CHIEF SAYS DEFICIT TARGET CAN BE MET WITHOUT A TAX RISE
description: The budget director said today that the Senate could avoid a tax increase and a sharp cut in the President's military budget by revising some budget estimates and assuming that stronger economic growth would help shrink the 1987 deficit.

title: Florida Schools End Use Of Polygraph Tests
description: The Polk County schools today halted their five-year-old practice of subjecting students to polygraph, or lie-detector, tests in disciplinary cases after a controversy over the use of the tests.

title: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES;
description: Wake County, N.C., is offering $104 million of general obligation public improvement bonds through underwriters led by the First Boston Corporation.

title: GOODY PRODUCTS INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Reflects the results of Opti-Ray Inc., a supplier of sunglasses, acquired in May 1985.

title: IU INTERNATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After an extraordinary tax credit of $3,316,000, or 12 cents a share. c-Net loss and is after a loss from discontinued operations of $4,240,000. The year-earlier quarter results were restated.

title: CITIZENS FIRST BANCORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The per share earnings reflect a 2-for-1 stock split payable June 9.

title: Whitson to Pitch at Stadium
description: Ed Whitson's fears of pitching in Yankee Stadium have not subsided, but today he accepted the chance to return to the Bronx and try again to win the hearts of his critics.

title: BORG-WARNER CORPORATION reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Roast of Cronkite
description: You have less than two weeks to pick up a $1,000 ticket to the fund-raising dinner that will finance the Walter Cronkite Regents Chair in Communications at the Uversity of Texas, of which the former CBS News anchor is an alumnus. The May 6 program at the Mayflower Hotel will be a roast of Mr. Cronkite, and it even has a title: ''No, No, Walter, That's NOT the Way It Is.''

title: Another Easter Egg
description: TO THE LIVING SECTION:

title: MEDITERRANEAN AIRPORTS STEPPING UP SECURITY IN WAKE OF TERRORIST ATTACKS
description: Every half hour or so, maintenance workers empty the ashtrays and trash cans at the international airport here. It is not out of a fetish for cleanliness, but for security. They are looking for bombs.

title: PUGET SOUND POWER & LIGHT CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
O'Grady Is Suspended
description: Mac O'Grady, the pro golfer whose criticisms have rankled the commissioner of the PGA Tour, Deane Beman, was fined $5,000 and suspended for six PGA Tour events yesterday by Beman. The commissioner has been the target of O'Grady's most stinging remarks published in recent newspaper articles, but so have other tour officials, at least one fellow player and one course on the tour.

title: RANDOM HOUSE ACQUIRES RIGHTS TO SHCHARANSKY BOOK
description: Random House has acquired the rights to publish in the United States and Canada the memoir of Anatoly Shcharansky, the Soviet human-rights advocate who was released two months ago after spending nine years in prison and labor camps. Publication is planned for the fall of 1987.

title: GOULD INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes a tax credit of $1.4 million.

title: E-SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes income of $522,000 from discontinued operations.

title: GLENFED INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes a tax loss carryforward of $3,760,000. c-Includes a tax credit of $11,565,000. d-Includes a tax credit of $4,176,000.

title: CLUBS, TOURS AND UPCOMING EVENTS
description: ON Sunday, more than 20,000 cyclists will coast along the Belt Parkway, the Brooklyn-Queens Expressway and F.D.R. Drive, traveling over five bridges and through all five boroughs as they pedal the 36-mile Five Boro Bike Tour. It is the 10th anniversary of the tour, which has more participants than any other bicycle ride in the world, according to Paul Sullivan, program director of American Youth Hostels, which co-sponsors the event with Citibank.

title: MELVILLE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net loss and includes a loss on operations of the discontinued Foxmoor division of $9,646,036 and a gain on the disposal of that division of $646,366.

title: FACING THE 8-BALL
description: The pass was doomed the instant it left John Vanbiesbrouck's stick. Mike Gartner of Washington skated to intercept it as neatly, as clearly, as an arrow on a television diagram. The goal, a quick one-on-one strike, was almost an afterthought.

title: AMCA INTERNATIONAL LTD reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income. There were no share earnings applicable to common stock.

title: WEST GERMANS QUESTION SUSPECT IN DISCO BOMBING
description: The West Berlin police questioned a Jordanian today who has been arrested on suspicion of involvement in the terrorist explosion in a discotheque on April 5, but they reported no major breakthroughs in the case.

title: 60-MINUTE GOURMET
description: I HAVE always felt that certain foods, flavors and textures go together as well and naturally as Lea & Perrins, Moet & Chandon and Currier & Ives. Cooked chicken livers and Madeira wine are like that.

title: 'ALEX: THE LIFE OF A CHILD'
description: ONE of the more unfortunate effects of running a television formula into the ground is that the good tends to be lost amid the mediocre. There are some viewers, for instance, who absolutely refuse to watch another television movie that offers an exercise in uplift connected to what has become disparagingly known as the disease of the week. It is to be hoped that these understandably disgruntled folk will reconsider, at least for a couple of hours, and give a chance to ''Alex: The Life of a Child'' on ABC this evening at 9 o'clock.

title: DREAM IMAGERY OF 'VIENNA: LUSTHAUS'
description: Some of the images are lovely. Infinitely tender in their touch, a beautiful young man and woman caress each other, then sink to the floor to couple with balletic grace. Skaters in plumed hats glide soundlessly through the moonlight; waltzers whirl by to fragments of Johann Strauss. Two slender blond women undress each other, shedding their mannish coats to reveal lacy white petticoats and bloomers; as a harpist in flowing robes plucks a series of liquid, vibrating notes, they are silently joined by other young women, all in frilled white underclothes.

title: CLEVER TREATS FOR EYES
description: 1. Visual Trick This new Italian handbag looks good enough to eat. It is shaped and colored just like a thick, crusty loaf of bread.

title: BALL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 30
description: b-Includes a gain of about $3.3 million, or 14 cents a share, principally from the disposition of the company's investment in PLM AB, a Swedish packaging company.

title: High Hopes Fail
description: With just a few games remaining in the regular season and the Nets' prospects for accomplishing anything significant in the playoffs growing dimmer with the loss of Darryl Dawkins to injury, Bernie Mann, one of the team's principal owners, knew that it would take a drastic measure to fill the void.

title: RIGHTS PANEL LEADERS AT HEARING ASSAIL REPORT OF MISMANAGEMENT
description: Clarence M. Pendleton Jr., chairman of the United States Commission on Civil Rights, said today that a Government audit reporting mismanagement and financial irregularities at the commission was ''unfair, inaccurate and incomplete.''

title: MORE PEOPLE CHOOSE SMALLER HOUSEHOLDS
description: Fewer Americans are forming large families these days, new Census Bureau figures indicate. Between 1980 and 1985 the number of households grew much faster than the population in general, indicating that more people are choosing to live alone or in couples.

title: BINGHAMTON SAVINGS BANK reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes tax credits of $756,000 for the latest quarter and $46,000 for the year-ago period. There were no year-earlier per share figures reported, since the company went public in September 1985.

title: STERLING DRUG INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
HEALTHAMERICA CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Instead, Be Covert
description: Now that we've seen overt military action in Libya, is covert action still such an unpalatable alternative?

title: The Ticking Clock
description: One of the loudest sounds here these days is the ticking of the clock. We hear it in the House of Representatives where Speaker O'Neill is banging his gavel for the last time. And in the White House, where the President laments that he has only three more years to work for ''peace.''

title: Trade Vote Delayed
description: Backers of President Reagan's bid to negotiate a free-trade agreement with Canada failed to gather enough strength today to assure approval but managed to delay a vote in the Senate Finance Committee until Wednesday. Congressional and Administration sources said promises of Administration help in the agriculture, timber and energy sectors could figure in the last-minute bargaining. Wednesday is the legal deadline for action on the request to negotiate an agreement.

title: PRIME COMPUTER INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 30
METS' 5TH STRAIGHT TIES THEM FOR FIRST
description: The Mets rolled on to their fifth straight victory last night when they survived the elements and beat the Pittsburgh Pirates, 7-1, on a muddy track in a steady rain and in a 45-degree chill.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article in the Business People column on April 15 about the impending departure of Roscoe L. Egger Jr. as Commissioner of Internal Revenue misstated the number of commissioners who have been certified public accountants. He was the sixth C.P.A. in the job.

title: DYNALECTRON CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 27
description: b-Includes earnings of $35,000 from discontinued operations.

title: KEY CENTURION BANCSHARES reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
A New Assault On Illegal Honking
description: Yet another sign made its debut on the city's streets yesterday, this one warning ''Don't Honk.'' But city officials admit it will probably be as difficult to enforce as most of the city's noise ordinances.

title: Districts Win Ruling On Passover Closings
description: Three Queens school districts seeking to close schools for the first two days of Passover won an initial victory yesterday in State Supreme Court in Queens.

title: QUERIES MOUNT FOR POLICE CHIEF IN OREGON CITY
description: Late last month Police Chief Penny E. Harrington called a news conference to announce that her husband would not be indicted.

title: BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: CENTRUST SAVINGS BANK reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After extraordinary gains of $16,160,000 for the quarter and $34,666,000 for the 6 months. c-Net loss d-After an extraordinary gain of $1,389,000.

title: MERIDIAN BANCORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Slicing Without Tears
description: WHENEVER I give cooking demonstrations around the country, students in the class ask me how I manage to chop onions and shallots so quickly and evenly. There are two answers, really: 50 years of practice and knowing the proper technique. Random slashing at an onion with a knife will not only yield uneven results - big chunks that cook more slowly than smaller ones - but it will also make your eyes tear. The tears are triggered by crushing the onion rather than slicing it. Crushing releases volatile substances in the cells that combine to form sulfuric acid. Using a sharp 10-inch chef's knife properly will minimize tearing.

title: The Bitter Harvest Of Pornography
description: To the Editor:

title: Tadeusz Jan Wiktor, 65, Dies; Devised Anti-Rabies Vaccine
description: Tadeusz Jan Wiktor, a research scientist at the Wistar Institute of Anatomy and Biology in Philadelphia and an authority on rabies, died in his sleep Sunday at his home in Wynnewood, Pa. He was 65 years old. Dr. Wiktor began his 25-year association with Wistar, the nation's first independent institution devoted to biomedical research, in 1961.

title: Profits Scoreboard
description: See accompanying notes for special items.(Loss) * Loss in year-earlier period.

title: BIG CITY BICYCLING: NEW YORK ON A ROLL
description: NEW YORK CITY American Youth Hostels, 75 Spring Street, New York, N.Y. 10012. Telephone: 212-431-7100. Annual membership $20 adult, $10 teen-agers, $30 family. Two- to four-day trips leave every weekend, year-round. Weekend trips April through

title: HIGH COURT REJECTS SWEETENER REVIEW
description: The Supreme Court refused this week to look into the way the Federal Government approved public use of the sweetener aspartame, despite critics' arguments that the product, sold under the brand name NutraSweet, may cause brain damage.

title: WALDHEIM'S SON SEEKS TO COUNTER A 'MANHUNT'
description: So determined was Gerhard Waldheim to defend the reputation of his father, Kurt Waldheim, the former Secretary General, that two weeks ago he took an unpaid leave from a Vienna banking job to come to the United States.

title: CONSOLIDATED EDISON CO OF NY INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
FIRST MISSISSIPPI CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income c-Includes a gain from discontinued operations of $900,000.

title: OLD STONE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After tax credits of $250,000 for the latest quarter and $388,000 for the year-earlier period.

title: Advertising; Brainreserve Shifts
description: Faith Popcorn, 40 years old, a founder of the Brainreserve agency, has stepped up to chairman to make room for a newcomer, Peter J. Flatow, 41, long a package goods man on the client side, to take over as president and chief operating officer. He has come in from Bristol-Myers, where he was director of corporate development. He also worked for the company's Drackett Company and before that experience he was with Lever Brothers, American Can and Johnson & Johnson.

title: U.S. Rebukes Thailand Over U.N. Libya Vote
description: The Reagan Administration sharply rebuked Thailand today for backing a United Nations Security Council resolution that condemned the United States air raid on Libya last week.

title: MOBIL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
50-YEAR-OLD CO-OP IS STILL EXPANDING WHILE OTHERS FAIL
description: IF the Hanover Consumer Cooperative Society's Food Store needs living proof of its 50th anniversary, there are still some of the 17 original members - Betty Dankert, 84 years old, and Herbert and Mimi Sensenig, 79 and 75 - who have personally eaten through a large slice of American consumer history.

title: FIRST LIBERTY FINANCIAL reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Turkey's Turn to Protest
description: Turkey is outraged, and rightly, by Bulgaria's refusal even to acknowledge its dreadful abuse of an ethnic minority. As The Times's Henry Kamm reports from Sofia, a campaign is under way to destroy the cultural identity of one million ethnic Turks in a Communist country of nine million. Turkish-speakers are forced to change their names; Turkish-language publications and broadcasts have been silenced. According to Amnesty International, more than 100 ethnic Turks have been killed and hundreds more arrested.

title: Celtics Sweep; 19 for Jordan
description: Kevin McHale scored 31 points to lead a balanced Boston attack tonight, and the Celtics hammered the Chicago Bulls, 122-104, for a three-game sweep of their playoff series.

title: BALLET: JOFFREY 'ROMEO'
description: A NEW cast of star-crossed lovers danced ''Romeo and Juliet'' on Sunday afternoon when the Joffrey Ballet presented John Cranko's choreographic adaptation of Shakespeare's play at the New York State Theater.

title: CAPITOL BANCORPORATION reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
GENERAL MOTORS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
GEORGE BREITMAN
description: George Breitman, a leader of the American Trotskyist movement who edited many of the writings of Malcolm X, died of a heart attack Saturday at Beekman Downtown Hospital. He was 70 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: HEALTH WORKERS CONSTITUTED MAJORITY OF HYFIN DEPOSITORS
description: Hospital and health-service workers make up the majority of depositors in the Hyfin Credit Union, which is at the center of allegations against Jay L. Turoff, the city's former taxi chief.

title: KANSAS CITY POWER & LIGHT CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
CINCINNATI MILACRON INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
CURTISS-WRIGHT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
DR. GEORGE E. BURCH, TULANE CARDIOLOGIST, DIES IN NEW ORLEANS
description: Dr. George E. Burch, an internationally known cardiologist, died April 15 at his home in New Orleans after a brief illness. He was 76 years old.

title: BUCKS WIPE OUT 18-POINT DEFICIT AND NETS IN SWEEP
description: Perhaps it was better this way. After a stunning 24 minutes of basketball in which they established a franchise record for points scored in a playoff-game half and built a surprising 18-point lead against the formidable Milwaukee Bucks, the Nets looked to be well on their way toward winning tonight's game and extending their opening-round playoff series.

title: Drexel Names Senior Officer
description: Samuel E. Hunter, who resigned three weeks ago as vice chairman of Merrill Lynch Capital Markets, the investment banking subsidiary of Merrill Lynch & Company, will join Drexel Burnham Lambert as a senior vice president in charge of the firm's equity trading departments, Drexel said yesterday.

title: RECITAL: ART OF KAYAGUM FROM KOREA
description: BYUNG KI HWANG, one of the foremost interpreters of the kayagum, a 12-stringed Korean zither with strings made of twisted silk fiber, is the first composer to have written ''modern'' music on an instrument that dates back some 1,400 years. And on Sunday afternoon at Carnegie Recital Hall, Mr. Hwang, accompanied by Sang Won Park on the changgu (an hourglass drum), performed a program that contrasted his own original descriptive pieces with formal traditional kayagum music.

title: CUOMO AIMS SHARP ATTACK AT REAGAN
description: Asserting that increased despair among the poor ''is threatening the tranquillity of the whole nation,'' Governor Cuomo today attacked the social policies of the Reagan Administration and said they had led to a ''growing division'' between rich and poor.

title: CHRYSLER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Share earnings reflect a 3-for-2 stock split in February 1986.

title: Whither Laxalt?
description: A question asked with increasing frequency these days in political Washington is: Is Senator Paul Laxalt of Nevada, President Reagan's closest friend in Congress, seriously contemplating seeking the 1988 Republican nomination for President? Columnists are mulling the possibility, and client-hungry campaign consultants are openly promoting it.

title: REAGAN SAYS SANDINISTAS SEEK TO 'BUILD A LIBYA'
description: President Reagan said tonight that the Nicaraguan Government was seeking to ''build a Libya on our doorstep.''

title: Why Shuttle Will Carry Military Satellites
description: To the Editor:

title: BIG THREE INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
BARNES GROUP INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes income from discontinued operations.

title: CONVICTION IN COLLAPSE OF CRANE
description: A construction foreman was convicted yesterday of charges stemming from the collapse of a 35-ton crane that crushed the legs of a pedestrian last May.

title: U.S. Petroleum Data
description: In millions of barrels except refinery utilization

title: PUERTO RICAN PARADE CHECKED
description: State Attorney General Robert Abrams is investigating allegations of irregularities in the organization and financing of the Puerto Rican Day Parade, a spokesman said yesterday.

title: Journal Ads Ruled Taxable
description: The Supreme Court ruled unanimously today, in a case of importance to professional and scholarly journals, that a tax-exempt medical organization must pay taxes on profits it earns from selling advertisments in its monthly journal.

title: BRITISH AIR'S MOVE TO THE BULOVA BUILDING IN QUEENS
description: The city's efforts to encourage office development in Queens got a boost recently when British Airways agreed to move its American headquarters from Manhattan to a new office facility being carved out of the former Bulova Watch Corporation building in Jackson Heights.

title: Advertising; Feminine Touch for Ad Agency
description: WHEN they were getting together the press kit that would announce their new ad agency, the folks behind Lotas Minard Patton McIver Inc. figured out that so far in their careers in the big time they have made advertising for at least 150 different products and services.

title: U.S. TESTS 3d BOMB IN MONTH
description: A nuclear device nearly 12 times as powerful as the Hiroshima bomb was detonated in the Nevada desert today.

title: DIAMOND SHAMROCK CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income

title: The Caribbean Source
description: TO THE LIVING SECTION:

title: Afghan Rebel Base Reported Encircled
description: Thousands of Soviet and Afghan soldiers were reported today to have surrounded a key Moslem rebel base in southeastern Afghanistan. Rebel commanders said they lost scores of men to air raids and artillery fire.

title: Atoms Club Out of Penn
description: The Atoms Track Club of New York has withdrawn from this week's Penn Relays, contending that the track and field classic has discriminated against women by cutting back on the number of events for clubs.

title: JAZZ: TRUMPETERS SALUTE ELDRIDGE
description: THE ''Generations of Jazz'' series brought trumpeters to the Village Gate on Sunday - Clark Terry, Randy Brecker, Michael Mossman and Johnny Carisi, along with a speech by the trumpeter Roy (Little Jazz) Eldridge. The series, designed to expose new jazz talent alongside well-known players, is sponsored by the New York local of the American Federation of Musicians; between sets, the union awarded Mr. Eldridge a well-deserved plaque for lifetime achievement. ''I'm glad I kept my dues up,'' he said.

title: U.S. REMOVES CURB ON ALTERED VIRUS
description: The Department of Agriculture, concluding that there was virtually no danger to humans or the environment, today lifted a two-week suspension on the sale of a living, genetically altered virus as a vaccine to combat a swine disease.

title: Marietta Net Up 66.2%
description: The Martin Marietta Corporation, benefiting from a restructuring program, said yesterday that first-quarter earnings soared 66.2 percent, to $46.2 million, or 84 cents a share, from $27.8 million, or 47 cents a share, a year earlier. Martin Marietta, a leading aerospace contractor based in Bethesda, Md., said that sales rose 6.9 percent, to $1.08 billion, from $1.01 billion in the 1985 quarter.

title: Topics; Liberations; Old Friends
description: This week, 64-year-old Clara Cohen will leave South Shore Manor retirement home in Brooklyn to spend Passover in the Berkshires - with friends she met a year ago at summer camp. ''I was not aware there were such things as senior citizen camps,'' Miss Cohen said.

title: MAYOR QUALIFIES HIS STANCE ON FORFEITING CONTRIBUTIONS
description: Mayor Koch, who announced recently that he would forfeit political contributions from people indicted for ''ripping off the city,'' yesterday backed away from his pledge.

title: DOW SLUMPS 24.92 ON PROFIT TAKING
description: A severe bout of profit taking on Wall Street yesterday sent stock prices down sharply in heavy trading.

title: N.H.L. Playoffs; Flames Top Oilers, Lead Series by 2-1
description: Joel Otto scored at 7 minutes 32 seconds of the final period tonight to give Calgary a 3-2 triumph over the Edmonton Oilers. The Flames took a two-games-to-one lead in the four-of-seven-game Smythe Division final series.

title: Comings and Goings
description: Fred Hobdy has stepped down as basketball coach at Grambling State University after 30 years to take a full-time job as the school's assistant director of athletics under Eddie Robinson. . . . Pete Rose, the player-manager of the Reds, said he would probably take himself off the team's injury list to make his 1986 playing debut this weekend in Houston.

title: Quadriplegic Loses Plea To Retain Morphine
description: A state appeals court today rejected an emergency request by Elizabeth Bouvia, a quadriplegic, for an order barring doctors from taking her off morphine, which eases her pain.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: WEDNESDAY, APRIL 23, 1986
description: The Economy

title: CORRECTION
description: Because of an editing error, an article in Sports Pages yesterday about the United States Football League's antitrust suit against the National Football League described a motion incorrectly.

title: AGGRESSIVE PROSECUTOR: REENA ANDREA RAGGI
description: In the month since she became United States Attorney for the Eastern District in Brooklyn, Reena Raggi has taken the complicated findings of a yearlong inquiry by the State Department of Investigation and got a guilty plea from a key suspect.

title: The Lonely Eye in Space
description: A vital part of America's spy satellite system has probably been put at risk by the Titan missile launch failure last Friday. The disaster leaves only one photo-reconnaissance satellite in orbit. Should it fail, no immediate replacement is available and no means of launching one anyway. The United States must now view the closed world of the Soviet Union through but a single keyhole.

title: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES;
description: The Jacksonville Electric Authority of Florida is tentatively offering $450 million of refunding revenue bonds with a maximum yield of 7.583 percent for an issue due in 2014 through underwriters led by Shearson Lehman Brothers Inc.

title: THEATER: 'ORCHARDS,' 7 ONE-ACTS
description: SEEKING to expand its repertory, the Acting Company had the enterprising idea of commissioning a number of American playwrights to write their theatrical versions of Chekhov short stories. The result, seven short plays grouped under the title of ''Orchards,'' opened last night at the Lucille Lortel Theater. The most successful are the most Chekhovian (plays by Wendy Wasserstein and David Mamet) and one, a monologue by Spalding Gray, that totally disregards its source. It is the middle ground of ''loosely'' and ''freely'' that leads others astray. All seven are under the direction of Robert Falls. As intended, ''Orchards'' is a showcase for talented young actors.

title: Parker Defended
description: Chuck Tanner, who was Dave Parker's manager when both were with the Pirates, said he would defend Parker against the Pirates' charges that his past use of cocaine affected his performance.

title: MILD QUAKE STARTLES WESTCHESTER
description: A mild earthquake rumbled across lower Westchester County early today, startling residents but apparently causing no damage or injuries.

title: EASTERN UTILITIES ASSOCIATES reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
NBC Giving Old Shows To Library of Congress
description: NBC will donate its entire collection of television programs, including such classics as ''Howdy Doody'' and ''The Steve Allen Show,'' to the Library of Congress, the network's chairman, Grant Tinker, said this week.

title: COCA-COLA BOTTLING CO CONSOLIDATED reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes a gain of $3,537,000, or 55 cents a share, from the sale of Waycross-Douglas Coca-Cola Bottling Co. and McRae Coca-Cola Bottling Co. c-Includes net from discontinued operations of $72,000.

title: PLEA BARGAINS BIG HELP IN EASING THE CASELOADS
description: Three defendants indicted by state or Federal grand juries in the city's corruption scandal have taken an option with a long and controversial history -the plea bargain.

title: FREEPORT-MCMORAN ENERGY reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes a non-cash charge of $318,774,000 from the writedown of oil and gas assets. The company said year-ago results are not available because the partnership was formed in April 1985.

title: CORRECTION
description: A report in the Going Out Guide yesterday carried an outdated opening date for the exhibition ''Realism From the People's Republic of China'' at the Grand Central Art Galleries. The exhibition did not open yesterday; it has been rescheduled to begin May 15.

title: Williams to Go Pro
description: John Williams, the sophomore forward who led Louisiana State to the National Collegiate Athletic Association Final Four, is giving up two years of eligibility to seek a professional basketball career. ''I'm doing today one of the most painful things I ever did in my life,'' Williams told reporters in Baton Rouge, La.

title: UNITED BANCSHARES OF ARKANAS reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Whither Wick?
description: The capital is alive with speculation these days over how far former Government officials who are now in private business can go toward using their old Administration contacts without being accused of unethical or even illegal conduct.

title: GIBSON IS INJURED AS TIGERS LOSE, 6-4
description: Don Baylor, Rich Gedman and Tony Armas hit home runs off Jack Morris in the first five innings to lead the Boston Red Sox to a 6-4 victory over the Detroit Tigers tonight.

title: Sears Mortgage
description: Sears, Roebuck & Company announced a new thrust into the mortgage loan business, called the Sears Mortgage Corporation. Edward A. Brennan, chairman and chief executive of Sears, which handles a portfolio of 125,000 mortgages worth $6.5 billion, said he hoped the company would originate $3 billion in mortgages this year. The new unit was formed by consolidating the mortgage operations of Dean Witter Reynolds Inc., the Allstate Insurance Company and the Sears Savings Bank of California.

title: BBDO INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
New Manville Plan
description: The Manville Corporation said yesterday that it had made several changes in its previously filed plan for reorganization that benefit commercial creditors at the expense of shareholders.

title: ALEKSEI ARBUZOV, PLAYWRIGHT, DIES
description: Aleksei Arbuzov, a Soviet playwright whose work has been produced in the United States, died Sunday, the Soviet press reported in Moscow yesterday. He was 77 years old. One of the Soviet Union's most popular playwrights since the late 1930's, Mr. Arbuzov found acceptance in London, on Broadway and in American provincial theaters with his depiction of searching, dreaming young people and their personal relations, eschewing the traditional girl-meets-tractor approach of Socialist Realism.

title: No Supercows Needed
description: To the Editor:

title: COMPUGRAPHIC CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Hit by Coin, Peeters Says
description: Pete Peeters, the Washington goaltender, says he was struck in the eye by a flying quarter thrown from the stands at Madison Square Garden Monday night during the Capitals' 6-3 victory over the Rangers.

title: HELP IN FILLING OUT IRISH FAMILY TREES
description: ON May 18, 1850, the wife of Michael Quin placed an advertisement in The Boston Pilot asking anyone with information about her husband, whom she had not seen since the previous January, to contact her through the newspaper's office.

title: SAFETY TIPS FOR PEDALERS
description: LAURENCE REILLY, bicycle coordinator for the Department of Transportation in New York, says all cyclists riding in the city should wear protective hardshell helmets. Mr. Reilly should know; he was in a bicycle accident with a taxi cab several years ago and says, ''I am alive today because I was wearing a helmet.''

title: IT'S CALLED MEXICAN, BUT IS IT GENUINE?
description: THINK of Mexican food and what comes to mind? ''We'll have two chicken tacos, a beef enchilada, a couple of chimichangas and a side of refried beans, please. And some nachos and a little guacamole to start. Oh, and a frozen margarita - blue, if it comes that way. Make that one blue margarita and one strawberry. And hold the salt.''

title: Publisher Makes Initial Offering
description: The Western Publishing Group, a New York-based company specializing in children's coloring and story books, began the initial public offering yesterday of 10.08 million common shares at a price of $20 a share through underwriters led by Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc.

title: MET OPERA'S PRODUCTION OF 'FIGARO
description: THE Metropolitan Opera's recent production of Mozart's ''Nozze di Figaro'' combined some spectacular singing with the dingy production, sets and costumes of Jean-Pierre Ponnelle. In the opera house, Mr. Ponnelle's gigantic classical pillars and stylized decadence served to dwarf Mozart's human drama, frostily rebuffing the spectator's engagement. However, the ''Live From the Met'' telecast (which, despite the series title, was taped last December and will be shown on Channel 13 tonight at 8) should not be missed: on television, with the benefit of close, fluent camera work instead of the fixed long-shot a seat at the opera house inevitably provides, this ''Figaro'' captures for posterity one of the Metropolitan's finest recent moments, complete with English subtitles.

title: Gromyko Misses Fete; Reported Ill With Flu
description: President Andrei A. Gromyko missed a Lenin's Birthday gathering in the Kremlin today, a week after he was reported ill with influenza.

title: CORRECTION
description: The Executive Changes column in Business Day on April 14 misidentified the company that named Everett C. Reed as a director. It was Mohawk Paper Mills Inc. of Cohoes, N.Y.

title: Paper Rates Rise At Citicorp Sale
description: At Citicorp's regular weekly auction of commercial paper yesterday, rates rose for the first time in five weeks.

title: METROPOLITAN DIARY
description: FOR Morris Hochberg, now of Southbury, Conn., it felt both strange and wonderful to return for a visit to the Brooklyn neighborhood where he grew up some 40 or 50 years ago. The sights were, of course, mostly unfamiliar. Somehow, though, Mr. Hochberg felt he had walked these streets only yesterday.

title: COMMON OPERATION ON CHILDREN DEBATED
description: THE most common operation being performed on children today is the insertion of tubes into the ears to combat the effects of middle-ear infections. There is now growing concern over its effectiveness and controversy over when it is appropriate, with few good studies to support the arguments of either side. The situation is likely to worsen as more schools screen children for middle-ear problems and, finding them, recommend medical treatment.

title: GOULDS PUMPS INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Twyla Tharp Benefit
description: The Twyla Tharp dance troupe will present a benefit performance and party for the company on Sunday at 5 P.M. at the Palladium, 126 East 14th Street.

title: RORER GROUP INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After a gain on the sale of businesses of $139,527,000, or $6.44 a share. c-After income from discontinued operations of $1,621,000, or 8 cents a share.

title: FOR FIBER, EASY MUFFINS
description: ON the surface of it, the muffin mania that has swept New York and other cities in recent years looks like a boon for fiber lovers. Stacked up on food-shop counters, apparently the epitome of old-fashioned, home-baked goodness, muffins have an irresistible appeal. Alas, far too many are full of fat, sugar and refined flours. Moreover, they have a bland, cakelike texture - chocolate-chip varieties included - that is the antithesis of a true muffin.

title: GRAND TIME FOR THE WHALERS
description: Even for them, the players who had worked and plotted and endured pain to do it, what happened this month was tinged with surprise.

title: BRIGGS & STRATTON CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Leaders All Quit In a Black Township
description: The last four town councilors in the black township of Alexandra resigned today, saying their hopes for rebuilding the community had been shattered by anti-apartheid violence.

title: OF RETIRMENT, MORALE AND THE SENIOR DIPLOMAT
description: For years, senior American diplomats have regarded themselves as somewhat like university professors whose expertise only improved with age. But now, as part of a new law designed to streamline the Foreign Service, the diplomats are being treated like military officers who, if passed over for promotion, are forced to retire years ahead of when they planned.

title: ROCK: BRIAN SETZER
description: BRIAN SETZER, who led the rockabilly-styled Stray Cats until 1984, is now trying to leap from the 1950's to the 1970's. At the Beacon Theater on Friday, leading the five-man band Radiation Ranch, Mr. Setzer introduced his latest material - earnest tales of outcasts and romantic losers, with folk-rock guitar lines.

title: LOCAL AIRPORTS LOSING TRAFFIC
description: The New York-New Jersey region's share of American trans-Atlantic air passenger traffic dropped to 60 from 75 percent last year, a Port Authority panel said yesterday. The panel called for action to keep the region's pre-eminence from slipping.

title: ALLEN GROUP INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes a provision for credit losses of $1.8 million, or 19 cents a share.

title: I.B.M.'S 84 RETAIL STORES ARE ACQUIRED BY NYNEX
description: The Nynex Corporation yesterday propelled itself into the ranks of the largest personal computer retailers, acquiring all 84 of the International Business Machines Corporation's Product Centers in a surprise move that suddenly dealt I.B.M. out of showroom sales of its own equipment.

title: FOOD NOTES
description: A Taste of Luxury The sign over the morels at Fairway says, ''If you have to ask what to do with them, don't buy them.'' At $6.99 a quarter-pound, that's good advice. But if the mere thought of fresh morels sauteed on toast induces rapture, now is the time to savage the food budget and indulge. They are available not only at Fairway Fruits and Vegetables, 2125 Broadway (74th Street), but also at Balducci's, 424 Avenue of the Americas (Ninth Street), which has them for $24 a pound; Dean & DeLuca, 121 Prince Street (at Greene Street) for $25 a pound; Paradise Market, 1000 Madison Avenue (83d Street) for $7.99 a quarter-pound; Grace Balducci's, 1241 Third Avenue (71st Street) for $30 a pound, and Flying Foods, 43-43 Ninth Street, Long Island City (Fridays and Saturdays only, 10 A.M. to 3 P.M.) for $15 a pound. As supplies improve, prices are likely to decrease.

title: COLORADO NATIONAL BANKSHARES INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The net for 1985 is restated for pooling of interest acquisition.

title: GIFFORD-HILL & CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes a tax credit of $900,000. c-Net loss includes a loss from discontinued operations of $1,806,000.

title: RUSSIAN TESTIFIES SHE WAS INTIMATE WITH 2D AGENT
description: A Russian emigre who pleaded guilty to spying testified today at the espionage trial of a former agent of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, Richard W. Miller, that she also had a relationship with another bureau agent that was personal and sexual in nature.

title: Olivetti to Acquire Triumph-Adler
description: Ing. C. Olivetti & Compagnia, the Italian computer and office machine manufacturer, said that it had agreed to acquire the 98.4 percent stake in Triumph-Adler A.G., the unprofitable maker of personal computers and other office equipment, now held by Volkswagen A.G., the West German auto maker.

title: 17 ARE CHARGED IN A PLOT TO SELL WEAPONS TO IRAN
description: Federal authorities charged 17 suspects yesterday with plotting to sell more than $2 billion in American-made weapons to Iran, including fighter planes, tanks, missiles and other sophisticated armaments.

title: COMMUNITY BANK SYSTEM reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
EX-AIDE CRITICIZES U.S. ON A DRILL AT SHOREHAM
description: A Federal official who resigned in protest of a report on an emergency evacuation drill at the Shoreham nuclear power plant said today that the Administration had put pressures on his former agency to allow the plant to open.

title: PROFITS FALL AT CHRYSLER AND G.M.
description: The General Motors Corporation and the Chrysler Corporation today reported earnings declines for the first quarter that were generally in line with analyst's expectations.

title: DEXTER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes a pre-tax gain of $2.4 million from the sale of Puritan-Churchill Sanitation Chemicals business, and a pre-tax gain of $1 million from the sale of the former headquarters of Howe & Brainbridge. These were offset by a pre-tax charge of $4.4 million associated with restructuring.

title: WEDNESDAY SPORTS
description: Baseball Yankees vs. Royals, at Kansas City, 8:35 P.M. The final game of the three-game series, after which the Yanks return home for 10 games in 11 days beginning with the Cleveland Indians tomorrow.

title: SHAMROCK HAS DEFICIT
description: The Mobil Corporation, the nation's second-largest oil company after the Exxon Corporation, reported yesterday that its profits increased 37.5 percent over the first quarter of 1985.

title: Economic Scene; Need for U.S. Leadership
description: THE annual economic summit conferences of the seven major industrial democracies -the United States, Japan, West Germany, France, Britain, Italy and Canada - have increasingly been dominated by political events.

title: Advertising; Stock Trading Halted For Doyle Dane Group
description: Over-the-counter trading in Doyle Dane Bernbach Group stock was suspended yesterday after a morning flurry sent prices up 5 points, to 28 1/4.

title: RANGERS PONDER NEW APPROACHES
description: They came away from the Philadelphia experience with a new self-image and suddenly a vision. These Rangers, John Vanbiesbrouck had said, could challenge to the very end. These Rangers, Mike Ridley had said, were a different group from the one that went slipsliding through the regular season. These Rangers had a chance to be famous, they said.

title: Bridge: A Top Partnership Draws Attention to Accord, N.Y.
description: For half a century it has been accepted that the best New York partnerships rank high in the country and in the world.

title: FRENCH SAY THEY FAVORED STRONGER ATTACK ON LIBYA
description: French officials, confirming a statement Monday by President Reagan, said today that the Government had favored a more ambitious and hard-hitting action against Libya than the one carried out last week by the United States.

title: TRUSTCOMPANY BANCORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
REAGAN URGES END OF OIL TAX
description: President Reagan today urged Congress to repeal the ''windfall profits'' tax on the nation's oil industry, saying that ''no significant'' revenue is currently being provided to the Treasury under the 1980 law.

title: TALES AND LEGENDS OF ALL-NIGHT CLUBS
description: Maybe the best story of 52d Street is the one about Robert Benchley, blotto, and the elephants he thought he saw marching past the ''21'' Club. They did march past ''21.''

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: BEAUTY SPOT The industrial environs of Long Island City, in Queens, are like an oyster that is hiding a pearl. The pearl is the Isamu Noguchi Garden Museum, near the East River at 32-27 Vernon Boulevard, at 33d Road.

title: CHARLES K. WILKINSON
description: Charles K. Wilkinson, curator emeritus of Near Eastern art at the Metropolitan Museum of Art, died of a heart attack Friday at his home in Sharon, Conn. He was 88 years old.

title: CONSULT CONGRESS
description: Military retaliation against Libya for its support of terrorism has proved immensely popular. It may even be effective in deterring future terrorist attacks, although I doubt it. But the air strike, as carried out by President Reagan and his advisers without Congressional consultation or approval, almost certainly was an unconstitutional usurpation of the war-making power.

title: CENTRONICS DATA COMPUTER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 30
description: b-Net loss

title: ZENITH ELECTRONICS CORPORATION OF INDIANA reports earnings for Qtr to April 5
description: b-Net income. c-Restated to reflect the results of Inteq Inc., acquired May 30, 1985, and accounted for as a pooling interest.

title: ECONOMICS LABORATORY INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
OPERA: TWO BY MENOTTI AND DAVIES
description: A PAIR of 45-minute children's operas was mounted with spirit Sunday afternoon by the Preparatory Division of the Manhattan School of Music. ''Chip and his Dog,'' by Gian Carlo Menotti, drips with sentimental condescension to the future citizenry of the world; ''The Rainbow,'' by Peter Maxwell Davies, is subtler and engaging at times, but neither really hits the mark.

title: WINE TALK
description: THERE'S Nov. 15 and there's April 15, and in this context, at least, neither has anything to do with taxes. They are, more or less, the two dates on which a vintage of Beaujolais is introduced.

title: HOUSE QUIETLY VOTES TO RAISE ITS LIMITS ON OUTSIDE INCOME
description: Without advance notice or debate, members of the House of Representatives today voted a $7,510 increase in the limit on their outside earnings.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: THE GOOD MOTHER. By Sue Miller. 310 pages. Harper & Row. $17.95. A QUICK summary of the plot of ''The Good Mother'' tends to sound like a standard soap-opera scenario: woman gets divorced, woman meets new man in Laundromat, woman becomes involved in hot new romance, woman's 4-year-old daughter accuses woman's lover of sexual harassment, woman's ex-husband sues for custody, woman agonizes over relationship with lover, woman goes to court in effort to regain custody of daughter. In the course of these events, there are lots of steamy sex scenes, lots of melodramatic arguments and lots of painful goodbyes.

title: CONSUMER PRICES OFF 0.4% IN MARCH FOR SECOND MONTH
description: Paced by a record 12 percent drop in the price of fell in March for the second consecutive month, the Labor Department reported today.

title: 12 Are Entered For Blue Grass
description: A suprisingly large field of 12 3-year-olds, nearly all of them under consideration for the 112th Kentucky Derby on May 3, was entered today for the $239,600 Blue Grass Stakes at Keeneland Thursday.

title: BIO-LOGIC SYSTEMS CORP reports earnings for Year to Feb 28
description: b-Includes gains from tax credits of $77,000 for the latest year and $3,600 for the previous year. Figures are corrected from Saturday's editions.

title: GULF CANADA CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes gains of $19 million from discontinued operations and $133 million from the sale of assets. c-Includes a gain of $45 million from discontinued operations.

title: FIAT OWNERS SEEK LIBYA'S BIG STAKE
description: The Italian owners of Fiat S.p.A. have offered to buy back the large minority share that Libya owns in the company, a Fiat spokesman said today.

title: CAROLINA POWER & LIGHT CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
The Evolution of a Jitney
description: For the exterior, Roy Lichtenstein painted a pop art design.

title: Key Rates
description: * Municipal Bond Index, The Bond BuyerSalomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: Market Place; Steelmakers With a Niche
description: WHILE large, integrated steel producers like United States Steel, Bethlehem Steel and Armco have faced severe problems and red ink in recent years, fortune has smiled upon smaller, selected companies within the same industry. These are the nonintegrated producers, fabricators and distributors.

title: MARTIN MARIETTA CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
VELELLA WINS STATE SENATE RACE
description: Guy V. Velella, a former Republican member of the State Assembly, was elected to the State Senate yesterday, to fill the seat of Senator John D. Calandra, a Republican, who died Jan. 20.

title: MUSIC: SERKIN, LEVINE AND ST. LUKE'S
description: TWO exceptional musicians crossed paths Sunday night, each at a different point in his life. One was James Levine, who conducted the Orchestra of St. Luke's in an all-Beethoven program at the Metropolitan Museum. The other was Rudolf Serkin, the soloist in the composer's C minor Piano Concerto.

title: CULLUM COMPANIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 5
Jersey Utility In 2 Offerings
description: The Public Service Electric and Gas Company, a New Jersey utility, is selling $450 million of 10-year and 30-year first-mortgage bonds in two separate offerings.

title: They All Do It
description: Afterward, I imagine, Colonel Qaddafi will write a book explaining how it all went wrong, as David Stockman has just done.

title: MONOSODUIM GLUTAMATE STILL A MYSTERY
description: FOOD companies and not a few restaurant chefs swear by it, though seldom openly.

title: Nine Receive Awards For Off Off Broadway
description: Seven actors and actresses and two playwrights received Jean Dalrymple Awards for Off Off Broadway performances last night at a dinner benefit at Regine's for the American Theater of Actors.

title: DRAVO CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
DOLLAR IN BROAD RETREAT; NO INTERVENTION SEEN
description: The dollar retreated yesterday on speculation that central banks would make no immediate concerted effort to prop up the dollar.

title: MACMILLAN INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The latest quarter loss includes a pre-tax gain of $3.7 million on the sale of joint ventures.

title: Poles Study 4th Amnesty For Political Prisoners
description: The Government spokesman said today that Polish political prisoners could soon be freed in what would be the fourth amnesty in four years.

title: MCDONALD'S CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
WATCH ON LIBYANS STEPPED UP IN U.S.
description: The Reagan Administration is tightening surveillance of Libyans living in the United States, Federal officials said today.

title: NASA WASTED BILLIONS, FEDERAL AUDITS DISCLOSE
description: The space agency and its contractors have wasted billions of dollars on the shuttle and other space programs despite warning after warning by Government inspectors that such heavy losses were occurring through bad management, Federal audits show.

title: Officer Who Shot Man Put on Modified Duty
description: A police officer who fatally shot an unarmed man during a struggle Monday night was placed on modified assignment yesterday and had his gun taken away, the police said.

title: AMPCO-PITTSBURGH CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net loss

title: BALLY'S PARK PLACE INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
MORRISON KNUDSEN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
3 Hostage Guards Freed From Indiana Prison
description: Assault teams hurling concussion grenades and firing plastic bullets stormed a cell block at the Indiana State Prison today and freed three guards held by convicts in the second uprising in six weeks.

title: Vilas Returns And Is Beaten
description: Guillermo Vilas of Argentina, a former champion and playing in his first tennis tournament in seven months, lost his first-round match at the $325,000 Volvo Monte Carlo Open today to Marian Vajda of Czechoslovakia, 1-6, 7-5, 6-4.

title: Budd Future in Doubt
description: Zola Budd, the South African-born runner, may not be allowed to compete for England in the Commonwealth Games in Edinburgh this summer.

title: Title for Tillman
description: Henry Tillman, an Olympic gold medalist, stopped Bash Alli at 1 minute 25 seconds of the first round tonight to capture the North American Boxing Federation cruiserweight title.

title: Prince Edward Island Votes the Tories Out
description: Voters in Canada's smallest province have ended seven years of rule by the Conservatives in favor of a new Liberal government, the third provincial Liberal victory in the country in a year.

title: STOCK TRADING LINK SPANS THE ATLANTIC
description: In Columbus, Ohio, Robert Lentz is delighted that the London Stock Exchange and the National Association of Securities Dealers Inc. began a trans-Atlantic link today.

title: TO JOHNSON, LANGUAGE IS MELODY
description: ''Y OU know who's in New York? Remember that guy - John somebody?''

title: COURT UPSETS ALABAMA AWARD AS TAINTED BY JUDGE
description: The Supreme Court ruled 8 to 0 today that a justice of the Alabama Supreme Court violated due process of law when he cast the deciding vote in a decision in which he had a ''substantial'' financial interest.

title: BELL INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
A DARKENED CANYON OF TOWERING OFFICES
description: If there is anywhere that midtown Manhattan is going, 52d Street is already there. It has become what real-estate developers celebrate, but many other people fear - a part of town with nothing but skyscrapers, tall buildings set cheek-by-jowl from one block to the next.

title: DIVING-SAFETY TIPS STRESS AWARENESS
description: As many as 300 Americans, most of them young men, sustain serious injuries each year from diving accidents, according to a study by Dr. Milton Gabrielsen of Nova University in Fort Lauderdale, Fla. Because these accidents often involve neck and spinal damage they can result in lifetime crippling.

title: Third-World Diet
description: TO THE LIVING SECTION:

title: Richard Moores Dies at 77; Drew 'Gasoline Alley' Strip
description: Richard Moores, author and artist of the syndicated comic strip ''Gasoline Alley,'' died today at a hospital here. He was 77 years old. Mr. Moores took over production of the comic strip, whose charcters include Walt, Skeezix, Nina, Slim, Clovia, Joel and Rufus, after its creator, Frank King, died in 1960.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: WEDNESDAY, APRIL 23, 1986
description: International Britain will expel 21 Libyan students for suspected involvement in ''student revolutionary activities.'' The 21, all men, were arrested in England, Wales and Scotland. They include a pilot trainee who, the authorities said, telephoned Tripoli radio last month with an offer to form suicide squads to attack American military installations. [ Page A1, Columns 3-4. ]

title: NEWSPAPERS TOLD OF STRONG PROFITS
description: With newspaper profits strong and thought likely to remain so in 1986, North America's newspaper publishers ended their convention here today expressing confidence that they were in a business with a strong future.

title: MBI BUSINESS CENTERS reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: The fourth quarter and year results were restated to reflect the company's purchase of Micro South Corp. on April 1.

title: THE MELTING POT BUBBLES IN REGO PARK
description: Roll call, the teachers agree, is the most difficult part of the day: Ho Suk Ping He, Yana Katzap, Tkkun Amongi, Azaria Badebr, Rotcheild Boruhov, Eduardo Yun.

title: COORS, ADOLPH CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
ALTOS COMPUTER SYSTEMS reports earnings for Qtr to March 29
description: b-Includes gains of $11.4 million for the quarter and 9 months from the sale of an investment in an affiliated company.

title: INSURANCE INQUIRY SEES NO COLLUSION
description: The Justice Department today turned down a consumer organization's request to investigate allegations that insurance vestigate allegations that insurance companies have colluded to deny liability coverage in certain businesses.

title: SUSPECT HELD IN DEATH OF 4 ELDERLY ATLANTA WOMEN
description: The Atlanta police said today that they had arrested a suspect in the slaying of four elderly women whose deaths kindled fear in inner-city black neighborhoods.

title: NEWHALL INVESTMENT PROPERTIES reports earnings for Qtr to March 30
description: b-Includes a gain of $1.9 million, or 43 cents a share, from the sale of properties.

title: MUSIC: GE AND MACBRIDE
description: GE GAN-RU and David Macbride, two composers whose recent works were presented at Asia House on Saturday evening, represent mirror images of East-West musical fusion. Mr. Ge, China's first avant-garde performer, comes from Shanghai and studies composition at Columbia, whereas Mr. Macbride, who is of Eurasian parentage, has enriched his Oriental heritage by traveling to China. Their joint concert, at which both were on hand to explain their esthetics, presented three pieces by each musician.

title: Gibson Disabled
description: Kirk Gibson, the Detroit slugger who hurt his ankle scrambling back to first to avoid a pickoff throw in Boston Tuesday night, has been placed on the 21-day disabled list, but it is expected to be a month to six weeks before he rejoins the team. Gibson, whose .359 batting average was seventh in the American League, sprained the ligaments in his left ankle as he hurried back to the bag just ahead of a throw by Roger Clemens in the second inning of the Tigers' 6-4 loss to the Red Sox. An X-ray examination revealed no fracture, but Gibson's ankle was placed in a splint, and Dr. David Collon, the Tigers' orthopedic consultant, said it would take four to six weeks for it to heal.

title: L.F. Rothschild Net Up 84%
description: L. F. Rothschild, Unterberg, Towbin Holdings Inc., the investment banking firm that went public last month, said yesterday that its net income rose 84 percent in the first quarter, to $13.8 million, or 94 cents a share, from $7.5 million, or 54 cents a share, the year before.

The library said the information the young scholars wanted could be obtained elsewhere, and thus they could not be admitted.

description: In the aftermath of the United States air strikes against Libya in response to that country's suspected involvement in terrorist activities, some American amateur and professional sports teams are reconsidering plans to compete in events scheduled in Europe this spring and summer. Of particular concern are the highly visible national teams that represent the United States in world competition.

title: UP TO 15 INCHES OF SNOW BURIES THE REGION'S SPRING
description: The promise of tulips and sweet spring grass seemed to fade a bit yesterday when a winterlike storm surprised the New York region and covered areas east and west of the city with more than a foot of wet snow.

title: DAY PROGRAMS, CITY VACATIONS FOR CHILDREN ARE INCREASING
description: WHEN the final school bell frees Manhattan's public and private school children to enjoy the summer, some will board buses for sleep-away camps in the country. But many will stay behind, and for them the doors of the city's proliferating day camps, summer schools and summer programs will be open wide, offering ''more options than ever before,'' according to Peggy Bradt, director of the Parents League.

title: GRADUATE STUDIES IN CRITICISM
description: A collaboration between the Parsons School of Design and the New School for Social Research will offer the country's first graduate program in architecture and design criticism.

title: Jakarta Bars Times Reporter From Reagan's Visit to Bali
description: The Government has barred a New York Times reporter, Barbara Crossette, from covering the visit of President Reagan to Bali next week because of articles she wrote that it considers offensive, authoritative sources said today.

title: Detroit Resource Makes Offering
description: The Detroit Resource Recovery Authority is offering $450 million of bonds with a maximum yield tentatively set at 9 1/4 percent for bonds due in 2008 through underwriters led by Smith Barney, Harris Upham & Company.

title: AIRLINE, STATE AGENCY AND F.A.A. LIABLE IN CRASH
description: A World Airways DC-10 would not have skidded off an icy runway at Logan International Airport and into Boston Harbor in 1982 if the airline and two agencies had performed their legal duties ''without negligence,'' a Federal district judge ruled today.

title: Eckerd Holdings

A $290.5 million issue of 11 1/8 percent subordinate debentures due in 2001 was offered at 89 1/4, to yield 12.75 percent, while $352.2 million face amount of zero coupon bonds due in 2006 are offered at a price of $539.01 per $1,000 bond, to yield 12.89 percent if held to maturity. The debt securities are rated B-2 by Moody's.

Persico Informer Says He Got $50,000 Bonus
description: A 59-year-old Long Island man testified yesterday that he had received a $50,000 reward for informing Federal agents that his home was being used as a hideout by his wife's cousin, the reputed Mafia leader Carmine Persico.

title: CORRECTION
description: A Washington dispatch yesterday about refunds to Federal employees and retirees to reflect savings on Blue Cross and Blue Shield payments gave an incorrect date. The savings occurred in or were projected for 1985, not 1984.

title: Norfolk Southern Gain
description: The Norfolk Southern Corporation, citing reduced fuel and labor costs for its railroad subsidiaries, said its first-quarter earnings rose 3.9 percent, to $103.7 million, or $1.65 a share, from $99.8 million, or $1.59 a share, a year ago. Total operating revenue from its railway and trucking units was $1.02 billion, up 18 percent from $862.2 million a year earlier. But the former figure included revenue of $158.7 million from North American, which did become part of the Norfolk-based Norfolk Southern until last June.

title: Art by Fonda
description: Henry Fonda's paintings look, well, like Henry Fonda - worn elegance, crisp precision, slightly ascetic. Two signed lithographs fetched $1,600 on Tuesday night at Sotheby's during a benefit auction for Very Special Arts, which supports arts for the handicapped.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: THE CONGRESSMAN'S DAUGHTER. By Craig Nova. 301 pages. Delacorte/Seymour Lawrence. $16.95.

title: AMERICAN BUSINESS PRODUCTS INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Nuclear Race, Nuclear Restraint
description: Should America strive for a nuclear arsenal clearly superior to the Soviet Union's, or quit the race and settle for parity? Mr. Reagan's predecessors made a clear choice on this basic issue: parity, with agreed limits on strategic missiles. Mr. Reagan has never been so sure. Despite his tentative decision this week to abide by SALT II, the policy of mutual restraint in nuclear weaponry still stands in peril, for which the Soviet Union bears a rich share of the blame.

title: In Defense of Lobbyists
description: A glance at the press these days somehow makes it appear that, with the possible exception of Libya, the major concern of Americans is an increase in advocacy here in the nation's capital. Reports speak darkly about the rapidly growing power of the lobbyist, about an ''excess of access,'' about the ''tidal wave'' of Administration officials who have turned to private practice for profit.

description: The political strategist for the Senate Republicans declared today that Guy V. Velella's ''overwhelming'' special-election victory exposed as a ''fantasy'' the Democratic hope of gaining control of the chamber next fall.

description: Hours before the American bombing of Libya, Italy suggested that the United States ask the North Atlantic Treaty Organization to consider joint military action ''against terrorism,'' a senior Italian official said today.

title: Technology; Tripping Up Enemy Radar
description: IN World War II, the German military, concerned that its U-boats' jutting snorkels might be vulnerable to detection by Allied radar, applied a radar-absorbent coating to the snorkels to make the U-boats far more difficult to detect.

description: The Martin Marietta Corporation promoted Richard M. Davis yesterday to the new position of president of the company's Michoud aerospace operations, the division that builds the external fuel tanks for the space shuttles.

title: U.S. NOW CASTING DOUBT ON ALLIES' LIBYAN POLICY
description: Senior Administration officials said today that the United States saw no real early prospect of joint allied military action against Libya last week and therefore decided to carry out the bombings by itself.

title: BBDO Direct Wins Jenny Craig Account
description: BBDO Direct has become agency for Jenny Craig Weight Loss Centers, an Australian import that sprang up last year in Los Angeles and now has a total of 27 company-owned operations there and in New Orleans and Chicago.

title: CORRECTION
description: The Market Place column in Business Day on April 9 about utilities with nuclear plants incorrectly described a rate increase given to the Public Service Company of Indiana. None of the increase will pay for the abandoned Marble Hill nuclear plant.

title: The Bombs Bestir the Allies
description: It is regrettable but undeniable that it took America's unilateral military strike at Libya to persuade our European allies to take concerted action against Colonel Qaddafi. Very late in the day, they have bestirred themselves not just to appease an enraged superpower but to act against terrorism, diminished trade and lost tourism. They have agreed to condemn Libya as a sponsor of terror, to expel many of its diplomat-agents and restrict the rest, to rethink the wisdom of training its pilots and to become more selective about the Libyan students they will educate.

title: Texaco Appeal
description: Texaco Inc. filed its arguments with the Texas Court of Appeals yesterday on why a lower court's judgment in favor of the Pennzoil Company should be overturned. In its brief, Texaco listed 90 ''points of error'' that it contends require reversal of the lower court's decision, including assertions that the trial court's application of New York law, which governed the case, was flawed and that the charge to the jury was unfair.

title: LIBYA A WEEK AFTER RAID: QADDAFI SEEMS FIRMLY IN CONTROL
description: A week after the American air raid on Libya, Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi appears to be still firmly in control of the country, despite suggestions by the Reagan Administration that the attack provoked significant dissension.

title: Apple Sees Strong Earnings
description: Apple Computer Inc. said today that it expects continued strong earnings for the remainder of the fiscal year, which ends Sept. 26. The company also said it had increased its expenditures on marketing and product development.

title: EX-CITY OFFICIAL TOOK A NEW JOB OVER OBJECTIONS
description: The chief financial officer of the city's public hospital system went to work for an overseas affiliate of a major city contractor a year after he negotiated a new $85 million contract with the company.

title: Judge Bars City Search For S.I. Site Developer
description: A state judge yesterday barred the city from seeking a new developer for a 50-acre site on Staten Island pending resolution of a lawsuit.

title: Chili Con Pickle
description: The House Press Gallery celebrated J. J. Pickle Chili Day yesterday for the 20th consecutive year, believed to be a gustatory record for journalists' consumption of a preparation by a member. The Democratic Congressman from Texas for whom the day is named brought in a bubbling cauldron of what he calls Venison Texas Red, which he makes to the recipe of the legendary chili maker Wick Fowler and from which he rigorously excludes beans. One consumer pronounced it ''nice and spicy but a little furry.''

description: The folks at IKEA, the Scandinavian furniture and housewares company, are basking in a state of low-key euphoria these days. Their latest venture into the American market, a sprawling one-story, 155,000-square-foot complex in the Potomac Mills Mall in Dale City, Va., a 45-minute drive from the capital, appears to be a resounding success.

title: HAROLD ARLEN, COMPOSER OF SONG STANDARDS

title: QUEENS WOMAN IS SHOT DEAD IN ROBBERY ATTEMPT
description: A 45-year-old Queens woman was shot and killed yesterday morning on a quiet residential street in Astoria in an apparent robbery attempt, one block from the junior high school where she worked as a lunchroom aide.

title: Reichmanns' Stake

With the 10 percent already owned, the Reichmanns now have 75 percent of Walker.

title: SUMMER, THE PEARL AND DOCTOR J
description: As the Milwaukee Bucks hurried to their bench at the end of the first quarter Tuesday night. they trailed the Nets not only on the scoreboard, 36-24, but also in inspiration. Quickly, the five Bucks who had been on the court plopped onto small folding chairs while their teammates stood up and gathered around, the better to hear Don Nelson during the timeout. As he knelt in front of the five players on the chairs, the Bucks' coach glared in anger.

title: CITY'S SCHOOLS ACCUSED OF OVERPAYING FOR SUPPLIES
description: The Bureau of School Supplies of the New York City Board of Education pays more than double the prevailing retail price for some items used in public schools, the chairman of the City Council's Education Committee said yesterday.
