title: 'A CHILD IS WAITING,' ADOPTION
description: ADOPTION is not on the national agenda; ''A Child Is Waiting'' suggests that perhaps it should be. Some 34,000 children in the United States -''older, imperfect,'' the program calls them - are legally free to be adopted. Unawareness of their availability limits the chance of their finding a home; bureaucratic inertia may also play a part. The WNBC-TV report, on Channel 4 at 9:30 tonight, examines a little-known issue.

title: GRAPHIC TECHNOLOGY reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Greensweep Account
description: The Andersons of Toledo, Ohio, has called on Rice & Rice Advertising, Minneapolis, to take its multimillion-dollar Greensweep account.

title: ROCK: SCOTT JOHNSON
description: SCOTT JOHNSON'S compositions are like a brisk ramble through some musical metropolis. Here's a little baroque polyphony; around a corner, there's a progressive-rock group; a little further along are some piquant, Stravinsky-ish woodwinds; up ahead is a funk band.

title: Whither Gavin?
description: On the heels of a report that President Reagan was ready to nominate a new Ambassador to Mexico comes word from broadcasting circles in New York and diplomatic circles in Mexico City that the Ambassador who is leaving that post, John Gavin, is negotiating with Spanish International Network, a New York-based television network, for management of it and/or some of its affilitate stations. The network has 383 television outlets around the United States and is said to reach 82 percent of the nation's Spanish-speaking residents.

title: JUDGE ORDERS SCHOOLS TO OPEN ON PASSOVER
description: A State Supreme Court justice in Queens ruled yesterday that schools in three Queens districts must open today and tomorrow during Passover, despite decisions by the community school boards to close.

description: THE Sony Corporation's enthusiasm for its eight-millimeter camera/recorder, or camcorder, may well be justified, according to several consumer electronics analysts.

McCaffrey, had resigned. His duties will be assumed by Terence J. Fox, Iroquois's 48-year-old chairman and chief executive.

THE DANCE: GARGANO AND TROUPE
description: CARA GARGANO appears to have the knack of weaving movement into a whole. And there were moments in ''Dream Song'' and ''Eden Suite,'' two of the six dances performed by Cara Gargano and Dancers on Tuesday at the Horace Mann Theater, that suggested Miss Gargano is capable of small but interesting surprises. But it was difficult to tell much more about her choreography without seeing it performed by more capable dancers than most of those she worked with here.

title: Ballet or Bust
description: Balletomanes eager for tickets to the four performances of the Kirov Ballet, the first in this country in 22 years, have lined up at the box office of Wolf Trap Farm Park and deluged it with telephone calls every day since the tickets became available on Sunday.

title: LACKING FOSTER CARE, CHILDREN SLEEP IN OFFICES
description: As many as 100 children needing placement in foster care are being forced to wait in caseworkers' offices each day because of a shortage of homes, city officials and child-care workers said yesterday.

title: HUTTON, IN GLUM REPORT, SAYS IT'LL NARROW BASE
description: The E.F. Hutton Group will narrow its businesses in coming years, a period that it expects to be one of the most difficult that the securities industry has faced, the brokerage house says in its annual report.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: THURSDAY, APRIL 24, 1986
description: The Economy

title: EXECUTIVES
description: * American Stock Exchange said Ivers W. Riley would join its restructured senior management team as senior executive vice president in charge of marketing, new products and strategic planning.

title: CELLO: MORK IN DEBUT
description: TRULS OTTERBECH MORK, a young Norwegian cellist, came to Town Hall's ''Select Debut'' series preceded by an impressive list of competition victories, and showed a correspondingly impressive way with the standard sonata literature Monday evening. Mr. Mork has not only a fine lyrical tone and polished technique, but also a somewhat more songful way with melody - and a more liquid, lyrical tone - than is currently in fashion. Indeed one could observe him opening his mouth to draw breath as a singer would at the beginning of each phrase; it's a good way to think, for any instrumentalist.

description: A NUMBER of products on the market can turn a shower into a steam bath or a bathtub into a whirlpool. The Steam! Maker by Teledyne Water Pik is installed with a wrench between the shower arm and head. To get the maximum effect, the manufacturer suggests that the shower curtain be fully shut; extending the curtain or shower door to the ceiling with a vinyl sheet or plastic barrier will give the best results. The Steam! Maker does not allow a shower and steam at the same time. It can be found at the Garber Hardware and Paint Company, 49 Eighth Avenue, at Horatio Street, for $19.95.

title: One Who Knows

The other day Billy Sample, who played with Whitson last year before moving on to Atlanta, was asked if he had any advice on how his former teammate should cope with the pressure from fans.

title: Ways to End the Impasse With Managua
description: After the long and arduous debate over United States assistance to the contras, a fundamental question remains: What is the best way to reach a political solution in Nicaragua? The only way to answer this question is to analyze clearly the motives and goals of the actors involved.

description: Bob Brooke, the eloquent center of the Rangers, sat in front of his locker, arms on his knees and sweat pouring down his face, and said he was on Cloud Nine because he had never done this before.

title: Puerto Rico Says 91 Died in '85 Mud Slide
description: Ninety-one people died in last October's rock and mud slide in a Ponce slum, the Puerto Rico Justice Department said today as preparation moved ahead on a new attempt to recover bodies still buried under tons of rock.

title: SENATE VOTES TO REJECT REAGAN PLAN TO END 43 DOMESTIC PROGRAMS

She is singing Eboli, a part that was once to have belonged to Agnes Baltsa, who withdrew long ago, and then to Bianca Berini, who was indisposed.

Once the glittering showcase for series such as ''The Mary Tyler Moore Show'' and ''M*A*S*H,'' CBS is increasingly lending its imprimatur to rather dismal mediocrities. title: Bavarian Symphony To Give Two Concerts
description: The Bavarian Symphony Orchestra, in its first United States appearance since 1978, will give concerts on Sunday and Monday at Avery Fisher Hall. Under the direction of its music director, Sir Colin Davis, the orchestra on Sunday will play Beethoven's ''Eroica'' Symphony, Debussy's ''Prelude a l'Apres-Midi d'un Faune'' and Stravinsky's Symphony in Three Movements. Monday evening's program will include Berlioz's ''Symphonie Fantastique'' and Mozart's Symphony No. 39.

title: Brady Gun Suit Dismissed
description: A Federal district judge has dismissed the lawsuit James S. Brady, the White House press secretary, filed against the manufacturer of the .22-caliber pistol that John W. Hinckley Jr. used to shoot President Reagan, Mr. Brady and two others, a lawyer for Mr. Brady said Tuesday. The lawyer, Frederic W. Schwartz Jr., said the office of the judge, John Garrett Penn, notified him of the decision Monday night. No order by the judge has been made public.

title: MID-APRIL CAR SALES OFF 23.5%
description: Sales of new American-made automobiles tumbled 23.5 percent in mid-April from the comparable period last year, when interest-rate incentive programs were offered at four of the six major manufacturers.

title: CREST STAGES A TURNAROUND
description: Just a year ago, Colgate toothpaste seemed to be on the verge of ending the 25-year reign of Crest as the nation's best-selling dentrifice.

title: PEKING MAYOR'S MOTTO: PAY HEED TO MOP AND PAIL
description: If Edward I. Koch should tire of struggling with the problems of New York City, he has a standing offer to swap jobs from a man who reckons he has a still tougher city to run: Chen Xitong, Mayor of Peking.

title: Providence Executive Denies Prostitution Role
description: An insurance executive pleaded not guilty today to a dozen felony counts in the operation of a prostitution ring the police say involved Brown University students and two juveniles.

title: Kemp Favors Trial
description: Jan Kemp, the former University of Georgia instructor, said she would probably force a new trial rather than accept a reduced award in her suit against the university and two of its officials. ''Money's not the issue with me - it's the principle,'' said Mrs. Kemp, whose $2.58 million jury award was cut to about $680,000 on Tuesday by Federal District Judge Horace Ward.

title: PANHANDLE EASTERN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
SUMMER FURNITURE: A NOSTALGIA FOR YESTERDAY
description: AS soon as the first trees begin to flower, Manhattanites with terraces and their suburban neighbors with yards and patios turn their thoughts to the new crop of summer furniture. For those who want either to replace pieces that have not fared well over the winter or to add to their porch or poolside furnishings, there is a wider than usual diversity of summer furniture on the market this year. It runs the gamut from simple and utilitarian designs to whimsical and hand-hewn rustic pieces.

Jeff Ruland, recovering from arthroscopic surgery on his left knee, has been given medical clearance to resume playing with the Washington Bullets. He practiced yesterday and he will probably play tonight in the playoffs against the Philadelphia 76ers.

Conducted by Julinda Lewis Williams and Larry Phillips, the free seminar will feature a discussion of arts and fiscal management, the incorporation process and procedures for applying for grants, with panelists representing six organizations. Information: (718) 875-9710.

title: IS PUNK ROCK'S OBITUARY PREMATURE?
description: IN Britain and the United States, certain pundits have decided that 1986 is the 10th anniversary of the punk-rock movement -and that punk is dead. The arithmetic has some logic; the first Ramones album appeared in 1976, though punk might also date back to the New York Dolls, Iggy and the Stooges, the Velvet Underground, ''You Really Got Me'' by the Kinks or Elvis Presley's ''Hound Dog.'' Anniversary or not, however, punk's obituaries are premature.

title: THEATER: JOHN CAGE IN READING
description: ''MUSHROOMS ET VARIATIONES,'' a new work by the composer John Cage, is an intricately designed poetic text inspired by his recent forays into mycology. The poem, which Mr. Cage read aloud for the first time at the Diane Brown Gallery on Monday evening, is an autobiographical stream-of-consciousness-styled meditation that touches glancingly on many themes - mushrooms, nature, cooking, music, art and the composer's interaction with friends and associates.

title: CAPITALS' BARRETT ENJOYS REPRIEVE
description: John Barrett's reprieve came in the form of a message just before a practice. Since 1980 he had toiled for the Detroit Red Wings. He had survived changes in coaches and owners and philosophy and outlook.

title: CONTRAS ARE SAID TO RECEIVE NEW ARMS
description: United States officials said today that Nicaraguan rebels had been recently resupplied with enough guns and equipment to be able fight for at least several more months.

title: BARRACKS OF QADDAFI'S GUARDS SURVIVED U.S. RAID
description: United States Air Force planes that attacked the Azziziya compound in Tripoli on April 15 failed to strike two buildings that serve as quarters for Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi's elite guard, military experts familiar with the Pentagon reports on the raid said today.

description: THE high level of dancing of the New York City Ballet remains a marvel if not a surprise, as proved again at the opening of the company's season Tuesday night at the State Theater.

title: ORGANIC FERTILIZERS: OLD STYLE VS. NEW
description: NOW that the tulips are in their glory, those of us fortunate enough to have them in great plenty may pause for a moment of self-congratulation. We remembered to order our spring bulbs last summer - or if we procrastinated, as gardeners often do - to buy them at our local garden center. We planted them, at the proper depth, depending on their kind and the nature of our soil, early enough so that they could form healthy root systems before the thermometer plunged toward winter. Mindful of last year's drought, we watered them well. And of course we fed them, probably with bone meal, according to the almost universal prescription.

title: Austria, Look at Yourself
description: Kurt Waldheim's campaign poster for Austria's presidential election says, ''We Austrians will choose whom we want.'' No doubt they will. And it says something about the country's voters that the more evidence there is that Mr. Waldheim lied about his activities during the Nazi period, the more popular he seems to be.

title: LIBYAN AIDES ORDER 200 REPORTERS OUT, THEN CHANGE MIND
description: Libyan officials today ordered more than 200 foreign journalists to leave the country. Hours later, they retracted the order. The seeming confusion was widely seen here as the result of differences within the Government of Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi and between Information Ministry and security officials over how to handle the foreign press.

title: JUDGE SANCTIONS END OF FEEDING IN A COMA CASE
description: A State Superior Court judge ruled today that an artificial feeding tube could be removed from a comatose 31-year-old woman on the ground that she had a constitutional right to refuse medical treatment, even if it meant death.

Marty Goldensohn, the moderator of the program, describes them as ''kids having kids.'' Americans have the highest percentage of births to unmarried teen-agers in the Western world.

title: Scherer Plant

Scherer Corporation of Troy, Mich., said it would close its plant at Somerset, N.J., around May 15 because of the drop in demand for hard medicinal capsules since the most recent Tylenol poisoning scare. The company said that the operation, which employs 100 people and makes two-piece capsules, is for sale.

title: WEEKENDER GUIDE
description: Friday TALL TALES AND TRUE There will be many tales told in New York this weekend about ''why certain things came to be,'' as an African phrase describes the art of storytelling. None are likely to give the same explanation for any particular phenomenon, but no matter. Beginning tonight at City College's Aaron Davis Hall, a three-day conference on storytelling around the world will explore the tradition and feature some noted practitioners of the craft. Shared at the festival will be Creole and Hasidic tales; legends from the Skagit tribe of Puget Sound and the Lakota Sioux, and stories from Latin America, Ghana, China, Italy and elsewhere. The program opens tonight with remarks by Richard Lewis, an expert on children's literature, followed by a ''concert of storytellers'' that includes Muriel Bloch, a teller of North African and Middle Eastern tales; Peninnah Schram, who relates Jewish and Hasidic legends; Michael Parent, a French Canadian raconteur; Argentina Palacios, a Latin-American storyteller, and Mary Carter-Smith, the official ''griot'' (a French West African word for one who is both an oral historian and a poet) of Baltimore. A 9 P.M. concert by the folk singer Odetta, followed by a wine-and-cheese reception with all the performers, will follow. Tickets are $30 for the weekend ($10 for students with identification). A ticket for tonight alone costs $13.50; for tomorrow $23; and at Sunday's shows, a donation is requested. The hall is at Convent Avenue and 134th Street.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: FRIDAY, APRIL 25, 1986
description: International President Reagan prepared for a trip to the Far East. He conferred with Congressional leaders and aides as he made ready for his longest journey in office, a 22,000-mile, 13-day trip. The journey will include meetings with Southeast Asian foreign ministers in Bali and with the leaders of other major industrial democracies in Tokyo. [ Page A1, Column 3. ]

title: Hoyt Agrees to Plea
description: The San Diego Padres pitcher LaMarr Hoyt, charged with weapons and drug violations, has agreed to plead guilty to a public-nuisance count in exchange for having the other charges dropped. The arrangement, which must be approved by a judge, is expected to be made formal during a Municipal Court hearing today in San Diego, said Stuart Swett, chief deputy city attorney in charge of the criminal division. Hoyt would be sentenced to three years' probation and fined $350, Swett said. His probation terms would require that Hoyt, 31 years old, violate no laws and not possess or be under the influence of any drugs unless it is under the direction of a doctor. The charges against Hoyt stemmed from Feb. 18, when San Diego police said they stopped Hoyt's car and found him in possession of a knife and two marijuana cigarettes. It was his second arrest in eight days and led to his admittance to a drug and alcohol rehabilitation center in Minnesota during spring training. He underwent a monthlong treatment program before rejoining the Padres before the season. Hoyt, in newspaper interviews published yesterday, said he had been unfairly labeled an alcoholic and in some ways regretted his stay at the Hazelden Center. ''If I'd known exactly what I was getting into, I'd never have gone,'' Hoyt said. ''I'd have quit baseball. I wanted to quit while I was in there.'' Ten days into a 28-day treatment program, Hoyt said, he called Ballard Smith and told the Padres president he wanted out of the center and out of basball.

Dulles, head of the Central Intelligence Agency in the 1950's.

title: ART PEOPLE
description: IT'S a 35-foot-high jumble of pillars and cones, fluorescent scribbles, stripes and splatters with an Italian name, ''Salto nel Mio Sacco,'' which in English means ''Jump Into My Sack.''

title: A MIDRISE CO-OP PROJECT IS GOING-UP IN BAY RIDGE
description: There is a little corner of the Bay Ridge community in Brooklyn on which James C. Gherardi, a builder based in Flushing, Queens, has been putting his own strong stamp in the last few years. He is in the midst of his second project there.

title: GUIDRY OUTSMARTS THE INDIANS
description: Once, he was a strikeout pitcher, perhaps the most dominant of his day. But Ron Guidry is nearly 36 years old, and his left arm is no longer the overpowering weapon it was in the late 1970's. So he has found other ways to win.

title: SHUTTLE PHOTOS: ISSUE OF CREW'S FATE
description: The photographs released Wednesday showing the space shuttle Challenger plunging toward the ocean suggest that within days of the disaster officials of the National Aeronautics and Space Administration suspected the crew cabin remained largely intact until it hit the water, sources familiar with the investigation say.

title: BRITISH AIRWAYS OFFICE HIT BY BOMB BLAST IN LONDON
description: A predawn bomb blast damaged a British Airways office and other stores on London's busiest shopping street today, spraying glass into the street and igniting a fire. One passer-by was treated for shock.

title: SEALED AIR CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Moiseyev Dance Group at the Met Sept. 2-14
description: The Moiseyev Dance Company will perform at the Metropolitan Opera House from Sept. 2 through Sept. 14, in the opening performances of a three- month tour that will take the Russian folk company to 17 American cities. The tour, produced by ICM Artists Ltd., marks the company's first visit to the United States in 12 years, and the first full-scale American tour of a Soviet attraction to have resulted from last November's summit meeting.

title: TRAK AUTO CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-Net income

title: POP AND JAZZ GUIDE
description: Cecil Taylor Unit, Sweet Basil, 88 Seventh Avenue South, at Bleecker Street (242-1785). The pianist Cecil Taylor invented his own jazz language - a torrent of tone clusters, two-fisted chords ripped loose from conventional harmony, monumental tremolos and stretches of tumultuous yet luxuriant lyricism. Mr. Taylor is happier with the pianos and the concert halls of Europe, but now and then he brings a band to a New York club, where listeners can see as well as hear the hyper-speed interaction in the music. Mr. Taylor's latest Unit includes marimba, trombone, tenor saxophone and a singer along with piano, bass and drums. Today through Sunday, with sets at 10 and 11:45 P.M. and 1:30 A.M.; there is a $10 cover and a $6 minimum.

title: INTERNATIONAL RECTIFIER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After tax credits of $47,000 for the quarter and $183,000 for the 9 months. c-Net income and includes losses from discontinued operations of $988,000 for the quarter and $971,000 for the 9 months. The quarter was also after a reversal of a tax credit of $477,000 and the 9 months also after a gain of $785,000 from the cumulative effect of an accounting change. The year-ago periods were restated.

title: Ashkenasi and Serkin
description: The violinist Shmuel Ashkenasi and the pianist Peter Serkin will play music by Busoni, Bach, Brahms and Toru Takemitsu tomorrow night at 8 at the 92d Street Y (on Lexington Avenue). Tickets are $7.50 to $10. Information: 831-8603.

title:
WHEN THE ALLIES WON'T PLAY BALL;
HELP THEM OUT OF A RUT
description: Europe is the theater of most terrorist activity. Yet, to Americans' astonishment, many Europeans have reacted with hostility or apathy to the bombing of Libya. Americans have long been bewildered by Europeans' seeming approval - even adoration - of aggressive anti-Americanism, and have been dismayed by Europe's seeming impotence in the face of Middle Eastern terrorism. Political explanations of this mystery seem insufficient, but psychology may offer an answer. Could Europeans be suffering from the ''Stockholm syndrome?''

title: THEATER: CRONYN AND TANDY
description: THERE comes a time halfway through ''The Petition,'' a new play by Brian Clark, when an elderly woman tells her elderly husband an unbearably sad secret. The characters are Sir Edmund and Lady Elizabeth Milne of Belgravia, but audiences aren't visiting the Golden to study the marriage of some fictive English couple. The real subject of ''The Petition'' is one of the most illustrious marriages in the history of the American stage - that of the play's stars, Jessica Tandy and Hume Cronyn. And when Miss Tandy tells Mr. Cronyn her tragic news, what can only be described as a religious hush descends on the house. We know we are about to watch a Cronyn-Tandy moment, an acting phenomenon now unique in the Broadway theater and possibly never to come its way again.

title: The Message Military-Pension Changes Send Those in Uniform
description: To the Editor:

title: ART: INTERNATIONALISM AT LA DEFENSE IN PARIS
description: THE quarter called La Defense, way to the west of the Arc de Triomphe, is not one that turns up every day on postcards from Paris. Though far from inconspicuous - its towers dominate the landscape for miles around - La Defense is thought to be not much fun. We have so many dehumanizing office towers back at home that there is something dreary about the thought of leaving the uniquely hospitable historic center of Paris and going to gape at tall buildings marked ''Fiat,'' ''IBM,'' ''Esso'' and ''Rank Xerox.''

title: Pennzoil Bars Texaco Plan
description: The Pennzoil Company spurned a proposal from Texaco Inc. yesterday aimed at settling the multibillion-dollar legal dispute between the companies out of court.

title: STANHOME INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
F.B.I. BEGINS INQUIRY INTO KILLING OF NEWARK TEEN-AGER BY OFFICER
description: A Federal investigation was begun today into the fatal shooting Monday of a Newark teen-ager by a police officer from the neighboring town of Irvington.

title: PENNZOIL CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
ART: JURIED EXHIBITION AT NATIONAL ACADEMY
description: THE open juried show at the National Academy of Design, 1083 Fifth Avenue, at 89th Street, has the potential to fill an important need. There are now few juried shows anywhere and probably none in which a broad range of artists can exhibit within a selective, traditional framework. The more the academy opens up this show - in odd-numbered years, the annual is available to members alone - the less protected and more dynamic the National Academy will become.

title: CONSOLIDATED-BATHURST INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes a $47.4 million charge related to the writeoff of the investment in Sulpetero Ltd. and the reduction of the book value of its holdings in Sulbath Exploratin Ltd. c-Net income The company's stocks are traded on the Montreal Stock Exchange.

title: THE EVENING HOURS
description: WHILE England slept, loyal supporters of the Winston Churchill Memorial and Library gathered Monday at the Waldorf-Astoria's cocktail terrace, where an impassive figure in beefeater regalia stood guard. The occasion was a tea party to celebrate the 60th birthday of Queen Elizabeth II. Was the Queen privy to the party? ''She's probably in bed by now, don't you think?'' said the hostess, Olga McCluskey, M.B.E., ducking the question and checking her watch. ''It's after 11 o'clock in England.'' Silver trays of finger sandwiches, scones and crumpets with Devonshire cream circulated amid the palms. Were these the Queen's favorite tea foods? Sir James Murray shook his head and said: ''I'm afraid I'm not on tea-taking terms with the Queen, although I kissed her hand when I was made Ambassador to the U.N.''

title: PRIEST REFUSES TO RECANT VIEWS ON SEX ISSUES
description: A priest at the Catholic University of America says he will not recant his views on sexual issues despite a threat by the Vatican to strip him of his standing as a Roman Catholic theologian.

STANDARD SHARES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28

The year-earlier net results include losses of $546,000 for the quarter and $645,000 for the year.

In addition, operating earnings were down sharply in the latest quarter at its Devilbiss Co. unit, which makes paint spraying machinery, robots and medical supplies.

title: Thatcher's Son to Stay In Dallas Flat After All
description: Mark Thatcher, son of Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher of Britain, will be allowed to stay in his condominium under tight security despite the building owner's efforts to evict him, officials said Thursday.

title: MOST STUDENTS IN CITY'S SCHOOLS TAKE A DAY OFF
description: Despite the Board of Education's decision to keep the city schools open during Passover, more than half the students and about 40 percent of the teachers stayed home yesterday.

title: WHO ARE THESE PEOPLE?
description: Like Butch and Sundance, the Washington Capitals find themselves pursued by a posse of inexplicable tenacity. The Capitals have fired what may have been their best shot, yet coming through the canyon is that rag-tag collection of citizens called the New York Rangers.

description: Harvey Shepherd, the head programmer for CBS television, has resigned from the network for a studio job, citing pressures ''beyond belief'' in the competition for audience ratings.

title: SOUTHWESTERN ENERGY CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
A Baseball Habit Falls From Grace
description: The ceremony has many variations, and the order of ritual can change. But once he's tapped the small end of the bat against his spikes a couple of times, grabbed his jersey once or twice, taken a tuck or two and a few practice cuts, no self-respecting slugger worth his spit would think of standing in to face a fastball without shifting his chaw and squirting out a little tobacco juice.

title: MUSIC: MEHTA CONDUCTS
description: RESIDENT virtuosos of the New York Philharmonic stepped out of the ranks last night to remind us that a great orchestra can occasionally put together a splendid concert without the aid of visiting soloists. It is difficult to imagine, for instance, that any famous touring flutist could give a more hauntingly lovely performance of Griffes's ''Poem'' than Renee Siebert played on this occasion under Zubin Mehta's sympathetic direction.

title: Reunion for P.S. 70
description: Six months ago, rummaging through his basement in Jamaica Estates, Queens, Herbert Reiman came across his elementary school graduation photograph. The date read June 1936, and nostalgia spurred Mr. Reiman to action.

description: b-After an extraordinary tax benefit of $926,000, or 3 cents a share. c-Net income and after an extraordinary tax benefit of $568,000, or 2 cents a share.

description: Salvadoran security forces are continuing an investigation into a kidnapping ring involving at least two senior army officers and several rightist political activists here who are accused of abducting affluent businessmen for million-dollar ransoms.

title: In Scandal's Shadow
description: As New York City's scandals sweep from Parking Violations Bureau to Taxi Commission to hospital agency, Mayor Koch cancels contracts and projects that might appear tainted. The cancellations, while appropriate, show a city floundering without a moral compass and a Board of Estimate hesitant to shed excessive campaign obligations.

title: MUSIC: ROSSINI WORKS BY CLARION CONCERTS
description: ALTHOUGH he retired from professional composition at the height of his career, Rossini just couldn't stop writing music. In his leisure time, he fashioned little songs, skits and pieces in an intermezzo style, which he referred to as the ''Sins of Old Age.''

description: Eamonn Coghlan said he was no longer puzzled.

description: A senior Justice Department official has recommended that former Secretary General Kurt Waldheim be barred from entering the United States because of his actions as a Wehrmacht officer in World War II, Reagan Administration officials said today.

description: Continuing the mixed trend in first-quarter profits for oil companies, Texaco Inc. yesterday reported a 2.5 percent increase, while the Standard Oil Company dropped 26.2 percent and the Pennzoil Company declined 26.3 percent.

description: The Japanese Government sought today to put distance between itself and a much-heralded report that calls for a restructuring of the Japanese economy to place less emphasis on exports and more on domestic consumption.

description: Mark Talbott of Marblehead, Mass., will be out to reclaim his sport's most prestigious title when the $25,000 Xerox North American open squash racquets championship opens today in St. Paul.

description: Two movie studios announced exclusive arrangements with cable companies today.

description: Should a woman who has no college degree and works at a car dealership be chairman of a Federal council on women's educational programs?

Drinking Age Bill in Hawaii
description: The Hawaii Senate has passed and sent to the Governor a bill to raise the drinking age to 21 years from 18 on Oct. 1. The Federal Government has said it would withhold some highway funds from states that did not raise the drinking age. Such a move could cost Hawaii as much as $18.9 million.

title: VERMONT RESEARCH CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 29
description: b-Net income

title: POP AND JAZZ GUIDE
description: Julie Wilson, Oak Room, Algonquin Hotel, 59 West 44th Street (840-6800). Since Julie Wilson emerged two years ago from semi-retirement, she has had a succession of cabaret triumphs, choosing adventurous programs of songs by Cole Porter, Stephen Sondheim, Richard Rodgers and Lorenz Hart, and George and Ira Gershwin. She has just returned from a month at the Ritz in London, her first appearance in that city in 20 years, followed by some engagements in Brazil. Now she is back in the Oak Room of the Algonquin Hotel, where she sang for 17 weeks last fall, this time with a new program made up of the songs of Irving Berlin, who will celebrate his 98th birthday on May 11. As usual, she will be accompanied by Billy Roy, who uses both a piano and an unusually expressive face to support her singing. Miss Wilson performs tonight and tomorrow at 9:15 and 11:15. There is a $15 music charge and a $15 minimum.

title: SHELL OIL CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
CHUBB CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes realized gains of $14.1 million in the latest quarter and $600,000 in the earlier period.

title: TECUMSEH PRODUCTS CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
'MR. LOVE,' A BRITON'S SEARCH IN MIDDLE AGE
description: IN a truly hilarious episode from ''Mr. Love,'' a star-struck usher saves the day when the projector showing ''Casablanca'' breaks down; she takes to the stage with a perfect Ingrid Bergman imitation, only to be matched by a milquetoasty English gardener doing Humphrey Bogart with a near-cockney accent. But ''Mr. Love,'' which opens today at the Festival Theater, never fulfills the outrageous promise of that scene. The British film is not really a comedy, but a small, sentimental movie about the gardener's search for love.

description: A gunman was fatally shot last night in the Borough Park section of Brooklyn by the owner of a candy store that he had robbed moments earlier, the police said.

Simmons, the Dallas investor who had proposed a hostile $26-a-share bid for the company. CSX said it had paid $5 a share for the options, which carry an exercise price of $28 a share.

JURY IS TOLD OFFICERS FALSIFIED KEY REPORT IN HIT-AND-RUN CASE

BRIEFS

title: MIME: 'MUMMENSCHANZ, NEW SHOW'
description: AS the saying goes, what do you do for an encore? Mummenschanz, the mime trio from Switzerland that enchanted viewers with its first production in the 1970's, has finally come up with an answer in the form of its latest fun-filled fantasia.

title: Austin, Tex., Offering $325 Million at Up to 8%
description: In the largest competitive tax-exempt bond sale of the week, Austin, Tex., is offering $325 million of utility systems revenue bonds with a maximum yield of 8 percent for bonds due in 2016 through underwriters led by Bear, Stearns & Company.

title: POP/JAZZ
description: TOMORROW night, Josef Zawinul will step onto the stage of Carnegie Hall alone - without Weather Report, the band he has led since 1970. His only backup will be the patterns programmed into four drum machines at his feet that will allow him to shift gears at any moment behind the bass lines, melodies and chords he's improvising on four keyboards.

title: Transamerica Fills President's Position
description: The Transamerica Corporation yesterday announced the election of Frank C. Herringer, one of the company's two executive vice presidents, as president, filling a vacancy. James R. Harvey will continue as chairman and chief executive officer.

title: In New York, the Jazz Life Is Mostly the Blues
description: To the Editor:

title: COMMON MARKET IN PACT ON TERROR
description: Cabinet Ministers from countries of the European Community agreed today to step up their exchange of information on terrorism with the United States and other nonmember nations.

title: SUTCLIFFE'S HOMER TOPS EXPOS
description: Rick Sutcliffe, the Chicago pitcher, hit a three-run homer and Jerry Mumphrey hit one with the bases empty as the Cubs defeated the Montreal Expos, 7-5.

title: New Offer on Toxic Waste Bill
description: The Senate today offered a new compromise to the House on legislation to renew the toxic waste cleanup law in an effort to break a long stalemate over the bill.

title: HOLLYWOOD UNSURE ON CANNES TRIPS
description: Steven Spielberg, Martin Scorsese and Whoopi Goldberg have canceled their trips to the Cannes Film Festival while many Hollywoodians are reassessing their plans as a result of recent terrorist acts in Europe and the American bombing in Libya.

title: Drug Tests Planned For Boston Police
description: All 2,400 employees of the police department will undergo random drug testing starting in June, Police Commissioner Francis Roache announced today.

title: SCHOLARLY DISCIPLINES: BREAKING OUT
description: Two years ago a dozen professors at Bryn Mawr College got together and formed a private study group of a kind that has been popping up on campuses around the country.

title: Madrid Blast Kills 6 Civil Guards
description: An explosion probably caused by a car bomb rocked central Madrid today, killing at least six Civil Guards and injuring other paramilitary soldiers and pedestrians, the police said.

title: DUCHESS OF WINDSOR, 89, DIES IN FRANCE
description: Almost half a century after a King of England abdicated his throne to make ''the woman I love,'' his wife, the socialite divorcee from Baltimore who became the Duchess of Windsor died in seclusion today at her home on the outskirts of Paris. She was 89 years old.

title: Trial of F.B.I. Agent Interrupted by Judge
description: A Federal district judge interrupted the testimony of an admitted Soviet spy today and sent jurors in the espionage trial home while he conferred with lawyers about undisclosed developments.

Mitchell-Lama Units To Retain Rent Curbs

description: Though the year is still young, a strong candidate has emerged for comeback player of 1986. He's Peter Schuster, a former captain of the West German national polo team, who suffered spinal damage when his mount fell on him during a match in West Berlin three years ago.

title: UNION ELECTRIC CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Suitor Increases Bid for Warnaco
description: The W Acquisition Corporation, continuing its pursuit of Warnaco Inc., said that it would increase its cash offer for the clothing maker by $2.50 a share, to $46.50, or a total of about $469.7 million, if shareholders rejected Warnaco's recapitalization plan. In response to the sweetened bid, Warnaco postponed until May 5 a shareholders' vote on its plan that had been scheduled for today.

title: TAX BILL'S OUTLOOK HELD BRIGHTER AFTER MEETING
description: Without dealing in specifics, Senator Bob Packwood, the chairman of the Finance Committee, suggested today that his committee consider writing a tax bill in which tax rates would be lowered dramatically and nearly all deductions and tax preferences would be disallowed.

title: FINISHING LAST BOOK OF FATHER
description: Harry Kalven Jr., a law professor at the University of Chicago, was completing the first draft of a book on the First Amendment when he died of a stroke at his desk in 1974.

title: Bridge: Member of Title Team in '64 Has Small Triumph in Jersey
description: One of the most exciting world championship matches ever played was the Italy-Britain semifinal in New York City in 1964. The Italians won by 6 international match points and went on to win the world title.

description: The Commerce Department, in a victory for the American semiconductor industry, said today that it had determined that Japan has been dumping computer memory chips in the United States at below production costs.

CORRECTION
description: A music review yesterday of works by Ge Gan-ru and David Macbride misidentified the composer of the song cycle ''To. . . .'' It is Mr. Macbride.

title: DANCE: PERRY ENSEMBLE
description: THE program presented by the Peridance Ensemble on Wednesday at the Theater of the Riverside Church was a model of clarity and good ballet manners. Many of the performers come from the Peridance Center, a Manhattan-based dance school founded and run by Igal Perry. And Mr. Perry and his staff are turning out dancers with a clean, clear line and attractively fresh stage personalities. Mr. Perry's choreography, which made up most of the program, seemed designed to display those qualities in the dancers. But two of the five dances rose above the level of well-crafted showcase pieces.

title: TIMES MIRROR CO INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The company said latest quarter results are partial results of two months of operations at Publishers Paper Co., 80 percent of which was sold to Jefferson Smurfit Corp. as of Feb. 2, 1986. Not included is the art and graphic products group sold in June 1985.

title: FRIDAY SPORTS
description: Baseball Yankees vs. Cleveland Indians, at Yankee Stadium, 7:30 P.M. (Television - Channel 11, 7:30 P.M. Radio - WABC, 770; 7:30 P.M.). Mets vs. Cardinals, at St. Louis, 8:35 P.M. Dwight Gooden will oppose the defending league champions for the second time this season. In the Mets' home opener, Gooden lasted 8 innings, gave up 5 hits, struck out 6 but was not involved in the decision as the Cardinals won, 6-2, in the 13th inning. (Television - Channel 9, 8:30 P.M. Radio - WHN, 1050; 8:30 P.M.). Basketball Detroit Pistons vs. Atlanta Hawks, at Pontiac, Mich., Game 4 of the three-of-five-game Eastern Conference opening-round playoff. The Hawks, leading two games to one, can clinch a meeting with the Boston Celtics in the next round. (Television - WTBS, 8:05 P.M.) Utah Jazz vs. Dallas Mavericks, at Salt Lake City, Game 4 of the three-of-five-game Western Conference opening-round playoff. The Mavericks can earn the spot against Los Angeles with a victory. Boxing Hockey Rangers vs. Washington Capitals, at Landover, Md., 8 P.M. The Patrick Division series, a four-of-seven-game series, has become a two-of-three-game finish. (Television - MSG, 8 P.M., live; Channel 9, tape about 10:30 P.M. following the Mets' game. Radio -WNBC, 660; 7:50 P.M. live.) Canadiens vs. Hartford Whalers, at Montreal. The winner will take a 3-2 lead in the four-of-seven-game series. Track and Field 92d Penn Relays, at the University of Pennsylvania, Franklin Field, Philadelphia, 11:30 A.M. Volleyball Yugo USA Challenge Cup, finals, at Nassau County Community College, Garden City, L.I. In this culmination of a four-stop tour by four of the top women's teams in the world, Cuba will play Peru for the championship at 5:30 P.M., followed by the United States against South Korea in the consolation match at 7:30.

title: KNIGHT-RIDDER NEWSPAPERS INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The latest quarter earnings were after one-time costs of 2 cents a share for the shutdown of the company's Viewtron operations.

title: THE SCREEN: '8 MILLION WAYS TO DIE'
description: HOW did ''Eight Million Ways to Die'' commit suicide? Let us count the ways. The first clue is a plot, derived from Lawrence Block's books, about a detective named Matthew Scudder (Jeff Bridges) who gets involved in the murder of a young prostitute by a drug dealer. But there is no detecting in this detective story, and no story. Between Scudder's unconvincing meeting with the prostitute and the unbelievable final shoot-out, the movie, which opens today at the Manhattan Twin and other theaters, marks time.

title: SYSCO CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 29
FILM: 'ECHO PARK,' WITH TOM HULCE
description: ''ECHO PARK,'' about a small group of aspiring oddballs living on the Hollywood fringe, is affable but inert, which is virtually its style. It has the manner of an Alan Rudolph film before it's been edited to inject some sense of movement or, at least, a reasonable narrative progression from one nutty non-event to the next.

title: Remains of Challenger Crew Will Be Flown to Dover, Del.
description: The remains of the seven crew members of the space shuttle Challenger are to be flown to Dover Air Force Base in Delaware on Tuesday for final treatment in accordance with the families' wishes, the space agency announced today.

title: US TOBACCO CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
AUGAT INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
SURVEY FINDS 'OUTDOOR' U.S. THAT WANTS NATURE AREAS KEPT
description: A survey conducted for a Presidential commission on recreation finds that ''the America of 1986 is an outdoor-oriented country.'

title: AVNET INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 28
description: b-Including charges of $2.1 million, after taxes, related to a facility closing, moving of an operation and additions to bad debt reserves.

title: SCANA CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
US VACATION RESORTS reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income The loss for 1985 includes an unusual charge of $700,000 to pre-tax income to cover the estimated costs associated with the temporary conversion of the company's Hi-Tide resort to a rental park.

title: GULF STATES UTILITIES CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
NEW AIDS CASES UP SHARPLY IN CITY, 510 IN 2 MONTHS
description: The number of new AIDS cases in New York City jumped sharply in the last two months, city health officials said yesterday. The rise ended a six-month period in which newly reported cases had remained constant.

title: SUN CO INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
INDEPENDENT COUNSEL IS NAMED IN INQUIRY OVER E.P.A. DOCUMENTS
description: A panel of Federal appellate judges named an independent counsel today to investigate charges that a former Assistant Attorney General, Theodore B. Olson, gave false testimony about the withholding of documents of the Environmental Protection Agency from Congress in 1982 and 1983.

title: KEY PHARMACEUTICALS INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Fort Howard Pact To Buy Lily-Tulip
description: Fort Howard Paper Company has agreed to acquire Lily-Tulip Inc., a maker of disposable cups, for $326 million, the companies announced yesterday.

title: U.S. SEEKS CHANGES AT THRIFT UNITS
description: In a series of sweeping new regulatory initiatives, the Federal Home Loan Bank Board proposed today to require thrift institutions to double their net worth over a period of six years and gradually adopt generally accepted accounting principles.

title: DEFENSE CHIEF BEHIND AQUINO: A 2-EDGED SWORD?
description: On the second day of what has come to be known here as the revolution last February, the men who had seized military power from former President Ferdinand E. Marcos struck a bargain with the woman who had taken the political initiative.

title: Silt at the Ship Terminal
description: In the palmy days of trans-Atlantic travel, the greatest liners nudged easily up to the edge of Manhattan. Now the largest of them, the Norway, cannot even make it into the Passenger Ship Terminal because the berthing area has silted in so much.

title: SHAKLEE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Powell Elected
description: Marvin Powell, a tackle with the Jets, today was elected president of the National Football League Players Association. The first vice president will be Brian Holloway of the New England Patriots and Mike Kenn of the Atlanta Falcons was elected second vice president. As president, Powell will head a nine-member union executive council.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''It appears that we are having a steady increase in cases with occasional plateaus.'' - Dr. Stephen Schultz, deputy director for epidemiology at the New York City Health Department, describing AIDS. [ A1:5. ]

title: OILERS TIE SERIES AS GRETZKY GETS 3
description: Wayne Gretzky scored three goals and set up two others tonight to help the Edmonton Oilers to a 7-4 victory over the Calgary Flames that tied their four-of-seven playoff series at two games each.

title: EXECUTIVES
description: * Archer-Daniels-Midland Co., Decatur, Ill., a flour, grain and soybean oil producer, said Albert M. Andreas had retired from its board of directors.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: TERRORISM: How the West Can Win.

title: MOVE TO CHANGE TEAMSTERS STEPS UP
description: The organizers arrived an hour late, nearly missing the shift change. The guards refused to let them use the parking lot to hand out petitions. It was too cold, too windy and too wet to set up the banners, and no one had thought to bring a raincoat.

title: TALLEY INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Walker Shares
description: The New York investor Ivan F. Boesky said he had sold 5.7 million common shares of Hiram Walker Resources Ltd., or 7.6 percent of the company's shares outstanding, to the Belzberg family of Canada.

title: Canadian Play At Brooklyn Theater
description: The New Theater of Brooklyn is presenting ''Waiting for the Parade,'' a Canadian work that explores the experiences of five women during World War II, waiting at home for their husbands, sons, fathers and lovers to return. Melanie Joseph directed the John Murrell play.

title: NUGGETS ELIMINATE BLAZERS BY 116-112
description: Alex English hit the decisive basket with 1 minute 10 seconds remaining and Lafayette Lever scored 30 points as the Denver Nuggets defeated the Portland Trail Blazers, 116-112, tonight to win the three-of-five-game playoff series in four games.

title: ALLEGHANY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes pre-tax gains on securities transactions of $3.8 million in the latest quarter and $1.6 million in the earlier period. The latest quarter results reflect the operations of Chicago Title & Trust Co. and its subsidiary, Chicago Title Insurance Co., which were acquired June 30, 1985.

title: In Re Brennan Birthday
description: Associate Justice William J. Brennan Jr. actually reached the age of 80 today, but when he was invited to the Supreme Court conference room by his clerks yesterday afternoon, he figured a modest observance might be at hand. Inside, to his astonishment, were more than 200 cheering people, a 4-foot cake topped by a marzipan model of the Court building and, probably most unusual of all, the other eight members of the Court handing down a unanimous social and personal judgment.

title: REAGAN HAS TALKS ON TOKYO SUMMIT AND CALLS AQUINO
description: President Reagan conferred today with Congressional leaders and aides as he prepared for the longest journey of his Presidency, a 22,000-mile, 13-day trip to the Far East.

title: Advertising; Shearson Shifts Ads To Color
description: SHEARSON LEHMAN BROTHERS' television advertising is about to blossom into living color.

title: SHELL CANADA LTD reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The company is listed on the Toronto and Montreal stock exchanges.

title: ALEX BROWN & SONS INCORPORATED reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
CITY HOPES TO ADD BEDS FOR 250 FOSTER CHILDREN
description: City officials, acknowledging that a shortage of foster homes is forcing as many as 100 children to wait in caseworkers' offices each day for placement, said yesterday that they are seeking state permission to add about 250 beds for children in group care.

title: VIEW-MASTER INTERNATIONAL GROUP INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Rangers Savoring Comeback
description: They ran the tape and they cheered the ending. They ran it again, they cheered again, and still those final minutes seemed implausible. First came the Huber goal. Then came the Brooke goal, then overtime, and then Brooke scored again.

title: Concert of Ben Weber
description: There will be a retrospective concert of works by the American composer Ben Weber at Symphony Space tomorrow night at 8.

title: L.I. Runner Gains Upset in 1,500
description: Kim Certain of Half Hollow Hills High School, Dix Hills, L. I., scored an upset victory today in the girls' 1,500-meter run at the Penn Relays.

title: Judge Bars an Effort To Relocate Women
description: A State Supreme Court justice in Manhattan yesterday blocked the city's effort to relocate 130 homeless women from a Lower East Side shelter to make room for homeless families.

title: DELTA AIR LINES reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income c-Includes gains of $8,400,000, or 20 cents a share, for the latest 9 months, and $49,653,000, or $1.24 a share, for the earlier 9 months, from the sale of aircraft.

title: CITY URGED TO REHABILITATE 20,000 APARTMENTS
description: The Partnership for the Homeless, a group of 338 churches and nine synagogues, has submitted a proposal to Mayor Koch urging the city to spend $526 million in the next two years to rehabilitate 20,000 city-owned apartments.

title: 67th St. Book Sale
description: The Friends of the East 67th Street Library will hold their 10th annual book sale tomorrow and Sunday, at 328 East 67th Street, between 10 A.M. and 5:30 P.M. There will be 18,000 books for sale, starting at 25 cents for paperbacks and $1.50 for hardcover books.

title: EUROPE AND U.S. TO TALK ON TRADE
description: The United States and the European Common Market are backing away from what had appeared to be an imminent confrontation in a dispute over restrictions on American farm sales to Spain and Portugal, Commerce Secretary Malcolm Baldrige said today.

title: MAJOR CHANGES PROMISED FOR HOSPITAL UNION
description: The apparent new leader of the largest hospital-workers union in the city, Georgiana Johnson, said yesterday that she planned to make major changes in the union, if she is certified the winner of an election for president.

title: Glemp and Jaruzelski Ask End of Sanctions
description: The Polish leader, Gen. Wojciech Jaruzelski, and Jozef Cardinal Glemp held five hours of talks today in their first meeting in 10 months.

title: NICKLAUS 'ELECTRICITY' DRAWS A CROWD
description: Jack Nicklaus, who turned back the clock just 11 days ago to become the oldest man to win the Masters, was worn out. ''It's both from my own excitement of winning the Masters and demands on me since then,'' he said today.

title: PUROLATOR COURIER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Bond Fraud Suits Filed
description: The New York City Housing Development Corporation was accused yesterday of securities fraud in lawsuits filed by investors in Chicago and New York.

title: PINOCHET FOES WEIGH LINK WITH LEFT
description: Frustrated by the refusal of President Augusto Pinochet to open talks about a transition to democracy, Chile's largest opposition political front has begun expressing a willingness to seek a common strategy with some Marxist-Leninist groups.

title: VULCAN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes a non-recurring gain from the sale of assets of $10,48l for latest quarter, and a gain from the sale of assets of $328,671 for year-ago period.

title: Parker's Reply
description: Dave Parker, who left Pittsburgh after the 1983 season and signed with the Cincinnati Reds as a free agent, says the Pirates' lawsuit that alleges he breached the multiyear contract he signed with the club in 1979 was just an effort to save the Pirates from paying him $5.3 million in deferred payments.

title: DOLE PROPOSES SUSPENSION OF LAW RESTRICTING SOVIET TRADE
description: Senator Bob Dole, Republican of Kansas, the majority leader, proposed today that the Jackson-Vanik Amendment to the 1974 Trade Reform Act be temporarily suspended as ''an encourgement and incentive to the Soviets to take another look at their human rights policies.''

title: Ratings Lowered At USF&G, Unit
description: The claims paying ability rating of United States Fidelity Guaranty Company was lowered to AA from AAA and the commercial paper rating of its parent company, the USF& G Corporation, was reduced to A-1 from A-1+ by the Standard & Poor's Corporation. The action by the rating service affects $1.1 billion of bonds that have been insured by USF& G, or about 78 issues.

title: Stocks Rally a Bit; Dow Up 2.11 Points
description: The stock market broke a two-day slump yesterday by chalking up a slight rise, but trading activity was reduced by concern over the recent poor performance by the bond market, and by the Passover holiday.

title: TERMIFLEX CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
WHEELING-PITTSBURGH STEEL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net loss Latest quarter results include an extraordinary credit of $1,843,000, reflecting application of net operating loss carryforwards equal to and offsetting a charge in lieu of income tax expense.

title: SERVICE MERCHANDISE CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Advertising; Domaine Wines
description: Lord Geller Federico Einstein has added another product line to its assignment from Schieffelin & Company. It is the Domaine Chandon California wines that were formerly handled by Tatham-Laird & Kudner in its San Francisco office, which it closed. The advertising spending could be around $1 million.

title: SPECIFIC PROTEIN FOUND IN BRAINS OF ALZHEIMER'S DISEASE PATIENTS
description: Scientists have found a protein in the brains of people with Alzheimer's disease that does not appear to exist in normal brains. The protein may prove valuable in diagnosing the devastating disease and may provide better understanding of its cause.

title: POLICE OFFICER IS ATTACKED BY TEEN-AGE GIRLS AS PEDESTRIANS WATCH
description: A police officer on duty in civilian clothes was attacked on the street behind City Hall yesterday by a group of teen-age girls who beat her and bloodied her nose as a lunchtime crowd of pedestrians looked on, the police said.

title: FORD MOTOR CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
HOUGHTON MIFFLIN CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes tax credits of $4,716,000 in the latest quarter and $4,361,000 in the earlier period.

title: Eligibility Debate Stalled
description: The dispute over amateurs and professionals competing together in the Olympics will last through at least one more set of Games, the head of the International Olympic Committee said today.

title: Boy Trapped in Hole Is Saved
description: A 21-month-old boy fell into a narrow, 15-foot-deep hole on a farm today and was trapped for more than three hours before being freed unharmed by rescuers who dug a parallel hole to reach him, the authorities said.

title: REAGAN ORDERS A STUDY TO DECIDE IF U.S. SHOULD BUILD NEW MISSLE
description: President Reagan has ordered a study to investigate if the United States should develop a new mobile multiple-warhead missile that is about the size of the 78,000-pound Minuteman, Administration officials said today.

title: FIRST SECURITY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
IMPERIAL CHEMICAL INDUSTRIES LTD reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The results are in U.S. currency and at an exchange rate of $1.48 to the pound, the rate prevailing on March 31, 1985. Share earnings represent per American Depositary Receipt, or ADR. Four units of ICI ordinary stock are represented by each ADR.

title: UNITED CITIES GAS CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
DALLAS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes a loss from discontinued operations of $501,000.

title: TIGER INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After a non-cash charge of about $13.2 million resulting from the effects of changes in yen-dollar exchange rates on certain long-term obligations payable in Japanese yen. The Flying Tiger Line Inc. unit had a pre-tax loss of $27,909,000 in the latest quarter, compared with a pre-tax profit of $401,000 for the year-earlier period.

title: Travels With Reagan
description: Security considerations, high on the priority list of White House officials these days, have brought a change in plans for President Reagan's visit to Tokyo for the economic summit meeting early next month.

title: Bond Prices Plummet Again
description: Bond prices declined sharply yesterday, continuing a trend that began Tuesday, primarily tied to the fall of the dollar. The drop brought this week's decline in long bond prices to about eight points.

title: BL Shelves Sale of Units
description: The state-owned auto maker BL P.L.C. has shelved plans to sell its profitable Land-Rover, Range-Rover and Freight-Rover divisions to the private sector, Paul Channon, the Secretary of Trade and Industry, said today.

title: Population Rate Outruns Our Resources
description: To the Editor:

title: QUAKER OATS CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After net from discontinued operations of $5.4 million, or 14 cents a share, for the quarter and 9 months.

title: F.B.I. SAYS CRIME REPORTS IN THE U.S. ROSE 4% in '85
description: Reported crime jumped 4 percent in 1985, with even bigger increases in the South and West, after declining the three previous years, the Federal Bureau of Investigation said today.

title: FILM: '3 MEN AND CRADLE'
description: WHEN you're told that ''Three Men and a Cradle'' is about a trio of young, swinging Parisian bachelors who suddenly find themselves minding a tiny baby, you might well groan. In your hubris, you probably suspect that you can anticipate every gag that could possibly be milked from that basic situation.

title: DONNELLEY, RR & SONS reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
AMERADA HESS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After a ''substantial,'' non-specified charge for inventory writedowns to current market values. c-Net income

title: A.T.&T. Announces a $1.5 Billion Rate Cut
description: The American Telephone and Telegraph Company today announced a $1.5 billion reduction in long-distance rates, which the company said would amount to an average 8.9 percent decrease in long-distance bills for its residential customers.

title: TM COMMUNICATIONS INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Union to Propose N.F.L. Sanction
description: The executive director of the National Football League Players Association will deliver to management Tuesday a program calling for the permanent suspension of football players who repeatedly abuse drugs.

title: Warnings of Eruption From Alaska Volcano
description: The Coast Guard warned fishermen today to stay away from Augustine Volcano, as geologists said a violent eruption could occur within two days.

title: Afghan Rebels Report Heavy Enemy Air Raids
description: Afghan rebel commanders said today that Soviet and Afghan warplanes were killing and maiming hundreds of their men in nonstop raids on rebel positions in southeastern Afghanistan.

title: T.C.U. Is Facing N.C.A.A. Penalty
description: Texas Christian University could lose as many as 25 football scholarships during a two-year period under possible National Collegiate Athletic Association penalties, according to two published reports.

title: KNOLL INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 30
Paine Relocation Seen
description: Paine Webber Inc., the Wall Street brokerage house, is expected to announce today that it will relocate its computer operations, and possibly several thousand employees, to Weehawken, N.J. John C. Meditz, chairman of the Weehawken planning board, said last night that plans call for Paine Webber to begin moving its computer operations to a riverfront development in Weehawken on June 1. Mr. Meditz said he ''expects'' that Paine Webber will also move ''several thousand'' employees to the waterfront site known as Lincoln Harbor. A Paine Webber spokesman declined comment.

title: Economic Scene; The President's Summit Goals
description: THE fallout from the American attack on Libya continues to shadow Administration thinking as President Reagan leaves for the Far East and the Tokyo economic summit conference. While reaffirming his willingness to use military force against terrorism, President Reagan is seeking means - especially economic incentives - to keep other Arab states from lining up behind Libya and for reducing Arab animosity toward the United States.

title: Entertainer Is Released From Nigerian Prison
description: The songwriter and singer Fela Anikulapo Kuti, an outspoken critic of military rule and corruption, was released from prison today, the military Government announced.

title: Bank President's Wife Slain
description: A gunman demanding $100,000 ransom shot and killed a bank president's wife at her home and wounded her husband and another bank officer when they delivered only about $20,000, the police said. The body of Wanda Byler, bound and shot several times, was found under a bed. Her husband, James Byler, president of the Farmers State Bank of Texas County, and Kay Jordan, a bank officer, were taken to a hospital but their conditions were not disclosed. Mr. Byler had received a call telling him to deliver $100,000 to secure his wife's release.

title: INTERLAKE INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes a pre-tax extraordinary charge of $4,686,000.

title: ART: A RODIN COLLECTION ON DISPLAY AT THE MET
description: THIS is an unusual experience: an exhibition of Rodin bronzes and plasters in which the sculptor is upstaged by B. Gerald Cantor, his most avid collector to date. It is available through June 15 at the Metropolitan Museum of Art.

title: Governor Says Deaths Decline With New Law
description: Preliminary figures indicate that raising New York's drinking age has saved lives and reduced injuries in car accidents, Governor Cuomo said yesterday.

title: Soviet Team Tops Canada, 7-4
description: The Soviet Union scored three goals in the first 6 minutes 35 seconds today and went on to a 7-4 victory over Canada on the first day of play in the medal round of the World Hockey Championships.

title: The Road to Deavergate
description: Senator Joseph Biden, Democrat of Delaware, has assembled the necessary ''majority of the minority'' of the Senate Judiciary Committee to request that Attorney General Meese consider asking for court appointment of independent counsel to investigate the pursuit of clients by Michael Deaver.

title: CELEBRATING THE FUTURISTS OF PAST AND PRESENT
description: PERFORMANCE art, the emerging, hard-to-define genre that touches on theater, comedy, dance, video, music, mixed-media and art gallery ''happenings,'' has reached an auspicious historical moment. Laurie Anderson, Whoopi Goldberg and Eric Bogosian have made their way from the fringes of the avant-garde performance scene into the theatrical and movie mainstreams, and potential new ''art stars'' are popping up all over the place.

title: LEGGETT & PLATT INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The share earnings for the 1985 quarter is restated to reflect a 3-for-2 stock split which became effective March 14, 1986.

title: 3 DESIGNERS SEE THE FUTURE: CLEAN, SPARE BUT SEDUCTIVE
description: The challenge facing the fashion business is to make clothes that enhance a woman's appearance and are easy to manage and easy to wear, according to designers now completing their fall collections. This perception is affecting the shape and style of clothes for the next season.

title: CLOROX COMPANY reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
TBC CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
TERA CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net loss and includes a loss of $219,000 from discontinued operations.

title: EXPERTS ASSERT TESTS PROVE DINOSAUR-BIRD FOSSIL IS REAL
description: The famous Archaeopteryx fossil, which appears to show the evolutionary transition between dinosaurs and birds, has been thoroughly retested and confirmed as authentic, British scientists reported yesterday.

title: Judge Rules For Du Pont
description: A Federal judge in Richmond ruled late yesterday that E. I. du Pont de Nemours & Company did not infringe on another company's patent by making Kevlar, a brand of high-strength fibers that many think could develop into a multibillion-dollar market.

title: WESTERN SAVINGS & LOAN ASSN reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The share earnings for 1985 have been retroactively adjusted for a 200 percent stock dividend effective July 1, 1985.

title: Harney And Burke In Lead
description: Jack Burke Jr. and Paul Harney combined for a nine-under-par 61 to take the first-round lead today at the $500,000 Liberty Mutual Legends of Golf.

title: Cuts in Budget Deepen The Dark for the Blind
description: To the Editor:

title: TODD SHIPYARDS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 30
description: b-Includes $1.5 million in pre-tax non-recurring charges. c-Includes $11.5 million in non- recurring charges. d-Net income

title: THROUGH A GLASS BRIGHTLY: ARTISTS' CREATIONS ABOUND IN CITY'S WINDOWS
description: MANUELA FILIACI enjoys doing windows.

title: Henze's 'Miracle'
description: The Stony Brook Contemporary Music Ensemble, under the direction of Arthur Weisberg, will present the first New York performance of Hans Werner Henze's ''Miracle of the Rose'' at Columbia University's McMillin Theater, Broadway and 116th Street, Sunday night at 8.

title: THETFORD CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes tax loss carryforward benefits of $22,000 for the quarter and 6 months.

title: NORTHERN STATES POWER CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Advertising; Ayer Executive Pleads Guilty on Kickbacks
description: An N. W. Ayer vice president working on the multimillion-dollar United States Army recruiting account pleaded guilty in Federal court on Tuesday to charges he took about $60,000 in kickbacks from suppliers over 12 years.

title: Harpooning Congress
description: The Reagan Administration doesn't want to anger Japan by reducing the amount of fish it may take from American waters. Yet as long as the Japanese continue whaling, the law requires Washington to do just that.

title: KEY SITE ON UPPER WEST SIDE IS PURCHASED BY DEVELOPERS
description: What may be the most conspicuous spot at the gateway to the Upper West Side - Broadway and 72d Street - has been purchased by a group that includes William Zeckendorf Jr., the real-estate developer who is already remaking the neighborhood.

title: Artistic Producer Quits Post at Folger Theater
description: John Neville-Andrews, the artistic producer of the Folger Shakespeare Theater for the last five years, said today that he had resigned and that his successor was expected to be Michael Kahn, the chairman of the acting department at the Juilliard School in New York City.

title: Quadriplegic Obtains Court Help on Morphine
description: Elizabeth Bouvia, a quadriplegic, won another legal battle today when a state judge ordered physicians at a county hospital to make no further reduction in her morphine dosage.

title: ALLIED-SIGNAL UP 38.8%
description: Allied-Signal Inc., a company that was changed greatly by a merger and divestiture in 1985, reported yesterday that profits rose to $186 million in its first quarter, a 38.8 percent gain over the prior year's $134 million.

title: THERMEDICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
When Women Go to Court
description: Members of the New York bar are reluctant to take the divorce cases of women with no identifiable assets because the courts are so ''stingy and inconsistent'' in awarding legal fees. Some women may spend seven years trying to get the courts to enforce child support judgments. And at least one courtroom has seen such blatant sexism that the judge invited a female lawyer to sit on his lap.

title: LIBYA RAIDS: BEHIND ALLIES' REACTIONS
description: Shifting coalition politics in West Germany, Italy and France and an unhappy history of joint military actions weighed on the Reagan Administration as it sought allied support for its air raids against Libya last week.

title: METS BEAT CARDS IN 10th
description: The Mets did it with flourishes tonight in the opening round of the battle for first place. They rallied with two runs in the ninth inning and another in the 10th to defeat the St. Louis Cardinals, 5-4, and extended their winning streak to six games.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: FRIDAY, APRIL 25, 1986
description: International

title: WALKER ENERGY PARTNERS reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-Included a $14,809,000 writedown of oil and gas properties.

title: Exhibition of Art On 'Threepenny Opera'
description: The Museum of the City of New York is presenting a collection of 60 works by the School of Paris artist Arbit Blatas, all inspired by the 1954 production of ''The Threepenny Opera.''

title: MILLIPORE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The share earnings reflect a 2-for-1 stock split paid earlier this month.

title: VALERO ENERGY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes a pre-tax write-down to market prices of $35.4 million for refinery inventories and a non-cash pre-tax write-down of $26.1 million for investments in oil and gas properties. c-Includes a pre-tax provision of $7.5 million to write off the investment in the company's coal operation. d-Net income.

title: SONAT INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes a gain of $12.5 million, or 31 cents a share, from the sale of Boise Cascade Corp. stock. c-Includes a gain of $63,153,000 for an accounting change.

title: AT THE MOVIES
description: THE controversial film maker Jean-Luc Godard paid a quick visit to New York the other day and divested himself of news of plans for a new movie, some thoughts on the continuing uproar over his film ''Hail Mary,'' a few words about his current television retrospective at the Film Forum 1 and a little recent production history.

title: VIACOM INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
VIETNAM'S FALLEN: 108 MORE FOR MEMORIAL
description: Stonecutters today began etching into the Vietnam Veterans Memorial the names of 108 servicemen killed or missing in action in the Vietnam War that were omitted when the monument was dedicated in 1982.

title: VICTORY MARKETS INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Arias and Noah Gain in Monaco
description: Fourth-seeded Yannick Noah of France defeated Pablo Arraya of Peru, 6-3, 6-4, and eighth-seeded Jimmy Arias of the United States eliminated Marin Vajda of Czechoslovakia, 6-1, 6-2, today in the second round of the $405,000 Monte Carlo Open tennis tournament.

title: 'COST GOALS' FOR MISSLE DEFENSE PROGRAM EXPECTED IN NEXT BUDGT
description: The director of research for a missile defense shield said today that he would present ''the cost goals'' of such a shield in next year's budget request to Congress.

title: RACIAL CONFRONTATION IN 'HALLMARK' DRAMA
description: ALWAYS stretching a bit higher than the bulk of the competition, television's ''Hallmark Hall of Fame'' has compiled an unusually distinguished production record, hailed with everything from top awards to a retrospective at the Museum of Broadcasting. Its latest presentation, on CBS this Sunday at 9 P.M., is ''Resting Place,'' directed by John Korty and starring John Lithgow and Frances Sternhagen. Once again, the sense of making an extra effort is palpable.

title: 2 BRITISH PARACHUTISTS SAFELY LEAP FROM EMPIRE STATE BUILDING'S 86TH FLOOR
description: Two amateur parachutists from London jumped from the 86th floor of the Empire State Building yesterday and made safe landings 60 seconds, and 1,050 feet later, two blocks down Fifth Avenue. It was the first time anyone has tried to make a parachute jump from the landmark building since it was built 55 years ago.

title: Dining Out Guide: Elegant Italian

title: CASTING FOR FISH AT GREAT LENGTHS
description: Less than five years ago, any surf-fisherman in this country who could consistently cast a 3- or 4-ounce metal lure more than 300 feet was regarded with respect by his peers. Today, the best of the tournament casters are doubling that distance.

title: Diner's Journal
description: I HAVE been wandering through Greenwich Village with a gastronomic divining rod in recent months, hoping to turn up a good, reasonably priced French bistro serving earthy fare in a comfortable, low-key atmosphere. Persistence seemed to have paid off last week when I discovered Chez Jacqueline on a relatively tranquil stretch of Macdougal Street.

title: Blues by CeDell Davis
description: CeDell Davis will play Delta blues tonight and tomorrow at Tramps, 125 East 15th Street (777-5077). Sets begin at 9:30 P.M. and midnight; there is a $10 cover and a two-drink minimum.

title: RESTAURANTS
description: THERE is no better textbook on this evolution of so-called new American cuisine than the menu at An American Place, the 2 1/2-year-old restaurant owned by Larry Forgione, the Thomas Paine of America's culinary revolution. On his menu, you find such Early American artifacts as planked salmon, buffalo steak and apple pandowdy next to such voguish 1980's preparations as barbecued squab, grilled free-range chicken and domestic fresh foie gras. Mr. Forgione was among the first to hop on the now-crowded haywagon of all-American cooking when he was at the River Cafe; his current effort shows how exciting American cuisine can be, although it is not a uniformly smooth trail.

title:
WHEN THE ALLIES WON'T PLAY BALL;
RAISE THE ANTE
description: Sgt. Kenneth Ford, the American soldier killed in a Berlin discotheque two weeks ago, was in West Germany to help Europeans defend themselves against the Warsaw Pact. Yet none of the United States' European allies, except for Britain, would cooperate in mounting the strike against Libya. This lack of support raises the most serious questions yet about America's continued participation in the North Atlantic Treaty Organization.

title: DRUG PATROL BEGINS OFF L.I. SHORE
description: For the first time, Federal authorities have begun operating undercover high-speed patrol boats and aircraft from Long Island to try to intercept drug-laden vessels heading for the Island's shoreline.

PHILHARMONIC PRESENTS SOLOISTS FROM THE RANKS
description: A TYPICAL symphonic program offers an overture appetizer, a concerto with a big-name soloist, maybe a painless palate-cleanser in the form of something new and safely short, and finally a major symphonic statement from somewhere in the 19th century.

title: Love Those Crowds
description: Anticipating yet another surge of crowds, the National Gallery has set up an advance reservation system to ease congestion at a show of paintings from the Soviet Union that opens next week. Washingtonians can now obtain free tickets at a desk in the gallery's East Building, and out-of-towners may get them, for a service charge, at any Ticketron outlet nationwide or by calling Tele-tron at 1-800-233-4050.

title: Congress; Budget and the Republican Breach
description: The Republican Party has always suffered from ideological disagreements between moderates from the Northeast and conservatives from the Middle West and Rocky Mountain regions. But as the party has successfully spread its influence to new parts of the country, particularly the South, and become more of a national institution, it has started to encounter the more severe forms of fragmentation that have long plagued the Democrats.

title: NICARAGUANS MEET ON NEW CHARTER
description: Sandinista leaders and representatives of four Nicaraguan opposition parties held another of their regular meetings last weekend to debate the country's new constitution. What made this session different, however, was the locale: New York, not Managua.

Earthquake Rattles Greece
description: A strong earthquake measuring 5.2 on the Richter scale jolted eastern Greece today, but there were no reports of injuries or damage. A spokesman for the Athens Seismological Institute said the quake was centered in the Aegean between the islands of Euboea and Chios, about 80 miles northeast of Athens.
