title: NEWS SUMMARY: SATURDAY, APRIL 26, 1986
description: International Britain will expel Libyan students of airplane engineering and maintenance and trainee airline pilots if they do not leave voluntarily. The British Government announced that it was curtailing the studies of more than 200 students and a small number of trainee pilots. [ Page 1, Column 6. ] An American was wounded in Yemen, and a British businessman was shot and killed in France. The American, a communications officer at the United States Embassy in Yemen, was shot from a passing car as he drove home from church in Sana, the capital, the State Department said. The British manager of an American-owned subsidiary of Black & Decker was shot and killed at his home near Lyons, France. An explosion in Vienna shattered the office entrance of Saudi Arabia's state-run airline, and the police in Heidelberg, West Germany, said the unoccupied car of an American serviceman and a Canadian military van had been set afire. [ 4:1. ] Corazon C. Aquino accepted an invitation from President Reagan to visit the United States sometime in the fall, a spokesman for President Aquino said in Manila. The announcement was confirmed in Los Angeles, where White House officials said Mr. Reagan had extended the invitation to Mrs. Aquino in a telephone conversation Thursday night. [ 1:2. ] The President began his trip to the Far East. He was optimistic as left Andrews Air Force Base near Washington, and brushed aside potential difficulties at the summit meeting of in Tokyo in such areas as trade and measures against terrorism.

title: No-Hit Streak Ends
description: Jeff Bloom, the Tufts University pitcher who was trying for his fourth consecutive no-hitter, had something of an off day yesterday, and so did his team. Bloom struck out 10 batters in a Division III game against Bates, bringing his total for his last 4 starts to 49 strikeouts.

First Interstate
description: First Interstate Bancorp is still interested in a merger or other combination with the Bank of America, but is only in ''the most preliminary of deliberations'' regarding the venture, Joseph J. Pinola, First Interstate's chairman and chief executive, said. Speaking from prepared remarks at First Interstate's annual meeting, Mr. Pinola said that the combination would enable the resulting company to stave off competition from East Coast banks. First Interstate, the nation's ninth-largest banking concern, had previously declined to comment on reports linking the two companies.

The news conference is scheduled one day before the deadline for a college player to declare his eligibility for the draft.

description: Federal law prohibits allocating food stamps to an individual who earns more than $438 a month; the ceiling for a family of four is $888 a month. Last month, in response to a question from a local official, the Food and Nutrition Service of the Agriculture Department clarified what constitutes income to establish food stamp eligibility. A policy memorandum said, ''Money received from the sale of a person's blood or blood plasma is considered earned income for food stamp purposes.''

description: By abolishing South Africa's pass laws, President P.W. Botha has taken a tangible step away from the state-sponsored racism that sets his nation shamefully apart. title: BELDING HEMINWAY CO INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes $96,000, or 4 cents a share, reflecting the company's share of the equity in earnings of a real estate limited partnership.

title: STRATUS COMPUTER INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
IN CENTRAL PARK'S SECRET GARDEN, A BURST OF SPRING
description: The heady scent of lilacs, seductive and mysterious, wafts onto Fifth Avenue, luring pedestrians through an ornate wrought-iron gate at 105th Street. Inside is a six-acre explosion of color and smell and verdure that might be more at home in the English countryside than in upper Manhattan.

title: ADVEST GROUP INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
FOXBORO CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
OSHKOSH B'GOSH INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
SIPPICAN INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
JWT GROUP INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The year-ago quarter results included a charge of $2.8 million for loss on the divestiture of EA-International advertising subsidiaries.

description: b-Includes a gain of $1,378,000 and a non-recurring gain of $3,137,000 for latest quarter, and a non-recurring gain of $1,261,000 for year-ago period.

title: KEYSTONE INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After a loss from discontinued operations of $382,000.

title: REAGAN CONSIDERS CHANGE FOR GUARD
description: The Reagan Administration is preparing legislation that would limit the authority of governors to keep their National Guard units from being sent abroad for training.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: * Canadian Marconi Co., Montreal, said it had been awarded a contracct valued at about $10 million to supply GTE Corp. with radio equipment for a U.S. Army field communications system.

title: RADIONICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Italian Dies of Tainted Wine
description: A 70-year-old man died today after drinking tainted wine, bringing to 24 the number of people killed by poisoned wine since last month, the authorities said. The man, identified as Augusto Costigliolo, was brought to San Martino Hospital four days ago, suffering from severe poisoning, doctors said. The police said Mr. Costigliolo had drunk wine containing dangerous amounts of methanol.

title: TACO VILLA INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 26
INTERMETRICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $36,000 for the quarter and $461,000 for the year. c-After a loss from discontinued operations of $3,903,000. d-Net income

title: HORIZON INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to March 29
NEW YORK APARTMENTS SHOULD NOT BE INHERITABLE
description: The New York State Division of Housing and Community Renewal has proposed a new code of regulations for rent stabilized apartments. There are several hundred thousand of these apartments in the state, most of them in New York City where they represent the only significant supply of rental housing still available. One proposed regulation would allow tenants of rent stabilized apartments to pass their apartments on to relatives in perpetuity. Many tenant groups argue that this right of inheritance should be expanded to include ''friends'' and ''companions'' of tenants possessing the apartments. Allowing any such inheritance would be a mistake.

title: 5-Borough Riches
description: Lois Rivkin is sure people are not sampling enough of the cultural diversity of the city, such as the Tibet Museum on Staten Island.

title: Trio and Singer
description: The harpsichordist Elaine Comparone, with the cellist Fred Sherry, the oboist Bert Lucarelli, the tenor Charles Bressler and others, will play works by J. C. F. Bach, C. P. E. Bach, Geminiani, Beethoven and Lester Trimble at Merkin Concert Hall, 129 West 67th Street, tonight at 8:30. The program will include the New York premiere of Trimble's ''Petit Concert.'' Tickets are $10; information: 362-8719.

title: T.W.A. AND NORTHWEST POST LOSSES
description: Two major airlines, Northwest and Trans World, yesterday reported losses for the first quarter.

title: INTERNATIONAL SHIPHOLDING CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
EDDIE BAUER, PIONEER IN USE OF DOWN GARMENTS, IS DEAD
description: Eddie Bauer, who pioneered the quilted goose-down insulated jacket and founded the sporting goods mail order company that bears his name, died of a heart attack April 18 at Overlake Hospital in Bellevue, Wash., a suburb of Seattle. He was 85 years old.

title: ...WHILE ACROSS THE ATLANTIC, ANGLOPHILIA RULES
description: Whenever Alan Christian has gone on the air on WFBR radio in Baltimore lately, he has known exactly what most callers were going to talk about: affection for Britain and distaste for other European allies who did not support the bombing of Libya.

title: DINNER BELL FOODS reports earnings for Qtr to March 29
Edberg Is Victor In 2-Day Match
description: Stefan Edberg of Sweden, seeded second in the $325,000 Volvo Monte Carlo Open tournament, had to struggle over three courts for two days and survive a first-set shutout before beating West Germany's Andreas Maurer, 0-6, 6-4, 6-3.

title: LOUISVILLE GAS & ELECTRIC CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
South African Mob Slays Black Policeman
description: A mob hacked a black policeman to death with machetes and knives today during riots in Soweto after the police turned back throngs of young blacks protesting the arrests of 15 students.

title: MUNFORD INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 3
description: b-Includes pre-tax gains on the disposal of operations of $245,000 for the latest quarter and $134,000 for the year-earlier period.

title: Peete, With 135, Leads by 2 Shots
description: Calvin Peete sank a 9-foot birdie putt at No. 12, a 3-foot birdie putt at 13 and 16 pars on his other holes today as he shot a 2-under-par 70. That gave him a two-round total of 135, nine shots under par, and a two-stroke lead at the Houston Open.

title: Accomplice-Corroboration Rule Is a Check on Unjust Conviction
description: To the Editor:

title: IOWA ELECTRIC LIGHT & POWER CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
JET AMERICA AIRLINES INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
WESTBRIDGE CAPITAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes investment gains of $1,181,000 for latest quarter and $3,000 for year-ago quarter.

title: SUPERIOR SURGICAL MANUFACTURING CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
PARIS BUSINESS FORMS reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After an extraordinary insurance payment of $120,000.

title: WHITE SOX DEFEAT TIGERS ON HOMER, 9-7
description: Harold Baines broke a 7-7 tie with his second homer of the game, a two-run shot in the eighth inning tonight, giving the Chicago White Sox a 9-7 victory over the Detroit Tigers.

title: CHILLY RECEPTION AWAITS REAGAN IN BALI
description: President Reagan's meeting in Bali next week with the foreign ministers of non-Communist Southeast Asian countries is not likely to be the friendly encounter the White House has been predicting, according to officials in the region, who say feelings toward the United States are now frostier than at any time since the end of the Vietnam War.

title: NEW ON THE BLOCK: CHARIVARI
description: ''We were the first on Broadway, we were the first on Columbus, we were turned on by being pioneers again,'' Jon Weiser was saying the other day, standing with his partners, his mother, Selma, and sister, Barbara, in their new Charivari boutique at 201 West 79th Street on Amsterdam Avenue, the last Upper West Side avenue to undergo gentrification. It officially opened April 1, 19 years to the day after the family opened its first shop, a women's boutique, on Broadway and 85th Street, a corner that was, at the time, unfashionable.

title: RUNNING FOR FUN, NOT GLORY
description: They call this a carnival. A sunny, warm, glorious Penn Relays day was promised and delivered. Red and blue flags flew above stately Franklin Field yesterday for the next-to-last day of the 92d running of the self-proclaimed world's largest track and field meet, Philadelphia's multi-ethnic rite of spring.

title: CANADIENS TOP WHALERS, 5-3
description: Guy Carbonneau scored a pair of goals to help the Montreal Canadiens defeat the Hartford Whalers, 5-3, tonight and take a three-games-to-two lead in their Adams Division final series.

title: A Family Policy That Makes Sense
description: The growing recognition of the shocking number of women and children living in poverty in the United States is long overdue. If, as a result, the nation is to develop a family policy that can begin to deal effectively with some of the problems the nation faces, we all must understand the problem more clearly.

title: DEAVER LOBBIED FOR THE KOREANS 5 MONTHS AFTER LEAVING U.S. POST
description: Michael K. Deaver represented a foreign client at a meeting with an official of the National Security Council five months after he left his job as deputy White House chief of staff, according to a report he filed with the Justice Department.

title: ELECTRONIC SPECIALTY PRODUCTS reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net loss

title: KELLOGG CO () reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The share earnings reflect a 2-for-1 stock split paid Jan. 6.

title: MINORITIES' CAUCUS, DIVIDED, FALTERS IN ALBANY
description: Twenty years after it was founded to advance the interests of minority groups, the state's Black and Puerto Rican Legislative Caucus has declined in influence and is suffering from deep divisions within its ranks, according to present and former members and other observers here.

title: TALMUDIC CLASSES ON CAPITOL HILL
description: The Place: H-131, a small lunchroom on the House side of the Capitol.

title: OHIO ART CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
STRIKE IN BOSTON HALTS COMMUTER RAIL SERVICE
description: This city's commuter rail service was halted today when unionized machinists and electricians joined striking railroad maintenance workers on picket lines. The 25,000 commuters who use the rail service were forced to find alternative transportation.

title: NASA SAYS AUDITS PRODUCED SAVINGS
description: The space agency asserted today that two New York Times articles depicting waste and mismanagement in the space program were ''inaccurate'' in some respects and gave ''a misleading impression'' of the agency's performance.

title: ALLIES IN ANTITERROR EFFORT
description: Attorney General Edwin Meese 3d said today that a new agreement between the United States and its European allies to share information about international terrorists was a sign of ''significantly greater cooperation'' in the Atlantic alliance.

title: The U.N. Today: April 26, 1986
description: ECONOMIC AND SOCIAL COUNCIL United Nations Children's Fund Executive Board - 10:30 A.M.

title: Hard Truths About Race
description: Former Gov. Charles Robb of Virginia offers this challenge to fellow Democrats: End the ''conspiracy of silence'' and start a frank discussion of ''new obstacles to black progress.'' It would be an undertaking both risky and promising, but the Democrats are well advised to try it.

title: LAWTER INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
MYERS (L.E.) COMPANIES (N) reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The company said latest first quarter results were affected by the closing of some operations, reductions in personnel and the sale of its Canadian unit.

title: LILY-TULIP INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Sea-Land, CSX
description: The board of the Sea-Land Corporation, a containerized shipping company, voted late today to permit the CSX Corporation to acquire its outstanding shares for $28 a share.

title: SILICON VALLEY GROUP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Career May Be in Peril
description: A knee injury suffered by Don Robinson of the Pittsburgh Pirates last Sunday while pitching against the Chicago Cubs is apparently more serious than first realized and could threaten the career of the 28-year-old right-hander. Robinson, who had arthroscopic surgery on his right knee last year, damaged a ligament in the knee and was placed on the 21-day disabled list Monday.

title:
Patents;
A Garden in Space By Inventor, 84
description: A space garden to rotate around the earth in perpetual sunshine and grow plants, was patented this week by Lawrence E. Stanhope, who is 84 years old and lives in Lakeland, Fla.

title: Malone Unable to Play
description: The Philadelphia 76ers will face the Washington Bullets tomorrow in the final game of their opening-round playoff series without Moses Malone, their star center who is recovering from fractures in the bones that surround his right eye. And should the 76ers win the game, which will be played in Philadelphia, they will be without him for the rest of the playoffs. Malone has not played since March 28 when he injured his eye in a game against the Milwaukee Bucks.

title: What the Friends Have Taught
description: Hundreds of Friends will gather in their beautiful old brick meeting house on New York's East 16th Street this weekend to worship - and also to celebrate. It is the bicentennial of Friends Seminary, a Quaker day school, and the community celebrates with them.

title: COMPUTER HORIZONS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
WEST CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
AERONCA INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
UNITED PRESIDENTIAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes investment gains of $75,049 for latest quarter and $31,744 for year-ago period.

title: RAMTEK CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income

title: U.S. TO ASK FARM TALKS IN TOKYO
description: President Reagan will urge participants at the Tokyo economic summit conference next week to work toward a reduction of quotas, subsidies and other barriers to world trade in farm goods, according to senior Administration officials.

title: AUSTRIAN SAYS WALDHEIM GOT ONLY CURSORY CHECK
description: Kurt Waldheim, the former United Nations Secretary General, was hired in 1946 as the personal secretary to Austria's Foreign Minister because American intelligence agencies said he was not a Nazi, according to the minister's top lieutenant, who had himself worked for American intelligence.

title: HARRIS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 28
description: Results are corrected from yesterday's editions.

AMERICAN MOTORS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
UNIFI INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 30
description: Share earnings reflect a 50-percent stock dividend paid in February 1986.

title: AETNA LIFE & CASUALTY CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes realized net capital gains of $71 million and a $38 million tax credit. c-After a $1 million realized capital loss.

title: BEARINGS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes a pre-tax charge of 12,500,000 for inventory writedown. c-Net income

title: 'CULTS' AND THE AGED: A NEW FAMILY ISSUE
description: Elderly men and women have increasingly become targets of solicitation by nontraditional religious groups, according to social workers, law enforcement officials and the American Association of Retired Persons.

title: Erte Designs Costumes Featured in Calif. Play
description: Erte, whose timeless costumes were the rage of Paris in the 1920's, has returned to the theater.

title: IN NEWARK MAYOR RACE, CLASHING VISIONS OF CITY
description: Broad Street in front of City Hall has been repaved and had its traffic stripes repainted, a sure sign, some say, that a city election is imminent. But this year the focus is on the 80-year-old City Hall itself, which has become a house divided.

title:
Patents;
Jump-Start Mechanism
description: The Ford Motor Company received a patent this week assigned by a West German inventor for an indefinitely variable transmission mechanism that can give a car a jump start or a slow push. Dieter Hahne of Bergisch-Gladbach was granted patent No. 4,583,423. Ford has no present plans to offer the invention.

title: ARLEY MERCHANDISE reports earnings for Qtr to March 28

Patents;
A Machine for First Aid
description: A LIGHT, battery-powered machine that helps a rescue worker provide first aid to a heart attack victim or someone suffering from a lung ailment was patented this week by a Massachusetts engineer.

title: BAKER, MICHAEL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Bronze Star for Slain Diver
description: The parents of Robert Dean Stethem, a Navy diver shot dead by hijackers of a Trans World Airlines jetliner in Beirut last June, today accepted a Bronze Star awarded posthumously to their son for ''extraordinary'' courage. Mr. and Mrs. Richard Stethem accepted the award at a ceremony at the Navy Seabee Memorial near the Arlington National Cemetery.

title: SATURDAY NEWS QUIZ
description: Questions are based on news reports in The Times this week. Answers appear on page 50. 1. To some observers, this symbolized the giant step a city took to promote an event. Identify the city and explain. 2. An announcement from Vienna about Kurt Waldheim, former Secretary General of the United Nations, was positive, but a recommendation from Washington that was negative. What were they? 3. What the House of Representatives gave itself one day it took away the next. What happened? 4. A food fish will be virtually unavailable in restaurants and stores in the metropolitan area. What kind of fish is it and what is the reason? 5. Five Democrats on the House Judiciary Committee have petitioned Attorney General Edwin Meese 3d to appoint an independent counsel to investigate some activities of a former Reagan Administration official. Who is he and what activities are they? 6. What European country said it would expel 21 Libyan students for suspected involvement in ''revolutionary activities?'' 7. The mighty oak is in Maryland, but mightier still are a sycamore in Ohio, a Douglas fir in Washington and a redwood and a sequoia in California. Explain. 8. Flags will fly at half-staff from Buckingham Palace and Government buildings on Tuesday, when the Duchess of Windsor is buried. True or false? 9. ''Not an easy thing for someone named Stevenson to do,'' said a political observer. To what action was he referring? 10. The Government of South Africa abolished laws prohibiting blacks from (living freely/moving freely/ living and moving freely) within the country. 11.

title: JOHN KORTY, A FILM DIRECTOR WHO PREFERS TV
description: According to the established wisdom in Hollywood, film is a director's medium while television is more likely to be a producer's medium. But John Korty, who has just directed ''Resting Place,'' a ''Hallmark Hall of Fame'' presentation to be shown this Sunday evening on CBS, disagrees.

title: WOLOHAN LUMBER CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
ALBA-WALDENSIAN INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income

title: ROCKET PAYLOAD THAT EXPLODED IS UNDER DEBATE
description: A respected trade publication is contradicting widespread reports that the Titan rocket that exploded last week was carrying an advanced spy satellite, the KH-11.

title: TITAN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes a loss from discontinued operations of $398,000. The 1985 results have been adjusted to reflect a pooling of interest merger in May 1985.

title: SCHWARTZ BROTHERS INC reports earnings for Year to Jan 31
BEVERLY INVESTMENT PROPERTIES reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Year-ago figures are not available as the company went public on Dec. 30, 1985.

title: OAKITE PRODUCTS INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
EG&G INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
CONCERT: UITTI AND GOLDSTEIN
description: Many of the interesting experiments with stringed-instrument sonority are being made with the bow. Frances-Marie Uitti and Malcolm Goldstein kept us abreast of them in a dual concert at the Alternative Museum on Wednesday night.

title: MURRAY LOUIS REMAINS TRUE TO HIS INITIAL STYLE
description: Murray Louis is still Murray Louis - as both dancer and choreographer, he remains recognizably himself. The three new works his dance company presented in New York this season would have to be called among the most inimitable in the dance world today.

title: CHANGE IS SOUGHT IN TAX COLLECTING
description: THE Democratic-controlled Senate passed a bill last week that seeks to put tax collections back where they were before a recent Tax Court decision.

title: PENN CREW WINS ADAMS CUP RACE
description: Pennsylvania's heavyweight varsity crew decisively defeated Harvard and Navy today, winning the Adams Cup for the first time since 1977 and re-establishing itself as the crew to beat for Eastern rowing supremacy.

title: NASA NOMINEE GETS A ONCE-OVER
description: SENATORS were clearly concerned last week by reports that the National Aeronautics and Space Administration had wasted more than $3.5 billion while cutting or delaying safety expenditures for the space shuttle.

title: The President's View of Deaverism
description: ''Mike has never put the arm on me, or sought anything or any influence from me since he has been out of government.'' Thus did President Reagan recently vouch for Michael Deaver, his former deputy chief of staff, now under investigation by the executive and legislative branches for possible violation of conflict-of-interest laws. In a technical sense, that testimonial to a friend may be completely accurate, but as is becoming clearer, remarkably incomplete.

title: LAROUCHE TACTICS PROVOKE DISPUTE
description: Charles R. Zimmerman is an elderly, forgetful and bewildered millionaire who says ''I'm mad at myself now'' for turning over hundreds of thousands of dollars to the network of organizations around the political extremist Lyndon H. LaRouche.

title: PROJECT NEAR WETLANDS GETS APPROVAL
description: AFTER a six-year battle with environmentalists and community activists, a developer has won approval from Nassau County to construct a condominium project in Glen Head 100 feet from a section of the county's largest tract of fresh-water wetlands.

title: ORGANIZING FOR EARLY MUSIC
description: ''I'll tell you why there is such an interest in early music,'' Benjamin Peck said the other day.

title: THAT'S ASPERA TESTING THE ICE
description: AMONG BIRCHES By Rebecca Hill. 323 pp. New York: William Morrow & Company. $17.95. REBECCA HILL'S first novel, ''Blue Rise,'' is prefaced by a quotation from Edna St. Vincent Millay that could apply to ''Among Birches'' as well: ''It's not true that life is one damn thing after another; life is the same damn thing over and over.'' In ''Blue Rise,'' Miss Hill's characters speak a near-perfect Deep Southern idiom. In this book, an otherwise engaging group lapses at times into an unfortunate psycho-rap. And while (as implied by her title) Miss Hill has this time left the Southern milieu behind, she has once more taken as her subject that nebulous, filamented and fragile relationship called marriage, that pairing in which man and woman become for each other lover, brother, sister, mother, father and friend. And she sets this alliance squarely where it belongs -within a context larger than the family of origin, the family of friends.

title: Stephanie Prohl To Marry in June
description: Mr. and Mrs. Edward R. K. Prohl of Chappaqua, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Stephanie Kurtz Prohl, to C. Stuart Chandler, a son of Joan Houze Chandler, also of Chappaqua, and Jerry Terrell Chandler of New York. A June wedding is planned.

title: CONTROVERSIAL TAX ON SALTWATER FISHING FACES HURDLES
description: THE REAGAN Administration's proposal to require a Federal license for saltwater recreational angling has hooked few supporters.

title: GRANT AIDS PROGRAM TO FIGHT ALCOHOLISM
description: WITH a donation of $6.7 million, the Rutgers University Center of Alcohol Studies and the New York State School of Industrial and Labor Relations at Cornell University plan to form a joint alcohol research institute that is expected to be the first preventive effort of its kind in the world.

title: R. E. Goldstein Is Engaged To Nancy Barnard Lubell
description: Mrs. Paul Barnard Lubell of Brookline, Mass., has announced the engagement of her daughter Nancy Barnard Lubell to Richard E. Goldstein, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Morris Goldstein of Deerfield Beach, Fla.

title: 'TALKING CAR' ADDS EXTRAS
description: THE FIRST time I drove a Maxima, it made me sit up and take notice because it was the world's first talking car, offering warnings about lights left on and doors ajar and other failures. That was back in 1981, long before Datsuns were being called Nissans, and the company's luxury four-door had just been introduced.

title: Out of the Herd, Into the Primary
description: One way to make news in recent months has been to announce a decision not to seek the Democratic nomination to run against New York's Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato; last week, Mark Green announced that he would seek it.

title: TV SHOPPING BRINGS THE MALL TO THE HOME
description: Susanne Birkner was sitting home, bored, flipping the cable channels one night, and there suddenly, on 29, was the Home Shopping Network, a new national show offering shopping by television for hours on end.

title: LIFE, DEATH ON A RENEWAL LINE
description: THE Monday morning line meanders out into the corridor, leaving newcomers to form a shivering clot outside the door. Evidently not a good time to take on the Motor Vehicle Bureau, but then I'm out of practice. I used to be able to renew my driver's license in a few moments at home.

title: EFFORT TO IMPROVE U.S. SCHOOLS ENTERING A NEW PHASE
description: A conviction is growing among American educators that, after several years of preoccupation with issues like competency tests for teachers and stiffer graduation requirements for students, the nationwide effort to improve the quality of public schools has entered a new and more complex stage.

title: Gramm-Rudman-Traficant
description: This month's award for Heroic Press Release goes to Representative James A. Traficant Jr. of Ohio, a freshman Democrat who is one of the litigants seeking to overturn the Federal budget-balancing law.

title: About Men; A Middle-Aged Orphan
description: I WAS 38 YEARS OLD when my father died. I am now 45, but I don't feel I had 38 years of fathering. In fact, I've heard more from my father these last seven years than I ever did when he was around.

title: The Striped Bass Ban Will Soon Go Statewide
description: There will soon be one less kind of fish to fry in New York State. Last week the state banned commercial fishing for striped bass because of unsafe levels of PCB's, a suspected carcinogen.

title: SPECIAL FILMS FOR SPECIAL PHOTOS
description: FILM has its own personality and perception. One type of film turns skies dark and makes a forest look white. Another sees only in extremes of black and white, erasing the grays that exist in any scene. Other film reacts to all colors of light and is of such fine grain that the viewer may be persuaded that the image is sharper than the original subject.

title: DOING THE WORKING WOMAN'S CHORES
description: SUSAN BELL, trying to juggle a new job and an apartment move in the same week, was struck by how badly she ''needed a wife.''

title: Mountain Yielding Last Buildable Tracts
description: LATE in the 17th century, Gerrit Geritse arrived from the Netherlands and obtained the land around what is now known as Garret Mountain in Passaic County - at 500 feet, one of the tallest in the state.

title: COUNTY CALLED BACK: A DAY-CARE SUCCESS
description: Florence S. Pearlman is certainly living in the past regarding the letter written by Shelley B. Mayer [ Letters to Westchester Editor, March 30 ] .

title: A Top I.R.A. Guerrilla Is Killed in Ambush
description: A leading Irish Republican Army guerrilla was shot and killed today in an ambush by British soldiers as he prepared to attack security forces, the police said.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: WITH LOUIS AND THE DUKE: The Autobiography of a Jazz Clarinetist. By Barney Bigard. (Oxford University, $18.95.) The autobiography of the jazz clarinetist Barney Bigard, edited by the British-born drummer and New Orleans music enthusiast Barry Martyn, is a congenial memoir by a man who went from collecting brick dust on the streets of New Orleans to being chauffeured in a Rolls-Royce.

title: Guest Observer; An Eye on Money
description: SOMETIME SOON I want to get all my money together and dump it on the kitchen table. My money and I seem to be drifting apart. The monthly, quarterly and annual accounting I get from assorted financial institutions isn't satisfactory. Just once, I'd like to see all of it in one place.

title: CORRECTION
description: A front-page headline and article yesterday about a plan to build a new Madison Square Garden misstated the cost.

title: Berbick Sued for Belt
description: When the Canadian Professional Boxing Federation stripped Trevor Berbick of his Canadian heavyweight title in January for refusing to defend the title, the group didn't make a clean job of it. Berbick lost the title but managed to hold on to his $1,500 championship belt.

title: MARCOS PLAINTIFFS FACING HURDLES
description: Lawyers in three cities for plaintiffs in suits involving Ferdinand E. Marcos are seeking to overcome complex legal questions of jurisdiction in order to use the United States Federal courts as a forum for the suits. They are also seeking the courts' authority to order Mr. Marcos to appear to give depositions.

title: HARRINGTON PARK
description: RESIDENTS of Harrington Park don't seem to mind when outsiders come to the conclusion that they live in an uneventful, sleepy little town.

title: 2 FRENCH LEADERS GET ALONG SO FAR
description: A leading conservative politician here was trying the other day to explain something that has surprised many in this country over the last six weeks: Prime Minister Jacques Chirac seems to be getting along very well with President Francois Mitterrand, a man he has spent years criticizing.

title: MICHAEL HEDGES, WINDHAM HILL GUITARIST, TO PERFORM
description: TWO of the county's most distinguished older theaters and one of its best-known choruses will present performances this Saturday, heralding one of the year's busiest entertainment months.

title: COULD THE FED GO 'OVER THE SIDE'?
description: WHILE the Reagan Administration and others were urging the Supreme Court last week to yank the teeth of the 1985 deficit-reduction law, there were suggestions from their opponents that the Administration's argument threatened what has been called the Government's ''headless fourth branch.'' This is the collection of more than a dozen independent regulatory agencies created over the last century, including the Federal Reserve Board, the Federal Trade Commission and the Securities and Exchange Commission.

title: 'ETHICAL' STOCK FUND MAKES MARK
description: IT WAS at a boat show, during the gasoline shortages of the early 1970's, that Maurice L. Schoenwald, a lawyer from Great Neck, got the idea for a mutual fund that would invest in alternative-energy and energy-conservation businesses.

title: Lois E. Lovett Is Wed To William J. Drewes
description: Lois E. Lovett and William J. Drewes were married yesterday. The Rev. John Denniston performed the ceremony at St. Mary's Roman Catholic Church in Manhasset, L.I. The couple's parents are Mr. and Mrs. Thomas B. Lovett of Manhasset and Mr. and Mrs. William F. Drewes of Douglaston, Queens.

title: Wedding Planned By Miss Franklin, Derek Kirkland
description: Mr. and Mrs. Donald R. L. Franklin of Short Hills, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter Elizabeth Ames Franklin to Derek Granger Kirkland, a son of Mr. and Mrs. William G. Kirkland of New York.

title: FLAMES STYMIE OILERS
description: Lanny McDonald and Joel Otto scored second-period goals and the rookie Mike Vernon stopped 30 shots tonight, helping the Calgary Flames push Edmonton near elimination with a 4-1 victory over the defending Stanley Cup champion Oilers.

title: FUND HONORS 16 WHO RISKED LIVES FOR OTHERS
description: A 14-year-old Louisiana boy who battled his way through rapids to save a friend has been honored by the Carnegie Hero Fund Commission.

title: Article 499886 -- No Title
description: A pollution-control company in Suffolk County has paid the largest penalty for violating an environmental law in state history.

title: Noel Pick Is Wed To Miss D'Amico
description: Mary Lisbeth D'Amico, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John F. D'Amico of Princeton, N.J., and Noel Christopher Pick, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Franz A. Pick of Munich, West Germany, were married yesterday in the Catholic Mission of St. James in Rocky Hill, N.J. The Rev. John M. Banko officiated.

title: A FRENCH STAR LOSES ONE
description: LA MASCOTTE in Commack was last reviewed a year ago and received three stars. This February the restaurant moved to new, larger quarters a few hundred yards away, but it has a similar French country look.

title: Talking Multiple Bids; Hot Market Requires Strategies
description: THE overheated market for homes in the New York suburbs has brought on the return of competitive bidding. It is a phenomenon peculiar to exceptionally strong markets and can affect the customary negotiating strategies of both buyers and sellers.

title: WHEN LOOKS PLEASANTLY DECEIVE
description: LONG before the first bite of food arrives at the table, diners can employ a few short cuts to size up an unfamiliar restaurant's potential.

title: 'ALICE' AND DEL TREDICI - GOING STEADY
description: David Del Tredici has spent nearly 20 years composing while under the influence of Lewis Carroll's ''Alice'' books. He has set ''Jabberwocky,'' the Mad Tea Party, the Lobster Quadrille and, more recently, the two elegiac preface poems, moving from nonsense into grand passion. The obsession has produced a hit record - the Chicago Symphony's recording of ''Final Alice'' with Georg Solti and soprano Barbara Hendricks made it onto the classical charts alongside the Pachelbel Canon and Luciano Pavarotti, almost unheard of for a contemporary piece -and now an hourlong ballet choreographed by Glen Tetley for the National Ballet of Canada. Life with ''Alice'' has also radically changed the style of the composer's music, and driven him to create a new concert form which ignores practicality.

title: Grappling With the Housing Issue
description: ''WE promise to do better.'' That seems to be the gist of a reply by the Koch administration to the call by the city's major development companies for faster, more-dependable, better-coordinated processing of housing proposals.

title: POLISHING THE TEEN-AGE MOVIE IMAGE
description: ''Teen-agers have no advocate,'' maintains David Seltzer. ''I think any other minority so maligned by Hollywood would have pickets around the theater saying: 'We are not just idiots.' ''

title: WATSON SLIPS INTO TIE FOR LEAD
description: Midway through the front nine at The Woodlands Tournament Players Club course today, Calvin Peete turned to his caddie, Dolpus (Golf Ball) Hull, and said, ''It looks like Watson is back.''

title: DEBATE ON DIRT ROADS: CHARM VS. COMFORT
description: EDWARD J. Kearin, Highway Superintendent for the town of Lewisboro, pointed down the winding dirt road where crews were pouring fill into the ruts and potholes that were the remains of the ravage each winter wreaks on the town's dirt roads. A month ago, he said, ''You'd have seen miles of mud with deep ruts, almost impassable. We got calls about cars getting stuck in mud. Well, they just have to get towed, and it's not the department's responsibility.''

title: BROOKHAVEN OFFICE RENTAL IN DISPUTE
description: BROOKHAVEN Town officials are embroiled in a battle with the owner of an East Patchogue office building that the town rents.

title: Le Carre's Toughest Case
description: Joseph Lelyveld's article ''Le Carre's Toughest Case,'' (March 16) brought back a flood of memories and prompted me to write this reminiscence of John le Carre's father, Ronald Cornwell, from his American daughter-in-law's perspective.

title: CABARET: CLAUDIA HOMMEL SINGS 'CANCIONES A LA VIDA'
description: CLAUDIA HOMMEL, a singer and actress who performs in both theater and cabaret, brings a sense of theater with her when she goes into cabaret. Last year, in several appearances at Jan Wallman's, she performed ''a workingperson's cabaret'' that brought together songs and comments on various kinds and circumstances of labor.

title: THE DO'S AND DON'TS OF USING PORTABLE ELECTRIC SANDERS
description: PORTABLE electric sanding machines can save hours of tedious and tiring hand sanding or scraping -provided the right machine is selected and properly handled.

title: MOVING AT 120 M.P.H. (SOMETIMES)
description: After years of declining rail travel in the United States, a steadily growing number of Americans are turning to Amtrak. They are finding that it can often be much more convenient and comfortable and sometimes more reliable to travel by train instead of plane. Experience demonstrates repeatedly, however, that an Amtrak traveler should be prepared to cope with the unexpected, because problems are frequent.

title: PUBIC ART THRIVES WITH STATE SUPPORT
description: CONNECTICUT is becoming known as a patron of the arts, having committed nearly $2.3 million in the last few years for sculpture, paintings, wall hangings and stained glass. This art, not found in museums or art galleries, is on view at schools, courthouses and other public buildings.

title: THE DWINDLING BLACK PRESENCE ON CAMPUS
description: WINGS and claws ferociously displayed, a squadron of stone griffins perches atop Cobb Gate, the Gothic entrance to the main quadrangles of the University of Chicago. Not long after I began my Ph.D. studies there more than a decade ago, a book was published showing a photograph of the most forbidding of Cobb's griffins with what was then viewed as a humorous caption - ''admissions officer defying entrant.'' Today, not everyone would find that funny. Since reaching a peak in the mid-1970's, the number of black students and faculty at American colleges and universities has once again declined, and any hint of a revival of exclusionism is no joking matter.

title: WRITER-IN-RESIDENCE: Norman R. Augustine; TEACHING MARIETTA THE LAW OF DIVERSITY
description: IN the 1960's, as a rising middle-level manager in the aerospace business, Norman R. Augustine felt like a frustrated prophet of doom. Everywhere he saw projects taking pratfalls, efficiency being destroyed by too many auditors, too many Government regulations, and too many managers demanding too many meetings and too much paperwork.

title:
ON LONG ISLAND;
Mitchel Field Is Fulfilling Its Promise
description: WHEN the Federal Government turned the 1,265-acre Mitchel Field air base over to Nassau County 25 years ago, the stipulation was that the property be used for the benefit of the county's residents. A recently completed survey by the Town of Hempstead's Department of Industry and Commerce shows that after a long delay the county gained many benefits from the property more are to come soon.

title: WHERE SEALS AND BIRDS STEAL THE SHOW
description: The chill bare world of the Pribilof Islands narrowed to a jagged rectangle in a plywood observation blind.

title: METS STOP CARD BID IN 9TH AND TAKE 8TH IN ROW, 4-3
description: When you're hot, you're hot. And the Mets stayed red-hot today as they beat the St. Louis Cardinals, 4-3, for the third straight time, for their eighth straight victory over all and for the Cardinals' sixth straight loss.

title: CORRECTION
description: The caption accompanying an article last Sunday about the Bach Aria Group incorrectly identified members of the group. Musicians pictured were members of the John F. Kennedy High School Band in Plainview as they were being instructed by an artist-fellow of the Bach Aria Group, and flutists rehearsing separately.

title: Sally Kaufmann Weds Richard Kirkpatrick Jr.
description: The Hammond Museum in North Salem, N.Y., was the setting yesterday for the wedding of Sally English Kaufmann and Richard Bruce Kirkpatrick Jr. The Rev. C. Kenneth Hall, a Presbyterian minister, officiated.

title: History Begins to Draw Lessons From Libya Raid
description: To the Editor:

title: Elizabeth Meyers Marries
description: Elizabeth Meyers and Jeffrey Scott Portnoy were married yesterday at the Sky Terrace of the Galleria in New York. Rabbi David Posner officiated. The couple's parents are Edward M. Meyers of New York and Betty Gardner Meyers of Santa Fe, N.M., and Sid Portnoy of Tarrytown, N.Y., and Bernice Portnoy of Selden, L.I.

title: Opposition Leader Is Arrested in Liberia
description: The chairman of a coalition of four Liberian opposition parties has been arrested on charges of sedition, the private Monrovia radio station Elwa reported today.

title: LEMMON RELIVES THE PAST IN O'NEILL'S JOURNEY
description: WHen the curtain descends on Eugene O'Neill's ''Long Day's Journey Into Night,'' as shattering a moment as the American theater knows, Jack Lemmon lets out a moan that sounds soul-deep. It is the final personal stamp in a performance as James Tyrone that promises to stir passions and incite debates much as Dustin Hoffman's Willy Loman did two seasons ago. Similarly, the revival under Jonathan Miller's direction, which opens tomorrow at the Broadhurst, dares to defy the traditional approach to O'Neill, which saw its ultimate expression in the Jose Quintero-Jason Robards revival of ''The Iceman Cometh'' earlier this season.

title:
USE TARIFFS, NOT QUOTAS;
ENDING THE 'LUNACY' OF TRADE PROTECTION
description: ALTHOUGH the dollar has weakened over the past year, the trade deficit remains uncomfortably large and continues to generate pleas for protection. In response to the pleas, America is increasingly extending protection to its industries and doing so in the worst way - with quotas rather than tariffs.

title: Recent Sales
description: Belle Mead $219,000 4 Staats Farm Road *2*4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, new colonial; breakfast room, *2*front and rear porches, 1.5 acres; taxes to be assessed. Edison $121,000 2104 Timber Oaks Road *2*2-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 2-year-old town-house condominium; *2*foyer, patio, $69 monthly charges; taxes $1,595. Franklin Township $168,000 531 New Brunswick Road *2*4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 3-year-old colonial; *2*foyer, family room, patio; taxes $2,872. Middletown $141,900 59 New Monmouth Road *2*3-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 6-month-old colonial; *2*cathedral ceiling, 1.5 acres; taxes to be assessed. Mountain Lakes $170,700 204 Boulevard *2*4-bedroom, 2-bath, 30-year-old Cape Cod; *2*screened porch, patio, 2d kitchen; taxes $3,174. Saddle River $380,000 240 East Saddle River Road *2*4-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 77-year-old chalet; *2*fireplace, modern kitchen, 2.5 acres; taxes $2,375. OTHER AREAS Islip Terrace, L.I. $100,000 135 Sea Cliff Street *2*4-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 30-year-old high ranch; *2*dining room, eat-in kitchen, den; taxes, $2,800. Millwood, N.Y. $132,500 302 Saw Mill River Road *2*2-bedroom, 2-bath, 37-year-old, 2-story frame; 2-story; *2*eat-in kitchen, fenced yard, nursery, 0.33 acre; taxes $2,912. Redding, Conn. $210,000 18 Deacon Abbott Lane *2*4-bedroom, 2-bath, 10-year-old raised ranch; *2*hardwood floors, 2.3 acres; taxes $2,205.

title: PLAYS THAT SOUND LIKE SITCOMS AND SOAPS
description: If we are to accept the evidence in Andrew Bergman's ''Social Security,'' residents of Mineola are unsophisticated provincials who never go to the theater unless ''Fiddler on the Roof'' is playing and for whom brie is a shockingly expensive delicacy on the level of caviar. The fact is that these and other observations are figments of Mr. Bergman's joke-filled imagination (an imagination that was earlier, and more enjoyably, demonstrated in his screenplays for the movies ''Blazing Saddles'' and ''The In-Laws''). Mineolans - and their Long Island neighbors in Garden City and Hempstead, as well - could easily outsmart ''Social Security,'' the latest in a wave of plays that demonstrate that the theater is increasingly becoming a way station for the fare one might normally find on television. Call it the Sitcom and Soap Sweepstakes. Undoubtedly, there are television talent scouts in every audience, along with nonprofessional theatergoers who like to be reminded of what amused or interested them on their home screens.

title: Opticians Helping in Search For Killer of Swedish Premier
description: Opticians are contributing to the search for the killer of Prime Minister Olof Palme, the police say.

title: Margaret Blakey To Marry in July
description: Albert Gallatin Blakey 3d and Gretchen Vedder Blakey of York, Pa., have announced the engagement of their daughter Margaret Strait Blakey to Glenn Anthony Pagan, the son of Mr. and Mrs. John Pagan of New York. A July 26 wedding is planned.

title: AT JOHNSON TRIAL, GLIMPSES OF THE RICH
description: On the cluttered conference table in Surrogate Marie M. Lambert's vast office the other day lay a cellophane-wrapped packet of cocktail napkins. Their inscription: ''Where there's a will, there's a relative.''

title: True Loyalty
description: To the Editor:

title: Maggi Payne's Version Of California Music
description: On the basis of her concert Thursday night at the Experimental Intermedia Foundation, 224 Centre Street, Maggi Payne would appear to be a lesser but still valuable member of the California school of electronic composers - a school that constitutes about the most vital source of electronic music being created today.

title: GROWING UP AT THE SAVOY
description: BOSTON BOY By Nat Hentoff. 176 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $15.95. ''EATING a huge salami sandwich very slowly'' on Yom Kippur, the Day of Atonement, the day of fasting, while sitting on his family's porch overlooking the main street leading to the local synagogue, 12-year-old Nat Hentoff enjoyed not so much ''that awful sandwich'' as the experience of his first act of rebellion, and the knowledge of ''how it felt to be an outcast.'' Inquiring, exploring, observing, Mr. Hentoff grew up in the Boston of the 1930's and 40's, where he learned about prejudice first-hand from youthful gangs of ''Irishers,'' then learned how to fight anti-Semitism when he went to work at age 15 for a crusading young Irish Catholic editor, Frances Sweeney, to whom he dedicates this book.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: VERACRUZ. By Rosalind Wright. (Harper & Row, $18.95.) Veracruz, Mexico's principal Caribbean port, provides a fabulous setting for this ambitious historical novel.

title: Kenneth A. Lang Wed To Miss van Bemmelen
description: Deborah Ann van Bemmelen, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Henri van Bemmelen of Rye, N.Y., was married yesterday to Kenneth Andrew Lang, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Wesley Lang of Garden City, N.Y. The Rev. David Uhl, a Presbyterian minister, and the Rev. William Meyer, a Lutheran minister, officiated at the ceremony at the Rye Presbyterian Church.

title:
INVESTING;
LOOKING FOR A SURGE IN O-T-C STOCKS
description: THE Dow Jones industrial average and the Standard & Poor's 500 index have been smashing records in the recent market rally. Meanwhile, the Nasdaq industrial average, an index of securities traded over-the-counter, has yet even to graze the high mark it scored in June 1983.

title: Anne Brockie Is Wed To Michael F. Wright
description: Anne Simmons Brockie, a daughter of Sarah K. O'Hara of Old Lyme, Conn., and Arthur H. Brockie of Mountain Lakes, N.J., was married yesterday to Michael Francis Wright, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Philip J. Wright of Armonk, N.Y. The Revs. Jack M. McKelvey and Norman Hall performed the ceremony at St. Paul's Episcopal Church in Englewood, N.J.

title: AUTO LAW CHANGES SOUGHT BY CUOMO
description: Governor Cuomo proposed changes in the state's so-called lemon law this week that would give greater protection to consumers who buy problem-plagued new cars.

title: YONKERS WEIGHS RULING ON SCHOOLS
description: THE outline of a final school integration plan for Yonkers was issued in Federal Court last week, but the proposal - a compromise, the contending parties agreed - only seemed to open a new chapter in the five-year-old legal struggle.

title: Marie Sourbeer to Wed
description: Marie Sourbeer and Spero Thomas Lappas of Harrisburg, Pa., plan to be married July 12 in Harrisburg. Mrs. Sourbeer, the daughter of M. and Mrs. Donald Waugh of Harrisburg, is a medical assistance worker with the Pennsylvania Department of Public Welfare. Her fiance, the son of Mrs. Tom Lappas of Danbury, Conn., and the late Mr. Lappas, is a partner in the law firm of Stefanon & Lappas. The future bride's marriage and that of Mr. Lappas ended in divorce.

title:
ART;
PHOTOGRAPHERS EXPLORE ARTIFICE
description: ALONGSIDE so-called ''straight photography'' -the capturing of the real world that runs the gamut from the work of Ansel Adams to everybody's snapshots - there is and has always been photography concerned with the creation of art, with the imitation of painting, and, thus, with artifice. Such concocted photographs have abounded lately and the work of some of the most-noted practitioners has been gathered for ''Photographic Fictions,'' an exhibition at the Whitney Museum of American Art in nearby Stamford, Conn., through May 28.

title: Youthful Enthusiasms
description: How sad to read the earnest letters of March 23 regarding Mario Vargas Llosa's charming article, ''My Son, the Rastafarian'' (Feb. 16). Apparently, not one of those writers is a parent, as each missed what was, to my mind, Mr. Vargas Llosa's point: Young people go through many stages, some bizarre enough to cause their elders consternation, pain and even embarrassment, but, given time, ''this, too, shall pass.''

title: NEW GROUP AIDS JAPANESE STUDENTS
description: A NEW organization in the county is attempting to help Japanese parents obtain appropriate educational services for their children in the local schools.

title: ONLY AS OLD AS YOU FEEL
description: They come to laugh, share stories and learn at the Steinberg Senior Citizen Center, run by the town of Greenburg. The director, Elsie Morris, stretches the imagination with her crafts workshop while 76-year-old fitness expert Emily Crispens gets the blood flowing with her exercises.

title: HUDSON CROSSINGS SET RECORD
description: VEHICULAR traffic between New Jersey and New York City reached a record in 1985, with 105.6 million cars, trucks and buses entering the city from the Garden State.

title: CANNONEER CREATES JUST THE RIGHT BOOM
description: WHEN Connecticut towns plan a special event, they frequently call on John Kovacs of Guilford.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: SEASONS OF THE HEART. By Cynthia Freeman. (Putnam, $17.95.) With her track record of best-selling titles (''Come Pour the Wine,'' ''No Time for Tears''), Cynthia Freeman's new novel is already a commercial success.

title: A NEIL SIMON GEM FUNNY AND MOVING
description: DURING the last 20 years it has been a rare season in which a Neil Simon play has not lighted up a Broadway theater. Regardless of what the critics write about Mr. Simon, his mega-hit plays such as ''Barefoot in the Park,'' ''Plaza Suite,'' ''Biloxi Blues'' and ''Brighton Beach Memoirs'' have made him America's most popular playwright.

title: BACK TO THE WORLD OF 'THE GLITTERING PRIZES'
description: While no quite a class reunion, ''Oxbridge Blues,'' a series of seven films adapted by Frederic Raphael from his own short stories, in part returns to the terrain that served as the canvas for Mr. Raphael's ''Glittering Prizes,'' the acclaimed BBC mini-series that played here on public television in 1978.

title: I.R.S. Audits
description: To the Editor:

title: A HIGH-RENT DISTRICT: MAIN STREET IN WESTPORT
description: ON a recent Saturday in Westport, the narrow sidewalks of Main Street were teeming as usual with shoppers. They strolled past two rows of trendy stores, including 18 clothing shops, 3 bookstores, 9 restaurants and a specialty pet-food shop. There seemed to be no doubt that Main Street was in a healthy condition.

title:
DINING OUT;
BUCKS COUNTY: A PLUS AND A MINUS
description: WITH the warmer days and breaking buds of spring, thoughts turn to a ramble in the countryside capped, perhaps, with dinner at a rustic inn.

title: OFFICIALS RECALL DEAVER AS ACTIVE ON CANADA ISSUE
description: White House officials say that when Michael K. Deaver was deputy White House chief of staff he adamantly urged that a special envoy on the acid rain issue be appointed, as was sought by Canada, according to a report to Congress.

title: PREPARING FOR THE JOB SEARCH
description: JOHN PAGANO, a senior at Pace University, had a bad habit that could have hurt his chances on job interviews. He tended to slouch in his chair. In a mock interview with Alba Shane, director of career planning and placement for Pace, Mr. Pagano became aware of his bad habit and corrected it.

title: STAGE: 'EMERALD CITY,' BASED ON BARRY
description: IN a program note to ''Emerald City,'' his new play at the Colonnades Theater, Donald Marcus acknowledges his debt to Philip Barry. Actually, ''Emerald City'' is a reworking of Mr. Barry's ''Holiday'' for the ''me-first generation.'' As such, it is a flip comedy about shallow people.

title: SAMUELSON-DRENTH TAKE RUN
description: There were people who came out because their partner demanded they come out. There were people who were waiting for the computer to give them a partner because they did not have one. There were husbands partnered with wives, fathers partnered with daughters, and brothers partnered with sisters. And there were famous partners.

title: Minors and Adults
description: To the Editor:

title: RARE MOMENT FOR A GLOBAL ECONOMY
description: IN a single week, the Japanese fretted that the yen had climbed too high, Federal Reserve Board chairman Paul A. Volcker thought aloud about the dollar collapsing, and Treasury Secretary James A. Baker 3d berated West Germany for not cutting taxes and interest rates more. Meanwhile last week, the Senate Finance Committee nearly blocked President Reagan's attempt to widen trade with Canada, and the acrimony over protectionism in agriculture reached the point where the Common Market's ambassador to Washington called American charges ''hogwash.''

title: QUIET EFFICIENCY BEGETS SUCCESS IN SAO PAULO
description: A quarter of a century ago, many of the best American players were rugged individualists - brilliant cardplayers, full of determination but intolerant of their partners. Sparks would fly at the table, and partnerships tended to be short-lived.

title: CORRECTION
description: The publisher of ''Turning the Tide: U.S. Intervention in Central America and the Struggle for Peace'' by Noam Chomsky was listed incorrectly in the April 13 Book Review. The publisher is South End Press.

title: WORKERS AREN'T BETTING ON INFLATION
description: NEARLY 15 years ago, amid considerable fanfare, the Communications Workers of America signed its first contract with A.T. & T. that included a clause automatically increasing wages as the Consumer Price Index rose. Labor viewed the cost-of-living adjustment, or COLA, as one of its principal achievements, a big step toward insulating paychecks from the ravages of inflation.

title: IS THE ARMS CONTROL AGENCY FOR CONTROL?
description: To the Editor:

title: BRITAIN'S TIES TO U.S. ARE BEGINNING TO CHAFE
description: ''WE'VE seen the consequences of saying yes to the use of the bases,'' a member of Margaret Thatcher's Cabinet remarked as he surveyed the political fallout from the Prime Minister's hugely unpopular decision to go along with President Reagan on the Libyan bombing raid. ''We haven't seen the consequences of saying no.''

title: REAGAN TRIES TO BREAK THE LOGJAM IN CONGRESS
description: SQUEEZED into President Reagan's schedule last week as he prepared for the annual economic meeting of leading industrial democracies was a session highlighting both the environment he leaves and the one to which he will no doubt be returning.

title: E. D. Pardoe 3d, Helen Mahoney Exchange Vows
description: Helen Stephenson Mahoney was married yesterday to Edward Devon Pardoe 3d by the Rev. Harold E. Barrett at Grace Episcopal Church in New York. The bride is a daughter of Daniel J. Mahoney and Jean W. Mahoney, both of Palm Beach, Fla.

title: After the Challenger
description: John Noble Wilford's article on the space shuttle appears to overestimate the shuttle payload launch costs compared with those of competitive expendable launch vehicles (E.L.V.'s). The article cites a ''true mission cost'' of $124 million, or $50 million more than the scheduled NASA price for commercial users.

title: CUOMO'S POLITICAL GAMBLE
description: When the Governor of New York criticizes the President of the United States and his policies as sharply as Mario Cuomo did before the American Newspaper Publishers Association in San Francisco the other day, you have to think he's in a great hurry to leave Albany and replace Ronald Reagan in the White House.

title: NEW JERSEY GUIDE
description: BUCKLEY AT SETON HALL William F. Buckley Jr. is coming to Seton Hall University in South Orange Thursday to speak, but he is not likely to be billed as a May Day speaker.

title: PORTABLE CD PLAYERS GROW STILL SMALLER AND CHEAPER
description: They were meant for joggers, but somebody had misjudged the audience. It wasn't just runners and other peripatetic folk who wanted those portable CD players you can wear on a strap and take for a walk. People buy them who never take them outdoors. They plug them into their regular home stereo systems. It's a cheap and easy way to enter the digital era with a minimum of fuss.

title: January and Littler Lead by 4
description: Don January and Gene Littler teamed for a third-round 65 today and took a four-stroke lead in the Liberty Mutual Legends of Golf tournament. Their score after 54 holes was 191, 19 under par.

title: COMRADE ETCETERA'S REPORT FROM HELL
description: KANGAROO By Yuz Aleshkovsky. Translated by Tamara Glenny. 278 pp. New York: Farrar, Straus & Giroux. $17.95. WITH due respect, and apologies, to Leonard Schapiro and Robert Conquest, the most searching histories about the Stalin era in the Soviet Union have been written by novelists like Aleksandr Solzhenitsyn and Arthur Koestler and memoirists like Nadezhda Mandelstam and Eugenia Ginzburg. In recent years, the novelist Vassily Aksyonov, Ginzburg's son, has joined this group, and now there is Yuz Aleshkovsky, another emigre from the Soviet Union to the United States, whose Schweikian novel ''Kangaroo'' - as obscene a book as I have read in years, and who can blame him? - uses laughter to reveal hell. The translation must have been unusually difficult, and is marvelously done by Tamara Glenny.

title: TOWARD GLOBAL ORDER
description: Most comments on the United States' accelerating campaign against Libya have treated it as an isolated episode, provoked by an eccentric, and confined to the issue of terrorism, for which a state is legally responsible. But the American pressure on Libya should also be viewed in the cold perspective of geopolitics as the first step in carrying out what should be called the Reagan Doctrine.

title: APPEAL FILED IN DISMISSAL OF LIBEL SUIT AGAINST BOSTON GLOBE
description: John R. Lakian, a Republican candidate for Governor of Massachusetts in 1982 whose libel suit against The Boston Globe was dismissed last summer, has filed an appeal seeking to be declared the winner in the case and to be awarded nominal damages.

title: Miss Michaud, G. Scott Diddel To Be Married
description: The engagement of Suzanne Marie Michaud to G. Scott Diddel, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Andrew G. Diddel of New York and West Falmouth, Mass., has been announced by her mother, Anna G. Michaud of Greenwich, Conn.

title: Budget Juggling Is Not Just a Memory
description: Stealing a leaf (page 97, inter alia) from the high-priced memoirs of David Stockman, Budget Director James Miller, his successor, has now announced that the Federal deficit really isn't as bad as the world believes - if Congress would only accept his numbers. Forewarned by Mr. Stockman's chronicle of his years juggling budget estimates, Congress ought to respond with a suspicion bordering on contempt.

title: VICTORIAN FANTASIES RULE SEA CLIFF
description: ''I TOLD Richard, my husband, never take me to Long Island and put me in a ranch house,'' recalled Karen Santoro, who grew up in a vintage Colonial in Providence, R.I.

title: THE TELEVISION GAP ON LONG ISLAND
description: Nassau County Comptroller Peter King's odyssey for political support to upstate New York was recently reported [ ''King Tests Waters Upstate'' ] . Like other Long Islanders in public life before him, Mr. King was surprised by the media attention available in Buffalo.

title: CONSUMER RATES
GOING ON IN THE NORTHEAST
description: AFRICA IN BALTIMORE Joe, the Baltimore Zoo's newly acquired bull elephant, will be at home today in his week-old, three-acre park, separated by a natural stone wall, at least for the present, from three neighboring elephants, Dolly, Vaal and Anna.

title: BO, CONSIDER THESE OPTIONS IN CHOOSING YOUR SPORT
description: BOY, do I know what Bo Jackson has been going through! Although it seems like yesterday, it was three years ago that I was in a similar situation, a situation that everybody wishes they were in but a difficult one once you're in it.

title: HAWKS DEPENDING ON SIZE
description: More than any other National Basketball Association team, the Boston Celtics, with their big, strong and talented front line, have influenced how teams draft, make trades or seek free-agent talent.

title: GOING BY THE LABEL
description: MAN'S CALENDAR IS SET BY THE stars; wine's is fixed by nature. The fury of the January storm determines the date the vines flower in June; the heat of the August sun sets the date of the September harvest. No dates in the wine calendar are immutable: even Nov. 15, the day they always open the floodgates of the Beaujolais nouveau, was ignored last year to give the grapes more time on the vine.

title: CHAPTER AND VERSE ON HOW TO BUILD A GOTHIC CATHEDRAL
description: While they were visiting Amiens Cathedral prior to making a film based on David Macaulay's 1973 book ''Cathedral: The Story of Its Construction,'' Larry Klein and his associates from Unicorn Projects saw that the book, with its cross-hatched drawings reminiscent of 19th-century black-and-white illustration, was sold at the cathedral's memento shop and was used by many visitors, including families. As the production crew walked through the awesome cathedral, one of the purest Gothic churches in France, they found themselves, like other visitors, referring to the book's drawings that detail the church's construction. ''We realized we were experiencing the cathedral with the book,'' said Mr. Klein, one of the film's producers. ''We decided to try to make the film do the same.''

title: Whitson Misses A Start and Blames Pain and Ailment
description: Ed Whitson was scheduled to start at Yankee Stadium yesterday, but he never made it to the mound against the Cleveland Indians. Whitson cited intestinal problems and a soreness in his rib cage as the reason he did not pitch.

title: CORRECTION
description: A London dispatch yesterday on Britain's order curtailing the activities of Libyan students incorrectly reported the number of students affected. It is 334.

title:
GARDENING;
WHEN BULBS HAVE STOPPED BLOOMING
description: TO most of us, flowering bulbs capture the very essence of spring. Their tender, green shoots emerge from the ground at the first hint of the new season's warmth, and persevere against winter's belated attempts to prevail. They soon burst into bloom, often where the last vestige of winter is still evident in melting drifts of snow.

title: MORTGAGE REFINANCING SURGING
description: THE Grobers of West Hills acquired $25,000 for home-improvement purposes by refinancing their three-year-old mortgage. The Burkes refinanced their Smithtown home and realized more than $100,000 for investment purposes.

title: PROSPECTS
description: Another Discount Drop?

title: YACHT RACE TO SALUTE LIBERTY
description: Now and then, one of the giant catamarans and trimarans that commonly compete in European yachting races also enters a race in the United States. But next week, at least nine of these monoliths are expected to leave Rouen, France, for a race that will finish in New York Harbor.

title: EUROPE TRIES TO FIND ITS OWN WAY TO FIGHT BACK
description: IT is a long way from Tripoli to Tokyo, but the American bombardment of Libya has succeeded in catapulting terrorism to the top of the agenda for the leaders of the seven largest industrial democracies when they meet in Japan beginning next Sunday. The air attacks - and President Reagan's assertion that he might repeat them or even extend them to Syria or Iran if those countries, too, were found to be fomenting terrorism - provoked contradictory impulses of anxiety and belated solidarity among United States allies. They also opened a difficult debate about the role of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization.

title: STEADY ELECTRICITY COST SEEN IN NEW YORK AREA
description: Electricity bills for many residents of New York, New Jersey and Connecticut are expected to remain stable or to fall during the rest of the year because of lower prices for oil and other fuels, utility officials and regulators say.

title:
WESTCHESTER JOURNAL;
WOMEN'S HEALTH
description: ''This is our third annual Women's Health Day -we've had terrific success with it,'' said Dinah G. Reath, president of the auxiliary of the Northern Westchester Hospital Center, which will sponsor the event at the hospital on Tuesday from 10 A.M. to 3 P.M. The program will include morning and afternoon seminars on a variety of topics.

title: Maureen T. Houghton Weds James B. Blaney
description: Maureen Theresa Houghton and James Bernard Blaney, students at St. John's School of Law, were married yesterday at St. Patrick's Roman Catholic Church in Smithtown, L.I., by the Rev. Robert F. McKee.

title: SIX PIANISTS TO VIE IN CONTEST
description: NEXT month, a career will be launched. That was the motivation in establishing the Marcia M. Polayes National Young Artists Competition, sponsored by the New Haven Symphony and being held for the first time on May 17.

title: MOVIEMAKERS COME TO MAIN STREET
description: WHEN the producers of ''The River'' wanted stars Sissy Spacek and Mel Gibson to battle an on-camera flood, Tennessee obligingly located farmland that could be flooded on demand. Kentucky let film crews for a PBS version of ''The Adventures of Huckleberry Finn'' dump 50 truckloads of dirt on a paved street to recreate a 19th century setting. And when NBC needed a bank to blow up for a TV movie, Minnesota found one that was slated for demolition.

title: Susan Caulfield Langham Is Engaged
description: The engagement of Susan Caulfield Langham to Alexander Timpson, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Carl W. Timpson of Locust Valley, L.I., and Prouts Neck, Me., has been announced by her parents, Jean Sheridan of Wickford, R.I., and Charles Markham Langham Jr., of Lenox, Mass. The wedding is planned for July.

title: Robin Crawford To Wed in August
description: Mrs. Frank A. Crawford of Glastonbury, Conn., has announced the engagement of her daughter, Robin Vicki Crawford, to Andrew Mark Heller, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Preston B. Heller Jr. of Chagrin Falls, Ohio. An August wedding is planned.

title: Susan Reinfeld To Wed in Fall
description: Mr. and Mrs. Albert I. Reinfeld of South Orange, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Susan Mann Reinfeld, to Jeffrey Zager, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Jack Zager of Nashville.

title: DEVISING THE STRATEGY FOR A VISIT
description: A temporary cease-fire has been declared in Kyoto's Great Temple War, and that is both a boon and a potential source of confusion for travelers.

title: Ann Steere Is Married
description: Ann Blyth Steere and William Thomas Bailey 4th, bank officers, were married yesterday in the Fox Chapel Presbyterian Church in Pittsburgh by the Rev. John Telford Galloway Jr. The bride was attended by Margaret Phillips Steere, her sister; Elizabeth Ann Schmidt, the bridegroom's half-sister; Chandler Barnes Luke; Helen Patricia Browne, and Melinda Sue Treutle.

title: IT WAS A MESS! HOW HENRY JAMES AND OTHERS ACTUALLY WROTE A NOVEL
description: ''THE WHOLE FAMILY'' - a composite novel first published in book form in 1908 - was the result of one of the most fascinating experiments in the history of American writing. It was William Dean Howells who first thought of bringing together a dozen of the leading American writers to collaborate on a novel, each writing a chapter focusing on one character. As the unofficial dean of American literature, Howells had served as editor, adviser and friend to most of the important writers in the nation. He felt sure that he could persuade 11 distinguished authors to join him in writing a book. In the spring of 1906, he suggested the project to Elizabeth Jordan, the energetic editor of Harper's Bazar (as it was then spelled). She responded with enthusiasm and eagerly agreed to undertake the editorial work, suggesting the inclusion of, among others, Henry James. The chapters would appear serially in Harper's Bazar and then be collected in a book. It seemed like an editor's dream. It turned out to be an editor's nightmare.

title: 'TAI-PAN' CONTRASTS OLD CHINA AND NEW
description: The history of American film and television production in China has been prickly from the start.

title: PETS GIVE THE AGED NEW INTEREST IN LIFE
description: TWENTY elderly residents of Francis Asbury Manor, a retirement home here with an extended-care facility, were in the activities room, many in wheelchairs. Some stared into space; others slumped in their chairs, dozing or lost in a private world.

title: Lisa E. Novick to Wed A Lawyer in December
description: Mr. and Mrs. John Novick of North Woodmere, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter Lisa Ellen Novick to Mark Edward Goldberg, a son of Adrienne Goldberg Shields of Lawrence, L.I., and the late Robert S. Goldberg. A Dec. 6 wedding is planned.

title: ONE-WAY VERRAZANO TOLL IS CUTTING REVENUES
description: A month-old experiment creating one-way, $3.50 tolls on the Verrazano-Narrows Bridge has caused a drop in toll revenues and has added traffic to the Holland Tunnel, according to traffic planners and community activists.

title: More Pressure On the Shuttle
description: No one knows when the space shuttle will fly again. But aerospace experts speculated that it could be called back into service earlier than expected because of a crisis in spy satellite launchings.

title: PROPOSALS, LIKE WEAPONS, ARE ALSO PROLIFERATING
description: ALTHOUGH the United States and the Soviet Union have apparently made little progress in arms control negotiations, there has been no shortage of ideas and theories for and against different proposals offered by the two sides. What follows is a discussion of some of the arguments. Question. It was disclosed last week that President Reagan has tentatively decided to continue the policy of ''not undercutting'' the strategic arms limitation treaty signed with the Soviet Union in 1979, but never ratified. Didn't Mr. Reagan say that this treaty was so bad he would never seek Senate approval of it?

title: NOW, IT'S DIAL-A-JUST ABOUT ANYTHING
description: WHILE serving as a young Mormon missionary in France, Clarence Jolly was more than a little upset when gifts from home arrived broken and crushed. The upset lasted - so much so that in 1980, more than 15 years after he returned to Salt Lake City, he started Dial-a-Gift, which delivers - guaranteed intact - baskets of cakes, candies, gourmet food, even wine and champagne. Today, Dial-a-Gift has 580 franchised dealers throughout the United States, and is expected to tally $8 million in sales this year.

title: REAGAN, LEAVING FOR TALKS IN ASIA WARNS TERRORISTS
description: As he began a 13-day trip to Asia, President Reagan declared today that the world's ''dictators and terrorists'' had to be prepared for the consequences if they perpetrated ''cowardly acts'' against Americans.

title: PANEL STUDYING MAJOR CHANGES IN RUNNING STATE
description: ''I'VE been involved in a lot of important pieces of legislation, but this could be the pinnacle,'' said Senator Matthew Feldman, Democrat of the 37th District (part of Bergen County).

title: BRODERICK CRAWFORD, OSCAR-WINNING TOUGH, DIES
description: Broderick Crawford, the heavyweight tough guy who won an Academy Award for his performance in ''All the King's Men'' and later starred in the television series ''Highway Patrol,'' died today.

title: After the Challenger
description: If the early days of aviation had been directed by such a ponderous bureaucracy as NASA seems to be, we would still be waiting for a safe design upgrade on the Wright brothers' original.

title: GRADUATION -- HIGH POINT OF A SHORT LIFE FILLED WITH HOPE
description: GRADUATION Day! Is there ever a time that holds more hope? Perhaps only birth.

title: Trautmann Voted Best of Schoolboys
description: John Trautmann made a wise decision Thursday night. Entered in both the 1,500- and 3,000-meter schoolboy races Friday at the Penn Relays, the Monroe Woodbury (N.Y.) High School senior chose to run in the 3,000.

title: By Air and by Sea; How to Hail a Cab
description: Driven by the same compulsion that has sent so many people clambering up Mount Everest, two young Londoners - a Mr. McCarthy and a Mr. Boyd - parachuted off the Empire State Building last Thursday. That was impressive, but so was what Mr. Boyd did on landing.

title: NORWALK'S DEPRESSION MURALS TO REGAIN THEIR LUSTER
description: FOR decades, students at the old Norwalk High School threw spitballs and food at the large murals that covered the walls of their cafeteria. They did not know then that the paintings would become one of the largest collections in the country of intact murals commissioned by Works Progress Administration, and the subject of a local restoration project.

title: NEW YORK AREA SCHOOLS FIND LIBYA A HOT TOPIC
description: On the night that United States planes bombed Libya, boarding students at the private Wooster School in Danbury, Conn., rushed to the apartments of their dormitory masters to ask what the action meant.

title: FETE IN WORKS AT CONSTITUTION'S HOME
description: In the elegant first-floor room of Independence Hall where the creators of the Constitution argued and sweated at candle-topped tables, a national park ranger had plunged into his tour guide spiel.

title: FIFTH GRADERS CHATTING IN LATIN
description: AT the Ridge Street School in the Blind Brook-Rye School District, fifth-grade students hold conversations and sing in their foreign language class. While this is a common approach when a modern language is being taught, it comes as something of a surprise when the words are Latin.

title: Black Forest
description: To the Editor: John Dornberg's fine article on the Black Forest (Travel, Feb. 9) reminded me of an experience my family and I had some years ago. We were driving through Germany from Switzerland in early spring. And the Black Forest, sure enough, had its share of snow on a multitude of pine trees that make up the famed woodland, known to most of us from fairy tales by the Brothers Grimm.

title: KORNBLUTH: COHEN'S 'CAPE COD NOCTURNES'
description: ARTHUR COHEN has been painting in and around Provincetown, Mass., for the last 25 years. He has shown to good notices in New York City, as well as in his own territory, and his work has been acquired by the Museum of Modern Art, the Metropolitan, the Whitney and the Hirschhorn Museums.

title: NEW YORK CITY OFFICIALS CITE 50 FOOD OUTLETS FOR VIOLATIONS
description: The New York City Department of Health last week released a list of 50 food establishments cited for violating the health code.

title: DOING EUROPE IN HIGH STYLE AT LOW RENTS
