description: After years of experimentation, my wife and I have hit on a European vacation style that offers us the most in comfort, economy and pleasure. Simply put, we fly in the off-season, rent a car, then seek out a convenient base in an apartment hotel or condominium in a major city or, more often, a spa or resort (ski, lake or seaside) in the region we want to explore.

title: 'A Lesser Life'
description: To the Editor:

title: Lisa K. Shiver Is the Bride Of William Arthur Jacoby
description: Lisa Karen Shiver, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. David Shiver of Arkadelphia, Ark., was married yesterday to William Arthur Jacoby, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Monte H. Jacoby of Stamford, Conn.

title: THE ENVIRONMENT
description: THE developer of Pelican Cove has won partial approval from the state Department of Environmental Protection's Division of Coastal Resources: Yes to condominiums, no to a larger marina.

title: Janet Remlin Is Engaged To Livingston Morris Jr.
description: Mr. and Mrs. Charles E. Remlin Jr. of Wilton, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter Janet Gail Remlin to Livingston Van Buren Morris Jr., the son of Ann C. Morris of Bedford, N.Y., and Mr. Morris of Cedarhurst, L.I. A June wedding is planned.

title: CONSUMER PRICE FALL TIED MAINLY TO OIL
description: Inflation's disappearing act continued in March, with consumer prices dropping a steep four-tenths of 1 percent, the same as in February. Falling oil prices get most of the credit: Gasoline dropped a record 12 percent. But analysts have been warning Americans not to get too smug about the permanency of the drop. Once oil bottoms out, they say, inflation is likely to rise again. Indeed, costs of services, an increasingly large segment of the economy, rose in March.

title: PRINCIPAL'S METHODS DIVIDE NEW HAMPSHIRE TOWN
description: A bitter confrontation over educational values and technique is taking place in this largely rural, blue-collar community.

title: Julia A. Stabler Weds T.W. Hull in Princeton
description: Trinity Episcopal Church in Princeton, N.J., was the setting yesterday for the wedding of Julia Amesbury Stabler, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Coleman Stabler of Princeton, to Thomas Walker Hull, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Lyman Walker Hull of Seattle. The Rev. Richard Bower performed the ceremony.

title: Susan Haack Engaged
description: The engagement of Susan Marie Haack to John Robinson Lenoir has been announced by her parents, Mr. and Mrs. Allan H. Haack of Wantagh, L.I. Mr. Lenoir is the son of Mr. and Mrs. John Lenoir of Memphis, Tenn.

title:
WHAT'S DOING IN;
DUBLIN
description: The weather may be at its most temperamental, but you can be lucky, and anyway, it is hard to beat the spring and early summer for exploring Dublin, an intimate sort of capital city, scarred in part by architectural destruction but retaining much of its old attraction. You may bemoan the spread of multicolored fast-food outlets along O'Connell Street, but good spirits are restored by a little banter with chatty assistants in Clery's department store, where generations of Dubliners and visitors have gone for value.

title: NEW CASSETTES: FROM MONTEVERDI TO RED NORVO
description: Red Norvo A ''Jazz at the Smithsonian'' presentation, featuring Mr. Norvo, with Tal Farlow, Mavis Rivers and others Sony Video 58 minutes. $29.95 It is not easy to stifle as engaging a musical personality as the vibraphonist Red Norvo, but this video cassette of a 1982 concert at the Smithsonian Institution in Washington goes a long way toward doing it. Mr. Norvo has a musical and personal charisma that is low-keyed, slyly witty and thoroughly engaging.

title: TWO MUSICALS TURN BACK THE CLOCK TO THE EARLY 60's
description: ''Beehive,'' a delightfully lighthearted show celebrating pop women of the 1960's, begins as a teen-age girl inserts a coin into a giant jukebox. When the machine lights up, it frames the stage on which the cast of six singer-actresses, sporting lumpy oversized ''beehive'' hairdos, introduce themselves to ''The Name Game,'' the mnemonic jump-rope ditty popularized in 1964 by Shirley Ellis. The word ''beehive,'' they sassily announce, means many things, from ''a skin irritation caused by an excessive use of Aquanet'' to ''a group of incredibly overworked hair stylists.''

title: CREATING A CAREER FROM A LILY GARDEN
description: LYNNE ROSENTHAL'S Stamford garden was born out of a need to conquer the land.

title: TRADING PLACES: FEMALE MONEY EXPERTS
description: THEY didn't take the financial world by storm, they took it one step at a time, working harder than male colleagues to make their mark. So say three successful Westchester investment advisers: Nola Maddox Falcone, Mary Ann McNulty and Judith Werbitt, who entered the stock market at a time when female traders were few and far between.

title: Fair Divorces
description: To the Editor:

title: NEW CASSETTES: FROM MONTEVERDI TO RED NORVO
description: Monteverdi's 'L'incoronazione di Poppea' A Glyndebourne Festival Opera production, featuring Maria Ewing, Dennis Bailey, Cynthia Clarey, Robert Lloyd, Elisabeth Gale, Dale Duesing; with Raymond Leppard conducting the London Philharmonic Thorn EMI/HBO Video 148 minutes. $39.95 Monteverdi's ''L'incoronazione di Poppea'' is an eloquent introduction to opera's earliest style, and Glyndebourne's blending of sensuality with decorum makes this gloomy but tensely dramatic production a successful one.

title: Carla Stimer's Camping In Cabaret Show
description: In the early stages of ''Gotta Have Me Go With You,'' an hourlong cabaret program at Don't Tell Mama (through last night) sung by Carla Stimer with the backup voices of David James Robinson and Matthew Sarles, one's attention was focused on Miss Stimer's appearance - a 1920's doll with a Louise Brooks helmet bob - and the very busy costume changes and movements of the trio.

title: Doctor Guilty in Death
description: Dr. Stephen Levine, a brain surgeon, was sentenced today to 180 days in jail after being convicted of the involuntary manslaughter of his wife, Myrna Levine, in May 1984. Mrs. Levine, addicted to the painkilling narcotic Demerol, died of an overdose. A prosecutor, Robert Dawson, said Dr. Levine had issued more than 225 Demerol prescriptions for his wife.

title: Cable TV
description: For devotees of the cable, the week ahead holds the promise of four premieres, including one of the smash hits of 1984, a topnotch romantic comedy, a British drama marked by splendid performances, and a medieval adventure spiced by 80's humor.

title: American Catholic in Rome
description: Barbara Grizzuti Harrison's article ''American Catholic in Rome'' (March 16) must have cheered a great many Roman Catholics, as it did me, by its wonderfully sensitive recounting and analysis of her experiences in Rome and elsewhere in Italy.

title: 11 Held in Prison Smuggling
description: Six inmates at the Federal penitentiary at Lewisburg, four women and a man, have been charged with participating in marijuana smuggling during Moslem services at the prison chapel, the Federal Burau of Investigation says. The smuggling was recorded by surveillance cameras in an investigation that began in January 1985, the bureau said Wednesday. All 11 suspects are Sunni or Shiite Moslems and face maximum sentences of 45 years in prison and $250,000 in fines.

title: SUNDAY SPORTS
description: Baseball Yankees vs. Cleveland Indians, at Yankee Stadium, 1:30 P.M. For Cleveland's Phil Niekro, this is a return to the Stadium, where he pitched for the Yankees the last two years. (Television - Channel 11, 1:30 P.M. Radio - WABC 770, 1:30 P.M.) Mets vs. Cardinals, at St. Louis, 3 P.M. Bob Ojeda will be opposed by the ace of the St. Louis staff, John Tudor. (Television - Channel 9, 3 P.M. Radio - WHN 1050, 3 P.M.) Tigers vs. Chicago White Sox, at Detroit. (Television - Channel 7, 3 P.M.) Basketball Celtics vs. Atlanta Hawks, at Boston. Opener of four-of-seven-game Eastern Conference semifinal. (Television -Channel 2, 1 P.M.) #76ers vs. Washington Bullets, at Philadelphia. The winner will meet Milwaukee next. (Television - Channel 2, 3:30 P.M.) Women: United States Olympic Festival East Regional Trials, Rutgers Athletic Center, Piscataway, N.J. The final day of qualifying for the team that will represent the East at the Festival July 25-Aug. 3. Golf Houston Open, final round. (Television - ESPN, 1:30 P.M.) Liberty Mutual Legends of Golf, at Austin, Tex., final round. (Television -Channel 4, 4 P.M.) L.P.G.A. S&H Classic, at St. Petersburg, Fla. Hockey Rangers vs. Washington Capitals, at Madison Square Garden, 7:35 P.M. A Ranger victory advances them to the Wales Conference final. A loss forces a seventh game Tuesday in Landover, Md. (Television - MSG, 7:30 P.M. Radio -WNBC 660, 7:20 P.M.) Whalers vs. Montreal Canadiens, at Hartford, Game 6 of the Adams Division final that the Canadiens lead, 3-2.

title: THE CAREFUL SHOPPER
description: Quality and Quantity And Bulk Discounts Seabergh's Depot in White Plains is a source of wholesale and retail frozen foods, with posted prices reflecting bulk purchases by the trailer load. Quantity discounts are provided on larger-scale transactions with restaurants, nursing homes, bowling alleys and hot-dog cart owners and most of the food is domestically produced.

title: May Wedding Planned for Sally Verner Shropshire
description: The engagement of Sally Verner Shropshire to Philip St. George Cocke 5th, the son of Mrs. Cocke 4th of Rappahannock Academy, Va., and the late Colonel Cocke, U.S.A., retired, has been announced by her mother, Maxine Verner Shropshire of Longboard Key, Fla. The wedding is planned for May 31.

title: The Court's New Libel Ruling Will Please the Press
description: Under the common law inherited from England, a plaintiff could win a libel suit merely by proving that a statement had damaged his reputation. Later, American courts began to recognize truth as a defense, although the defendant still had to prove it.

title: A WILD CHECK CHASE IN FRENCH
description: We are not bold travelers. We do not bestride the globe, swaggering from continent to continent. We're careful, timid.

title: LONG ISLAND JOURNAL
description: BOLOGNA AND BULLETS WHEN John Catanzaro of Brentwood opened his new delicatessen in Islip Terrace last month, he stocked up on bologna, ham and bulletproof aprons. The cold cuts are items you'd expect to see in a deli on Long Island; a bulletproof apron is not.

title: AIDS: REASON CLOUDED BY A PLAGUE MENTALITY
description: THE AIDS epidemic has engendered a new fear that sometimes masquerades as parental concern when healthy schoolchildren may be exposed to classmates who have AIDS (acquired immune deficiency syndrome) or ARC (AIDS-related complex).

title: 'Madison Square' May Move Again
description: The changing face of New York may soon get more than just a nip and a tuck. Gulf and Western Industries, the owner of Madison Square Garden, said last week that it intended to build a new Garden two blocks to the west, then tear down the none-too-old arena and replace it with an office and shopping complex.

title: After the Challenger
description: The National Aeronautics and Space Administration clearly deserves a shake-up, but it also deserves better than what it's been getting since the loss of the Challenger (''After the Challenger: America's Future in Space,'' by John Noble Wilford, March 16).

title: Wall of Building Falls; 21 Families Evacuated
description: Twenty-one families who had ignored a city order to vacate a Lower East Side building were evacuated last night after a portion of the rear wall collapsed, officials said.

title: PAPERBACK BEST SELLERS: April 27, 1986
description: Fiction

title: THE NEW GLOBAL TOP BANKER: TOKYO AND ITS MIGHTY MONEY
description: Long famous for its prowess in exporting everything from cars to computers, Japan has now become the premier supplier of a new export: money.

title: CITY BALLET: 'LA SOURCE' IS REVIVED
description: THE New York City Ballet's performance Wednesday night at the New York State Theater was notable for its fine dancing and choreographic magic.

title: THE MANY FACES OF SPRING; A GARDENER'S SURPRISE
description: NOW that spring is upon us in its full glory, I can't wait to get outside and see what new surprises Mother Nature has for me this year.

title: DO PRICES AT RARITIES AUCTIONS INDICATE TRENDS?
description: One tends to evaluate the annual Robert A. Siegel Rarities of the World auctions in terms of their bidding strength and individual prices realized. There has not been a weak sale in the past two decades, but there have been much stronger sales than this year's edition, most notably those held in the 1970's.

title: Once a Zen Buddhist
description: To the Editor:

title:
GARDENING;
WHEN BULBS HAVE STOPPED BLOOMING
description: TO most of us, flowering bulbs capture the very essence of spring. Their tender, green shoots emerge from the ground at the first hint of the new season's warmth, and persevere against winter's belated attempts to prevail. They soon burst into bloom, often where the last vestige of winter is still evident in melting drifts of snow.

title: But You Can Call Him Mr.
description: Representative Jim Wright, the House majority leader, says Secretary of Defense Caspar W. Weinberger had a very different attitude toward Government funds when he was director of the Office of Management and Budget. ''He used to be Cap the Knife,'' the Texan told a friend the other day. ''Now he's Cap the Ladle.''

title: Pretoria Makes A Big Concession On Apartheid
description: There is perhaps no single more important instrument of apartheid, and certainly none more common, than the green passbooks South Africa's blacks - and only its blacks -have had to carry at all times. Last year alone, there were 132,000 arrests for pass-law violations; most of those convicted served a few weeks in jail.

title: LOCAL BOARDS LIST CITY PARKS AS TOP CONCERN
description: Park maintenance has replaced police patrol as the No. 1 concern among New York City's 59 community boards, according to a recent survey by the Mayor's office.

title: LONDON MUSICAL TO OPEN IN UNLIKELY SPOT
description: METUCHEN, N.J. -

title: LATIN ENVOYS TRY TO REVIVE CONTADORA PLAN
description: Diplomats from several Latin American countries are trying to revive the stalled Contadora peace process in Central America out of concern that if Congress approves more aid for the Nicaraguan rebels, it will then become all but impossible to achieve peace in the region.

title: Richard Lang to Wed Georgiana Crawford
description: Mr. and Mrs. Homer Crawford of Waterford, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Georgiana Crawford, to Richard John Lang of Germantown, N.Y. A May 31 wedding is planned. Miss Crawford attended the Convent of the Sacred Heart in New York and graduated from the Karafin School Inc. in Mount Kisco and Windham College.

title: KOHL DEFENDS WALDHEIM, SAYING CRITICS ARE ARROGANT
description: Chancellor Helmut Kohl of West Germany today strongly defended Kurt Waldheim, the former United Nations chief, and called critics of Mr. Waldheim's wartime role arrogant.

title: Charles Morton 3d Is Wed To Judy E. Tamm in South
description: The wedding of Judy Elizabeth Tamm to Charles Morton 3d took place yesterday at St. Andrews-by-the-Sea Methodist Church in Hilton Head, N.C. The Rev. Harold Lewis performed the ceremony.

title: CORRECTION
description: The caption accompanying an article on March 16 describing how infants are taught to swim at the Huntington Y.M.C.A. incorrectly identified a mother and child taking part in the course. They were Suzanne Boyce and her son, Bryan.

title: A PAINIST FINDS 88 KEYS TO HAPPINESS
description: WALK into Morton Estrin's high-ranch in Hicksville, and it's not hard to guess what his life is all about. There are two Baldwin grand pianos, records, recording equipment, busts of composers, a photograph of Brahms, another of Toscanini.

title: From Slide Rules to Apartments
description: During World War II, the Keuffel & Esser Company, a manufacturer of drafting tools and surveying instruments, raised spiders in its landmark building in Hoboken.

title: DANCE: 'THE ART OF PILAR RIOJA,' A NEW BILL
description: PILAR RIOJA, whose concerts of Spanish dances are always welcome, was especially persuasive Thursday night when she offered a new program, ''The Art of Pilar Rioja,'' at Repertorio Espanol. There was never more than one dancer on stage. Yet she filled the stage with a multitude of passions and rhythms.

title: Fatal Subway Accident Is Subject of an Inquiry
description: The Transit Authority is investigating an accident in which a subway motorman died Friday night at the controls of a train, an authority spokesman said.

title:
GARDENING;
WHEN BULBS HAVE STOPPED BLOOMING
description: TO most of us, flowering bulbs capture the very essence of spring. Their tender, green shoots emerge from the ground at the first hint of the new season's warmth, and persevere against winter's belated attempts to prevail. They soon burst into bloom, often where the last vestige of winter is still evident in melting drifts of snow.

title: FOR ALL THE ATTRACTIONS OF FAILURE, IT'S PROBABLY BETTER TO SUCCEED
description: To the Editor:

title: 'CARELESS LOVE': SOAP OPERA IN STAMFORD
description: JACK is a struggling actor.

title: The Volcker Humor
description: The Federal Reserve Board is generally regarded in Washington as a fairly grim agency, inhabited largely by accountants and practitioners of the dismal science. But its chairman, Paul A. Volcker, is acquiring a reputation as something of a stand-up comic.

title: HOSPITALS GIVING NUMBERS TO QUALITY
description: A TYPICAL hospital stay costs hundreds of dollars less in New Jersey than in neighboring states, according to the latest statistical report by the Princeton-based New Jersey Hospital Association. But can patients be sure that high-quality care is part of the bargain?

title: MEXICO PUSHES TOURISM ANEW
description: TWO shocks have sent Mexico reeling in the last year - a devastating earthquake that rocked Mexico City and this winter's collapse of world oil prices. The country has generally recovered from the first shock, burying its dead and rebuilding. But the oil trauma will cause more lasting economic devastation, and Mexico has begun a desperate search for ways to replace its largest source of foreign earnings. Suddenly, tourism - an industry whose fortunes sagged dramatically for the past few years - is a major Government priority.

title: FIRST DEMOCRATIC SUDANESE PARLIAMENT IN 2 DECADES OPENS
description: The Sudan's new Parliament, the first to be democratically elected in almost two decades, held its first session today.

title: Jury Out in Alien Smuggling
description: A Federal jury has deliberated six days without reaching a verdict in the trial of 11 religious leaders accused of smuggling aliens into the United States. The jury is to reconvene Tuesday.

title: THE BIG RED PAINTPOT
description: ARTISTS AGAINST WAR AND FASCISM Papers of the First American Artists' Congress. Introduction by Matthew Baigell and Julia Williams. Illustrated. 310 pp. New Brunswick, N.J.: Rutgers University Press. $23. THE American Artists' Congress, which came into existence in 1935 and for a few years enjoyed the support of a great many American artists, including some distinguished ones, was in certain respects a typical phenomenon of the 1930's. ''Artists Against War and Fascism,'' the book Matthew Baigell and Julia Williams have now produced on this organization and its activities, is similarly a typical product of the 1980's. For it is an entirely representative example of the kind of interest American academics nowadays take in the cultural history of the 30's. Mr. Baigell is a professor of art history at Rutgers University and Miss Williams is described as ''affiliated'' with Rutgers.

title: COLLEGES FACE A GLOOMY BALANCE SHEET
description: WELL-TRAINED people and new ideas are essential to retaining power in a complex, changing world. But the source of both is being threatened.

title: Q AND A
description: Keeping the Noise Down Question: The answer to a question in the column of March 23 said that there is no law restricting the time of day during which an apartment resident can practice a musical instrument. It seems to contradict the answer to a similar question that ran on Dec. 9, 1984, which also had to do with noise. Which answer is correct? . . . G. L., Manhattan Answer: The answers to both questions are correct. While there is no law or code that limits the hours during which a resident can play a musical instrument, radio or phonograph, the Administrative Code prohibits any ''unreasonable'' noise that disturbs any resident no matter what the time.

title: VOICE PRINTERS TO ANSWER THE CALL OF THE LOON
description: Loon trackers in New Hampshire plan to record the calls of the reclusive water birds on tape this summer.

title: The House Votes Both Ways on Pay
description: It might not have mattered that House Speaker Thomas P. O'Neill Jr. did not have to face the voters again when he complained at midweek that members of Congress ''haven't the guts or the courage to stand up and say we need a pay raise.'' But most of his colleagues do not want to join the Speaker in retirement, so the House moved with unusual speed last week to overturn a vote, taken the day before, to raise the limit on members' outside earnings.

title: SMALL NEW PHILANTHROPY WITH MODEST GOALS
description: The Mukti Fund would be easy to overlook among the country's 24,000 grant-making foundations.

title: Dr. James P. Marr Dies at 88; A Gynecologist in Manhattan
description: Dr. James Pratt Marr, a Manhattan obstetrician and gynecologist for 54 years, died Wednesday at his home in Manhattan after a short illness. He was 88 years old.

title: Miss Nelson Marries John A. Grammer Jr.
description: The wedding of Mary Anne Katherine Nelson, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Lawrence Nelson of Fairfield, Conn., to John Albert Grammer Jr., the son of Mrs. Grammer of Hightstown, N.J., and the late Mr. Grammer, took place yesterday. The Rev. Dr. Ernest Hunt performed the Episcopal ceremony at the Church of the Epiphany in New York.

title:
WESTCHESTER JOURNAL;
FIREFIGHTERS' CENTENNIAL
description: THE Rye Fire Department is 100 years old - and its members have organized a parade to prove it.

title: Sarah Carter Is Married
description: Sarah Ames Carter, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Burr Noland Carter II of Richmond, and Schuyler Everett Grey 3d, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Schuyler Everett Grey 2d of Denver, were married yesterday at St. Stephen's Episcopal Church in Richmond. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. D. Raby Edwards, assisted by the Rev. W. Holt Souder. The bride is publisher and president of Sportdeck, producers of direct-mail advertising in Boston. Mr. Grey is a financial consultant at Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenner & Smith in Boston.

title: DOWNEY AND KING IN POLITICAL SQUEEZE
description: IN RECENT days it appeared highly possible that two Long Island officials - Nassau County Comptroller Peter T. King and Representative Thomas J. Downey - had the inside track for statewide offices. But this week Mr. King is facing a real battle for a statewide post, and Mr. Downey is apparently out of the running.

title: NORTHVILLE INDUSTRIES AND LAND USE
description: Your article on the Northville Industries Corporation facilities [ ''For Northville, Shifting Fortunes'' March 30 ] raises important questions relating to land use and the values that direct our decisions in this regard. It is clear that the only value that has driven Long Island's town planners is the tax dollar. This can sometimes be shortsighted, as is the case with Northville Industries.

title: THOSE WHO MISS THE DERBY ARE OFTEN THE BEST
description: HANG on there a minute, racing fans!

title: Planted Antonyms Explained
description: Now that I have seen the solution to the puzzle ''Planted Antonyms'' (March 30, edited by Eugene T. Maleska), I am just as confused as ever.

title: Swamp Skirmish In Massachusetts
description: WHEN a shopping-center developer sought permits to build a mall over a swamp in Attleboro, Mass., the regional offices of the Federal Environmental Protection Agency and Army Corps of Engineers objected. The Corps of Engineers in Washington overruled its New England office and granted a permit last summer.

title: Saudi Arms Sale Is Voted Down In 2 Committees
description: Washington's longstanding and complicated relationship with Saudi Arabia came under new strain in Congress last week. Senate and House committees voted to stop President Reagan from selling $354 million worth of advanced weapons to the Saudis.

title: CORRECTION
description: A picture caption on page 22 of the Arts and Leisure section today gives an incorrect opening day for the Sankai Juku dance troupe at the City Center. The first performance will be Wednesday at 7:30 P.M.

title: DRUG TESTS BY EMPLOYERS ARE ON THE RISE
description: AT LEAST two major employers on Long Island, Entenmann's Bakery Inc. and the United States Postal Service, are now giving mandatory urine tests to job applicants to weed out users of illegal drugs.

title: O'NEILL'S FATHER SHAPED HIS SON'S VISION
description: In ''Long Day's Journey Into Night,'' Eugene O'Neill's thinly disguised portrait of his family, there is no hint of how vital an influence the acting career of the father - in the play called James Tyrone - was to become on the writing career of the son. Indeed, to heighten the play's tragedy, O'Neill implies that the son - self-described as a mere stammerer, a man without even ''the makings of a poet'' - probably will die young of tuberculosis.

title: Appeals Court Unties a Gag
description: A year ago this month, a Queens teen-ager shook the Police Department by charging that officers at the 106th Precinct in Ozone Park had beaten him and shocked and burned him with an electric stun gun to force him to confess that he had sold $10 worth of marijuana. The allegations by the teen-ager, Mark Davidson, set off a chain reaction that spread last week to the Appellate Division of State Supreme Court in Brooklyn, which, in a landmark decision, struck down a judge's gag order.

title: Black College Votes For Divestment Move
description: Officials of Spelman College here announced today that they would sell about $1 million in holdings the predominantly black women's school had in companies doing business in South Africa.

title: Maria Owings Shriver Wed To Arnold Schwarzenegger
description: Maria Owings Shriver, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. R. Sargent Shriver of Washington, and Arnold Schwarzenegger, a son of Aurelia Schwarzenegger of Graz, Austria, and the late Gustav Schwarzenegger, were married yesterday in Hyannis, Mass. The Rev. John Baptist Riordan performed the ceremony at St. Francis Xavier Roman Catholic Church.

title: Oil Prices
description: To the Editor:

title: IN HAITI, HOPES ARE NAMED 'FREEDOM'
description: When a rainstorm broke over the city, it hit the waterfront slums with the effect of an air-raid alarm. In the dark, men pushed sacks into the doorways and women woke up the children, grabbing babies and their few belongings off the floor. Within minutes, the rain had filled the sewage ditches, spilled over and seeped into the shacks in a thin black ooze.

title: START WITH GERANIUMS AND LEARN HOW TO TRAIN TOPIARIES
description: I like to think that topiary began as an attempt to create a living sculpture. After all, sculpture traditionally belongs in the garden. Cement urns, lead rabbits, marble Adonises and wrought iron fountains have been a part of garden planning since man first put trowel to soil. Why not chisel a sculpture from a living plant?

title: HELPING CHILDREN ADJUST TO SCHOOL
description: APPROXIMATELY 20 to 30 percent of American children experience school-adjustment problems. In some economically disadvantaged urban districts, estimates of school maladjustment have run as high as 70 percent.

title: HOW 401(K)'S HURT LOWER-PAID WORKERS
description: THERE is a quick way for the Senate Finance Committee to raise billions of dollars in tax revenue: End the popular middle-income tax shelter known as the 401(k) plan.

title: Old Barns Turned Into Luxury Homes
description: OLD Westchester County barns have been going quickly in recent years as farmland becomes housing developments, but recently three old barns have appeared on the hillsides in North Salem and Lewisboro, looking as if they had always been there.

title: Jennifer O'Brien to Wed
description: Mr. and Mrs. Robert B. O'Brien Jr., of Morristown and Bay Head, N.J., and Delray Beach, Fla., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Jennifer Sarah O'Brien, to Timothy Landers, a son of Dr. David E. Landers and the late Patricia Landers of Teaneck and Bay Head, N.J. A June 22 wedding is planned.

title: HOSPITAL HAILING ITS ALUMNI
description: STAMFORD HOSPITAL is celebrating its own 90th birthday by tracking down people whose birthdays were celebrated in its maternity ward.

title: Military Concern Is Indicted
description: One of the nation's largest military surplus companies and four men were indicted Friday on charges of conspiring to steal and resell Government property, a prosecutor said.

title: Miss Collinsworth Publisher, to Wed William Hamilton
description: Mr. and Mrs. Even Thomas Collinsworth Jr. of Longboat Key, Fla., and Boothbay Harbor, Me., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Eden Collinsworth, to William Hamilton, a son of Ellen Ballentine Hamilton Hayne of St. Helena, Calif., and the late Alexander Hamilton, also of St. Helena. The wedding is planned for July 26.

title: Eliminating A Bad Example
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Cathy Lynn Stamm to Wed
description: The engagement of Cathy Lynn Stamm to Dr. Jerome Edward Kaufman has been announced by the parents of the future bride, Dr. and Mrs. Julian Stamm of Scarsdale, N.Y. A June wedding is planned. Dr. Kaufman, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Harry Kaufman of Sunrise Lake, Fla., is an attending psychiatrist at the Beth Israel Medical Center. Miss Stamm is a supervisor at the Catholic Charities treatment and school consultation program.

title: Clam Diggers in Alaska Defy Volcano Threat
description: Despite warnings that the rumbling Augustine Volcano could erupt in a major explosion and cause a tidal wave, about 1,500 clam diggers are flocking to beaches near Anchorage, 180 miles northeast of the volcano.

title: DON'T WAKEN THE LEGHOLD BAN
description: UNTIL recently, public reaction to New Jersey's leghold-trap ban focused on the merits of the statute.

title: EXCERPTS FROM PASTORAL PLAN
description: Following are excerpts from the draft of a pastoral letter drawn up by a panel of Bishops of the United Methodist Church:

title: THE MANY FACES OF SPRING; A FLORIST'S LEGACY
description: WHEN I walk around the backyard on clement days, I often wonder how my grandfather would have liked the tulips, the lilies and the asparagus bed.

title: SANDSTROM USES HIS HEAD
description: IN the unofficial code of ethics of the National Hockey League, it is far better to give than to receive, particularly in the case of elbows, knees, hips and knuckles.

title: Gail Ockerbloom To Marry in Fall
description: Mr. and Mrs. Richard C. Ockerbloom of Winchester, Mass., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Gail Mary Ockerbloom, to David Michael Freeman, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Stuart Freeman of Katonah, N.Y. A November wedding is planned. Miss Ockerbloom, a graduate of Boston College, is a technical support manager at Kronos Inc., manufacturer of computerized time devices in Waltham, Mass., where her fiance is a marketing communications coordinator.

title: BERGEN GETS EQUITY THEATER
description: IS the American Stage Company Bergen County's counterpart of the fabled Group Theatre of the 1930's. Or New Jersey's version of Joseph Papp's Public Theater?

title: HOLDING OUT, HOLDING FAST
description: NELSON MANDELA The Man and the Movement. By Mary Benson. Illustrated. 269 pp. New York: W. W. Norton & Company. Cloth, $16.95. Paper, $7.95. WINNIE MANDELA By Nancy Harrison. Illustrated. 183 pp. New York: George Braziller. $14.95. ONE of the most striking features of the crisis in South Africa is how little is new about it. The black majority - surely one of the most patient groups of people in the world - has made essentially the same demands since the end of World War II. The ruling white minority, rather than trying to figure out what might form a reasonable basis for negotiation and peaceful change, has tightened its grip and tried to discredit the opposition.

title: BAN ON A-ARMS URGED IN STUDY BY METHODISTS
description: An influential panel of Bishops of the United Methodist Church, the third largest church body in the United States, has drafted a pastoral letter denouncing the use of nuclear weapons and the doctrine of nuclear deterrence.

title: When Bread Is a Bootleg Item
description: THE Oregon Department of Agriculture checked the laws on bread and, sure enough, the eight-ounce French baguette being sold in the state was strictly illegal under a 1919 statute.

title: ARKANSAS TRIES TO REGAIN ITS FOOTING
description: ALL over Arkansas these days, politicians are out stumping with a message that has come to be increasingly familiar around the country: if the state's economy is ever to revive, it must find a way to compete for foreign investments.

title: A HAVEN OF MOUNTAINS AND MEADOWS
description: Glacier National Park, a million acres of mountains, lakes and gentle Alpine meadows with only one paved road cutting through, seems the very opposite of Manhattan. And that, of course, is what makes it an ideal place for a get-away-from-everything vacation.

title: NEW CASSETTES: FROM MONTEVERDI TO RED NORVO
description: Fela in Concert View Video 57 minutes. $39.95 The dissident Nigerian songwriter Fela Anikulapo Kuti was arrested last year as he embarked for an American tour.

title: EDITOR SAVES WORLD
description: HIDDEN AGENDA By Anna Porter. 322 pp. New York: E. P. Dutton. $14.95. I'M a sucker for opening sentences, and this book starts beautifully: ''No one likes to think about suicides. Least of all, the men who run the subways.'' There's a lead with legs. It would be tough for anyone to maintain that pace for the length of an entire novel, so I can't fault Anna Porter for seldom again quite reaching that Mach 1 of laconic hipness, but I do wish we'd been up there more often.

title: TRADES COULD CHANGE OPTIONS IN EARLY ROUNDS
description: In Tuesday's National Football League draft, the Giants will be looking for help at many positions - defensive line, inside linebacker, defensive backfield, wide receiver and running back.

title: IN THE TOWNSHIPS, FEAR AND ANGER ARE IN THE AIR
description: Along a dirt street in this black township northeast of Johannesburg, a yellow Volkswagen passenger van lies on its side, gutted and blackened by a recent fire. Next to it, a sooty bed frame and coiled springs form the other half of a roadblock.

title: ART AND POLITICS IN BONAFEDE'S 'ADVICE'
description: In 1981, Winston Ntshona and John Kani canceled performances of their South African production of ''Waiting for Godot'' at the Baltimore International Theater Festival because of a protest by local black leaders. This odd - and seemingly paradoxical -footnote to apartheid is the inspiration for Bruce Bonafede's ''Advice to the Players,'' a play about a collision of art and politics.

title: 1,000-Mile Race Starts
description: Just four hours after 31 runners completed a 24-hour road race over a one-mile loop in Flushing Meadows-Corona Park, a smaller but more ambitious band headed out over the same course yesterday for a somewhat more daunting challenge. They were beginning the Sri Chinmoy 1,000-mile race.

title: Amy Beth Klebanoff Plans To Marry Jonathan Macey
description: Mr. and Mrs. Howard Klebanoff of West Hartford, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter Amy Beth Klebanoff to Jonathan Rosenfield Macey, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Morris Macey of Atlanta. The wedding is planned for June.

title: WESTCHESTER GUIDE
description: ISRAEL WORK PROGRAM Volunteers for Israel is ''a well-kept secret that I hope to make more public,'' said Renee Trell, a former volunteer who will explain the program at 8 P.M. Wednesday in the Woodlands Community Temple at 50 Worthington Road in White Plains.

title: Seizing Pornography
description: The Supreme Court has made it easier for the authorities acting under judicial warrants to seize books and movies alleged to be obscene - or at least as easy as it is for them to seize guns or drugs. By a 6-to-3 vote, the Court ruled that, under Federal law, the standards for obtaining warrants to seize obscene material are the same as those for other contraband.

title:
ART;
SEEING IS DECEIVING: 'PHOTOGRAPHIC FICTIONS' IN STAMFORD
description: ALONGSIDE so-called ''straight photography'' -the capturing of the real world that runs the gamut from the work of Ansel Adams to everybody's snapshots - there is and has always been photography concerned with the creation of art, with the imitation of painting, and, thus, with artifice. Such concocted photographs have abounded lately and the work of some of the most-noted practitioners has been gathered for ''Photographic Fictions,'' an exhibition at the Whitney Museum of American Art in Stamford through May 28.

title:
ART;
HAITIAN ART: EXPLORING VOODOO TO THE CONTEMPORARY
description: EVER since the 1940's, when the Centre d'Art was opened in Port-au-Prince, Haiti, when the Surrealist poet Andre Breton praised Haitian art in his book ''Surrealism and Painting'' and the Museum of Modern Art in New York City acquired its first work by a Haitian artist, the colorful and haunting art of that nation has been exhibited and collected the world over.

title: New York Family Court To Get New Top Judge
description: Judge Kathryn McDonald was appointed Administrative Judge of the Family Court of New York City, Chief Administrative Judge Joseph W. Bellacosa announced last week.

title: S.I. SCHOOL TRYING TO EASE RACIAL DISCORD
description: The police van that pulled up at the apartment complex in Stapleton, S.I., was on special duty - delivering parents to a Parent-Teacher Association meeting at New Dorp High School.

title: EASY MONEY AT THE C.I.A.
description: MANHUNT By Peter Maas. 301 pp. New York: Random House. $17.95. ONE of Edwin P. Wilson's last acts as a free man, on a plane from the Dominican Republic carrying him to certain arrest in New York in June 1982, was to tear up a handwritten account of his assets and liabilities after 27 years working for the C.I.A., the Navy and himself in what might loosely be called the world of intelligence. An alert United States marshal on the plane recovered the list. From one point of view, you could say Mr. Wilson had done all right: his net worth was roughly $14 million. On the other hand, when the prosecutors were done with him he was in solitary confinement in a tough Federal prison, serving sentences totaling 52 years with no better than an outside chance of parole somewhere around the year 2000, when he would be 72.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: PRIZE STORIES 1986: The O. Henry Awards. Edited by William Abrahams. (Doubleday, $17.95.) In his introduction to the 66th O. Henry Award prize stories, William Abrahams laments the way writers today stress artifice at the expense of truth.

title: CORRECTION
description: A photograph of Adolf Eichmann in the World section on April 13 carried an incorrect credit from Magnum Photos Inc. It should have been credited to Gjon Mili of Life magazine.

title: RECAPTURING A BOND BETWEEN BROTHERS
description: HE was the last of us, the child of middle age, the fourth and final son, the one my father, in his penchant for puns, called Alice, telling anyone who asked about future children, ''Das is alles.'' But he meant far more to me than merely the end of fertility, more than my parents' futile last attempt to conceive a longed-for daughter.

title: LIBYA FINDS FAULT WITH MILITARY AFTER BAD SHOWING IN U.S. ATTACK
description: The Government of Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi is enmeshed in a bout of unusual self-criticism over the poor military fight it put up against the American air raid.

title: NEW CASSETTES: FROM MONTEVERDI TO RED NORVO
description: All This and Heaven, Too Starring Bette Davis, Charles Boyer, Barbara O'Neil; directed by Anatole Litvak, 1940 MGM/UA Home Video 141 minutes. $59.95 This tense drama is mainly of interest now as a dressy sampling of Bette Davis's golden-era reign at Warners.

title:
ART;
WORKS OF THE CANADIAN INUIT: A CULTURE ADAPTS AND THRIVES
description: WHEN art exhibitions devoted to distant cultures are presented in our area, the public expects insight into relatively unfamiliar material.

title: Holmes for Pension
description: Wise investments may have made his own finances secure, but Larry Holmes, the former heavyweight boxing champion, wants to help assure less successful fighters some of the same security. Holmes, who was in Cleveland to help promote a series of fights in the city, told a news conference there that he would like to see a pension plan developed for boxers.

title: FURTHER INTO A TRAP
description: The number of terrorist incidents directed against American citizens living, working or traveling outside the United States has increased dramatically in the past three years. More Americans have been killed or wounded in such attacks in the past 30 months than in the previous 13 years.

title: HOW HOPSITAL REACTED
description: ADMINISTRATORS at Muhlenberg Regional Medical Center here had less than 24 hours' notice that their hospital would be listed in The New York Times last month as one of 14 in the state with higher-than-expected death rates for Medicare patients in 1984. They tried in vain to find out how the predicted death rates had been calculated.

title: WIDE CAMPAIGN TO SAVE RARE BIRD
description: SOME 15 to 20 pairs of piping plovers - shore birds that resemble sandpipers - are getting a lot of attention these days from the United States Fish and Wildlife Service, the Connecticut Department of Environmental Protection and private conservation groups. But unless state residents also do their part, the small birds - the only ones of the species in Connecticut -could become even more rare, experts say.

title: HIGH-TECH FUND-RAISER FOR THE 80's
description: Hands Across America, a national fund-raising event planned for the Memorial Day weekend, is an undertaking of elongated proportions aimed at helping the hungry and homeless.

title: Gwenyth Jones To Wed in June
description: Gwenyth Jones of Manhattan, a clinical neuropsychologist at the Bronx Veterans Administration Medical Center, and Bruce A. Blumberg, a lawyer from Westfield, N.J., have announced their engagement. A June wedding is planned.

title: Some Companies Want a Town House of Their Own
description: WHEN officials of the Nike athletic-apparel company, which started deep in the backwaters of Oregon a decade ago and mushroomed into a $1 billion-a-year national phenomenon, decided that they needed a New York office, they ruled out locations in either the garment district or the boutique valleys of the East Side.

title: PLAYING THE COMMODITIES MARKETS
description: BACK in the salad days of college life, I briefly made a small fortune trading soybean oil. Pyramiding contract upon contract, I accumulated enough of the viscous liquid to float the Queen Mary - not an inappropriate image as it turned out, for the rising market had depended on a tank farm full of water. An operator named Anthony DeAngelis had convinced the investment community that what was in the tanks was far more valuable than H#2O.

title: Merger Mythos
description: To the Editor:

title: Early Broadway Success
description: Although Mr. Crawford had appeared in two dozen motion pictures over a period of 12 years, the Willie Stark character in ''All the King's Men'' - based on Robert Penn Warren's fictionalized depiction of the rise and fall of Huey P. Long - was the hulking, husky-voiced actor's first starring role, and it won him the New York Film Critics Award as well as the Oscar.

title: GARBAGE SAID TO BE GROWING ENERGY SOURCE
description: Garbage has become the fastest-growing source of electricity from unconventional supplies, according to a report released today.

title: Stevenson Sues
description: Back when Democrats were riding high in Illinois, the election rules were revised to make it virtually impossible for independent candidates to run. Last week, however, Adlai E. Stevenson 3d, the party's candidate for Governor, renounced his nomination and sued to have the rules declared unconstitutional. Mr. Stevenson, a former Senator and the scion of famous Illinois Democrats, wants to run for Governor as an independent.

title: MODEST PROGRESS REPORTED ON CHEMICAL ARMS BAN
description: The Conference on Disarmament, which ended its spring session here this week, has made modest progress toward a treaty that would ban the production, storage and use of chemical weapons, Western diplomats say.

title: Dimitrova in Philadelphia
description: The Bulgarian soprano Ghena Dimitrova will be the guest soloist at the Academy of Music on Friday in a concert marking the 10th anniversary of the Opera Company of Philadelphia.

title: Votes in Congress; Last Week's Tally in Key Eastern States
description: Senate

title: August Wedding For Miss Emery
description: Mr. and Mrs. John M. Emery of Cedarhurst, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Deborah Davie Emery, to John Davenport Maine Jr., the son of Mrs. Thomas Cutler of Brooklyn Heights, N.Y., and John D. Maine of Philadelphia. An August wedding is planned.

title: Justice Reprimanded
description: When an insurance company paid only $1,650 of an Alabama woman's $3,028 hospitalization claim, she sued, and a jury said the company owed her $3.5 million in punitive damages. The award was later upheld, 5 to 4, by Alabama's highest court.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: BLACK MISCHIEF: The Mechanics of Modern Science. By David Berlinski. (Morrow, $17.95.) The Newtonian vision of the universe as a machine governed by elegantly simple laws has died a hard death in physics.

title: THE BENEFITS LOST IN EARLY RETIREMENT
description: Following are answers to some questions from readers of the Personal Finance column. Q: How can I obtain information about earnings credited to my Social Security account, and benefits I can expect to receive? I'm 55 years old and considering stopping work soon, but wonder if early retirement would reduce whatever benefits I'm eligible for when I become 62. A: For information on your account, ask your local Social Security office for form SSA-7004, ''Request for Statement of Earnings.'' Within five weeks after you return the completed form, you should receive a computer printout of your Social Security earnings for your entire career, through 1984. (There is typically a 12-month lag in crediting your last full calendar year's earnings to your Social Security record.) If you retire early - that is, before age 65 - it will reduce the amount of benefits you are ultimately entitled to receive, since the amount of benefits is determined by your earnings over your entire career. Even if you were at or above the maximum level for Social Security payroll deductions, you are likely to be penalized for not working from age 55 to 62. ''In all probability, those years will be counted as zero earning years and you will suffer a loss of benefits,'' says John B. Trollinger, a spokesman for the Social Security Administration.

title: 'A Lesser Life'
description: To the Editor:

title: THE ENDURING ESSENCE OF KYOTO
description: I gave the Kyoto cabdriver directions to the hotel. ''Your Japanese is wonderful!'' he said. ''Not like a foreigner's at all.'' Years ago I would have wallowed in the compliment. Now I know it is the obligatory response to Japanese words coming from a foreign mouth. ''Have you been to Kyoto often?'' ''Not for many years,'' I said. ''When I lived in the Kansai area 27, 28 years ago, I used to come over as often as I could.'' ''Oh, well,'' he said, ''Kyoto doesn't change.'' He didn't correct this observation even after he explained that because it was Sunday, he was taking me a long way round to avoid the heavy traffic on the main shopping street. ''As a matter of fact,'' I said, ''one change I've noticed in Japan is that everyone seems to own his own car these days.''

title: Bookshelf
description: Additional titles of interest:

title: Christiana Gaddis To Become Bride
description: An August wedding is planned by Christiana Peabody Gaddis and Ferdinand David Masucci, the parents of the future bride, Mr. and Mrs. Donald Charles Gaddis of Indian Hill, Ohio, have announced. Mr. Masucci is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Louis M. Masucci of South Orange, N.J.

title: Beth Stanley-Brown Engaged to Wed Peter Horan, a Banker, in September
description: Dr. and Mrs. Edward Garfield Stanley-Brown of Ridgewood, N.J., and Nantucket Mass., have announced the engagement of their daughter Elizabeth Powell Stanley-Brown to Peter Garrett Horan, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Edward L. Horan of Rehoboth, Mass. A September wedding is planned.

title: FIRST GLIMPSE OF THE ANCIENT IMPERIAL CITY
description: No matter how old, no matter how vivid the expectations, or what has been learned so carefully ahead of time from others who have written about them, cities are new when you first see them. What I saw on my first trip to Japan might be noticed, too, by others who go for the first time, but when I go back I won't see these things. I will take them for granted, and then I will see another layer, like the nine layers of Troy, another new city to be explored.

title: 5 FEMALE COMPOSERS BREAKING BARRIERS
description: ''WE like to have it both ways. We don't like to be considered 'women composers' - unless, of course, it works to our advantage.''

title: THE HERO WHO LIVED TO REGRET IT
description: THE STORY OF A SHIPWRECKED SAILOR By Gabriel Garcia Marquez. Translated by Randolph Hogan. 106 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $13.95. THIS short piece of reportage was ghostwritten in 1955 by Gabriel Garcia Marquez for a young Colombian sailor named Luis Alejandro Velasco, who was swept off his destroyer into rough seas on a voyage from Mobile, Ala., to Cartagena, Colombia. He found himself next to a life raft and scrambled aboard. His four shipmates who fell into the sea at the same time were drowned as they struggled to join him. For 10 days Mr. Velasco drifted in the Caribbean Sea without food or fresh water. His spirits rose and fell like the waves around him - sinking as he heard the cries of his drowning friends, rising as he realized that he would soon be rescued, sinking again as airplanes flew overhead and their pilots failed to see him.

title: Added Victors In Zoning Battle
description: To the Editor:

title: Q AND A
description: Question:We are interested in seeing some of the Amazon River and would like the names of companies that sponsor trips there. - L. A. K., West Palm Beach, Fla. Answer:A variety of trips are available at widely varying prices. Some are sponsored by museums, and this year two eight-day tours are scheduled by Discovery Tours, the travel department of the American Museum of Natural History (Central Park West at 79th Street, New York, N.Y. 10024; 212-873-1440). The departure dates are June 21 and 28 and the price of $1,498 a person, double occupancy, includes round-trip air fare from Miami to Iquitos, Peru, as well as accommodations in jungle lodges, trips by canoe along a tributary of the Amazon, most meals and escorts that include ornithologists.

title: Linear Bay Ridge Co-ops
description: The mansion, old and derelict, had one sign of its former grandeur. It bore an original dedication plaque with the inscription ''The Ridge 1900.''

title: U.S. AIDES DIVIDED ON FURTHER RAIDS
description: Senior Reagan Administration officials say that since the American bombing of Libya on April 15, no consensus has developed within the Government on how far to go in repeating such attacks to counter an expected rise in anti-American terrorism around the world.

title:
CRITICS' CHOICES;
Photography
description: The career of the French photographer Jacques Henri Lartigue, who was born 90 years ago, runs backwards towards his youth. He did not turn professional until he was pushing 70, at which point he began to photograph clothes and celebrities for fashion magazines.

title: Julie Wilson Sings Works by Irving Berlin
description: During the past two years, Julie Wilson has performed highly acclaimed cabaret programs of the songs of Cole Porter, Stephen Sondheim, Rodgers and Hart, George and Ira Gershwin and Kurt Weill. Now, returning to the Oak Room of the Algonquin Hotel, 59 West 44th Street, she has arrived at the songs of Irving Berlin.

title: Abdication Reconsidered
description: ALMOST half a century ago, King Edward VIII of England gave up his throne for ''the woman I love'' - an American divorcee named Wallis Warfield Simpson, who later became the Duchess of Windsor. When she died last week in France, at the age of 89, the reaction in London proved that the argument over the abidication she inspired has hardly diminished. Following are excerpts from editorial comments in two British newspapers.

title: ITALY TELLS LIBYA TO CUT ITS STAFF
description: Italy ordered Libya today to cut its diplomatic staff here by 10 and severely restricted the movement of those Libyan diplomats who remain.

title: Rockets Defeat Nuggets
description: Akeem Olajuwon scored 24 of his game-high 38 points in the second half today to help the Houston Rockets hold off a fierce Denver Nuggets' rally for a 126-119 victory in Game 1 of their National Basketball Association Western Conference second-round playoff series.

title: FRENCH MAGIC WITH STALE BREAD
description: Ask a native of the Dordogne in southwestern France what single dish is a specialty of the region - one that might not be found elsewhere - and the reply may well be la mique or, more specifically, la mique Sarladaise, referring to its birthplace in the town of Sarlat.

title: TROUBLES PILING UP FOR HERZOG
description: Three weeks into the season, Whitey Herzog sat at his desk and considered the strange numbers engulfing his St. Louis Cardinals: the team batting average of .215, the six-game losing streak, the Mets' eight-game winning streak. He nodded toward the locker room next door and said: ''That lineup won 101 games last year.''

title: Holman Wins Bowling, Surpasses $1 Million
description: Marshall Holman won his 20th career title and surpassed the $1 million mark in earnings today with a 233-211 victory over Mark Baker in the title game of the $250,000 Firestone Tournament of Champions.

title: Ban on School Speech Is Overturned in Florida
description: A ban on a speech to a school by an American living in Nicaragua has been overturned by a Federal magistrate on the ground that it violated students' rights of free speech.

title: Children Held in Drug Sales
description: The Hartford police took two children into custody after they were observed helping deliver heroin to buyers. While police officers were watching an apartment building on Thursday they realized a 10-year-old girl and a boy, 15, were helping to deliver drugs. The children, whose names were withheld, were taken into police custody and turned over to juvenile authorities.

title: CORRECTION
description: In the captions accompanying ''Men's Style Preview,'' April 13, the designers of two items were misidentified. The shearling overcoat is by Luciano Soprani. The Amercan collegiate look is by Giorgio Armani.

title: Amtrak
description: To the Editor: I had to go to a meeting in Schenectady, and so I took the train (Amtrak). It was very enjoyable, and I'm glad I did.

title: Two More Steps For Biotechnology
description: The biotechnology business got two boosts last week as Government scientists weighing risks and benefits decided that a living virus with one gene removed was safe to use as a vaccine for pigs and that a bacteria with one gene added was safe to test as a pesticide for corn.

title: MUNICIPALITIES SEEK FILM STARDOM
description: IN the last year, Stamford has been portrayed as a city where rape victims seek revenge on rapists and where a nuclear accident turns the high-school honor society into a motorcycle gang.

title: Piggott to Ride Again
description: Lester Piggott, the English jockey who retired last year to become a trainer, has agreed to come out of retirement to help a fellow trainer out of a tight spot. According to Vincent O'Brien, the 50-year-old Piggott will ride the O'Brien-trained Tate Gallery next week in the 2,000 Guineas race at Newmarket, one of the five English Classic races.

title: NEW JERSEY JOURNAL
description: MILTON OHRING of the Stevens Institute of Technology in Hoboken decided one day that having students standing around while he demonstrated scientific equipment was not the best way to convey knowledge. He wanted them to participate.

title: ROAD GAMES THAT CUT COMMUTING'S MONOTONY
description: DRIVING regularly on a highway, even one as attractive as the Merritt Parkway, can be boring, but not if the driver has a good repertory of Highway Games. The rules are simple, any number of drivers can play and the game board and pieces are available to all.

title: ASTROS DEFEAT REDS, 1-0
description: Billy Hatcher scored from third base on a passed ball with two out in the ninth inning tonight, giving the Houston Astros a 1-0 victory over the Cincinnati Reds. The victory was Houston's ninth in its last 11 games.

title: PICASSO'S GENIUS GLOWS IN HIS SKETCHBOOKS
description: Already in his lifetime, it was well known that Picasso never threw anything away. He even kept, for instance, the official pass that was issued to him when he was installing ''Guernica'' at the Paris Exhibition of 1937, not to mention every least notation from his own hand and a vast correspondence from others.

title: Music
description: If there are still tickets for sale (and you'd better check now), try to get one for the New York Philharmonic's pension fund benefit at Fisher Hall Tuesday night. The Philharmonic pulls out all the stops for these affairs, and though this program is devoted more to what might be called ''fun'' than to the noble offering of Brahms and Daniel Barenboim last year, the temptation can't be denied. Even if it's sold out, you might want to show up on the plaza and take your chances on returns.

title: THE BEST GIFTS OF ALL FOR THE SICK: TIME, THOUGHTFULNESS
description: SO it's ungracious to resent - yes, even to get very irritated by -certain gifts. So be it. The truth is that there are gifts that strain to the limit temperaments that are usually placid and equable. They're appalling, gimmicky, ugly, tacky, and how a friend could pick them out, pay for them, wrap them and send them - to YOU - is beyond comprehension.

title: Trains to Run in Boston
description: A Federal judge said today that striking transportation workers must return to work, temporarily ending a walkout that had stranded an estimated 25,000 commuters for one day.

title: WHAT'S NEW IN PERSONAL SERVICES
description: TIME is money, the adage goes. And a growing number of people, particularly in two-career families, are willing to spend some money to buy some time.

title: THE STURDY OILSKIN SHUNS CHIC
description: Taking perverse pride in their weather, the British have never willingly come in from the cold - or the rain.

title: Another American Ship Is Halted in Persian Gulf
description: The Iranian Navy said today that it had briefly stopped an American merchant vessel in the Persian Gulf in the second such incident since Iran began to check ships for cargo bound for its war enemy, Iraq. [ In Washington, the Defense Department and the State Department had no comment on the report.

title: THATCHER SON CAUGHT UP IN TERRORISM FEARS
description: With its Social Register tenants, antique-filled lobby and air of quiet propriety, the stately apartment building just north of downtown seems more a setting for an episode of ''Dynasty'' than an international incident.

title: Hatred in Uniform
description: Marine and Army recruits swear to uphold the Constitution and defend the Government of the United States. That is reason enough for their commanders to be alert to their participation in activities of something called the White Patriot Party. This anti-black, anti-Semitic, paramilitary group in North Carolina vows to ''resort to revolution'' if elected leaders don't satisfy the grievances of white people.

title: House Resales Soar as Rates Plummet
description: A VENERABLE five-bedroom colonial home was placed on the market in Summit, N.J., several weeks ago, priced at $299,000. Within two days there were so many buyers competing for the house that the seller was able to raise the price to $310,000 and get it. This was no fluke.

title: RHODE ISLAND AT 350: ECONOMY (AND SCANDALS) UP
description: This was supposed to be a good year for Rhode Island. The tiniest state is celebrating the 350th anniversary of its founding by Roger Williams. After decades of industrial decline, Rhode Island's economy seems to have finally turned around.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: MAJOR JOHN ANDRE: A Gallant in Spy's Clothing. By Robert McConnell Hatch. (Houghton Mifflin, $17.95.) Before dawn on the morning of Sept. 22, 1780, in a cluster of fir trees atop a hill on the west bank of the Hudson, two men met to discuss a scheme that might have changed the outcome of the American Revolution. Brig. Gen. Benedict Arnold, hero of many a battle in the cause of independence, told Maj. John Andre, adjutant general to the British commander, that for $:20,000 he would arrange to turn over the crucial post at West Point and 3,000 rebel troops. Ten days later, in the village of Tappan, N.Y., a thousand American soldiers and residents of the neighborhood, all of them sad-faced and many of them weeping, watched as Andre died, gibbeted as a spy. Meanwhile, Arnold had slipped through the lines into British-held New York City to collect his reward. The story has been told many times before, but this is the first work to concentrate on Andre's career, making full use of the Andre family papers. Mr. Hatch presents a portrait of a most engaging young man -British-born of Huguenot ancestry, urbane, well traveled, possessing a flair for writing light verse and drawing. He was a charmer of women, among them the Philadelphia belle who became Mrs. Benedict Arnold. Mr. Hatch depicts him in a highly elegant style that frequently scants significant facts and names. To his credit, Mr. Hatch does make it clear that, although to his contemporaries, American as well as British, Andre was a tragic hero, his heroism had great flaws.

title: SCHOOLING FOR 4-YEAR-OLDS STIRS QUESTIONS IN COUNTY
description: WHILE the demand for prekindergarten, day-care and Head Start programs seems to be steadily rising, a number of county educators and child-care administrators expressed serious reservations about making formal education available to all 4-year-olds, as was recently proposed for New York City children by a mayoral commission there. But interviews also suggested that the distance between local critics of the idea and the State Education Commissioner, who strongly endorsed the proposal, was not that great.

title: WHAT IS AN ALLY?
description: There has been a maximum of short-term politicking and a minimum of strategic political thought in the matter of opposing Libyan-backed terrorism. This has been the case in Europe, except for Britain's Margaret Thatcher, as well as in Washington.

title:
GARDENING;
WHEN BULBS HAVE STOPPED BLOOMING
description: TO most of us, flowering bulbs capture the very essence of spring. Their tender, green shoots emerge from the ground at the first hint of the new season's warmth, and persevere against winter's belated attempts to prevail. They soon burst into bloom, often where the last vestige of winter is still evident in melting drifts of snow.

title: By Air and by Sea; Maritime Matrimony
description: Spring for the yachtsman has always meant scraping barnacles and polishing brightwork. Nowadays it also means bookings for weddings. After a decade in which young people scorned nuptial ceremony, they are turning to yachts.

title: THE UNITED NATIONS ATTEMPTS TO SQUARE ITS OWN ACCOUNTS
description: WHEN the General Assembly reconvenes tomorrow, delegates from the 159 member countries will not debate a crisis of global politics, but one closer to home, what Secretary General Javier Perez de Cuellar describes as the ''most serious financial crisis'' in United Nations history.

title: 2 TOWNS UNITING TO FIGHT BIGOTRY
description: TWO adjacent Essex County communities beset by three years of racist vandalism will join Governor Kean and legislators in a ''Harmony Day'' next month to prove that bigotry has failed to divide them.

title: Seton Hall Wins Close Relay
description: The 92d annual Penn Relays ended today, and one of the championship races was so close that each team insisted the other had won.

title: Disabled Sue Philadelphia
description: Disabled students at Temple University sued the city in Federal court Wednesday, asserting that a recently renovated subway station is inaccessible to the handicapped. Whenever a subway station is renovated using Federal money, the law requires making the station accessible.

title: MOUNTAIN COUNTY FIGHTS RED TAPE AFTER A FLOOD
description: The great flood of last November that washed away farms, houses, people, trucks, livestock and highways in the dark of night has already produced stories throughout Pendleton County from which legends arise.

title: GROUPS PLAN DEFENSE OF IMMIGRANTS' RIGHTS
description: Representatives of more than 40 immigrant and refugee organizations and others met at Hunter College yesterday to establish a network for the defense of civil rights for all immigrants, including undocumented aliens, in the metropolitan area.

title: UNIVERSITY OFFERS STUDY IN ENGLAND
description: THE University of Hartford will begin a scholarship program next year in which a student will study at Hertford College of Oxford University in England.

title:
INVESTING;
THE 'DOW THEORY' SIGNALS A FALL
description: The big bullish swing in stock prices may be over, at least for the time being, according to one time-honored technical study. The ''Dow Theory,'' which charts the tandem action of the Dow Jones industrial and transportation averages - on the assumption that the manufacturing and transportation sectors tend to prosper or decline together - sent up a warning flag last week, when both averages fell after failing to post new joint highs.

title: CHINA'S ECONOMIC ILLS ARE MANY, C.I.A. SAYS
description: China is suffering ''numerous problems'' as a result of its seven-year-old program to introduce market-oriented economic policies, according to a Central Intelligence Agency report made public today.

title: WHO OWNS THE PAST?
description: THE POSTER SHOWS A large, rough pair of workingman's hands draped over the shoulders of a young girl in a red sweater who clutches the gnarled fingers in her own.

title: MEN, WOMEN AND CHILDREN FIRST
description: THE GOOD MOTHER By Sue Miller. 310 pp. New York:

title: The Audubon
description: To the Editor:

title: DESTITUTION IS JUST A DIVORCE AWAY
description: WOMEN AND CHILDREN LAST The Plight of Poor Women in Affluent America. By Ruth Sidel. 236 pp. New York: Viking. $16.95. RUTH SIDEL, a professor of sociology at Hunter College, has also been a psychiatric social worker whose clients were families trying to cope with serious economic and emotional problems. A major strength of ''Women and Children Last'' is that Mrs. Sidel draws deeply and equally from these two elements of her professional experience.

title: ROMANTICISM OR CYNICISM? ONLY SALLE KNOWS
description: As much as anyone, David Salle has become synonymous with 1980's American art. In his large mixed-media paintings, images from high and low culture - many of them appropriated -collide in ways that continually create and cancel meaning. Salle's strengths and weaknesses have a lot to say about what it means to be an artist in an age of pluralism - where so many conflicting constituencies exist side by side, and where every artistic approach may be analyzed from the perspective of every other.

title: PENN STATION REVAMP IS IN ARENA PLAN
description: Plans to build a new Madison Square Garden will not only keep the city's professional basketball and hockey teams in New York for at least 20 years, but will also lead to a reconstruction of Pennsylvania Station that will restore its ''sense of dignity,'' an official of the Garden's corporate owner said yesterday.

title: On Language; The Time Has Come
description: A TIMELY REMINDER: Daylight-saving begins today. Those of us who rely on a mnemonic (pronounce the opening letter m as in pneumonia, or gnu, or knee-jerk) murmur, ''Spring ahead, fall back,'' and set our cheap new quartz watches ahead, thereby ''saving'' an hour of daylight.

title: TEAMS MAKE THE BEST OF THE DIFFICULT CHOICES
description: It's not that difficult to take Bo Jackson with the first pick of the National Football League college draft. Or Tony Casillas with the second. But what about the 100th pick? Or the 200th? Or the 300?

title: NOTED WITH PLEASURE
description: How Not to Act When an actor and a director disagree on how a part should be played, the result can be a disaster. In ''Blessings In Disguise'' (Knopf), Alec Guinness describes an experience with Carol Reed.

title: Jennifer Elisabeth Clausi To Marry Robert Benoit
description: Mr. and Mrs. Adolph S. Clausi of Cos Cob, Conn., and Purling, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter Jennifer Elisabeth Clausi to Robert A. Benoit, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur Benoit of Cos Cob. A July wedding is planned.

title: Teachers End 2-Week Strike At Music College in Boston
description: The sound of music is being heard again at the Berklee College of Music, where teachers have returned to their classrooms after approving a contract agreement ending a two-week strike.

title: THE CHIPS ARE DOWN
description: IBM VS. JAPAN The Struggle for the Future. By Robert Sobel. 262 pp. New York: Stein & Day. $18.95. ROBERT SOBEL is a professor of business history at Hofstra University and a syndicated newspaper columnist with many books to his credit. In ''IBM vs. Japan,'' he discusses the looming battle for control of the computer industry between the International Business Machines Corporation and several Japanese competitors. He argues that the Japanese are going to have much more trouble in computers than they had in automobiles and consumer electronics, largely because of the strength of I.B.M. The computer giant has subdued all threats in the past and it is learning from the experience of the auto industry how to meet the Japanese challenge.

title: Claudia Dowling To Wed in August
description: Mr. and Mrs. Peter G. Dowling of Somerville and Cape May, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Claudia Ann Dowling, to Robert James Burzichelli, a son of Mayor and Mrs. John D. Burzichelli of Paulsboro, N.J. The wedding is planned for August. The future bride is the director of marketing and advertising for the Seligco Food Corporation in Lindenhurst, L.I., which manufactures Dolly Madison Ice Cream and other products.

title: TARZAN MONKEY DESCENDANTS ARE BEING OUSTED BY FLORIDA
description: Eighty wild descendants of monkeys imported for ''Tarzan'' films in the 1930's face deportation, which animal lovers say will destroy the nation's only colony of free-roaming monkeys.

title: Pop-Jazz Singing By Cocktail Combo
description: The jazz quartet Combo Cocktail wants to have it both ways. In some numbers, the group, led by the pop-jazz singer known simply as Nora, spoofs the sophisticated, pseudo-beatnik sophistication of early 1960's cabaret.

title: NEW YORK LUXE LOOKS
description: FABRIC IS WHERE IT starts. It is the stuff of which fashion is made, not only in the literal sense but often the inspirational one as well. This is certainly the case judging from advance looks at what many of America's top designers are planning for fall.

title: NEW CHAMPION AMONG ELMS
description: Kansas is not giving up in the debate over which state is home to the biggest elm tree in the nation.

title: MUCH MARCOS ART IS SAID TO BE BOGUS
description: The vast majority of works in a master painting collection of Imelda R. Marcos, including one she believed to be by Michelangelo, are inconsequential works by unimportant artists, according to the director of the Frick Collection and other art experts.

title: HISTORIC BUILDINGS RESCUED BY FUND
description: WHEN a building that is part of Connecticut's heritage is in danger of ruin or being razed, money from the Historic Properties Preservation Fund is available to save it.

title: ACADEMIC YEAR IS ENDING IN A FLURRY OF CONCERTS
description: MUSIC lovers have numerous reasons for campus-hopping for the next few weeks, as Connecticut schools and colleges prepare to conclude the academic year with final flurries of music.

title: APARTHEID PROTEST AT YALE TAKES SOME NEW TURNS
description: THE scene has become familiar on campuses around the country.

title: AS FLOW OF ILLEGAL ALIENS GROWS, COMPLAINTS MOUNT IN THE WEST
description: In this fast-growing city 16 miles north of Mexico, hospitals say they are being swamped by the cost of treating illegal aliens.

title: THE MANY FACES OF SPRING; A DRIVER'S DISCOVERIES IN THE NEXT LANE
description: EVERY year around this time, as soon as the buds appear on the trees, the interesting cars begin to appear on Long Island's roads. It's a sure sign of spring - like crocuses blooming or hay fever.

title: Rubble Art
description: Edward E. Klein, a developer in Chappaqua, N.Y., described his idea as ''one of those larks you don't do a second time.''

title: THE 'IRRITANT' THEY CALL PEROT
description: H. ROSS PEROT, the quixotic founder of the computer-services company Electronic Data Systems, champion of prisoners of war, crusader against drug abuse, advocate of educational reform, super-patriot, second-richest man in America, is having a frisky time with his new hobby.

title: LONG ISLAND GUIDE
description: MORE THAN A BEACH Jones Beach State Park, its devotees insist, is more than just a pretty, wide, white ocean beach. It's a ''great environmental teaching laboratory,'' says Myron H. Blumenfeld, chairman of the Long Island State Park and Recreation Commission. To prove it, the park and the National Audubon Society have scheduled a seven-part spring Family Nature Series program that begins today and then shifts to Saturdays through May 17. The opener, at 10 A.M., is devoted to ''Seashells by the Seashore.'' Future programs include an ecology walk, also at 10 A.M., and a session on nature photography, at 1 P.M., both this Saturday; ''Fishing Around Long Island,'' May 10, and ''An Introduction to Bird Watching,'' May 17. The series is adapted for rain or shine status. It costs $3, $2 for children under 12, for each session. The programs begin at the Interpretive Building and Parking Field West End II. For information call 277-4289.

title: ON THE STREET WHERE YOU LIVE
description: CREATIVITY isn't rampant among road namers, and the signs on Fairfield County's 15,000 or so roads usually bear names that stick to predictable themes.

title: WHERE DID SAM THE FROG GO? AND HOW COME?
description: CHRIS and his older brother, Sean, wanted to know about Sam, the frog that had died.

title: A 'QUANTUM LEAP' FOR JUDGE
description: BEYOND the window of her chambers, the lower Manhattan skyline was shrouded in thick gray storm clouds. Miriam Goldman Cedarbaum stared pensively into the distance, then swiveled around in her leather arm chair to talk about the circuitous path that led to her appointment last month to the United States District Court.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: STALIN. By Alex de Jonge. (William Morrow, $19.95.) Alex de Jonge, who teaches at Oxford University and has written biographies of Rasputin, Peter the Great, Dostoyevsky and Baudelaire, turns his considerable talents to a life of Stalin. Mr. de Jonge's work is largely one of synthesis, yet he draws so widely from the literature and blends his material so well that this eloquent, engrossing chronicle surpasses its genre and acquires a pulse and a point of view all its own.

title: New & Noteworthy
description: CRAZY HORSE AND CUSTER: The Parallel Lives of Two American Warriors, by Stephen E. Ambrose. (Meridian/New American Library, $8.95.) Stephen E. Ambrose's account of the lives and careers of George Armstrong Custer and the Oglala Sioux leader Crazy Horse concludes with Custer's death at the Little Bighorn in 1876 and the killing of Crazy Horse by Government soldiers the following year. ''This is a tale of inevitable tragedy,'' one reviewer said in 1975, ''movingly told and well written.'' The author ''has breathed new life into the familiar facts.'' THE DOLLMAKER, by Harriette Arnow. (Avon, $4.50.) Gertie Nevels follows her husband from the hills of Kentucky to the slums of World War II Detroit -where he hopes to find work in the war plants - and finds herself uprooted spiritually and culturally. In an essay reappraising the 1954 work, Joyce Carol Oates said in The Book Review in 1971 that this ''brutal, beautiful novel . . . has a permanent effect upon the reader. . . . One is convinced, partway through the book, that it is a masterpiece. . . . There are certainly greater novels than 'The Dollmaker'; but I can think of none that have moved me more, personally, terrifyingly, involving me in the solid fact of life's criminal exploitation of those who live it.'' It is, she said, ''one of those excellent American works that have yet to be properly assessed.'' MARIA THERESA, by Edward Crankshaw. (Atheneum, $10.95.) This biography of the Empress who came to the throne of the Hapsburg Empire in 1740 at the age of 23 and guided it through some of its most difficult years is a ''warm, almost worshipful life,'' one reviewer said in 1970. ''Mr. Crankshaw has managed . . . to rescue Maria Theresa from the history books and to turn a monument into a warm and appealing woman.''

title: SAVINGS CAPTURES TRIAL
description: Savings, a 3-year-old colt who is not nominated to the Kentucky Derby, won the final Derby prep race of the spring today with a 6 1/2-length victory in the Derby Trial Stakes on opening day at Churchill Downs.

title: October Wedding For Ann Carlston
description: Dr. and Mrs. John Anthony Carlston of Virginia Beach, Va., have announced the engagement of their daughter Ann Hunter Carlston to William Jeffrey Kramer, the son of Mr. and Mrs. John S. Kramer of Princeton, N.J. and Greensboro, Vt. An Oct. 4 wedding is planned.

title: 'QUALITY CONTROL' AT COMMUNITY COLLEGES
description: THE recent article on stepped-up recruitment campaigns at Nassau Community College and Suffolk County Community College [ March 30 ] describes quite well one aspect of the effort to cope with declining enrollment.

title: Deborah Therese Ambrose To Wed David J. Wismer
