description: Mr. and Mrs. John Francis Ambrose of Pinehurst, N.C., have announced the engagement of their daughter Deborah Therese Ambrose to David Joseph Wismer, a son of the late Rev. and Mrs. Eli F. Wismer of Tenafly, N.J. A May 31 wedding is planned.

title: COOKING THE LIGHT FANTASTIC
description: THE MINI-REVOLUTION probably began in October 1984 at the Four Seasons in New York City. Breaking with tradition, the glamorous and high-priced restaurant was the first to offer alternatives to the traditional high-fat, high-calorie meals that had always been the hallmark of elegant dining. Not only did the restaurant provide healthful dishes, it promoted them.

title: THE MEDIUM AND THE ARTIST
description: A BASIC distinction between a fine artist and an artist working from a craft tradition sometimes can be seen in the approach to media, rather than in a medium itself. That comes across clearly in the paired New Jersey Artist exhibitions now at the State Museum here.

title: Samantha Rand Plans To Wed Editor in June
description: Jeanne Gundry Rand of Princeton, N.J., and Howard Morris Rand of Oldwick, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter Nancy Satler Rand to David Scott Gibbons. He is the son of Mary Weitzel Gibbons of New York and Felton Lewis Gibbons of Hopewell, N.J. A June wedding is planned.

title: AFTER THERAPY, WHAT?
description: LISA AND DAVID TODAY Their Healing Journey From Childhood and Pain Into Love and Life. By Theodore Isaac Rubin. 146 pp. New York: Macmillan Publishing Company. $14.95. IN case you didn't know, ''David and Lisa,'' that touching film of some 20 years ago about two deeply disturbed adolescents who reach out to each other, wasn't true. It was based on the novelette ''Lisa and David'' by Theodore Isaac Rubin, who has written a sequel. They are here published together as one novel.

title: OFFENSIVE LINE PRESENTS NO. 1 AREA OF CONCERN
description: These are the times that bring a boy's mischievous grin to Mike Hickey's freckled face. Just what devilish thing is Hickey, the Jets' draft maestro, going to do now? The Jets, who choose 22d in the National Football League draft Tuesday, need help on the offensive line - the draft's deepest position - and linebackers, along with a healthy running back and defensive back.

title: Clare Jane Weds Brian L. Dalgetty
description: Clare Adele Virginia Jane, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Jane of Half Moon Bay, Antigua, was married yesterday to Brian Larry Dalgetty, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Jay Dalgetty of Basking Ridge, N.J. The Rev. Dr. John Bishop peformed the ceremony at Christ Episcopal Church in Greenwich, Conn., assisted by the Rev. William Kimball, a Lutheran minister who is the bridegroom's brother-in-law.

title: SOLID WASTE STILL INTRACTABLE
description: A YEAR ago this Thursday, a new state law designed to ease the transition to resource recovery went into effect. Among its provisions was a bonus of $1 a ton for any municipality with a solid-waste facility.

title: DOCUMENT TRACES HESSIAN WAR ROLE
description: A KEY document, ''The Trenton Prisoner List,'' has surfaced to identify the Hessians taken captive in the Battle of Trenton on Dec. 26, 1776, and to provide significant clues to their subsequent activities.

title: Lynn Lurie Is Fiancee Of Andrew Ian Koven
description: Lynn Alice Lurie, a first-year student at the Fordham University School of Law, and Andrew Ian Koven, a lawyer studying for a master's degree in law from Columbia University, plan to be married in June, her parents, Mr. and Mrs. William L. Lurie of Harrison, N.Y., have announced.

title: IF YOU SUCCEED, WHY NOT TRY AGAIN?
description: There is a saying among grandmasters,''Don't try to win the same game twice.''

title: INQUIRY ON TUROFF TURNS TO OTHER FIGURES
description: Federal prosecutors, confident that they have the evidence to obtain a bribery indictment against the city's former taxi chief, Jay L. Turoff, say they are now focusing on a potentially larger corruption case.

title: NEWARK LIBRARY'S WITHDRAWAL OF PHOTO EXHIBIT STIRS DISPUTE
description: THE withdrawal of a photography exhibit at the Newark Public Library has generated a dispute between library officials and the photographer.

title: VISION TESTS NEEDED FOR THE STATE'S MOTORISTS
description: In Connecticut, you do not need an eye test to renew your driver's license. State legislators have studied this problem, but nothing has happened. This scares me. I live in Connecticut. You must be able to see danger to avoid it. Many drivers on Connecticut highways cannot see what they should see.

title: ABOUT LONG ISLAND
description: ECUMENICAL Council Vatican II (1962-65) led to many changes for Roman Catholic Church all over the world, but one change that Pope John XXIII might not have envisaged was what happened in Oceanside. St. Anthony's Church lost its choir, but Long Island gained an ecumenical chorale.

title: Don't Forget The Senators
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: OPERAS CONDUCTED AS SYMPHONIES WITH VOICES
description: The new Angel release of ''I Capuleti e i Montecchi'' -Bellini's setting of the ''Romeo and Juliet'' story, though not based on Shakespeare's version - is part of a welcome trend toward issuing live opera performances on records, even though the performing here is not of the livest sort. It comes from a production mounted in the spring of 1984 at the Royal Opera House, Covent Garden. It makes particularly interesting listening for one who saw one of the performances (the second of the run) in London.

title: LATIN NATIONS JOIN U.S. IN EFFORT TO COMBAT DRUGS
description: Amid growing alarm at the impact of drugs on their own societies, Latin American nations have joined the United States in preparing a strategy to combat narcotics trafficking throughout the Americas.

title: STAGE: EQUITY LIBRARY OFFERS 'THREE SISTERS'
description: THE energy the cast brings to the Equity Library Theater production of Chekhov's ''Three Sisters,'' and their enjoyment of the complex play, is often infectious. This work presents so many difficult challenges to directors and actors that any company staging it deserves compassion. But the Equity version suffers considerably from confused, and sometimes confusing, direction and some miscasting.

title: Ecuador Seeks Plane Carrying Top Official
description: A plane carrying Education Minister Camilo Gallegos, his son and three other officials disappeared Friday on a flight from the capital.

title: TOPPING OFF MASS TRANSIT'S BUDGET
description: WITH gasoline prices falling and motorists presumably in a better mood, mass-transit planners in the metropolitan area have been casting covetous glances at gasoline taxes as a source of funds. The Regional Plan Association, a private research group, recommended last month that motorists help the hard-pressed Metropolitan Transportation Authority by paying higher local and Federal gasoline taxes, higher bridge and tunnel tolls in New York City and higher motor vehicle registration fees in the M.T.A. district - New York City and the seven closest New York counties. But in addition to New York City's 8.25 percent sales tax, motorists already pay 8 cents a gallon to the state and 9 cents to the Federal Government. The city and state taxes go into general funds; of the Federal tax, 8 cents is used for highway construction and a penny goes to mass transit. James Brooke, who covers transportation for The Times, asked Felix G. Rohatyn, the investment banker who is chairman of the Municipal Assistance Corporation and heads the transit committee of Governor Cuomo's Council on Fiscal and Economic Priorities, and James J. McGowan, director of government affairs for the Automobile Club of New York, for their thoughts. Some excerpts follow. FELIX G. ROHATYN: More Funds Are Needed

title: PUTTING IT TOGETHER
description: PRESIDENT CORAZON C. AQUINO dates her central ideas of politics and government to a sad, intimate, now- cherished time when she made weekly conjugal visits to her husband, Ninoy, during his years as a political prisoner of Ferdinand E. Marcos - years of seething in confinement while he became a legend among Filipinos. She listened closely in those hours at the side of this intensely talkative man who lived and eventually died for the cause of restoring representative government to his fellow Filipinos.

title: INDONESIA'S SUHARTO: MYSTERIOUS AND REMOTE, BUT IN FIRM CONTROL
description: Of all the heads of friendly governments President Reagan is likely to encounter while in office, President Suharto of Indonesia may be the most remote and mysterious.

title: IN-HOME THERAPY FOR BEHAVIORAL ILLS
description: IT was nearly 6:30 A.M. one recent morning when Stanley Rybicki, a behavioral psychologist, knocked on the door of a ranch house in a Yonkers residential neighborhood.

title: SUMMARY SUNDAY: APRIL 27, 1986
description: International The President warned dictators and terrorists to be prepared for the consequences if they perpetrated ''cowardly acts'' on American citizens. President Reagan issued the warning after arriving in Hawaii, his second stop on his way to an economic summit meeting in Tokyo. Before he left Los Angeles, he indicated in his weekly radio address his Administration's willingness to remain involved in economic and security matters in the Pacific. [ Page 1, Column 6. ] American officials are undecided on how far to go in repeating attacks similar to the one on Libya to counter an expected rise in anti-American terrorism around the world. President Reagan has said the United States would strike again. [ 1:5. ] The Qaddafi regime is undergoing self-criticism of the fight it put up April 14 against the American air raid. American pilots evaded the Libyan air defense system and were already over Tripoli dropping bombs before antiaircraft fire began. Meanwhile some Libyan troops abandoned their posts and their commanders were slow to give orders, according to Western diplomats and Eastern-bloc sources. [ 1:3. ] Money is flowing out of Japan to the rest of the world, through investments ranging from automobile plants in Michigan to United States Treasury bonds to loans for petroleum development in the South China Sea. Japan has become the world's premier supplier of money, fueled by profits from exports and huge pools of domestic savings. [ 1:5. ] Haitian troops fired on a crowd of 10,000 people who had marched through Port-au-Prince, the capital, after a memorial service for political victims of the Duvalier era, and eight people died and dozens were wounded, an army officer said.

title: PANEL SEEKS TO END UNCONTROLLED SALE OF MEDICINES
description: A Congressional panel recommended today that drug manufacturers be prohibited from giving free samples of their products to physicians. The panel said some physicians sold pharmacists the medicines, which thus ended up in an uncontrolled distribution system.

title: Rev. Allen Winston Cook Is Wed to Lucie Haggerty
description: Lucie Valle Haggerty and the Rev. Allen Winston Cook were married last night at the Tabernacle Baptist Church in Florence, S.C., by the Rev. Wayne Miller. Mrs. Cook, a daughter of Mrs. Richard Farnsworth Hunnewell of Locust Valley, L.I., and Joseph John Haggerty Jr. of New York, is a graduate of Francis Marion College, which her husband attended. They both received associate degrees from Gloryland Bible College in Florence.

title: SCULPTURE GOES PUBLIC
description: THEY ARE CALLED ''sculptures,'' but they are unusual, hybrid works that more often resemble furniture, architectural structures, landscaped gardens or even electrical and plumbing systems. Yet, while the new public art defies easy categorization, city planners and developers are commissioning them with increasing frequency, and they have already transformed the look of many prominent parks, plazas, lobbies and public squares.

title: OPERA: ARROYO IN THE MET'S 'CAVALLERIA'
description: IT was nice to have Martina Arroyo back at the Metropolitan Opera Thursday night. Miss Arroyo had not sung at the Met since 1977, and she returned as Santuzza in Mascagni's ''Cavalleria Rusticana.''

title: EXPRESSIONISM IN FORT LAUDERDALE, HISTORY IN THE FINGER LAKES
description: Abstract Art in Florida Exhibit At the end of World War II, a new generation of American artists forged a new style of painting. Known as Abstract Expressionism, it emphasized the artist's expression of intense emotion either through active gestural marks on the canvas or through the dynamic of optically active color relationships.Among the leaders of this movement were Jackson Pollock, Willem de Kooning, Mark Rothko, Robert Motherwell and Richard Pousette-Dart.

title: Making English Official Language
description: BY action of the City Council, English was declared the official language of Fillmore, Calif., a community where roughly half the 10,000 residents are Hispanic.

title: Valerie Johnson Planning to Wed
description: The engagement of Valerie Lynn Johnson and Stephen Gardner Dent has been announced by the parents of the bride-to-be, Mr. and Mrs. Ronald N. Johnson of Ormand Beach, Fla. A September wedding is planned.

title: GIDDYUP ON HORSE BLOCK ROAD
description: A PROPOSAL to rehabilitate Farmingville's downtown business area and widen a stretch of the main street, Horse Block Road, is moving toward construction after more than three years of planning and court battles.

title:
MUSIC;
MONTCLAIR TO HOLD EARLY-PIANO FESTIVAL
description: AN ''Early Piano Festival,'' in which a copy of an 1825 Conrad Graf fortepiano will be used - the Graf represents the pinnacle of Viennese piano-building of the 1820's - will be held at Montclair State College Wednesday through Friday.

title: THE MANY FACES OF SPRING; A PLEA FOR THE FARMER
description: ''LET us get up early to the vineyards; let us see if the vine flourish.''

title: Changing South Africa 1983
description: Nov. 2: White referendum approves limited political role for mixed-blood and Indian groups; blacks still excluded. 1985 Feb. 1: Government says it will no longer forcibly relocate blacks living near white cities.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: THE LOVE ISLAND. By David Glover. (Robin Clark/ Salem House, $13.95.) The British may never recover from the failure of the Empire, but at least they're still trying to figure out what went wrong.

title: FOUNDER OF ALDRICH MUSEUM LOOKS TO ITS EXPANSION
description: LARRY ALDRICH runs his 22-year-old contemporary art museum in Ridgefield the way he ran his Seventh Avenue dress business in Manhattan for more than half a century - personally.

title: IN QUOTES
description: ''We did what we did, and we didn't do what we didn't do.'' Paul A. Volcker, Fed chairman, on whether the United States intervened in currency markets.

title: Elaine Anne Weir Is Wed To Stephen E. Sherman
description: Elaine Anne Weir, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John D. Weir of Lloyd Harbor, L.I., was married yesterday to Stephen E. Sherman, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Milton Sherman of Bolton, Conn. The Rev. John B. Bardsley performed the ceremony at the Huntington (L.I.) United Methodist Church.

title: Libya Plans Response To Europe's Sanctions
description: Libya said today that it would take action in response to sanctions imposed Monday by the European Community.

title: Rapid Transit to Dulles: An Idea Reborn
description: Twenty-five years ago, when the Federal Aviation Administration opened Dulles International Airport 26 miles west of Washington in rural northern Virginia, it set aside a strip of land for a mass transit system to improve access between the city and the airport, a trip that takes at least 45 minutes for many drivers.

title: BEST SELLERS: April 27, 1986
description: Weeks This Last on Week Fiction Week List 1 THE BOURNE SUPREMACY, by Robert Ludlum. 1 8 (Random House, $19.95.) The hero of ''The Bourne Identity'' foils a plot to seize Hong Kong and bring China into conflict with the West. 2 I'LL TAKE MANHATTAN, by Judith Krantz. 1 (Crown, $18.95.) Rich and beautiful Maxi Amberville conquers the world of magazine publishing. 3 A PERFECT SPY, by John le Carre. (Knopf, 1 $18.95.) The tale of Magnus Pym, a British secret agent, and his father, Rick, a flamboyant con man. 4 BREAK IN, by Dick Francis. (Putnam, $17.95.) 2 6 Mystery, melodrama and bitter family rivalry in the world of British steeplechase racing. 5 LAKE WOBEGON DAYS, by Garrison Keillor. 4 35 (Viking, $17.95.) Yarns about life in a small Minnesota town. 6 THE MAMMOTH HUNTERS, by Jean M. Auel. 3 23 (Crown, $19.95.) Ayla continues her adventures in the prehistoric world in a sequel to ''The Clan of the Cave Bear'' and ''The Valley of Horses.'' 7 LIE DOWN WITH LIONS, by Ken Follett. 6 13 (Morrow, $18.95.) An Englishwoman caught between the C.I.A. and the K.G.B., romance and loyalty, in contemporary Afghanistan. 8 HOME FRONT, by Patti Davis with Maureen 7 5 Strange Foster. (Crown, $15.95.) A semi-autobiographical novel by the daughter of President and Mrs. Reagan. 9 SEASONS OF THE HEART, by Cynthia Freeman. 5 5 (Putnam, $17.95.) A businesswoman is torn between devotion to her husband and her mentor. 10 THE HANDMAID'S TALE, by Margaret Atwood. 8 9 (Houghton Mifflin, $16.95.) In the America of the future men and women perform assigned services. 11 HIGH JINX, by William F. Buckley Jr. 10 3 (Doubleday, $16.95.) Blackford Oakes on the trail of the traitor who spoiled a plan to liberate Albania. 12 JOANNA'S HUSBAND AND DAVID'S WIFE, by 11 6 Elizabeth Forsythe Hailey. (Delacorte, $17.95.) Two sides of a marriage revealed through diary entries. 13 NERILKA'S STORY, by Anne McCaffrey. (Del 9 4 Rey/Ballantine, $12.95.) While fighting a plague on the planet Pern, Nerilka finds a true love. 14 TEXAS, by James A. Michener. (Random House, 13 29 $21.95.) Four hundred fifty years of history in fictional form. 15 CYCLOPS, by Clive Cussler. (Simon & 16 14 Schuster, $18.95.) The quest for a vanished ship involves Fidel Castro, the Kremlin, the White House and the moon. Nonfiction 1 YOU'RE ONLY OLD ONCE! by Dr. Seuss. (Random 1 7 House, $9.95.) A checkup at the Golden Years Clinic in pictures and rhyme; the first Dr. Seuss book for adults. 2 BUS 9 TO PARADISE, by Leo Buscaglia. (Slack/ 2 11 Morrow, $16.95.) Another trip with the ebullient advocate of the virtues of love. 3 THE MAN WHO MISTOOK HIS WIFE FOR A HAT, by 3 4 Oliver Sacks. (Summit, $15.95.) Clinical tales about strange neurological disabilities. 4 THE GREAT GETTY, by Robert Lenzner. (Crown, 5 8 $18.95.) The life and loves of J. Paul Getty. 5 WHEN ALL YOU'VE EVER WANTED ISN'T ENOUGH, by 11 2 Harold S. Kushner. (Summit, $16.95.) A rabbi discusses ''the search for a life that matters.'' 6 BLESSINGS IN DISGUISE, by Alec Guinness. 4 5 (Knopf, $17.95.) The autobiography of the distinguished English actor. 7 IACOCCA: An Autobiography, by Lee Iacocca 6 78 with William Novak. (Bantam, $19.95.) The rise of an immigrants' son to top jobs at Ford and Chrysler. 8 ADRIFT, by Steven Callahan. (Houghton 9 9 Mifflin, $15.95.) One man's survival for 76 days on an inflatable raft in the Atlantic. 9 WISEGUY, by Nicholas Pileggi. (Simon & 8 11 Schuster, $17.95.) The experiences of Henry Hill as a member of a Mafia family. 10 YEAGER: An Autobiography, by Chuck Yeager 7 42 and Leo Janos. (Bantam, $17.95.) The story of the first man to fly faster than sound. 11 ARCTIC DREAMS, by Barry Lopez. (Scribners, 10 4 $22.95.) A rhapsodic report on human life and wildlife north of the Arctic Circle. 12 GREED AND GLORY ON WALL STREET, by Ken 15 11 Auletta. (Random House, $19.95.) The fall of the investment bankers Lehman Brothers Kuhn Loeb. 13 A LIGHT IN THE ATTIC, by Shel Silverstein. 12 164 (Harper & Row, $13.50.) Light verse and drawings. 14 ON THE ROAD WITH CHARLES KURALT, by Charles 28 Kuralt. (Putnam, $16.95.) The television reporter tells of Americans he's encountered. 15 A PASSION FOR EXCELLENCE, by Tom Peters and 40 Nancy Austin. (Random House, $19.95.) Ways to achieve distinction in management. 16 NECESSARY LOSSES, by Judith Viorst. (Simon & 1 Schuster, $17.95.) Life is a series of losses, the author argues, and we must confront them in order to grow. Advice and Self-Help 1 FIT FOR LIFE, by Harvey Diamond and Marilyn 1 36 Diamond. (Warner, $17.50.) A diet for weight loss and physical fitness. 2 CALLANETICS, by Callan Pinckney with Sallie 2 22 Batson. (Morrow, $17.95.) Exercises to enable women to look ''10 years younger in 10 hours.'' 3 WOMEN WHO LOVE TOO MUCH, by Robin Norwood. 3 30 (Tarcher/St. Martin's, $14.95.) Ways to avoid or end addictive, unhealthy relationships with men. 4 THE RICE DIET REPORT, by Judy Moscovitz. 4 4 (Putnam, $16.95.) A diet developed more than 40 years ago at a clinic in North Carolina is explained by a successful user. 5 THE BE (HAPPY) ATTITUDES, by Robert 5 25 Schuller. (Word, $12.95.) Inspiration from a California clergyman.

title: Reagan Invites Aquino to Visit
description: President Reagan telephoned Corazon C. Aquino last week, two months after she replaced his friend, Ferdinand E. Marcos, as President of the Philippines. In a brief call, their first conversation, Mr. Reagan invited Mrs. Aquino to Washington after the elections in November.

title: AROUND THE GARDEN
description: This Week:

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS
description: WHAT HAPPENED TO PATRICK'S DINOSAURS? By Carol Carrick. Illustrated by Donald Carrick. Unpaged. New York: Clarion Books/ Ticknor & Fields. $12.95. (Ages 5 to 9) WHY do kids love dinosaurs? They love how weird and scary they look and how much they resemble the monsters of their own imaginations. They love their fun-to-pronounce, crazy names and the number of different kinds and the fact that they lived (safely long ago) in a world that seems like a fantasy of outer space. When these things are combined, it becomes fun to imagine creatures so weird and so remote as part of your own world. It's also fun to imagine yourself as part of theirs.

title: Samaranch Seeks Accord
description: The dispute between North and South Korea on the prospective venues of the 1988 Summer Olympic Games must be resolved in June if all nations are to participate, International Olympic Committee President Juan Antonio Samaranch said today.

title: JAZZ: CECIL TAYLOR UNIT
description: THE current lineup of the Cecil Taylor Unit, which ends a run at Sweet Basil (88 Seventh Avenue South, near West Fourth Street) tonight, roils and rages like the other groups the pianist has led since the 1960's. Yet with Thurman Barker on marimba, Steve McCall on drums and the singer Brenda Bakr, it can also lighten up now and then; its multilayered intensity shades into music that is still percussive, yet delicate.

title: Modest Hobart Program Succeeds
description: THE PHONE in the office of Dave Urick, the Hobart College lacrosse coach, rang last Tuesday and the caller was Mike Taranto, a star player from Irondequoit High School in Rochester who had been the target of considerable recruiting effort.

title:
NUMISMATICS;
OLD DESIGNS FOR THE NEW COINS
description: Two of the most popular designs in United States coinage history may be resurrected for the new gold and silver bullion coins to be issued by the United States Treasury. Reports indicate that four gold bullion coins may feature the obverse design of the much-acclaimed Saint-Gaudens double eagle, while the one-ounce silver coin may carry the design of the Walking Liberty half dollar.

title: Social Events; Assorted Festivities
description: Parisian Beneficiary April 27 - Incorporated by an act of Congress, the American Hospital of Paris opened in 1910 and serves patients from all countries, depending for support on patient revenue and contributions. A Champagne buffet and rare-book auction, with books in the $200 to $2,500 range, plus a talk by the author Jerzy Kosinski, will be be held at 6 P.M. at Christie's, Park Avenue at 59th Street, to benefit the hospital. Tickets, $100, at the door. Helping a Boy's Club April 28 - For the 14th year, the women's committee of the Kips Bay Boy's Club will present its decorator show house, displaying the works of 15 design firms in the 1895 home once occupied by the architect Cass Gilbert. The showcase benefits the club's after-school programs in the South Bronx. Tickets for a cocktail-party preview, from 6 P.M. to 8 P.M. at 1 East 94th Street, $100, from 212-893-8600 on Monday. Loft Party April 28 - A 7 P.M. cocktail party starts off an evening of readings by Blythe Danner, excerpts from Meredith Monk's new movie, ''Book of Days,'' other performances and dancing, all in a huge loft overlooking the Hudson River on the 11th floor of 450 West 31st Street. Tickets for the evening, to benefit the House Foundation for the Arts, $125, from 212-206-1440. Surrealist Ball April 30 - With laser lights, synthesizers, an all-female salsa band and performances on a toy piano and car horns, the Guggenheim Museum will hold a fund-raising Surrealist Ball at the museum from 9 P.M. to 1 A.M. There will be prizes for best costumes.

title: RANGERS LOW-KEY
description: Today they offered logic.

title: OLD ROOTS, FRESH SOUNDS KEEP THE STONES UP TO DATE
description: The Rolling Stones's ''Dirty Work'' (Rolling Stones 40250, LP, CD and cassette) is this grizzled band's best album since ''Some Girls'' of 1978. In between have come three other studio albums - ''Emotional Rescue,'' ''Tattoo You'' and ''Undercover'' - plus a live tour album and a couple of greatest-hits collections. ''Dirty Work'' may not be quite at the level of ''Some Girls,'' which mustered up the quintessential Stones misogyny combined with a remarkable feeling for the seamy streets of New York. But its excellence, contrasted with the relative drought in between, tells us something about how this aging, very adult rock band sustains its creativity, and something about how the lucrative mechanics of record deals affect that creativity.

title: REACHING FOR PERFECTION - THE LIFE AND DEATH OF A DANCER
description: Just over two months ago, one week before the end of the New York City Ballet's winter season, Joseph Duell, age 29, one of the company's principal dancers, took his own life. It is shocking when someone commits suicide and it is shocking when someone you know commits suicide. But when there is a suicide in the midst of a ballet company, the shock is mixed with a bewilderment that shakes our world to its very foundations.

title: JUST A COTTAGE SMALL BY A SHOPPING MALL
description: CRABGRASS FRONTIER The Suburbanization of the United States. By Kenneth T. Jackson. Illustrated. 396 pp. New York: Oxford University Press. $21.95. EVERYTHING conspired to make it happen: farmland was a drug on the market and crops were surplus commodities; gasoline was cheap and so were autos; Congress repeatedly subsidized interest rates for mortgages that encouraged an outward flow; cities accumulated blacks, debts and crime. And so it came about, the greatest exodus of city population into new suburbs in world history, coupled with the greatest expansion of suburban housing. From the end of World War II in 1945, this revolution ran unchecked until the oil embargo of 1973, and still continues in varying degrees into the 1980's. In ''Crabgrass Frontier,'' Kenneth T. Jackson, a professor of history at Columbia University, unfolds the comprehensive history of those forces behind the suburban boom and the implacable and virtually irresistible pressures that brought it about. (Whether it was inevitable is a question yet to be resolved.) He sets the stage for future revisionists with this ''essay,'' as he terms it - a history of authoritative scope, winner of the Francis Parkman Prize of the Society of American Historians and a Bancroft Prize in history, awarded by Columbia.

title: FIELD IS SEEN AS WIDE OPEN FOR A CUOMO RUNNING MATE
description: Five weeks before a state Democratic ticket is designated, Governor Cuomo is still trying to select a lieutenant governor candidate, a choice that is unusually important this year because Mr. Cuomo may run for President in 1988.

title: NEW CASSETTES: FROM MONTEVERDI TO RED NORVO
description: The Swimmer Starring Burt Lancaster, Janice Rule, Kim Hunter, Marge Champion, Bill Fiore, Joan Rivers; directed by Frank Perry, 1968 RCA/Columbia Home Video 94 minutes. $59.95 On a glorious summer Sunday afternoon, Neddy Merrill (Burt Lancaster) decides to swim home across Fairfield County through the pools of his friends, all of whom, like Neddy, drank too much the night before.

title: CONNECTICUT GUIDE
description: WILDLIFE ART Wildlife on canvas and in the flesh will be exhibited in the Thames Science Center's Wildlife Art Festival, to be held at the center, Gallows Lane in New London, Saturday and next Sunday.

title: American Catholic in Rome
description: As one seeker of religious home to another, I would like to compliment Barbara Grizzuti Harrison on her article. How well she expresses the need many of us have to somehow match a private spiritual vision with institutional realities. My own search within Judaism for liturgical beauty, intellectual liveliness and community has led me to conclusions very like those of Mrs. Harrison. ERNEST RUBINSTEIN Hoboken, N.J.

title: SUIT CHALLENGES TACTICS OF CHURCH
description: A former official of the Church of Scientology, testifying at the trial of his suit charging the church with fraud, says church staff members engaged in a pattern of lies, tricks and deception in efforts to keep him from disclosing how the organization operates.

title: Budget Hotel
description: In the late 1970's, the area surrounding Plainfield, N.J., in Middlesex County, appeared doomed as businesses closed and retailers fled. But now, in the 1980's, the area is enjoying a surge in business development, primarily in campus-style office complexes.

title: IN FLORIDA, A WAITING LIST TO WATCH EXECUTIONS
description: A father hopes to relieve the pain of his son's murder by watching the slayer executed. A writer watches an electrocution to help with his novel. A legislator watches and wonders if the process is humane.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: SWORD OVER RICHMOND: An Eyewitness History of McClellan's Peninsula Campaign. By Richard Wheeler. (Harper & Row, $21.95.) Gen. George B. McClellan's campaign against Richmond, Va., in 1862 should have ended gloriously for the Union Army.

title: LIFE WITHOUT EUPHEMISMS
description: PLAINTEXT Essays. By Nancy Mairs. 154 pp. Tucson: The University of Arizona Press. $15.95. NANCY MAIRS has a way of dropping her bombshells casually, almost in passing.

title: TRIAL IS AWAITING TESTIMONY OF SPY
description: Although there are months of testimony and dozens of witnesses to come, the Government's case against Jerry A. Whitworth, who is charged with espionage, may reach a peak in the coming week with the anticipated testimony of the prosecution's most crucial witness, John A. Walker Jr. Mr. Walker, who has acknowledged heading a spy ring for the Soviet Union, is to testify against Mr. Whitworth as part of an agreement made with the Government when he pleaded guilty to espionage charges in Baltimore last October. Prosecutors say Mr. Walker recruited Mr. Whitworth, a longtime Navy friend, as a spy in 1973.

title: THE DOCTOR'S HOUSE CALL - 1986 STYLE
description: DOCTORS who made housecalls were, until recently, heading toward extinct-species status. A few supporting figures from Physician Management, an American Medical Association publication: In 1960, family practitioners made 68 million house calls nationwide. By 1975 that figure had slid to 17 million, and continued to slide well into the 1980's.

title: Shari Beth Neufeld Wed
description: Shari Beth Neufeld, the daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Milton Neufeld of Stratford, Conn., and Abraham Hatem, a son of the late Mr. and Mrs. John Hatem of Columbus, Ohio, were married April 19 by Judge Paul D. Shapero of the Probate Court of Stamford, Conn.

title: CORRECTION
description: Because of a transcription error, several words were dropped from a sentence in ''Reading Before Writing,'' an essay by Alexander Marshack in the April 6 Book Review. The sentence should have read:

title: Off the Empire State
description: Michael R. P. McCarthy, a 25-year-old Briton, says he parachuted from the Eiffel Tower two years ago.

title: NEW CASSETTES: FROM MONTEVERDI TO RED NORVO
description: Medea A ballet by Georgiy Aleksidze; 1979 Kultur 70 minutes. $59.95 This ''Medea,'' a one-act ballet filmed in 1979 in the Soviet Union, may be of considerable interest to balletomanes curious about modern Soviet ballet.

title: TEAMS SEEK ANSWERS TO A NEW SET OF QUESTIONS
description: IN the old days, as a National Football League draft approached, teams worried more about a prospect's size and speed than his financial demands and social habits. Scouts were satisfied knowing about a quarterback's arm, a receiver's hands and a defensive back's quickness. Things like that. These days that's not enough. These days, the N.F.L. clubs are asking other kinds of questions. Now they want to know about agility, vertical jumps, percentage of body fat, hang time, who his agent is and what kind of ''citizen'' is he, which is a polite way of asking, ''Has the kid used drugs?'' And if so, what kind and to what extent.

title: Ann Patterson Nash Weds Lee Kennedy in Baltimore
description: Ann Patterson Nash, a daughter of Mrs. Carl A. TenHoopen Jr. of Annapolis, Md., and the late David Chenault Nash of Baltimore, was married yesterday to Lee McCardell Kennedy, a son of Mary Ann Daily of Baltimore and Jerome McDonald Kennedy of Gaithersburg, Md. The Rev. Robert Patterson performed the ceremony at the Episcopal Church of the Redeemer in Baltimore.

title: REWARDING MUSIC BY A PRIZE-WINNING COMPOSER
description: To borrow some terminology from film criticism, Nonesuch's new album of music by George Perle (Nonesuch 9 79108-1, disk; 79108-4, cassette, and 79108-2, compact disk, due out in May) is something of a sleeper - a modest production that is immodestly rewarding.

title: NEW MOOD REIGNS AT L.I.U.
description: A YEAR ago, when Dr. David J. Steinberg arrived to become president of Long Island University, it was ''the worst of times and the best of times,'' he recalled recently.

title: SPRING STYLE IN A BREEZE
description: THERE are at least two things the women pictured here have in common. The first is easy to spot: they're all hanging on to their hats in the face of some recent stiff spring breezes.

title: Helen Davlin Is Married
description: Helen Kingsley Davlin, a daughter of Andrew Davlin Jr. of Pismo Beach, Calif., and Mrs. Thomas Allan Ennis of Hobe Sound, Fla., and New York, was married yesterday to William Gerard Reardon, a son of Mrs. Frederick A. Reardon of Providence, R.I., and the late Mr. Reardon. Msgr. George F. Bardes performed the ceremony at St. Thomas More Church in New York.

title: Tamara Nash Is Married To Richard Allen Ammons
description: Tamara Susan Nash, a program representative with the Office of Contract Programs at the American University, was married yesterday to Richard Allen Ammons, the director of development at the Johns Hopkins University School of Advanced International Studies in Washington. Bishop John Hurst Adams of the African Methodist Episcopal Church performed the ceremony in the Dunbarton Chapel at the Howard University School of Law.

title: Singapore Honors Rescuers
description: Three Irishmen, a Briton and a Singaporean who burrowed through the ruins of a collapsed hotel to save 17 people, received awards for bravery today. The five were among 93 men honored for deeds involving the collapse of the New World Hotel last month in which 33 people died. Patrick Gallagher, Thomas Gallagher and Michael Prendergast of Ireland, Michael Scott of Britain and Tan Jin Thong of Singapore received medals.

title: The Best of Times Are Not Likely To Last Forever
description: ''We're getting the best of the best news right now,'' said Robert G. Dederick, chief economist at Chicago's Northern Trust Company. ''But we have to recognize where it's coming from, and that this won't keep coming.''

title: SADDER MUSIC AND STRONGER POETICS
description: PEOPLE often ask why modern literature is so sad, as if it were somebody's fault, and it occurred to me that it might be useful to compile An Intelligent Reader's Guide to Sadness. In modern life and literature, sadness is so ubiquitous that quite a few writers have pronounced on it.

title: ETHNIC HUMOR BUBBLES TO THE SURFACE OF THE MELTING POT
description: Watching ''Wise Guys,'' Brian De Palma's funny new movie about a couple of pals who are saved from a life of crime by their incompetence, is like coming in at the end of a chapter of American social history. One of the pals is Italian, one Jewish, and ethnic gags abound, featuring such fixtures as an Italian godfather and a Jewish mother. ''Wise Guys'' is hardly an important movie, but there's something important about what it, along with others of recent years, represents.

title: Manning Injures Knee
description: One of those pickup basketball games may have cost the University of Kansas star forward, Danny Manning, a chance to make the United States team that will play for the world basketball championship this summer. Manning, who said his left knee ''popped'' during a campus pickup game last week, has a strained tendon in his left knee and is expected to be wearing a soft cast for at least three weeks.

title: Nancy Pitt Is Affianced
description: Nancy Alice Pitt and Gordon Eliot Sands, both of New York, will be married in June, it has been announced by the future bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. G. Selden Pitt of St. Davids, Pa.

title: Sarah Rex, John Geary Are Married
description: Sarah McCune Rex, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert McKay Rex of Darien, Conn., was married there yesterday to John Norton Geary, a son of Mr. and Mrs. John Clyde Geary of Suffield, Conn. The Rev. Walter Taylor performed the ceremony at St. Luke's Episcopal Church, assisted by the Rev. Francis Virgulak, a Roman Catholic priest.

title: ALI'S MEDICINE
description: EVERY so often, Muhammad Ali would reach into a can of mixed nuts, pick out a cashew and munch it. In a cream shirt and black pants but barefoot, the three-time heavyweight champion was sitting in a stuffed chair in his 11th-floor suite at the Las Vegas Hilton where half a dozen visitors had been granted an afternoon audience in the hours before Spinks-Holmes II.

title: Insurers Pocket Hospital Savings
description: To the Editor:

title: ESTABLISHED SHELTERS FOR CHILDREN
description: Hermann Gmeiner, an Austrian who had no children of his own but who had provided homes for tens of thousands of homeless children around the world since World War II, died yesterday in the Innsbruck University Hospital after a cancer operation April 8. He was 66 years old.

title: Alison and Tracey Finn Plan to Wed Dr. Bradley Jacoby and Daniel Duffy
description: Mr. and Mrs. A. Michael Finn of Bronxville, N.Y., have announced the engagements of their daughters Alison Mary Finn and Tracey Maureen Finn.

title:
IN SHORT: NONFICTION;
A SMITHSONIAN SAMPLER
description: This year, the Smithsonian Institution's National Museum of American Art will mount an exhibition of paintings and sculpture from its vast holdings in six cities around the United States. TREASURES FROM THE NATIONAL MUSEUM OF AMERICAN ART (Smithsonian Institution, $39.95) is the handsome and substantial catalogue of the show, which features such classic American artists as Winslow Homer, Mary Cassatt, John Singer Sargent and Andrew Wyeth, as well as those largely forgotten, like the turn-of-the-century portrait painter Cecilia Beaux.

title: FRENCH ART FROM SOVIET MUSEUMS
description: An exhibition of 41 Impressionist, Post-Impressionist and early modern paintings from the Hermitage in Leningrad and the Pushkin Museum of Fine Arts in Moscow will go on view here Thursday at the National Gallery of Art.

title: A Vote to Curb Military Pensions
description: For years, Representative Les Aspin got nowhere with his complaints that the military pension system was flawed because it encouraged expensively trained servicemen to retire after only 20 years and parlay their Government experience into high-paying jobs in private industry. But the prospects for pension-system overhaul brightened considerably last year when Mr. Aspin, the Wisconsin Democrat, became chairman of the House Armed Services Committee.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: KAFFIR BOY: The True Story of a Black Youth's Coming of Age in Apartheid South Africa. By Mark Mathabane. (Macmillan, $19.95.)

title: Travels With O'Neill
description: With Congressional races heating up, the most sought-after Democrat for fund-raising events and appearances in general is not one of the host of once and future Presidential candidates, but a lame-duck Congressman.

title: DOES CUOMO'S ITINERARY DISCLOSE HIS INTENTIONS?
description: ONCE again Governor Cuomo was on the road last week, his eighth out-of-state trip since the first of the year, and once again he was saying that he was not running for President.

title: Evelyn Williams And J. P. McNiff Planning to Wed
description: Evelyn Ewing Williams, a project manager for the Council on the Environment of New York City, a citizens' group affiliated with the Mayor's office, and John P. McNiff, a third-year law student at New York University, plan to be married in September. The announcement was made by the future bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Eugene P. Williams of St. Louis.

title: Tornadoes Kill Child in Iowa
description: Two tornadoes touched down in northwest Iowa tonight, killing a child, injuring two people and heavily damaging several farms, witnesses said.

title: THE VIEW FROM MOON CROSSING BRIDGE
description: The wide Oigawa flows calmly under the Togetsukyo, or the Moon Crossing Bridge, in the northwestern reaches of Kyoto. The sun has not come out yet, and the air is slightly blue with a touch of mist. Above the river towers the mountain called Arashiyama, the Storm Mountain. The scenery has been celebrated in Japanese literature for a thousand years. The sense of eternity hangs heavily on Kyoto, the ancient capital of Japan.

title: HEARING CALLED TO EXPLORE USE OF 'CRACK' BY TEEN-AGERS
description: CALLING for a countywide ''war on crack,'' three members of the County Board of Legislators have scheduled a public hearing Tuesday to draw attention to the growing use of the especially addicting form of cocaine and to its popularity among Westchester teen-agers.

title: THE TOP CHOICES AND WHO MAY GET THEM
description: The information in this chart was compiled by Michael Janofsky and reflects information from personnel experts and other N.F.L. team officials. There are only 27 first-round picks because Cleveland used its choice, acquired in a trade, to take Bernie Kosar in the 1985 supplemental draft. 1. Tampa Bay Buccaneers: 11 picks over all They are thin everywhere on defense, but they can't pass up Bo Jackson of Auburn, who is everything you ever wanted in a running back and more. Still, don't rule out the possibility of a trade. 2. Atlanta Falcons: 10 picks Only one team had a worse pass defense last season, which means improvement along the line for more pressure is mandatory. Tony Casillas of Oklahoma, a natural nose guard for the Falcons' new 3-4, is a perfect pick. 3. Houston Oilers: 11 picks Chances are the Oilers will trade down once or twice to get a defensive lineman. If they don't, they will take Jim Everett, the quarterback from Purdue, who will either give Warren Moon a run for his considerable money or will be traded later. 4. Indianapolis Colts: 11 picks The Colts' passing game hasn't been the same since Bert Jones was around and the Colts played out of Baltimore. They want Everett but may have to settle for Chuck Long of Iowa. Later, they will get a much needed wide receiver and offensive lineman. 5. St. Louis Cardinals: 12 picks The Cardinals couldn't stop the run last year, which makes Jon Hand, a 6-6 1/2, 280-pound defensive end from Alabama, an ideal pick.

title: MANILA PURSUING ASSETS OF MARCOS IN SWITZERLAND
description: Philippine investigators have completed the first step in what is expected to be a long process of recovering the assets of Ferdinand E. Marcos held in Switzerland, according to a legal consultant to the investigation.

title: STEWS ARE QUITE ALL RIGHT IN THE SPRING
description: STEWS are usually considered heavy, fortifying, cold-weather fare and not the dishes to whet the appetite in spring. But there are exceptions. Lightened veal or lamb stews and ragouts - simmered in broth and white wine, the chunks of tender meat mingled with fresh vegetables and seasoned with verdant herbs - are suitable for spring dinners. Chicken, also simmered in white wine and perfumed with garlic and fennel, is similarly spring-like.

title: A SOLUTION OFFERED TO PARKING PROBLEM
description: It was interesting to read the article ''Parking Poaching Charged'' [ March 16 ] , which described the parking space ''border skirmish'' between Cedarhurst and Lawrence merchants and their employees.

title: TRIBES FORM BUSINESSES TO FIGHT JOBLESSNESS
description: In the early 1970's, when unemployment on the Choctaw Reservation in Mississippi had climbed to more than 65 percent, the tribal chief, Phillip Martin, proposed that the Indians open a manufacturing business.

title: HELPING A HELPER
description: When Tom Brady reached his 18th birthday, he immediately joined Thornwood's Volunteer Fire Department, following family tradition. Now, 15 years later, the 70 members of the volunteer fire department have banded together to help Mr. Brady - who must soon have a combined heart and lung transplant.

title: A SUFFOLK CASE RAISES MAJOR RIGHTS ISSUES
description: IN ITS unexpurgated version, the transcript of a conversation on the evening of Aug. 25, 1982, secretly recorded by an undercover Suffolk County police detective, fairly bristled with profanity.

title: NORTHEAST JOURNAL
description: Canine Threat For Vermont Deer WHEN spring comes to Vermont, it brings out a grim side of nature.

title: DARK SIDE OF GROWTH: DRUGS
description: ''SOMEONE had better get excited soon about the problem of drug abuse,'' Representative Frank J. Guarini said, ''because the problem is getting worse and our country is slipping away.''

title: Cynthia Stix to Wed James D. Bennett in August
description: Beverley McDonnell Stix of Wallingford, Pa., and Cape May, N.J., and Dr. Daniel Louis Stix of Old Lyme, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter Cynthia Stix to James Donald Bennett, a son of Mr. and Mrs. James H. Bennett of Corry, Pa. The wedding is planned for August.

title: NEITHER HAWK NOR DOVE
description: NUCLEAR ETHICS By Joseph S. Nye Jr. 162 pp. New York: The Free Press. $14.95. AT the height of the antinuclear emotions that gripped Western societies a few years ago this book could probably not have been written. That, after all, was the period in which nuclear weapons were debated in absolute terms by all and sundry, and each side - nuclear abolitionists and nuclear protagonists - pretended to possess the absolute truth. I remember a sense of profound uneasiness when, during weekend shopping in London's Hampstead Village, a woman next to me in a greengrocer's shop held a toddler on her arm who wore a big button on his little body inscribed ''Babies Against the Bomb.''

title:
REWRITING THE RULES ON RETIREMENT;
A WORTHY ADDITION TO SOCIAL SECURITY
description: OVER the past three decades, Congress has recognized the need of America's retirees for financial security. It has expanded Social Security and encouraged the growth of private pension plans and individual savings. There is no reason to change that strategy by cutting back 401(k) plans.

title:
ABOUT WESTCHESTER;
EARLY DELIGHTS
description: MYRA and Gilbert Spector once ordered a tree through the mail. ''You see this humongous tree in a picture,'' said Dr. Spector, who jokingly describes himself as a ''dentist turned gardener.'' ''And what they send you is a few twigs.''

title: Nancy C. Hnat Is Married To Daniel Joseph Finn 3d
description: Nancy Clark Hnat, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Richard Frederick Hnat of New Vernon, N.J., was married yesterday to Daniel Joseph Finn 3d, a son of Mr. Finn 2d of Boston and the late Mary Ross Finn. The Rev. George Chorba performed the ceremony at the First Presbyterian Church in New Vernon.

title: Youth Sought for Questioning In Killing of Brooklyn Woman
description: Detectives are seeking to question a teen-ager who was seen near the Brooklyn apartment of a 20-year-old student minutes before she was shot to death in her doorway late Thursday night, the police said yesterday.

title: A New Charge and More Subpoenas In City Scandal
description: ''Corruption,'' said Gibbon in ''Decline and Fall of the Roman Empire,'' is ''the most infallible symptom of constitutional liberty.'' If that is so, there was ample evidence last week that liberty was in good shape in New York City.

title: NEW HAMPSHIRE ASKS RETURN OF 200-YEAR-OLD DECLARATION
description: New Hampshire is demanding the return of a purported first copy of the Declaration of Independence that was found in an Exeter museum, Attorney General Stephen Merrill said Friday.

title: HEMINGWAY ON WRITING: 'REMEMBERING ACCURATELY'
description: NEXT month, Charles Scribner's Sons will publish Ernest Hemingway's final novel, ''The Garden of Eden.'' Hemingway began the book in 1946, at the age of 47, and worked on it off and on for the next 15 years, while also writing ''The Old Man and the Sea,'' ''A Moveable Feast,'' ''Islands in the Stream'' and ''The Dangerous Summer.'' A story of love and obsession, ''The Garden of Eden'' is about David Bourne, an American in his mid-to-late 20's, a World War I veteran and a newlywed, who has recently published his second novel. On his honeymoon in the south of France and Spain with his wife, Catherine, he is just beginning to receive letters from his publisher enclosing very good notices for his second book. Already Bourne would like to begin writing something new, and much of ''The Garden of Eden'' concerns the tension between a man's love and need for his work and his deep love for a wife who encourages him to write, but, in fact, can't stand for him to. She provides many obstacles and seductions, including a younger woman, Marita, and strange, disturbing sexual roles for the three of them to play. In many of the fragments excerpted here we see him trying to make a start and, through him, glimpse Hemingway looking back to create a novel that reflects some of his own experience as a young writer.

title: THERE IS BRILLIANT WRITING IN MESSIAEN'S OPERA, BUT...
description: It is always difficult for a critic not to be impressed by a large-scale work that has the name of a celebrated composer attached to it, but with Olivier Messiaen's ''St. Francis of Assisi'' a special effort must be made.

title: HOLOCAUST MEMORIAL SET
description: YOM HASHOA - Holocaust Remembrance Day - will be observed throughout next week with personal recollections, Torah dedications, concerts, plays, art exhibitions, dramatic readings, religious services and candlelighting ceremonies by schools and religious groups.

title: YANKS' STREAK SNAPPED AT 6
description: During the Yankees' game with the Cleveland Indians yesterday, a squirrel symbolically cavorted on the screen behind home plate. The crowd cheered. The fans, after all, cheer a lot of the nuttiness that occurs at Yankee Stadium.

title: ORIOLES BEAT BLUE JAYS, 11-5
description: The rookie catcher John Stefero drove in four runs with a single and a three-run homer tonight, leading the Baltimore Orioles to an 11-5 victory over the Toronto Blue Jays.

title: AUSTRIANS EXAMINE THEIR PAST ALONG WITH WALDHEIM'S
description: IT used to be said half-jokingly that the Austrians had convinced the world that Hitler was a German and Beethoven, who was born in Bonn and lived here, was an Austrian. Unlike West Germans, who painfully wrestled with questions of historical guilt, the Austrians took refuge in the notion that in 1938 their little country became ''the first victim'' of Hitler's aggression.

title: YANK, TIGER PITCHING SURPRISE
description: WHEN the so-called experts were making preseason predictions, many made their selection for the American League East based on two related facts: The Detroit Tigers would win the division because they had the best corps of starting pitchers and the Yankees would not win because their starters were afflicted with major question marks. It is too early for the prognosticators to panic, but the results of the first three weeks of the season reveal some intriguing developments.

title: PRIEST SHUTTLES BETWEEN PULPIT AND PIT
description: EVERY day except Sunday, the Rev. Alphonse Stephenson leaves his priestly duties at St. Peter's Roman Catholic Church here, drives 67 miles to New York and conducts the evening performances of ''A Chorus Line,'' the leggy, long-running musical at the Shubert Theater.

title: SILVER TO WHICH AGE ADDS LUSTER
description: Eric N. Shrubsole came to New York 50 years ago this month, with $5,000 worth of period silver and orders from his father, Sydney James Shrubsole, to open a New York branch of the antique silver business he had founded in London in 1910. The first thing young Mr. Shrubsole did was to visit all of his father's clients - driving from New York to Dallas, traveling by train to Los Angeles and from there by plane to San Francisco. When he returned to New York he had sold all the silver - and spent all the money.

title: WALL STREET CRIME AND ITS DIVIDENDS
description: IT HAS become part of the accepted order of things on Wall Street that the price of a big company's stock will suddenly shoot skyward, fueled by nothing more than a rumor that some corporate raider is contemplating a takeover. That is the smoke. Fire often follows when a takeover bid is in fact launched, enriching those who managed to grab up in advance the shares of the corporate prey.

title: 'A HERD OF INDEPENDENT MINDS'
description: PRODIGAL SONS The New York Intellectuals & Their World. By Alexander Bloom. 461 pp. New York: Oxford University Press. $24.95. READING this book I was continually thinking of a moment - perhaps a critical moment, though Alexander Bloom makes nothing of it -in the summer of 1965. Dozens of people had been flown in to New Brunswick, N.J., from all over, their tickets paid for by some vaguely benign foundation, to take part in a Partisan Review conference on the Future. Happy as we all were to attend this grand affair, few of us visiting firemen made much of a mark on the proceedings, which were dominated by a large contingent of the very persons Mr. Bloom has been studying, the New York Intellectuals; full of polemical vigor, contemptuously anti-Socialist, they allowed no consideration of courtesy to old or new acquaintances to qualify their freedom of expression.

title: Dance
description: A contingent of dancers from Netherlands Dance Theater makes its only New York appearance Friday night when Netherlands Dance Theater, Junior comes to Lehman Center for the Performing Arts. The ''junior'' troupe tours when the main company is not performing and, like the parent company, its repertory features works by Jiri Kylian, the talented Czech-born director of this ensemble from The Hague.

title: For All the Attractions of Failure, It's Probably Better to Succeed
description: To the Editor:

title:
NATURE WATCH;
ROCKWEED OR BLADDERWRACK
description: Fucus vesiculosis Size: Sprays, to three feet.

title: WHERE THE DRIVER ANTS AND THE DRILL BABOON DWELL
description: Season in, season out, the most popular programs on public television take to the outdoors. Natural history is a sure-fire winner. Flowers unfold in stop-motion photography; monkeys scramble over tree-tops; sharks, apparently, are best of all. Everyone (comparatively speaking; public-television audiences are not as large as a commericial network's) loves to watch sharks. The reason for all this enchantment is not clear, although it may have something to do with the restfulness of it all. Slogging through a rain forest or listening to humpback whales sing, we are a long way from crowded subways, unpleasant streets and the usual urban distractions. Also, it is a good deal easier to worry about ecology than, say, Colonel Qaddafi. The great outdoors is a staple on public television, and only a sourball would wish it were not.

title: Leaflets, Not Bombs
description: To the Editor:

title: Inching Ahead On Alzheimer's
description: So little is known about Alzheimer's disease that doctors rely mainly on psychological testing to diagnose it. But the discovery of a protein that appears to be unique to the brains of the disease's victims has raised hopes that a chemical diagnostic test - and a better understanding of Alzheimer's - may not be far off.

title: HEADED MONSANTO COMPANY
description: Francis J. Fitzgerald, the newly appointed president of the Monsanto Company, died early yesterday morning after suffering an apparent heart attack at his home in suburban St. Louis. Mr. Fitzgerald was 58 years old.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: BRAVO BURNING. By Donald Tate. (Scribners, $15.95.) The most striking thing about this first novel by a former Vietnam War reporter is the blustering vitality of its style.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: A FRIENDSHIP. By Manlio Cancogni. Translated by Iole Fiorillo Magri. (Paideia, P.O. Box 343, Ashfield, Mass. 01330, $15.) As youths in pre-World War II Rome, Manlio Cancogni and his fellow literary aspirant Carlo Cassola formulated an esthetic they dubbed ''the subliminar'' -defined loosely as ''those rare moments when the opaque texture of things ripped,'' unveiling the doors of perception.

title: Sheila Marie Hopkins Marries David M. Sola
description: Sheila Marie Hopkins and David Mark Sola were married yesterday at the Church of the Holy Family in Manhattan. Msgr. William J. McMahon and the Rev. Thomas K. Tewell, a Presbyterian minister, officiated.

title: Jamaica
description: To the Editor: As we all are aware, these are tough times for travelers, and I am sure you hear many horror stories about tourists' experiences. Therefore, I thought you might like to hear a story of a very happy and positive travel experience.

title: 38 MILES AWAY, ANOTHER LAND, THE SOUTH BRONX, BECKONS
description: IT is 38 miles from my driveway in northern Westchester to the Board of Education parking space in front of the elementary school in the South Bronx where I teach special-education reading. Those 38 miles may have taken me farther than most longer distances I have traveled. I have been to Wisconsin, California, England, Italy and France. No other journey has called forth such a response of foreignness from friends and acquaintances. I mention ''South Bronx'' in Westchester and I have heard: ''You're brave,'' ''You're crazy'' and ''You'll be raped in the girl's room.'' I might have answered the same way one year ago.

title: Felice Ludington, Account Executive, To Marry James Taylor, Boat Builder
description: Mr. and Mrs. Francis Henry Ludington Jr. of Pelham Manor, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Mary Felice Ludington, to James North Taylor, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Stephen W. Taylor of Oklahoma City. The wedding is planned for June 21.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''It is high time that Libya put its house in order.

title:
DINING OUT;
LILAC MOTIF IN LARCHMONT
description: THE space in this self-styled little bistro is still as limited as it was when The Cabbage Patch occupied the premises, but little else reminds one of the former restaurant. Brasserie des Lilas replaced cabbage with lilac (lilas), the flower as much in evidence as its colors, repeated throughout the cozy dining room in shades from softest lavender-gray to deep violet.

title: CABARET: A NEW PLACE FOR COMICS
description: COMEDY has come to the Upper West Side at Stand-Up NY!, a handsomely appointed 175-seat club located on the site of the former 78th Street Theater Lab (236 West 78th Street). The club offers mainstream-style stand-up humor by rising young talents who are perhaps a year or two away from the Johnny Carson- or David Letterman-show level of national recognition.

title: Defending His Jinx
description: To the Editor:

title: Two Requests for A Deaver Inquiry
description: During a news conference earlier in the month, President Reagan asserted that Michael K. Deaver, the White House aide turned lobbyist, ''has never put the arm on me, or sought anything or any influence from me since he has been out of Government.'' Questions about Mr. Deaver's activities on behalf of foreign governments and domestic corporations continued, however, and last week the Government's ethics office and five Democratic senators asked the Justice Department to consider naming a special prosecutor to investigate Mr. Deaver.

title: POLLY CAME THROUGH
description: CRUSOE'S DAUGHTER By Jane Gardam. 224 pp. New York: Atheneum. $12.95. IN her latest book, the prize-winning English novelist Jane Gardam has created the charming fictional autobiography of one Polly Flint, whose seafaring father in 1904 brings her to live with her spinster aunts and their grim companions in a yellow house beside the sea in northern England.

title: TEACHING VALUES TO CHILDREN
description: I must respond to an article by Kenneth P. Marion, ''The Date We Break, and Other Lessons for Youth'' [ Opinion Page, April 13 ] . Mr. Marion would like to recapture the values of life for our children. How can one do this?

title: BOMB BLASTS IN FRANCE AND LEBANON ROCK AMERICAN AND BRITISH OFFICES
description: Predawn explosions ripped through deserted offices yesterday of American Express and an American computer company in Lyons, France, and a British bank in Beirut, Lebanon. The authorities said the bomb blasts and fire caused extensive damage but only one person was wounded. [ In Mexico City, the police defused a bomb found in a car parked next to the United States Embassy Saturday afternoon, United Press International reported. ] The explosions were the latest in a series of attacks on American and British targets in Europe and the Middle East since April 15, when United States warplanes based in Britain took part in air raids against Libya in retaliation for what was described as Tripoli's involvement in terrorism.

title: A Greater Getty
description: To the Editor:

title: BET THE SYSTEM, IF YOU CAN FIGURE IT OUT
description: IT is the dream of Kentucky Derby bettors to find a system that will magically yield the name of the winner. Two such systems have evolved in recent years, both with documentably sterling records of success. This year their combined wisdom is that all three of the strong favorites for the 112th Kentucky Derby will lose.

title: The Decline and Fall Of a 'Taxpayer'
description: The West 80's have changed a lot since Nessim Watson and Joe Fusco were young boys, almost to the point where they scarcely recognize their own neighborhood.

title: An Everybody-Wins Natural Gas Bill
description: The world is awash in cheap energy. Who cares if the natural gas industry remains under Federal price regulation?

title: O'ROURKE ATTACKS MEMBER-ITEM PLAN
description: Andrew P. O'Rourke, the Westchester County Executive, said yesterday that if elected governor, he would eliminate so-called member items from the state budget, saying that Governor Cuomo ''bought'' his budget by doling out such ''goodies.''

title: A.M.C. Loss Is Narrowed
description: The American Motors Corporation said on Friday that it lost $18.9 million in the first quarter, an improvement from a year earlier when it lost $29 million. Sales fell slightly, to $918.2 million, from $919.4 million.

title: BIRMINGHAM JAIL: A CITY PONDERS PLACE IN HISTORY
description: A wrecking crew is to arrive Monday at the jail that was an emotional rallying point at the height of the civil rights movement in the 1960's.

title: NBC News Establishes A Brokaw Fill-In 'Pool'
description: NBC News has created an ''anchor pool'' of correspondents who will fill in for Tom Brokaw, the chief anchor on the ''Nightly News'' program, a move away from the policy of having a principal substitute for Mr. Brokaw. Roger Mudd, the Washington-based correspondent, had filled the role of permanent substitute anchor before the change.

title: JANUARY, LITTLER WIN SENIORS
description: Don January and Gene Littler shot a final-round 64 today to hold on for a two-stroke victory in the Liberty Mutual Legends of Golf tournament.

title: MYSTERY MEN SPICE N.F.L. DRAFT
description: ONCE, before a little bone in his 240-pound body was broken, Keith Byars might have expected to earn, oh, a million dollars tomorrow, N.F.L. Draft Day. And Mike Schad? He would have been among the usually forgotten Canadian college football players, none of whom is playing in the National Football League now.

title: Hope at Last for Public Works
description: New York's Wicks Law, which bars use of a general contractor on public works, costs city and state taxpayers more than $100 million annually and hampers coordination of construction jobs. For years, Mayor Koch has sought its repeal, only to be blocked by craft unions that wield power in Albany.

title: Shifts and Turns On the Career Path
description: Elsewhere in the fascinating world of communications John B. Caldwell Jr. is taking a turn on his career path; Jack Young, who left the presidency of Foote, Cone & Belding/East in February, has found a new home, and Peter Chrisanthopoulos has been given new responsibilities at Ohlmeyer Communications.

title: BLUE JAYS WIN, 8-0, WITH 3 HOME RUNS
description: Cecil Fielder, a rookie, hit a two-run homer and George Bell and Rance Mulliniks added home runs today to lead Jim Clancy and the Toronto Blue Jays to an 8-0 victory over the Baltimore Orioles.

title: French Nuclear Test Reported in Pacific
description: France exploded an underground nuclear device today at its Mururoa test site, its first test of the year and 73d at the South Pacific atoll since 1975, the New Zealand Government said.

title: WHITE HOUSE TEMPO SHIFTS WHEN NO. 1 IS AWAY
description: Repairs on the leaking roof on the West Wing of the White House have speeded up sharply now that workers no longer have to worry about disturbing President Reagan.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: MONDAY, APRIL 28, 1986
description: International President Reagan rejected a claim by Ferdinand E. Marcos that he is still the rightful President of the Philippines, White House officials said. Mr. Reagan spoke by telephone to Mr. Marcos soon after Mr. Reagan arrived in Honolulu on the second day of his 13-day trip to the Far East for a meeting with foreign ministers of Southeast Asian countries in Indonesia and to attend the annual ecnomic summit meeting in Tokyo May 4 to 6. The phone conversation was the first direct contact between Mr. Reagan and Mr. Marcos since the deposed President fled the Philippines Feb. 26. White House officials said Mr. Marcos's claim to the presidency was turned down gently, but firmly. [ Page A1, Column 6. ]

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: THE TRIUMPH OF POLITICS: How the Reagan Revolution Failed. By David A. Stockman. Illustrated. 422 pages. Harper & Row. $21.95.

title: AFTER 3 YEARS, POLICE CONTINUE TO HUNT PENN STATION SNIPER
description: Three years ago today, Emily Lucchesse, a 50-year-old homeless woman, was resting on the floor of the Anthony Oliveri Women's Center on West 30th Street in Manhattan when a .25-caliber bullet came through an open window and struck her in the hip.

title: CANADA-U.S. PACT ON CARS IS STRAINED
description: Some strains are starting to appear in the 20-year marriage of the American and Canadian auto industries.

title: Bridge: A Venerable British Player Is Leaving Federation Post
description: A singular figure in the world of bridge recently announced his retirement: Harold Franklin of England.

title: STARS TACKLE CLASSICS AT STAGED READINGS
description: There are no costumes and no set, the pay is minimal, the task is arduous, and the results are seen one time only in a bare-bones staged reading.

title: MONDAY SPORTS
description: Hockey Maple Leafs vs. St. Louis Blues, at Toronto. Game six of the four-of-seven-game Norris Division championship, with the Blues leading, three games to two.

title: 3 CHILEAN SERVICES, BUT NOT ARMY, BACKING AN OPEN ELECTION IN 1989
description: Three branches of the Chilean armed forces want a plebiscite that is scheduled for 1989 to be converted into a free and open election for a new president, according to Chileans close to military leaders.

title: Question Box
description: QUESTION: When Darrell Evans of the Detroit Tigers hit 40 home runs last season, and at 38 became the oldest player to lead the American League in home runs, whose achievement did he surpass?

title: INFANT IS TOSSED FROM 4TH FLOOR, BUT IT IS CAUGHT
description: An 18-month-old Brooklyn girl, hurled by her father through the closed window of a fourth-floor apartment last night, survived when she was caught by a passer-by on the street below, the police said.

title: BRITISH TOURIST SHOT DEAD NEAR SHRINE IN ARAB QUARTER OF JERUSALEM
description: A British tourist was shot dead yesterday in the Arab section of Jerusalem while visiting a religious shrine revered by some Protestants as the site where Jesus was buried, the Israeli police said.

title: An Import Tax Would Provide Relief for Oil States
description: To the Editor:

title: NEW G.O.P. GROUP CRITICIZES RIGHT AND IS ASSAILED IN TURN
description: Amid criticism from the right, some self-described mainstream Republicans have held their first national convention here.

title: ANTONY TUDOR RECEIVES FRESH ACCOLADES AT 77
description: ''I'm very glad I'm getting old,'' Antony Tudor, the acclaimed ballet choreographer, said. ''If I were not an ancient citizen, I wouldn't be getting all this.'' At 77, Mr. Tudor has become the subject of new veneration. This afternoon he will receive the Capezio Dance Award in private ceremonies at the Juilliard School. He will give a rare lecture May 8 at the Martha Graham School of Contemporary Dance. And May 20, Mr. Tudor will receive the Handel Medallion, New York City's highest cultural award, in a ceremony at City Hall. That evening, the medallion will be presented publicly on the stage of the Metropolitan Opera House, in a special, all-Tudor evening planned by Mikhail Baryshnikov, artistic director of the American Ballet Theater.

title: AFGHANISTAN MYSTERY: WHERE IS LEADER?
description: President Babrak Karmal of Afghanistan did not appear in Soviet television reports of celebrations today marking the anniversary of the 1978 Communist coup, adding to speculation about his whereabouts and standing.

title: Outdoors; Tangents for Anglers
description: HE who angles without passion is craven, someone who has allowed family, romance or a career to vitiate his quest.

title: BUREAU OF STANDARDS IS PINCHED TOO
description: More than 80 years ago, the National Bureau of Standards was established to standardize American weights and measurements and to supply the nation's industries and regulators with studies and statistics on materials and manufacturing processes so that American consumers could be assured of safe goods of high quality.

title: CORRECTION
description: A music review on Thursday about the Greitzer Ensemble at Merkin Concert Hall misstated the family connection of the flutist Jody Schwarz. She is a daughter of Sol Greitzer, the violist and conductor, and Shirley Greitzer, the pianist.

title: HIROHITO TAKES A BOW AS JAPAN'S OLDEST EMPEROR
description: Somebody asked Emperor Hirohito a few months ago what he thought about Halley's Comet, with all its attendant fuss. The Emperor paused and, according to press reports, replied that he thought it nice that he got a chance to see it again.

title: IMPROVING AUSTRALIAN TIES WITH INDONESIA TURN SOUR
description: Relations between Australia and Indonesia, only recently improved after years of mistrust, have been set back unexpectedly in the last two weeks, according to officials in both countries. The cause is a series of sharp responses by Jakarta to an Australian newspaper article about President Suharto of Indonesia and his reported wealth.

title: Larouche a Leader in Playoffs
description: The promotion of Pierre Larouche from the minor leagues Jan. 27 was perhaps the first giant step for the Rangers in their stunning success in the National Hockey League playoffs.

title: 3-WAY MERGER TO CREATE LARGEST AD AGENCY
description: Three of the world's top 20 advertising agencies are combining in a first-of-its-kind merger to create, for the time being at any rate, the largest such company.

title: HOW THEY'LL RUN FOR THE ROSES
description: The Kentucky Derby is expected to draw a field of 12 to 20 horses. If more than 20 are entered Thursday morning, when post positions will be drawn, the field will be limited to the 20 with the highest earnings in graded stakes races. Following are the leading contenders for the race, as compiled by Steven Crist. Snow Chief

title: MUSIC: DONALD ISLER, PIANIST
description: AT Symphony Space Tuesday, Donald Isler paid a fascinating homage to a great predecessor. He played a program of piano music by Artur Schnabel, framed with sonatas by Schnabel's beloved Schubert and Beethoven. Schnabel's commitment as a world-famous pianist to the lofty German masterworks, his eschewal of surface charm and the whole repertory of music that thrived on it, changed the face of piano playing midway in this century. He has defined the moral high ground for pianism ever since.

title: Aggressors, Self-Defense and Nicaragua
description: To the Editor:

title: Commercial Building Ebbs
description: Los Angeles will top all cities in the United States in nonresidential construction this year with about $3.87 billion of work, but there will be scant growth in the market for industrial, commercial and office buildings, according to a survey by the Chicago Title Insurance Company.

title: D'Arcy Masius Opens An Office in Dublin
description: D'Arcy Masius Benton & Bowles is opening an office in Dublin largely to handle the Mars account in Ireland, that wonderful green land where there is very little advertising. D'Arcy, in fact, will be the only American agency operating there under its own name.

title: STEINBRENNER SAYS WHITSON SHOULD SHUN PRESS
description: Ed Whitson, the Yankees' beleaguered pitcher, pitched a good inning of relief yesterday, and George Steinbrenner said he hoped to relieve Whitson's problems by having him stop talking to the news media. Whitson, however, said reporters have not been his problem.

title: MAN WHO SEIZED EICHMANN RECALLS SECRET ROLE
description: On a chilly night in May 1960, Peter Malkin approached a slight, baldish man walking home on a suburban street in Buenos Aires. ''One minute, sir,'' Mr. Malkin said. A second later his beefy forearm snapped around the man's neck, and Adolf Eichmann, the former Nazi SS officer responsible for the slaughter of nearly six million people, found himself under arrest by the state of Israel.

title: Bessie Love, 87, an Actress From Silent-Film to TV Eras
description: The American-born actress Bessie Love, whose career stretched from silent movies to television, died Saturday night at Mount Vernon Hospital, her daughter said today. She was 87 years old.

title: ETHNIC IMAGES: WHAT WE SEE ISN'T ALWAYS WHO WE ARE
description: Pepe le Pew of cartoon fame, the romantic if somewhat mixed-up skunk with a French accent, elicits roars of laughter from an American audience. To them, his fake accent and romantic exploits are quintessentially French.

title: Economic Calendar
description: Listed below are the target release dates for major economic indicators scheduled to be released this week. Monday

title: THE RISE IN THE WEST
description: Even after Swaps came to Churchill Downs from California to win the 1962 Kentucky Derby, it was almost as if some old prospector's mule had won the roses. Horses from California, especially those bred there, were regarded as curiosities from outlaw territory, a separate breed from the thoroughbreds raised on the bluegrass outside those old Kentucky homes and raced in New York and Florida.

title: Hit-Run Driver Kills 2 L.I. Boys on Bicycle
description: Two teen-age boys sharing a bicycle were killed Saturday night when they were struck by a drunken motorist who then drove away, the Nassau County police said today.

title: 2 Crutches, No Derby
description: IN his Queens home near the Aqueduct racetrack, Angel Cordero Jr. was having lunch. Crabmeat and tomatoes. Buttered toast. Orange juice. As he ate, the 43-year-old jockey was talking as fast as ever, his words tumbling out as quickly as horses out of a starting gate. At a glance, he appeared well enough to be on his way to the Kentucky Derby where he rode last year's winner, Spend a Buck.

title: Miss America on the Job
description: An unlikely liaison has been formed between Miss America and the Bureau of the Census. Warming up for its major effort in 1990, the bureau last year chose five counties in East Central Mississippi as a test area for questionnaires and procedures.

title: Simone de Beauvoir Didn't Always Speak Out
description: To the Editor:

title: I.B.M. CHIEF CONFIDENT BUT NOW MORE CAUTIOUS
description: A year ago in Atlanta, presiding over his first annual meeting as chief executive of the International Business Machines Corporation, a confident John F. Akers predicted that his company would post ''solid growth'' in 1985. Within two months he backtracked as a stubborn computer slump began to drive I.B.M. to its first yearly profit decline in six years.

title: INDIANS TOP YANKS AGAIN
description: After Bob Tewksbury, the Yankees' effective rookie pitcher, left the game with Cleveland yesterday, the club's media-relations director, Harvey Greene, announced that Tewksbury had slight soreness in his right forearm but that it was ''not serious.'' Wrong. Tewksbury's slight soreness turned out to be severely serious for the Yankees because his 4-2 lead became a 9-7 loss created by his replacements, Brian Fisher and Dave Righetti.

title: LOOSE-LINKED NETWORK OF TERROR: SEPARATE ACTS, IDEOLOGICAL BONDS
description: The recent spate of terrorist attacks against Americans and other victims has left in its wake a long trail of both casualties and question marks.

title: NOT 'PETITE' ANYMORE
description: ROSES, straw skimmers, balloons, ticker tape and other paper goods came flying out of the stands last night as the Rangers left a few more decibels and memories in the apparently obsolescent eaves of the fourth Madison Square Garden.

title: Belfast Car-Bombing Is Averted by a Tip
description: An anonymous tip from nationalist sources probably prevented a very large Irish Republican Army car bomb from exploding in Belfast's city center as hundreds of Protestants marched past in annual parades, the police reported today.

title: MANAGERS REVIVING A PROJECT'S PRIDE
description: The reputation arrived at the Jacob Riis Houses before William Russo did.

title: Wine and Cheese Suit For 3 Gallo Brothers
description: Until last week, when Ernest and Julio Gallo filed suit against their younger brother for trademark infringement, few people outside of Merced County, Calif., had ever heard of Joseph E.
