Gallo. While Ernest, 77 years old, and Julio, 76, were operating the world's largest winery, Joseph, 64, quietly built one of the largest private ranches in California. He is also a grape-grower, dairyman and cheese maker.

title: Seagram's New Cooler Goes for the Gold
description: Seagram, which is No. 4 in the wine cooler market, the fastest growing segment of alcoholic beverages, on Friday in Los Angeles introduced its new entry, Seagram's Golden Wine Cooler.

title: THE KINGS OF THE SPORT
description: FOR half a century, the Triple Crown has been thoroughbred racing's greatest prize. A 3-year-old who can win the Kentucky Derby, the Preakness Stakes two weeks later and the Belmont Stakes three weeks after that, is the dream of every horseman, the hero of every fan. For most Americans, the racing season begins and ends with the five weeks in spring when the Derby winner tries to join the elite 11 who have swept the series, legends such as Count Fleet, Whirlaway, Citation, Secretariat and Seattle Slew.

title: 5 YEARS AFTER CONTROLLERS' STRIKE, F.A.A. STRUGGLES TO REBUILD FORCE
description: The Federal Aviation Administration graduated 91 students from its academy here this week, rookies the agency needs in its efforts to rebuild the ranks of controllers who direct the nation's air traffic.

title: CITY TO OVERHAUL INQUIRIES SYSTEM
description: The Koch administration is planning major changes in the way it examines allegations of corruption at city agencies, because of complaints from the top city investigator that the current system is poorly equipped to detect such corruption.

title: Market Place; Dramatic Rise Of Vistar Films
description: WITHIN the last two years, many entertainment companies have gone public, including Vestron Video, Tri-Star Pictures and the Vistar Films Corporation.

title: People
description: * H. Weller (Jake) Keever has been named executive vice president, sales, at the ABC-TV Network, which has also appointed John Tiedemann Jr. senior vice president, national sales manager, and Robert I. Silberberg, senior vice president, general sales manager.

title: RANGERS BEAT CAPITALS, 2-1, AND CLINCH SERIES
description: The Rangers pulled off one more coup.

title: Mr. Duarte vs. the Untouchables
description: A momentous criminal case in El Salvador may finally give President Jose Napoleon Duarte a lift he badly needs. He has gotten nowhere in trying to end a deadlocked civil war. He's suffering heavy political attack for imposing unpopular austerity measures. And his Government has so far been unable to bring to justice the military perpetrators of human-rights crimes. But he now has a chance to challenge the untouchables.

title: Lee Hits No. 246
description: Leron Lee, a former major leaguer, hit his 246th home run in Japanese baseball today, tying a record for foreign players held by the retired Clarence Jones. Lee, 38 years old , the designated hitter of the Pacific League's Lotte Orions, hit the milestone homer, his third of the season, in a game against the Seibu Lions in Miyagi, northern Japan. Lee joined the Orions in 1977 after playing for the Los Angeles Dodgers in 1975-76.

title: FOR A DAY, BICYCLES RULE CITY STREETS
description: For John Foss, the Verrazano-Narrows Bridge presented the big challenge. There, he would try to pedal his red unicycle across the 6,690-foot span, through whipping winds and over a rain-slickened roadway.

title: AT 54, THE SHOE IS NOT WEARING OUT
description: Every spring the word goes out, the same word as the spring before. Bill Shoemaker is retiring, anytime now; soon. And every spring the legendary jockey hears the word, smiles, mounts his horses and rides some more. Next August he will gallop past his 55th birthday. On Saturday he will mount his 24th horse in a Kentucky Derby. After 37 years in the business, and more than 8,500 career victories, Bill Shoemaker has yet to sight his own finish line.

title: CORPORATE PROFITS WEAK DESPITE ECONOMIC GAINS
description: Despite stronger-than-expected economic growth in the first quarter, corporate earnings for the first three months of 1986 remained weak, with profits depressed for a wide range of industries.

title: Judge Sustains Smoking Suit
description: Disagreeing with a recent Federal appeals court decision, a United States District Judge has ruled that health warnings on cigarette packages do not protect tobacco companies from lawsuits.

title: JAPAN'S EMPHASIS ON STABILITY
description: Last September Japan joined four other nations in an agreement to help drive up the yen in relation to the dollar. The move was seen as crucial to narrow the trade gap with the United States and head off protectionist measures being proposed in Congress.

title: REAGAN REBUFFS MARCOS IN CLAIM TO THE PRESIDENCY
description: President Reagan has gently, but firmly, rejected an assertion by Ferdinand E. Marcos that he is still the rightful President of the Philippines, White House officials said today.

title: Accounts
description: Hitachi America to USAdvertising for a variety of trade campaigns.

title: Home at Last
description: The New York Lacrosse Club doesn't generally have a problem attracting players. Those who played the game in college are frequently unwilling to give it up once they graduate, and, since there are no professional lacrosse teams, the club's two amateur squads have their pick of former collegians.

title: DODGERS GET 13 HITS TO BEAT BRAVES, 7-4
description: Bill Russell singled home two runs and scored once today to lead a 13-hit attack and propel the Los Angeles Dodgers to a 7-4 victory over the Atlanta Braves.

title: MARCOS ADDRESSES PHILIPPINE RALLY
description: Ferdinand E. Marcos, asserting that ''I am ready to fight,'' told his followers here today to keep demonstrating in his behalf, but without violence.

title: Fort Howard's Lily Bid Cheered Amid Doubts
description: When Paul J. Schierl, chairman and chief executive of the Fort Howard Paper Company, dug into the company's coffers in 1983 for more than half a billion dollars to buy the Maryland Cup Corporation, a leading manufacturer and distributor of paper and plastic food service products, Wall Street hailed the action as a brilliant diversification move.

title: DANCE: ROBERT LA FOSSE IN CITY BALLET DEBUT
description: DANCERS from the New York City Ballet and American Ballet Theater rarely move from one company to the other. But to illustrate the exception to the rule, Saturday afternoon at the State Theater we saw Robert La Fosse, a Ballet Theater principal until last fall, make his debut with the City Ballet.

title: D'Amato to Seek Rise In Funds to Curb Drugs
description: Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato said yesterday that he would introduce legislation to increase Federal spending to curb drug abuse by $450 million over three years.

title: Nynex Plans New Service
description: The Nynex Corporation today will introduce a new telephone service that allows companies to switch between long-distance carriers to get the lowest cost and the best connection. The service, called intellihub dedicated network service, will be offered by New York Telephone, a Nynex unit, with equipment produced by Northern Telecom Ltd., a Canadian manufacturer of electronic equipment.

title: Iraq Reports Strike Against Kharg Island
description: Iraq said its planes set fire today to oil installations on Iran's Kharg Island oil export terminal and also hit a vessel off the Iranian coast in the Persian Gulf.

title: Washington Watch; Oil Industry's Tax Prospects
description: THE decision by President Reagan to endorse Congressional repeal of the ''windfall profits'' tax on oil is not expected to raise significantly the slim chances of passage.

title: Policing Our Thoughts
description: Michael Conroy is a professor of economics at the University of Texas. He is active in the Latin American Studies Association, the leading scholarly group on the subject in the country.

title: Risky Precedent in Science-Teaching Standards
description: To the Editor:

title: The Clean-Up Job At City Hall
description: Everyone appears to agree that City Hall, much-besmirched, is in need of a cleansing.

title: PROST, LOW ON FUEL, WINS RACE
description: Alain Prost of France, exploiting the few drops of gasoline left in his McLaren-TAG car, outdistanced Nelson Piquet of Brazil and won the Grand Prix of San Marino today.

title: LAWYER TESTIFIES ON HIS DISMISSAL OVER CHALLENGING A JOHNSON WILL
description: A lawyer who was dismissed by J. Seward Johnson for objecting to a will revised in the favor of Mr. Johnson's wife was among the witnesses testifying in Manhattan Surrogate's Court last week in the suit over Mr. Johnson's will.

title: NYSTROM BEATS NOAH IN FINAL
description: Joakim Nystrom of Sweden beat Yannick Noah of France, 6-3, 6-2, today to win the rain-abbreviated final of the $325,000 Monte Carlo Open tennis championship.

title: The U.N. Today; April 28, 1986
description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY Meets at 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: THE TRACKS: 3 STEPS TO GLORY; PIMLICO
description: IT seemed like the right thing to do on that day in 1868: Pick up the pieces from the Civil War and try to revive a style of life that had been shattered. And, to the Governor of Maryland, Ogden Bowie, one of the pieces was the business of throughbred racing.

title: Article 698786 -- No Title
description: Since the city's Parking Violations Bureau stopped using private debt-collection services last month, it has amassed a backlog of more than $20 million in overdue summonses that it currently cannot pursue, according to officials of the agency.

title: Book by Another Reagan Aide
description: Martin Anderson, fomerly a top domestic policy adviser to President Reagan, is joining the parade of insiders who have written books on the Reagan years. The former budget director, David A. Stockman, in his newly published book, calls Mr. Anderson a ''first-class free-market economist'' and a ''hard-core anti-spender,'' treating him with far more respect than most of his other former colleagues.

title: For Arab Residents, Gaza Is Like Soweto
description: To the Editor:

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: I.M.F. SEES IMPROVED ECONOMIES
description: The International Monetary Fund, diagnosing the global economy shortly before the economic summit meeting of key industrial nations, today projected faster growth for most countries, greater convergence of their economic policies and continued pressure on world oil prices.

title: Bank Workers in Minnesota Retain Union in 22-to-18 Vote
description: Workers voted 22-to-18 Friday to retain their union at the First American Bank and Trust of Willmar, Minn., one the few unionized banks in the United States.

title: MAJOR NEW STUDY ON BLACKS STIRRING RESENTMENT IN MANY
description: A $1.9 million study of the status of black Americans has become an object of controversy among black scholars, although research on the project has not been completed and the final results are not to be published for nearly two years.

title: METS LIFT STREAK TO NINE
description: Not even the pitching machine named John Tudor could stop the march of the Mets today as they streaked past the St. Louis Cardinals, 5-3, for their ninth straight victory and the Cardinals' seventh straight loss.

title: Boston Court Order To Ease Commuting
description: Railroad company officials say they expect to restore service for 25,000 commuters Monday after winning a court order forcing sympathy strikers back to work, a spokesman said today.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: MONDAY, APRIL 28, 1986
description: Companies

title: AS DRAFT NEARS, JACKSON IS MAKING THE CHOICES
description: WITH the National Football League college draft a day away, an uncertainty remains as to whether Bo Jackson, the outstanding running back from Auburn and the player most likely to be chosen first, will ultimately sign with the team choosing first, the Tampa Bay Buccaneers.

title: HOBBLED 76ERS BEAT BULLETS BY 134-109 AND TAKE SERIES
description: It seemed certain that the Philadelphia 76ers would be profoundly affected when they learned Friday that they would be without their injured center Moses Malone for the remainder of the playoffs. The only question was: How?

title: U.S. Routed, 10-2
description: Czechoslovakia trounced the United States, 10-2, and West Germany and Poland played a 5-5 tie today on the final day of the consolation round at the world hockey championships.

title: Teamster Challenger Opens His Campaign
description: The president of largest teamsters local in Cleveland formally announced today that he would challenge Jackie Presser as head of the 1.9 million-member national union.

title: Korean Student Protest Broken Up by Police
description: Riot policemen fired tear gas to disperse more than 1,000 student demonstrators in this central city today after an opposition rally calling for electoral reform.

title: COMPANIES SHIFTING HUMAN-SERVICE AID
description: When executives from Baltimore's five top insurance companies met last Thursday, the talk was not about marketing financial services, but rather about hunger, homelessness, health and housing and the condition of education and the elderly.

title: THE PRICES OF CHANGE AND FAME
description: Mayor Dianne Feinstein and others here are trying to turn one of San Francisco's main thoroughfares, Van Ness Avenue, into a kind of American Champs Elysees, a boulevard of elegant shops, restaurants, nightclubs and apartment buildings.

title: AIDES SEE REAGAN WELL POISED FOR TOKYO
description: Despite widespread agreement that President Reagan is unusually well poised as he enters the economic summit to be held next week in Tokyo, key aides and other officials say prospects for the success of his agenda remain linked to factors largely out of his control.

title: De-emphasizing the Links
description: In the 1982 Congressional elections, flushed with the Reagan victory and seizure of Senate control two years earlier, the Republican National Committee conducted a national television campaign to support the party's candidates across the nation. Using the theme ''Stay the Course,'' the ads urged voters to back up their Grand Old President by sending Republican candidates to Congress in record numbers.

title: A Mideast Roster of Violence: the Militants and Their State Sponsors
description: Pan-Arab Leadership of Arab Revolutionary Forces An alliance of 22 Libyan, Palestinian, Lebanese, and other groups brought together in 1985 to fight Israel and American and Western ''hegemony'' in the Middle East. Says it will set up suicide squads to attack American interests everywhere if Libya or any other Arab state is attacked by the United States. Members include the following: Libyan Peoples Committees Set up throughout Libya to provide a power base for the Government. Leader: Colonel Muammar el-Qaddafi Members: Tens of thousands Al Burkan (The Volcano) Underground faction of the Peoples Committees, leader unknown, set up with purpose of liquidating Qaddafi opponents living abroad. Syrian Baath Party Ruling party and policy-making body of Government. Leader: President Hafez al-Assad Members: Thousands Palestine National Salvation Front 6 Palestinian groups allied with Syria and Libya. Receive most financial and military assistance from Libya. All have headquarters in Damascus and bases in Lebanon. Advocate armed struggle as a course to deal with Israel and are opposed to Yasir Arafat, the P.L.O. chairman, and any negotiated Middle East settlement. Since 1974, all have said they are devoting themselves to raids against Israel and Israelis in occupied Arab terrorities. The Popular Front for the Liberation of Palestine (PFLP) Leader: Dr. George Habash Members: 800 in eastern, northern and southern Lebanon The PFLP-General Command Leader: Capt. Ahmed Jebril, who once served in the Syrian Army Members: 500 in southern, eastern and northern Lebanon Fatah Uprising Comprised of dissidents in Mr. Arafat's mainstream Fatah movement.

title: 1,200-Year-Old Tomb Of Mayans Discovered
description: A Mayan tomb more than 1,000 years old, apparently royal and apparently untouched by looters, has been discovered in the Central American nation of Belize, an American archeologist has reported.

title: Don't Snub Sakharov
description: Exactly a decade ago, candidate Ronald Reagan - seeking to wrest the Republican nomination from President Ford - exploited a glaring example of the blind eye being turned to human rights by detente.

title: A Drug Bill's Bad Side Effects
description: Congress is considering legislation, quite properly, that would stop a new phenomenon on the drug scene - underground chemists who manufacture so-called analogs, or ''designer drugs.'' By altering the molecular structure of a drug listed as a controlled substance, chemists can create a drug that is entirely legal but that produces effects similar to an illegal substance.

title: In the Wings, A 52-Year-Old
description: No one has waited longer to become Japan's Emperor than the 52-year-old Crown Prince, Akihito. But when he ascends to the Chrysanthemum Throne occupied by his father for the last six decades, Akihito will symbolize many of the changes that Japan has gone through since World War II.

title: SHULTZ ADVOCATES U.S. COVERT PROGRAMS TO DEPOSE QADDAFI
description: Secretary of State George P. Shultz today advocated the use of ''disruptive'' covert action against Libya as a possible alternative to more military retaliation for new terrorist attacks.

title: TOXIC POLLUTANTS LINGER AS THREAT TO THE HUDSON
description: More than 10 years after New York State officials reported that PCB's had contaminated the Hudson River, the state's most important waterway is cleaner, by many standards, than it has been in years. But still it is threatened by the continued dumping of thousands of pounds of toxic chemicals each month.

title: HAITI BACKS POLICE ON DEATHS OF 7, SAYING AGITATORS PROVOKED CLASH
description: Haiti's ruling military-civilian council said today that the police, in shooting into a crowd of thousands of marchers on Saturday, displayed ''a normal reaction'' in guarding a military post against ''an attempted invasion.'' Seven people were killed. The Government, in two communiques, expressed its ''strongest regrets'' to the victims' families. But it said that the incident had been provoked by ''agitators'' and that an investigation was under way to find ''the bad-intentioned individuals who are at the origin of the incident.''

title: Knowing Onions
description: No sooner did Senator Pete Wilson of California read an assertion in Congress that the Texas 1015 SuperSweet Onion had won the 1985 Sweet Onion Challenge than he sprang into indignant reply mode. It was Representative E. (Kika) de la Garza who had boasted to his fellow legislators that the Texas product ''was named the sweetest raw onion in the nation'' at the challenge, held in El Centro, Cal.

title: YUCATAN'S FIBER CULTURE EBBS
description: A century ago, when mechanization revolutionized American agriculture and binder twine was a highly sought commodity, the agave plant and the henequen fibers it produces were king in all the Yucatan Peninsula. The peninsula's major city, Merida, was the richest in the country, and Mexico dominated the world henequen market.

title: A GREATER SALT LAKE MIGHTN'T BE SO GREAT
description: The Great Salt Lake is getting even Greater, transforming northern Utah's biggest asset into the area's biggest potential menace.

title: Last 6 U.S. Journalists Leave Libya as Requested by Tripoli
description: The remaining American journalists in Libya left here today under the very firm request of the Libyan Government.

title: ABC HOPING TO WIN ITS CORPORATE GAMBLE
description: Only a bettor with unlimited optimism, and cash, would gamble on the three legs of the Triple Crown weeks in advance of the first race. But ABC, in becoming the first network in 12 years to buy the rights to all three races, has pretty much done the corporate equivalent.

title: WHALERS FORCE A 7TH GAME
description: Michael Liut, back in goal after missing two games because of an injury, stopped 32 shots and Kevin Dineen scored his sixth goal of the playoffs tonight to lead the Hartford Whalers to a 1-0 victory over the Montreal Canadiens.

title: HOROWITZ AGAIN HEARS CHEERS OF LENINGRAD
description: Reunited with a city and a concert hall in which he spent some of his happiest days as a young pianist, Vladimir Horowitz gave his first recital in Leningrad in 61 years today.

title: BIRTHDAYS: COUPLES' IDEAS VARY
description: TO celebrate his wife's 30th birthday, Steven Baker, a Los Angeles stockbroker, invited 50 people to a surprise party.

title: NICARAGUA REPORTS REBEL LOSSES
description: The Nicaraguan Army said today that it killed or wounded 1,000 rebels this year.

title: THE TRACKS: 3 STEPS TO GLORY; CHURCHILL DOWNS
description: IN the years after the Civil War, horse racing, like most other aspects of Southern life, was still suffering. Breeding farms graced the Kentucky landscaped between Louisville and Lexington, 75 miles to the southeast, where limestone soil and bluegrass nourish the breeding and raising of race horses. But something was needed to revive the horse society and provide a showcase for these farms.

title: Advertising; U.S. News Revels in New Look
description: AT news conferences that will start today at the ''21'' Club and then roll across the nation, Mortimer B. Zuckerman, the chairman, editor in chief and owner of U.S. News & World Report, will report that the extensive redesign of the magazine generally did not disturb the magazine's hard-core subscribers and indeed helped increase circulation by 250,000 in the first quarter.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''We believe that Asian nations are the masters of their own fate.'' -President Reagan. [ A11:3. ]

title: Is China Looser About Birth Control?
description: Ardent right-to-lifers opposed to family planning have used China's population control program as an excuse to attack American population assistance programs, including our support for the United Nations Fund for Population Activities. But there is now evidence that China's policy, which was aimed at limiting each family to one child, has undergone important if little noticed changes. The evidence suggests that in the last two years, China has adopted a more flexible attitude toward the one-child policy while strengthening prohibitions against physical coercion and brutality.

title: 2.1% RISE IN MACHINE TOOL ORDERS
description: New orders for American-made machine tools rose 2.1 percent in March from February's level, according to a report to be released today by the National Machine Tool Builders' Association. Industry analysts attributed the small increase to the nation's sluggish industrial growth and uncertainty about how proposed changes in tax legislation will affect capital spending.

title: 'STRONG MEDICINE,' FROM THE ARTHUR HAILEY NOVEL
description: TAKE the well-worn literary formula of an Arthur Hailey best seller. Combine thoroughly with the sort of audience-research television constructed on the rock of short attention spans. The result - ''Strong Medicine,'' a four-hour movie beginning on Channel 11 tonight at 8 - is a prescription for prolonged stupefaction.

title: BY APPOINTMENT, THE FEDERAL BEES
description: Some Federal employees work for free.

title: AIDS TEST AT ISSUE IN HOMOSEXUAL'S BID TO HAVE CHILDREN VISIT
description: John Doe, as he is being called in legal documents, is a former Chicago resident who wants his two young daughters to visit him in San Francisco, where he now lives.

title: THATCHER FAULTS U.S. TERROR POLICY
description: Referring pointedly to her Government's readiness to allow the use of British bases in the American raids on Libya, Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher contended today that the United States had an obligation to fight the terrorism of the Irish Republican Army by agreeing to an extradition treaty that has been held up for months in the Senate Foreign Relations Committee.

title: Traffic Solutions for a Commercial Ghost Town
description: To the Editor:

title: PBS FILM EXAMINES ELEPHANTS IN THAILAND
description: ''ELEPHANT GAMES'' is a moderately charming film about elephants, specifically elephants in Thailand. Some are kept as pets, some haul logs in teak forests and some, the feature players in the film, compete in the Thai equivalent of an American rodeo. The 30-minute film will be seen on Channel 13 at 10:30 tonight.

title: RECITAL: BUGG, BASS-BARITONE
description: G. WILLIAM BUGG, a bass-baritone who teaches at Samford University in Birmingham, Ala., made his New York debut at Carnegie Recital Hall on Wednesday night accompanied at the piano by Donald Sanders. The program included works by Purcell, Strauss, Honegger, Ravel and Carlisle Floyd, among others.

title: CONSERVATIVE CHIEF SEES HIMSELF AN 'UMPIRE' AS FEDERAL JUDGE
description: J. Daniel Mahoney, the longtime leader in New York State of the Conservative Party, which has often criticized ''activist'' Federal judges, says he will not carry any ideological baggage with him when he is sworn in tomorrow as a United States Court of Appeals judge.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * BR Investors Inc., a private holding company, appointed Barry Aved president and chief executive of its Brooks Fashions division, a chain of women's apparel stores, effective about May 12.

title: The Lone Hurdler
description: As an undergraduate hurdler at Princeton, Sally Anderson was a three-time Ivy League champion. But no field back then ever posed less of a challenge to her than the one she faced - or didn't face - at the Penn Relays the other day.

title: Net Up Sharply At Aetna Life
description: The Aetna Life and Casualty Company said on Friday that it earned $250 million, or $2.20 a share, in the first quarter, almost five times the $56 million, or 50 cents a share, earned in the comparable period last year.

title: Ferraro's Identity Problem
description: You remember Gerald Ferrara, that fellow from Queens whose wife was active in politics? Well, the Republican National Committee has not forgotten.

title: THE TRACKS: 3 STEPS TO GLORY; BELMONT
description: ''M ANY horses can win the first two legs of the Triple Crown,'' says Woody Stephens. ''But you have to be a stayer to get the Belmont distance of a mile and a half.''

title: PEN's 'Silenced Voices' Will Focus on Turkey
description: The playwright Arthur Miller and other American writers will honor Turkish authors as part of the PEN American Center's ''Silenced Voices'' series Wednesday night at 8. The series, which previously focused on writers from South Africa, the Soviet Union and the Philippines, provides a showcase for authors who have been censored or imprisoned in their own countries.

title: SCORES SAID TO DIE IN BATTLE FOR AN AFGHAN GUERRILLA BASE
description: A Western diplomat said today that more than 100 Afghan rebels may have died in a battle this month for an important rebel supply base near the border with Pakistan. He said many Soviet and Afghan Government soldiers also died.

title: ZAIRE NOW DANCING TO DIFFERENT BEAT
description: Things don't get hopping in the Matonge quarter until two or three hours after midnight. By then, milling young men in billowy shirts and baggy pants and young women in flouncy dresses or cotton print pagnes have reached critical mass and the music starts blasting.

title: GIRL, 17, IS SHOT ON THE SUBWAY
description: A teen-age girl on an A train stopped in the Columbus Circle station last night was shot in the leg by a man getting off the train, the transit police said.

title: The Editorial Notebook; Flights of Non-Fancy
description: According to conventional wisdom, airline deregulation has meant lower fares and poorer service. People willing to put up with delayed flights, harried attendants and sardine seats are winners. Business travelers, who value convenience and can't take full advantage of discount rates, are supposedly losers.

title: JAPANESE DEMAND WATCHED
description: As the credit markets prepare for a record Treasury financing next week, attention is focused on the willingness of Japanese investors to keep buying American notes and bonds.

title: FOR BREEDERS, THE DERBY ADDS THE MOST VALUE
description: Mention the Triple Crown to a major thoroughbred breeder in North America and the glaze that slips over his eyes will be tinged with green - dollar green.

title: Loans Given to Brazil
description: The World Bank on Friday announced $258 million worth of loans to help develop Brazil's farms and cities.

title: STAGE: 'SWEET CHARITY,' A BOB FOSSE REVIVAL
description: CAN six or seven knockout song-and-dance turns transform an also-ran Broadway musical into a classic? Of course not, but just try telling that to the audiences who are about to have some indecent fun at the revival of ''Sweet Charity.'' As choreographed by Bob Fosse and performed by the dynamic Debbie Allen and company, the numbers in this 1966 musical adaptation of Federico Fellini's ''Nights of Cabiria'' tear away from its dreary book with centrifugal force. By the late hour when the star leads a crack battalion of red-and-gold troops through the torrential kicks and leaps of ''I'm a Brass Band,'' hard-core addicts of old-time Broadway might be tempted to parade in the aisles, if only the Minskoff weren't a modern Broadway house without any aisles.

title: IN ONE YUGOSLAV PROVINCE, SERBS FEAR THE ETHNIC ALBANIANS
description: The ethnic Albanian majority in the autonomous province of Kosovo is feared by the minority population of Serbs and Montenegrins, who believe the Albanians are seeking to drive them out of the province.

title: CHIEF COUNSEL IS CHOSEN AT INVESTIGATION AGENCY
description: A Federal prosecutor in Brooklyn, Susan E. Shepard, has been selected to direct investigations for the state agency responsible for uncovering corruption and mismanagement, state officials said yesterday.

title: Cable Commitment Stressed at Warner
description: James L. Gray, who last week was named president and chief operating officer of Warner Cable Communications Inc., sees his new appointment as a reinforcement of Warner's committment to the cable industry.

title: CELTICS WIN OPENER
description: The Celtics, sparked by Kevin McHale, pulled away with a 14-0 spurt in the third quarter and beat the Atlanta Hawks by 103-91 today in the opener of their four-of-seven-game Eastern Conference semifinal playoff.

title: Fuel-Economy Car Standards
description: The Transportation Department says it will not decide until summer what fuel-economy standards to set for 1987 and 1988 model cars. A 1975 law established a long-term target of an average 27.5 miles per gallon for each auto maker's fleet, but the department has the authority to revise this if some other level is deemed the ''maximum feasible'' for any given year.

title: Record Treasury Offering Awaited
description: The Treasury will announce Wednesday plans to auction what securities dealers expect will be a record-size package of new notes and bonds in the week of May 5. In addition, the Treasury will hold its regular weekly auction of new three-month and six-month bills today.

title: AID TO ETHIOPIA SAVES 7 MILLION
description: Seven million people have been spared starvation in Ethiopia by ''a remarkable success story of international relief,'' but serious problems remain, a congressional report said today.

title: Johannesen to Perform
description: The pianist Grant Johannesen will perform with the Guarneri String Quartet on today and tomorrow at 8 P.M. at Alice Tully Hall.

title: PROJECT MANAGERS IN A HURRY
description: Peter M. Lehrer and Gene McGovern are in a hurry.

title: Catching Up
description: * A year and a half after Coach Jim Walsh pulled the George Washington High School football team off the field just before kickoff rather than risk another physical beating by a bigger, stronger A Division opponent, the Public Schools Athletic League has assigned his squad to play in the B Division next season. The move might appear to be a victory for Walsh, whose dramatic gesture led the Board of Education to suspend him briefly and reprimand him for insubordination. But board officials insist that the reassignment is merely routine, resulting from a customary biannual review of division alignments rather than from the coach's campaign to have the Trojans dropped in class. Walsh will get a chance to address the issue today, when he testifies in Bronx Supreme Court in a $10 million damage suit filed against the city, the board and the P.S.A.L. by Sixto Benitez, a former George Washington player. Benitez, who suffered a broken neck and other injuries in a 1983 A Division game, maintains that officials were negligent in rejecting Walsh's repeated pleas for a B-level classification.

title: PATRIARCHY: IS IT INVENTION OR INEVITABLE?
description: Gerda Lerner, the historian, was talking about patriarchy, the form of social organization. ''As a system, patriarchy is as outdated as feudalism,'' she said on a recent morning after a meeting of historians at a Manhattan hotel. ''But it is a 4,000-year-old system of ideas that won't just go away overnight.''

title: TITLES, TIARAS AND TUXEDOS
description: THERE may or may not be a Triple Crown on the race tracks of America this year, but tiaras, titles and one very genuine crown will be making the scene as the horsey set gathers in Kentucky one more time.

title: NEW TECHNIQUES PUT SPOTLIGHT ON ANCHORS
description: On a live interview on the ''CBS Evening News'' recently, Dan Rather, the CBS anchor, confronted Secretary of State George P. Shultz with a report that the United States attack on Libya had jeopardized the chances for a summit conference, and tried to elicit a direct response. ''Is that true?'' Mr. Rather asked.

title: AMERICANS IN EUROPE LIE LOW
description: Americans living in Europe have become accustomed to a lot of things in the last two weeks.

title: Typhoon Kills 2 in Nepal
description: A typhoon killed 2 people and injured 25 on Saturday night in Biratnagar, 150 miles southeast of Katmandu, the Nepalese press agency said today. Winds as strong as 100 miles an hour persisted for an hour.

title: Chamber Music Society To Celebrate With Gala
description: The Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center will celebrate its 1,000th performance Wednesday at 7:30 with a gala concert at Alice Tully Hall. Proceeds from the evening will benefit the society.

title: 15 Monkeys in Dispute
description: People for the Ethical Treatment of Animals plans to begin a ''conscience camp and permanent vigil'' this morning on the grounds of the National Institutes of Health in Bethesda, Md., remaining until the Government gives up 15 macaque monkeys that were the subject of an abandoned scientific experiment. The goal of the demonstration is to have the monkeys sent to a sanctuary, Primarily Primates, in San Antonio.

title:
SPORTS WORLD SPECIALS;
SLUGGING IT OUT
description: The Hillerich & Bradsby Company of Louisville, Ky., maker of the legendary Louisville Slugger baseball bats, says it loses $2 on every bat it produces for professional players. That rounds out to a quarter of a million dollars a year, but nobody's crying over it. The promotional value of big-league business is immeasurable, and roughly 80 percent of today's major leaguers use Louisville Sluggers.

title: Arts Appointment
description: The Kitchen, a center for video, music, dance, drama and film, at 512 West 19th Street, has announced the appointment of Barbara L. Tsumagari as executive director.

title: CORRECTION
description: A report on the Washington Talk page last Wednesday about commemorative coins misstated the composition of the 50-cent Statue of Liberty commemorative. It contains 0.33 troy ounces of copper and 0.03 troy ounces of nickel; there is no silver.

title: THE MERGING OF REAL ESTATE AND LITERARY CLASSICS
description: THERE is a smart new apartment block rising in Manhattan, on Third Avenue, called the Royale; the sign outside proclaims its name, and then underneath, in smaller letters, ''Remembrance of Things Past.'' As far as I know this represents an innovation; lots of apartment houses in New York have names (most of them are listed in an excellent guidebook that Atheneum published a year or so back, ''Living It Up'' by Thomas Norton and Jerry Patterson), but the Royale is surely the first building to boast a subtitle as well - and a literary subtitle at that.

title: STRANGE TOPS PEETE IN PLAYOFF
description: Curtis Strange, who set a PGA Tour money-winning record in 1985, broke out of his 1986 doldrums in spectacular fashion today when he came from three shots back to force a playoff, then sank a 30-foot birdie putt on the third extra hole to beat Calvin Peete and win the Houston Open.

title: CORRECTION
description: Dispatches from Washington Friday, Saturday and yesterday about the lobbying activities of Michael K. Deaver, the former White House aide, incorrectly described the requirements of the law on appointing an independent counsel to investigate the situation. The Attorney General has 30 days to respond to five Senators' written request for such an appointment unless he decides to conduct a preliminary investigation to determine whether a counsel should be appointed. In that case, the investigation by the Attorney General must not exceed 90 days, and he is then required to respond within 15 days of completion of the preliminary investigation.

title: Alaska Volcano Emits Steam
description: The Augustine volcano continued to emit a 10,000-foot plume of steam today and instruments registered minor earthquakes, but geologists who have been predicting a major eruption say they cannot be sure when it may occur. Over the weekend hundreds of clam diggers ignored the potential danger of a tidal wave that could be generated if part of the 4,025-foot volcano on Cook Inlet southwest of here sloughed off into the water.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: NORTHLAND MOVIES The Nordic Film Festival, consisting of nine recent feature films made in the Scandinavian countries and Finland, opens today at the U.A. Eastside Cinema, Third Avenue at 55th Street. The house has been taken over through Sunday by the American-Scandinavian Foundation, which had run a similar festival once before, designed to acquaint New York, where none of the films have ever been shown, with cinema making in the part of the world outsiders often tend to associate mostly with the work of Ingmar Bergman.

title: 18 Held in Investigation Of Credit Card Theft
description: Eighteen men, all Nigerian nationals accused of obtaining credit cards or numbers by searching mailboxes and trash cans, are to be arraigned Monday on charges stemming a two-month undercover operation.

title: LAROUCHE'S HERSHEY DIET
description: ''Hello, Candy Kisses Motel.''

title: 'Spy Dust' Raising Interest
description: Thanks to the alarm raised last summer over an obscure chemical purportedly used by Soviet secret police to spy on American diplomats, a market for ''spy dust'' has apparently been created in the United States.

title: ECHO BAY MINES LTD reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes a gain of $1.1 million on the sale of aircraft. All dollar figures are in Canadian dollars.

title: Why I'm Unloading My I.B.M. Shares
description: For the 800,000 owners of shares in I.B.M., including me, the time has come to understand that personal divestment is the proper answer to our company's continuing operations in South Africa. By its mere presence there, I.B.M. collaborates with apartheid.

title: Allied-Signal
description: Allied-Signal Inc. said its board had declared a special dividend of one share of common stock of the Henley Group Inc. for each four shares of Allied-Signal common stock. The dividend completes Allied-Signal's previously announced spinoff of Henley as an independent company. Allied-Signal said the dividend, which will be paid to shareholders of record on May 16, would be distributed May 27 or ''as soon as practicable'' after the Securities and Exchange Commission completes a review of documents relating to the spinoff.

title: Market Place; Analysts Favor Ad Agencies
description: WHILE the takeover pace is slowing in some industries, advertising agencies appear to be moving into high gear. Plans for a blockbuster merger announced over the weekend would create an advertising giant with combined billings of $5 billion a year.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: TUESDAY, APRIL 29, 1986
description: Markets

title: FRENCH CENTER IS DEDICATED TO SCIENCE
description: In Paris's last great open space, 75 acres in the northeast known as La Villette, thousands of people crowd daily into a still incomplete, 880-foot-long building to explore by sight, touch and smell the wonders of the planet and outer space.

title: Key Rates
description: * Municipal Bond Index, The Bond Buyer Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: Rights Group Requests Pressure on Indonesia
description: An international human rights monitoring group has asked President Reagan, in his meetings with President Suharto and other Indonesian officials, to address human rights issues that include what the group says are the executions without trial of several thousand people suspected of being criminals in recent years.

title: SINGER CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes an after-tax gain of $16.9 million from the sale of a majority equity interest in Singer's Malaysian subsidiary. The company said that included in its results are favorable foreign exchange adjustments totaling $3.1 million and $4.4 million for the 1986 and 1985 periods, respectively, representing the effect of translating local currency borrowings in Brazil and Mexico into U.S. dollars. The company also noted that it has adopted a new pension accounting standard, which increased the latest quarter net by $1.9 million and will benefit subsequent periods in 1986 by a similar amount.

title: BELO, AH CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
CINCINNATI FINANCIAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes capital gains of $6,565,000 for the latest quarter and $4,440,000 for the earlier period.

title: STAGE: A NEW 'LONG DAY'S JOURNEY'
description: IF there's one word said more often than any other in Eugene O'Neill's ''Long Day's Journey Into Night,'' it must be ''fog.'' The fog in this play doesn't come on little cat feet; its arrival is predicted incessantly in the Connecticut summer home where the author's surrogate family, the four haunted Tyrones, will settle the scores of a lifetime during a single day in 1912. And once the fog has swallowed up the household, as with nightfall it must, it brings both sadness and peace to O'Neill's pitiful brood. The alcohol-fueled journey into the fog in ''Long Day's Journey'' is a journey back through time. When the Tyrones finally accept that ''the past is the present,'' they can begin to forgive, if not forget, the betrayals of which their tragic history is made.

title: STEWART-WARNER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes a non-recurring pre-tax gain of $1,811,000 from the sale of a stake in Plexus Corp.

title: PUBLIC SERVICE CO OF NORTH CAROLINA INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
YANKEES' BULLPEN GETS NEEDED REST
description: And for only the fourth day, the bullpen rested.

title: TEJON RANCH CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
EXPOSAIC INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Better Deal Sought
description: Bret Saberhagen, the American League's Cy Young Award winner and the most valuable player in the World Series last season, is suing Rawlings Sporting Goods' parent company in an effort to end an endorsement contract that pays him two baseball gloves a year. The Kansas City Royals' pitcher, who signedthe contract at spring training in March 1983, shortly before his first professional season, claims in part that the pact is void on the ground its terms were misrepresented to him.

title: JUDGE PUTS OFF GOTTI CRIME TRIAL UNTIL AUGUST TO REVAMP THE JURY
description: After 10 days of jury selection, the judge in the Federal racketeering trial of John Gotti, the reputed crime boss, abruptly postponed the case yesterday until August.

title: HEEKIN CAN INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After a loss from discontinued operations of $553,000.

title: Matsushita Plant in U.S.
description: The Matsushita Electric Industrial Company, Japan's largest consumer electronics maker, is likely to pick Vancouver, Wash., as its first videotape recorder production site in the United States, according to a Matsushita official. He declined to confirm reports that Vancouver had been selected, but said today that ''it appears that a decision has been made.''

title: TORONTO FORCES 7TH GAME
description: Walt Poddubny, who was benched earlier in the series, scored with 7 minutes 35 remaining tonight to lift the Toronto Maple Leafs to a 5-3 triumph over the St. Louis Blues, forcing a seventh and deciding game in the Norris Division final.

title: New U.N. Development Chief
description: The General Assembly today approved William H. Draper 3d as administrator of the United Nations Development Program. Mr. Draper, 58 years old, of White Plains, N.Y., will replace Bradford Morse, who headed the program for 13 years. Mr. Draper is president and chairman of the Export-Import Bank, a Federal agency that supports the sale of American goods abroad.

title: CROSS, AT CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
THE DANCE: TSAI FUNG
description: THE TSAI FUNG DANCE COMPANY was founded in 1982 with the aim of expressing Chinese tradition in modern dance and music. Some of the dances performed by the company on April 25 at Pace College's Schimmel Center had the look of uneasy hybrids. But there was also authentic theater, much of which tended to occur when Jiang Qi was on the stage.

title: HERITAGE COMMUNICATIONS INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The company said a gain of 2 cents a share is included in the latest first quarter net resulting from a change in accounting for pension costs.

title: Profits Scoreboard
description: See accompanying notes for special items.(Loss) * Loss in year-earlier period.

title: MCA INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
OSMONICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Conifers Growing At Volcano Crater
description: Conifer seedlings are growing in deep ash near the crater of Mount St. Helens for the first time since the volcano erupted on May 18, 1980, researchers say.

title: MEESE DOUBTS AN EARLY DECISION ON BARRING WALDHEIM FROM U.S.
description: Attorney General Edwin Meese 3d indicated today that a decision on whether to bar former United Nations Secretary General Kurt Waldheim from the United States as a result of his wartime activities was unlikely to come before Sunday's presidential election in Austria, where Mr. Waldheim is a candidate.

title: Advertising; Big Merger Analyzed By Rivals
description: A LONG the extremely talky byways of advertising known as Madison Avenue yesterday there was only one major topic of conversation - the big merger.

title: IN SUDAN, TIDE TURNS AGAINST THE U.S.
description: Several university students, their clenched fists raised in defiance, added their voices to angry chants of ''Down, Down, U.S.A.!'' at a rally held recently in this gritty, time-worn capital to protest American air strikes against Libya.

title: Telecom to Sell Commercial Paper
description: British Telecom Inc. plans to offer up to $500 million of commercial paper in the American market through Goldman, Sachs & Company.

title: Topics; Big Jumps; Optimism, Amended
description: Our editorial on Sunday about juggled numbers in the Federal budget wrongly implied that David Stockman and Murray Weidenbaum alone concocted a ''rosy'' forecast in 1981 to promote an official fiction that spending and revenue would soon be in balance. That was unfair to Mr. Weidenbaum, then chairman of the Council of Economic Advisers.

title: CORRECTION
description: Because of an editing error in Marshall Green's article published yesterday, ''Is China Easing Up on Birth Control?'', an official formerly in charge of India's population program was misidentified. Mr. Green had supplied the proper name, Sanjay Gandhi.

title: Required Reading; On Good and Evil
description: Excerpt from a recent statement in the Congressional Record by Senator William L. Armstrong, Republican of Colorado, on good and evil in politics, with reference to ''Modern Times,'' a book by Paul Johnson:

title: Book Reviews by Reagan
description: When President Reagan was asked if he had read David A. Stockman's ''The Triumph of Politics,'' which accuses him of economic ignorance and willingness to listen to incompetent advisers, he dryly replied that he didn't ''have too much time for fiction.''

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL LOS ANGELES (NL)- Placed Bill Madlock, third baseman, on 15-day disabled list. Recalled Reggie Williams, outfielder, from Albuquerque of the Pacific Coast League.

title: Rural County Wins Environment Fight
description: To the Editor:

title: COATED SALES INC reports earnings for Year to Feb 28
BALLY MANUFACTURING CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
KAPLAN INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net loss

title: Ex-Cell-O, TRW
description: The Ex-Cell-O Corporation will buy the compressor components division of TRW Inc. of Cleveland for a price to be determined within two months, the companies said.

title: PAR TECHNOLOGY reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Ferraro's Son Pleads Not Guilty on 2d Charge
description: John A. Zaccaro Jr., son of the 1984 Vice Presidential candidate, Geraldine A. Ferraro, pleaded not guilty today to a charge of selling a regulated drug.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''An accident has occurred at the Chernobyl nuclear power plant as one of the reactors was damaged.

title: GIBRALTAR FINANCIAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
City Restrained On Residency Rule
description: A State Supreme Court justice yesterday delayed for two weeks the enforcing of a city order requiring city policemen, firefighters and correction officers to tell their agencies if they live outside New York City or six surrounding counties.

title: FOSTER WHEELER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Soviet Persuasion
description: Only a few weeks ago in Moscow, J. Carter Brown, director of the National Gallery, talked Soviet authorities into including the Matisse classic ''Harmony in Red'' in the exchange exhibit of 40 other paint-ings from Soviet museums that opens at the gallery in Washington on Thursday. He promised that the famous work, known popularly as ''The Red Room,'' would not have to move on to Los Angeles and New York with the rest of the collection so it could be sent to France for a fall commitment there.

title: NASH FINCH CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes pre-tax charges related to LIFO inventory adjustments of $245,000 for the latest quarter and $688,497 for the year-earlier period.

title: FMC Will Sweeten Shareholders Offer
description: The FMC Corporation, a military contractor and chemical and machinery company, said today that it would sweeten its recapitalization plan by $10 a share in cash, to $80 a share and one new share of the recapitalized company.

title: DEAVER REQUESTS A SPECIAL INQUIRY INTO HIS LOBBYING
description: Michael K. Deaver, the former deputy White House chief of staff, asked today for appointment of an independent counsel to investigate charges that his lobbying activities had violated Federal conflict-of-interest laws.

title: CLASH CENTERS ON SHY SNAKE AND A DAM
description: A shy, nocturnal snake and a dam in arid West Texas are posing the first major Congressional challenge to the Endangered Species Act since the 1970's, when a tiny fish, the snail darter, held up construction of the Tellico Dam in Tennessee.

title: A NEW NO. 12 COMES TO TOWN
description: True to the tradition established by a quarterback who stormed this town in white shoes more than two decades ago, Jim Kelly was here to look at women. Wasn't there once a time when a requirement for the position in New York City included the ability to throw great spirals and greater parties?

title: PRESIDENT BEGINS TRIP TO INDONESIA
description: President Reagan declared today that the United States must be willing to defend its values and its citizens ''unflinchingly'' in the face of terrorism.

title: CONCERT: DEL TREDICI'S 'CHILD ALICE'
description: BENEATH the rippling, sunlit surface of ''Alice in Wonderland'' and its appurtenant tales and poems there run other currents. One is of pointed social and political comment, but that seems of no interest to David Del Tredici, whose long compositional obsession with Alice Pleasance Liddell and the stories spun for her by the Rev. Charles Dodgson (Lewis Carroll) had its most recent local manifestation in the complete presentation of ''Child Alice,'' for huge orchestra and amplified soprano, Sunday afternoon at Carnegie Hall.

title: MICOM SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31

DeBartolo, a developer of shopping malls, tried to buy the Chicago White Sox in 1980 but was rejected because other American League owners said he would be an ''absentee owner.''

description: International A major Soviet nuclear accident apparently occurred at a power plant in the Ukraine. The Kremlin acknowledged there had been an accident and said ''aid is being given to those affected.'' The announcement - the first official disclosure of a nuclear accident ever by the Soviet Union -came hours after Sweden, Finland and Denmark reported abnormally high radioactivity levels in their skies. The four pieces, if that hoary musical term fits the little segments of aural experience Miss de Compiegne brought us - recorded bits of everyday life, her own voice and those of others, plus the colorations of synthesized sound - all evoked carefully created and intensely felt moods.

title: Robins Perjury Issue Is Raised

Robins Company's bankruptcy case said Federal prosecutors should consider if a perjury investigation was warranted involving the company's premature payment of $6.8 million in selected debts. ''I'm not suggesting there has been,'' Federal District Judge Robert R. Merhige Jr. said.

But scientists fear that because of a lack of funds and transportation, many of the fossils may be lost or spoiled before they can be carried to the safety of research facilities.

The service, at 20-minute intervals from 9:05 A.M. to 5:55 P.M. Monday through Friday, connects with existing service from Grand Central Terminal and the Port Authority Bus Terminal. Buses from the airports run between 8:40 A.M. and 5:30 P.M.

title: Reagan Talk to Marcos Gets Aquino's Thanks
description: President Corazon C. Aquino said today that she would use force only as a last resort to keep Ferdinand E. Marcos from returning to power and thanked President Reagan for telling the ousted ruler that ''the Filipino people have spoken.''

title: Careers; Logistics Graduates In Demand
description: LOGISTICS - the science, or perhaps the art, of getting an object from here to there - offers some interesting job possibilities.

title: Topics; Big Jumps; That's the Ticket
description: The Automobile Club of New York objects to the city's proposal to increase maximum parking fines from $40 to $100, plus late penalties that could reach $50 for a total of $150. No other American city has such high penalties for illegal parking, the club says.

title: Aid to Ex-Presidents: How Much Is Too Much?
description: Like so many other areas of Government, the cost of supporting former Presidents has grown steadily. But with Congress acutely conscious of the call for deficit reduction, former Presidents may be about to face leaner times.

title: PEOPLE EXPRESS WOOS BUSINESS FLIER

title: Four Mounted Escapees Tracked Down in Texas
description: Prison guards and police officers with tracking dogs chased down four convicts today after they overpowered a prison guard and fled on horseback through the piney woods of East Texas..

title: U.N. CHIEF SUGGESTS U.S. CONTRIBUTION BE CUT
description: Secretary General Javier Perez de Cuellar, stating that ''no single country should be in a postion in some way to threaten or to blackmail the United Nations,'' suggested today that the United States should pay less of the United Nations budget.

title: House Unit Said to Consider Impeaching Convicted Judge
description: The House Judiciary Committee is considering impeachment proceedings against a convicted Federal judge who refuses to resign, a member of the panel said today.

''Normally I'd answer the question with an everyday player, because a pitcher's too easily injured,'' said Bill Giles, who doubles as the Phillies' owner and chief baseball man.

title: NOTES ON FASHION
description: WHILE the rest of the world was watching Hyannis, Mass., where Maria Shriver wed Arnold Schwarzenegger last weekend, Willi Smith reports he was thinking about the nuptials of another member of the Kennedy clan: Caroline. Several seasons ago Miss Kennedy's fiance, Edwin Schlossberg, created a T-shirt for Mr. Smith. This season, the designer will return the favor. He's been hired to design wedding outfits for Mr. Schlossberg, his ushers and best man. EXECUTIVES at The Limited report that they have ended on-again, off-again negotiations with the designer Stephen Sprouse for a low-priced collection to be sold in their youth-oriented Limited Express stores. Mr. Sprouse is still looking for a deal, his friends say. Downtown keeps wishing and hoping.

During halftime of Saturday afternoon's Western Conference semifinal game between the Denver Nuggets and the Houston Rockets, Brown said he knew of three teams that were interested in trading for Dantley, who averaged 29.83 points during the regular season, second only to Dominque Wilkins of the Atlanta Hawks.

title: SOFTWARE GETS ITS DAY IN THE SUN
description: THE Software Publishers Association, a microcomputer trade association, presented its 1985 ''Achievement in Software'' awards last week. Like the film industry's Oscars, the software industry's top prizes are awarded in a seemingly endless profusion of categories, ranging from ''Best Software Product'' to something called ''Best Adaptation From Another Medium.'' The envelopes, please. In the category of Best Software Product, the winner is: Windows, from Microsoft. This epic program, years in the making, is a multitasking, windowing environment for I.B.M. PC-compatibles, which means it allows several different programs to be called up on screen simultaneously. ''Powerful,'' the critics said, but ''painfully slow.'' Windows also won for Best Technical Achievement, and again for Best User Interface.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: TALKING ANIMALS AND OTHER PEOPLE. By Shamus Culhane. Illustrated. 463 pages. St. Martin's Press. $24.95. SHAMUS CULHANE has had a long and varied career in animated movies, dating from 1924, when he was only 15. His first job consisted of punching holes in drawing paper, but by 1930 he had graduated to the ranks of the animators, developing his skills under Max Fleischer in the heyday of the Fleischer Studio's celebrated sexpot, Betty Boop. Subsequently he went on to work for Walt Disney and other leading studios, and also made his mark as a pioneer of television animation.

NEW HOPE AT FISK UNIVERSITY
description: There are still cracks in the walls of many of the 26 buildings, some of them national historic landmarks, that make up the Fisk University campus. On occasion there is no hot water in the dormitories. The faculty is still awaiting that long-promised raise. And there are bills left to be paid. But the $4 million debt owed by the school a year ago has been whittled down to $600,000, salary increases for the college's 56 faculty members are said to be only a few paychecks away, and on an unexpected cool, rainy spring day, there was heat in the library.

title: CORRECTION

It was the critic, Anna Kisselgoff, and not Boris Kochno, the ballet's librettist, who said the style was derived from Expressionism and Constructivism in the Russian theater before 1924.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE

Rather than embroidering natural beauty, she extricated the essence of it, interpreting and manipulating the forms through her own outlooks. A new exhibition of 45 O'Keeffe pieces has gone on view at Hirschl & Adler Galleries, 21 East 70th Street (535-8810), the first sizable show of her work in New York in several years.

title: 'TRADE WAR,' REDUCING THE BARRIERS
description: ''TRADE WAR'' has a subtitle: ''A Short Course on the Tokyo Summit.'' This isn't quite accurate; next week's economic summit isn't really under examination here, and its process and politics are likely to remain as obscure or as clear, depending on what you know about it already, as it did before. On the other hand, so what? Summits come, summits go, and it's what they fight over that's important. ''Trade War,'' on Channel 13 at 10 o'clock tonight, does an imaginative, even entertaining, job of explaining.

title: Tax-Reform Tips For the Senate
description: The Senate Finance Committee has come a cropper on tax reform. When deliberations collapsed, the chairman, Bob Packwood, pulled back the bill and took the committee into closed session. His latest idea is to go from one extreme to another - from a crazy quilt patchwork of ideas that would serve to complicate the already mystifying tax system to a sweeping, pure version of a simple flat tax. The former approach failed because it departed from the basic principles of tax reform. The latter is alluring but politically unrealistic.

title: Great Western Ends Citadel Offer
description: In the climax to an acrimonious takeover fight, the Great Western Financial Corporation terminated its tender offer today for the shares of the Citadel Holding Corporation after an insufficient number of shares were tendered. Great Western had sought to take over Citadel, parent of Fidelity Federal Savings and Loan, by offering 1.2 shares of Great Western common stock for each share of Citadel common stock.

title: Frances Phipps, 62, Founder Of Connecticut Antique Show
description: Frances Phipps, a writer and founder of the Connecticut Antiques Show, died of a heart attack yesterday at New Britain (Conn.) General Hospital.

title: SUBWAY AIDES TO WEIGH CUTS ON 11 ROUTES
description: The Transit Authority will study the possibility of eliminating sections of 11 subway lines because of low ridership, transit officials said yesterday.

2 More Blacks Die In South Africa Unrest
description: Two black men were killed in South Africa today, the police reported, and witnesses said black youths stoned a minibus carrying the former French Prime Minister, Laurent Fabius.

title: COACH OF FOOTBALL AT U. OF WISCONSIN
description: Dave McClain, the University of Wisconsin's football coach, collapsed in a sauna and died of cardiac arrest today shortly after working out on an exercise bicycle at Camp Randall Stadium, authorities said. He was 48 years old.

title: GENERAL DYNAMICS OFF
description: Two of the nation's leading aircraft producers yesterday reported opposite results for the first quarter of 1986. The Boeing Company, the world's leading manufacturer of commercial jets, announced a 34.5 percent increase in its net income while the General Dynamics Corporation, a major military contractor, said it had a 24.4 percent decline.

title: NUCLEAR MISHAPS: RECORD SINCE '57
description: Oct. 7, 1957 - A fire in the Windscale plutonium production reactor north of Liverpool, England, spreads radioactive material throughout the countryside. In 1983, the British Government says 39 people have probably died of cancer as a result. 1957 - A chemical explosion in Kasli, U.S.S.R., in tanks containing nuclear waste from the weapons program spreads radiactive material over an area the size of Manhattan in the Urals, forcing a major evacuation. May 23, 1958 - Nuclear-fuel elements rupture in an experimental reactor at Chalk River, Canada, severely contaminating the building and slightly contaminating the immediate surrounding area. About 600 men participate in the cleanup. Jan. 3, 1961 - An experimental reactor in Idaho Falls goes out of control at a Federal installation, killing three technicians, one of them impaled by a reactor control rod. There is said to be no danger to the public, but the plant has very high radiation levels. Some Federal investigators later suggest the mishap was sabotage resulting from a lover's triangle. Oct. 5, 1966 - The core of the Enrico Fermi experimental breeder reactor near Detroit partly melts when a sodium cooling system malfunctions. The emergency shutdown apparatus stops the reaction from running away and no injuries occur, but radiation levels inside the plant are high. Jan. 21, 1969 - A coolant malfunction from an experimental underground reactor at Lucens Vad, Switzerland, results in the release of a large amount of radiation into a cavern, which is then sealed. There are no injuries. Oct. 17, 1969 - A fuel-loading error causes a partial fuel meltdown at a gas-cooled power reactor in Saint-Laurent, France.

title: Israelis Report Capture Of a 'Terrorist Ring'
description: The Israeli police announced today that they had captured a ''terrorist ring'' suspected of two killings and two attempted killings in Jerusalem in the last six weeks, including the slaying of a British tourist last Sunday.

title: NEW-HOME SALES SOAR BY 27.4%
description: New-home sales shot up 27.4 percent in March to the highest level in history, the Government reported today, as the housing industry continued to outperform all other segments of the economy.

title: Langer Finds A Loophole
description: Bernhard Langer has returned to the PGA Tour in hopes he'll be able to convince the Internal Revenue Service that he's much more attached to West Germany than to the United States - for tax purposes, at least.

description: b-After a tax credits of $280,000 for the quarter and $512,000 for the 6 months. c-Net loss includes a charge of $6,000 from the reversal of a tax credit for the quarter and for the 6 months.

description: b-Includes income from discontinued operations of $5,657,000 and an extraordinary charge of $1,940,000 for quarter and income from discontinued operations of $5,272,000 for year- ago quarter.

title: Woman on West Coast Takes Tylenol and Dies
description: A university laboratory technician who collapsed after taking two Extra-Strength Tylenol capsules died of cyanide poisoning, a coroner said today.

title: What a Caucus
description: Although women enjoy a modest majority in the overall population, they are a small minority in the Congress, only two Senators and 23 Representatives among the 535 lawmakers. Since their presence was formalized in 1977 as the Congresswomen's Caucus, the members and organizers of the present Congressional Caucus for Women's Issues have learned the old lesson that minorities can increase their influence if they combine with other minorities.

title: THE MAX ROACH SECRET: KEEP ON EXPRIMENTING
description: BRUSHES in hand, Max Roach sat behind his drums at a midtown rehearsal studio.

title: ASSESSMENT OF U.S.
description: United States intelligence sources said today that the nuclear disaster in the Soviet Union started as long as four or five days ago and was continuing to spread radioactive material into the atmosphere.

title: FOOD NOTES
description: Union Square Benefit On Saturday, a benefit luncheon at the Union Square Cafe for the Union Square Park Community Coalition will feature spring produce from the Greenmarket. The Union Square Greenmarket, the oldest of the 18 greenmarkets in the city, was organized in 1976. At that time, the renewal of Union Square Park, which had deteriorated markedly, seemed an impossible challenge. ''The City Planning Department was desperately seeking some way to spark a change in Union Square,'' Barry Benepe, director of the greenmarket program, recalled, ''and for the first few years things were pretty grim around here.'' This summer, fairs and entertainment will mark the 10th anniversary of the Union Square Greenmarket. The luncheon celebrates the first anniversary of the completion of the renovation of Union Square Park. The new Union Square Park Community Coalition, consisting of community groups and block associations, is dedicated to continued improvement of the park and hopes to sponsor special events such as concerts throughout the summer. The benefit luncheon will be at 12:30 P.M. at 21 East 16th Street. Tickets are $30 and are tax-deductible. For reservations call Oliver Johnston at 212-505-1454.

title: Bonds Offered By Louisiana
description: A $143.1 million issue of Louisiana general obligation bonds was offered yesterday through underwriters led by Citibank.

description: b-Includes a special charge for termination benefits of $3,300,000 for the quarter and 9 months.

WILL TOO MANY CHEFS SPOIL BUDGET?
description: When politicians get cornered and their budget balance sheets just do not add up, there is a time-honored practice in the capital for solving the problem. It is called ''cooking'' the budget numbers, and the chefs are getting out their stew pots again this week.

title: KOCH TO ANNOUNCE PLAN FOR 250,000 APARTMENTS
description: Mayor Koch, faced with growing pressure to deal with the city's critical housing shortage, has put together a $4.2 billion proposal to build or rehabilitate 250,000 apartments for low- and middle-income New Yorkers over the next 10 years, according to city officials.

title: EASTERN AIR REGISTERS A LOSS OF $110.6 MILLION
description: Eastern Air Lines reported yesterday that it lost $110.6 million in the first quarter, a period in which the airline underwent strike threats from its flight attendants and pilots, affecting bookings, and was battered by fare wars in many markets. In the quarter a year ago, the carrier earned $24.3 million, or 35 cents a share.

title: Last of Texas Fugitives Waited 'to Be Caught'
description: The last of four inmates who escaped a work detail on horseback was found sitting in a tree, ''just waiting to be caught,'' an official said today.

title: Time to Sell a Stake In Cable TV Unit
description: Time Inc., in what it called the first steps of a restructuring program, said yesterday that it would make a public stock offering of up to 20 percent of its cable television subsidiary and that it had approved a ''poison pill'' to discourage takeovers.

title: DANCE COPYRIGHT CASE IS REOPENED ON APPEAL
description: A Federal Appeals Court panel has ruled that a book of still photographs of dancers performing George Balanchine's ''Nutcracker'' may infringe upon the ownership rights of the late choreographer's estate.

title: A House Resolution Assails Soviet Tactics
description: A resolution, introduced today by Representative Robert S. Walker, a Pennsylvania Republican, and co-sponsored by 124 other House members, condemned Moscow's failure to provide the world with quick notification and information about the disaster at the Chernobyl nuclear power plant in the Ukraine.

title: 15 Pretoria Soldiers Hurt
description: Five South African army troop carriers were involved in a chain collision today, injuring 15 soldiers, the army information office said. Three soldiers were taken by helicopter to a Johannesburg hospital from the accident site in Roodeport, about 15 miles to the west. The others were treated and released.

title: Conrail Sale Stalls
description: Representative John D. Dingell, chairman of the House Committee on Energy and Commerce, rejected today the Reagan Administration's plan to sell its 85 percent interest in the Consolidated Rail Corporation to the Norfolk Southern Corporation and called for a new plan that would preserve Conrail's independence and allow for public ownership in it.

title: HELEN HAYES AWARDS ARE PRESENTED
description: ''Would you believe that in 30 years of playing O'Neill I have never, ever shared an award with him?'' Jason Robards asked Monday evening from the stage of the National Theater. ''This is the first time. And to have it happen in the first city of Washington, in the presence of the first lady of the theater and for a play by America's first playwright makes it very exciting.''

title: 22 INJURED AS LOS ANGELES LIBRARY BURNS
description: More than 250 firefighters battled a stubborn, smoky fire that swept through the Central Los Angeles Library today, injuring 22 firefighters and destroying thousands of books in the downtown landmark building.

title: U.S. APPROVES GIFT OF CONTRA COPTER
description: The State Department has given approval for a private anti-Communist organization to send a UH-1B Huey helicopter to help Nicaraguan rebels evacuate injured and sick from the war zones, Reagan Administration officials said today.

title: VIRTUAL CERTAINTY OF FAILURE SHOWN FOR SHUTTLE SEAL
description: New and unpublished test results show that a failure of a safety seal on the space shuttle Challenger was virtually inevitable because of a combination of cold weather on the morning of the launching and serious design flaws.

title: DIVERSIFIED ENERGIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31

description: To the Editor:

title: Chernobyl's Other Cloud
description: The Soviet nuclear accident transcends national boundaries. Its radioactivity has already been detected in Sweden, 700 miles away, and may threaten other countries. Poland has banned the sale of milk from grass-fed cows. Danes urgently seek iodine pills. For the Russians to have stayed silent about the disaster for three days does not invite their neighbors' trust. To dispel the cloud of fear that has spread beyond its borders, the Soviet Union needs to share promptly all that it knows.

title: THE NUCLEAR DISASTER
description: What Happened In an unusual public admission, the Soviet state radio said a ''disaster'' had occurred at a nuclear power plant in the Ukraine. West German and Swedish officials said Soviet officials had asked for help in controlling a burning nuclear reactor. The nuclear accident, described by Swedish experts as potentially the worst ever at a power plant, sent a radioactive cloud across parts of the Soviet Union, Eastern Europe and Scandinavia. Moscow provided few details, but intelligence sources believe that the accident occurred last Thursday or Friday and that radiation was continuing to spew yesterday. Western experts say they believe graphite used to moderate the nuclear reaction in the plant caught fire. They disagree on whether the fire was associated with a meltdown, in which nuclear fuel rods burn out of control.

title: 5 ARE INDICTED IN THE DUMPING OF LEGAL PAPERS
description: Five people were indicted yesterday on charges of falsely claiming to deliver thousands of court notices they were paid to deliver, in what city and state officials called ''rampant corruption'' among process servers.

title: METHODIST BISHOPS BACK PASTORAL LETTER DENOUNCING USE OF NUCLEAR ARMS
description: The Council of Bishops of the United Methodist Church, the third-largest church in the United States, voted unanimously today to issue a pastoral letter declaring the bishops' ''clear and unconditioned'' opposition to any use of nuclear weapons.

description: THE American Honda account is not leaving its agency. But the agency is leaving its agency.

description: The experiment was long and exacting: precise measurements were required, strict temperature controls, imported bacterial cultures and a good nose.

title: Bombs Over Libya
description: Pieces of intelligence continue to surface on the Libya bombing raid. Praising the performance of his service yesterday, Navy Secretary John F. Lehman Jr. told the American Institute of Aeronautics and Astronautics that the 15 carrier-based Navy planes that attacked Benghazi failed to drop only three of their bombs because of mechanical problems. The Pentagon has not said how many bombs they carried, but analysts estimate the number at 100.

title: Golf Magazine Picks Publisher
description: Peter A. Bonanni, 53 years old, has been named publisher of the Times-Mirror Company's Golf magazine. Mr. Bonanni, who is currently president of the Simmons Market Research Bureau's media studies division, had previously been group vice president of CBS Publishing and publisher of Woman's Day; president of the Charter Publishing Company (which then published The Ladies' Home Journal, Redbook and Sport); advertising sales manager of The New York Times Magazine, and publisher of Dial, Channel 13's monthly magazine. He also had a 90-day stint as executive vice president-publisher of Rolling Stone.

title: HOUSE DEMOCRATS DRAW BUDGET PLAN FOR '87
description: House Democrats have drafted a tentative budget that would cut military and domestic programs equally and would provide no ''significant new revenues,'' Representative Jim Wright of Texas, the Democratic leader, said today.

title: PBS to Televise Kirov
description: The first performances of the Kirov Ballet of Leningrad in the United States since 1964, scheduled for June 2 and 3 at the Wolf Trap Farm Park for the Performing Arts near Washington, will be televised by PBS, it was announced today. The ballet will perform ''Swan Lake'' on those dates. A two-and-a-half-hour version will be made available to public television stations June 7 for use when scheduling permits.

title: PHASE-OUT OF A-PLANTS IN U.S. IS URGED
description: A coalition of consumer, environmental and scientific groups said today that the Soviet nuclear accident showed that nuclear power plants in the United States should be phased out.

The Eisenhower Medal
description: The United States Holocaust Memorial Council will present the first Eisenhower Liberation Medal to the American military for its efforts to free the European concentration camps in 1945. Accepting the presentation from the council chairman, Elie Wiesel, at a ceremony next Tuesday in the Rotunda of the Capitol will be Gen. John A. Wickham Jr., Army Chief of Staff; Gen. J. Lawton Collins, former commander of the VII Corps, and Lieut. Gen. William W. Quinn, former chief of staff of Seventh Army Intelligence.
