title: SCHOOL BOARD WORKING ON TRIVIA, WAGNER SAYS
description: After four months on the Board of Education, Robert F. Wagner Jr. said yesterday that the board spent most of its time on trivial matters and had abdicated its responsibility on matters of education.

title: 2 SHAKESPEARE TROUPES VIE FOR SCANT DONATIONS
description: A highly regarded theater company that introduces students to Shakespeare is in danger of closing as an indirect - and, by all appearances, unintended - result of the producer Joseph Papp's new Shakespeare theater for high-school students.

title: Britain Alters Tax Plan
description: The British Government withdrew today a much-criticized proposal to put a 5 percent tax on share units known as American depository receipts and said it planned instead a 1.5 percent tax. A.D.R.'s are shares in British companies denominated in dollars, making them attractive to Americans. The proposed 5 percent tax had been sharply criticized in the United States and by leading British companies with American shareholders.

title: COURT BACKS A RIGHT TO EVIDENCE ON BEHAVIOR BEFORE DEATH PENALTY
description: The Supreme Court ruled 6 to 3 today that a convicted murderer has a constitutional right to present evidence of good behavior in jail to a jury considering whether to impose the death penalty.

title: BankAmerica's Dividend View
description: Officials of the BankAmerica Corporation said today that the troubled banking company would have to see sustained strong earnings before reinstituting its stock dividend, which was eliminated in January.

Washington to Pros?

The deadline for undergraduates to apply is midnight Saturday. Washington has scheduled a news conference for Friday morning at Syracuse to announce his decision.

description: Walter K. Gutman, a New York stock market analyst, writer, artist and avant-garde film maker, died of a stroke Sunday at his Manhattan apartment. He was 83 years old.

description: Riot policemen fired tear gas to break up anti-Government and anti-American demonstrations on two Seoul university campuses today.

title: THEATER: WEILL'S 'LOST IN THE STARS' AT LONG WHARF
description: NEW HAVEN, April 26 -''Lost in the Stars,'' which was to be Kurt Weill's last show, was designed as a musical tragedy. As such, it is filled with noble sentiments, the nobility in Mr. Weill's music, the sentiments confined to Maxwell Anderson's adaptation of Alan Paton's novel ''Cry, the Beloved Country.''

title: RULING MAY SETTLE AIDS TEST DISPUTE
description: The United States Patent and Trademark Office has decided to allow formal proceedings to determine whether French or American scientists were the first to invent the AIDS antibody test, spokesmen for the French researchers reported yesterday. However, American officials said they were unable to confirm the report.

title: TRUMP PLAN: WIDE IMPACT ON WEST SIDE
description: The vast Television City development proposed for the far West Side of Manhattan would blanket southern Riverside Park and much of the Upper West Side in shadow for hours at a time and flood nearby streets with cars and pedestrians, according to a new study.

title: OFFICER IN STUN-GUN TRIAL DENIES THAT HE AIDED IN AN ASSAULT
description: A New York City police officer took the witness stand yesterday and denied charges that he had held down a teen-age prisoner to allow a sergeant to torture the youth with an electric stun gun in a Queens station house.

title: WINE TALK
description: PEOPLE in California like to say that wine is nothing but the pure, fermented juice of fresh, healthy grapes. That's something like saying professional baseball is a game played by clean-cut youths who don't smoke, drink, chew tobacco or chase women. It's possible but not probable. It's also not very helpful to think of wine as simplicity itself. Consider the recent revelations of the addition of toxic substances, including a component of some antifreezes and methanol, or wood alcohol, to Austrian and Italian wines, and the blending of the tainted wines with other wines.

title: F.B.I. Man Tried to Fool Russians, Emigre Says
description: A Russian emigre testified today that her lover, Richard W. Miller, then an agent of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, told her he was playing ''a political game'' and wanted the Russians to think he was working for them.

title: Market Place; The Fine Print In Bond Issues
description: THE New York City Housing Development Corporation's plan to retire this week a $178 million issue of high-interest bonds sold in 1982 is attracting attention in the municipal bond market as an example of the risk that investors assume when they agree to buy new bonds before reading all the fine print.

title: BINDLEY WESTERN INDUSTRY reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: HEART'S DESIRE. By Gwyneth Cravens. 259 pages. Alfred A. Knopf. $16.95. WHEN we first meet the three heroines of ''Heart's Desire,'' we're inclined to write them off, a bit condescendingly, as familiar, and not all that interesting types. There's Judy, Tommy Hammond's pert, devoted wife, who obediently cooks and cleans house for her handsome hubby and worries that she's unworthy of his attentions. Then there's Effie, Tommy's formidable mother, a spunky, ''can-do'' woman of the New West - you can picture her being played by an older Sally Field in the movie version of the novel - who's fond of dispensing chirpy, greeting-card encouragements like ''New York in the fall must be the most inspiring fantastic place for you to achieve every possible success in every way.'' And finally, there's Effie's daughter Nancy, a sweet, somewhat muddled girl, who comes across on first meeting as a variation on your standard-issue American teen-ager - narcissistic, insecure and obsessed with science fiction.

title: CHILEAN REBELS BLAST HOLE IN WALL AT THE U.S. EMBASSY COMPOUND
description: Guerrillas fighting the military Government set off 13 bombs today and shot and wounded four guards at an army officers' housing development, the police reported.

title: GENERAL PUBLIC UTILITIES CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
BOB HOPE GIVES A LESSON IN COMEDY
description: ''Can you comment on timing?'' Bob Hope was asked yesterday as he stood in a Manhattan auditorium before a crowd of fans, invited guests and young aspiring comics.

title: Ferry and a Freighter Nearly Collide Off S.I.
description: A Staten Island ferryboat and a Greek freighter nearly collided in dense fog yesterday morning, the Coast Guard reported.

title: SEA LAND CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 30
description: b-Net income The company has restated previous-year results for adoption of Statement of Financial Accounting Standards No. 87, Employers' Accounting for Pensions.

title: OGDEN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes net of $697,000 from discontinued operations.

title: PATRICK THRIVES AS NEW RANGER LEADER
description: He sat at his locker not even two months ago in the days of the Rangers' disarray, his face ashen, his hands and legs crossed, shooting air through a tightened mouth. He was slumped like an old hound who had grown weary on the trail. ''I promise,'' James Patrick said. ''This won't taint me. It won't ruin me, but I know now that the world of sports is not kind.''

title: FIELDCREST MILLS INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income

title: People
description: * Robert Cox has joined Young & Rubicam as group creative director and senior vice president. Mr. Cox was previously executive vice president, director of creative services at Needham Harper Worldwide.

title: A NEW BEGINNING FOR SANKAI JUKU TROUPE
description: Some things will be different when the curtain rises on Sankai Juku, the popular Japanese theater-dance troupe, which returns to New York with a two-week engagement that opens tonight at City Center. There will be no dangling high in the air, hanging upside down by the ankles -a spectacular effect that in some ways identifies the company and its style of dark, primal imagery. There will also be a new member in the five-man troupe. But little else has changed since Yoshiuki Takada, a longtime member of Sankai Juku, fell to his death last September when the rope he was hanging from on Seattle's Mutual Life Building snapped.

title: O'Grady on Beman
description: Mac O'Grady and his lawyer, Steve Novak, said yesterday that the PGA Tour commissioner, Deane Beman, ''is biased'' and should therefore step aside and allow an independent arbitrator to listen to their appeal of Beman's ruling on O'Grady last week. Beman ordered that O'Grady be suspended from six tour events, fined $5,000 and serve one year probation for ''conduct unbecoming a professional golfer.''

title: BIG V SUPERMAARKETS INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
WINERIES GET EUROPEAN TIPS
description: New York's wine makers should concentrate on developing their own image, rather than on copying Europe or California, said a group of wine experts from France and West Germany who visited 16 wineries in the Finger Lakes region last week. At a seminar here the six wine makers talked about what they had seen and suggested ways to improve New York State wines.

title: ATLANTIC SOUTHEAST AIR LINES reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
NOURISH, DON'T STARVE HUMAN GENIUS
description: The greatest danger in the monstrous Federal deficit is not, as widely feared, that we will saddle our grandchildren with a crippling mortgage from the 1980's. It is that, in a panic to avoid that sorry legacy, we will make even worse public decisions than those that led to the deficit in the first place.

title: HAYNES IS SENT TO BRONCOS
description: The Giants enjoyed a spectacular day yesterday in the National Football League draft.

title: CULBRO CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes a gain of $15,100,000 on the sale of Helme Tobacco Co.

title: U.S. TOURS IN KIEV TO KEEP SCHEDULE
description: The relatives of two groups of tourists and students from Long Island who have been sightseeing in Kiev, 60 miles south of the nuclear accident, said yesterday that they had received word that the tour groups were unaffected by the disaster and planned to carry through with their schedule.

title: Signing On
description: Although they're currently consumed with more pressing matters, the Rangers acknowledge that their Madison Square Garden rink may have a new look when the team takes the ice next season. As 14 of 21 clubs in the National Hockey League do now, the Rangers may sell advertising on 20 sideboard panels between the goal lines.

title: CARNEGIE HALL DETAILS PLANS FOR OFFICE TOWER
description: Carnegie Hall officials unveiled plans yesterday for a 59-story office tower they hope to begin building next year on an empty site just east of the 95-year-old concert hall. The tower, which would cost upward of $100 million, according to its developer, the Rockrose Development Corporation, would include expansion space for Carnegie Hall on its lower floors and provide approximately $43 million in rental payments to Carnegie Hall and to the city for the first 13 years after the hall leases the land to Rockrose.

title: '84 TEST OF GENE-ALTERED VIRUS STIRS CONCERN
description: Members of two Congressional subcommittees today expressed concern that the Department of Agriculture had placed the public and the environment at risk by failing to oversee field-testing in the development of genetically altered products.

title: COOPER INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
RAYCHEM CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes a charge of about $2.2 million, or 19 cents a share, for severance costs related to a reduction in employment and reflects a modification to the provision for income taxes to adjust the expected annual effective tax rate from 34 percent to 30 percent. The latest quarter results include the operations of Elographics Inc., acquired in a pooling of interests transaction in January. The year-ago results are restated to give effect to the acquisition.

title: BETHLEHEM STEEL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes a non-recurring charge of $15 million for anticipated losses relating to oil-field equipment.

title: STRUTHERS WELLS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
U.S. URGES REVOCATION OF GOTTI'S BAIL
description: Federal prosecutors yesterday urged that John Gotti, the reputed crime boss, and three codefendants be jailed while awaiting trial on Federal racketeering charges because they posed a ''substantial danger'' to the safety of others.

title: APPARENT PACT LEADS TO DEATH OF 18-YEAR-OLD
description: A pair of teen-age sweethearts in Brooklyn entered into an apparent death pact Monday that left the boy dead of a stab wound, his girlfriend injured and authorities seeking a motive.

title: THE GIANTS' BIG TRADES
description: Not long after Bo Jackson was tapped by the Tampa Bay Buccaneers as the No. 1 selection in yesterday's National Football League draft, the Giants suddenly turned the Broadway Ballroom of the Marriott Marquis into a supermarket checkout counter. By trading in their coupons on an offensive linemen they couldn't sign and a cornerback they had too much trouble signing, the Giants obtained the opportunity to choose five of the first 53 players over the first two rounds. In looking toward Super Bowl XXI, no other team stocked its roster with so many rookies so quickly.

title: Antipoverty Programs Pass House, 377 to 33
description: Legislation to extend Head Start, the preschool program for poor children, and other antipoverty programs through 1990 was passed by the House today by a vote of 377 to 33.

title: Mets' Wilson Thriving
description: Mookie Wilson of the Mets, who was sent to Tidewater of the International League on Saturday to play himself back into shape after suffering an eye injury in spring training, had a double and two singles in five times at bat against Columbus on Monday night. Wilson, who played left field for the third straight game, scored three runs, drove in two and stole a base. The progress of Wilson, who must be recalled no later than May 15, is being monitored daily by the Mets.

title: Cuba to Defer Repayments
description: Cuba has told its foreign creditors that it will suspend debt payments for 90 days while seeking more favorable terms and $500 million in cash to make up for a projected shortfall.

title: TRI-STATE MOTOR TRANSIT CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes a gain of $298,000 from the sale of a terminal facility. c-Net loss

title: HARSCO CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Kalish & Rice Assigned Marcal Paper Business
description: Kalish & Rice Advertising of Philadelphia, one of the Earle Palmer Browne Companies, has been tapped by Marcal Paper Mills to do advertising for its institutional paper products, which last year billed close to $1 million.

title: Peru General Dismissed In a Drive on Graft
description: The Government, campaigning to end police corruption, has dismissed the chief of the Republican Guard, its third biggest police force, and 10 of his subordinates.

title: WILLIAMS COMPANIES reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes a $6.6 million writedown in the carrying value of Williams' stock in Bancoklahoma Corp. and a $5.7 million gain on the sale of stock acquired as part of the proceeds from the company's 1984 sale of Edgecomb Metals Co. The year-ago first quarter earnings were restated for an accounting change.

title: SCREEN: 'FUNNY DIRTY LITTLE WAR'
description: ''Funny Dirty Little War'' was shown as part of the 1985 New Directors/New Films Series. These are excerpts from Vincent Canby's review, which appeared in The New York Times on March 30, 1985. The film opens today at the Public, 425 Lafayette Street, and will move to the Quad, 34 West 13th Street, on May 9.

title: Kaiser Aluminum Wins Election
description: The Kaiser Aluminum and Chemical Corporation overcame a second attempt by an investor group to oust its board.

title: DANCE: HOUSTON-JONES
description: THE performance artist Ishmael Houston-Jones's ''Adolfo und Maria or 'Duh Guvnuh's Dancin' Gal,' '' performed on Sunday night at the St. Mark's Church Danspace, is a theater-dance piece with all the bold, crude vigor of poster art. Huck Snyder's cabaret set is a standout. Black dancing girls and minstrels start out from the painted proscenium of the gaudy stage within the dance space, with equally vivid side curtains that are pulled out as this ingeniously staged evening progresses. Doug Henderson and Guy Yarden have composed a slyly witty score that cleverly incorporates musical styles from several periods, including occasional traditional song. And Mr. Houston-Jones is a strong performer with a rich and resonant voice.

title: Commodore Move
description: Commodore International Ltd., known for its inexpensive home computers, is introducing its Amiga personal computer in Europe this week. The company's chief executive, Thomas Rattigan, said the European sales efforts should help Commodore with domestic sales of the Amiga, a low-priced personal computer that resembles Apple Computer's Macintosh. Amiga was introduced about a year ago, but a lack of software and its incompatibility with other computers have inhibited sales.

title: UNEXPECTED MOVES SPICE DRAFT
description: Once again yesterday, the National Football League showed why its college draft is one of the most unpredictable, if not entertaining, events in sports.

title: 5 Are Named Winners Of Playwrights Award
description: Five writers have been named winners of the 1986 Playwrights U.S.A. Awards for outstanding work produced in a noncommercial theater during the 1983-84 and 1984-85 seasons.

title: PENTAGON DEPUTY OUSTED OVER A DISCLOSURE OF SECRET INFORMATION
description: The Defense Department has dismissed a senior official on the ground that he provided secret information for a news article on an American covert intelligence program, Government officials said today.

title: THE PRACTICE OF LUNCH
description: A HEAVY workload often means working through lunch - skipping the midday meal entirely or grabbing a late-afternoon sandwich, a yogurt, a candy bar or a diet soda at the desk. From any point of view, most nutritionists agree, this is one of the worst possible dietary practices. In terms of weight loss, it is better to eat the main meal of the day at lunchtime and have a light supper in the evening than skip lunch and eat dinner ravenously.

title: GENERAL AMERICAN INVESORS CO reports earnings for As of March 31
description: The latest period's share asset figure is after a capital gain distribution of $1.07 per share and income dividend of 47 cents per share, both paid in March 1986. Assets represent net assets.

title: THE TUMULT DIES IN HAITI, BUT TENSION SURVIVES
description: An uncertain calm has returned to this weary capital after a traumatic weekend in which a peaceful memorial march erupted in violence and political leaders broadcast denunciations of the ruling military-civilian council.

title: BODIES OF ASTRONAUTS FLOWN TO DELAWARE
description: The crew of the space shuttle Challenger lifted off for the last time from the Kennedy Space Center today, in seven metal coffins riding in the cargo bay of an Air Force transport plane.

title: THE CULINARY SIGNS OF SPRING ACROSS THE LAND
description: APRIL is ramp eating season in West Virginia, when the pungent smell of the wild leeks permeates every hill and hollow. ''They're synonymous with spring,'' says Jim Comstock, editor of The West Virginia Hillbilly. ''Ramps go with changing the oil or your underwear.''

title: MOONPIE, STAPLE OF THE SOUTH
description: THE name of the visionary has been lost in the fog of history.

title: QUEENS DEMOCRATS LINING UP TO BACK SHULMAN CANDIDACY
description: After months of political turmoil, Queens Democrats are preparing to designate Claire Shulman, the interim Queens Borough President, next week for nomination for a three-year term with little or no opposition.

title: KEY PART OF ROCKET IS FOUND
description: Salvage teams have recovered a key piece of wreckage from a rocket joint that investigators believe ruptured and caused the destruction of the space shuttle Challenger, the National Aeronautics and Space Administration said today.

title: STALEY CONTINENTAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes a charge of $11,186,000 related to restructuring of the company for quarter and for 6 months. c-Net income includes loss from discontinued operations of $668,000 for quarter and $8,249,000 for 6 months.

title: Attn. Straphangers: 7 New Designations
description: Transit officials are giving yet another stir to the subway system's alphabet soup.

title: Congress; THE WAR ON TERRORISM, FROM TRIPOLI TO BELFAST
description: One of the unexpected ripple effects of the confrontation this month with Libya may be Senate approval of a treaty that would make it easier for the United States to send suspected terrorists from Northern Ireland back to face British prosecution.

title: CHALLENGE ON OIL ACCOUNTING
description: The Petro-Lewis Corporation, the big oil-and-gas drilling company, said yesterday that it might take a $300 million charge against earnings for its third fiscal quarter because of the interplay between lower oil prices and oil and gas accounting standards.

title: A KINSHIP WITH SEASONAL CANADA GEESE
description: I HAVE always loved Canada geese, have always felt, actually, a kind of kinship with them. As a child, when I saw a skein of them passing overhead, unzipping a spring sky, I thought of their ''V'' - oldest gander always in the lead - as a kind of shared victory sign, a confirming nod from the heavens, and a dare to go with them, to fly.

title: NORWEGIAN PREMIER QUITS IN BUDGET IMPASSE
description: Prime Minister Kaare Willoch's minority Government collapsed early today after losing a vote of confidence, 79 to 78, in Parliament.

title: Fish Fillet, the Easy Way
description: When buying fresh fish for fillets, I buy the whole fish, not a strip of barely identifiable skinless, boneless white flesh that will dry out if left to sit in the refrigerator too far in advance of cooking. At home, I fillet the fish just before cooking. The art of filleting is not the daunting task that most people think. It is easily accomplished, and with a little practice quickly done. Better fish markets will fillet whole fish for you, but you should know how to do it yourself. The best knife for the job has an 8- to 10-inch-long slightly flexible blade.

title: AVX CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income

title: REAGAN PLANS CIVIL SERVICE SHIFT
description: President Reagan today approved a plan to revamp the Civil Service pay system and give Federal managers more flexibility to reward their best workers with higher pay, a top Federal personnel officer said.

title: Walter P. Margulies, 71, Dies; Corporate Design Executive
description: Walter P. Margulies, a founding partner and chairman emeritus of Lippincott & Margulies Inc., marketing consultants and designers of industrial packaging and trademarks, died Monday at his home in Hobe Sound, Fla. He was 71 years old and also had a home in Westhampton Beach, L.I.

title: PRUDENTIAL FINANCIAL SERVCES reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
WARNER-LAMBERT COMPANY reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
CANDIED VIOLETS: HOW VERY FRENCH
description: FRENCH people often eat violets, as anyone who has made a close study of French pastry can tell you. The little purple sugar flowers often seen on ornate cakes and candies in Paris patisserie windows are not a chef's imitations of violets but real violets that have been mummified in sugar. By themselves, these crystallized flowers, brittle and slightly perfumed, taste like bath salts. The flavor blends particularly well with chocolate. According to both a 19th-century confectioner's manual and the best-selling French herbalist Maurice Messegue, candied violets are recommended for chest disorders.

title: Credit Rating Cut For Texas Utility
description: The credit rating on $3.6 billion of Texas Utilities Electric Company outstanding debt was reduced, the Standard & Poor's Corporation announced yesterday.

description: b-After an extraordinary tax credit of $87,000. c-Net loss and includes loss from discontinued operations of $12,339,000.

CLOSE MONITORING IN U.S. AND CANADA
description: The United States and Canada took steps yesterday to provide early warning of any increase in North American atmospheric radioactivity resulting from the Soviet nuclear accident.

title: NATIONAL MAGAZINE AWARDS GO TO 13
description: Science 85 won a National Magazine Award for articles in the public interest yesterday for its ''Technology of Peace'' issue of December 1985, that drew readers' attention to the scientific and political issues that underlie arms control and disarmament.

title: CONTINENTAL INFORMATION SYSTEMS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
description: The year-earlier results are for the quarter and 9 months ended Feb. 28. The company changed its fiscal year- end from May 31 to Feb. 28.

title: Required Reading; Latest Fad: Education
description: From a speech supporting increased Federal aid to education delivered in the Senate by Senator Ernest F. Hollings, Democrat of South Carolina, April 23:

title: EVENT RECALLS BRITISH DISASTER
description: The Soviet disaster is similar in some respects to the world's first major reactor accident, which occurred October 1957 at the Windscale plutonium-production plant in northern England. The Windscale accident is estimated to have caused as many as 33 subsequent cancer deaths.

title: U.P.I. Says Toll May Pass 2,000
description: United Press International, quoting a resident of Kiev, reported yesterday that the death toll at the site of the nuclear disaster in the Soviet Union north of Kiev may have surpassed 2,000.

title: US STEEL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes a non-cash charge of $351 million to reflect reductions from book values assigned to inventories of its Marathon Oil Co. unit. c-Net income includes a gain of $33 million from the sale of assets, the favorable impact of $50 million in LIFO inventory liquidations, an extraordinary gain of $38 million from the extinguishment of debt and a $45- million gain relating to an accounting change. Latest-quarter results also include a $37 million gain from the sale of assets, the favorable impact of $20 million in LIFO inventory liquidations, an extraordinary gain of $8 million from the repurchase of debt and a charge of $19 million related to acquisition costs. Year-ago figures are restated to reflect the company's merger in February 1986 with Texas Oil & Gas Corp.

title: Times Fills Ad Positions
description: The New York Times yesterday named Tim Maby director of classified advertising. Lance R. Primis, senior vice president for advertising, announced the appointment.

title: SIMPLE, INNOVATIVE CUISINE TRAVELS WELL FROM WEST
description: WHEN two of the most widely praised chefs of a celebrated California kitchen decide to move, relighting their fires in Manhattan, a certain amount of speculation ripples through gastronomic circles from coast to coast. Mark Peel and Nancy Silverton, the husband-and-wife team who figured large in the success of Spago's Restaurant in Beverly Hills, arrived at Maxwell's Plum last October, he as executive chef, she as pastry chef. Installed in the newly redecorated restaurant, the chefs, both 31, have put an end to any question about their succeeding in the highly critical world of New York restaurants. They continue to delight with their style of cuisine - highly innovative yet simple.

title: LEADING INDICATORS UP BY 0.5%
description: The Government index designed to predict the direction of the economy climbed five-tenths of 1 percent in March, the 10th straight month without a decline, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: PANEL URGES MONEY CURBS IN CAMPAIGNS
description: Calling New York's system of financing elections a ''breeding ground for cynicism and corruption,'' a joint state-city panel recommended sharp new limits on political contributions and campaign spending yesterday.

title: Both Iran and Iraq Cite Gains In Fighting in Their Gulf War
description: Iran said today that its forces had inflicted 4,000 casualties on the southern front and Iraq contended that it had captured 17 enemy positions in the rugged mountains on the northern border.

title: Surgery for Dawkins
description: Darryl Dawkins, the Nets' center who missed 31 of the last 32 games of the regular season with a back ailment, underwent microsurgery yesterday, and afterward his surgeon said Dawkins would be playing basketball in three months. After the surgery was performed by Dr. Reuben Hoppenstein, at the Hospital for Joint Diseases in New York, the Nets' team physician, Dr. Dennis Quinlan, said Dawkins would remain at the hospital for about a week and then begin a supervised training program.

title: SENATORS AT HEARING SUPPORT A BILL TO TIGHTEN LOBBYIST RESTRICTIONS
description: Members of the Senate Judiciary Committee today indicated broad, bipartisan support for a bill proposing new restrictions on the lobbying activities of former Federal employees, but Reagan Administration officials opposed the measure as too sweeping.

title: ADIA SERVICES reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
CIRCLE EXPRESS reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes an extraordinary credit of $141,000 for the latest quarter and $29,000 for the earlier period.

title: Concert Artists Guild Names Winners for '86
description: The first-prize winners of the 1986 Concert Artists Guild International Competition are the American violinist Maria Bachmann, the French-hornist Marie-Luise Neunecker of West Germany and the Canadian flutist Marina Piccinini. Each will receive $2,500, a debut recital at Town Hall during the 1986-1987 season, management services and a specially commissioned work.

title: Upbeat at 50
description: Some people prefer to forget about their 50th birthdays. But Zubin Mehta is not being allowed to.

title: TIM McINTIRE
description: Tim McIntire, an actor and musician who starred in the film ''American Hot Wax,'' died of congestive heart failure April 15 at his home in Los Angeles. He was 42 years old.

title: USF&G CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes a gain on investments of $50,253,000 and a tax credit of $42,758,000. c-Net loss includes a gain on investments of $28,218,000. Year-ago figures were restated.

title: STONE CONTAINER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income.

title: Venerable Comic
description: Howard Cosell was humble. Brooke Shields cried. Dick Cavett quoted La Rochefoucauld. Robert Klein sang a song. And a raft of friends showered Bob Hope with one-liners at dinner Monday night, when the Museum of Broadcasting celebrated his half-century in radio and television.

title: CASUALTIES IN SOVIET COULD KEEP RISING, U.S. EXPERTS ASSERT
description: American experts said yesterday that deaths and injuries from the reactor accident in the Soviet Union may continue to mount for several weeks in the vicinity of the disaster if severe radiation has been released.

title: PHILHARMONIC: STERN, PERLMAN AND CABALLE
description: ZUBIN MEHTA had three aces up his sleeve for last night's New York Philharmonic Pension Fund concert and, perhaps not surprisingly, the orchestra's music director played a winning hand with them. With Montserrat Caballe, Isaac Stern and Itzhak Perlman as the soloists in this Live from Lincoln Center program, the audience that demands the trappings of a gala event could hardly have been more satisfactorily catered to. It is sometimes true, however, that stacking the deck with big names does not always guarantee that a genuine concert will take place.

title: AIRBORNE EXPRESS reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes a non-recurring net gain from aircraft transactions of $489,000, or 8 cents a share.

description: b-Includes gains on investments of $319,000 and a tax loss carryforward of $1,321,000. c-Includes gains on investments of $50,000.

title: EXECUTIVES
description: * American Express Co. announced that F. Ross Johnson, president and chief operating officer of RJR Nabisco Inc., and Drew Lewis, chairman and chief executive of Union Pacific Railroad Co., had been elected directors of the company.

description: b-Includes a non-operating loss of $5.2 million resulting from the strenghening of the Japanese yen and its effect on debt repayable in yen.

description: b-Includes capital gains of $180,400 for the latest quarter and $19,693 for the earlier period.

title: 24-Hour Gaming Will Keep Atlantic City in the Resort Race
description: To the Editor:

title: Economic Scene; Tokyo Meeting And the Dollar
description: THE first phase of the dollar's decline, lasting from the beginning of March 1985 until a few weeks ago, was gradual and orderly - the very model of a soft landing. But anxieties are growing, in the financial markets and foreign capitals, that the decline is in danger of turning into a free fall that could mean serious trouble for the American and world economy.

title: A LEXICON OF ATOM POWER
description: Containment building or vessel: Large dome-shaped structures intended to confine radioactive leaks.

title: AUSTRALIA'S RELUCTANT PRESS CHAMPIONS
description: Bats swooped through the hot, dark sky. Balinese dancers with gold sunburst headdresses waited to welcome the Reagans. And security guards with bright batik shirts and blank faces lined the tarmac.

title: FOR GIRLS WHO WANT TO SAY NO
description: REALIZING that many teen-agers are poorly equipped to resist the pressures to go too far too soon, several organizations have issued guidelines. Today, the Y.W.C.A. of the U.S.A. is releasing a videotape on teen-age sexuality, ''It's Okay to Say No Way,'' with a leader's guide. The package is available to organizations nationwide that serve young people. (Send a check for $75 to Program Service Division, Y.W.C.A. of the U.S.A., 726 Broadway, New York, N.Y. 10003).

title: BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: IN TROUBLED OIL BUSINESS, IT MATTERS LITTLE IF YOUR NAME IS BUSH, SONS FIND
description: A year ago this month, with the price of oil about $28 a barrel, a small independent oil company in the oil-rich Permian Basin of West Texas started selling interests in a limited partnership to drill high-risk wells.

title: U.S. STEEL POSTS LOSS IN QUARTER
description: The United States Steel Corporation, now more in energy than in steel, yesterday reported a first-quarter loss of $249 million, reflecting a reduction in value of the oil inventories of its Marathon Oil unit.

title: The Picture in Haiti
description: Haiti's caretaker Government, led by Gen. Henri Namphy, deserves this much credit: it has finally put enough distance between itself and the ousted Duvalier dictatorship to impel Duvalierist provocateurs to violence.

title: JAKARTA DETAINS, THEN EXPELS CORRESPONDENT OF THE TIMES
description: The Government of Indonesia yesterday detained and then expelled a correspondent for The New York Times who was seeking authorization to report on President Reagan's visit.

title: MESA LIMITED PARTNERS reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The share earnings are in units. The year-ago results are pro forma since Mesa L.P. was created in December as part of a reorganization plan of Mesa Petroleum Co. The partnership received the oil and gas assets of Mesa Petroleum on Dec. 27. The latest quarter figures include $28 million resulting from natural gas contract settlements.

title: 27 Killed in Sri Lanka As Rebel Groups Clash
description: Twenty-seven Tamil guerrillas were killed today in a battle between rival rebel groups in northern Jaffna district, security sources said.

description: b-Includes a realized investment gain of $42.4 million in the latest quarter and an investment gain of $16.4 million for the year-ago period.

U.S. Petroleum Data
description: In millions of barrels except refinery utilization

title: INDONESIA BARS TWO JOURNALISTS IN REAGAN PARTY
description: President Reagan arrived today on this Indonesian island on the first major stop of his trip to the Far East, but the occasion was marred, White House officials said, when the Indonesian Government detained two Australian journalists in the President's party and barred them from the country.

title: VICTORY FOR CHICAGO MAYOR AS HIS CANDIDATES WIN
description: Exactly three years after he became Mayor of Chicago, Harold Washington today won what he called ''a working majority'' in the City Council.

title: Film Society Schedules Elizabeth Taylor Honor
description: The Film Society of Lincoln Center will pay tribute to Elizabeth Taylor on Monday at 8:30 P.M. at Avery Fisher Hall.

title: SPERRY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes a loss from discontinued operations of $13,200,000 and a loss on disposal of discontinued operations of $220,000,000. c-Includes a loss of $1,500,000 from discontinued operations for quarter and $1,900,000 for year.

title: Sell Missiles to Kill Americans?
description: Picture an American jetliner filled with summer travelers as it takes off from a European city. Perched on a hilltop more than three miles away is a terrorist aiming a shoulder-held Stinger antiaircraft missile at the jet. Within seconds, the airliner with its hundreds of passengers disappears in a bright orange inferno.

title: Raychem Net Up; Stock Falls
description: The Raychem Corporation's stock plunged $20 a share, to $106, yesterday in heavy New York Stock Exchange trading after the company stunned analysts with lower-than-expected earnings.

title: LOUISIANA LAND & EXPLORAION CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After a $6 million charge from cost reductions and a $3.1 million writedown of refinery LIFO inventories.

title: SOVIET KEEPS LID ON NEWS COVERAGE
description: The Soviet Government, never forthcoming about domestic disasters, has kept tight control on information about the accident at a nuclear station in the Ukraine.

title: What a Woman
description: Washington provides mixed evidence that business is coming to recognize equality of the sexes. The Greater Washington Board of Trade has decided to honor Louise Lynch, president of a local travel and telephone-answering business, at a black-tie dinner next month, but the title they will bestow on her is 1986 Man of the Years.

title: YANKS WIN SLUGFEST
description: The latest Yankee Stadium ritual received its first serious test last night and worked - at least for a while - as well as the nine-run, seventh-inning explosion the Yankees needed for a 14-11 victory over the Minnesota Twins.

title: CLARK EQUIPMENT CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes an extraordinary credit of $759,000. c-Net income

title: MUSIC: WORKS OF WEBER
description: BEN WEBER lived from 1916 to 1979, and for most of his life he supported himself as a music copyist, teacher and grant recipient while composing music in the serial or 12-tone method of Arnold Schoenberg, arranging notes according to predetermined ''tone rows'' instead of keys and scales.

title: Quick Count
description: For a team that had officials of the Guiness Book of World Records right there with clickers in their hands to validate the count, the University of Tennessee football squad was just a bit modest last Saturday when it claimed the record for the largest crowd ever to see a spring practice game.

title: GREAT SOUTHERN FEDERAL reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net loss

title: CLEMENS STRIKES OUT 20 TO SET MAJOR LEAGUE MARK
description: Roger Clemens of the Red Sox set a major league record tonight by striking out 20 batters in a 3-1 victory over the Seattle Mariners.

title: 2 MANVILLE EXECUTIVES LEAVE
description: The Manville Corporation said yesterday that its two top executives were leaving, to be replaced by a new management team. The changes resolve what was considered the last major snag to gaining approval of its three-and-a-half-year-old bankruptcy reorganization plan.

title: POLES ARE WARNED TO SHUN SOME MILK
description: Polish television tonight warned citizens in the northeastern provinces to avoid drinking milk from grazing cows, which it said could be contaminated by particles of radioactive iodine detected here after the nuclear accident at the Chernobyl power plant in the Ukraine.

title: SALVADORAN OFFICIALS MEET WITH REBELS
description: Salvadoran Government and leftist rebel officials held talks on Saturday for the first time in more than a year, rebel and Government officials announced.

title: 'CATHEDRAL' AND 'STONE CARVERS,' ON CHANNEL 13
description: ''CATHEDRAL'' is a delight; ''The Stone Carvers'' is, too. Are you interested in civilized television? Put these two programs back to back, which is how Channel 13 is showing them tonight, and you have the most civilized package imaginable. After tonight it should be gift-wrapped, put away, and then hauled out for the holiday season and pledge weeks.

title: A KEY 3D-WORLD ECONOMIST
description: The Argentine economist Raul Prebisch, who helped shape economic development throughout the developing world, died yesterday at age 85.

title: SOVIET SPY TESTIFIES HE RECRUITED HIS RELATIVES TO HELP THEM OUT
description: John A. Walker Jr., confessed leader of a Soviet spy ring, testified today that he attempted to recruit family members into espionage because he was a ''good-hearted guy'' seeking to help his relatives ''out of the pits.''

title: CANADIENS GAIN, 2-1: MEET RANGERS NEXT
description: Just when the Hartford Whalers seemed poised to take the giddiest step in their seven-year history as a National Hockey League team, the tenacity of 20-year-old Claude Lemieux manufactured a goal that sent the Montreal Canadiens to the Stanley Cup semifinals and sent the Whalers home.

title: CF & I STEEL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes gains on the sale of assets of $31,000 in the latest quarter and $313,000 in the earlier period.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: WEDNESDAY, APRIL 30, 1986
description: Nuclear Disaster

title: 2 States Would Save Champlain 'Monster'
description: Champ, the purported monster of Lake Champlain, has finally won full legislative protection.

title: HARVARD INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The company said the latest second quarter and first 6 months results include the operations of the Anchor Swan division, acquired Jan. 4, 1985, the Elastic Stop Nut division acquired April 12, 1985, and Trim Trends Inc., acquired Feb. 6, 1986.

title: The Neglected Message
description: The reaction here to David Stockman's book on the Reagan Administration is at least as interesting as the book itself.

title: AREA AROUND PLANT VARIES WIDELY
description: The immediate area surrounding the site of the Soviet nuclear accident is a thinly populated Ukrainian farming region of wooded steppe and small villages, although large cities, including the metropolitan center of Kiev, lie within a radius of 70 miles.

title: EASTERN AIRLINES INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income includes a tax loss carryforward of $1,677,000.

title: NEW JERSEY RESOURCES reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The company noted that its 1985 revenue was restated to reflect a customer billing credit. The restatement did not change net income.

title: The City Scandal's Challenge to Albany
description: Governor Cuomo's impressive package of ethics and campaign financing bills offers hope that New York can move forward from the city's current scandals. These ambitious bills challenge city Democrats whose one-party dominance spawns abuses, and upstate Senate Republicans, led by Warren Anderson, who resist overdue reforms.

title: TECH-SYM CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes a loss of $47,000 from discontinued operations.

title: FLUORIDE EFFORT LAGS IN THE U.S.
description: Forty years after the first American city fluoridated its water supply, only 61 percent of the population drink fluoridated water and America is unlikely to meet its goal of nearly universal treatment of water with the chemical, a Federal researcher says.

title: SIDNEY P. LANDAU
description: Sidney P. Landau, retired vice president for corporate development of the United Artists Corporation, died yesterday at the Mount Sinai Medical Center.

title: U.S. UTILITY STOCK PRICES FALL
description: The nuclear accident in the Soviet Union caused prices of the shares of many American electric utilities to fall yesterday. But the prices of futures contracts for many foodstuffs rose because of the possibility of food contamination in Eastern Europe that would decrease supplies.

title: Shift to St. Peter's
description: The New Jersey Jammers of the United States Basketball League will hold a news conference this morning at St. Peter's College in Jersey City to announce that the franchise will play its home games this summer at the college's Yanitelli Center gymnasium, which seats 3,600. Last year, the Jammers drew 7,800 fans in 13 games at William Paterson College in Wayne, N.J., while finishing second in the seven-team league with an 18-7 record.

title: 60-MINUTE GOURMET
description: IF I had to pick my favorite meat, it would be pork. It is the richest in flavor and certainly one of the most versatile meats around, whether in the form of chops, a roast, a stew or sausage. The wealth of seasonings that may be applied to pork are beyond count.

title: Drug Traffickers Hanged
description: Two convicted drug traffickers and a man sentenced to death for illegal possession of firearms were hanged today at Kuala Lumpur's Pudu jail, the Bernama news agency reported.

title: Comings and Goings
description: Ingrid Kristiansen of Norway, who holds the women's world-best time in the marathon and the world record for 10,000 meters, will run on May 31 in the 15th L'eggs Mini Marathon for women in Central Park. Mrs. Kristiansen and about 10,000 other entrants will run 10,000 meters, the distance at which she set the record of 30 minutes 59.42 seconds last July in Oslo. . . . Tom Seaver, who was scheduled to start for the Chicago White Sox last night, left the team for California because of the death of his mother in Fresno, Calif. . . . Shawon Dunston, the Chicago Cubs' shortstop who suffered an injury to his left arm on Monday night in San Diego, is expected to miss one or two games because of a sprained wrist and thumb.

title: 'ROARATORIO' WILL OPEN NEXT WAVE FESTIVAL
description: The Brooklyn Academy of Music announced yesterday that the fourth Next Wave Festival of avant-garde performing arts will open the academy's 1986-87 season on Oct. 7 with ''Roaratorio,'' a collaborative, full-evening work by Merce Cunningham and John Cage. The announcement was made at a news conference at City Hall with Mayor Koch and Howard Golden, the Brooklyn Borough President.

title: Woman Charged With Taking Baby
description: A Bronx woman was arrested yesterday and charged with the kidnapping of a 2-month-old girl on April 4 from the apartment of the infant's mother. The baby was recovered last night in Connecticut, the police said.

title: Eaton to Acquire Farley Subsidiary
description: Farley Industries, a closely held consumer and automotive products company, said it had agreed to sell a subsidiary of its troubled Condec Corporation to the Eaton Corporation.

title: Boos for Mister Feel-Bad
description: Say this for David Stockman: He gives value for money. Two million dollars is the money he is said to have got for writing his book, ''The Triumph of Politics: Why the Reagan Revolution Failed,'' which illustrates again why, if your game is either literature or government, Washington is the only place to play it.

title: CHIEFTAIN DEVELOPMENT CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Texas Sells Land Bonds That Yield Up to 7.30%
description: A $542.8 million issue of Texas veterans land bonds was tentatively offered yesterday through underwriters led by Citibank with yields of 7 percent and more for bonds due in 2000 and longer, up to a maximum of 7.30 percent for the 2003 maturity.

title: TELEX CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
JETS FOCUS ON OFFENSIVE LINE
description: The Jets once again plucked a relatively obscure player out of the National Football League draft yesterday when they chose an offensive lineman, Mike Haight of Iowa, for their troubled line.

title: ACTION INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to March 29
MOSCOW'S SILENCE ON DISASTER ASSAILED IN EUROPE
description: West German and Swedish officials reported today that the Soviet Union had made urgent appeals for technical advice and assistance in handling what were said to be uncontrolled graphite fires and the meltdown of the radioactive core at the Chernobyl nuclear power station.

title: COMDATA NETWORK INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
U.S. OFFERS TO HELP SOVIET IN DEALING WITH ACCIDENT
description: The United States formally offered humanitarian and technical assistance to the Soviet Union today to help it deal with the nuclear accident near Kiev.

title: 4 Hanover Traders Join Security Pacific
description: The Security Pacific National Bank, seeking to bolster its foreign exchange operations in New York, has hired four senior traders from the Manufacturers Hanover Trust Company.

title: PICNIC FOODS: HOT WEATHER PRECAUTIONS
description: Picnics, barbecues and camping meals are staples of summertime recreation, but precautions should be taken during the warm weather fun to avoid food poisoning.

title: INTERNATIONAL GAME TECHOLOGY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income

title: INTERNATIONAL CONTROLS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The company said latest quarter results include for the first time the operations of Transway International Corp., acquired Dec. 27, 1985.

title: One Alaskan Volcano Rumbles, Second Erupts
description: Augustine Volcano continued to rumble but is unlikely to erupt violently, while another Alaskan volcano apparently erupted without causing injuries or damage, the authorities said today.

title: CITIZENS SAVINGS FINANCIAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes an extraordinary charge of $1,280,655 from prepayment of penalties for early repayment of advances from the Federal Home Loan Bank.

title: Jersey Certificates Total $144 Million
description: New Jersey is offering $144 million of certificates of participation through underwriters led by L. F. Rothschild, Unterberg, Towbin.

title: SIGNS POINT TO A MELTDOWN, SCIENTISTS IN SWEDEN ASSERT
description: Swedish scientists said today that they were convinced that the radioactive core of a Soviet power-generating reactor melted after an accident at the weekend, making it the worst nuclear power plant disaster in history.

title: INDUSTRIAL CONDOMINIUMS AT THE OLD BUSH TERMINAL
description: For more than 60 years a cluster of industrial buildings on the Brooklyn waterfront once known as Bush Terminal has provided millions of square feet of space for the city's manufacturers.

title: FILM: THE OBSESSIONS OF 'ROUTINE PLEASURES'
description: JEAN-PIERRE GORIN, its French-born director, describes ''Routine Pleasures'' as a film essay about ''America - under-budget and in a shoe box,'' which is accurate as far as it goes.

title: FESTIVE FLIGHT TO MOSCOW RESUMES U.S.-SOVIET AIR SERVICE
description: The first American commercial flight to the Soviet Union since 1978 arrived here Tuesday, carrying the American Ambassador and 56 other passengers who drank champagne to toast the resumption of air service between the superpowers.

title: LUXURY IN A LOAFER
UNIVERSAL LEAF TOBACCO CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes net from discontinued operations of $457,000.

title: PERSONAL HEALTH
description: THE parents of teen-agers -two teen-age boys in my case - have all heard that today more adolescents are becoming sexually active and at younger ages than ever before. The time between the first kiss and intercourse has been dramatically shortened for many teen-agers: 80 percent of boys and 70 percent of girls report having had sex while still in their teens. By age 15, one girl in five is no longer a virgin; by age 17, half of all girls have had sexual intercourse.

title: CHROMALLOY AMERICAN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Year-ago first quarter preferred stock dividends exceeded net.

title: ROSS COSMETICS reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
description: b-Net income.

title: CURTICE-BURNS INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 28
Dow Slides 17.86 Points, to 1,825.89
description: After remaining in a holding pattern for several sessions, stock prices fell sharply yesterday. The decline was attributed to a variety of factors, ranging from the nuclear accident in the Soviet Union to the price of stock index futures.

title: COLONIAL LIFE & ACCIDENT INSURANCE CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
TELERATE INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
TRILOGY LTD reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Yes, Raise the Alcohol Tax
description: A large group of leading economists proposes to raise $12 billion annually for the Federal Treasury by sharply increasing taxes on alcohol, which have not kept pace with inflation. Although sales taxes generally are not the best approach to budget balancing, reverting to higher taxes on alcohol seems a good way to help reduce the deficit.

title: U.S. PAYS $1.8 MILLION A YEAR TO COVER RENT FOR U.N. STAFF
description: The United States will spend $1.8 million this year to rent apartments for 45 members of the United States mission, Michael E. Coughlin, the mission's administrative officer, said today.

title: Greyhound Lines In Regional Split
description: The parent of Greyhound Lines Inc. said it would divide the country's largest bus company into four regional carriers and let independent agents manage all terminals. The moves were the latest by the Greyhound Corporation to reorganize its bus unit to focus on short-hop services, stressing markets that airlines do not serve.

title: 2 OFFICIALS OPPOSE BILL ON ACID RAIN
description: High officials in the Reagan Administration today emphatically opposed legislation to control acid rain that was recently introduced in the House with broad bipartisan support.

title: WESRAY GETS TURN AT OWNING AVIS
description: Avis Inc., the nation's No. 2 car-rental company, is expected to change hands soon for the 10th time since it was created 40 years ago. This time the new owner will be the Wesray Capital Corporation, an investment organization headed by former Treasury Secretary William E. Simon.

title: BURIAL NEXT TO HUSBAND IN WINDSOR FOR DUCHESS
description: The Duchess of Windsor was buried today beside the castle of the same name, next to the husband who gave up his throne and country for her sake.

title: 76ERS FOIL BUCKS
description: The Celtics had squandered an 18-point lead to the Atlanta Hawks and, with 3 minutes 57 seconds to go in this second game of their playoff series tonight, Boston held a 109-108 lead.

title: Charles Bonnay Dies; French Photographer
description: Charles Bonnay, the French war photographer, died Monday of complications from acute leukemia. He was 55 years old.

title: METROPOLITAN DIARY
description: A FEW months ago, Janet Sheldon, a police officer from Brooklyn, treated herself to a new car, a Toyota Corolla, if you're curious, although that really doesn't matter. What is pertinent is that when the car's odometer passed the 1,000-mile mark, Miss Sheldon began feeling strangely eerie, as if she had become the main character in a science-fiction movie.

title: KLEER-VU INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net loss

title: Spare Us the Nostalgia for George Wallace
description: To the Editor:

title: RECITAL: LESLIE SIXFIN, PIANIST
description: THE best parts of Leslie Sixfin's piano recital at Carnegie Recital Hall on Friday evening gave every reason to hope that at whatever career level she eventually finds her niche, she will be a pianist well worth listening to. Her Bach (the Toccata BWV912) is vivid and bracing, never pedantic.

title: F.H.A. Halts New Lending
description: The Federal Housing Administration told lenders today to stop taking applications for Government-insured home mortgages because the agency has reached its $57.4 billion credit ceiling. One analyst said the action would force conventional and Veterans Administration loan rates somewhat higher.

title: OWNERS TAKING A BOLD STEP WITH ENGLISH COLT
description: ''We're the forerunner,'' Anthony Richards said from his wheelchair, perched just inside Barn 42 at Churchill Downs this morning. ''We're the experiment. Of course, we're also here to win the race.''

title: Bridge: Key Deal in Knockout Event Hinged on Position of Queen
description: The Vanderbilt Knockout Team Championship in Portland, Ore., last month had more than its share of hard-fought, tight matches.

title: GORE OPPOSES FLETCHER AT NASA BUT EXPECTS SENATE CONFIRMATION
description: Senator Albert Gore Jr. said tonight that he would oppose the nomination of Dr. James C. Fletcher to head the National Aeronautics and Space Administration but added that he expected Dr. Fletcher to win speedy confirmation in the Senate.
